column2: Once upon a time ranking the college football teams of the country was relatively a simple matter. There were just so many elevens in each section that qualified for consideration year in and year out.
OMAHA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- An alert, smooth-functioning Creighton football team outplayed the Fort Riley, Kan., Centaurs, 34 to 7, today.

A furnished duplex apartment containing nine rooms and three baths in 812 Park Avenue has been leased by Count Joseph Humann Guilleminat through Warren Marks Associates and Pease Elliman. The rental was one of many reported in East Side buildings over the week-end, indicating a continuance of the demand for suites beyond the customary Fall renting season.

New York's Fire Department honored its dead of the last twelve months yesterday with annual memorial services at which Mayor La Guardia told 3,000 firemen that modern war, by bringing "battle into every home in every city in the country," had made them part of the nation's defense.

The fourteen-story apartment building at 100-104 Central Park South, at the southwest corner of Sixth Avenue, has been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to the 100 Central Park South Realty Corporation of 521 Fifth Avenue. It occupies a plot 71 by 100 feet, opposite Central Park, and was sold for about $700,000, according to revenue stamps on a deed recorded in the Register's Office.

VICHY, Oct. 11 -- The French Government's budgetary receipts for July amounted to 9,292,000,000 francs, compared with 7,103,000,000 in June. In the total receipts taxes amounted to 8,335,000,000 francs. Compared with July, 1941, receipts increased 1,630,000,000 francs, or 21 per cent.
Certain New York restaurants and hotel associations are planning a meatless day each week in a voluntary effort to conserve meat and avert rationing.

The fatal shooting of Jeremiah Buckley, Bronx tavern keeper, early yesterday morning with a police revolver was termed "an unfortunate accident" after several hours' investigation. Nevertheless, it was announced, the case would be presented to the Bronx Grand Jury.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- New Yorkers are everywhere. They are turning Exchange Street into an undimmed-out Broadway and Bush's diner into the Automat. A major difference is that there is never a queue for breakfast outside the Automat at 5 A.M. There is at Bush's diner every morning.

There are suggestions from England, reluctant at first, but now more enthusiastic, that the big bombers of the United States are all right. They always were, and to say that they are not suitable for European use is to misunderstand their function.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Forty-six citizens described as "dangerous or potentially dangerous," have been ordered to leave the West Coast, Lieut. Gen. John L. De Witt, head of the Western Defense Command, disclosed today.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Jacksonville Naval Air Station football team vanquished the Spence Field Army Air Base of Moultrie, Ga., today by 33 to 0.

An "eternal vigilance" to keep democracy alive now and in the post-war days must be kept by the American people, Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah, Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia University, and Professor Avery O. Craven of the University of Chicago declared yesterday at the Chicago Round Table, broadcast over the NBC network as part of the Institute of Inter-American Affairs.
OMAHA, Oct. 11 -- Heavyweight Boxing Champion Joe Louis, in an almost casual manner, today told The Associated Press "my fightin' days are over."

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- British bombers attacked Hanover and other targets deep in Western Germany today and Royal Air Force fighters swept over the St. Ormer and Abbeville areas of occupied France in a series of daylight attacks that continued the intensified Allied air offensive against Nazi-held Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Slinging Sammy Baugh pitched three touchdown passes as the Washington Redskins trounced the Cleveland Rams, 33 to 14, in a National League football contest before 33,250 spectators today.

With the duck season in the intermediate zone almost at hand, signaling the start of waterfowl shooting in Connecticut, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New York and many other States on Thursday, New York's Conservation Department has joined others in urging hunters to do their "full share in the conservation of materials vitally needed in the war effort."

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 112.8 on Sept. 29. This compares with 112.2 a fortnight before, 110.8 a month before, 107.1 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 11 -- The Japanese are beginning to suffer from a lack of tonnage, says the Tokyo correspondent of the Hamburger Fremdenblatt. To have sufficient ships to maintain supply routes in the South Pacific, the Japanese Government, the correspondent says, decreed that shipments of coal, iron and steel inside the islands be carried by railroad.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., Oct. 11--Clergy, nuns and 500 parishioners from all parts of Long Island attended the golden jubilee celebration of Our Lady of Consolation Home for the Aged at North Amityville this afternoon. The home, formerly known as St. Catherine's Infirmary, an adjunct of Most Holy Trinity Parish, Brooklyn, is now administered by the diocesan office and is managed by the Sisters of St. Dominica. whose mother house adjoins tlle eighty-acre tract.

America must feel indebted not only to Great Britain, China and Russia for fighting with us and for us, but must also never forget her indebtedness to countries like Norway, Holland and France as "witnesses of the truth" for us, the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig declared yesterday in his sermon at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

The need for recognition and observance of "universal laws" was cited by the Rev. Laurence I. Neale, pastor of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, in his sermon yesterday.

Consolidated Railroads of Cuba yesterday reported for the fiscal year ended or June 30 a consolidated net balance transferred to profit and loss of $1,603,339. After debits and credits to profit and loss and surplus, the balance transferred to surplus was $115,587, increasing the latter item to $9,313,082, compared with $9,197,495 on June 30, 1941.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Trade in soy beans is near the vanishing point, and much of the business in futures that is being done represents evening-up operations, traders eliminating their positions in the market. Futures sold last week on the Board of Trade at the lowest prices of the season and lost 2 3/8 to 4 5/8 cents a bushel for the week.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 11 -- An important tightening of state of siege regulations was announced today by police who informed all local newspapers that they henceforth would not be allowed to print the text or summary of speeches dealing with foreign affairs delivered at public meetings even if such meetings were authorized by police.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- The National Bank of Detroit will be named agent to carry out an agreement for a $200,000,000 bank credit to be established soon by the Bendix Aviation Corporation, it has been disclosed here.

MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 12 -- The German siege army at Stalingrad, bled white by enormous losses, broke off the assault yesterday, the Red Army announced today, but Soviet dispatches warned that strong enemy reinforcements were moving up to renew the effort to take the city.

The Giants and the Eagles staged a harum-scarum game before a gathering of 28,264 at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Perhaps it was not the best football in the world that was on display but the fray was jammed with spectacular runs, dazzling pass catches, sudden turns in fortune and plenty of points.

Arturo Toscanini conducted his third and final performance of Berlioz's dramatic symphony "Romeo and Juliet" yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Again the work was performed by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and the Westminster Choir, with the solo parts taken by Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano; Jacques Gerard, tenor, and Nicola Moscona, bass.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Elmer Davis Director of the Office of War Information, today announced appointment of afive-man inter-agency publications committee to recommend by Nov. 1 further discontinuance and curtailments in government publications.

One Bronx boy was stabbed and seriously wounded and two others beaten at 6:30 o'clock last night when they were set upon by forty others, Negroes, in front of a scrap pile the three had collected at 831 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Nearly 300 persons, among them an American consul from Tangier and five French consular agents, arrived in Baltimore today on the Portuguese refugee ship Serpa Pinto and by nightfall seven of them had been released by the authorities.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- St. Mary's Gaels defeated the University of Nevada, 20 to 6, today before 6,500 fans. It was the first victory of the season for the Gaels and their new coach, Jimmy Phelan, former University of Washington mentor.
The cranberry crop promises to be the third largest on record. Even so, the small scarlet berries won't be noticeably abundant, all things considered.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Weather conditions were generally favorable for drying the new corn crop last week and husking has started in various sections, but it is expected that another week or so of dry weather will be necessary before it will be safe to crib the bulk of the crop.

William Jacobus, who became the Navy's first scrap metal salvage expert thirty-one years ago and subsequently saved the government and New York City millions of dollars by thwarting unscrupulous junk dealers, said last night that the city's household scrap piles were probably worth $120 a ton or more.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 11 -- With the government's rate for loans on cotton raised a cent a pound and with the indicated yield of that staple showing a decrease of 210,000 bales in the last month, prices of cotton futures recovered last week half of their losses of about $1.50 a bale.

Mayor La Guardia requested officially yesterday that all hotels, restaurants and eating places in the city, as well as all private householders, observe Tuesday of each week as a meatless day, as part of the campaign to conserve essential foodstuffs.

The National Hockey League will inaugurate its season on Oct. 31, with two games listed for the opening night. The Boston Bruins will visit the Canadiens in Montreal while the world champion Toronto Maple Leaf sextet will entertain the New York Rangers.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Oct. 10 (Delayed) -- Major William S. Hipps of Lumber City, Pa., who went along as an official observer of today's raid on Rabaul, New Britain, reported with delight that he saw a stream of automobile headlights on the main road leading from Rabaul to the hills outside the town.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -With an entry that exceeded expectations the Fall Hutchinson horse show was held today at Hutchinson Farms in this town.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 11 -- The bill sponsored by Senator Green of Rhode Island, which would release the Treasury's unpledged silver for consumption by industry, will come up for its first hearing before a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee on Wednesday, Edward Krehbiel, president of Black, Starr Gorham, Inc., announced here at a meeting of the New England Retail Jewelers Association.

EAST ALTON, Ill., Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- The Western Cartridge Company, in a telegram to the War Labor Board, charged tonight that the American Federation of Labor struck its East Alton plant yesterday in an effort to bring about recognition of the union as exclusive bargaining agent for the factory before the WLB could decide the matter.

With New York City registration off 12 per cent from that of 1938, the year of the last State election, leaders of the three legal political parties all expressed yesterday the opinion that the light registration was favorable to their candidates.

BUFFALO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- State Controller Joseph V. O'Leary, describing employment of mothers in war industries as "a possible threat to family life," said today that mothers should not be considered a labor supply source until all other sources had been exhausted.

VICHY, France, Oct. 11 -- Lectures to the assembled personnel of all large factories in France are being delivered by the delegates of the Information Secretariat in Vichy in order to explain to the workers the process by which they are being assisted and selected for service in Germany, it was made known today.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 11 -- Benjamin Kaufman of Trenton, N.J., national commander and Rabbi Philip Bookstaber of Hamburg, Pa., national chaplain, of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, spoke this morning from the pulpit of the Hickory Street Presbyterian Church.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 11 -- The diplomatic incident between the United States and Chile, created as a result of Chile's protest to President Roosevelt yesterday following statements made in a speech by Sumner Welles which the Chilean Foreign Office considered "offensive to the dignity of this country,'' continued without solution tonight.
Mayor La Guardia's attempts to curb gambling in this city were defended by the Rev. Karl M. Chworowsky in his sermon yesterday morning in the Flatbush Unitarian Church, Brooklyn.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 11 (AP) -- In what the Wayne County Coroner, George D. Winchell, called a murder and suicide by shooting, Walter T. Rowe, 55, of 64 Love Street, and his wife, Mrs. Eva Courtmarsh Rowe. 57, were found dead today at their summer camp at East Bay on Lake Ontario.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 11 (AP) -Japanese positions at two points south of Tangyang, Western Hupeh Province, have been attacked by a Chinese unit, the Chinese High Command reported tonight, and a Japanese attempt to encircle the attackers with a counter-attacking force of 2,000 was frustrated.

The jitterbug, handmaiden of swing, is rising from its lowly estate, members of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing were told yesterday at their October meeting in the Hotel Astor. This delight of the youngsters, hitherto scorned or derided by the conservative pundits of the ballroom floor, and a direct descendant of the "Lindy Hop," no longer can be ignored, according to those who spoke of the trend of social dancing.
Samuel Reshevsky, regarded as one of the world's leading chess masters, yesterday tasted defeat for the first time since 1936 in competition involving the United States championship.
Mrs. Robert Donner of Buffalo has come to the Weylin from Colorado Springs.

William J. Schieffelin, honorary chairman of the Citizens Union, has been named chairman of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee for the Election of George J. Mintzer, Republican nominee for Supreme Court justice in the First Judicial District.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- A change in the ceiling price of flour which removed many of the inequalities that had existed in the original order and permitted mills to resume the offering of flour failed last week to have any effect as a price-making influence on wheat, as the present ceiling, combined with that on wheat, offal, is regarded as preventing mills from buying cash grain on a large scale.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- An outbreak of liquidation by holders of grain futures on the Board of Trade was reflected last week in a moderate increase in the volume of business, but the turnover is regarded much below normal in view of the size of the decline in prices.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Activity in the stock markets here continues to broaden. Last Monday's officially recorded bargains numbered 6,426, which was a new high record for a day since the war started, while the week's total was 28,702, also a wartime record and comparing with 23,004 in the previous week and 20,000 a fortnight ago.

Considerable wartime waste of manpower and inefficiency in the operation of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad since its seizure by the government on March 22, last, was charged in the company's annual report for 1941 just issued. The charge was made by George P. McNear Jr., president and principal owner of the 239-mile freight line that runs between Effner, Ind., and Keokuk, Iowa.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- The first licensed obedience trials of the Victory Dog Training Club, held at the Boston Arena today for the benefit of the United Nations Relief Fund drew an entry of 110 dogs, representing more than thirty breeds.

VICHY, Oct. 11 -- In all countries the question of methods of financing the costs of war and the consequences of the war from the financial viewpoint continues to be a subject of constant discussion. The annual report of the Bank of International Settlements in Basle, contains interesting remarks on this topic.

The rival major party candidates for Governor, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democrat, and former District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Republican, will begin their intensive speaking campaigns this week.

New glass packages for shaving cream and tooth paste, to replace collapsible tubes using war-needed tin, are slated to receive vigorous promotion by individual manufacturers. The Mennen Company has scheduled an advertising campaign on behalf of its brushless and lather shave creams in glass jars, using full pages in two colors in a selected group of magazines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The battleship Oregon, famous for her dash around Cape Horn in 1898 in time to join in the destruction of the Spanish fleet at the Battle of Santiago, will be scrapped for metal to be used in this war.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The size of the United States military force in the British Isles has reached the point where this may be accurately termed the largest foreign invasion since the Battle of Hastings, it was said today, and the major problem of both the American and British authorities here is to help the American Army fight the battle of boredom until the moment for all-out action arrives.

The Regional Plan Association reported yesterday that "while the New York region's share of all war contracts has declined, most parts of the region outside the central city are nearing full employment."
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 11 (AP) -Scoring in every period, Green Bay smothered a reorganized Detroit eleven, 38 to 7, in a National Football League game 0efore 20,000 today.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Asked three questions paralleling those Joseph Stalin answered last Sunday in a letter to Henry C. Cassidy of The Associated Press, Prime Minister Churchill stood today on previous statements on aid to Russia, saying no further statement was called for.

The Rev. Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, Dean of Drew Methodist Theological Seminary, Madison, N.J., recently back from England where he preached to all denominations, occupied the pulpit at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, yesterday morning and challenged the right of isolationists to sit at the peace table.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 11 -- The convention of the United Mine Workers of America, in recess over the week-end, will be resumed tomorrow with proposed wage-increase demands for the union's 500,000 members the most important question before it.

Keen interest in all phases of the food situation is reflected in an unusually heavy demand for tickets for a symposium on "Our National Food Supply," scheduled to take place tomorrow in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 12 -Four little Norwegian corvettes and a British destroyer that led them seriously damaged four Axis submarines and shelled several others in a forty-eight-hour battle in the Atlantic, the British Admiralty announced early today.

Aiming to further religious education among Jewish children, 500 delegates representing a like number of Jewish fraternal and benevolent societies met yesterday in the Hotel Astor and formed the League of Jewish Fraternal Organizations.

Samuel C. Greenfield, chairman of the taxation committee of the Teachers Union of New York City, declared yesterday that the passage by the Senate of the 5 per cent Victory Tax on incomes above $12 a week and "the reduction of taxes on corporations from the low rates passed by the House" constituted a major blow to the winning of the war.

The Canadian dollar was irregular last week. Working down from 87.50 cents, on Monday, it sold at 86.62 cents on Thursday, to rebound slightly to 87 cents, at the close, for a loss of 7/16 cent from the preceding week. The absence of buying in the face of even modest offerings accounted for the softer tone.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that specific dollar-and-cent prices had been established on wool grease, raw soap stocks, recovered or acidulated soap stocks, distilled fatty acids and stearic and oleic acids.

Dr. John F. Sly, regional price director for the Office of Price Administration, welcomed yesterday the statement made on Saturday in Washington by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, in which housewives were urged to accept "most of the responsibility" for keeping prices down and to serve, in effect, as "price wardens."

On June 26 the Germans launched from Kursk the great offensive which has carried them to the banks o the Volga. That was 108 days ago. But fifty-two of these vital fighting days have been used up in the siege of Stalingrad. Russian troops still hold the ruined city.
The fingerprint classification system of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has again uncovered the criminal past of a man who tried to go straight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Having completed semi-final moves last week on the largest tax bill and the second largest war appropriation bill in the country's history. Congress will take preliminary steps this week toward tackling the next big war problem facing it -- that of marshaling more effectively the nation's manpower for combat and for the war production of arms and essential food and fiber products.

With statues being removed and melted for ammunition, the qualities in man for which they were erected should be remembered, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers declared yesterday in his sermon in the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The four-motored American "battleships of the air" that in Friday's raid on Lille inflicted the heaviest defeat on the German Air Force since Dieppe, appeared to have presented the Germans with the necessity of revising entirely their methods of defense, said observers here today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 11 -- For the second time in two days, United States Army heavy bomber planes attacked Bengazi yesterday, smashing dock facilities and bombing Axis ships anchored there. The raiders struck just as progress was being made in rebuilding dock facilities that had been damaged or destroyed in previous Allied raids.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, Oct. 12 -- Wang Chi-shi, Chinese business man who escaped from Singapore and at present is one of the leaders of the overseas Chinese in Chungking, said today that business and industry in Singapore are almost at a standstill because of the lack of shipping facilities.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Office of Price Administration tonight extended its control of rents to ninety-seven more defense areas, taking in most major cities and Alaska.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND ARMY, Lebanon, Tenn., Oct. 11 -- The officers responsible for the conduct of last week's manoeuvres on both sides assembled here this morning with their staffs, from generals commanding an army corps down to majors commanding battalions, to hear a review of their operations by the supervising umpires.

The Associated Actors and Artistes of America, the A.F. of L. overall body in control of all entertainer unions, now has on its hands a three-cornered dispute among its affiliates involving the jurisdiction of "Wine, Women and Song."

Joe Louis will be the second heavyweight champion to retire with the title still in his possession since the introduction of the Marquis of Queensberry rules to the sport. The Brown Bomber's only predecessor in this respect was Gene Tunney, who gave up the crown in 1928 after having defended it twice, against Jack Dempsey and Tom Heeney.

Retailers plan to appeal to high school and college authorities to change the times of the coming midwinter school vacations so that students may be employed in the pre-Christmas shopping period to meet a threatened serious shortage of salespeople and other employes, according to announcement by the Retailers Central Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Walter King Venning has been appointed director general of the British supply mission in Washington, succeeding Edward P. Taylor who resigned because of ill health, it was announced today.
LEBANON, Tenn., Oct. 11 -- Suspension of the Second Army's manoeuvres brought quiet to the hillsides of mid-Tennessee, but not to the household af Walter Bailey.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11 -RKO has closed a deal with George Petty, artist and cartoonist, for the right to use his name, drawings and services as technical adviser in connection with a film to be called "The Petty Girl." Although the prototype for Petty's figure is his daughter, RKO accompanied announcement of the deal with a statement that the studio will conduct a "national search" for an unknown to play the title role.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that while the people of the United States rightly might feel deep shame at having failed after the first World War to take steps to prevent another war, the "powerful mood of self-condemnation" often produces evil instead of good.

A birdie 3 by Doug Ford of Hummocks on the nineteenth hole enabled him and Ted Scholes to defeat Arthur Cunningham and William Tobin of Plandome, 1 up, in the final of the member-guest tournament of the North Hills Golf Club in Douglaston, Queens, yesterday.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 12 -Germany is on the verge of collapse on the military and home fronts, Antoine Delfosse, Minister of Justice and Information of the Belgian Government-in-Exile, declared in a statement released early today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 11 -- Major General George C. Kenney, air commander in the Southwest Pacific, awarded Silver Stars today to fourteen United Stakes Army fliers and other servicemen.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

VICHY, Oct. 11 -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France for Sept. 10 shows a global net increase of 57,000,000 francs in credits accorded to the securities markets. Bills discounted increased by 266,000,000 francs, but short-term advances on bonds declined by 291,000,000.

Gil T. Wagner has purchased the estate of John H. Beger Jr. in Wilson Place, Rumson, N.J., through Charles E. Sweeney, broker. The property includes a modern colonial home of twelve rooms and two and one-half acres.

A six-point program "as a means for keeping steadfast and resolute in wartime" was offered to members of his congregation in his sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.
Manhattan's midtown area took on a festive air yesterday as thousands of out-of-towners flocked into the city to spend the Columbus Day week-end here.

The six-story elevator apartment building for sixty families at 43-33 Forty-eighth Street, Long Island City, has been purchased by an investor from the Superior Investing Corporation. It is 125 by 90 feet and is assessed at $173,000. James C. McCormick was the broker in the sale of the property, which brought cash over mortgages amounting to $160,118.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Thomas Franklyn Manville Jr., 48 years old, heir to asbestos millions, was married this afternoon at the City Hall to Miss Wilhelmina Boze, 20-year-old blonde actress, of Andrews, S.C. This is the sixth marriage for Mr. Manville.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided yesterday at a pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral marking the thirty-second anniversary of the consecration of the church. Bishop John F. O'Hara, Military Delegate to the Armed Forces of the United States, pontificated, assisted by Mgr. William A. Scully, secretary for education of the Archdiocese of New York.

A new cross, carved in rich walnut, symbolizing "the most powerful force in the universe, the force of relentless good-will," was dedicated yesterday morning in the chancel of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, by the Rev. Elmore M. McKee, rector.
MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 12 (AP) -The Soviet midnight communique:'

Declining slightly in the early days of last week -- probably on profit-taking after September's rise -- the week-end stock market again became strong and active. On Thursday, transactions crossed the million-share mark for the first time in 1942, THE TIMES's stock averages reaching the highest point since January.

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Governor Charles Edison asserted tonight that Americans must learn to "recognize the footprints of the Trojan horse" and to understand that anti-Semitism is "a part of the Nazi scheme to divide and rule."

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- American theorists' and amateur strategists' view that the massive bombing of Germany can play a major role in defeating Reichsfuehrer Hitler was taken up today by Major Gen. Nikolai Zhuravleff, a high Red Air Force staff officer.

NORTON, Mass., Oct. 11 -- The function of a college is primarily the pursuit of knowledge and the search for truth, Dr. Herbert J. Davis, president of Smith College, said in a Founder's Day address at Wheaton College yesterday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The undefeated Bears routed the Cardinals, 41 to 14, today in a National Football League game before 38,500 fans for their sixteenth consecutive victory. The national professional champions punched over three touchdowns against their Chicago rivals in the first quarter, two more in the second and another in the last.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 11 -- "Coca-cola and chewing gum are incapable of undermining European culture and America, though very conversant with the canning industry, is not in a position to speak of human civilization and its future development."

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The convincing victories won over Nazi fighters by the United States Flying Fortresses and Liberators in the American bombers' raids over France have enhanced the prospects of a successful Allied invasion of the Continent, in the view of observers here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The shutting down of gold mining in the United States to free material and labor for work more essential to war production while the Congressional silver bloc still opposes the use of American silver for industrial purposes has given rise here to complaints that one industry is being discriminated against as compared with the other.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The state of emergency imposed by the Germans last Tuesday to combat sabotage in the Trondheim area of Norway was lifted tonight, the Norwegian Telegraph Agency said. Radio reports from Oslo were given as the source of information.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- Steel ingot output for the country last week moved up one-half a point to 99 1/2 per cent of rated capacity and indications are that production will approximate this figure this week. Steel operators still point out, however, that, given the raw materials, the industry could operate at a higher rate and thus produce more steel.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Producers now receiving orders for steel bars can promise delivery no earlier than the first quarter of 1943 even though the orders bear high priority ratings, the magazine Steel said today in its weekly market summary.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 11 -In the third of the post-season sailing regattas held today off the Larchmont Yacht Club, Bus Mosbacher, at the helm of the International Class sloop Susan, maintained her point lead by finishing second to Arthur Davis's Patricia, which led the way home.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Prices of grains were on the downgrade last week. Announcement of ceiling prices on a long list of agricultural commodities by the Office of Price Administration resulted in liquidation by holders of futures contracts, and wheat and rye sold at the lowest prices in more than a month, and corn and soy beans at the lowest since last December.

The effect was completely to confuse the enemy, as shown by an intercepted hurry-up radio call for all German fighters to get to Lille when the Americans began methodically dropping their bombs on warehouse, railway yards and locomotive works targets.

Uncertainty regarding the price ceiling and increased hedge selling were reflected in a slightly easier trend in cotton prices last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts at the close on Saturday showed net losses of 16 to 18 points for the week.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- In a decked-over indoor public swimming pool in the working-class district of North Hammersmith in London fifty girls from 16 to 18 years old were watching a diminutive gymnasium instructor lightly throwing a 200-pound male onto the mat.

A sufficient time has now elapsed since the signing of Fall leases for the more acute irritation to subside. But there are some who still feel strongly. Realizing, perhaps, the futility of writing to landlords about the matter, a New Rochelle lady has decided to vent her indignation to the editors.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained unchanged at 108.2. Even though the prices of several individual agricultural commodities showed changes, the farm products and raw materials groups remained unchanged.

Smaller furniture dealers, who are wondering which will force them out of business first, the decline in consumer demand or the lack of merchandise, are trying to decide whether to close their doors immediately, thereby salvaging whatever equity they have left, or "see it through" with a view to reaping a harvest soon after the war is over.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Allied medium bombers scored two bomb hits on a 10,000-ton Japanese seaplane tender in the Solomons Sea south of New Ireland yesterday and left the vessel, which carried at least twelve Zero fighter planes, heavily damaged and motionless, the Allied Command announced today.

Because most men consider a round number more significant than an irregular one, we are all disposed to make something of the fact that Columbus landed in the New World four and a half centuries ago today. Fourteen Ninety-two seems and is a long time ago.

Contributions of the film industry to art are not all concerned with animated images on a celluloid film. For instance, out in Hollywood they consider it no trick at all to whip up a smooth new complexion in less time than it takes to dream about it.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- The price ceilings on meats, lard and livestock products are expected to have a general overhauling in the immediate future and announcement that the maximum price that could be charged on lard would be increased 90 cents 100 pounds, effective Tuesday, did not come as a surprise to the provision trade.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Two thousand members of this fashionable community watched this afternoon from the slopes above the Tuxedo Racetrack a review of the Third Battalion of the Seventeenth Infantry, New York Guard.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Joe Louis may believe he's through with boxing, but "neither boxing nor the entire fight world will ever be through with Joe Louis," National Boxing Association President Abe J. Greene said tonight.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Officials of the South Portland Shipbuilding Corporation will meet with the Maritime Commission and the War Labor Board in Washington tomorrow in an effort to settle the wage differences which resulted in a partial walkout at the yard yesterday.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Grim-faced, hardrock miners broke a precedent by working a Sunday shift to blast loose all the ore they can before this historic camp's gold mines close for the duration.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 11 -President Juan Antonio Rios announced today he was postponing a projected visit to Washington because "official information circulated in the United States about my country has created an unpleasant atmosphere."

NOW the college football situation is thoroughly confused, or just what might have been expected. Most of the ordinary guide lines were lost before the first punt of the season went soaring over the turf.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Selling of oats last week carried the market for that grain into the lowest ground since the crop started to move in volume, although the recession was accelerated by the decline in corn. Grain men expressed the belief that while the oats crop this year is large, farm consumption will be unusually heavy and the accumulation of stocks at terminal markets will be small.
MALDEN, Mass., Oct. 11 -- Fifty years after James Bailey Upham wrote the Pledge of Allegiance now recited in every public school in the country, 8,000 persons honored him at his grave here today.

A record field of nineteen, including Doublrab, Parasang, Imperatrice and Devil Diver, is named for the $10,000 Interborough Handicap that will feature the opening today of the Fall racing at Jamaica.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11 -- Lieutenant Harry E. Reiseberg has an idea that a battery of huge tongs can be used after war to salvage the hundreds of Cargo ships sent to Davy Jones's locker by bombs and torpedoes.

Most divisions of the wholesale markets experienced peak Fall activity last week and many buyers were in town on short buying trips to fill in depleted stocks, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
Seven new films will arrive at Broadway theatres this week. The schedule follows:

All the title talk concerning the Brooklyn Football Dodgers apparently was premature. For the team that got such a flying start on the road opened its home season in the National Football League yesterday at Ebbets Field and slowed down, or was slowed down, by the surprisingly strong Pittsburgh Steelers.

In his letter to THE TIMES Norman Thomas argues that we should ignore Stalin's plea for a second front on the ground that we do not know that it would be feasible, and that Stalin's request is "less than fair" since Stalin did not open a second front against Japan and gave Hitler the "green light."

The shortage of skilled labor has suddenly become acute. Proposals are being made for the conscription of labor. The demands of total war are so remorseless that we cannot afford to reject in advance any proposal, no matter how drastic, that may promise to prevent defeat or to bring the day of victory substantially nearer.

Colonel Roger Hilsman, former commandant of cadets at the Ateneo de Manila, largest Jesuit college in the Philippines, was one of the leading heroes of the fighting in the Philippines, according to reports disclosed yesterday by the Jesuit Philippine Bureau of 51 East Eighty-third Street.

To advance the wartime program of the Child Study Association of America, a variety show enlisting many noted entertainers will be presented Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Clifton Fadiman will act as master of ceremonies for the show, which is entitled "CSA Varieties."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period, Oct. 3 to 9, are given in the appended tabulation:

TORONTO, Oct. 11 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today rejected the idea of having John L. Lewis invited to sit in at the forthcoming labor peace parleys between the federation and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 11 --The Philadelphia Americans gained the verdict over the Kearny Scots, 4 to 1, in an American Soccer League championship fixture at Scots Field today. At half-time the victors were leading, 1 to 0.

Hubert Valentine, Irish tenor, made his New York debut last night at Town Hall. He was assisted by Francis Flanagan, violinist, who had given two previous recitals at the hall. They divided the first half of the evening in a regular classical program, but after the intermission Mr. Valentine took sole possession singing Irish ballads.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Residents of Wimbledon, London suburban sports center, today went through a realistic full-dress rehearsal of scenes that might occur in an invasion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The hunt for Roger Touhy and his desperado companions shifted to Indiana today when a Catholic Priest at Fort Wayne notified Chicago police that a member of the "Terrible Touhy" gang had told him over the telephone:

Dr. George C.D. Odell, Brander Matthews Professor Emeritus of Dramatic Literature at Columbia University, whose labor of twenty-two years on the details of New York theatrical life has resulted in thirteen large books called "Annals of the New York Stage," a matter of about 4,000,000 words, will receive on Oct. 23 the Gold Medal of the New York Historical Society.

Marking the 450th anniversary of Christopher Columbus's discovery of the New World, 750 members of the Knights of Columbus of the archdiocese of New York held a meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor at which Archbishop Francis J. Spellman was elevated to the Fourth Degree of knighthood in the order.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Monday, Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- Representative Melvin J. Maas, Republican, of Minnesota, who visited New Zealand recently on a special mission, urged the United Nations to remain united after the war to save the world from future conflicts.

Condemning the "loose talk" and the complacency that he attributed to some of our leaders Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command and the First Army, declared yesterday at the annual ceremony of the Massing of the Colors in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church that the American people were ready for any sacrifice necessary for victory.

In a second warning to scrap-metal dealers that the city will stand for no delay in getting its Victory scrap to the steel mills, Mayor La Guardia made yesterday a veiled threat to take away the business licenses of those who do not cooperate fully in the salvage campaign.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP -Secretary Wickard disclosed today that there was a shortage of facilities for crushing, transporting and storing this year's record crop of soy beans.

The New York City WPA Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Mahler, was heard late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall in the first of a series of four concerts sponsored by the Workmen's Circle on behalf of the Treasury Department's War Saving Stamp Campaign.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Oct. 12 -- Wendell Willkie's visits to the Allies became a round-the-world-trip yesterday when he arrived here by airplane from China by way of Siberia.

Ohio State, coached again by Paul Brown, who only two years ago tutored a high school eleven, has the best college football team, in the opinion of ninety-one sports writers throughout the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The government's action in fettering German prisoners in retaliation for the chaining of British and Canadian captives is severely criticized as competition with Nazi barbarity by British leaders who are waiting anxiously with the rest of the nation for Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement to the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- According to plans which are being made by the WPB's conservation division, women will give their used silk, nylon and rayon hosiery to a national collection for use in powder bag manufacture. The salvage campaign will probably operate through retail sources, an official in the division said.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., yesterday reported for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $498,216 after charges and taxes, equal to 52 cents a capital share. For the similar period of 1941 the company had reported a net loss of $693,049.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Widespread Axis fears that the Allies are preparing an assault on the enemy's North African positions from Dakar to Egypt were evinced today by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels and a French spokesman on the Nazi-controlled Paris radio as well as the Rome radio.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- At least 60,000 women in the State must receive pre-employment training and 100,000 more enrolled in supplement courses during the next year, Oakley Furney, State Vocational Education Commissioner, said today.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- The United States may soon take control of the British-operated Iran railway that carries American supplies to Russia, reliable informants said today.

Add to the list of films opening this week, Paramount's "The Glass Key," which will arrive at Loew's Criterion tomorrow. The film, a remake of the melodrama by Dashiell Hammitt, features Alan Ladd, Brian Donlevy, Veronica Lake, Joseph Calleia, Frances Gifford and William Bendix.

It looks as if this season will be remarkable for the number of cycles by individual musicians. Leading off among the artists giving a series of concerts was Bernardo Segall, Brazilian pianist, who presented at the Town Hall last night the first of three evenings devoted to the sonata form.

Milk distributors in the metropolitan area who increased their prices for fluid milk to stores in September following the increased price to farmers must return to their previous ceilings within three days or risk prosecution, Samuel Poses of the enforcement staff of the regional OPA declared yesterday at a meeting at the OPA office of government officials, distributors and retailers.
CAIRO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

The well-known French modernist, Fernand Leger, who for some time now has been living in the United States, is having two one-man shows, both of which opened yesterday to continue through the remainder of the month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Ogden H. Hammond Jr., a foreign service officer who was put on leave without pay in March, 1941, lost his fight in the United States Court of Appeals today to be put back on active status and an efficiency rating of "unsatisfactory" revoked.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Four Albany men pleaded guilty in Federal Court today to a charge of conspiring to obtain about $50,000 from employes on a government construction project at Voorheesville and were fined $10,000 each.

Columbus Day trade in local stores was active, with sales volume ranging 10 per cent or more ahead of the same day last year, merchants here reported yesterday. Shopping crowds were heavy throughout most of the day, and three large stores here remained open until 9 P.M. to take care of war workers and others.

The German High Command, in its only reference yesterday to the fighting inside Stalingrad, reported that "an enemy group was annihilated." The German communique was quoted in German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 12 -- The National Labor Relation Board's decision to investigate complaints of alleged collusive closed shop contracts between the American Federation of Labor and Henry J. Kaiser in West Coast shipyards was denounced at today's session of the federation convention as "something very close to treason."

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 12 -- A new high mark in building here this year was set in September, according to a report by the municipal building department which issued permits last month aggregating $277,117, topping July, the next best month, by $5,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- It was learned authoritatively here today that the references to Axis influence and espionage in Chile and Argentina, embodied in the speech that Sumner Welles, as acting Secretary of State, delivered at Boston last Thursday were made because this government had proof that Axis agents in those countries had transmitted information that has led to the sinkings of ships in American waters.

ALTON, Ill., Oct. 12 (AP) -- A conference between union leaders and War Labor Board conciliators ended in no decision tonight in the unauthorized strike of A.F.L. molders and foundry workers at the Western Cartridge Company's East Alton plant.

OTTAWA, Oct. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's third victory loan, with a "minimum requirement" of $750,000,000 as its objective, will be offered in two maturities, Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- California vintners were told today by the Office of Price Administration that permission to increase their present March, 1942, ceiling prices on sales of sweet and dry wine to bottlers would be forthcoming soon.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Although some sections of the stock market were subject to a little profit-taking, prices remained steady. Business was somewhat restricted, but the iron and steel and shipping shares were stimulated by Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement.
COACHES, scouts, graduate managers and interested bystanders were giving the football returns a loud going-over. Here are some of the passes that were caught before they hit the ground.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12 -- Yale will present a patched-up eleven in Baltimore against Navy on Saturday because of injuries suffered in the Pennsylvania game.

Senator James M. Mead intends to campaign for the election of John J. Bennett Jr., who bested him for the Democratic nomination, although the campaigning apparently will not be under the auspices of the Democratic State Committee.

NEWARK, Oct. 12 -- One hundred thousand workers in downtown Newark will go to work at unaccustomed hours tomorrow in New Jersey's first effort to relieve congestion on public transport systems by staggering working hours.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 13 -- German armored and infantry forces resumed attacks in the Stalingrad area yesterday after a short lull, and in one sector of the city the Russian defenders were pressed back slightly, the Soviet High Command announced today.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Two C.I.O. organizers were removed from the scene by police today as operations at the South Portland Shipbuilding Corporation returned to near normalcy after a walkout of workmen who, an A.F.L. union official said, "got tired of waiting" for promised wage increases.

It was a refreshing, lively collection of furs that was offered for fashion inspection yesterday afternoon at Jaeckel's. Super-luxury was out; good taste and novelty were in. Here were coats for active women to wear, but the showing did not stop with these; there were handsome wraps that women will want to don for late afternoon and evening.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 12 -- An Army fighter plane crashed into the home of Mrs. Webb Weeks, widow of a New York doctor, on Valley Road here this morning, killing the pilot and causing a fire that destroyed the 200- year-old house.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve system reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ending Oct. 7: Increases of $60,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans; $199,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $395,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $289,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $584,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

LONDON, Oct 12 -- The strength of the forces of Fighting France in this country has been bolstered by the addition of 950 French officers and men who fought against the British at the Diego Suarez naval base in Madagascar last Spring, General Charles de Gaulle's headquarters here announced today.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, said last night that the election of the Republican State ticket would bring "fresh minds and fresh energies" into the State administration and would assure a more efficient coordination of State and national war activities.

To help keep alive the memory of the Czechoslovak village of Lidice, which died under Hitler's vengeful wrath last June 10, a memorial sculpture was presented yesterday afternoon by Jo Davidson, noted American sculptor, to the Lidice Lives Committee, at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

OTTAWA, Oct. 12 -- Difference of opinion is running strongly in Canada regarding the wisdom of the reprisals announced Saturday for the fettering two days previously by the Germans of prisoners taken at Dieppe, who undoubtedly include a large number of Canadians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- A plan aiming to make the scrap collecting and financing operations of the government operate more smoothly was worked out today at conferences between executives of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's War Materials, Inc., and the War Production Board's conservation division.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- President Roosevelt recommended tonight the drafting of 18 and 19 year old youths for military service as an essential measure to speed victory, and indicated that it may become necessary to draft labor for mine, mill, factory and farm to meet the country's huge war production commitments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- A serious shortage of manpower and machinery for agriculture theatens to make some of the most important objectives of the Department of Agriculture's program of increased food production this year unattainable, a department spokesman said today.

Due to the varying percentages of non-ferrous metals involved, alloys have become a stumbling block in the War Production Board's efforts to speed the flow of scrap metals, Elias J. Bernstein, president of the Empire Metal Merchants Association, told members group held in the New Yorker Hotel.

In a new shape the old Oregon is going to war again. After dozing at her Portland dock for seventeen years, the famous ship has been ordered broken up for naval scrap. President Roosevelt, who once saved her from a similar fate, must have hated to give the final word, but it was wisely given.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 12 -- The University of North Carolina observed today its 149th birthday by rededicating its spirit and resources to the service of the Republic.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Greater production of plastics for the two-fold purpose of replacing scarce materials in the war effort and providing more civilian goods to help close the inflation gap was urged by speakers at the Fall convention of the Society of the Plastics Industry at the Westchester Country Club here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- The government lost its anti-trust suit against James C. Petrillo and his American Federation of Musicians today when Judge John P. Barnes of the Federal District Court dismissed the Department of Justice petition for an injunction to end the union's ban on the recording of music for radio, juke boxes, and other public reproductions.

Retailers here have made extensive use of increased advertising linage, booklets, posters, etc., emphasizing the necessity of early mailing of Christmas gifts to soldiers overseas. Eighteen days remain before the deadline and the stores here look forward to a considerable increase in the volume of such gifts.

A head finish on the post followed by a claim of foul left 26,963 fans temporarily in doubt yesterday as the thoroughbreds returned to Jamaica for the nine-day race meeting which continues until Wednesday, Oct. 21. When the officials had acted in due course, F.L. Tyler's Eire, a former Wheatley Stable racer, had been adjudged the winner, while the sprint star, Doublrab, had to be content with second honors.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 12 -- Details of an agreement between the United States and Mexico to rehabilitate the Mexican railroad network by supplying locomotives and cars are virtually settled, it was learned today. An announcement of the agreement is expected shortly.
Still the champion and still willing to defend his title whenever the opportunity presents itself, Joe Louis yesterday declared he had no thought of giving up the heavyweight crown.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. opened his formal campaign for election as Governor tonight with a tribute here to the rank and file of party workers, Democratic and Republican, who had kept the two-party system alive and with a special appeal to Democratic workers for pluralities so large as to constitute a mandate that "there be no interruption in the march of progress."

Samuel Rubel, president of the Rubel Ice and Coal Corporation, has leased a furnished duplex suite in 737 Park Avenue through R. Fabricant, broker. Another large lease reported yesterday was an apartment of seven rooms and three baths in 262 Central Park West rented to Samuel Cohen, a dry goods store owner from South Africa.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Norbert Klein, chairman of a Milwaukee Town Hall program committee, said today that Colonel Hugh J. Knerr, retired former chief of staff of the Army Air Force, would be unable to appear at a Town Hall meeting tonight because of an order from Secretary Stimson.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 12 -- While under cover of the state of emergency the Germans were executing obviously innocent Norwegians at Trondheim, the power station in the affected coastal area some thirty miles from Bodoe was blown up by saboteurs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- President Roosevelt lauded today the "substantial contribution" of Palestine to the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Although war production is increasing steadily government expenditures of $5,500,000,000 in September were only seven-eighths as large as the total spent by consumers for civilian goods and services in that month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- The bodies of two 14-year-old Negroes, Charlie Lang and Ernest Green, who had pleaded guilty to waylaying a 13-year-old white girl and trying to attack her, were found hanging to a bridge today after a mob had taken them from the Quitman jail.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The War Production Board today announced that an amendment to order M-207 has placed pincheck fabrics, previously not included in the order, under its provisions. The classification of denim also was changed by the amendment.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The need for women in war industries was emphasized at the opening meeting today of the 1942 conference of directors, principals and supervisors of vocational schools, attended by about 250 persons.

Unless orders to the contrary come from Washington, the classic Army-Navy game will be played as usual this year. This message was delivered yesterday to the Football Writers Association at its weekly luncheon at Toots Shor's Restaurant by Lieut. Col. Lawrence (Biff) Jones, graduate manager at West Point.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The morale of the large American force in the British Isles is now reasonably high but there are factors in the situation that, if not dealt with promptly, are capable not only of damaging this Army's fighting condition but of disturbing the now flourishing relations between the Yanks and the British.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A bill giving the President power to commandeer or acquire by voluntary sale automobiles and other transport equipment is to be introduced early this week by Senators Reynolds and Downey.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Intensification of the drive against the Polish Catholic clergymen was reported today from German-occupied Poland, following a recent Nazi decree announcing that the Catholic Church of Poland and other religious bodies would henceforth be treated as private associations without public rights.

The long struggle to get the poll-tax issue discussed and voted on in the House of Representatives reached its end yesterday when the House took the Geyer bill out of the hands of the Rules Committee. This may or may not mean that the House will pass the bill, or that the Senate will concur if the House does pass it.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 12 -Not only has conscription of labor for Germany begun in France, but forcible measures are already in application, according to trustworthy reports received here, and there is little to choose between the lot of Belgian and French workers except that half their former French pay in addition to German pay is promised to the latter.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Oct. 12 -- Wendell Willkie, arriving here tonight from Fairbanks, Alaska, on his globe-girdling flight, said he thought it inappropriate while abroad to reply to "flippant statements made by certain public officials concerning the expression of my opinion in Russia on the question of a second front."

Workers of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office as well as school teachers will help householders fill out their application blanks for fuel oil in New York City, Lee S. Buckingham, State administrator of the OPA, said yesterday following the announcement in Washington that all dealers and suppliers of fuel oil, including kerosene, must register with their local boards Oct. 20 and 21.

Federal regulation of insurance companies to overcome lack of coordination among insurance commissioners of the forty-eight States was urged yesterday by John L. Train, president of the Utica Mutual Insurance Company, in an address before the eleventh annual convention of the National Association of Mutual Insurance Agents.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- A Navy Department communique:

Charles (Chuck) Perone, a converted tackle, proved the star as Theodore Roosevelt High School's football team battled a favored James Monroe eleven to a 6-all deadlock at Monroe Field yesterday. A gathering of 4,000 watched the struggle between the Bronx foes.

Salvage work on the capsized transport U.S.S. Lafayette, formerly the luxury liner Normandie, is still progressing rapidly and is "ahead of schedule," but Naval officials in charge of the vast project are not yet ready to predict when the hull will be ready to float out of its bed of mud and rock.

Commander Tom Hamilton had a great idea in instituting his athletic program in pre-flight schools for Navy aviation cadets, but at the same time he has thrown the biggest monkey wrench of all time into intercollegiate football.

No classroom was assigned to the teachers, guidance counselors, and graduate students who registered for course 260.31 in the New York University School of Education. For the course, entitled "Community Resources for Guidance," meets every Wednesday from 4:15 to 6 P.M. at a different guidance center.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- Ground fighting at Stalingrad during the last seventy-two hours has been limited mainly to artillery and mortar exchanges. There still are no indications in the Russians' reports that the present abatement is more than a pause in the operation.

Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, became the Army induction center for the Southern District of New York yesterday. Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City director of Selective Service, pronounced it far superior to the former center on Governors Island, after a tour of inspection with other draft officials.

A plan which provides for the regular weekly distribution of war information and morale films, produced by the government and by six major Hollywood studios, was revealed yesterday by the War Activities Committee of the motion picture industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Third Circuit Court of Appeals denied today a motion by the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey to dismiss an appeal by the State of New Jersey from a District Court ruling which fixed the railroad's tax indebtedness from 1932 to 1940 at more than $13,000,000.

AN EAST COAST PORT, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that twenty-three survivors of an American merchantman, sunk by shellfire of an Axis submarine, had been landed here by a British ship that picked them up after they had been adrift in the Atlantic three weeks.

The second you see them you want to know what they are. "Dehydrated potatoes," comes the flat answer. And then, as you still look puzzled, the maker explains. "You take a bit of dried potato, moisten it -- it expands when it's wet -- saute it, and coat it with a lot of grated cheese."

The Tuesday observance of meatless days, which won the approval yesterday of the Society of Restaurateurs and representatives of the National Restaurant Association, New York State Hotel Association and the City Hotel Association, will start next Tuesday, under a final announcement on the starting date made last night by Mayor La Guardia.

Referring to the letter from Emerson F. Davis in THE TIMES of Oct. 8, it may be said that when John Jones buys a bond payable to himself during his lifetime and at his death to Mary Jones he does the same sort of thing that is done every day of the week by persons who establish trusts for their children.

Faced with the necessity of supplying 25,000,000 lightweight cotton undershirts to the Army and Navy within the next several months, steps were being taken here yesterday by men's underwear mills to shut off additional Spring buying by wholesalers until more definite information can be obtained as to civilian supply of materials and skilled labor during the first quarter of 1943.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Of 5,000 conscientious objectors in the United States, 200 are engaged in relieving the manpower shortage at two general hospitals and six State institutions, it was revealed today.
OMAHA, Oct. 12 (AP) -- "My fightin' days are over." Uttering those words simply, sincerely, unhesitatingly, Joe Louis thus informed me yesterday of his intention of retiring from the ring.
It may become common to have your "ham on rye" or "chocolate malt" served in your favorite drug store by a trim girl soda dispenser, the New York Pharmacists Association said yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 12 -- Yesterday's air attacks against Malta, coming as they did after virtual cessation of large-scale raiding aimed at the island, are taken to indicate the straits in which the recent Allied air offensive against Axis supplies has placed General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps.
Today's declaration by the President that those known to be guilty of atrocities against their helpless victims in Nazi-held territories will be tried and punished is timely and necessary.

Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, speaking here yesterday morning at the annual Columbus Day exercises at Columbus Circle, praised the loyalty of Americans of Italian extraction and appealed for nation-wide tolerance for minority groups.

The Graduate School of the Juilliard School of Music announced yesterday the winners of its annual fellowships. The list shows the effects of the war, for there are eighteen fewer fellowships than last year and all but sixteen of the forty-three winners are women.

With expressions of friendship for the Italian people but condemnation of their government's political philosophy and its alliance with other dictator countries, Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and Assistant Secretary of State A.A. Berle Jr. addressed a gala Columbus Day celebration yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera House.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Chilean press generally expressed hope today that the postponement of President Juan Antonio Rios's visit to the United States as the result of a speech by Sumner Welles would not cause a misunderstanding between the two countries.

Harold Kohon, 25-year-old New York violinist, who made his New York debut four years ago at Town Hall, last night gave his second local recital at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. The major works on his program were the Beethoven F major sonata, the Wiemawski concerto and Ravel's "Tzigane."
Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal representative to the Vatican, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon aboard a transatlantic clipper from Europe.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- There was considerable air activity over the Channel today, but there was no confirmation here of German reports of nuisance flights by single British planes over north and northwest German territory. The loss of one British plane was conceded.
SAMPSON, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Brief ceremonies next Saturday will "establish" the new naval training station here and three days later the first contingent of 250 recruits is expected to arrive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- William M. Jeffers, rubber administrator, told the Senate Agriculture Committee today that if the Army wanted to substitute rayon for cotton as a base for its heavy duty rubber tires the Army would get rayon regardless of the protests of any Congressional group or any one else.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

CLEVELAND, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The H.K. Ferguson Company of Cleveland has received contracts from the Defense Plant Corporation for Construction which will "almost double" the nation's present detinning capacity by next Summer, H.K. Ferguson, president, announced today.

The recent indications that Modern Age Books was winding up its business were confirmed yesterday. Its staff and editorial directorship seriously depleted in recent weeks by the war, the firm had been finding it difficult to continue and it was announced yesterday that the assets had been disposed of and contracts and titles transferred to other publishers.

This should develop into a busy week for many hunters. The waterfowl season opens in this zone on Thursday, and that day also marks the beginning of the woodcock and grouse seasons in the southern part of the Empire State.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- The stanch tenacity of the defenders of Southern Russia has had an effect throughout the front. For example, an attack by Col. Gen. Eduard Dietl's Arctic army, which had been expected by the defenders of Northern Russian ports early in September, failed to develop.

The casing of the first shell fired into Germany by United States forces in the last war is going back at Hitler's legions. Max Weinstein, president of Russeks Fifth Avenue, said yesterday that it would be turned into Manhattan's scrap drive on Thursday.
Coach Lou Little sent the second and third elevens through one of the longest and most intensive drills of the season at Baker Field yesterday as work was eased for the Columbia regulars.

The action of Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, in excluding this city from his Sunday order extending control by his office of rents in ninety-seven additional defense areas brought approval yesterday from representatives of landlord organizations but keen disappointment from those representing tenant groups.

Six hundred thousand unnaturalized Italians living in the United States will be freed from the stigma of being alien enemies of this country, beginning next Monday, it was announced last night by Attorney General Francis Biddle in a speech at a Columbus Day celebration at Carnegie Hall.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Post-season racing was concluded today at the Larchmont Yacht Club with Bobby Mosbacher's International Class sloop Susan, Jay Lukens's Atlantic Hera and R.H. McCullough's craft Felicity the group leaders for the last four regattas.
Most nations seem to have traitors --Quislings, Lord Haw Haws, and others. Why have we Norwegians been singled out as the traitor nation par excellence?

The most important differences between the tax bill passed by the House last July and the Senate version are the changes in corporation rates and the substitution by the Senate of the victory tax for the House's 5 per cent withholding tax.

Equality of all nations in the post-war world and an unchecked cultural interchange among them were called for yesterday by educational and medical leaders at the closing sessions of a three-day Institute of Inter-American Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The American Medical Association obtained Supreme Court consent today for a review of a lower court decision holding the organization guilty of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law through alleged activities against Group Health Association, a local cooperative of government employes.
Sales of six homes in Queens for the Home Owners Loan Corporation, the Greenpoint Savings Bank and the Realty Mortgagee Corporation were reported yesterday by Butterly Green, brokers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that Henry Travers, character actor who was seen recently in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Mrs. Miniver" as a station master, will play Mayor Orden in the screen version of John Steinbeck's "The Moon Is Down."

Reorder activity was brisk in the wholesale markets here yesterday. Stores in war production areas continued to place a heavy volume of mail business. Retailers in other sections also contributed a heavy mail, as most retailers in such sections are now moving toward their seasonal peaks in apparel and accessory buying by consumers.
The significance of Columbus Day in a world at war was emphasized at more than one observance here yesterday of the 450th anniversary of the discovery of America.

Judith Anderson is the latest member of the cast of Miss Cornell's revival of "The Three Sisters," and Ruth Gordon is to know by tomorrow whether she, too, is to be in the company. The rehearsals were to have started a fortnight ago, but now they won't begin until next Monday, allowing Miss Anderson time to reach here from her home on the Coast.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct 12 -- There's a new head coach on the banks of the Raritan, where men would "die for dear old Rutgers." Harry J. (Rocky) Rockafeller has taken over and from the outset faced a number of disadvantages.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Proudly carrying her colors as top 3-year-old filly of the year, Vagrancy romped to victory today in the $4,350 Queen Isabella Handicap, to run her record to eleven triumphs in eighteen starts this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Jean Knox, chief controller of what is believed to be the world's largest women's military unit, the British Auxiliary Territorial Service, at a press conference before noon today in the British Embassy, exemplified her own belief that service in the A.T.S. is a woman's "finest education."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Tom Mountain, captain of Princeton's strong 1938 team, started Tiger preparations for Saturday's tilt at Franklin Field with the Pennsylvania powerhouse with a short pep talk to the entire squad on University Field today.

MOUNT HOLY, N.J., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Senator William H. Smathers, opening a State-wide speaking tour in his campaign for re-election, said tonight he was proud of the opportunity to rubber stamp measures endorsed by President Roosevelt.

After about five years of work in other fields Molly Picon has returned to Yiddish musical comedy as the star of "Oy Is Dus a Leben," which opened last evening at the Molly Picon (nee Jolson) Theatre at Broadway and Fifty-eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Navy borrowed an idea today from the "canned" greetings long featured by the telegraph companies.

Steel operations for this week are scheduled at 100.2 per cent of capacity, the highest since the start of the war, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This represents an increase of 1.6 points over the operating rate of 98.6 per cent last week.

Three weeks from today the people of New York will elect a Governor. This newspaper, which in the past has given its support successively to Alfred E. Smith, to Franklin D. Roosevelt and to Herbert Lehman, now recommends to its readers the candidacy of John Bennett.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- This war, so far as Treasury issues for subscription by the commercial banks are concerned, is to be financed at 2 per cent.

The British Broadcasting Corporation asserted yesterday that Reich Marshal Hermann Goering had deposited about $8,000,000 outside Germany, the British Information Services here reported yesterday, according to The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The American Navy paid three heavy American cruisers -- the Quincy, Vincennes and Astoria -- as part of the price for successful occupation of the Japanese air field on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons, the Navy revealed tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Reviewing the progress of the war when he received the freedom of the city of Edinburgh today, Prime Minister Churchill declared that the last two months were the "least bad" since January in the battle of the Atlantic.
MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

The farm property comprising about sixty acres of land with an eight-room dwelling, two large barns and several other outbuildings on Poplar Road, Wayside, N.J., was sold by Matilda B. Woolley to the Herbert G. Brooks Company.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 12 -- Prospects of peace in the American labor movement dimmed today as the convention of the United Mine Workers voted to extend its jurisdiction to unorganized workers in any and all industries which John L. Lewis and the union's international executive board might designate for organization in competition with the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

HEADQUARTERS, Solomon Islands, Sept 5 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Two over-age American destroyers were sunk after fighting to the last in an early morning sea battle with a Japanese light cruiser and destroyer force off Guadalcanal today.

In his Columbus Day speech last evening Attorney General Biddle stated that out of 600,000 Italians in this country classified ten months ago as "enemy aliens" only 228 had so conducted themselves as to merit internment; and that he had therefore, with the President's approval, issued an order, effective next Monday, removing Italians from the "enemy alien" list.

Mayor La Guardia formally dedicated yesterday afternoon the $50,000 clubhouse of the Columbia Association of the Sanitation Department at 912 Union Street, Brooklyn. He also dedicated a service flag for 108 members in the armed services.

VALLETTA, Malta, Oct 12 (AP) -- The British defenders of Malta established a new daylight record today as they shot down twelve Axis bombers and ten Axis fighters in slashing blows against new large-scale air attacks, described as the heaviest in months.

A ruling by the OPA affecting the fair trade pricing of specially packaged Christmas cosmetic sets is being awaited by the toilet goods industry, H.L. Brooks, president of the Toilet Goods Association and head of Coty, Inc., said yesterday in an address at the Fall convention of the Affiliated Drug Stores at the Hotel Biltmore.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Live hog prices slumped as much as 1/2 cent a pound today, one of the sharpest breaks in months, shaving millions of dollars from the value of the record swine population now on farms.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- Reports from Yugoslavia indicate that fierce fighting is going on in many parts of the country between patriots and Italian and German punitive expeditions.
