These expeditions were sent out in an attempt to restore the situation developing in various parts of Yugoslavia as the result of operations launched by the patriots after they reaped the maize harvest.

We are told that the entire country is saving rubber and gasoline. It is difficult to believe it when one notes the rapidly moving cars on the country highways and all those belonging to the Army. It is also difficult to realize it when one is ordered by the duly appointed authorities to drive from twenty-five to thirty-five miles in order to secure the right to have additional gasoline with which to drive home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Breathing defiance at a group of cotton State Senators, William M. Jeffers, the rubber director, declared today that no pressure group was going to stop him from substituting rayon for cotton in heavy duty tires if the Army wanted rayon.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- Reports from Yugoslavia indicate that fierce fighting is going on in many parts of the country between patriots and Italian and German punitive expeditions. These expeditions were sent out in an attempt to restore the situation developing in various parts of Yugoslavia as the result of operations launched by the patriots after they reaped the maize harvest.

We are told that the entire country is saving rubber and gasoline. It is difficult to believe it when one notes the rapidly moving cars on the country highways and all those belonging to the Army. It is also difficult to realize it when one is ordered by the duly appointed authorities to drive from twenty-five to thirty-five miles in order to secure the right to have additional gasoline with which to drive home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Breathing defiance at a group of cotton State Senators, William M. Jeffers, the rubber director, declared today that no pressure group was going to stop him from substituting rayon for cotton in heavy duty tires if the Army wanted rayon.
The text of the Columbus Day address of Attorney General Francis Biddle made at Carnegie Hall and broadcast over a nation-wide hookup of the Mutual Broadcasting System last night is as follows:

BALTIMORE, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Eastern aircraft industry, organized into a cooperative body for the interchange of men, ideas, machines and materials, acted today to alleviate a machine tool shortage at one plant.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 12 -- More police forces are being moved by the Vichy government into regions near the Swiss border. At Annemasse, for instance, a strong detachment of State police, commanded by two officers, has just arrived "for an indeterminate period."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- President Roosevelt prefaced tonight's radio talk with a Columbus Day statement in which he declared that the war objective of this country was "liberty for ourselves" and "liberation for others."

Ethelbert Smith said he was impressed by one odd fact in the matter of Stalingrad and the second front. And this was that Winston Churchill has had much more confidence in the Russian Army and in Joseph Stalin than have the anxious friends of Soviet Russia who are calling Winston Churchill names.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Elmer Davis, head of the Office of War Information, told the National Editorial Association today that the OWI was telling the enemy the truth about what we were doing in the war as the surest contribution toward victory.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- With two record votes the House paved the way today for consideration and probable passage of a long-pending bill to outlaw payment of poll taxes as a prerequisite to the right to vote for candidates for Federal office.

VICHY, France, Oct. 12 -- Official declarations treat the recruiting of labor for Germany today as a national emergency that leaves the workers no choice but to volunteer for the service if they have been designated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A survivor of the engagement in which three United States cruisers were lost in the Solomon Islands gave his account of the battle in stories released tonight by the Navy.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Captain Joseph Cannon, 31 years old, was killed and three enlisted men were injured in a motor accident involving three Army vehicles on State Highway 25 here at 3 A.M. today.

Twelve traffic officers employed by the Port of New York Authority on its three Staten Island bridges were suspended on Saturday charged with having made improper registration of tolls, it was disclosed last night by Billings Wilson, director of operations.

The Museum of Modern Art announces that artists of Latin America have sent more than half of the 855 posters received by the museum in the United Hemisphere competition which closed on Sept. 30. The competition was open to artists of the United States, Canada and Latin-American countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Under the seniority system that governs the succession to chairmanships of the committees of Congress, Senator George last year had a difficult choice before him. He could be chairman of Foreign Relations, a position of great dignity and some importance (though less in wartime than during peace), or he could head the Committee on Finance.

The collection of scrap metal for the great and growing war machine of the United States will begin in the Bronx this morning at 7 A.M. while Mayor La Guardia, in Washington, will seek to break the bottleneck that is threatened by the attitude of junk dealers.

It is quite safe to assert that the former drawing room of the old Whitelaw Reid mansion, 451 Madison Avenue, never before presented an appearance remotely resembling the transformation that has been wrought since the place was turned over to the surrealists.

PITY the poor newspaper man. He keeps long hours toiling at his arduous and nerve-racking profession, and then in his so-called leisure he sits at his typewriter and writes books about the very same matters he has been reporting in his daily stint. Such books, of course, have made some reporters so famous and prosperous they don't have to be reporters any more and can be celebrated authors and radio commentators instead.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13 -- General Abelardo L. Rodriguez told the writer today that "Mexico could collaborate very effectively with the United States if we were not tied up with unnecessary red tape and if the United States looked upon us as allies and not merely as good friends. What Mexico needs most from the United States is good-will and understanding."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson said today he had ordered Colonel Hugh J. Knerr to refrain from public comment on the conduct of the war because the government "does not pay the officers of its Army and Navy to fight with each other."

Home decoration in a world of wartime changes, priorities and fuel problems provides the theme for seventeen newly decorated rooms which go on view today at Lord and Taylor, Thirty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue.

My attention has been called to the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 10 regarding President Roosevelt's statement on the St. Lawrence seaway and also to the fact that THE TIMES of Oct. 11 carried Thomas C. Dewey's statement on the same subject.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The Channel Islands, including Sark -- the raid on which precipitated the dispute over binding prisoners of war -- were reported today to be garrisoned by a German force exceeding 10,000 men. Information reaching here discloses that the enemy has drawn on large reserves of labor from the occupied countries of Europe to do chores in these small islands.

Local home relief rolls, which have shown a progressive drop since August of last year, are rapidly being exhausted of employables qualified to fill requisitions by the WPA for project work, it was revealed yesterday by William Hodson, Commisioner of Welfare.

With the duck season opening tomorrow in the intermediate zone, which includes most of New York as well as the near-by States of Connecticut, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island, John T. Gibbs, acting conservation commissioner, has issued some final instructions as an aid to clear away any cobwebs that might exist in the minds of hunters regarding the new regulations.

The Bears may beat the Giants when they clash in the Windy City on Sunday, but they'll have to do it on Wrigley Field and not on paper. George Halas's mighty aggregation is heavily favored, and probably rightfully so, to turn back Steve Owen's men, but the coach of the Giants insists that the Bears will have to do it on the gridiron, and that no rave notices in the papers will do the trick.

The public enthusiasm for new clothes does not wane in spite of present-day conditions. It was a substantial crowd that assembled in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton yesterday noon to view the collection presented by Jonai. Seventy-five per cent of the collection was custom made which gave it a flavor of individuality.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

Although stocks of Scotch whisky in storage in Britain are sufficient to supply the English home and export markets for about six years, continuation of the war for three years or more may bring about a period when the product will not be available because of the regulations requiring it to be aged before sale, Harry L. Lourie, vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, said yesterday.

MONTREAL, Oct. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Curtailment of production of nine newsprint mills in Quebec Province to release 50,000 horsepower for war industries was announced tonight following conferences between officials of the Wartime Prices and Trade Board, the National Selective Service and H. J. Symington, Power Controller.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- James F. Byrnes, director of economic stabilization, moved today to control rents on all real property throughout the country, commercial as well as residential.

Paul Governali and his bulletlike passes were temporarily grounded at Baker Field yesterday as Coach Lou Little worked on improving the Lions' running attack for the Light Blue's home game with Army Saturday. Governali, however, was still the central figure in most of the ground plays.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- An amended plan for the purchase by the Penn-Jersey Water Company and John H. Ware Jr. of the common stock of the Northeastern Water and Electric Corporation from the trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation for $600,000 less than contemplated originally was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Christopher Columbus received a good deal of attention in the Moscow press. He well might do so, aside from today's special circumstances which make the discovery and existence of America of considerable importance to the Russian people.
Following is the text of the prepared statement issued by former Governor Alfred E. Smith endorsing the Democratic State ticket headed by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- A registration statement covering the proposed sale of 40,000 shares of preferred stock, 5 per cent cumulative, par value $50, by the Houston Natural Gas Corporation was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- High praise for the part newspapers are playing in promotion of the war bond and scrap drives was heard today by two groups of newspaper executives who are in conference here.

Sixty-five days after the event we are learning of the serious losses we suffered in the operations in which we seized Tulagi Harbor and the Guadalcanal airfield. Prime Minister Curtin admitted the sinking of the Australian cruiser Canberra within ten days. The loss of our own cruisers Quincy, Vincennes and Astoria has just been announced at Washington, though the Japanese claimed their destruction the morning after the event.

Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, opened the borough's scrap drive yesterday at a rally held outside the Hunter College building, Sixty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, near a three-ton heap of scrap gathered from the college grounds.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 13 -- The convention of the American Federation of Labor recommended today that the national war effort be "streamlined" by a Presidentially named "over-all board of military and civilian strategy," charged with the centralization of manpower, procurement of supplies and food and the administration of a rationing program.

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 -- Russian gratitude for the medical aid sent to the Soviet Red Cross society by the United States and other lands was expressed today by Dr. Nikolai Kotelnikov, chairman of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Society in the U.S.S.R., in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Members of the Republican Committee of 100 at a meeting yesterday in 575 Park Avenue received an account of the Republican party's stewardship in this State from Miss Jane Todd, member of the Assembly from Tarrytown and vice chairman of the Republican State Committee.

Six hundred thousand Italians living and working in this country, six million Americans of Italian parentage, must have found Attorney General Biddle's Columbus Day speech the biggest story of the year. Beginning next Monday, as Mr. Biddle announced, the six hundred thousand will no longer be treated as alien enemies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- As Wendell L. Willkie nears the capital to report to the President on the "specific jobs he gave me to do for him" abroad, the interest of Washington in the Republican national candidate of 1940 is greater than at any time since he was making his campaign against Mr. Roosevelt.

There probably has never been a soldier or sailor who bade farewell to the lady of his choice without adding " . . . and don't forget, you promised to send me your picture!'' Departing heroes, moreover, entertain some particular theories about the sort of photograph they want, so it behooves the subject to look her prettiest when the likeness is recorded.

TRENTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The State Government declined today to accept as a gift a rolling 112-acre estate in Somerset and Morris Counties with a $50,000 residence formerly used as a home for aged women.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Four veterans of the surprise raid by American Army planes on Japanese installations in the Philippines April 10 were among four teen airmen to whom Major Gen. George F. Kenney, head of Allied air forces in the Southwest Pacific, awarded Oak Leaf Clusters today.

By combining the strongest forces of New York's metropolitan amateur loop with the survivors of last year's circuit, the Eastern Amateur Hockey League again will operate as an eight-club outfit for the 1942-43 season, President Tom Lockhart of the league said yesterday through The Associated Press.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 14 -- Russian troops, wresting the initiative from the Germans in key sectors of the now wintry southern front, recaptured lost positions in Stalingrad yesterday and cut a new gash in the Nazi flank to the northwest, a Red Army communique said today.

The five-story apartment house containing thirty-two states at 1-9 Gifford Avenue in the Bergen section of Jersey City, N.J., was sold by Hugo Boepple Jr., trustee, to the 647 Realty Company, Inc. Ben Schlossberg, Inc., were the brokers.

As a sometime officer of the Indian Army I have no doubt the righteous will hold that I am a most unsuitable person to express any opinion on the Indian problem, the more so as I am quite unregenerate and look back to my service with pride rather than shame.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- Walt Disney has acquired screen rights to a collection of stories of R.A.F. fliers, compiled by Flight Lieutenant Roald Dahl, assistant air attache to the British Embassy in Washington, involving the sprites, called gremlins, who are said to fly with the pilots and help or hinder them in battle.

Nina Quartin, Russian soprano, who was last heard in Town Hall three years ago, returned there last night to give an all-Russian program. Her selections ranged from the opening Cavatina from Glinka's "Russian and Ludmilla," to a final modern group by Stravinsky, Prokofieff and Shostakovich.

HOULTON, Me., Oct. 13 -- The body of J. Frederic Burns, 43, lawyer and former president of the State Senate, was found early today about fourteen miles from here, near his automobile in a gravel bank, with a bullet wound in his chest.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 13 -- More than 9,000 war workers in Nassau County will be without the use of their automobiles within sixty days because of the worn condition of their tires, Richard A. White, county administrator of war transportation, said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Production of luxury vegetables and some of the most important salad constituents must be curtailed to allow land, labor and transportation facilities to be shifted to more essential products, the Department of Agriculture stated today.

Replying to charges made by tenant organizations that some landlords were in effect increasing rents by reduction in services, elimination of concessions and other means, in violation of the spirit of the rent-control law and the informal rent level of March 1, 1942, fixed for New York, William J. Demorest, chairman of the Manhattan Voluntary Rent Control Committee, said that complaints of that nature were being investigated "as thoroughly as any other type of complaint."

Two speeches were made on Monday by the war leaders of the English-speaking peoples. Winston Churchill's address on receiving the freedom of the city of Edinburgh did not arouse great interest in Britain, according to the report of Mr. Daniell, because he said nothing he has not said just as well before.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Sophomore Jim Warfield, halfback, figured in ten of the twenty touchdowns registered by Princeton's first string against the scrubs in the one-hour scrimmage that ended today's football practice. Warfield carried for five scores and passed for five more.

After the excitement of its opening day, when there was an amazingly big crowd -- a late count set it at more than 27,000 instead of 26,963 -- Jamaica settled down to normal with the second afternoon of its Autumn meeting yesterday, though there was a little of almost everything racing can provide, including a disallowed claim of foul in one of the features and victories for both favorites and long shots.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Senator James M. Mead, who was the rival of Attorney General Bennett for the Democratic nomination for Governor, joined Mr. Bennett today in a series of campaign appearances in the heavily Republican western corner of the State, where the Senator has a large personal following.

Out-of-town buyers arriving in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 896, which compared with 1,010 in the preceding week and 760 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Store space was involved in the bulk of the commercial leasing contracts reported by brokers in Manhattan yesterday.

The Federal government will subsidize milk dealers in the metropolitan area by purchasing their milk at an officially established rate of $3.30 a hundredweight and reselling it to them at $3.10, it became known yesterday, through an announcement made by Charles J. Blanford, administrator of the New York marketing area.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 13 -- The defensive attitude of Germany, apparent in the recent speeches of Adolf Hitler and Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, is emphasized further in an editorial in the Frankfurter Zeitung. The article also reflects a longing for peace with Britain and apprehension over the morale on the home front.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 13 -- Changing his plans in response to a suggestion from the White House, Wendell Willkie said tonight that he would end his world air tour, during which he undertook missions for the President, at Washington instead of New York.
LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's statement on the manacling of prisoners of war:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- With speed reminiscent of that with which it declared war last December on Germany, Italy and Japan, Congress went into high gear today to put 18 and 19-year-old youths into the Army.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- As indications increase that the Germans are turning from offensive to defensive warfare, the necessity for a single strategic plan agreed on by the American, Russian and British General Staffs becomes increasingly apparent, it is believed here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- WAAC officers detailed to the Holabird Ordnance Motor Base in Baltimore will learn how to make minor repairs on motor vehicles in the field and in a garage behind the field during their four-week course there, the War Department stated today.

Reports that Reich Marshal Hermann Goering has salted away a dollar or two outside Germany appear to be confirmed. Speaking over the Berlin radio on Oct. 4, Goering made the mistake of challenging the British to "give me the names of the banks and tell me what sums I have in them."
The ranking of college football teams in the nation-wide poll of The Associated Press emphasizes the dislocation brought about by the war.

Donald H. Blythe, 31-year-old defense worker, of 217 Eckford Street, Brooklyn, who apparently has lived an exemplary life since his escape from a Massachusetts prison farm nine years ago, was released yesterday in $1,000 bail on a habeas corpus writ pending his return to Massachusetts for a hearing on a warrant that is expected to arrive in a few days.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A new London may arise from the ashes of the old. It is being planned now by Sir Edward Luytens and Sir Charles Bressey, who have been commissioned by the Royal Academy to draft the future capital of the British Empire.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- After conferring with President Roosevelt at the White House today six New England Governors said they were "very much reassured and very much encouraged" about the New England fuel situation.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Supporting Allied naval forces in the Solomon Islands battle areas, General Douglas MacArthur sent a large formation of heavy bombers into smashing attacks on the Japanese airdrome at Rabaul, New Britain, again yesterday for the third time in a week, a communique said today.

Trade buying in cotton largely offset hedging in the December position yesterday and the futures market held within a 12-point range, closing at the day's lows, 3 to 7 points under Saturday's final prices.

Plans were outlined yesterday for a "Youth Parade" and war rally to be held Saturday morning marking the beginning of a nation-wide Army recruiting drive to spur enlistments among youths of 18 and 19 in line with President Roosevelt's radio message to the nation Monday night.

Despite war conditions and intermittent increases in political tension between the United States Government and the Vichy government of France, the latter will continue to meet promptly the debt service provisions on its United States dollar bonds.

Extension of the stamp-plan mechanism to embrace rationed foods, so that "hunger-weakened" people in this country might be of maximum value in helping to win the war, was suggested yesterday by Roy F. Hendrickson, Administrator of the Agricultural Marketing Administration, Department of Agriculture.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Driven through perhaps the only scrimmage of the week, the Yale eleven today struggled against the defensive alignments the Navy used against Princeton, and which the Eli coaches expect to face in Baltimore Saturday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 -- Having captured part of one street in a Stalingrad factory district last evening, the Germans mounted another attack against the factory today, but failed to gain and lost two companies in the attempt. The last two days' fighting, after a brief lull, seems to make it clear that the enemy is continuing his attacks, which if not so heavy as last week's, are aimed at the same objective.

The hospitals of New York and other cities that may be victims of air raids and other enemy attacks are one of the most important battlefronts of civilian defense, and as such should get all the public support possible so that their value in emergencies be not lessened. James M. Landis, United States Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, declared here last night.

Maintenance of promotional efforts to preserve the drug industry's "most valuable asset," the shopping habits of customers, was urged upon the industry yesterday by Richard Manville, director of research of Donahue Coe, at the luncheon meeting of the semi-annual convention of the Affiliated Drug Stores at the Hotel Biltmore.

National and classified were the only two categories to show a gain in newspaper advertising of fifty-two cities measured by Media Records in September and the total was down 2.5 per cent from the like 1941 month. For the nine months the decline in linage was 6.2 per cent from 1941.

Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, former national leader of the German-American Bund, would have fought the United States in behalf of Nazi Germany only with the "greatest reluctance," according to a statement signed by him and produced in evidence yesterday in Federal court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- What the removal of 600,000 Italians from the classification of enemy aliens, as announced by Attorney General Biddle in New York last night, means was explained by the Department of Justice today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Walter Wiesmiller, Pennsylvania's present first-string center, played twenty-nine minutes of the Yale game last Saturday with a small bone broken in his hand, it was learned today from X-ray pictures.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Roosevelt announced that the Electric Home and Farm Authority would be abolished and the White House reported the seizure of three munitions plants in Maryland and Delaware and the arrest of five men for bribery in connection with their operations.

Flight Lieutenant Lance Wade, a soil conservation worker for the United States Department of Agriculture little more than a year ago and now the top-ranking American ace in the British Royal Air Force, apparently has been sharing things with his friends all his life.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, 72-year-old Prime Minister of South Africa, arrived here today to discuss "the coming of the offensive stage of our war effort" with British leaders, including Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The War Labor Board unanimously rejected today the demand for a $1-a-day pay increase made by the United Automobile Workers' Union (C.I.O.), for 115,000 Ford Motor Company employes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A measure outlawing the poll tax as a prerequisite for voting was passed overwhelmingly by the House late today after a bitter sectional fight centering around the issues of States' rights, the constitutionality of the measure and the vote for the Negro.

Declaring that New Yorkers would find a different city when the program for its improvement is carried out, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday that the municipal government was using the present time to make actual contract plans which would be put into operation as soon as the war was over.

It was Mia Slavenska's night at the Metropolitan Opera House last night when the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo presented three standard works, "Scheherazade," "The Nutcracker" and "Beau Danube," with her in two of them. Quantity, however, was less important than quality, for Miss Slavenska has never danced so brilliantly hereabouts before.
CAIRO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A joint communique of British General Headquarters and the Royal Air Force:

Sales of several homes in Brooklyn and on Long Island were reported by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn yesterday. The two-family house at 4106 Highland Avenue, Brooklyn, went to a client of Joseph Malady and the two-family home at 230 Ninety-second Street to a client of M.J. Stapleton.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A feature in the generally quiet stock markets today was a further sharp rise in oil shares. Anglo-Iranian took the lead with a rise of more than 30, while Burmah, Shell and V.O.C. recorded rises.

A total of $12,175,000 of public housing authority securities were announced yesterday by fourteen communities throughout the country, of which fourteen issues of notes, aggregating $10,323,000 are scheduled to be sold on Oct. 21, and one issue of $1,852,000 of bonds on Oct. 22.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 7 you referred to the endorsement of Frederick R. Coudert Jr., Republican candidate for the State Senate, by the Citizens Union, and quoted the Union as having stated that it had investigated the charge that the Coudert committee had devoted insufficient effort to investigating Nazi and Fascist influences in the schools, which the Union declared to be "entirely without foundation."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Alex Watson, Hudson River pro, and Mike Turnesa of Elmsford, were the only players to break par in the Westchester P.G.A. weekly one-day tournament today at Westchester Hills.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Kiska, the only island in the Aleutian chain apparently still occupied by Japanese, was subjected to a rain of bombs from Army airplanes during daily raids from last Thursday through Saturday, the Navy Department announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Four New York witnesses, headed by Mayor La Guardia, laid before the Senate small business committee today a variety of plans to obtain for the New York metropolitan area a larger share of war contracts.

George Abbott presents a new musical comedy, "Beat the Band," at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre tonight. The book, which is by George Marion Jr. and George Abbott, deals with the vicissitudes of an orchestra leader, his get-rich-quick brother and his pretty young ward from the West Indies.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 13 -- Craig Wood of Winged Foot, the new metropolitan P.G.A. champion, turned in an individual card of 67 as he and Mark J. Stuart won the one-day amateur-pro event of the Long Island P.G.A. with a 31, 34 -- 65 over the Meadow Brook Club course today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Fowler Harper, deputy chairman of the War Manpower Commission, disclosed today that peacetime safeguards demanded by management and labor are proving obstacles in drawing up compulsory service legislation for the war industries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The government has decided to lease privately owned homes and buildings and remodel them to provide living quarters for war workers. Vacant warehouses, abandoned hotels and other large structures will be remodeled for the same purpose.

A 50-year-old Puerto Rican, who had threatened, according to the police, to kill the members of a family he formerly lived with because they objected to his paying attention to a younger daughter, shot and killed her sister yesterday, seriously wounded the younger girl and then killed himself with the same pistol after waylaying the girls in the vestibule of a Harlem loft building at 1400 Fifth Avenue.

It would be wonderful if one could write that last night, while the cables were humming with fresh news of the glorious defense of Stalingrad, Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra, in Carnegie Hall, were giving a program of Russian music which adequately hymned the epic now unfolding on the banks of the Volga.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- By drawing on 60,000 nurses available for military service the Army expects to raise the number of nurses in the Army Nurse Corps to 31,000 in 1943, Colonel E.J. Walsh stated today at a House Military Affairs Committee hearing on the Edmiston bill for raising the pay of Army nurses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Government, declaring that more than $1,000,000 in management irregularities might be involved, seized today the plants of Triumph Explosives, Inc., at Elkton, Md., and of five subsidiiaries and arrested five men on bribery charges.

Profit-taking yesterday afternoon again halted a rise in the stock market, but part of the gains were held. Public utility issues managed to hurdle the mild selling wave and emerged with sizable additions, but some of the rails fell behind.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, changing its mind a second time in the proposed sale by the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation of its interest in the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, hastily called back for deletions today a report in which it had recommended adoption of the plan by the stockholders of Columbia Oil.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The government is acting to aid small retailers to get supplies, thus preventing their being forced out of business, Hugh Dalton, president of the Board of Trade, announced today.

The city's restaurant and hotel owners, having reached virtually unanimous agreement on the plan to start "meatless Tuesdays" next week, found themselves in a quandary yesterday on just what constitutes a meatless menu for meat conservation purposes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- T.V. Soong, Chinese Foreign Minister, made a farewell call on President Roosevelt today preparatory to leaving for China for conferences with Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek. It is assumed that Dr. Soong will give the Generalissimo a first-hand and detailed account of America's situation, attitude and plans in regard to the war.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the newcomer will be "Iceland," a Twentieth Century-Fox musical starring Sonja Henie and John Payne. The supporting cast is headed by Jack Oakie, Felix Bressart, Osa Massen, Sterling Holloway, Joan Merrill and Sammy Kaye and his orchestra.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A communique:

Because New York City is said to be the only large center in the country with a surplus of housing space, it is likely to become the home of several government agencies soon to be moved out of Washington. Experts have estimated that this city contains at least 100,000 vacant housing units, mostly in Manhattan.

The report of the Consolidated Laundries Corporation for the twelve weeks ended on Sept. 12 shows a net profit of $62,974, after charges and Federal taxes, equivalent to 15 cents each on 372,000 shares of common stock, after preferred dividend requirements.

The Bronx piled up its scrap on selected vacant plots yesterday as 600 trucks combed the borough to haul away the piles citizens had stacked on the sidewalks. At 8 P.M. it was announced that the borough had collected 15,292 tons, well over its minimum quota of 10,000 but far under the goal of 50,000 tons that Borough President James J. Lyons predicted would be reached.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The War and Navy Departments named today thirty-four more industrial plants which have qualified for award of the Army-Navy "E" for excellent production of war materials.
The East and West Sides of Manhattan were well represented in the reports of late Fall apartment leasing received from brokers and building owners. Recent rentals included the following:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 13 -- Russian preparations for a new offensive were reported today by a new German propaganda agency, the International Information Bureau. The agency said Russian resistance at Stalingrad might be intended to give time for the completion of these offensive preparations.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- There are now "well over 500,000" Canadians now on active service, Colonel J.L. Ralston, Canadian Minister of National Defense, disclosed here today. They have been brought here by the Atlantic convoy system without the loss of a single man.

JAIPUR, India, Oct. 9 (Delayed ) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi's birthday week was celebrated here today with an early morning procession and a complete hartal [cessation of work] in Hindu shops and offices. It was non-violent, but effective and city-wide, and more impressive in its way than all the violence New Delhi, Bombay and other cities have experienced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Swift action was taken today by the House and Senate Military Affairs Committees to lower the draft age from 20 to 18, in line with President Roosevelt's recommendation of last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Liquidation was in evidence in the grain markets at the opening on the Board of Trade today, but it was short-lived and short covering combined with a better commission house demand caused a rally of around 1 cent a bushel in the leading grains.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Brig. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis, only Negro general in the United States Army, said today that there had been friction between Negro and white soldiers in the British Isles "due partly to resentment on the part of white troops against the way the British people entertained Negro troops."
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Two United States destroyers, the Philip and the Renshaw, were launched today at the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company yards here before a small group of spectators that included a party of teachers and students from the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, New York, and a dozen members of the Admiral Philip Camp, United Spanish War Veterans, of Brooklyn.

A longe-range plan to avoid a disastrous post-war slump in shipping and at the same time secure the position of the United States as a leading maritime nation is being studied by a special committee set up and subsidized by the shipbuilding and shipping industries, it was disclosed yesterday.

Recovering from the letdown noted in August, sales of thirty-one leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 11.3 per cent in September, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

All old cannon and cannonballs on Fort Jay, Governors Island, which have no definite historic value, have been sold for scrap and are being shipped to a large Pennsylvania steel mill for more active participation in the war, Colonel T. L. Crystal, commanding officer, announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- Two officials of the War Price and Rationing Board here narrowly missed being shot today when an irate applicant for additional gasoline ration books ran amuck and fired five shots from a .32 caliber revolver in the crowded offices of the board.

The problem, "What shall we do for day care for children of working mothers?" will be one aspect of a program on "The War and the Young Child" to be held tomorrow afternoon at 2:30 o'clock at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
Leslie, Lady Doverdale, of London is at the Savoy-Plaza.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 13 -- United States Flying Fortresses scored a probable hit and numerous near-misses in an attack on a medium-sized Axis merchant vessel in the harbor of Tobruk yesterday. Enemy fighters were seen, but they did not attack.

Failure to resist the temptation to splash muddy water on a nattily uniformed Army Captain resulted yesterday in Salvatore Aurisano, 19 years old, of 586 Linwood Street, Brooklyn, being Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein's fifty-third candidate this year for enlistment in the Army.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Among fires recently set by Belgian saboteurs was one that destroyed 250 tons of straw in a paper factory at Braine- Le-Comted, according to information reaching here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- In a midnight battle with Japanese warships in the Solomon Islands, United States warships sank one Japanese heavy cruiser, four destroyers and a transport, and repulsed an enemy attempt to land more troops on Guadalcanal, the Navy Department announced tonight.
TRENTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- New Jersey's statute granting tax exemption to personal property stored in commercial warehouses was held constitutional today in a State Supreme Court ruling.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 13 -- For the first time in months rush-hour riders of buses and trolley cars here went to and from work in comparative comfort today as a new stagger-hour system had its first real test.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- Inventory control is coming, with the date of enforcement of the regulation and the degree of hardship which will grow out of it depending primarily on how retailers act within the next few weeks, H.I. Kleinhaus, general manager of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said here tonight in an address before the New England Controllers Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A planned economy covering every part of the world at war with Hitler is in process of formation.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- Inventory control is coming, with the date of enforcement of the regulation and the degree of hardship which will grow out of it depending primarily on how retailers act within the next few weeks, H.I. Kleinhaus, general manager of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said here tonight in an address before the New England Controllers Association.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith came out whole-heartedly yesterday in support of the Democratic State ticket, terming John J. Bennett Jr. and his associates exceptionally well qualified to carry on the series of Democratic State Administrations which Mr. Smith himself started.

There are hundreds of young women qualified by real experience to work on farms and who are anxious to get into service. I do not mean simply women who will pick apples. I mean women who will go for the duration of the war to any farm, large or small, considered in need of help.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Reflecting unusually heavy war demands, cold storage holdings of meats on Oct. 1 were about 11 per cent below those of a year ago, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Lieut. Col. L.S. (Larry) MacPhail, who resigned his posts of general manager and president of the Dodgers recently, yesterday announced that he had acted to give up his membership on the board of directors, now his only connection with the club.

RYE, Oct. 13 -- In order to solve the serious manpower problem which Canada is now facing, an extensive pooling of plant facilities will be undertaken, E.T. Sterne, administrator of chemicals of the Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board, declared today at the closing session of the Fall convention of the Society of the Plastics Industry at the Westchester Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A planned economy covering every part of the world at war with Hitler is in process of formation.

Because of the reduction in the available supply of fuel oil in this area, the minimum legal temperature of buildings heated by oil in New York City was cut yesterday by the city Board of Health from the previous 68 degrees to 65. Places heated by coal, gas or other means must still maintain the 68-degree minimum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Automobile owners will be restricted to five tires per car when gasoline rationing goes into effect on a nation-wide scale Nov. 22. The Office of Price Administration announced at the same time today that registration for gasoline ration books would start Nov. 9 in the thirty-one States to which rationing has not been applied up to this time.

Special shopping service divisions for service men with Christmas gift lists are being established by leading department stores in the city, it was announced yesterday by the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue, which promoted the project.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 13 -- At a meeting presided over by President Juan Antonio Rios and with all members attending, the Cabinet this morning discussed Chile's international position and the diplomatic incident with the United States following statements made by Sumner Welles, United States Under-Secretary of State, in a speech in Boston that the Chilean Foreign Office considered "offensive to the dignity of this country."

Although special offerings were introduced on the New York Stock Exchange in February, that institution insists they are still in the experimental stage. At one time it announced all offerings would be held open for at least fifteen minutes to allow out-of-town firms to place their orders.

A WEST COAST PORT, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Rescued crew members of a United States tanker said today that their ship had been torpedoed by a submarine, believed to be Japanese, and that they had left it burning but still afloat twenty-five miles off the Oregon coast.

ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND, HEADQUARTERS, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Major Gen. Simon T. Buckner, announced the award of the Purple Heart to four officers and three men, and the award of the Air Medal to three officers and five men, all lost in aerial action in the Aleutians.

Mrs. Annette Friedwald, 23 years old and the six-month bride of a soldier, identified a youth yesterday in Felony Court as the robber who held her up with pistol for fifteen minutes at noon on Sept. 30 in the haberdashery she conducted with her mother at 3586 Broadway.
DECATUR, Ga., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Colonel John A. Nelson, 62, automotive officer of the Fourth Service Command and a veteran of thirty-seven years' continuous service in the Army, died at his home today.

Ezra B. Whitman, consulting engineer of Baltimore, has been elected president of the American Society of Civil Engineers for 1943, it was announced here yesterday by George T. Seabury, secretary of the society.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 -- The split between the United Mine Workers and the Congress of Industrial Organizations came to the fore again today at the U.M.W. convention in a long distance clash between John L. Lewis, president of the miners, and Van A. Bittner, formerly one of his lieutenants and now assistant to the president of the United Steel Workers, who is Philip Murray, also head of the C.I.O.

The office of District Attorney Hogan has submitted to the State Attorney General data obtained in connection with an investigation into alleged improper solicitation of funds by various committees of the American War Heroes Foundation, Inc., operator of the Park Avenue canteen, in which many prominent men and women were interested, it was said yesterday in the Attorney General's office.
Earl Walsh hasn't recovered completely from the effects of the Tennessee debacle, but a Fordham triumph over West Virginia's Mountaineers at the Polo Grounds on Saturday might work miracles.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Mrs. Albert Becker of North Jersey won the season's last one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today by touring the hilly course or the Essex County Country Club in 43, 43--86. This was the second event won by the North Jersey player out of four in which she has competed.

The strange, irrational situation which results in keeping the Governments huge hoard of silver buried in the ground at a time when that metal is badly needed for use in the war is at last about to get a public airing. Hearings are scheduled to begin today before a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee on the bill sponsored by Senator Green of Rhode Island to release the Treasury's unpledged silver for consumption by industry.

A number of issues are wound together in the dramatic clash between the Senate Agriculture Committee and William M. Jeffers, the rubber administrator. For clarity of thought it is important to disentangle them.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- In an unemotional, almost colorless voice and manner, Prime Minister Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today that his government had asked the Swiss to approach Berlin to propose a mutual cessation of the manacling of war prisoners.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Edgar G. Brown, director of the National Negro Council, said today that Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, was guilty of "serious and heart-rending discrimination" in his exclusion of New York City from immediate Federal rent control.

Russell V. Cruikshank, vice president of the Cruikshank Company, 148-year-old New York realty firm, was elected president of the Real Estate Board of New York yesterday at a meeting of the board of governors of that organization. He succeeds George L. Allin, realty lawyer, who had served for three years.

WASHINGTON, Oct 13 -- Axis propagandists are busily corroborating the speech delivered last Thursday by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, which emphasized the interest of the Axis powers in retaining their diplomats and spies in this hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen contended today that the salvage section of the WPB was working "in conjunction and conspiracy" with the Association of American Railroads and railroad bankers to help them rid themselves of their less profitable lines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Sales and deliveries of Persian lamb skins, karakul and similar skins used chiefly as furs in the manufacture of garments are once more subjected to the provisions of the General Maximum Price Regulation, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 13 -- An all-time high in pari-mutuel wagering for a Keeneland Fall opening was set today as a record crowd estimated at 8,000 bet $120,429 on the seven-race program. The previous best mutuel handle at the seven-year-old track was $85,962 set in 1939.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Semi-final poll returns from Queens and the Bronx in the New York Governorship race show John J. Bennett running considerably ahead of Thomas E. Dewey in the Bronx, but indicate a close race in Queens.

Awaiting heraldry as a Victory food special for the second time this Fall is the apple -- the apple that is as typically American as watermelon or chocolate ice cream or corn on the cob. From Oct. 22 to Oct. 31 it will be starred in stores throughout the nation.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Oct. 13 -- A Marine Corps major with the prosaic name of John Smith was revealed here today as the Number One ace of all American air forces. Major Smith, who is from Lexington, Okla., has shot down seventeen enemy planes -- more than any other American pilot anywhere -- over the Solomon Islands area since Aug. 21.

The English-type residence at 21 Oxford Road, in White Plains, containing nine rooms and three baths and reported held at $22,000, has been sold by the Home Life Insurance Company to A.E. Fast for occupancy. Dusenbury Roberts were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Literally, the War Production Board's Food Branch has put a lid on hoarding of canned foods. By means of a special plastic top for tin cans, the WPB expects hoarding will be stopped early in 1943.

Two midtown theatres will present new film attractions this morning, at the Capitol, the offering will be "A Yank at Eton," a Metro picture starring Mickey Rooney. Directed by Norman Taurog, the comedy features Ian Hunter, Tina Thayer, Edmund Gwenn, Freddie Bartholomew, Marta Linden, Alan Mowbray and Juanita Quigley. . . .

A drive to popularize the last stanza of "The Star Spangled Banner," on the ground that it is more appropriate to the present emergency than the more commonly used first stanza, was announced yesterday by the Writers War Board, which hopes that the American Legion and other patriotic societies will take up the idea.

With a message from General Jan Christian Smuts, Prime Minister of South Africa, expressing "the strong hope that the present world crisis would mark a long step forward toward the realization of the Zionist vision," and other messages lauding the contribution of Palestine Jews to the United Nations' war effort, the forty-fifth annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America opened last night at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, expressed the belief today that Hitler would refrain from bombing America for fear of waking up Americans to a more intensive war effort. At a war bond luncheon here, Mr. Davis recalled how war bond sales skyrocketed in Hawaii and Alaska after they were attacked, and said:

Two changes in the application of maximum price regulation No. 220 are being sought by the Corset and Brassiere Association of America and the Associated Corset and Brassiere Manufacturers, Inc. Melvin Kleeblatt, counsel for the former organization left yesterday afternoon for Washington to confer with OPA officials regarding the proposed amendments.

An apartment of sixteen rooms and six baths occupying an entire floor in the building at 927 Fifth Avenue has been leased by Leon Cotnareanu, director of Coty, Inc., through Douglas L. Elliman Co., who also rented apartments in 25 East End Avenue to Edward P. Pierce Jr.; in 117 East Seventy-second Street to William Habicht, and in 559 Madison Avenue to Eddy Clifford.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Judge John P. Barnes, who denied on Monday a government plea for an injunction to break the ban ordered by James C. Petrillo on the making of musical recordings and electrical transcriptions, filed today a memorandum on his decision in which he suggested that further Department of Justice efforts would be futile.

TORONTO, Oct. 14 -- Unity in the war effort was the keynote today of the final session of the convention of the American Federation of Labor which ended with the re-election of President William Green, Secretary-Treasurer George Meany and the thirteen vice presidents of the Executive Council.

The Keys to Victory drive to collect nickel silver for special uses by the Navy ends today. Yesterday, at a luncheon at the Hotel Roosevelt, E.J. Durkin, national director of the drive, said that he was confident the amount collected had well exceeded the original objective of 100,000,000 keys.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -Drastic action in the House to force wider distribution of war contracts among smaller manufacturers was threatened today by a trio of New York Representatives. Telling the Senate Small Business Committee that the Smaller War Plants Corporation needed "extreme prodding," Representative Celler said:

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 -- The expected renewal of large-scale operations at Stalingrad has not yet occurred, though the army newspaper Red Star reported today that in some sectors battles with the attacking enemy were severe, with the main pressure still exerted in the northwestern outskirts.

The elderly man was not sure a newspaper would be interested in the death of Anna Marquard at the age of 93. She had died of natural causes, was buried yesterday, and her only claim to attention, he said, was that she had served his family for seventy-seven years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- President Roosevelt still hopes for an early opportunity of discussing with President Juan Antonio Rios of Chile the problems of cooperation in defense of the Western Hemisphere, despite postponement of the Chilean President's scheduled visit to Washington, he stated in a message sent to the latter today.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The Most Rev. William Temple, Archbishop of Canterbury, today blamed the clergy for religious apathy shown by the British public. Discussing problems of the church in the upper house convocation, the Archbishop of Canterbury criticized clergymen who "gabbled" prayers and conducted services in a monotonous and lifeless reading of lessons.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Speaking in the auditorium of the Saunders Trade School here, Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, declared tonight that the election of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee, or Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate, would deliver the government of New York State into the hands of machine politicians chiefly interested in the election of delegates to the 1944 national conventions.

The announcement yesterday by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, who, as head of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during the late depression years made loans to many needy banks throughout the country, that these banks, at their option, may defer amortization of these loans for the duration of the war, came as welcome news to many institutions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A sigh of relief went up in every unit of the war administration today when Secretary Stimson revealed the size of the Army that is planned for 1943. Until that figure was settled and known, the great related problems of manpower, production, prices, allocation, the character of our civilian economy and the requisite working conditions in war industry could not be moved toward solution.

Henry P. Kendall of Boston has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Brown Corporation, which operates one of the largest sulphate pulp mills in Canada at La Tuque, P.Q. Wentworth Brown has been named as vice president.

The art collection of Mrs. William Fox, wife of the former motion picture producer, will be sold at auction at the Kende Galleries at Gimbel Brothers beginning on Nov. 23. The entire proceeds of the sale will be paid to Mrs. Fox in war bonds, according to announcement yesterday.

With the hunting season opening Monday in New York, except on Long Island, for cotton-tail rabbits, pheasants and squirrels, the Conservation Department has announced that another addition has been made to the landowner-sportsmen controlled public hunting areas in the State.
The factory, containing 75,000 square feet of space, known as the Perth Amboy Tile Works, at Sayre Avenue, Perth Amboy, N.J., was sold to the Kincaid Realty Company, Inc., by August Staudt.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The strong tendency shown in yesterday's markets continued today. The oils opened with a fresh burst of strength but weakened on profittaking with the Iranians, Burmah and Shell being affected most.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Royal Air Force and British Middle East headquarters:
Earle V. (Doc) Painter, who has been ministering to the aches and pains of the mighty Yankees for thirteen seasons, has lost his job, it was revealed yesterday.

With greetings from both President and Mrs. Roosevelt, the twenty-eighth annual convention of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, started yesterday a five-day session in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company yesterday received the "T" banner of the United States Treasury, emblematic of an average investment by employes of 10 per cent of their salaries in war bonds and stamps.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The village of Mamaroneck was the first community in Westchester bounty to exceed the metal and rubber salvage quota assigned by the Westchester County Salvage Committee, the committee announced today.

The collapse of conspicuous consumption as a result of the proposed increased income taxes was predicted yesterday by Dr. Persia Campbell, director of consumer services division of the Greater New York civilian defense offices.

JUST the other day Lieut. Col. Lawrence McClung Jones, called Biff, the former Army head football coach, who is now "home on the range" again as Graduate Manager of Athletics at West Point, said that to the best of his knowledge and belief the annual Army-Navy football game would be played this year, but he didn't know where. With regard to the site, the jury was still out.

BUNDI, India, Oct. 11 (delayed) -- This little State, buried away in the vast Rajputana Agency, many miles from a railway, is a good example of that old, unhappy India that the Congress party wants to reform or abolish. Meanwhile, it is going through a process of modernization, thanks to its young and energetic British Dewan, Mortimer Robertson.

This is the age of mechanized warfare, but the United States Army wants 125,000 dogs for local defense, field messenger work and other duties. In the last World War of machine guns, high explosives and other technological weapons they used canary birds in cages to detect the presence of gas in the trenches.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A special Food Price Division, consisting of six branches and headed by A.C. Hoffman, who has been price executive of the OPA food and food products branch, was set up today by the Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -- American-manned bombers are carrying supplies from the Middle East to the Yugoslav army of General Draja Mikhailovitch, and Italian occupation forces are strengthening their defenses along the Dalmatian coast in fear of an Allied invasion, private advices from the Balkans reported tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Northwestern cash interests were on the selling side of the local wheat market today. Prices were slightly higher early but there was no snap to the buying and reports that hedges were being switched from Minneapolis because of the unusually wide price difference caused many professional traders to turn to the selling side.

Two trophies for greatest fourth-quarter increase in output will be offered member machine tool companies by the National Machine Tool Builders Association, it was announced yesterday by John S. Chafee, newly elected president of' the group.

Milk marketing experts in New York foresaw yesterday the time, possibly in only a few months, when cream for coffee and ice cream for dessert might become casualties of war. The reason is that increased payrolls and shifts of population have created a condition whereby consumers as far south as Miami, Fla., are drinking what used to be surplus New York milk.

The annual report of the Phoenix Securities Corporation for the year ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net asset value of $11,639,783 at the year end after deducting accrued dividends on the preferred stock. This was equivalent to $150.57 a share for the preferred stock and to $9.32 a share for the common stock.

The belated announcement of the loss of three American heavy cruisers in the action around Guadalcanal raises once more the whole question of the wisdom of our war censorship and information policy. These three cruisers -- the Quincy, Vincennes and Astoria -were sunk on Aug. 9.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 14 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, denounced today the proposals for the freezing of labor in war industries as a blow at the rights of the American worker and warned labor leaders and the government "not to travel too rapidly in the restrictions imposed upon free labor in America."

Following President Roosevelt's speech on Monday night recommending that youths 18 and 19 years old be drafted, enlistments in that age group have more than doubled in this city, it was disclosed yesterday. With a majority of the new enlistees showing a preference for the Navy, however, draft officials indicated that schedules for calling up older men and married men without children might be retarded only slightly.

Two bottlenecks in the city's effort to speed household and industrial scrap metal to the mills were broken yesterday while Manhattan, last of the five boroughs to pile its household offerings on the sidewalks, made ready for its Victory salvage pick-up today.

For once there seems to be a man in Washington, Mr. Jeffers, who is not afraid to say to a Senatorial committee what he intends to do in running his job, regardless of politics and political pressure groups.

Seven-elevenths of the Manhattan College football team that will start against Detroit Sunday at the Polo Grounds will be sophomores. Coach Herb Kopf revealed such plans yesterday, as the Jaspers went through a defensive scrimmage in preparation for the contest with Gus Dorais's Titans, an outfit that figures to put the inexperienced Manhattan youngsters to quite a test.

SMYRNA, Turkey, Oct. 12 (Delayed) -- Reports to this Turkish port on the Aegean, barely twelve minutes by plane from German airbases on the enemy-occupied islands of Lesbos, Chios and Samos, have disclosed that the Germans and Italians have withdrawn all but skeleton garrison forces from the Greek islands and from Italian Dodecanese.

The thirteen-room house for two families on a plot 36 by 100 feet at 41-38 Fifty-seventh Street, Woodside, L.I., was sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to Herman Glaser through Wm. A. Krahe Son, Inc., and Frank Vytiska Jr., co-brokers.

Lou Schaefer, the former rider who, as a trainer, developed Challedon, saddled the winner of the Sennings Park yesterday at Jamaica when he sent out J.J. McIntyre's Redthorn to win rather easily at the end of a mile and a sixteenth.

The toilet goods industry yesterday began readjusting itself to elimination by the War Production Board of limitation order No. L 171, a move which puts the cosmetics business back on a raw-materials allocation basis rather than production quotas.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- The wartime program for baseball will be mapped at a double-header meeting of the major and minor leagues in Chicago starting on Dec. 1.

The interests of consumers and industry will be carefully guarded in any further governmental restrictions, but spokesmen for various war agencies, speaking at the opening session of the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the Tanners Council of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, made it clear that the war will come first and that sacrifices must be made by all.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 14 -- United States fighter pilots had their first large-scale aerial combat over the front south of the region of El Alamein yesterday and downed two German fighter planes.

Columbia's first team tested its attack against Army's type of defense at Baker Field yesterday for more than an hour and a half and then turned around and spent another hour stopping Army plays run off by the second team.

The holiday season will witness a sharp increase in mail-order type of advertising by stores which in the past have paid little attention to this type of copy, retail executives pointed out. Increased difficulties of transportation will cut down sharply the number of shopping trips made by consumers and they will have to depend more on ordering by mail.

Appointment of a national committee of bankers to work with the Office of Price Administration in devising a workable plan for clearing coupons of the nation's rationing system through the bank was announced yesterday by W.L. Hemingway, president of the American Bankers Association.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 14 -- A high official in the Foreign Ministry, who declined to allow his identity to be divulged stated today that the Argentine Government regarded the "momentary tension in relations between this country and the United States, caused by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles's Boston speech," as satisfactorily overcome.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND ARMY, Lebanon, Tenn., Oct. 14 -- The armored elements of the Blue forces moving north through mid-Tennessee to force a crossing of the Cumberland River made an eighty-mile march during the night.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 14 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, declared here tonight that "the most reactionary element in our State" was now in control of the Democratic State organization, and said that only through election of the Republican State ticket could the people of New York be assured of "a vigorous and progressive" administration during the next four years.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister of South Africa, who arrived in London yesterday, attended a War Cabinet meeting today and lunched with King George, with whom he discussed the war in Buckingham Palace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- It required an average of only 70.1 days to build Liberty ships in September, as compared with 83.3 days in August, and 241.3 days in January, the Maritime Commission reported today. Sixty-seven were delivered last month.

A seditious attempt to damage the morale of the armed forces through letters cursing the United States and belittling its power, while floridly praising the Axis, was charged yesterday to Mario Albert Boet, 46-year-old mineral salesman, of 170 East Ninetieth Street.

THERE John Gunther swallows the world a continent at a time William Henry Chamberlin digests it country by country. The lesser of the two great literary pythons has just finished gulping our northern neighbor; his "Canada, Today and Tomorrow"* appears to be a serviceable, common-sensical book, even though it betrays a lack of auctorial immersion in the subject material in one or two spots.
Cooperation, inflation and taxes were the principal topics discussed yesterday at the eleventh annual convention of the National Association of Mutual Insurance at the Hotel New Yorker.

Government and railroad officials, leaders in society and philanthropy, and Army and Navy officers participated in the formal opening yesterday of a new lounge for service men on the east balcony overlooking the main concourse of the Grand Central terminal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a modified plan of reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company which provides for its acquisition of the Boston Providence and the Old Colony Railroads.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Donald Nelson, war production chief, said today that Andrew J. Higgins of New Orleans, advocate of production-line ship construction, "must come into this war effort in a bigger way."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Wendell Willkie on his return from his mission to European and Asiatic war fronts. His other callers included Representative Andrew J. May, Jonathan Daniels and Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador.

FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The head of one of Britain's women's armies stepped from the platform of a Fort Des Moines auditorium today to make certain that an injured Waac received her officer's commission first hand.

VICHY, France, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -The French Government has accepted an offer by the United States State Department to remove to America for the duration of the war 5,000 Jewish refugee children up to 18 years of age, most of them orphans or concentration camp inmates whose identification papers have been lost.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Columbia's Paul Governali is long on passing and short on rushing -- but he doesn't have to worry about his ground game. The Lions' star has been throwing a football virtually as far as any one else propels it by running and passing combined.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct 15 -The Red Army, fighting in the welcome chill of an approaching Winter, repulsed several more tank-supported German attacks in the Stalingrad and Caucasian areas yesterday without yielding ground, the Soviet Command announced early today.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. promised in a campaign speech here tonight that if elected Governor he would maintain and enlarge the State's program for the care and treatment of the mentally sick and mentally defective.
Mr. and Mrs. C. Ledyard Blair will arrive today at the Plaza to stay through the Winter.

Judging by their workout yesterday, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers will counter the strong overhead attack of the Washington Redskins with their own forward passing game when the teams meet in their National League clash Sunday at Ebbets Field.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Reports of a widening rift between Germany and Italy came from neutral European capitals today as Adolf Hitler's Gestapo strong-arm chief visited Rome and conferred at length with Premier Mussolini in what seemed obviously to be something more than a social call.

Price-fixing by mills provided yesterday the only feature in the cotton futures market as many traders stayed on the sidelines to await official interpretation of the Price Control Act with regard to cotton. With comparatively few contracts for sale, this buying sent active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to net gains of 6 to 18 points after the market had floundered early in the session.

Two banking groups obtained yesterday the award of eleven separate issues of various public housing authority bonds aggregating $19,500,000. One group, headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation and Shields Co., won the award of the major issue of the day, that of $9,137,000 Pittsburgh Housing Authority bonds.

The time is propitious for fish -- fish baked to a melting tenderness, or broiled to a deep, becoming brown, or combined with milk in a steaming hot chowder to warm the cockles of your heart. Supplies, a spokesman for the Fishery Council proclaims, are "moderate to liberal," in happy contrast to recent weeks, when they have been a bit on the sparse side.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 14 -- After a lapse of nearly eighty years, Brazilian society will attend tomorrow a royal wedding, uniting Dom Duarte Nuno, pretender to the Portuguese throne, and Princess Maria Francisco de Orleans e Braganza, a member of Brazil's former imperial family.

T.H. Everett, horticulturist for the New York Botanical Garden, urged "victory gardeners" last night to get an early start on next year's gardens by preparing their soil now and analyzing the lessons of this year's harvest. He spoke before 300 persons in the third of a series of lectures sponsored by the Botanical Garden at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Every Bermudian and a host of Americans knew and loved Tommy Fox, who died a few days ago still the "uncrowned king" of St. David's Island, now largely a possession of Uncle Sam. Tommy (Henry Mortimer) was tall as a ship's spar; his skin, burned with the suns of eighty-one Summers, was like tanned leather; he carried himself with kingly dignity.

RAVENNA, Ohio, Oct. 14 -- When Frances Deardorff taught the second grade in the yellow brick schoolhouse at Gambier her favorite pupil was a big-eyed 9-year-old named Florence Bittinger, who had brought from Alabama "an awfully cute little Southern drawl."
GUADALCANAL, Oct. 14 (AP) -Life in the Solomon Islands is like a picnic in only one way -- the ants are always present.

Without supporting developments for further extension of the recovery movement, the stock market experienced yesterday its first set-back in about a week. Losses ran as high as 2 points in the morning, but sufficient support reasserted itself in the late trading to permit the net changes to be held at major fractions.

Stockholders of the $3,000,000,000 Electric Bond and Share Company battled yesterday with the management, and at times with one another, in one of the most acrimonious annual meetings recorded in corporate history. The meeting, held in the utility's headquarters at 2 Rector Street, lasted nearly five hours and was attended by about 300 stockholders.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -Joan Crawford and Fred MacMurray will be co-starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "Above Suspicion," a novel by Helen MacInnes which the studio purchased a year ago for a reported $25,000. Myrna Loy and William Powell had previously been scheduled to play the leading roles in the film, which deals with two British agents who pose, while traveling on the Continent, as a professor and his wife.
" Momma and Dad, I hope you are proud of me now."

When Harold M. Fox, 45 years old, of 1717 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, who was sponsor for the hanging of an honor roll flag across 174th Street between Bryant and Longfellow Avenues, came up for sentencing yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court, Magistrate Ambrose Haddock said: "I had intended to give you a jail sentence, but instead I am going to see that the profits you made in this enterprise are used up."

The activities of James C. Petrillo recently received the endorsement of the American Federation of Musicians, the union that he heads. The delegates to the American Federation of Labor convention have now given him unanimous support. This clarifies the issue. Mr. Petrillo is not a racketeer, not a lone outcast, not a freak; he has merely carried to unusual lengths policies which his fellow union leaders feel to be perfectly legitimate.

Solicitor General Henry Epstein, Democratic nominee for Attorney General, last night challenged Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, to present "a bill of particulars" on the charges made in his acceptance speech that the Democratic State administration was filled with incompetence, cobwebs and waste.

Forty-two United Nations seamen were lost in the sinking of two ships announced by the Navy Department yesterday. One ship was a small vessel of United States registry, sent to the bottom off the north coast of South America late last month; the other was a medium-sized Panamanian ship sunk in the same area late in August.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Showing disregard for a soggy course, Kent Miller's Elkridge, one of the nation's best timber-toppers, fenced perfectly and won in handy fashion in the Governor Ogle Steeplechase Handicap, $3,500-added feature of the midweek Laurel program today.

A new record in employment was reached in August, with 57,700,000 persons engaged in all branches of industry and the armed forces, according to the division of industrial economics of the National Industrial Conference Board.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A Navy communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Mrs. Roosevelt said today that she would be very glad to go to England if any useful end could be served thereby, but that such a trip was a future rather than a present possibility.

" Beat the Band" Mr. Abbott calls the new musical comedy that he put on at the Forty-sixth Street last evening. The verb is well chosen. For Johnny Green's score, which runs a considerable temperature, is written on the downbeat in the idiom of tomorrow.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14 -- A suit charging violation of rent-ceiling regulations, said by local officials of the Office of Price Administration to be one of the first of its kind in the country, was filed in the First District Court here today by counsel for Major Harry B. Silver, Commander of the Fifty-second Station Hospital at Fort Hancock, N.J.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Britain's obligations to Russia in the matter of supplying urgently needed equipment, munitions and raw materials have been carried out fully, Richard Kidston Law, Financial Secretary of the War Office, said in the House of Commons today.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Prof. James A. Hamilton of Yale, president-elect of the American Hospital Association, today warned American women that the shortage of hospital personnel is becoming so acute that more women may have to give birth to their babies at home.

E.R. Squibb Sons, including domestic and Canadian subsidiaries, had in the fiscal year ended with June net earnings of $2,432,386 after all charges, including taxes and $150,000 reserve for inventory contingencies, according to the annual statement to stockholders yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The Royal Air Force last night bombed the German naval base and shipbuilding center at Kiel with 4,000 tons of bombs until searchlights wobbled crazily and anti-aircraft guns were out of action in probably the most successful of seventy raids upon this target, it was announced here today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
