Chains and other large-volume food retailers, although the recipients of the smallest percentage allowances under the "alternate pricing method" recently announced by Price Administrator Leon Henderson, yesterday appeared to be among the most satisfied of the various trade groups affected by the order, which becomes effective today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Attorney General Francis Biddle disclosed today that copies of his Columbus Day address, announcing that 600,000 unnaturalized Italian aliens living in the United States would be removed from classification as "enemy aliens," now are being dropped in Italy.
MOSCOW, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter granted yesterday without opposition an application by the Albany Susquehanna Railroad Company which will result in the reduction of $315,000 dividends paid annually to Susquehanna stockholders by the Delaware Hudson Railroad Company in order to meet Federal corporate income taxes payable by the Susquehanna.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Japanese, despite setbacks in sea, land and air fighting in the Solomon Islands during the last week, have returned to land troop reinforcements on Guadalcanal under the cover of naval guns, the Navy announced tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., 0ct. 14 -- Newark's newest office building, the 20-story, $6,000,000 Prudential Building, occupying an entire block on Washington Street between Bank and Academy Streets, will be taken over by the government.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Followers of Dr. Vladimir Matchek, Croat peasant leader, have revolted against the government of Dr. Ante Pavelitch and fighting is now raging in the Nazi-created State of Croatia, Yugoslav circles said tonight.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- Another Soviet communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 14 -Unable to find volunteers for the so-called Norwegian Legion, or to compel a sufficient number of Quislingists to prove on the battlefield their attachment to Nazi ideals, the Quisling authorities have recently been resorting to the shanghaiing of Norwegians to fill the quota demanded by the Germans.

Concrete evidence, showing why Washington has forged to the top in the Eastern Division of the National Football League, may be found in the official statistics released yesterday. These disclose that in four games the Redskins have defended so brilliantly that the average gain per game on opponents' running attack is only forty-six yards.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Provided there is no excessive hoarding of shoes, Americans may continue to put a well-shod foot forward the rest of this year and in 1943, despite false rumors of a scarcity of shoes, the Department of Commerce said today.

Amid cheers, yells and some crying the Rodeo rode into the grounds of Bellevue Hospital yesterday and put on a show for more than 2,000 children, doctors, nurses and out-patients, as well as a sprinkling of youngsters who obviously were playing hookey from school to see the show.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night restored Leonide Massine's "Three-Cornered Hat" to its repertoire at the Metropolitan Opera House, and proved that though, it has passed its twentythird birthday, there is life in the old work yet.

The Trianon Room of the Ambassador was formally opened for the season last night with a subscription dinner dance given as a benefit for Bundles for America and also as a special tribute to the United States Coast Guard. Funds derived from the fete will be applied by "Bundles" to the purchase of recreational facilities for Coast Guard stations along the Eastern Seaboard.

Some 350 members of the New York graphic arts industries were told yesterday to cut expenses and eliminate frills if price control had curtailed their profit margins by J. Ronald Atwater, head of the Printing and Writing Papers Section of the Office of Price Administration, in an address at the Hotel Commodore.

The directors bf the St. Joseph, South Bend Southern Railroad recommended yesterday that its stockholders accept an offer to buy their stock made by the New York Central Railroad. The Interstate Commerce Commission has approved the offer.

The National Minute Men of Democracy wish to take issue with your editorial of Oct. 12 in which you call for a sales tax to reach all income or compulsory savings to tax all income without removing incentives, or both.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A Japanese heavy cruiser and four other vessels have been sunk by United States submarines in Far Eastern waters, while three other enemy ships have been damaged, the Navy Department announced today. These new successes for United States submarines had not been reported previously, it was added.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Army and Navy commanders headed by Secretary Stimson appealed to Senate and House Military Affairs Committees today for prompt action on legislation to make youths of 18 and 19 subject to the draft in order to assure next year an Army of at least 7,500,000 men with maximum striking force.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -Legislation to permit the Treasury to sell non-monetery silver to private industry for consumptive use and to lend monetary silver for non-consumptive purposes was approved today by a Senate Banking subcommittee, but Senator McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said that Senators from silver States would oppose it "most heartily."

During this past week the press and radio have informed the American public of the warning issued to Nazi authorities by the British War Office to the effect that if British prisoners of war are chained or shackled the British will retaliate by chaining an equal number of German prisoners.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold to the Interurban Realty Company, representing Lagana Brothers, contractors, a large vacant plot of land comprising the block front on the east side of Lexington Avenue from 130th to 131st Street.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Sergeant Meyer Levin, the Brooklyn bombardier who flew with the late Captain Colin P. Kelly and released the bombs that hit the Japanese battleship Haruna off the Philippines last December, has bailed out of another Flying Fortress and won a new decoration, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 14 -Squaring off for a real blast against the "so-called neutral press" in Europe, the German Foreign Office spokesman today warned the newspapermen of Switzerland and Sweden against "incorrect attitudes" in discussing the new order.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Car owners who have more than the five tires per car which are to be allowed under the national gasoline rationing regulations can begin selling the extra tires to the government tomorrow, the Office of Price Administration announced today.
What follows is an old Toscanini story, while the experience that it narrates, each time it is undergone, is tantamount to an entirely new impression.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -- It windows are shattered, the doors blown off and corners wrecked by bombs. Russian women and children who once lived peacefully in its room are dead -- slaughtered by the Germans. But today Russian machine guns, anti-tank guns and rifles point through the bricked-up windows of this four-story apartment building in the outskirts of Stalingrad known as 217 Bar A.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct 14 -Heinrich Himmler, German Gestapo chief, has just concluded a three-day visit to "German services" established in Rome, Milan, Turin, Genoa and Naples, according to a semi-official announcement received here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- By a unanimous vote the House passed today the bill creating a Women's Auxiliary Reserve of the Coast Guard. The bill, also introduced in the Senate on Sept. 29, now awaits a hearing by the Senate Naval Affairs Committee.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 14 -- Mrs. Antone Rebello, asked by a local draft board to decide which of her 20-year-old twin sons should join his brother, Edward, in the Army, told the chairman today:

The first in a series of bimounthly After-Duty Cocktail Dances under the auspices of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Second Region Council, was given yesterday afternoon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The Department of Justice has been investigating trade practices in the handling of shipping documents in order to reduce the number of persons to whom such data are available, and a new system of identifying codes and symbols will soon be inaugurated in the interest of "national secrecy," John W. Montigney, assistant director of the division of traffic movement, Office of Defense Transportation, disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- While German announcements of the sinking of the liner Orcades off Cape Town and the liner Duchess of Atholl between Cape Town and Freetown were received with reservations, it was said in authoritative quarters that "wolf packs" of U-boats, which recently operated near the United States coast, apparently had been driven to new fields.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -- Swedish reports that an Allied convoy was lurking off Dakar, preparing for a landing in French West Africa, and an official German claim that two loaded British transports had been sunk off South Africa, suggested today that major naval operations might be shifted to the South Atlantic.

Coach Earl Walsh sent his Fordham football men through a two-hour workout yesterday on Rose Hill during which they scrimmaged for more than sixty minutes. It was the last hard drill in preparation for Saturday's game with West Virginia. Blocking and tackling on the dummies and machines also was emphasized.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 13 (Delayed) -- There is every reason to believe that United States forces will consolidate their holdings in the Solomon Islands and continue the Pacific offensive begun there, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, declared here today in a report to newspaper men on his recent flying trip to Guadalcanal Island and bases elsewhere in the South Pacific.

A five-story, high-stooped brownstone house at 17 East Sixty-seventh Street has been donated by its owner, Mrs. Henry S. Glazier, to the American Women's Voluntary Services "for the duration," according to an announcement made yesterday at A.W.V.S. Greater New York headquarters, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Semi-final institute poll returns on the New York Governorship race show John J. Bennett, Democrat, holding a substantial lead in New York City.

Warning that the possibility of a surprise attack on New York City is always present, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday, in presenting commissions to twenty-five members of the headquarters staff of the City Patrol Corps, that this protective organization must take nothing for granted but must be alert and ready for action at all times.
In your issue of Oct. 8 there was published a letter from Emerson F. Davis concerning United States Savings Bond regulations. In reply to the letter Mr. Davis has been advised as follows:

The performance of the patriotic play, "Doodle Dandy of the U.S.A.," to be given Sunday afternoon at the Hunter College Theatre, will be under the sponsorship of the United Service Organizations and Junior Programs, Inc. Miss Elizabeth Newton is chairman of the junior sponsoring committee and is being assisted by Miss Mary Louise Strong and Miss Patricia Potter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- British correspondents in this country are conferring with censorship officials over what they think is unjustifiably severe censorship regulations against news going to Britain, it was learned today.
Dealers in household goods, art works, recreational equipment and war products figured in the commercial rentals announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -If King Richard III was sorely in need of a horse, as he apparently was, judging by the thousands of school orators who have so declaimed, Yale's new football coach, Howie Odell, is even more sorely in need of a center to put into action against the Navy at Baltimore this Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Republican gains in the Congressional elections next month are predicted in a poll of fifty Washington newspaper correspondents taken by Newsweek and made public today.

Gasoline stocks in the United States last week amounted to 79,731,000 barrels, a decrease of 630,000 from the 80,361,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 80,432,000 barrels.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

" The Damask Cheek" has postponed its opening at the Playhouse from Tuesday, Oct. 20, to Thursday, Oct. 22. The play has been trying out in Boston. Myron McCormick, who has been ill there, will not return to the cast until Saturday afternoon.

Many former associates of Mrs. Mary Ann Barber Estill, a pioneer Salvation Army officer in this country and many foreign lands, joined in a final tribute to her yesterday at a funeral service conducted in the Centennial Memorial Temple of the organization at 120 West Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A bill to give the government authority to control all rents in the country, not only on dwellings and dwelling establishments but including hotel and rooming house rates, and also permitting the President to fix rents in commercial buildings, was reported unanimously today to the House by its Banking and Currency Committee.
The first New York City mother and daughter to enlist for service in the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps have been accepted for military service and will leave Saturday for Fort Des Moines, Iowa.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- A Supreme Court jury awarded tonight a verdict of $433,333 to Maximilian J. Zicovich of Yonkers in his suit to collect a commission for arranging the sale of Commodore Edgar F. Luckenbach's fleet of twenty-two coastal freighters, reputedly the largest such fleet in the world.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 14 -- There now appears to have been a thorough clean-up in the ranks of German military leaders over the failure to take Stalingrad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Achievement of the 1943 goal of 7,500,000 soldiers would mean that this country would have at the end of next year an Army almost twice the size of the 4,000,000 men in uniform at the end of the first World War.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Wendell L. Willkie reported to President Roosevelt late today on his 31,000-mile world-circling tour of the war battlefronts. After the meeting he expressed the view that "Germany will never conquer Russia," and renewed his demand for a second front at the earliest possible moment to shorten the war and reduce its cost in human lives.

Leonard Field, general manager of the Gaslight Production Company which is currently presenting "Angel Street," has leased a large apartment in 327 Central Park West. With the closing of this lease the building is now fully rented according to Frederick Fox Co., brokers.

An accounting suit, brought by Stanley Clarke as trustee of the Associated Gas and Electric Company to recover more than $4,000,000 from the Chase National Bank, was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when the bank moved to dismiss three of the five causes of action and to strike out portions of the complaint as "frivolous, irrelevant, unnecessary and scandalous."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The war on the Western Front in Europe will be fought in the air until Allied bombing paralyzes German industrial production, Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, premier American ace in the last war and president of the Eastern Air Lines, reported today to Secretary Stimson.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Colombia and Venezuela were reliably reported today to have initiated a joint effort to bring Chile into closer hemispheric cooperation, with a reconciliation between Chile and the United States as their first objective.

Bank clearings of the twenty-three principal cities of the nation for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $6,293,195,000, a gain of 3.4 per cent over the $6,084,774,000 for the corresponding week a year ago, but a decline of 14.6 per cent from the preceding week's total, according to the report announced yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Offensive and defensive tactics came in for equal attention yesterday as Manhattan went through its final heavy paces for the intersectional meeting with Detroit's unbeaten and unscored-on eleven at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

When "Rosalinda" ("Die Fledermaus") comes to the Forty-fourth Street on Oct 26, the version used will be that of Max Reinhardt rather than the one prepared by George Marion Jr., it became known yesterday. Mr. Marion has been busy lately attending to the musical comedy book he wrote for the newly opened "Beat the Band" and consequently has not been able to devote any time to "Rosalinda."

Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, has been spanked verbally by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles, and yesterday he arranged a press conference to make a public apology to Mr. Welles and to call attention to his change of heart.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- The Court of Errors and Appeals, the State's highest tribunal, upheld today a year-old injunction restraining the American Car and Foundry Company from paying $500,000 in common stock dividends until it has paid a dividend not exceeding $7 a share on preferred stock for 1936 and an additional dividend of $1.29 a share for 1938.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, asserted tonight that it might yet be necessary to tell Americans with essential war skills to take the jobs for which they were best suited.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Four Waterbury units of the Chase Brass and Copper Company received the Army and Navy "E" today at ceremonies in which Donald M. Nelson, war production chief; General Hugh A. Drum, Chief of the Eastern Defense Command, and Admiral Thomas C. Hart of Sharon, Conn., former commander of the Asiatic Fleet, participated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The following is the text of the Draft Bill approved today by the House Military Affairs Committee:

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The Germans are still masters of their economic fate and there is no sign to date of any failure to carry out what they wished to accomplish in that field, the British Ministry of Economic Warfare reported today in a cautious appraisal of the enemy's position at the beginning of another Winter.
BUNDI, India, Oct. 12 (Delayed) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi is unknown and only the vaguest rumors of war have reached the outlying villages of this little State in the untouched heart of India.

MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- Though violent fighting was reported today in the northern part of Stalingrad, where the enemy is making desperate efforts to break through a workers' dwelling quarter and enter the factory zone, the most important operations now progressing in the Russian South are in the Caucasus.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday a net income of $43,714,559 for the three months ended Sept. 30. This was equal to $2.34 on the company's 18,686,794 shares of capital stock and compares with $47,462,130, or $2.54 a capital share, in the September quarter last year.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 15 -- Opening a strong drive to urge the public to purchase Victory bonds, the Ministry of Finance's Committee for the Distribution of Victory Bonds published an open letter today in the newspaper Ta Kung-Pao.

Strength in the near months, reflecting the continuance of price-fixing operations by mills and a fair amount of hedging in the distant contracts, developed yesterday in the cotton futures market. In a moderately active session active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 to 8 points above Wednesday's final quotations.

A surprising upset occurred yesterday at Jamaica, where 11,243 racegoers saw the entry of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Barnett run one, two among just about the finest lot of juvenile fillies that could be mustered. Medid and Bridleour finished in that order, a length apart, returning $23.90, $18.10 and $16.60 for $2.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Oct. 15 -- United States Marines on Guadalcanal have been "effectively meeting every force that the enemy has hurled at them," Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, declared today aboard a famous fighting ship before presenting awards to thirty-four heroes of the Solomon Islands, Coral Sea and Midway battles.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Christopher W. Wilson, 62, of 236 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, an attorney, was killed and his wife and daughter were injured today when their automobile struck a tree on the New York Post Road near Albany.

A call for tenders of $32,000,000 par value of bonds issued by five companies leased by the Seaboard Air Line Railway was announced yesterday by L.R. Powell Jr. and Henry W. Anderson, receivers for the road. The aggregate current market price for the issues is $5,000,000.

Owen D. Young, industrialist and dairy farmer leader, who was a leading dark horse possibility for the Democratic nomination for Governor, gave his unqualified endorsement yesterday to John J. Bennett Jr., the Democratic nominee.

C. McD. Davis, executive vice president of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad, was elected president yesterday at a meeting of the directors here. He succeeds George B. Elliott, who was relieved of his duties as president at his own request and who was elected chairman of the executive committee.
LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
The sidewalks of New York, which have given the nation many fighters in this and other wars, also gave 113,217 tons of scrap metal up to last night to be made into arms for victory against the Axis.

The German radio said last night that the Nazis had "broken the cornerstone of the Russian defense system in the northern sector" of Stalingrad by capturing the Dzherzhinsky tractor factory, which it declared was taken by storm, putting the Germans on the Volga River along a two-mile front.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A resolution introduced in the Senate by Senator Norris to investigate the refusal of the National and Columbia broadcasting systems to sell time to the Cooperative League of the U.S.A., tonight brought a charge from the National Association of Broadcasters that it "constitutes one of the gravest threats to freedom of speech in recent years."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A Navy communique:

United Nations airplanes are bombing Italy these nights with an explosive which ranks with the R.A.F.'s famous "block buster." It consists of Attorney General Biddle's Columbus Day speech. The Rome radio is annoyed at our decision not to regard unnaturalized Italians in this country as enemy aliens.
During this week of preparing Columbia for Army, life has become one pep talk after another for Lou Little.

Your readers are doubtless somewhat familiar with the contents of the bills that have been introduced in Congress which would amend the Selective Service Act to include 18-and 19-year-olds on the same basis as men of 20-45. This proposal raises a serious issue, on which many psychiatrists and other medical men will want to be heard before a decision is made.

Alexander Sved, baritone of the Metropolitan Opera, who gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night, has a naturally distinguished voice, even if his employment of it is not always distinctive. It is a meaty voice, ranging in tone from velvety softness to resonant fullness.

DENVER, Oct. 15 -- Reclamation of arid land in the West has already done much to help in the war, but must do more, in order to supply more electric power for war production industry and irrigation for food products, President Roosevelt declared in a letter read by Abe Fortas, Under Secretary of the Interior, at the convention of the National Reclamation Association here today.
During the years Marie Tempest was on the stage the critics had many glowing things to say about her, but it remained for Noel Coward, who wrote "Hay Fever" for her, to sum them up:

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- To meet the competition of high-wage war factory jobs, delegates to the American Management Association conference here today were urged to improve working conditions and emphasize the attractiveness of office work as well as step up salaries to Federal Civil Service ards or better.
Why is a metal salvage campaign like a military campaign? Because all predictions and generalizations are unsafe.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 15 -- Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu stated officially this evening that Argentina had no intention of breaking off relations with the Axis powers, at least for the present.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Expansion of the Navy's blimp patrol from twenty-three to one hundred and fifty-one to fight the submarine menace was revealed today by Rear Admiral R.E. Davison.

Weakening tendencies in the stock market were aggravated yesterday by selling of considerable proportions, and more than one-half of the issues dealt in lost ground. While the majority of losses were around a point, there were exceptional declines of 2 to 3 points which gave the list its worst slump since late July.

Every once in a while some unsung genius invents a nylon stocking or an automatic mixing machine -- and every one says, "But we ought to have had this all along!" Such is the case of the "perfume stick."

The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company of San Francisco presented informally yesterday a plan to obtain 100 per cent ownership of the Home Fire and Marine Insurance Company of California, of which it owns 55 per cent, and the Occidental Insurance Company of San Francisco, in which it holds 32.5 per cent.

The American seaman was praised yesterday by Captain Edward Macauley, deputy war shipping administrator, the guest speaker of the luncheon meeting of the Propeller Club of the United States, which opened its two-day annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

To assist the banks which subscribed heavily to the Treasury's new $4,000,000,000 financing, the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System made net purchases of $217,352,000 of United States Government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that this year's cotton crop, if sold at September farm prices for lint and seed, would return to growers $1,530,000,000, the highest income since 1925 and 38 per cent more than last year's crop.

Sammy Baugh of Washington, the punting leader in the National Football League for several years, wrested the lead from Cherokee Jack Jacobs, Cleveland freshman, during the last week-end. Slinging Sammy has averaged 46.4 yards per try.
The Conservation Department has announced an amendment to the original order for Long Island regarding the open season there for grouse or partridge.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 -- Both Mexican and American sources asserted today that the espionage situation in Mexico was well under control. Besides concentrating enemy aliens in Mexico City, the police are watching all foreigners pretty closely.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- The New York State Unemployment Insurance Law applies to all maritime workers whose employment is performed wholly or in greater part in the State, the Court of Appeals ruled today in six appeals taken by Attorney General Bennett on behalf of Industrial Commissioner Miller.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed in September totaled 966,149 bales of lint and 174,537 bales of linters, compared with 925,089 of lint and 122,138 of linters in August and 877,971 of lint and 129,608 of linters in September last year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The nation's department store sales during the week ending Oct. 10 were up 25 per cent over the same period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Newspapers will get the bulk of more than $1,000,000 which the Florida Citrus Commission will spend to advertise the State's record-breaking crop of oranges, grapefruit and tangerines, The Associated Press reported yesterday from Lakeland, Fla.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Aided by fine weather, Boston bombers of the Royal Air Force, escorted by Allied fighters, made two heavy attacks on the Havre docks this afternoon following a harassing offensive in the late daylight yesterday by single-engined Mustang fighters on Nazi barges, a freight train and railway locomotives in the Netherlands, the Air Ministry reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Despite smashing blows struck at Japanese warships and transports by our air forces on Guadalcanal, the Japanese have continued their offensive operations in the Solomons, the Navy Department reported tonight.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
MOSCOW, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

Reporting on operations during the first nine months of this year, Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, informed stockholders today that the profit available for dividends amounted to $30,710,499, or $1.06 a share, on 28,845,927 shares of common stock.

Representatives of nearly 200 weaving mills were asked here yesterday by officials from the Army Air Force, Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, to submit bids on nylon parachute cloth required for military purposes. While no official figures on the total amount sought could be divulged, it was estimated unofficially that requirements were in the neighborhood of 40,000,000 yards, with deliveries scheduled into the third quarter of 1943.

At last there is some progress toward changing the conditions which have created a silver scandal. A Senate Banking subcommittee has approved a bill to correct the existing situation in which war industries are being denied badly needed silver while our Government is compelled to keep its hoard of nearly 3,000,000,000 ounces of that metal buried in the ground in idleness.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15 -- John M. Hopwood, engineer and industrialist who left his own business six weeks ago "for the duration" to direct the collection of 5,000,000 tons of scrap for the steel mills, today resigned as president of War Materials, Inc., the government's salvage agency.

An exhibition and auction will be held under the auspices of the Brooklyn Heights Committee of Russian War Relief, Inc., in the Norwegian Club, 117 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, on Sunday afternoon, beginning at 2 P.M. The exhibits may be viewed until 4 o'clock, when the auction will begin, continuing until 7 P.M.
Sales by savings banks of town houses on the West Side were among the realty deals reported yesterday in Manhattan.

Mushrooms merit attention. On your shopping tour this week-end you'll notice that prices have dropped in the past few days. In fact, they're the lowest they have been in many months, according to the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Selection of a Westchester County court jury was begun today in the first degree manslaughter trial of Dr. Frank F. Marino of New Rochelle, accused of performing a criminal abortion resulting last March 28 in the death of Miss Cleo Florence Moore, 19-year-old "hostess" for an automatic juke box concern.

A major food shortage and a "scandal far greater than the rubber situation" looms in the near future, unless immediate steps are taken to coordinate the nation's system of food production and distribution, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, declared yesterday.

THOSE Navy Pre-Flight teams have been flying high over the gridiron in this campaign, but a South Boston Boy Scout has sent warning of a possible crack-up tomorrow, Lieut. Comdr. James H. Crowley will be sending his Chapel Hill "Cloud Busters" against the Boston College Eagles tomorrow and that, according to the South Boston Boy Scout, is where the crash begins.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Accounts that have been trickling into the United States of the recent activities of Nelson A. Rockefeller in South America express the opinion that the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs performed a most useful function to the satisfaction of officials, industrial and labor leaders and the generality of the plain people he met in the countries visited.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- In announcing that American soldiers had joined marines in the Battle of the Solomons, where Army Air Force airplanes have been operating since the start of operations, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson disclosed today that Army units now were scattered through most of the bases in the Pacific.

New incorporations in the State down 40 per cent in the first were six months of this year, while dissolutions rose 50 per cent, it was reported yesterday at the annual Eastern conference of secretary-managers of local chapters of the National Association of Credit Men in the Hotel New Yorker.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- After a quiet opening the stock markets improved, with home rails providing the feature. Great Western gained 3/4 and Canadian Pacific moved up another 3-16.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct 15 -- This is about the only football center in the East where the Princeton Tiger is not regarded as all ready for a barbecue in the victim's role in its game with Pennsylvania's admittedly fine team at Franklin Field on Saturday.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- Eastern seaboard war plants, hitherto exempt from practice blackouts, henceforth must participate in such drills even if it involves temporary cessation of production, New York's Civilian Protection Director said today.

Denouncing the reported plan of the newly formed Ichud party in Palestine, which advocated the formation of a bi-national party in Palestine, Judge Louis E. Levinthal of Philadelphia, president of the Zionist Organization of America, last night demanded the "establishment of Palestine as the Jewish Commonwealth."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that survivors of a medium-sized United States merchant ship sunk by submarine action in the Atlantic during August had beer landed at a United States East Coast port.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Discussing flood control and conservation at a Democratic rally here, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. promised tonight that, if elected Governor, he would continue and expand the State's present policy for the development of its natural resources and would bring to a prompt completion the flood-control works now under way in Binghamton and the surrounding territory.

Two Cabinet members of the Belgian Government in London, who escaped last July from unoccupied France and arrived here a few days ago from England, gave a press interview yesterday afternoon at the St. Regis Hotel, in which they described the food situation in Belgium as desperate.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The British were not quite prepared for the statement that came from Moscow today saying in effect that the plan of the Allied Nations to try Nazi leaders for war crimes and atrocities was swell but why not start now with Rudolf Hess?

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 15 -- Champagne will be replaced by well water from a farm in Durham, Okla., when Choctaw, a Navy tug, is christened at the Charleston Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company yard Sunday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced the purchase of two screen stories, "My Name Is Ruth," by Eleanor Griffin, and "By the People," by Byron Morgan. The former yarn, bought as a vehicle for Margaret O'Brien and Phillip Dorn, deals with a French priest and a girl who help a band of refugees escape from the Nazis.

Tribute was paid yesterday to 2,000 members of the American Women's Voluntary Services Manhattan war savings staff who, in eight months, have sold $30,000,000 in war stamps and bonds. A. luncheon, commemorating the accomplishment, was held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria and was attended by 700.

It comes as something of a shock to discover among the leaders of the American Football Statistical Bureau weekly compilation of "college" teams the names of Frank Filchock and Jim Poole of Georgia Pre-Flight, one being listed as an outstanding passer and the other an outstanding receiver.

How the shortage of war materials has hit the playground construction program carried on by the city Department of Parks since Robert Moses became commissioner in 1934, was illustrated yesterday at the one-acre playground just opened on Park Avenue between East 108th and 109th Streets.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 15 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today that eight officers and men of the United States Army Air Forces had received Silver Stars for gallantry in action and that Oak Leaf Clusters had been awarded to seven previous winners of the decoration.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 15 -- The Axis air forces employed even larger numbers of bombers and fighters against the island of Malta yesterday. As many as sixty fighters were sent as escort on a single bombing mission. It was obviously a bid to overwhelm the defenders, but that the raiders failed to do.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 15 -- A German submarine torpedoed and sank a 4,000-ton merchant ship last Thursday night in the St. Lawrence River off Metis Beach, a Summer resort, it was announced today by the Naval Service Department. The place of the sinking is within 220 miles of Quebec City, and is the farthest upstream that any U-boat has penetrated.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 15 -- Men formerly renowned as researchers in Germany and elsewhere in occupied Europe will play an important part in the United Nations war effort in the Middle East as a result of the formal opening yesterday upon Mount Scopus of a new Institute of Pharmacology at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Cherish your old rubbers and overshoes, says the Office of Price Administration, because the new "victory" ones will not last as long and will be the last word in the war's fashion mode, conservatism.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15 -- Harvard practiced nearly three hours today for the football game with Dartmouth here Saturday. Again there was a long session on defense against the Indians' plays, but even greater was the Crimson's stress on its kicking and passing.

It is the patriotic duty of every employer in essential war work to seek the deferment of drafted employes who are important to production, Major Ernest M. Culligan, director of information and public relations of Selective Service, declared yesterday at the closing session of the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the Tanners Council of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 15 -- A waning sample of old-time royal splendor -- crowns, coats-of-arms, royal tapestries and insignia -- amid a plain democratic environment was an odd keynote at the religious wedding today of Prince Nuno Duarte, Duke of Braganca and Pretender to the throne of Portugal, and Brazilian Princess Maria Francisca de Orleans Braganca, granddaughter of Dom Pedro, the second and last Emperor of Brazil.

Pieced together from cable messages, letters and eye-witness accounts, a dramatic story of the nomadic wanderings of bands of homeless Jewish children across the warring countries of Eastern Europe was told yesterday at the third day's session of the twenty-eighth annual convention of Hadassah, Women's Zionist Organization of America, meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

It is gratifying to note that despite the war the New York Academy of Medicine has decided to continue its annual "graduate fortnight" for the benefit of physicians in the metropolitan region, which embraces not only New York but the cities of New Jersey, Connecticut and other near-by States.

Lowering the draft age to 18 will cause a sharp cut in enrollments at all colleges because under recent regulations deferments can be granted only to young students who have completed two years of certain engineering, scientific or other highly specialized courses, it was said yesterday by officials at selective service headquarters here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Liquidation developed today in the grain and soy bean markets on the Board of Trade. Soy beans led the decline, losing 2 7/8 to 3 1/8 cents a bushel and closing at the lowest level since last November. The October contract finished at $1.58 5/8, or 1 3/8 cents below the price that the government has guaranteed farmers they will receive at country loading points for the 1942 crop.

New York's large hotels are rapidly assuming the role of fashion impresarios. Under their aegis many designers are getting a visual introduction to the public. The luncheon presentations are the stage on which well-edited collections created by the talents of individual designers are getting a distinguished presentation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Just as American soldiers and sailors have been instructed in English ways and customs through brightly written books issued by the United States Army, our armed forces in New Zealand may learn the customs of that country through "Meet New Zealand," a similar pamphlet.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed gold holdings and note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date, while the ratio of reserve was at the lowest. Holdings of United States Government securities increased $217,352,000 during the week.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Dr. Cyril Garbett, Archbishop of York, addressing the Northern Convocation at York today, criticized by implication Prime Minister Churchill's decision to chain war prisoners in retribution for like German action. The Archbishop said that England should uphold international law and could not outdo the Germans in barbarity.

A series of "glamour girl" burglaries on Staten Island by pretty young women wearing green slacks and tan camel-hair coats appeared solved yesterday with the arrest of two girls from Manhattan, one of them 17 years old and the other 16.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- In the brief period since he has taken office, City Manager William A. Walsh has acquired an unidentified "double" who uses Mr. Walsh's name and various pretexts over the telephone to induce lawyers and politicians to come to the city manager's office in City Hall for "appointments."

Since the welfare of children is primarily dependent upon security in the home and the affection of parents, the care of children in wartime will be the chief responsibility of the women of America, speakers at a round-table discussion agreed yesterday afternoon at the New York Times Hall.

The world's first six-bladed, dual-rotation, controllable-pitch propeller, which is said to increase the efficiency of high-speed aircraft about 5 per cent, has been developed by the propeller division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation and is being delivered to the Army Air Forces, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The House Military Affairs Committee unanimously approved today a bill to reduce the draft age to 18 years and moved to bring the measure to the floor of the House Saturday.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Three new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. The Strand will offer "You Can't Escape Forever," a Warner Brothers production starring George Brent and Brenda Marshall. Supporting roles in the melodrama are played by Gene Lockhart, Eduardo Ciannelli and Roscoe Karns. . .

MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- It is a year ago today that the foreign colony and diplomatic representatives left Moscow on short notice for Kuibyshev. Only a handful of diplomats stayed in the capital, the largest group being the Americans, who remained in the Ambassador's private house.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Second Officer Frank A. Santina of Montclair, N.J., has been named to receive the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal for heroism "above and beyond the call of duty." The award will be made in New York City tomorrow night by Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, at the annual banquet of the American Merchant Marine Conference.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 15 -- Commander John E. Whelchel, Navy's head coach, finished hard work for the Yale game today when he sent his squad through its third successive scrimmage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- In an angry clash with Senator Murray, chairman of the Small Business Committee, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, Army Chief of Supply, declared today that hundreds of small industrial plants would have to close "and you can put that down as a fact."

Bronislava Nijinska's new ballet "Snow Maiden" received its second performance at the hands of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, and again proved itself to be a fragile but winsome little work.

Heavy Japanese losses of top-ranking army and navy commanders in the opening months of the war in the Pacific were disclosed belatedly yesterday in a Tokyo broadcast of posthumous awards of the Order of the Golden Kite, Japan's highest military decoration, The Associated Press reported.

VICHY, France, Oct. 15 -- Dispatches attributed to Madrid and published today in the [German-controlled] Paris press -- without any basis of confirmation here -- report a heavily escorted United States convoy off the French West African coast near Dakar.

Dimitri Shostakovich's Seventh symphony, which is being performed this week by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, will be given again later in the season when Artur Rodzinski takes over as guest conductor, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Britain's war production must be planned as a comprehensive whole with those of the United States, Canada and the rest of the British Empire, Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, said yesterday, announcing an "active service" program for civilian workers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today the bill reported yesterday authorizing the government to regulate and stabilize rents of all residential and commercial property, including hotels and rooming houses.

An attack on Public Law 528, which provides for recapture of excess profits through renegotiation of contracts, was made yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York and the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, both of which called for repeal of the law because it hampered war production.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 15 -- With Italy entering her third war Winter under conditions admittedly less favorable than those confronting her in previous war Winters, a section of the Nazi press believes the time opportune to comment on some of the economic and financial problems besetting Germany's Axis ally.

The board of governors of the Federal Reserve System has adopted Amendment No. 9 to Regulation W, it was announced yesterday. The amendment becomes effective Oct. 26. The changes are technical or administrative, designed to improve the practical workings of the regulation.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 15 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, sounded a warning here tonight that an increasing shortage of farm labor in the State was creating a crisis in the production of food and dairy products which, unless checked, would seriously hamper the country's war efforts as well as cut down on the shipment of food to our troops and allies abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- United States Shoe Corporation, also trading as Red Cross Shoe Company, Cincinnati, has filed an answer to a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission which charged misuse of the American National Red Cross name and emblem for commercial purposes in the sale and distribution of shoes.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, raised the possibility yesterday that recent acts of vandalism and physical violence against civilian defense workers were inspired by "persons seeking to stir up racial and religious disunity," as he announced an investigation of the cases by his department.

A casualty station for the emergency treatment of victims of possible bombing attacks in the insurance district of lower Manhattan was dedicated yesterday on the ground floor of 85 John Street, in the National Board of Fire Underwriters Building.

LONDON, Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- Reports that the British were massing boats for an invasion of France and that British and American invasion fleets were poised for an assault on the French West African port of Dakar were broadcast repeatedly today by the Berlin radio.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Senate Military Committee asked the War Department today for confidential information on how it intends to use an army of 7,500,000 men. That figure has been made the goal for 1943. The committee plans to report to the Senate tomorrow its bill to lower the draft age to 18 years.

There were more Hitler effigies hanging from lamp posts in Yorkville yesterday than in any other part of Manhattan Island, and observers who toured the borough during the scrap-metal collection reported that the neighborhood piles of household scrap were higher than in most other sections.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Oct. 16 -- Allied airmen supporting their comrades fighting the Japanese in the lower Solomons bombed and "evidently seriously damaged" an enemy light cruiser yesterday near Faisi in the northern area of the island chain, a communique said today.

The International Utilities Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan of recapitalization and merger designed to meet the requirements of Section 11 (e) of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Note circulation established a high record as reported today in the weekly condition statement of the Bank of England with an increase of 3,035,000 to 846,277,000.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Breeze Corporations, Inc., of Newark, N.J., manufacturer of electrical and allied products, has filed a suit in Federal court in Buffalo asking that a lawyer here and the Sheriff of Monroe County be restrained from disposing of 5,000 shares of its capital stock, valued at $40,000.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Mrs. Harry Dow of the home club won low-gross honors in the closing one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association when she toured the south course of the Westchester Country Club in 43, 42 -- 85 today.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Keeping up their constant interception of German supply ships that creep along the coast of occupied Europe, British light naval forces early yesterday morning destroyed a large enemy vessel in the English Channel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- President Roosevelt's callers included Robert M. Scotten, Minister to Costa Rica; Norma H. Davis, chairman of the Red Cross, and Senator Murray of Montana.

Two muggers who pleaded guilty to assault in the second degree in connection with the mugging of George Fernandez, 17, of 132 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, were sentenced yesterday in Bronx County Court to from one and one-half to three years in jail.

The four-story apartment house at 41-26 Seventy-third Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Freehold Equities, Inc., Samuel Reznick, president, to a client of William Roth through Globus Realty Corporation, broker. The building is on a plot 225 by 60 feet, contains fifty-nine apartments and was bought subject to mortgages aggregating $153,453.

Major Gen. T.A. Terry, commanding the Second Service Command, yesterday called off the youth parade, originally intended to spur recruiting among the 18 and 19-year-olds, which had been scheduled for tomorrow. The reason given was that not enough time had been allowed to permit the kind of promotion that would insure success.

MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- The Soviet Government came out bluntly today for immediate trial and punishment "with all the severity of criminal law" of any German ringleader already imprisoned by the Allies, and specifically named Rudolf Hess, a captive in Britain, as one of the "organizers of German atrocities" who should pay now for his misdeeds.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Patrolman Richard Schneider was under suspension today because on Tuesday night he put in a telephone call for a policeman instead of-going out himself to investigate the activities of a prowler at a building adjoining his home, according to Police Chief Gustave J. Swan.

Fordham's coach, Earl Walsh, has considerable respect for the offensive power of West Virginia's football team. That was evident yesterday on Rose Hill as the Rams stressed defensive work for the second straight day. More than half the two-hour session was devoted to a dummy scrimmage in which the reserves ran Mountaineer plays against the varsity.

Two hundred and fifty industrialists and educators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore under the joint auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers and the National Education Association, were warned against post-war domination of both industry and education by the Federal Government unless industry is permitted to make a "modest" wartime profit and teachers to receive reasonable wartime salaries.

Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, accused Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate, last night of having been, prior to Pearl Harbor, "a positive force for isolationism and appeasement," and termed the record of John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic standard bearer, "simply inconsequential" on the then burning issues of the day.

Declaring that the hospitals of New York are in the war "beyond their financial depth," William S. Paley, chairman of the sixty-fourth annual United Hospital Campaign, made an appeal yesterday to every citizen who can give. The annual report disclosed that 1,238,963 persons had received care during 1941 at the seventy-six voluntary non-profit hospitals served by the United Hospital Fund.

Rhoten Shetley, first-string quarterback of the Football Dodgers since the incomparable Ace Parker was removed from the Flatbush gridiron scene, yesterday was inducted into the United States Army at Atlanta, Ga.

Since she was a comedienne Dame Marie Tempest was the mistress of her fate. For comedy comes from the mind and will, and does not surrender to chaos or adversity. When she was 77, in uncertain health and entitled to rest and leisure, her home in London was wrecked by bombing.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Samuel Reshevsky and Isaac Kashdan, co-chess champions of the United States, met here tonight in the third game of a national title match arranged for them by the USO camp shows with Reshevsky winning after forty moves.

Mayor La Guardia complimented the people of London on their fortitude under war conditions last evening as he spoke on a short-wave program sponsored by the World Wide Broadcasting Foundation and sent to London over WRUL's short-wave facilities.

MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- The declaration of the Soviet Government concerning the responsibility of the Hitlerite invaders and their associates for crimes committed by them in the occupied countries of Europe follows:

Manufacturers and wholesalers of apparel and clothing who make sales at retail without first posting on their premises ceiling prices covering such sales and filing a statement of their "retail" selling prices in accordance with the GMPR were warned yesterday by the regional enforcement division of the OPA that legal action will be taken against all future violators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Additional rationing programs will be started by the Office of Price Administration almost as rapidly as the War Price and Rationing Boards can absorb them, spokesmen for the OPA said today.

Charles Chaplin, famous film comedian, director and author, announced yesterday on arriving here from Hollywood that he would discard his traditional mustache, baggy trousers and wabbly walking stick when he starts work on his new picture, "Lady Killer."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Prices in primary markets edged upward in the week ended on Oct. 10 and the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index rose 0.1 per cent. Further advances in prices for livestock and dairy products again accounted for the rise, which brought the all-commodity index to 99.8 per cent of the 1926 average.

Four men who were convicted last July of disposing of $125,000 worth of jewels taken from Mrs. Harry W. Breyer in a hold-up near Philadelphia in 1939 were sentenced to long prison terms by General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 15 (AP) -- At present production domestic factories would need nearly eight months to make the durable goods called for by unfilled orders on their books, General Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said today in the bank's monthly bulletin.

Not many months ago some of them were walking the New York streets, going to shows and movies, visiting the service clubs, just as soldiers, sailors and marines are doing today. There was no outward sign to distinguish them from the others, or that would distinguish them if they were here today.

The Atlantic Monthly Press and Little, Brown announced yesterday they were putting up a $5,000 prize for the best non-fiction manuscript "having to do with the war or the peace that will follow it." The two concerns, which work in conjunction, set virtually no limits on the type of book sought but designated only that entries must run to at least 65,000 words and must be received by April 15, 1943.

Pending an interpretation of the salary and wage freezing order of the Economic Stabilization Board, all salary increments for teachers and school employes in New York City will be withheld, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

Three or four over-zealous youths between the ages of 16 to 18 years late Wednesday night invaded the Chelsea district and removed eight or ten iron gates from in front of as many houses on West Twenty-first Street, between Ninth and Tenth venues and deposited them on a scrap heap in front of a church on the corner.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Since President Roosevelt's endorsement of him, John J. Bennett, Democratic candidate for Governor, has gained 4 points in popularity throughout New York State.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Treasury increased tonight its call for tenders for weekly Treasury bills to the all-time high of $500,000,000. This is five times the quantity sold a year ago.
Two organizations interested in the welfare of women and children in Great Britain are conducting fund-raising appeals for Christmas toys -- Bundles for Britain and the British War Relief Society.

In a Berlin broadcast that was recorded by The Associated Press, the Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung was quoted as reporting yesterday that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel had returned to North Africa after a visit to Berlin and had resumed active command of the Axis forces on the Egyptian front.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- An elaborate plan for dissolution of the Portland Electric Power Company of Portland, Ore., was filed today with the Securities and Exchange' Commission by its trustees, Thomas W. Delzell and R.L. Clark.

LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Embittered and disillusioned Croat peasant followers of Dr. Vladimir Matchek were reported tonight to be waging a new and independent guerrilla war against occupation forces and the brown-shirted Ustachi storm troopers of the Italian puppet, Ante Pavelitch.

Government control of labor, as a result of the failure of workers to go voluntarily into war industries, was predicted yesterday by Brig. Gen. Frank J. McSherry, director of operations of the War Manpower Commission, in an interview at the Hotel Astor.
MADISON, N.J., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Drew Theological Seminary celebrated its seventy-fifth anniversary today, twenty-four days in advance.
Perfect flowers at pleasant prices -- such is the report of the New York Department of Agriculture on this week's crop of blossoms.

Freight movement into New England over the Boston Albany Railroad, a subsidiary of the New York Central Railroad, increased 76 per cent in the first six months of this year over the same period of last year, F.E. Williamson, president of the trunk line, said yesterday following a meeting of the Eastern Railroad Presidents' Conference.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 15 -- Citing Bismarck's words, "Switzerland is a country that must pay for the windows its newspapers have broken," the German Foreign Office spokesman today continued his tirade against the "so-called neutrality", of the Swiss press.

A plea for the acquittal of three of the twenty-five German-American Bund leaders on trial in Federal court was made yesterday by Theodore Kiendl, their assigned counsel, on the ground that they are not guilty of the single criminal activity of which they are accused.

A confessed pyromaniac, who spent Wednesday night minding a neighbor's baby while a fire he had set in the Leon Furniture Company's warehouse at 120-17 Fourteenth Road, College Point, Queens, blazed furiously, was locked up at the Flushing precinct last night on an arson charge.

In the last year the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross has doubled its membership and greatly expanded its activities to meet the many urgent demands placed on it by the war, Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director of the chapter, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the chapter at its headquarters, 315 Lexington Avenue.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 15 (AP) -- William M. Jeffers, rubber director, indicated today that gasoline rationing and rigid observance of the 25-mile speed limit might bring tires for everybody. Hero today for a personal inspection of Akron's growing synthetic rubber industry, he said to newsmen:

OTTAWA, Oct. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits in the week ended yesterday increased $7,431,000 to $42,193,000, it was shown today in the statement of the Bank of Canada. Banknotes in circulation increased $6,778,000 to $642,478,000.

Mrs. Charles Moore Bleecker of the Weylin gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the hotel for Mrs. John Percival Jefferson of Santa Barbara, Calif. The other guests were Mrs. Francis Oakey, Mrs. Reginald W. Rives, Mrs. Robert J. Kelly and Mrs. John Chase.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The country-wide shortage of beef for civilian consumption has been felt in Washington chiefly by patrons of chain stores, whose supplies rarely last the day out, and in lesser degree by purveyors of "quality cuts," of which more are available, although not enough to meet the demands of many, who are perforce turning to lamb, veal and chicken.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- House and Senate conferees on the $9,000,000,000 wartime tax bill accepted today the Vandenberg amendment "freezing" Social Security old-age benefit taxes for 1943.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Head Coach Howie Odell today picked four substitutes for injured regulars -- Wally Warfield, center; Marion Dietrich and Ted Kiendl, tackles; and Sam Scovil, quarterback -- to start Saturday's game at Baltimore against Navy.
MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

HEADQUARTERS, ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND, Oct. 15 -- United States ground forces have occupied another of the Andreanof Islands in their campaign to drive the Japanese invader out of the Aleutians, the Army announced tonight.

A consolidated net profit of $3,787,902 for the fiscal year ended on June 30 was reported to stockholders yesterday by J.W. Schwab, president of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc. The profit, which is equal to $6.41 a share on 590,528 shares of common stock outstanding, remains after deducting all charges, including foreign-exchange adjustments and setting up $750,000 reserve for contingencies, on which taxes have been paid.

Drawing a capacity attendance of more than 600 persons, the fourth annual White Elephant cocktail party and tea dance was given yesterday afternoon in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre under the auspices of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The country-wide shortage of beef for civilian consumption has been felt in Washington chiefly by patrons of chain stores, whose supplies rarely last the day out, and in lesser degree by purveyors of "quality cuts," of which more are available, although not enough to meet the demands of many, who are perforce turning to lamb, veal and chicken.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- House and Senate conferees on the $9,000,000,000 wartime tax bill accepted today the Vandenberg amendment "freezing" Social Security old-age benefit taxes for 1943.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Memories of golf's other and better days were awakened today as more than 250 players turned out for the qualifying round of the fifth annual Geist Memorial tournament at the Seaview Country Club, one of the pet projects of the late Philadelphia utility magnate.

Southern leadership has made so much progress in recent years toward ending the evil of lynching that when news of a crime of this kind arrives it seems to come like a ghost from an earlier and darker and discreditable day. The United Press brought word this week of the discovery of the bodies of two 14-year-old Negro boys found hanging to a bridge in the town of Meridian, Miss.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced adoption of policies with respect to petitions by converters who also wish to act as jobbers of finished textile piece goods under provisions of Maximum Price Regulation No. 127.

The sick we have with us always. But since Pearl Harbor we must also reckon with the wounded. WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Senate and House conferees neared completion today of the $9,000,000,000 wartime tax bill by completing action on practically all major issues.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Globe the newcomer will be "The Devil With Hitler," a Hal Roach comedy with Alan Mowbray, Marjorie Woodworth, Bobby Watson, Douglas Fowley and Joe Devlin.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 16 -- A grandfather entered the Army today with a contingent of Englewood selectees.
LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Violent disorders against Nazi repressive measures and brutal reprisals were reported today from many parts of oppressed Europe.

AMHERST vs. Rochester -- The football guide has been no help. A man might better look in the World Almanac. The right section, of course, would be that devoted to memorable dates and historic events. An amiable vote for Amherst.

Herbert Brownell Jr., manager of the Republican State campaign, said last night that the scheduled tour of Staten Island that Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, was to have made today had been canceled because of the illness of the candidate.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc., yesterday announced the award of citations to five concerns engaged in war production, who were revealed by a survey just completed to be offering the most unusual opporunities to women.

The national ranking of college football teams is likely to undergo a big revision after today's returns are in, and there should be a marked reduction from the twenty-one remaining unbeaten and untied in major competition.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 16 -- Although the Axis air force cut down the scale of losses on the fifth day of the Blitz on Malta yesterday by changing tactics and employing fighter-bombers instead of Sunkers-88's, it remained as ineffectual as ever.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- President Roosevelt reported to Congress today that non-war activities took 5.2 cents of every Federal dollar and would total $4,194,000,000 in the fiscal year 1943, a decrease of 35.6 per cent from the peak non-war expenditures in 1939 and about $1,000,000,000 under expenditures last year.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Vichy radio announced last night that a French naval air officer was killed in combat over West Africa last Sunday, and the Germans prefaced their broadcast of this news with a statement saying "fighting activities have started over Dakar."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 16 -- Five of the Spanish newspaper men accredited to Berlin have left the Reich since the resignation of Pamon Serrano Suner as Foreign Minister, according to reports received here through private channels. Among the correspondents who have left is Arriba's.

SYDNEY, N.S., Oct. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Apart from the death loosed by her torpedo, the German submarine that sank the Caribou was itself believed to have contributed to the loss of life. Some survivors said that as she broke surface, the hull of the U-boat capsized one or two rafts and smashed a lifeboat, and they believed some of those on the raft and boat were lost.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 16 -- The Opposition's no-confidence motion in the House of Representatives failed last night in a vote of 17 to 47, after an all-day debate in which the high point was the speech of Joseph G. Coates, former Prime Minister and ex-Opposition leader.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16 -- A business boom "such as the world has never known" when the peace is signed and America's factories, mines and farms are turned back to the production of things for living rather than for killing was predicted here today by Charles H. Watts, president of the Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation and the Beneficial Management Corporation.

The German High Command said yesterday that Nazi tanks and infantry had smashed through Stalingrad's defenses to the Volga and stormed a fiercely defended factory area, but military spokesmen declared the Red Army "is continuing to fight as if nothing had happened."

ONEONTA, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Melvin C. Eaton, former State chairman, and other Republican party workers took part today in receptions given to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. on a campaign tour through the Chenango and Susquehanna Valleys.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The crews of four Canadian bomber squadrons in the Cologne attack last night -- the 110th R.A.F. raid of the war on that Rhineland city -- said today that great fires were visible long distances from Cologne and that the glow from the burning city could be seen on the homeward flight to within twenty miles of the Netherlands coast.
Most of those baseball fans who watched the St. Louis Cardinals romp this year are raving, and rightfully so, because they had never seen anything like that before.

Differences narrowed appreciably in the cotton futures market yesterday as spot houses bought the December. Hedging operations continued moderately active, however, in the distant contracts. On the New York Cotton Exchange active months ended the session 1 point lower to 4 points higher than Thursday's closing prices.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, Oct. 17 -- Chungking is rapidly becoming the headquarters for Frenchmen escaping from occupied areas of the Far East hoping to join the Fighting French. Recently two arrived from Peiping, three from Indo-China and one from Kwangchowwan.

A growing interest in American textiles of enduring quality and good design has been indicated by the number of visitors to a new department at Altman's, devoted exclusively to the display of Botany Perennials, executives of the store said yesterday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- The Engineers Public Service Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amended plan for recapitalization of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, a subsidiary, making drastic revisions in the original plan.

Army's cadets and Army's football team are expected to do some marching at Baker Field this afternoon when the unbeaten West Pointers face Columbia in the feature attraction on the subway circuit. The cadet corps will march at 1:45 o'clock; the cadet eleven will start at 2:30.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday the terms and conditions of a $1,000,000,000 revolving credit to finance the production of war supplies. All negotiations relating to the credit have been completed in cooperation with the War Department and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and final arrangements with 400 banks in virtually every State will be completed this month.

Fred V. Encarnacion, a Filipino chief petty officer in the Navy, with two sailor sons, turned State's evidence yesterday against his former Japanese partner in a Chinese lottery game in East Fifty-eighth Street, and brought about the latter's conviction in Special Sessions.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The stock market closed the week on a good note with industrials and the home rails continuing to attract most of the business. Gilt-edge issues remain dull with the 3 1/2 per cent war loan remaining steady despite the fact the half-year interest will come off in ten days.

Overalls in the audience are good form when Dr. Artur Rodzinski and his Cleveland Orchestra play, and particularly when they are playing the Shostakovich Seventh symphony, dealing with the siege of Leningrad.

As Justice Matthew J. Troy started to dispose of 150 gambling cases yesterday in Special Sessions he commented caustically on Police Commissioner Valentine's charge that many bench warrants in gambling cases had not been executed because offenders had been permitted to give fictitious names and addresses when they were freed on bail.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A dispatch to Reuters, British news agency, from Zurich, Switzerland, told today of reports that a letter discussing the possibilities of a separate peace for Finland had been sent recently by Field Marshal Baron Carl Gustav Emil Mannerheim, Finnish Commander in Chief, to Pope Pius.

Above everything else, marketing needs to increase its speed and accuracy, Norwood Weaver of the Magazine Marketing Service declared yesterday in discussing the service's new County Buying Power Index at a luncheon meeting of the Market Research Council at the Yale Club.

PITTSBURGH, Saturday, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A terrific explosion at the Duquesne Works of the Continental Roll and Steel Foundry Company shook the Ohio River communities of Sewickley and Coraopolis at 1 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Plans for revising the set-up of the Office of Price Administration's field staff and putting more responsibility in the hands of districts and regional offices struck a snag here today in the form of organized opposition from directors of the State offices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission announced today a policy of waiving jurisdiction over intrastate power companies that tie in their lines with interstate utilities in order to increase power supplies needed by war industries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Disregarding Senate criticism of his program for expanding rayon plants to enable them to produce 50,000,000 pounds more of high-tenacity yarn for use in military vehicle tires, William M. Jeffers, the rubber director, has ordered the program to be put into effect.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 16 (AP) -- All 171 employes of the abandoned Higgins Shipyard have offered to work without pay for 60 days to get the plant into wartime production.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Three second lieutenants who participated in a devastating United States Army Air Force attack on Rabaul, New Britain, in which four Japanese ships were sunk or damaged were among eleven American officers and men receiving Silver Stars today from Major Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of Allied air forces in the Southwest Pacific.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- The grain markets showed today considerable resistance to selling pressure on the Board of Trade, and while wheat dipped to a new low on the current downturn and December oats and July rye went to new seasonal lows, there was good support on the breaks.

Advocates of public ownership within the Government have succeeded in writing into the new tax bill a means whereby officials of a municipality could obtain control of utility properties even where local laws or the sentiment of a majority of the voters might prevent the municipality itself from taking such action.

With collections on installment accounts receivable coming in at an unprecedented rate as a result of the credit restrictions of Regulation W, retailers must be exceedingly careful to avoid any dissipation of their liquid assets which would make it impossible for them to resume normal operations after the war, John R. Trost, manager of the New York office of the National Retail Furniture Association, warned yesterday.

THE aged Father William could balance an eel on the end of his nose and do other astonishing things. But Father William, a fictional character, was hardly as remarkable as the flesh-and-blood subject of Dorothy G. Wayman's biography, "Edward Sylvester Morse."* Professor Morse could play a flute with his nose. He could draw with two hands simultaneously, sketching in two wings of a butterfly with absolutely perfect symmetry.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 16 -- A wave of disorder and bloodshed was reported in unoccupied France tonight as Frenchmen, goaded into revolt by Chief of Government Pierre Laval's efforts to drive them into labor for Germany, challenged the government's measures by strikes and violence.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Virginia's worst transportation tie-up in years attributable to floods was eased tonight as the Richmond, Fredericksburg Potomac Railroad began to move North-South trains which had been delayed nearly twenty-four hours, past Fredericksburg.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- Sam Wood, independent producer-director, announced today that his second production for Columbia release under his new contract with the company will be a film adaptation of "Jubal Troop," novel by Paul Wellman, which will be published this Winter.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Frederick A. Godley, associate professor of architecture at Yale University, has been named master of Timothy Dwight College and promoted to a full professorship.
