Flashing an explosive razzle-dazzle attack that swept to three touchdowns in the first quarter, St. Benedict's Prep of Newark, N.J., coasted to a 26-6 triumph over Columbia's freshmen at Baker Field yesterday. It was the first home game for the Lion cubs.

Strengthened by Bill Jefferson, versatile left halfback just purchased from the Philadelphia Eagles, the Brooklyn Dodgers continued preparations yesterday at Ebbets Field for their important National Football League clash there tomorrow with the Washington Redskins.

From a military standpoint, the calling up of the youths from 18 to 19 years of age is surprising only in that it was delayed. In modern combat of rapid movement the advantage of a supple body and a supple mind is a prime essential.

Howard Barlow, American conductor, has been engaged to direct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in eight concerts during the first two weeks in November, it was announced yesterday. During the fifteen years that he has conducted the Columbia Broadcasting Symphony Orchestra, Mr. Barlow has done important pioneer work for symphonic music and especially for American orchestral compositions, several of which will appear on his Philharmonic programs.

The Adams Express Company, an investment concern, had on Sept. 30 net assets of $15,501,355 applicable to its common stock, or $10.59 a share, against $10.62 and $12.33 a share, respectively, on Dec. 31, 1941, and Sept. 30, 1941, according to its quarterly report to be released today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Senate Education and Labor Committee voted unanimously today to recommend passage of a bill reducing the number of government questionnaires which business men must answer by eliminating unnecessary duplication.

The National Association of Broadcasters announced here yesterday that it "expects to cooperate" in any suits that commercial transcription companies may bring in the State courts in connection with the various questions involved in the Petrillo radio case.

Since this newspaper has endorsed the candidacy of John J. Bennett in the State election, political logic alone would counsel endorsement of the three fellow-candidates who will be his colleagues in office in the event of his election. In the interest of good government a Governor is entitled to the support of an administration representing his own party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Sumner Welles, acting secretary of State, denied today an Argentine report that Felipe A. Espil, the Argentine Ambassador here, had recently told him that Argentina would not sever relations with the Axis.

On our statute books are many laws that require a man to have a high school certificate or its equivalent. A man may not even take the examination to become a registered architect unless he has a high school certificate. Colleges and post-graduate schools require that boys have high school certificates before they enter.

Donald Blackwell and Raymond Curtis plan to open their production of "The Willow and I" on Broadway the first week in December. The John Patrick play, dealing with two sisters in love with the same man, will be tested out of town for at least one week.

SYDNEY, N.S., Saturday, Oct. 17 -- Loss of 137 lives -- Canadians and Americans, civilians and members of the armed services -- was believed today to have been the toll of the torpedo sinking early Wednesday morning of the Newfoundland-Nova Scotia steamer Caribou, which went down a few minutes after being struck in Cabot Strait by a German submarine.

Stepping off on another aspect of his anti-gambling crusade, Mayor La Guardia took the pinball machine manufacturers of Illinois and Michigan over the coals yesterday as being "on the same gutter level of the tinhorn."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, extended economic controls today to salaries under $5,000 a year and told the first session of his government, management, labor and farm advisory board that he was more interested in "keeping prices down than keeping profits up."

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 16 -- Never since the armistice was signed in June, 1940, has the internal situation in France been more tense, but there have been no serious troubles -- not yet, at all events -- and resistance to the conscription of labor for Germany remains passive rather than active.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- "We have come to the stage when the crucial moment of the war is opening," Labor Minister Ernest Bevin told the Transport and General Workers Union's conference here today.

Tax-exempt securities, particularly those of public housing authorities, comprised the new bond issues offered here to the public this week. Fourteen issues of bonds and notes aggregating $20,940,000 were marketed, and of the amount $19,500,000 represented eleven housing authority flotations, the first in this field since mid-August.

A diligent lawyer assigned by the court to defend Clemon Allen, a Negro boy, won the lad's acquittal and discharge in General Sessions yesterday on a first-degree felony-murder indictment in the fatal stabbing of James O'Connell, 15 years old, last Nov. 1.

After two days of corrective reaction, the stock market returned yesterday to the advance. The session was confined generally to buying in selected issues, and the improvement was confined principally to fractions. Weakness during the morning hours in American Telephone produced some sympathetic action in other stocks, but better demand in the afternoon helped to right the list.

VICHY, France, Oct. 16 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval, addressing the Council of Ministers today, announced his determination not to tolerate any breach of order or interference with the principle of freedom to work.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- A warning that representative government in this country was endangered by "the development of dictatorial methods" was sounded at the opening session today of the directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs by the federation president, Mrs. John L. Whitehurst of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Francisco Stewart, president of the Argentine merchant fleet, said today that he had successfully completed his mission with the negotiation of an agreement with United States shipping officials for use of United States ports by about twenty-four government-owned Argentine merchant vessels and affecting cargoes to be carried.

The reconstruction of Palestine as a Jewish state under the Zionist conception must be considered as part and parcel of the vision of a happier post-war world, and not as an isolated problem, Dr. Oscar I. Janowsky declared yesterday.

Tapia Caballero of Chile, a singularly well-schooled pianist, perhaps thought it incumbent upon him to prove that he was as much at home in classic as in more modern and exotic music when he made his New York debut last night in Town Hall.

Alben W. Barkley, majority leader of the Senate, addressing 1,000 delegates of the Zionist Organization of America at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, endorsed the Zionist aims and principles, asserting that Americans generally and people "all over the world are devoutly concerned over the restoration of the land of Palestine as the home of the Jew."

Yesterday we printed on this page a letter from a distinguished group of psychiatrists and other medical men protesting against the proposed draft of young men of 18 and 19 into the armed forces. Boys of this age are, they contend, in a large percentage of cases emotionally immature.

There is an enthusiastic sightseer in town who, equipped with a map of the city, is going to cover a lot of ground over the week-end. People who meet her will be delighted with her quick humor and immediately see a resemblance both in looks and personality to Queen Elizabeth of England.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, having already turned over one new leaf with the addition of Bronislava Nijinska to its staff of choreographers, last night turned over another and an even newer one by presenting at the Metropolitan Opera House a ballet by Agnes de Mille, with a score by Aaron Copland based partly on American folk tunes, and with choreography rooted in American folk dance.

The Ferargil Gallery will open on Monday what is announced as "the first labor art show in the United States." It is sponsored by the Dressmakers' Union, Local 22 of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, and will be held for the benefit of United China Relief.

Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, last night rebuked Republican leaders for criticism of Wendell L. Willkie for going to the Near East, Russia and China as the representative of President Roosevelt. Mr. Alfange spoke from radio station WQXR on a forum sponsored by the Greater New York Industrial Union Council.

DALLAS, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A hard-running Temple football machine outpowered Southern Methodist U. but a fumbled ball at a critical moment left it with nothing better than a 6-6 tie in the Cotton Bowl tonight.

Showing a sharp decline from the increase of 63 per cent in August and 88 per cent in July, merchandise inventories of New York City department stores on Sept. 30 were 44 per cent above the 1941 level, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CESME, Turkey, Oct. 16 -- In a tented village on a rugged hillside and in rude dwellings within the Turkish seaport town of Cesme itself -- lying on the Aegean Sea barely six miles from the German-occupied island of Chios -- nearly 2,000 Greek refugees are facing the rainy season and a long Winter with insufficient housing, food and clothing.

Seven hundred letters and 1,500 posters have been distributed announcing the shopping service for the armed forces sponsored by the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell, chairman of its shopping service.

The annual convention of the Book Manufacturers Institute, which was postponed to accommodate government representatives who were scheduled to address the meeting, will be held Oct. 22-23 at the Hotel Hershey in Hershey, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- Families with incomes of more than $2,000 a year will be the only ones affected by the voluntary "share-the-meat" plan, the prelude to meat rationing, Agriculture Department officials said today. Those in the lower bracket are said to eat not enough meat anyway, and to be below the two and one-half pounds a week quota set for each person.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- Private William J. Smith, 24, Brereton, Ill., a demoted sergeant, renounced his American citizenship today and asked deportation to "a neutral power of official designation or of my choosing."

LONDON, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- The Polish Government in exile has indicted ten men for the murder of 400,000 Poles, it was announced tonight. They head a list of 3,000 war criminals selected by the Polish Government for trial after the war.
ATLANTA, Oct. 16 -- Georgia authorities prepared today to speed enforcement of a "quarantine order" calling for the registration and treatment of all in the State having venereal diseases.

Samuel Reshevsky, now leading by 2-1 in his United States chess championship match with Isaac I. Kashdan, co-champion, returned to the city yesterday well pleased with his success in the third game of the United Service Organizations series at the Plattsburg Barracks on Thursday night.

Officials of the Army, Navy, city and State will greet official representatives of the twenty-nine Allied nations with their color-guards taking part in a "British harvest festival," to be held tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. in old Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway, at the head of Wall Street.

Fifteen, including top sprinters and good stayers, are named for the Continental Handicap at the intermediate distance of a mile and a sixteenth at Jamaica today. Whether the sprinters can last that far in the $12,000 test or the stayers can get up quickly enough is the question that will occupy approximately 25,000 persons on the only Saturday of the Fall meeting.

After reading the remarks made the other day by Lieut. Col. Lawrence (Biff) Jones, West Point graduate manager, in connection with this year's Army-Navy football game, I am wondering why the authorities have not decided upon a definite site for the contest.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 16 -- Educators in nursing were urged today to have 55,000 student nurses in their ranks by next Spring.

The New Opera Company is offering a prize of $250 in war bonds to the person selling the largest number of season subscriptions before Nov. 3, the date of its opening performance at the Broadway Theatre, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Lytle Hull, president.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16 -- The Mexican Senate today discussed details of a possible law that would require foreigners of military age to take training in the Mexican Army.
Pennsylvania went from fourth place into national leadership yesterday in the scrap metal salvage campaign sponsored by the nation's newspapers, and Montana came up from seventh to second place.

Those who favor a closed season on waterfowl shooting for the duration of the war will find their side of the story explained by Mrs. G.N. Edge, chairman of the Emergency Conservation Committee, which has just released a pamphlet on this subject entitled "The Ducks and the Democracy."
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- British bombers returned last night to Cologne and again blasted that Rhineland city and arms center, which last Spring received the heaviest bombing of any center in all Germany.

Wednesday of next week, Oct. 22 will mark the 134th anniversary of the birth of Samuel Francis Smith, author of the hymn "My Country, "Tis of Thee." The hymn has had a nationwide use on patriotic and religious occasions by three or more generation of American people as expressive of their loyalty and devotion, as also of their yearning for the might of divine protection, common inheritances of humanity the world over.

Associated Press photographs from Papua show three Australian soldiers with beards. One might think that these men, who will not be dictated to, had beards because some upstart of an officer told them to shave. But a photograph of an American flier comes down from the Aleutians.

An additional 987,805 pounds of metal picked up in Manhattan yesterday brought to 113,711 tons the city's pile of household scrap gathered in the one-month newspaper-sponsored salvage campaign that ends officially today. It was estimated last night that the figure would reach 150,000 tons by the time all the heavy items are brought in, including steel safes and metal doors, which require special equipment for salvaging.

The duty of every man, woman and youth in the United States to make some sacrifice willingly to help win the victory will be the topic of sermons tomorrow in the New York area. In ritualistic churches the Feast of St. Luke, the physician, will be celebrated.

New issues of notes of six local housing authorities aggregating $58,066,000 were awarded yesterday through competitive bidding to Wall Street banks and banking firms. The Chemical Bank and Trust Company and associates obtained $43,800,000; Salomon Brothers Hutzler, $7,946,000; the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, $3,500,000; R.W. Pressprich Co., $2,000,000; F.S. Moseley Co., $435,000, and Harvey Fisk Sons, Inc., $385,000.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, urged last night a balanced war program "right now," and to accomplish it he advised the country to wake up and realize that there are "limitations even to what 130 million people can do, whether it is raw materials or manpower.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 16 -- The first news of active preparations to retake Burma some day came in an announcement made here today that General Sir Archibald P. Wavell has just returned from an inspection trip to the Indo-Burma frontier.

Declaring that the 5,000 members of the Fighting French forces now with the British troops in Egypt are first-class fighting men with second-class materiel, Norman Jefferys, 25-year-old American member of the American Field Service Volunteer Ambulance Corps, described yesterday his experiences under fire in Syria and Egypt in the last two years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- What the farm needs is some glamour, Congress was told today:

Retail trade continued active here this week. Department store sales were estimated as showing a gain of 10 to 12 per cent over last year. Columbus Day business was active, but some disappointment was expressed that the percentage gain over 1941 was not greater in view of the low sales figures last year.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Doug Ford of Hummocks, who has had a sensational winning streak since he reacquired the New York State junior championship the past Summer, rearranged the formula for pro-amateur tourneys in a one-man show at the Pelham Country Club today.

No prospective bidders appeared yesterday at a hearing by the Board of Transportation on the form of contract for removal and disposal of the rapid transit storage yards at 159th Street and Eighth Avenue. Demolition of the yards and removal of the storage tracks will produce an estimated 7,000 tons of high grade scrap metal destined for war use.

As Mayor La Guardia criticized the operation of interstate trucks through residential streets yesterday, Police Commissioner Valentine barred trucks from East 189th Street in the Bronx in an effort to prevent accidents such as the one that caused the death of an 8-year-old boy, Joseph Picone, Thursday night.

YORKERS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Despite his resignation ten days ago, former City Manager Raymond J. Whitney has submitted a budget of $11,200,584 for the city for 1943 to City Clerk Francis Heafy, it was announced today. Mr. Whitney's proposed budget calls for a $316,000 reduction in the tax levy.

This is the tale of the roast. In the very beginning, the housekeeper ordered a rump pot roast, boned and rolled. It weighed mere than four pounds, cost $1.71 and represented a little less than half of the weekly meat ration, since hers was a family of four.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 16 (AP) -- The travel of a half-dozen football teams across Virginia was interrupted today by floods which broke rail transportation in the northern part of the State, but it appeared tonight that all of them would get through in time for engagements tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Japanese have succeeded in setting up artillery on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons and are shelling American positions, the Navy announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Many large fires were started in Kiska, in the Aleutian Islands, on Wednesday when United States Army bombers and fighting planes, in a new attack, rained incendiaries on the camp area, the Navy Department reported today. In the same assault our fighter planes strafed and destroyed three enemy seaplanes on the water.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16 -- The impetus of the Germans' latest offensive at Stalingrad carried them forward during the latter part of yesterday, when, according to the latest official reports released in Moscow today, several streets fell into their hands.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 17 -- The Stalingrad garrison "withdrew from one of the city's settlements" yesterday under the pressure of "numerically superior" German shock troops who were supported by hundreds of tanks and planes in their furious new effort to split the Red Army defenders.

Volunteer groups should concentrate on nutrition outside of war industries while government agencies work in the plants, Dr. Edward S. Rogers, director of the Office of War Nutrition Services, State War Council, declared yesterday.

Mr. Lande, whose letter advocating a standard apartment-lease form appeared in your issue of Oct. 10, 1942, may very well be right when he says that the "only solution toward having sensible and intelligent leases" is to induce the Legislature to pass a law. It is, of course, a solution which cannot be viewed with equanimity -- there are too many laws already.

The Rev. Raymond H. Rosche, for the last four years pastor of the Presbyterian Church, Old Forge, N.Y., will be installed next Friday evening, at 8 o'clock, as the pastor of the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant, 310 East Forty-second Street, near Second Avenue.

Two young Negroes who on Sept. 16 participated with two others in the bludgeoning and robbing of Bombardier Partrick Murphy of the Royal Air Force on Fifth Avenue near Forty-sixth Street were sentenced yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions on their previous guilty pleas.

In the post-war period business, labor and government will cooperate in a socialized capitalism "which, I think, will be a good thing," Paul T. Babson, president of United Business Service, Boston, predicted yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Direct Mail Advertising Association, which held a one-day conference on wartime direct mail and printed promotion at the Hotel Roosevelt.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Allied air forces in New Guinea again supported the hard-fighting United States Marines and troops on Guadalcanal by a bombing expedition to Buin, where the Washington Navy Department announced a new Japanese naval concentration had been sighted General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters said today.
The greeting card industry has put Santa Claus to work selling war stamps in a series of eight Christmas designs that made their appearance yesterday in shops throughout the city.
LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Claude Wickard called on farmers today to plan for a 10 per cent increase in the 1943 Spring pig crop to meet increasing demands for pork. He asked also that next year's hogs be marketed ten pounds heavier than this year's as another means of increasing meat and lard production.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Errol Flynn, film star, surrendered today on a charge of raping a 17-year-old girl at a party and was released under $1,000 bail.

Asserting that he had received a new opinion from the Corporation Counsel's office, Dr. John E. Wade Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday that he had rescinded an order issued on Thursday to withhold annual salary increments from Board of Education employes pending approval by the National Economic Stabilization Board.

Ed Lally's letter appearing in THE TIMES last Saturday was interesting. I agree that Charley Keller of the Yankees is the hardest hitter in major league baseball and that he would clout forty or more homers a season if he was not a member of the New York club and thus played more home games in some other ball park.

An award of $350,000 was made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook to attorneys for the plaintiffs in an accounting action by stockholders of the General Investment Corporation, which ended recently with the approval of an offer of $1,375,000 by defendants for a settlement of the case.

VICHY, France, Oct. 16 -- Joseph Darnand, chief of the French Legion's new corps of militant guardsmen, known in France as S.O.L. -- Service d'Ordre Legionnaire -- in an interview with the newspaper Gringoire today described his organization as "a group trained with care on technical, political and physical lines," constituting "an active militia in the front rank of the legion phalanx."

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 16 -- Moravian defeated Fort Hamilton under the arcs tonight, 26 -- 0. The Greyhounds scored in each of the four periods, Steve Sydorak carrying the ball across for three of the markers. The fourth touchdown, in the final period, was registered by Dave Griffith.

A capacity audience of 3,000 persons heard a dozen writers, artists and actors, headed by Charles Chaplin, call for the early opening of a second front in Europe at a rally of the Artists Front to Win the War in Carnegie Hall last night.
Don Rodolfo Michels, the Chilean Ambassador, and Senora de Michels have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 10 were 239,121,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 2,056,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 1,989,000 and 69,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

The American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 net income of $752,079 after depreciation, amortization and $1,550,000 provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

In THE TIMES of Oct. 12 a news item from Malden, Mass., gives credit to the late James Bailey Upham for the authorship of the pledge of allegiance which is now recited daily in the public schools. While Mr. Upham, as on of the proprietors of The Youth's Companion, may have originated the idea the actual writing of the pledge was done by Francis Bellamy, at that time one of the editors of the weekly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee today unanimously approved a bill lowering the draft age to 18, as requested Monday by President Roosevelt. At the same time the House Rules Committee cleared the way for House consideration tomorrow of a similar measure, with the prospect that it will be passed by nightfall.

Damages of one cent each, the lowest on record in Supreme Court here, were awarded to Albert Levey and Charles Silvers by a jury before Justice Benedict D. Dineen in a verdict made public yesterday after an eight-day trial of their $100,000 damage suit against the Westchester Racing Association and detectives in its employ.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Edward Haight, 17-year-old Stamford, Conn., youth, will be tried for first-degree murder rather than for kidnapping when he faces a Westchester County Court jury on Oct. 26 in the rape and killing of two little sisters near their Bedford Village home on Sept. 14, officials announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Swirling flood waters of the Potomac and other rivers menaced today sections of the national capital, caused four deaths and wide destruction and left at least 2,000 people homeless in a large area of Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., United States Secretary of the Treasury, made a surprise appearance in London today before some 300 newspaper correspondents summoned by the Ministry of Information to meet him. He disclaimed connection with any official mission, citing the absence of a brief case as evidence.

James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, will speak Tuesday night in Rochester with Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., nominee for Governor, it was announced yesterday at Democratic campaign headquarters.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals reinstated today a suit by three stockholders of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line (Mokan) Company for an accounting by seven of its officers and directors for alleged waste of more than $1,000,000 in what the suit charges were exorbitant salaries, lawyers' and engineers' fees and expenses of litigation.

We, Indonesian aviation cadets of the Netherlands East Indies Air Force, do not feel quite at ease to read in the Sunday TIMES of Oct. 11 sentences like: "What shall we do with respect to the Netherlands East Indies?" and "We shall give autonomy in one degree or another in the other colonies" -- that is to say, other than China.

The report of the United Corporation, utility holding company, for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after expenses and charges, of $841,554. This was equal to 34 cents a share on 2,488,712 shares of $3 preference stock, and compares with $1,776,092, or 71 cents a preference share, in the September quarter a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- With nine Bishops conducting the rite of laying on of hands, the Rev. Dr. Oliver James Hart was consecrated today as Bishop Coadjutor of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania, in ceremonies conducted beneath the Gothic arches of the Memorial Church of the Advocate.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Captain Randolph Churchill received a vote of confidence tonight from the Preston Conservative Association after a two-and-a-half-hour meeting called at the request of the Prime Minister's son.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The war of reprisals against prisoners was carried a step further tonight by the German High Command, which announced over the Berlin radio that its captives regardless of nationality might be made to atone henceforth for any alleged mistreatment of German prisoners, including those taken on the Russian front.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Donald M. Nelson told the country's newspapers today that they had done a magnificent and unprecedented job in carrying on the household scrap salvage campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Demand for gasoline and motor oils during August, as measured by refinery sales, dropped 21 per cent below a year before, falling to 51,600,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported today.
Forty transatlantic passengers arrived here last night on two flying boats, one a Pan-American Airways Clipper and the other a Flying Ace of the American Export Airlines.

Declaring that during the stress of extraordinary conditions, socialistic theories seek an opportunity to insinuate themselves into the government, W.G. Curtis, chairman of the executive committee, Insurance Economics Society of America, warned yesterday that social welfare proposals now before Congress were a direct attack on the Constitution of the United States because the basic concept was socialistic.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- The railroads must have additional locomotives and freight cars if they are to continue to offer adequate transportation, the nation's leading shippers, attending the annual meeting of the National Association of Shippers Advisory Boards, were told today.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Freezing of titles for champions in the armed services today was pronounced as a National Boxing Association policy for the war's duration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A plan for nation-wide periodic inspection of the tires of all operating vehicles was announced today. It will aim to prevent operation of cars if tires need repairs, or mechanical faults are causing unnecessary tire wear. The inspection system, it was also announced, would disclose whether any passenger car owner was attempting to keep or use a tire in excess of the five permitted under gasoline rationing regulations.
In one of the letters printed in THE TIMES last Saturday a gentleman called your attention to the fact that he had seen binoculars suspended from the necks of many racegoers visiting Belmont Park.

A man, his wife and a woman friend were taken to Bellevue Hospital yesterday suffering from malnutrition, having existed on nothing but sleeping pills for five days, according to the story told to the police by one of the victims, a former bookmaker's runner who said he feared to ply his trade because of recent police activity.

AT AN ADVANCED UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, in the South Pacific, Oct. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- Marines defending their Guadalcanal base in the Solomon Islands against stubborn Japanese incursions have captured forty American-built 75-millimeter guns within the last few days.

Despite previous warnings to the food trade, the regional Office of Price Administration here continues to receive numerous complaints from consumers that retailers are requiring the purchase of other merchandise as a condition for the sale of coffee and other scarce items, it was learned yesterday.

Declaring that the city had paid $630,000 since 1934 as a result of fraud and collusion in workmen's compensation claims, William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, joined Mayor La Guardia yesterday in asking Governor Lehman to appoint an impartial investigator to go into the matter.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The increasing demands of military traffic on the railroads and the burden of handling the rising war production will mean that 2,000 more British freight trains must run each week in the coming Winter than were in operation last year, it was estimated here today.

THE Playwrights' Company, now at the beginning of its fifth season, recently notified its stockholders that it has current capital and surplus of $144,934.62. It also has a hit in "The Eve of St. Mark," and quite a hunk of "The Pirate," which are good for capital and surplus, too.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Leon Henderson gave assurance today that ample gasoline would be provided for the needs of farmers and others engaged in essential occupations under the nationwide rationing program.

MEXICO, like other countries at war, has experienced a revival of popular interest in art, Benito Coquet, Director of Adult Education and Esthetics of Mexico, said here last week on the eve of returning to his native country after a brief visit to New York and other American cities.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 17 -Switzerland now harbors 13,000 refugees, according to official figures published today. The proportion of Jews is not indicated. The influx has waned in recent days, chiefly because of the very severe measures taken in frontier districts by both German and French authorities, but it is expected that some French workers avoiding labor conscription may slip through the barriers.

A voters' school to educate women in the importance of the Congress about to be elected will be held for the benefit of women in the entire metropolitan area on Tuesday at the New York Times Hall, 240. West Forty-fourth Street, under auspices of the New York City League of Women Voters.

Normal extracurricular activities will not be discontinued because of the war at the New York University Washington Square College of Arts and Science, Dean Charles Maxwell McConn, who has been a college administrator for the last thirty-two years, said yesterday.
NOTRE DAME, Ind., Oct. 17 -- War has brought important shifts of emphasis to the academic life of the Notre Dame student.

THROUGH the thousands of years that he has walked with man the dog has retained the primitive gifts of his wolf ancestors. He hears infinitesimal sounds that go unheard by human ear. He detects mere ghosts of odors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- Although housewives have 20 per cent more money to spend than last year, they will have to reduce their buying of foodstuffs, M.A. Girshick of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today.

THE record companies have made public their best sellers in the popular field each week, but they have been more reticent about the comparative sales of their more elaborate recordings. Occasionally, however, they make some disclosure of bestseller ranking in the latter category, and it is worth noting for the light it casts on public tastes in music and performers.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Hamilton College rallied in the second half to tie Oberlin, 20 to 20, in a wild game today.

YES, Congress is some good. It is much good. Indeed it is among the greatest goods of our national life, for it is the most distinctive thing about our organized American way and it conditions the freedom of our unorganized way. All governments have executives. They all have courts of a sort.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Wendell L. Willkie made his world-encircling journey of inspection and good-will at his own request and with the approval and assistance of the President, without which, of course, it could not have been undertaken. He was not asked to go, but his suggestion was cordially met, and his personal commission from the President was such that he was intimately received by the heads of foreign States.

Chick Varney is a drug-store restauranteur, and readers of Jerome Barry's earlier story have met him before. In "Leopard Cat's Cradle" he is more or less involved in the mystery over the death of one of Jane Ellin Joyce's admirers.

The Long Island Horticultural Society will hold its eighth annual meeting at the Hotel Wellington on Wednesday, Oct. 21. After luncheon at 1:30 P.M., Dr. William J. Robbins of the New York Botanical Garden will speak on "What Horticultural Science Is Doing to Help Win the War."
BALDWIN, L.I., Oct. 17 -- The Valley Stream Central High eleven gained its fourth straight victory when it defeated Baldwin, 13 to 8, today.

SIMPLE SHMEREL is in essence a figure whom all tellers of folk tales have loved: the dolt who, by sheer luck and his own witlessness, outwits the wise, the rich and the powerful. He embodies the characteristics and adventures of the heroes of a body of traditional Jewish folklore and he bears a name which in certain regions is a byword for simpleton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Federal Government's decision to erase the term "alien enemy" from 600,000 Italian noncitizens within the United States leaves only 311,893 persons here to whom this term can be applied. Of these 263,930 are Germans, 47,963 are Japanese.

IT is bit late in the of a course of history, perhaps, to note that radio is a pervasive and persuasive instrument, capable of altering the lives of listeners almost anywhere. But you are always being reminded of it again, frequently by some bizarre incident out of the past.

An 85-yard punt return by George Pagano for a touchdown in the opening period and his successful conversion from placement enabled Seward Park to topple DeWitt Clinton from the unbeaten ranks yesterday at Randalls Island. The score was 7 -- 6.

The committee on public service in the metropolitan district of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, in recommending that the chamber adopt a resolution endorsing the New York City Coordinating Corporation, designed to increase small plant participation in war production, again called attention yesterday to "the comparatively insignificant share of the nation's war contracts" awarded to "New York the greatest manufacturing city in the country in peacetime."

One minute the counters were loaded with "tricks," otherwise known as gadgets or jewelry adornments. At the next look the counters were bare, divested of their contents by 'teen-age girls who crowded into the Saks-Thirty-fourth Street department store yesterday to take part in the biggest concerted effort yet staged by 'teen-agers in the war stamp drive.

SYDNEY, N.S., Oct. 17 (U.P.) -Survivors of the passenger steamer Caribou, sunk in Cabot Strait Wednesday by an enemy submarine with a loss of 137 Canadians and Americans, told today how the U-boat surfaced after the sinking and plowed ruthlessly through men, women and children struggling in the icy waters.

The Associated Press recalled last night that a dispatch from a United States Army base in West Africa reported Oct. 10 that U-boats were carrying on an intensive campaign off Cape Palmas, which is on the border between the Ivory Coast and Eastern Liberia.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Compulsory education for women in uniform was urged today at the conference of the National Council of Women by Miss Violet Markham, chairman of the government committee that recently investigated morals and living conditions in the three women's services.

LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Fullback Joe Muha shattered Clark Shaughnessy's dream today to build a gridiron empire this year at the University of Maryland as Virginia Military Institute roared to a 29 -- 0 triumph before a homecoming crowd of 5,000.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Amherst defeated a hard-fighting University of Rochester eleven today, 6 to 0. It was the third straight victory for the Jeffs and Rochester's first setback.

THE reported delivery to Washington of the documentary, "Defense of Leningrad," via Wendell L. Willkie's plane, the Gulliver, last week brought a reminder that the Russians not only are holding Stalingrad but are busily making films as well -- including several ambitious ventures.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- While no decision has been made yet by the War Production Board on New York City's application for priorities on $50,000 worth of steel bolts needed for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, it was indicated at the board's offices today that enough of the steel would probably be allocated to the tunnel to safeguard constructions already made and prevent deterioration of the work.

YOU will find an extremely interesting essay by Robert Allerton Parker in the handbook prepared for the surrealist exhibition, now being held as a benefit foe the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies at this organization's headquarters in the old Whitelaw Reid mansion, 451 Madison Avenue.

CHUNGKING, Oct. 17 -- The announcement of the American and British decision to enter into prompt negotiations for the relinquishment of extraterritorial rights in China came as a complete surprise both to official and unofficial quarters in Chungking.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius of Washington are at the Savoy-Plaza.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 (AP) -Billy Hillenbrand, the touted "air express" from Evansville, Ind., delivered three touchdowns through the air today to give Indiana University a clean-cut 19-to-7 victory over the Pitt Panthers in their intersectional battle before a crowd of 20,000.
LAWRENCE, L.I., Oct. 17 -- Undefeated Freeport High made it four in a row by halting Lawrence, unbeaten in two previous games, at Horn Memorial Field today, 14 to 6.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 17 (AP) -Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commander of American forces in Southeast Asia, arrived from Chungking, China, today and said he would see General Sir Archibald Wavell, British Commander in Chief in India, tomorrow.

SOMEWHERE IN WEST AFRICA (Delayed) (AP) -- A vast "underground railway," set up by the Fighting French and the Allies to free fellow-countrymen from the Vichy yoke, is doing a rushing business throughout the great hulk of West Africa.

In a series of three auction sales at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., the Rosenbach Company will liquidate its entire stock of antique furniture and art property. The first of these sales will be held on next Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons. Part two of the collection will be dispersed in November and a month later the final section will be offered at auction.

A second front is being opened by the New York stores. Already an "alert" is being flashed to war-conscious customers to stand by for new patterns and for plastics to replace materials and metals on priority lists. War-model merchandise, accompanied by war-measure slogans, is being launched as fast as ships in a Kaiser shipyard.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- There is a strong suspicion here that the order to shackle British prisoners of war originated in Hitler's own mind in one of his carpet-chewing rages. If that were all, the whole matter could be ascribed to the Fuehrer's delight in cruelty for its own sake.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Georgia Tech's Yellow Jackets, displaying loads of power, a dash of razzle-dazzle and even the ancient Statue of Liberty play, swamped the under-manned Wildcats of Davidson College, 33 to 0, today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The text of the latter of General Marshall, Chief of Staff, to Representative Wadsworth was as follows:
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 17 -- The American Friends of Lafayette will observe their tenth anniversary at a meeting at Lafayette College next Saturday.
LONDON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Reports from the Continent said tonight that German execution squads were continuing their grim "program of pacification" in occupied countries.

"The Vintager," a painting by Valesquez that was completed in 1618 and has been exhibited in Madrid, London and Boston, before coming to this city, was sold at auction yesterday for $15,500, with other items from the collection of the late Herbert M. Sears of Boston.
Except for Henry B. Mosle's letter in THE TIMES of Oct. 4, I have read nothing and heard nothing in recent days which approaches the farm problem in a realistic manner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (Wide World) -- This overcrowded war capital has had a 4,5 per cent decrease in crime.

The pumpkin is a melon, they say who would be scientific, a gourdlike herb of the family Cucurbitaceae -- and any resemblance to cucumber in that name is not coincidental. The pumpkin vine creeps along the ground, an earthy plant, and puts forth blossoms beneath the notice of any one less than a bee or a farmer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Axis propagandists have been busy the last few days predicting a "second front" at Dakar, French West Africa, putting forth in this connection purported descriptions of what they call the efforts of the United States to take over the British Empire, becoming with Africa and including India.

IN the past fortnight London has seen two new plays of quality, one by an established dramatist and the other by a new one of the highest promise. The old hand is Patrick Hamilton, whose "Rope" and "Gaslight" have been seen by you although under slightly changed titles ("Rope's End" and "Angel Street").
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 17 -- The Montclair Teachers eleven showed a strong attack in turning back C.C.N.Y. by 25 -- 0 today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 17 -- Bob Margarita made a 64-yard touchdown run against Lafayette to give Brown a 7-to-0 victory over the Leopards before an Alumni Day crowd of 10,000 today. The victory gave Brown another week's lease on a berth in the country's unbeaten ranks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The War Labor Board declared today that any further wage increases in the automobile industry "at the present time" would be contrary to "the interests of the war effort."

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND ARMY, Lebanon, Tenn., Oct. 17 -- This week's tactical problem of the Second Army's manoeuvres was solved late yesterday on the fourth day of the attempt of the attacking Blue forces to cross the Cumberland River from the south and destroy the defending Red forces to the north.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 17 -- The establishment of a British Army headquarters in Palestine is an indication of Palestine's vital role in the Middle East's war effort. The headquarters is known as "Palestine Base and Lines of Communication Headquarters."

ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, the State adjutant general, representing Governor Lehman at a rally on the Plaza in front of the State Office Building today, urged enlistment by young men of 18 and 19, pointing out that by volunteering they could choose which arm of the service they wished to enter.

WHEN it was published first in England, the title of this book was "Sound and Fuehrer." The present title lacks the satirical twist that the contents call for; moreover, it will suggest German propaganda to those who jump to conclusions.

A survey is being made of the route of the Inter-American Highway from Mexico City to Guatemala. The new road goes through Chalco and Amecameca to Cuautla, thence to Izucar de Matamoros, Huajuapan de Leon, Oaxaca, Tehuantepec and on to Tapachula near the Guatemala border.

FREDERICK LEYPOLDT might have lived to be a prosperous butcher in Germany if he had obeyed his father and followed the family tradition. But he rebelled at the idea and emigrated to America, where he became a respected but financially unsuccessful publisher and bibliographer.

Apropos your editorial of Oct. 3, "Fashions in Smokes," in which you observe that "the pipe is the smoke of meditation," and in answer to which Harry Edeson in a letter published Oct. 11 presses the superior merits of the cigar, I venture to submit the following excerpt taken from an editorial that appeared in The Times of London Oct. 22, 1936, headed "The Pipe."

FOR some time telephonic radio transmissions have been relayed between London and New York via South America during magnetic storms, thus dodging the subarctic storm zone. It seems logical that such a relay system might be arranged for short-wave broadcasts carrying war programs over the Atlantic.

The plight of the investor in utility securities -- particularly common stocks of utility holding companies -- and the confusion of managements with respect to the over-all regulatory provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act were brought strikingly to the fore last week.

Duck and geese hunters going to North Carolina to shoot this Winter need not apply for a Coast Guard identification card, according to an interpretation of existing regulations by Game Commissioner Hinton James of that State.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (AP) -- With a dazzling exhibition of broken field runs by Mickey McCardle and Howard Callanan, Southern California dashed the hopes of Washington State College for an unblemished Pacific Coast Conference title today.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The University of North Carolina loosed terrific power in the second half today and ended Duquesne's 16-game winning streak, 13 to 6, before a homecoming crowd of 14,000.

RADIO-MINDED New Yorkers, both men and women, are now enrolling at city police precinct stations in a local branch of the War Emergency Radio Service. The idea is to form a short-wave network to function in any wartime emergency if normal communication channels are disrupted.

It seems to me THE NEW YORK TIMES'S endorsement of Mr. Bennett for Governor is on untenable grounds. Apparently its theory is that there have been three good Democratic Governors in a row and, furthermore, THE TIMES has a long record of supporting State Democratic administrations, so it will go along now, even though the last two Democratic Governors opposed Mr. Bennett's nomination at the State convention in Brooklyn.

In selecting shrubs for Fall planting, the gardener need by no means confine himself to the varieties that "everybody has." If one will search for them, new ones are to be found, although they are not given as much publicity as the new annuals or roses.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 17 -- Eastern car owners whose supplemental gasoline rations expire next Thursday were directed today to apply to their local War Price and Rationing Boards for renewals. Simultaneously the country's 27,000,000 motorists were asked by Price Administrator Leon Henderson to begin at once the conservation of their tires without waiting until the rationing and conservation program goes into effect Nov. 22.

AFTER the last war Eugene Goossens asked a number of British composers to write a series of fanfares which he introduced at his concerts in London. He is now repeating the experiment in this country, for he has asked some American composers to write fanfares to be introduced at his concerts with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra "as stirring and significant contributions to the war effort.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The decision of the War Department to transfer its Allowance and Allotment branch to Newark, N.J., was prompted not so much by congestion in Washington, although that is a major problem, as by the fact that at Newark the Army will be able to tap a larger reservoir of labor than is available in the capital.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The House of Representatives in the new Congress starting in January is certain to have at least sixty-four new faces.

A discount of 20 per cent in rates for ordinary private passenger automobile bodily injury insurance has been applied for those holding a basic A ratio card, and a 10 per cent discount has been awarded to holders of a supplemental B book, it was announced yesterday by the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters.

Last week a process for "reconstituting" milk, endorsed by the New York Academy of Medicine, was demonstrated in Long Island City by its inventor, Dr. Charles E. North, who has been studying the drying of milk fat and of whole and skim milk for twenty-five years and recombining the fat and the dried skim milk to produce something which, when mixed with water, is as good as milk fresh from the cow and much cheaper.

The second season of Monday Morning Musicales, patterned after the series of concerts entitled Musical Mornings which were established more than half a century ago by the late Albert Morris Bagby, will begin Nov. 23 and continue on successive Mondays through Dec. 7 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 17 -- The mighty Iowa Seahawks -- newest product of the coaching genius of Lieut. Col. Bernie Bierman -- saw their four-game winning streak brought to a dismal end today by a Notre Dame team that did not know it was supposed to lose.
IN its resume of its forty-second season last June the Philadelphia Orchestra disclosed that three of its members had joined the armed forces. Three more have joined up since.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 (AP) -- New York dairymen may be leaving their farms for war plants or quitting business because of rising costs, according to the State's Agricultural Commissioner, but their cows are staying on the job.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- Princeton, clutching at the first of its two scoring chances with the avidity of a drowning man grasping at a straw, managed to stave off mighty Penn before 35,000 stunned fans in Franklin Field today and emerged with the equivalent of a moral victory in a 6 -- 6 tie.

A grabbed leg and saddle cloth sharply changed the outcome of as sensational a horse race as the season has seen when Riverland was disqualified yesterday at Jamaica after finishing the scantest of noses in front of Boysy with 24,022 racegoers cheering these two to hoarseness, since they had l divided much of the betting on the Continental Handicap.
MOSCOW, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Members of the Women's Auxiliary of Union Settlement have take over the pre-opening performance of "The Pirate," a comedy by S.N. Behrman, with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in the leading roles, on the night of Nov. 10 at the Martin Beck Theatre.

Convinced that a breakdown of the entire system of retail food prices is inevitable unless the industry's difficulties are promptly corrected, independent retailers here, dissatisfied with the attitude of the Office of Price Administration, are planning to make formal complaint to the Senate Small Business Committee, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The American forces on Guadalcanal Island, in the Solomons, are facing large numbers of Japanese troops, but "no full-scale land fighting" has yet developed, the Navy Department reported this evening.

Six months ago the average American never heard of Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons. Far from the tourist trails, it slumbered under a tropical sun, visited only by the boats that came to collect the copra harvested by its handful of natives and whites. The island is about the size of Long Island, though shorter and fatter in shape.

LARGE Spanish caves being as scarce and remote as castles, and still harder to get at in these tire-saving days, Director-Producer Sam Wood had an appropriate specimen built on a Paramount sound stage for the finishing up shots of "For Whom the Bell Tolls."

FRENCH music of the past has always been weighed down By certain prejudices: "trifling, elegant or quaint," it has been regarded as a sort of coquette, endlessly humming the Bergere legere to herself and pivoting through the steps of a perpetual minuet, charming and vivacious, it is true, but incapable of experiencing a profound thought or emotion.

There are still some private citizens and companies handling war work who do not fully understand the set-up of priorities for air transportation. And as a result some people entitled to travel by commercial airliners continue to go by rail when on missions closely connected with the war effort.
WE were very much interested in several opinions expressed in your article in the Sunday TIMES Radio Section of Oct. 4 captioned "500-Watt Crisis."

The Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company announced yesterday the hiring of eight women in the last week who will be trained as shipyard workers. These women are taking courses and soon will be working alongside men.

The playing heard from James Friskin at his piano recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall was, as always, scholarly, absolutely sincere and rich in insight. Again, the artist's loftiness of purpose and high ideals were manifested in the works chosen for performance, chief of which was the Aria with Thirty Variations, composed by Bach for his pupil, Johann Theophilus Goldberg, a celebrated harpsichord virtuoso.

Complete transformation of one of the city's largest social groups, diverting the efforts of its 600 members exclusively to war work, is announced today by the Drama Study Club. For the duration of the war, regular club programs, ordinarily held twice monthly through the season, and the assessment of dues have been suspended by action of the board of directors.

IN spite of its obvious defects, this work by one who is both a statesman and a scholar fills a definite need. Of all the books we have about Russia we have no single work that sets out deliberately to tell us the story of the evolution of Russian culture.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 -- The question whether 4,000 employes and former employes of the Ford Motor Company shall be required to pay income tax on back wages totaling $3,000,000 was raised today in a Federal Court suit filed by U.A.W.-C.I.O. lawyers against the United States Collector of Internal Revenue.

WALKING is not only the best way to see a country, to know its people by the roadside, to swap talk with them over the flour barrel, but also to come into certain humors with one's self; to settle certain behind-the-curtain intimacies of the mind (and agreements) that the noisy city makes almost impossible of solution.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- R.P.I. scored in every quarter against the Brooklyn College eleven today for a 47-to-7 victory.

Accounting procedures for affiliated corporations received several new definitions last week when the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals upheld the decision of Vice Chancellor Kays in the suit of Oscar B. Cintas of Havana against the American Car and Foundry Company.

The graduation exercises of the October class of the school for Customs Guards took place Friday afternoon on the steps of the Custom House. Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs, administered the oath of office to fifty-two men.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 17 -- Greenfar's Betty, owned by Charles Henry Mellon of Convent, N.J., and handled by Lawrence MacQueen, won the English springer spaniel novice stake at the Bath County field trials today. In the second series Betty turned in a beautiful retrieve on a wounded runner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Award of Congressional Medals of Honor to two heroes of the Coral Sea battle has been authorized by President Roosevelt.

"DAYS BEYOND RECALL" is an idyllic little tale about Haynes Hollow, a gloomy valley hidden in the dark wooded slopes of the Catskills with a rushing stream echoing through its rocky gorge. A foreword tells how the three big Haynes brothers came to settle there and subdue the hollow into fertile farm lands for their descendants.

One of the interesting things about furs this year is the ingenuity with which they are styled. Mink, Persian, nutria, fox and so on, have always charmed us with their beauty and luxurious warmth. Skill in handling has been developed to the nth degree, so now designers are free to experiment with combinations of fur with handknitting, fabric, paillettes or what-have-you.

The first war-time Navy Day parade down Fifth Avenue will be held next Saturday, Commander Charlese Hann Jr., chairman of the New York Navy Day Observance Committee, 70 Pine Street, announced yesterday.

Three new French stamps are on a cover received here last week from Marseille. A 4-francs brown and carmine marks the centenary of the death of Stendhal, pseudonym of Henri-Marie Beyle (1783-1842), essayist and novelist. The stamp carries his portrait.

"OUTBACK" Australia is one of the most fascinating places in the whole world, and any book about it based on first-hand observation is bound to hold the interest of all readers who can be induced to pick it up. Mrs. Hill's volume, first published in England about five years ago under another title, has the virtues of good journalism.

Just the same, I don't think people who get their idea of farmers from what goes on in Washington can know very much about the farmer or what he is up against.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 17 (AP) -Paced by Sophomore Lou Corriere's running and passing, the University of Buffalo overwhelmed Hartwick College today, 50 to 6. Corriere accounted for four of Buffalo's eight touchdowns.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Oct. 17 (AP) -- To Frank Leahy, hospitalized coach of the Notre Dame football team, the outstanding feature of the 28-0 victory over the Iowa Pre-Flight squad today was the poise of the Irish, especially when backed to their goal line.

AIR WAR: Anything may happen to a flier in wartime. From Russia last week came reports of an unnamed Soviet flier who had to fight off a German attack with a plane full of monkeys. The monkeys spent the time hopping from their seats to the windows and back again.

Activity in most wholesale markets continued brisk last week, although scarcities in many lines hampered forward buying, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

As wartime freight and passenger traffic goes into high gear, women increasingly are moving up to take their places in railroad yards, hangars, bus and truck terminals, which custom once made a man's domain. If the people do not believe in the war they cannot be coerced into creating the necessary effort. A perfunctory acquiescence will not do, as we saw in France.

The Holland-America Line last week observed the completion of seventy years of service in the transatlantic trade, which began with the departure of the liner Rotterdam from the port of Rotterdam on Oct. 15, 1872. That ship was the first of four bearing the same name, a single-screw iron ship of 1,684 gross tons and carrying sail for auxiliary power.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 17 -- Williams ran into unexpected opposition today, but finally hit its stride to defeat Bowdoin, 19 -- 0. The Ephmen cashed in on a Bowdoin fumble for one touchdown, passed for another and scored a third on a 45-yard run-back of a punt by Gunnar Hayes.
With victory meaning a long step toward the Eastern championship of the National Football League, Brooklyn and Washington will collide at Ebbets Field this afternoon, starting at 2:30.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 17 (AP) -- A victory-starved Mississippi State football team, displaying the power that carried it to the Southeastern Conference championship last year, roared back from two setbacks to crush Vanderbilt, 33 to 0, today and knock the Commodores from the undefeated ranks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- Attorney General Biddle asked Congress tonight to enact legislation providing penalties of death or life imprisonment for any one committing acts of sabotage or espionage, or otherwise aiding the enemy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Before the war is ended the name of Guadalcanal may have been forgotten by the public in the play of great forces and events, but the Navy, the Marine Corps and all of the air services will mark it on their battle records as the spot where they began offensive operations against Japan.

In the last war, as well as in the earlier armed conflicts, the Engineers were troops whose task during field operations mostly consisted in maintaining routes of communication.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Grain markets dipped early today, with wheat declining around 1 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade on selling induced by reports that there was little chance that the price ceiling on flour would be raised. However, there was no material pressure thereafter, and later when short-covering developed the market executed a right-about-face and rallied sharply, closing 1/8 to 1/2 cent higher than yesterday.

BUFFALO, Oct. 17 -- Duke's Blue Devils, undisturbed by a tedious all-night train ride, vanquished Colgate, 34 to 0, before a stunned crowd of 18,782 in Civic Stadium today to hand the Red Raiders their first setback.
Army took its objective at Baker Field yesterday with such speed, blocking and tackling as no cadet eleven has displayed in years to crush Columbia by 34 to 6.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17 -- When historians come to write the history of this war, one fact singled out as having utmost importance may be the public's persistent and longtime belief in airpower.

Although Boys High's hard-hitting eleven managed to stop Stuart Goodman twice to halt serious bids for touchdowns, the wearers of the Red and Black were unable to prevent the rugged Abraham Lincoln High left halfback from booting a first-quarter field goal which gave the unbeaten Coney Islanders a 3-2 triumph over Coach Walter Muller's team at Boys High Field yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Scoring a safety on a kick blocked by Len Hansen and Gil Greenberg, Rutgers broke a 7-7 deadlock in the last period to beat Bucknell at the Rutgers Stadium today by 9 to 7.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 -- Navy's football team, three times in scoring territory, made good twice today on the mud-soaked Municipal Stadium gridiron. Yale, finding the midshipmen vulnerable on four occasions, came through only once. As a result, the men from Annapolis outscored the Elis, 13 -- 6, but in so doing proved very little.

The Latin-American Council of the Free World Association, in which many important Latin-American government officials and educators play a prominent part, adopted a resolution and a declaration of principles yesterday in which Latin-American neutrality in the war was condemned as dangerous because the Axis powers were termed as menacing to Latin-American nations as to the Allied countries.

EXCEPT for the terse explanation that they are on convoy duty, the British Admiralty has shrouded in official secrecy the activities of the fifty over-age United States destroyers that were transferred to Britain in September, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- Criticism of American operations in the Solomons was voiced today by Representative John M. Costello of California, a member of the House Military Affairs Committee, who told the House that he feared that the Navy "has attempted to conduct a grandstand play in the Solomon Islands without asking aid of the Army ground and air forces."

May I congratulate you on your splendid editorial of Oct. 13, in which you endorse Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor. You have stated with great force and clarity what seems to me to be the unanswerable reason why he should be elected.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 (Wide World) -- The automobile industry, which has been breaking records almost daily in making war products, is becoming concerned lest the raw materials situation force a leveling off of activity.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- The Union College eleven remained undefeated today, launching an aerial attack to defeat Vermont, 26 to 12.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The massive sailors of the Great Lakes Naval Training Station stopped Wisconsin for two periods today before a couple of sophomores -Jack Wink and Elroy Hirsch -came to the rescue with two of the longest touchdown runs of the season -- one the length of the field -to give the undefeated Badgers a 13-to-7 triumph.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Dr. Lee De Forest, often called the "father of radio," said in an interview today that he was nearing the final phase in the development of a terrain altimeter, which determines the distance above ground rather than sea level, to which aneroid altimeters, now in use, are limited.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The menace of fire struck at this flood-swept Rappahannock River city tonight when a 250,000 capacity gasoline storage tank was ignited and exploded, spewing flames in the direction of several adjacent tanks.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 17 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., addressing Dutchess County Democrats tonight, declared that he had made no political commitments in his campaign as Democratic candidate for Governor and was under no obligations which would embarrass him when elected.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 17 -- Exhaustive statistical data on the University of Michigan's compulsory physical hardening program reveal that the 1,850 participants in the sixteen-week Summer term improved themselves an "average of at least 20 per cent over their previously unsatisfactory condition.''

PANAMA, Oct. 17 -- Americans with a background of years of residence in Latin America who are familiar with the present positions of Argentina and Chile in World War II approve the statement made by Sumner Welles, United States Under-Secretary of State, in Boston in reference to Axis espionage and propaganda bases and believe that he said things that urgently needed saying.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission announced today action designed to increase zinc production at the smelter of the American Smelting and Refining Company at Rosita, Mexico, and to release coke for steel production in Monterrey, Mexico.

OTTAWA, Oct. 17 -- The sinking by Nazi U-boats during the last week of a cargo ship as high up the St. Lawrence River as Metis Beach, and of the Nova Scotia-Newfoundland ferry steamer Caribou with a loss of 137 lives, including sixteen women and fourteen children, has brought the war very near to Canada.

A detachment of officers and enlisted men of the Fighting French Naval Aviation force were feted yesterday afternoon at a reception in the Jade Room of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, on the eve of their departure for training with the air arm of the United States Navy.

THE four Melendy children, that joyous family who entertained themselves and their readers so ingeniously in "The Saturdays," return a year older but not a whit less active. They find green fields, woods and brook, too, to conquer when they move to the country to a ridiculous Victorian house known to all the countryside as The Four-Story Mistake.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Passing and plunging in sensational fashion the University of California at Los Angeles Bruins hurdled another obstacle on their drive toward the Pacific Coast Conference football championship today with a 21-to-0 victory over their keenest rivals, the California Bears, before 35,000 fans.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Spencer Washington, or Spencer Washington Bey, whatever the case may be, was in the Mercer County Jail tonight because Uncle Sam refused to address him by a title conferred by a Moorish sect.

In response to reports that some British seamen temporarily in this country had complained of financial hardships suffered because of money exchange difficulties, officials at the British Consulate said last week that there had been no change in the procedure affecting seamen ashore, and that all of them were "adequately cared for."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The largest and the third largest of the eight Lutheran Church bodies in the United States and Canada today took a long step toward unity of doctrine, cooperation in educational and mission matters, exchange of pastors and the right of laity of one body to partake of the Lord's Supper in churches of the other.

GEORGE GERSHWIN'S "Rhapsody in Blue" is to be heard in the initial concert of Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra on Nov. 1 over WEAF. Inclusion of one of Tin Pan Alley's most famed compositions was not made for "mere novelty," it was stated, but because the maestro had long wanted to perform what he regards as "a great work."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17 -Ohio State University's gridiron juggernaut rolled to its fourth straight conquest of the campaign today, completely frustrating the Boilermakers of Purdue in every department.

Highly interesting news for the American ski world came in the form of two important announcements yesterday. From the Mountain Training Center in Camp Carson, Col., comes word that a brand new ski cantonment is nearing completion in the heart of the Rockies, while the National Ski Association discloses that the War Department once again has granted it the privilege of recommending men for service with the mountain forces.

Manhattan and Detroit will clash in an intersectional football game at the Polo Grounds this afternoon. The kick-off is set for 2:30. The Jaspers will donate their share of the net proceeds to the National Catholic Community Service, an affiliate of the USO.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

Barnard College has introduced for the first time this Fall a special program known as the "American Heritage," designed to present world history from the American point of view. All entering students are now required to take at least one year of history prior to graduation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced today that the Office of Price Administration had authorized it to raise ceiling price limits on all refrigerator egg futures contracts to 37.9 cents a dozen, effective on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Georgetown and Auburn battled to a 6-6 deadlock in a sea of mud before 12,500 spectators tonight. The scoring was confined to the second period.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 17 -- Nearly all areas of Connecticut are suffering from a labor shortage, in some instances so acute that appeals are being made to housewives to take jobs in war industries.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Bottled up in its half of the field for virtually three quarters, Villanova's football team got rolling in the last period tonight to topple Florida from the list of unbeaten and untied teams, 13 to 3, in a major upset at Shibe Park.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Santa Clara's Broncos made another successful raid inside the Pacific Coast Conference today and galloped off with the pelt of the league's defending champions, Oregon State College. The score was 7 -- 0.

The information concerning the real identity of Joseph Shearing is made for the first time in "Twentieth Century Authors," edited by Stanley J. Kunitz and Howard Haycraft, a book which will contain more than 1,850 biographical sketches and portraits of contemporary writers.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 17 -- Corky, J.G. Leiper's two-time winner of the Ormead Cup Steeplechase Handicap, narrowly missed retiring the trophy today when Alcadale, Morris H. Dixon's big brown gelding, forged from behind to beat him in the feature event of the eighty-fourth annual Rose Tree Hunt races.
