KENILWORTH, N.J., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Bill Hilditch and Dave Starr of Galloping Hill, playing on their home course, gained the semi-finals of the first annual New Jersey public links best-ball golf championship today by defeating Jack Loeffler and John Sierge, another home team, 1 up, at the twenty-second hole.
TO learn at first hand just how war conditions have affected book publishing in England, Curce Hitchcock of Reynal Hitchcock will go to England late this month to spend six weeks to two months there.

A tremendous hullabaloo has been raised by one Chicago newspaper about the cases of jaundice that have followed the inoculation of Army recruits with yellow-fever vaccine. Accordingly this department has looked into the Army's supposed negligence with the result that it has been unable to discover anything that savors of negligence or that gives any cause for alarm.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Labor must forego "wage profiteering" during the war and refrain from attempts to take advantage of wartime conditions to push real wages above the prevailing levels, Wayne L. Morse, public member of the War Labor Board, today told a convention of the Printers National Association.

A war strategy board composed of organization leaders to coordinate the activities of millions of women is in the offing. It has been impelled, executives explain, by increasing dissatisfaction over lack of focus and direction from Washington on both consumer problems and the use of woman power in the war program.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 17 -- Handing Tulane its worst football beating in many years ought to be a tough job but it didn't look like it today as Georgia's unbeaten club surged over the Greenies, 40 -- 0, before 18,000 sun-toasted customers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- By a vote of 345 to 16 the House passed today a bill requested Monday by President Roosevelt lowering the draft age to 18 years. Drafting now begins with the group aged 20.

LONDON, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- The Fighting French movement called on France tonight to meet "violence with violence" in "open war" against the Vichy government's efforts to draft French labor for Nazi war factories.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 17 -- Carrying on the Malta blitz for the sixth day, the Axis air forces yesterday almost broke even in planes lost, but failed to do any effective bombing. Although they sought to overwhelm the defenders with as many as sixty fighters on a single mission, the raiders were twice forced to jettison bombs short of their target.

WENATCHEE, Wash., Oct. 17 (AP) -- An emergency army of white collar workers, women and students, marched into the apple orchards of the Wenatchee and Yakima districts this week-end to help save a crop valued at millions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- To speed up the construction of war housing projects the National Housing Agency today authorized the lengthening of the forty-hour work week now called for in contracts and announced that contractors will be reimbursed for the overtime pay involved.

LAUREL, Miss., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Howard Wash, a Negro convicted here yesterday for the murder May 18 of Clint Welborn, a dairyman, was taken from the jail at 1 A.M. today and lynched by a large mob of men. This was the third lynching in Mississippi this week.

THE long anticipated rationing of photographic materials for amateurs has finally arrived, according to word received from the Eastman Kodak Company in Rochester. It is announced that dealers' requirements in film will be a proportion of their usual needs.

"I HAVE," said Mr. Blake, thumping his good right thigh, "just the thing for Wilbur this Christmas." And with that he lifted a twelve-year-old bottle of Scotch from a carton and held it up to the light.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Hope of enduring peace in the world and of better people in nations awakened to a common brotherhood was expressed in speeches here today by Vice President Wallace and Louis Bromfield, Pulitzer prize winning novelist.

The brisk Fall air is an incentive to physical effort, and the Department of Parks of New York City offers the car-less New Yorker a chance to exercise his muscles at his chosen sport within subway or bus distance of his front door.
COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Texas Christian's Horned Frogs thundered on among the nation's unbeaten, untied football teams today over the hull of once mighty Texas A. and M.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- Regrouped in a narrow salient driven between Stalingrad's defense forces, the Germans now are attacking northward and southward parallel with the Volga, and though the Russians, who withdrew from an industrial settlement Thursday evening in good order, are putting up the most stubborn resistance, the besiegers, at great cost, have made a further advance in one direction.

Trade source poured yesterday into the cotton-futures market heavy price-fixing orders against stocks of cotton purchased recently by the government for lend-lease purposes, but the demand was met by equally strong hedge sales. Under this two-sided activity contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange failed to react decisively, prices holding within a narrow range.

A five-year dispute between the De Nobili Cigar Company, formerly of 35-11 Ninth Street, Long Island City, and Local 647, Cigar and Tobacco Workers Union, C.I.O., finally has been settled, Alan F. Perl, regional attorney for the National Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday.

After two rounds of the annual tournament for the individual championship of the Interscholastic Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club, the group leaders yesterday were Marcy Hanft of Thomas Jefferson High School, Henry Nattens of De Witt Clinton, Leon Lipschitz of James Monroe, David Levinson of Abraham Lincoln and Max Ginsburg of Newtown.

The report of Ernest Brown, British Minister of Health, speaks of the "stubborn good health" of England and Wales, despite food rationing and a shortage of physicians, and attributes the showing to "a spirit of cooperation for the common good." That there should have been no major epidemic, though hundreds of thousands were crowded during air raids in shelters that were anything but sanitary, is certainly cause for gratification.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- French Chief of Government Pierre Laval's armed forces killed forty Frenchmen at Lyon and fifteen at Amberieu and wounded 200 at each place yesterday in attacks on crowds demonstrating violently against the shipment of French workers to Germany, The Times, London, reported today in a dispatch from the French frontier.

Veronicas or Speedwells grow in such a variety of heights and designs that there is a place for them not only in the garden proper, where their graceful spires rise like tall blue church steeples, but in the rock and wall garden as well. They vary in size, habit of growth and adaptability, for some prefer a full sunny position while others grow well in partial shade.

CIVILIANS are working hard, long, with concentration. Men and women are doing jobs that take strong muscles, alert minds, healthy nerves. Some toil during the night. Others learn skills that are new and unfamiliar. And each has to be more adaptable, more energetic, more efficient than ever before the war.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Caked in mud, the football teams of Penn State and Cornell trudged off Schoellkopf Field today with only a scoreless tie to show for sixty minutes of futile football.

Although Dec. 17 will not be here for some weeks, I believe it would be of inestimable service to our war effort if President Roosevelt were to proclaim Dec. 17 Valley Forge Day and if due preparations were to be made to celebrate that day fittingly.

A mid-Autumn fete that has received a large advance subscription from members of society, including many patrons of music actively interested in the support of the New Opera Company, will take place Tuesday afternoon when a balloon party and tea dance will be given at the Stork Club under the auspices of several committees representing the opera organization.

SO seldom do the great majority of those of us who have remained in civilian life get a revealing glimpse of the actual horrors of the war at sea that I believe many of your readers will be interested in the following excerpts from a letter written by a young woman giving an account of her experiences when her ship was torpedoed on its way to Bermuda recently.

The Junior League of New York has just accepted into its organization as provisional members nearly one hundred young women of society who recently completed an intensive training course designed to acquaint them with social problems in a democracy at war, as reflected in the public and private community services in the city.
CANTON, N.Y., Oct. 17 (AP) -- St. Lawrence University upheld its 1942 scoreless offensive record today by losing to the Cortland Teachers eleven, 26-0.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- The police have extended the ban on bingo to games played under church auspices, in line with the new anti-gambling drive of City Manager William A. Walsh, it was disclosed today by the pastors of two of the three Catholic churches here that conduct weekly bingo games.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The story of how a Carrollton, Ohio, Red Cross worker cheated death to help wounded and dying marines in the Solomons was related today by a colleague.

Meeting in New York City for the first time since the organization was founded in 1912, the Investment Bankers Association of America will hold its annual convention tomorrow and on Tuesday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Because of the pressure of war-time conditions, the usual four-day business sessions, which normally attract several hundred investment bankers from all parts of the country, will be telescoped into a two-day gathering.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Proof of the change that golf is undergoing as a result of the war was provided today when Lieutenant Richard D. Chapman of the Army Air Forces and W.B. (Duff) McCullough of Huntingdon Valley went down in defeat in the first round of the fifth annual Geist Memorial Tournament at the Seaview Country Club.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- A program aimed at the curbing of prostitution and venereal diseases in the United States and its possessions through the efforts of the 2,000,000 members of the General Federation of Women's Clubs was started today at the meeting of its board of directors.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Flood waters in river basins of three States ebbed slowly today, leaving behind five dead, many millions of dollars of property destruction and high-water records.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The board of directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs today asked that women receive more representation on policy-forming committees of government departments and agencies.

In view of the rapid decline in installment accounts receivable resulting from Regulation W, more than 95 per cent of corporate installment sellers will be able to qualify or the tax relief offered to them under Section 736 of the current tax bill, which received final approval by House and Senate conferees on Friday, it was estimated yesterday.

Confidence in the North African situation was expressed by R.G. Casey, British Minister of State in the Middle East, according to the British radio as heard yesterday in New York by the Columbia Broadcasting System and reported by The United Press.

Men have dreamed of a highway to Alaska from the United States, but there were a lot of obstacles in the way, mountains and muskeg, that mushy stuff that goes down to the freezing level. Now the war has brought it about. The Alaska Highway will be ready for use near Dec. 1. It is so important it has been called the "American Burma Road."

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- French Chief of Government Pierre Laval's latest efforts to enforce the migration of skilled labor to Germany have been met by increasing resentment and a rising tide of sabotage and strikes, according to information reaching here today.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
IN a new wing of the White House, built since the war started and opened, a former Justice of the Supreme Court is organizing the greatest experiment in planned economy in the history of the country.
LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Ursinus stopped six Franklin-Marshall threats within the 20-yard line today to open its football season in a surprise scoreless deadlock with the diplomats.

THE metropolitan championships begin here today with a two-session contest for non-masters' pairs and will continue through the week. All events will be played at the Park central Hotel, with afternoon sessions beginning at 2 o'clock and night sessions at 8:30.

A HIGHLY significant point was made by John Grierson last week in a talk before a session of the Institute of Inter-American Affairs. Speaking about the service which our films are lending or can lend to the furtherance of international amity, Mr. Grierson, who is Film Commissioner of Canada, said: "We think we satisfy friendship with other and different countries if we find in them the things that we ourselves enjoy.

The failure of many owners of commercial vehicles to fill out and return their applications for certificates of necessity may result in their inability to operate those vehicles after Nov. 15. A reminder to owners urging to return their applications promptly was issued yesterday by William J. Clark, local regional manager of the Division of Motor Transport, Office of Defense Transportation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 17 -- All rubber produced in Brazil has been placed under the exclusive control of the "Rubber Credit Bank," with the right to seize stocks if it is found that they are abnormally large or if their destination is considered questionable.

WHEN Bruno Walter begins his engagement as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra Thursday night, he has scheduled on his initial program the first performance of John Alden Carpenter's Second symphony.

Henry J. Kaiser, the West Coast shipbuilder who has astounded the country with the speed of his ship construction, disclosed yesterday in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria that he had steadily reduced the number of man-hours required to build Liberty ships and that his record vessel -- launched in ten days and delivered in fourteen -- had been completed with 375,000 man-hours of labor.

While retail trade was spotty last week, Columbus Day sales drew excellent consumer response in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Oklahoma's Sooners finally learned the secret of scoring today and applied the lesson so spiritedly they whitewashed Kansas, 25 to 0, for the first Sooner victory of the season. A slim crowd of 4,805 saw the game.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Fair Weather, a shifty daughter of Sickle-Fairday, raced to a popular victory in the Keeneland Special, the 2-year-old filly race which featured today's program at the Keeneland track. Fair Weather earned $5,175 for her owner, Joseph E. Widener.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The National War Labor Board moved today to prevent "wildcat" strikes which interfere with war production by adopting a three-point program designed to stop such labor troubles.

PERCENTAGE-WISE, retail sales have started to show soaring increases over last year now that comparisons are being made with the quiet period that followed the "beat-the-tax" spurt of 1941. More evidence is discovered, too, of another revival of "scare buying" by the public, induced, it is suggested, by the informal rationing of coffee, bacon and other food items.

PUBLISHERS have been chary this year of sending out the usual advance lists of the books they expected to issue in the Fall. Even if they had succeeded in getting the sheets of these volumes printed off by the Spring or early Summer it was uncertain when they would be able to get them bound, so they hesitated to raise hopes that might be disappointed.

Announcing that members of the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street, had pledged to buy through the synagogue $235,000 of war bonds, Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein in his sermon there yesterday declared that "it is high time to stop criticizing adversely the spirit of America."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17 -- More than 100 students at Yale University are enrolled in classes in Japanese, Russian and Malayan for the Fall term. The classes, part of the all-out effort to equip Yale men for important Jobs in the war effort, are being taught by streamlined language methods in intensive sessions.

CAMP LIVINGSTON, La., Oct. 17 (AP) -- An American version of England's Commandos, a Swimmando Corps, has been developed here on the marsh lands of Central Louisiana, the Twenty-eighth (Pennsylvania) Infantry Division announced today.

JAIPUR, India, Oct. 14 (delayed) -- When the stream of American tourists flows back to this famed "Pink City" after the war they are going to find it more thoroughly transformed and improved than New York after Robert Moses got through with it.

Earlier impressions in retail circles that an inventory limitation order would not be issued by WPB changed last week into an apparently growing belief that such an order would be put into effect early next year.

As a prelude to today's worldwide observance of Mission Sunday, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman made an appeal last night over a special National Broadcasting Company program for support of the Catholic missionaries who despite the war have remained at their far-flung posts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Bureau of Ships of the Navy Department was reorganized today to put younger men in its administrative posts. The bureau has charge of the building and maintenance of ships.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The "Fighting Illini," conquerors of mighty Minnesota, proved their right to carry the traditional Illinois battle cry by downing Iowa, 12 to 7, today to remain among the nation's top undefeated football teams.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Syracuse availed itself of three Holy Cross errors to defeat the Crusaders at football today, 19 to 0.

"Russian soldiers don't go in much for goose-stepping and other such fanciness," says an American lately stationed in Moscow. "Marching down the street they stroll rather than parade. In almost any squad of fours are tall and short, side by side, and no one bothers greatly to keep line or step.

Each season new chrysanthemums from various introducers appear on the scene. Some of these fall by the wayside, but just as many remain, so that it becomes more and more difficult to select the best varieties for which one can find garden space, especially with vegetables coming to the forefront as they must.
ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Andover won a hard-fought contest from the Harvard freshmen eleven today, 13 to 7. The game was marked by powerful offensive drives and weak defensive play on both sides.

Captain Robert C. Lee, who was re-elected as national head of the Propeller Club of the United States at its convention last week, declared in his annual report that the "duty" of the shipping organization to carry on its educational campaign and its program of support for the merchant marine was more evident than ever, and that its role in the national economy was steadily increasing in importance.

BACK to the Ozarks Marguerite Lyon now takes the readers of her earlier book and no doubt many besides -- the Ozarks, where "a hand-made roof, like a hand-made quilt, is true folk art" and where the invitations to a party are a happy and sociable as the party itself -- since there are no telephones and every invitation means a personal call.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 17 -- In the past Summer the response of Mount Holyoke undergraduates to a world at war was a "vacation" spent in constructive work, in jobs in many fields and in study.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Complete agreement was reached today by the House and Senate conferees on the greatest tax bill in history. The bill, as finally reported, will yield close to $9,000,000,000.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- Boston College climbed over the toughest obstacle of its 1942 football journey today by defeating Lieut. Comdr. Jim Crowley's North Carolina Naval Pre-Flight Cloudbusters, 7 -- 6, before 25,000 at Fenway Park.

War bonds totaling $1,100,000 have been sold by members of the City College student body and faculty since the attack on Pearl Harbor, it was announced yesterday by Professor Richard B. Morris, director of the college's Civilian Defense Council, City College, according to Treasury Department officials, now leads all other colleges and universities in the State.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Three hundred eighty-six medals were pinned on American air heroes at an advanced operational base today in the greatest mass presentation of awards for valor in the United States Army's brief but colorful history in the Southwest Pacific.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 17 -Details regarding the execution on Oct. 6 of the first ten victims of the state of emergency in Trondheim are reported today by the Malmoe newspaper Arbetet, which, although unable to reveal the source, guarantees its reliability.
SHIFTING from the collegiate gridiron to the paid post-graduate field, one team stands out. That's right, the Great Big Bears.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A Navy Department communique:

From developing a program for China's child war victims to supervising health activities for 20,000 Japanese at a war relocation project was the shift made recently by Miss Sally Lucas Jean. Miss Jean was chairman of the children's division of the China Aid Council when she was called by the War Department to direct health work among the Japanese evacuees at a 72,000-acre camp in Poston, Ariz.

August Dijan, acting secretary of the Yugoslav Officers and Seamen's Union, said yesterday that negotiations that have been going on in London between representatives of his union, the Yugoslav Government and the Yugoslav ship-owners were nearing a successful conclusion.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 17 (AP)--Malta's stalwart defenders bagged eight Axis planes during daylight today to raise their total to 115 so far this month in the Mediterranean theatre's greatest aerial assault, described by Rome as intended to screen movements of reinforcements to North Africa.

Rising above the clamor of "men first," in the Board of Education's wartime vocational education program, is a greatly expanded schedule for retraining women displaced from consumer industries. A plan to recruit 1,500 women immediately for a general machine trades course is being undertaken with the cooperation of local union offices at the Women's Trade Union League, 247 Lexington Avenue.

DENVER, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A demand that agriculture be given priorities co-equal and co-ordinate with the arms and shipbuilding program as to manpower, machinery and fertilizers was made in a resolution adopted by the National Reclamation Association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Fowler V. Harper, deputy War Manpower Commissioner, said tonight that there was "no cause for public hysteria" over manpower and that the nation was successfully harvesting one of the largest crops in history despite the farm labor shortage.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The Vichy government has given French citizenship rights to 500 of the Nazis' Gestapo agents in France who will be engaged in rounding up French workers to be sent to Germany, according to information received here today by the Fighting French news agency.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided at a solemn mass of thanksgiving yesterday morning in the Church of St. Raymond, Castle Hill and Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, opening the four-day centenary celebration of the founding of the parish.

WASHINGTON, Oct 18 -- The approach of the Congressional elections two weeks hence brought today from two national leaders, Herbert Hoover and Philip Murray, appeals to all voters to register their wills on the candidacies offered as an indication that the democratic process still rules in America and that the determination to achieve victory is strong.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Big Gary Famiglietti provided most of the horsepower for the Chicago Bears' strong ground attack today, scoring twice and ripping up huge yardage to escort the National champions to a 26-to-7 victory over the New York Giants in a National Football League game.

The disunity and racial prejudice that are prevalent among nations today and the theory of isolation or self-sufficiency are the result of mankind forgetting the existence of God, Mrs. Harper Sibley of Rochester, a member of the National Preaching Mission, declared m a sermon yesterday morning in St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Prices for all deliveries of soy beans dropped last week to the lowest levels of the season on the Board of Trade here, the December going into new low grounds for any future in about a year. Stop-loss orders were uncovered on the way down.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Officials of the Blue and Gray Association, sponsors of the annual North-South all-star football game, today announced completion of the South's coaching staff and acceptances by several star players of bids to play in the classic.

Fifteen thousand children from 200 welfare institutions in the metropolitan area will be guests at a special performance of the rodeo in Madison Square Garden this afternoon. Harold J. Dibblee, vice president of the Garden, will welcome them.

Addressing a congregation that included doctors, dentists and pharmacists, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday that we were realizing more fully the close relations between the healing art and religion, the close cooperation between the priest and the physician.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 18 -- The Wheatley Hills trio of Willie Klein, Miss Evelyn Odom and Bob Odom had a combined score of 229 -- 10 -- 219 to win the team competition in the Army Emergency Relief tournament at the Sound View Golf Club today, but the gallery's interest and plaudits went to a special exhibition match.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Japanese forces on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons, though harried by our planes, are being disposed for a strong attack on our airfield, the Navy said today. Many Japanese ships were reported to be still concentrated in the Buin-Shortland area, 300 miles northwest of Guadalcanal.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Active contracts for future delivery of corn managed last week to hold slightly above the season's lowest prices on the Board of Trade here, but the market showed a heavy undertone generally, scattered liquidation appearing on the upturns.
CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The aircraft carrier Princeton, fourth ship to bear that name, was launched with extreme informality today at the yards of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation here.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- The question of real estate tax assessments has been put to Thomas E. Dewey and John J. Bennett Jr., candidates for Governor, as well as candidates for the Legislature, by the State Association of Real Estate Boards.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- The Germans, sending fresh divisions into action at Stalingrad, are pressing southward parallel to the Volga in an attempt to seize another of those large, sprawling buildings behind whose walls the Russians have established powerful fire points.

Better manned and obviously the stronger unit throughout, the University of Detroit defeated Manhattan, 21 to 7, before 12,500 fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday to continue among the nation's unbeaten and untied football teams.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- The American position in the Solomon Islands became increasingly critical tonight as the Navy reported enemy naval and troop concentrations pointing to a "strong assault" against the island's vital airport, now held by the United States forces.

VICHY, Oct. 18 -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France dated Sept. 17 shows no important change in the credits granted the securities market for the decrease of 395,000,000 francs in discounts was compensated within a few millions by an increase in bills bought on the market and by thirty-day advances on bonds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The first meeting of the top executive personnel of the war production drive headquarters, through which 1,650 labor-management committees will seek to sustain and increase war production, will be held here tomorrow.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 18 -- A plea that men who have served prison sentences, if "physically, mentally and morally healthy," and selected men now in prison be permitted to fight for America was voiced here tonight by Lewis E. Lawes, former warden of Sing Sing prison, at the opening session of the annual Congress of Correction.

The Canadian lollar displayed a strong undertone last week, resulting in a recovery of all of the loss sustained in the preceding week. Buying was mainly for the account of those preparing to meet mo.nthend commitments which lifted remittance on the Dominion to 88.06 cents, on Thursday, a gain of a full cent over anearly-week low. The close at 87.87 cents' reflected a net gain of 7 cent over the preceding week.

Only by uprooting the causes of war and being prepared to make as great sacrifices in peace time as in war can the world expect to avoid war and usher in the practice of the teachings of Jesus, the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, declared, in a sermon yesterday morning.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18 -- Harvard University announced today the names of the fourteen trade-union representatives who have been selected by their unions to study for nine months as Labor Fellows under the auspices of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, the Littauer School of Public Administration, and the Department of Economics.

Revocation last week of the WPB cosmetic order, L-171, is not an invitation to the feminine public to squander its beauty products. Valuable materials and still more valuable man-hours that go into their making will continue to be strictly limited.

With emphasis shifting from the home to the factory in the scrap metal drive, the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office will start today to concentrate on the household salvage of rubber, fats, rags, tin cans and silk and nylon hosiery.

DOUGLAS SOUTHALL FREEMAN, distinguished editor of The Richmond News-Leader and Pulitzer-crowned author of a monumental four-volume biography of Robert E. Lee, is a man who has hold of a bear by the tail and can't let go. His particular bear is the history of the War Between the States as it was fought in Virginia (Mr. Freeman is an impartial historian, but a Southerner, too, and naturally wouldn't dream of calling it the Civil War).

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 -- Edward M. Borger, president of the Peoples Natural Gas Company, has received a leave of absence to join the American Red Cross Field Service abroad as an ambulance driver, the company's board of directors said today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- The wheat market has been unsettled by the placing of a price ceiling on flour by the Office of Price Administration, which price is estimated to have been figured on the basis of the national free-grain average return to farmers of $1.02 3/4 a bushel for wheat as of Sept. 15, or about 76 per cent of the so-called parity level.

Investment banking is an indispensable function in the economy of the United States and the full effort of the Investment Bankers Association of America is pledged to assist the government in winning the war, John S. Fleck, president of the association, said here yesterday on the eve of the association's thirty-first annual meeting, which will be held today and tomorrow in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Reeling off 71 yards in eight plays in the third quarter, the University of Scranton came from behind today to beat Canisius, 7 to 2, before 3,000. It was Scranton's third victory in four games and its second triumph over the Buffalo eleven in a home-and-home series.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Dynamite lies ahead of undefeated, untied Illinois in its surprising gridiron drive.

THAT'S better than a fair Army football team that Earl the Red Blaik is sending into the scrimmages this Fall. The Kaydets showed everything except a flashy forward passing attack against Columbia and they didn't need to show that, even if they had it.

VICHY, Oct. 18 -- To check a rise in prices of stocks in Germany a recent law there made it obligatory for owners of securities to declare possession of certain shares and to sell their holdings if an official demand was presented to them.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- A committee of ten distinguished American psychiatrists declared tonight that the drafting of 18 and 19 year old youths would not impair "the future mental integrity" of the country.

Thanking all the citizens of New York for their enthusiasm and help during the household scrap metal campaign, Mayor La Guardia yesterday characterized the collection of more than 130,000 tons of scrap as "a magnificent job."

Subway riders will heave a sigh of relief now that the new reflecting "silver bowl" lamps are being installed in trains. Twice as much illumination will be provided at seat level. Because they are plated with silver, copper and aluminum the new lamps will do much to rob trains of their present funereal aspect.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -- As a result of the splendid job of collecting scrap metal done by the country's newspapers, there is no evidence now of any steel mills closing down, Lessing J. Rosenwald, War Production Board conservation head, declared here today.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Netherlands Government here broadcast a warning to the people in its homeland tonight that Allied fliers intended to make vigorous attacks on all forms of transport in the Netherlands.

The audience which packed Carnegie Hall and overflowed upon the stage when Bronislav Huberman played last night in that auditorium welcomed the violinist with an enthusiasm that left no doubt of its regard and appreciation of his art.
OMAHA, Oct. 18 (AP) -- William M. Jeffers, national rubber conservation director, said in an interview here today that "people travel too much and they must stop it."

Women of Italian origin in the United States will take an increased part in volunteer war work as a result of Attorney General Francis Biddle's action in freeing 600,000 Italians in this country from the "enemy alien" classification, Mrs. Rosa Rudami Fox predicted yesterday.

Apartment houses and all multiple dwellings, office and other commercial buildings and institutions other than those for children, the sick and the aged will be cut 33 1/3 per cent below their normal fuel oil requirements, Joel Dean, director of the OPA fuel rationing division, announced yesterday in explaining the details of the rationing system to 500 fuel oil dealers at the Hotel Commodore.

Declaring "this is the beginning of a new age," and "Christ is the great word for this hour," the Rev. Fred Robert Tiffany, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Richmond Hill Baptist Church, 114th Street and Ninety-first Avenue, Queens, described today's need of "a great faith produced by a great word."

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Harvesting of corn is under way in many sections of the Corn Belt, especially in areas where the grain matured early and escaped with little or no damage from frost in September. The moisture content in the grain in the favored sections is still relatively high, but the quality of the arrivals indicates that after a period of dry weather users of corn will have no cause for complaint.

Charles Appleton and A.M. Goldstein of New York won the non-masters' or "amateur" pair championship in the first day's play of the annual metropolitan contract bridge championship tournament, which opened last night at the Hotel Park Central.
AN ADVANCED UNITED STATES AIR BASE, in the South Pacific, Oct. 4 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The "sea-bees" are hard at work in the South Pacific islands.

Universal apparently rounded up all the juveniles on its contract list when it set about making "Get Hep to Love," now playing at the Palace. There is Donald O'Connor, looking natural enough to pass as the lad next door; there is Peggy Ryan, a smart little comedienne; there is that jitterbug aggregation known as The Jivin' Jacks and Jills and, of course, there is the studio's young soprano, 14-year-old Gloria Jean.

The New York City League of Women Voters will sponsor two sessions of a "voters' school" tomorrow in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. Under the title "You and Your Congress," the sessions will be conducted from 10 A.M. to 12:15 P.M. and from 2 to 4 P.M.

To a male watching the imminent approach of meatless days one of the most disturbing elements in the preparations is the frenzied search for meat substitutes. Many a housewife's brow is already furrowed with this problem, and it can be assumed that she already has in her kitchen files a thick folder of recipes for quaintly named dishes which are neither fish, fowl nor flesh.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Delegates attending the thirteenth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America tonight observed the 200th anniversary of the arrival in this country of Henry Melchior Muhlenberg, Patriarch of Lutheran churches in America.

The German High Command announced yesterday that German troops attacking in Stalingrad had captured all of the Red Barricade gun works and, after repelling heavy Soviet attacks, had driven the Russians out of the adjoining city area.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- E.H. Stubblefield resigned today as warden of Stateville Penitentiary, scene of the recent sensational escape of the gangster, Roger Touhy, and six other long-term desperadoes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Eliminate the purchase of one can of canned foods every week and you will make a substantial contribution to the war effort, Charles L. Sheldon, chief of the Containers Branch of the War Production Board, said today.
EATONTOWN, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Fort Monmouth's football squad battled to a 14-14 tie on Frawley Field, Camp Charles Wood, today in a fast game against the Manhattan Beach Coast Guard eleven.

Until a few months ago the average American had never heard of Guadalcanal. Yet today average Americans in the uniform of our armed forces are fighting in that far-off island of the Pacific a major and perhaps decisive battle. We cannot, for understandable reasons, obtain many of the details of the fight that is hourly developing there.

The whole-hearted cooperation of hotels, restaurants and other eating places in the city will make possible a flying start tomorrow on a sweeping program of meat conservation, geared to the rationing formula to be adopted by the Federal government early in 1943, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People" from his desk at City Hall.

LONDON, Oct 18 (U.P.) -- Fighting French sources said tonight that Vichy had sent most of France's modern warships to Dakar under German pressure, coinciding with persistent Nazi predictions that an Allied attack on that base was imminent.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 18 -- Lifting the veil of altruistic interests professed by National Socialist spokesmen in the "new ordering of Europe," Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Reich Minister of Propaganda, in an open-air speech to a gathering in Munich this afternoon, made at the same time an almost frantic appeal to the population of the birthplace of national socialism to continue as a "shining example of patriotic sentiment, national unity, perseverance and strength."
DES MOINES, N.M., Oct. 18 (AP) -- A four-motored Army bomber crashed atop Sierra Grande Peak in northeastern New Mexico, killing at least eleven persons, it was reported today.

Buying of cotton by mills and the trade more than offset hedge sales in the futures market last week and the market ended on the up side after fluctuating irregularly. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts showed net gains of 3 to 12 points, following losses of 16 to 18 points in the preceding week.

The Grand-Lafayette Corporation has purchased for investment from the United Equities, Inc., the six-story loft building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 372 Broome Street. J. Edgar Leaycraft Co. was the broker.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND ARMY, Lebanon, Tenn., Oct. 18 -- Major Gen. King Dai-fung of the Chinese military mission has followed the manoeuvres of the Second Army in this area with admiring and sometimes envious eyes.

Revisions of cargo war risk rates on a number of important trade routes are announced by marine underwriters here. The revisions involve both increases and decreases and represent a revaluation of potential war risk hazards. Generally, the reductions are on certain voyages confined to the Western Hemisphere, while the increases are on voyages to Africa and the East and Far East.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 -- Despite the recent step-up in production of steel, new orders continue to pile into the offices of the steel manufacturers. Little or no headway has been made on backlogs, and fresh business in the last two weeks has been somewhat greater than in the same period last month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- With more than a million farm workers taken into the services or diverted to industry in twelve months, and with new agricultural machinery almost impossible to obtain, threats are growing of serious shortages of essential foods next year.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Only two years have passed since the battle of Britain was raging, but already the exploits of the United States Flying Fortresses and Britain's Lancasters have called into question the lessons it taught. Chief among these was the tenet that daylight bombing in the face of strong fighter defenses was an extravagant expenditure of men and machines compared with the damage the bombers could do.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- More women who have little or no need for additional income or who have family responsibilities are going to have to take training and enter war industries if war production is to be maintained, Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, deputy commissioner of education, said today in a summary of results of two years and two months of training offered by the State's vocational schools.

A commission of women leaders of labor, management, education and civic affairs has been appointed by State Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller to advise her concerning the growing problems of women in war industry, it was announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 18 -- George Rowbotham, young Llanerch golfer, today won the coveted Clarence H. Geist Memorial Trophy by defeating Bill Hyndman of Old York Road, 2 and 1, in the final round of the tournament at the Seaview Country Club.

For ten days Detectives Patrick Hogan and William Mulligan of the East Fifty-first Street Station have spent most of their time shadowing a notorious sneak thief in the Fifth, Park and Madison Avenue district above Fifty-first Street.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 18 -- Field trial champion Wakes Wager of Greenfair, owned by Major and Mrs. Joseph C. Quirk of Hempstead, L.I., and handled by Lawrence MacQueen, added to his imposing array of laurels by winning the open all-age stake for English springer spaniels as the Bath County field trials were concluded today.
OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The St. Bonaventure College football team won its first game of the season today, downing the Fort Totten Army eleven, 7 to 0.

Launching a better type of stock company this evening at the Morosco is Ronald T. Hammond, with the cooperation of Lee Shubert. Their first offering will be John Drinkwater's comedy "Bird in Hand," which has been slightly "pruned" for this occasion and which Mr. Hammond directed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 -- Sir Cedric Hardwicke has been signed by Twentieth Century-Fox to play Colonel Lanser, the Nazi commander, in the screen version of John Steinbeck's "The Moon Is Down." Orson Welles, Charles Laughton, Alfred Lunt and George Sanders had been mentioned for the assignment.

With the fact in view of twenty to thirty million people returning to civilian production and industry upon the close of the war, our high school youth in the first two years are rightfully concerned with their own prospects of placement. To us adults this concern may be a spurious matter when the job at hand is to fight the war and achieve victory, but to the youngsters it is of vital importance.

ISTANBUL, Oct. 17 (Delayed) -- Field Marshal Slavko Kvaternik, former Croat War Minister, is held incommunicado in a Zagreb prison following his mysterious dismissal from the Cabinet. The Marshal's half-Jewish wife committed suicide and their son Eugen Kvaternik, Ustashi terrorist and former Zagreb police chief, has been removed from office, according to foreign sources that received the information direct from Croatia.
MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A Navy Department communique:

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The stock markets experienced a distinct slowing down in activity last week. The substantial advance in the preceding fortnight was due to be followed by a pause for consolidation, and this has occurred. Although the volume of business contracted, there was, however, no loss in strength.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Office of Price Administration today warned manufacturers, producers and wholesalers against suggesting retail prices in any manner, even under a State Fair Trade Contract, without putting the retailer on clear notice that the suggested fair trade prices might be changed only if they did not exceed the retailer's ceiling price as determined under OPA regulations.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- Orders to install additional protection at more than 600 grade crossings in the State have been sent to forty-four railroads, the Public Service Commission announced today. All the crossings are protected by gates or watchmen, but new safeguards have been ordered, because in the last two years accidents at grade crossings have increased, reversing a sharp decline in the years 1929 to 1939, when many crossings were eliminated.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Oct. 19 -- Allied heavy bombers, supporting the embattled American forces on Guadalcanal, made four large-scale attacks last night on Japanese naval units at Buin, enemy base on Bougainville Island in the northern Solomons, and were believed to have hit three cruisers and several other vessels, a communique said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Army medium bombers scored multiple hits on two Japanese destroyers Friday northwestward of Kiska in the Aleutians, the Navy reported in a communique this afternoon. Pressing home the attacks over a period of forty-five minutes, the Marauder planes (Martin B-26 two-engined bombers) scored five hits on one of the enemy destroyers and four on the other.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals smashed a two-game losing streak by pushing over a fourth-period touchdown to defeat the Detroit Lions, 7 -- 0, today in a National Football League game before 14,100 fans at Briggs Stadium. Fullback Bob Morrow ran 5 yards for the lone score.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Hedging pressure from the Northwest depressed December oats to the lowest price of the season last week on the Board of Trade, and the market showed little disposition to rally. The quality of Northwestern oats is said to be less favorable than that from the central West, but comparatively little of the latter is being offered.

The controversy over Mayor La Guardia's proposal to buy the Staten Island Edison Company plant for not more than $16,500,000 was widened yesterday when former United States Attorney Charles H. Tuttle announced his chairmanship of a committee of thirty-six groups formed to oppose the step.

Hadassah and the Zionist Organization of America ended their concurrent conventions yesterday by holding a joint mass meeting at the Manhattan Center at which Mayor La Guardia warned against any attempt to re-establish "tariff barriers and regulations" in the post-war discussions, and declared that there should not be "a protectorate in any place in the world."
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 18 -- Mrs. O'Leary's cow did start the $197,000,000 Chicago fire, the son of the man who butchered the cow declared today.

In Agnes de Mille's "Rodeo," the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo has a hit on its hands. Its fourth performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night kept the large audience laughing, clapping its hands to accompany the square dances and cheering lustily at the final curtain.

With the halting of offshore fishing by boats carrying passengers for hire, it is expected that some repercussions will be heard in the New York area. A meeting of boat captains will be held at Sheepshead Bay tonight to file an appeal with the captain of the port.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- The joint Army-Navy pennant for outstanding performance in war production will be awarded to thirty-four more industrial plants, it was announced tonight. New companies selected for the award were as follows:

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 18 -- An announcement that cotton consumed in September was more than had been expected, huge government orders for cotton goods and a tight situation in the market for spot cotton accounted last week for a firmer tone in cotton futures. Much price-fixing also was evident.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, will have the support of "thousands of veterans'' throughout the State on election day, Jacob Ark of Rochester, recent New York State Department Commander of the American Legion, said yesterday in a statement made public at Dewey-for-Governor Committee headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street.

TORONTO, Oct. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Jay J. Allen, long active in the Canadian motion picture industry and in the distribution of British films in this country, died here yesterday at the age of 53. He was born in Bradford, Pa. ,
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A communique:

In your issue of Oct. 14 there is published a letter from Morris Shapiro as chairman of the executive council of the United Parents Associations, in which he criticizes the Citizens Union for endorsing Senator Coudert for reelection.

An audience of 1,500 bought $18,000 worth of war stamps and bonds late yesterday afternoon to attend the second concert given at Carnegie Hall by the New York City WPA Symphony Orchestra under the sponsorship of the Workmen's Circle.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Indicating the seriousness of the defiance movement of the French people that centered last week at Lyon, Chambery, Annecy and Amberieu, was a Vichy radio report today that Pierre Laval had returned to his capital after an all-day conference with Nazi chieftains yesterday at Paris.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 -- Italian aliens of the Far West, beginning at midnight tonight, will be revlieved from curfew and travel restrictions which have hindered their movements since last Winter, but exclusion from the West Coast, on an individual basis, of all persons deemed dangerous to military security will continue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A survey to determine feasibility of utilizing any surplus production capacity which may exist or develop later in the paint industry, for production of war materials other than paint, varnish and lacquer products, has been launched by the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, it was announced here today by Ernest T. Trigg, president of the group.
LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- An Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

That prices on the Stock Exchange should have sold slowly down early last week, after the Monday holiday, was partly due to profit-taking on the season's rise, but more particularly to knowledge that fighting of some importance was in progress at the Solomon Islands and absence of any plain statement of results while last week's markets were open.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Swift punishment after the war for guilty Nazis must be supplemented with an entirely opposite policy to be applied to the German people as a whole, particularly the future generations, the Archbishop of Canterbury said here today.

MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 19 -- Russian defenders entrenched firmly in the rubble of Stalingrad killed thousands more German troops and wrecked forty-five tanks in two narrow sectors yesterday in hurling back furious German armored and infantry onslaughts, the Red Army announced today.

The National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters announced yesterday the revision of rates for injury and property damage liability insurance for manufacturers and contractors. For New York and Louisiana there was a complete revision of the bodily injury rates resulting in reductions in the average premium levels.

Above the din and clamor of groups demanding day care programs for the children in New York City, Mayor La Guardia, Commissioner of Welfare William Hodson, Dr. Alice V. Keliher and other persons, are trying to get facts that will substantiate the need for grants under the Lanham act, which provides Federal funds, or WPA funds.

The seventeenth-century Dutch painters are well represented in the three-room exhibition at the Duveen Galleries on Fifth Avenue which is held in aid of the American Women's Voluntary Services and the Queen Wilhelmina Fund. The collection centers around the works of Frans Hals's numerous portraits of stanch, jovial burghers and their sedate wives, and Rembrandt's religious canvases, with their Calvinistic austerity and depth of feeling.

Despite any charges of imperialism, Great Britain and the United States must police the world after the war till some program of lasting peace is evolved, Lieutenant C. Leslie Glenn, chaplain of the Naval Midshipmen's School at Columbia University asserted in his sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel on the university campus.

The New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities yesterday afternoon elected Judge Jonah J. Goldstein president of their council. He succeeds James S. Hays, who served for two terms. Delegates from 1,500 Jewish fraternal and benevolent organizations, representing 300,000 members, attended the session at the Hotel Edison.
MOSCOW, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Unity of the Christian churches at this time when civilization is imperiled was urged by the Right Rev. James Edward Freeman, Bishop of Washington, in a sermon at the National Cathedral today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 18 -- "Above all, since the entry of the United States into the war France no longer believes in a German victory and her sentiment is to limit if not to avoid collaboration with Germany," the newspaper Suisse of Geneva said in this morning's issue.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- On the Rainbow Bridge this afternoon representatives of management and labor of Canada and the United States joined in pledging loyalty to the all-out war against the Axis and the restoration of freedom and independence to all countries.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street, suggested in his sermon yesterday morning that "the older generation all too frequently underrates its capacity to help in the present crisis."

The city will have its first surprise daytime air raid drill soon, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, in his weekly radio "Talk to the People" from his desk at City Hall. The drill, the Mayor explained, will be held by direction of Major Gen. William N. Haskell, State Director of Civilian Defense, and will be heralded by the sounding of the city's air raid sirens.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Three freighters for Britain were launched at the Todd-Bath Shipbuilding Corporation's yard today, completing a thirty-ship contract with the British Ministry of War Transports and freeing the yard for full-time construction of Liberty ships for the Maritime Commission.

Cramming the vital points into a wild and woolly first half, the Washington Redskins toppled the Brooklyn Dodgers before 25,635 thrill-sated fans at Ebbets Field yesterday and, on the wings of a 21-10 victory, so solidified their first-place hold in the National Football League's Eastern division that they will be difficult to dislodge in the future.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at 108.2. There are few changes in the group indexes, due mainly to the fact that ceilings have been imposed on many commodities. These ceiling prices are the only prices known to the public, but price regulations have loopholes, and actually the prices of the commodities have been fluctuating in spite of the seeming stabilizing effect of the price controls.

The recital given by Emanuel List, the Metropolitan bass, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall was one of those rare and happy occasions when an artist and his hearers find themselves completely in rapport and not one dull moment is encountered.

As pleasant, and perhaps profitable, an afternoon for children as could be imagined was offered yesterday at the Hunter College Theatre when Junior Programs, Inc., presented "Doodle Dandy of the U.S.A.," a fantasy based, as the program rather affectedly announces, on the Four Freedoms.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Charles L. Compton, 55 years old, of Ithaca, is in Geneva General Hospital with a fractured skull. His condition is critical. He has not recovered consciousness since he was struck on the head with a mallet during a free-for-all fight at the new Naval Training Station at Sampson on Seneca Lake yesterday afternoon.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Heman II, 7-year-old brown gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale of this city, was named champion for the second year in a row at the annual Fairfield and Westchester Hounds hunter trials conducted over the picturesque course at the Yale Farms today.

Cooper Union has announced lts program for the 1942-3 series of free forums that are held on Sunday, Tuesday and Friday evenings in the Great Hall at Eighth Street and Astor Place. The Sunday and Tuesday sessions are given over to war themes, but the Friday lectures carry the heading of "American Roots."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Ernesto Barros Jarpa said last night that President Juan Antonio Rios had directed the Chilean Ambassador to thank President Roosevelt for his message, sent after Senor Rios postponed his trip to the United States.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman led the Archdiocese in observance of world-wide Mission Sunday yesterday, as he presided at a solemn vesper service celebrated by Auxiliary Bishop Stephen J. Donahue at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Five thousand persons crowded into the church, many standing in the aisles.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Karl Hermann Frank, German Secretary of State for Bohemia-Moravia, announced today in a speech in Prague that all close relatives of Czech leaders now living in London had been arrested and sent to concentration camps in reprisal for the Czechs' continued resistance to the Germans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A postwar "inter-democracy union" will be "psychologically feasible and imperative" as a result of "the excesses of nationalism in recent years and the effects of the present war," according to a report just released by the American Council on Public Affairs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- A new ceiling price on lard went into effect last Tuesday at $13.80 a hundredweight, or 90 cents above the previous ceiling, but the market moved up the full amount of the increase in one day and trading came to a virtual standstill.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Oct. 10 to 16 are given in the appended tabulation:

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 -- Members of the Building Service Employes International Union, A.F. of L., voted tonight an authorization to their officers to call a general strike at the city's four major department stores unless a contractual agreement is forthcoming by Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Board of Directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs urged President Roosevelt and the Secretaries of War and Navy today to take action for the prevention of intoxication among men in uniform.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers smothered the Cleveland Rams under a barrage of forward passes today to win a National Football League game, 45 to 28, before a crowd of 12,000.

Tile Autumn benefit theatre party under the auspices of the Musicians Emergency Fund, postponed from last Monday will take place tonight at the performance of George Abbott's "Beat theI Band" at the Forty-sixth StreetI Theatre.

VICHY, Oct. 18 -- As is shown by the increase of deposits in the banks and savings accounts as well as by the tone of the Bourse, available capital does not cease to accumulate in France. For this reason the government considers the moment opportune to offer employment to this capital by another loan.
Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, left the city last night to open his second week of up-State campaigning with a major campaign speech tonight in Buffalo.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- At their scattered bases in Britain today the pilots and crews of ninety-three of ninety-four giant Lancaster bombers that raided the big Schneider Le Creusot armament plant yesterday told their story of the Royal Air Force's most daring daylight attack, which, it was disclosed, lasted only seven minutes.
Penthouse apartments in buildings on the East Side were among the suites in Manhattan reported leased over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Increased recruitment and training of women workers on a voluntary basis in every phase of war production and in civilian activities was urged today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

AT AN ADVANCED U.S. ARMY BOMBER BASE, in the South Pacific, Oct. 10 (delayed) (AP) -- The "Helen Wings" Flying Fortress was hot after a Japanese seaplane off Rekata Bay in the Solomons recently when somebody took a pot shot at her from below.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 18 -- New precautionary measures have been taken by the Germans in the coastal area of Stavanger, Norway, where, according to a Swedish correspondent, an invasion or enemy landing is generally expected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, announced tonight that the Defense Plant Corporation, a subsidiary of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, had authorized four contracts totaling $925,000 for new war plants and facilities and that it also had authorized contracts with two distilleries in Kentucky for equipment.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 18 -- Two stakes were completed today in the second sanctioned retriever field trial in a series of three arranged by the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club. The first was a novice event, which was won by the Chesapeake Bay Miss Lou, owned and handled by Mrs. John Holmes of Smithtown Branch, L.I.

The twilight of the super teams is upon us. Not only is Minnesota twice fallen, but the man who led the Golden Gophers through seventeen successive games without defeat and then exploded the bubble of their invincibility as the coach of the Iowa Naval cadets has now had his own three-year winning sequence interrupted.

Shortages of materials are bringing about curtailment of the size of newspapers and increases in advertising rates and sales prices in Brazil, according to the monthly bulletin of advertising conditions in that country issued by Empreza de Propaganda Standard, Ltda., advertising agency of Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo.

HAZLEHURST, Miss., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Governor Paul B. Johnson said in Jackson tonight that he had ordered two companies of State guardsmen to Hazlehurst to aid in the search for a Negro wanted in connection with the fatal shooting of Chief Deputy Sheriff John M. Box.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The French National Committee made a significant reshuffle today when it merged the Commissariat of Colonies, Economy and Mercantile Marine with the Commissariat of Colonies and Foreign Affairs, naming Rene Plevin as chief.

There has been and probably will be no official explanation of why American troops have landed in Liberia. But the landing coincides with reports of German submarines operating against Allied convoy routes from Cape Palmas, which is just over the border of Eastern Liberia.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick told members of the Riverside Church yesterday morning that the present war should cause no disillusionment regarding Christianity, because "it is not Christ's gospel and ethic that have failed; it is the negation of them, their flouting and denial." Dr. Fosdick added:
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Brides who are starting housekeeping and bombed-out families who have lost their possessions will soon have only official "utility" furniture with which to furnish their new homes.

Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, recommended last night that government subsidies be granted to small business to keep it going throughout the war to act as a "democratic check upon the monopolistic practices of big business."

You will have to admit that beans that bake in just forty-five minutes are pretty remarkable! As a matter of fact, we think them, nothing short of miraculous. For after testing and sampling, we can readily say that their flavor is almost exactly like that of old-fashioned beans -- the kind you used to soak overnight and carefully tend during an eight-hour session in the oven.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -- After failing to make a first down in the first half, the surprising Pittsburgh Steelers broke loose for two touchdowns in the second half today to beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 14 to 0, for their third straight victory in the National Football League.

Thus far Kiska Island has been useful to Japan chiefly for purposes of propaganda on the home front. Its seizure was exploited as a consolation prize for the failure to take Midway. It has been an expensive prize. Japanese troops on Kiska are in a worse position today than their fellows in the jungles of Guadalcanal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Senate is to vote this week on reduction of the draft age to 18 and both houses will act on the conference report on the new tax bill. With these the only important controversial issues immediately ahead, Congress is expected to take a vacation by the week-end to permit members to go out into the election campaign and perhaps have a week or two of rest after it is over.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 18 -- The Axis air forces continued attacks against Malta and held down their losses yesterday, but British losses also dropped on the seventh day of the-blitz and the enemy again failed to do any effective bombing.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- The Russians have maintained a two-mile-long pontoon bridge across the Volga at Stalingrad, it was disclosed today, and that is one reason why the Red Army has continued to stand up under the fierce German attacks.

The critical shortage of physicians brought about by the demands of the Army and Navy has prompted Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, to approve what purports to be a plan of action, but which leaves us exactly where we have been these many months.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 17 (delayed) -- The disturbances that began Aug. 5 have not affected public subscriptions to the Government of India loans, a high financial authority told this correspondent today. Borrowings continue at a rate of about 20,000,000 rupees weekly, which is about five times the pre-war average, he said. Sales of defense loans, alone, totaled 1,260,000,000 rupees Oct. 10.

War material orders valued at many hundreds of thousands of dollars have been spread equitably among Connecticut industries through the activities of the Connecticut War Industries Commission, according to a departmental report just made to Governor Robert A. Hurley by Harvey L. Hooke, director of the commission.

Set upon by a gang of Negroes in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon after he had attempted to settle a street dispute between a white boy and two Negro boys, Detective Harry Bowser was saved from possible serious injury by the chance arrival of his brother, Herman, a member of the Navy shore patrol.

Flags of the United Nations flew alongside the standards of Britain and the United States yesterday for the first time in the observance of the ancient British Harvest Festival in historic Trinity Church.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 18 (AP) -- In a surprise raid today on three tourist cabins, established outside of Norfolk, members of the Fifth Naval District shore patrol and a Norfolk police vice squad rounded up 115 persons in one of the biggest "moral" raids ever conducted here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Industrial firms have fallen far behind the desired goal in converting their fuel oil burners into other systems, Harold L. Ickes, the Petroleum Coordinator, announced tonight, and simultaneously Ralph K. Davies, deputy coordinator, warned that if the program were not carried out voluntarily the government could take the whip hand.

There is no need to believe all the rumors relayed to London yesterday from the Continent to see that the Nazis have begun a new campaign in the Mediterranean countries. These reports say that Mussolini has been summoned to explain to Hitler why Italian morale is as dangerously low as Himmler found it on his recent inspection trip and that the Germans intend to take over the Adriatic ports of Trieste and Fiume.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 18 -- With planes, smoke bombs and detonators in action to provide a realistic touch, 4,000 men, women and children were moved from Camden by land and by water today in the greatest surprise test evacuation of its kind ever staged in the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Some answer to knotty problems involved in any compulsory manpower legislation, including questions of pay scales and the individual rights of workers and management, may be forthcoming this week.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, James A. Farley, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer and Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay are among those who have joined the endorsement committee of the New Opera Company, it was announced yesterday with the issuance of a booklet entitled "War's Challenge to the Lovers of Music."

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- When Santa Claus sails over British chimney pots this Christmas he will have fewer toys with him than ever before and those he can scrape together will make a light load, for most of them must of necessity be poor substitutes for the playthings of happier days.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 18 (Reuter) -- The war in the Pacific will probably be ended before the conclusion of the war in Europe, according to opinions expressed today in usually well-informed quarters here.

Spurred by cooler weather, both wholesale and retail business again climbed, although major shortages continued to appear, according to the weekly reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Mrs. David de Sola Pool of this city was chosen yesterday for the third time as national president of Hadassah, the women's Zionist group, and Judge Louis E. Levinthal of Philadelphia was elected unanimously for a second term as president of the Zionist organization of America at the end of their concurrent conventions here.

Registration this year in sixty up-State and Long Island cities and villages where voters must qualify in person dropped nearly 14 per cent compared with the registration for the last State election in 1938. The percentage of decrease in registration in New York City, where the registration period ended a week earlier, was 12 per cent.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Auby C. Strickland, chief of the United States Fighter Command in the Middle East, said today that his fliers were up against superior Axis forces in nearly every fight, but that they "are determined to whittle the enemy down to their size and then dispose of those left."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Army and Navy ferry planes, which deliver personnel and material to the United Nations' fighting fronts, are bringing strategic materials back to the United States on their return trips, the Office of War Information announced today.

BUFFALO, Oct. 19 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, declared tonight in a speech before a group of citizens of Polish extraction in St. John's Kanty Hall that the war was the primary issue in the current political campaign.

Remember when you were a kid? Did you ever want to be taught how to box by an expert? Did you spend long, happy hours building ship models? And when you were a little older, did you wish you could learn to dance?

The government's decision to erase the term "enemy alien" from Italian noncitizens leaves -- aside from the Japanese -- as "enemy aliens" almost exclusively the noncitizens of German or formerly of German nationality.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 19 -- Enemy losses of aircraft over Malta yesterday reached their lowest point in eight days of Blitz -- two machines -- but that reduction was effected only by the raiders turning tail at the approach of defending Spitfires. Hence, the enemy usually missed his bombing objectives.

We offer a list of situations wherein white people most often offend the feelings of Negroes. Unintentional slights are grouped with perversely malicious acts because what is done in honest ignorance by one person may be a deliberate insult by another.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Here is a summary of the report of the Office of War Information on the performance of American military and naval aircraft:

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Soviet High Command reported today that the defenders of Stalingrad, who had lost one block of wrecked buildings, repelled German tank and infantry assaults yesterday.

With nearly 500 investment bankers from all parts of the country in attendance, the Investment Bankers Association of America began its two-day thirty-first annual meeting and war finance conference in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Ray (Sugar) Robinson scored his thirty-seventh straight victory as a professional tonight, but although he hit Izzy Jannazzo with virtually everything in the book, the undefeated Harlem Negro couldn't knock out his crafty opponent and had to be satisfied with a ten-round decision.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- American naval vessels shelled the Japanese positions on the northwestern shore of Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons on Saturday while the opposing air and sea forces continued trading punches in an action the Navy has indicated may be the opening rounds of a major contest.

The cotton futures market fluctuated yesterday within a 10-point range. Price-fixing orders and hedge sales appeared in almost equal volume during the day. In a rather small market active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the session near the lows, 4 to 5 points under Saturday's final quotations.

The beneficent workings of Japanese "co-prosperity" in the Netherlands East Indies are described in a note in the current Foreign Commerce Weekly. All banks were closed, except Japanese banks. European shops were ordered to remain open, but many soon had to cease business because their stocks were exhausted or their staffs interned.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Workers Defense League suggested in a letter today that Governor Paul Johnson, President Roosevelt and Attorney General Francis Biddle address a public gathering at Meridian, calling on citizens to testify against members of a mob which lynched two Negro boys near there last week.

Hotels and restaurants of New York City announced yesterday they were prepared to comply fully with Mayor La Guardia's program for meatless Tuesday's beginning today to conserve beef, lamb and pork for the armed forces and for lease-lend requirements.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- Overriding limited but vociferous opposition, the members of the Third District of the National Association of Broadcasters approved today a resolution upholding the policies of the national organization in its campaign against James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- A shooting mystery that puzzled authorities three years ago was revived today in Supreme Court, where Mrs. Lottie E. Isbell of Larchmont sought to recover $13,500 in additional insurance benefits on the grounds that her husband did not commit suicide but was murdered in Scarsdale on April 10, 1939.
BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 19 -- "The Anglo - Saxon menace to French Africa," is the general theme of the Paris press, according to reports from the occupied French capital today.

Jamaica's final three days of racing got off to a turbulent start yesterday before a crowd of 14,584, third biggest gathering of the Autumn meeting, which began on Columbus Day. The crowd sent a total of $965,892, of which they retained $862,828.90, through the betting machines; they saw a disqualification, sat in at the suspension of two jockeys and the fining of a third, and watched six favorites go down to defeat.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Severe punishment has been meted out to United States Army fliers who "were found guilty of inhuman acts" in their bombing of Tokyo on April 18, according to reports from Japan broadcast by the official German news agency.

The first volume in a projected series of annual surveys of the principal developments in inter-American affairs will be released by Columbia University Press on Oct. 30. The coverage includes cultural relations, social welfare, public health and labor, as well as politics, diplomacy, economics and finance.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt today nominated three temporary rear admirals and a captain to be permanent rear admirals.
Federal Judge John Bright has leased an apartment in the Town House, 108 East Thirty-eighth Street through N.A. Berwin Co., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Stringent regulations to curb what Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, called a wave of evictions and "phoney" sales of rented homes in areas under rent control, were issued today.

DETROIT, Oct.19 -- The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., announced tonight that an arbitrator's award of $924,000 in back pay to 1,197 Ford employes had settled all but twenty-five cases in which the union alleged that unfair labor practices governed discharges.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- The demand that the position of Rudolph Hess be immediately clarified so that it can be established whether he is a criminal or enjoying immunity as a plenipotentiary of the Hitlerite government in England is made in a leading article in Pravda today.

A vagrancy complaint against Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler, 50-year-old beer-baron of the prohibition era, who is free in $5,000 bail after surrendering ten days ago to Federal authorities on charges that he headed a black market sugar ring, was dismissed yesterday in Harlem Magistrate's Court after a brief hearing before Magistrate Harry Andrews.
