Naturalization aid is becoming increasingly difficult because many aliens are ashamed to admit their status, Mrs. Louis de L. Oppenheimer, chairman of naturalization for the New York Section of the National Society of Jewish Women, said yesterday at Essex House.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Women engineering draftsmen are needed by the hundreds for the government's war agencies, the Civil Service Commission said today. The main need is in electrical, topographic and statistical fields.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Payment of $40,000 in fines was made by four Albany residents today, following their pleas last week of guilty to charges of conspiracy in a labor "kickback" case. This coincided with the convening of a grand jury to consider a second case of a similar nature.

Testimony of corporate officials on accounting difficulties is to the effect that it is more difficult now to "close" the books at the end of a quarter than it used to be at the end of the year. So rapidly have conditions changed in the last two years that company treasurers are not certain, once they have set aside provisions for taxes and contingencies that their appropriations are at all adequate.

The present war has had two apparently conflicting effects on motor transport. It has added mightily to the burden of freight and passengers that must be moved in trucks and buses on the one hand, and seriously reduced the number of vehicles needed for this task, on the other.

Faced with mounting Federal taxes for war expenditures, the State administration must "cut through some of the red tape and start important tax reforms" in the State's fiscal structure in order to lessen the income tax burden of its taxpayers, Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, declared here last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A War Production Board survey of eight leading civilian industries which have been converted to war production showed today that employment in most instances is back to normal or better and is increasing.

DETROIT, Oct 19 (AP) -- Out of the war Americans may develop a "cosmopolitan appetite" which will eliminate sectional habits in eating, Miss Mary I. Barber of Battle Creek, food consultant to the Secretary of War, said today.

NOW there are some lovely targets jutting up above the gridiron, the unbeaten and untied teams. There they stand for all to see -- and it would be a good idea to look quickly, because some of them are bound to go down shortly. For one thing, some untied and undefeated teams will be running into other untied and undefeated teams, with a consequent downward revision of untied and undefeated teams.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- London is being prepared in that cagey way that the necessities of the war dictate to welcome Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who, it is now generally known, is coming here to visit Queen Elizabeth. It was all very hush-hush about her coming at all until the wire services reported from Washington that the President's wife would not visit Britain unless she could assist in the war effort.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Unlike any other Republican candidate in recent times, Thomas E. Dewey shows surprising strength among the young voters.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 19 -- The interpretation placed abroad on the arrival in New Delhi of General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell and General Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck -- that it presages an Allied drive against Burma -- is received here with the greatest skepticism.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 19 -- Negotiations for the formation of a European postal and communications union, which have been in progress in Vienna for the past week, were concluded today, an agency dispatch from that city stated.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Reporters were permitted to question Irwin Kadens at the Fillmore police station here today. Head bandaged, wearing an old jacket and shirt, his head and hands bloody, he talked freely.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 19 -- "The real authors of the National Labor Relations Act planned it so as to enable them to destroy every independent union," it was charged today by Cyril D. Savage, president of the disestablished Wright Aeronautical Employes Association, which has been dissolved by order of the National Labor Relations Board.

A trade association of raincoat manufacturers here who are working on government orders was organized yesterday at a meeting held at the Hotel New Yorker. Tentatively called the New York Raincoat Manufacturers Association, the new group is headed by Simon Cohen of the Greater New York Raincoat Company.

If the procedure for renegotiating war contracts fails for want of cooperation on the part of contractors business men may well expect the imposition of arbitrary authority and the rigid limitation of profits, Carman G. Blough, chief of the contract review branch, procurement policy division of the War Production Board, warned yesterday at the fourth Accounting Institute, being sponsored in the Hotel Pennsylvania by the School of Business of Columbia University.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- German authorities attempting to enforce Europe's "new order" have carried' out more executions in Czechoslovakia and have rushed troop reinforcements to Austria, where sabotage and guerrilla warfare are spreading, reports from the Continent said today.

New York City's 300,000 users of fuel oil will fill out their applications under fuel oil rationing in the first week of November and will take or send them to the 400 public schools designated to handle that phase of registration, it was announced yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, State OPA director, 535 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Senators La Follette of Wisconsin and Thomas of Utah introduced in the Senate today five bills designed to extend to farm workers in "industrialized agriculture" many of the rights given to urban workers by New Deal labor legislation.

Unofficial conversations to explore the possibility of making available larger allotments of essential civilian goods, such as work clothes and bedding supplies, to distributors serving congested war-production centers, have been held between WPB officials and leading Worth Street textile houses, it was learned yesterday.
Bob Steuber, senior halfback at the University of Missouri, is the leading scorer among the nation's college football players.

HEADQUARTERS, ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- Two Japanese destroyers that were left in flames last Friday in Aleutian waters by a force of twenty-six Martin Marauder bombers were disguised as cargo ships, and it is believed that they were carrying fighter planes for the Japanese garrison on Kiska Island, the Army announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- The whea market moved in a narrow range today, with no special feature except for a small amount of buying of the May early, credited to Northwest milling interests. Most professional traders as well as outside interests, waiting for announcements from Washington that would clarify the various phases in the price-ceiling situation in regard to which there is still much uncertainty.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- John Sutton and Preston Foster will play the leading roles in Twentieth Century-Fox's "Torpedo Squadron 8," a film account of the exploits of the United States Navy's mosquito boats, the studio announced today.

The Giants' football party, battered and weary from its losing tussle with the Bears in Chicago on Sunday, arrived at Grand Central yesterday minus two of its players, Tuffy Leemans and Bob Trocolor, rookie halfback. Leemans and Trocolor, casualties in the engagement, left the train at 125th Street and went to St. Elizabeth's Hospital.
Add two more openings to this week's list of new film arrivals: "My Sister Eileen," at the Radio City Music Hall, and "The Flying Tigers," at the Capitol, both opening on Thursday.
We read, on Oct. 4, your editorial "First Frost," which painted rather a gloomy picture of frost-blitzed flowers in your vicinity. "Petunias, save in sheltered spots, are a withered memory.''

Bronislava Nijinska's "Chopin Concerto" received the second of its three scheduled performances by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Immeasurably better danced than at its premiere, its crystaline beauty was revealed in something of its true value.

While final figures on city-wide registration disclosed yesterday a substantial drop in the number of male voters who registered for next month's election, the number of women registrants showed only a slight decline from 1938, the last comparable year.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 19 -- Declaring unalterable opposition "to the evils of the liquor traffic," the convention of the United Lutheran Church of America asked President Roosevelt today to take "the most aggressive means" at his disposal to protect those in the armed services and in war industries against "these devastating evils."
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 19 -- A famine that may be one of China's most disastrous is increasing in Honan Province south of the Yellow River.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The second report of the Office of War Information was issued today -- on the past, present and future of American aircraft -- and in every particular it encourages the hope that "candor and common sense" will henceforth abide as the chief elements in all official news of the war which comes from that source.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- Ezequiel P. Paz, publisher of the newspaper Prensa, one of the most influential newspapers in the world, warned last night that the freedom of the press was being seriously threatened in this country, especially in the interior of the republic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Creation of a new division in the War Production Board which will have responsibility for all transportation priorities, domestic as well as import, was announced by A.I. Henderson, deputy director general for industry operations of WPB.

Declaring that "the public has been very generous with funds" donated to Army Emergency Relief, "and we want them to know how the money is being spent," Major Gen. T.A. Terry, Commanding General of the Second Service Command, Services of Supply, in a press interview yesterday, outlined the achievements of the relief organization during its first five months.

Sinking of two medium-size United States merchant ships, one in July in the North Atlantic and the other in August in the Caribbean, was announced yesterday by the Navy Department. They brought to 496 the number of merchant vessels sunk in the Western Atlantic since Pearl Harbor, according to The Associated Press's compilation.

Colonel Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippine Army, one of the last men to escape from Bataan, declared here last night, after receiving the Pulitzer prize for interpretive correspondence for The Philippines Herald during 1941, that "the Philippines were not lost when we surrendered in Bataan," but had been lost when the United States refused after the last war to police the world and check aggression.

Many factors are now tending to drive up per interview costs and extend the time of field surveys, H.A. Stone, in charge of field research for Daniel Starch, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

By 1:15 yesterday every table in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis Hotel was taken, nor was there an empty seat at a table. It was a smart crowd; an expectant crowd. Jo Copeland was showing her Fall and Winter line. These were sophisticated clothes for the woman who likes luxury.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 19 -- The theft of jewelry valued at $250,000 from Big Three Farm, the estate of Mrs. James N. Hill at Wheatley Hills, L.I., was disclosed today by Inspector Harold R. King, in charge of the Nassau County Detective Division.

Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, declared last night that he favored government participation in a planned economy and a vast program of public works as a post-war program to assure economic security and personal liberty for all.

Michael Fortunato, 42 years old, of 31-69 Thirty-fifth Street, Astoria, Queens, whose body, with four bullets in it, was found yesterday morning in a parked automobile near his home, was revealed last night as a salesman for contraband gasoline rationing books.

Traffic deaths increased sharply during the dimout hours in September compared with the same period of 1941 although there were 224 fewer accidents, it was reported yesterday at Police Headquarters. The Safety Bureau of the department also announced that the regular weekly and weekend comparison with the same period of a year ago showed a decline in all categories.

A Colt automatic pistol with a bullet numbered "310" was presented last night to Lieutenant Liudmila Pavlichenko, Russian woman sniper who is credited with having killed 309 Germans single-handed, at a farewell celebration held in her honor at Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

Max L. Hutt, former instructor in education and head of the Education Clinic at City College, was dismissed from the faculty of the college last night by the Board of Higher Education, meeting in Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue. There was no opposing vote.

Warning that the menace of enemy submarines would become progressively worse this Winter, Rear Admiral Emory Scott Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the Investment Bankers Association of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that "we can't lick the submarine menace, though we may be able to ameliorate it."

Secondary distribution of 20,374 shares of non-voting, no-par common stock of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company of America, was made yesterday after the close of trading by Smith, Barney Co. at $67 a share, with a discount of $1.25 a share to dealers.

No matter what mechanized weapons are developed to combat the enemy, "the war will finish in the cellars and on the roofs in hand-to-hand fighting," Major W.E. Fairbairn of the British Army declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Advertising Men's Post of the American Legion in the Hotel Lexington.

Three of the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System, those of Chicago, Philadelphia and Atlanta, have reduced their discount rates, in line with the banking program to assist member banks in financing the war to the fullest extent possible, it was revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19 -- Two Yale players, Tackle Marion Dietrich and Center John Warfield, were injured in the Navy game at Baltimore Saturday. Dietrich is not expected to return for the Dartmouth game next Saturday. Warfield did not drill today.
The guess in this corner as to the ten best college football teams in the country of this date is as follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- President Roosevelt vetoed several minor bills; his visitors included Daniel J. Tobin, Senator Bunker and Secretary Hull.
Eighty-seven scholarships have been awarded to students at the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music, it was announced yesterday by George A. Wedge, the dean.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision holding constitutional an Atlanta ordinance requiring that taxicabs carry a sign that they are for white passengers only or for Negro passengers only and prohibiting them from carrying both in the same vehicle.

VICHY, France, Oct. 19 -- Boom conditions prevail in Dakar, French West Africa, where military, naval and commercial activities have increased tremendously in the past year, according to a letter published in the Temps today from its correspondent there.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 14: Increases of $386,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks; $178,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $364,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $483,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and a decrease of $331,000,000 in United States Government deposits.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Three Belgians have been executed on orders of a German court marital for "helping the enemy," according to a report by the Belgian newspaper Le Pays Reel today.
Favored players led the way after the first sessions of the metropolitan contract bridge championship play for women's pairs and for open teams-of-four at the Park Central Hotel here yesterday.

The vacant plot 122 by 100 feet at 514-22 West Twenty-third Street was sold by the Bank for Savings to a client of Stein Salant, attorneys. Cadwalader, Wickersham Taft represented the seller. E. Osborne Smith, Inc., were the brokers.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

The Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation, which has been presenting young artists in debut recitals for the last seventeen years, yesterday afternoon at Town Hall presented the first of this year's winners, David Sarser, 21-year-old violinist, of Kansas City, Mo., who received deferment from his local draft board to make the appearance.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Counsel for Dr. Frank F. Marino, New Rochelle physician and Army captain on trial in Westchester County Court on a manslaughter indictment charging he performed a criminal abortion that caused the death last March 28 of Miss Cleo Florence Moore, 19-year-old juke box "hostess," declared in his opening address to the jury today that the doctor was the victim of a "frame-up."

Discussing the part commercial banks must play in financing the war, Under Secretary of the Treasury Daniel W. Bell, in his speech to the Investment Bankers Association last night, remarked that these banks would be called upon to finance an "unprecedented'' share of the deficit.

The youthful Withold Malcuzynski, the last pupil of Ignace Jan Paderewski, stimulated his large audience to applause and huzzas in his first New York recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. His recital here last Spring had stirred unusual interest, partly due, perhaps, to the distinguished auspices under which he pursued his later studies.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 19 -- At 9 o'clock this morning, while King Christian X of Denmark was taking his daily ride through the streets of Copenhagen, his horse shied and he was thrown over its head.

Since there are now for the first time more playgoers than playwrights on Broadway, we may expect an unusual number of revivals this season. We shall be lucky if all the plays are as durable as the late John Drinkwater's "Bird in Hand," which was restored to the Morosco last evening, but we could be a lot luckier with the performance.
BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 19 -- Radio Paris [Nazi-controlled] broadcast this warning to the French people tonight:

The first New York showing of textiles created by Dorothy Liebes from non-priority materials opened yesterday on the fourth floor of W. J. Sloane, Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. The materials by the noted San Francisco designer, who arrived from California yesterday for the opening, will be on view for two weeks.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- New methods of dehydrating foods, whereby, for example, a ton of carrots can be reduced to 190 pounds, were described today as of "vast importance" in the war.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- To protect shipping traveling around the Cape of Good Hope and also from South America against Axis submarines, the United Nations gradually have established a series of air bases along the African West Coast and it is merely incidental if these bases ring Dakar, French West Africa, which the Germans hoped to make a stepping stone to Latin America, it was stated here today.
Mrs. George E. Ward sticks pins in the Axis. Red and white ones in Nazi-occupied France. A green and white one in Tokyo. They signify bombings by the Allies.

The sixteenth floor and part of the seventeenth, containing about 15,200 square feet of space, at 500 Fifth Avenue, have been leased by E.B. Badger Sons Company, petroleum engineer, from Sherman K. Ellis Co., Inc., through Cushman Wakefield, Inc., and the Hudhattan Corporation.

Dr. Marvin A. Stevens, a football coach no longer but still a football man at heart, praised contact sports as a body builder, to the disparagement of physical education fitness programs, before the Football Writers Association at the meeting at Toots Shor's restaurant yesterday.

Removal of some of the 130,000 tons of scrap piled at various points in New York City began yesterday, according to Albert Pleydell, Commissioner of Purchase, but it will be a long job and at least at the beginning will move at the rate of "less than 400 tons a week."

Jose Ferrer is casting a covetous eye at the role of the Baron in Katharine Cornell's revival of "The Three Sisters"; presently he has the leading male role in "Vickie." If he decides to shift, that would complete the casting. Rehearsals for the Chekhov play have been delayed, pending the arrival of Judith Anderson and Ruth Gordon; they may begin the end of this week.

Elmer Davis, who is all for giving the public war facts to which it is entitled without imperiling our fighting forces, has performed a signal service by telling us where our planes stand. Though we are warned of "crushing defeats" in store and told that the air forces of the United Nations are not likely to eclipse those of the enemy, his report is anything but discouraging.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Although Sweden's exports to Germany since the war show an increase when measured in monetary terms, it is not yet possible to say whether this represents merely a rise in prices or an actual increase in the quantity of goods exchanged, W. Bostroem, Swedish Minister to the United States, stated today.

The stock market returned yesterday to the narrow movements which characterized most of the pre-recovery markets and to the accompaniment of a further slackening of interest. Volume was, in fact, under the half-million-share mark for the first time this month as sales on the Stock Exchange contracted to 401,000 shares, against 504,800 on last Friday.

After deliberating more than five hours a jury of six men and six women returned a verdict of guilty at 10:43 o'clock last night in Federal Court against twenty-four of twenty-five leaders of the German-American Bund, accused of conspiracy to counsel resistance to the Selective Service Act.

Although America still is fighting a two-ocean war with a one-ocean Navy, we took the offensive in the Tulagi area in August and the Japanese fear and resent it, Admiral Ernest J. King, Chief of Naval Operations, declared here last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct, 19 -- Paul Runyan of Metropolis and Jerry Desio of Green Valley, playing alternate shots, won the Metropolitan P.G.A. Scotch foursome championship with a 36-hole score of 76, 76 -- 152 over the Gedney Country Club course today.

The shoe industry is now more seriously concerned by the manpower problem than materials shortages and industry leaders may appeal to the War Manpower Commission to freeze workers in shoe plants, it was reported yesterday at the Spring opening of the Volume Shoe Manufacturers at the Hotel New Yorker.

Six midshipmen who were graduated with outstanding honors from the Naval Midshipmen's Reserve Training School of New York received presentation swords yesterday afternoon at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. Admiral Ernest J. King was a surprise visitor to the ceremonies and presented one of the swords.

WHEN Americans say "pioneer" they think of the West. But every Summer the amateurs put on plays in the little theatres of Vermont and New Hampshire that look back to the days when pioneering meant going north, up the valleys of the Connecticut and the Merrimac. A visitor to Vermont from Connecticut is struck by the familiarity of the place names -- Wallingford, Stamford, Manchester, Windsor, Hartford, Norwich, New Haven, Fairfield, Bristol, Guilford, Chester.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- One of the two Nazi saboteurs who were spared death in the electric chair when six accomplices were executed will testify against six persons indicted here for treason, J. Albert Woll, Federal District Attorney, stated today.

The average German citizen should be forgiven if he is becoming a little puzzled regarding the Nazi war aims when Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, is so obviously puzzled himself. Dr. Goebbels announces that as the result of its conquests Germany is no longer a have-not nation.

Aroused over traffic conditions on East 189th Street, the Bronx, which they hold responsible for the death of an 8-year-old boy under the wheels of an interstate truck there last Thursday night, seventy-five neighborhood women came to City Hall yesterday to demand that Mayor La Guardia correct the condition.
College football attendance, as reflected in 127 games played so far this season by forty-four colleges of major caliber, is about 25 per cent lower than a year ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 -- The last batch of a total of 3,000 Mexican farm laborers to be brought into California under a "good neighbor" program for saving the State's sugar beet crop went to work in the fields today.
Deer hunting opens in six Maine counties tomorrow, while the official opening date for the other sections of the State is Nov. 1, with the season ending Nov. 31.
The four-story apartment house at 2772 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by P. Walker Morrison, Lazarus Joseph and Leon Leighton, trustees of Series B-K mortgage investments, to Rose Goldstein.
We have just returned to our posts after a memorable furlough in New York City, and we do want to thank all those Americans who, in their warmhearted way, made the visit an unforgettable one for us.

Artist members of the Dressmakers Union, Local 22, of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, have assembled a large group of their oils, water-colors, temperas, pastels and monotypes and will open a show today at the Ferargil Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, to continue through Nov. 7.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Captain William Lloyd Osborne of Los Angeles and First Lieutenant Damon Gauss of Winder, Ga., have arrived safely in Australia after a dramatic escape from the Philippines and a 159-day journey by foot and small boat.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 19 -- A report prepared for Bermuda's Government and Legislature by the Colony's Wartime Supplies Commission on its recent mission to Washington, as made public today, revealed that opposition had been expressed in the Assembly to Bermuda's direct participation in lend-lease arrangements.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- President Roosevelt has ordered three actors of the Hedgerow Theatre, founded and operated by Jasper Deeter in Rose Valley, deferred from military service as conscientious objectors.

The Rev. Dr. Stuart Nye Hutchison, moderator of the Presbyterian Church of the United States of America, in an appeal that will be read from the pulpits, or distributed to the congregations of 8,000 churches asked yesterday that the 2,000,000 members provide an emergency fund of $1,000,000 by Nov. 8 to meet the church's obligations resulting from the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- While some American war planes are badly designed or ill matched against the equipment of the enemy, the combat performance of United States aircraft on the average has been good and in the last two months it has been more than that, according to the Office of War Information, which issued today a thirty-two-page report on this country's military and naval aircraft.

Because priorities have made it impossible for the Board of Education to equip fully the new Radio Training Center at Public School 20, Manhattan, the board appealed yesterday to school children and their parents for old radio sets and parts.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- London was watching France today, the day selected for the registration of all male Frenchmen between the ages of 18 and 50 for work in Germany. This project, generally considered to be the severest test of the Vichy government's ability to unite France in collaboration with the Nazis, appeared to be headed toward failure, with France ridden with bitterness and incipient revolt.

Declaring that the campaign to defeat State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. was being conducted by Communists, Mayor La Guardia endorsed the Senator's candidacy yesterday and said he would help re-elect him.

It is strange that in a war in which armies are counted by millions and in which nearly the whole two billion or so of the globe's population are involved, a decisive engagement should be fought in a scantily populated, half-unexplored area of no economic importance. Yet this is a true description of the Battle of the Solomon Islands.

Maintaining that the Italians have been as ruthless and barbaric as the Germans, Franc Snoj, a Minister of State of the Yugoslav Government in exile, made public here yesterday an Italian document threatening executions, which he said had been smuggled from Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The formal fuel oil rationing regulations were issued today by the Office of Price Administration. The regulations, as already announced, curtail fuel oil use by an average 33 1/3 per cent, with 15 per cent as the minimum cut.
Miss Gertrude R. Cushman left $65,000 to Protestant Episcopal churches and charitable organizations, according to her will, filed, yesterday for probate in Surrogates Court.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

The World's Championship Rodeo became the Wild West of movie and story book yesterday at the Madison Square Garden in the eyes of 15,000 crippled and underprivileged children, most of whom had never seen a horse outside wagon shafts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Production of durable goods for civilian use had ceased almost completely by the end of the Summer, the War Production Board reported today in making public a summary of reports it collected in August from 3,021 manufacturing plants in seventy-four metals-working industries.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- This day was like many in August, 1940, just before the Battle of Britain really started.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Irwin Kadens, 32-year-old Army deserter turned desperado, who was hunted for many crimes in Illinois, Michigan and Ohio, was trapped this morning in the hold-up of a currency exchange here and beaten into unconsciousness by a policeman who risked his own life rather than endanger civilians with gunfire.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- This was Blue Monday at the University of Pennsylvania. Every one on the campus was blue. Some of the football players were black and blue -- Bert Stiff's face looked like something it doesn't look like normally -- and Coach George Munger was trying awfully hard not to allow himself to feel the same way.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 19 -- Support for the recent declaration by United States Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles regarding Axis agents' activity in Argentina and Chile should be general in the Latin-American press, according to the newspaper El Norte of San Pedro Sula, which approves Mr. Welles's stand in an editorial today.
VICHY, France, Oct. 19 -- Pierre Laval, the Chief of Government, will broadcast an address to the French nation tomorrow night. The subject of the address has not been made public.

Immediate establishment of a system of coffee rationing by the Office of Price Administration was asked yesterday by the New York State Food Merchants Association, representing 5,000 independent retailers throughout the State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Military Affairs Committee unanimously reported to the Senate today the measure lowering the draft age to 18 and asserted that its prompt enactment would shorten the war and reduce casualty lists.

A new issue of 50,000 shares of Elastic Stop Nut Corporation 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, $50 par value, is being offered today at $50 a share and accrued dividends by a syndicate headed by White, Weld Co., and including Shields Co., H.M. Byllesby Co., Inc., and the First Trust Company of Lincoln, Neb.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, always will "vigorously strive to stamp out the vicious un-American vice of racial and religious discrimination," according to a letter sent by him to Robert T. Bess, executive director of the Anti-Job Discrimination League, Inc., of 16 Court Street, Brooklyn, and made public yesterday at the Bennett campaign headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

Nine thousand items of White House correspondence of the Coolidge Administration suddenly went off the auction market late yesterday and started toward a permanent home in the Library of Congress in Washington.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 6 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In the previous week the bank had reported an increase of 19 per cent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Irwin Kadens, 32-year-old Army deserter turned desperado, who was hunted for many crimes in Illinois, Michigan and Ohio, was trapped this morning in the hold-up of a currency exchange here and beaten into unconsciousness by a policeman who risked his own life rather than endanger civilians with gunfire.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 -- "We will be able to finance the war because of our income tax law," Seth T. Cole of Albany, president of the National Tax Association, said today in opening the annual conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A plea for extra rail transportation to enable "those who live on borrowed time" to get to Florida for the Winter was made to the Office of Defense Transportation today by Governor Spessard Holland.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Moore Bleecker of the Weylin and Cold Spring Harbor left yesterday to spend the remainder of the Autumn and Winter in Santa Barbara, Calif.

Elaborate divertissements by professionals, who have donated their services, will be features of the gala cabaret-revue and supper dance, known as "Incendiary Blondes," to be given on Friday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc.

The original handwritten manuscript of "The Murder of Lidice," a dramatic poem by Edna St. Vincent Millay that was presented over the NBC network from 10 to 10:30 o'clock last night, brought $1,000 at an auction held immediately after the performance in Studio 8-H in the RCA Building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Legislation to provide punishment, up to and including the death penalty, for hostile acts against the United States was introduced today by Chairman Van Nuys of the Senate Judiciary Committee, on recommendation of Attorney General Biddle.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A Navy Department communique:

Dorothy Baker, Seattle-born soprano, who has been a soloist at St. Bartholomew's Church for the last six seasons and who gave her first New York recital three years ago, last night gave her second Town Hall recital. Gibner King was her accompanist and her program included the aria "Leise, leise," from Weber's "Der Freischuetz," and groups in French, Italian, German and English.

Events tonight: Jean Watson, song recital, Town Hall, 8:30 o'clock; New York College of Music to present music banned in Germany and occupied countries at the MacDowell Club, 8:30; Miklos Schwalb, pianist, and Stephan Ballarini, baritone, recital at Hotel Plaza, 8; Floyd Worthington, song recital, Barbizon Recital Hall, 8:30; Geon Choral Ensemble, conducted by Marcella Geon, program at Kenmore Hall, 145 East Twenty-third Street, 8:30; Rothschild String Quartet, concert at Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

In anticipation of the projected curtailment in paper production, a wave of buying, most of it believed to be speculative, has swept the market, manufacturers reported here yesterday. Practically all types of paper, many of which had been in very slow demand for months, have shared in the activity.

With a view to ameliorating the effect of the heavy tax burden placed on individual taxpayers by the 1942 revenue bill, the Senate Finance Committee inserted a provision for the allowance as deductions from income of certain medical and dental expenses of the family, including payments for accident and health insurance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- The Senate was urged today by Raymond E. Willis of Indiana to insist on the right to confirm high-salaried employes of the War Manpower Commission, to prevent the chairman, Paul V. McNutt, from creating "a vast McNutt-for-President army" out of commission personnel.

Columbia's football squad reported to Coach Lou Little at Baker Field yesterday ready to start preparations for the Pennsylvania game Saturday. The excellent condition of the varsity group is Little's chief consolation from the 34-6 defeat at the hands of Army.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- In a firm but relatively quiet market today the home and South American rails were the brightest feature. London Transport C stock rose 1 1/2 to 53, while several others gained up to 1/2 point. Stocks are being bought because of their fairly high yields.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Coach Tad Wieman ordered rest for his first-string Princeton football players following Saturday's surprising 6-6 tie with Penn, but sent the second team through a ninety-minute scrimmage with the junior varsity on University Field today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- The noon communique of the Russian High Command reports a German advance inside Stalingrad and the loss of one block by the defenders. This is the Germans' first appreciable success since they established themselves last week in a salient athwart the Russian positions.
RICH HILL, Mo., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Alfred M. Landon declared tonight that the New Deal had treated the war "as a glorified WPA project."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The War Production Board issued orders today for mandatory collection of tin cans in more than 400 municipalities. Nation-wide collection on a mandatory basis will go into effect when additional shredding and detinning facilities become available.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

If the new season has more enchanting programs than the one that Yves Tinayre and his colleagues put on at THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall last night, it will be an extraordinary one. Mr. Tinayre goes by the short descriptive of baritone, but he is scholar, conductor, speaker and artist.

The New York City Cancer Committee opened its sixteenth annual drive at a luncheon at the Town Hall Club yesterday. Mrs. Francis J. Rigney, commander of the women's field army of the committee, said the committee would need $75,000 to meet the growing demands for its services and educational work in the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Importers were advised by the War Production Board today of several additions to and shifts in the lists of materials covered by the General Imports Order M-63. The charges will become effective Oct. 21.
Chinese Observer Eyes Manoeuvres. So our headline said yesterday, and in the first paragraph, as in every good newspaper first paragraph, was the whole story:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- William Fox, once a prominent-motion picture financier, lost today a request for review by the Supreme Court of his conviction on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice and of the subsequent $3,000 fine and a sentence of one year and a day.

The Corn Products Refining Company and its subsidiary sales companies, reported for publication today profit from operations before taxes and depreciation in the nine months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $22,834,070, compared with $15,479,632 on the same basis for the first nine months of last year.
A middle-aged man perched on a high stool at a long counter devouring a hamburger. Between bites he talked to his companion, who was similarly engaged.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- The forthcoming visit of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt drew columns of comment today in British newspapers, one of which called her "America's favorite 'aunt,'" and London's cockneys, impressed by stories of her energy in attacking social problems, hoped she would visit them to hear their troubles.

Esther Dorothy opened her new fur establishment at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon. Here is a woman in the fur business for women, a new departure in this field. She had previously opened a shop in Boston.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 20 -- Both Ezequiel Padilla, Foreign Minister, and General Lazaro Cardenas, Minister of National Defense, in press interviews today explained to the Mexican people the government's decision to allow Mexicans residing in the United States to enroll in the American armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that some older men would be furloughed from the Army to return to farm and factory jobs essential to the war effort as soon as younger men, especially the 18 to 19 year old youths, were available for induction into the military forces.

Mayor La Guardia devoted half an hour yesterday afternoon to a discussion of curbing excessive drinking when he conferred with Jack Townsend, president of Local 15 of the Bartenders Union and other union members.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

Buffeted by war clouds and menaced by mutters from devotees of the practical, all-purpose hat, the gay "little hat" made a very gallant stand yesterday at Bragaard's luncheon showing in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The House bill creating a Women's Reserve in the Coast Guard Reserve won a favorable report fro ma Senate commerce subcommittee today and was referred to the full committee for hearing tomorrow.

The Brooklyn Football Dodgers received their severest reprimand of the year at Ebbets Field yesterday. It was probably the toughest ordeal they've ever had to go through, but the head man, Mike Getto, gave it to every man and in a tone that left nothing to imagination.

With Count Fleet running and winning yesterday and Shut Out and Alsab scheduled to clash today, Jamaica is ending its Fall meeting in a blaze of championship competition. Count Fleet, who had set a world mile 2-year-old record at Belmont Park, dashed home first in the Thunderclap purse, for which the brown colt was a 1-to-4 favorite.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Airmen from the command of General Douglas MacArthur roared back into action yesterday after a one-day lay-off and probably caused "extensive damage" at the Japanese base of Buin, in the Northern Solomons, where shipping and an airfield were attacked for the fourth time in five days, it was announced today.

The thirty-two-page report on the country's military and naval aircraft, just published by the Office of War Information, is in some respects the finest document that has come out of Washington since Pearl Harbor. It gives the American public the kind of detailed information about our aircraft that it has long been eager to have.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, conferred yesterday with Mayor La Guardia and then with John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, on the demands by the Transport Workers Union for higher wages and a maintenance of membership clause for the city's rapid transit workers.

A minimum gain of thirty-five Republican seats in the House of Representatives at the Nov. 3 election was predicted yesterday by Representative J. William Ditter of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, in an interview at the Hotel Barclay.
One of the strangest sights in this topsy-turvy football season is a set of seven college gridiron greats remaining on top in The Associated Press poll two weeks in succession.
Indignation in labor circles here and in Washington has followed reported statements made by Rear Admiral Emory S. Land in a speech here Monday before the Investment Bankers Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Roosevelt gave his endorsement today to Senator Norris, independent, of Nebraska, for re-election, reaffirming his 1936 statement that the 81-year-old Nebraskan "was one of the major prophets of America" whose candidacy transcends State and party lines.
At the State-controlled public hunting area at Carmel, N.Y., the opening of the upland season was greeted on Monday by more gunners than had been expected.

An extraordinary campaign is under way in the Seventeenth District against Frederic R. Coudert Jr., who is a candidate for re-election to the State Senate. The character of this campaign is accurately revealed by a leaflet that comes to hand under the title "Who's Back of Coudert?" The charge is made that he is the candidate of Laval and Hitler.

So far as any one knows, Adolf Hitler's agents were not active last week in the State of Mississippi, but Hitler's work was being done there. It was being done by mobs which carried out three lynchings within that one week. The courts and police of Mississippi, whose authority was defied, are taking action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Declaring that current proposals for compulsory service in war production are merely "tinkering with the program for mobilizing America's economic resources," the House committee investigating national defense migration, of which Representative John H. Tolan of California is chairman, proposed today the statutory creation of an Office of War Mobilization as supreme authority for directing the war economy, military and civil.

Steady progress for the cooperative movement in Great Britain and China despite war conditions was reported last night by speakers at a meeting of the International Committee for Cooperative Reconstruction at the Hotel Commodore. The thirty persons present represented more than a dozen nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Representative Andresen of Minnesota told the House today that America's "middle class, backbone of the nation," was threatened with liquidation by current and impending taxes, and suggested that Congress "do something about it."

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- More than 530 German, Italian and Japanese submarines have been sunk or damaged by the British and United States Navies in the long, bitter battle to maintain the United Nations' sea-borne communications in the face of enemy attacks "enormously increased" over those of World War I, A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, revealed today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 20 -- The United States Government's decision not to regard Italian residents as enemy aliens has made a deep impression in Argentina because it destroys one of the arguments against a rupture of relations with the Axis that is used with great frequency by supporters of President Ramon Castillo's policy.
Jacob La Motta, 162 3/4, Bronx, stopped Bill McDowell, 154 1/4, Dallas, after forty-four seconds of the fifth round of the scheduled eight-round bout last night at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, complained to President Roosevelt today that New York City, Rochester, Philadelphia and Chicago had been discriminated against in distribution of Army and Navy clothing orders.

The scarlet muffler of the Red Cross worker, the saucy stripes of the student nurse and the dog-eared textbook of the first-aid pupil are familiar symbols of the contemporary scene. They are symbols, too, of the new scientific approach to health and home-making that characterizes the modern American woman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Secretary Knox has assigned the names of four cruisers lost in the Pacific -- the Houston, the Vincennes, the Astoria and the Quincy -- to new vessels of the same type now under construction.

The New York State Department of Insurance has approved the second set of reductions in passenger automobile insurance rates announced late last week by the National Association of Casualty and Surety Underwriters, making total reductions in recognition of gasoline rationing averaging around 30 per cent.

While the birth rate in New York City declined last week from the record-breaking mark of the preceding week, it was still far above corresponding weeks of recent years and well above the 1942 average to date, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday.
A cablegram of sympathy to Edouard Herriot, former French Premier and President of the defunct Chamber of Deputies, was sent yesterday by twenty-five prominent Americans.

Switching out of the December position into the distant months featured trading in cotton futures yesterday. Commission houses negotiated most of the transfers with spot merchants, who showed similar eagerness to dispose of March and May contracts.

Criticizing the Army for not having thought out all the aspects of the new bill to draft 18 and 19- year-olds, Mayor La Guardia suggested three changes in the bill in a talk over WABC at 10:30 o'clock last evening called "Putting Sense in the Draft Law."

VICHY, France, Oct. 20 -- In a radio broadcast addressed to French workers, whom he asked four months ago to volunteer for labor in Germany, Chief of Government Pierre Laval, France's unshakable guide toward collaboration with the Nazis, told them tonight that they must go to work in the plants of the Reich on government orders.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 20 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. promised here tonight that he would marshal every resource of the State to help win the war as James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, charged that Thomas E. Dewey, Mr. Bennett's Republican rival, was a political reactionary and was fomenting distrust and suspicion of the conduct of the war.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 20 -- James V. Bennett, Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, told the annual Congress of Correction of the American Prison Association today that under a new and more liberal classifying system all prisoners will be accepted for the armed services upon discharge or parole if they are recommended by the special selective board for their institution and by the armed service commander.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, urged the French nation by radio tonight to resist Chief of Government Pierre Laval's appeal for workers to go to Germany.
Sounding as though she were in the room, Mrs. Winston Churchill, speaking from "somewhere in England," described yesterday the work of the Y.W.C.A. in England.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 20 -- President Enrique Penaranda de Castillo urged the Chamber of Deputies today to consider at once the agreements between the Export-Import Bank and the Bolivian Government.

Former Supreme Court Justice Cornelius J. Smyth, chairman of the campaign committee supporting Jerry Finkelstein, Democratic and American Labor party candidate for State Senator in the Seventeenth Senatorial District, now represented by Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican candidate for re-election, announced yesterday that Governor Lehman had endorsed Mr. Finkelstein. In a letter to Mr. Finkelstein, the Governor wrote:

" The Time, the Place and the Girl," a musical comedy based on the show of the same title first produced in 1907, will have its postponed premiere this evening at the Mansfield under the auspices of Georges D. Gersene. The musical is derived from the original version by Will M. Hough, Frank R. Adams and Joe E. Howard, and has been brought up to date by Will Morrissey and John Neff.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Retail prices of women's nylon hose will be slashed, beginning Thursday, from prevailing "inflationary levels," under an order issued today by Leon Henderson, OPA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Roosevelt sees the effect of the voluntary meat rationing program in his daily menus, just like other Americans. He is finding less roast beef, pork and other rationed meats on the table, and more substitute dishes.

From the rice lands of Louisiana, Texas and Arkansas come reports of a record crop. Harvesting, which began early in August, will continue through this month. Already in Texas alone, the season's yield is said to exceed that of last year's by the impressive quantity of six million bushels.

Peggy Guggenheim opened her new gallery last evening with a reception held for the benefit of the American Red Cross. The gallery, at 30 West Fifty-seventh Street, has been named Art of This Century, and contains her entire collection of paintings, objects and sculpture representative of the various movements that, during the last three decades or so, have gone to compose modernism.

Scrap dealers began yesterday to haul away the city's collection of metal for the war while the City Council adopted unanimously a resolution commending newspaper publishers for the successful manner in which they had induced householders and industrial concerns to contribute.

Thirty-nine local department and specialty stores will participate in series of three cooperative advertisements to be run in nine New York newspapers during the first half of November, it was announced yesterday by the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 20 -- The entire Chilean Cabinet resigned this evening "to give the President complete freedom of action."
Operating results for the third quarter of this year were announced yesterday by three important steel companies.

While reorganization rail securities crumbled, Wall Street took stock yesterday of the endeavor of Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana to have speculative profits in them subject to a 90 per cent tax. Analysts agreed that the Senator is laboring under a faulty understanding of Section 77 reorganizations if he thinks that any speculator or group of speculators, or all speculators combined, can alter findings of fact once approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The National Labor Relations Board unanimously outlawed a closed shop contract today, ruling it an attempt to "legalize a conspiracy between the designated (bargaining) agent and the employer fraudulently to deprive" all pro-contract employer of their jobs.

Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto made public yesterday a letter to Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the State Racing Commission, calling on the commission to curtail horse racing to two days a week instead of six and to close all automobile parking spaces at race tracks.

Jean Watson, Canadian contralto, who made her New York debut a year ago, gave her second Town Hall recital last night. The event was a benefit for the Maple Leaf Club for Service Men of the Allied Nations at 601 Fifth Avenue.

A proposal by the Securities and Exchange Commission to require over-the-counter dealers to tell their customers the best independent market at the time of each trade was opposed yesterday by Joseph V. O'Leary, New York State Controller; Joseph D. McGoldrick, New York City Controller, and J.J. Mulcahy, controller of the Port of New York Authority, in a letter to Ganson Purcell, chairman of the SEC.

Although the complete season's schedule will not be ready until next week, Ned Irish, director of basketball at Madison Square Garden, announced a two-night invitation tournament will be staged at the Eighth Avenue arena on Monday, Nov. 23, and Wednesday, Nov. 25.
LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Great Britain's fast Mosquito bombers attacked three of Germany's most strongly defended areas today in another of their precision daylight raids.

Up at Manhattan College where the green begins, the title of the song Head Coach Herb Kopf and his staff were crooning yesterday was: "There'll Be Some Changes Made." The errors of the Jaspers in the game against the University of Detroit on Sunday still rankled in Kopf's breast and Herbie isn't a person who suffers in silence.

Officials of the Detroit Edison Company are faced with a perplexing problem these days. Recently officials of the city of Detroit asked the company to rebate to customers approximately $8,000,000 for 1942 since the company would be liable for approximately that amount in excess profits taxes in the current year.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- A break in the weather at Stalingrad was reported today to be limiting air activities, but not hampering the enemy's ground forces. With undiminished violence strong forces of tanks are battering the Russian positions in the city's northern industrial regions.

The possibility that thousands of owners of commercial vehicles may be unable to operate trucks, delivery vehicles and even hearses and ambulances because of their failure to fill out and file applications for a certificate of war necessity before Nov. 15 was called to the attention of the police and trade associations in this area yesterday by William J. Clark, regional manager of the Division of Motor Transport of the Office of Defense Transportation.

Two leading economists, one a woman and American-born, the other a man and foreign-born, engaged in a debate yesterday in which the native American citizen showed no fear of wartime legislation as a threat to the democratic way of life, while the naturalized citizen decried stringent measures as a menace to democracy.

In an effort to maintain production of copper in the face of a labor shortage and higher operating costs, a committee of nine men representing several war agencies in Washington is reviewing the present monthly production quotas of the individual producers.

The City College eleven met the Savage School of Physical Education in a two-hour scrimmage yesterday in Lewisohn Stadium. Dr. Joe Alexander arranged the scrimmage, feeling that his boys needed more work under actual game conditions.

PRINCETON, N.J, Oct. 20 -- Princeton's varsity eleven tested Brown's defense as set up by the third squad for the first time on University Field today as preparations got under way for Saturday's encounter with the undefeated New Englanders here.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, charged here tonight that his Democratic opponents had failed to develop any constructive program for the State's wartime needs but instead had complacently adopted the attitude of "let Washington do it."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Army, Navy and Marine Corps planes bombed Japanese troop concentrations and supply dumps on Guadalcanal Island on Sunday and Monday (Solomon Islands time), the Navy announced this evening, but otherwise a lull seems to have settled over that tropical battle front.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Jimmy Bivins, Cleveland's slugging Negro light heavyweight, invaded the heavyweight ranks again tonight to take a close decision from Bob Pastor of New York, before some 10,576 spectators in the Cleveland Arena.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Reuter reported today under an "Italian Frontier" dateline that an Italian Alpini regiment had mutinied at Gorizia, in Northern Italy, when it was ordered to the Russian front.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- There is "strong" evidence that the All-India Congress party has directed its so-called non-violence campaign to interrupt communications that would be vital in case of a Japanese invasion, the Duke of Devonshire. Under-Secretary of State for India, told the House of Lords today.

Anticipating enactment of legislation to draft youths 18 and 19 years old, high school boys in this city in "considerable numbers" are leaving their classrooms and enlisting in the armed forces officials of the Board of Education disclosed yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Gunners on United States Flying Fortresses who shot down seven of twenty Zeros in fierce air battles over New Britain Aug. 7 in support of the American attack on the Solomon Islands received silver stars today from Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney.

Lack of incentive to increase earnings, which will be one result of the passage of the tax bill now before Congress, will bring about a sharp reduction in the resistance toward increased costs, William J. Casey, chairman of the board of editors of the Research Institute of America, predicted yesterday at the closing session of the fourth Accounting Institute at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Ninety-seven areas, including New York City, in which there was still much unemployment and to which war contracts should be routed were reported to the War Production Board today by the War Manpower Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Production quotas for farm machinery and equipment were cut 50 per cent by a War Production Board order today, virtually concentrating output in the hands of small and intermediate producers. This concentration, which is the first to be applied to a major industry, will free the larger implement manufacturers for war work.
A method to convert household budgets to a wartime schedule is described in a booklet. "How to Win on the Home Front," published yesterday by the Public Affairs Committee, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

With only 4,000 domestic workers registered for jobs with the United States Employment Service here, as compared with 8,000 a year ago, and the shortage of such workers becoming increasingly acute, Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, yesterday urged householders to stagger their work as a means of making these workers available to the greatest possible number of employers.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York adopted last night the report of its judiciary committee recommending the reelection of Supreme Court Justices Peter Schmuck, Lloyd Church and Bernard Botein for the three Supreme Court vacancies to be filled on election day.

A new issue of $300,000 of temporary loan notes was scheduled yesterday by Chicopee, Mass., for award on Oct. 22. The notes will be dated Oct. 28, 1942, and will mature in $100,000 amounts on Feb. 17, 1943, April 15, 1943, and May 14, 1943.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Death is decreed as the post-war penalty for Nazi crimes in Poland that led to death or to "special suffering." The Polish Cabinet made this decision at a formal session, according to information now made public.

The announcement by the British Admiralty that 530 Axis submarines have been sunk or damaged since the start of the war is news of first importance. Even this figure does not represent a grand total; for it does not include losses inflicted by Russia, by France before her armistice, or the complete damage done by our own Navy.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new commercial space was Modell's, Inc., which leased a store in the building at 202 Broadway, near Fulton Street, through the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation, agents.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA (Delayed), Oct. 7 -- If the flies will please get off my arms and out of my mouth and eyes, I will write a little article comparing the job of war correspondent in this war and in the last one. In the last war I was not a correspondent, but I saw some in France.

In these days of widespread coffee shortage and possible rationing the following formula may be of interest to your readers. It came to the writer's notice in a European country where government restrictions on foreign exchange had led to scarcity and high cost of the delectable beverage.

Pleas of guilty to thefts of $30,000 of funds of the Provident Loan Society of New York in the last three years were entered in General Sessions yesterday by Mrs. Inez Cheyne, a widow, and trusted employe of the society for eighteen years, and John Carl Borrs, a former chain restaurant manager.
After nearly six months of deliberation the judges of the $12,500 Harper Brothers non-fiction manuscript contest announced yesterday their decision.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Driving the varsity against the freshmen through a long scrimmage in preparation for the Dartmouth game here Saturday, the Yale coaches today uncovered Stan Weiner and Bob Pickett, a pair of freshman breakaway halfbacks who scored several touchdowns apiece.

The Bowery Savings Bank has just sold the six last town houses which it had owned in the upper East Side section of Manhattan. The residences have been acquired by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, in a cash transaction, according to Wm. A. White Sons, brokers in the deal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- That a request to all war agencies to forecast their requirements for finished products for a year and a half in advance has been sent out by Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board Chairman, was revealed here tonight.

Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University charged last night that the government was trying to "freeze" the American press and the Bill of Rights in a domestic revolution which was attacking our traditional democracy under the cloak of war emergency.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, told a group at a dinner tonight that Thomas E. Dewey and John J. Bennett Jr. were wanting in the qualities required to meet the problems that face a wartime Governor in "the greatest State of the Union."

Scrapping the first part of the original inventory plan, which called for quarterly stock and sales reports, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, announced yesterday in Washington that an order controlling the inventories of finished consumers goods in the hands of wholesalers, retailers and manufacturers would be issued in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Disciplinary action against Major Lynn Farnol because of the erroneous story released at Mitchel Field, L.I., about fifth-column air markers has been changed to reprimand and reassignment.

New film attractions will arrive in two Broadway theatres this morning. At the Astor the new comer will be "For Me and My Gal," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical starring Judy Garland. Gene Kelly, who was featured in the stage hit, "Pal Joey," makes his screen debut in the film, as does Keenan Wynn and Lucille Norman.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The United Lutheran Church in America pledged its aid today to the nation's leaders and to "the men and women of the armed forces, at home and abroad, and to our country in this critical hour."

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 20 (AP) -- United States and British planes have struck heavy blows ashore, asea and aloft in a new, stepped-up offensive, communiques from the United States Army Air Forces and the Royal Air Force disclosed today.
LONDON, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- The British Navy for the first time in history has permanently accredited a civilian United States correspondent to the Home Fleet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Since July 1, 1940, some 500,000 new "living units" of all types have been built for war workers by the government or private industry at a cost of $2,000,000,000, John B. Blandford Jr., Administrator of the National Housing Agency, said today.

VICTOR HUGO'S long and turbulent life spanned much of the nineteenth century; Hugo's poems, plays and novels are among the glories of French literature; his valiant championship of political freedom and human rights made him a mighty force whose influence may yet be felt for good among his countrymen. Yet in this country few people read Hugo today or know anything about his spectacular career.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- In order to ascertain what United States soldiers want as Christmas gifts from home, Colonel A.C. Hahn, chief of the United States Postal Service in the European theatre of operations, has interviewed a number of soldiers himself, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Germany's need of French labor and the Nazi's desire to frighten the French into further "collaboration" by talking of an Allied attack on French colonies have been conspicuous in German broadcast propaganda in the last couple of days.

The apartment house containing fifty-four suites at 2962-64 Decatur Avenue, in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx, was sold by William J. and Charles A. Buckley to an investing client of James J. Leibman and William Rosan, attorneys.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 873, as against 896 in the preceding week and 782 in the similar period of 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 389, which compared with 363 for last Tuesday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, defending its right to require geographical integration of a holding company system and the constitutionality of section 11 (B) (1) of the "death sentence" clause, filed yesterday in the Second Circuit Court of Appeals here a brief seeking affirmation of its order of April 14 requiring the North American Company to drop all but the Union Electric Company of Missouri and its subsidiaries from the present $2,300,000,000 chain of utilities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Congress sent its largest tax bill in history to the White House today and President Roosevelt said he would sign it tomorrow to make higher excise levies on a long list of items effective Nov. 1.

Prices and volume increased yesterday in the stock market to the approximate levels of the recovery peak earlier in the month. Gains of a point and more were liberally scattered throughout the list at the close and this bridged the gap between the highs of early last week and the subsequent tapering off of values and business.
NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Joe Cronin, manager of the Boston Red Sox, is going overseas for the American Red Cross -- but he hopes he'll be back for baseball next year.

How to take your own measurements accurately and adequately for home dressmaking and fitting was the subject of the first lecture yesterday in a radio sewing course for beginners over Station WQXR under the auspices of Bloomingdale's.

Dorothy Thompson, the columnist, repudiated yesterday the use of her name by the Allied Voters Against Coudert, in their attempt to block the re-election of State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. in the Seventeenth Senate District.

The rediscount rate of one-half of 1 per cent which has just been established by the Federal Reserve Banks of Chicago, Philadelphia and Atlanta is the lowest charge for advances to member banks in the history of our Federal Reserve System. For that matter, it is undoubtedly the lowest discount rate in the history of central banking.

The Book-of-the-Month Club which frequently "repeats" authors it distributes, has laid its hand on Isak Dinesen again -- for the third time. The Danish author (the Baroness Karen Blixen) had her first book, "Seven Gothic Tales," taken by the club in 1934.

William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, in an interview here yesterday, said the board was considering the establishment of ten regional offices to handle requests of employers for permission to adjust wages within limits set up under the wage stabilization plan.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Oct. 21 -- Byron Darnton, a war correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was killed accidentally Sunday in an advanced operational area in New Guinea, it was announced today.

HOLLYVVOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -- John Craven, Broadway actor and son of Frank Craven, was signed to a term contract today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and will make his screen debut in William Saroyan's "The Human Comedy," replacing Gene Kelly, who has been switched to "Private Miss Jones."
Byron H. Uhl, district director of immigration and naturalization and a veteran of fifty years' service on Ellis Island, soon will retire from active duty, it was announced yesterday.
Selection of a new general manager of the Brooklyn Baseball Club may be made in three or four days, or it may take weeks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A relaxation of gas rationing restrictions which will benefit Florida vacation centers this Winter was announced tonight by the Office of Price Administration.

In a spirit of sacrifice the country has resigned itself to acquiescing in the demand for the drafting of the 18 and 19 year old classes. In the end, however, it will not be to the advantage of any one concerned if such a step is taken for false and misleading reasons.

Twelve detectives assigned to the office of Police Commissioner Valentine raided the Florida Republican Club at 2035 Second Avenue, between 104th and 105th Streets, at about 6:30 o'clock last night, arresting forty-seven men on gambling charges.

Although Argentina has not broken off diplomatic relations with the Axis powers, her artists won five prizes, more than went to any other Latin-American nation, in the competition held by the Museum of Modern Art for posters to help unite the Western Hemisphere against Axis aggression.

Dr. Evan C. Williams, vice president of the General Aniline and Film Company, has leased a large apartment in 280 Park Avenue through Culver, Hollyday Co., Douglas L. Elliman Co., agents. Another large lease reported yesterday was an eleven-room duplex in 1021 Park Avenue to Charles H. Marshall through Douglas Gibbons Co.

A majority of ranking radio network executives believe solution of the problems raised by the ban of the American Federation of Musicians on recordings can come only through direct negotiation with the union's leader, James C. Petrillo, and not through any protracted legal or economic battle, it was learned yesterday.

Criticizing the Office of Civilian Defense for having given two New Jersey concerns exclusive rights to manufacture and distribute stirrup pumps for household use in New York City, Councilman Hugh Quinn of Queens said in the City Council yesterday that he would move to amend the law to exclude both brands from the local market.
With the innovation of "meatless Tuesdays" yesterday, hotel and restaurant patrons began changing their eating habits for the duration to conserve red meats for the armed forces and for lendlease.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 21 -- The Russians announced today that their Stalingrad garrison had repulsed two furious German attacks supported by seventy tanks inside the city yesterday and quoted Nazi captives as saying their divisions had lost 70 per cent of their effectives in the last few days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Some of those who are obliged to try to explain to the outside world the purposes of the United States, so far as those purposes are now definable, wish that the picture they present could be less sketchy; that the authorized version of America's role in the world were more specific.

The Municipal Court term of Magistrate's Court was like a scene from a mad farce yesterday as five ranking bridge experts tried for three hours to persuade Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio that duplicate bridge is a game of skill and not chance.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Countrywide training of "foster parents" to care for tiny babies of war-working mothers was suggested today by Dr. Dorothy B. Nyswander, New York regional supervisor of the Federal Works Agency's war public services.
LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A British headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

An amendment to the Federal laws on deportation was proposed by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind here yesterday as the proper remedy for difficulties created by the tendency of alien seamen to quit the ships in which they arrive here and then seek employment on American ships at higher pay rates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- Here is a summary of the main features of the new tax bill:

Common stock dividend disbursements in the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were 8.8 per cent below the corresponding period in 1941. They amounted to $1,341,422,000 in cash, compared with $1,470,124,000, according to The Exchange, monthly magazine published by the New York Stock Exchange.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20 -- Twelve juvenile fillies, half of them eligible for Saturday's $20,000 added Selima Stakes, contested the Top Flight Purse today, but Max Marmorstein's Edie Jane, not named for the rich purse, scored in a brilliant effort to make it two straight at Laurel Park.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Wheat prices rose 1 1/2 cents a bushel in the early trading today on buying by shorts and mills induced by an announcement that the Commodity Credit Corporation would purchase cash wheat at the full loan price at country points where emergency wood or steel bins were available for storage purposes.

It cannot be said often enough. There can be too much emphasis on the better world for which the United Nations are fighting. It carries the danger of suggesting that our present world is not worth defending against Hitler.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the House of Commons today hailed the visit of Henry Morgenthau Jr., United States Secretary of the Treasury.

The four-story apartment group containing forty-eight suites at 146-52 Glenwood Avenue, in the Journal Square section of Jersey City, was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to the 150 Glenwood Avenue Corporation.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The railways were a feature in today's stock markets, the shortage of stock for sale tending to accelerate the rises. Junior home rail shares showed gains up to 20s, while in the foreign section both the ordinary and prior charges were 5s to 20s better.
BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 20 -- Following are textual excerpts from an address broadcast to the French people tonight by Chief of Government Pierre Laval:
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Six men of the crew of thirty-five were lost when a small United States merchant ship was torpedoed and sunk off the coast of South America early in October, it was revealed by the Navy Department yesterday. The ship was attacked in daylight by a submarine that sent a torpedo into her engine room.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- For the first time since Rudolf Hess's dramatic flight to England Germany tonight took responsibility more or less directly for him. This action was linked with new and dire German threats of reprisals against prisoners in German hands.

Turning his attention to the weakest phase of the attack on which depends Columbia's hopes of victory over Penn, Coach Lou Little worked on the Lions' running game all yesterday afternoon at Baker Field.

A KIND-HEARTED citizen tried to cheer up a coach whose football team had been running behind since the start of the season. "That's all right. I can bear it," said the coach. "We're losing only one game a week."

Today THE TIMES has the sorrowful duty of announcing the death of Byron Darnton -- "Barney" to more friends than he could ever count. Other members of our reporting staff have risked their lives in this war. Barney was the first to fall. He died at the height of his powers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- G-men were sent in to the South today for the third time in nine months to investigate Negro lynchings.
Mayor La Guardia, whose talents are as many as they are sometimes surprising, turned auctioneer yesterday afternoon for the benefit of United China Relief. He was a good one.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Germany now has four Army groups operating in Russia, each commanded by a general who is directly responsible to Adolf Hitler, as a result of his military reorganization, a British source said today. The four Army groups and their commanders were listed as:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Shock and a deep sense of personal loss were expressed by newspaper colleagues of Byron Darnton, NEW YORK TIMES war correspondent killed in the line of duty in New Guinea.
