Mr. Darnton was widely known and respected by members of the Washington press corps and by the many correspondents from foreign capitals of the world who are gathered here at present.

Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York, the country's highest-ranking woman contract bridge player, and for the year 1941 the top-ranking player of either sex, won another tournament yesterday. Paired with Miss Ruth Sherman of New York, she took first place in the women's pair contest of the metropolitan championships in progress here at the Park Central Hotel.
Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel 3d have come from Newport to the Pierre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Roosevelt endorsed the candidacy of Senator Norris of Nebraska, nominated Captain Edward L. Cochrane, new chief of the Navy's Bureau of Ships, to be a rear admiral, and held his press conference.

Striking new wartime applications of flat glass which are producing "some of the most important aids to ultimate victory of our armed forces" were described yesterday by John D. Biggers. president of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, in a statement of earnings to stockholders.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Archduke Albrecht von Habsburg is the head of a marauding band of Hungarian ruffians who are terrorizing Vojvodina Province, Yugoslavia, according to the Yugoslav Government in London. The report, said to come from "the most reliable sources," places Albrecht in personal command of an outfit calling itself the Rodjos Guards.

The National Association of Manufacturers issued a statement yesterday commending the War Labor Board for its three-point program designed to reduce the number of "wildcat" strikes interfering with war production.

Jay N. Whipple, partner in the Chicago investment firm of Bacon, Whipple Co., was elected president of the Investment Bankers Association of America at the concluding session yesterday of the two-day annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Mass trials to determine whether German-American Bund members are entitled to retain United States citizenship acquired through naturalization are in prospect, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa revealed yesterday. Thirty actions to nullify the citizenship certificates of former Bundists on the ground that their oaths of allegiance to the United States were insincere and fraudulent are now pending.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A voice vote of the Senate passed and returned to the House this evening the Second Supplemental War Appropriation and Contract Authorization Bill of the current fiscal year, carrying $15,851,196,887, most of it for the Navy, and providing for the construction of 2,100,000 tons of new combat and auxiliary vessels, 14,611 naval airplanes and a thousand small defense craft.

Four checkers at the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's freight depot at the foot of West Twelfth Street and four motor truck drivers were arrested yesterday in an alleged conspiracy in which $75,000 in merchandise was stolen from the depot's platform in the last few months and sold to fences.

More than a year has passed since the Air Warden Service was inaugurated. During that time the wardens have walked the streets in all kinds of weather. We've given freely of our time -- attending first-aid courses, lectures, meetings, military drill and, of late, have been called out of bed in the wee hours of the morning when the alert sounded or the blue signal beckoned us.

The biggest step forward so far in getting the city's household scrap metal from the salvage heaps to the steel mills was announced yesterday at City Hall by Mayor La Guardia. It was that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation had agreed to move 500 tons of metal a day to its mills directly without using intermediary scrap dealers.

Those who can recall the fashions of twenty years ago received a distinct shock yesterday afternoon when they walked into the rooms on the roof of the St. Regis Hotel, where the Gotham Hosiery Company was giving a press cocktail party.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 21 -- By order of the German authorities in Norway, an area sixty miles long and some twenty wide along the Swedish frontier, beginning roughly north of Bodoe and ending slightly south of Tromsoe, has been proclaimed a prohibited area and considerable German forces have been concentrated there.

Funeral services for Byron Darnton, war correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in the Southwestern Pacific area, who was killed accidentally last Sunday at an advanced operational base in New Guinea, were scheduled to be held there yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The new types of canned soups which are beginning to appear on grocers' shelves are higher in food value than the old-style soups -- one reason why most of them cost a few cents more, the Office of Price Administration told consumers today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The French people were encouraged by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to continue and increase their opposition to the forced labor program of Chief of Government Pierre Laval in a statement that bracketed M. Laval with the adherents of Reichsfuehrer Hitler.

The latest tabulation of individual statistics released by the National Football League shows three Green Bay Packers and a Brooklyn Dodger in front in the five departments of play, a situation reminiscent of last year when week after week Green Bay and Brooklyn players dominated.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- For the better part of an hour today Army's football forces scrimmaged on the Plain in their last hard workout before Saturday's visit to Cambridge for the renewal of the series with Harvard.

Dr. Horacio Oyhanarte, former Minister of Foreign Affairs of Argentina, who arrived yesterday at La Guardia Field aboard a Pan American transatlantic clipper, revealed that he was returning to his native country "to take an active part in the political picture."

A proposal that the good neighbor principle, a "proven hemisphere policy," be expanded into "a new international order" after the war was made yesterday by Wayne Chatfield Taylor, Under-Secretary of Commerce, at a luncheon arranged by the New York Board of Trade in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to honor the Republic of Brazil.

With a warning that "the stern realities of war, sacrifice and persons danger" were ahead, 753 midshipmen, the largest graduating class in the two-year history of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University, received commissions as ensigns yesterday morning at ceremonies in Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Advices from the Continent indicated today that the appeal of General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French leader, for "revolt against treason" was likely to have more success than Chief of Government Pierre Laval's demand for more skilled Frenchmen for German war factories.

Recent increases in new orders for semi-vitreous dinnerware, together with a decline in output resulting from a steady loss of labor, has forced many potters to close their books for the balance of the year, it was learned yesterday. A few factories are taking orders for delivery in the latter part of November.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Sharply criticizing what he called lack of coordination between five government agencies handling production and distribution of petroleum and its products, Senator O'Mahoney urged immediate coordination of their activities in a report to the Senate today.

WITH ADVANCE R.A.F. FIGHTER SQUADRONS, in Egypt, Oct. 21 -- Air activity over the fighting area in the Western Desert was appreciably increased yesterday and today. In fact, the roar of motors overhead never ceases from dawn to dusk and it seems to be louder than on any preceding occasion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Roosevelt gave the Pacific War Council at its regular Wednesday meeting today what Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, described as a "factual report" on the situation in the Solomon Islands.

Frank Koch, the former city fireman who is under investigation by the Kings County District Attorney's office in connection with the hold-up murder of Fireman Thomas J. Hitter on Oct. 30, 1938, submitted yesterday to lie-detector tests in the prosecutor's office.

ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- Miss Elsie M. Bond, assistant secretary of the State Charities Aid Association, was named today chairman of the State War Council's Committee on Child Care, Development and Protection. The committee is to prepare plans for caring for thousands of small children while working mothers are engaged in various phases of war work.

Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, was re-elected chairman of United China Relief yesterday at the organization's annual meeting here. Other officers re-elected were Wendell L. Willkie, honorary chairman; W.R. Herod, vice chairman; James L. McConaughy, president; B.A. Garside, vice president and secretary; James G. Blaine, treasurer, and Daniel P. Adams, assistant treasurer.

Manuel Rionda, president of the Manati Sugar Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that, barring unforeseen factors, he would be in favor of dividend action by next June if by that time the company had a $2,500,000 cash position and if the government had bought the company's entire sugar crop at prices at least equal to those paid for the last year's crop.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Since the Atlantic Charter, now the proclaimed peace program of the United Nations, is essentially a reiteration of the principles prescribed for the world by Woodrow Wilson in 1918, those who strive to get the maximum of propagandist use from that document are constrained to recall the unhappy sequel to the Wilsonian doctrines and to seek solid ground for arguing that next time it will be different.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- Operations at Stalingrad during the last three days, fought in a driving rain, have brought the enemy little except an increased death roll. Today's reports give a clearer picture of the fighting since last week-end. They record incessant attacks, highly critical moments for the defenders and amazing recoveries at times when a further sag on the narrow front seemed inevitable.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Samuel Nuzzo, former business agent of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, A.F. of L., was indicted today on eighty-nine counts charging forgery and grand larceny by the special grand jury investigating the affairs of the local on an order issued in February by Governor Lehman.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 21 (AP) -- An all-woman murder jury, chosen to try 32-year-old James Kearns of Trenton on a charge of shooting his estranged bride to death six; years ago, was locked up tonight in the Hotel Hildebrecht here.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- While news vendors sold papers bearing dates 137 years apart -- those of the last century ones being reprints of The Times of London --representatives of the British Dominions and colonies and of European and Allied nations laid wreaths today at the base of Lord Nelson's column in Trafalgar Square at a ceremony commemorating the famous naval victory.

In the first eight months of this year the total of income payments to all individuals in the United States rose 22 per cent, according to the calculations of the Department of Commerce. The largest single gain was in wages and salaries. They were up about 25 per cent. All groups gained except one -- dividends and interest.

Although consumers of live poultry here face a cut of at least 20 per cent in supplies because of the threatened withdrawal of the available poultry cars, the city officials are "helpless" in the situation, Markets Commissioner Daniel P. Wooley explained yesterday.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 21 (AP) -- A brush fire which swerved tonight into Topanga Canyon, in the Santa Monica Mountains, was checked at least temporarily after the 3,300 residents of the canyon had been ordered to leave their homes.

Thirteen governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms whose terms are to expire next month have been renominated. Two members have been named to fill vacancies and a successor nominating committee has been nominated.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 21 -- Little basis for Democratic optimism appears to exist in Rochester, where a well-entrenched Republican organization is determined to do its best to elect Thomas E. Dewey as Governor. This despite the fact that Mr. Dewey is not personally the most popular Republican in the State, so far as the Monroe County G.O.P. is concerned.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Dr. Frank F. Marino of New Rochelle, United States Army captain on trial for manslaughter in Westchester County Court, denied flatly from the witness stand today that he performed an abortion which resulted last March 28 in the death of Miss Cleo Florence Moore, 19-year-old juke box "hostess."

Lieut. Comdr. Lewis S. Parks, U.S.N., a hero of the present war, told the officers and employes of the Kollmorgen Optical Corporation last night at a dinner in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, that the war would not be won solely by the purchase of war bonds but through the use of materials and men.

HEADQUARTERS, ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- The powerful Japanese radio station on Kiska Island, over which the Japanese in halting English have been telling American fliers that they were all to die at the hands of the Japanese, was silent today, ripped and torn apart by American cannon and machine-gun fire.

In North Carolina recently the school system, faced with a shortage of drivers for its fleet of 5,000 buses, decided to use women operators. According to officials, the women, young and attractive, drive buses more efficiently than men and display to a high degree a constant alertness and caution.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Longs-moldering resentment against the administrative policies of John B. Keenan, Director of Public Safety here, erupted at a testimonial dinner given last night for a retired police lieutenant, resulting in a chain of hectic incidents that made Police Department history.

As the campaign for the Governorship enters its last two weeks the position of Mr. Alfange, the Labor party candidate, becomes more and more remarkable. By every available test of sentiment Mr. Alfange will receive only a very small percentage of the total vote.

Solicitor General Henry Epstein, Democratic candidate for Attorney General, declared last night that the election of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, was needed to prevent wasteful appropriations and impairment of social welfare laws by a Republican-controlled Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Priority ratings having proved ineffective, eight government agencies were bluntly told today by Donald M. Nelson to stop all non-military construction for the Federal Government which is not essential to the war.

TORONTO, Oct. 21 -- Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn, whose colorful political career and caustic comment often brought him afoul the Federal Government and at times injected him into international prominence, resigned tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Sports schedules of many American schools which have to use motor transportation to get their teams to games may have to be revised and curtailed extensively this Winter.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell has served notice that she will seek to collect "many thousands of dollars" damages from nearby Hillsborough Township and its officials for "inconvenience and expense" they caused her by demanding payment of $13,850,705 in personal taxes.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 21 -- After a day of feverish activity in government circles that drew party leaders and other prominent political figures to the Presidential Palace, a new Cabinet -- the second since Juan Antonio Rios became President on April 2 -- took the oath of office late this evening.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Complete overhauling of the Federal price control structure was urged today by Albert W. Hawkes, Republican nominee for the United States Senate.

Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Great Britain won yesterday a judgment dismissing the $1,000,000 libel suit brought against him by William Griffin, publisher of The New York Enquirer, who is under indictment in Washington on charges of conspiracy to lower the morale of the armed forces of this country.

Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, Republican candidate for Congress in Connecticut, has withdrawn as a sponsor for a dinner to be given at the Hotel Astor next Tuesday for the benefit of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, it was learned yesterday.

" The Damask Cheek," a new comedy by John van Druten and Lloyd Morris, will have its deferred premiere tonight at the Playhouse under Dwight Deere Wiman's banner. Flora Robson has the starring role. A comedy of manners, the time is 1909 and the locale an aristocratic menage in the East Sixties, New York City.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Ohio State's Buckeyes, the nation's greatest offensive aggregation two weeks in a row, have climbed from second to first in team rushing, thus backing up the No. 1 rating given them again in The Associated Press poll of sports writers.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Allied submarines have sunk ten Axis supply ships so far this month in the Mediterranean, a recaptulation showed today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 21 -- In an article in today's Popolo d'Italia Carlo Scorza, former secretary of the Fascist party and one of the hierarchs of the regime, called on Italians everywhere to "have faith in the victorious destiny of Mussolini."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The popular vote for Federal, State and local candidates on Tuesday, Nov. 3, may rise to a point that will refute those public pulse-testers who report a state of apathy among the electorate. What has been labeled apathy may prove to be only the silence of the disgruntled, although the available registration figures mathematically demonstrate that in many areas the vote will fall far be- low recent elections.

NEWARK, N.J, Oct. 21 -- Senator William H. Smathers in a statement made public here today linked his Republican adversary with Representative Fred Hartley Jr. of the Tenth New Jersey Congressional Districts whom he described as an isolationist and obstructionist.

Before Winter comes in Russia there is an interval which the Germans have christened the "mire season." Berlin has just announced its arrival. It brings rain and mud as a dismal promise of the snow and ice to follow. It is in such weather that Hitler must now finish his Summer offensive.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21 -- It may not have been exactly a "fit day out for man or beast," but the Tigers of Princeton worked for two and a half hours at University Field today, preparing for Saturday's encounter with Brown at Palmer Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Taking advantage of conditions which were similar to those in the Princeton game, Penn's varsity squad today prepared for Columbia's invasion. There was a general improvement in bah handling.

Frantic efforts yesterday on the part of some stores to unload stocks of nylon hosiery at prevailing prices before imposition today of considerably lower OPA ceilings under Regulation 95, were reported here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, told the opening session of the American Municipal Association today that civilian defense had made "heartening progress'' in American cities in the last few months, but that it still needed much more development.

Many executives of the War and Navy Departments, the War Production Board and other government agencies occupied with prosecution of the war will address the annual meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers, to be held Dec. 2 to 4 at the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday by William P. Witherow, president of the organization.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Full maintenance of teaching programs during the war emergency and careful guarding of playground and recreation facilities were urged by Dean Alfange, the American Labor party's candidate for Governor, in a speech here tonight.

Intensive workouts were staged by the Football Dodgers and the Giants yesterday as the intracity rivals continued to ready themselves for their National League clash on Sunday at Ebbets Field. The Giants were favorites in the 1941 engagement at the Brooklyn ball park, but were set back, 16 -- 13.

Many wholesalers and jobbers reported sold-up conditions yesterday at the Spring shoe show at the Hotel New Yorker. Covering against possible labor shortages in the industry the early part of next year, buyers were active in all branches of the market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Secretary Stimson appealed to Congress today, on the eve of Senate consideration of the bill to lower the draft age to 18 years, to reject the proposed amendment to prohibit the sale of all alcoholic beverages, including wines and beer, on military reservations or in adjacent communities.

The Republic Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries announced yesterday, in a statement to stockholders covering the third quarter of 1942, a net profit of $2,581,100 after all charges and $18,400,000 provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes.
LONDON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- The Axis "war of nerves" on the treatment of war prisoners grew in bitterness today as Germany indicated she would scrap completely the Geneva convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Philip Murray, President of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and John Green, president of the C.I.O.'s Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, asked President Roosevelt today to remove Rear Admiral Emory S. Land as chairman of the United States Maritime Commission and War Shipping Administrator.

Lewis H. Brown, president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, reported yesterday in a statement to stockholders consolidated net income of $1,085,947 for the third quarter, against $1,470,183 for the similar quarter of last year. Earnings on each share of common stock after preferred dividends were $1.23, against $1.62 a share for the three months ended on Sept. 30, 1941. Sales increased to $28,074,219 from $25,941,410, Mr. Brown pointed out.

Four new films will have local premieres this morning. "My Sister Eileen," with Rosalind Russell, Brian Aherne and Janet Blair in the starring roles, will be the new offering at the Radio City Music Hall. The Columbia comedy was directed by Alexander Hall and produced by Max Gordon, who also produced the current stage hit of the same name.

Lee J. Eastman, president of Packard Motors, has leased a furnished apartment in Essex House, at 160 Central Park South, through William A. White Sons. The lease was one of many reported yesterday on the East Side, including a rental of a ten-room suite in 1040 Park Avenue by Jack Schiffer through the J.H. Taylor Management Corporation and Warren Marks Associates.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 21 -- Because of wartime uncertainties, no invitation was issued by any city for the next convention of the United Lutheran Church of America, which closed its biennial convention today.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 21 -iThe belief that General DouglasI MacArthur was being handicapped by the lack of "centralized thoughtI and command" in the conduct ofI the war in the Pacific was voicedI tonight by Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce l in a speech before 350 members and guests of the Westport Republican Women's Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it has simplified the forms which some 25,000 companies use in filing quarterly financial reports with that office. The data supplied voluntarily by the companies provides basic financial information required for studies of price control.
CAIRO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Royal Air Force and British Middle East Command:
Within a short time the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Editors will gather to consider awards for the outstanding fishing achievements of the year.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 21 -- A merger of three of this city's largest churches, now faced with the task of filling vacant pastorates, was proposed today. One institution, to be known as "The Federated Church of East Orange," would be formed by joining Calvary Methodist, Munn Avenue Presbyterian and First Congregational Churches.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique issued early today:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Registration figures for Westchester County, as compiled by the Westchester Board of Elections today showed a possible total vote of 222,520 in the coming election, a drop of 31,192, or 12.3 per cent, under the total of 253,712 for the last Gubernatorial race in 1938.
The case in favor of the poll tax has failed to receive adequate presentation.

Mitchell F. Hepburn became Premier of Ontario in 1934, in a Liber al landslide that was sometimes compared to the New Deal movement in the United States. One of his first political actions was to begin a "battle with the money barons" over hydroelectric contracts and he pronounced himself "well to the left" but he had been involved, since 1937, in a struggle with the unions of the C.I.O.

The prospects for a drastic revision of the government's policy on distributing steel among war plants were "distinctly stronger" at midweek, according to Iron Age. The publication reports that steel makers, who favor a "budget" plan for regulating the flow of metal to consumers, appear to have come out ahead of the automotive men who have been pushing a steel distribution plan of their own.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Proposing a new yardstick for the measurement of square mileage in the service area of a public utility company, counsel for the Middle West Corporation asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to approve a plan for the establishment of the Central and Southwest Utilities Company as a top holding company with five operating subsidiaries serving an area 1,220 miles in length.

A chestnut filly named Dark Discovery became a giant killer at Jamaica yesterday when she toppled both Alsab and Shut Out in the $16,550 Gallant Fox Handicap, the long run of a mile and five furlongs which featured the final day of the Metropolitan Jockey Club meeting.

A somewhat altered philosophy appears to be ruling the special offerings on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Yesterday a successful offering was delayed intentionally to 12:40 o'clock so that firms on the West Coast might have an opportunity to work on it.

LONDON, Oct 21 -- Threatening death or other severe punishment on any United Nations airmen found "guilty" of "inhuman acts" in air raids upon Japan, Tokyo today gave the names of four United States fliers claimed to have been captured during the raid upon the Japanese capital last April and promised to publish the names of other American airmen accused of attacking various non-military objectives.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 21 -- Wars cannot be won with "an unholy ratio" of one to one between industrial workers and armed forces, a figure based on comparison of present American employment with the proposal of a 13,000,000-man Army, Alfred C. Fuller, president of the Manufacturers Association of Connecticut, declared here today at the group's annual meeting.

Stop wondering whether you're ever going to find time for some serious cooking, whether you're ever going to be able to make those hearty, homely desserts that your family craves now that Autumn has piqued their appetites. Even if you devote hours each day to the Red Cross or the Motor Corps, you can, with almost no effort at all, present the members of your household with a brown, crisp, delicious strudel.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Holders of shares in the Amsterdam Stock Exchange worth more than 100,000 guilders, (about $54,000) acquired after Dec. 31, 1941, can be compelled to sell them at forced sale or to turn them over to the Bank of the Netherlands, according to a decree issued by M.M. Rost van Tonningen, Dutch Nazi leader whom the Germans appointed secretary-general of finance and president of the bank.

Joseph Goebbels, German Minister of Propaganda, has admitted in his weekly article in the Reich that the British are better off than the Germans regarding food, according to a German broadcast recorded yesterday by Reuter.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 22 -- Reinforced Russian defenders of Stalingrad seized the initiative in a factory area yesterday and swarmed back through several buildings, a communique reported today, and south of the city the Germans were reported to have been hurled back several miles.

WASHINGTON, Oct 21 -- Two American destroyers, the Meredith and O'Brien, have been lost in the Solomon Islands within the last few days, while American planes have scored bomb hits on a Japanese cruiser and a destroyer and have shot down twelve Japanese planes, the Navy announced tonight.

FLYING combat planes in this war is a terrific test of the human frame, which is why there is so much stress on physical training of Army and Navy aviation cadets. This observer has at hand two almost massive volumes compiled by Army and Navy officials for the guidance of instructors and students in their aviation training programs.

Realizing of profits in the afternoon nipped yesterday another forward push by the stock market. The halt in the fresh recovery on the Stock Exchange came after prices had equaled their highest levels of the year under revived demand.

With the announcement yesterday by the Navy Department in Washington of the sinking of a medium-sized United States merchant ship and another medium-sized vessel of Papama registry, The Associated Press's compilation of ships sunk by enemy submarines in the Western Atlantic since Pearl Harbor passed the 500 mark and rose to 501.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A husband's dissatisfaction with the coffee that his wife said she had been "lucky to get" has led to exposure of an extensive black market in Massachusetts and a promise by officials of the Office of Price Administration that it will be wiped out.

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City draft director, said yesterday that he was in agreement with Mayor La Guardia's contention that men deferred from military service should be willing to participate in their community's civilian defense activities. The director refrained from commenting, however, on the Mayor's desire to compel all deferred men to join a civilian defense unit.
FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND ARMY, LEBANON, Tenn., Oct. 21 -- The third week of massive manoeuvres here indicates why the second World War is slowing down in its pace.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 21 -- James R. McKee, 84 year old son-in-law of President Benjamin Harrison and one of the principal figures in the formation of the General Electric Company in 1893, committed suicide at his North Street home this morning by firing a .38 caliber pistol bullet into his right temple.

Captain Edward Macauley, Deputy War Shipping Administrator, will speak at the dedication of the Hamilton Farms United Seamen's Service Rest and Recuperation Center on the C. Suydam Cutting estate near Gladstone, N.J., Saturday afternoon, it was announced yesterday by Douglas P. Falconer, national executive director of the United Seamen's Service.

Professional and amateur strategists are agreed that it will be hard to win the war in the Far East unless Burma is wrested from the Japanese. Amateur strategists note the end of the monsoon season and hope that the chance for attack may be near. Generals in the field know the difficulties of the terrain and must be sure that their preparations are adequate.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The knotty problems posed by soaring wages were tackled by the House of Commons today in an ill-tempered debate that failed to accomplish much beyond giving the matter an airing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A series of three White House conferences on shipping and shipbuilding problems emphasized today the importance of transportation in the offensive plans for the United Nations.

The carryover of ranch-bred mink skins this year will be considerably less than in 1941 and it is now apparent that by the time the new crop of such skins comes into the market the big supply of pelts which disturbed the fur trade last Winter will have been largely consumed, Maurice Cantor, president of the New York Auction Company, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission voted finally today to reject the request of Station WNYC of the New York municipal broadcasting system for longer operating hours. The decision was on a vote of 5 to 2, with Commissioners George H. Payne and Paul Walker opposed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A Navy Department communique:
LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Richard Welling, lawyer and for many years one of the most active civic workers in New York, heading many clubs and leagues for self-government and for youth guidance, was honored yesterday at the City Club. The occasion was the publication tomorrow of Mr. Welling's story of his life work, a book entitled "As the Twig Is Bent."

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Flying over the English Channel in weather suitable for daylight raiding -- a clear blue sky and brilliant sunshine -- United States Flying Fortresses bombed the enemy submarine base at Lorient, France, as well as the airdrome at Maupertus, near Cherbourg, this afternoon. From these operations, which were supported by squadrons of Allied fighters, three bombers were missing.

The National Better Business Bureau will make an attack on "shortage appeals" in advertising copy, Kenneth Barnard, general manager of the Chicago Better Business Bureau and chairman of the national group's wartime activities committee, reported yesterday, following a meeting of the committee at the Hotel Lexington.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 21 -- Scrimmage on a regular-game basis was ordered by Commander John E. Whelchel, Navy's head football coach, today as he primed the midshipmen for the meeting with Georgia Tech here Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Legal power to bring about orderly marketing of livestock products was delegated today by Donald M. Nelson, production chief, to the Secretary of Agriculture, Claude R. Wickard. While it covers cattle, calves, sheep and swine, its application is expected to be confined this year to the marketing of the biggest crop of hogs in the history of the United States, which will be coming to market in November and December.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Roosevelt signed the record-breaking new tax bill today soon after it reached his desk. His approval before midnight was necessary so that a long list of higher excise levies could become effective on Nov. 1, instead of a month later. The difference to Federal revenues is $65,000,000.
As up-to-the-minute as today's newspaper, Fall and Winter fashions were presented yesterday by Arnold Constable at the Waldorf-Astoria.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -It fell to an elder statesman from a distant part of the British Commonwealth today, when this island was celebrating Nelson's victory at Trafalgar, to sound a new call to arms.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Home rails provided the feature today in a generally bright stock market business, junior issues being traded on a considerable scale. Southern preferred gained 20s, while Great Western and London North Eastern preferred went up 10s each. South American rails also improved with Buenos Aires Great Southern and Buenos Aires Western up 1/4, prior charges rising 10 to 30s.

The Santa Claus of the Bowery, an elderly gentleman with long white whiskers and sideburns and an amply rounded paunch to complete the traditional figure, was revealed yesterday following his death as John Hickfield, enemy alien.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Chungking had a three-hour air raid alarm ending at 11 o'clock tonight. An undetermined number of enemy planes attempted to reach the provisional capital "by several routes" but were turned back by thick mists covering all the Szechwan Province.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Six years ago Senator George Norris of Nebraska, running for the seat which he has held with honor since 1913, received a warm endorsement from President Roosevelt. Since Mr. Norris was running by petition, as an independent, against a Democratic as well as a Republican candidate, the President had to break his own party line.
VICHY, France, Oct. 21 -- Lorient, the naval harbor on the Brittany coast, sustained a heavy bombardment by the British Royal Air Force in daylight today, according to an announcement here.

Manhattan sloshed through a muddy two-hour scrimmage with the freshmen at Manhattan Field yesterday as the squad continued to prepare for the meeting with powerful Duquesne at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Liberty National Bank and Trust Company, trustee of the Central of Georgia Railway, has filed a petition in Federal Court here asking payment of past due interest on $7,000,000 of Central of Georgia bonds.

Pierre Laval, past master of lies, ex- pert in hypocrisy, specialist in treason, outdid himself in his broadcast to the French people on Tuesday night. Germany has plundered occupied France by force and trickery. She is starving the French people. She continues to murder innocent French citizens.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Flying Fortresses on their longest foray of the war in Europe smashed in daylight today at French bases. The precision bombing fortresses hit the U-boat base at Lorient on the Breton coast of France and the Nazi airdrome at Maupertus, near Cherbourg, from which aircraft work with submarines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Robert C. Brown Jr., Chicago patent lawyer, and Waldemar Kaempffert, science editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, urged at a Senate Military Affairs subcommittee hearing today the creation of an Office of Technological Mobilization, through which the country's scientists and laboratories could be used in the war effort.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The WPB is embarking upon a program of concentration of production in industry to speed the war effort, the extent and shape of which "must depend upon the way the war develops," Joseph L. Weiner, deputy director, Office of Civilian Supply, told members of the Association of Commerce here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- The House adopted today a conference report on the $15,851,196,887 appropriations bill providing the Navy with funds to build 14,611 planes and authorizing 500,000 tons of aircraft carriers and 500,000 tons of cruisers.
Twenty-one-year-old Edna Skinner can't eat spinach. But Popeye and science to the contrary, it hasn't stopped her from helping to sell $5,000,000 worth of war bonds.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The question of immediate trial for Rudolf Hess arose Oct. 15 when the Tass agency in Moscow circulated the reply of Soviet Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff Molotoff to a 10-month-old communication from a number of European governments in exile.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Roosevelt signed the tax bill, conferred with the Pacific War Council and discussed the shipping situation with a group including Maritime Commissioners Land and Vickery, Lewis O. Douglas and Harry Hopkins; his visitors included Andrew J. Higgins, Lord Halifax and Lord Camerose, Admiral Standley, Representative McCormack and Byron Price.

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 78,956,000 barrels, a decline of 775,000 from the 79,731,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Declaring governmental mobilization of men and women for war production inevitable and urgent, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, promised today a Senate Military Committee that within two weeks he would send a detailed legislative program to President Roosevelt for his consideration and recommendations.

To have served for fifty years on Ellis Island is to have been part of American history in the making. Byron H. Uhl, district director of immigration and naturalization, can carry that proud thought into retirement with him.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 21 -- A contrast between the Democratic and Republican record on the performance of campaign promises was drawn by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti at a Democratic campaign rally here tonight.
Excerpts from the address of Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts yesterday, as dispatched from London by The Associated Press and Reuter, follow:

At her harpsichord recital, last night in Town Hall, Wanda Landowska repeated the pronounced success registered in the same surroundings earlier in the year when she first returned to the local concert platform after a prolonged absence.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- In the present air battles on the Stalingrad and Leningrad fronts important new tactics are being evolved as new or modified types of aircraft are introduced on each side. Both Russian and German High Commands are using planes in closer coordination with the ground forces than ever before.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Although the Moscow radio and Russian newspapers continued to call for immediate trial of Rudolf Hess, deputy German leader who is a prisoner of the British, no such suggestion from the Soviet Government has been made to the British Government.

Camera studies by Roman Vishniac, taken in countries overrun by Nazi forces, have been placed on view at the New School for Social Research. In grim contrast with picnics and a street scene in a little Russian town before the blight fell are close-ups of children showing fear in their faces, the old people without hope, beggars, pushcart tradesmen in stormy weather with their poor and scanty wares, and other tragic subjects.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, closing a hearing on an application by the Elizabethtown Consolidated Gas Company for permission to increase rates to meet uncontrollable costs, reminded the company today of the board's reluctance to allow rate increases during the war.

HONOLULU, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander in chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, said in a speech today that success in the battle of the Solomon Islands rested on "the quality of our leadership."

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 21 -- Under the heading, "A Dismal Failure," The Daily Californian, campus newspaper at the University of California, asserted today that 99 per cent of the more than 10,000 students "don't give a damn" about the war effort.

A series of industry operations charts, enabling manufacturers in four important light manufacturing industries to tell at a glance what war items they can make, has been issued by the New York-Northern New Jersey office of the War Production Board, John F. McKernan, regional deputy director in charge of production service, announced yesterday.

The shortage of meat and fat products will cause "a breakdown of the German nation in 1943" and lead to its internal disruption, Dr. Stefan de Ropp, director of the Polish Information Center, declared yesterday at a luncheon held under the auspices of the League for Industrial Democracy at the Hotel Commodore.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Buying of wheat futures attributed to mills more than offset local pressure and liquidation today, and prices averaged somewhat higher than yesterday, holding within a range of about 1/2 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 21 -- The Assembly, after a secret session this afternoon, agreed to adopt lend-lease methods for supplies, but did so charily, as the text of a message later sent to the Governor reveals.

Bolstered by a persistent current of trade-covering orders in the near months, the cotton futures market rose yesterday gradually to moderate gains after opening at the lows, unchanged to 1 point under Tuesday's final prices. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts posted their best prices and net gains of 12 to 18 points at the close.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- William Cagney, United Artists producer, today announced the purchase of screen rights to Louis Bromfeld's novel 'McLeod's Folly," as a vehicle for his partner-brother, James Cagney. The Cagneys have engaged Agnes Christine Johnston to adapt the story to the screen, and they expect to begin production late this Winter.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 21 -- It is probable that we have in our long-term prisons more alcoholics, or persons in whose lives heavy drinking has played an important part, than prison officials realize, Austin H. MacCormick, executive director of the Osborne Association of New York City, told the Congress of Correction today.

Aldous Huxley's "The Art of Seeing," which is to be released next Wednesday, is both the story of the author's own re-education in seeing and the story of the methods of visual education. Huxley was 17 when he became nearly blind, was guided when walking and read by Braille.
BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 21 -- Germany has extended the time for Pierre Laval, French Chief of Government, to fill the quota of 150,000 skilled workers for the Reich, it was understood here today.

Stockholders of the Barber Asphalt Corporation at a meeting held yesterday in Perth Amboy, N.J., voted to amend the certificate of incorporation so as to include shipbuilding among the specifically stated corporate objects if undertaken during a period of war or national emergency.

The wholesale markets here yesterday took the news of the forthcoming WPB inventory control order in their stride in contrast to the marked concern shown last Spring when such regulation was first broached.

Any legislative inquiry that investigates the public schools of New York City and fails to find racial discrimination, anti-semitism, naizism and fascism is either hypocritical or blind, Solicitor General Henry Epstein declared last night at a rally in Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Allied Voters against Coudert.

For the second successive day, Columbia worked on its running attack at Baker Field yesterday, this time against the defensive formations that Coach Lou Little expects Pennsylvania to use Saturday. The drill lasted three hours, despite the rain and mud.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- British submarines operating off the coasts of Libya and Italy have sunk four more enemy supply ships that were trying to run supplies to Africa. Two ships were sunk by the same submarine. Another submarine torpedoed a large supply ship at close range, despite a screen of enemy destroyers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, has formed a Newspaper Industry Advisory Committee to serve as a channel for discussion of the war-time problems of the newspaper industry, which have been increasing materially under the impact of the war economy.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21 -- Mexico is threatened with commercial paralysis because of a serious shortage of intercity transportation, such as buses, General Jesus Celis Campos, director of transit in the Federal District, disclosed today.

Fruit-growing for the "small suburban plot" was discussed last night in the last of a series of lectures under the sponsorship of the New York Botanical Garden at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

The National Association of Broadcasters made public last night communications from three network officials to Neville Miller, the association's president, setting forth their official position in the controversy with James C. Petrillo's American Federation of Musicians over the ban on recordings. It had been reported on Tuesday that a majority of network executives favored direct negotiation with the union instead of any legal battle.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- One of the greatest Balkan battles since the Nazis swept through Yugoslavia in the Spring of 1941 is raging in Southern Bosnia, where 1,200 German and Axis satellite troops have been killed in three days of fighting against Yugoslav patriots, who lost 600 to 900 men killed, wounded or captured, it was reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Possibilities of sponge iron as a substitute for scrap in steel making, long disputed by experts, will be tested thoroughly in order not to "miss any bets," Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said today.

Branch Rickey, general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, who is believed to hold the inside track for the same position with the Brooklyn Dodgers since the resignation of Larry MacPhail, left last night aboard a T.W.A. plane for St. Louis.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The Yonkers Professional Hospital at 27 Ludlow Street announced today that it will close on Oct. 31 because of the drain on its resources due to the war and an increase in rent.
In view of your recent editorial comments concerning the serious problem of the national manpower shortage, the following information might be of interest to you.

I have noticed that a drive has commenced for the demolition of the Third Avenue elevated. In addition to providing 50,000 tons of scrap vitally needed for defense and benefiting realty, there is another very important reason for its demolition -- the saving of human life.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- A letter written to his parents by Henry Glorch, machinist's mate, first class, on the transport George Elliott on the eve of the American invasion of the Solomon Islands, a letter which he hoped they would never receive, "because if you do get it, that means that I have been very unfortunate," was delivered a few days ago to Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Glorch of Chicago.

Garment manufacturers, returning from recent conferences with OPA officials in Washington, yesterday indicated their belief that a new order would be issued shortly covering the apparel and children's wear, superseding MPR 153 and the GMPR, and possibly using a percentage mark-up basis for prices.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 21 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Byron Darnton, war correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Lieutenant Bruce Fahnestock, famous for his pre-war exploration of the South Seas, were buried today in the Port Moresby military cemetery with full military honors.

The suspension of trading on the Stock Exchange caused yesterday by the air-raid alarm test brought a halt to a rally in stocks backed by substantial buying power. Even the few minutes of grace in the final hour before and after the pause enabled prices to push forward a bit after approximately four hours of weakening tendencies.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- If Rolland B. Marvin, Republican leader of Syracuse, had his way Thomas E. Dewey would not even be running for Governor, it is stated. But Mr. Dewey is the nominee and the Marvin organization will give him an excellent majority in Onondaga County.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Addressing the Japanese people, the Tokyo radio said today that the Ministry of Education, in conjunction with the military authorities, was preparing a scheme for teaching the Japanese way of life to the younger generations among the 1,000,000,000 people in the occupied territories.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The National War Labor Board unanimously approved today a new wage regulation designed to prevent the "pirating" of workers by the payment of higher wages for the same type of job.

Joseph Pulitzer said that when a man is looking for a job a letter of recommendation doesn't mean anything, but if he brings no letter of recommendation it means a good deal. Today one might say that lending your name as sponsor for a deserving cause doesn't mean anything.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan appeared yesterday in General Sessions in the unusual role of a supplicant for leniency for a young Puerto Rican father, who last Aug. 31 had stabbed with an ice pick and dangerously wounded a nun and a woman supervisor in the New York Foundling Hospital, in East Sixty-eighth Street because they refused to surrender his infant daughter to him.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 22 -- A young Naval ensign related last night how a powerful Negro mess attendant swam six hours through shark-infested waters, towing to safety a raft load of wounded seamen from the United States destroyer Gregory, sunk by the Japanese off the Solomons.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Government spending passed $20,000,000,000 for the current fiscal year today, and $18,400,000,000 of it was for war.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 22 (AP) -- United States and British planes continued yesterday their destructive attacks on Axis supply lines and advanced bases in Egypt. The land forces deployed between El Alamein and the Qattara Depression remained quiet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Formation of two boards of review, which will pass on construction projects whether military or civilian, was reported today by the War Production Board to administer the construction order which it issued yesterday curbing construction by governmental projects and to handle the combined work of five governmental agencies which have been passing upon construction.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek declared today that China was "shifting from the defensive to the offensive" and that the Allies were sending large amounts of supplies through new routes replacing the Burma Road.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation, in its report of operations for the first nine months issued for publication today by R.G.A. van der Woude, president, reveals earnings of $11,769,000 or 90 cents a share, compared with $14,485,000 or $1.10 a share for the corresponding period of last year.

Hirsch Jacobs saddled his 1,215th winner yesterday when Flaught, a son of Firethorn, carried the silks of Mrs. Jacobs to a half-length victory in the $6,300 Tarrytown Claiming Stakes as Empire City opened its Fall meeting before 12,460 persons.

Mayor La Guardia ordered the dismissal of Albert Berger as a city marshal after an investigation which resulted in Berger's arraignment in Felony Court yesterday on charges of having misappropriated about $7,000 entrusted to his care during the last six years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Prices in primary markets declined in the week ended Oct. 17 for the first time since mid-July, mainly because of Weakness of agricultural markets. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive wholesale price index dropped 0.2 per cent to 99.6 per cent of its 1926 average.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 22 -- One of Chief of Government Pierre Laval's arguments to induce French workers to volunteer for German armament plants is that an earnest of German intentions is to be found in that "since the armistice there have been several acts of generosity on the part of the victor, notably the liberation of 600,000 prisoners of war."

On Oct. 15 Lieut. Gen. Somervell, appearing before a Senate committee, spoke rather contemptuously of the usefulness of the small factories of the country in the war effort. He said that all of them together would be unable "to turn out one day's ammunition for all Allied troops."

ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Oct. 19 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain has refused to make a radio appeal for skilled French workers to serve in Germany, and representatives of Pierre Laval's government, attempting to address workers on the subject, are being ejected from factories, it was reported today.

Being a-weary of the haggard roles for the moment, Flora Robson is playing a light one in "The Damask Cheek," which was put on at The Playhouse last evening. John van Druten, the neat-fingered playwright, and Lloyd Morris, the learned critic and pedagogue, have spun out a comedy about the course of true love in 1909.

ABOARD A SUNDERLAND FLYING BOAT, off the Spanish Coast, Oct. 22 -- It is a long way from these fog-shrouded waters to the U-boat hunting grounds, off the eastern coast of the United States, but the Royal Air Force's Sunderlands, Wellingtons and Whitleys that patrol them are striking heavy blows in the campaign to maintain the North Atlantic lifeline to the United States coastal routes.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, one of the nation's largest utility holding companies, charged yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had not afforded it a "full and fair hearing" and had exercised "arbitrary" powers in ordering its capitalization reduced to one class of stock.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Lord Reith, former Minister of Works and Planning, called on Parliament today to decide immediately what sort of machinery should be set up after the war for guiding reconstruction -- chiefly in building new housing developments and also municipal planning.

Reports from Washington that President Roosevelt may make a second statement in support of the candidacy of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. brought encouragement yesterday to supporters of the Democratic nominee for Governor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- The task of supporting Federal anti-inflation activities must be tackled by municipal governments, Paul M. O'Leary, deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration, told the American Municipal Association today.

Japanese domination of most of the Western Pacific and much of Eastern Asia has not yet been seriously challenged in almost a year of war. when it is clearly and indisputably in her own paramount interest to do so; the bonds of the Tri-Partite pact are loose ones, liable to severance at any time it suits the interest of either party.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The stock markets were cheerful today, with industrial shares and South American securities the most active sections. Gilt-edge loans were 1-16 better where they were changed.

Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, president of the American Mission to Lepers, at the mission's thirty-fifth annual meeting held yesterday afternoon and last evening at the Henry Hudson Hotel, said that despite the second World War, the last year had been the most effective and fruitful of the mission's history.

OTTAWA, Oct. 22 -- Defense Minister James L. Ralston announced tonight that prisoners of war in Canada forcibly resisted shackling on Oct. 10, and that prisoners and guards received injuries, most of them of a minor character.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 22 -- Hal Price Headley's Equitable, although away from the winners' circle for two years, was installed an odds-on favorite in the fourth race at Laurel Park today and made good under smart handling by George Woolf.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase of $415,492,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, which were at a record high. Note circulation for the system as a whole was at the highest of the year to date, while ratio of reserve for the system and also for the New York Bank were at a low for the year.

An abundance of flowers -- such is the good word from the New York Department of Agriculture's roving reporter. This week-end finds plenty of fresh, flourishing chrysanthemums and a super-abundance of pompons on view in Manhattan flower stalls.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (AP) -- First experiments with tubeless automobile tires have proved successful in the District of Columbia, according to C.N. Emmons, superintendent of the municipal garage and shops. He told The Evening Sun today that tests of tubeless operation had been "completely successful."

Two members of a band of blaickmailers who extorted more than $1,000,000 from its victims in the last four years, were found guilty yesterday evening by a jury in General Sessions, after less than an hour's deliberation. They are Patrick O'Rafferty, former member of the Irish Republican Army, and Bruno Makara of 1443 Eightieth Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it has adopted "as a fundamental policy" the right of exporters to compensation for export functions actually performed. OPA set down two rules to guide the export trade in the application of the policy. They were:

WASHINGTON, Oct., 22 (AP) -- Representative Bland, chairman of the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, said today that the Maritime Commission had denied there was anything unlawful in a ship sales transaction with the Waterman Steamship Corporation of Mobile, Ala., which had been criticized by the Controller General's office.

Bank clearings of the twenty-three major cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday rose 32.5 per cent over the previous week's figure and recorded the moderate gain of 4.3 per cent from the total for the corresponding week last year.

The German High Command said yesterday that more "stubbornly defended ground, pillboxes and barricades were taken in the bitter battle" of Stalingrad, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Senate, by a vote of 49 to 25, today shunted the hotly contested "prohibition" amendment out of the bill proposing to lower the draft age to 18 years, and sent it to its military committee for hearings and recommendations which are expected to come, if at all, long after election on Nov. 3.

The new tax law just signed by the President has been subjected to many criticisms; but clearly its worst fault is that it has jacked up income taxes three, four, five and in some cases twenty or more times what they were only last year, without doing anything effective to improve the machinery of collection.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Clemson College's Tigers defeated South Carolina's Gamecocks, 18 -- 6, today, breaking a first-half deadlock with third and fourth period touchdowns. A crowd of 22,000 State Fair fans saw this fortieth meeting of the rivals.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, charged last night that "the swastika has appeared in the dimmed-out streets" of the city and that "home-grown Fascists" and "Hitler agents" were deliberately attempting to disrupt the nation's war efforts by fanning the flames of intolerance on the home front.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The Royal Air Force took up today the daylight operations in the British-American aerial offensive against the Nazis with bomber attacks over Northwest Germany and the Ruhr.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 22 -- Hope for adoption of the "skip-a-year-and-pay-as-you-go" income tax plan lies in appointment of Justice James F. Byrnes as director of the new office of economic stabilization, Beardsley Ruml, author of the proposal, told the national tax conference today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Two youths from New York City and one from Hartford were among ten members of the Navy armed guard of a merchant ship who were cited by Secretary Knox today in letters of commendation for gallantry in fighting off enemy bombing planes in a five-day engagement.
Why cannot some one convey to members of Congress some such message as this:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Pleas of innocence were made today by three Bayonne officials who were indicted last month on charges of conspiracy to obtain $7,100 in "kickbacks" in the purchase of trucks for that city. The defendants are James A. Mullanaphy, director of public works; Dennis Coughlin, his deputy, and Joseph J. Topoleski, director of parks and public property.

Four pieces of paper looking like "store-bought" money were displayed yesterday by the War Savings Staff as the first Japanese invasion currency to reach this country. The bills, in varying sizes according to their value, are printed in English with palm and coconut tree decorations.

Contributions to the sixty-fourth annual United Hospital campaign have reached $337,264 in the drive to raise $1,383,729 for the seventy-six voluntary member institutions, it was announced yesterday at the first report meeting of the Manhattan Women's Division in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Formation of a State Labor Non-Partisan Committee for the election of Frank C. Moore, Republican candidate for Controller, was announced yesterday by Vincent Ferris, secretary of the Allied Printing Trades Council, following a meeting during which Mr. Moore was questioned on matters concerning organized labor.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Two patrolmen, who had exchanged taunts and invectives with John B. Keenan, Director of Public Safety, while he was speaking at a testimonial dinner to a retired police lieutenant Tuesday night, were suspended here today by the director and ordered to stand departmental trial on charges of "conduct unbecoming officers."

There were prevailingly excellent performances at the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Bruno Walter as guest leader, last night in Carnegie Hall, but the program itself tended to the bromidic. The one contemporaneous score of the evening, which was John Alden Carpenter's Second symphony and received on this occasion its first performance, did not, on an initial hearing, appear to be one of Mr. Carpenter's most distinguished utterances.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- King George VI signed today a proclamation making those now 18 years of age liable for service in the armed forces. Those born between July 1 and Sept. 30, 1924, will register Nov. 7 and many of them may expect to be in the forces by December.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- A uniform method of taxing intangible personal property in New Jersey will be recommended to the Legislature on Monday by Governor Charles Edison, who will appear in person before a special session called at his request.

With limited price-fixing orders being met by scale-up hedge sales, the cotton futures market held yesterday within an 8-point range and closed unchanged to 1 point lower than Wednesday's final quotations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Department store sales for the week ended Oct. 17 showed a gain of 16 per cent as compared with the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Sales for the four-week period ended Oct. 17 increased 11 per cent.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Thirty-eight of sixty-two employes, who had beer dismissed by Joseph M. Byrne, Public Works Director here, for having participated in a six-day refuse department strike starting Oct. 1, were reinstated today by the director with loss of twenty-eight days' pay.

Until yesterday the people of this country certainly believed that the April 18 air attack on Japan was carried out without loss of an American plane or an American airman, except for the plane and the crew that were interned in Siberia. The country was encouraged to believe this because of the way in which news of the event was given out.
With deer hunting open in six counties in Maine, Pine Tree State officials report a bumper crop of deer in the State woodlands this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Donald M. Nelson will need all the support he can get, from the public, the press and the government high command, to enforce and retain his order that all Federal non-military construction must stop for the duration. The pressure to prevent issuance of the order was great, and it took courage on Mr. Nelson's part to make the hard and realistic decision.

Rather than attempt to carry on with rapidly dwindling inventories, Manhattan Housewares, Inc., 576 Broadway, one of the largest and oldest housewares jobbers in the city, has decided to liquidate for the duration of the war, M.J. Nadelson, vice president, announced yesterday.

A maximum of 65,000,000 pounds of tea, or 30 per cent more than estimated consumption under the March 27 WPB conservation order but approximately 35 per cent less than 1941 consumption, will be made available to this country for 1943 as the result of an agreement concluded this week between the British and United States Governments, it was announced here yesterday by Benjamin Wood, managing director of the Tea Bureau.

Up along Madison Avenue is a tiny dollhouse of a shop. It seems to be built, inside, of rows and rows of crystal bottles -- brimming with molten gold, topaz and amber -- that catch the pale light from the avenue and refract it into a thousand sunbeams.
Looking toward their battle with the Dodgers in Ebbets Field on Sunday with no trepidation whatever, Steve Owen's Giants romped through one of the best workouts at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The chairman of the War Manpower Commission, Mr. McNutt, announces that within two weeks he will send a detailed legislative program to the President to provide for compulsory labor service in wartime. He will ask for power to require a man to remain on a job or to transfer to another one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Senator Clark of Idaho said today that he would introduce legislation designed to restrict the powers of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians (A.F.L.), who has decreed an end to the broadcasting of "canned music."

Make friends with your butcher; consult him frequently; ask his advice about the cuts that are often neglected, usually cheap, always nourishing. Like most men, he will welcome the chance to exhibit the depth of his knowledge. Lamb, he will tell you, is more plentiful than beef or pork or veal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Several hundred representatives of the civilian labor force working on contracts for the Navy were urged tonight by President Roosevelt to let nothing stand in the way of their uninterrupted and earnest prosecution of their important part in winning the war.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- Construction of a canal between New Brunswick and Bordentown, N.J., to provide the missing link in the chain of inland waterways along the East Coast would eliminate the shortage of gasoline and fuel oil in Eastern States, Major J.H. Ross of Philadelphia, president of the Petroleum Carriers Association, said today before the Atlantic Deeper Waterways Association.

Mrs. George D. Pratt has purchased from Longfield Properties, Inc., the country estate of George Hepburn on Skunks Misery Road at Locust Valley, L.I., through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. The property consists of about twelve acres with a stone residence of fifteen rooms and six baths overlooking Long Island Sound.

A Tokyo dispatch broadcast yesterday by the Berlin radio quoted the newspaper Nichi Nichi for the opinion that Great Britain and the United States "probably intend to use the period from November to April for launching an attack on Burma." The broadcast was recorded by The Associated Press in New York.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 22 -- A spy who, police said today, worked for both sides in this war has been arrested here. He is 34-year-old Carl Ellsen, former Berlin chief correspondent of the now defunct Nazi news agency, Radio Mundial.

The Ballet Theatre, newly returned from a brief New England tour, opened the final section of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before a large audience. The novelty of the occasion was this company's first presentation of "Coppelia," with Irina Baronova as Swanilda.

A picture of bootlegging in Oklahoma was drawn by the liquor industry in an effort to remind Senator Josh Lee -- and the rest of the country -- how prohibitory law is working in that State. The Oklahoman was author of the dry amendment to the 18-19-year draft bill which was referred by the Senate to the Military Affairs Committee for hearings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- E.R. Stettinius Jr., Lend-Lease Administrator, said today that a contract had been let for construction of the first full-sized "seamobile." the redesigned gasoline-driven ship formerly called the Sea Otter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The War Production Board has approved a $27,000,000 expansion of Henry J. Kaiser's "Baby Pittsburgh" now rising in San Bernardino County, Calif., official sources reported today.

There's a lot of sparkle to be had for a comparatively low price these days. Such an announcement by Saks Fifth Avenue as a prelude to its fashion show in the Hotel Plaza yesterday is indicative of what a large store thinks is the buying temper of women this Winter.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Dr. Frank F. Marino of New Rochelle was acquitted by a Westchester County Court jury tonight of a manslaughter charge based on the abortion death of 19-year-old Cleo Florence Moore last March 28. The jury deliberated two hours in the trial that began a week ago before County Judge Frank H. Coyne.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- With the election eleven days away, Thomas E. Dewey continues to hold the lead over his two opponents for the Governorship of New York in the latest State-wide poll by the institute.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Oct. 22 -- Venereal diseases in twenty cities caused the loss of 62,106.58 days by men in the Navy from Jan. 1 to Sept. 19, according to Captain C.S. Stevenson of the Bureau of Medicine and Surgery, who had a paper read for him today at a conference held under the auspices of the United States Public Health Service and in conjunction with the annual session of the American Neisserian Association.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (AP) -- James K. Cullen, United States Commissioner, today held two men for action by the Federal Grand Jury in connection with the government's seizure of the Elkton, Md., plant of Triumph Explosives, Inc., whose executive vice president, Josef Ben Decker, already had waived preliminary hearing.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Bowie will open Nov. 16 for a sixteen-day meeting, the Maryland State Racing Commission announced today, completing the track's twenty-five-day allotment for the year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Tom G. Stitts, chief of the dairy and poultry branch of the Agricultural Marketing Administration, notified the Chicago Mercantile Exchange by telegram tonight that the government will require a minimum of 10,000,000 pounds of butter a month and that the trade will be notified tomorrow that it will buy butter at sellers' ceiling prices at their F.O.B. points, plus premiums for packing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Hopes that Princeton could check Brown's fast-breaking attack in Palmer Stadium on Saturday were on the wane today when what was supposed to be a climax in practice for the encounter turned into dull and uninspired play.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The group leaders of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office who are being enrolled on the basis of one for every twenty families will provide the "officers of the Civilian Army," James G. Blaine, C.D.V.O. chairman, said yesterday.

Charging that "we want Argentina and Chile to stop appeasing the Axis, but we're still appeasing Axis-enslaved and Axis-convinced Vichy and Madrid," Waldo Frank, author, lecturer and student of Pan-American relations, declared in a speech last night that "we must close up the fascist embassies.''
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A communique from British Headquarters and the R.A.F.:

One of the largest refunding plans in the history of municipal financing was presented formally yesterday to the city of Philadelphia. It provides for the exchange of a maximum of $162,296,000 of outstanding obligations of the city for new refunding bonds with extended call dates.

Whenever a company's advertising appropriation falls below a certain amount, the use of general advertising over a manufacturer's signature is relatively ineffective and in such instances expenditures should be directed mostly into dealer cooperative advertising or point-of-purchase helps, Professor James D. Scott, formerly research assistant at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration and now professor at Johns Hopkins University, states in a bulletin just published by the Harvard Bureau of Business Research.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Mrs. Lillian Galvin, wife of Paul Vincent Galvin, president of the Galvin Manufacturing Corporation, and her maid, Miss Edna Sibilinski, were found shot to death tonight in the Galvin home in suburban Evanston.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The country must learn that "we can fight as well on cabbage as on brussel sprouts, as well on codfish as on oysters," Arthur C. Bartlett, special assistant to the United States agricultural marketing administrator, told the American Dietetic Association today.
DETROIT, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Thirty-three industrial plants in six States, many of them former competitors, have combined to meet the country's need for steel armor plate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Elmer W. Henderson, a Negro employed by the Federal Government as a field representative of the Fair Employment Practice Committee, filed a formal complaint with the Interstate Commerce Commission today against the Southern Railway for alleged "Jim Crow" discrimination.
Dramatic clothes, relying for effect on starkly simple lines with a few startling flashes of color, were stressed at the Nelson-Hickson luncheon showing yesterday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration began today the buying of the "idle" tires with which it hopes to build up a stockpile to keep the country's 27,000,000 automobiles rolling.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 22 (AP) -- President Juan Antonio Rios and his new Cabinet, set up to fulfill Chile's long-deferred hemispheric obligations, cracked down summarily today on both Axis spies and obstructive internal politics.

The H. C. Bohack Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share against acumulations on its first preferred stock. The previous payment, a similar amount on July 10, was the first disbursement since 1933.
Manhattan's revived football forces pranced through their final heavy paces yesterday for the meeting with Duquesne's powerful eleven at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

A Brooklyn Federal court jury of seven men and five women found six men and a woman guilty last night of conspiracy to smuggle platinum out of this country to Portugal. The verdict was brought in to Judge Marcus B. Campbell at 10:55 P.M., after nearly ten hours' deliberation, and Judge Campbell set next Thursday for sentencing.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Dean Alfange, the American Labor party's candidate for Governor, tonight criticized John J. Bennett and Thomas E. Dewey, his Democratic and Republican opponents, for "failing to denounce the Christian Front."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Federal judges who enter the Army or Navy with an officer's pay must immediately be considered to have left the bench, Attorney General Biddle has informed the judicial conference, according to a report today by Chief Justice Stone.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 22 -- Another report of the Chamber of Deputies Committee for the Investigation of Anti-Argentina Activities, which is now under the chairmanship of the Socialist Deputy Juan Antonio Solari, was issued today, and it calls attention to pro-totalitarian activities pursued by the clergy of various denominations but especially by Catholic priests in the Territory of Misiones, where the most important German colony in Argentina is situated.

Arthur W. Page of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club has been nominated for another term as president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, it was announced yesterday by the nominating committee, of which I.A. Sprague is chairman.

Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen upheld yesterday the right of the city, in appointing firemen from the civil service eligible list, to "pass over" men who now have a 3-A classification for selective service but who face reclassification into 1-A.
