ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- Public observance of the birthday of Theodore Roosevelt next Tuesday was asked by Governor Lehman today in a proclamation in which he directed that the American flag be flown from all public buildings and requested that it be displayed on homes and places of business.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commanding United States forces in the European theatre, tonight emphatically denied Axis claims to have sunk transports heavily laden with American troops during the latter part of September.

" I've got it," Coach Lou Little declared yesterday as he burst into the Columbia dressing room at Baker Field, a trifle tardy, but in a lighter, airier mood than he had been in since just before the Brown game.

Herman Hoffman, Grand Master of the Independent Order Brith Abraham, announced yesterday his support of State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican candidate for re-election in the Seventeenth District, and denounced the campaign against him and for Jerry Finkelstein, Senator Coudert's Democratic and American Labor party opponent, as "reckless, untruthful and un-American."

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 22 -- Albert W. Hawkes, Republican nominee for the United States Senate, outlined today his attitude toward labor-management problems and accused his Democratic opponent, Senator William H. Smathers, of attempting to confuse the voters on his (Hawkes's) labor record.

Although "a superb job" has been done thus far in meeting initial requirements of the armed services, cotton textile mills were warned here yesterday that the "great task of supplying an army in the midst of large scale offensive action on many fronts" was still before them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 -- Judy Garland and Gene Kelly will play the leading roles in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Anchors Away," a photoplay by Michael Fessier and Ernest Pagano, the studio announced today. The story, which tells of the adventures of a girl who is elected sweetheart of a battleship, will follow "Girl Crazy" on Miss Garland's schedule.

For twenty-four minutes yesterday afternoon, from 2:30 to 2:54 P.M., New York City's normal pursuits were almost completely suspended by the first daytime air raid drill since the war began. It was ordered by Major Gen. William N. Haskell, State director of Civilian Protection, with the approval of the Army.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Treasury went swiftly to work today to prepare for the collection from some 50,000,000 Americans of the greatest tax levy in the history of the country.

Senator Frederic A. Coudert Jr., Republican candidate for re-election from the Seventeenth Senate District, yesterday answered recent statements made by Solicitor General Henry Epstein, who is candidate for Attorney General on the Democratic ticket.

Orson Welles, who has been at odds with RKO since the company asked his Mercury Production staff to vacate their offices at RKO while Welles was in South America last July, will return to the studio next week to re-edit and shoot a new ending for his forthcoming melodrama, "Journey Into Fear," RKO has announced.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The famous Guildhall Reference Library, founded in 1423 and badly damaged in the big German fire raid on London on Dec. 29, 1940, was reopened to the public today after having undergone extensive repairs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson said today the Army could not let Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays interfere with training and induction schedules.

Eleven hundred Girl Scouts from troops in the five boroughs of New York City will crowd into Studio 8-H of the National Broadcasting Company this evening to hear the first performance of a new song, "America Needs You," written by Kent Cooper, general manager of The Associated Press and dedicated to the Girl Scouts of the city.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- The Yonkers Common Council at a meeting tonight unanimously accepted the proposed budget of $11,275,081 for 1943 submitted today by William A. Walsh, newly appointed City Manager.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- A plan for the transfer of the assets of the international division of Ebasco Services, Inc., service company of the Electric Bond and Share Company system, to the Ebasco International Corporation, an inactive subsidiary of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22 -- A couple of freshman backs came up to the Yale varsity this week from Reggie Root's squad and a definite wave of optimism caught up every one in camp. One and all think the Bulldog is going to show a real bite.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The annual classic in Philadelphia, the Army-Navy game, has packed about 100,000 spectators into the Municipal Stadium. Annapolis has a population of about 16,000 and its stadium seats 22,000. Presumably the teams will meet on the scheduled date, Nov. 28.

The United States Trust Company, as executor of James D. Black, has sold to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, the one-story business building on a lot 28 by 110 feet at 119 East Twenty-third Street, between Lexington and Fourth Avenues. Erected in 1934 and leased to one tenant, the property had been in one ownership for forty-seven years.

Faced with the highest tax increase in the industry's history on Nov. 1, retail liquor dealers prepared yesterday for the greatest consumer buying rush since repeal. The new tax bill just signed by President Roosevelt, which increases the tax on distilled spirits from $4 to $6 a gallon, will add approximately 40 to 50 cents a quart to the price of whisky after that date, and "beat-the-tax" buying has already started, it was learned.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Industrial history was made here today as the enlarging and relining of Number 7 blast furnace of the Johnstown plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company was completed in twenty-one days, setting a record for the steel industry.

" Native Son," the dramatization by Paul Green and Richard Wright of the latter's novel of the same name, returns to Broadway this evening with Canada Lee, Anne Burr and John Berry playing the leading roles at the Majestic.

The National Committee on the Housing Emergency, in a statement issued yesterday through its subcommittee on inter-racial problems, urged the National Housing Agency to take "appropriate and adequate steps immediately" to see that there was no lag in war production in any part of the country because of the lack of housing facilities for Negro workers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Army is studying the possibility of returning older Army enlisted men to civilian life, Secretary Stimson said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- New moves to keep down the prices of bread, flour and pork to the consumer have been made by the Office of Price Administration and the Department of Agriculture.
MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:
Two floors totaling 10,000 square feet at 217 Grand Street have been leased to Belikoff Brothers, exporters of clothing. Irving R. Raber Company was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The first known effort by the Japanese to thrust forward by land on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons -- a "minor" action on Tuesday (Guadalcanal date) -- was repulsed by the Marine and Army defenders in the American positions, the Navy reported in a communique issued today.

UTICA, Oct. 22 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. promised tonight that the war would produce no forgotten American soldier, after Mrs. Mathilde Burling, founder and president of the Gold Star Mothers Association, and Mrs. Alexander Anderson, wife of Brig. Gen. Anderson, had addressed special appeals for his election as Governor, to the wives, sweethearts and mothers of today's soldiers, sailors and marines.

National advertising on automotive parts in 1943 will approximate the volume of this year and trade paper advertising will also remain about the same, it was announces yesterday following a three-day meeting in Chicago of the Automotive Advertisers Council, comprising the sales and advertising executives of forty-five producers of automotive standard equipment and replacement parts.
MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- Komsomolskaya Pravda, the newspaper of the Young Communist League, published today an analysis of the Summer campaign of the Yugoslav People's Army.

Coming to the assistance of the nation's commercial banks which, in turn, had subscribed heavily to insure the success of the Treasury's recent offerings of $4,000,000,000 of new bonds and notes, the Open Market Committee, on behalf of the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System, bought $415,492,000 of government securities in the week ended on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The vote by which the Senate returned to committee the Lee prohibition amendment to the bill lowering the draft age to 18 was as follow:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Four women, who said they were mothers of small children, testified in a Supreme Court hearing here today that they were held from three to fourteen days as material witnesses in the Hudson County Jail after they were seized by agents of the Hudson County prosecutor's office in a raid on a Bayonne night club last December.

Twenty-eight contract bridge pairs won their way last night to the final round of the open-pair contest in the metropolitan championships under way at the Park Central Hotel here. They were the survivors of forty-eight pairs that started Tuesday night.

Word comes, thanks to The Livestock Reporter, of a labor shortage on the Mescalero Apaches' big ranch (its area is greater than that of Rhode Island) in New Mexico. In the old days this did not occur. The Apaches were a raiding tribe. It was their practice to go and take what they required.

Volunteer first aid workers must seek shelter during an air raid alarm and remain under cover until the all-clear is sounded, unless their assistance is requested by emergency medical field units, under a ruling made public yesterday by Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, chief of the Emergency Medical Service, who said he had received numerous inquiries about the status of these persons.

William Flynn, 23 years old, the "baby-faced" gunman who shot and killed a patron of a bar on Park Avenue, near 123d Street, in a hold-up early last Jan. 21, was sentenced by Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. in General Sessions yesterday to die in the electric chair in the week of Nov. 30.
DEHRA DUN, United Provinces, India, Oct. 21 (delayed) -- The bitter lessons taught by Japan are being put to good use at the Indian Military Academy here.

Whether there will be tournament golf this Winter still was uncertain last night after officials of the Professional Golfers Association had spent five solid hours discussing their wartime problems, The Associated Press reported.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 22 -- The press asserts today that Theresa Kohn Devrisch, a German woman recently apprehended by secret police, formed part of an espionage organization that communicated with Nazi agents in the United States by means of used Spanish stamps.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Prices of bogs broke today, falling as much as 40 cents a hundredweight in late trading as producers made a slight increase in marketings, and processors, awaiting a new order from the Office of Price Administration on wholesale pork ceilings, showed reluctance to take offerings.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- A Supreme Court jury returned tonight a verdict against Mrs. Lottie E. Isbell of Larchmont, who sued the Travelers Insurance Company to collect $13,500 double indemnity in connection with the death of her husband, George W. Isbell, industrial engineer, who was killed by a pistol bullet in his parked automobile at Scarsdale on April 10, 1939.

To use ex-President Hoover's often misquoted phrase, the attempt to attach a dry-rider to the bill lowering the draft age to 18-years may be "noble in purpose." It is not noble in method, since its proponents are indulging their hobby at the expense of delaying legislation which most of them admit is essential to our success in this war.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Oct. 23 -- Japanese and Allied bombers exchanged blows, the Japanese bombing Port Moresby and the Allies Buin, while Allied ground forces were continuing to push the Japanese back toward Kokoda in the Owen Stanley Mountains, the Allied High Command reported today.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Great strides have been made in the social rehabilitation of severely injured industrial and war workers whereby, instead of existing on a pittance granted by the government in compensation or being forced to seek charity, they are trained for other jobs at full rates of pay, according to George Tomlinson, Parliamentary Secretary of the Ministry of Labor.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Vladimir Krushkoff, secretary of the Soviet Information Bureau, charged today that William Randolph Hearst and Colonel Robert R. McCormick, American newspaper publishers, and the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin have taken "every step to suppress the increasing demand by American public opinion for the opening of a second front."

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- One of the most closely guarded "military secrets" of the war seeped out today -- Captain Eddie Rickenbacker's one-man raid on the poker-proud chiefs of the United States Army Air Forces in this theatre.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- Yesterday, as on Tuesday, the Germans continued to attack without gaining ground in the northern regions of Stalingrad. The cold, driving rain continued and a little snow fell on the steppeland northwest of the city, laying a thin paste of mud on the brazen earth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Direct war production and the armed forces combined will engage the full time of better than a third of the country's population before the end of 1943, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Manufacturers who by mistake have employed ineligible aliens on airplane or confidential war contracts will not be prosecuted if the men were hired in good faith, Attorney General Biddle stated today.

VICHY, France, Oct. 22 -- Admiral Francois Darlan, Commander in Chief of the French armed forces, has flown to Dakar from Vichy, it became known today when he broadcast to the West African colony a message from Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, telling it to resist any attack as it did that of the British and de Gaullists in September, 1940.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Oct. 22 -- All of Senator Josh Lee's State, Oklahoma, is legally dry and has been since Statehood. A prohibition amendment was written into the State Constitution when it was adopted just before Statehood, Nov. 16, 1907.

The literature on the peace and post-war programs, already plentiful, will be increased by two books within the next few days. One of these, due Monday from Morrow, is "For Permanent Victory" and the subtitle, "The Case for an American Arsenal of Peace," indicates the theme.

TRENTON, Oct. 22 -- Suit has been filed in United States District Court here by the Office of Price Administration for an injunction restraining two operators of apartment houses in East Orange from receiving more than $40 a month from occupants.
MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (AP) -- President Mikhail Kalinin, addressing Russian youth today, declared that Russia's losses, "of course, are not small, but the Germans are losing more."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Lithographing plates are being made from processed paper and plastics which some experts believe may supplant zinc and aluminum in the offset printing industry, it was learned today.

The Federal Government, invoking the requisitioning powers granted the President by Congress last year, has taken possession of seven parcels of abandoned street car trackage in Nassau County to speed another 500 tons of steel to the mills, it was announced yesterday by the special projects section of the War Production Board.

VALLETTA, Malta, Oct. 22 (Reuter) -- An enemy fighter-bomber and three fighters were destroyed over Malta today when Axis forces made use of cloud cover for hit-and-run raids. A number of persons were killed or injured, but no damage was done to military property and very little to civilian property.

Francis Henry Taylor, director of the Metropolitan Museum, will deliver the installation address of the Senior Honor Society at the High School of Music and Art assembly at 10 o'clock this morning in the school auditorium.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Royal Air Force bombers were over Italy last night, the British reported today.

In the midst of gasoline and tire rationing and talk of further restrictions on automobile driving so as to give more rubber and fuel for the giant airplanes of modern warfare, a horse thief was sentenced to six months in Bronx County jail yesterday.

ASHTON, R.I., Oct. 22 -- Rear Admiral William Carleton Watts told workers at the plant of the Owens-Corning Fiberglass Corporation today that "years of war lie ahead," and predicted that there soon would be a readjustment of manpower and womanpower which would result "in the assignment to jobs which are best calculated to help in the war program."

LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Note circulation increased 753,000 this week to establish a high record of 847,030,000, the Bank of England reported today in its weekly condition statement. It was the fifth consecutive weekly advance.

How to adapt a home to the limited space modern living conditions demand by having one room take the place of several is illustrated in the exhibition of five "all purpose" rooms opening today at B. Altman Co., Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. This exhibit is being held in the Decorator's Gallery on the seventh floor.

There has been an improvement in neckwear sales, according to clothiers, who reported yesterday that numbers selling below the $1 level have been the best sellers. Knitted ties in solid colors have gotten a fairly good play. Moderate stripes in darker shades have also been selling well.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in one of its most rapid dispositions of a "death sentence" proceeding, ordered today the dissolution of the Lone Star Gas Corporation.
MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 22 -- The Springfield Museum of Fine Arts has announced a competition for a mural painting, open to all artists of the United States, Canada and Mexico. An award of $4,500 is offered the winner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Legation today made official representations to United States authorities over the publication by Time Magazine of an article describing the riot in a German officers' war prisoners camp at Bowmanville, Ont., when Nazi prisoners were manacled in retaliation for the chaining by the Germans of Canadians and British soldiers captured at Dieppe.

Workers convalescing from tuberculosis who have received prescribed rehabilitation or "hardening" may be adapted for service in many industries in support of the war production program, according to a report submitted yesterday to a group of medical and public welfare officials.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Interpretations issued today by the War Labor Board on its previous general orders in an effort to answer a large number of inquiries concerned General Order No. 3, issued Oct. 7.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Wheat prices fluctuated listlessly today within a range of about 1/2 cent a bushel, but responded to moderate purchases of futures attributed to mills which disclosed a lack of selling pressure and closing trades on the Board of Trade were at gains of 1/8 to 1/4 cent. Kansas City was up 1/8 to 1/4 cent and Minneapolis up 1/4 cent.

In this year of war activity the Community Service Society of New York has decided not to undertake a citywide Fall drive for funds. Instead a contributors committee of fourteen well-known business leaders under the chairmanship of Lindsay Bradford will conduct an informal campaign to assure the support of former donors and enlist new friends.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The new Materials Flow Plan, upon which high ranking executives of the War Production Board have been at work for several months, has been virtually completed and will be announced about Nov. 2, it was learned here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A proposal for sweeping reorganization of the government, aimed at complete wartime mobilization of the country's resources in materials and manpower, was presented to the House today by Representative Tolan of the special committee on defense migration.

NEW DELHI, India -- Letters, newspapers and magazines have in these days almost as slow a passage to the East as had William Hickey, so that it is only a short time ago that I happened to see Captain Liddell Hart's article, with the title, "Military Genius," in the Strand Magazine of last December.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on a $6,341,196,887 war appropriations bill which also authorizes the Navy to make contracts for $9,510,000,000 worth of new vessels.

MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 23 -- Russian troops tore into the German flanks above and below Stalingrad yesterday, capturing two lines of trenches to the northwest and wiping out a Nazi unit to the south, while twelve tanks were destroyed and a battalion [1,000 men] of shock troops annihilated inside the city, the High Command reported today.

A foreman in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, who declined to take cover during yesterday's air raid alarm and argued that his work was more important than the "child's play" of civilian defense tests, received a sentence of two days in jail and a $25 fine last night from Magistrate J. Roland Sala in Brooklyn-Queens Night Court.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 22 -- Complete expiation for the assassination of Reinhard Heydrich, former Deputy Reich Protector for Bohemia-Moravia, is to be exacted by the Reich from the Czech people for peace in the Protectorate and, before that is accomplished, there can be no recognition of Czech demands or aspirations, State Secretary Karl Hermann Frank said in Prague today at the unveiling of a memorial tablet for the late Protector.

Excess funds of New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $5,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $520,000,000, in contrast to a decline of $360,000,000 in the week for the Reserve System as a whole to $2,350,000,000.

IT isn't compulsory to read 800-page novels. This is a free country and you have a perfect legal right to cast a silent vote for fiction that can be held in one hand without spraining the wrist, by ignoring the literary behemoths and choosing novels of less grossly inflated proportions. You can even find novelettes without much difficulty.
BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 22 -- King Victor Emmanuel of Italy, who was taken seriously ill yesterday, is suffering from a heart attack, it was learned here today.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Asserting that not a single labor leader in the State had endorsed the candidacy of his Republican opponent, Albert W. Hawkes, Senator William H. Smathers declared in a statement made public here today that Mr. Hawkes's "self-portrait of himself as a friend of labor is about as truthful as the Hitler communiques announcing the fall of Stalingrad."

A. Bruce Fahnestock, who was 31 years old, was commissioned a lieutenant in the United States Army soon after Pearl Harbor and had been in the Australia-New Guinea area, with which he was intimately acquainted, since then.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson today said that the Japanese apparently had in their custody four American fliers who participated in the raid last Spring on Tokyo. He emphasized, however, that there was no ground for the Japanese contention, voiced by Axis radio, that these fliers were subject to reprisal for bombing of nonmilitary objectives.

Antique furniture and other property of the Rosenbach Company were sold at auction yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $12,447.50, making the total for the first two sessions of the auction $22,312.50. The auction will continue this afternoon.

Though the City College football team may continue to suffer mental agony when it loses at Lewisohn Stadium, the physical suffering will be somewhat alleviated because 1,500 diligent pebble pickers yesterday picked over one-half a ton of pebbles, nails, glass and assorted debris off the playing surface of the field at the second annual Pebble Picking Parade and Peanut Picnic.

Mayor La Guardia took the first step yesterday toward providing daytime care for the children of mothers working in defense industries when he named a committee of fourteen under the chairmanship of Welfare Commissioner William Hodson to coordinate all effort in that field.

The Delaware Hudson Company reported yesterday for the three months ended Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $1,194,366 after all charges and taxes, equal to $2.33 each on the 512,135 shares of capital stock outstanding. This compared with $2,255,386, or $4.40 a share, in the September quarter of last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The new approach of civilian supply, Donald Nelson said today, would be on a "positive basis -- we will direct the manufacture of so much of each item, instead of ordering the curtailment of items as in the past."

HONOLULU, Oct. 21 (delayed) -- Three of the little band of valiant marine and Navy fighter and bomber pilots who have been holding command of the air over Guadalcanal against heavy odds for two months came back from the Southwest Pacific front today with the tight-lipped promise: "We'll hold it all right."

Gregorian Court, the forty-nine-family apartment building on a plot 97 by 276 feet at 234-40 Gregory Avenue in Passaic, N.J., has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to Gregory Estates, Inc., headed by New York realty interests. J.I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

VICHY, France, Oct. 22 -- German officials in Paris tonight issued a warning to French workers that, unless they reported for departure to Germany at the hour assigned, the occupation authorities would be obliged to take measures of force.

OTTAWA, Oct. 22 -- Further economic regimentation of Canada in order to make the best possible use of available manpower and material resources is imminent but will be carried through in an "orderly and progressive manner," Donald Gordon, head of the Wartime Prices and Trade Board, declared today in a speech at Moncton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Charles Michelson, publicity chairman of the National Democratic Committee, said today that he and the national chairman, Edward J. Flynn, might retire from their jobs some day, but "certainly not" until after the November elections.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22 -- The war has speeded the United States to new frontiers of living and opportunity, and progress in science which ordinarily might have taken half a century has been made in the last few months under pressure of war necessity, Walter D. Fuller of Philadelphia, president of the Curtis Publishing Company and chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, told members of the St. Louis Rotary Club today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- This year's Army-Navy football game will be played at Annapolis and tickets to it will be available only to residents of that city, the White House announced tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 23 -- President Getulio Vargas unveiled today a monument to the late Alberto Santos-Dumont, Brazilian aviation pioneer. The monument, representing a winged man, was erected at the Santos-Dumont Airfield.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- With Prime Minister Winston Churchill acting as chief guide, Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Premier of South Africa, today visited Dover, one of Britain's "toughest" communities and scene of hundreds of attacks by Nazi air raiders and cross-Channel gunners.

"The Mummy's Tomb," a Universal melodrama with Lon Chaney Jr. in the title role, will open this morning at the Rialto. Featured in support are Elyse Knox, Dick Foran, John Hubbard, Mary Gordon and Virginia Brissac.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- A War Labor Board panel recommended today denial of a general wage increase for 31,000 maintenance employes of the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation.

A story of hope and despair, of gayety and tragedy was told yesterday by Mrs. Ethel G. Bell, 49, a missionary, and her two children, Mary, 14, and Robert, 11, who drifted for nineteen days on a tiny raft shared by fourteen others after the steamship bringing them home from Africa had been torpedoed in the South Atlantic.

MOSCOW, Oct. 23 -- The Germans continued today to attack the northern part of Stalingrad from several directions, though the reduction in scale that has marked the fighting since Wednesday was maintained. Russian counter-attacks are becoming more frequent and they nave brought the recapture of several German strongholds in built-up regions.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Viscountess Astor told the Oxford University Conservative Association tonight that she would like to see China and Russia included in the framework of the post-war social' reorganization drafted by the United States and Britain; but, she said, she thought the two countries should get into "the British way of thinking."

The serious issues raised in THE TIMES of Oct. 16 by a group of psychiatrists in reference to the impending draft of the 18-19 age group should not be regarded as an expression of the views of all or even of most psychiatrists. A number of the statements of fact need to be contested.
"JOHN," says my conscience, "you've got to give readers of THE TIMES some notion of the anthologies that are coming out this Autumn."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- A clash between the church and military officials developed here today in connection with the scheduled all-day manoeuvres of the Fifth Regiment of the New York Guard, 600 strong, on the fairways of the Wykagyl Country Club next Sunday.

Mrs. A. M. Sobol of New York and Charles H. Goren of Philadelphia won the contract bridge pair contest in the metropolitan championships at the Park Central Hotel here last night. It continued an amazing streak of tournament victories for 1Vrs. Sobel, who won the women's pair championship Tuesday and is in first place in the team-of-four contest.

New York's first wartime Navy Day parade, expected to be the largest and most spectacular in the Navy's history, will be held today, beginning at 2:30 P.M., on Fifth Avenue from Eighty-seventh to Sixty-second Streets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The civilian standard of living was higher rather than lower during the first year of war, two Commerce Department economists declared today. Their estimates indicated that 1942 expenditures for civilian goods and services will reach a record total of $79,000,000.

Last night saw the world premiere of Anton Dolin's little burlesque, "Romantic Age," at the Metropolitan Opera House as the last of the novelties scheduled for the Ballet Theatre's season there. The work is a companion piece to Mr. Dolin's "Pas de Quatre," which was set in the height of the romantic period of the ballet about 1840.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Delegates to the Navy's Labor Relation Conference urge in brief statements today immediate action to solve the question of draft deferment for workers in shore establishments and to cut down absenteeism due chiefly to minor illnesses.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Early twilight and the usual London fog were just softening the harsh, ugly contours of Paddington Station this afternoon when a special train pulled in and Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt got out to be greeted by King George VI and Queen Elizabeth in a scene that contrasted sharply with that in the Union Station in Washington when their roles were reversed.

President Roosevelt called for the election of Attorney General Bennett as Governor of New York in a telegram to the candidate emphatically reiterating his endorsement of Mr. Bennett as best qualified to preserve the liberal legislation enacted during the last three Governorships.

The revival of "Bird in Hand," Ronald T. Hammond's first offering of his local stock season, will terminate its Broadway engagement at the Morosco Theatre after tonight's performance. It will have been seen eight times. The John Drinkwater comedy opened last Monday night with a cast including Nicholas Joy, Harry Irvine, Romney Brent, Viola Roache, Harry Sothern, Frances Reid, J.W. Austin and Harry Barnard.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Seeking to have the Federal Government issue a definite pronouncement on whether police and firemen should be deferred because of the need for their services at home, John B. Keenan, Director of Public Safety here, demanded today the release from the Coast Guard of three patrolmen who had enlisted without having obtained a departmental leave of absence.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 23 (AP) -- You couldn't truthfully say Annapolis was taking in stride today the news that the Army-Navy football game was to be a strictly home-town affair, with Annapolis, site of the United States Naval Academy, the home town.

The loss of four cruisers in a few minutes of action during the first days of the Solomons campaign was only part of the price in ships sunk and damaged the Navy has paid for its first foothold on the long road to Tokyo.
ALBANY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- About 8 per cent fewer voters have registered for election on Nov. 3 than qualified to ballot in 1938, with New York City showing the heavier losses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Formation of a Coordinating Council for United Nations Committees was announced today by Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former Minister to Norway, national chairman.

A Federal court jury after deliberating for more than six hours last night reported it could not reach a verdict as to Sam Maceo, Galveston, Texas, night club operator, charged with narcotics conspiracy, but found Maceo's co-defendant, Joseph Schipano of New York City, guilty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Hazel E. Stiebeling, food economist for the Agriculture Department's Bureau of Home Economics, says the nutritional value, of the civilian food supply in prospect for 1943 would be below the average of the past two years because of indicated shortages of vitamin A, fats and carbohydrates.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 23 -- Extermination of Jews on the German model is widely expected in Norway after today's killing of a Quisling frontier guard by three young men, two of whom are officially stated to be Jews.

An approved policy for employers to follow in connection with the employment of women war workers, including the order in which women workers should be hired, has been outlined by the United States Department of Labor's women's bureau in Bulletin No. 194, "Your Questions as to Women in War Industries."

As a reader of THE TIMES on Sundays for the past twenty-five years, I have always wondered how long your staff could write about football without mentioning Massillon. Last Sunday I was pleased to see the name of Massillon appear in the story of the Ohio State-Purdue game.

Once a week -- Friday mornings -- the student body of 1,100 at the High School of Music and Art (Mayor La Guardia's favorite project) gather in the school's auditorium for a special event. Yesterday morning the appearance of Francis Henry Taylor, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the installation of students in the Senior Honor Society made a double attraction.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- The State Banking Department announced today its approval of change of location of the People's Industrial Bank from 447 Seventh Avenue, New York, to 249 West Thirty-fourth Street, effective after Nov. 1. The change is for not more than six months.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Last midnight's communique:

Well rested and well fed, in sharp contrast to its eerie ride through the floods for a defeat at the hands of North Carolina last Saturday, Duquesne expects to pick up the thread of its broken sixteen-game winning streak at the Polo Grounds today when the Iron Dukes meet Manhattan in the only local major game.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The foretop of the battleship Maine, long displayed as a historic relic at Annapolis, is going on the scrap heap.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Branch Rickey, vice president and general manager of the Cardinals, refused today to confirm or deny latest reports that he will become president and general manager of the Dodgers.

President Roosevelt's strong endorsement of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, was received with great satisfaction yesterday at the Bennett headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Canada complained to the United States today that the story in the magazine Time on disturbances at a prisoners' camp at Bowmanville, Ont., contained "distortions and inaccuracies" that would provide enemy propaganda material and might lead to further ill treatment of Allied prisoners in Germany.

Holiday advertising of wine is expected to receive impetus from clarification of the Treasury Department's interpretation of the new law relating to statements of alcoholic content. The National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., Washington, pointed out to the bureau that many imported wines which entered this country prior to May 15 have on back labels statements with respect to other wines and that these statements in many cases show the alcoholic content.

Perhaps the fact that he is an appointee of Mayor La Guardia, who has made himself enemy No. 1 of horse-racing bettors through his recent utterances, explains everything; but I cannot resist writing you concerning Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto's remarks on the sport of kings that appeared in THE TIMES on Wednesday.

Lee S. Buckingham, State OPA Administrator, announced at his office, 535 Fifth Avenue, yesterday that application form OPA-R-1100 for fuel oil and kerosene ration for heat and domestic hot water would be distributed to fuel oil dealers today at all fourteen local War Price and Rationing Board offices in New York City.

Asserting that he wished to be neither the victim nor the beneficiary of a "smear" campaign, Jerry Finkelstein, Democratic and American Labor party candidate for the State Senate against Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican, in the Seventeenth Senatorial District, denied yesterday that he was a Communist or had any dealings with Communists.

The War Production Board's first report on the progress of its drive to convert industry to war production makes good reading. It is not a complete report, but what it shows is enough to reveal some striking progress in changing a peaceful nation to a warlike one.
High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:
A feud between two brothers that began in the Mississippi Delta country last Summer was halted here by a pair of New York detectives Thursday night.

The Childs Company has failed to carry out sinking-fund provisions of its 1928 issue of 5 per cent gold debenture bonds and must pay $423,000 into the sinking fund for the issue, Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter ruled yesterday after trial of a suit by Lillian Birn, a minority bondholder.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A bill to force James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, to lift a ban preventing union members from making records for radio stations and "juke boxes" was introduced today by Senator Clark of Idaho.

Clothing manufacturers and contractors in higher cost areas where there is a surplus of labor have been allowed price differentials on it heir bids under a recent policy adopted by the Quartermaster Corps, it was revealed here yesterday.

Asserting that Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, "has no more interest in New York and its people than has any other carpetbagger," Borough President James A. Burke of Queens called on the voters of his borough last night to elect Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

QUEBEC, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Premier Adelard Godbout in a formal statement tonight protested "in the name of all our people, whether English-speaking or French-speaking'' against an article on the Province of Quebec in the magazine Life Oct. 19.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Captain E.V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, leading American ace in the last war, has been missing in the Pacific Ocean since Wednesday, the War Department announced tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 23 -- Aerial battles raged over the desert front yesterday, with the Allied air forces definitely on the offensive and the enemy trying desperately, and for the most part vainly, to protect his airfields, defenses and communications from assault.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Cunard Steamship issues advanced sharply today on the stock market on the announcement of payment of eleven years' arrears of dividend on the second preference stock. Ordinary shares showed a rise of almost 2s; first preference, one of 50s to 101 10s, and second preference, one of 11 10s to 150.

The usual influx of week-end hedge sales near the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday sent the market to the day's lows and final net losses of 13 to 17 points. Throughout the session values held moderately below the previous close, as many traders shied from forward commitments while weighing possible implications of the new ceilings placed on wheat and pork by the Office of Price Administration.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Americans are eating into their butter supplies at an unprecedented rate, and dairy trade representatives said today they would not be surprised if cold storage stocks had disappeared completely before the end of the year.

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Wake Forest -- A crowded house (Symphony Hall, Boston) heard Head Coach Richard Cresson Harlow of Harvard speak on Wednesday night. It was a flowery speech, nothing about football and all about gentians. Fancy that! One bewildered vote for Boston College.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- The Citizens Committee of 1,000, seeking re-election of Senator William H. Smathers, asserted tonight that United States Senator W. Warren Barbour was in New Jersey campaigning for Albert W. Hawkes while the Senate was considering the Lee amendment to the 'teen-age draft measure.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Oct. 24 -Northern Italy apparently had a second night's pounding from the British Royal Air Force as several points in Switzerland at midnight had their second air raid alarm of the night. The first came in Berne at 8:55 P.M. and lasted until 10 o'clock; the second was at 11:15 P.M. and ended at 12:08 A.M.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 23 -Albert W. Hawkes, Republican nominee for the United States Senate, declared today that the post-war reconstruction period "will belong to the youth of America," and asserted that his Democratic opponent, Senator William H. Smathers, "has forfeited all claim to a position of public responsibility" during the reconstruction period "by his evasive brand of statecraft and his record of absenteeism on the great social issues of his term."

HONOLULU, Oct. 21 (delayed) -- One thing the battle of the Solomons has clearly shown is that the Japanese are still offensive-minded, and at the current stage of the war in the Pacific that is all to the advantage of the United States.

TORONTO, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Sir Thomas White and Colonel Walter Gow have resigned from the board of directors of Barcelona Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., it was announced at the annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 17 were 238.118,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 1,047,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 1,014,000 and 33,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

The first performance of a new song, "America Needs You," was presented at 8 o'clock last night over the National Broadcasting System. Dedicated to the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, the song was written by Kent Cooper, general manager of The Associated Press.

George L. Fecke, promoter of the Park Avenue Canteen, ostensibly established to entertain soldiers and sailors and for which debutantes obtained funds, was found guilty in Yorkville Court yesterday of soliciting contributions without a permit from the Department of Welfare.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The British said today that a powerful naval force, built around three battleships and the aircraft carrier Illustrious, was in the Indian Ocean somewhere considerably east of Suez.

Dr. George C.D. Odell, Brander Matthews Professor Emeritus at Columbia University, received yesterday the gold medal of the New York Historical Society for achievement in history, in recognition of his "Annals of the New York Stage."

MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 24 -- Thousands of German troops, supported by heavy tanks, artillery and planes, struck yesterday at a Russian-held factory in Northern Stalingrad, but the Russians announced early today that "our units are beating off the Hitlerite attacks and inflicting heavy losses."
LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Genoa trembled and flamed last night under the R.A.F.'s two-ton "block-buster" bombs, pilots on the raid reported today.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A Navy Department communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- While compulsory industrial service was attacked in the Senate as "undemocratic" and a labor-management committee of the War Manpower Commission continued writing a report opposing Chairman McNutt's proposal for a national service law at this time, the War Labor Board acted on two manpower problems, one affecting the production of copper and nonferrous metals and the other, the migration of skilled tool and die makers from Detroit.

Immediate injunction proceedings will face violators of Order L-85 in the lower-price dress field, WPB officials told several hundred manufacturers yesterday at a special meeting called by the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group at the Hotel New Yorker.

The bridge experts went down one trick yesterday in their bid for a magna charta for duplicate bridge. They were "set" by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in the Municipal Court term of Magistrate's Court when he ruled that the game was one of chance, not skill, and therefore possessed of no more legal immunity than poker.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 23 -- In an address to members of the government party of Hungary yesterday, Premier Nicholas von Kallay, explaining proposed financial legislation, announced further tax discrimination against the Jews in Hungary.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., announced yesterday in the company's interim report to stockholders that sales for the six months ended July 31 had risen 15.8 per cent to $56,890,509 from the $49,138,776 volume for the corresponding six months of the previous year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Roosevelt today emphatically reiterated his endorsement of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor of New York.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- A "strong force" of Britain's big bombers, based here, carried out a heavy attack on Benito Mussolini's great northern port of Genoa last night.

Hundreds of women volunteers are needed to make surgical dressings and to pack kit bags for the armed forces, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. William G. Green, director of production service for the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

SEATTLE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Seattle area's twelve selective service boards declared today that they had stopped inducting married men into the Army. Stuart G. Thompson, chairman of the twelve boards, sent a letter to Representative Magnuson and Senators Bone and Wallgren, saying that the decision had been made unanimously.

Eleven, including Boysy and Doublrab, are named for the $9,800 Scarsdale Handicap at Empire City today. The mile-and-seventy-yard distance seems within the powers of such a sprinter as Doublrab, while Boysy may come on from behind fast enough to win, as he did in his nose finish with Riverland at Jamaica last Saturday.

As one of the aces of Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's Flying Tigers, Robert P. (Duke) Hedman of Webster, S. D., modestly admits that the young United States fliers forming the American Volunteer Group in China did a fair job in knocking down Japanese fighter and bomber planes.

Miriam Solovieff, young American violinist, was heard in a recital last night in Town Hall. The richly gifted player, whose musicianship and mastery of the instrument of her choice is no new story here, has matured still further in her art.

By liquidating a great variety of overlapping brands and needless ticket sizes, reducing spool sizes and conserving paper, the cotton thread industry has already prepared for the task of adjusting to a war economy, Josef Pollack, chairman of the board of the Cotton Thread Institute, declared yesterday at the group's annual meeting held in the Hotel Waldorf Astoria.

The action of this government in deciding that Italians here are no longer to be classed as enemy aliens was an act of justice which will make available to us in our war effort the services of many Italians who prefer what this country stands for to what the present rulers of Italy stand for.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 -- Representative Snyder, Democrat, was reported today to have advised a constituent that the "no-politics" Hatch act did not apply to postmasters.

An appeal to American industry to dig deeper for war salvage materials, to the extent of scrapping some of its older fabricated trade stock, was made by R. Merrill Decker, regional chief of the War Producion Board's industrial salvage section, in an address yesterday to representatives of seventy-five industries in this city that have just started organization of their own salvage committees.

Annual Girl Scout Sunday will be observed tomorrow in Roman Catholic and Protestant Churches and this morning Girl Scout Sabbath will be observed in synagogues. In view of the war conditions Scout troops in a body will attend regular services in their local house of worship this year rather than special borough-wide services for girls of the three faiths.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Oct. 23 -Major Gen. Edward Martin, Republican candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania, asked Attorney General Biddle today to investigate the part being played by Ramsey S. Black, third assistant postmaster general, in the Pennsylvania political campaign.

Acting District Attorney Thomas Cradock Hughes of Brooklyn announced yesterday that the results of two lie-detector tests given to Frank Koch, former city fireman, failed to indicate that Koch "was telling a lie when he denied being an accomplice or participant in the 1928 hold-up murder of Fireman Thomas J. Hitter or that he knew who committed the crime."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Determined to atone for last week's 6-6 Princeton tie, Pennsylvania meets Columbia in the twenty-fifth game of their series on Franklin Field tomorrow at 2 o'clock.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- With the big increase in American and British aircraft production, the United Nations have now not only caught up to but surpassed the total Axis output of aircraft, Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, said today.

The most eminent contemporary authority on hospital construction and administration has passed from the scene. He was Dr. S.S. Goldwater, who for forty years devotedly served not only this city but the entire continent. Because of his commanding personality and his zeal he was able to carry into effect policies that might otherwise have remained mere paper ideals.

Henry L. Doherty, president and founder of the Cities Service Company and philanthropist, who died on Dec. 26, 1939, left a gross estate of $11,542,044 and a net of $7,192,1576, aeeording to an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday by Depi uty Tax Commissioner Jacob L i Manicoff.

While England in the middle of war clings to the ceremonial investing the joint meeting of the Lords and Commons summoned on Wednesday to listen to the address of the Prime Minister of South Africa, there is little prospect that changes in the social structure, revolutionary as they may be, will modify very much the traditional forms which comfort Englishmen and give them a steadying sense of the permanence of their institutions.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, carried his campaign into Queens last night and in two rallies in Ridgewood and Jamaica pledged that if elected he would do all in his power to get the Legislature to pass a "fair" legislative reapportionment bill at the next session.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- In spite of direct appeals from President Roosevelt and General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, that the bill lowering the minimum draft age be enacted without imposing additional restrictions on the War Department, an apparent majority of the Senate seemed determined tonight to prevent by law the sending of 18-year-old inductees to foreign battlefronts.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Wheat broke today in the early trading on the Board of Trade, operators placing a bearish construction on an announcement that the Department of Agriculture and the Office of Price Administration had agreed on a program to permit farmers to redeem wheat pledged for government loans and sell it in the open market through the aid of a subsidy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Ernest Kanzler, director general for operations of the War Production Board, today cut types of cast iron kitchenware from about 200 to 12 and at the same time limited the amount of iron in them. By his order it is estimated 6,170 tons of pig and scrap iron will be saved annually against last year's consumption of 10,520 tons.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A communique:

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Proceedings to void the citizenship of twenty-seven naturalized residents of New Jersey on the grounds that their activities "have been incompatible with their citizenship" were instituted today in the United States District Court at Trenton by Thorn Lord, Assistant United Statees Attorney.

In a patriotic move to add to the recreational facilities for men serving in the armed forces, the Artists and Writers Association presented last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria a gala cabaret revue and supper dance entitled "Incendiary Blondes."

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 23 -- A laconic communique issued from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters, stating that American bombers on Wednesday afternoon bombed the Linsi coal mine installations of the British Kailan Mining Administration northeast of Tientsin on the Peiping-Mukden Railway became the topic of lively speculation here tonight.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation and subsidiaries reported net profit of $401,464 for the quarter ended Sept. 30, subject to audit and yearend adjustments. This figure is after a deduction of $583,000 for Federal taxes and is equal to 52 cents a share on 488,173 shares of common stock, after preferred dividend requirements.
MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique:

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 23 -- An American Airlines plane crashed and burned tonight on the steep slope of rugged Mount San Jacinto, a mile northwest of this resort, killing three crew members and nine passengers.

William A. Irvin, national chairman of the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower and former president of the United States Steel Corporation, opening the Brooklyn campaign yesterday for funds to increase safety activities, cited the need for greater safety in industrial plants, especially those engaged in war production.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Plainsmen of Auburn displayed amazing speed and power tonight to hand a 14-6 defeat to Villanova's Wildcats in their traditional intersectional game that drew 10,000 fans.

Public-housing securities again featured the market for new financing this week, although the number and size of the issues showed a marked contraction from the week before. Bonds totaling $1,875,000 were offered publicly, against $20,940,000 last week.

Just to show how fresh and keen a person should be over his morning paper, see what happened to Ethelbert Smith on page 18 yesterday. It comes very near to being his favorite page in the paper, as dedicated to permanent interests like home and children and food and clothes and beauty.

For the second successive week, housing authority issues featured public offerings of new securities here. The week's flotations, however, were smaller than in the preceding week, totaling $1,875,000 for two bond offerings, compared with $20,940,000 for fourteen issues last week. A year ago $1,832,000 in two bond issues were offered in this week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Although the dry forces in Congress led by Senator Lee of Oklahome have been pressing for a law to prohibit drinking around Army camps, public opinion is overwhelmingly opposed to another "dry era" for the nation.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Fighting French circles here said today that there was a "long-range possibility" that the crisis over the (draft of French labor in Germany might mean the fall of the Vichy regime.

Admiral Darlan has flown to Dakar to "defend the French Empire." Marshal Petain, in a message to the French West Africans, praises the "heroic empire defenders" at Madagascar, and speaks of threats against the empire -meaning, of course, Anglo-American threats -- which "have not the shadow of a pretext."

Though the Little Entente is dead and may perhaps never be revived in its old form, two of its members have pledged their friendship and their hope for a free Europe in the Czechoslovak-Yugoslav demonstration and exhibit which opened yesterday at Freedom House in this city.

New Yorkers hurried to "beat the tax" on liquors again yesterday, snapping up everything in sight in an effort to stock up before the additional tax of approximately 50 cents a quart on distilled spirits becomes effective Nov. 1.

ISTANEUL, Oct. 21 (Delayed) -- The German Labor Corps, under the direction of the Reich's foremost engineers and oilmen, it is learned, is rushing the dismantling of French and Belgian oil refineries, which are being transported to the Caucasus and rapidly reassembled to begin the immediate refining of petroleum from Russian oil fields already captured.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Striking for a pair of touchdowns in the first period, the North Carolina Naval Pre-Flight Training School eleven registered an easy triumph over the Temple eleven tonight. The home team never was able to get over the visitor's early thrusts, could do little against the alert Cloudbusters and went down to defeat by the score of 34 to 0 before a crowd of 25,000.

When Aage Andersen, able seaman, left his home in Denmark ten days before the Nazi invasion of that country on April 9, 1940, he told his relatives that he would be back "in about ten days" from a voyage to England. He was 21 years old then and had been at sea for five years.

The plea of a railroad superintendent on Pier 29, East River, that "it is a hardship for a man to refrain from smoking for eight hours," brought a sharp rebuke from Magistrate Anna M. Kross, in Essex Market Court yesterday where she imposed heavy fines on six men found guilty of smoking on two East River piers.

Dr. Gustav Egloff, one of the world's foremost authorities on petroleum, in an address last night at the Chemists Club before the American Institute of Chemists, of which he is president, said he "felt confident that synthetic rubber tires will evolve in the near future with a life of at least 100,000 miles.

HONOLULU, Oct. 23 (AP) -- All available Army and Navy sky and sea forces for the Southwest Hawaiian Islands are searching for Captain E.V. Rickenbacker and the crew of a heavy military plane, missing in a Pacific flight, the United States Army Hawaiian Department announced today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 24 -- Allied heavy bombers, continuing their support of United States forces in the Solomon Islands, sank or badly damaged a Japanese cruiser, one destroyer and eight transports or cargo ships in a raid in force on Rabaul, New Britain, General Douglas MacArthur announced today.

In the Caucasus the all-conquering Germans, who set out to conquer the world by breaking their enemies' lines with tanks and chewing them up with Stukas, are measuring their asserted gains by villages and regiments. They find an excuse for slow progress in "torrential rains."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Charleston, S.C., with a gain of 42 per cent, led all cities in department store sales in September, compared with September, 1941, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Evansville, Ind., was second with a gain of 40 per cent; Stockton, Calif., third with 39 per cent, and Long Beach, Calif., fourth with 38 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- The "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act were attacked as a "terrible thing" in the Third Circuit Court of Appeals today by the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation whose counsel suggested that the legislation be "sent back to Congress for clarification."

LONDON, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Africa loomed ever larger as the next major war theatre with the disclosure tonight that the Vichy French had strongly fortified Morocco and sent 500 of their 700 planes in Africa to Dakar, on the west coast.
Sales by savings banks of properties in the midtown section featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.
Many sportsmen who annually visit North Carolina and Lake Mattamuskeet will be reassured, if they entertained doubts, by the latest information from that sector regarding hunting regulations.

The price and material problems now faced by manufacturers of the so-called Victory cooking and heating equipment will be aired by them at a meeting with the War Production Board on Oct. 30, it was learned here yesterday. While some manufacturers are getting materials without too great difficulty and prices have been approved for thirty-four makers, an acute shortage of stoves is imminent, it was said.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Navy including the Marine Corps and the Coast Guard, now totals about 1,300,000 men, Secretary Knox said today in response to a question at press conference.

With Al Majewski scoring all three of his team's touchdowns, the Power Memorial Academy football team halted Poly Prep, 19 to 12, on the latter's gridiron yesterday. It was the second setback in three games for the Brooklynites and Power's second straight victory.

Today's events: Rose Goldblatt, piano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Victory concert, with Sonia Essin, contralto, and Marcel Grandjany, harp, participants, New York Public Library, 5:30; Lillian Bertin, piano, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30; Musical Art Quartet, Washington Irving High School, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The American marines and soldiers holding positions surrounding the airfield on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons repulsed on Wednesday (Guadalcanal date) the second light Japanese attack made in twenty-four hours, it was revealed in a Navy communique issued here late today.

Curtice Hitchcock, the New York publisher, has arrived in London to take up his survey, under the sponsorship of the OWI and the Book Publishers Bureau, of Britiish wartime publishing. He wlll stay from six weeks to two months.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Owen Lattimore, American political adviser to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, said tonight that the United Nations were planning to open new fronts "not only in Europe but in Asia," and that they eventually would wage a knockout offensive against Japan from the mainland of Chine.

Bent on making amends for their defeat at the hands of the Redskins last Sunday, the football Dodgers today will conclude preparations for tomorrow's visit to Ebbets Field by the Giants. Coach Mike Getto has planned a general rehearsal of offense and defense for the Dodgers today.

The need for better housing for approximately one-tenth of our potential or actual war workers, now discriminated against because they are Negroes, is underlined in a current statement of the National Committee on the Housing Emergency. Case studies of the situation in Philadelphia, Columbus, Ohio; Beaver County, Pa., and Connellsville, Pa., Hamtramck (an independent municipality in the heart of Detroit), Washington, D.C.; Wichita, Kan., and elsewhere, show that there has been discrimination.

To the 360,000 miles she has traveled since March, 1933, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt has added several thousand more. The first President's wife to fly the Atlantic is no stranger to travel by air, nor to travel by almost every other means except, perhaps, camels or elephants.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Another step in corporate simplification of the Erie Railroad was taken today with formal dissolution of ten underlying companies whose facilities formed major parts of the system.

A monument to Theodore Roosevelt, which was to have been unveiled on his birthday next Tuesday in Boone, Iowa, must wait for dedication until some happier anniversary when peace again makes bronze available for memorials.

NEW DELHI, India -- Hannibal must be rated high both as strategist and tactician. His victory at Cannae has become a model and symbol for the greatest modern military nation. He must also have been an efficient trainer of troops, for the Carthaginians do not seem to have been natural soldiers.

Lieutenant George Barr, missing after the April 18 raid on Japan and believed to be a prisoner, was born in Brooklyn. He lived in Queens after he was 8. He attended Northlands College at Ashland, Wis., for three and one-half years, and while there was a star forward on the basketball team and captain in his senior year.

VICHY, France, Oct. 23 -- Unoccupied France must furnish one-quarter of the skilled workers to be sent to Germany, Pierre Laval, the Chief of Government, told the Ministers' Council today. This proportion was established in accordance with the number and industrial capacity of workers in the two zones, he explained.

Although Canada Lee gave a memorable performance when "Native Son" opened in March of last year, he is giving a triumphant performance in the popular-priced revival put on at the Majestic last evening. He has pulled the part taut and made it vibrant.

German shock troops and tanks have overrun the major Soviet defenses in the Red October plant in northern Stalingrad to reach the Volga River after an assault "made possible by keeping the Russians in the dark as to the regrouping of German troops within the last two days," Berlin military quarters said last night, according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Roosevelt declared at his press conference today that the "severe punishment" Japan had announced she intended to inflict upon American aviators captured after the April raid on Tokyo and the German shackling of prisoners did not conform to the Geneva Convention for humanitarian treatment of prisoners of war.

With a brief message of greeting from King Peter of Yugoslavia and a stirring appeal for a speedy United Nations victory by Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, by short wave from England, an exhibit of the history and the fight for freedom of their countries was opened formally yesterday at Freedom House, 32 East Fifty-first Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Street railways and buses cannot possibly take the load which would fall upon them if automobiles should be eliminated entirely, Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, said here today in an address before the American Municipal Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Robbery was indicated tonight as the motive for the murder of Mrs. Lillian Galvin nad her maid, Miss Edna Sibilski, when police discovered that jewelry valued at $28,227 was missing from the Galvin home in Evanston.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Rent-control authority is necessary to prevent small business men and small defense manufacturers from being hedged in between rising costs and fixed-price controls, Paul Porter, who is in charge of rent control of the Office or Price Administration, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 -- Twenty-five women, the first to be employed by the Army on the West Coast as drivers of staff passenger cars and light trucks, ended eight weeks of work today for the California Quartermaster Depot with a perfect no-accident record.

Substantial opposition was expressed yesterday to Mayor La Guardia's plan to buy the plant of the Staten Island Edison Company when representatives of thirty-six civic and business organizations voiced their disapproval at a public hearing before the finance committee of the City Council in City Hall.

IN NORTHERN INDIA, Oct. 22 (Delayed) -- Italian prisoners of war -- many thousands of whom are interned in a camp near here -- are fatter, richer and healthier than they could ever hope to be at home or in their army. We could not visit or talk to individual prisoners, because that is forbidden by the Geneva Convention, but the camp commandant told us all about them.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Fred Annon, assistant to Paul Runyan at Metropolis, played a brilliant individual round of 68 in the Westchester one-day golf tournament at the Siwanoy Country Club today to tie Tom Kerrigan of the home club for honors in the pro event and annex both first and second places in the featured pro-amateur competition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Keying war production plans more closely to military strategy, President Roosevelt disclosed today that attainment of his numerical goals of 45,000 tanks and 60,000 airplanes in 1942 had been sacrificed to obtain weapons with longer range, more fire power and greater armor protection.

Early strength in railway shares gave the stock market yesterday a substantial foundation to withstand week-end profit-taking during the later hours. Although this selling erased or reduced many gains,the list generally managed to close slightly on the higher side.

The house at 2229 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, containing two seven-room apartments has been sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to Salo Better for cash over a purchase-money mortgage of $9,000. Hardy, Brauneis Naumann were the brokers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- Universal closed a deal today to borrow John Garfield from Warner Brothers for the leading role in the third sequence of "Flesh and Fantasy," the Charles Boyer-Julien Duvivier episodic film, of which two sequences have already been completed.

Retail trade continued active here this week, with seasonal apparel and accessory sales swelling retail volume substantially. Department store trade was estimated as running about 10 to 15 per cent ahead of the comparative week last year.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 23 (AP) -- United States Army bombers, striking far north in China, caused "serious damage" with many high-explosive and incendiary hits on the Linsi mine installations at Kuyeh in Hopeh Province, a communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stillwell's headquarters announced today.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 23 -General Ho Ying-chin, Minister of War, reporting the military situation in the period from the outbreak of the Chinese-Japanese hostilities to August, 1942, before the People's Political Council, said that a total of 11,129,572 able-bodied men had been conscripted.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A communique of British Headquarters and the R.A.F.:

Your hostess smiles, extends her hand, bids you take off your coat and hat. The hall is bright, asters glow from a blue vase, in the living room beyond there is the sound of conversation. Your host appears through a doorway. And before you know it, he is steering you over to the hearth, where a big log is burning busily.

BUFFALO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, said tonight the party's program was "to keep American labor free, to reinforce and fortify the whole structure of labor's rights and of labor's standards."

What kind of game are those bankers and bakers and candlestick makers who direct the Brooklyn Dodgers playing? From the stories in the papers it must be another version of "Button, button, who's got the button?"

President Roosevelt's statement yesterday on the New York State election was addressed to Mr. Bennett, but its real message was plainly intended for those Democrats and those members of the American Labor party who have hitherto been planning to vote for Mr. Alfange.

Total revenues of the city's unified transit system for the fiscal year ended on June 30 exceeded operating expenses by $21,531,191, it was disclosed yesterday. After deducting $1,000,000 for working capital reserve, a balance of $20,531,191 was available for the capital reserve fund, or $991,191 more than the estimate of $19,540,000 submitted to Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick a year ago by the Board of Transportation.

Government control of the steel supply soon will be changed once more to introduce a quota system which will establish, probably by quarters, exactly where each pound of this vital metal will go. Having begun with "directives" and "preference ratings," administrators of the war effort also tried priorities and allocations as a means to this end, with a limited success and an untoward amount of confusion and paper work.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Senator William H. Smathers asserted in a statement made public here today that the Republican party has failed to put forward a program for winning the war and that his Republican opponent for the Senate, Albert W. Hawkes, has not "expressed himself on anything but his dissatisfaction with the President and my record in supporting the President."

A year ago Minnesota and Michigan played at Ann Arbor before 87,000 in one of the hysteria scraps of the season. Today the Gopher and the Wolverine will have it out at Minneapolis, and from this listening post all is comparatively calm before the battle, even though it may be much more exciting than its predecessor.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Australian jungle fighters, inching forward over ground turned to quagmire by heavy rains, have shoved the Japanese farther back in New Guinea's Owen Stanley Mountains and reached positions about nine trail miles from the enemy base at Kokoda, it was reported today.

The sinking of two medium-sized United States merchant ships in a Russia-bound convoy in the North Atlantic was announced yesterday by the Navy Department after the survivors had been landed at an East Coast port. The Navy gun crew of one of the ships asserted it had downed two German airplanes during the attack.

Taking full advantage of their opponents' misplays, Columbia's freshmen defeated Princeton's junior varsity football team, 21 -- 9, on Baker Field yesterday. The Lions recovered a fumble and blocked a kick deep in Princeton territory in the third period, scoring touchdowns each time to overcome a 9-7 deficit at the half.
Defeat of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, would be interpreted abroad as a defeat for President Roosevelt, Senator James M. Mead declared last night.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Explosions -- principally the work of Belgian saboteurs -- have blown up Fort Neufchateau, one of the Liege fortifications; an airplane engine plant at Courcelles and the offices of the Friends of Greater Germany organization at Gilly, according to various reports reaching London today.

Only one more week remains in which to send Christmas packages to service men overseas through the American Women's Voluntary Services Victory Pastime Division, the public was reminded yesterday. Thousands of packages have been collected at the Services' Greater New York Headquarters, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street, and at the organization's neighborhood units, but thousands more can be used, according to Mrs. Zachary Goldston, chairman of the division.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Senator Nye of North Dakota asked America's allies today to take note that "Corporal" Wendell L. Willkie and "Private" Henry R. Luce did not speak for the United States.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- War production in New York is creating a heavy demand for moderately priced housing, stimulating the farm market and cutting office building and commercial property sales by two-thirds, according to George Long, president of the State Real Estate Boards Association.

The Appellate Division yesterday granted a stay sought by Assistant Corporation Counsel Charles C. Weinstein to restrain publishers of racing sheets from taking depositions from Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the State Racing Commission, and others, in the injunction suit by the publishers to prevent License Commissioner Paul Moss from banning newsstand sale of their racing publications.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- Governor Lehman joined tonight with Attorney General Bennett, whom the Democrats have nominated as his successor, in an attack on Thomas E. Dewey, Republican standardbearer, and his party's record.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Dorothy Thompson, newspaper columnist, in a radio talk tonight endorsed Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, Republican nominee for Representative from the Fourth Connecticut District, as a "liberal Republican" belonging to "that opposition to the Administration which is constructive, which is modern, which has broken with toryism and nineteenth century concepts, and lives in a modern world."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -Communities, shippers and the traveling public hereafter will have a chance to protest before a going railroad line is requisitioned and demolished to provide rail for use in connection with military posts and war plants.

Difficulties with Chinese ship crews are increasing, particularly in the Port of New York, and desertions among the Chinese are creating a manning problem that threatens to become serious, it was disclosed here last week. Negotiations are now going on between American, Chinese and British authorities in an attempt to find a solution to a situation that has plagued official shipping agencies for months.

The General Electric Company expects this year to manufacture $1,000,000,000 in war goods, according to a booklet mailed yesterday to stockholders in the company. The publication, censor-approved, tells the story of a war program that began in 1939 and which included tremendous expansion of plant, great conversion of existing facilities and the hiring and training of more than 50,000 new workers.

JAMES BUCHANAN DUKE consciously modeled his business career on that of John D. Rockefeller. He found that it paid. The reader of this unauthorized but respectful life will find it unfortunate. The story of a monopoly is the story of a monopoly, whoever is involved and whether the commodity is oil or tobacco.
