The favored teams were eliminated last night in the contest for the metropolitan contract bridge team-of-four championship, and Mrs. A.M. Sobel lost her bid to win three consecutive titles.

It is not always possible these to report just what part the commercial airlines of the United States are playing in the war effort. Every one knows they are carrying on with the greatly increased burden that has been put on them, and although details cannot be given at this time, it is known that they are flying to many places that formerly had no regular air service.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 24 -- New York City's facilities in housing and labor will be required in connection with the transfer of the Office of Dependency Benefits from Washington to the new twenty story Prudential Building here, it was disclosed today by Fred W. Vincent Jr., assistant director in charge of field operations of the Office of Decentralization, which is supervising the removal.
We have now reached the fourth year of this war and the defense phase has now ended. The stage is set for the last, the offensive phase.

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Automotive engineers have turned to photography to find out how well lubricating oils meet the requirements of actual service. The camera's new vocation was described by H.R. Luck of the Shell Development Company at the national fuels and lubricants meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

A Metropolitan Opera Box Subscription Committee has been formed to conduct a campaign for the sale of box subscriptions for the coming Metropolitan Opera season, it was announced yesterday. The committee is headed by Donald Peabody Blagden, member of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association.

Sharply criticizing the manpower program as now set up, Victor G. Reuther, assistant coordinator of war policy for the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O., demanded yesterday that a central agency be established in Washington that could be relied upon to carry out a "real manpower program."

The Japanese "Mein Kampf" assures its readers that the first Mikados ruled the whole world and that Nippon has a divine mission to bring the rebellious nations back into line under Hirohito. "Believe us," the monkeys told Mowgli in the Kipling tale, "we are the most wonderful people in all the jungle.
STORRS, Conn., Oct. 24 -- The University of Connecticut football team rallied to beat Springfield, 21 -- 14, before 2,500 fans today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- After a little more than two years of functioning, with amendments in several respects, the Selective Service Act is on the verge of being amended again in the light of the harsh realities of war.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 -- A special session of the Chamber of Deputies is expected to be held to speed the adoption of a decree establishing the death penalty to meet the "horrifying wave of criminality," the newspaper Excelsior reports.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, said in a speech at Sheffield today that Britain had been defending herself "too desperately to be able to help China as she deserves," but he promised China's day of deliverance would come.

In the belief that the House-approved bill removing the ban on child labor in the beet and sugar cane fields looms as a threat to child labor standards in the States, the National Consumer League is calling for a public hearing on the legislation and for Senate opposition when activities are resumed on its behalf.

THE Metropolitan Championships, which have been under way since last Sunday, will come to a close today with a two-session contest for mixed pairs. The sessions will begin at 2 and 8:30 P.M. and will be played at the Park Central Hotel.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 24 -- A scrapping Michigan State football team, paced by Dick Kieppe, beat the Great Lakes Naval Training Station eleven, 14 -- 0, before a homecoming throng of 11,600 at Macklin Field today.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 24 -- University of Iowa students, equipped with official information and a desire to be of service, will be available as speakers in the State during 1942-43. The squads are being organized as the Association of Forensic Speakers for Victory and will include debate, discussion and public forum groups.

The Golden Rule Foundation, 60 East Forty-second Street, proposed yesterday that all religious, educational, war-relief and philanthropic institutions consider a cooperative effort to "increase the percentage and the volume of wartime giving" by asking "each citizen to consider the advantages and importance of contributing the largest practicable portion of the 15 per cent of income exempted from taxation if given to charities."

While the Revenue Act of 1942, signed by President Roosevelt last Wednesday, Oct. 21, imposes the highest taxes of record in the United States -- so high as to amount to an experimentation in rates -- it reflects the most creditable attempt ever made to take the harshness out of arbitrary exactions.

In a series of three raids, during which one man broke an ankle by leaping from a window, police squads directed by Deputy Chief Inspector Michael J. Murphy arrested fifty-five persons between 5 and 5:45 P.M. yesterday in Manhattan in Mayor La Guardia's campaign against gambling on horse races.

The premiere of the 1943 Ice Follies, scheduled for the night of Dec. 1 at Madison Square Garden, will be a benefit for the Musician Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is acting president. The beneficiary for the last few years has taken over this initial performance of the gala ice show as a means to advance its relief work among talented musicians who need financial aid.

THERE is a street in Providence called "Benefit" and it is unique not only for that city but, if David Cornel De Jong's description of it be true, unique for any city. According to him, it has inspired poems, novels, paintings and rhapsodies.

Despite announced intention of the WPB to impose inventory restrictions, wholesale markets as a whole were quite steady last week and cancellations were rare, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

In THE TIMES of Oct. 20 was a letter from Edith Gold advocating the banning of "Finlandia," the tone poem of Sibelius, for the duration of the war. She also refers to "Axis music." The mere fact that we are at war does not mean that we should altogether lose our sanity.

The geese are flying south again. The countryman once more hears the faint gabbling overhead, and when he scans the skies he sees there in the high distance the clean-lined V of honkers on their way. He watches, and when he turns back at last to his Autumn tasks there is new assurance in his heart.

TICONDEROGA -- There are two spots on the headlands on Lake Champlain where the Indians so delighted in sunning themselves that it would appear Indian Summer was born there. One of them is Ticonderoga Peninsula, the old gateway to the Adirondacks in stage-coach days.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Making public the results of the first nation-wide public opinion survey of American cities and city planning, the Bureau of Urban Research of Princeton University revealed today that most American city dwellers considered the lack of good, low-priced housing to be the outstanding municipal problem of the day.

A contract for several million ammunition boxes, one of the largest war orders yet received by small business in this area, has been awarded to the United Metal Box Company in Brooklyn, Colonel R.W. Johnson, chief of the New York Ordnance District, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The urgency of united action against the Axis through the opening of a second front, if possible, was stressed by prominent speakers in this country today.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 24 -- For the second straight week the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame have removed a team from the nation's unbeaten ranks.

ANOTHER "beat the tax" spurt started up in retail trade last week when the tax bill was signed and the excise on hard liquor goes to $6 a gallon on Nov. 1 from the current level of $4. This spurt was only a sideshow, however, compared with the one of last year before Oct. 1 when appliances, jewelry, furs and numerous other items were affected.

"Multiple sclerosis" is the name given to a class of nervous diseases that manifest themselves by palsy, paralysis, tremblings and shakings, disturbances of speech. The acute forms comprise the majority of the cases of what is called "encephalitis" (inflamation of the brain).

THE packed audience that watched the judging of the 1943 New York Salon of Photography at the Camera Club at 121 West Sixty-eighth Street last Sunday came away with a liberal education of what it takes to win recognition in the camera salon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The gleeful exploitation today by Axis propagandists of the belated official admission here that Japan may have taken prisoners after the American raid over Tokyo was the latest phase in a kind of radio debate across the fighting lines that has lately developed into one of the major aspects of the war.

APROXIMATELY five months ago there appeared on these pages an article about how we troopers at Fort Riley bemoaned the fact that our post, dedicated largely to the relationship between horses and men and located at the precise geographical center of the country, suffered the neglect of that glamorous set of entertainers catering to those soldiers at the more accessible posts on the coasts.

WITH BRITISH FLEET off Alexandria, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A roaring fleet of American-made light sea-craft shelled the Axis-held supply port of Matruh, on the Egyptian coast, last night and darted away from the raid without the loss of a ship despite a three-hour Axis plane attack.

For the second time in this oddest of State campaigns, President Roosevelt has thrown some doubt in the contest for the Governorship by a much stronger endorsement of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. than he gave originally.

THERE are now four stories about Sylvie Ann and her friends, beginning several years ago with "Pumpkin Moonshine," the Halloween story which is still the best loved of Tasha Tudor's books. If we add "Snow Before Christmas" and "A Tale for Easter" to the list, we find all the seasons represented in these small, appealing volumes with their exquisitely colored illustrations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- How five American gunners in big bombers fought off Axis fighter planes on missions over occupied Europe was described by the War Department today in disclosing the award of Distinguished Flying Crosses.

To secure an adequate supply of trained men for the prosecution of the war and for post-war reconstruction the assignment of top-ranking high school graduates to colleges and universities for advanced study, under government subsidy if necessary, was called for by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, in his ninth annual report, which will be presented to the University Council tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A Navy Department communique:

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 -- Playing the same alert game that enabled them to score a smashing upset victory over Colgate last week, the Duke University Blue Devils rolled to a 28-0 triumph today over an injury-handicapped Panther eleven before 15,000 in Pitt Stadium.

By way of London comes word that Vatican City is issuing 25-centesimi green, 80c black and 1-lira blue stamps to direct world attention to the humanitarian work by Pope Pius XII during the present war. The design is a likeness of the Saviour, and a Latin inscription reads "I have compassion on the multitude."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- House servants, agricultural laborers, office boys, stenographers and a variety of other persons who never before were tax-conscious in the United States will feel a sudden twinge in region of their pocketbooks next year, when the 1942 Revenue Act signed this week by President Roosevelt takes effect.

The annual show of the Chrysanthemum Society of America and the Autumn flower show of the Horticultural Society of New York will be combined this year in an exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History on Nov. 5, 6 and 7.

A world at war brings increased usefulness of certain medicinal drugs. Often the shortage of such drugs may be met by employing some-native drug-producing plants, one of which is the Datura, or Angel's Trumpet. This plant, which is grown chiefly for ornament in our gardens, has long been known as a source of narcotic drugs.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- The German Air Force resumed its activity at Stalingrad yesterday, operating in force to support ground forces numbering 7,000 to 8,000 men, which with tanks maintained their attacks in the northern part of the city. mortar fire made elaborate preliminaries for yet another thrust at the walls of the disputed factory where the German advance has been halted for a week.

THE work of American artists long dead will help save the lives of soldiers of the United Nations, through an exhibition of paintings for the benefit of the American Field Service, opening to the public on Tuesday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street.

A warning that employers, especially small ones whose bookkeeping methods are not too comprehensive, must be exceedingly careful with funds collected next year as "victory taxes" was issued yesterday by Arthur R. Tucker, managing director of the Controllers Institute of America.

Washington plans for eliminating non-essential industry and for shifting labor from one industry to another are not likely to affect production of fur coats, which are regarded by war agency officials as higher-priced utility garments and not as luxury items, according to a statement yesterday by the New York Auction Company, fur auction concern, following a survey of opinion at Washington.

Questions from thousands of women throughout the country concerning what they can do at home to help men in service are being answered by the U.S.O. Wooden shower clogs are No. 1 on the soldier's request list, and they will be one of the first handicraft items stressed by the new Volunteer Projects Division, headed by Mrs. Robert Pirie.

DOWN on the tanbark in a cone of light from spots on either side of Madison Square Garden, Trigger, the horse, had pawed the ground six times to reveal his age, and now the "Sons of the Pioneers" came out of the darkness plucking guitars.

THE major event in New York's night life this week will be the opening on Wednesday evening of The Mardi Gras, a dinner and supper club, under the auspices of Alfred Mack, former promotion and banquet manager of the Hurricane and Paradise.

Rationing of men's clothing was declared unnecessary last week by wool mills, clothing manufacturers and retailers, but they warned that the fact government officials have indicated that such action is under consideration points to the possibility that there may be some restrictions.

NOVELS dealing with one aspect or another of the American Revolution increase and multiply exceedingly. Many of them are second-rate, some good; few even approach the high level of excellence attained by Agnes Sligh Turnbull's fine story of Western Pennsylvania.

HERE is a useful handbook for the Army wife -- which means that its information will be useful also to the woman who is thinking about going herself into military service. The author is the wife of an Army officer, and her purpose has been to answer such questions for other women as she had first to answer for herself.

Blackout curtains obscure an industrious project at the Bank Street School this week. Volunteer workers, headed by Mrs. Lucy Sprague Mitchell, are working far into the night making toys to equip the "mercy ship" bound in the near future for Portugal.

Despite the fact that numerous industries will have to undergo concentration and zoned distribution programs, practically none of them has as yet developed a voluntary program for nucleus plants or for the preservation of trade names and trade-marks of companies forced to shut down, a canvass revealed last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The most difficult wartime elements to fuse into an effective weapon against the enemy are the civilian and military viewpoints. This difficulty is at the root of the controversy over war information between the press, the public and many civilian officials on the one hand and the commanders of the armed services on the other.

WACO, Texas, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Texas Aggies repeatedly knocked at Baylor University's door today. The same number of times the door was barred. Baylor had two scoring chances, cashed in on one and that was the football game: Baylor 6, Texas A. and M. 0.

Plans for the formal licensed event of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club have been announced, completing the Autumn schedule of retriever trials in the Eastern sector. This meeting will be held Saturday and Sunday, Nov. 21 and 22 at Bayport.

Presly Neville Guthrie, 66 years old, former president of the Reading Iron Company, Philadelphia, committed suicide last night, according to the police, by inhaling gas in the kitchen of his apartment at 143-20 Thirty-seventh Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 24 -- Boy Scouts and their leaders from Long Island, New York and New Jersey joined today the annual pilgrimage to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Youngs Memorial Cemetery here to mark the birthday of the late President, which will occur on Tuesday.
Army, Navy and Marine ground and air forces are working together in close harmony in combat areas in the Pacific, but behind the lines there is some friction and considerable mutual criticism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The status of American prisoners of war has been heavily clouded this week by events abroad outside the control of the United States, in spite of the most scrupulous care on the part of this country to observe the humane regulations governing prisoners under the ponderous system set up by international convention.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Wisconsin repeatedly pounded on the touchdown door today before driving through twice on 55 and 80-yard drives to open its Western Conference title bid by beating Purdue, 13 to 0, before a homecoming throng of 20,000.

A WIZENED old lady who bore her 92 years with grace died a few days ago in a North Carolina plantation house overlooking the red tobacco lands of Caswell County. She was Mrs. Belle McGehee Phifer, probably the last person in the United States intimately associated with the Virginia episode of Frederick Delius the eminent English composer, who died at Grez-sur-Loing in France several years ago.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- In an offensive against the enemy in the Alamein sector of the Egyptian Western Desert battlefront, Britain's Eighth Army has smashed through Axis defenses at several points, according to latest press reports reaching London tonight from Cairo.

SWAN QUARTER, N.C. -- With the waterfowl season opening on Nov. 2, duck and geese hunters coming to Lake Mattamuskeet and other parts of North Carolina's coastal area are being informed that it will not be necessary for them to have Coast Guard permits for hunting if they are accompanied by a guide or other companion who has such a permit.

An appeal to owners of suitable buildings to remodel them into apartments to be leased to war workers or to the Federal Government for that purpose was made yesterday by Edward Weinfeld, State Housing Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Lend-lease goods transferred and services given during September reached an all-time high monthly value of $643,000,000, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., administrator, reported to President Roosevelt today.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 24 -- Two freshman backs -- one of them playing his first varsity game -- threw touchdown passes to a wing-footed sophomore to spark Penn State to a 13-10 victory over favored Colgate today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Roosevelt is "very grateful" for contributions to the scrap drive sent to him personally, but he thinks the donors would do better to send such gifts to local salvage committees, thus saving time in getting the contributions "into the scrap" and also lessening the burden on the overtaxed transportation system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Maritime Commission announced today that seven manufacturing plants and two shipyards have been designated to receive its "M" pennant, commission flag and labor merit badge for outstanding production performance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Navy has relieved Vice Admiral Robert L. Ghormley of command of the Solomon Islands action and replaced him with Vice Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., it was announced here today. Admiral Halsey distinguished himself last Spring in conducting the notable hit-and-run air and sea raid on Japanese installations in the Gilbert and Marshall Islands in the Japanese-controlled region southwest of Hawaii.

ISTANBUL, Oct. 23 (Delayed) -- Reports from authoritative foreign diplomatic circles in Ankara said tonight that the departure for Moscow of the Soviet Embassy's first secretary, Mme. Antonina Gigalova, might be considered evidence of further deterioration in Turko-Russian diplomatic relations.

Price and production, probably the two most important factors in industry in wartime, again have come into conflict in copper, a most essential metal in the waging of a mechanized war. Recognizing that a price incentive is needed even to maintain production, government authorities in Washington have started reviewing the price control over copper for the purpose of obtaining more of this metal for the war effort.

KING OF "ICEBERGS": Europe's tallest King, six-foot six-inch Christian X of Denmark, has never held himself aloof from his countrymen. They have grown accustomed to meeting him strolling in the parks or riding his horse through the streets of Copenhagen, alone and unguarded.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Chilean Government, which recently seemed satisfied with having achieved a reasonable economic readjustment to war conditions with the financial aid of the United States, is now in process of making the political readjustment that Washington and many Chileans regard as the logical and necessary counterpart of the economic adjustment.

The New York Federation of Jewish Charities, fathered by the wartime conditions of 1917, will mark its twenty-fifth anniversary next month by "staying on the job" to meet the community needs of a still greater war emergency and to carry forward the old humanitarian tasks that men of good-will perform in war or peace.

A new wartime task for women -- to help prevent the waste of manpower through accidents -- is being prepared for some 5,000,000 women in the country. Spearhead of the accident prevention drive, on invitation of the National Safety Council, is the National Council of Women.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Occupation, sensational 2-year-old from the stables of John M. Marsch, Chicago sportsman, came out to Kentucky today to prove to the home folks that he's every inch the great champion he's cracked up to be.
NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 24 (AP) -- With one lightning thrust, Nebraska drove to a touchdown at the end of the first half today and emerged with a 7-to-0 victory over Oklahoma.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Princeton's football team is no longer an unknown quantity. This afternoon, with 15,000 watching in Palmer Stadium, it passed and ran Brown into defeat by a score of 32 to 13, and it did it with poise, drive, speed and power.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- An alarming picture of food shortages in Puerto Rico was given today in a statement by Filipo L. de Hostos, president of the island's chamber

PROBABLY at no time in the history of the novel has the novelist who tries to write honestly and unflinchingly about the world he lives in been confronted by a situation which equals in complexity that of today.

Attesting to its worth by an almost phenomenal growth, the Ecole Libre, considered the only intellectually free French university in the world today, reopens for the second term this week with a student enrollment of 1,500 and a faculty of nearly 100 famous exiled scholars.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Farm wage rates in New York have soared an average of $13 to $18 a month and 80 cents to 95 cents a day in the past year, the Agriculture Department disclosed today. Rates Oct. 1 were the highest on record since 1920.

SOMEBODY has been trying to poison Pamela North's Aunt Flora with arsenic and Aunt Flora sends for Pam and tells her all about it in the hope that Pam's detective talent may be useful. Pam suggests that Lieutenant Bill Weigand be called in, but Aunt Flora will have none of it.
Your delightful TIMES editorial on the pumpkin moves me to say in the words of John Greenleaf Whittier, "What calls back the past like the rich pumpkin pie?"

War has put household tools into the hands of many a Junior Leaguer and aprons onto unaccustomed shoulders, as members struggle to maintain their longtime program of volunteer work undisturbed, despite the vanishing domestic and the absence of the usual "handy man."

Resistance to the invader in occupied France is being carried on by a highly organized group of three cells comprising labor, bourgeoisie and youth, the organization having an active membership of nearly 2,000,000 and an army of 50,000 men, according to Andre Philip, National Commissioner of the Interior and Labor of the de Gaulle government and a leader of French resistance to Germany.
Seven outstanding judges have been selected to serve at the National Horse Show, which will be held at the Riding and Polo Club, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street on Nov. 7.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace in THE TIMES Magazine of Oct. 11 suggested that the words "El Dia de la Raza" be translated to "The Day of Those Who Speak Spanish." He speaks Spanish, and I will bet a sombrero that he pronounces the word "rassa" and not "ratha," as taught in the schools of the United States, with the possible exception of Washington.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- The desert of Southern and Central Arizona, offering a restful interlude amid the thunder of a world at war, is getting ready for another Winter season. Resort hotels and guest ranches are preparing for late October and November openings.

OTTAWA, Oct. 24 -- Canada is spending $6,900,000 a day on the war, of which slightly over half is being raised by taxation. To make up the balance the whole country is just now throwing itself into the task of raising a loan that has been set at $750,000,000 minimum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- By a vote of 58 to 5 the Senate passed tonight, after eight hours of controversy and clashes with the Administration and Army command, its own bill to lower the Selective Service minimum age to 18 years, but provided especially that no inductee under 20 years of age should be sent into actual combat overseas without a full year of training.

WAR is a time for tightlipped tales of action, of physical heroism, of the unquenchable determination which leads to victory. War, that is, is a time for melodrama. All values have been weighed and all decisions taken. What is left is action. Mention a Nazi.

FROM the start of her career Josephine Lawrence has had an uncanny sense of timing -- plus an instinct for the theme, the kind of human problem which will hit the maximum number of people where they live. Her earlier novels -- "Years Are So Long," "If I Have Four Apples," "The Sound of Running Feet" -- were perfectly attuned to the mood of the depression and exploited its consequences with homely immediacy.

At the Metropolitan Opera House last night the Ballet Theatre restored to its repertory after a season's absence Eugene Loring's "Billyt he Kid," with music by Aaron Copland. This is the first production of the ballet which Mr. Loring himself has not staged, David Nillo having performed that function on this occasion.

The long-awaited court test of the constitutionality of the "deathsentence" section of the Public Utility Holding Company Act gained momentum last week with six major utility systems racing for a legal show-down with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

AN inter-club exchange of programs intended to aid club activity, make leading speakers available to clubs not usually able to secure them and encourage interclub fraternity is being promoted by the Camera Club, reports John W. Doscher, president.
CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Undefeated and untied Delaware won its fifth straight game today, beating Dickinson, 20 to 0, before 3,000. Delaware now is unbeaten in eighteen games.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, said today that he had been informed that the Federal Government soon would issue an order curtailing the use of newsprint by newspapers to 65 per cent of the current volume.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- A blue mallard duck, one of the flock in Depew Park here, today underwent a plastic surgery operation for the restoration of its upper bill, lost in an encounter with a snapping turtle a few days ago.
UNTIL recently you stopped in at the butcher's maybe four or five mornings a week. "Let's see," you would ruminate. "There are six of us, and we each eat a little under half a pound."

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 24 -- Coming from behind in the kind of race on which he holds the patent, the Calumet Farms Whirlaway today captured the twenty-ninth Washington Handicap before a crowd of 18,000. Whirly accomplished the feat at the expense of a couple of former platers, Thumbs Up and Riverland, who finished second and third, respectively.

SINCE Bernard Shaw has been slowly maturing and is now more than 86 years of age, it is time some one wrote a mature book about him. This is exactly what Hesketh Pearson has done in "G.B.S., a Full Length Portrait." Although he has written it with Mr. Shaw's frisky cooperation, he has tried to be candid about the white-bearded tycoon.

The annual benefit for the Washington Cathedral, under the auspices of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association, will be the performance of the S.N. Behrman comedy, "The Pirate," starring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, on the night of Dec. 15 at the Martin Beck Theatre.

THIS is the final week of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House. Four works will have their first presentations of the season, and the single premiere that had been scheduled has had to be postponed beyond the end of the current engagement.

More and more of the strength of Japan and the United States was being drawn last week into the battle of the Solomons. On the shores of Guadalcanal the troops of both sides stood poised for decisive action. In near-by waters, fast, slim craft of the fleets played a deadly game of hide-and-seek, while farther off lurked powerful ships of the line.

A careful check-up on the "family bus" is exceedingly important at this time. Drivers always have much more trouble with their automobiles in Winter than in any other season. And although cold weather has not yet set in, it will be upon us soon.

William J. Clark, Regional Manager of the ODT Motor Transport Division, reminded operators of commercial motor vehicles again yesterday that unless they held certificates of war necessity by Nov. 15 they would be unable to buy gasoline, tires, or replacement parts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A vast expansion within the next year of the personnel and payroll of the Office of Price Administration is regarded here as inevitable as rationing expands and the problems of administering the price-control structure become more numerous and more complex.

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Director of Selective Service for New York City, revealed yesterday that 4,728 selective service registrants have applied to date for volunteer officer candidate training. This large enrollment, Colonel McDermott said, whose average age is 31, equals the enthusiasm shown by younger men who are rushing to volunteer.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 24 Renewing his attack on Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, for saying the war was not an issue in the campaign, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, stressed tonight that he favored rearmament and aid to the Allies before Pearl Harbor.

In an effort to improve their power in bargaining and labor negotiations, members of the National Council of Marine Draftsmen are considering an expansion program that may entail the inclusion of draftsmen from other industrial fields and affiliation with one of the two major labor organizations, it was disclosed last week.

THEODORE WALDECK, a born explorer (his "On Safari" tells in humorous, human fashion how as a boy he started on his chosen career), knows the countries and animals which he describes at first hand, and blessed with a photographic memory he writes with an extraordinary vividness of detail and a keen sense of the drama constantly played out in the wilds.

IN "Members of the Family," Mr. Van de Water has written another chronicle of his Vermont farm and of the "four-dimension farming" which brings in dividends of values and satisfactions that never appear in the balance sheet of dollars and cents known to farmers in three dimensions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Published reports that the country's rubber problem had been "licked" and that automobile tires would be available for every one by Nov. 15 were declared today by William M. Jeffers, National Rubber Director, to be "erroneous and misleading."

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Holy Cross's big football team, which dropped three straight games in college competition this season, came to life with a bang today as it crushed a favored North Carolina State eleven, 28 to 0, before 7,500 at Fitton Field.

A young man of Manhattan who hails from Brooklyn, adores the Dodgers and finds time to play a lot of end for the Jaspers, staged a one-man show at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Herb Kopf's Kelly Greens downed Duquesne, 10 -- 7, before 12,000 spectators.

A MAN'S life may be conceived as the continuous conflict and reconciliation of his heredity anal his environment. So also the history of a region grows out of the action and reaction of its natural setting and the people who occupy it.

Indications multiplied last week that a new pricing arrangement is likely to be established for the women's apparel industries with the expiration of MPR 153 on Nov. 30. Garment executives returning from conferences with OPA officials in Washington during the last few weeks have indicated consideration is being given to a method based on mark-ups, which may take several forms.
WASHINGTON, Pa., Oct. 24 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York gave the principal address at Founder's Day exercises at Washington and Jefferson College today. He received the degree of Doctor of Laws.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- The Navy has issued letters of commendation to ten enlisted men, members of an armed guard crew on board a merchantman, for their conduct during repeated aerial attacks on their ships.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 24 -- Lafayette College defeated the University of Virginia eleven, 19-13, today with a rally in the last half that netted three touchdowns. A crowd of 8,000, including Pennsylvania's Governor, Arthur H. James, attended.

The steel industry's recovery of scrap metal as a by-product of its manufacturing operations has not kept pace with the gains made in the total tonnage of ingots produced, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, which explains why the industry is more dependent than ever upon outside sources of scrap to maintain production.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A draft treaty designed to accomplish the immediate relinquishment of American extraterritorial privileges in China was submitted to Dr. Wei Tao-ming, the Chinese Ambassador, by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 -- The University of California at Los Angeles dropped Santa Clara from the ranks of the unbeaten today, defeating the nation's eighth-ranked team, 14 to 6. A crowd of 40,000 saw the game.

BEFORE Pearl Harbor the author of this book started on an odyssey which has produced one of the most strikingly interesting autobiographies in the Negro literature of America, for it combines the subjective and objective approaches to the lives and emotions of Negroes in a way which no other work of its kind in recent years has quite achieved.

Characterizing President Roosevelt's second endorsement of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, as a death blow to the pretension of the American Labor party that Dean Alfange, its candidate, was the standard bearer for the New Deal in New York, Louis Waldman, former leading member of that party, issued a statement yesterday urging Labor party members to vote for Mr. Bennett.

More drastic revision and further clarification of the Army's dimout regulations is imminent, it was learned yesterday. It became known also that the Second Service Command had asked police and State Directors of Civilian Defense not to arrest store owners installing dimout screens pending approval by the Army.
MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Soviet Information Bureau communique:
ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- Governor Lehman, in a proclamation today, asked that Navy Day be observed Tuesday with memorial exercises for "our heroic dead" throughout the State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, disclosed today his approval of a $26,000,000 expansion of Henry J. Kaiser's steel plant facilities under construction at Fontana, Calif.

This department has recorded in the past the discovery by Dr. S. Ansbacher and his colleagues that pariminobenzoic acid ("paba" for short), one of the B-complex of vitamins, restores gray hair to its natural color. Some doubt was expressed by skeptics and some evidence accumulated that the anti-gray hair factor was calcium pantothenate, a compound of pantothenic acid, another "B."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -- A dynamic first-half ground attack kept Army's potent squad of gridiron warriors on football's victory highway today as the cadets scalped Harvard, 14 to 0, before 35,000, the season's largest crowd at Harvard Stadium.

Arthur G. Fink will, in all likelihood, succeed W. Stanfield Cooper as commander of the Bayside Power Squadron at tomorrow's election. He heads the slate that has been brought in by the nominating committee for consideration at the annual meeting to be held at Colonial House, Northern Boulevard and 158th Street, Flushing.

The age-old practice of making parsley baskets is being revived in our community, to the delight of many modern gardeners. As it is a practice that could be followed with pleasure and profit by many gardeners, a brief outline of the process may be useful.

EIGHTEENTH-CENTURY England was the great age of the tavern and the coffee house. Within the walls of these establishments were formed the many clubs of Georgian England. It is not surprising to learn that among these clubs there were some more convivial and less innocent than the rest.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- This is a letter written by a woman of Cologne to her husband on the Russian front. His name was Hans Lingling; hers is unknown, for she signs herself, "Your Wife." The letter is dated May 31.

HUNTINGTON PARK, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Miss Coral Houston, a Methodist missionary who was returned from China aboard the exchange ship Gripsholm, said that four and possibly five of the crew of a United States bomber who landed in occupied China after the bombing of Tokyo were captured by the Japanese.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Led by their stellar fullback, Jim Carey, who scored three touchdowns, unbeaten Amherst routed Wesleyan today 27 to 0 in a Little Three contest. Tallying twice in both the first and fourth quarters, The Lord Jeffs won easily, as Wesleyan never threatened seriously.

Last call for metal merchandise is sounding in the stores. With priorities in full force, lines of bathroom accessories are gradually becoming depleted. Some shops with stocks left over from pre-priority days can, however, still supply the demand.

After being locked up in a hotel after failure to reach a verdict in the trial of Sam Maceo. Galveston, Texas, night club owner, charged with narcotics conspiracy, a Federal court jury before Judge Francis G. Caffey acquitted the defendant yesterday morning. The jury resumed deliberations at 10 A. ]Vf. and reached the verdict txventy minutes later.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- The possibility of conscription of women without first giving to them equal constitutional status with men was denounced today as a "death blow to the rights of women" by Mrs. Harvey W. Wiley, chairman of the National Woman's Party, meeting here for its biennial convention.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- In an impressive ceremony on the Wesleyan University campus this afternoon, Raymond Baldwin unveiled a plaque at the site of the home occupied by Woodrow Wilson during his days here as professor of history and football coach.

Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Marshall Berck gave a reception and buffet supper last night at their home, 784 Park Avenue, to celebrate the ibirthday of Mrs. Berck's father, President Rafael L. Trujillo of the Dominican Republic.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Autumn again brings equestrians, golfers, fishermen and hunters to Atlantic City. Shore fishermen are pulling in kings, flounders, weaks, croakers, black bass, porgies and an occasional striped bass. In the back waters catches include eels, weaks, kings, croakers and small bass.

Russia's cities have been Russia's bastions. Anchors of the Red Army defense, they have time and again stemmed the Wehrmacht's sweep across the featureless plains of the Russian homeland. Kiev, holy "mother city" to millions of Russians, and Odessa, grain port on the Black Sea, held the invader for two months.

IF the little child's first concern lies in what he sees close at hand, it is not long before he has a dawning consciousness of the extent of the world, a growing interest in the long distances that may be traveled in boats, trains, automobiles and airplanes and a realization that there are places very different from those to which he is accustomed, where there are new and strange sights to be seen.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- In a widening program of war activities to bring the college and community together in mutual interests and participation, the faculty of Sarah Lawrence College has volunteered a series of evening extra-curricular courses open, for the first time, to the public as well as to the students.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Portland area is launching ships at the rate of one a day, for a time at least.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Trade reports covering the last month or so indicate a sharp revival in home furnishings and furniture purchases in war production centers that in some cases verges on "scare buying," but the industry as a whole is still far from happy over trade conditions.

THE art of the poster attained, honestly earned, a place of prominence in the exhibition schedule of the week just concluded. It is not a large show that the Museum of Modern Art is holding in one of the main-floor galleries, but it is an "all-star" performance in that the examples displayed won either prizes or honorable mentions in the United Hemisphere Poster Competition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Despite some local shortages of coffee, the stocks of the nation's favorite breakfast beverage are at least normal and perhaps above, informed government sources said today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- In the middle of the Winter of 1921 a small Russian force was fighting in the heart of the Ossetia Mountains and on the southern slopes of the main Caucasian range. The task was to reach the Georgian military highway, a free way for the Red Army advancing southward across the Caucasus.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The undefeated Boston College Eagles exploded a dazzling aerial attack today to humble the Wake Forest Deacons from North Carolina, 27 -- 0, before a crowd of 20,000 at Fenway Park.

These paintings of old masters are from the magnificent collection recently presented to the National Gallery of Art in Washington by Joseph E. Widener. To the Mellon collection and the Kress collection has been added what David Finley, Director of the National Gallery, has called one that "in scope and quality has rarely been equaled in any period of collecting in Europe or America"

YOU must understand in the first place, Robert P. Tristram Coffin makes plain, that uncle are in a class by themselves. It is not only that they are quite unlike aunts and parents and other relatives. They are set apart -- how gloriously! -- from civilization itself.

To women in rural communities throughout the country has fallen the lot of a the triple threat offensive. In fields planting and harvesting bumper crops, in kitchens canning and drying food stores for the nation's cupboard, and in civilian defense posts guarding their homes, they are hastening the return of their men in uniform.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- Australian troops in New Guinea, supported by American bombers, were reported today to have advanced over the mountain-track hump close to the Japanese base at Kokoda.

Wherever one may journey in this country to see, at first hand, the amazing spectacle of aircraft production, he will find the same basic problem bringing anxiety to the key men of the industry. This is the problem of adequate materials. A near-miracle has been performed by these men, their colleagues in other contributing industries and their suppliers.

Jose de Aguirre, president of the Basque Republic until Generalissimo Francisco Franco's forces conquered that territory, declared yesterday that the United States must adopt a stiffer attitude toward Petain and Franco if it wishes to win the support of the common people in South America.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 (AP) -- State tax revenue in the first quarter of the fiscal year dropped nearly $7,000,000 from the same period of 1941, with losses in gasoline levies and motor vehicle fees mainly responsible. These and other revenue, however, the State Tax Commission said today, in most instances were running "in accordance with" Governor Lehman's 1942-43 budget estimates.

PROFESSOR NEUMANN'S book is a cautious and comprehensive study of "the total state in a world at war." The nature and origins of Leviathan, threatening to remove the last vestiges of democratic society from the earth, have now been discussed by a very great many reporters, biographers and specialists in the social sciences.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- German setbacks at Stalingrad and their failure to take Leningrad before Winter have aroused widespread disappointment and grumbling in Finland, reports from Helsinki said today.
CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Paced by Jim Secrest, who made all the touchdowns, Rochester University toppled Hamilton from the ranks of the unbeaten today. The score was 33 -- 0.

J. Clarence Chambers Jr., in THE TIMES Radio Section of Oct. 18, asks skeptically for the name of "a single commercial program on any major network in which a Negro has ever been accorded the courtesy title of 'Mr.' . . . or has lever been represented in a drama except in the role of a servant, or an ignorant or comical person.

The $6,000,000 United States destroyer Daly, named after Sergeant Major Daniel Daly of the Marine Corps, who served with distinction during the Boxer Rebellion and was credited with originating the exhortation "Come on you - - - -, do you want to live forever?" in the First World War, was launched at high water yesterday at the Bethlehem Steel and Ship Building Company's yard, Mariners Harbor, S.I., as part of the Navy Day celebration.

As a result of extensive experience in a number of war plants, Dr. George K. Bennett and Richard A. Fear, members of the staff of the Psychological Corporation, have developed tests to determine industrial intelligence, mechanical comprehension, manipulative ability, all for the purpose of simplifying and standardizing the task of personnel managers who have to hire men and women for war work.

During 1942 the electrical manufacturing industry will have produced an estimated $5,000,000,000 worth of products, George C. Thomas Jr., president of the Thomas Betts Company, Elizabeth, N.J., and president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, reported yesterday.

German torpedo planes sent two medium-sized United States merchant ships to the bottom of the North Atlantic in an attack on a convoy bound for Russia about mid-September, the Navy Department announced yesterday. One of the vessels sank within two minutes with the loss of twenty-two members of her crew.

Construction will begin Wednesday on a government-financed detinning plant in Long Island City, Queens, which, with five similar plants and nineteen shredding plants to be built in various parts of the country, will increase the nation's recovery of critically needed tin from used cans by 65 per cent within seven months and double it within a year.

If parents pick on children about their food, aren't we all picked on about food? For the last hundred years our betters have scolded, now about our table manners, now about our eating too much or too fast: diet fads have gone through the American family like a prairie fire.

The vanguard of fuel oil dealers appeared yesterday at offices of the fourteen local War Price and Rationing Boards to obtain application forms OPA-R-1100 for fuel oil rationing to distribute to their customers this week. The dealers will register on Tuesday and Wednesday, send out the forms to their customers, and the customers will file their application in the first week of November.

ON a leave of absence from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Herbert Kline, documentary film producer, now is in Mexico making a feature-length drama dealing with Nazi oppression of the people of conquered Europe.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- President Bancroft Beatley of Simmons College today called upon the government to define its policy with regard to women in the war effort and thus put an end to uncertainties now plaguing students and colleges alike throughout the country.

A GLANCE at the records of the American Play Company re "The Moon and Sixpence" reveals that much of the American circulation of the widely discussed W. Somerset Maugham novel undoubtedly can be attributed to the many times it has shuttled back and forth in the mails to the Hollywood studios.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Long-range naval patrol planes that are considered ideally suited for searches at sea have joined in the hunt for the United States Army plane in which Captain E.V. Rickenbacker was a passenger, the Navy Department announced today.

The American Foundation for the Blind announced yesterday at its headquarters, 15 West Sixteenth Street, the award of ten new scholarships and seven renewals to sightless students throughout the country. They amount in all to $4,060. One resident of New York State, David C. Williams of Rochester, is on the list as a renewal.

PROFESSOR Harold Burris-Meyer of the Stevens Institute of Technology, who has made an extensive study of the use of music in industry, suggests that American composers should seriously consider writing works to be performed in factories while men and women are at work.

WHEN the still dazzling madcap who had been born Constance Scott sent her granddaughter from France to the old homestead in Pittsburgh. after the girl's father had fallen at Ypres, Paul Scott had an inspiration -- he took his hitherto misfit great-niece to see the Scott steel mills.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt today devoted a brief interval to an extremely crowded day appeasing the friendly curiosity of the British people about her at a mass interview and spent the rest of the time studying them and their problems of civil defense and rationing, which the United States is just beginning to tackle.

IF there is much doubt that Harry James possesses one of the more popular orchestras of the moment, it should be dispelled by the record of his present activities. He is a regular feature on the "Spotlight Bands" program over the Blue network (WJZ) and supervises a thrice-nightly weekly show over Columbia (WABC).
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Prices of livestock steadied today after a week of divergent trends, with hogs declining following announcement of new ceilings for wholesale pork.

The official flag of the Fighting French Forces was presented yesterday to Captain Alex de Manziarly, head of the volunteer bureau of the military mission of the Fighting French delegation in New York, by Mrs. Stehlin Cochery and Mme. Lacine Broutarge, representing the French American Club, at the latter's headquarters, Holland House, Rockefeller Plaza.

Winning his race by 200 yards, John Emmerling of New Dorp retained the Richmond cross-country title yesterday in the P.S.A.L. borough championships over the 2 1/4-mile Van Cortlandt Park trail. Emmerling the only defending champion on hand, experienced little trouble leading the field, but his team placed second to Curtis.
The first six-year high school plan under the New York City educational system will go into effect in February with the reorganization of the Hunter College high and elementary Schools.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, declared yesterday afternoon that women voters throughout the State were turning to the Republican party this year because they realized that the election of the Republican State ticket would "step up" the State's participation in the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Smithsonian Institution gave full credit today to the Wright brothers as the true pioneers in airplane invention, as freely as for twenty-eight years it firmly withheld this credit in favor of Samuel P. Langley.

IT is a pleasant thought that mothers who read Miss White's books when they were little girls may now read her latest one to their own children, finding it as fresh and delightful, as inventive in incident and as shrewd in its understanding of human nature, as the early stories written many years ago.
BASTROP, Texas, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A general court martial at Camp Swift today sentenced Private George S. Knapp, 38, to hang for the murder of 38-year-old Lucy Rivers Maynard.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- American women were urged today to give all their compacts, except one, to the scrap metal drive, and to check up on their cosmetic containers for other salvage items.

THE New Friends of Music, which opens its seventh season this afternoon in Town Hall, has dedicated its concerts for the year to the late Emanuel Feuermann, the eminent 'cellist. In announcing the dedication I.A. Hirschmann, the organization's founder, made the following statement: "This supremely gifted artist and man was one of the first to appear in the New Friends of Music concerts, and participated in its programs each year since its inception in 1936.

The report of the Worthington Pump Machinery Corporation, which makes and sells various types of mechanical equipment, for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 shows a net profit of $2,018,687, after a provision of $8,285,197 for Federal income and excess profits taxes, based on an 80 per cent rate.

In choosing trees and shrubs for Fall planting the gardener does well at this time to study some of the graceful "feathery" subjects that lend such an airy charm to plantings. These plants are equally fine when used as a supplement to evergreen borders or as foliage specimens.

Due to the sharp increase in litigation involving educational problems during the last three years, a new division in the New York City Corporation Counsel's office has been established to deal exclusively with such cases.

MORE than a hundred years of New York is to be glimpsed in the big current group exhibition at the American British Art Center. Some of the pictures have been seen before; many of them have not. Beginning with the remarkable "Opening of the Erie Canal," by Imbert, the assembled pictures include paintings and prints of the last century, but the majority of the work shown has been drawn from the period since 1900.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 24 -- Governor Tugwell called today a special legislative session for Monday to deal with war emergency problems. In his message he said the insular government must do what it could for itself before asking Federal aid, and stressed the willingness of the WPA regional administrator, Paul Edwards, to increase employment provided the Puerto Rican Government would step up its effort.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, who has put a lot of life into the stiff and formal institution of First Lady, has broken another tradition by flying to Great Britain to visit Queen Elizabeth, inspect American Army and Navy camps there, visit her three "adopted" children, and generally survey war conditions.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 24 -- The undefeated Williams College eleven scored its fifth victory of the season today, routing Tufts, 47 -- 6, on Weston Field.

We are accustomed to think of the Russian front as the longest battleline in the world. It is not. Our own battleline in the Pacific is more than three times as long. True, most of it is water, but every water lane between the points we hold is an avenue of defense or attack.
LONDON, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- Axis fears of an Allied attack on West Africa, in coordination with the offensive in Egypt, were apparent today from the broadcasts of the Berlin, Paris and Vichy radios.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Just back from a raid on Japanese-held Rabaul Harbor, New Britain, in which ten enemy ships were sunk or damaged, enthusiastic United States airmen reported today that concentrated Japanese vessels had made excellent targets for their bombs.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- Louisiana State pointed its big guns skyward and blasted the star-studded Georgia Naval Pre-Flight footballers, previously undefeated, 34 to 0, tonight before 15,000 fans.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Tennessee crushed Furman at football today, 52 to 7, before 5,000 fans.

As "beat-the-tax" buyers gave fresh impetus to the rush for liquor yesterday, retailers reported that blends and gin were running out in some localities, that some distillers were rationing supplies, that the Christmas buyer apparently was joining the rush, and that soldiers and sailors in uniform had not wavered from their traditional habit of buying not more than a pint.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Roosevelt High School of Yonkers scored a 13-6 upset victory today to deprive Mamaroneck High of a share in the W.I.A.A. lead. As a result, Portchester went in front with its late rally against Davis.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- The automotive industry's cooperative effort on the war production front was two years old today with one-time passenger-car builders busy pouring out armaments at the rate of $17,000,000 daily, or $6,000,000,000 annually.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 24 -- Economic Coordinator Joao Alberto Lins Barros, whose office combines the powers given in the United States to Price Administrator Leon Henderson and War Production Board Chairman Donald M. Nelson, tersely told meat exporters today that, unless provision were made to supply meat for the Rio de Janeiro population, he would suspend the slaughtering of cattle for export.

Dakar, Vichy's strategic outpost on the bulge of West Africa, has again become an uneasy spot in the global war. Axis propagandists assert that an Anglo-American assault is in the making on a more powerful scale than the abortive attempt by the British and Free French to take the key port in 1940.

THE time has come for an up-to-date report on the activities of Armed Forces Master Records, Inc., the organization which has dedicated itself to the job of raising libraries of masterwork recordings for the men in service.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Joe Muha, Virginia M.I.'s candidate for all-America honors, put on an effective show today as the cadets defeated the University of Richmond football team, 20 to 6, before 7,000 spectators in City Stadium.

Retail trade here made a better comparative showing last week, with increased volume in seasonal apparel and accessories swelling volume. Department store volume was estimated as showing an increase of 10 to 15 per cent over the 1941 week.
FREDERICK STOCK, who met his sudden end last Tuesday, was a builder from the ground up, a humanitarian, and one of the greatest forces of his period in American musical development.

MANY people, including this reviewer, have long believed, firmly, that Angela du Maurier would, one day, produce a major romantic novel. Here it is; a story that more than fulfills the most sanguine of expectations; a romantic tragedy based on a fundamental, tragic conception, deriving nothing from coincidence or temporal circumstances and attributable, in no way, to the sins or faults of those involved in the drama.

WITH U.S. MARINES ON GUADALCANAL, Oct. 15 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Japanese have landed 11,000 reinforcements on Guadalcanal and are subjecting United States positions to a prolonged bombardment by land, sea and air.

ABOARD THE TEXAS ZEPHYR -- Linking busy Army camps in Colorado with the booming war plants of Fort Worth and Dallas, this speedy Burlington streamliner is performing an important wartime service in making the 835-mile run daily in 18 1/2 hours, the fastest schedule ever set between Denver and Dallas.

The suggestion that World War II be named the "War of Spirit," as it was described in the speech of Prime Minister Jan Smuts of South Africa Wednesday in London, was made in a sermon yesterday by Rabbi Hyman J. Schachtel in West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street.

Undismayed by President Roosevelt's all-out endorsement of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, leaders of the American Labor party planned yesterday an intensive last-week campaign for Dean Alfange, their candidate for Governor.

"DOODLE DANDY OF THE U.S.A.," that children's program based on the Four Freedoms, may well return to town and a Broadway theatre for a run starting the night before Christmas and going through January.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- A new service for visitors, designed to facilitate the trips which friends and relatives make to see men stationed at the rapidly growing Army posts near by, will be put into effect by city officials this week with the inauguration of a clearing house for advice on hotels and other information at the Boardwalk offices of the Municipal Information Bureau.

TORONTO, Oct. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Toronto Globe and Mail said in a dispatch from Ottawa today that United States allocation authorities have revised downward the heavy cut made in steel exports to Canada Oct. 1 and "with this help and severe domestic control Canadian war plants will be able to scrape by the critical steel shortage."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Paced by Captain Frank Gnup and Berney Bernatowitz, the Fort Monmouth eleven got back into the victory column today with a 13-2 triumph over the Army plebes before 1,000 in Michie Stadium.

ARMY-NAVY: For years one of the nation's most colorful Fall spectacles was the annual Army-Navy football game. It was usually played in or near a large population center -- Philadelphia in most years, but also in New York, Baltimore, Chicago and Princeton, N.J. -- and was seen by as many as 110,000 persons.

The Brooklyn's Museum's recent scrapping of two dozen Japanese swords, scabbards and decorative hand guards for steel salvage was protested last night by the Municipal Art Society as an "impassioned" act destructive of part of the general cultural inheritance of the world.

Brooklyn College's T formation operated effectively for a 38-to-0 victory over the New York Aggies at the Brooklyn College Field yesterday. The triumph was the first in ten starts for the Kingsmen over a two-year period.

In the Western Ocean the Iceland gales are roaring out of the north and the destroyers shudder and ship it green as the convoy staggers home. In the Western Ocean the subs are hunting and men are dying as the torpedoes burst in sudden flame. . . .

Debutantes and their escorts, many in the armed forces, will not be deprived of their dances because of the war. Although many of this year's girls, those who made their debuts a season or two ago and young matrons are engaged in war work of various kinds, there will be many parties, subscription dances and other charity fetes for their enjoyment.

This city is prepared to handle with thoroughness and dispatch any emergency needs of its population resulting from a surprise bombing, William Hodson, Welfare Commissioner, declared yesterday in outlining a civilian assistance plan devised by his department to meet such an exigency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- American soldiers and sailors in Northern Ireland are advised not to argue religion or politics. In a new pocket guide issued jointly by the War and Navy Departments, the further suggestion is advanced that Americans "lean over backward to make friends with the guy who talks differently, thinks differently, but fights the same war."

The Navy took over on Fifth Avenue between Eighty-seventh and Sixty-second Streets for nearly two hours yesterday and a throng estimated by the police at 300,000 obviously had a fine time watching and cheering the 10,000 marchers.

LONDON (By Air Mail) -- We were on one of the usual offensive sweeps -- a daylight raid on some works near Lille. During a widespread dogfight over the target I chased a 109 down several thousand feet, but lost him in cloud. Pulling up to regain my height, I found the sky completely empty.
ASIDE from the ceremony at Buckingham Palace that made movie star Merle Oberon Her Happy Ladyship the big event of the month was the launching of Noel Coward's naval film, "In Which We Serve."
THE Philadelphia Eagles are scheduled to play the Great Big Bears in Chicago this afternoon. Really, now, should that be allowed to go on?

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- The fightin'est Yale team that has gone to the football wars in years perpetrated mayhem upon strongly favored Dartmouth this Indian Summer afternoon to register its first major victory since the Blue beat the Green in 1940.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Fewer than 2 per cent of the 5,500,000 men in the armed services will cast their ballots in the Nov. 3 election, according to a country-wide survey.

After two rounds of the first national amateur championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Manhattan Chess Club last night, the leaders, with two straight to their credit, were Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Manhattan and Marcy Hanft of Brooklyn in Section A; Mandel Epstein and Sven Almgren, both of Brooklyn, in Group B, and Robert Langfelder and Donald Sibbett, both of Brooklyn, in Group E.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Quarterback Emery Nix, 175-pound football dynamo, passed for two touchdowns and scored one himself today to lead the unbeaten, untied Texas Christian Horned Frogs to a 21-to-0 victory over the Pensacola Naval Air Station before a crowd of 5,000.

AT the Founder's Day concert, to be given Friday night in the Library of Congress to honor the birthday of Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, the Coolidge Quartet, assisted by Johana Harris, piano, will present a program comprising a new sonata for violin and piano, written specially for the occasion by Roy Harris; the Second string quartet by Anthony Collins, and Beethoven's quartet, Op. 59, No. 2.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (Science Service) -- Guns naturally suggest butter -- thanks to Herr Goering's classic remark. Easier and more abundant production of butter, even in a gun-dominated age, is promised by a process on which United States Patent No. 2,299,440 was issued this week to Professor Peter A. van der Meulen of Rutgers University, and David Levowitz of New Brunswick, N.J., assignors to the Research Corporation of New York.

During late Winter, when one yearns for a glimpse of the Spring that is "just around the corner," foresighted window gardeners will be enjoying the stimulating effect of brilliant blossoms on their own window sills.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 25 -- A large Japanese seaplane tender was believed destroyed at Rabaul, New Britain, by Allied bombers, the High Command announced today.

He must know a good deal about the construction of plays, about scene-design, about lighting, acting, costuming, make-up.

Visiting nurse service "as usual" to the New York public plus the increasing responsibility of training young nurses for public health work on the home front was the two-fold program outlined yesterday for the year by Miss Katherine Faville, director of the service, for the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Archbold Stadium, a hoodoo to Cornell ever since it was built, continued to jinx the Ithacans today when the Syracuse football team, paced by a 195-pound battering ram, Tommy Maines, triumphed, 12 -- 7, in the presence of 15,000 spectators.

ERICH WOLFGANG KORNGOLD is one composer who never had to struggle for a living. He became famous at the age of 13 when his ballet "The Snow Man" was produced at the Vienna Opera. By the time he was 24 his opera "The Dead City" had been performed in many cities in Europe and introduced Maria Jeritza to this country at the Metropolitan.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- The O'Connell organization, which Thomas E. Dewey has used as "whipping boy" in the 1938 and 1942 campaigns, will be "all out" to defeat him on Election Day. Attorney General Bennett was not the first choice of the O'Connell clan as the Democratic candidate, but since the Brooklyn convention there has not been the slightest doubt that the local organization would give its full support to the Democratic ticket.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 24 -- Dr. Otto Dietrich, the Reich's press chief, is the latest Nazi party light to be called in to help explain to the German people that all they have to do now to win the war is to hang on, "for time and space henceforth work for Germany."

The Marine Section of the Thirty-first National Safety Congress will open Tuesday afternoon at the Sherman Hotel in Chicago, where maritime safety measures and problems will be discussed by an imposing list of experts.

Operators of commercial motor vehicles in the metropolitan area who fail to return within ten days of receipt properly filled out applications for certificates of war necessity may not be able to conduct their business after Nov. 15, William J. Clark, regional manager, ODT Division of Motor Transport, warned yesterday.

No one, with the possible exception of the public relations department of the Fred Harvey Restaurants, will be inclined to take it very seriously.

WHEN Lawrence Tibbett was a student at Manual Arts High School in Los Angeles twenty-five years ago -- a tall, shy boy eager to overcome the effects of a frail childhood -- his campus hero was a young man his own age named Jimmy Doolittle.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 24 (AP) -- North Carolina's unbeaten record joined the football scrap heap today as Tulane's Green Wave followed blond Lou Thomas to a 29 -- 14 victory over the previously unbeaten Tar Heels before 22,000 spectators.
