PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- The dam of Pennsylvania's pent-up scoring power burst before 45,000 awed fans in Franklin Field today as Columbia was engulfed, 42 to 12. And at that the Quakers had a pair of long touchdown gallops called back because of penalties.

THE answer to every important question in politics is a compromise. Is humor a handicap in American political life? Yes and no. But that is a contradiction! Then the compromise, a la politics, would be this: humor is a political handicap if paraded publicly; it is an asset if indulged privately.

EVERY historian or biographer appears to have his own particular Elizabeth Tudor, for the portraits of her run the gamut from the blackest villainy to that effulgent Gloriana who was the bright star of the complex period that is known by her name.

AT AN ADVANCED STRIKING BASE OF THE ALLIED AIR FORCES IN WESTERN DESERT, Egypt, Oct. 24 (AP) -- United Nations airmen, letting go with everything they had when the British Eighth Army struck with their offensive against the Axis desert army, seem to have gained the upper hand quickly in the first phase of the fighting.

Failure by the OPA to grant exemption sought from Regulation No. 127 by several converters of cotton dress fabrics will adversely affect post-war markets for American cotton, according to the National Cotton Council.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 24 -- The St. John's prep eleven of Brooklyn dropped its second game of the season to a Nassau team when it bowed, 19 -- 6, to Mineola High's Maroons today.

Evander Childs rolled up its fourth victory and remained undefeated by crushing the DeWitt Clinton eleven, 27 -- 0, yesterday in the second game of a schoolboy twin bill at Randalls Island. Theodore Roosevelt rode roughshod over Stuyvesant, 28 -- 0, in the opener.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Elmer (Tippy) Madarik directed a 62-yard advance in the second period and tossed a 19-yard touchdown pass to Arthur Link to give the undefeated University of Detroit football team a 6 to 0 victory over Georgetown tonight before 20,307 spectators.

The Province of Honan, in China, south of the Yellow River, has a population about equal to that of Mexico, about six times that of Denmark or Finland, about half again as large as Hungary, nearly three times that of the City of New York. In short, it has about 20,000,000 people.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- Steel mills in the Great Lakes area have been shattering an old theory for months. Until war demands disrupted schedules, it was general in the steel industry to consider that about 10 per cent of the blast-furnace capacity must be shut down continually for relinings and repairs, or that repairs prevented the industry's furnaces from operating at any one time above 90 per cent of theoretical capacity.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

SEATTLE, Oct. 24 (AP) -- California's thrice beaten Bears lived up to pre-season predictions for the first time today to knock Washington's football eleven out of the undefeated class, 19 to 6, with a dazzling display of running and passing before a homecoming crowd of 31,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Little interest is being taken in the grain markets pending further developments in regard to the application of price-control measures and the ultimate effect of price ceilings announced recently, brokers said today in explaining the lack of outside speculation in wheat.

According to reports received from Havana last week, David Joffo's recent presentation of imperforate sheets of Cuba's 1942 "For Democracy" series to President Roosevelt has created within Cuban philatelic ranks a demand for an official inquiry into the circumstances attending the printing of the stamps in imperforate condition.

Only a few months after Germans had ceased the systematic bombing of one British town after another the English began to discuss rebuilding. Populations had been uprooted, industries had been shifted. There could be no return to the old Britain, with its haphazard, speculative building, its slums, its spreading seashore bungalow colonies, its ribbonlike roads.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Almost everywhere an American in Britain goes these days he encounters signs of anxiety about this country's relations with her allies. The British people everywhere are painfully conscious that as a nation they are disliked and distrusted by large numbers of Russians and Americans who are fighting the same war, and the knowledge disquiets and puzzles them.

THERE are manifestly some difficulties in describing fully a tract of land 801 miles long, 773 miles wide, with several sets of climates, and inhabited by six and a half million people. This is Texas, which entered the Union in 1845 with the reservation that she could split herself in five States if she wished to, but hasn't wished to.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of the Allied air forces in the Southwest Pacific, awarded fifty-four decorations to thirty-five officers and men during a visit to an advanced operational base, it was disclosed today.

THE civilized world observes next Wednesday the beginning of an epic of tragic heroism. On Oct. 28, 1940, a hitherto undefeated Italian army crossed the frontier of occupied Albania and invaded Greece. For more than five months the small but well-trained forces of the tiny Greek nation not only withstood the tanks, aircraft and seasoned infantry of Mussolini but pushed them steadily back, far behind their starting point.

The problem of drafting university students seems to have been satisfactorily adjusted in England, Alex D. Lindsay, master of Balliol College, Oxford, declared last night when he arrived at La Guardia Field. Thirty-two passengers arrived in two transatlantic flying aces that docked within an hour of each other.
CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Lakehurst Naval Air Station eleven shoved over two second-half touchdowns today to beat Penn Military College, 20 to 7.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Port Chester kept its record unblemished and took the Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association football lead by halting previously unbeaten A.B. Davis High of Mount Vernon, 14 to 13, at Howard Field today.

Many apparently conflicting -- and definitely confusing -- reports have been published recently relative to the meat supply situation. Inasmuch as some of these reports have been based on comment by persons in a position to speak authoritatively, it is natural that the public is somewhat confused and that housewives may fear a "meat shortage" with far less reason than is justified by the facts.

Two performances of Thornton Wilder's new comedy "The Skin of Our Teeth," with Tallulah Bank-head. Fredric March, Florence Eldridge and Florence Reed in the leading roles, at the Plymouth Theatre, have been taken over to raise funds for philanthropic organizations in the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- About 700 of the country's physicians urged the Supreme Court today to declare unconstitutional Connecticut legislation which prohibits doctors from prescribing contraceptive devices for married women when necessary to preserve life or health.

HERE is a further record of Mr. Churchill's dynamic utterances during the war. Some run to many pages, others are brief announcements or messages of greeting, but, taken as a whole and with an italicized diary of events to help the sequence, they are easy reading and reveal, not merely the emergency but the man of many gifts on whom the emergency thrust ultimate obligations of greatness.

The report of the House Select Committee Investigating National Defense Migration, headed by Representative Tolan, is on the whole an encouraging one. Many of its criticisms of the existing war organization are clearly warranted. When it talks of the "competition" and "jockeying" among present war agencies, and of the "conflicts in orders and demands" emanating from them, it merely retells a story that is too familiar.

A sixty-yard run by Larry Isaacs in the third quarter gave Susquehanna its only touchdown in its clash with City College at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The score proved sufficient to bring victory, however, for the Beavers, who have yet to score a point this season, extended their unenviable record and went down to defeat. 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The War Labor Board, seeking to provide quick action on voluntary employer-employe wage agreements, is setting up machinery to handle 10,000 cases a week by using the income tax return method of accepting statements at face value with penalties for untruths.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Prices Board today ordered that Siberian seal, Belgian beaver, Baltic tiger and French leopard -- exotic trade names created by fur fashion stylists -- are henceforth to emerge as plain dyed rabbit.

The price of fluid milk, as paid to dairy farmers, will move to a new record high Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday by Charles J. Blanford, Federal-State administrator of the metropolitan New York milk market. The November price will be $3.50 a hundredweight (forty-six and a half quarts) to producers of Class I, or so-called "fluid," milk.

The excellent suggestion by Vice President Wallace in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Oct. 11 to celebrate Columbus Day throughout the Americas as the "Day of the New World" deserves general support. The present world crisis should not deter us in our working day and night for what Vice President Wallace calls the "New World ideal of international peace based on real friendship and understanding."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (Copyright, 1942, by Science Service) -- The United States Public Health Service is preparing to go to the extreme limits of its authority in all-out war on venereal disease which threatens to sabotage our war effort by its inroads among the armed forces and the army of war industry workers.

In a radio address to the nation two weeks ago tomorrow President Roosevelt advocated drafting young men from 18 to 21 years of age into the armed forces as an essential measure to speed victory. In the week that followed his speech the House of Representatives adopted a measure lowering the draft age from 21 to 18 years.
THE radio page of last Sunday's TIMES contains a letter from Mr. Sillerman, president of Keystone Broadcasting System, regarding network coverage.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 -- A new priorities office that will be part of the economic section of the American Embassy has been created and will begin to operate Jan. 1, 1943, official American circles said today.

THE opening of the New Opera Company a week from Tuesday marks an early start of the gala Winter season. Music, theatre, entertainment and gayety give the needed respite for war-frayed nerves. Beautifully gowned women add glamour to dimmed-out nights.

ABOARD A BRITISH TORPEDO BOAT, in the Mediterranean, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- American-made light craft of the British Mediterranean Fleet shot up Axis positions along the coast near Matruh last night. The vessels surprised the enemy 100 miles behind the Alamein line, fought off numerous air attacks and carried out an extensive raid.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that printing of the nation's new "all-purpose" general ration book will begin in a few days, and that copies will be in the hands of every one around the first of the year, if the planned printing schedules are maintained.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

Necessity -- or her step-sister, Priority -- is the mother of a score of inventions in the cosmetic world. Faced with shortages and restrictions on every side, manufacturers of feminine furbelows have gone into a huddle and emerged with a brand new wartime wardrobe for their products.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique issued early today:

The State Liquor Authority has been an "enlightened force" in this State, Dean Alfange, candidate for Governor on the American Labor party ticket, declared yesterday. Asserting that the SLA under the chairmanship of Commissioner Henry E. Bruckman has administered the law "fairly and justly," Mr. Alfange pledged his support to the continuance of the present system of liquor control here.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 24 -- Minnesota's Golden Gophers, twice beaten this year, started back toward the gridiron pinnacle they held as national champions the last two years by defeating favored Michigan today, 16 to 14, for their first Western Conference victory of the season.

Eric Underwood justly points out that old England used the poetic Fall instead of Autumn, discarded it and left us to preserve it. To complete the story it should be added that Fall supplanted a still older name of the season, which was Harvest, without denoting, except by implication, the gathering of crops.

THE troops fighting the Japanese in New Guinea have learned to listen for the chant. The chant is a strange business. It starts well to the rear of the most forward Jap positions. And it starts with a single high-pitched penetrating voice. That voice speaks commandingly for a few moments, then ceases abruptly, and another voice, farther forward, takes up the chant.

The insatiable demand of the war-production giant has placed a burden on the country's waste material dealers such as they have never experienced before. And accompanying it has been a spotlight that has brought into clear relief the operations of these little-known conservers of the nation's cast-off products and materials.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 -- Three thousand "extra" tires, turned in by motorists, were jumbled together in a hopeless tangle here today in a government warehouse.

AMERICANS and Britons, toiling fighting and dying together, must cooperate more closely than two democracies have ever cooperated before. This does not necessarily mean that they must like each other. History has its numerous instances of nations acting as effective allies while indifferent or chilly in their mutual regard.

The honeymoon of Gypsy Rose Lee and Biff Brannigan starts in San Diego and we are permitted to follow it as far as Ysleta, Texas. The newlyweds are traveling in a trailer accompanied by Gypsy's mother, Evangie. Odd, isn't it ?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Men and women with experience in the field of education are being recruited for service both at home and overseas by the American Red Cross, according to J. Blaine Gwin, national director of personnel for the Red Cross.

THE Eastman School of Music of the University of Rochester will present its annual symposium of American orchestral music from Tuesday through Friday in Rochester, N.Y. The symposium will consist of five concerts devoted to works by contemporary composers, which will be performed by the Eastman-Rochester Symphony Orchestra, under Dr. Howard Hanson.

CINCINNATI, Oct 24 (AP) -- The University of Georgia's speedy Bulldogs stunned the hitherto unbeaten Cincinnati Bearcats with three quick touchdowns in the first period today, then toyed along for their sixth straight victory, 35 -- 13, before a homecoming crowd of 15,000.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Washington State virtually ousted the defending champion Oregon State from the Pacific Coast Conference football race today by winning, 26 to 13.

TO say that "Look to the Mountain" is a remarkable novel is specifically true. It is not exactly news. LeGrand Cannon has written two novels before this -- "A Mighty Fortress" and "The Kents" -- which many readers accounted remarkable. Thus, since he has been pretty thoroughly discovered already, one cannot very well shout the discovery all over again.

IN his two earlier novels, "The Sea of Grass" and "The Trees," Conrad Richter has made a solid contribution to the long shelf of Americana; in "Tacey Cromwell" he goes back into the Arizona Territory a half century ago, to find a protagonist in the hennaed sporting-house madam who gives the book its name.

TWENTY-ONE operas are included in the repertoire of the Chicago Opera Company for its thirty-second season which opens Nov. 7, at the Chicago Civic Opera House. Among the works listed for performance is Moniuszko's "Halka," the first Polish opera to be offered by the organization.

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Subsidies for small storekeepers and factories to enable them to pay their rents for the duration were proposed here today by Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor.

If the nation had lost sight of the fact that there is a battle to be won on the financial front as well as on combat fronts, it was reminded of it forcibly at the close of last week by the disclosure that the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System, operating through the Federal Open Market Committee, had had to purchase the unprecedented total of $415,492,000 of government securities in a single week.

THE shortage of labor in Hollywood this week resulted in the shutdown for an indefinite period of Leon Schlesinger Productions, Inc., which makes fifty-two cartoons a year for release by Warner Brothers, including twenty-six Looney Tune shorts and twenty-six Metric Melodies shorts.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The crash of a giant airliner on Chino Ridge of rugged Mount San Jacinto yesterday carrying twelve persons to their deaths resulted, a Western Defense Command announcement said today, from a collision between an Army plane and the airliner.

Apropos of beards, your editorial "The Wartime Beard Crop" fails to clear up that which, for me, has been a source of unsatfied curiosity for many years. I refer to the basis for the Spanish proverb, "If you see your neighbor's beard being shaved, put your own in soak," meaning, soften it up, as your turn will be next.

When the war is over the United States merchant marine will be in a position of "world predominance" and there is no reason why it should not be insured in the American insurance market instead of abroad, Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, vice chairman of the Maritime Commission and Deputy War Shipping Administrator, declared last week.

The necessity for early shipment of Christmas gifts to men serving in the armed forces abroad has inspired committees of three organizations here to arrange special fetes for the near future to expedite the collection and dispersal of the Yuletide presents.
WASHINGTON, Pa., Oct. 24 -- Gene Weimer and Bud McMahon each made two touchdown passes as Washington and Jefferson defeated Hobart by 25 -- 0 today in the annual Homecoming Day contest.

German infantry and armored formations again attacked inside Stalingrad on Friday and in fierce house-to-house fighting "threw the enemy out of various streets," the German High Command said yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

LADIES who listen to soap-operas can take heart this morning because an expert has just come up with some data to prove that they are not per se the psychoanalyst's despair. The expert in question is Dr. Paul Lazarsfeld, director of Columbia University's Office of Radio Research, and the following conclusions are based on studies made under the general supervision of Dr. Herta Herzog:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 24 -- The new Chilean Foreign Minister, Joaquin Fernandez y Fernandez, arrived here tonight from Montevideo, Uruguay, en route to Santiago, Chile, toward which he will continue his journey early tomorrow morning by air.

Savages are not so squeamish about eating insects as we are. Indians of our western plains will dine on grasshoppers and crickets when nothing better is available, Bushmen look upon termite eggs as we do on caviar, and native of the West Indies find the white grubs in the pith of palm trees as palatable as chestnuts.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Pocono Mountains resorts are preparing to observe Halloween in traditional fashion. The Skytop Club will hold its annual Autumn reunion of members and their friends next week-end. Features of this house party will be a dinner dance on Saturday night for which the Windsor Room will be decorated, followed by Halloween games and other entertainment.

Dull trading resulting in irregular gains marked operations on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Sales totaled 290,180 shares, against 245,250 shares in the preceding week-end market, and of 580 issues traded, 239 rose, 157 fell and 184 were unchanged.

As Boysy hammered his way to a neck victory yesterday, virtually all Empire City wagering records went into the discard, with $1,661,293 clicking briskly through the tote on a crisp Fall afternoon. Of this the public retained $1,485,605.40.

Antiques are now enjoying a renaissance in popularity. Shortages, it seems, will limit more and more the manufacture of many types of household furnishings, and forehanded home-makers are now making it their business to become familiar with what is available in the antique field.

Narrow price fluctuations prevailed again yesterday in the cotton futures markets as two-sided activity by mills prevented decisive movement. At the close of the short session on the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts were only 1 to 2 points under Friday's final quotations.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 24 -- Ohio State's dream of a football empire blazed brighter than ever today as the undefeated, untied Buckeyes conquered Northwestern, 20 to 6, to achieve their fifth straight victory of the season.

EVERY six weeks or so the United States Patent Office issues a patent for some new electronic device to Dr. Ernst Fredrik Werner Alexanderson, whose inventions have served radio's development as have those of few others. An Alexanderson idea made possible in October, 1918 -- just twenty-four years ago -- President's Wilson's ultimatum to Germany by high-power radio.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee today summoned the heads of the Administration's economic stabilization program to answer on Monday complaints that laws to protect farm prices were being ignored.

AT the siege of a Polish fortress in 1613, a Scotchman, George Learmont by name, was captured by the Russians. He settled in the country after his release and became the ancestor of the poet and novelist Mikhail Yurevich Lermontov, who was born in 1814.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 24 -- The passing ability of Eddie Prokop and the speed of Georgia Tech's backs paced the unbeaten Yellow Jackets to a 21-to-0 victory today over the Naval Academy football team, which was able to hold its own when it came to power plays.

Max Schmeling, former work heavyweight boxing champion, turned in his continental title to the European Boxing Union yesterday, according to a German broadcast recorded in New York by the Associated Press. The broadcast quoted a dispatch from Rome.
Mrs. John R. Drexel Jr. of Southern Pines. N.C., is at the Plaza.

Capitalizing on a break in the fourth quarter, John Adams High drove 22 yards to a touchdown to gain a 6-all tie with its Queens rival, Flushing, at Memorial Field, Flushing, yesterday. A crowd of 4,000 saw the eleventh annual battle between the schools.

The third part of the collection of the late Colonel E.H.R. Green brought $22,350, or about 20 per cent more than the appraised value, when publicly sold by Daniel F. Kelleher in Boston on Oct. 17. This brought to approximately $79,370 the total realized at the first three auctions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A naval expedition into the Gilbert Islands and the Ellice Islands lying northwest of the Solomons and southwest of Hawaii, in Japanese-controlled waters, struck four small Japanese ships, but found no large force, the Navy Department reported today.
HONOLULU, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Major Gen. Clarence L. Tinker died in a long-range, overwater night bombing attack against the enemy last June 6.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Carnegie Tech scored its third victory of the football season today, displaying a diversified attack to turn back the University of Buffalo, 27 -- 14, before a Homecoming Day crowd of 4,672.

With main floors and basement departments active, retail trade was good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 24 -- While for the third night in succession an air alarm was sounded in various parts of Switzerland, including Berne, as "unidentified" airplanes flew over the country, complementary reports were received here of the damage done in Italy by British Royal Air Force raids.

With the winner still left in the race for the Eastern championship of the National Football League and the loser virtually eliminated as a title possibility, the Giants, the defending champions, will clash with-the-Dodgers at Ebbets Field at 2:30 P.M. today.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 24 -- Paced by the sparkling performance of Stan Szymakowski, Lehigh broke the jinx in the long series with Rutgers today and turned in a 28-10 victory over its traditional foe. More than 6,000 fans witnessed the Engineers' first victory over Rutgers since 1936, when Lehigh triumphed, 19 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Office of War Information announced today that it assumed joint responsibility with the War Department in the maintenance of secrecy concerning details of the Tokyo raid on April 18. OWI said in a statement:
LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 25 -- The Royal Air Force's biggest bombers from Britain are giving Northern Italy a severe pounding by day and night.

WASHINGTON, Oct 24 -- When the Senate on Thursday, acting with courage mixed about evenly with pre-election caution, smote the camel on the nose, that symbol of national prohibition was wounded sorely but not fatally, for it is sure that he will be back trying to get his head under the tent.

Rose Goldblatt, youthful pianist from Montreal, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall The program comprised Saint-Saens's "Caprice on Airs de Ballet from Gluck's 'Alceste'"; Mozart's sonata in C, (K. 330); the Bach-Busoni "Chaconne"; Beethoven's sonata, Op. 109; the Ravel "Sonatine"; Chopin's "Varriations Brilliantes" and a "Suite for Piano" by the Canadian composer, Alexander Brott.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Solomon Islands continued to be the focus of our Pacific strategy this week and the operations there were affecting the course and duration of the war.

HONOLULU, H.I., Oct. 24 -- Announcement of the appointment of Vice Admiral William F. Halsey as Comsopac (Commander in the South Pacific), which puts him in tactical command of the Solomons campaign, will be hailed with delight by the men of the Pacific Fleet.

While persons who annually take off for Florida after the first hard frost will probably do the same this year, there are many others who are considering the Sunshine State for the first time as a likely vacation spot. This army of civilians is going South for different reasons -- to visit relatives in camps, for short furloughs from war jobs and on extended vacations for health's sake.

HONOLULU, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Three days of intensive search by all available Army and Navy sky and sea forces have failed to uncover a trace of Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, American war ace of World War I, and the crew of a big Army plane that disappeared Wednesday.
DEHRA DUN, United Provinces, India, Oct. 20 (Delayed) -- How American timber is being replaced by Indian was shown to newspaper men at the famed Forest Research Institutes here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The controversy concerning the fate of three historic cannons in this city was definitely settled today when representatives of the Army placed them in the custody of John Rosch, former city historian, who had strenuously opposed Mayor Chauncey T.S. Fish in his desire to add them to the scrap pile.

Final plans are now being completed by retailers in many cities and towns throughout the country to develop as much Christmas shopping in November as possible. The triple objectives of reduction in retail delivery mileage, easing of problems inherent in manpower shortages and bringing down inventories in line with the forthcoming WPB inventory limitation order underlie the plans, many of which will be cooperative and community-wide in scope.

It isn't a gift horse really; it is more of a white elephant. By the terms of the last will and testament of Joe Sibley, Johnny Fletcher becomes the guardian of a race horse named Ulysses. Generous provision is made for the upkeep of the horse, but none far the upkeep of Johnny Fletcher, except that when and if Ulysses wins a race the purse is to go to Johnny.
THIS story of the Soviet Union during the two years before Hitler tore up his pact with Stalin and launched his invasion is a work of first-rate importance on a subject of compelling public interest.

SOVIET SCIENCE -- On Nov. 7 and 8 there is to be a congress of American-Soviet friendship at the Hotel New Yorker and Madison Square Garden, New York City. Though the congress is to take the form of a tribute to Soviet Russia for its gallant struggle against the Nazis it has scientific aspects of importance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A decision of a special three-judge Federal court in Wichita, unanimously upholding the constitutionality of the Emergency Price Control Act and Federal wartime regulation of housing rents, was described today by Price Administrator Leon Henderson as "an unqualified victory."
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The State Woman's Christian Temperance Union today re-elected its president, Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin of New York City, and all other officers, with only one contest.

The necessity for the appointment of a Food Administrator, with over-all control of the food industry during the wartime emergency, is now generally conceded in official quarters as the only workable solution to the industry's problems, it was reported in the trade yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Oct. 24 -- Perseverence in an intelligent and active educational campaign will determine "whether we will ultimately succeed in eliminating from America the twin scourges of syphilis and gonorrhea," Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General, declared today in his final address to medical officers of the Army and Navy, and heads of public health service organizations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Stanford's unpredictable Indians upset the Southern California Trojans today, 14 to 6. Some 25,000 fans, in Kezar Stadium prepared to witness another Stanford debacle, were treated to a gridiron surprise.

SOME months back the news columns printed a poem and a short account of its author. It was news because John Magee Jr., who wrote it, was a pilot officer in the R.C.A.F. who had recently been killed in a flying accident at an English field.

Details of the Coast Guard precautionary program against port fires during the war are given in the current service bulletin, issued last week. A fleet of 252 craft, including 101 new vessels of revolutionary design, all carrying modern fire-fighting equipment, are a part of the program.

The necessity for the appointment of a Food Administrator, with over-all control of the food industry during the wartime emergency, is now generally conceded in official quarters as the only workable solution to the industry's problems, it was reported in the trade yesterday.

IN his introduction to "A Treasury of British Humor," which Coward-McCann will publish Nov. 2. Morris Bishop says: "You will grant that most people laugh, and that what they laugh at is humor." That is perhaps as good a definition as any, even though it does not explain why some people laugh at things that fail to bring a smile to the lips of others.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Rice's boys in blue rallied in the closing minutes today to scare the daylights out of Texas, but two touchdowns in the first half stood up and the Longhorns took their second straight Southwest Conference football victory, 12 -- 7.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND FIELD ARMY, LEBANON, Tenn., Oct. 24 -- A Blue attacking force of tanks and infantry with superior masses of other arms including air, all commanded by Major Gen. William H. Simpson, won this week's battle of mid-Tennessee against the Red defense forces under Major Gen. Durward S. Wilson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board is preparing to recommend government control of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad for the duration of the war because of the refusal of the company's president to accept the board's order for settlement of his dispute with the railroad brotherhoods.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army cracked through German General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Alamein line before dawn today, front line dispatches said tonight, after opening the long-expected Allied offensive with the aid at sea of a roaring fleet of new type American-made light warships and American airmen in the thick of the desert battle.

What does a paratrooper think about on his first jump? Only a paratrooper knows, and he usually forgets how he felt as his training progresses. Here, however, are the vivid impressions set down by one young soldier in a letter written to his mother within a few hours after that critical first venture.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 24 -- British and Turkish naval officers who served in opposing navies in the Eastern Mediterranean in the last war are amicably conferring at the Haifa naval base in Northern Palestine during the first official visit to this country of a Turkish staff mission.

"ARMS for the Men of China" is the 1942 clarion call of Chungking radio to the United States. Aside from the two North American transmissions from 15.19 and 9.635 megacycles at 6:30 P.M. and 10 A.M. respectively, the latest short-wave schedule from Chungking includes broadcasts for Asia and the South Seas, Europe, Australia, East Russia, Japan.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Oct. 25 -- The Germans threw two freshly reinforced infantry divisions, eighty tanks and "large" air forces against Russian positions in Stalingrad yesterday, a Soviet communique said today, but after bitter hand-to-hand fighting the Nazis were thrown back with heavy losses.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Most of today's German newspapers continue to accuse the United States and Britain of violating the Geneva convention protecting prisoners of war. They argue that President Roosevelt's statement that the hands of German prisoners were tied after the Dieppe raid was evidence that the German complaint was well founded.

Aside from the two North American transmissions from 15.19 and 9.635 megacycles at 6:30 P.M. and 10 A.M. respectively, the latest short-wave schedule from Chungking includes broadcasts for Asia and the South Seas, Europe, Australia, East Russia, Japan.

They argue that President Roosevelt's statement that the hands of German prisoners were tied after the Dieppe raid was evidence that the German complaint was well founded.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- Miss Alice Paul, leading militant woman suffragist and founder of the National Woman's Party, was elected national chairman of the party today at the close of its week-end biennial convention. She succeeds Mrs. Harvey W. Wiley who, with Miss Paul and other "fighting" suffragists, has in the past served her cause in jail after White House picketings.

Brisk activity continued in most wholesale markets, although the pinch in raw material supplies was felt more acutely and affected deliveries of many items, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices.

Next to the treacherous Ides of March, the windy weather of late October produces more sniffles than any other time of year. The common cold, according to the New York Academy of Medicine, is likely to be more common than ever in the weeks to come.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Steel mills are giving customers no assurance that delivery of materials will be made in the fourth quarter of this year on "orders with low ratings, assigned on Production Requirements Plan certificates," the magazine Steel reported today.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt concluded her visit with the King and Queen at Buckingham Palace this morning and left the capital for an undisclosed destination in the country where she was to stay the rest of the week-end.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

In a final effort to stimulate intelligent voting Nov. 3, the New York State League of Women Voters will distribute throughout the State today thousands of broadsides entitled "The Next Congress -- Most Important in United States History."

MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 26 -- German assault troops captured two streets in a factory settlement in Northern Stalingrad yesterday, while a Russian relief army bearing down from the northwest swept through an inhabited locality and seized a stronghold where 3,000 German dead were found lying in trenches and dugouts, the Soviet High Command announced today.

Events tonight: Smetana's "My Country," played by members of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Society under Herman Adler, as conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; violin recital by Roman Totenberg, Town Hall, 8:30; song recital by Roland Hayes, New York Times Hall, 9; concert by the faculty of the Dalcroze School of Music, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:45; Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro," by the 9 o'Clock Opera Company, Juilliard School of Music, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The War Department disclosed tonight the names of seven Army men who were on the plane carrying Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, foremost American flier in the First World War, which has disappeared somewhere in the Pacific.

Refusal of leaders and individuals to recognize Christ as the supreme leader is the cause of the present world chaos, the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, vice chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday in a sermon in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- Well-informed diplomats reported tonight that Japan's effort to extend her "Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere" to invaded Thailand was meeting civilian resistance like that provoked by the Nazi "New Order" in occupied Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Elimination or modification of the requirement that Selective Service inductees under 20 years of age receive at least a year's training before assignment to combat duty overseas appeared probable tonight. The requirement was voted by the Senate before it passed last night the bill to lower the draft age to 18.
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- A Chicago department store hung out the "help wanted" sign today for a number of modest salary jobs with absolutely no future.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -Awards of the Silver Star for "gallantry of the highest order" to four Army Air Force enlisted men who bailed out of their disabled Flying Fortress in Burma on June 4 were announced by the War Department today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 25 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, in his regular Sunday afternoon short-wave broadcast to Italy, appealed to the Italian people today to start a "passive revolution" against their German allies, who, he said, were taking away their food. The Mayor delivers his weekly talk over the National Broadcasting Company's short-wave stations, WRCA and WNBI.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 25 -Judge Ferdinand A. Hoyt of Beacon, candidate of the Democratic and American Labor parties opposing Representative Hamilton Fish in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, opened the final week of his campaign today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- Turning the biggest military parade held here since World War days into a pageant of American unity, 25,000 fighting men and civilians marched today in a Navy Day procession which lasted five hours and was witnessed by 400,000 persons.

Erica Morini, violinist, was the soloist late yesterday afternoon with the New York City WPA Symphony. Orchestra in the third of the war stamp concerts to be sponsored at Carnegie Hall for the United States Treasury by Mayor La Guardia and the Workmen's Circle.
MALDEN, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Malden Catholic High defeated the Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School eleven of New York by 25 -- 0 before a crowd of 5,000 at the Malden Stadium today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- Eddie O'Shea, Broadway actor now appearing as a young marine, Private Thomas Mulveroy, in "The Eve of St. Mark" in New York, has been signed to a seven-year contract by Hunt Stromberg, the United Artists producer announced through his Hollywood office.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 112.3 on Oct. 13. This compares with 112.8 a fortnight before, 112.2 a month before, 107.4 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

An educational campaign intended to cut down the number of home accidents -- which are estimated to comprise 42 per cent of all accidental deaths and more than half the injuries -- will be undertaken through questionnaires delivered by school children to 600,000 homes in the city, the Greater New York Safety Council announced yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Robert A. Maxwell, 85-year-old retired insurance man, and his daughter, Mrs. Vivien Sacksell, 46, were found dead of stab wounds this morning behind the locked door of the attic of their two and one-half story home in the Milbrook section here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 25 -- While Berlin continues to play up alleged atrocities committed by Allied troops, the outburst, faithfully echoed by Virginio Gayda and others in the Italian press, is particularly aimed against United States pilots and Commando soldiers, who are called gangsters and their leaders "miserable criminals."
AT AN R.A.F. BOMBER STATION, in England, Oct. 25 -Airmen who raided Milan in daylight yesterday sat around a log fire at their mess here today discussing among themselves many angles of the attack.
After ten months of war in the Pacific the role of Australia in the campaign there is still uncertain.
Six new films are listed to arrive this week at local first-run houses. The schedule follows:

Jed Harris is back on Broadway and aims to do two plays this season, he says. Yesterday Mr. Harris refused to disclose the titles, content or authorship of both plays. However, he did acknowledge that the first one would have Eugenie Leontovich in the cast and that rehearsals would start within a few weeks.

The nation must rely primarily on private enterprise and the stimulant of the profit motive for creating and maintaining full employment after the war, but these should be supplemented with a program of public works and government expenditures to provide needed facilities and services for taking up the slack in employment, according to a report of a study on post-war reconstruction, made public yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- United States Army Flying Fortresses, continuing their devastating offensive in support of American forces in the Lower Solomons, dumped seventeen tons of bombs on Rabaul yesterday, sinking a Japanese gunboat, probably sinking three cargo ships and leaving fires and explosions visible for 100 miles, it was announced today.

Admiral Ghormley's removal from command of operations in the Solomon Islands can hardly be termed summary. Ever since the revelation on Oct. 12 that three of our heavy cruisers, the Quincy, Astoria and Vincennes, had been sunk in night action with the Japanese, the public has sensed that a change was due.

The award of cash prizes totaling $67,350 was announced last night at the final performance of the seventeenth annual World's Championship Rodeo at Madison Square Garden. The prize money will be paid today.
Your excellent editorial "Mr. Alfange in a Vacuum," suggesting his withdrawal from the campaign, makes one reflect on the possibility of such sensible advice being followed.

Because of the emphasis now given to the responsibilities of trained and experienced business and professional women in the war, the National Federation of Business and Professional Womens Clubs, Inc., has appointed a vocational advisory committee, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The Bears today gave their coach, George Halas, a rousing send-off to his new job as lieutenant commander in the Navy by crushing the Eagles, 45 to 14, to remain unbeaten through eighteen games, twelve of them in National Football League competition.

AT Harvard University a learned Russian exile, who opposed both the Czarist and the Communist regimes, broods upon the tragic lot of man and draws conclusions about it from veritable mountain ranges of statistics drawn from all recorded history. His name is Pitirim A. Sorokin; he is chairman of the Harvard Department of Sociology and author of a formidable work called "Social and Cultural Dynamics."

VICHY, Oct. 25 -- On the occasion of the distribution of prizes in the contest recently held to advertise the national savings bonds, Pierre Cathala, Minister of Finance, made an address in which he gave unpublished indications of the financial situation of France.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Cleveland Rams withstood a flurry of fourth-quarter passes from Bud Schwenk and made two magnificent goal-line stands today for a 7-to-3 National Football League triumph over the Chicago Cardinals before 7,896 Cleveland Stadium spectators.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Oct. 24 (Delayed) -- It may now be said that the British Eighth Army has been preparing for this offensive, which at present is raging in the Western Desert, since last July. That is the time when, after the Eighth Army had withdrawn from Libya, it finally halted General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's advance toward the Nile delta.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Aneurin Bevan, Labor member of Parliament, told 35,000 persons at a second front demonstration in Trafalgar Square today that the Russians were suspicious of the policies dominating Britain and for that reason wanted Rudolf Hess, former No. 2 Nazi, put on trial.

A 22-year-old youth with a record of two arrests was fatally shot in Brooklyn early yesterday while trying to escape from two patrolmen who were questioning him following the complaint of a Navy Yard worker.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Despite a protest by the Protestant Ministers Association, reiterated in various pulpits this morning, the Fifth Regiment, New York Guard, held field manoeuvres today in the form of a sham battle, as planned, on the fairways of the Wykagyl Country Club here.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- With United States, British, South African and Australian fighter and bomber planes playing a prominent part, bitter fighting raged tonight in the Egyptian bottleneck between El Alamein and the Qattara Depression, where the British Eighth Army had penetrated General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's main position at some points and held its gains despite furious counter-attacks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A Navy Department communique:

Herbert Brownell Jr., campaign manager for the Republican State ticket, ridiculed yesterday claims made earlier in the day by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, that he would be elected. Mr. Brownell contended that all reports indicated a sweeping victory for Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, and the entire Republican State ticket.

Richard Strauss's "Salome" and Pergolesi's "La Serva Padrona" will be restored to the repertoire of the Metropolitan Opera Association, it was revealed yesterday with the issuance of its prospectus for the 1942-43 season, which will open on Nov. 23.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Dollars and cents ceilings approximating the individual canner's March (1942) figures have been placed on canned domestic crab meat, it was said today by the Office of Price Administration. This action will lighten "the squeeze" on wholesale and retail distributors and lift their maximums from 6 to 20 per cent above levels prevailing under the General Maximum Price Regulation.

UNION CITY, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Scoring two touchdowns within eight minutes of the opening whistle, St. Michael's High School turned back a late challenge today to defeat the Boys Town High eleven of Omaha, Neb., 13 to 6, in their second annual game before a crowd of 12,500. The Westerners won last year, 7 to 6.

WITH ADVANCE ALLIED AIR STRIKING FORCES, in Egypt, Oct. 24 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The United States Army Air Forces have been operating in strength with the Royal Air Force in the air offensive preceding the start of the British Eighth Army's land battle on the Alamein front, and the Allied pilots have tried all day without success to entice Axis air forces into combat.

Before a war-conscious congregation in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Mgr. Francis W. Walsh of St. Gabriel's Church, Riverdale, the Bronx, vicar delegate of the Army and Navy Ordinariate, solemnly pledged the resources and every "last man" of the Holy Name Society, if necessary, in fighting the war and achieving an early peace.

We shall be thrown together more closely this Winter under heat rationing, because we shall be shutting off some rooms to save oil. It will be like the old days, when the family gathered around the base burner in a cozy comfort of companionship.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Jacksonville Naval Air Station turned back a stubborn Tampa University eleven today, 26 -- 0, in a hard-fought contest. The attendance, limited to Navy personnel, numbered about 3,500.

The last full week of the State campaign begins today with supporters of Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, confident of his election, supporters of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee, doubtful but still hopeful of a late shift of voters, and adherents of Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate, expectant of a large enough vote for him to preserve the party's balance of power in a State election.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 25 -- The transfer of Admiral Edward Clifford Kalbfus, retired, president of the Naval War College and commandant of the Naval Operating Base here, to the General Board of the Navy in Washington was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Joseph W. Martin Jr. and Edward J. Flynn, chairmen, respectively, of the Republican and Democratic National Committees, issued a joint statement today declaring that the Nov. 3 elections should represent "the judgment of our whole citizenry" and urging all employers to stagger hours so that workers might vote without interruption to war tasks.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Carried along by the first rush of their offensive to crush General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps, the Allies in Britain's Eighth Army have driven through gaps in his main Alamein defense belt and have fanned out to the rear of Axis "soft-shelled" infantry and artillery, dispatches from the front said tonight.

Notes from North Carolina indicate that all blinds on Mattamuskeet Lake have been reserved for the two opening days of the approaching season, according to Game Protector Oscar Chadwick, but that some are available outside of the refuge.

It could hardly be said that last week's financial markets were governed by war news. It was not until the close of the week that the forward movement of the British in North Africa gave signs of a major offensive in that quarter. Up to that time the obscurity of the picture was not broken.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has announced the purchase of two plays, "Flare Path," by Terence Rattigan, and "A Highland Fling," by Margaret Curtis. "Flare Path," a current Anthony Asquith production on the London stage, deals with an actress and her husband, who is a member of the R.A.F..

The German High Command, in a report on Stalingrad, announced yesterday that German troops had captured Spartakovka, a northern suburb, and occupied all but one of the fortified Red October foundry buildings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, today asked business and industrial concerns throughout the nation to "dig deep and then even deeper" for vital scrap materials, asserting that these sources must be depended on for supplying the major part of the supplies required for the balance of this year.

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY FORCES, in China, Oct. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Heavy Liberator bombers of Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's China air task force seriously damaged Japanese-operated coal mines around Linsi, in Northeast China, Wednesday, in one of the longest bombing raids of the war.
CAIRO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Announcement of new price ceilings on hog products last week failed to change the general supply and demand situation to any extent. Packers said it was more a question of having cured product and lard to sell than to find buyers.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 25 -It was learned here today that the bulletin issued this morning in Copenhagen regarding the condition of King Christian of Denmark, following his riding accident last Monday, described his illness as pneumonia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today conditions under which some individual consumers and registered industrial users of sugar will be able to dispose of excess stocks in order to avoid deterioration in unsatisfactory storage places and at the same time get idle supplies back into consumption channels.

Nine-hundred and eleven American Protestant bishops, deans, other clergymen, editors of Protestant publications and presidents of colleges with Protestant affiliations have signed a petition urging all anti-Fascist nations to carry the war "into the German hub," it was made known yesterday by Kenneth Leslie, editor of The Protestant.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The Royal Air Force and the British Navy are hard at it to make General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel battle to his death with Britain's attacking Eighth Army in the Egyptian desert without help from his Axis home bases. That is the evident purpose behind the continuous British bomber attacks on the cities of Northern Italy.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Oct. 25 -- United States bombers in the greatest raid thus far of the China air task force blasted Japanese-held Hong Kong today with tons of high explosives and incendiary bombs, turning the great Kowloon dock area of the conquered British Crown Colony into an awesome scene of destruction.

In anticipation of new controls to be imposed by the Director of Economic Stabilization, the upward course of agricultural prices has been checked and the index of all wholesale prices, compiled weekly by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, has recorded a decline for the first time since mid-July.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 25 -One hundred and twenty-two killed and 521 wounded -- officially stated in today's Italian High Command communique -- is the toll inflicted yesterday and during last night by the Royal Air Force in its third day of intensive activity over Northern Italy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Secretary Knox declared today that "no matter what the reverses along the road to Tokyo and Berlin,'' Americans can be sure of ultimate victory.

THERE'S life in the Bulldog yet. Yes, sir; maybe there were bigger games and larger crowds elsewhere, but Old Blues turned pink with pleasure in the Bowl when Howie Odell's Eli team threw Dartmouth for a stunning loss. That's the Dartmouth team that beat Harvard, too; which is cause for further rejoicing and higher hopes in New Haven.

The question before American colleges is no longer how they can be preserved intact, but to what extent they can be used in the war, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, declared yesterday in his annual report.

Prohibition of the sale of liquor was advocated as "advantageous to the national war effort," in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Edward E. Chipman at the Lefferts Park Baptist Church, Fourteenth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UP) -- China's women, by helping their country resist Japan, have made more progress in the last four years than in all the years since the 1911 revolution, Mme. Wei Tao-ming, wife of the new Chinese Ambassador to the United States, declared today.
INSIDE THE GERMAN LINES, on the Egyptian Front, Oct. 24 (Delayed) -- The biggest battle of Egypt is under way.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Sweeping social reforms without parallel in the recent history of the British people will be proposed in a semi-official report that is expected to be submitted to the House of Commons next month. The few who have seen it say it will show the way toward abolition of unemployment and poverty after the war.
The article of Lewis Wood in THE TIMES of Oct. 18 on alien enemies was really discouraging for "the Attorney General's most loyal enemy aliens" -- the some ten thousand refugees from Nazi oppression.

Russia will give powerful and loyal cooperation to a workable scheme of international security after the war, if other powers show equal good-will, Professor Albert Einstein told 2,800 persons attending a testimonial dinner for him last night at the Hotel Commodore. Dr. Einstein telephoned his address from his home in Princeton, N.J., where he is ill.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- After a quiet beginning in which a further consolidation of gains recently made was carried to its conclusion, the stock market resumed its advance at the middle of last week and closed with the most speculative sections displaying fresh strength and broadening activity.

Two-sided activity by mills in the cotton futures market exerted last week a steadying influence on prices, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ending the period with net declines of 4 to 13 points as hedge selling and liquidation of the distant months increased in late dealings.

Ella Belle Davis, an exceptionally gifted Negro soprano from New Rochelle, gave last night her first New York recital at Town Hall. Although she did not know it at the time, a sheaf of red roses presented to her at the intermission were from the grave of her teacher, Edith W. Gaudenzi, who died on Thursday and was buried yesterday.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The New Friends of Music launched its seventh season late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall with a program featuring the piano quintet of Schumann, and also containing the string quartets, Op. 3, No. 5, and Op. 76, No. 5 of Haydn.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- The continued success of various drives for scrap metal throughout the nation again affected steel ingot output last week, when the rate for the country as a whole moved up one point to 100.5 per cent of rated capacity.

Mayor La Guardia warned landlords yesterday not to use the war as an excuse for increasing rents, supplying insufficient heat or failing to repair their premises and keep them in sanitary condition. He also indicated that he expected them to "cooperate" fully with the police in his anti-gambling drive.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 25 -- A possibility of one or more British break-throughs in the Axis position on the Egyptian front was acknowledged tonight by a Berlin military spokesman, who hastened to add, however, that in his opinion this might by no means be tantamount to a final British success.

On the twenty-fourth anniversary of the founding of the Czechoslovak Republic, a commemorative service was held yesterday morning in the Jan Hus Presbyterian Church, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street, the oldest Czech church in the United States.

A committee to make a Statewide study of New York's farm problems, with special emphasis on the serious farm labor shortage, and to recommend the most effective utilization of available agricultural manpower was appointed yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.

The Brooklyn Museum, far from discriminating against any work of art because of the war, bought four important Japanese prints last Summer and a Japanese priest robe last month, Laurance P. Roberts, director and curator of oriental art, said last night in reply to the Municipal Art Society's protest against the recent scrapping of some Japanese swords and scabbards.

A serious problem will face the city within six months unless daytime care is provided for the children of mothers working in war industries, the report of the Committee on Wartime Care of Children asserts.

Purchasing a box of apricots, a package of raisins, a pound of prunes has become almost as difficult as buying a bag of coffee. In fact, up until very recently, dried fruits have been notable by their absence in most stores about the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Treasury announced today the offering tomorrow through Federal Reserve Banks of $2,000,000,000 of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, Series D-1942, for cash subscription at par and accrued interest.

SOMEWHERE IN WEST AFRICA, Oct. 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- The list of heroic Americans killed in action in the cause of their country has been lengthened by three fearless bomber ferry fliers who swapped the safety of internment for a 100-to-1 chance to deliver the goods.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- German shock troops that broke into a factory in northern Stalingrad have been hurled back or destroyed, it is reported today. Despite the resumption of violent fighting, the activity of the German Air Force, the arrival of fresh German troops and a general improvement in the weather, the Germans have made no appreciable progress during the last three days.
New leases in buildings on Park Avenue were among the latest apartment rentals reported in Manhattan over the week-end.

Twelve judicial positions in this city will be filled as a result of the elections to be held Nov. 3. We present as a trustworthy guide for voters the recommendations of the leading bar associations and of the Citizens Union with regard to candidates for these twelve places.

DETROIT, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Don Hutson, running ahead of his all-time scoring pace of last season, was held without a touchdown today for the first time this year, but the Green Bay Packers nevertheless whipped the Detroit Lions, 28 to 7, in a National Football League game before 19,097 spectators.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- More than 1,400 Serbs, including women and children, were shot dead in a new wave of terror in the Axis-created Croat State, the exiled Yugoslav Government reported today.

The magic spell that the Brooklyn Dodgers have cast over the New York Giants of recent years again asserted itself before 23,244 spectators at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Brooks toppled the Giants, 17 to 7, and thus virtually eliminated them from repeating as Eastern champions of the National Football League.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- The Washington Redskins, striking through the air for one touchdown and blocking a punt for another, clung to the Eastern Division lead of the National Football League today by turning back the Pittsburgh Steelers, 14 to 0.

ALBANY, Oct. 25 -- Orthodox political calculations, based on factors which appeared on the surface during a ten-day tour of up-State New York, would give Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, a lead of about 400,000 over John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee, in the fifty-seven counties outside New York City.

Harper Brothers, observing its 125th anniversary, has reached back in time to one of its early lists, that of 1838, to select a book for reissue in a facsimile edition. It is "Retrospect of Western Travel," by the English author Harriet Martineau.

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., made public yesterday an open letter to Mayor La Guardia, asking him to intervene in its dispute with the Board of Transportation over a general wage rise for employes of the city's unified transit system.

Only four of the thirty-five competitors entered in the United States amateur championship preliminaries remained undefeated after the fourth round had been completed at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.

VICHY, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- American and British air raids on French industrial centers depressed stocks last week on the Paris Bourse, particularly issues of the Schneider munitions group and other concerns whose plants were involved in bombings at Le Creusot and Lille.
MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

VICHY, Oct. 25 -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France dated Sept. 24 shows no change in the credit accorded the securities market. Thirty-day advances on bonds declined by 190,000,000 francs and bills discounted by 105,000,000, but bills bought on the market by the bank rose 331,000,000.

The growing church in Africa presents a tremendous ground for optimism and at the same time a challenge to the rest of the world, the Rev. Dr. Newell S. Booth, a missionary in the Belgian Congo, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

EAST HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Jessica Garrup, 27-year-old practical nurse, was slain today in a beach cottage here, and a man whom police found lying across her body, screaming hysterically, was held without bail on a Coroner's warrant in connection with the case.

An investor purchased from the Greenwich Savings Bank the five-story tenement for ten families at 128 West Ninetieth Street on which there is an assessed valuation of $27,000. The house has six-room apartments and is on a plot 26.6 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Oct. 17 to 23 are given in the appended tabulation:

Any one who cares to see a two-ocean navy, as well as the world's largest collection of regimental insignia, fancy needlework or a toothpick tower, can do so today by visiting the annual Hobby Show when it opens at 11 A.M. at the Sachs Auditorium, 505 Eighth Avenue.

Saying that he was speaking as a "pinch hitter" for Coleman B. Cheney, Socialist candidate for Governor, who is in the Army, Norman Thomas declared yesterday that New York State would be about as well or ill governed whichever of the major party candidates was elected and that only the speakers of the Socialist party were campaigning on vital issues.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Oct. 26 (U.P.)A. communique:

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 25 -- Prices of cotton for futures delivery moved erratically last week on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange. Buying by the trade and price-fixing by mills on all dips offset increased hedging pressure. Although inter-month operations apparently subsided, there was further modest narrowing of premiums of late positions over the near months.

If we had not suffered so frequently in the past from the results of overconfidence, we should certainly be asking now whether the tide of war had not definitely turned. At few if any previous occasions in this war has the course of battle on all fronts seemed more uniformly favorable to the cause of the United Nations.

Before this war is many weeks older chances are strong that a committee of prominent retailers will have submitted a list of suggestions on further minor contributions that shoppers should make to the war program by voluntarily ceasing to demand services that qualify as luxuries.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose slightly to 108.4. Changes occurred mainly in the prices of the agricultural commodities. Because there is a price ceiling on flour and none on wheat, the Commodity Credit Corporation has been authorized to resell to the farmer the wheat that has been placed under loan in an effort to remove the likelihood of a price "squeeze" on flour millers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 25 -- The Allied bombing and strafing effort yesterday was the heaviest ever carried out in the Middle East, and the United States Army Air Forces reported activity on a scale larger than ever before. Enemy positions, gun emplacements, trucks and stores all got their share of explosives.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Although many of the causes for expansion of the Bank of England's circulation are well known, the City was interested last week in the brief explanation given by the Chancellor of the Exchequer. He said that the wartime increase of about 60 per cent was more than accounted for by the increase in total wages, whether through the larger number of wage earners or through the higher wages or overtime pay.

"The battle begins tonight," General Bernard Montgomery, commander of the Eighth Army, told the reporters gathered at his headquarters as the drive was launched to push the Axis forces out of Egypt. "The battle continues," said the communiques issued last night from both sides of the 40-mile front, the shortest, yet in some respects the most crucial, in the war because it is central to them all.
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- Today's news includes an illustration of the way in which the Russians maintain the vital Lake Ladoga route to Leningrad.

MAHOPAC, N.Y., Oct 25 -Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, predicted tonight as he neared the end of his up-State campaign that he would cut heavily into the normal Republican pluralities outside New York City.
Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff have returned to 860 Park Avenue from Southampton, L.I., where they spent the Summer.
Yale and Princeton are coming to Baker Field on Nov. 14 to play game of football, and reservations are in order right now.
The first gift of $50,000 to the United Hospital Fund campaign was announced yesterday by William S. Paley, general chairman of the drive. The gift was made by Mrs. Charles S. Payson.

Your editorial opposing Mr. Alfange's candidacy on the ground that the vote he will draw will not be sufficient to elect him but will only help defeat the Democratic candidate omits several relevant and material facts which voters supporting Mr. Alfange are taking into consideration.

Real conquest is really a spiritual matter, the "inner conquest of a nation by the persuasive forces of justice, fair play and goodwill," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

Mandatory "meatless Tuesdays," with penalties for eating places that fail to conform, were proposed yesterday by the Society of Restaurateurs as more efficient and less troublesome to the public and to restaurant operators than the eight-point program suggested recently by the food requirements committee of the War Production Board.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation had a net income of $8,941,246 for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, according to a statement released for publication today. This is equivalent to 96 cents each on 9,277,788 shares of common stock.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The Office of Price Administration moved rapidly last week to place limits on the flour and wheat markets, and an announcement made jointly with the Department of Agriculture virtually placed a ceiling on the cash grain at a price equal to $1.02 a bushel at country points, or 32 cents below actual parity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Brig. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator and Acting Commissioner of Work Projects, announced today that instructions had been sent to all WPA State Administrators for reinterviewing and classifying all WPA workers in the country and all those awaiting assignment to WPA to expedite transfers to war industries, farm work or other employment.

ST. BONAVENTURE, N.Y., Oct. 25 (AP) -- St. Bonaventure College avenged an early season defeat at the hands of Scranton University today, utilizing a powerful ground offensive to roll up a 20-7 victory.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Ministries of Air and Home Security issued this communique today:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (AP) -- St. Mary's pushed Loyola of Los Angeles out of the select circle of undefeated football teams today by scoring a well earned 13-to-0 victory before a crowd of 20,000 at Gilmore Field.

At the Hillside Hospital, Seventy-sixth Avenue and 263d Street, Bellerose Manor, a playground and recreation center covering several acres was dedicated yesterday. It was constructed by the Wender Welfare League, made up of former patients, at a cost of $5,000 in honor of Dr. Louis Wender, medical director of the hospital.

One hundred and fifty thousand persons witnessed colorful Navy Day parades in the Bronx and Queens yesterday as both boroughs proudly presented, for the first time en masse, their well-equipped civilian defense units. Veterans' organizations, church groups and civic and business contingents also participated in the organized demonstrations of home-front preparation.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Two short passes in the second and third periods gave the Canisius football team a 14-7 victory over the Fort Totten Army eleven today before 5,882 spectators.

VICHY, France, Oct. 25 -- British planes made attacks yesterday in unoccupied France, and the attacks have been energetically protested in London, according to a communique issued here tonight. A protest against this "aggression" immediately was forwarded through the French Embassy in Madrid.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Professor J.B.S. Haldane, chairman of the National Air Raid Precautions Coordinating Committee, issued a warning today of possible German gas attacks on Britain, saying the first such blows would be on a large scale, probably against Lon don, Birmingham, Glasgow or other big cities.

Contributions totaling $21,182,263 have been received to date by the United Service Organizations War Fund Campaign, it was announced yesterday by Prescott S. Bush national campaign chairman. He pointed out that there was 488 campaigns of local community chests and war fund drives being conducted this Fall from which the USO would benefit.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The lowest prices of the season for oats were reached last week on the Board of Trade here because of the weight of hedging pressure from the Northwest, where cash grain is moving freely in striking contrast to the very limited supplies of that grain being offered by Illinois farmers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The board of directors of the American Society of Newspaper Editors authorized today appointment of a special committee of newspaper executives to act on behalf of the society on any subject growing out of the war emergencies.

The principal foe which humanity today must defeat is the enemy which lies within ourselves, the Right Rev. Spence Burton, soon to be enthroned as Bishop of Nassau, declared in a sermon yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York and Charles H. Goren of Philadelphia completed an unusual run of tournament victories in the metropolitan contract bridge championships at the Park Central Hotel here last night when they won the two-session contest for mixed pairs.
The text of Mayor La Guardia's short-wave address to Italy yesterday, as recorded and translated by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:

While advertisers are showing a tendency to go slow in the preparation of 1942 budgets, there appears to be more confidence in the advertising outlook than was apparent in the early part of the year, according to advertising agency executives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Our marines, soldiers and airmen have smashed five heavy assaults on our western defense line on Guadalcanal in the Solomons as the Japanese, equipped with tanks, have started in earnest their drive aimed at our forces holding the air field and surrounding portions of the island, the Navy said tonight.
Yesterday's closing wholesale cash prices for commodities in the New York market, unless otherwise noted, were:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The acquisition by the Anaconda Copper Mining Company of the 52 per cent stock interest of Howard P. Eells Jr. and associates of Cleveland in Basic Magnesium, Inc., for a purchase price of $75,000, was announced today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26 -- E.K. Bryson's Marksman, capably handled by Jockey Danny Scocca of Washington, D.C., withstood a long drive to win the sixth race, best offering on today's program before a crowd of 5,000.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26 -- Many little health tricks to keep war workers well were disclosed at the American Public Health Association's annual meeting which began here today. They are things each man and woman can do for himself in addition to food, medical, sanitation and safety precautions.
MONTREAL, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Sixteen persons were killed today in the crash of a Royal Air Force ferry command aircraft on the north end of Montreal Island.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- An indication of the pattern which the War Production Board will follow in eliminating nonessential civilian items and simplifying production of others, was given today in a formal explanation of the WPB's order cutting production of kitchen enameled ware from a peacetime total of 450 items to a wartime limitation of twenty-five.

Charitable bequests of more than $500,000 made in the will of Mrs. Harriet Parsons James, wife of the late Arthur Curtiss James, railroad financier and industrialist, were reduced because her estate was not large enough to provide for full payment, it was disclosed yesterday when the estate tax appraisal was filed here.

The board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., has addressed a memorandum to the Securities and Exchange Commission opposing a proposed rule of the Federal agency that would oblige over-the-counter dealers to disclose market prices to customers in each transaction. The proposal is officially known as Rule X-15C1-10.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The condition of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve System announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 21: Increases of $1,258,000,000 in holdings of Treasury notes, $639,000,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds, $2,000,000,000 in United States Government deposits and $248,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $511,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
VICHY, France, Oct. 26 -- Continuing his military inspection tour of French Africa, Admiral Francois Darlan, Chief of the Armed Forces, arrived today in Fez, Morocco.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A Navy Department communique:

The nine-story loft building at 397 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, has been sold for cash above a first mortgage to the Beros Service Corporation. The seller was the Van Nostrand Corporation. The building is assessed at $145,000 and is fully rented.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -Details of a transaction by which the Coast Guard cutter Seneca was sold in 1936 by the Coast Guard for $6,605 and repurchased in 1941 by the Maritime Commission for $45,000 were laid before Congress today by Representative Bland of Virginia.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- You've heard of the Waacs and the Waves. Well, now it's the Wows.

The twelve railroads seeking a 10 per cent increase in intra-State passenger rates in New York are not justified in this demand since they are enjoying "a prosperity and an unprecedented increase in earnings," Harry R. Booth, an attorney for the Office of Price Administration, asserted at a hearing yesterday in the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.
