MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A Tass dispatch from Geneva today, reporting on the visit of King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Helena of Italy to Genoa on Friday, said they went there "on the insistent demand of the Fascist government" after reports reached Rome of panic caused among the population and local authorities by the first destructive British air raid there Thursday night.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -Captain Leland P. Lovette, chief of the navy's Bureau of Public Relations, said today that the Navy has transported 600,000 American soldiers to overseas stations "without the loss of a single man."

Nineteen double-headers, one more than last year's record total, have been listed for the 1942-43 college basketball season at Madison Square Garden. The program, the largest and most attractive ever listed for the Eighth Avenue arena, was announced yesterday by Director Ned Irish.
AN AMERICAN AIR BASE IN NORTHERN INDIA, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant Alvic Watson of Fayetteville, N. C., was credited today with the first American air victory in the skies over India.

A two-foot long wool-work plaque depicting the United States shield and an eagle poised in the background over the prayer, "God Bless America," was one of the feature exhibits yesterday at the opening of the Victory Hobby Show for service men and war workers at Sachs Auditorium, 505 Eighth Avenue.

With a crowd of 10,680 on hand Empire City moved into the last full week of its Autumn meeting yesterday, but the sport was almost secondary to the first air raid alert on any New York track. Coming between the first and second races, the whining sirens sent the crowd scurrying beneath the stands under the marshaling of air raid wardens, who went into action quickly.

With 50 per cent of the domestic sulphite and sulphate pulp sold in the United States produced by West Coast mills, the War Production Board order banning all shipments to mid-Western and Eastern markets for the next two months is the most serious blow the pulp and paper industry has experienced in recent years and will force a complete revision of established supply practices, executives in the field reported here yesterday.

Adolph Bolm has been engaged by the Ballet Theatre to serve in the capacity of regisseur general and will join the company at the Metropolitan Opera House as soon as he arrives from his home in Hollywood toward the end of this week.

CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 26 -- Hitler, Hirohito and Mussolini should be executed or placed in captivity before peace conferences are begun by Great Britain, the United States, and China following the war, Mayor La Guardia declared today in an address initiating the Community Chest campaign here.

ALBANY, Oct. 26 -- The first "ration banking accounts" in the United States were opened here and in adjacent cities and towns today as the Office of Price Administration, with the cooperation and assistance of thirty-three banking offices in the Albany, Troy and Schenectady area, laid the groundwork for a system which is expected to be adopted nationally.

Discrimination against Negro youths by war industries was scored yesterday by Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune, director of Negro affairs of the NYA. She said many schools were refusing to train Negro boys and girls because they felt there was no use fitting them for work while jobs were denied to them.

The report of the Pepsi-Cola Company and its subsidiaries, issued for publication today by Walter S. Mack Jr., president, shows for the first nine months of 1942 profit approximating $12,400,000 after all charges but before income and excess profits taxes.

Roman Totenberg, violinist, who appeared at the Town Hall last night, deserves credit for trying to spruce up his program with a bit of intelligent window dressing. Essentially his wares were not much different from the usual violinist's concert, but Mr. Totenberg's program notes suggested hat he had arranged his selections to include "examples of the most important changes of style in violin playing from Bach to the present."

The general reader will learn little by studying the roll-call by which the Senate voted to lower the draft age to 18 years, with an amendment which will delay for a year the combat use of drafted soldiers under 20. There were former "isolationists" and former "interventionists" on both sides.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Because its continuance would seriously interfere with the war, the anti-trust trial of the American Optical Company, Bausch Lomb Company and others has been adjourned for an indefinite period, the Department of Justice said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Roosevelt called the Naval High Command into conference late today as the defenders of Guadalcanal, in the Solomons, apparently faced one of the most terrific ordeals in American history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned to Oct. 18 totaled 8,183,839 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters, compared with 6,857,017 bales a year ago and 7,027,189 bales two years ago.

Lieutenant (jg) James R.C. McGovern, Navy pilot, has been killed in action, according to information received yesterday from the Navy Department by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. James P. McGovern of 8794 Fifteenth Avenue, Brooklyn.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 26 -Insular representatives of mainland food processors, canners, millers and other food products companies protested today to the United States Departments of the Interior and Agriculture, and the Agricultural Marketing Administration against their elimination from the projected distribution set-up of the AMA.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- An angry Senate farm bloc, demanding revisions in Federal price policies which would permit prices paid to farmers for their products to go higher, was turned down today by James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director; Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, and Secretary Wickard.

Declaring that the issue in the Governorship campaign was establishment of progressive government in New York State, Mayor La Guardia made last night over WJZ an appeal for election of Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, and his running mates, Joseph V. O'Leary, candidate for Controller, and Alexander Kahn, candidate for Attorney General.

If sports writers and spectators were startled at the superb brand of play Yale unfolded against Dartmouth last Saturday, an even more surprised individual was Howie Odell, Eli coach. He told of his own amazement at the Football Writers Association weekly luncheon meeting yesterday at Toots Shor's restaurant.

A drive to establish free nursery schools as a part of the public education system will be opened Saturday at the annual luncheon of the United Kindergarten Mothers of New York City in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. will be the principal speakers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Major Gen. William S. Key, a National Guard officer since 1906 and veteran of the Aisne-Marne offensive World War I, has been named provost marshal general in the European theatre, the War Department announced today.

A net profit of $10,481,332 was reported yesterday by the Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30. The net was after all charges, including $6,425,000 provision for Federal taxes on income computed at rates in the 1942 Revenue Act.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- All types of alcoholic beverages sold by the package or by the drink, with the sole exception of beer on draught, will cost the American consumer more when increased Federal excise taxes go into effect Nov. 1, the Office of Price Administration said today.
CAIRO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Representative Cole of New York wrote Attorney General Biddle today that the government's anti-trust action against The Associated Press had caused "a great deal of grave concern."

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 26 -- An extensive hijacking ring, accused of having taken $50,000 worth of whisky at pistol point, has been smashed, it was announced today by E.E. Conroy, New Jersey chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

A special Federal grand jury, which for eighteen months has been trying to find out what became of a $1,500,000 fund collected from members of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Motion Picture Machine Operators, returned yesterday perjury indictments against three men.
In less than a year of war the United States has established clear-cut, qualitative air superiority in the Pacific.
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 26 -- Articles by Hanson W. Baldwin, military editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, criticizing the Australian war effort, aroused antagonistic comment today.

More aggressive hedging in the closing minutes on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday sent quotations on active contracts to the day's lows and final net losses of 2 to 5 points after they had held within a 5-point range most of the session.

Total war necessarily involves unparalleled Governmental controls. In peacetime men and women as individuals buy the things that they want for their own personal welfare. Private industry, responding to this demand, makes these things for them. In wartime the great all-powerful customer is the Government.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26 -- Officials of the Maryland Jockey Club announced today that the Calumet Farm's Whirlaway would be the only horse to start in the $10,000 Pimlico Special, feature of Pimlico's opening-day program Wednesday, and that he would therefore win in a walkover.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The adult American's voluntary meat ration, two and a half pounds a week, is a "feast" compared to meat allowances in lands overseas, the Office of War Information pointed out today.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Oct. 25 (Delayed) -- It is now established that elements of the British Eighth Army achieved in their entirety the objectives that had been set for them in the first phase of the British offensive that is now under way in this theatre of war.

Following is the text of Wendell L. Willkie's report to the people on his recently completed trip. The talk was made last night over the combined networks of the Columbia Broadcasting System, the National Broadcasting Company, the Mutual Broadcasting System and the Blue Network.

The directorship of the Atlantic Monthly Press in Boston, a post that has been vacant since Chester Kerr left many months ago for government service, has been filled by John Scott Mabon. Mr. Mabon, who started in the editorial position yesterday, has been with several New York publishing houses, most recently with Knopf, where he was on the editorial staff.

The people of Italy seem to have been sharing one bit of entertainment and edification not available to us at home -- Mayor La Guardia's short-wave broadcasts in the Italian tongue. One doesn't know what the effect has been, or whether the Mayor told the Italians anything they didn't know.

General Wavell believes in busman's holidays. Such time as he can spare from his duties as British Commander in Chief in India, with a special eye on the reconquest of Burma, he apparently devotes to writing essays and books on military history.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Mrs. Roosevelt heard her first real air raid warning in England today just as she was speaking at an Auxiliary Territorial Service training center not far from London. The First Lady continued her speech without faltering, thereby winning the admiration of several thousand girls who have acquired their nonchalance toward sirens after more than three years of war.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 26 -Working more than an hour today, the Newark police emergency squad rescued Irving G. Steinbrick, 17 years old, who was wedged between an elevator and a shaft wall. It was necessary to cut off all of his clothing and pour fifteen gallons of motor oil over his body.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 26 -- The Quisling Minister for Propaganda, Guldbrand Lunde, died yesterday with his wife in a mysterious automobile accident, rumored to have been caused by Norwegian patriots.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Striving to gain elbow room in which to fight on the scale and in the fashion that the occasion demands, the British Eighth Army in Egypt spent the third day of battle in consolidating its initial successes and in inching forward wherever possible.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, charged here tonight in a speech at the Sunders Trade School that followers of Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, had made a deal with professional drys to gain votes in the election.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- An air raid alert caught Westchester County by surprise at 2:29 P.M. today, but public response was "very satisfactory," according to Captain Rossiter Holbrook, deputy county director of civilian protection.

For the first time the Allies seem to have established control of the air above an extended battle zone through which they are pressing a major offensive. The battle for the sky sweeps over a vast arc that spans the Mediterranean from Northern Italy to Egypt.

" The Moon and Sixpence," a screen version of the W. Somerset Maugham novel, will have its local premiere tonight at the Rivoli Theatre. The entire proceeds will be turned over to the American War Work of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, according to United Artists, which is releasing the film.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Armour Co. of Illinois, meat packers, announced today the conclusion of negotiations for a $50,000,000 revolving credit agreement with twenty banks, headed by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 26 -- The Legislature met in special session here today at the request of Governor Charles Edison to receive his proposals for revision of the method of taxing intangible personal property, but the Senate adjourned abruptly without acting on a bill deferring this year's assessment date to Dec. 31.

The heads of the National Association of Securities Dealers feel strongly enough about the proposal of the Securities and Exchange Commission to introduce a rule for complete disclosure of all matters pertaining to prices on securities traded over the counter to suggest they might drop out of the picture if it were adopted.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Mayor La Guardia's criticism of the Office of Decentralization Service for bringing the Office of Dependency Benefits to the new Prudential Building here was answered today by ODS officials in Newark. Mayor La Guardia asserted yesterday that New York could have provided suitable office space for ODB and that Newark could neither provide nor house the clerks who must be engaged.

First-hand word of how men in the Army want their "gals" to look was expressed yesterday by Thomas Brigance, one of the best-known of New York's young designers, who is now in the Army. Mr. Brigance has been here for a few days on furlough.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- A field of twenty-two competed this morning in the Westchester P.G.A. thirty-six-hole championship at the Gedney Country Club, then decided that the weather was unsuitable for golf and voted to postpone the second round until Thursday afternoon at 12:30.

Roughly 40 per cent of the printing jobs in the city over the last year tied in with the war effore in some way, either in text or design, it was estimated yesterday at the opening of the eighth annual Exhibition of Printing sponsored by the New York Employing Printers Association in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A number of letters have come to this correspondent from voters describing a familiar local political situation and asking the same general question. The following is a summary:
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 26 (AP) -James H. Carr's Frontier Jane ran a front-running race all the way today to capture the best event of an all-claiming card at Rockingham Park.

HONOLULU, Oct. 26 -- The last hours of the aircraft carrier Wasp as her heroic officers and crew fought to save her and then, hopes of that gone, swam to each other in the water and gave life belts to those who could not swim, were described today by her skipper, Captain Forrest P. Sherman.

MOSCOW, Oct. 26 -- Strong German forces that had been persistently attacking a factory in northern Stalingrad met with some success late yesterday, when detachments gained a foothold within the factory's boundaries. Earlier in the day a few streets in an adjacent settlement had been lost by the Russians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A list of twenty-seven industrial plants selected to receive the joint Army-Navy production award for outstanding performance on war work was made public today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

The woman who presides over the kitchen in a certain apartment on the upper East Side would open her eyes in genuine surprise if you told her she was a pioneer. "Why, that's silly," she would say in a matter-of fact voice. "My kitchen is just like dozens of others in the city, and making fruit cake isn't what you'd call a pioneer-ish activity."
VALLETTA, Malta, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A British communique:

Wendell Willkie gave the country a report last night of the impressions he brought back with him from a journey as remarkable as the travels of Marco Polo. He found everywhere in Eastern Europe and in Asia a feeling of warm friendship for the United States. But he also found evidence of some bewilderment because our deeds thus far have failed to match our promises, particularly in the matter of the delivery of war supplies.

Every branch of the fur industry ranging from trapper and fur rancher to the retailer who specializes in making up his own garments will be represented in the National Council of the Fur Industry now being organized, it was stated yesterday by J.D. Silberman, president of the American Fur Merchants Association, who has been taking an active part in the formation of the new trade group.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, pledged last night that, if elected, he would make it the "first order of business" of his administration to bring the facilities, skilled management and manpower of the State into full war production.

Stocks of women's nylon hosiery being withheld from distribution, about which there appears to be considerable difference of opinion between industry executives and OPA officials, may be "smoked out" in time to provide Christmas shoppers with their last wartime opportunity to acquire such stockings, it was indicated here yesterday.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers, largest single unit in the American Labor party, last night called upon the 100,000 members of his organization in this city and State to cast their votes for Dean Alfange, the party's candidate for Governor, and thus help encompass the defeat of John J. Bennett Jr., the Democratic candidate.
The SRO sign has been put away in storage for the duration at most of the colleges, but this week will see a reversion to the boom days of football at four or more focal points of national interest.

Sufficient lift was given yesterday by a wide assortment of specialists to hold the stock market at the high levels of the recovery movement. As a group the public utilities exhibited the best general strength, and had it not been for the lack of major activity in some of the pivotal issues, brokers said the list might have surpassed the year's peaks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Roosevelt, in a tribute on the eve of Navy Day tomorrow, wrote "there is not a man, woman or child in the land who has not been thrilled by its triumphs and inspired by its indomitable courage."

Another blast from Washington, this time from the OWI, at the poor, patient American people, which reads as follows: "In this war the United States has just begun to fight. In the months to come battles may be lost and crushing defeats may be suffered.

" Little Darling," a light comedy by Eric Hatch, opens tonight at the Biltmore. Tom Weatherly, nominally Dwight Deere Wiman's press agent, is the producer, and this is his first venture since 1936, when he sponsored "The Illustrators' Show" for a brief engagement.
IN alphabetical order, Bates, Brown, Dickinson, Illinois and Santa Clara were hauled down out of the unbeaten and untied class in the recent scrimmaging. Five down and more to go. It can't miss.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 - Postponement of final action on the teen-age draft bill until after the election a week from tomorrow appeared almost certain today as the House ran into a snag in attempting to send the differing House and Senate versions to conference.
It appears to me that the case of Mr Coudert, whose re-election you advocate, should be considered in the following light:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Navy Department announced this evening the sinking of the United States aircraft carrier Wasp in the Solomon Islands region on Sept. 15 (Solomons time) as the result of a Japanese submarine attack.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Leo T. Crowley, the Alien Property Custodian, announced today seizure of the American assets of a French dyestuff combine, which had come under control of Germany's I.G. Farbenindustries since the invasion of France in 1940.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -The American people will have to cut down their standard of living to help win the war, Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr., speaking as a representative of the Secretary of the Treasury, said today.

General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander, British Commander in Chief in the Middle East, had at least nine Imperial divisions available for his offensive in Egypt, and although he failed to hold "slight initial gains," a continuation of "stubborn" British attacks was expected, the German Transocean news agency reported yesterday, according to a Berlin broadcast that was recorded in New York by The United Press.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stillwell's headquarters communique:

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Senator William H. Smathers, Democratic candidate for re-election, charged in an address here tonight that Republican Senators wrecked the peace of 1918, and said that President Roosevelt would need the strongest kind of support in the Senate "if our inevitable victory is to be followed by a lasting peace."

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 12 per cent for the week ended Oct. 24, in comparison with the same week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission reported today that average daily production of electric energy for public use in September reached a record high of 568,675,000 kilowatt-hours, or 1.5 per cent over the figure for August.

Mayor La Guardia cheerfully accepted yesterday the fact that the secret of his regular short-wave propaganda broadcasts to Italy had become known through a press dispatch from Berne, Switzerland, where his appeal to the Italians to wage a "passive revolution" against the Germans had been heard on Sunday.

An ecclesiastical council set up by the New York City Congregational Church Association to consider financial problems that may force the closing of the Kings Highway Congregational Church, Avenue P and East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, decided unanimously last night to advise the board of trustees that continued operation of the church is not justified "under such a heavy burden."

Frank F. Ferryman, who earned a place in the finals on Sunday, ended his schedule last night by beating L. Neidich of Elizabeth for his fifth consecutive victory on the United States amateur chess championship preliminaries at the Manhattan Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -Loretta Young, recently signed to a Paramount contract calling for two pictures a year, will be featured in Ethel Lina White's English mystery novel "Her Heart in Her Throat" as a second vehicle this year.

In his promised report to the American people on his recently completed trip to the Middle East, Russia and China, Wendell L. Willkie renewed last night his demand for the establishment of a second fighting front in Europe, and added to it an expression of hope that our forces in India could soon begin an all-out attack on Burma.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- With price ceilings in effect on flour and bread, and a recent announcement that loan wheat would be made available to mills at a price that would prevent a squeeze between the raw material and flour, wheat traders have about given up hope that there will be any material upturn in the market despite hearings now being held by the Senate Agricultural Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Trading in the stock market was optimistic today. There was a good demand for textiles but the outstanding feature was a fresh spurt in South American rails in which dealers reported a big turnover. Many industrials improved.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased residential quarters was Elmer J. Mather, vice president of the National Dairy Products Corporation, who leased an unfurnished suite in 965 Fifth Avenue through Win. A. White Sons, brokers.

Roland Hayes has been singing in this city now for twenty-three years and his voice is no longer flawless, yet in his recital last night at the New York Times Hall, the Negro tenor showed once again that he is a unique artist. Time has not blurred his sympathies nor his gift for making even a three-line song a complete experience in which the last shade of meaning is explored and communicated.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -United States airmen rode their Flying Fortresses through extremely bad weather and heavy anti-aircraft fire to carry out their third successive night raid on Rabaul harbor, wellspring of supplies for Japanese in the Solomons.

Dr. Maurice E. Rogalin, former principal of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on a two-count forgery indictment arising from an investigation by the Kings County District Attorney's office into the disappearance of $18,000 from the funds of the school's General Organization.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- As a hearing on the reorganization plan for the St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt) opened in Federal District Court today, the railroad's attorneys attacked the plan principally on the basis of an allegedly erroneous valuation for capitalization purposes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Representative Melvin J. Maas of Minnesota, a colonel in the Marine Corps Reserve who was on active duty until Oct. 17, received the Silver Star today for gallantry in action in New Guinea.

When Columbia clashes with Cornell at Baker Field on Saturday it will be, in the words of Lou Little, a game between young, inexperienced teams, each looking for its first major victory of the season. The Columbia coach and Carl Snavely, the Big Red mentor, have had little to cheer about thus far, but one of them may be able to smile along about dusk on Saturday.
Ohio State for the third straight week tops The Associated Press poll of sports writers asked to pick the country's best college football team.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Eighteen American pilots who have been serving in the Royal Air Force and the Royal Canadian Air Force were transferred to the United States Navy as commissioned officers at a brief ceremony held at the American Embassy today.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES, in the Egyptian Desert, Oct. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- An American fighter squadron shot down four enemy planes and damaged three more over the desert battlefield today, making this the most successful day the United States fighter pilots have yet had in this theatre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Thousands of small community stores needed to supply the requirements of suburban and rural communities will be helped materially to remain in business if an equitable distribution of inventories is asured, the Special Wholesale and Retail Inventory Policy Committee reported today to Joseph L. Weiner, Deputy Director of the War Production Board's Office of Civilian supply.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Seeking to forestall the manpower drain on war industry plants because of the induction of highly skilled and technically trained men into the Army, a plan for occupational deferment has been drawn up by the War Manpower Commission, and will be put into effect soon, it was reported today.

Many "how to" books are so replete with directions that they often destroy the spirit that must accompany the instructions. Whether it be learning how to hit a golf ball or drilling a pointer for field trial work, the teacher can be dull or enthusiastic. "

Police of nine States were notified yesterday to be on the lookout for three young Bronx girls who ran away from their homes Sunday night and are believed to have taken $7,500 in cash belonging to the father of one of them.

Efforts to revive prohibition in whole or in part were denounced yesterday as a blow at national unity and morale by speakers at a convention of the Distillery, Rectifying and Wine Workers Inter national Union in the Hotel Commodore.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 26 -- The long-expected Japanese air attacks on our bases in East India began yesterday, it was announced in today's British General Headquarters communique. "Chittagong and some airdromes in Northeast Assam" were involved. Chittagong is in Bengal on the Bay of Bengal, not far from the Burma border, while Assam is a province in Northeast British India, adjacent Go Burma.

Private Whittlesey, who lived at 823 Park Avenue, was a sophomore at Yale when he enlisted in the Marine Corps in January. He was a graduate of St. Paul's School, Concord, N.H. He was a nephew of Lieut. Col. Charles Whittlesey of the Lost Battalion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that eligibility for "C" gasoline cards would be placed under added restrictions when nation-wide rationing goes into effect Nov. 22.

Today I viewed with pride the great piles of metal which are to be converted into weapons to help preserve our way of life. Even my lowly frying pan, flat-iron, etc., will go through the fiery furnace to be resurrected as aids to our brave fighters.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -The Navy issued its fifteenth casualty list of the war today, reporting 408 men, from forty-three States and Hawaii, killed, wounded or missing.

Arrangements have been made by Panama City, Fla., for the placing of a total of $1,911,024 of new 4 per cent bonds, it was learned here yesterday. The city has awarded to R.E. Crummer Co., Inc., an issue of $1,600,000 of these bonds, dated as of Jan. 1, 1942, and due on Jan. 1, 1972, callable on Jan. 1, 1957, at a price of 98.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Vincent T. Manas, senior mechanical engineer in the Federal Public Housing Authority of the National Housing Authority, reported today that a new-type bathtub made of plywood withstood a recent performance test by the Bureau of Standards "fairly well."

The four-story mercantile building at 42 Water Street, between Coenties Slip and Old Slip, was sold by Samuel Kilpatrick to a client of W.E. Dean Co. This structure is on a plot 25 by 62 feet and is assessed for $20,500.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Manhattan's regulars were given a respite from practice yesterday as a reward for the 10-to-7 upset of Duquesne on Saturday. While the first-string players rested, Coach Herb Kopf took the reserve forces to Baker Field for a scrimmage against the Columbia reserves.
TORONTO, Oct. 26 (Canadian Press) -- The Dionne quintuplets made their stage debut at Maple Leaf Gardens here today and went through their performance like seasoned troopers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A heavy run of cattle was unloaded here today, but a strong demand from Eastern interests kept choice steers and yearlings steady. Other classes, however, were weak to 25 cents a hundred pounds lower.

In an opinion written at the request of Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner and chairman of the Anti-Discrimination Committee of the State War Council, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, declared yesterday that "Jim Crow" has been banished from New York labor organizations and that the State was determined to make the exile permanent.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The OPA announced today that it will start rationing coffee to civilians starting at midnight Nov. 28, and will grant an allowance of one pound every five weeks to every individual in the country 15 years old or over.

The National Maritime Union opened a "Safety-at-Sea" exhibit yesterday at its headquarters, 346 West Seventeenth Street. Designed to spur recruiting for the merchant marine, the exhibit will be open to the public for a week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, denied emphatically today a published story that Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the WPB production executive committee, had threatened to resign.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A drop in the price of more than 20 per cent was registered today in the auction of the last peacetime catch of sealskin furs.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct 26 -- Colleges of the United States must prepare themselves at once to suspend the liberal arts type of education for the duration, convert their facilities to meet the needs of the Army and Navy, and be ready to accept loyally any sacrifices they are called upon to make, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, declared in his annual report to the board of trustees today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 26 -Three hundred and fifty-four persons were killed and more than 3,000 injured, of whom 500 are in serious condition, at Genoa as a result of Friday night's second successive bombing raid by the British, according to an Italian communique received here tonight.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26 -Told by Coach Tad Wieman to forget their sparkling 32-13 triumph over Brown last Saturday, Princeton's varsity football players waded into the job of preparing for the first round of Big Three competition, the engagement with Harvard at Cambridge on Saturday, in a two-hour session on University Field today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 26 -- Working in the closest cooperation with ground forces, Allied airmen struck hard at the Axis troops all along the Alamein front yesterday and over the Mediterranean continued to throttle enemy supply lines. So effective are these air attacks that they deserve to rank alongside those of the British Eighth Army, though the manpower involved is, of course, not in any way comparable.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Japanese have launched a massive air, land and sea attack against the American forces on Guadalcanal, in the Solomon Islands, the Navy announced in a communique issued tonight.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Johnny Beazley, pitching star of the 1942 world series, applied today for placement in the Navy's physical fitness program, Lieutenant W.R. (j.g.) Walker, recruiting officer in charge of the Navy's V-5, V-7 and Seabees program here announced.

The solution of the hold-up killing of Patrolman Leon Fox in Coney Island twenty months ago, which led police over a trail marked by murder, suicide, Broadway gunfights and countless criminal arrests, only to turn successful through a dealer's stamp on a battered fedora hat, was announced yesterday by Thomas Cradock Hughes, acting district attorney of Brooklyn.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (Reuter) -Prince Albert De Ligne, 30-year-old godson of the late King Albert of Belgium, has arrived in London after a dramatic escape from the Nazis with a tragic story of life in Belgium.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -Pennsylvania's varsity football squad donned sneakers and sweat clothes in Weightman Hall gymnasium today, where actual work started for the game here Saturday with the undefeated West Point team.

Henry Clayton Metcalf died unheralded and unsung in Westport, Conn., on Aug. 27 at the age of 76. Our general preoccupation with fighting the war should not prevent us, however, from pausing to pay full tribute to the career of one of the most devoted servants a democracy could have.

Theodore Roosevelt had a capacity for thinking about the whole world, Mrs. Harper Sibley of Rochester told a large audience of school children yesterday afternoon at the celebration of the eighty-fourth anniversary of the former President's birth at Theodore Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

Pedrich Smetana's symphonic cycle of six tone-poems, grouped under the collective title of "My Country," was performed last night in Carnegie Hall to commemorate the twenty-fourth anniversary of the founding of the Czechoslovak Republic, sixty years, almost to a day, after this great hymn to Emetana's nation and to liberty was first heard by any audience, Nov. 5, 1882 in Prague.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- A jury of nine women and three men was completed tonight in Federal court to try the six relatives and friends of Herbert Haupt, executed Nazi saboteur, on charges of treason. Two alternates are still to be selected.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- When coffee rationing starts Nov. 28 it will still be possible to get a cup of coffee in a restaurant regardless of how much is used at home.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Toys in as great a volume as possible will be sent over this Christmas by the Bundles for Britain organization, Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, president, said today.

While members of the American Women's Voluntary Services in uniform "borrowed" trays of petits fours from the guests' tables to keep the "hosts" quiet during dinner, four retiring justices and one judge were honored at the Hotel St. George last night.

One newspaper advertising classification which is showing a steady rise is amusement advertising, particularly for motion pictures, reports yesterday indicated. New York newspapers have registered a gain of about 15 per cent in such linage so far this year over 1941 and further gains are expected.

Hope that America will avoid the black market menace in cosmetics because of the long-range view taken by the government was expressed yesterday by E.M. Haslam, British representative of Elizabeth Arden, who is here on a short business trip.

The rain yesterday failed to deter New York's "beat-the-tax" liquor buyers. Because of the weather, few stores attempted to maintain lines outside, but most large retailers reported that scores of eager purchasers poured in as soon as the doors opened in the morning and that sales continued unabated throughout the day.

A benefit exhibition arranged in behalf of the American Field Service opened with the private view from 4 to 7 P.M. yesterday at the Whitney Museum, 10 West Eighth Street. Beginning today the admission fee will be 50 cents (25 cents on Saturdays and Sundays).

A disclosure that members of a Kings County jury that recently convicted an attorney of grand larceny for withholding $250 in connection with a draft board case had told the prosecutor that they "felt sorry" for the defendant and that if restitution would help him they would pool their jury compensation for a week and contribute it to that end was made yesterday in Kings County Court.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 26 -- Opposition to the amendment which Senator Lee O'Daniel of Texas fastened to the 18-19 year draft act, requiring one year's training before being sent into combat, was expressed today by Roane Waring, National Commander of the American Legion.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 26 -- "Veterans of two years and more of desert aerial warfare are praising the work of our fighter pilots," Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, commander of the United States Army Middle Eastern Air Forces, said today, adding that he was "extremely proud" of the work that was being done by both fighter pilots and crews of medium bombers in the present battle.

Dean Alfange, the American Labor party nominee for Governor, will not withdraw as an active candidate, it was made clear yesterday. This followed rumors that, because of President Roosevelt's unqualified endorsement of the Democratic nominee, John J. Bennett Jr., Mr. Alfange might ask the voters to ignore his name on the ballot.

Although the subscription books will not be closed until tonight on the Treasury's new offering of $2,000,000,000 of one-year certificates of indebtedness, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that orders already in hand were unusually large.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- In the face of a subcommittee report which said the bill was unconstitutional, the Senate Judiciary Committee by a vote of 13 to 5 reported today a bill to abolish poll taxes. A similar bill already has passed the House.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav patriots have inflicted heavy losses on a German punitive expedition sent to wipe out resistance in the town of Kralivo, a pre-war aircraft manufacturing center, the Yugoslav government-in-exile reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -The War Production Board directed today fish canners to release for civilian consumption 20 per cent of the total amount of salmon, California pilchard, Atlantic sea herring and mackerel packed between March 1, 1942, and next Feb. 28.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Interpretations of the Wage and Hour Law laid down by the Supreme Court in June were left unchanged when it refused today to grant rehearings in two cases.

George Washington Herz, former assistant United States attorney, announced yesterday that Local School Board 48, of which he is chairman, had gone on record in opposition to the demolition of metal fences around school buildings for war scrap purposes. He disclosed that the board was appealing to the Mayor and the Board of Education not to demolish the fences.

Nine-year-old Ellen Marie McGurk stepped from a hospital bed yesterday afternoon and started walking after seventy-two days of treatment for infantile paralysis by the Sister Kenny method. It was the climax of the first public demonstration here of the Kenny method, developed by an Australian nurse in the Queensland bush.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The British said that the Japanese attacked airdromes yesterday and today in Northeast Assam Province, near the Burma border. Details were lacking immediately on today's raid, in which one enemy raider was downed.

HAVANA, Oct. 26 -- The delay and irregularity of mail deliveries from the United States are causing much complaint here, particularly as regards second-class postal matter. Subscribers to United States publications, which have wide circulation in the island, are receiving weekly and monthly magazines far behind schedules and up to today the latest American daily newspapers reaching Havana are dated early in October.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 27 -- The Red Army maintained its lines in Stalingrad yesterday in a seesaw battle in which the Germans drove a wedge into Russian positions in one sector and then were forced to withdraw, the Soviet High Command announced today.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 26 -The character of the internal disturbances in India has changed from mass riots and demonstrations to individual acts of sabotage which are harder to deal with and in some ways more dangerous, a government official of India said today. This official deals directly with questions of internal security.

WITH THE UNITED STATES AIR FORCES, In China, Oct. 26 (AP) -- American bombers blasted Honk Kong again early today, flattening the main electric power plant a few hours after the colony's waterfront had been set aflame yesterday afternoon by the greatest assault yet executed by airmen of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's China command.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 26 -- All Chungking was electrified by the news that American bombers with fighter escorts Sunday afternoon and again early this morning dumped twenty tons of bombs on Hong Kong's docks, shipping and warehouses, blowing up the power station and shooting down ten and probably five more of eighteen Zeros and I-45's.

Hugh Gibson, former Ambassador to Belgium, declared last night in a lecture in the McMillin Academic Theatre of Columbia University that a second front in Western Europe would not be necessary for the defeat of Germany.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Two German bombers were destroyed over Britain today, one by anti-aircraft gun fire and the other shot down by a thrice-decorated fighter ace of the Royal Air Force.

Mrs. Helene Rosenberg, 40 years old, an air raid warden with a son in the Navy, paid a $10 fine in Flatbush court yesterday for interfering with the arrest of a burglar suspect, although she had originally reported the incident to the police.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Edward Haight, 17-year-old Stamford (Conn.) town employe, went on trial in Westchester County Court today for the murders of Helen Lynch, 8, and her sister, Margaret, 7, Bedford Village school children.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Greece will commemorate tomorrow the second anniversary of the Italian invasion -- with casualties from famine surpassing any experienced during actual campaigning against the Axis Powers.

As New York City for a second week observed meatless Tuesday to conserve pork, beef and lamb for the armed forces and for lend-lease, organized groups of delicatessen stores fell into line and closed their doors.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opened with a preview last evening two one-man shows: paintings and drawings by Pavel Tchelitchew and sculpture and drawings by the late John B. Flannagan. The exhibitions, which will continue until Nov. 29, occupy all of the galleries on the second floor.

JUST how the seats for the Army-Navy football game at Annapolis will be distributed this innocent bystander does not know, but what seems a good suggestion has been put forward by Lieut. Col. Herbert B. Hayden of the Ordnance Department, United States Army. With his permission here is exhibited a copy of a letter he wrote on the subject:
The text of The Associated Press answer to the United States Government's charge of violation of the anti-trust laws follows:

Americans who console themselves with the thought that Japanese cities will burn like tinder under attack were warned yesterday by former Ambassador to Japan Joseph C. Grew that this tinder is only another false notion about the enemy.

The Greek forces fighting on the desert front in Egypt consist of two brigades, many of whose officers and men escaped from Greece after the German invasion, Nicholas G. Lely, Consul General of Greece in New York, said yesterday in an interview on the anniversary of the Greek struggle with Italy.

German troops have 0ccupiedl several more streets and blocks of house in the northern suburbs of Stalingrad and Soviet relief attacks on the southern flank 'ave failed," a German communiqu6 reported yesterday.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, discloses a net income of $28,567,498, after all expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.54 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $34,743,604, or $2.08 a common share, in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1941.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 -- Experiments revealing that butter fat and possibly all fats of animal origin are superior in the nutrition of the young to vegetable oils, a finding of great import for the health of future generations, were reported today before the American Public Health Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The United States Public Health Service has adopted a new program to combat the inroads of venereal diseases on the health of the armed forces and workers in the war effort, it was learned otday.

The deferred opening of "Rosalinda" will take place tonight at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre under the auspices of Lodewick Vroom, who is acting as producer for the New Opera Company. "Rosalinda" is the new name for the English version of "Die Fledermaus" or "The Bat," Johann Strauss's operetta first offered here in 1881.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A United States Air Forces Head. quarters communiqL :

Yesterday, anniversary of Theodore Roosevelt's birthday, the Roosevelt Distinguished Service Medals awarded by the Roosevelt Memorial Association were bestowed. The choice of the judges was fortunate and it is ratified by public opinion. Thirty-two years ago Theodore Roosevelt was talking admiringly and affectionately of "Harry Stimson." Political miasmas of that day have long disappeared.

Charges that the Navy Department's licensing system for the production of officers' uniforms, which is confined to two manufacturers is monopolistic, and that the Army's uniform procurement policy, which places the vast bulk of its business with manufacturers of civilian men's clothing, results in inferior apparel, were made yesterday at a meeting of the National Association of Uniform Manufacturers, Inc., 112 East Nineteenth Street.

Public offering of $9,500,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, series A, of the Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company, is made today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Salomon Bros. Hutzler. The bonds, which are dated Nov. 1, 1942, and mature in 1967, are priced at 99 3/4 and accrued interest.

Ration banking, already in extensive use in England, is being given its first tryout in this State, preparatory to adoption on a national scale. Working in cooperation with the Office of Price Administration, eighteen banks and their fifteen branches in the Albany-Schenectady-Troy district have volunteered their services to work out in actual practice a simple and reliable system for the exchange and accounting of ration stamps, coupons, certificates or other paper.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 27 -- In the first account by a German war correspondent to reach Berlin on the present struggle in Egypt, Hans Scheidel, a soldier, says that "the supreme Luftwaffe general in North Africa" was nearly killed in a Royal Air Force low-level surprise attack.

The latest Girl Scout undertaking, that to provide 100,000 cookies weekly to USO canteens of the city, was begun yesterday afternoon at a "cookie party" in the headquarters of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, 670 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Russian morale is high and the people are putting everything into the fight with every assurance that their country will win, according to reports here today.

As an air raid warden who has taken first aid, I take exception to the contradictory rules issued by Dr. Bernecke, published in your paper of Oct. 23. He states we are to stay under cover during air raids and, then, in the next paragraph, tells us what we are expected to do with casualties who will certainly not be found under cover.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Oct 28 (AP) -- Allied fighter pilots made a strafing attack on the Japanese base at Lae, New Guinea, yesterday, giving remote support to their embattled comrades on Guadalcanal, 900 miles to the southeast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Coffee extract manufacturers renewed their requests to Washington officials today to approve plans for moving some of the coffee extract plants established in the United States to Brazil and put them into service there making extract for shipment to American soldiers abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- United States Army troops defending the southern side of the airfield on Guadalcanal Island have thrown back a Japanese attack that temporarily pierced their lines, while Marine Corps troops holding the western end of the field have made slight advances in encounters with the enemy, the Navy Department announced tonight.

Two new films will arrive in mid town theatres this morning. At the Roxy the new attraction will be "Thunder Birds," a Twentieth Century-Fox production filmed in Technicolor starring Gene Tierney with Preston Foster and John Sutton. Supporting roles in the drama, which has an aviation background, are played by Jack Holt, Dame May Whitty, George Barbier, Richard Haydn and Reginald Denny.

It is odd that Wendell Willkie's report on his travels in the Eastern Hemisphere should be chiefly concerned with the one big country that he did not visit, and this is India. "I did not go to India," he reminded his hearers.

VICHY, France, Oct. 27 -- Workers in the occupied zone continue to fail to respond to the appeals and summonses to report for work in Germany. [The United Press quoted the German-controlled Paris newspaper as saying 30,000 had responded and special workers' trains would leave daily hereafter.]
Major changes in the tactics and technique of the employment of air power are occurring in the Pacific as a result of our combat experience of the first ten months of war.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A strong force of Japanese fighters and bombers that struck United States airfields in the Dibrugarh area of Northeastern Assam Province Sunday killed an American air officer and a British subject, wounded five Americans and destroyed or damaged several grounded transport planes, a United States Army communique disclosed today.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Swinging through three southern tier counties in his final up-State tour of the campaign, Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, declared that the Democrats had failed to develop any plans for dealing with the State's wartime emergencies and instead, in desperation, were resorting to a campaign of "bogey men and rumors" and boasts of past performances.

Matthew Gordon, former news editor of the Columbia Broadcasting System and now of the Office of War Information, has written "News Is a Weapon," a book Knopf will publish Nov. 9. For four years, the author says, he collected case histories of enemy news operations.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Major William G. Benn, leader of three devastating raids on the Japanese stronghold of Rabaul, New Britain, in which 100,000 tons of shipping were believed blasted, received the Distinguished Service Cross from General Douglas MacArthur today for "extraordinary heroism, courage and leadership."

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 27 -- Dodging and weaving forward in the uncanny light of the African moon, infantry units of the British Eighth Army extended the Allied-held area by assaults on enemy strong points Sunday night, and yesterday tenaciously held their gains despite the sway of heavy fighting, which, according to the latest reports, continues.

The newspaper account of the House committee headed by Representative Tolan urging a single war agency for all-out effort is one of the most sensible and genuinely constructive reports coming out of our capital that should match along with the straight-from-the-shoulder report issued by the rubber committee headed by Bernard M. Baruch.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 27 -- King Christian X of Denmark, critically ill of pneumonia, tonight signed a royal decree naming Crown Prince Frederik as Regent.

An interesting element in the third quarter results of the United States Steel Corporation was that earnings before taxes were substantially lower than in the 1941 period. Even deducting the current year's heavy wage increase, the corporation's earnings would have been $93,500,000 before taxes of any sort, against $94,600,000 a year ago.
Property owners resent being called "gouging landlords" by responsible public officials.

More extensive use of the city's public school buildings and grounds for recreational and vocational defense purposes was advocated yesterday by leaders of educational, recreational and civic groups at a conference called by Frank Peer Beal, chairman of the recreation committee of the Community Councils of the City of New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Hog receipts expanded today, and, although the number placed on sale could not be considered large in view of the heavy demand for slaughter material, prices slumped 15 to 20 cents a hundred pounds.

Marine insurance companies, which have written more than $16,-500,000,000 of war-risk insurance on shipping after three years of actual war experience, as of Sept. 30 this year had a credit balance on cargo war-risk operations, it was announced yesterday by the American Institute of Marine Underwriters.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Bequests of $200,000 to Princeton University, $50,000 each to Smith College, Cornell and Rutgers, and $10,000 to Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J., were provided in the will of Ellis Earle that was filed here today with Vice Ordinary Alfred A. Stein in Prerogative Court.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Wheat prices declined 1/2 to 1 cent a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, largely in sympathy with rye, but there was no material pressure except for a brief period following the opening and buying of the December, which went to 3 cents under the May, against 3 1/2 cents under at the finish on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Against the distant backdrop of sea warfare being waged around the world and highlighted by the savage battle thundering over Southwestern Pacific waters Americans honored their warriors of the waves today as speeches and parades marked observance of the first war-time Navy Day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Congressional investigation into the extent of Administration plans to employ direct and indirect governmental subsidies to stabilize farm prices, and possibly those in industry, will be asked in legislation to be presented to the Senate under bipartisan sponsorship on Thursday.

Dr. Malcolm Goodrich, president of the New York Academy of Medicine, warned yesterday against "any lapse of vigilance involving the public health" during the war period, in addressing volunteer workers in the current campaign of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service.

Characterizing Navy Day yesterday as a "war day of grim realities," Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the Third Naval District and of the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, called on thousands of workers there to show "solid proof" to the remainder of the nation that Navy Yard civilians "stand ready to fight with their dollars as well as with their hands and skills."
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, last night challenged Thomas E. Dewey to tell what State expenditures he planned to cut in order to achieve the various tax reductions which Mr. Dewey promised recently.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The American consumer is getting steadily out of debt, at least to his private creditors, though he will owe the government more and more in the form of taxes. A Commerce Department report today indicates that outstanding consumer debt dropped $450,000,000, or 6 per cent, during July.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A Navy Department communique:
MOSCOW, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Further Congressional action to lower the minimum draft age to 18 years was postponed formally by the House today until Nov. 9, the Monday after next Tuesday's general elections.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Cedar Farm's He Rolls, after finishing third in two starts at this meeting, made good on the last day of the long session by winning the featured Fort McHenry Handicap.

Five of the ten candidates who will compete in the national amateur championship chess finals, to be started at the Manhattan Chess Club tomorrow night, were determined when play in the sixth and semi-final round of the preliminaries ended at that club last night.

The assertion by Wendell L. Willkie that India was an American problem was welcomed yesterday by Sirdar J.J. Singh, president of the India League of America and a former member of the All India Congress Committee. Mr. Singh said the cause of India "is the cause of the United Nations."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The War Labor Board authorized today pay increases to certain skilled groups in the maintenance, construction and powerhouse departments of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler companies, but denied union requests for general increases and a $1.50 hourly minimum for all skilled workers.

Time and again since the present crisis developed, public opinion, as tested by Gallup surveys, has shown that it is well ahead of Congress and the Administration in the sacrifices it is willing to accept or in the clarity of its view regarding the needs of the situation.
Referring to the Carnegie Hall meeting on Oct. 21 held by the Allied Voters Against Coudert, THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 22 contained the following statement:

In connection with the announced plan of WPB and OPA to "smoke out" hoarded stocks of women's nylon stockings for Christmas shoppers, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers announced here yesterday that it estimated such stocks in the hands of mills by the end of this week would equal about one week's normal consumption.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Coastal Command aircraft have accepted the responsibility of patrolling 500,000 square miles of the northern waters off the Russian coast, the Air Ministry announced tonight.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 27 -- If you aren't convinced that this is war, try to imagine how fantastic Annapolis City Counselor Henry J. Tarantino's words would have sounded at this time last year.
Mayor La Guardia told a group of East Side housewives yesterday that New York City would receive its full share of meat if he had to go to Washington and insist on it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Roosevelt reaffirmed today that the Atlantic Charter applies to all humanity and brushed aside suggestions that there were controversies between him and Wendell L. Willkie over that or any other phases of the 1940 Republican Presidential nominee's trip to the fronts and his drank report to the nation.

Sari Biro, young Hungarian pianist, who made her debut here two years ago, gave last night at Town Hall her third New York recital. Her particularly heavy program included Bach's C minor partita, Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 111: Chopin's Andante spianato and Grande Polonaise Brillante, and Prokofieff's "Suggestion Diabolique."

The use of motion pictures, both as an aid in rapid military training and in the maintenance of civilian morale, was discussed yesterday by Army and Navy spokesmen and by representatives of China and Russia at the opening of the fiftysecond semi-annual meeting of the Society of Motion Ficture Engii neers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Big Army bombers raided the Japanese camp on Kiska Island, in the Aleutians, last Friday and Saturday and dropped heavy loads of bombs without encountering air opposition, the Navy reported today.

"Bundling up," as an answer to Winter winds whistling either in 65-degree rooms or around city street corners, was given several new and fetching twists yesterday at Franklin Simon's showing of warm Winter costumes during luncheon in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton.

More than 3,000 employes of 200 large loft buildings, mostly in New York or owned by New York institutions, already have been paid $502,000 in recent weeks in the form of overtime or additional pay due under the recent decision of the Supreme Court that building and maintenance workers in structures housing firms engaged in interstate commerce were eligible for the benefits of the Wages and Hours Act.

The merger of the Pittston Company and its subsidiary, the United States Distributing Corporation, together with the recapitalization of Pittston, was proposed yesterday in letters sent to stockholders of both companies. A special meeting of United States Distributing preferred and common stockholders was called for Dec. 16 to vote on the proposals, while the Pittston stockholders will vote on Dec. 17.

If you spent your childhood in the country, you probably remember rising at a gray hour and going down to the pasture to gather the mushrooms that had appeared in the night. You carried a tin pail, the dew was wet about your bare legs, your mind was filled with directions given you by a well-intentioned adult.

In case you want to see a middle-aged author philandering with his daughter's school room-mate, "Little Darling," which was put on at the Biltmore last evening, is undoubtedly your dish. Eric Hatch, a script-writer, author of "Five Days" and "Unexpected Uncle," thought up this one in a houseboat; and Tom Weatherly, man-about-Broadway, has produced it with a gilt-edge setting by Watson Barratt that represents bookcases, fireplace, divan and stairway leading to the second floor.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- There will be no new tax legislation considered by the Senate Finance Committee until after next March 15, its chairman, Senator George of Georgia, said today.
The deer-hunting season opens in the Adirondacks on Sunday, and the date also marks the beginning of small game hunting on Long Island.

Miss Byrd Elliot, violinist, gave a well-constructed program last night in Carnegie Hall. It embraced a Purcell Suite, the Sibelius concerto, Brahms's G major Sonata for violin and piano, and short pieces by Mozart, Scarlatti-Heifetz, Handel-Flesch, Hummel-Heifetz.

Arthur O. Dietz, president of Commercial Investment Trust, Inc., has leased a furnished apartment in 50 East Seventy-seventh Street through William A. White Sons. The same broker also reported leasing apartments to Leonard H. Leslie in 35 East Seventy-fifth Street, Francisco Murature, in 245 East Seventy-second Street, J. Arthur Adler, in 125 East Fiftieth Street and John A. Toepfer in 230 Central Park South.

In this newspaper today there is published the text of the answer made by The Associated Press to the suit filed recently by Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold charging it with violation of the anti-trust acts. The legal aspects of this suit can safely be left to the lawyers and the courts.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- American householders, already under restrictions as to the use of oil in heating their homes, were asked by the War Production Board today to avoid using gas heaters, kitchen ovens or gas fireplaces to supplement residential heating.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- "Four-figure'' air raids on Germany, such as the thousand-plane bombings of Cologne and Bremen, will be less "infrequent" in the future, Sir Archibald Sinclair, Secretary of State for Air, told a meeting of civil defense workers today.

The story of a telephone call that lifted the veil of mystery which for thirty-nine years has enveloped two persons involved in the adventurous career of the fabulous "Cheiro," alias "Count Hamon," who at the turn of the century was financially and socially the most successful palmist in the history of the occult arts, was unfolded yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

Crisp and stimulating as the invigorating air that greeted New York yesterday morning was the collection that Howard Greer brought in from Holywood and presented at the Astor Hotel. The clothes were lively and full of pep. They had fresh ideas, They demonstrated what a vivid and sound imagination can do with, or in spite of, L-85.

Despite the fact that Congress, in enacting the 1942 Revenue Act, specifically rejected certain tax privilege provisions that would permit public bodies to acquire private utility properties and operate them free of Federal taxes, representatives of the Bonneville Administration are negotiating with the Treasury Department for a special tax exemption that would permit the purchase by a governmental agency of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, it was disclosed yesterday.
CAIRO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Royal Air Force and the British Middle East Command:

Buyer registrations in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 904, which compared with 873 in the preceding week and 620 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's recordings numbered 364, as against 389 for last Tuesday.

Like all other branches of aviation, aircraft manufacturing has always been a highly competitive enterprise. Since the days of the Wright brothers American plane builders have risen or fallen as their research and engineering skills created new and better designs for planes and followed through with the best methods of producing them.

The Chinese Ambassador, Dr. Wei Tao-ming, presented medals of honored merit yesterday to six American doctors and one woman organizer of relief work at the annual meeting of the American Bureau for Medical Aid to China in the home of Dave Hennen Morris a member of the agency's board of directors, at 19 East Seventieth Street.

Emmet J. McCormack, vice president and director of the Moore-McCormack Lines, has been named chairman of the shipowners' and operators' division of the United Seamen's Service campaign for a $6,000,000 sea welfare fund. The service is setting up a worldwide system of clubs and rest homes for officers and men of the merchant marine.

Opening prices on many important raw furs for the new collecting season to begin shortly are likely to range from l0 to 25 per cent or more under the levels of December, 1941, when first sales of fresh goods were made last year, according to a market analysis issued yesterday by the United Fur Brokers.

A suit by three stockholders of the Cities Service Company to compel the estate of the late Henry L. Doherty to account for moneys allegedly entrusted to Mr. Doherty by the Cities Service Securities Company was disclosed yesterday on a motion by the estate to dismiss the suit for failure to state a cause of action.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:
ARLINGTON, Mass., Oct. 27 (AP) -- "Jackie" Shea, 5 years old, has a letter he never will part with -- a letter that said "if I don't get back -----"

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 - Albert W. Hawkes, Republican candidate for United States Senator, in his final campaign drive through Essex County today discussed the place of the United States in the postwar world and declared that "when peace comes, today's global warfare must be translated into global welfare through a greater economic production and a wider and more generous distribution of what is produced than has ever before been achieved."
The Bell Aircraft Corporation has declared a year-end dividend of $2 a share, payable on Nov. 25 to stock of record of Nov. 10. The previous payment, in the same amount, was on Dec. 24 of last year.

The Aircraft War Production Council, East Coast, Inc., a nonprofit corporation formed recently by eight major Eastern airplane manufacturers to speed war output by the pooling of resources, announced yesterday that I.S. (Stick) Randall, assistant to the chairman of the board of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., had been appointed general manager of the council.

TRENTON, Oct. 27 -- Senate President I. Grant Scott of Cape May County and Majority Leader George H. Stanger of Cumberland County were blamed today by Governor Charles Edison for the refusal of the Republican-controlled Senate to act yesterday on his bill designed to pave the way for revision of the method of taxing intanglible personal property.

Employes of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel rejected yesterday representation by the New York Hotel Trades Council, A.F. of L., by a vote of 935 to 473. This was the result of an election conducted by the State Labor Relations Board from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. in the Julia Richman High School Annex, 121 East Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that he had instructed his war production leaders to obtain electric power for war plants from the cheapest sources available "consistent with war requirements."

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 -- There is every indication that the battle for Stalingrad is gradually swelling in scale and pitch and that the violence reached in September is being approached again. There is, however, a significant difference. Then the Germans were seeking to broaden their front; now their strategy is to narrow it.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Oct. 27 (U.P.) -- Jack Singer, 28-year-old International News Service correspondent with the Pacific Fleet, whose death as a result of the explosion of a Japanese torpedo while writing a dispatch aboard the aircraft carrier Wasp was revealed by Captain Forrest P. Sherman, had been reported missing for weeks.

Two years ago today the 45,000,000 people of Italy went to war with the 7,000,000 of Greece. More precisely, Mussolini, in what was probably the last important step he took without previously getting Hitler's permission, sent an unprepared Italian army, against the advice of his generals, into Greece.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Princeton, suddenly welcomed among the football-elect by reason of its decidedly convincing victory over Brown last Saturday, settled down to serious work today for what Tad Wieman, head coach, is firmly convinced is apt to be the Tigers' toughest assignment of the season -- Saturday's annual game with Harvard at Cambridge.

Manhattan's football forces, fresh from the surprising victory over Duquesne last Saturday, dug in at Manhattan Field yesterday and began pointing all their guns for the clash with Villanova at Philadelphia Sunday. The Jaspers reviewed the films of the Duquesne upset before going out on the field.

A new program of war courses, introduced into the school system this Fall, has modified the rules for graduation of all high school students, Board of Education officials disclosed yesterday. Thirteen subjects, dealing with war industries or war activities, have been added to the curriculum.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Arnold Pressburger, United Artists producer, announced today that he has borrowed Anna Lee from RKO for the leading feminine role in "Never Surrender" with Brian Donlevy and Walter Brennan. The film, which deals with the Gestapo's persecution of the Czechs, will go before the cameras Friday with Fritz Lang producing and directing for Pressburger.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Mosquito bombers today made a series of stabbing attacks on objectives on the coast of Europe from Denmark to Belgium. Shipyards at the German port of Flensburg, at the east end of the Danish frontier, were bombed by these high-speed aircraft flying at low level, the Air Ministry announced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Atlantic Charter, among other things, declares that the signatory governments "respect the right of all peoples to choose the form of government under which they will live; and they wish to see sovereign rights and self-government restored to those who have been forcibly deprived of them."

According to a Berlin broadcast that was recorded in New York by The United Press, the German High Command declared yesterday that the Allies in Egypt "with strong new forces attempted in vain to penetrate into the German and Italian tank army yesterday" [Monday], but that the battle "is progressing with unabated fierceness."
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 27 (UP) -Senator Byrd of Virgipda, a member of the Senate Naval Affairs Committee, charged here today that some phases of American censorship had proved "very foolish and unwise."

Antony Tudor's "Gala Performance" had its first and only presentation of the season by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, with Miriam Golden, Nora Kaye and Karen Conrad in its three chief roles. It is a gay and biting little burlesque of the old-fashioned ballet and the everlasting psychology of the ballerina, and it should never be left out of the repertory for so long.

The Associated Press filed its answer yesterday in the United States District Court here to the Federal Government's civil suit charging it with violation of the Sherman and Clayton Anti-Trust Acts. It denied that it was a monopoly and charged that the government's construction of these statutes would abridge the freedom of the press, as guaranteed in the First Amendment to the Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The text of the salary regulations issued today by James F. Byrnes was as follows:

The Roosevelt Distinguished Service Medals, which are awarded every year on the anniversary of Theodore Roosevelt's birth, were given last night to Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War; Booth Tarkington and Dr. Rufus M. Jones, founder of the American Friends Service Committee, at a dinner at Theodore Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

Retroactive wage and salary increases affecting principal subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation, amounting to $14,600,000 for the first nine months of 1942, were equivalent to $1.68 a share for the common stock without adjusting tax items, it devolves from the report for the third quarter made public yesterday by Irving S. Olds, chairman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Curtailment of newsprint, copper, zinc, printing ink and other materials necessary to newspaper publication was discussed today with officials of the War Production Board by its newspaper advisory committee after the twenty-four newspaper publishers belonging to it had been told by Donald M. Nelson that a curtailment of newspaper operations was unavoidable.

In addition to developing a comprehensive program for wartime operations, Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., is also preparing for the post-war period and will be ready to release a broad promotional campaign the minute the conflict is over, Howard P. Hildreth, manager of sales promotion and advertising of the company, yesterday told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executive Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- Showing respect for Hank Mazur's punting as well as his open field running, the Pennsylvania coaches today put Bob Odell, LeRoy Pletz and Bert Stiff through one of the longest kicking drills of the season.

A rumor that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had closed one of the city's local draft boards as the result of a fist fight between a clergyman and a member of the board was denounced yesterday as "vicious, fantastic and Axis-inspired" by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service here.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 28 -- The Red Army stopped a new German offensive in a workers' settlement and factory area of northern Stalingrad yesterday after a successful Russian counter-attack had driven the Nazis out of South Stalingrad on to the bleak steppe below the city, the Russians said today.

Representatives of the United Mine Workers and of soft coal operators of the Appalachian Joint Wage Conference began yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore to devise plans to put into effect the six-day week for 400,000, bituminous miners as requested by Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and solid fuel administrator.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 27 -- United States Senator William H. Smathers, Democratic candidate for re-election, completed a campaign tour of Union County tonight with a reiteration of the statement that his Republican opponent, Albert W.
