Hawkes, former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, would be "out of step" with a "win-the-war" Congress that was needed to assure "real unity and loyal support of our Commander in Chief."
As far as I know there has never been a war in which nobody got hurt, and it may be that I am just one of the unavoidable casualties, I and a million or so.

Rarely, indeed, does Stout Steve Owen lose his temper, but when the portly coach of the New York Football Giants does, uncomfortable is the mildest word that best describes those around him at the time. The unusual happened yesterday morning when the Giants reported for practice at the Polo Grounds.

A Brooklyn team defeated the Mayfair Bridge Club team of New York last last for the metropolitan contract bridge team-of-four championship, bringing to a close the tournament which began Oct. 18 at the Park Central Hotel here.

The three young Bronx girls who ran away from their homes Sunday night were still missing yesterday, but the $7,500 that 15-year-old Rose Amalfitano took from a closet in her home at 286 East 149th Street is being sent back to her parents.

One of the biggest shocks to Eastern form players jolted them at Empire City yesterday when an obscure selling plater from Detroit and Thistle Down, Bon Jour, dominated the running of the Hannibal Handicap to win easily by three lengths.

I HAVE constantly been horrified to find historians accepting political speeches as statements of fact. Cicero's denunciations of Catiline and Mark Antony are no more sober historical documents than the campaign speeches of American politicians." So writes Mr. H.J. Haskell, author of "The New Deal in Old Rome," editor of The Kansas City Star and long an acute and disillusioned student of political and politicians, in his introduction to his excellent biography, "This Was Cicero."*

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 27 -- Six Nazis, including three women and one adherent of Spanish Generalissimo Francisco Franco, were arrested yesterday because they shouted "Down with Mexico! Long live Germany! Long live Franco!" in Xochimilco, a small town fifteen miles from Mexico City, the newspaper Nacional reported today.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- United States Navy Day was observed here today by a parade and a broadcast to America by Admiral Harold R. Stark, commander of American naval forces in European waters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Roosevelt conferred today with Sir George Gater, British Permanent Under-Secretary of State of the Colonies, who is chief of the British Section of the Anglo-American Caribbean Commission, and Charles W. Taussig, chairman of the American section.

A late spurt of trade buying pushed quotations of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to their best levels and final net gains of 6 to 8 points yesterday. The market moved narrowly throughout the rather quiet session as trade price-fixing orders were matched by scattered hedge selling and liquidation of the distant months by mills against receipt of spot cotton.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 27 -- Argentine exports to European neutrals for the first nine months of this year show a considerable increase over the corresponding period last year, owing chiefly to the fact that Swedish ships that were immobilized in their home ports for a considerable part of last year have now begun operating again.
The adolescent girl is largely responsible for the 10 per cent rise in juvenile delinquency in New York City in the last year, Justice Stephen S. Jackson of Children's Court asserted yesterday.

Extended passing and signal drills featured yesterday's two-hour workout on Fordham Field as Coach Earl Walsh began intensive preparations for the annual game with the Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's on Saturday at the Polo Grounds. It was the first practice for the Rams since last Thursday and, while contact work was barred, Walsh drove the boys at a rapid clip.

Baby carriages for twins must not be made, according to the War Production Board, despite appeals by mothers and dealers and one manufacturer's offer to count such carriages as two in adhering to its metal quota. The carriage proposed would require twelve pounds of steel, whereas the limitation order, restricting producers to the number of units made in the year ended June 30, 1941, permits the use of only six pounds in each.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, took a hand yesterday in the New York Gubernatorial campaign by calling upon the 1,500,000 members of the A.F. of L. in this State to vote for John J. Bennett Jr. and all his associates on the Democratic ticket as "the real, true, loyal friends of labor."

VICHY, France, Oct. 27 (U.P.) -Strong reinforcements have arrived at the strategic West African base of Dakar, whose defenses were inspected last week by Admiral Francois Darlan, the official French Information Agency reported tonight.

Unless systematic saving out of current income is practiced by the entire nation, inflation cannot be avoided and many people will experience hardship in paying their taxes, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury John L. Sullivan told delegates to the forty-ninth annual meeting of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, which began its two-day session yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Colonel Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, declared last night that although training schools and production lines are now turning out men, ships and machines at an ever faster rate, it still is not fast enough to do "properly our vast world-wide job of patrolling, of escorting and of fighting on all the seas."

Firms handling goods connected with the war program were among the lessees of business space figuring in yesterday's rental reports. Several tenants in various parts of the city also were listed as taking additional space for expansion purposes.

The birth rate in this city again reached a new high for the year in the week ended last Saturday, when 2,889 babies were born, it was reported yesterday by George T. Palmer, deputy city health commissioner. The total had not been surpassed in any week since June, 1923.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The extent to which the war effort has caused movements of civilian population in the two years since the 1940 census, resulting in losses in more than half the States and rapid gains in a few of the others, was disclosed today by the Bureau of the Census.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia recalled yesterday that Captain Forrest P. Sherman, commander of the airplane carrier Wasp, which was sunk Sept. 15 in the South Pacific, had served with him on the Joint Permanent Defense Board until two months ago, when the captain was assigned to command the carrier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -Interstate Commerce Commission put under strict control today the movement of coal by railroad to ports on Lakes Michigan, Ontario and Erie and at New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Hampton Roads, Va.

With the first real freeze of the season predicted for early today in this area, the Weather Bureau yesterday was permitted to announce the fact in advance on the radio as a means of warning farmers, gardeners, householders and others who might be affected.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 27 -- Here in this town which has recently become the home of the largest training school for the Women's Naval Reserve. Navy Day had a special significance. The town, the Waves and Smith College gathered to pay tribute to that Navy which has become so integral a part of this community's life.

Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, sent a telegram yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES in which he declared his feeling that "the nation owes the newspapers a debt of gratitude for the invaluable service they have rendered through the newspapers' United Scrap Metal Drive."

The aircraft carrier Wasp went to her death off the Solomon Islands last Sept. 15, the waters about her sprayed with exploding shells, detonated by the fierce fires that destroyed her, Lieutenant (junior grade) Martin S. Erlanger said yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- More than 4,000,000 German soldiers had been killed or wounded by August, President Eduard Benes of the Czechoslovak Government-in-Exile said today.

A report that big league baseball might scramble the American and National Leagues into "Eastern" and "Western" omelets next season in order to combat the wartime transportation problem raised a storm of scornful comment from diamond officials yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, issued stringent new regulations today designed to hold salaries to an individual limit of $25,000 in 1943 after payment of Federal income taxes, customary charitable contributions, life insurance premiums and fixed obligations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27 -- Captain Don Forte put in full-time duty with his Harvard mates today and worked well all the way. It now seems possible that he, rather than Cummings, will be on the right wing against Princeton.

Lavish use of color and originality were the dominating features of the demonstration of "what can be done to unpainted furniture and how to do it" which opened yesterday at Abraham Straus, Fulton Street, Brooklyn.
The way the police told the story yesterday, Frank Erickson, most unpopular bookmaker in the book of Mayor La Guardia, has been deprived of the services of his most trusted "pay-off" man.
LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Britain withdrew military deferment today for younger men in about 150 trades nonessential or of minor importance to the war effort.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27 -- Coach Howie Odell of Yale worked for speed and power on the attack today in a long scrimmage of the varsity against the reserves. The running of the freshman backs, Stan Weiner and Bob Pickett, who made their varsity debuts in the surprise victory over Dartmouth, continued to please the coaches.

With the hulks of eleven other stanch American ships the carrier Wasp now rests beneath the waters that wash Guadalcanal. As fast and fine a fighting craft as there was in our Navy, her destruction adds a heavy burden to the loss of the Lexington and Yorktown.

Earnings of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., for the six months ended on Aug. 1 have been revised to give effect to a reduction of $236,000 in taxes based on the 42 per cent rate enacted in the 1942 revenue bill, Jack I. Straus, president, informed stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting.
A sixty-day drive to raise $1,000,000 in ibis city will be opened by the Greek War Relief Association today, which is the second anniversary of Mussolini's invasion of Greece.

Nathan Goldsmith, 44 years old, president and treasurer of the Manhattan Coffee and Sugar Company, Inc., of 25 Division Place, Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Jacob A. Visel in the Federal Building, Brooklyn, charged with telling the Office of Price Administration that his company had only 4,000 pounds of sugar when it had 517,000, which was to be put into the "black market," a United States attorney said.

The Japanese broadcast yesterday their version of a big naval and air battle fought on Monday in the Solomon Islands area, claiming the sinking of six United States warships -- four aircraft carriers, one battleship and a ship of unidentified type.

A simplified version of the frequently mentioned layaway plan for post-war selling has been adopted by the Blackstone Corporation, Jamestown, N.Y., which promises priority on its electrical appliances in the post-war period to customers why buy a war bond and inform the company of this fact.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 28 -- Wendell Willkie's broadcast to the United States about his visit to the Middle East, Russia and China was generally hailed warmly here by the press this morning, but his remarks that there was no longer any British Empire and that the colonial possessions were only remnants of it evoked in some quarters regret that he had not visited India and some British colonies on his travels.

The war news returned yesterday as the dominating market influence, and recent buyers hurried to take profits. Values were reduced 1 to 2 points in the morning although the list steadied sufficiently in late trading to lift prices from the lows of the session.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Destruction of key American aluminum plants to cripple this country's light metals industry was the chief objective of eight Nazi saboteurs landed with a huge store of explosives on the east coast by U-boats in June.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The defense of Edward Haight, 17 years old, of Stamford, Conn., in his trial for the murders of Margaret Lynch, 7, and her sister Helen, 8, will be based on insanity, his attorney notified District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher in Westchester County Court today.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, last night accused Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican rival, of injecting racial and religious issues into the political campaign. The charge was made at a Democratic rally in Staten Island as Mr. Bennett opened his New York City drive for votes.

With a limitation of markets in prospect for the brewing industry as the result of a proposed ban on cross-hauling of beer, the industry is now preparing a brief on the subject and will submit it to the Office of Defense Transportation in about two weeks, it was learned here yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The stock markets were busy again today after yesterday's big turnover. The South American rails and the home industrials were particularly active.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The War Manpower Commission announced today a program for ending the critical manpower shortage in the dairy, livestock and poultry industries which, if made fully effective, would constitute a virtual freezing of employes in these occupations.

The six-story building containing thirty-five apartments and nine stores on the southwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 122d Street has been sold by Mrs. Emma Ludecke to the Kutudis Corporation for $20,000 above a mortgage of $112,100 held by the New York State Teachers Retirement Fund.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 -- Mention of Major Gen. Alexei Rodimtseff's Guards has appeared frequently in descriptions of the battle for Stalingrad and today a writer in the army newspaper Red Star reveals the crucial role played by this unit at the end of September, when the Germans were forcing their way to the Volga and had seized Iron Hill, which dominates the city and a long stretch of the river.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- This was London's day with Mrs. Roosevelt. In the morning she saw how this city's civilians have been trained for front line fighting against air attack and watched demonstrations of fire fighting and rescue work.

Reassembling his regulars for more work on a defense which has been growing more porous every Saturday, Coach Lou Little started preparing Columbia at Baker Field yesterday for this week's meeting with Cornell.
LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's greeting to King Victor Emmanuel today as broadcast from Berlin, follows:

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Albert W. Hawkes, Republican nominee for the United States Senate, dismissed today as politically inspired a statement by Chairman Ernest W. McFarland of the Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures that a committee inquiry "very strongly indicates" that Mr. Hawkes spent in his primary campaign more than the $50,000 permitted.

J.B. Partridge, who through the years has had success with horses of varying grades, seldom has done better with any thoroughbred than with Minee-Mo, the 5-year-old gelding that scored yesterday at Empire City. A crowd of 13,442 saw Minee-Mo dash home first by three lengths in the Anchors Aweigh Purse at a mile and a sixteenth, which some had thought was too far for him.

Rationing, just now coming really close to most Americans, is an old story to both our Allies and enemies. With this fact in mind the International Documents Service of Columbia University Press has issued "Wartime Rationing and Consumption," a report of the Economic Intelligence Service of the League of Nations that considers rationing as a world-wide phenomenon.

In the five counties of this city there are no fewer than 223 candidates for the State Legislature in this year's election. Obviously, it is impossible for any newspaper to attempt to examine adequately the individual claims of all these candidates.

The United States must give diplomatic recognition to Genera Charles de Gaulle's French National Committee and let the Fighting French leader participate in the strategic conduct of the war as a full-fledged ally, Walter Lippmann, writer and columnist, declared last night.

THE war news is enough to make everybody agree that it's very warm for October. Aside from that, this observer just sent off a letter to a marine lieutenant. The address was "c/o Postmaster, San Francisco, Calif." But the marine lieutenant isn't in San Francisco by a long shot.

Two war correspondents who lost their lives recently were honored in a resolution adopted by the Overseas Press Club of America at its weekly luncheon yesterday at the Lotos Club, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street The men were Byron Darnton, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent killed in New Guinea on Oct. 18, and Jack Singer, International News Service, killed aboard the aircraft carrier Wasp on Sept. 15.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Choice steers and yearlings advanced to new highs for the last year and longer in the cattle market today on gains ranging to 25 cents a hundred pounds. The strength throughout the cattle section was attributed primarily to the need for dressed beef. Eastern interests were an important factor in the trade.

TRENTON, Oct. 28 -- Senator William H. Smathers carried his complaint against the campaign expenditures of Albert W. Hawkes to the United States Attorney General today, and in a speech here tonight declared the election of his Republican opponent would be hailed by the prohibitionists as a victory for their cause.

The number of manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers who made a profit during the first half of 1942 was far in excess of those reporting profits in 1940, according to results of a survey released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. Eighty-nine per cent of manufacturers reporting registered profits, 92 per cent of the wholesalers and 83 per cent of the retailers.
From slacks to evening clothes, Russeks Fifth Avenue rounded out a fashion pageant yesterday. The occasion was the Wednesday fashion luncheon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the end of last week amounted to 79,545,000 barrels, an increase of 589,000 over the 78,955,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these supplies were 82,390,000 barrels.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 29 -- German troops have scored a 200-yard advance in one sector of the North Stalingrad factory area, but they have been slaughtered to the last man in another sector and their losses for one day inside the city totaled more than twelve companies of infantry -- 2,400 men -- the Soviet High Command announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The textiles continued prominent in an otherwise quiet stock market today, the reason being the speculative demand for low priced shares with post-war prospects. Gilt-edged issues were easier where changed with the 3 1/2 per cent war loan down 1/8 point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- -Speaker Rayburn, in a speech tonight over the Blue Network of the National Broadcasting System, asserted that Congress had passed ungrudgingly and promptly the legislation needed to wage the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Declaring that haphazard and excessive recruiting of doctors for the armed services has led to a dangerous health emergency among the civilian population of the country, a Senate subcommittee studying manpower problems recommended urgently today that President Roosevelt, at the earliest possible moment, order a resurvey and reallocation of medical personnel.
In a race against Winter weather, the Federal Government seized yesterday 2,700 gross tons of abandoned street car rails in Queens County.

The second anniversary of the Italian attack on Greece was observed yesterday afternoon with meetings at Freedom House, 32 East Fifty-first Street, and at the headquarters of the Friends of Greece, 52 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Earl Wild, musician, first class, United States Navy, will be the piano soloist when Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony perform George Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" next Sunday, it was announced yesterday. The concert, which will be Toscanini's first radio appearance of the Fall season, will be heard from 5 to 6 P.M. Sunday over WEAF and the NBC network.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 28 -- Two New York owners swept the field today in the opening stake of the nineteenth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association, held in the covers of the Ingham Hill Game Farm at Saybrook Point.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins, denouncing what he termed an "attempt to lash and browbeat a law-abiding citizen into 'patriotism,' "granted yesterday an injunction against the picketing of an uptown drug store which had refused to close at 11 P.M. in a movement described by the New York Retail Druggists Association as a "crusade nation-wide in scope" for earlier closing as a wartime measure.

BEACON, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Ferdinand A. Hoyt, Democratic and American Labor party candidate for Representative in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, tonight characterized as "fishy" the explanation offered by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., his Republican opponent, of the charge made that in 1939 he had received $3,100 from alleged pro-Nazi sources.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Greece has set the example that "every one of us must follow until the despoilers of freedom everywhere have been brought to their just doom," President Roosevelt said tonight in a message to Cimon P. Diamantopoulos, the Greek Ambassador.

Agnes de Mille joined the Ballet Theatre as guest artist last night in the season's first presentation of her "Three Virgins and a Devil" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The work is no longer a novelty, but it is none the less welcome, for its humors are lusty and its performance is full of vitality when Miss de Mille is there to whip it up.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- The Japanese consider their campaign of conquest in the Netherlands Indies completed and have abolished the blackout and nightly curfews, a Dutch infantry officer who escaped from Java reported today.

To the Secret Service of the Treasury Department, he is Alex Kerr; to the police of the Flushing precinct, he is Edward Wellman; to both, he is an excellent ice-skater, who on Tuesday night virtually glided into custody as an escaped counterfeiting suspect.

While admitting there is no authority in the General Maximum Price Regulation which would enable it to "smoke out" hoarded stocks of nylon hosiery in time for Christmas shoppers, OPA officials said yesterday that inventories could be checked as part of its enforcement of pricing regulations.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Fresh proof of the far-reaching effect of the Royal Air Force raids on Germany has been found by the British, who today pointed out that only forty-eight hours ago a decree was issued in the Reich giving special priorities on a long list of consumer goods, indispensable for a simple way of life, particularly with a view to meeting the needs of persons whose property has been destroyed in air raids."

Little by little the war comes closer to the folks at home; for a few, as yet, it comes in sorrowful notifications to the "next of kin"; for the rest in little deprivations -- rationing of gasoline, of sugar, of fuel oil, and now of coffee; inability to buy tires, automobiles, bicycles and a long list of articles made of metal or rubber.
HONOLULU, Oct. 28 -- The fighting in the Solomons is getting tougher all the time, said four Navy fighter pilots who passed through Honolulu today en route to the States for more planes.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt took time out this afternoon from her sight-seeing and fact-finding excursions in England and her role of honored guest to hold an informal "court" of her own before going to see "Flare Path," a play about the Royal Air Force.
CAIRO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Royal Air Force and the British Middle East Command:
So many people are closing big country houses for the duration that I wondered if one of your readers has a pool table to offer 250 orphans.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- The Japanese were disclosed today to have destroyed or damaged at least ten grounded fighters besides the previously announced "several transports" in raids on American airfields in Assam in Northeast India, but their attempts to smash these bases of the United States Army Bombers and Ferry Service to China were regarded here as futile.

The Appellate Division was asked yesterday by attorneys for William Solomon, former Tammany leader of the Seventeenth Assembly District, North, and Charles H. Mullens, former Assistant State Controller, to reverse the convictions and dismiss the indictments of the two men on charges of accepting $28,000 in bribes from the now defunct Burland Printing Company, in connection with the award of printing contracts.
The soldier vote from New York State will total approximately 40,000 out of the 400,000 men in the armed forces from the State who would otherwise be eligible to vote, it was indicated yesterday.

J.F. Hartlieb, president of the Continental Can Company, announced yesterday in a consolidated statement covering the twelve months ended with September net earnings of $5,353,762 after deducting $7,943,653 for depreciation and estimate income and excess-profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Tea drinkers are safe from rationing unless coffee rationing results in an unexpected big shift to tea-drinking, Deputy Price Administrator O'Leary said. He indicated, however, that OPA would have a tea rationing program should a "very bad shortage develop."

A completely new system for the control and allocation of materials in the war program will be put into effect for the second quarter of 1943, Henry P. Nelson, chief of system planning for the War Production Board, reported yesterday at the annual luncheon of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Hearing on the application of the Long Island, the New York Central and ten other railroads for an increase in intrastate commutation fares being held in the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn before Commissioner Haden Alldredge, designated by the Interstate Commerce Commission as hearing master, was scheduled to come to a close today.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 -- Sixty-nine horses raced for all they were worth at Pimlico today, but the seventieth ran around the track unopposed and took all the glory and the largest purse.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Liquidation was on in rye futures again today, with prices dipping around 2 3/4 cents a bushel to a new low level since October, 1941, before the selling movement ran its course. The December sold down to 61 cents, where shorts bought and a moderate rally developed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- The Radio Corporation Of America and its subsidiary, the National Broadcasting Company, today issued a general denial of the charges brought against them by the Mutual Broadcasting System in a suit in the United States District Court of Chicago last Jan. 11.

By penalizing proper merchandise preparations by many stores, the type of inventory limitation proposed by the WPB will bring about the shutdown of many manufacturers without benefiting either the consumer or the small merchant, according to an analysis covering merchandise inventories and the supply of civilian goods made for the Retailers Advisory Committee by Walter Rothschild, president of Abraham Straus.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Frank Leahy, head football coach at Notre Dame, returned to the campus today after seventeen days in bed at St. Mary's Hospital, Rochester, Minn., where he underwent treatment for a back ailment.

Corporations with payrolls which include persons whose net income from salaries after the deductions permitted by the order issued by James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, appear to exceed $25,000, are making a close study of the order with a view to putting its provisions into operation.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The North American Light and Power Company, asking dismissal of a claim for more than $20,000,000 by its subsidiary, the Illinois Iowa Power Company, questioned today the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission in such matters.

Valuable French carpets of modern design removed from the French liner Normandie when that vessel was converted into the U.S.S. Lafayette, now undergoing salvage operations, were among the articles sold at auction yesterday by the United States Customs Service in the Appraiser's Stores, 201 Varick Street.

After spending two nights away from home, the 3-year-old prospective policeman who tangled rush-hour traffic last Monday night by blowing a toy whistle at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, was claimed yesterday at the shelter of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, 2 East 105th Street by his mother, Mrs. Emily Jensen of 125 West Sixtieth Street.

The Office of Price Administration by extending until 5 P.M. today the period for registration of fuel oil dealers and until Nov. 6 that for filing of consumer forms, averted yesterday a situation which might have deprived thousands of fuel oil users of a large part of their rations.

Although the net sales of the General Motors Corporation for the first nine months of 1942 amounted to $1,503,880,455 and were beginning to catch up with 1941 volume, which was $1,818,352,012 for the same period, earnings for the common stock were one-half those for the first nine months of last year, according to the third-quarter report made public yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation.

A performance of much prevailing liveliness and excellence of Johann Strauss's "Fledermaus" -- under the title of "Rosalinda" -- was given by the New Opera Company last night in the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. The opera was sung in English, in an Americanized translation of the Reinhardt version first heard in the Twenties, with huge success, in Berlin, and Mr. Reinhardt had taken a hand in the production.

Declaring the crisis in India is a grave threat both to India's security and to the war program of the United Nations, a new national organization called the American Round Table on India urged yesterday that President Roosevelt attempt "to bring about a conciliation between th British Government and the Indian groups."

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- War Minister F. M. Forde asserted today that Hanson W. Baldwin, military editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, had displayed "complete ignorance of everything Australian" in a recent article in that newspaper.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 -- A Congressional committee laid the blame today for the crash of an airliner, killing its twelve occupants, to an air rendezvous between the pilot of an Army bomber and the co-pilot of the commercial ship. The two planes were in a collision Friday night near Palm Springs.

BUFFALO, Oct. 28 -- Thomas E. Dewey pledged the Republican party here tonight to a "forward-looking" progressive State Administration and outlined a five-point labor program designed to bring industry and labor within New York into "closer cooperation and understanding."

Unsatisfied with the results thus far in the drive to procure 600,000 used typewriters for the Army and Navy, the War Production Board will soon start an intensive publicity campaign stressing the urgent necessity for the relinquishing of machines by business concerns, it was learned yesterday.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Penn's football squad, occupied with the serious business of preparing for Army's invasion of Franklin Field on Saturday, is already working before crowds. As the players arrived for today's session they threaded their way through long queues of ticket seekers outside the offices of the Athletic Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress and former Director of the Office of Facts and Figures, has resigned, or has suggested his resignation, as assistant director of the Office of War Information, it was learned in reliable quarters today.

In the office above his fish market on a narrow, shop-crowded street in lower Manhattan a mussel "specialist" talked with enthusiasm about his favorite shellfish. Mussels are meaty, fine-flavored, delicious -- and so cheap," he said with emphasis, and then went on to describe their popularity among people of French and Italian heritage.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, disapproving the proposed minimum capital requirements amendment of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., drafted its own rule today, prescribing for brokers and dealers subject to its jurisdiction a maximum ratio of aggregate indebtedness to net capital of 2,000 per cent.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Ration banking, designed to simplify the nation's rationing procedure, met a "fine reception" on its inception in the Albany-Schenectady-Troy area today, Lee S. Buckingham, New York State Director of the Office of Price Administration, reported tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 28 -- A feature of the war in the air over the Egyptian battle area yesterday was the skill and good fortune of the United States fighter group -- skill in the way the pilots fought and good fortune in their getting excellent enemy targets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Japanese losses in troops and equipment in ground fighting on Guadalcanal Island since last Friday (Solomon Islands time) "have been very heavy as compared to our own," the Navy announced today.
BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 28 -- Still licking wounds from the violent British bombings of the weekend, a subdued Italian people today observed the twentieth anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 28 -- New York State, with a quota of 8,000 and until Dec. 31 to meet it, is 36 per cent behind its goal of supplying physicians to the armed services, Dr. Henry W. Cave, chairman of Procurement and Assignment of the War Manpower Commission in the Second Service Command, reported today at a meeting of the Second District Branch, New York State Medical Society, at the Garden City Hotel.

Wartime management of industry was sharply criticized here last night by Dr. Harry Arthur Hopf, head of the Hopf Institute of Management, at the monthly meeting of the Litho Club of New York at the Builders Club. The War Production Board, he asserted, is still without real power and adequate experience of the kind that counts.

AT AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Sept 30 (Delayed) -- Little evidences of fifth column activity or work of hired enemy agents has been found in the course of the United Nations counter-offensive in the Solomons.

Reporting yesterday on operations for the first nine months of this year, A.W. Robertson, chairman of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, informed stockholders that the income before provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes amounted to $78,513,719, compared with $45,302,297 for the 1941 period.

The scope of Federal aid in wartime child care is "definitely limited," Mrs. Florence Kerr, assistant to the Federal Works Administrator, declared last night in explaining the exact terms on which the Lanham Act and WPA projects might be helpful to a local community.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 28 -- Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla described the American Army as "the best equipped in the world," according to the press today. Senor Padilla gave an interview to the press to explain once more why Mexican citizens residing in the United States were being drafted into the United States Army.

Not only are women expected to be "the backbone of industry" before long, but training programs are being constantly expanded to prepare girls for all types of work, local guidance counselors were told yesterday at a conference on job and training opportunities for the 1943 high school graduate.

A furnished duplex apartment of nine rooms in the building at 812 Park Avenue has been leased by John H. Armand to Nathan Straus, former United States Housing Administrator. Warren Marks Associates were the brokers and Pease Elliman acted as agents for the building.

The report of the Boston Edison Company for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday by James V. Toner, president, shows a net income of $5,312,766, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $2.15 a share on the outstanding capital stock, and compares with a net of $5,623,768, or $2.28 a share, in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1941.

On receipt of a teletype message from the New York police, the Boston police have started a street-to-street search for 15-year-old Rose Amalfitano, who vanished from her home in the Bronx last Sunday with $7,500 in cash which her father had withdrawn from a bank to buy a house.

Simon W. Gerson, Communist campaign manager, points with pride to Madison Square Garden, and well he may. The Communists have once more hired the big hall for their election eve rally and there is not the slightest doubt that they will succeed in filling the hall, as they have always done at political mass meetings and Bolshevist anniversaries.
It is about time American people realized that, in order to win a war and with it an enduring peace, we must be prepared to sacrifice blood, money and time.

The story of a young Norwegian seaman who swam a mile to a raft and aided in rescuing fellow members of his crew after a torpedoing was told here yesterday by Captain James Hunley, master of a small American freighter lost in mid-September in the South Atlantic.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- Walt Disney announced today that he will combine four more of his Latin-American cartoons into a feature-length film to be called "Surprise Package." The picture will include a live-action introduction, a Mexican episode, a Brazilian episode, an Argentine episode and a subject title "The Cold-Blooded Penguin," which deals with the Antarctic bird which migrates to Chile.

Judged merely from the standpoint of pianism, the playing heard from Claudio Arrau at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall merited superlative praise. Few are the keyboard artists able to command the wide variety of remarkable color effects at the Chilean pianist's disposal, or possessed of such perfect control of ravishing tone.

American and Foreign Power ] The American and Foreign Pew-i er Company, Inc., announced yesterday the declaration of dividends! of 90 cents a share on the $6 preferred and $1.05 on the $7 preferred I stocks, boh for payxent Dec. 15. These dividends are on account of accumulations for the quarter end-{ ed on Sept. 30, 1932.

LONDON, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- A Royal Air Force commentator said today that an additional 5 to 10 per cent of Germany's fighter planes had been pinned down in Western Europe and the Mediterranean areas since Summer by Allied air and land offensives and that more than half the Nazi fighter force thus was kept away from the Russian front.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Five Navy fliers, pilots of dive bombers and torpedo planes which attacked Japanese naval forces in the Coral Sea and off the Solomon and Midway Islands, sinking an aircraft carrier, received medals today in ceremonies at the Alameda Naval Air Station.

LONDON, Oct 28 -- Thousands of Czechoslovaks throughout Britain observed the twenty-fourth an niversary of their homeland's independence today with solemn religious services in twenty-eight cities and towns and men and women pledged themselves anew to continue to fight and work for their country's liberation from the Nazi oppressors.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Steve Vasilakos, White House peanut vendor for the last thirty-three years, today observed the second anniversary of Italy's unprovoked attack upon his native Greece by going into the war bond business with the slogan:

Myron S. Short, executive vice president of the Buffalo Savings Bank, was elected president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York at the concluding session yesterday of the association's forty-ninth annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- In a drastic move designed to assure that the installation of copper in buildings will be cut to the absolute minimum, the War Production Board today issued orders barring the purchase, sale, delivery and use of copper for such purposes.

The Dodgers continued to show enthusiasm in preparing for their National League contest with Cleveland at Ebbets Field Sunday. During yesterday's workout at the Brooklyn ball park the Dodgers went through their plays with a verve and pep that won the admiration of Coach Mike Getto.

Necessarily the lowering of the draft age will create new problems for the colleges. In Philadelphia today presidents and deans representing virtually every large or small college and university in the country will meet, under the aegis of the Association of American Colleges, to consider some of these problems.

The Italian propaganda agency indicated yesterday by a diatribe against Mayor La Guardia's accent and ancestry that his short-wave broadcasts to Italy were getting to the people, according to The United Press.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 28 -- Mrs. James McMillen of the Nassau Country Club was re-elected president of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the annual meeting this morning at the Cedar Creek Club. Other officers chosen were Mrs. Ernest Korber, Cedar Creek, vice president; Mrs. Thomas Rudel, Cedar Creek, secretary, and Mrs. E.G. Richmond, Cherry Valley, treasurer.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 28 -- The German infantry at Stalingrad has reached the end of its tether and no decision can be reached without an extensive regrouping of heavy artillery, it was declared in authorized German circles tonight, according to the Nazi-controlled S.T.B. News Agency.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 28 -- Soldiers from Britain who have suffered the boredom and confinement faced by garrisons at desert and frontier posts man a good part of the ground defenses of Malta.

A dinner of the writers' organization, the P.E.N. Club, by long tradition a polite, semi-formal periodic banding together, developed inexorably step by step last night into a wide open shouting, table-pounding discussion.

OTTAWA, Oct. 28 -- All waste of money and manpower in government departments and in military administration must be cut to the minimum by order of Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley and the Controller of Government Office Economies.

Trade papers, which suffered linage declines because large manufacturers withheld campaigns to distributors and dealers while they were converting to war work, have now reversed their downward trend, reports yesterday indicated. In most instances their linage is still running below a year ago, but at least they have stopped their declines and some are beginning to move ahead.

On the covered deck of the training ship Prairie State in the Hudson River at 135th Street, 470 midshipmen were commissioned as ensigns yesterday morning after four months of training. They were graduated from the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School one week after a record class of 753 had received commissions from the Columbia University division.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Ernst Peter Burger, who with George John Dasch was spared from the death meted out to their six Nazi saboteur companions, described today how they crossed the Atlantic in a German submarine to land on the Long Island and Florida coasts and identified scores of items in the equipment which they brought, intending to wreck the aluminum production of the United States.

Your leading editorial in THE TIMES of Oct. 25 hits the nail squarely on the head in regard to the ineptitudes of Congressional confusion in organization. In this supreme crisis, when the ultimate issue is whether large-scale, democratically governed societies can be run with reasonable efficiency, honesty and justice, we have the constant spectacle of a multitude of overlapping divisions of functions in committees in both houses.

Inability of the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot to obtain sufficient quantities of specific sizes in muslin sheets to fill invitations recently opened may force mills to cut down civilian allotments further in order to supply urgent military needs, it was reported yesterday by leading Worth Street sellers.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- With Ray Zoellner and Frank Dixon setting a record-breaking pace as they finished in a deadlock, the New York University cross-country team defeated Army, 18 to 37, today to give the Violet harriers their twelfth straight victory over a two-year period.

The powers and policies of the Price Adjustment Board have been cleared up and confirmed by certain amendments to the war contracts renegotiation section of the Defense Appropriation Act included in the Revenue Act of 1942, signed a week ago, it was declared yesterday by Maurice Karker, chairman of the PAB, at an informal luncheon given by officers of the New York Ordnance District of the War Department.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- T.P. Wright, deputy director of airplane construction for the United States War Production Board, had a lengthy audience with King George at Buckingham Palace today and told him all about the mission of the United States aeronautical experts, which Mr. Wright heads, now visiting this country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The more than 100 field offices of the Wage and Hour Division will be used by the War Labor Board in the administration of wage stabilization measures, it was announced today by William H. Davis, chairman of the WLB.

Mothers concerned about accepting war jobs and uncertain about plans for their children may receive free advice from New York's seven private family welfare agencies, it was announced today. The seven agencies operate forty-three central and district offices in the five boroughs.
In a letter which you published today Dr. Robert Kempner complained that Germans in the United States are labeled as enemy aliens although Austrians and Italians were liberated from this stigma.
The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission has announced the personnel of its new advisory committee. Eleven are in the group that will represent New York.

The Japanese reported another United States bombing of Hong Kong yesterday -- the third in four days -- and said the attack was made by seven B-25 medium bombers escorted by five P-40 fighters, according to a broadcast recorded by The Associated Press.

LONDON, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- The Vichy radio, making a new threat to coerce French workers into going to Germany, said today that, if they refused, "the line of demarcation between the two zones, now symbolic and temporary, may become real and lasting."

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 28 -- The pilots and crews of American pursuit planes and bombers are not the only ones who risk their lives on bombing raids such as Sunday's at Hong Kong. Two newspaper men, Riley O'Sullivan of The Associated Press and Teddy White of Time and Life, and a 42-year-old Chinese camera man, H. (Newsreel) Wang, accompanied the Hong Kong raiders.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Mgr. Nicholas A. Marnell, founder and only pastor of our Lady of Lourdes Church here, will be buried Friday at the foot of the church shrine. Special permission of town officials and Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh of the Newark Archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church was obtained for the unusual burial, which was one of the late pastor's last requests.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Clark Gable, now a bronzed officer in the Army Air Force, stressed "individual discipline" on a nationwide scale as necessary for victory as he spoke for the new officers graduating from the Miami Beach air forces school.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Frankie Sinkwich of Georgia has put two field lengths between himself and Columbia's Paul Governali in their feud for ranking as 1942's leading ground gainer. And Frankie owes much of his success to a fellow who is the target for just a few of his passes, Lamar Davis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Nine rules by which consumers making coffee at home after Nov. 29 can make the ration of one pound every five weeks go further were given today by Paul M. O'Leary, Deputy Administrator of the Office of Price Administration.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Allied bombers, returning to action after a two-day lay-off, have struck two more blows in support of American forces on Guadalcanal, hitting at least two Japanese ships at the feeder base of Rabaul and setting fires visible for eighty miles on enemy airdromes in the Northern Solomons, it was announced today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Oct. 29 -- General Douglas MacArthur affirmed in a statement today his gratitude for "unanimous" support in Australia and declared he held no personal political ambitions.

Taxes must be paid. War bonds must be bought. We must curtail even our use of necessities. Moreover, about one-half of our doctors and surgeons must join the armed forces if we are to raise an army of 9,500,000. Yet if the battle against cancer lags, the result will be disastrous.

Having recovered from an attack of pneumonia, Gilbert Miller got back to his office on Tuesday and immediately swung into action, the immediate result being the choice of Monday night, Nov. 30, and the Belasco as the time and place for the opening of "Lifeline."

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28 -- Charles P. Taft, assistant director, Office of Defense, Health and Welfare Service, told the American Public Health Association today that the shortage of doctors, as the result of the great demands made on our medical personnel by the armed services, now constitutes "the most serious handicap" to the government's general health and sanitation program.

Dr. Willis Rodney Whitney, vice president in charge of research of the General Electric Company since 1928, has won the 1943 John Fritz Medal, it was announced yesterday, "for distinguished research, both as an individual investigator and as an outstanding and inspiring administrator of pioneering enterprise, coordinating pure science with the service of society through industry."
Coach Earl Walsh sent his first and second Fordham elevens through more than an hour of scrimmage against the reserves yesterday on Rose Hill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- An application which may prove to be the pattern of many to come was made to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Santa Fe Transportation Company, which asked permission to issue and transfer to its parent, the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, common stock and a note to pay off $1,298,000 advanced on open account.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The Stars and Stripes, the newspaper of the United States Armed Forces in the European theatre of operations, will blossom out Monday as a full-fledged daily to be read by thousands of Americans in the British Isles with eagerness matched only by letters from home.
"You've got to shop through yourself, for some one else," the teacher told the class yesterday and in those words lay a real challenge.

All sinkings of major United States naval vessels reported to the Navy Department up to noon yesterday have been announced to the public, Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, said last night in an address in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The stock market continued yesterday to exhibit uneasiness over the Pacific situation. Selling was again not pressing, but there was much hesitation among buyers. Volume on the Stock Exchange dropped to the second smallest amount since the start of the month, as transfers totaled only 496,950 shares against 628,640 shares on Tuesday.

VICHY, France, Oct. 28 -- One of the final scenes in Admiral Francois Darlan's North African inspection trip occurred at Mers el-Khebir, where in the cemetery of the Algerian port the Chief of Vichy's Armed Forces paid official tribute to the sailors in the French Navy who were killed in the British attack on the French fleet July 3, 1940.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- For some time there has been a feeling here, especially among Conservatives who sincerely believe in the British Empire as a force for progress and peace, that Britain has been hiding her light under a bushel too long.

A small United States freighter attacked by Nazi torpedo planes off the North Cape of Norway managed to make its way into a Russian harbor in a damaged condition, but was subsequently sunk by a U-boat near Bear Island as she was attempting to return to this country, it was disclosed yesterday by a survivor after the Navy had announced the loss of the ship.
WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES, in Egypt, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- American airmen have downed fifteen Axis planes and damaged many others since the start of the present Allied land offensive in Egypt.

It began twenty years ago with the March on Rome, a parade of swaggering youth so much in the mood of Italian grand opera of the cloak-and-dagger type that nobody took it seriously. Today it has trampled over Europe from the coasts of Brittany to the banks of the Volga.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Sixteen persons were killed and more than a score were injured, several critically, today when a Detroit Street Railways motorbus, jammed to its doors with school children office workers and factory employes, was ripped in two by a passenger train.

Director Byrnes's regulations, designed to hold down individual salaries to a top figure of $25,000 in 1943 after payment of Federal income taxes, customary charitable contributions, life insurance premiums and "fixed obligations," do not improve upon the President's original order to accomplish this end.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Tickets for the annual Army-Navy football game, Nov. 28, at the United States Naval Academy's Thompson Stadium, will be restricted to bona fide residents living within a ten-mile radius of Maryland's white-domed colonial State House in Annapolis and to academy personnel.
In your issue of Oct. 21 you print a dispatch from London concerning the behavior of Archduke Albrecht von Habsburg.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, is campaigning like a demagogue, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., the Democratic standard bearer, charged last night in a speech at the Jamaica High School, Queens. Mr. Bennett said his opponent was attempting to be "all things to all men."

The board of directors of United States Steel Corporation authorized on Tuesday the calling for redemption on Dec. 31 of $30,000,000 of the corporation's serial debentures maturing in 1944, 1945, 1946, 1947, 1948 and 1951, it was announced yesterday.

Air raid wardens and members of the City Patrol Corps will be on duty with members of the regular police force Saturday night as a precaution against Halloween vandalism and the destruction or removal of property that would be hard to replace due to war shortages, Police Commissioner Valentine announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Labor, management and farm groups were at odds today with Paul V. McNutt, director of the War Manpower Commission, over his espousal of a National Service Act as well as the program which he announced yesterday for stabilizing the employment of dairy, livestock and poultry workers.

Still seeking some combination that will bolster Columbia's poor defense, Coach Lou Little made two major shifts in his line-up yesterday as the Lions prepared for Cornell's visit to Baker Field Saturday. Little chose Wesley Holden to replace Frank Horvath as starting quarterback, and is converting Bill Sutphen, reserve guard, into a center.

Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, continued last night to demand that Thomas E. Dewey and John J. Bennett Jr., his Republican and Democratic opponents, denounce by name the Christian Front. Mr. Alfange spoke at three meetings in Brooklyn, and over the radio in a separate broadcast.

American submarines were again prowling the coast of Japan and the China Sea yesterday as they have been doing since last December -- and sinking enemy ships. The operations of our submarines have been some of the most successful of the Pacific war, but they are largely unheralded and unsung -- because of the Navy's insistence upon secrecy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The War Production Board, carrying out its policy of clamping down on construction, issued stop orders today affecting seven Far Western power and irrigation projects, including part of Grand Coulee Dam.

"Our thinking and our planning in the future must be global," is the considerate conclusion of Wendell L. Willkie after his trip through the war countries. Applying this global "thinking and planning" to a "global peace plan," Mr. Willkie says that the world must be free "economically and politically."

Of every ten women who get a permanent wave, at least five wish they hadn't! Such, at least, is the estimate of an unbiased bystander who has listened to the weepings and wailings of a whole procession of frizzle-pated plaintiffs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The War Department today assigned nine officers of the Waac to nine service commands. Each Waac officer on duty in service command headquarters will be Waac branch chief of the commanding general's personnel division.

Nashville, Tenn., announced yesterday two new issues of bonds, aggregating $450,000, for award on Nov. 24. One issue of $250,000 will be dated as of May 15, 1942, and will mature serially on May 15, 1944 to 1963. The other, of $200,000, will be dated as of Feb. 15, 1942, and will mature on Feb. 15, 1945 to 1964.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- A suggestion that doctors be required to report all pregnancies to public health authorities as a part of a program for the protection of women workers in war industries was made today by Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association, in an address before the National Safety Congress and Exposition.

With its torch blazing above the strains of the Marseillaise and "The Star-Spangled Banner," the Statue of Liberty, "enlightening the world," was rededicated yesterday while half of the earth continued the struggle to preserve the freedom for which it stands.

Increased buying by New Orleans interests and mills brought moderate gains to the cotton futures market yesterday. At the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts were 10 to 11 points above Tuesday's final quotations.

William R. White, who has been Superintendent of Banks of New York State since January, 1936, has resigned to become a vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, it was announced yesterday by Governor Herbert H. Lehman and by the Guaranty Trust.

Ten players who qualified in the preliminaries, concluded at the Manhattan Chess Club last night, and three from out of town, who were seeded, are ready for the finals of the United States amateur championship starting under the auspices of the United States Chess Federation at the Manhattan Club at 6:30 o'clock tonight.

Most of the necessary supplies to fight this war and support the civilian populations of our allies are carried on British ships. British merchant sailors spend long months on dangerous seas with nothing to break the monotony of constant vigilance and empty rest periods.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Mr. Willkie, in his report that the "reservoir" of good-will for the United States is leaking in Europe and Asia, made certain statements about the Chinese which were of the deepest interest to those who are intimately acquainted with the diplomatic discussions that preceded the outbreak of war with Japan.

Running like a well-oiled machine, Clifford Goldstein, City College captain, carried off the individual honors in yesterday's City College-Fordham-St. John's cross-country race over the five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Rark. Establishing a lead of approximately 200 yards on Jack Mayes of the Rams in the first three miles, Goldstein had an even wider margin on his rival at the finish.

The residence of the late Jay Gould, Fifth Avenue at Forty-seventh Sereet, has been leased as an annex to the Gimbel Brothers Art Auction Department, conducted by the Kende Galleries, under terms of a contract signed yesterday morning by Frederic A. Gimbel on behalf of his company and Charles C. Nuitt, executor of the estate of Finley Johnson Shepard and his late wife, Helen Gould Shepard, daughter of Jay Gould.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 28 -- The first really concerted German counter-attack and the largest tank engagement that have yet occurred in the present battle in Egypt ended yesterday with British Eighth Army units in possession of the ground they had taken in slow advances by infantry during three days and four nights. During Monday night British forces made further progress, still utilizing the moonlight, and often used their bayonets in fierce hand-to-hand encounters.

Operations of the Wheeling Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries in the third quarters of 1942 resulted in a net profit of $839,659 after $705,000 Federal income and $650,000 excess profits taxes, according to an announcement yesterday.

Warner Brothers is formulating plans to enter the newsreel field and expects to have its first news clips in theatres by Jan. 1. According to present plans, two and possibly three issues of the Warner newsreel will be released each week.

Attorney General John J. Bennett began yesterday an action to dissolve a "monopoly" of ice companies, which, he alleged, controlled 75 per cent of the manufacture and sale of the product in Brooklyn and Queens.

One-fifth of earth's children are Chinese. They are the largest racial group. To Americans they may seem touched with strangeness. To those who have worked with them and for them, as the China Aid Council and the American Committee for Chinese War Orphans have done, the latter since 1937, they are just like other children.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29 -- Recent studies on nutrition have revealed that the principle of relativity applies to diet as it does to space and time, according to reports presented today before the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Carpet production is currently running at less than one-third of the normal rate and is due to decline further as mills continue their active solicitation of war work, Steele Winterer, vice president of A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., declared here today at the Midwestern wartime problems conference of the National Retail Furniture Association.

LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Note circulation as reported today in the weekly statement of condition of the Bank of England continued its uninterrupted rise to the record total of 851,175,000, an increase of 4,145,000 in the week. This brings notes in circulation to within 30,000,000 of the authorized fiduciary issue of 880,000,000.

Declaring that Russian production alone was not enough, Wendell L. Willkie renewed last night his plea that the United States send increasing supplies to Russia "if they are to hold that hard-fought front which is ours as well as theirs."

The youth problem in the next generation will be acute as a result of war conditions, General George L. Carpenter, successor to General Evangeline Booth as international leader of the Salvation Army, warned yesterday following his arrival in this city from an extensive tour of the United States and Canada.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Percy Hugh Beverley Lyon, headmaster of Rugby, said in a speech at a luncheon gathering in London today that although the Nazi creed was diabolical, it had the power to inspire millions of men and women with the virtues of endurance, loyalty, courage and self-sacrifice, whereas Britain had become "content with a milk-and-honey Christianity very different from the austere gospel preached from the hills of Galilee."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Secretary Ickes said today that railroad shipments of oil to the East in the week ended Oct. 24 dropped to an average of 759,233 barrels daily, a decline of about 10 per cent from the preceding week and almost 100,000 barrels below the record figure in September.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The War Production Board's accentuated program for the standardization and simplification of production in civilian as well as military lines was carried into the paper field today with a revision of WPB's limitation order L-120.
Mayor La Guardia delivered a sharp rebuke yesterday to Washington officials over their failure to remove more than 100,000 tons of metal scrap from the city.
The text of Director Byrnes's salary regulations, published this morning, states among other things as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- As a result of the operation of the Property Requisitioning Act of Oct. 16, 1941, the government obtained 10,000,000 pounds of aluminum during the twelve months ending Oct. 16 from dealers who had it in stock but who had first "refused to sell it at fair prices," President Roosevelt told Congress today in a report on the first year of the statute's existence.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The India League, an organization composed of natives of India living in this country as well as of British subjects who are sympathetic to the aspirations and demands of the All-India Congress party, launched a drive tonight to get President Roosevelt, Premier Joseph Stalin of Russia and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of China to intervene in settlement of the problem of self-government for India.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- A reduction of 24 per cent in the motor-vehicle traffic toll of the country in the first nine months of this year, a saving of 6,600 lives, was reported today by the National Safety Council. The total was 21,290, compared with 27,900 for nine months last year.

BURLINGTON, Wis., Oct. 29 (AP) -- War tales issuing from Axis propaganda ministries have prompted the Burlington Liars' Club to establish a department for professionals, and in inaugural ceremonies today the first award went to Nazi Germany's Paul Goebbels.

WITH A BRITISH ARMORED DIVISION, in the field in Egypt, Oct. 28 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The German Africa Corps is experiencing real shock tactics for the first time in this desert war, and is moving back slowly, but thus far surely.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Secretarly Ickes predicted today completion by June 1 of the 24-inch Texas to East Coast pipeline, the second "leg" of which, from Illinois, has just been authorized by the War Production Board.

Sergeant Donald Hallman of the United States Marine Corps, a New York newspaper man, triumphed in the opening round of the United States amateur chess championship finals last night at the Manhattan Chess Club.

Branch Rickey, for many years the highest-paid executive in baseball as guiding genius of the Cardinals, yesterday was appointed president and general manager of the Brooklyn Baseball Club to succeed Larry MacPhail, who recently resigned to accept a lieutenant-colonelcy in the United States Army.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Plans by 17-year-old Edward Haight to bludgeon his guards and stage a dramatic break for freedom from the Westchester County Court, where he is on trial for murder, have been balked by deputy sheriffs, officials disclosed today.

ALFRED KAZIN, the boy wonder of American literary criticism, has been employed for several years on an ambitious work of critical revaluation whose approach, like that of a storm, has been heralded by flashes of lightning in our more scholarly magazines. "On Native Grounds,"* which is "in part an effort at moral history," is published today.

MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 30 -- The Germans, at a cost of 1,500 men and eleven tanks, pushed fifty to 100 yards deeper into North Stalingrad yesterday, it was announced here today, but this fourth Soviet setback in the Volga city in two days was offset by reports that blizzards sweeping the Western Caucasus already had frozen to death hundreds of Germans.

Hearings on the applications made by twelve railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission for an increase of 10 per cent in passenger fares within New York State were concluded yesterday. Interstate Commerce Commissioner J. Hayden Alldredge, who had been conducting the hearings in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, said all who opposed the proposed increase might submit briefs to the full commission by Dec. 15.

Strong selling pressure from spot firms, presumably hedging and liquidation of distant months, caused prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to sag yesterday to final net losses of 14 to 15 points, the day's low levels, after the market had held steadily near to the previous close during most of the moderately active session.

Our Army assigns about 6.5 medical officers to care for 1,000 enlisted men. The British ratio is said to be 4.75. Does it follow that our forces are over-doctored? It is argued that the 6.5 ratio comes down from a time when the Army was small and that a force of 10,000,000 can do with less.

Approximately 60 per cent of the paint, varnish and lacquer volume this year will be directly or indirectly influenced by the war effort, Ernest T. Trigg, president of the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, advised members yesterday in the industry's "Convention at Home."

I have had an experience with our New York State Unemployment Act which shocks me. An old gardener up my way needs a job. I need work done that he can do -- odd days now and then. He wants to work for me, but he cannot do more than a total of $3 worth in any seven consecutive days without jeopardizing his right to unemployment insurance of $18 a week for twenty weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Optimistic reports about the wool supply situation are unjustified and have caused considerable concern to the War Production Board, members of a woolen and worsted industry advisory committee were told yesterday by officials of the wool section of the Textile, Clothing and Leather Branch of WPB.

A partial answer to the question of what the public is doing with its greatly increased income appears in the figures of the Department of Commerce showing a marked drop in consumer debt. One of the President's seven points against inflation last April called for an increase in thrift and a repayment of debts.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 29 -- Miss Katharine E. McBride was inaugurated today as the fourth president of Bryn Mawr College at ceremonies held in Goodhart Hall.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A joint communique of British General Headquarters and the R.A.F.:

Mrs. Florence Kerr, an assistant commissioner of the WPA, said yesterday that work relief, "as such," is disappearing from the American scene and that she would like to see the Government give the organization an "honorable discharge."

William Ottman Jr., president of George Ehret Co., has rented a large apartment in 740 Park Avenue through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. Frederick M. Stewart, vice president of the Neo-Gravure Company, leased an apartment in 320 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The coordinated mass of the British Eighth Army was reported dealing methodically tonight with German 88-mm. guns that have, in some cases, slowed the Allied advance in the desert.

Grapefruit is increasing in supply and decreasing in price. This bulletin, which constitutes the brightest news received from the food front during the week, comes by way of Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, director of the consumers service bureau of the New York Department of Markets.

THE cry of the ballyhoo brigade for the Mauriello-Savold heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden this evening is that they are "the best heavyweights around." That's faint praise, indeed. Sergeant Joseph Louis Barrow is no longer "around." Neither is Corporal William Conn. Bob Pastor has retired. Many of the best men in lighter divisions are in various branches of the armed service.

The subtle sartorial art of Nettie Rosenstein was on display yesterday noon at the Hotel Pierre. Through the full length of the Cotillion Room, at the luncheon hour, paraded the manikins wearing models, designed for midseason wear in town, that gave a satisfactory demonstration of the sophisticated talents of this well-known designer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 24 showed a gain of 18 per cent as compared with the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Sales in the latest four-week period increased 14 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- It would be logically possible -- if not sensible -- to say in a dispatch from Washington something like "the Japanese were repulsed on Guadalcanal tomorrow."

AT AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Sept. 30 (Delayed) -- In six weeks of operations in the Solomon Islands area of the South Pacific, Catalina flying boats have made patrol flights totaling more than 500,000 miles and at times, in a single day of patrolling, have accumulated mileage equal to more than half the distance around the world.

Robert G. Albion, the maritime authority who is best known for his detailed study, "The Rise of the Port of New York," has done an account of American merchant shipping in wars from 1775 to the present, The germ of the book, Mr. Albion says, was the discovery of a notebook kept by a New York merchant during the Revolution to enter insurance rates paid on voyages.

Details on the new issue of $4,258,000 of bonds scheduled by Detroit, iVfich., for award on Nov. 17 were made known yesterday by the city officials. The issue will be known as sewage disposal revenue refunding bonds and will be dated Nov. 15, 1942, and will mature serially Nov. 15, 1944 to 1956.

Timidity of buyers because of the uncertain Pacific situation accounted again yesterday for an irregular and dull stock market. Some weakness cropped out in the morning but this was supplanted by a firmer tone in the afternoon. Changes in prices in both directions were confined to fractions except in a few instances.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- An appeal for a clear moral perception devoid of hatred or thought of vengeance against the Germans was made today by the Archbishop of Canterbury at a mass meeting in Albert Hall held in protest against Nazi persecution of the Jews.

OTTAWA, Oct. 29 -- Canada's "Book of Remembrance," a richly decorated, hand-inscribed volume containing the names of more than 66,500 Canadians who died in the first great war, has been completed after ten years' labor.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase of $216,498,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, which were at a record high. Note circulation for the system as a whole was at the highest of the year to date, while ratio of reserve for the system and also for the New York Bank were at a low for the year.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Representatives of the Investment Bankers Association of America asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to withdraw its proposed rule requiring disclosure of market price by over-the-counter dealers in order that the industry might present a more workable solution to the problems sought to be corrected.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A Navy communique:
Declaring that New York City has the greatest supply of unemployed labor in the country, Mayor La Guardia called on Federal agencies yesterday for a greater allocation of war contracts to the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Roosevelt's obedience to his own order for a ceiling of $25,000 on salaries after allowance for payment of taxes and other fixed charges will still leave him considerably more than $25,000 to live on, budget figures made clear today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A new offensive to obtain higher price ceilings for farm products was started today as farm State Senators assailed what they called "high-handed and illegal" administration of the new Price Control Act.

Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller approved yesterday as fair and reasonable an offer of settlement made by the Omnibus Corporation in accounting suits brought by minority stockholders of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company. The settlement, to which no opposition was presented, involves no money payment but grants options for the purchase or exchange of stock to all minority stockholders of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.

A day after they had been scheduled originally to come up for auction here, some 9,000 letters from the files of the late Edward T. Clark, private secretary to Calvin Coolidge, set out yesterday on their return journey to Washington, this time to become the property of the Library of Congress, to be sealed for twenty years.

WITH AN ATTACKING BRITISH TANK UNIT, on the Alamein Battlefront, Oct. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- A tank battle is sweeping over the desert floor, for the Germans brought up their armor yesterday afternoon in an effort to block the forward movement of the British.

In an afternoon of upsets at Empire City, when all the favorites lost, Red Moon, a 4-year-old daughter of Burning Blaze, and carrying the colors of J.A. Kelley, captured the featured Laura Dianti Purse at 30 to 1 and completed a double for Jockey Ted Atkinson.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Entering the homestretch in the New York Governorship race, Thomas E. Dewey shows a slightly increased lead in the latest institute poll of New York State.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The crash of a training plane in a field three miles from Stewart Field today killed two cadets of the Military Academy.
The Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that 331 public schools in the city have been designated for registration next week of consumers of fuel oil.

BRITISH TANKS, in Egypt, Oct 27 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- For a brief period tonight the desert was like early twilight as attacking British tanks and Axis artillery engaged in a terrific close-range duel and as Allied planes lighted the moonlit sky further with flares and tracer bullets.

Citing an advertisement that appeared in an up-State weekly newspaper, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, charged last night that Republicans were seeking votes on the claim that the New Deal had wanted war and had "hurried" the nation into it.

Things apparently have been happening fast since the hectic annual stockholders' meeting of the Electric Bond and Share Company on Oct. 14. Stockholders of the giant utility holding company demanded then that the management not only "fight the Securities and Exchange Commission" but also bring new blood to the board of directors.

A statement by Coleman B. Cheney, Socialist candidate for Governor, attacking the capitalistic system was made public last evening at Socialist headquarters, 303 Fourth Avenue.
