Professor Cheney, now a private in the Army, said that he had been denied opportunity to make a speech in person and forbidden to make a political speech.

Richard A. Knight, disbarred attorney, who received a jail sentence on his plea of guilty to sending annoying letters to judges and lawyers, lost another round in his legal battles in Supreme Court yesterday. Justice William T. Collins granted motions by defendants to dismiss the $100,000 damage action by Mr. Knight against members of the New York County grand jury for January 1942.

Owen D. Young, industrialist and dairy farm leader, made his first radio speech last night for the election of John J. Bennett Jr. as Governor. Mr. Young, who had been a leading figure in the background as a Democratic dark horse possibility for the nomination, praised Mr. Bennett's qualifications, and attacked those of Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican nominee.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Effective blows were dealt the Axis forces in Egypt by Allied aircraft in the past thirty-six hours, during a period when the British Eighth Army remained motionless, gathering strength for another forward surge. The most notable achievement was the torpedoing of a large enemy tanker in the harbor of Tobruk early this morning -- the third Axis tanker to be destroyed in the past four days.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Warner Brothers announced today that Walter Huston and Ann Harding have been signed to play former Ambassador and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies in the screen version of Mr. Davies's book, "Mission to Moscow," which will go before the cameras Monday, with Michael Curtiz directing.
At the annual meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, held yesterday at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, officers were elected for the coming year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Plans for a war nursery school in Middletown, Conn., financed from Lanham Act funds, await approval here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Army trucks traversed the entire length of the Alaska-Canada road known as the Alcan Highway this week, marking completion of this project in a little more than six months, Secretary Stimson said today. The formal opening of the project will probably take place on the Alaskan-Canadian border on Nov. 15.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, has been selected as the sixth recipient of the Hoover Medal, according to an announcement yesterday by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. He will receive the medal at the Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, which will be held in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, in the week of Jan. 25.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Branch Rickey "will do us a lot of good," said Manager Leo Durocher of the Dodgers when informed today that Rickey had signed a contract as president and general manager of the club.

The three four-family houses at 145, 149 and 151 Bay Thirteenth Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by Standard Properties, Inc. The buildings are each on plots, 25 by 108 feet. Each is assessed at $10,000.

An appeal to manufacturers operating under the production requirements plan to adjust quickly their outstanding purchase orders to conform to the quantities and ratings authorized on their fourth-quarter certificates was made yesterday by H.M. Brundage, deputy regional director of the War Production Board in charge of materials and priorities.

The six-story apartment house with self-service elevator at 40 East Fifty-first Street has been sold by the United States Trust Company to Alexander H. Pincus, operator, for cash over a first mortgage of $27,500 for ten years at 3 per cent. Assessed at $75,000, the property is 20 by 100 feet and is fully rented at $8,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The American marines and soldiers on Guadalcanal Island have thrown back three recent Japanese assaults, but in one case only after the enemy had pierced their lines, the Navy reported in a communique issued here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- More than 1,000,000 Christmas parcels were included in a record total of 3,396 tons of mail sent to American armed forces overseas during the first twenty-five days of October.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- The dismissal of William P. Sullivan, a teacher of history in the New York City high schools, was sustained today by the Court of Appeals when it affirmed the order of the court below. Sullivan was served with charges on March 7, 1941, accusing him of incompetent service and intoxication.

The report of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, made public yesterday by Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, shows a consolidated net income of $16,357,304, after all operating expenses, taxes at the 1942 rate and other charges.

Awards were made to seven painters and one sculptor yesterday by the Allied Artists of America who will open their twenty-ninth annual exhibition to the public tomorrow at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, following a private opening this afternoon.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 29 -- The banking methods of Martin Scharloo, unorthodox, to say the least, would horrify Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, but it is safe to predict that Mr. Morgenthau would place Mr. Scharloo in the front rank of any list of men with an eye for making a sound investment and doing it when the nation needs millions of such investors.

May I say that Mr. Krock's column this morning hit the nail on the head exactly. The United States or England could have had peace with Japan at any time if they had been willing to "sell China down the river," and we are at war with Japan because we refused to do so.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Andrew J. Higgins, the Louisiana shipbuilder, was told today that he would receive a contract for 1,200 C-46 twin-engine transport planes for the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Treasury and the War Labor Board announced today plans for setting up regional machinery for the administration of Federal controls over wages and salaries and the Treasury explained some of the methods it would use to apply them to salaries of more than $5,000 a year.

New and somewhat more liberal war and aviation clauses will be included in all current and future life insurance policies of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, and certain provisions of such clauses in outstanding policies also have been liberalized, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Ever since General MacArthur obeyed orders and left the Philippines to assume what was described as "supreme command" in a sector of the Far Pacific many persons in Washington have been aware that a critical atmosphere has settled around him.

The Blackfriars Guild, who are very engaging people indeed, last evening banged their way into a new season with a production of a mixture called "Inside Story," the work of Peter Sheehan of Rochester. According to the program, Mr. Sheehan has a job in a war production factory and he keeps away from producers; he also, quite clearly, keeps abreast of the times and he writes good gags.

Continuation after the war of labor-management committees and other cooperative efforts that now are contributing to total war production would prevent a post-war depression, Solicitor General Henry Epstein, Democratic candidate for Attorney General, declared yesterday.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Administration of the $30,000 bequest of Miss Kate Stephens to the University of Kansas recalls her romance, blighted sixty-six years ago by the death of the young professor to whom she was engaged, for she set up the Byron Caldwell Smith Award, named in his memory.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Senator William H. Smathers made a plea for his re-election tonight on the ground the election of his Republican adversary, Albert W. Hawkes, would be good news to the Axis dictators.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
The Consolidated Riseuit Company resumed yesterday the payment of dividends on the common stock with the declaration of 25 cents a share. The last one was 10 cents on March 24, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -- Secretary Stimson, Secretary Knox and Donald M. Nelson, war production chief, called on war industries tonight to make certain that an opportunity is given every employe to cast his ballot in the elections Tuesday.
The Ballet Theatre last night put on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House the season's only presentation of Antony Tudor's "Dark Elegies," set to the "Kindertotenlieder" of Gustav Mahler.

The Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's were tossing the caber yesterday on the polo field at the Westchester Country Club in Rye. In lieu of a caber, they were using human projectiles measuring upward of 6 feet 3 inches.

The concert given by Bruno Walter and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall had two memorable features. One was the noble Seventh symphony of Sibelius, with which Mr. Walter began his program.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Frank Strazza of the Round Hill Club, Greenwich, and Mike Turnesa of the Elmsford Country Club tied for the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship with 146 at the Gedney C.C. today and will play off the tie over eighteen holes Sunday afternoon, teeing off at 1:30.

Directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York authorized yesterday the lowering of the "discount rate" from 1 per cent to one-half of 1 per cent on advances to member banks against collateral comprising government securities due or callable in less than one year.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Polish guerrillas have been very active lately, according to news reaching the Polish Government-in-exile here today.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Albert W. Hawkes declared today that Senator William H. Smathers had raised the prohibition question in the Senatorial campaign in a last desperate effort to "stave off certain defeat."

As a result of increasing emphasis in the school program on attaining greater adjustment of school and child, a new major unit, to be known as the Division of Child Welfare, will be established by the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday by Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade.

Americans everywhere can take satisfaction in the report that General Motors made, in the form of an advertisement, on its production for war in the first nine months of 1942. Not only is the total of more than $1,200,000,000 worth of goods built and delivered a staggering one, but the variety of materials is almost equally amazing.

Two excellent newspaper men, one entrusted with the job of keeping "dangerous information" out of circulation, the other charged with telling the American people what they have a right to know, did a good deal to clear up the question of news in wartime during their joint session in The New York Times Hall on Wednesday evening.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Sept. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Stories of Japanese treachery, one telling of how twenty-eight of thirty marines paid with their lives for honoring a Japanese flag of truce, were reported today by Solomon Islands casualties evacuated to the Navy mobile base hospital here.

Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Naval Affairs Committee, declares in an article entitled "The Battle of the Atlantic," in the current issue of Collier's, that in World War I "we claimed somewhere between 500 and 600 certain and probable sinkings of German subs."

It is just like Christmas these days at the Morgan Street Annex of the New York postoffice, where mail for members of the armed forces are handled. That's what they are saying down there, although Dec. 25 is still distant. For tens of thousands of holiday packages and hundreds of thousands of letters are being handled daily by specially trained personnel.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Fifty-two of the sixty members of a women's motor corps of the Yonkers Red Cross resigned last night following receipt of a letter by Mrs. Alice P. Frink, captain of the corps, from Chairman Justin X. McCarthy of the Yonkers Red Cross Chapter, it was learned today.

Retail stores in general favor January store-wide clearances but are doubtful about white sales, according to a survey released yesterday by the Meyer Both Company, advertising organization. Special events planned for January will generally be keyed to the war effort, it was said.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Hunk Anderson and Luke Johnsos were appointed co-coaches of the Chicago Bears today when George Halas, coach-owner of the National Football League champions, officially relinquished his duties to become a lieutenant commander in the Naval Reserve.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- The first of a group of witnesses the government expects will link the saboteur activities of Herbert Hans Haupt, executed Nazi spy, directly to the six Chicagoans on trial for treason, were put on the stand today in Judge William J. Campbell's court.

Charge account collections by local department stores showed an increase of 7.9 per cent in September, according to the twenty-store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The increase, while smaller than that noted for each of the preceding two months, continues the trend noted since the charge account amendment to Regulation W became effective.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commander of the United States forces in the European war theatre, was reported tonight to have been called home for "important consultations" with high military officials.
A High command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

How to simplify living conditions and reduce costs for the war worker and post-war home owner constitutes the main theme of the Invention for Victory exhibit opening today at the Brooklyn Museum. A room unit designed for dormitories to be built for 150,000 Washington war workers during the coming year and two and one-half sections of a pre-fabricated house are on view in the Exhibitors Gallery on the first floor.

A united front by the various retail liquor package store groups in the metropolitan area and Long Island was indicated yesterday with the appointment of Gerald F. Dunne to the post of executive director of the Metropolitan Package Store Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Liquidation in corn and rye, headed by houses with Eastern connections, carried both grains to new seasonal low levels today and caused recessions in wheat and oats early. Corn sold off around 1/2 cent a bushel to a new low since last December and rye dropped around 1 cent and went into new low ground in over a year.

Combined net earnings of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation and its subsidiaries amounted to $11,285,985 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, according to the unaudited figures announced yesterday.

Premier Mussolini sent Reichsfuehrer Hitler his "greetings of sincerest comradeship" yesterday in a telegram thanking Herr Hitler for his message of congratulations Wednesday on the twentieth anniversary of the Fascist regime in Italy, according to a German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press.

The Associated Press recorded a Berlin broadcast last night of a German Transocean news agency report that the British had attempted to land yesterday morning at Axis-held Matruh, on the Egyptian coast west of the Alamein battlefield, and had been frustrated, with six fully laden landing vessels destroyed.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Oct. 30 -- American Flying Fortresses of General Douglas MacArthur's command, continuing their support of United States forces on Guadalcanal, blasted the Japanese naval base of Buin in the northern Solomons yesterday, scoring a direct hit on an unidentified enemy ship and straddling four others with bombs, it was announced today.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, carried his campaign into Manhattan's lower East Side last night and in two speeches charged that the Democratic party in the State was "blissfully unconscious" of present-day needs and that only through the election of the Republican State ticket could New York be assured of a liberal State administration.

Mike Getto walked into the Dodger dressing room yesterday morning and breathed a deep sigh of relief. Pulling on his practice uniform for the first time all week was Dean McAdams, the key triple-threat back. The extent of his previous "work" since last Sunday had been sitting in a whirlpool bath, trying to unkink a charlie horse.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday declined 15 per cent from the 1942 peak reached in the preceding week and gained only 2 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago, largely due to the sharp decrease in transactions at New York.

Special insignia for workers in war plants to protect them from the charge of draft-dodging were suggested yesterday by Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, in a telegram to Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commissioner.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Creation of local boards to review New York real estate assessments is endorsed by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, but no statement on the question has been made by his Republican opponent, Thomas E. Dewey, according to the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards.

The campaign of the Solomons, which was still at a crisis yesterday, well illustrates the kind of military problems we face in the Pacific war. They are problems of distance and logistics, but, above all, they are problems of coordination.
MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
Internal Revenue officials called attention yesterday to the new Federal excise taxes that go into effect Sunday morning.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 29 -- Adolf Hitler has ordered the capture of Stalingrad at all costs and is planning a Winter campaign in the Caucasus with twin drives against Batum and Baku designed to break through to the Middle East toward Teheran in Iran and Kirkuk and Mosul in Iraq, this correspondent was informed today in a conversation with a competent neutral observer just arrived from Germany and the Balkans.

An "open house" reception will be held by Collectors of American Art at the gallery, 106 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Sunday afternoon from 5 to 7 o'clock. John Taylor Arms will be guest of honor and will speak on "The Meaning of Prints."
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Another government spokesman -- Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary and Minister of Home Security -- went after Britain's critics tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Establishment of an Enlisted Training Corps in American colleges and universities, intended to utilize the institutions of higher education more effectively after the lowered Selective Draft bill is passed, was voted by the Association of American Colleges, assembled here at a special meeting to consider problems created by the war program.

WASHINGTON, Oct 29 (AP) -- The War Production Board issued today a code of building standards restricting the size of new homes and the use of scarce lumber and metals, which must be followed in all future dwelling construction whether publicly or privately financed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The War Department ordered a speed-up today in its system of putting inductees into service, to make up for the men lost to the Army by deferments of agricultural workers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 27 (Delayed) -- Last night and yesterday we visited the most forward positions of the British Eighth Army, going along lanes through enemy minefields that had been progressively cleared by engineers and infantrymen.

Representatives of the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths discussed religion's place in the postwar world yesterday at a symposium at Town Hall under the auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. The Rev. John Elliott, secretary of the committee for religious organization, presided, and the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, foreign secretary of the Federal Council of Churches, served as toastmaster.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The Ministry of Health launched a drive today for public discussion of the problem of combating venereal disease which, authorities said, has shown a sharp percentage increase since outbreak of the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A bill designed to extend a uniform system of overtime payments to all of the more than 2,000,000 civilian employes on Federal payrolls was reported to the Senate by Senator Mead today as "an Administration measure" with the approval of the Committee on Civil Service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Roosevelt expressed his "sincere confidence" in the future of Turkey in a message of felicitation today to President Inonu on the occasion of the nineteenth anniversary of the founding of the Turkish Republic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- New York State had 3,927,991 dwelling units with a median monthly rental value of $33.88 in 1940. Urban units were valued at twice the rental rate for rural farm dwellings.

To hear people talk about food rationing one would imagine that it says in the Good Book that man lives not by meat alone. The correct word is bread, but the word is seldom encountered in the substitute menus for meatless Tuesdays.

Warner Brothers' screen adaptation of the George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart comedy, "George Washington Slept Here," will open today at the Strand. Starring Jack Benny and Ann Sheridan, the film's supporting cast includes Charles Coburn, Charles Dingle, Percy Kilbride, Lee Patrick, William Tracy, Douglas Croft and Hattie McDaniel.

Six men and one woman convicted a week ago yesterday of conspiracy to smuggle platinum out of this country were sentenced yesterday by Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Federal court, Brooklyn, to serve prison terms and pay fines.

A crisis with respect to manpower in retailing in 1943 was foreseen yesterday at the annual meeting of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association at the Hotel Roosevelt. The present personnel situation was reported as growing serious and much of the meeting was given over to discussion of ways and means of alleviating the situation.

Tami Mauriello, Bronx heavyweight contender, and Lee Savold of St. Paul will clash in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. With the rivals ranked high among the current crop of heavyweights, and with the fight being the first in the Garden in more than a month, Promoter Mike Jacobs is confident that a crowd of more than 12,000 fans will attend.

Two members of Selective Service boards, one from downtown Brooklyn and the other from East New York, appeared in the Brooklyn-Queens Night Court last night against three potential selectees who, according to the complaints, had attempted forcibly to arrange their own draft classifications.

William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System and general chairman of the United Hospital Fund's current campaign, announced yesterday contributions ranging to $5,000. A $5,000 gift was received from the Adele R. Levy Fund, Inc., and two anonymous $5,000 gifts also were received.

The long-awaited order curtailing the production of paper has been finally approved, it was reported here yesterday, and calls far only a minor reduction in paper operations from the average rate of the six-month period ended on Sept. 30.

Billings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the whole of 1942 will be well over $1,500,000,000, at least 56 per cent better than net sales of $961,000,000 in 1941, Eugene G. Grace, president, said yesterday after the quarterly meeting of directors here.
William Hodson, Commissioner of the Department of Welfare, named five charitable institutions yesterday that he said practiced racial discrimination in the admission of inmates.
William Hodson, Commissioner of the Department of Welfare, named five charitable institutions yesterday that he said practiced racial discrimination in the admission of inmates.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and the correspondents reporting her visit here started out almost simultaneously early today to visit stations of the Eighth Air Corps, United States Army Air Forces, of which her son, Lieut. Col. Elliott Roosevelt, commands two photo reconnaissance squadrons.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Railroad freight running time between Chicago-St. Louis and the Pacific Coast will be lengthened by one day, beginning at 12:01 A.M. on Sunday, Nov. 1, C.E. Johnston, chairman of the Western Association of Railway Executives, announced today.

William R. White, who has just resigned as Superintendent of Banks of this State, leaves behind him an enviable record. Although the youngest man ever to hold that responsible position, he has had, with one exception, the longest period of service in the history of the department, and the years of his service have been critical ones.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Speculators in the Argentine rails who took the view that they had good post-war prospects and bought stocks at steadily rising prices were shocked today when a slump followed the report of Central Argentine, which disclosed that an increase in gross revenue of 536,932 had been more than offset by a rise of 617,217 in working expenses which was not shown in the weekly traffic returns.

Justice Matthew J. Troy at the end yesterday of one of the longest calendars of gambling cases in the Manhattan branch of Special Sessions found he had established what was believed to be a record of total fines for one month in the Gambling Term.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Following last week's decline, commodity prices in primary markets again turned moderately upward during the week ended Oct. 24. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' wholesale price index of 889 series advanced 0.1 per cent.

Colonel Robert R. McCormick and the Tribune Company, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, filed a separate answer in the Federal court here yesterday to the government's civil action against The Associated Press for violation of the anti-trust laws.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The office of Arenibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress and assistant director of the Office of War Information, issued a formal statement today denying that he had resigned from the OWI post.
SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -General MacArthur's hard-working Flying Fortresses returned to attack Rabaul in the brilliantly moonlit hours early this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- "Father" William E. Riker, former candidate for Governor of California and leader of the Holy City cult in the Santa Cruz Mountains, below this city, was arrested today by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a warrant charging sedition.

The battle for the Solomon Islands is important to both Japan and the United Nations because Japan has set the conquest of Australia and Siberia as its principal objectives in the war, Otto D. Tolischus, former Tokyo correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES told members of the China Society of America at a luncheon in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.
MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- The midnight communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The authority of President Roosevelt to have the eight Nazi saboteurs tried last Summer by a secret military commission instead of a civil court was unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court today in an opinion supplementing the memorandum ruling handed down July 31 at a special session.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Lester Bailey, 72-year-old farmer and last resident of the 40,000 acre tract of the Bear Mountain-Harriman Interstate Park, whose forebears settled here before the Revolution, has been missing since last Friday.

Only ten openings are promised for Broadway next month -- two less than last November. None of them is due next week. Here is the list for the remainder of the month, subject to change with or without notice:

Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, laid down his program last night for mustering the nation's productive resources. His big point was to have every war job cleared through a single agency, the United States Employment Service.

Success or failure of our campaign in the Pacific will be the determining factor in the rationing of wool apparel the latter part of next year, according to woolen manufacturers, who said yesterday that they felt certain that there would be no civilian restrictions during the Spring of 1943.

Having spent two days trying to plug gaps in the defense, Columbia turned to the offense at Baker Field yesterday and devoted the last heavy workout before tomorrow's game with Cornell to polishing its attack.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Mrs. Edith E. Earle, honorable secretary and organizer of the Legion of British Women of New York City, is planning to open a "communal kitchen" for women war workers in New York, where they may obtain prepared meals for home consumption, the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Administration has apparently decided to shelve for the present any move for a compulsory control of manpower mobilization, according to reports current after a visit of the Combined Labor Victory Committee to President Roosevelt.
R. Henry Norweb, United States Ambassador to Peru, and Mrs. Norweb are at the Waldorf-Astoria and have been joined by their daughter, Miss Jeanne Norweb, a student at Vassar College.

While the action at Guadalcanal hangs in suspense, and suspense fills the minds and hearts of all Americans as they wait for news of the fighting, one thing can be said of this battle that distinguishes it from Bataan and other last-ditch stands in the Philippines. This is a fight which we initiated.

Mrs. Katie Hartland, 60-year-old Englishwoman, who says she is the widow of "Count Louis Hamon," who, as "Cheiro," was the favorite palmist of Continental royalty and society at the turn of the century, testified yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court in her suit to annul the second marriage of her first husband, Henry A. Hartland, on the ground that the first marriage is still valid.

Coincidental with the opening of the deer hunting season in the Adirondack region on Sunday, Acting Conservation Commissioner John T. Gibbs has asked the cooperation of all in keeping hunting fatalities and injuries at a minimum.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- For a coach whose team has been such a pleasant surprise not only to himself and his sfaff but possibly even to itself, Coach Earl (Red) Blaik of Army was in anything but an optimistic mood today.

The leaders of organized labor oppose compulsory manpower mobilization until voluntary methods have been fully tried. But why not try them? Why do not leaders of organized labor cooperate to end the artificial scarcity of labor brought about by legal or union restriction of hours?

SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 29 -A i great field trial spaniel added to hig long string of American victo-, ties today,'Field Trial Champion Wakes Wager of Greenfair placing first in the open all-age stake for springers, the final event, at the nineteenth annual meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- More than 42,600 war production workers have been killed in industrial and other accidents since the Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor, Dr. Victor G. Heiser, author and medical consultant to the National Association of Manufacturers committee on healthful working conditions, said today at a conference sponsored by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts.

Thousands of football fans undoubtedly were disappointed to read that the Army-Navy game will be played at Annapolis under restrictions barring the vast majority of spectators who have witnessed this crowning highlight of each amateur gridiron season for many years.

The New York War Savings Staff will open a portable cottage, in which every purchaser of $2 or more in war stamps may make a recording of a "voice letter" to be mailed free to any man or woman in the United States armed forces anywhere in the world, today at 10 A.M. in War Bond Square.

A large apartment in 1120 Fifth Avenue has been taken by Mrs. Watson B. Dickerman of Southampton, L.I., through Douglas L. Elliman Co., who also leased apartments in 40 Fifth Avenue to Dr. Carmyn J. Lombardo and in 1205 Lexington Avenue to Catherine E. Shawber.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 30 -- Establishing a firm place for themselves in the Allied air effort, United States fighter pilots shot down twenty-two enemy fighters in the first five days of the new Allied offensive in Egypt and lost only two themselves, it was announced today.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

"One of Our Aircraft Is Missing," a topical feature-length drama produced and directed in England by Michael Powell, will open this morning at the Globe. Made with the cooperation of the Royal Air Force, the British Air Ministry and the Royal Netherlands Government in London, the film is presented by Alexander Korda and released through United Artists.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Twelve former residents of the United States were included in a list of 274 civilians reported by the Canadian External Affairs Department last night to be interned by the Japanese at Hong Kong.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30 -- The Kenny method for the alleviation of the after-effects of infantile paralysis was declared today at the closing sessions of the American Public Health Association to be "equally as hopeless" as earlier methods aiming to achieve the same results. Dr. Henry R. McCarroll of this city, an orthopedic surgeon connected with the Washington University School of Medicine, presented these views following a demonstration of the Kenny technique.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A joint communique of British General Headquarters and the R.A.F.:

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Nathan L. Jacobs, State attorney for the Office of Price Administration, asserted tonight a practice of evading wholesale meat price ceilings by billing butcher shops for "invisible items" had become widespread in New Jersey during the last sixty days.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday a communication to directors and executive officers of all member banks in this district in which he said it would be necessary for banks to purchase government securities in full proportion to their available resources.

Jackson S. Hutto, Deputy Supertendent of Banks of New York State, was appointed yesterday Superintendent of Banks by Governor Herbert H. Lehman. He succeeds William R. White, who resigned earlier this week to become a vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Royal Canadian Air Force announced tonight that Sergeant Leonard Joseph Barnard of 323 Forty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, N.Y., had been killed on active service overseas, and listed his wife as his next of kin.

A retailer who cut prices in violation of the State Fair Trade Law last March, the month taken by the Federal Government as the basis for its retail price ceilings, did not thereby win the right to continue to sell at such cut prices, in violation of the State law, "for the duration," the Appellate Division ruled yesterday.

The first cooperative drive ever held in this city to encourage early Christmas shopping will get under way tomorrow when forty leading retail stores here begin an intensive "Shop Early, Carry Your Own" campaign.

Scoring all except two of its points in the first half and holding the aroused losers at bay in the second half, Poly Prep's football team dropped the Horace Mann School eleven from the ranks of the unbeaten at Horace Mann Field yesterday.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 30 -- The results of the Westport town election on Oct. 5 were upset today when Judge Frank V. McEvoy of the Fairfield County Superior Court handed down a decision invalidating the absentee ballots cast by thirty-two local soldiers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today assigned Preston Foster and John Sutton to leading roles in "Army Wife," a Gone Tierney vehicle, which Jo Swerling is writing from Ursula Parrott's novel, "A Far Off Music."

Two recent events -- the Montevideo Pan-American Conference of Free Italians and the speech of Attorney General Biddle on Columbus Day -- have stirred profoundly the millions of Italians and sons of Italians in the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- In a joint action by the Canadian and American governments, paper production, including newsprint, was frozen at 100 per cent of the average operating rate of the six months' period from April 1 to Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Appealing to all citizens to vote in the election Tuesday, President Roosevelt declared today that we must use ballots as well as bullets in the all-out war to keep democracy alive.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (AP) -- With 1942 shipments of Thompson Products, Inc., and consolidated subsidiaries expected to reach approximately $90,000,000, more than double last year's total, F.C. Crawford, president, announced today earnings of $1,463,914 in the nine months ended on Sept. 30.

Flanked by elder statesmen of the Democratic party, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. brought his campaign for the Governorship to a climax last night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, only a short distance from the working-class district in Red Hook where he was born.

Fuel oil consumers whose dealers have failed to supply them with ration application forms, which must be filed next week, may obtain the forms from their local rationing boards, State Director Lee S. Buckingham of the Office of Price Administration announced last night.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 31 -- Allied bombers probably extensively damaged a Japanese aircraft carrier, scored two hits on a warship described as either a cruiser or a battleship, probably damaged still another cruiser and left an unidentified ship ablaze in a raid on Buin, the High Command announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- To a New York clerk, Stuart M. Campbell, 27 years old, a silver medal was awarded tonight by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission for saving a man from being run over by a subway train.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Young People's concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.; Fritz Kreisler, violin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Felix Salmond, 'cello, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30.

CAIRO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Lieutenant Lyman Middleditch Jr. attributed his victory over the Messerschmitts to his conservation of high-caliber ammunition. Describing the exploits of the Black Scorpion Squadron with which he flew, Lieutenant Middleditch said that on the afternoon of the big fight the Scorpions suddenly discovered the air full of Messerschmitts which "looked like brand new ones, probably just brought over from Crete."

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 30 -- All factories have closed in the French Department of Haute-Savoie after a widespread strike movement and feeling is running high against working in Germany, reports reaching here said today. Important reinforcements of State Police have arrived.
BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press.
LONDON, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- The crew of at least one German submarine has been imprisoned for failing to attack Allied shipping off Norway, reports reaching the Norwegian Government here said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Members of the Senate Committee on Small Business felt that they had won a victory today in breaking up a practice in the War Department of earmarking orders for material for particular companies.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt visited Dover today and, through naval glasses, she looked toward the Nazi guns just twenty-three miles across the English Channel and remarked how close Britain's shores were to the land that the Germans had overrun.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 30 (AP) -- German news agency reports received here today from Berlin said the Russians were massing "powerful shock armies" for a Winter attempt to break through the Germans' Vitebsk-Smolensk line some 275 miles west of Moscow.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Compulsory registration of 42,000,000 women between the ages of 18 and 65 to ascertain how many might be fitted into the war-production program is under consideration by the Administration, President Roosevelt stated today.

Four hundred commanding officers of the Police Department, meeting yesterday in the line-up room at police headquarters, were told by Commissioner Valentine that he expected them to see to it that the city had an honest and orderly election day on Tuesday.

A German broadcast recorded yesterday by The United Press in New York said the High Command had reported that British forces carried out a strong attack on the Egyptian front Thursday after a violent duel between German artillery and British tanks, but said it failed.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- In a stock market which otherwise was quiet selling continued in the foreign rails and many prior charges fell 20 to 40s. Among the ordinary issues Antofogasta lost 10s and Buenos Aires Western 5s.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Seventeen-year-old Edward Haight smirked and chuckled in County Court today while his own transcribed words, recounting the most shocking story in the history of Westchester crime, were read to ashen-faced jurors by Chief Assistant District Attorney John J. Dillon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Chairman Nelson of the War Production Board may receive authority to designate a Federal Food Administrator with power over all phases of the nation's food problem, according to definite reports tonight.

Complete elimination of James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, from American politics will result from next Tuesday's election, Mayor La Guardia declared last night in a radio speech from Station WJZ over a State-wide hook-up.
DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 30 -- The tire factory at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant is to be shipped to Russia under the lend-lease program.

Franklin L. Moe, 51 years old, merchandise broker with offices at 7 Water Street, was found dead late last night, with a self-inflicted bullet wound in his head, in a garage at the rear of his home at 38-10 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing, Queens. A pistol with one discharged bullet was found beside his body.

Getting enough vitamin B1, that promoter of verve and vigor, is difficult on two counts. Either you dislike the cheap sources of it with an acute abomination -- as, for example, wholegrain breads and cereals -- or you can't afford to eat much of the more expensive foods in which it's found, like lean pork or chicken.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- As the Rome radio reported today that honors had been heaped on Commander Enzio Grassi of the Italian submarine Barbarigo for the sinking of two American battleships, authoritative British sources explained that Commander Grassi's actual achievements had been attacks on a British freighter and a British corvette.

New municipal financing will continue relatively small next week. Only eight issues, aggregating $1,748,600, have been scheduled for award. The weekly average of new municipal issues for the year to date, according to Daily Bond Buyer, now stands at $23,067,056.
New Jersey's Fish and Game Commission has called attention to the opening date of the upland game season lest there be any confusion among hunters about the migratory waterfowl or woodcock seasons.

The problem of unemployment in New York appears to be no nearer solution today than in midsummer, when city officials and Federal authorities began their joint studies of the situation. Last July formal recognition was given to the incongruity of having 400,000 workers idle here, while factories elsewhere were bulging with Government orders and competing for men.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A Navy communique:

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- A sealed indictment was filed with Justice Riley H. Heath of Ithaca in extraordinary term of Supreme Court today by the special grand jury investigating financial affairs of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- The phrase most overworked by Chicago dry goods wholesalers as goods shortages increase is: "I'm sorry, but -- ," and the inability to take on additional business hits buyers for the big mail-order houses as well as the little fellows.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Charging that brewers and bottlers were being permitted to impede the tin can salvage program with the active cooperation of the War Production Board's Conservation Branch, Burton M. Parks, recently head of the tin can unit, has submitted his resignation to Lessing J. Rosenwald, branch chief.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Turkey herders around Topeka are sleeping in the open, near their high-roosting, and high-priced, flocks, keeping their rifles at their sides.

Frank E. Gernon is to retire today as a partner in Hayden, Stone Co., according to the weekly bulletin of the New York Stock Exchange, which also lists the retirement of J. Taylor Foster from partnership in Spencer Trask Co., of William P. Sargeant and C. Emmett Wilson from Sargeant, Malo Co. and of Perry MacKay Sturges as a special partner in Halladay Co. today.

A total of $579,517 has been raised thus far in the United Hospital Campaign, or $76,208 more than in the comparable period in the 1941 drive, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse, chairman of the Manhattan women's division.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Organization of a joint railroad labor-management conference to promote maximum use of railroad facilities in the war effort was announced today by Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation.

The stock market had yesterday alternating periods of strength and weakness, but managed, in the final hour, to wipe out early losses and to close fractionally higher on the day. Low-priced issues provided the main activity and lifted the day's transfers on the Stock Exchange to 517,060 shares from 454,940 shares on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Specialized price control for the vast American construction industry -- from repairing a leaky roof to construction of giant projects such as Boulder Dam -- will go into effect on Nov. 5, the Office of Price Administration announced today. OPA said the plan resulted from the necessity for a pricing method other than that provided by the general maximum price regulation.

Miss MacGuire has been appointed chairman of a committee of debutantes assisting with plans for the benefit Autumn Fiesta, a supper dance, fashion show and entertainment to be given Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of members of the Real Estate Board of this city.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Assisted by powerful air support, in which United States fliers are steadily piling up a brilliant record, infantry troops of the British Eighth Army in Egypt pushed forward again today, capturing many German prisoners in fighting at close quarters, according to reports reaching London tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Japanese fleet has withdrawn from the vicinity of the Solomon Islands, and the American forces on Guadalcanal are still occupying "every inch of ground" they ever controlled there, Colonel Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, stated today at a press conference.

With eight, including Alsab, named for the $25,000 added Westchester Handicap, the Empire City meeting is expected to reach its high point today with the running of the mile and three-sixteenths test, which now is one of the outstanding handicaps of the New York season.

CAIRO, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- Allied troop are battering steadily into the Alamein line, and deserters and prisoners pouring in from the enemy lines, many of whom fought in Russia, stress that the British artillery barrages are worse than anything they endured before Leningrad, Moscow and Smolensk, front dispatches said tonight.

Jobbers and fabricators of secondhand bedsprings will soon be asked by the Office of Price Administration to sign agreements that they will not sell at prices in excess of those found by a survey to be the average prevailing prices in March, it was learned yesterday.

The City Planning Commission adopted a three-phase program yesterday for capital improvements in the city by authorizing a 1943 capital budget of $37,769,570, a five-year program of $330,000,000 and expansion of the post-war construction program from $628,000,000 to about $680,000,000.

BEACON, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Representative Hamilton Fish, seeking re-election in the Twenty-sixth District, tonight predicted the election of a Republican majority in the House as a protest against the New Deal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Representative Boykin (Democrat, Alabama) said today he had been assured the War Production Board order halting the issuance of priority certificates for private home building would be withdrawn by Monday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Cigarettes and cigars will cost the consumer higher prices beginning Sunday to absorb the new Federal excise taxes, the Office of Price Administration stated today.
DETROIT, Oct. 30 -- Directors of the Chrysler Corporation voted today a dividend of 75 cents a share on its common stock, payable on Dec. 14 to stock of record of Nov. 14.

OAKLAND, Calif., 0ct. 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Charles Moore had received so many unhappy telegrams that she was almost afraid to open the one the conductor handed her as her train sped eastward carrying her toward a reunion with her parents in Carthage, S.D.

FORT MYERS, Fla., Oct. 30 (AP) -- An Army medium bomber missing from Page Field near here since Wednesday night was located today four miles west of Venus, Fla., where it had crashed, killing the seven members of the crew.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Judge Oscar S. Caplan fined two union officers $200 and costs each today after a policeman testified that they did not act to halt a slowdown at a war production plant.

The exhibit of the American Institute of Graphic Arts devoted to "the best in American book production during the last decade" will be held in the Pierpont Morgan Library from Nov. 24 through Dec. 7, it was announced yesterday by the A.I.G.A. The collection of 200 books has a Latin American counterpart that was assembled by the Institute with the assistance of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs and is now being shown in Buenos Aires.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Corporate financing rose sharply in September, reaching $64,270,000, against $9,825,000 in August and $8,571,000 in July, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Branch Rickey, reiterating that he would not do anything about choosing a Brooklyn manager until he conferred with Leo Durocher in St. Louis, today called the Dodgers' 1942 boss "an astute and fine tactician on the field."
Rulings by the OPA with respect to the new retail prices on cigars and cigarettes, reflecting the excise taxes effective tomorrow, were awaited yesterday by the tobacco trade.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct 30 -- Put on the "alert" for an hour and five minutes today by the presence of "unidentified planes." the San Francisco Bay area spent several more hours in speculation because of the cryptic language of an explanatory statement from the Army.

The fifteen-story apartment building at 322 Central Park West, at the northwest corner of Ninety-second Street, has been sold by the Central Hanover Bank Trust Company to Arthur D. Schlechter through L.J. Phillips Co., brokers.
AMHERST vs. Massachusetts State -- Judging from an Australian guide book that has come to hand, our soldiers "down under" must be seeing some queer birds. An amiable vote for Amherst.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Reports that Germany has been buying rubber from Japan and has succeeded in taking delivery of it have been heard and are credited in official circles in Washington.

Aided by the heavy "beat-the-tax" buying of liquors, retail trade here showed substantial increases this week. Some department stores had sales gains of about 25 per cent over last week, in which buying of foodstuffs as well as liquors played an important part.
An SOS from the Brazilian Consulate at 60 East Forty-second Street yesterday brought two pounds of coffee from a local dealer to the representatives of the world's greatest coffee-producing country.

The Office of War Information and the Office of Co-ordinator of Inter-American Affairs are scheduled to assume control at midnight tonight of the nation's commercial short wave radio transmitters. Unless there is a last-minute hitch today, all programs broadcast tomorrow on the higher frequencies will be sponsored by the Federal Government for the first time in radio's history.

Directors of the General Water, Gas and Electric Company ordered yesterday payment of 75 cents for the quarter ended June 30 and 75 cents for the quarter ended Sept. 30 on the company's preferred stock. On April 1 a dividend of 75 cents was distributed.

Praise for the efforts of State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican candidate for re-election in the Seventeenth Senatorial District, on behalf of teachers and civil service employes was expressed yesterday by J.M. O'Neill, chairman of the Legislative Conference of City Colleges; John M. O'Shea, legislative representative of the Health and Physical Education Teachers Association, and members of the Civil Service Employes Committee for Senator Coudert's Re-election.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- The newest success of Allied fliers in their raid on the Buin area, announced here today, ran General MacArthur's bomber total to twenty-seven Japanese ships sunk or damaged in six raids in the last eight days.

Africa is a combat zone that USO recreational facilities haven't reached yet, but it isn't too far away for a homesick corporal from this city to keep abreast of current Broadway productions, because, he writes, "occasionally a NEW YORK TIMES finds its way to this part of the world."

In a letter appearing in THE TIMES last Saturday, E.J. McGonigle wrote that the Brooklyn baseball club "two weeks ago had eight or nine candidates for the job vacated by Larry MacPhail." I think he exaggerated the number, but I know there will be about nine aspirants for Leo Durocher's Job if he enlists or is drafted.

Laundry business in defense areas has increased from 60 to 100 per cent, it was disclosed yesterday at the regional convention of the American Institute of Laundering, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore. The 500 laundry owners present were warned to make every effort to keep their help by improving working conditions as far as possible to curb the high labor turnover being experienced by the industry.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- An exceptionally heavy attendance of Midwest retailers is expected at the National Shoe Fair opening here next Monday, when some 800 lines will be shown in three hotels. The fair, which is sponsored jointly by the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association and the National Shoe Retailers Association, will be the first to make a comprehensive showing of styles permissible under order M-217 of the WPB.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- Spitfire fighters of the Royal Air Force shot up a freight train near Ostend and a ship near Zeebrugge, Belgium, this morning and later the light, fast Mosquito bombers attacked a German airfield and factory in the Netherlands and enemy ships off the Netherland coast, the Air Ministry reported tonight.

It appears that there is still doubt in some quarters as to how the voter should deal next Tuesday with those candidates whose records prior to Pearl Harbor will not stand careful scrutiny. Of course, this is not to be wondered at, I suppose, since there have been partisans in both major parties who have done their best to confuse the issue.

It was a great evening at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, for the Ballet Theatre was giving its annual presentation of "Giselle" with Alicia Markova in the title role and Anton Dolin as her partner. The occasion has become something of a rite over the years as the incredible perfection of Markova's performance has been bruited about.

The report of the Standard Oil Company of California, announced yesterday, disclosed a net profit of $21,453,073 for the first nine months of this year, after all charges, including provision of $8,534,000 for Federal income taxes. The result is equivalent to $1.65 a share and compares with $24,613,198, or $1.89 a share, earned in the corresponding period of last year, when Federal income tax deductions were $4,368,000.

While total store sales of department stores in this Reserve district showed a decline of 5 per cent for September, in comparison With a year ago, the basement departments had an increase of 7 per cent for the month, according to the review issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., Oct. 30 -- New Zealand fliers are fighting in the Solomons area under American command, Defense Minister Fred Jones revealed today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Wheat showed a firm undertone in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, but the volume of business remained restricted. Late in the session pressure from professional traders developed in the distant months and the market turned easy.

Thomas E. Dewey accused the Democrats last night of having substituted "evasion, contradiction, ghosts of the past and fruitless invective" for the normal political campaign, and added that the "reactionary elements now controlling the Democratic party in the State" have shown their "complete intellectual decay and moral bankruptcy."
College football today enters the second half of the season with a program that will bring out crowds of pre-war proportions.

It may be of interest to many Americans to learn that the British Army more than a year ago established a Bureau of Current Affairs which has for its purpose the fostering of group discussions among the soldiers concerning the vital problems of the day.

BERRYVILLE, Ark., Oct. 30 (AP) -- At least twenty-eight persons were killed and more than 200 injured, many critically, when a tornado leveled more than half of this Ozark Mountain town late last night.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- British East Africa troops have entered Fianarantsoa, most important town of Southern Madagascar, and it is doubtful that Vichy French forces that have withdrawn to the south can offer further effective resistance, a communique from British Lieut. Gen. Sir William Platt said tonight.

Invading the garment manufacturing district just south of Times Square, center of the home territory of David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, women of the family of Solicitor General Henry Epstein, Democratic candidate for Attorney General, distributed yesterday thousands of leaflets urging votes for Mr. Epstein.

Diplomatic reports disclose, to the surprise of many, that Admiral Francois Darlan may shortly succeed Pierre Laval as head of the Vichy Government. According to these reports, Admiral Darlan's true objective, when he started on his tour through French Africa, a fortnight ago, was to ingratiate himself with the Germans.

James Sanders, 54 years old, the cotton-mill owner from Mobile, Ala., who was arrested Oct. 23 at the request of the authorities of Copiah County, Miss., as a fugitive on an assault indictment growing out of a reported feud with his brother over the settlement of the estate of their father, was discharged on that charge yesterday by Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate in the Felony Court.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The Belgian Government in exile filed formal protests today against the forcible deportation by the Nazis of Belgian workers for labor in the Reich.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- Brig. Gen. Clayton L. Bissell revealed tonight that his Tenth United States Air Force had attacked the Japanese "somewhere" in Southeast Asia every day since the first enemy raid on American bases in Northeast India last Sunday.

In Topics of The Times of today the statement is made that "Winston Churchill has recently told us what plain people have known all along -- without the firm conviction that America was coming to its aid, the British people could never have mustered the resolution to stand up against Hitler."

Another war Christmas is near, and among those who will most need friends are the thousands of refugee children who have been torn from their families. Many of them are in Britain, victims of Nazi bombs that drove them from their homes. Those who have lost their parents have found refuge with good friends, with private families, in children's hostels.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 31 -- Russian troops defending the approaches to the Georgian military pass through the Caucasus Mountains have been forced to retreat again in the Nalchik area, but the Red Army defending Stalingrad killed 1,100 more Nazis in a successful stand yesterday in the ruins of that Volga River city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, commanding general of the United States Air Forces in the Middle East, received the Distinguished Flying Cross today for "extraordinary achievement" as commander of a squadron of six B-17 Flying Fortresses that attacked Andaman Island in the Bay of Bengal last Spring.

All work on the $81,000,000 Brooklyn-Battery vehicular tunnel, which was to be a link in the nation's chain of defense highways, was ordered stopped by the War Production Board yesterday until after the war. The board explained in Washington that the step was taken to conserve metal and other critical materials needed more urgently for the manufacture of war supplies.
A woman was killed and two women and two children were injured yesterday when a truck and trailer weighing seven tons ran away at Fourth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn.

There is an air of the Arabian Nights about this 1,671 miles of road from Dawson Creek in Alberta to the Alaskan Fairbanks. Only last March Canada and the United States came to an agreement about it. March 1, 1943, was the date set for its completion. Even that seemed a bit rosy.
LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A British East African Headquarters communique:
This is to applaud the committee of the Baseball Writers Association of America for its selection of Mort Cooper as the most valuable player in the National League for this year.

Magistrate Richard F. McKiniry's conviction last August of Sam Boston, 57-year-old betting commissioner, as a common gambler under the Vagrancy Act was reversed yesterday in a decision handed down by Justices Bayes, Doyle and Northrup of the Appellate Term of Special Sessions.

Plans to liquidate J. Stirling Getchell, Inc., one of the country's leading advertising agencies, were announced yesterday by J.V. Tarleton, president, after a certificate of dissolution had been filed in Albany. The stoppage of motor car production and rationing of tires and gasoline have brought about a sharp decrease in the agency's billings, he said.

This newspaper takes pride in the series of articles on the Pacific war which it has just published under the signature of its military critic and reporter, Hanson W. Baldwin: pride in Mr. Baldwin for doing the job so well, pride in the fact that in this country criticism of our military and naval effort is passed by the censors and has its due effect.

Some time today Mrs. Irene Russell of Portland, Ore., expects to be reunited with her son, William, 23-year-old gunner's mate in the Navy, somewhere in New York. The reunion is being arranged through the naval and city officials.

Our perfectly good headline said "Race Bias Charged to 5 Institutions." How many of us in commenting on this story of race discrimination in New York City orphanages will remember the 5 in the headline? Our subhead yesterday stated that as a result of such discrimination the five institutions will lose 405 orphans for whose care the city pays.

An audience sharply divided in its political sympathies hissed, booed and applauded Frederic R. Coudert Jr. and Jerry Finkelstein, Republican and Democratic candidates for the State Senate in the Seventeenth Senatorial District, when they spoke last night at a meeting in Hunter College, Park Avenue at Sixty-eighth Street.

The right of the War Labor Board to intervene in a strike of employes of a brokerage house was questioned yesterday by J.S. Bache Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, following receipt of a telegram from the WLB stating that it had taken over jurisdiction in the dispute.

The Association of American [Railroads estimated yesterdaythat: the Class I railroads in the first nine months of this year had /L combined net income of $572,300,' 000 after interesL, taxes and rentals. This compared with $359,710,614 for the similar period of 1941.

Despite the tension and bustling tempo of metropolitan life, New York City has a smaller percentage of rejections for military service because of mental disorders and nervous ailments than the national percentage, it was revealed yesterday by Colonel Leonard G. Rowntree, chief of the medical division of National Selective Service.

Mrs. Florence Kerr, an assistant commissioner of WPA, declares that work relief, "as such," is disappearing from the American scene, and that she would like to see the Government give the organization an "honorable discharge." The suggestion is altogether sound. In the present labor shortage there is no room for made-work.

OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 30 -- Litter brothers placed first and second today in the open allage stake for cocker spaniels, the first event on the program of the eighteenth meeting of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America held in the covers of the Ingham Hill game farm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Army General Staff officers have been sent on dangerous missions to every war theatre, it was disclosed today, to get a first-hand picture of front-line conditions for General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff.

Workmen took over the Harry Payne Whitney mansion at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street yesterday and the sound of hammer and falling masonry echoed through the once lavishly furnished halls of the big house.

The first-degree murder conviction of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, one of the most powerful racketeers in the country's criminal annals, and his two henchmen, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone, was affirmed yesterday by the Court of Appeals at Albany in a 4-to-3 decision.
In his "Wood, Field and Stream" column appearing in THE TIMES on Tuesday, Lincoln A. Werden mentioned an interesting phenomenon long known to those who love animals.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- The German labor decree in Belgium also covers the deporting of women for work in the Reich, but it was not known whether any women had been deported, the Belgium Government said here today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 30 -- Although General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel threw small lots of his armor into brief counter jabs here and there against the expanded British lines yesterday, British guns, tanks and infantry met the thrusts and inflicted casualties on Axis units.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United States has one food which Agriculture Department officials wish they could advise consumers to hoard. That is wheat flour.

Marshall Field Co., retail merchandising concern, reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 net profit of $1,231,773 after provision of $1,328,819 for Federal taxes. Earnings for this period were credited with an over-accrual of $412,384 in Federal taxes in the first six months, F.D. Corley, president, explained in his letter to stockholders.

Lady Williams-Taylor, who will leave next week for her home in Nasasu, the Bahamas, had among her guests at luncheon yesterday in the Oak Room of the Ritz-Carlton her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pierrepont Perry, and George MacDonald.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Roosevelt was critical of newspapers today for publishing a story about the imminent return for "consultation" of Lieut. Gen. Dwight Eisenhower, commander of the United States forces in the European theatre, although the article in question had been submitted in advance of publication to the Office of Censorship, which had interposed no objection.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Communist party petition on which Israel Amter was nominated for Governor was turned over today to the Dies committee investigating un-American activities. Stephen W. Birmingham, chief investigator for the group, took custody on a subpoena issued several weeks ago.

The only activity this week in the market for new securities was the public offering of $9,500,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the Alabama Great Southern Railroad through a syndicate headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler. This issue was taken quickly at the offering price of 99 3/4 and accrued interest.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The most sinister problem confronting the post-war world will be Germany, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the Scottish Unionist Conference in Glasgow today.

The Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's will swoop into the Polo Grounds before 30,000 fans today at 2 P.M. and hope to find victory over Fordham at this end of their transcontinental trek. This has been a colorful series and another rousing battle is anticipated.
"No rough stuff will be tolerated," Mayor La Guardia warned yesterday to those who plan to celebrate Halloween tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The 1,200 Army transports for which Andrew J. Higgins, Louisiana shipbuilder, is to receive a contract are to be built of wood. They will not be the regular C-46 Commandos, but an adaptation in plywood known as the C-76.
Tami Mauriello got up from the floor to win his fight at Madison Square Garden last night.

In his report to Congress on the operations of the Property Requisitioning Act in the past year, President Roosevelt points out that the mere existence of the Government's authority to requisition and its use in a limited number of instances have "expedited the voluntary sale of large quantities of critical material."

The deadline for retail liquor sales under the old tax schedule comes tonight and New York consumers gave every indication yesterday of being aware of the fact. All day eager purchasers filled department stores and the large volume outlets, snapping up everything in sight in a determined effort to stock up before the increased levies of as much as 50 cents a quart become effective.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 30 -- A Quisling frontier guard pursued a Norwegian woman refugee into Swedish territory and, at gunpoint, tried to compel her to return, but was arrested in time by Swedish military authorities, it was learned today.

In your editorials today and yesterday you are asking for a longer working week for building workers, seemingly under the impression that there is a shortage of such labor. But there is no such shortage and so even the prevailing forty-hour week on Federal construction jobs is unfair to those of us who have been idle a great part of the year.

The Treasury Department's proposed spending tax is certain to be revived in the next tax bill, already in the making, M.L. Seidman, certified public accountant, said yesterday afternoon in an address before the Association of Customers Brokers in the Governors Room of the New York Stock Exchange.

Manikins ranging in age from 11 months to 8 years of age will display wartime clothes for children in a miniature fashion show to be held at a luncheon of the United Kindergarten Mothers of New York City in the Hotel Pennsylvania today.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 30 -- David Giles, 45 years old, Negro, of 2 Rosemont Avenue, Teaneck, N.J., was shot and killed in his package liquor store here last night by two white men who the police described as "obviously professional" assassins.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Chairman George of the Senate Finance Committee said today that the $25,000 limitation on net salaries would cause the Treasury to lose tax revenue, would raise administrative costs and penalize the man who works for his income.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- China will need from five to ten billion dollars in foreign credits for post-war reconstruction and she is confident that "friendly powers" will advance this amount, Foreign Minister T.V. Soong told yesterday's closed session of the People's Political Council, reliable informants said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Led by a triple-threat halfback, Charley Kuhn, Kentucky rolled over George Washington, 27 to 6, before 5,000 spectators tonight.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

It began when an 18-year-old war worker was fined $25 for speeding in a battered 1933 coupe he was not licensed to drive. Repairs and fuel for the car had taken all his cash, so he sent word from the court to his employer.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- Reliable reports said tonight that Adolf Hitler's military "purge" had been extended to civilian quarters, with Dr. Karl Clodius, trade expert, and Helmut Suendermann, assistant press chief, the latest to be dismissed.

TRENTON, Oct. 30 -- The first all-woman jury to try a murder case in New Jersey, perhaps the first in the nation, decided tonight after nearly seven hours' deliberation that James Kearns, 33 years old, was guilty of second-degree murder in the killing of his wife, Marjorie, 22, in Trenton on Feb. 27, 1936.

Academic dignity on Morningside Heights was suspended for two hours yesterday afternoon when 200 Columbia College freshmen and sophomores put on a bruising test of strength, stamina and clothing in the traditional "rush" on South Field.

Proving that they practice what they preach, the forty-one members of the services to the armed forces division of the American Red Cross, North Atlantic area, reported at the Red Cross Blood Donor Center, 2 East Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday and contributed forty-one pints of blood to the metropolitan chapter's blood bank.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (AP) -- John Marsch's good colt Occupation will the season's 2-yearseek to clinch old championship tomorrow by winning the twentieth running of the $15,000 added Pimlico Futurity, with the speedy Count Fleet appearing to be the principal barrier.

It was not until Egon Petri had been playing half an hour last night in Carnegie Hall that the pianist did himself and the great music that he discoursed a real measure of justice. Then he made up greatly for lost time, as in his interpretations of Schubert, Franck, and later composers on the program.

War production plants in Erie and Niagara Counties have reached an agreement that it is expected will result in a full utilization of manpower and assist in "eliminating piracy" among employers in that area, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director, of the Manpower Commission, announced yesterday.

In anticipation of the resignation of Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. as chairman of the Republican National Committee soon after election, friends of Werner W. Schroeder, national committeeman from Illinois, are seeking commitments from members of the committee to elect him national chairman in place of Mr. Martin, it was learned yesterday.

GLASGOW, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The defensive phase of the war is drawing to a close and Great Britain is beginning to take the offensive, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today in an address before the Scottish Unionist (Conservative) Conference here.
Two of the losers in the opening round of the amateur championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Manhattan C.C. were first to finish and win in the second round last night.

By the end of 1943 war production manpower must jump from 12,500,000 to 20,000,000, Raymond Rubicam of the War Manpower Commission and chairman of the executive committee of Young Rubicam, New York advertising agency, declared in a message sent to members of the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, which concluded its "convention at home" yesterday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

That all was not well with German military and civilian medicine we learned last Winter when typhus infiltrated not only the troops on the Russian front but parts of Germany itself. With medical courses telescoped, doctors and nurses licensed to practice after inadequate training, and Jewish doctors persecuted, the demands of the army have accentuated a situation which had become disturbing by 1939 and which is now highly dangerous.

Alex Yokel decided yesterday to close the revival of "Three Men on a Horse" after tonight's performance. The John Cecil Holm-George Abbott comedy opened at the Forrest Theatre on Oct. 9 and will end its engagement there after a total of twenty-seven showings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Secretary Hull called today for "a world in which Jews, like every other race, are free to abide in peace and in honor." He made this statement in receiving a group of American rabbis who left with him a memorandum in connection with the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Balfour Declaration of Nov. 2, 1917.

While payrolls of the steel industry reached a new monthly high mark of $124,777,000 in September, nearly $5,000,000 over the previous peak, established in July, average employment declined for the third successive month to 641,000, a fall of 18,000 from the peak of 659,000 in June, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

There must be an immediate speeding up of the Police Department's drive against gambling and vice, Commissioner Valentine declared yesterday at a meeting in the line-up room at Police Headquarters, attended by 400 commanding officers of the department.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Herbert Haupt, executed Nazi saboteur, worked on the production line where the Norden bombsight was being manufactured, according to testimony given today in Federal court, where six of Haupt's relatives and friends are on trial for treason.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 30 -- The two afternoon newspapers, Aftontidningen and Nya Dagligt Allehanda, today published a letter allegedly circulated by a large German firm here among Germans residing in Sweden warning them against persecutions by the Swedes and advising them not to provoke Swedish citizens "until further notice."

A wage increase of approximately $5 a week for 15,000 truck drivers employed in New York City was recommended in an award handed down last night by Hugh S. Sheridan, impartial chairman of the Arbitration Authority for the New York City Trucking Industry.

In a telegram sent yesterday by Arturo Toscanini to Deems Taylor, president of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, the conductor made known his attitude in choosing four American works for performance at the concert he will direct tomorrow in Radio City with the NBC Symphony Orchestra.
