A tearful feminine voice over a telephone, pleading for help in finding a "regulation shirt" for one of the uniformed women's organizations, was the origin of the uniform department that has been formally opened by Saks Fifth Avenue.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 29 (Delayed) -- As the use of modern communications, built up by generations of patient, painstaking effort and toil, is impaired by the ravages and demands of war, trading throughout the Middle East gradually is moving back to primitive forms of merchandise and barter.

The higher parity price for cotton brought a flurry of buying orders into the cotton futures market at the opening yesterday, but scale-up hedge selling subsequently dulled the buying enthusiasm and pared the initial gains. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed 5 to 12 points above Thursday's final quotations, with the near months leading the list.
VICHY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Admiral Francois Darlan reported today to the Pierre Laval Cabinet on "measures taken to assure the defense of French West Africa," including the important naval base at Dakar.

Concern over the post-war world dominated the 119th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs yesterday in the Hotel Astor. Delegates from 600 clubs representing a membership of 350,000 attended.

VICHY, France, Oct. 30 -- Another trainload of French war prisoners, the fourth to be released under the new system of exchange for skilled workers, reached Compiegne today from Germany. There were 1,075 prisoners in the group, which was welcomed by Fernand de Brinon, Secretary of State in the office of the Chief of Government.

One issue of railroad bonds aggregating $9,500,000 was the only new security offered here this week for public subscription. The total compared with two flotations totaling $1,875,000 last week and with $62,473,000 for nine bond offerings in the week ended on Oct. 31, 1941.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 30 -- John Dun, 50-year-old American Field Service ambulance driver from Tucson, Ariz., saved ten wounded men and three ambulances after three hours in the sands of the Qattara Depression under intense enemy fire, it was revealed today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- When the Westchester Professional Golfers Association, in a wartime gesture, opened its weekly one-day tourneys this year to allow a member pro to play with three amateur partners, providing the four played together, it was hardly anticipated that any one would score the grand slam that Jerry Desio of Green Valley made at Bonnie Briar today.
A special meeting of stockholders of Ludlow Manufacturing Associates has been called in Boston for Nov. 19 to act upon a plan of reorganization, for which a two-thirds vote is required.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Mordecai Ezekiel, New Deal economist, has been appointed executive assistant by Charles E. Wilson, vice chairman of the War Production Board.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Demand deposits in Canadian chartered banks totaled $1,526,786,000 on Sept. 30, compared with $1,422,883,000 Aug. 31 and $1,110,339,000 on Sept. 30 last year, the Finance Department reported today in its monthly statement.

THE Music Critics' Circle of New York City held its first meeting of the season last week. It was decided to make awards to American composers in the same categories as last year, namely to orchestral, chamber music and dramatic works, both new and revived, and in the same manner, by selecting several works for rehearing at its concerts.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- This is the high season in the Country of the Sun -- or so they tell you in the Southwest. Some say that when the friendly Papagos and the shy Pima Indians kneel before the famed Wishing Shrine of the Old Pueblo the season has come again to this vast area of warm sunshine and cloudless days in Winter.

WITH the reading of every new book in the Rivers of America Series, each volume written by one whose association with his river is close and personal, one realizes more and more how ineradicably interlocked with flowing water are the memories of those who have been brought up near it.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Billy Murphy, 165-pound halfback from Siloam Springs, Ark., and his good right arm brought Mississippi State its third successive Southeastern Conference football victory today, a 6-0 triumph over Auburn, before 9,000 fans.

Our children must not bear the cost of war. So President Roosevelt has said, and so every American believes. They must not bear that cost in weakened bodies, in ignorance, in emotional instability, or in the warping and undermining of character.

" HEROES of the Great Patriotic War" are being postally honored by the U.S.S.R., according to word received from Moscow. They include seven guerrilla fighters who won laurels in the heavy fighting around Sevastopol before the city fell to the Germans, and among them are Talalikhin, Erhekalin, a farm housewife named Kosmodemjanskaja, and a farmer named Costello.

THE little boys have their picture books of airplanes and the big ones have their mystery and adventure tales of aviation, but a good story in this field for the in-between has been as hard to find as a hen's tooth until Esther Wood wrote "Silver Widgeon."

TO the comment that "They Were Expendable" had been a fine choice of title for his book on Lieutenant Bulkeley and his crew, W.L. White said: "I had to shove it down the throat of every one who had anything to do with the book before publication.

After Mrs. Roosevelt had regaled the visiting king and queen of England with American "hot dogs" and hamburgers, the public wondered what they would set before her when she returned their call, and the immediate supposition was fish and chips.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- A powerful Boston College football team that brought back memories of Charley O'Rourke's days dealt deep humiliation to Georgetown today by romping over the haughty Hoyas, 47 to 0, in the presence of 30,000 amazed spectators at Fenway Park.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31 -- No Hollywood movie writer would have the nerve to turn in a script ending the way Harvard's victory over Princeton did in the Crimson's old stadium today.

The Germans broadcast yesterday a special announcement, without any Allied confirmation, that great convoy battles were raging in the Atlantic Ocean and that in one attack yesterday U-boats had sunk eighteen Allied merchantmen totaling 131,000 tons near the Canary Islands.
The last-minute rush of "beat-the-tax" buyers swamped liquor stores yesterday. The volume of buying established new records, with some stores reporting that business was double that of Friday.

DRESS ORDERS: Girls of Britain's East Suffolk Land Army were ordered last week to spruce up their appearance and cease the "deplorable habit of combining most unsuitable civilian garments with uniforms." It was said that even American soldiers, used to the sweaters and chapped bare legs of school girls at home, were beginning to comment critically.

Since Dec. 17, 1903, the whole world, with the sole exception of the Smithsonian Institution, has known that the Wright brothers at Kitty Hawk were the first human beings to fly a practical airplane. The Smithsonian, however, clung to the claim of its former secretary, Professor Samuel Langley, to the prior invention of successful plane models.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Still maintaining her whirlwind pace and fatiguing every one trying to keep up with her, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt called on Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands today, inspected a collection of Royal Air Force photographs, lunched with the American Newspaper Correspondents Association, had tea with the Duchess of Kent, visited St. James's Palace and received President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia and other Czechoslovak leaders.

WITH most of the new Fall floor shows already launched, the majority of night club proprietors and restaurant owners are content this week just to rest and smile at the tinkle of the cash register and the bustle of crowded rooms.

Tuesday's ballots may be as strategic as bullets in fighting this war. In this conviction, leaders of the League of Women Voters are winding up the most intensive effort in their history to get the largest possible number of the electorate to the polls.

Captain William H. Lee, assistant manager of the United States Lines, has been called to active service in the Navy and has reported for duty at a post outside the United States, it was announced yesterday. He has been in the naval reserve, with the rank of commander, since 1919.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Chet Podd's kicking and passing sparked Bucknell to an 13-to-7 upset victory over Lafayette today before a crowd of 7,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- King Charles II of England closed the coffee houses of London because he believed that they were breeding places for rebellion, but the OPA is cutting down on the use of coffee by citizens of the United States because coffee is a necessity and every one must get his share.

A three-month nationwide search by government agents for Edward James Smythe, described as former chairman of the executive committee of the Protestant War Veterans Association and an active Axis propagandist, ended here with his arrest Friday night and his arraignment yesterday for conspiracy to violate the wartime sedition statute.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Premier of South Africa, in a "man-to-man" broadcast in Dutch to the Netherlands and Belgium tonight, bade the people of those countries be courageous and have hope, for "humanity will yet gather the fruit of the sacrifices borne by our sorely stricken generation."

After the swift conquest of Poland, Norway, the Netherlands, Belgium and France many people began to assume that Germany had somehow changed the fundamental laws of warfare. They believed that because of the application of the gas engine to military uses in the air and on the ground, the great conflict would be won or lost solely in terms of German "Blitz."

New York is taking a major role in the production of materials and parts for the country's rapidly growing merchant marine, according to a survey of city and State industries in this field, made public last week by the regional news bureau of the Office of War Information.

Scores of inventors have tried to generate electricity with the aid of windmills. Because the wind does not always blow, it has been necessary to use storage batteries, with the result that over-all costs and charges have proved to be formidable. The most scientific attempt thus far made to solve the problem seems to be presented by the installation on top of 2,000-foot Grandpa's Knob, near Rutland, Vt.

Arthur Sullivan of St. Francis Prep sped to victory in the sixth annual N.Y.N. interscholastic cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. He finished the 2 1/4-mile event in 11:51.6, leading 364 other harriers.

AS a scene for a novel, a State orphan asylum would seem offhand to be somewhat unpromising. One tends to expect a story that is bitter, grim, sober-toned and perhaps a little monotonous. One is haunted, not unreasonably, by the ghost of Oliver Twist.

Thomas E. Dewey wound up his formal campaign for the Governorship last night with a rally in the Bronx, where he stood confidently on a platform in Theodore Roosevelt High School and poked fun at the campaign efforts of the Democratic opposition.

OPERATIONS of American forces in the European theatre -- and that means those garrisoned in Northern Ireland as well as those on this island -- are directed from what Londoners call "a block of luxury flats." Translated into New Yorkese this means an apartment house that might be found in the better sections of Queens or upper Manhattan.

THE American Republic plainly confronts a new era. The nation which emerges from the stormy events of our time -- the Great Depression, the New Deal and the Second World War -- will have undergone a drastic alteration. In many respects its economy, its social outlook and its political preconceptions will be completely transformed.

PLANT MODIFIER -- Colchicine, which changes plant inheritance, so that vegetables and flowers of a new kind can be produced, has a rival in sanguinarine, extracted from Sanguinaria canadensis, the scientific name of a common Eastern wild flower called bloodroot because of its red juice.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- Although Democratic registration in California exceeds the Republican by 1,000,000, Attorney General Earl Warren, Republican, is the favorite over Governor Culbert L. Olson, Democrat, after a campaign marked by considerable mudslinging.

The forty-ninth season of Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, will open Wednesday morning with a lecture on the war by Quentin Reynolds, war reporter and eyewitness of the Dieppe Commando Raid. Held every week-day except Thursday, the lectures commence at 11 A.M.

With New York stores leading the way, reports from stores and retail organizations in all sections of the country indicate widespread participation in cooperative and individual campaigns to urge the public to do its Christmas shopping early and to carry as many packages away with them as possible.

QUITE possibly you have now and again noted pictures in the public prints of Donald Voorhees, and if so you may have wondered where you had seen the gentleman before. Ever willing to oblige, these columns will tell you and then get on with the story.

Copper sellers had to adjust themselves to new restrictions last week as the War Production Board sought to step up deliveries of metals to the most important channels of armament manufacture, according to The Associated Press.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 31 -- A relatively indifferent registration, coupled with the absence of some 30,000 men in the service, indicates a light vote in Rhode Island, a condition that Republicans hope will enhance their chances.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 31 (AP) -- In as thrilling a game as ever was played in their colorful and spirited rivalry, the Wolfpack of North Carolina State College upset favored North Carolina, 21 to 14, in a Southern Conference football game played before 14,000 fans today.

I don't invent the words that crop up daily in the English language, I just record them. I don't get excited over some of the new recruits, not even those that seem silliest, for I know that only the fittest will survive. The others are scrapped, screened out over the sieve of usage and thrown away beyond recovery.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 31 -- Mothers, wives, sisters and sweethearts were instrumental in starting the movement in the Haute-Savoie Department of France against the departure of workers to Germany, according to information reaching here tonight.
WE noticed in last Sunday's TIMES that Roy C. Witmer, vice president in charge of sales for the National Broadcasting Company, took a turn at bat in behalf of the networks.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A Pitt eleven hardened by tough opponents and outweighing Carnegie Tech, its home town rival, by an average of eighteen pounds to a man, wasn't forced a great deal today in whipping the Tartans 19 to 6 before a small crowd of 5,000.

A large-scale bookmaker who tried to outwit the police by operating from a rented room in a twenty-two-story apartment house at 850 Amsterdam Avenue, near 102d Street, was seized there yesterday with his clerk. Also arrested was Allan Steinberg, 32 years old, lessee of the well-appointed five-room apartment, who was charged with allowing the bookmaker to ply his trade.

THIS may be a mechanized war but it still leaves room for the lone soldier with a keen eye and a good rifle -- the sniper. Dispatches from every front have paid particular attention to sniping, and New York has recently seen in person the remarkable Ludmilla Pevlichenko, the 25-year-old Soviet woman sniper.

A tradition nearly a century old will be broken at City College next February, when, for the first time since the college was founded as the Free Academy in 1848, women will be admitted on an equal basis with men to day sessions of three of the college's professional schools -- Technology, Business and Education.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 31 -- The University of Richmond eleven, which was supposed to specialize in forward passing, did most of its gaining on the ground today to beat Washington and Lee, 8 -- 6, before 5,000.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The University of California at Los Angeles swept aside another barrier in its drive to a Pacific Coast Conference football title today by thumping Stanford, 20 to 7. Fifty-five thousand spectators saw the game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- "New and unusual clauses designed to break Federal rent ceilings" are creeping into rental leases throughout the country, the Office of Price Administration said today, adding that they could not be enforced if the tenant knows his rights.

AUGUSTA TUCKER'S first novel, published in 1939, told the story of Miss Susie Slagle's boarding house in Baltimore. Both Miss Slagle and the hostel were unique. She was a charming gentlewoman who possessed kindness and wisdom and tact; the place she ran with the help of Hizer, her colored butler and man-of-all-work, was limited to Johns Hopkins medical students.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, Federal Bureau of Investigation chief, today called the arrest of Heinz August Luning, Axis spy under death sentence in Cuba, a "magnificent" piece of work by the Cuban police and their visiting head, General Manuel Benitez.

The Columbia University War Relief Committee will sponsor a country fair Friday and Saturday featuring Chinese sword dancers, English round dances and American square dances to provide a collaborative United Nations motif. The fair will open at 5:30 P.M. on Friday and at 8 on the following evening.

THE League of Composers will hold a joint meeting of all of its committees, Wednesday at 4:30 P. M., at the home of Mrs. W. Murray Crane, 820 Fifth Avenue, to discuss "music in wartime," and develop plans whereby the league will be enabled to function with the greatest efficiency during the present world crisis.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The bitterest political campaign in Illinois in decades will come to a showdown Tuesday when more than 4,000,000 voters will decide whether C. Wayland Brooks, Republican pre-war isolationist, will return to the United States Senate, or whether Representative Raymond S. McKeough, Democratic New Dealer, will displace him.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A suit charging Montgomery Ward Co. with violation of ceiling price regulations was filed in the United States District Court today by the Office of Price Administration. The action alleged that prices on many items listed in the company's Fall-Winter 1942 catalogue were from 2 to 85 cents above prices filed by the company with the local war price and rationing board.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- An intense campaign closed in Connecticut with the customary predictions of victory by both parties, averaging 35,000 plurality for the State ticket by the incumbent Democrats and 25,000 by the Republicans.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- A survey of political opinion in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, which comprises Orange, Dutchess and Putnam Counties, disclosed today that Representative Hamilton Fish maintains an edge over his Democratic-American Labor Party opponent, Ferdinand A. Hoyt, despite the attacks made against Mr. Fish's pre-Pearl Harbor isolationist record in Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- Despite the furor which has sprung up outside the Securities and Exchange Commission since the proposals for changes in the proxy rules were suggested several months ago, it now appears that an unrelated outcropping from the prolonged discussions is in the offing and is of such a character that it will meet almost universal approbation.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Members of the United States mission of aeronautical experts who have just completed a tour of Britain expressed admiration today for the British aircraft industry, both in production and in the spirit of the workers.

STARTING today, local stores and many others throughout the country will urge earlier Christmas shopping in order to conserve delivery service, etc. The "overseas Christmas," with a deadline of today, saw more than 1,000,000 parcels for the armed services abroad received for distribution.

POST-WAR: Eighteen months ago Parliament commissioned one of Britain's outstanding economists, Sir William Henry Beveridge, to survey economic problems likely to arise after the war. Last week word came from London that Sir William had just about completed his report -- 80,000 words, mostly in longhand.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The war has revived Chicago's faith in its own destiny as the Sandburgian "wheat-handler, pork-packer City of the Big Shoulders." It is not so much the volume of war orders that swamp its factories as the fact that the orders are establishing the city as pre-eminent in lines of industry which are expected to be all-important in the post-war world -- aviation, rubber, aluminum.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- Notre Dame's Fighting Irish, beaten and tied in early season contests, continued on the comeback trail to the football heights today by defeating a stubborn Navy eleven, 9 to 0, for their fourth straight conquest.

While total business kept up its brisk pace, lines grew shorter and deliveries became slower on whatever merchandise was still available in the wholesale markets, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

THE use of guest stars on radio programs is nothing new, to be sure, but seldom have the sponsors employed their services with such a vengeance as this season. As one listener put it, a program without Madeleine Carroll or Orson Welles might win a Peabody prize for originality.

Heavy buying of liquors to beat the higher Federal excise tax and of foodstuffs in restricted supply featured retail trade here last week. Department store volume was substantially higher, with some establishments having increases ranging to 25 per cent ahead of the comparative 1941 week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Merchandise exports -- exclusive of shipments to American military forces abroad -- exceeded $700,000,000 in both August and September and were the highest on record for those months the Census Bureau reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Airplane production for September was 10 per cent above August, ordnance production was up 7 per cent, the production of ships for the Navy and Army rose 22 per cent and the production of merchant ships by 10 per cent, Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chief, said today in the fourth of a series of monthly reports to the country.

Germany has protested to Sweden over publication by two Stockholm newspapers of a mysterious form letter, said to have been circulated among German nationals in Sweden, purporting to give them "secret instructions" to refrain from provoking Swedes "until further notice," according to a Berlin broadcast recorded here yesterday by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP)-- Edsel Ford, head of the Ford Motor Company, said today that through the education efforts of the Federal Bureau of Investigation "the American people as a whole have been enlisted for law enforcement, not only morally enlisted, but intelligently and actively."

If Dr. Gustav Egloff, distinguished oil chemist, is right -- and he usually is -- we need not worry about synthetic rubber. In an address recently delivered before the American Institute of Chemists he showed that we can get all we need from natural gas.

THE original device by which Miss Barksdale presents the beginning of our great American feast day gives to an old story a fresh and rich perspective, for we learn of it through the eyes and ears of a grandchild of two of the first celebrants.

A cold and dreary Labor Day week-end at a Connecticut Summer colony forms the setting for this novel. Tom and Sally Acheson are expecting a self-invited and unwanted guest, but she does not arrive on the train which she was supposed to have taken.

TORONTO, Oct. 31 -- Toronto's Stanley Cup champions vastly outplayed the New York Rangers, circuit titleholders, tonight for a 7-2 victory in the opening game of the National Hockey League season before 11,777 fans at the Maple Leaf Gardens.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 31 (AP) -- An inspired West Virginia University team, striking repeatedly with sledgehammer drives and a sharp passing attack, pulled Penn State from the ranks of the unbeaten today with a 24-0 triumph before a homecoming throng of 12,016.

Seven hundred and fifty persons attended a dinner last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel commemorating the seventieth birthday anniversary of Dr. Emanuel Libman, physician and scholar long identified with the Hebrew University in Palestine.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Williams continued undefeated in football today, giving a brilliant display of power plays, blocking and aerial defense, before which hitherto undefeated Union lost, 41 to 15.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 31 -- Underdog Wisconsin, arising to gridiron heights, blasted Ohio State's Buckeyes from football's No. 1 ranking today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Sales of wholesalers advanced only 3 per cent in September over the same month a year ago, the Census Bureau announced today, while sales for the first nine months this year were 16 per cent above the corresponding period of 1941.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Tennessee scored all its points in the second quarter, combining breaks with neat passing and running to rout Louisiana State 26 -- 0, before 15,000 today. It was L.S.U.'s first Southeastern Conference loss.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that deferments would be granted to families required to move from low-rental project apartments because of the earnings of 18 and 19-year-old youths. The regulation will remain in effect, the announcement said, until Congress takes final action on a bill lowering the draft age to include young men in those categories.

FOR more than two years France has been under the Nazi heel. During that period the Germans have been in control of the press and radio and maintained a strict censorship on all outgoing mail. There is, as a result, an almost complete blackout of information on developments inside France, particularly on the evolution of public opinion in that country.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Drexel couldn't stop Big Jim Hardy today. Result: Gettysburg beat the visitors from Philadelphia, 18 to 0.

BY producing "Native Son" at $1.65 top, the Brandts may make some money. At least this column hopes so. For whatever their motive may have been, they are performing a public service: As directed by Orson Welles, "Native Son" is excellent theatre, put on the stage with creative imagination.

The fuel oil shortage is going to change all of us oil users (who formerly have lolled in our beds and listened to the clicking of the thermostat turning on the oil burner) into Eskimos, carpenters, plumbers and "wool wearers." Even so, we are not going to be very comfortable unless we watch out, and watch out very quickly.

THE nation now beckons to young men of 18 and 19 and says. "Come." For two years the question of including them in selective service was gingerly avoided. In hundreds of thousands of homes parents still regarded them as children, entitled to at least a few more sheltered months before becoming involved in the grimmest lottery of the human race.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A Navy Department communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 31 -- National Socialist Sunday will be celebrated in Copenhagen and other large Danish cities tomorrow by Dr. Fritz Clausen and his party of Danish Quislings. To avoid friction, Copenhagen newspapers have asked the population to stay away from the neighborhood of the meeting halls.
In reply to numerous inquiries about his position in this election, Wendell L. Willkie said last night that he would vote for Thomas E. Dewey and the entire Republican State ticket.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- Pilots who participated in Flying Fortress attacks on enemy shipping in the Buin and Faisi area Friday night reported today that they left two ships in wreckage along the beach and a third probably damaged from near misses.
ST. PAUL, Oct. 31 -- Led by Senator Joseph H. Ball and Governor Harold E. Stassen, Republican candidates for Congressional and chief State offices in Minnesota are expected to be re-elected.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who has taken no announced position on the candidates for Governor in the present campaign, yesterday endorsed Frank C. Moore, the Republican candidate for State Controller, on the basis of competence and experience, and attacked Joseph V. O'Leary, Democratic and American Labor nominee, as a "ghost" trying to "sneak back into office."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Forces of the American Army overseas, with 300,000 soldiers sent abroad in the last two months, now total about 800,000 men.

These twenty-five years since the Balfour Declaration, on Nov. 2, 1917, have shown that in Palestine Jews can do all the work and perform all services necessary for the life of a self-sustaining community. In merchandising, finance, learning and various crafts Jews had shown their skill in many lands and over long periods.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Oct. 31 -- Relying mostly on straight football, the Amityville High eleven trounced Babylon, 34 to 12, today on the winner's field to keep its undefeated and untied record safe through five games this season.

The first certificate for completion of apprenticeship issued by the State Apprenticeship Council was presented yesterday morning to Eli Cooper of 1,153 Colgate Avenue, the Bronx, a machinist employed on war work at the Potter Tool and Machine Works, 79 East 130th Street.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A Soviet information bureau communique:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 31 -- A conflict that may lead to interesting developments was raging today between the Chamber of Deputies committee investigating anti-Argentine activities and Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu.

THE leaders of the American motion-picture industry have an "intelligent understanding" of the role which the screen may be expected to play in the war program, according to Sidney Bernstein, film adviser to the British Ministry of Information.

BEFORE, during and after this country's participation in the First World War there was a great deal of excitement about the hyphenated citizen. The German-American, and, to a slighter degree, the Austrian and Hungarian-American became somewhat of a national issue. Theodore Roosevelt emphatically called them a menace, and lesser men echoed his vivid patriotic objections to "hyphenism."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- At least 3,000,000 women must be recruited into the country's labor force within the next twelve months if a serious shortage is to be avoided, Secretary Perkins said today in commenting on the virtual disappearance of unemployment and the appearance of shortages in specific industries everywhere.

LONDON, Oct 31 (UP) -- Labor Minister Ernest Bevin said in a short-wave broadcast directed to French workers today that those who go to Germany to work in war factories would be held as prisoners and hostages and "if they attempt to exercise the freedom to return, concentration camps will be awaiting them."

JAKE FALSTAFF once said of himself: "I elected, in the wisdom of my youth, to be a peasant. * * * Less of my peasanthood than you might imagine has been stripped from me." It was a remark Emerson would have liked and understood.

In a recent dispatch from Moscow, Ralph Parker, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent, wrote: "Winter need not seriously check operations in the Caucasus, which, despite the Stalingrad drama, now is Russia's main front." Last week the Wehrmacht, after a two months' stalemate in the foothills of the mountain range that runs 700 miles between the Black and Caspian Seas, pushed forward again.

Stuart Goodman, high-scoring back, gave another impressive exhibition of his skill as he led Abraham Lincoln High's eleven to a 40-to-0 victory over Thomas Jefferson on Lincoln's field yesterday. The triumph was the fifth straight this season for undefeated and untied Lincoln and the seventeenth in a row over a three-year period.

BESIDE the dead body of Sir Maurice Lawes are the shattered fragments of a snuff-box that once belonged to Napoleon. But those fragments tell a tale, or, rather, two tales, one true and one false. One tale is that Eve Neill, engaged to be married to Sir Maurice's son, Toby, is the murderer.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- General MacArthur's bombers, which blasted three Japanese warships in Buin and Faisi anchorages yesterday, rounded out a month's air offensive around the Solomons that cost the enemy twenty-nine ships sunk or damaged and sixteen more possibly damaged, a tabulation of official reports revealed tonight.

Secondary schools throughout the country are adjusting their programs to meet the demands of war and in many, both public and private, the emphasis now is upon mathematics, physics, science and technical shop courses.

THE author of this book was the personal pilot of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. He began flying for China in 1935 and continued until late in 1941, during which period it is probable that he saw more of China than most living men.

Former President Herbert Hoover, who was Administrator of Food during the last war, made an appeal last night for a program of food production to meet the "appalling situation" Europe faces after the present conflict. He declared that production and a prepared study of food supply could meet the problem.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago tomorrow the Balfour Declaration was given to the world. It was in the form of a letter from the British Foreign Secretary to Lord Walter Rothschild. In it Arthur J. Balfour wrote: "His Majesty's Government view with favor the establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people and will use their best endeavors to facilitate the achievement of that object."

MOSCOW, Oct. 31 -- Though the Stalingrad battle, now entering its eleventh week, still holds first place in interest here, all reports indicate that the Caucasian front now is the scene of the most significant operations.

Northern gardeners are often urged to get their hardy bulbs in the ground as early as possible. That is good advice in the case of daffodils and a necessity when the Fall bloomers are considered, but it is a mistake to include the bulbous irises in the list.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31 -- Although redistricting has reduced Indiana's delegation in the House of Representatives from twelve to eleven, it is probable that the Democrats will increase their present four seats to five or even six.

The government's campaign to recruit former merchant seamen for sea duty with the expanding merchant marine brought responses from 16,000 merchant seamen and maritime engineers who volunteered to join the Victory Fleet, the War Shipping Administration announced yesterday.

Bond dealings last month continued on an active scale and, although the turnover was slightly below that of the previous month, it was the second largest of any month in three years, or since September, 1939, and the heaviest for the month of October in six years, or since 1936.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Over the air waves to the embattled Marines in the Solomons crackled this tribute today:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Representative Leroy D. Downs, Democrat, of Norwalk, publisher of an evening newspaper in that city, chuckled tonight as he disclosed that as a publisher he had received a letter from Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., minority leader of the House and Republican National Chairman, asking him "to give every consideration to advancing the candidacy of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce," Republican candidate for Congress in the Fourth Connecticut District.

The sixteenth annual Debutantes New Year's Ball will take place on the night of Jan. 1 on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. As in past years, several young women will make their debuts at the dance. Mrs. Thomas W. Edgar is chairman of the patroness committee, Miss Tricia Hurst heads the junior group and Miss Louise Stewart the sub-debutante committee.

Following announcement of the order freezing salaries and wages on Tuesday, a number of companies have taken steps toward revising or discontinuing their bonus plans, especially those based on profits, it was learned yesterday.

New securities offered here in October for public subscription were the smallest in amount for that month in several years, with bond flotations falling to the lowest total for an October since 1939 and stock emissions to the poorest level since 1933.
New York's General Postoffice was a scene reminiscent of a heavy day before Christmas yesterday, as huge piles of packages intended for members of the armed services overseas awaited dispatch.

Paul Governali's pass floated through the gathering dusk at Baker Field and Otto Apel, making a catch over his shoulder like an outfielder on a long fly ball, raced to a touchdown less than two minutes from the end of the Columbia-Cornell thriller yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The British people and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt seem to have a natural affinity for each other. The generally misunderstood and widely criticized British are almost pathetically pleased at every sincere effort to appreciate the complexities of their problems, and there is no doubt in their minds that the President's wife is sincere and serious in her fact-finding mission.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in October was the heaviest of any month this year and the most active for a corresponding month since 1939. However, the volume of business for the ten months of the year was the smallest in twenty-nine years, or since 1913.

Pogo sticks and roller skates may come into vogue eventually. Bicycles and trains, at the moment, are solving the problems of transportation for suburban clubwomen, especially in maintaining attendance at meetings. Manhattan has recently become a favorite place of rendezvous, since all (rail) roads lead to New York, in this metropolitan area.

NOTES on some round-the-clock short-wave listening. An Englishman speaking to Europe, after comparing Von Ludendorf with Herr Hitler "because he knew how to make war but knew nothing of peace," sent Joe Goebbels a few tips for his weekly article in "Das Reich."

PRIZES have been awarded in the fifty-third annual exhibition of American painting and sculpture, current at the Chicago Art Institute through Dec. 10. The Ada S. Garrett prize of $750 was given to Edward Hopper of New York for his painting "Night Hawks."

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 31 -- The Republican party, normally resurgent in non-Presidential election years, appears likely to elect at least five out of seven of its nominees to major State and Congressional positions.

DENVER, Oct. 31 -- United and vigorous protest is coming from Colorado gold mining men against the WPB order which closed all big gold mines. The order spells death, they say, for Cripple Creek, Victor, Alma Fairplay, Ward and other smaller camps chiefly dependent on gold for livelihood.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Trading in grain futures today on the Board of Trade here was small and dull, the maximum price range being 3/8 cent a bushel. It was not until late in the session that wheat had a range of more than 1/8 cent, but covering by local shorts afterward resulted in a little activity, and the market closed 1/8 to 1/4 cent higher than yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Roosevelt questioned in the past week while speaking at a press conference the use of the adjective "decisive" to describe the battle centering in the Island of Guadalcanal in the Solomons.

Declaring that support of State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican candidate for re-election in the Seventeenth Senatorial District, was not a question of politics, Dr. Samuel Nirenstein, president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, expressed yesterday disagreement with "the unfair charges made against Senator Coudert."
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31 -- The Mexican Government has decided to send troops to overseas battlefronts, it was learned today from authoritative sources.

MONTREAL, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Canadiens won their National Hockey League opener tonight, capturing a fast-moving game from the Bruins, 3 -- 2, before a packed house in the Forum. Maurice Richard, the Canadiens' only rookie, made his debut in the game and assisted in his team's first goal.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 31 -- Another United States fighter pilot scored a victory as the American Air Force continued to play an important role in the Allied air offensive, which is still inflicting heavy damage on Axis forward defenses and on rear areas.

I believe that you overlooked a beautiful denouement in the little story you told recently in your "About" column in which the generous Barmecide of the Arabian Nights tale tantalized a beggarly wretch by feeding him phantom meals.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (Canadian Press) -- Arsenal gained sole possession of first place in the Football League's southern section today by defeating Crystal Palace, 7 -- 1, while Chelsea was held to a 1-1 draw by Tottenham.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- Two pass interceptions and a 52-yard dash, the only long gain from scrimmage of the game, toppled Army from the ranks of the unbeaten today as Pensylvania defeated the cadets, 19 -- 0, before 68,000 at Franklin Field.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- Sixteen "boom towns" populated wholly by persons of Japanese ancestry during the Summer and early Fall have now become "ghost cities." As they mushroomed on race tracks and county fair grounds of Washington, Oregon, California and Arizona, their thousands of 100-by-25-foot wooden barracklike buildings offered temporary shelter for more than 100,000 Japanese evacuees, removed from their coastal homes by the Army in a forced population movement unparalleled in American history.
The first round of the battle for Guadalcanal ended last week. The second round of the engagement which, it seemed clear, would be a battle for the entire Southwest Pacific, was awaited.

ALL children skip, chant, hum, invent sound effects when they play train, or in some other way express themselves in rhythm. All children have music in them. Conventional music lessons can soon take it out of them, as, looking back, many parents can testify -- parents who now say, "I can't carry a tune."

SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 31 --Winning first honors today in the all-age stake for English springer spaniels at the eighteenth meeting of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America, Staindrop Hurricane of Greenfair became a field trial champion.

The National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War is revising its agenda to draw the full force of its membership into the immediate war effort. An emergency council is being appointed to direct these activities and the cooperation of the Department of State has been granted for a new program designed to strengthen the national defense against psychological inroads attempted by foreign agents.

Tomorrow is the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Balfour Declaration favoring "the establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people." Dr. Chaim Weizmann, interviewed by S. J. Woolf for today's issue of our Magazine, and Dr. Judah Leib Magnes, whose letter from Jerusalem also is published today, give TIMES readers perspective on what the quarter century has brought.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine an article by J. B. Priestley warns the world against hate and counsels wisdom as a means of victory. Mr. Priestley lays the ground for his exposition by saying that making people conscious of war may be overdone, and "in any event propaganda of this kind can never become the solid foundation of morale."

The new master plan to control the flow of raw materials to war plants, now being evolved by the War Production Board for application in the second quarter of next year, will be a compromise between the contract warrant plan, favored by automobile manufacturers, and the steel budget plan, brain child of the steel industry, reports last week indicated.

DETROIT, Oct. 31 -- Both the Democrats and the Republicans are afraid to predict the outcome of the Michigan election in which the chief interest lies in the race between Senator Prentiss M. Brown, Democrat, and Judge Homer Ferguson, Republican.

WE Chileans," wrote one of the judges of the literary contest sponsored by La Nacion and won by Magdalena Petit with this remarkable novel of seventeenth-century Chile, "normally lack imagination, and have instead good judgment and common sense," a condition that, despite advantages, he considers "limiting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The National Symphony Orchestra, which opens its twelfth season of subscription concerts at Constitution Hall on the afternoon of Sunday, Nov. 8, has been forced to duplicate its entire set of equipment in Baltimore, it was learned today.

LOOK -- up in the sky!" "It's a bird!" "It's a plane!" "It's Superman!" These magic syllables are "Once upon a time ----," 1942 style. They introduce the time-hallowed fairy tale as the modern American youngster knows it and wants to know it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Rear Admiral John Sidney McCain, 58 years of age, chief of the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics, received the Distinguished Service Medal today for "exceptionally meritorious service" in the South Pacific and in the Solomons campaign.

The eleventh forum on current problems under the auspices of The New York Herald Tribune will be held Monday and Tuesday, Nov. 16 and 17, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Leading statesmen of the United Nations, including President Roosevelt, Sir Stafford Cripps, Wendell Willkie and Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, will be among those participating in the program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- American sea and air reconnaissance units ranged Southwest Pacific waters today watching for a reappearance of Japanese naval forces, including some of the enemy armada that Colonel Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said had left the scene of the Solomon Islands battle.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Roy Dale McKay and Jackie Field today dealt the death blow -- for this year at least -- to the Mustang jinx, leading Texas University to a conclusive 21-7 football victory over Southern Methodist. It was the second consecutive year Texas has trimmed the team it always found hardest to beat.

ANOTHER of the great mansions of yesterday, together with its contents, will be put up for auction on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday by Tobias, Fischer Co. This is Richmond Hill at Irvington-on-the-Hudson, where the sale will be held.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 31 -- The Imperial Eighth Army was reported driving home a major attack against General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's anchor positions near the Mediterranean coast tonight under cover of a rolling artillery barrage and sweeping air assaults in which American and British planes ranged from the desert battleground to Axis reinforcement bases on Crete.

THE radio, it is said, represents a cross-section of American life, culture and taste, and to the extent that any such generalization can be true, this one probably is. And, for the most part, it is one on which the program-makers can and do dwell with some pride, or at least with no great shame.

Because she is busy in furthering wartime care of young children, while serving as president of the National Association of Nursery Education and dean of the Mills School for Nursery Kindergarten and Primary Teachers, Miss Amy Hostler seemed a good person to ask about any new points coming up for parents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The War Department announced today that the Army Specialist Corps had been abolished as a separate agency and will be merged with the Army Officer Procurement System as a part of the regular Army.

THE HYPO CLUB, a new camera group organized by former members of the Associates Group of the Metropolitan Camera Club Council, makes its debut tomorrow at 7:30 P. M. in the Hudson Room of the Hotel Woodstock, 127 West Forty-third Street.

Retail trade was brisk last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were crowded, with accessories most active.

The present headmaster of Rugby, where Tom Brown went to school, in a speech reported in this paper day before yesterday, thought it a pity that Hitler should have given the German people something which British leadership had failed to provide for its own people.

A movement to draft some of the iron and bronze generals in the city's parks and public squares for this war, as scrap metal, gained strength yesterday without the approval of Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

Nearly five million tons of scrap metal was reported up to yesterday in the nationwide salvage campaign sponsored by the newspapers, and figures from thirty-two States were not yet complete. The total so far was announced by the Newspapers United Scrap Metal Drive Campaign as 4,852,438 tons.

Medical social service workers of New York's voluntary, nonprofit hospitals were praised yesterday by Dr. Claude W. Munger, former president of the American Hospital Association and chairman of the advisory committee on medical social service of the United Hospital Fund.

THE lowly comic strip, which has brought joy and excitement into the lives of millions of youngsters and misgivings to a lesser number of elders, appears to have a fairly respectable ancestry. The adventures of Terry, Barney Google and Superman may be traced back, in a more or less direct line, to the prehistoric picture writings of the caveman, the Sumerian limestone mosaics and the inscriptions on the walls of Egyptian tombs.

Actual and potential manpower and material shortages may have greater impact upon manufacturers during the months directly ahead than the restrictions likely to be placed on buying because of inventory control, according to views expressed last week.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The British plan of attack in Egypt, apparent since the offensive was launched two weeks ago, calls for a limited advance with great power behind it, then a rest period, then another surge, possibly in some other part of the forty-mile line between the seacoast and the Qattara Depression.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 31 -- Rutgers tallied three times for the second half to defeat Springfield College, 21 to 0, before 3,000 spectators in the Rutgers Stadium today.

THE middle Moffat, as any one could guess who met the Moffats in the first volume devoted to that nice family, was Jane, unpredictable one who liked to look at the world upside down. Self-styled, because every one else in the family, even Catherine the cat, had a distinguishing title, no one ever knew what Janey was going to do, least of all Janey herself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Navy announced in a communique tonight the sinking of another American aircraft carrier in the Battle of the Solomons, the fourth to go down in the Pacific since the war started on Dec. 7. The Navy said the lost carrier was the one previously reported severely damaged in a battle with strong enemy forces northeast of Guadalcanal on Monday (Solomons time) when the United States destroyer Porter was sunk.

The consumer has not utilized fully his right to institute civil action against retailers who charge more than ceiling prices, Walter Gellhorn, chief attorney for the New York regional bureau of the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday.

War Bond Square, on the northeast corner of Fifty-second Street and Sixth Avenue, the new center for outdoor rallies to promote the sale of war bonds and stamps, was dedicated yesterday by a representative of the Navy and members of the New York State War Savings staff of the Treasury.

TWO professional models, togged in country club sports outfits and with their cheeks and eyebrows done in Hollywood panchromatic, waited "on location" in front of a newly painted bus station. The bus driver had scrubbed the grime from his hands, was wearing a freshly laundered uniform and was fidgeting.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Outlines of a national wage and salary-control policy began to emerge here this week, a policy linked directly with various aspects of the critical manpower problem.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- With public interest centered upon the war and with no county offices and few local posts to be filled, a light vote is expected when Westchester County goes to the polls next Tuesday.

Deep inside THE TIMES of Oct. 10, doubled in length and enveloped by articles on pinball machines and chewing gum, appeared a brief account of long-distance telephone priorities instituted by the Board of War Communications to become effective Sunday, Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON Oct. 31 -- The biggest problem now pending before Congress is the mobilization of sufficient industrial manpower to handle essential wartime military and civilian production, and yet it is a problem which was scarcely envisaged by Congress and the public as little as six months ago.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Death, solitary confinement and hard labor are punishments to be imposed in Norway for a great variety of acts of sabotage against the Nazi administration, a Swiss Telegraphic Agency dispatch from Stockholm said today.

President Roosevelt is manifestly correct in stating that the so-called Atlantic Charter, issued as a declaration by Prime Minister Churchill and himself on Aug. 14, 1941, "applies to all humanity." The name given to this document was unfortunate. One need only re-read it to see that it is also, as far as it goes, a "Pacific Charter" and a "World Charter."

A drastic reorganization of the Japanese Government to "strengthen Japan's fighting power," probably foreshadowing an even greater domination of the nation by the military clique headed by Premier General Hideki Tojo, was announced by the Tokyo radio yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

FROM Buenos Aires comes word that the postal authorities are planning to issue a 5-centavo stamp to mark the centenary of the birth of Jose C. Paz, statesman, diplomat, and founder of La Prensa, a daily newspaper in Buenos Aires.

A GROUP of young American singers and musicians, organized by Leopold Sachse, have formed the Shoestring Opera Company. They have chosen that name because it indicates the state of their finances. The idea is that they will use the Therese Kaufman Auditorium of the Y.M.H.A. for their productions and no one will accept fees until after a sinking fund of $6,000 has been raised.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Tulane's Green Wave combined drama with heads-up football today to defeat Vanderbilt, 28 -- 21, before 20,000.

Boston recently had a book fair, and the talk was all about books. A Canadian visitor made some useful criticism about American books, saying that except for one or two authors -- she had novels in mind -- American writers were not popular outside America, because Americans all wrote so much alike.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct 31 -- In this one-party State where the election of the Democratic nominees by overwhelming majorities always has been regarded as a matter of course, except when Herbert Hoover carried Texas for President, there is little to stimulate public interest.

I have just been reading in THE TIMES Magazine Professor Smith's elaborate and ingenious defense of Congress and the uses of compromise. One can agree with everything he says and still feel that it would be better if the compromise were made on a higher level of conscience.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 31 -- "I never knew what the Lord's fortitude and endurance truly meant until I saw it stark naked on that amazing Chinese Fifth Army's trek across the malaria and cholera-infested jungles and mountains from Burma to India," declared youthful E. T. D. Lambert who led the troops through country he had surveyed ten years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Clark Shaughnessy's battling Maryland University Old Liners, knocked back on their heels at the outset by Florida's 'Gators, ripped the Southerners' defense to pieces in the final half today, and grabbed a tingling intersectional duel, 13 -- 0, with brilliant Tommy Mont in the starring role.

THE Harper l25th Anniversary Award of $12,500 for the best book of non-fiction submitted before May 1, 1942, has been divided between John Andrew Rice and Julian Green, the former for his book, "I Came Out of the Eighteenth Century," and the latter for "Memories of Happy Days."

A SOUTH PACIFIC PORT, Oct. 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Captain William J. McKennan of Herkimer, N.Y., one of the first to land when Marines stormed the Japanese seaplane base at Gavutu on Aug. 7, is another fighting American who is convinced that "the Japs are no match for our outfit, man for man."

JED HARRIS'S first play this season is to be "To the Purple" (tentative title), opening here in December. Labeled a comedy, the plot deals with three Russian actresses residing in this country. The trio will be limned by Eugenie Leontovich, Elena Miramova and Ludmilla Toretzka.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 1 -- The Germans made new gains yesterday in their offensive across the Nalchik plain at the foot of the Caucasus Mountains, the Soviet midnight communique said today, but the Red Army seized the initiative inside Stalingrad and won new successes northwest of the Volga city and on the Black Sea front.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 31 -- Minnesota had too much power for a stubborn Northwestern team and defeated the Wildcats, 19 to 7, today for its second Western Conference victory in thre starts.

Ice skating hostesses chosen from among the ranks of society's young women skaters will make their appearance next Thursday afternoon on the rink of the Figure Skating Club of New York atop Madison Square Garden, where an ice skating carnival and tea will be presented to advance a notable home front war effort.

PHIL McNALLY had a cabin cruiser on the Gulf of Mexico and hired it at $25 a day to people who wanted to fish. Most of his passengers took him and his ostensible business at face value, but Miss Hallie Kent was a shrewd observer and she suspected that he might be a detective or even a G-man on the trail of the diamond thieves who had been in the news lately.

Major league baseball's concluding and largest single financial contribution of the year to the nation's war effort was made yesterday when $362,926.65 was turned over to the United Service Organizations in the latter's offices in the Empire State Building.

Establishment of nursery schools as an integral part of the public school system was advocated yesterday by speakers at the third annual luncheon of the United Kindergarten Mothers Association, attended by 700 parents and educators at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 31 -- Indications are that Republicans will have a sweep.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- With a cry of "get out the vote" rising above the din of local and national issues raised during months of contests before an apparently preoccupied and indifferent electorate, the 1942 Congressional and State campaigns closed tonight, except for eleventh-hour blasts, and awaited the opening of the polls next Tuesday morning.

The most talked of rookie player of the professional football season, Bill Dudley, will be in town today when the surprising Steelers face the Giants at the Polo Grounds at 2:30 P. M., while the Dodgers strive to keep alive their hopes for an Eastern championship by beating the Rams at Ebbets Field at 2:15 P. M.

When Fritz Kreisler came on stage for the initial offering of his recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall the entire audience rose and welcomed him with a prolonged ovation, in a tribute of affection and esteem so wholehearted and overwhelming that he was visibly touched to the core.

While the Indians of San Ysidro are putting on a corn dance, one of the tourist spectators is murdered. He is Devoe Fulton, a guest at Greta Myron's dude ranch near Santa Fe. Pecos Appleby, a special investigator, takes charge of the case and soon has six suspects on his hands, but no convincing evidence.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- Massachusetts has about 2,000,000 registered voters, but there are only three contests of sufficient interest to bring them to the polls Nov. 3.
HONOLULU, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Lieutenant Howell M. Forgy, 220-pound chaplain aboard a heavy cruiser, said today he was the chaplain who originated the phrase, 'Praise the Lord and pass the ammunition."

Blood collected at seventeen Red Cross centers from 50,000 contributors a week must reach one of eight laboratories for processing in twenty-four hours and must be maintained during transit at about 40 degrees Fahrenheit. To solve the problem thus presented Major Elihu Church has designed a galvanized steel refrigerated trunk which can be moved easily on casters.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique issued early today:

The Maritime Commission and the War Shipping Administration have under consideration a proposal to turn over a number of new merchant vessels, built in the United States, to the Chinese Government to permit the establishment of a nucleus Chinese merchant marine operating in the Allied war trades out of United States ports, it was disclosed last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Married men without children are rapidly being reclassified in the light of their civilian occupations, selective service officials said today, and many are expected to be called soon for military service.

AGAIN the chief London openings now under review happen to be of American plays. Both had big successes on your side, but neither -- or so it seems to this correspondent -- is likely to do so over here.

LAUGHTER is sweeping the underground of a ravaged, starving Europe. Over the coffee tables, in the music halls, along the assembly lines and even inside the concentration camps venomous little tales are feeding a rising river of ridicule that Hitler and his Hooligans of Hate are powerless to stop.

After a firm and quiet opening, the stock market in the short sesson yesterday advanced moderately, with the steels, utilities and rails among the groups showing the greatest gains. The volume of trading on the Stock Exchange was the largest for any Saturday since Oct. 1, amounting to 350,210 shares, compared with 290,180 on the previous Saturday.

When Freddy Jacoby fails to win a high-point trophy in outboard racing -- that's news. It might have been different during 1942 if the customary high-scoring trophies had been in competition and if Statistician George W. Sutton Jr. had kept his pencils sharpened.

A GAY story with a heroine who has a past, a hero who prefers dead Indians to live football players, a stout bunch of the latter and an ex-carnival performer are the amusing people in this story of an old Southern plantation. Tambay had been a wonderful and romantic vision to the young carnival player the first time she saw it, twenty-five years ago.

To raise funds for the relief of French prisoners of war and children in unoccupied France, the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies will present a series of ten concerts on alternating Wednesdays beginning this week and continuing through March 24, in the Salle des Fetes of the council's headquarters at 451 Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The special market committee of the Chicago Association of Commerce, it was learned today, has fixed the week of Feb. 1 to 6 as the best date for the Spring wholesale market showings, after careful consideration of the problems of both wholesalers and retailers under war conditions.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Cleveland's entire waterfront now is a restricted area patrolled twenty-four hours a day by guards equipped with machine guns, the Coast Guard district headquarters here revealed tonight.

Formal organization of the American Foundation for Pharmaceutical Education to serve as a clearing house for funds to be used directly in the interest of pharmaceutical education was announced yesterday.

The seizure of fifty-one enemy aliens here last week by government agents was announced yesterday afternoon at the offices of E. P. Foxworth, agent in charge of the local Federal Bureau of Investigation.

HISTORY has to be rewritten every generation, it has been said, and rightly. For every generation discovers new truths or rediscovers old ones which seem to change the meaning of its experience and make it therefore seem necessary to change the record of its experience.

Captain William Maguire, veteran Catholic naval chaplain, to whom the creators of the song "Praise the Lord and Pass the Ammunition" had attributed that phrase, emphatically denied yesterday that he had "manned a gun" during the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister of South Africa, in an international broadcast tonight called for elaboration of the Atlantic Charter in "the economic and social sphere" to guarantee a post-war "healthy international life."

WHEN her husband was assigned to duty at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, Agatha had to move from a seven-room house in Winthrop, Mass., to a three-room apartment on Brooklyn Heights. At first she thought she had contracted claustrophobia en route.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 31 -- The Lawrenceville School today defeated the Hill School, 26 -- 13, in their annual football clash on Dell Field.

Women in uniform are to have their own recreational center in New York City. This bureau, comparable to the recreation center maintained at 99 Park Avenue for men in service, will be housed in the Central Branch Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue.

EDWARD W. BEATTIE JR. is a red-headed young man from Stonington, Conn., and Yale, who has seen a great deal of history made since he departed post-haste for Tokyo in 1937. He watched the Sino-Japanese War while the International Settlement at Shanghai still provided a grand-stand seat.

THE essential truth about Japan is doubtless in this tremendously interesting book, despite the author's frequent interpolations of history which makes it difficult for the reader of the narrative, classified as a novel, to distinguish its fact from its fiction.

IN the introduction to his anthology. "The Viking Book of Poetry," which came out last year, Richard Aldington draws a distinction between the "general" and the "personal" anthology. In the personal anthology "the compiler puts in only what appeals to his own special taste and ignores poems which the rest of the world had been admiring for a long time."

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 31 (AP) -- A gallant band of Kansas football players outplayed a heavily favored Nebraska team for fifty minutes today, but finally yielded to an old-time jinx and dropped a 14-to-7 thriller to the Cornhuskers.

SALINAS, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Lack of seed, which has retarded expansion of California's guayule rubber project, appears to have been overcome by the successful mechanical garnering of seeds from the 560 experimental acres planted in Salinas Valley.
Every Fall there is some discussion of the meaning of the name of Indian Summer. I have not recently seen the explanation which I learned in childhood, and which seems to be most reasonable.

THE first thing to understand about the Flying Tigers is that their aerial campaign over the Burma Road was no two-bit side-show on the fringe of World War II. And the second thing to get straight is that they were not a bunch of freebooters or soldiers of fortune who sold their skills, courage and lives for a monthly paycheck.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 31 -- Outplaying its rivals all the way, the Garden City High eleven gained its fifth victory in six starts and snapped a three-game streak for Manhasset by 19 -- 6 today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Adah Wilson McCormick, widow of Harold McCormick, Chicago financier, and George Tait 2d of Santa Monica, Calif., were married in the First Congregational Church here today by the Rev. Fred A. Line.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Three thousand miners, almost all of whom came straight from the coal mines, were summoned to London today to hear an off-the-record talk by Prime Minister Churchill who outlined to them the grave dangers of the present fuel shortage in Britain and told them what had to be done.

THIS volume takes you on another journey through the haunted house that is James Thurber's mind. In the dark and low places you are on your hands and knees, with your widest part hoisted a little too high, like the ectoplasmic creatures that creep around in Thurber drawings.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Charges of spreading propaganda to break down good relations between Mexico and the United States were preferred by government officials today against a man they tentatively identified as an American citizen.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Nov. 1 -- One Japanese cruiser was destroyed and another severely damaged in the third straight attack by Allied bombers on shipping in the harbor at Buin in the Northern Solomons, General Douglas MacArthur's command announced today.

Days crowded with defense work and other new activities as well as a servantless world are bringing new popularity to the custom of eating in the kitchen. This double use of the kitchen has several advantages. For one thing, it is likely to be the warmest room in the house.

GENIUS, some one has said, is an infinite capacity for taking pains, but as Hollywood generally perceives it -- in artists, at least -- it is an endless capacity for suffering them. Seldom do you behold an artist upon the screen -- an artist, that is, of whom the audience has been carefully informed as to his "gift" -- who does not spend his days and nights waging a tough wrestling match with his soul.

The establishment of a uniform wage system for merchant seamen of several of the United Nations and the determination of future wages and working conditions aboard the vessels of those nations by joint negotiation were the leading topics of discussion at an international seamen's conference held recently in London.

James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, will deliver "the most sensational speech of the campaign" tonight, Vincent Dailey, State campaign manager, announced yesterday. Mr. Farley will speak from 10:30 to 10:45 from station WHN over a State-wide network.

BIG SPRING is a Texas town about a hundred miles west of Abilene and the same distance south of Lubbock. That's in the cattle and oil country, not far from New Mexico. Prairie country, where water used to be scarce enough that a big spring was ample excuse for building a settlement.

The steel industry's Federal tax bill rose 80 per cent in the first nine months of 1942, compared with last year, and net profits after taxes and special contingency reserves declined 40 per cent, a survey of fourteen companies shows. To the extent made public, the contingency reserves were increased by one-third over last year.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Greenwich, author, playwright and world reporter, prepared tonight to wind up her campaign to become Connecticut's first woman member of Congress with a series of week-end radio broadcasts and speaking appearances here and in Norwalk and Stamford.

THE recall of the Chinese Ambassador, Hu Shih, has been universally regretted, for no one of his nation has made himself so popular in this country since the visit of the incomparable Li Hung Chang. It is said that Dr. Hu Shih has attended more dinners than any other diplomat in Washington and traveled more miles over our country than even Mrs. Roosevelt.
THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which closed at the Metropolitan Opera House last week, looks as if it is on the verge of a new period in its career.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Connecticut has a definite but not an acute milk shortage in the face of a rising demand, officials admitted here today. It is due in large measure to an ever-swelling influx of war workers and their families, they said, and not to lowered milk production caused by herd slaughter, as some sources have reported.

Trade buying featured activity in the cotton futures market yesterday. This demand, offsetting hedging and New Orleans selling, reached its peak in the waning minutes of the two-hour session on the New York Cotton Exchange, sending prices on active contracts to the day's highs and final net gains of 4 to 7 points.

DENVER, Colo., Oct. 31 -- Colorado, traditionally unclassifiable politically, will enter the election Nov. 3 with its hottest contest between Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, and Governor Ralph L. Carr, Republican, for the six-year term in the Senate.

THE suit for $1,619,147, filed this week in the United States District Court by Pare Lorentz, documentary film producer, against RKO-Radio Pictures, listing thirteen causes of action, constitutes a precedent-making step in motion picture litigation.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- Some 27,000 employes of the New York City rapid transit system have been frozen into their jobs by a decision of the Court of Appeals which upheld the constitutionality of the Wicks Act, which also puts them under civil service.

WASHINGTON -- Motorists are going to give their tires extra-special care hereafter, or they are not going to drive. William M. Jeffers, rubber "czar," has cautioned automobile owners that as owners of rubber tires they are "custodians of a material more precious than gold" and should treat their tires accordingly.
The storm of battle is roaring again across the Egyptian sands and British, Imperial and American forces at last have taken the offensive.

One of the nation's largest aircraft engine plants -- the Pratt Whitney factory operated by the Buick Motor Division of General Motors at Melrose Park, Ill. -- is supplying 63 per cent of all its electric power requirements by the simple expedient of harnessing horsepower generated by engines during their "break-in" or test runs.

From back of barricaded doors, Clayton Seagears of the Conservation Department's game division at Albany has been attempting to ward off most requests for additional recipes on venison. It is chiefly his own fault for putting too many of his expert findings into the recently issued department booklet, which we understand is fast going out of print.

Smarting from its one-point upset at the hands of Fordham Prep in its previous game, Brooklyn Prep's football team bounced back into the winning column by handing previously undefeated Power Memorial Academy a 13-to-0 setback at Brooklyn College Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Federal regulations issued recently by James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, with the aim of stabilizing wages and salaries during the war gave to the National War Labor Board jurisdiction over all wages and over salaries up to $5,000 a year except those of supervisory or professional employes not represented by recognized unions.

With the war now global, the task of supplying oil to meet the essential civilian and military needs of the United States and associated nations is becoming more difficult. Chiefly a problem of transportation so far, there is the chance of it extending to the oil refining and producing divisions if the war lasts several years.

Ten thousand copies of a poster, "Churches Welcome Service Men," will be put up this week in public conveyances and other places by the Service Men's Council of the New York Federation of Churches, of which the Rev. Carl V. Herron is the executive secretary.

The leasing by the government of the short-wave facilities of five broadcasting companies was announced formally yesterday in Washington by the Office of War Information and the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, with programming and supervision by the OWI scheduled to start tomorrow.

The most difficult major offensive in two years of fluctuating battle clawed slowly last week across the North African desert. It had been launched eight days ago, just before dawn, by a mighty Allied artillery barrage reminiscent of the gun-wheel-to-gun-wheel fire of World War I.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 31 -- Dartmouth's football team, which has tasted the bitter and sweet of football fortune so far this season, bowed to William and Mary today as the Virginians handed the Green a 35-14 defeat before 7,000 disappointed Dartmouth house party spectators.

ATLANTA, Oct. 31 -- Georgia dash and Georgia daring, personified by All-America Frankie Sinkwich and his pass-snatching partner, George Poschner, took the measure of a great Alabama football team, 21 -- 10, before 33,000 fans with a sensational fourth-period attack today.

PINEHURST, N. C. -- The land where holly grows on trees instead of sprouting from buttonholes has been enjoying fine warm weather. Most of the cottages are already occupied and the hotels report many guests registering for the season.

Restaurant life promises to carry on with its customary animation despite darkened streets and reduced transportation. To meet the demands of gay cocktail and dinner hours designers have launched an exciting over-the-table-top mode.

With an attack on Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican State chairman, for his connections with the defunct German-American Bund, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ended last night his formal campaign for Governor at the traditional Democratic closing rally in Carnegie Hall.

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons headed by the Misses Cornelia Wilmot Allen and Eleanor Travers are aiding in the arrangements for the luncheon in behalf of the Masters School Day Nursery to be held on Nov. 10 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

IN "The Weald of Youth" Mr. Siegfried Sassoon continues to write about a world that is doubly dead with such delicate precision and brooding charm that the seventeen chapters approach the plane of poetry. Not, heaven forbid, prose poetry with its purple patches, but that substance of poetry that is sometimes implicit in the regretful remembering of things and ways long past -- Blake's "lost traveler's dream under the hill," as it were.

Miss Helen Young has resigned, effective today, as director of nursing at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after thirty years on the nursing staff of the Presbyterian Hospital, it was announced yesterday. She has been succeeded by Miss Margaret E. Conrad, a graduate of the Presbyterian Hospital class of '20.

In a year when interest in the election as a whole is subnormal, more than usual interest has been manifested, nevertheless, in a series of local contests for Congress and membership in the State Legislature in New York City.

There are three Asey Mayo stories in this volume: "The Headacre Plot," "The Wander Bird Plot" and "The Swan Boat Plot." Two of them are Cape Cod stories, while the third has its setting in Boston, but with plenty of Cape Cod atmosphere supplied by Asey and his cousin Jennie.

OTTAWA, Oct. 31 -- With one more week to go and an objective of "at least" $350,000,000 to be reached, 668,322 Canadians have in two weeks poured $564,863,750 into their Third Victory Loan.
