The response, both in the amount to date and in the number of subscribers, is far ahead of any previous record.

THOUGH there is documentary proof to the contrary, every schoolboy knows that George Washington swore like a trooper at Monmouth. In "Morning in America" Willard Wiener has written a brilliant novel about Charles Lee, the Revolutionary major general who so richly deserved the curses of his Commander in Chief on that battlefield. Mr. Wiener has tackled his thankless task with wholehearted gusto.
THE inspector examines the baggage. "Any cameras, explosives, firearms? Any matches?"

LONDON, Oct. 31 (Reuter) -- How the British destroyer Wolverine rammed and sank a U-boat in the Mediterranean Sea while returning from escorting a recent Malta convoy has now been described by her commanding officer, Lieut. Comdr. P. W. Gretton.

TRENTON, Oct. 31 -- There was a growing belief among observers today that Albert W. Hawkes, Montclair Republican, has a good chance to unseat United States Senator William H. Smathers, Democrat, in next Tuesday's general election in New Jersey.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- An Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 31 -- After having tried in vain for years and finally obtained authority to use autos, because of wartime conditions, Bermuda's doctors now are likely -- again because of wartime conditions -- to have to continue with horse and buggy, it was disclosed today.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Among the New Jersey corporations which notified the Secretary of State's office today of the moving of their principal offices were:

The combined annual show of the Chrysanthemum Society of America and Autumn flower show of the Horticultural Society of New York will open Thursday at 7 P. M. in the American Museum of Natural History. Admittance to the opening is by invitation.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 -- The speedy Count Fleet today stamped himself the probable Winter book favorite for next season's 3-year-old racing classics when he carried the yellow and black silks of Mrs. John D. Hertz of Chicago to an easy victory in the Pimlico Futurity.

TWO sisters and the daughter of one of them have a time with their men in this pleasant story of family life in a small California town. Mrs. Hazeltine, tiny and pretty, was also a capable mother to her four lovely children.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Yale's football team gave further evidence of its growing power today when it humbled a well-regarded Brown eleven by the score of 27 to 0.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Warren Shannon of the unbeaten White Plains eleven and Art Rouse of A.B. Davis High, each scored two touchdowns in the battle between the W.I.A.A. teams today. White Plains, however, had the advantage of a score by Mort Grossman and two conversions by Co-Captain Frank Pitassi for its fourth consecutive victory, 20 -- 12.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Falling back upon what proved to be a highly effective passing game after its ground attack had stalled in the first period, the City College football team accounted for two touchdowns in the second quarter and went on to defeat Hobart College, 20 to 6, today.

An event of unusual interest to society and the musical world will occur Tuesday night when the New Opera Company will usher in its second subscription season with the world premiere of Dr. Walter Damrosch's "The Opera Cloak" and Mussorgsky's "The Fair at Sorochinsk" at the Broadway Theatre.

About 10 per cent of all industrial disability is caused by accidents. The rate is rising because millions of men and women who have been idle during the years of the depression are not only at work again but at work that calls for the exercise of newly acquired skills and that exposes them to unfamiliar hazards.

Tentative civilian allocations during the first quarter of 1943 on a wide range of finished cotton textiles, which form the backbone of dry goods merchandised by large retailers and wholesalers, were being studied here last week by textile sales executives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Office of Price Administration today ordered the packing industry to reduce its prices on canned beef sold to the Army through the issuance of specific dollars-and-cents prices at which packers and canners can sell such products in ten zones throughout the country.

The presence of blank spaces on rows A, B and C of voting machines in Manhattan and the Bronx on Tuesday, in the columns for Justices of the Supreme Court, should not confuse voters, the Board of Elections announced yesterday.
CANTON, N.Y., Oct. 31 (AP) -- St. Lawrence University ended its football season today with a 19-to-6 triumph over Hartwick, highlighted by Tony Vaccaro's 73-yard touchdown dash.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 31 -- Michigan swirled through highly regarded Illinois for four touchdowns and administered to the Illini a drubbing every bit as decisive as the 28-14 score before a happy throng of 33,000 today.

Geared to the needs of an all-out program, colleges and universities throughout the United States have turned over their buildings, classrooms, laboratories and equipment to the Army, Navy and allied services, transforming the traditional quiet campuses of the land into huge training centers where a powerful fighting force is now being forged.

ANTIQUE exhibitions are always entertaining events, both to the general public and the serious collector. The first one of the season, opening tomorrow afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria, seems likely to be no exception.

A collective form of "Victory branding," similar to that which automotive manufacturers employed early in the history of the industry, was suggested yesterday by Ben Nash, industrial designer and merchandising consultant, as one method of keeping alive trademarks when civilian products are shut off or their manufacturers forced to close down.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Wendell L. Willkie's frank and critical report to the people this week on his global flying tour of the war fronts caused both joy and dismay in Administration quarters, and undoubtedly strengthened Mr. Willkie's stand with the people, though not with the Republican organization, as a formidable political figure.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

THE account given in Harry W. Flannery's "Assignment to Berlin" of its author's interview with P. G. Wode-house has received considerable attention here. It is pointed out that there is no truth in Wode-house's assertion that he had not been in England for seventeen years.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 30 -- The much improved Lehigh University football team ran at will in its game against Hampden-Sidney today, winning, 51 -- 6. A colorful house party crowd of 9,000 saw the Engineers roll up their third successive triumph and tally twenty-five points in the second quarter.

Six days after his defeat in the 1940 Presidential elections Wendell L. Willkie, the Republican standard bearer, addressed the 22,000,000 Americans who had voted for him. "We must," he said, "constitute ourselves a vigorous, loyal and public-spirited opposition.

KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 31 -- British, South African and American officials witnessed here today launching of the African Sun, a 10,000-ton cargo carrier, in the yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

The report of the Monsanto Chemical Company and its American subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $3,978,435 after Federal income and excess profits taxes and after a deduction of $710,268, representing 10 per cent of excess profits which is returnable after the war, but before minority interests.

MACABRE paintings on motifs from The Day of the Dead, by the Mexican artist Antonio Alvarez, make up the current show at the Wakefield Gallery and Bookshop. Alvarez can draw and despite the grim humor of his subject-matter he achieves interesting decorative effects.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Uncle Robert, widely known sponsor of entertainments for children, announced today that responses in his contest for an American name for nursery schools to replace "kindergarten," because of its German origin, had come in from Galveston, Texas, and other distant parts of the country, as well as from all parts of the metropolitan area.

TOMMY MALONEY, Kerman Garale and Janina Dybowska are all victims of Fascist aggression. They come from different parts of the world and live in different homes in the British Isles. And although they have never met they have one thing in common.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- Holy Cross an Colgate battled to a 6-6 tie before 15,000 fans at Fitton Field today in the tenth meeting between the two colleges.

A thousand teachers in the metropolitan area are expected to attend the ninth annual foreign language conference to be held next Saturday at the New York University School of Education under the sponsorship of the university and six teachers' groups, it was announced yesterday by Professor Henri C. Olinger, chairman of the conference committee.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Robert T. Day, aged 19, a pharmacist's mate, third class, from Niagara Falls, N.Y., was cited today by Navy and marine authorities as proof that 'teen-age boys have the stuff of which heroes are made.

Louis R. Chauvenet of Charlottesville, Va., built his score to 4 1/2 -- 1/2 and a substantial lead yesterday in the final series for the United States amateur chess championship being played at the Manhattan Club.

Professor D. W. Brogan in his article "Is Britain's Empire Able to Survive?" implied that education should have made the leaders in India cooperative with the British rule. The implication is that once the Indian leaders were schooled in the "constitutional principles of Burke and Bagehot," political allegiance would follow.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 31 -- Sir Cosmo Parkinson, personal representative of Viscount Cranborne, Secretary of State for Colonies in London, has completed interviews with bodies representing various interests in Jamaica and will proceed to Trinidad shortly, it was announced today.

HOLLYWOOD. SINCE the world as we know it today is largely conditioned by the activities of heels -- of the international variety -- it might be apropos at this time to devote a few paragraphs to the genus heel by examining the case of Jack Carson. Mr. Carson is Hollywood's all-American heel.

Describing his opponents as men who understood the prosecution of crime, Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, declared yesterday that an understanding of the conditions that caused crime was far more important to the public good.
" LISSEN," the top sergeant said. "This sodjer comes up an' asts me if I have any Huxley. I looks on my roster an' I says what's his serial number?"

TORONTO, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- Viscount Bennett, former Conservative Prime Minister of Canada, charged today that Wendell L. Willkie "proposes to sabotage the British Empire" and is not competent to speak on Indian problems.

CHICAGO has a series of "Victory" concerts. Like those here at the Public Library and the Metropolitan Museum, they follow the idea of the Myra Hess concerts in London. They are given at noon in the Chicago Art Institute and each program is half an hour in length.

Large retirements of securities by two public utility companies lifted the total of bonds called before maturity for payment in October to $73,764,000, compared with $28,761,000 in the preceding month and $31,351,000 in October, 1941.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Delaware's long football winning streak was in peril for three quarters today, but the unbeaten and untied Blue Hens came from behind to beat Penn Military, 19 to 14.

THE lights go out abrupty, the grouped soldiers suddenly quiet their talk and lean forward in eager anticipation, a white beam stabs the darkness to the screen and the movie at the "Here We Are," our camp theatre, is on. For American soldiers must have their movies even here in the bush country, "somewhere in Australia," hundreds of miles from the nearest flag stop.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- R.A.F. attacks on Genoa and Milan, the first mass bombings of Italian cities in this war, coinciding with the renewal in North Africa of a struggle between Germans and British-American forces for control of what Italians used to call their sea, may have contributed to sadden the twentieth anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome this week.

IN its series of weekly duplicate games last Winter the Cavendish Club experimented with various unusual methods of scoring, both in pair and in team-of-four contests. One of its experiments brought back the duplicate pair game with total-point scoring, which was the most popular form of duplicate play until match-point scoring was generally adopted (about 1931).

A PERSONAL confession in these times is not necessarily of importance. Rousseau is dead. The man who offers to tell all must have something to tell. These facts must be applied to Mr. Seabrook, as they would be to a lesser or greater man.

Walter Nash, New Zealand's Minister to the United States, urged yesterday immediate creation of a "post-war reconstruction council" by the United Nations to determine and to tell the world just how the Atlantic Charter would be put into practice.

According to a recent ruling, Americans visting Canada for business purposes will be able to obtain gasoline in addition to the existing quota of sixteen gallons. The exigencies of industry have been recognized by government officials, who have announced that professional men need no longer worry about being left stranded owing to a gasoline shortage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- The Army and Navy Journal defended today as wise military strategy the Army's suppression of news of United States losses in the Tokyo raid and the Navy's deferred announcement of American ships sunk at Midway Island and the Solomon Islands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Science Service) -- A radial engine of the type familiar to Americans through long use on airplanes, but run by expanding steam instead of exploding gasoline vapor, is one of the 669 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 31 -- The Coast Guard Academy defeated Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today, 33 to 0. The first period was hard fought and ended scoreless, but Rensselaer weakened at the beginning of the second period and the cadets started scoring on deceptive passes and line bucking.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The presence of the War and Navy Department Buildings on Constitution Avenue, and hourly sight of the uniforms that dominate the passing throng of the capital, obscure and even make repugnant current thoughts of politics and campaigns for office.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- A mass execution of fifty-five Polish hostages in one day at Palmiry was carried out on the order of Dr. Ludwig Fischer, Governor of Warsaw, it was learned here today. The action followed the derailment and blowing up of an ammunition train at the important railway junction of Nasielsk, north of Warsaw.

Current calls for war work volunteers are centering on the drive for 97,000 borough group leaders, according to Mrs. Walter Bunzl, chairman of recruitment for the Greater New York CDVO. Officials believe that once this block plan organization is set up it will expedite the systematic enlistment of volunteers for all pressing services.

The United Seamen's Service announced yesterday that O.J. Hartwig, former American secretary of the consul general of Peru in New York had been named to conduct a survey in the Panama Canal Zone and Balboa to determine the need for recreational and rest facilities for merchant seamen there.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Michigan State's favored Spartans had to turn on the heat in the last period today to settle for a 7-7 tie with a Temple University team before a homecoming crowd of 10,000.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 31 -- Amherst, led by Agnew, who scored two of the six touchdowns, continued its undefeated string by overwhelming Massachusetts State today, 43 to 0. The Statesmen never seriously threatened the Jeff goal line.

Reports in the men's clothing industry last week, as its members were preparing bids for large quantities of Army uniform business, indicated that the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America may consider lower wage rates on future government orders if the New York market does not obtain a fair share of the contracts.

" THE VINEYARD" is fairly named. It is a novel starring the wine industry -- its history, its development, its disasters and successes, and its fascination for the vignerons whose lives were devoted to the culture of the grape. The scene is in a rich valley near San Francisco and the story centers round Villa Montino and its vineyards.

TWO synchronously arranged one-man shows at the Museum of Modert Art, which opened last week, permit us to survey, retrospectively, the achievement of a painter and of a sculptor. It is achievement that, in the instance of Pavel Tchelitchew, ranges from 1925 to the present year, and that, with respect to John B. Flannagan, represents all that there will be, for the American sculptor died, a suicide, last January.

IN the preface to their brief popular history of the United States soon to be published under the title, "America: The Story of a Free People," Professors Allan Nevins and Henry Steele Commager remind us that "European Historians and travelers, admitting readily enough the substantial virtues of the American people, long insisted that American history was colorless and prosaic, lacking in variety and richness and grace.

Students at Wilson College are gaining understanding of contemporary and post-war problems not only in formal courses this year, but in new progress outside their Chambersburg, Pa., classrooms. Most notable of the innovations is the weekly all-college convocation at which authorities discuss national and international affairs.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Film Star Greer Garson and Actor Richard Ney, now an ensign in the United States Navy, both professed surprise today when informed Mr. Ney's father had reported that they would be married tomorrow.

INCITED to action by George Whinney's Letter to the Editor, in which he expressed annoyance at having to wait a whole week for the solutions of cross-word puzzles, THE TIMES invited opinions from other puzzle fans on this burning subject.
The war of the world was approaching another crisis last week.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Britain has won one of the greatest production victories of the war in the all-time record harvest she has gathered this year. It is a critical factor, too, in terms of shipping space freed for carrying more tanks to Russia by Arctic convoys, for battling more planes through to Malta, for transporting men and material to the African desert, for striking at the Axis in all theatres of the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation had $1,776,193,577 in loans outstanding and commodities owned as of Sept 30, compared with $1,261,701,216 a year earlier, the Department of Agriculture said today.

An attendance of more than 600 persons is anticipated for the rally luncheon sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, which will take place Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Miss Lucrezia Bori, the Guild's chairman, will preside and Mrs. John DeWitt Peltz will act as master of ceremonies.

The basic authority for the wage and salary regulations issued last Tuesday by James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, is the power vested in the President by the Emergency Price Control Act of 1942, as amended, the purpose of which is to aid in preventing inflation.
CAIRO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

In a pronounced departure from tradition, caused by the war, the National Horse Show this Autumn will present to the show ring enthusiasts who attend its only two sessions little of the glamour, fanfare and pervading excitement that have characterized the shows for decades past.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Experience and stamina paid dividends as anticipated in Archbold Stadium today as the North Carolina Naval Pre-Flight School's powerful array of football operatives bagged a 9-to-0 victory and tumbled the hard-battling Syracuse eleven from the ranks of the nation's unbeaten squads.
Flight 5 of United Air Lines was cruising along between New York and Chicago recently on its three-mile-a-minute journey to the Pacific Coast with Captain Ed Hale at the controls.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Party spokesmen appealed tonight to the voters to demonstrate by use of their right of franchise that democracy remained unimpaired on the home front.

MOSCOW, Oct. 31 -- Operations in the Egyptian desert preceding the present British offensive have this past Summer received but scant attention from the Soviet press. The fact that only two German panzer division were involved there compared with at least twenty on this front, and a correspondingly smaller proportion of infantrymen, caused the average Russian to think of Egypt as a minor sideshow.

Radio waves, 200,000 of them a second, are used to coat steel plate with tin in a flash -- all in accordance with an invention conceived by Glenn E. Stoltz, Westinghouse engineer, and developed by his colleagues, R.M. Baker and Milton Vore.

Campbell and a jury in the treason trial of six relatives and friends charged with sheltering and aiding the young Chicagoan in his mission for Germany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Whether or not thousands of soldiers and sailors' wives will receive free maternity care next year depends on the hearings two identical bills will receive from the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 24 amounted to 237,986,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. Compared with the preceding week, this represents a decrease of 132,000 barrels, comprising a decrease of 175,000 in stocks of domestic crude, but an increase of 43,000 in stocks of foreign crude.

Newman said in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday.

IT isn't often that one man can help five football teams, but George Halas did it. He left the Great Big Bears and joined the Navy. That will be helpful to the Detroit Lions, the Green Bay Monsters, the Cleveland Rams, the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Chicago Cardinals. Those teams still have games to play with the Great Big Bears.

Last week, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at 108.4. The index continued to show the effect of price regulations. The over-all price regulations based on the March ceilings under the general maximum price regulations are gradually being superseded by special price orders.

News comes from Rome, via Berlin, that "Crown Prince Humbert of Italy has received the rank of marshal in the Italian Army by royal decree on the recommendation of Premier Mussolini." Time was when Humbert seemed an attractive figure. Twelve years ago he married Marie Jose, daughter of a Belgian King who did not surrender to the Germans.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Marquette bounced the University of Detroit from the ranks of the nation's unbeaten football teams today, whipping the Titans, 10 to 0, before a crowd of 7,000.

Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican State Chairman, charged last night that the Saturday night speech of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, attempting to link him with the German-American Bund, had backfired and that Mr. Bennett, through his "false charges," had proved himself a traitor to the American Legion and "slandered his own comrades."
The three leading candidates for Governor will continue their campaigns until almost the last hour tonight, the eve of tomorrow's election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The Under-Secretary of War, Robert P. Patterson, and the Under-Secretary of the Navy, James V. Forrestal, announced tonight that thirty-six additional war plants would receive the joint Army-Navy production award for outstanding work.

Ten years ago the Socialist party wound up one of its most successful campaigns with a meeting that overflowed Madison Square Garden at which Norman Thomas was the hero of 20,000 wildly enthusiastic voters.

Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, in his sermon yesterday in the James Memorial Chapel, Broadway and 120th Street, declared that it had been said that "our Western World no longer stands on a spiritual foundation."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- Dennis Cardinal Dougherty, Archbishop of Philadelphia, called today for national unity and sacrifices unto death to win the war, warning that in the alternative this nation would be "pounced upon by vultures, which will devour it to the bone."

LONDON, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Waacs, said today she would recommend that many of the features of women's war organization training she had observed in Britain during the past week be made a part of the Waac program.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- Delegates to the New England Jewish National Fund conference this afternoon voted to establish in Palestine a colony bearing the name of Massachusetts, where refugees and demobilized soldiers could be settled.

An extra charge for coffee served with table d'hote and blue plate dinners was proposed yesterday by the Society of Restaurateurs, comprising 240 service restaurants here, as a means of reducing the consumption of coffee with meals.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A headquarters for United States forces in China, India and Burma communiqu:

BERNE, Nov. 1 -- Comparing Germany's financial position in the First World War with that of today, Kurt Lange, vice president of the Reichsbank, asserts that the material reserves on which the Reich could now draw were considerably stronger than its enemies surmised.

Preaching yesterday morning on the great significance of All Saints Day, particularly in the light of the present-day crisis, Bishop William T. Manning called upon Christians everywhere to renew their faith in God and in the future, explaining that it was such a faith that had given greatness, power and victory to the saints and had made their lives an inspiration for us today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 1 -- With campaigning in the New Jersey senatorial contest in the final stage, Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City predicted today that Hudson County would give Senator William H. Smathers a plurality of 100,000 votes in his bid for re-election.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 -- Increased collections of scrap iron and steel throughout the country last week continued to buoy the spirits of officials in the steel industry, and there were instances where a slight inventory of scrap was accumulated.

The experience with the New York Unemployment Insurance Act which Burnett Walker describes in his letter in the Oct. 30 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES will not occur under the act as amended, effective Nov. 30, 1942 (Laws of 1942, Ch. 640).

In Egypt, grappling armies swayed slowly over the desert battlefield yesterday as the British continued the tedious and costly process of reducing enemy strong points and clearing minefields and obstructions.
A High Command communiqu broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Three earth shocks, the second strong enough to frighten churchgoers from houses of worship in Sandpoint and Coeur D'Alene, Idaho and cause a temporary shutdown of Northern Pacific Railway operations east of here, were felt today in the mountain region east and north of Spokane.
Today is the first of four days during which home-owners and operators of apartment and office buildings must file their applications to avoid penalties under fuel oil rationing.

In a statement issued last night from his headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, accused Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican rival, of a "total disregard of the facts" in campaign speeches made this year.

A couple of freshman backs with the speed and elusiveness of jackrabbits encompassed the defeat of the Football Giants before 19,346 fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Bill Dudley and Curt Sandig led the Steelers to a thrilling 17-to-9 victory.

Nino Martini, tenor, was the soloist late yesterday afternoon with the New York City WPA Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, in the fourth and final war stamp concert in the series sponsored by the Workmen's Circle. Herman Adler was again the conductor and there was an audience of 2,600.

Prompt admission by the Navy that an American plane carrier attacked by the Japanese a week ago off the Santa Cruz islands was so severely damaged that she had to be sunk by our own forces offers a welcome contrast to the long delays which marked acknowledgment of previous losses among our carriers.

Less than a month after the enactment of the new price-control law members of the Senate farm bloc are denouncing the "high-handed and illegal way" it is being administered and calling for an investigation. The farm Senators contend that, although Government subsidies were scarcely mentioned in consideration of the legislation, they are being used to play a dominant part in farm price control.

Events tonight: Doris Doe, song recital, Town Hall, 8:30 o'clock; American Society of Ancient Instruments, Josef Smit, viole de gambe, assisting soloist, New York Times Hall, 9; faculty of the Dalcroze School of Music, concert of chamber music, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:45; Alfred Mirovitch, all-Chopin piano recital, Midwood High School, Brooklyn, 8:30; Salmaggi Opera Company to present "Faust," Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

A committee headed by George H. Brown Jr., chairman of the Girard Trust Company, Philadelphia, has been formed for the first mortgage 6 per cent certificates, due March 1, 1946, of the Lower Broadway Properties, Inc., owner of the 50 Broadway Building.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The 1942 Congressional election campaign neared its close tonight amid statements from several sources.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Navy's announcement of the sinking of a second aircraft carrier in the Solomons caused much comment when linked with the statement of Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, Wednesday night in an address in The New York Times Hall under auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Why a perfume should be named for a violin is difficult to see -- or, for that matter, how it is named at all. A new perfume -- christened none the less after the mellow instruments made by a master in seventeenth century Cremona -- is the sort that creates memories.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. rejected yesterday a proposal from Dewey headquarters that a force of special deputies be named to police tomorrow's election. Mr. Bennett said he had depended upon his regularly employed assistant attorneys general and local police in the elections of 1939, 1940 and 1941 with entirely successful results and would do the same this year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Lions held the vaunted Bears without a touchdown by rushing today but the National Football League champions scored twice on passes and again on a field goal to win, 16 to 0, before 12,205 at Wrigley Field.

Kazuo Aoki, a minor bureaucrat and yes-man to the Japanese Premier, General Hideki Tojo, since the General's Kwantung Army days, emerged yesterday as the head of Japan's new Super-Ministry of Greater East Asia, according to Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

The concert given by the New Friends of Music late yesterday afternon in Town Hall had as its participants the Coolidge Quartet and Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, duo-pianists. As its share in the proceedings the Coolidge ensemble presented Haydn's quartets, Op. 71, No. 1, and Op. 20, No. 4.

OTTAWA, Nov. 1 -- Beginning tomorrow all Canadian business will be "frozen" to the extent that it will be forbidden, except under special permit, to move to larger premises, to create new outlets or to stock lines of goods not already handled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board has ordered an election to determine which union, if any, shall bargain for 453 employes of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company's generating plant at Kearny, N.J.

Twenty members of the New York City Junior League got themselves tangled in a bunch of electric-wire cords yesterday and emerged with broken fingernails, a vague idea of the intricacies of a wall plug and a smattering of improved spelling technique.
In THE TIMES of Oct. 30 I observe that the Welfare Commissioner proposes to remove from their institutional homes 405 children.

The Rev. Dr. Stuart Nye Hutchison of Pittsburgh, the 1942 Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., officiated at a union All Saints Day celebration of the Sacrament of the Lord's Supper held by the Presbytery of New York yesterday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

The American people will choose tomorrow thirty-four Governors and many other officials in their States and cities, but by far their most important task in this time of crisis will be choosing a new group of Senators and a new House of Representatives.

William A. Clarke, principal of John Adams High School, Brooklyn, called on 1,500 BMT employes yesterday to help organize public opinion here to exert an American influence on post-war peace terms, in the interest of the peoples of the countries involved.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 1 -- Turkey is in graver danger than ever before of aggression from the belligerents in World War II and the Turkish Republic faces a long and difficult Winter and Spring fraught with fresh perils menacing the nation's steadfast, armed neutrality, President Ismet Inonu warned this afternoon in opening the fourth session of the sixteenth National Assembly in a traditional address in the Turkish capital.
SCRANTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A magnificent aerial attack gave the University of Scranton a 14-14 tie with a favored Lakehurst Naval Air Station aggregation today.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Despite rainy weather, two battalions of the New York Guard, the Third of the Fifty-eighth Regiment from Westchester County and a provisional battalion from the Twelfth Regiment of New York City, carried on field training on the Warburg estate here today as scheduled.
Only three new films are scheduled so far to open here this week. The newcomers are:

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America yesterday denied reports current in the men's clothing industry that it was considering accepting lower wage rates on future government orders to be placed in the New York market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- American forces inflicted severe damage on the Japanese fleet in the big sea and air battle fought northeast of Guadalcanal Island last Monday, scoring bomb hits on two carriers, two battleships and two cruisers and two torpedo hits on a third cruiser, besides destroying more than 100 planes and probably destroying about fifty others, the Navy reported today.

Dr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Neill of Washington, D. C., and Middleburg, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Virginia, to Aviation Cadet William Ely Chambers Jr., U. s. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ely Chambers of New York and Cornerwae, Hewlett, L. I.

The price rise on liquor and cigarettes, which becomes effective today as a result of increased taxes, will have no material effect on advertising campaign plans previously arranged for these products, according to agency executives. The increases amount to as much as 50 cents on a quart of whisky and are 1/2 cent a pack on cigarettes.

The Anchor Club of the Police Department, composed of Knights of Columbus, held its seventh annual memorial services at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. Three thousand members of the organization assembled in front of the West Fifty-fourth Street Police station shortly after 3 o'clock and, headed by the department band, marched up Eighth Avenue to Fifty-seventh Street, to Fifth Avenue and to the cathedral.

BERNE, Nov. 1 -- Pursuing a, drive for the Balkans foodstuffs, the Reichsbank's "purchasing commissions" have hit a costly snag in both Rumania and Bulgaria, according to advices received here tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The heaviest barrage yet seen in the Middle East, together with an Allied air offensive, marked the latest successful advances launched by Lieut. Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery, commander of the British Eighth Army, and one is now known to have included an important rise of land.
CAIRO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A Joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communiqu:

CANTERBURY, England, Nov. 1 -- This ancient seat of English Christianity was hard at work today digging itself out of ruins left in the wake of the heavy German daylight bombing raid just before sunset yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Increased mobilization of American youth behind the war effort was urged today by James T. Nicholson, vice chairman of the American Red Cross in charge of the American Junior Red Cross, as the latter organization opened its annual enrollment for services.

Entering their most intensive month of effort of the pre-Christmas season, the publishers have prepared large lists with many strong titles in all fields. Here are just a few of the highlights of the next few weeks in the order of their appearance.

The concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Bruno Walter, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, with Nathan Milstein, the Russian violinist, as soloist, proved one of the notable events of the current music season. Mr. Walter, Mr. Milstein and the orchestra were all in an inspired mood, providing a series of performances not soon to be forgotten.

AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 1 -- This afternoon, from Studio 8-H in Radio City in New York, Arturo Toscanini gave with the NBC Symphony Orchestra the first all-American program of his career for his radio audience. A reaction to this event from the standpoint of a member of that audience may be of interest to its readers.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 1 -- In the presence of the Duke of Windsor, Governor of the Bahamas, and the Duchess; the commanding officers of the British and American forces stationed here, members of the American consular staff and colonial government officials, the Right Rev. Spence Burton, a native of Cincinnati, was enthroned today as the ninth Bishop of the Anglican diocese of Nassau in a ceremony at Christ Church Cathedral.
Charlotte Claire, in the Great Northern Hotel, 118 W 57th St.

MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 2 -- Russian troops, switching to the attack in the big battle of Stalingrad, made advances both in the northern and southern parts of the city yesterday, but the Germans again forged ahead in their offensive on the plains of Nalchik at the foot of the Caucasus Mountains, the Soviet midnight communique said.

Shipments of all types of hosiery during September amounted to 12,648,730 dozen pairs, compared with 13,770,634 dozen pairs in September, 1941, a decrease of 8.1 per cent, according to figures issued by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

With activity confined to mill price-fixing in the near months and hedging and liquidation in the distant positions, the cotton futures market last week experienced only slight price variations. At the end of the period on Saturday active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 10 to 16 points after having lost 4 to 13 points in the preceding week.

Although retailers generally were buying more conservatively, wholesale trading continued fairly brisk last week, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings opened their National Hockey League campaign by blanking the Boston Bruins, 3 to 0, before 10,870 spectators at the Olympia Stadium tonight. Goalie Johnny Mowers of Detroit turned in the shut-out.

Extension of unemployment insurance to more workers, especially those in small business establishments, and increase of benefits by allowing an extra differential for families having one or more dependents, was recommended yesterday in a report to Mayor La Guardia by William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- During the past few weeks Britain's home front has been put into shape for the approaching Winter. With the blackout time coming earlier day by day all sorts of changes have had to be effected to make wintertime living conditions conform with the hours of daylight as well as with the increasing shortage of manpower and transport.

When the announcement was made recently prohibiting charter and party fishing boats from making their customary trips offshore to the fishing grounds, many New York captains affected by this order believed the measure would be only temporary.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Cecil Isbell threw five touchdown passes, including three to Don Hutson, as the Green Bay Packers went on a scoring spree to defeat the Chicago Cardinals, 55 to 24, in a National Football League game before a crowd of 15,000 today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Winter sailing was started today at the Larchmont Yacht Club for the eleventh successive year with an outward naval tang to it along with the canvas jamming that in the records has done so much in training officers for sea duty.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Persons still skeptical about Britain's war effort, especially those to be found in the United States, were answered today by Home Secretary Herbert Morrison speaking indirectly on behalf of Minister of Production Oliver Lyttelton.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- General Douglas MacArthur's bombers, making their fourth raid in four days upon enemy shipping concentrations in the Buin-Faisi area of the northern Solomon Islands, are believed to have sunk or seriously damaged seven more enemy vessels to bring their ten-day total to forty, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A Navy Department communiqu:

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress and chairman of the executive committee of the World Jewish Congress, will leave today for Mexico for ten days of conferences with Mexican officials and representatives of the Mexican Jewish community on problems of the war and aid to oppressed Jews.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Chinese "sea guerrillas" operating along the Fukien Province coast have destroyed two Japanese transports, the Central News Agency reported today.

IT begins to look like a sustained flight by the Boston College Eagles. Who is going to bring those birds down? They have Temple, Fordham, Boston University and Holy Cross ahead of them. One of them might beat the Eagles if the wind happened to be blowing the right way.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Enough food will be supplied by the country's farms next year to keep Americans well fed, but shortages of individual commodities are likely, the Department of Agriculture predicted today in a summary of next year's food production outlook.

Stories from our far-flung battlefronts invariably point to a simple, childlike faith in God that is serving to buoy the spirits of men under fire, the Rev. Ernest R. Palen, pastor of the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, said }in his sermon yesterday morning '.on "A Faith for Hard Times." i

After reading Hugh Byas's letter to your paper on Oct. 30 I am deeply surprised that intelligent people like him should have uttered at this moment such words as "the United States or England could have had peace with Japan at any time if they had been willing to 'sell China down the river,' and we are at war with Japan because we refused to do so."
Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. returned to the United States from London last night and said he had been much encouraged by what he saw in Great Britain.

The adequacy of the coming peace will be measured by the extent to which the Jewish problem is solved, three speakers declared yesterday at an inter-faith meeting held at B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, west of Broadway.

VICHY, Nov. 1 -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France for Oct. 1 shows the effects of the September settlements in the securities markets. Credits accorded to the markets rose by 962,000,000 francs, of which the greater part appeared in an increase of 613,000,000 in bills discounted and one of 271,000,000 in bills purchased on the markets by the bank.

News accounts from far places where our American troops are stationed are gradually filling out a picture of revised methods of courtship made necessary by local customs. These indicate with few exceptions that the clock is being set back and a governor put on speed.

Asserting that Thomas E. Dewey had proposed no definite program in his campaign but had tried to "coast in," James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, called upon the Republican nominee for Governor last night to tell what he would do for the welfare of the men in the armed forces when they returned from war or how he would relocate them and our war workers in the peace after victory.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Procedure has been simplified for mailing of packages from the United States by the next of kin or designated beneficiaries to prisoners of war and interned civilians.

A revitalized Christian faith must be achieved by the Christian Church to meet the challenge of godless religions, declared the Rev. Franklin P. Cole in a sermon yesterday morning at the Congregational Church-in-the-Gardens, Ascan Avenue and Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens.

A month's commemoration of the issuance twenty-five years ago of the Balfour Declaration, in which the British Government pledged itself to facilitate establishment of a Jewish national home in Palestine, began last night in Carneige Hall with a mass meeting under the joint auspices of the American Emergency Committee for Zionist Affairs and the American Palestine Committee.

If democracy is to survive the present world upheaval it will be because it has learned to recognize the fact that it rests upon divine sanctions, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared in his sermon yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Mayor La Guardia called upon the New York Telephone Company yesterday for "more cooperation" with his anti-gambling crusade and expressed doubt that the "complicated telephone service set-ups" used by bookmakers on horse races could operate without the company's knowledge.

Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican Chairman, charged that Communists and fellow-travelers were conducting a last-minute campaign against State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican candidate for reelection in the Seventeenth Senatorial District, falsely representing themselves to be Republicans.

Conrad Thibault. American baritone, who has sung widely on the radio, gave his third Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon. Alderson Mowbray was his accompanist and, with the exception of one group in French and another in Spanish, the program was in English.

The Republican party cannot be cured of its reactionary tendencies, but the Democratic party can and will be cured, Alex Rose, State secretary of the American Labor party, and one of its principal leaders, declared last night in a final radio round-up staged by laborite candidates and leaders.

I am not sure the rationing of food is not the most fortunate thing that ever happened to the United States. It provides a new source of joy. This was forcibly impressed on me when I got a pound of coffee yesterday. I was ecstatic, and came home and enjoyed that coffee more than I had ever enjoyed any coffee in my life before.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Members of the National Shoe Retailers' Association and the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers' Association gathered here today for the National Shoe Fair which opens tomorrow and continues for three days with displays of advance styles.

At the conclusion of the sixth round of the United States amateur championship tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night. Louis R. Chauvenet, champion of Virginia, was still showing the way with 6 1/2 points out of 7 to his credit. Having defeated Leonard Fondiller of Manhattan in 19 moves in the fifth round, he won from G. Gustafson of Brooklyn in a brilliantly conducted queen's pawn opening after 20 moves.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, Oct. 31 (Delayed) -- It is reported that the British Eighth Army has obtained a fair-sized bag this time, mostly German, and that it has inflicted heavy casualties. It is not permitted to say how many of the enemy troops have been taken prisoner or killed or wounded, but the number is gratifying.

Our military leaders should be commended for their gusto on the job. If they were less aggressive, or more modest in their appeal for manpower, we might rightly feel uneasy. What we expect them to perform is a miracle -- the creation practically overnight of a force strong enough to smash two military machines patiently fabricated by a whole generation of professional killers.

Net earnings of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 were $4,794,060, after all charges and after providing a reserve of $2,455,480 for estimated Federal and State income taxes, according to a report issued for publication today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- There will be no change in the price ceiling on wheat or flour when the permanent ceiling is put into effect early in December unless Congress takes action and forces the Office of Price Administration to revise its program, according to officials on the Board of Trade who attended a hearing held by the Senate Agricultural Committee in Washington early last week.

Sawdust lies scattered on the white-tiled floor of the crowded store, cylinders of salami and round ivory-colored cheeses hang from the ceiling, tins and jars stand on the shelves in informal confusion. And behind the refrigerated-showcase, of the sort you might see in any number of shops in the city, stands the be-aproned Mario.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 1 -- A variation of the absurdity of "carrying coals to Newcastle" is said to be under investigation here.

The new one-story taxpayer containing a large A. P. food market at 733-39 Third Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-sixth Street, has been purchased by an investing client of Joseph L. Lefkowitz through L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers. It is assessed at $113,000 and was sold by Land Properties, Inc., the builders, who were represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney.

War has blacked out practically everything in Britain but British courage. War in Britain is so stern and so serious that it will also black out Christmas for her hundreds of thousands of boys and girls unless their American friends volunteer now to send them the toys which Britain, geared up to war production, is unable to produce.
It seems in order at this point, as football closes the book on October, to ask what's any other team got that is lacking to Boston College?

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- United States fliers destroyed two, and probably three, Japanese planes and damaged six others when a large formation of enemy bombers and fighter planes raided American air bases in Assam Province, bordering Burma, on Oct. 28, it was announced today.
MONROVIA, Liberia, Nov. 1 (AP) -- United States currency not exceeding twenty-dollar bills in denomination became legal tender in Liberia today under an executive order of President Edwin Barclay.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- For the first time since she came to Britain, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent a full day today with United States troops, attending their religious services, visiting the sick, inspecting camp arrangements and chatting in homely fashion with officers and men everywhere she went.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The American Legion "is unalterably opposed" to the proposal which would deny the Army the use of 18 and 19 year old selectees for combat until they had received a year's training after induction, its national commander, Roane Waring, said tonight.

With one of the oddest and most apathetic campaigns in the history of New York State coming to a close today, supporters of Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, confidently expect his election by a plurality of at least half a million.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1 -- Mexico's decision to send troops outside her national borders is expected to be followed by other Latin-American countries, Mexican political circles said today. It is believed that all American countries in the Western Hemisphere that declared war on the Axis will want to be represented on the battlefronts.
MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- The midnight Soviet Communique:

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The Illinois-Mississippi waterway promises to be a busy highway this Winter, carrying ships built at Great Lakes shipyards to service the naval fighting forces at home and abroad. When the St. Lawrence sea lane freezes (it is blocked by ice three to five months each year) -- all deliveries of new vessels must be made by inland waterway.

Continuing prayers for our soldier and sailor dead, to be said today, the Feast of All Souls, and throughout the month, were asked yesterday by the Rev. William F. King in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Secretary Knox says the first round in the battle of the Solomons is over. It is a long round that lasts almost four months. Available information indicates that the present pause marks nothing more than a draw, with neither side entitled to any claims of victory. What the future holds no man can safely predict beyond the certainty that the enemy will try once more to drive us from these islands.

An exchange deal involving a midtown commercial building and a Long Island estate was announced yesterday when it was disclosed that Frederick Brown, the operator, sold the eleven-story offices and showrooms at 8 to 10 East Forty-ninth Street, near Fifth Avenue, to William C. Atwater Jr., his brothers and sister.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 1 -- Yesterday saw some of the heaviest Allied air operations since the present battle in Egypt began. The enemy tried a few Stuka attacks, two of which were intercepted.

Friedrich Schorr, Wagnerian baritone, who has appeared as Wotan 250 times and as Hans Sachs more than 200 times since he joined the Metropolitan Opera Company eighteen years ago, will retire from the operatic stage this season, General Manager Edward Johnson announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia in a brief radio address last night urged Italian-Americans in this city to vote for the American Labor party candidate for Governor, Dean Alfange. Speaking in Italian, he made his appeal from the studio of WHOM, 29 West Fifty-seventh Street.
WAYNE, Pa., Nov. 1 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution have completed the national peace chimes in Valley Forge Memorial Chapel with the dedication of New Mexico and Florida State bells.

Their title hopes already hanging by the proverbial thread, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers were left hanging on the ropes yesterday at Ebbets Field, virtually eliminated from championship consideration as they floundered helplessly before a group of opportunists who call themselves the Cleveland Rams.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The body of Lester Bailey, last resident of the 40,000-acre tract of the Bear Mountain-Harriman Interstate Park, was found at 2 P.M. today on the northern edge of Oak Swamp, two miles from his home in Baileytown.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Investigators from the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee have been posted in Delaware, New Jersey, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island with instructions to remain on the ground until after Tuesday's elections, Chairman McFarland announced today.

A German broadcast recorded yesterday by The United Press in New York said German troops had penetrated Russian positions in the Tuapse sector of the Northwest Caucasus at "several points" and had pushed the enemy far back west of the Terek River, in the Central Caucasus.

Two words contained in the leading editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES today underscore the clue to much of what has happened in the historic past of the world's nations and which also provide an insight into the future.

Emphasizing that the war is tightening its grip on every form of economic activity, the National City Bank of New York in its monthly letter declares that the war's enormous demands for materials, manpower and money are pressing harder on available resources, many of which are passing more and more under government control.

A dispatch from London reporting that The Stars and Stripes, the newspaper of the United States Armed Forces in the European theatre of operations, would begin publication on a daily schedule today, becoming "the first service paper to go on a a daily basis," brought to light yesterday the fact that a daily service paper was established in the South Pacific theatre some weeks ago.
Not weapons of war but symbols of the day of peace were unloaded from Army trucks yesterday as the deadline for overseas holiday gift mailing arrived.

AN ARTILLERY OBSERVATION POST, IN EGYPT, Oct. 31 (Delayed) (AP) -- Bayonet-flashing British infantry smashed forward under an earth-jarring barrage last night and in savage hand-to-hand fighting dislodged Germans and Italians from another strong point on the Alamein front.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Army planes en route to the Southwest Pacific have joined the search for Captain E.V. ("Eddie") Rickenbacker, War Department officials disclosed today, in the hope that the missing World War I ace might still be found.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Packers of jams, jellies and apple butter, who received permission to increase prices to cover actual advances in production costs on the 1942 pack, have been ordered by the Office of Price Administration to notify their wholesale and retail customers in writing of the permitted increases which the jobbers and retailers may pass on.
VICHY, Nov. 1 -- Prospects for food and other supplies for the coming Winter in France are not favorable.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A communiqu:

I noted with interest a letter in your columns of Oct. 30 from Burnett Walker, who criticized the New York Unemployment Insurance Law because, at present, it provides that all persons earning more than $3 a week are ineligible for unemployment insurance benefits.

HEADQUARTERS, UNITED STATES FORCES, in the South Pacific, Oct. 28 (Delayed) -- A huge Japanese armada has limped away from the Solomon Islands licking wounds inflicted on it during the last two days by the United States Pacific Fleet.

Alarmed by the "seventh column," the carelessness that kills 102,500 persons a year in this country, women workers in the Todd Shipyards have pledged themselves to a drive to reduce the number of accidents to women in war work.

ALBANY, Nov. 1 -- Lively dairy herd trading and flow of farm labor to war industries have not, to date, cut down the metropolitan area's milk supply, Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, believes. He does think, however, that only prompt Washington action can prevent it in the near future.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Santa Clara's Broncos, big favorites, capitalized on a blocked punt and the resultant safety to squeeze by with a slim 8-to-6 victory today over the University of San Francisco. A crowd of 25,000 saw the game.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Representatives of independent labor unions in North Jersey who charge that the C.I.O. and the A.F. of L. have "lost the common touch" and who seek to eliminate "racketeering" from the union movement met here today to further plans for a State organization and to assist the Aircraft Workers of America in winning bargaining rights for workers at five plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in this area.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents will testify tomorrow at the trial of six persons accused of treason for aiding Herbert Hans Haupt, executed as one of the eight Nazi saboteurs landed on the east coast from German submarines.

KAY BOYLE is what is popularly known as a writer's writer. Her hard, graven, highly polished prose, her preoccupation with subtleties and refinements of thought and mood and character, her cold and piercing intelligence, which penetrates beneath all shams and pretensions, have won the respectful admiration of all those who care more for technical skill than for obvious emotional effectiveness.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Prices of corn were on the down grade last week on the Board of Trade and went to the lowest level since last December under scattered liquidation and weakness in the cash market, where grain with a high moisture content lost ground relative to futures because of the inability of elevators and industries readily to absorb the new corn coming forward from the country.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 1 -- The story of how a British company, isolated in an exposed position, beat off German tanks and truck-borne infantry for thirty-six hours and then rejoined its unit was told today by a 24-year-old sergeant.

New York State Communists, rallying 17,000 persons to Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon fort he final Communist meeting of the campaign, heard their leaders center their fire on Thomas E. Dewey as an apostle of appeasement, laud Wendell L. Willkie as the great liberal leader, alongside President Roosevelt, and demand the election of all "win the war" candidates for public office tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- After thrice thwarting Manhattan bids close to the goal line, Villanova swiftly took command late in the second quarter of their annual football clash today at Shibe Park and proceeded to make life miserable for the Jaspers during the remainder of the game.
Purchases by investors of dwellings and small multi-family buildings featured realty activity in Brooklyn, according to deals disclosed over the week-end.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- The final survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion in New York State shows Thomas E. Dewey leading by a substantial margin in what is widely regarded as the nation's most important governorship election this year because of its 1944 presidential implications.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 30 (delayed) (U.P.) -- Hedley Cook, former United States Consul in Bombay, left today for Alexandrette to open the new United States Consulate there. Alexandrette, on the Gulf of Iskanderun, is the main port of entry for American lend-lease supplies to Turkey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Niagara Power Company received today its choice of charging more than $15,500,000 which had been disallowed as part of the cost of its power project near Niagara Falls, to its capital surplus or to its earned surplus account.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Representative Hamilton Fish announced here tonight that he intended to sue Drew Pearson, newspaper columnist, for $500,000 after Tuesday's election.

In his regular short-wave broadcast to Italy yesterday afternoon Mayor La Guardia scored the Fascists for overlooking his charges against their government and responding to his broadsides by "personal attacks, and challenged them to answer ten serious questions on the actual state of affairs in Italy.
The friends and neighbors of Sergeant Meyer Levin, bombardier in the crew of the late Captain Colin Kelly, paid tribute to him yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The stock markets here were subdued and undecided last week. Uncertainty about the immediate outlook for the war on the three main battlefronts prompted all-around caution and some profit-taking.

Last week's financial markets were governed by uncertainty regarding the battle in the Far East. No definite information regarding that engagement was received, but the rather evident depression of spirit at Washington caused hesitation and therefore, during most of the week, a slow downward movement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A field goal booted by Bob Masterson, veteran end, in the final second of an exciting game gave the Redskins of the National Football League a 30-27 victory over the fiercely fighting Eagles today before 32,658 fans.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Irene Dunne will play Nora to William Powell's Nick Charles in "The Thin Man Goes Home," which will start in three weeks, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has announced. Myrna Loy, who had been seen as Nora in the studio's four previous "Thin Man" films, is now under technical suspension from salary because she has declined all assignments since her recent marriage.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- In a reorganization to become effective tomorrow Butler Brothers is removing the supervision of some 4,000 voluntary chain, independently owned and operated Ben Franklin and Federated Stores from its sales department, C.D. Southard, vice president in charge of sales, said today.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- There were several outstanding features in today's cheerful market. Based on the war news from Egypt, the home rails and industrials were well bought. Home rails led the way with all junior stocks higher.

That dark horse of the Fall 1940 publishing season, "The White Cliffs," has now passed its second anniversary. Here's the record to date: There have been twenty-eight printings, the most recent being 10,000 copies. The sale of the little book by the late Alice Duer Miller is well above the 200,000 mark, although Coward-McCann doesn't say just how high. On a recent single day the publishers received orders for 2,127 copies.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Eleven major league baseball teams pledged themselves today to purchase minor league players for $139,000 as they selected twenty men from the draft lists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Ceiling prices for cigars, beer and California wines and spirits were raised today by the Office of Price Administration to reflect new Federal taxes and higher production costs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The magic wand of football, Cecil Isbell's arm, has become the most potent weapon in the National Football League, throwing the Green Bay Packers to victory and the record books out the window.

Although no election results will be flashed tonight in Times Square for the first time in thirty-eight years. Police Commissioner Valentine has assigned 300 traffic policemen to the area and a full crew of firemen and auxiliary firemen will be on duty to prevent the sounding of false alarms.

Winding up his campaign for Governor with a State-wide radio address, Thomas E. Dewey declared last night that the Republican party in the State was pledged to the task of throwing the full force of New York's manpower and production capacity into the all-important job of winning the war as well as combatting on the home front the "corrosion of our democracy by corrupt political machines."

The importance of registering for fuel oil rationing on the three remaining days -- tomorrow, Thursday and Friday -- was emphasized last night by the Regional OPA offices, 535 Fifth Avenue, after registration had got off to a slow start on the first of the four days.

The Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday reserved decision in the controversy between the Federal Power Commission and the Niagara Falls Power Company on a petition by the utility seeking a stay of execution of an order issued by the commission on June 9 ordering Niagara Falls to write off $15,537,943 from its accounts.
In an open letter yesterday to the children of the city, Mayor La Guardia asked their help in preventing election day fires as a contribution toward winning the war.

GARDEN CITY, L.I. Nov. 2 -- Declaring there was no place in America for negative politics while the country was at war, James A. Farley appealed tonight to all liberals to cast their votes tomorrow for Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor.

Expressing complete confidence in his election as Governor on the Democratic ticket, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ended his campaign last night with an appeal to all registered voters, regardless of party, to go to the polls today.

OTTAWA, Nov. 2 -- Meat may be placed on a ration basis within the next six months in Canada, J. Gordon Taggart, Food Administrator, warned today in an address to the Ottawa Rotary Club. Rationing might not be necessary, he said, but would be imposed if the supplies under contract to Britain were not forthcoming.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Samuel Nuzzo of Newburgh, ousted business agent of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union of America, who is under indictment for alleged theft of funds from the union's treasury, was nominated for re-election at a meeting of the local in Kingston yesterday.

Igor Buketeff, 27-year-old American conductor, has won the first annual conducting award of the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University, it was announced yesterday, and he will be introduced to the public at an orchestral concert in Town Hall on Dec. 13.

The list of new film entries for this week dwindled to two yesterday with the withdrawal of "Street of Chance" as the Rialto's scheduled offering for Saturday. Because of the exceptionally good business being done by its current attraction, the Universal melodrama, "The Mummy's Tomb," the Rialto has decided to hold that film for a third week, starting Saturday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 2 -- Except for brief bulletins announcing that American elections were taking place and an editorial in Rome's Tribuna, German and Italian official commentators and press alike were silent on "crisis of Americanism," as polling was once termed by Mario Appelius of the Popolo d'Italia.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

There are no constitutional amendments or propositions to be voted on today. The machines will show only a list of candidates for public office -- State, Federal and local. We summarize here the recommendations which this newspaper has made to its readers.

Reporting on operations of the International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries, Thomas J. Watson, president, informed stockholders that earnings for the nine months ended with September were $18,652,433 before taxes, an increase of $5,435,216 over the $13,217,217 earned before taxes in the corresponding period a year ago.

The stock market ushered in yesterday a new month by snapping out of last week's pause as prices were bid up fractions to more than a point. Despite the interruption to business today due to the election day holiday, considerable confidence was exhibited in financial circles in the share list's structure as trading expanded to the heaviest in three weeks.

In addition to good fighters, the Army, Navy and Coast Guard have some potential sculptors, it appeared yesterday when work in terra cotta and clay by members of the armed services was exhibited for the benefit of the services in the game room of the New York Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- A psychiatrist for the defense described from the witness stand in Westchester County Court today an underground hide-out in which, he said, 17-year-old Edward Haight, on trial for the murders of two little Bedford Village girls, has hidden ninety assorted firearms and a fountain pen filled with blood.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 2 -- Whit Burnett, author, and editor of Story Magazine, obtained a divorce today from Martha Foley Burnett, who was co-founder of the magazine with him in Vienna in 1931. He obtained custody of their son. After receiving the decree, Mr. Burnett married Hallie S. Abbett of New York, a short story writer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The eve of the off-year Congressional and State elections found Capitol Hill practically deserted and political discussion at a low ebb.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

Earnings for the third quarter, ended on Oct. 3, are estimated by Paramount Pictures, Inc., at $3,455,000, according to the company's report announced yesterday. This is after all charges, including interest, provision for normal taxes and surtaxes at 45 per cent, estimated excess profits taxes of non-consolidated subsidiaries and reserves for possible excess profits taxes of the company and its consolidated subsidiaries.
CAIRO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

Dr. Carroll R. Daugherty, chairman of the economics department of Hunter College, will assume today his duties as director of the recently authorized research and review division of the War Labor Board. The division will have final jurisdiction over all proposed wage rate increases in plants employing eight or more workers.

The tire factory at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant was completed in January, 1938. It has been called the "world's most advanced tire plant" It is the first in which production was routed straight through from the hold of the rubber freighter to the automobile assembly line.

CHUNGKING, China. Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- United States Army bomber-fighters have raided Hong Kong harbor again, setting one Japanese freighter afire and scoring near misses on two other ships, and Chinese pilots, striking out on their own in American-made bombers, have struck a heavy blow at the Yangtze River port of Hankow, it was revealed tonight.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. (AP) -- The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company reported today for the third quarter of 1942 a net income of $1,017,162, or 57 cents a share on 1.776,092 common shares, after provision of $6,700,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

We are having an election today -- a small "d" democratic election. In our own State the campaign managers have made their usual hopeful predictions. Trust a campaign manager to look on the rosy side of things. But even the most optimistic campaign manager does not predict a vote of 90 per cent or more for his ticket.
Lord Camrose has returned from Canada, and is at the Waldorf-Astoria with his daughter, the Hon. Mrs. R.G. McNair Scott of Boston.

NOW the coaches, scouts and interested bystanders are beginning to trot out their all-America nominations. In a huddle yesterday the following candidates had their names tossed about in forward, lateral and backward passes:

The protests of wholesale grocers and other trade groups opposed to the so-called "contingent fee" bill which, as drawn, it is asserted, would prohibit transactions by regularly established commercial agents employed by contractors engaged in business with the government, have met with "encouraging" response, it was learned yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A movie-struck girl from the Middle West took the witness stand today before a courtroom jammed with women to relate her charges against Errol Flynn, film actor.

Jay N. Whipple, president of the Investment Bankers Association and a partner in Bacon, Whipple Co. of Chicago, sent yesterday to all members of the association a summary of its stand at a hearing held last week by the Securities and Exchange Committee in Philadelphia, opposing proposed regulation by the SEC of the sale of State and municipal bonds.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Sidney Fischman, 42 years old, a lawyer of Spring Valley, N.Y., was shot and wounded critically at 11:30 A.M. today in his automobile on New Hempstead Road here during an altercation with George Epstein, 54, a Rockland Lake hotel proprietor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- The United States Court of Claims in a unanimous decision today ruled that the Ford Motor Company of Delaware was entitled to recover tax overpayments for 1921 to 1926 inclusive.

Antiques ranging from the decorative to the utilitarian were placed on display yesterday at the 1942 New York Antiques Exhibition in the Basildon and Jade Rooms of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The show will continue daily from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. through Friday.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- This was a day of sharp contrasts for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. She had spent the night with Queen Mary and from the peaceful and gracious surroundings of the Queen Mother's wartime home in the country, the First Lady sped by car into the midst of the United States Army's toughest soldiers, the parachute troops.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- American submarines operating against Japanese shipping have sunk seven more ships and damaged three others, the Navy reported today in a new summation of submarine activities. No details of the exploits were made public except for descriptions of the types of vessels successfully attacked.

With New York City drawing the spotlight, an attractive program of fifteen scholastic football games is slated for the metropolitan sector today. Traditional battles between Erasmus and Manual and DeWitt Clinton and Stuyvesant gain top billing on the city card.

The four buildings on a plot 103 by 150 feet at the southeast corner of Tenth Avenue and Thirteenth Street were sold by Commander Vincent Astor through Webb Knapp and the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., to a client of Samuel S. Isaacs, attorney.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- A bachelor has been asked to improve the legal status of the 12,500,000 housewives in Britain.

With the winner of the Eastern Shore and Remsen handicaps packing top weight, Empire City, on the next to last day of its racing for the year, offers an Election Day card that has two features and the promise of good racing. Allen T. Simmons's Blue Swords, at 123 pounds, probably will be favorite in the field of seven expected to start in the $10,000 added Ardsley Handicap.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Government petroleum officials reported today that the fuel oil situation was still "tight" along the East Coast

The apparel-selling season for Southern and general warm-weather wear got under way here yesterday with openings by several members of the Sportswear Guild. Highlighted in the new lines were bright, gay colors, elaborate trimming details, unusual prints and novelty wool versions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Secretary Morgenthau, back from his visit to Great Britain, declared today that Americans were paying only half as much income tax as residents of the United Kingdom and Canadians. He had little light to shed on his movements in England except that he had gone "to have a look around and talk things over with the British Treasury."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Charles L. McNary of Oregon, Senate minority leader, today obtained unanimous consent to postpone for thirty days the printing of the permanent edition of the Congressional Record until Senator Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan can establish the "authenticity" of material inserted by him in the Record.

Three men charged with acting as Japanese agents without registering with the Federal Government pleaded guilty in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday before they were to go to trial. They were remanded to the House of Detention by Judge Marcus B. Campbell for sentence on Nov. 12.
