A lease involving 10,000 square feet of floor space at 122-30 West Twenty-seventh Street has been signed by the B-G Infant Coat Company, Inc., with Omnia Properties, Inc., through Moe Goodstein, broker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Married nurses will be accepted in the Army Nurse Corps "in the very near future," it was stated here today, as a further step in the policy put into effect Oct. 1 under which nurses who marry after enlistment are not discharged from service.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2 -- Head Coach Howie Odell excused the Yale varsity from practice today but sent the second and third elevens through a scrimmage which, though brief, was spirited. He promised the regulars a heavy workout tomorrow, with the jayvees executing Cornell plays as plotted by Yale scouts.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Considering the fact that this is only a midterm election in the United States the British press is devoting an extraordinary amount of space, despite the paper shortage, to the campaign.

The American Society of the Ancient Instruments, a family group of five Netherlanders who are now American citizens living in Philadelphia, appeared last night for the first time in New York at the New York Times Hall. The group, which is already well known to musicians through its recordings and its appearances in its home city, was founded thirteen years ago by its director, Ben Stad.

Eighteen additional Manhattan property owners have been granted permits for planting thirty-two new trees since the opening of the campaign early in October when eleven applications were made for twenty-six plantings, according to J.P. Lohman, executive secretary of the Live in Manhattan Committee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped about 25 cents a hundred pounds today, reacting to a sizeable run and predictions that even more head would be unloaded here tomorrow. Livestock men saw this as the start of the expected unusually heavy November, December and January marketings.

Net sales of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for the first nine months of 1942 amounted to $368,968,021, comparing with $350,936.844 in the same period of 1941, a gain of $18,000,000, or 5.14 per cent. In the third quarter sales were $125,541,843, about $550,000 less than $126,090,602 net sales in the third quarter of 1941.
AT UNITED NATION HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A communique:
Among the apartment leases reported yesterday was one for nine furnished rooms at 47 East Eighty-eighth Street signed by Jules Gourary through Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Milk production is falling steadily in New Jersey, where a shortage already exists, Colonel Arthur F. Foran, Director of Milk Control for the State, said here today. He described the situation as "dangerous," said the prospects for the Winter were dark.

BALDWIN, L.I., Nov. 2 -- Al Brosch, Bethpage pro, and Charles Sperber of Sound View put together a 33, 34 -- 67, to take top honors in what probably was the last Long Island P.G.A. pro-amateur golf tourney of the season today over the Milburn G.C. course.

A survey of the student body of New York University has revealed that 83 per cent of the undergraduates are in favor of the 18-19-year-old draft bill now before Congress, it was announced yesterday by Professor Darrell B. Lucas, research consultant and faculty member of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 3 (UP) -- The midday communique from General MacArthur's headquarters today announced:
DANVILLE, Va., Nov. 2 -- Husband and wife teams are being trained for war production here in an experiment which reaches into the realm of psychology and war morale.

The new Battle of Egypt has differed radically thus far from previous manoeuvres in the desert. It has been a grim night conflict of artillery and infantry, fought to a finish at the bayonet's point. Beneath the British rolling barrage Allied troops have continuously infiltrated Rommel's fixed positions.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Australian veterans of war in four continents had on Sunday pushed their counter-offensive through the Owen Stanley Mountains of New Guinea until they were able to look down upon Kokoda, which they threatened with a flanking movement, the Sydney Morning Herald reported today.

Births in New York City last week broke all records for the last twenty-seven years, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stabbins announced yesterday. He reported 3,031 births, against 2,889 the week before.

Despite the fact that the Treasury received more than $500,000,000 of "new money" yesterday from cash payments on subscriptions to its recent offering of seven-eighths of 1 per cent certificates of indebtedness, it made known here late in the afternoon that it would withdraw $337,311,000 from commercial bank depositories throughout the country in the latter part of this week.

Albert Bradley and Ormond E. Hunt were elected yesterday executive vice presidents of the General Motors Corporation at a quarterly meeting of the board of directors. E.F. Johnson, vice president in charge of the Dayton, Ohio, and Eastern Aircraft divisions of the corporation, was elected a member of the war administration committee as well.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $3,207,383. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to 50 cents a share on the company's outstanding common stock and compares with a net of $4,656,128, or $1.25 a common share, in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1941.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- Russian counter-attacks at Stalingrad have become more vigorous and more frequent, and ground is being won back from the enemy, which had bought it at such heavy cost in months of fighting.

Republican gains in Congress large enough to reflect popular dissatisfaction with the conduct of the war but not large enough to give that party a majority in the House of Representatives are expected to result today in the country's first wartime election since 1918.

Miss Barbara M. Hadden heads a group of young women comprising a junior committee aiding in the sale of tickets for the pre-opening performance of "The Skin of Our Teeth," a new play by Thornton Wilder, with Tallulah Banhkead, Frederic March and Florence Eldridge in the leading roles, on the night of Nov. 17 at the Plymouth Theatre, for the benefit of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre.

The continued resistance to Axis aggression in Yugoslavia led by General Draja Mikhailovitch, War Minister, was commended in a special message from King Peter II, made public yesterday by Konstantin Fotitch, Yugoslav Ambassador to the United States.

Mayor La Guardia's recipe for breakfast coffee in wartime is as fine a piece of constructive criticism as one can recall in a long time. His advocacy of the old coffee pot may be challenged by the percolators and the drippers and the many other schools of opinion and practice, but they will have to answer the Mayor in specific terms, spoonful against spoonful and cup against cup.

A case described by the Department of Justice as tending to define the rights of agricultural marketing cooperatives was closed in Federal court yesterday with the assessment of fines totaling $32,000 on three cranberry sales cooperatives, four companies engaged in the cranberry industry, and four individuals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities as announced today by the Federal Reserve System shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 28: Decreases of $137,000,000 in holdings of Treasury notes and $407,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and increases of $208,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $110,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks today upheld a restraining order prohibiting a landlord from evicting a tenant, holding that the landlord was not acting in good faith when he said he wanted the tenement for his own occupancy. Judge Hincks said he would issue a temporary injunction in favor of the tenant Nov. 5.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 -- Lieut. Comdr. Thomas Burrowes, a graduate of Curtis High School on Staten Island, N.Y., was in San Francisco today with the entire complement of the sunken destroyer O'Brien, eager to be assigned as a unit to a new destroyer for another crack at the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress in a message today to give him sweeping wartime power to suspend any laws hampering "the free movement of persons, property and information into and out of the United States."

Earnings of the Coca-Cola Company for the three months ended with September amounted to $15,342,843 before income tax deductions, against $16,856,088 on the same basis for the third quarter of 1941, according to the company's statement announced yesterday.

WITH AMERICAN AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Oct. 31 (Delayed) (AP) -- American airmen flying shark-nosed P-40s, known here as "peashooters," introduced a new trick in their air warfare with a dive-bombing assault on Hong Kong last Wednesday.

The Berlin radio, quoting a Japanese Army spokesman at Hankow, said yesterday that two planes attacked the region of Hankow and Wuchang, according to The Associated Press. The Axis version was that three bombs fell on Wuchang, across the Yangtze from Hankow, setting two thatched Chinese houses afire and collapsing a third.

The large and valuable art collection of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Nov. 17, 18, 19, 20 and 21 Mrs. McCann, who died on March 15, 1938, was the former Helena Woolworth, daughter of the late F.W. Woodworth, 5 and 10 cent store pioneer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A committee composed of tank-car lessors, shipper-owners in the petroleum industry, representatives of the American Association of Railroads, the Office of the Petroleum Coordinator and the Office of Defense Transportation has been named to recommend more efficient ways of using tank cars to carry oil to the East.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake this afternoon allowed a writ of habeas corpus in the case of ten Negroes held incomunicado in vice cases in the Hudson County jail since last June. He granted the writ to Arnold Crighton, attorney for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, who was acting for the prisoners.

Great Britain has reduced unessential production in some nonconvertible consumer goods industries to as little as 10 per cent of normal, and in no case permits such production to exceed 35 per cent of normal, according to a study of British war production controls issued here yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, Inc.

The body of a young woman discovered yesterday by a German shepherd dog, out for its morning walk with its master, in a ditch in one of the most desolate sections of Central Park was identified late last night as that of Mrs. Louise Almadovar, 23 years old, of 2090 Arthur Avenue, the Bronx, a waitress, who had been reported missing since 6:30 P.M. Sunday by her mother, Mrs. Viola Petecca.

VICHY, France, Nov. 2 -- In token of the government's decision to incorporate Armistice Day in the annual All Souls' Tribute to the Dead, Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, went to the Arch of Triumph in Paris today and placed a wreath on the tomb of France's Unknown Soldier of World War I.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- So heavy was business at the opening of the National Shoe Fair that rumors circulated that all shoe factories would be booked up by Dec. 1.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Ferdinand J. Herman of New York, former repair superintendent at Fort Dix, and Benjamin Gedinsky of Brooklyn went on trial today before Federal Judge Thomas J. Meaney on charges of conspiring to defraud the United States.

The entire strength and resources of the 250,000 members of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Alliance and Bartenders International League of America, A.F. of L., employed in hotels and restaurants throughout the country, will be thrown solidly behind the committee recently named by the American Hotel Association to combat future moves by dry forces for the return of prohibition, it was revealed yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 2 -- Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 Republican Presidential nominee, gave Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce his endorsement for Congress today when the two met before ceremonies marking the award of an Army-Navy E to the Auto Ordnance Corporation of this city, manufacturers of submachine guns.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- With every "defeat" the United States Navy gets better, if one is to believe Japanese propagandists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Text of Navy communique 178:

The local regional WPB Special Projects Salvage Section announced yesterday that title to 910 tons of scrap materials needed for the war had been conveyed to the United States Government by the City of New York. Included were 250 tons of copper and 60 tons of rubber from underground electrical conduits at Flushing Meadow Park.

AT UNITED NATION'S HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 3--Allied ground forces have recaptured Kokoda, chief inland base of the Japanese in New Guinea, and frustrated a Japanese attempt to land strong reinforcements at Buna, the strategic coastal base sixty miles east of Kokoda, General Douglas MacArthur's command announced today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Irwin Kadens, "three State crime wave," in court for the first time, howled down his attorney today and demanded trial on two death penalty charges instead of such "petty offenses" as robbery and rape.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- United States forces on Guadalcanal Island seized the initiative on Sunday (Solomons time) and as a result of their attacks "enemy artillery fire was silenced and the Japanese were reported to be retreating slowly," the Navy Department announced tonight.

VICHY, France, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Marescotti and Costantino Ruspoli, sons of the late Prince Mario Ruspoli di Poggio-Suasa and of the former Palma de Talleyrand-Perigord, have been killed in action on the Egyptian front, the Rome radio reported today.

Thirty-two Senators of the United States, the constitutional third of the Senate, are to be chosen today. Some candidates are novices. Nearly half are asking re-election. Each no doubt is a familiar figure in his own State. The names of the aspirants for another term must have appeared, some of them again and again, in the news.

HEADQUARTERS, UNITED STATES FORCES, in the South Pacific, Oct. 28 (delayed) (UP) -- One of the most powerful fleets ever sent to sea by the United States Navy is plying these waters for the Solomons showdown, but opposing them is a Japanese armada of truly formidable proportions.

The Guaranty Trust Company, trustee for the 5 per cent debentures of 1944 of the Alleghany Corporation, reported yesterday that the market value of the collateral pledged as security for the issue on Nov. 2 was $31,766,826, equal to 123.8 per cent of the $25,648,000 of the bonds outstanding.

Probably a good many of us received a mental jolt from the "air map" published in yesterday's TIMES as an advertisement of American Airlines. It gave us a new and startling view of the world as seen from the skies above the North Pole. Places we had thought firmly anchored in our school book atlas took on an entirely new relationship to each other when viewed from this lofty aerie.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Despite the heavy punishment that United States bombers have been dealing to Japanese shipping in the Northern Solomons and New Britain, American pilots agree that the enemy still has plenty of vessels at his bases in that area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers of America announced today that it had given authority for a seven-day week in coal mines in seven Western States to meet a growing demand for coal in that area.
LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Louis R. Chauvenet, champion of Virginia, lost for the first time yesterday in the national amateur tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club. He bowed to Irving Heitner, Philadelphia amateur champion, in a game advanced from the ninth round.
Perhaps many New Yorkers who glance hurriedly through the papers will not be greatly interested in what our trappers do or what the open seasons are on fur-bearing animals in our State.

The long-promised "roll back" of distillers' prices of the Office of Price Administration under the general maximum price regulation is ready for announcement this week it was reported in informed trade circles yesterday. Although wholesalers are likely to bear part of the burden, the distillers in all probability will be required to absorb the major portion of the adjustment intended to relieve the retailers' "squeeze," it was reliably learned.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
This is the week of the Army-Notre Dame game and probably the biggest crowd that will see a football game in the East this season, if not the country over.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A forty-minute battle the night of Oct. 11-12, in which possibly nine Japanese warships were sunk, was described vividly today by Captain Ernest Gregor Small of New Haven, Conn.

A principal defendant in one of the first major bookmaking raids stemming from Mayor La Guardia's order that the Police Department clean up gambling in the city or face a departmental shake-up was ordered discharged from custody yesterday by court direction because of insufficient evidence though the raided headquarters contained a racing wire ticker and a telephone switchboard that was operated by plainclothesmen during the arrest.

OTTAWA, Nov. 2 -- Pilot Officer George Beurling of Verdun, Que., leading Canadian air ace in the present war, with a record of twenty-nine enemy aircraft destroyed, most of them over Malta, suffered a fracture of the right leg in the crash of a large passenger airplane near Gibraltar three days ago while on his way home to Canada on leave.

While it is uncertain how many conventions will be permitted by the Office of Defense Transportation next year, it is certain that New York will get more than its normal share, James Morrison, convention manager of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, declared yesterday at a meeting of the New York chapter of the Hotel Sales Managers Association in the Hotel Savoy-Plaza.

Aside from a few livestock markets in various parts of the country, all securities and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today for the general election. All hanks in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and in twenty-nine other States will remain closed, but in the other States these institutions will observe banking hours as usual.

The box committee for the Red Cross War Fund benefit concert to be given Nov. 30 at Carnegie Hall by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra held its first meeting yesterday at Red Cross headquarters, 315 Lexington Avenue. Mrs. Thomas S. Lamont, chairman of special events for the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, presided.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The refusal of WRUL, a short-wave radio station in Boston, to sign a leasing contract with the government for use of the Office of War Information and the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs evoked sharp comment from those agencies today.
Buoyed up mentally by its 14-13 triumph over Cornell, Columbia's football squad reported to Coach Lou Little at Baker Field yesterday to start work for Saturday's battle with Colgate.
Fresh from its victory over Hobart on Saturday, its first of the campaign, City College will meet the Fort Totten football team today at 2 P.M. in Lewisohn Stadium.

Hanson W. Baldwin and THE NEW YORK TIMES deserve the thanks of the public for the authoritative, considered series of articles now appearing in your columns. They are a welcome relief from the outpourings of amateur strategists whose empty speculations occupy so much time and space over the radio and in newspapers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 2 -- The latest development in the British Eighth Army's westward drive, near encirclement of a sizable number of German troops, has occurred in the northern sector around the coastal road and railway, it was revealed here today.

Doris Doe, the mezzo-soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association, gave a song recital last night in Town Hall which bore witness to her soundness as a singer, her intelligence as an interpretive musician and her curiosity to explore untrodden paths of vocal literature.

A large group of debutantes headed by Miss Emma Converse Davis are aiding in the sale of tickets for the performance of S.N. Behrman's new comedy, "The Pirate," on the night of Nov. 30 at the Martin Beck Theatre for the benefit of the Children's Village.

A German broadcast, recorded yesterday by The United Press in New York, said German and Rumanian troops had captured Alagir in the Caucasus, twenty-five miles northeast of Orjonikidze, blocking the Ossetian military highway over the Caucasus Mountains.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Miss Mary Gesorki told the jury today at the treason trial here that her MacArthur button was torn from her lapel in the home of two of the defendants with the comment, '"Pooh, MacArthur never was any good."

Shipments of the United Aircraft Corporation and other income for the third quarter of 1942 amounted to $131,479,610, a new high for the period, comparing with $81,604,988 in the third quarter of last year, an increase of 61 per cent.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Refugees, returning American citizens and a small group of diplomats and their families made up the passenger list of the Carvalho Araujo, Portuguese vessel which docked at Baltimore today. Nearly 200 were on board.

Godfrey Haggard, British consul general, used the story of St. Martin and the beggar yesterday to thank members of New York's fur industry for their contribution of 1,000 fur-lined vests to British merchant seamen.
The news from Washington and the South Pacific yesterday was encouraging.

The National Coffee Association, 120 Wall Street, through its secretary, W.F. Williamson, took exception yesterday to Mayor La Guardia's recipe for brewing coffee and asserted that "nothing will be accomplished by the publication of official suggestions for ruining the coffee we do have."

You may belong to that school of thought that holds that the manufacture of mincemeat is an activity proper and peculiar to Autumn. In fact, you may be able to remember several successive Autumns when the aroma of stewing apples, the scent of clove and cinnamon, the fragrance of molasses blended in one warm perfume that wafted its way from the kitchen to the crooks and crannies of your house.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A plan for control of scarce materials designed to speed their flow into war production and eliminate waste caused by making too many of one part and not enough of another was described today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

Bernie Moore, coach of the Louisiana State University football forces, may truthfully say it has been a long time between visits. Back in 1935 Moore brought his Bayou Bengals here and enjoyed a field day at the expense of Manhattan College. L.S.U. romped to a 32-0 victory and Moore was a happy man.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Newspapers, columnists and radio commentators have not given the people a true picture of the efficiency of Congress in cutting non-war expenditures, according to Senator McKellar, a majority member of the Appropriations Committee.

We are informed that since the dimout traffic accidents have increased in the shaded areas. Speaking from the experience of driving professionally in New York traffic throughout the nighttime six days a week, I have some advice for those who walk and those who drive.

The police and License Commissioner Paul Moss invaded the theatrical district yesterday in the first step of what may be an official campaign against indecency in the legitimate theatres of dimmed-out Broadway.

The United States, as an ally of Great Britain, "cannot disown responsibility" for what the British do in India, Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian Congress party, said in a special message to America published yesterday.

Approximately 4,000,000 voters in New York State will record at the polls today, between the hours of 6 A.M. and 7 P.M., their choice for Governor and the rest of the State ticket, plus members of Congress, the State Legislature and the judiciary in the smallest turnout of the electorate since 1934.

CHICAGO, Nov 2 (AP) -- Walter Froehling, one of six on trial here on treason charges, made an unscheduled appearance on the witness stand in the middle of the government's case in Federal court today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Nov. 3 -- In a special bulletin released from Berlin shortly after midnight, the German High Command was quoted as acknowledging that the British Eight Army had succeeded in breaking through the German-Italian positions at several points on the Egyptian front, and as saying that Lieut. Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery was reported throwing his tanks into the attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Appointment of a committee composed of nationally known fiber and textile authorities and chemists to serve as a clearing house between the Quartermaster Corps and the synthetic fiber industry on technical matters relating to the utilization of such fibers in Army equipment, was announced today by the War Department.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Representative John W. McCormack quoted Secretary Stimson today as saying that Senator Henry Cabot Lodge was practicing "deception" if he was using for political purposes a letter that the Secretary sent to Mr. Lodge after his return from Libya.

I read with interest Hanson W. Baldwin's article on the Japanese domination of most of the Western Pacific in today's Los Angeles Times. He has seen and understood what the bulk of the United States has no true conception of.

Replying yesterday to Mayor La Guardia's criticism that telephone service was provided for professional gamblers, officials of the New York Telephone Company said they did not desire the type of business mentioned by the Mayor in his broadcast on Sunday.

The latest paragraph in the wretched story of Pierre Laval's attempt to send French workingmen into slavery in Germany comes in the form of a statement by the Vichy Secretary of State for Industrial Production, Jean Bichelonne, that workers in the unoccupied zone cannot be forced to go into enemy territory.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Professional traders who have been inclined to favor the bear side of the grain markets started to even up their position today in advance of tomorrow's election, and found offerings relatively light. Wheat futures on the Board of Trade closed 3/4 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel higher.
Today being election day and in the nature of a holiday for some, there will be afternoon performances for thirteen of the twenty- five current attractions. The list follows:
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 2 -- With campaign oratory ending tonight throughout the State, Governor Charles Edison called on all registered New Jersey voters to go to the polls tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--Women held jobs in almost every classification of labor in 1940, before the feminine rush into war jobs and as replacements for men called into military service, according to figures released today by the Census Bureau.
Directors of the Banque Canadienne Nationale authorized yesterday a quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share placing the stock on a $6 annual basis, compared with the $8 rate distributed previously.

Hanson W. Baldwin in his article published Oct. 26, in agreeing with my statement that the strategic importance of New Guinea was not recognized early enough, draws, I think, conclusions that greater local knowledge would have avoided placing emphasis on Australian politics.

Major Harvey Jablonsky of the West Point coaching staff yesterday painted a picture of the Notre Dame football forces which made them look as tremendous as the Chicago Bears and the Green Bay Packers combined. The picture was drawn for the Football Writers Association at its weekly luncheon meeting at Toots Shor's restaurant.

Trading in cotton futures continued quiet yesterday. The day's best prices for active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were posted ten minutes before the close, when more aggressive price-fixing sent the list to gains of 7 to 8 points.

Mrs. Ethel Epstein, wife of Henry Epstein, the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, was dismissed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as his labor adviser. She charged at once that the Mayor had ousted her as an indirect blow at her husband.

NEWGULF, Texas, Nov. 2 -- The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company received the Army-Navy "E" flag for its accomplishments in the production of war materials in a ceremony this afternoon. More than 4,000 employes of the company and their guests heard its achievements praised by Brig. Gen. Ray L. Avery, Commanding Officer of Edgewood Arsenal, and Commandant of the Chemical War fare School and by Rear Admiral P.W. Foote.

The Boeing Flying Fortress is "probably the best all-around military plane in the world" and adverse criticism of it is "just plain stupidity," Keith Ayling, author and R.A.F. pilot of World War I, told members of Advertising Men's Post 209, American Legion, yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Lexington.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Nov. 1 (Delayed) -- Throughout the last twenty-four hours on all sectors there has been something of a lull, but one that will almost certainly be of short duration. In one part of the front those troops of the British Empire that thus far have borne the brunt of the heaviest fighting were relieved by others who were fresher.

Scoring the largest weekly increase since the peak of Easter shopping last Spring, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed a rise of 22 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WARWICK, R.I., Nov. 2 (AP) -- An Army pilot, first reported rescued from Narragansett Bay after a collision of two single-seated training planes this afternoon in the air near Providence, R.I., still was missing late tonight, the First Fighter Command reported.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Light British and Allied naval craft struck twice yesterday at small German convoys off the French coast. The attacks, one early in the day and the other after sundown, cost the Germans one supply ship sunk, two more possibly sent to the bottom and another damaged and four escort ships damaged, while both enemy convoys were dispersed, the Admiralty announced today.

A sharp loss in automotive linage was chiefly responsible for a decline of 4.1 per cent in advertising linage of eight New York newspapers last month, from the corresponding 1941 period, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Major Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commander of the Panama Department and former Air Corps officer was nominated today by President Roosevelt for promotion to the temporary grade of lieutenant general.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2 -- For the second year in a row American-born golf pros soundly defeated foreign-born opponents today, winning by 7 -- 4 in the annual contest over the Crestmont Course. Tourney play for the Gaffney trophy was inaugurated in 1935 and the American-born pros lost on only two occasions.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Lieutenant the Hon. Peter Wood, second son of Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, today was reported killed in action. He was serving with the Royal Armored Corps in Egypt as a temporary captain. He was 26.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2--Almost at the same time that witnesses before a Senate subcommittee were testifying that the United States Employment Service had virtually broken down as an arm of the national manpower effort, President Roosevelt was called upon today to compel all hiring in the country to be effected through the Federal employment organization and to put the entire Selective Service program under the War Manpower Commission.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Dean Alfange, candidate of the American Labor party for Governor, made two speeches here today in behalf of Ferdinand A. Hoyt, who is running against Mr. Fish in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District.
Doctors have "a heroic part to play in this war of destruction," Archbishop Francis J. Spellman told the medical board and staff of St. Vincent's Hospital at their annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Reports filed with the House of Representatives disclosed today that the Democratic National Committee disbursements from Jan. 1 to Oct. 29 amounted to $503,278.33, while the Republican National Committee spent $116,301.29.

THE Germans, or at least a sizable number of them, think about little except war. They are supposed to be masters of the military art. But, actually, what's good about their war thinking? Having read Max Werner's"The Great Offensive,"* which is an excellent and heartening book, one can ask this seemingly preposterous question in all seriousness.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The rapid action by the Chilean Government in recently rounding up and prosecuting Axis agents has brought great satisfaction in Washington, a reliable source said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Science Service) -- Women are wanted for radio jobs in eight branches of the war services, George W. Bailey, chairman of the radio section, Office of Scientific Research and Development, has reported. The positions are open to women who know enough code and theory to pass the amateur radio operator's examination.

The marines at Tulagi Harbor and Henderson Field have piled up 22,000 tons of Japanese scrap, it was estimated here yesterday by Lieutenant A.J. Tucker, U.S.N.R., who was in command of underwater stabilization aboard the aircraft carrier Wasp when she was sunk in the battle for the Solomon Islands.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Axis troops aggregating thirty to forty divisions have been tied down in Yugoslavia by the "invisible army" of his countrymen, King Peter II said in a speech here today.

HAVANA, Cuba, Nov. 3 -- Uncertainty of the people concerning the amount of the coming sugar crop brought a statement this afternoon from Prime Minister Raymon Zaydin that a commission will leave soon for Washington to negotiate the sale of the harvest.

A retrospective exhibition of work by Peggy Bacon opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, and, beginning today, it may be visited by the public. The exhibition will continue through Nov. 21.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Office of Price Administration today issued a series of price orders instructing the liquor industry how to pass on to the consumer the increased Federal excise tax which went into effect Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Heads of three major farm organizations recommended tonight a four-point manpower program in place of what they called "misdirected efforts" of government agencies to fasten "far-reaching bureaucratic controls and restrictions" on farmers and farm workers.
WMC's recently announced intention to "freeze" dairy, livestock and poultry growers on farms against the vociferous manpower demands of defense industries and the draft is a step long overdue.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 3 -- At his first formal press conference here or abroad since he became Foreign Minister. Dr. T.V. Soong today told over fifty foreign and Chinese newspaper men that the energy exerted by the American people in the war effort was "tremendous" and that the United States was building a "great army, a tough army -- an army that will be unbeatable."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Surgeon General Thomas Parran of the United States Public Health Service said today that he was not in favor of compulsory allocation of physicians at this time. Testifying before a Senate Education and Labor subcommittee which is investigating methods to protect the health of the country by possible enactment of a National Service Act for the medical profession, he said:

BUFFALO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- An official of the Niagara Falls Power Company declared today the company "could not accede at this time" to a Federal Power Commission amendatory order permitting the company to transfer $15,537,943 from its asset accounts to the capital surplus account.

LYNN, Mass., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Police began an intensive search today for two 14-year-old girls who disappeared on separate days about three weeks ago, a search spurred by a third girl's story to police that a man in an automobile accosted here a few days after their disappearance and told her "You're next."

Two more United Nations merchant ships have been torpedoed and sunk by Axis submarines in Western Atlantic waters, it was disclosed by the Navy yesterday. One was a medium-sized British vessel, which was sent to the bottom within sight of a Caribbean island about mid-September, and the other was a small Yugoslav ship, sunk off the north coast of South America late in September.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Thomas E. Dewey was accorded a record Gubernatorial plurality of 70,969 in Westchester County today when he polled 121,432 votes, compared with 50,463 for his Democratic opponent, John J. Bennett Jr.

Another Vincent Astor property has been sold. This time Commander Astor, acting through his realty representatives and Webb Knapp, brokers, has disposed of the seven-story and basement loft building at the northwest corner of Lafayette and Broome Streets, known as 416-22 Broome Street and 200 Lafayette Street, to an investing client of Jerome Tanenbaum.

The police questioned three women and two men all day yesterday in an effort to clear the mystery surrounding the death of Mrs. Louise Almadovar, 24 years old, who lived with her parents at 2090 Arthur Avenue, the Bronx. Mrs. Almadovar was found dead in the northeast section of Central Park Monday morning.

In announcing the cup-a-day coffee ration the OPA stated "one pound each five weeks per person is not a drastic reduction." By contrast, the health and decency budget of the WPA published in 1936 called for half a pound of coffee a week per adult -- about three cups a day.

Advertising campaigns should be planned so as to avoid the mailing of calendars, catalogues, etc., during the month of December, when facilities are taxed to the limit, the U.S. Postoffice Department at Washington warns. Mailings should be made sufficiently in advance of Dec. 1 to permit delivery before that date.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered dismissal of petitions of six local units of the American Newspaper Guild that they be recognized as collective-bargaining units with the International News Service of King Features Syndicate, Inc.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov 4 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

Yesterday's was perhaps a turning point in American elections. Some formerly accepted yardsticks have already been discarded. Weather no longer makes the difference it did when roads were made of mud or dirt and transportation was by horse. More voters are splitting their tickets, at least in this part of the nation.

THE publishing house of Harper celebrated its 125th anniversary by offering an award of $12,500 for non-fiction. The judges, Harry Scherman, president of the Book-of-the-Month Club; J. Donald Adams, editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review, and the Harper editors could not make a choice between two leading contestants. So today not one but two prize-winning books are published, and two authors are sharing the spoils.

The shortage of popular brands of liquor here is due principally to discrimination on the part of distillers who have been overloading other States, Ben Botwinick, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Package Store Association, charged yesterday at a mass meeting of more than 600 package dealers in the Hotel Astor.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- With a larger vote cast today than expected, Rockland County ran true to form and gave Republican candidates generally good-sized majorities. Thomas E. Dewey ran well ahead of the State ticket, receiving 15,345 votes to 8,508 for John J. Bennett Jr., with Dean Alfange polling less than 1,400. Dewey carried the county by 5,037 in 1938.

In a surprising resurgence of voting strength, the Republican party early today appeared likely to win eleven new seats in the Senate and to add upwards of thirty members to the minority ranks in the House of Representatives.

Dorothy Thompson, columnist and radio commentator, was routed last night from her residence at 237 East Forty-eighth Street by a fire which she estimated destroyed one-third of her library of 2,000 books, many of them first editions.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A communique:

The Whitney Museum will offer informal gallery talks in connection with the current exhibition of American provincial paintings, which was arranged as a benefit for the American Field Service. Tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock Carl Carmer, author of "Stars Fell on Alabama" and "Genesee Fever," will discuss the "Hudson River School."

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 3 (AP) -- President Roosevelt momentarily laid aside today the pressing business of a nation at war and voted at the Town Hall where members of his family have appeared on election day for generations.

Unsatisfied by the New York Telephone Company's declaration that it did not want the business of bookmakers, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would seek a Federal law to eliminate out-of-town telephone service on a five-cent call basis.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- For giving enemy agents in Lisbon information regarding convoys between this country and Portugal, in one case endangering the lives of his own shipmates, a 21-year-old English merchant seaman went to the gallows at Wandsworth Prison today.

There were disparate and puzzling factors in the double bill by which the New Opera Company opened its second subscription season last night in the Broadway Theatre. Puzzling, in the first place, was what Dr. Damrosch's operatic comedy, "The Opera Cloak," was about.

Completing his schedule of twelve games in order to get back to Charlotteville, Va., to resume his studies, Louis R. Chauvenet, leader in the amateur championship at the Manhattan Chess Club, wound up last night with a score of 8 1/2 -- 3 1/2.

Studded with stars from the now defunct New York University squad, Fort Totten yesterday scored an impressive 51-to-0 triumph over an undermanned City College football team before 1,000 spectators in Lewisohn Stadium.

Dr. Charles Muzzicato, first Republican ever to represent the New Yorkers of the Eighteenth District in the State Senate, was identified primarily during his 1940-42 term with the Muzzicato Law to protect the five-cent fare.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Governor Prentice Cooper was re-elected for a third two-year term and his Democratic running mates in today's general election, Senator Tom Stewart and Utilities Commissioner Leon Jourolmon Jr., were returned to office without difficulty.

The German radio, apparently with the idea of minimizing the failure to capture Stalingrad and to attain the major objective of destroying the Red Army, broadcast yesterday a 1,300-word summary of the war in Russia to recall German victories of the past, according to The Associated Press.

German troops, attacking continuously in the Caucasus foothills east of Alagir and west of Orjonikidze, broke through strongly fortified and mined positions of the Red Army, the High Command reported yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

MINEOLA, L. I, Nov. 3 -- Complete returns from Nassau County's 312 election districts give Thomas E. Dewey a plurality of 73,669 votes over his Democratic opponent, John J. Bennett Jr. The plurality is the largest ever received in the county by any candidate.
The spotlight of total war was shifting yesterday from the ruins and rubble of Stalingrad to the snow-filled passes on the ramparts of Europe.

While the Army and Navy are clamoring for men, thousands of officers, commissioned and noncommissioned, soldiers, sailors and marines occupy desks in Washington and in various offices over the country. Among them are seasoned officers anxious to get back into the combat lines, "quicksies," sometimes called "ninety-day wonders." whose desk signs advertise every commission from second "looey" to colonel, from ensign to captain, enlisted men and personnel of both Army and Navy, all grades.

Evander Childs' undefeated and untied football team continued on its winning ways by overwhelming Theodore Roosevelt, 27 to 0, and Stuyvesant High scored its first victory of the season in four games by registering a surprising 12-to-6 conquest over De Witt Clinton in the thirty-third meeting of these old rivals in a double-header yesterday at Randalls Island Stadium before a crowd of 9,000.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Wednesday, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Senator Clyde L. Herring, Democrat, conceded early today the Senatorial election to his Republican opponent, Governor George A. Wilson.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Republican challengers swung into stretching leads over the Democratic Governor, Murray D. Van Wagoner, and Senator Prentiss M. Brown on the basis of mounting unofficial returns this morning from out-State Michigan.

Having done a citizen's duty by pulling the levers in the voting booth yesterday and thus saving America or dooming it, if you believed everything you heard, it seemed a not unfruitful way to spend half an hour taking a look at the whole story of this America that we were saving or dooming, as the case might be.
Winifred C. Stanley goes to Congress at the age of 33, with the job of assistant district attorney of Erie County and considerable political experience behind her.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Nov. 3 -- Thomas E. Dewey with the entire Republican State, county and legislative slates swept Suffolk County by a plurality of 28,829, polling 48,005 votes against 19,176 for Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. The sweep reached into virtually all of the 195 election districts of the county, only three in the township of Smithtown going against him.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- Indicating the motion picture industry's shortage of actors, two newcomers were assigned to leading roles in films today and a third male player was recruited from Broadway.
News that married nurses will soon be accepted in the Army Nurse Corps was hailed with a figurative three cheers yesterday by the nursing organizations in the city.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, Nov. 4 (AP) -- An avalanche of Republican ballots gave Governor John W. Bricker a third term early today and Republicans apparently won control of Ohio's Congressional delegation.

LONDON, Nov. 3 (Netherlands News Agency) -- The Japanese have established a bureau in Singapore, with branches throughout Malaya and Sumatra, for exchange of Malayan dollars and Sumatra guilders in what Netherlands East Indies experts here view as part of a drive to replace Dutch and British currency by new Japanese-issued currency.

Early returns yesterday from outside the city gave no indication of a landslide for the hunters. In fact the count at the State controlled public shooting area at Carmel, N.Y., showed a definite decrease in the attendance there during the second week of the upland game season.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Shoe manufacturers attending the conventions of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers' Association and the National Shoe Retailers' Association denied today that the manufacture of women's high heel shoes would be discontinued owing to wartime conditions.

A voter who had inadvertently swung back the lever in a voting booth before he cast his ballot won the right to another chance after he had taken his plea to Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null, hearing election controversies in the Bronx.

Maintaining that women's part so far in the war effort has proved their ability to stand the strain and fatigue of military medical tasks, an editorial in the current issue of the Journal of the Medical Society of the County of New York supports women physicians' efforts to obtain commissions in the Medical Corps of the Army and Navy.

Frank C. Moore, the State Controller-elect of the Republicans, was born in Toronto, Ont., on March 23, 1896, but when he was 11 months old his family moved to Buffalo, N.Y. Subsequently they moved again to Kenmore, N.Y., where Mr. Moore has lived for the last forty years and where his father, J. Fred Moore, is a merchant.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Reorganization of industry branches of the War Production Board to give labor, for the first time, definite responsibility for operations was made public today.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Hamilton Fish, veteran Republican, Representative who was a leading isolationist before our entry into the war, was re-elected tonight to the House for his twelfth term today. He defeated Ferdinand A. Hoyt, who ran on the Democratic and Labor party tickets, by 4,219 votes.
Residential properties were involved in nearly all of the real estate deals reported from near-by sections of New Jersey yesterday.

Nathaniel Lawrence Goldstein, the Attorney General-elect, was born in this city on June 9, 1895, the son of Max and Mollie Marayna Goldstein. He was graduated from New York University in 1915; became a certified public accountant in 1918 and that same year was graduated from New York Law School and was admitted to the bar.

Mayor La Guardia interrupted an all-day meeting with members of the Joint Permanent Defense Board at the Gracie Mansion yesterday long enough to visit Police Headquarters at 1:30 o'clock and assure himself that the election was proceeding without trouble.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Marie Tolstoy, granddaughter of Count Leo Tolstoy, is teaching Cornell students this Fall how to unravel the mysteries of the Russian language. She devotes more than four hours a day to tutoring in elementary and advanced Russian courses.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 3 -- Governor General Hans Frank of Poland has been dismissed by Reichsfuehrer Hitler and replaced by an Elite Guard general whose name has not been revealed, according to Berlin advices received today through private channels.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Nichols of Pleasantdale Farm, West Orange, N.J., entertained with a dinner last night at Hampshire House, taking their guests later to the New Opera Company's opening of its subscription season. In their party were Mrs. Carol Longone, John M. Williams and Giorgio Polacco.

AT AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Oct. 6 (Delayed) -- Japan has again put some of her best pilots into the air war of the South Pacific. This is the belief of American fliers who have tangled with enemy planes during the last week in this area.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Navy Department communique No. 180:

Georgia's unbeaten and untied Bulldogs have advanced to recognition as the nation's outstanding college football force and there doesn't seem to be much their rivals for the honor can do about it in the near future.

Thomas Edmund Dewey rose to national political eminence with unusual rapidity on the foundation of a spectacular but solid career as a young prosecutor who went after malefactors of influence and standing in criminal and political fields.

With the news that Ward Cuff may not be able to play on Sunday, the Giants started preparations yesterday for their game with the Eagles in Philadelphia. The star wingback pulled a tendon in his left thigh when he scored a touch-down against the Steelers last Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Hawaii was the only territory or possession of the United States where voters cast their ballots today for a Representative in Congress.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- Allied ground forces that captured Kokoda, advanced Japanese base for the ill-fated mountain thrust at Port Moresby, are continuing to push the enemy back toward the northern New Guinea coast, the High Command announced today.

President Roosevelt's request to Congress that he be given power to lift, for the period of the war, all customs barriers which impede the war production effort is plain common sense. This is a joint war effort in which men, materials, resources and information must be pooled.

MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- These days before the Soviet Union's twenty-fifth birthday are a period of intensive political activity. Meetings and lectures are taking place everywhere and many questions on the war situation are being asked and answered.
BOSTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Governor Saltonstall won re-election to a third term today by a lopsided majority over Mayor Roger L. Putnom of Springfield, Democrat.

OTTAWA, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press) -- A United Nations victory will make the capitalistic system work better because it will revive it with the new blood of full production, Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General of the United States, predicted tonight.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, declared today that "a near-miracle will be required to maintain farm production next year at 1942 levels."

HARTFORD, Conn., Wednesday, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Governor Robert A. Hurley at 12:20 A.M. today conceded the election to his Republican Gubernatorial rival, Raymond E. Baldwin. At that time Mr. Baldwin, who lost the Governorship to Mr. Hurley two years ago, led the incumbent by 12,000 votes.

IT appears that some twenty-seven football teams representing institutions of varying degrees of higher education remain untied and undefeated in the general scrimmaging this Fall. But not all of them are as strong as Boston College, of course.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 -- Evidence that Baltimore still is far short of its goal for referring 1,500 women a week to war industry appeared tonight in figures released by the United States Employment Service and in statements of personnel officials.

Two arrests were made at polling places in Harlem yesterday. Louise Terry, 41 years old, of 321 West 126th Street, an election inspector in the Fourteenth Election District of the Thirteenth Assembly District, at 327 St. Nicholas Avenue, was arrested at 2:10 P.M. by Patrolman James McGuire of the Clinton Street precinct, on a charge of electioneering in a polling place.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 3 -- Evidence that a Nazi spy ring functions in Chile in close cooperation with the German Embassy, transmitting news to Berlin of the greatest importance to the Nazis and detrimental to defense of this continent, was made public today by the Inter-American Emergency Advisory Committee for Political Defense of the Continent.

Blue Swords and Doublrab, both favorites with a crowd of 22,786 on one of Empire City's biggest days, dashed home first in the stakes at the Yonkers course. Needless to say, both victories were popular with the racegoers, who sent $1,435,962 through the totalizator.

The gala premiere of the New Opera Company's second subscription season last night at the Broadway Theatre was made the occasion for a round of dinner parties given by boxholders and other subscribers and an after-performance supper party given by Mrs. Lytle Hull, president of the company, and Mr. Hull.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 3 -- Early returns giving partial precinct counts from almost every part of the State indicate a Republican landslide. They indicate the almost certain election of Kenneth Wherry over Senator Norris, who ran as an independent, and Foster May, the regular Democratic candidate.
CAIRO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 3 -Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City voted as usual today at the Red Cross hut at 711 Bergen Avenue. Rain was falling and the Mayor commented:
Albert W. Hawkes, Republican, was elected to the United States Senate in New Jersey yesterday, defeating Senator William H. Smathers, Democrat.

Election Day trade in local stores was about equal to or slightly ahead of last year, according to estimates by leading retailers late yesterday afternoon. Buying got off to a slow start because of the rain in the morning, but by afternoon the main floors of many department stores were jammed, with many customers showing interest in Christmas gifts for men in service.
MOSCOW, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
The five-story store and apartment building at 962-64 Boston Road, in the Bronx, has been sold by the 962 Boston Road Corporation to the Macray Realty Corporation, of which Max Hiltzik is president.

Dean Alfange, Gubernatorial candidate of the American Labor party, and Alex Rose, its State secretary, declared last night that the vote polled by the A.L.P. constituted a victory for the "liberal and progressive" forces of New York.

History repeated itself in Times Square last night. Sober soldiers, sailors and civilians eddied northward, southward and flowed across the intersections in the enshadowed canyon under a sharpening November wind just as they had on election night in 1918, when the world was at war.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- One point separated the leaders after six races in the sailing dinghy series today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. The winner was Howard McMichael, who ran up 54 points in the ordeal to 53 for Jack Sutphen's Rum Dum, which was handled by Lieutenant Robert De Coppet.

Mr. Dewey has won a handsome victory and we offer him our prompt congratulations. He has accomplished one of the most remarkable feats in recent political history. At 40 he becomes the first Republican to be elected Governor of New York in more than twenty years.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen, Minnesota's 35-year-old Republican Governor, who is bidding for his third term and his personal choices as his successor and for the United States Senate, held steadily growing leads in early returns from today's general election.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The London Daily Mail quoted Sir Patrick Dollan, former Lord Provost [Mayor]of Glasgow, today as saying that Rudolf Hess had come to Britain as an "official ambassador of the Nazis" with peace terms that in effect would have made Britain "a German colony with Hitler as dictator and Hess as protector."

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 3 (AP) -- American ingenuity has found the answer to almost every problem except how to get a cup of synthetic coffee that tastes like the real McCoy, visitors to an exhibition of "contemporary products for the wartime consumer" at the New Jersey State Museum were convinced today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- Retreating from the blazing ruins of Nalchik, a health resort on the afforested slopes of the North Caucasus, the Red Army was unable to make a stand southeast of the town for the sixth successive day yesterday, according to today's Soviet communique, which reported an enemy advance.

When a wartime cook makes the most of the meat she buys she resorts to recipes that are as old as the silver teapot that once belonged to her grandmother. She may, for instance, assemble a loaf, seasoning it subtly and baking it to a delicious crispness. Or she may prepare a pie, topping it with pastry that is lighter than eider down.
Several apartments in the Park and Fifth Avenue neighborhoods and in the Gramercy Park section were among the late-season rentals reported yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 3 -- A coordinated series of bombing "outrages" in unoccupied France was officially reported late tonight to have occurred during last night and to have been mainly directed against local headquarters of Jacques Doriot's Popular party in Vichy, Clermont-Ferrand and Marseille.

Erasmus Hall High's unbeaten football team, doing all its scoring in the first half, continued its supremacy over its old Brooklyn foe, Manual Training, by handing the Blue and Gold a 21-to-7 defeat before 4,935 spectators at Ebbets Field yesterday. It was the fifth straight this season and the eleventh triumph in a row over a span of two campaigns for the Buff and Blue.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 3 -- It was the Royal Engineers -- more often known simply as sappers -- who made possible nearly every British advance since the beginning of the present battle in Egypt, for it was they who opened gaps in enemy mine fields so infantry and tanks could move forward.

When the typical voter of this city yesterday found himself alone with his conscience before the voting machine he saw a dozen or more positions for him to fill from among about three times as many candidates. How could he possibly be expected to have sufficient knowledge of the individual records of each of these men and their qualifications for the particular offices to which they aspired?

Inspection of yesterday's thirteen holiday matinees indicated that business was below expectations in many instances. Twelve of the twenty-five current Broadway attractions did not wish to compete with the election and therefore took the afternoon off.

Mayor La Guardia told 1,000 bartenders in this city yesterday that as part of his plan to maintain wholesome conditions surrounding the sale of liquor he was asking the State Liquor Authority to forbid package stores to sell half pints.

Every woman in the United States would walk barefoot on hot coals if it would help in any way to win the war. But we should all fight the efforts of do-gooders to put us into shoes we dislike simply because they say we should wear them.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Nov. 3 -- Breaking through for 20 points in the final period, the Valley Stream Central High eleven gained its sixth victory in a row by defeating Lynbrook, 38 -- 13. in the fourteenth annual renewal of the Election Day classic on Freeman's Memorial Field today.
Taking full advantage of the sweeping Republican victory throughout the State, the Republicans increased yesterday their majorities in both houses of the State Legislature.

Accepting the principle that Army and Navy apparel contracts be allocated to manufacturers on a geographical basis, both armed services yesterday awarded substantial orders to shops located in principal clothing markets, according to Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, defeated Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democrat, yesterday by a plurality of about 600,000, ending twenty years of Democratic control of the executive branch of the State government.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The combined shipbuilding program of Britain and the United States exceeds the current rate of losses through enemy action, Lord Leathers, Minister of War Transport, said before the Institute of Transport here today.

Registration for fuel oil and kerosene rationing will be resumed today at 331 public schools throughout the city, Lee S. Buckingham, State OPA director, announced yesterday at his headquarters, 535 Fifth Avenue. Registration will continue daily through Friday from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M.

With a very light vote cast for judiciary and county candidates, Supreme Court Justices Lloyd Church and Bernard Botein, both Democrats running with American Labor party endorsement, were re-elected in the First district on the basis of more than half the votes from Bronx County and with 70 of 1,033 election districts reporting in Manhattan.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- With two statements made by a defendant in the record under protest, defense counsel for six persons who are on trial on treason charges fought today against the admission of a third, contending that it, too, was obtained "under duress."

GREENWICH, Conn., Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- An informal motorcade of three cars, horns honking wildly, heralded early this morning the election of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce as the first woman to represent the State in Congress.

Joe Gordon was named the most valuable player of 1942 in the American League, it was disclosed yesterday. The surprise selection will leave Boston fans in general, and Ted Williams in particular, startled. The Yankee infielder follows Joe DiMaggio as recipient of one of baseball's highest honors, and again Williams is runner-up.

Although the book marts have had in stock for many months now a variety of guides and handbooks prepared on the theme of "how to get ahead in the Army," or Navy, or Coast Guard, what appears to be the definitive work on the subject is on its way.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Senator Charles L. McNary led Congressional candidates tonight in an apparent Republican sweep of Oregon.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Increasing patrol activity by both sides along the India-Burma frontier as the monsoon gradually subsides was reported today in a joint United States-British communique.

Thomas E. Dewey, Governor-elect of the State of New York and Republican successor to Herbert H. Lehman, interpreted his victory at the polls over the candidate of the Democratic party last night as a declaration that the people "want to put every ounce of our energies and of our resources wholly into the national war effort."
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Helped by the more cheerful war news, the stock markets were cheerful again today. Most sections showed increased business, and many small gains were recorded.
Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey, the new first lady of New York State, forsook last night the diffidence which has characterized her attitude toward her husband's recent campaigning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Continued American recognition of the Vichy Government was defended by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today in response to questions at his press conference. The questions were prompted by Wendell L. Willkie's recent criticism of the "continued recognition of the vicious and subservient Vichy Government."

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Texalite, entered by the Siravo Petrucci Stable, found the sloppy going to his liking and ran a front race today to win the Rockingham Park feature on an all-claiming card. A.B. Christopher's Searchlight was second, with I.M. Allen's Poppycock third.

WINNIPEG, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A big sale of Canadian oats for shipment to the United States and overseas destinations today overshadowed wheat trading in the Winnipeg Grain Exchange. It was estimated the sale of oats exceeded 600,000 bushels while inquiries were reported for additional quantities in the neighborhood of 1,700,000 bushels.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Margaret Walker of New Orleans has been chosen by Stephen Vincent Benet as winner of this year's competition for the Yale Series of Younger Poets. She is the first Negro to win the competition since it was begun in 1919 for poets who give promise of contributing literature for the future of America.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Sixteen enlisted members of the United States Army Air Forces received Silver Stars today for heroism during raids on Rabaul, New Britain, in August.

Fort Hamilton's football team, its manpower stripped earlier in the week when eleven men were dispatched elsewhere, was no match for Brooklyn College yesterday on the latter's field in Flatbush. Tallying in every period, the Kingsmen romped to a 39-0 victory, their highest point production of the campaign.

TORONTO, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Moderate gains were posted by the gold and base metal stocks in today's Toronto Exchange market and the Industrial and Western Oil groups held about even with Monday's final prices. Trading was dull throughout most of the session and the aggregate turnover was under 75,000 shares.

It was Clarence Adler's idea to do a series of concerts devoted to Mozart's 'piano concertos. At the first concert at the Town Hall last night three concertos were played. Mr. Adler was the piano soloist, as he will be throughout the series of six concerts in which fourteen concertos will be presented.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Another wave of sabotage and killings is sweeping over Europe as the people of the occupied nations resist the German authorities.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 3 -- The British attack that began in the early hours of yesterday morning developed a few hours later into the major tank clash fought to date in the present battle.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Senator C. Wayland Brooks, Republican pre-war isolationist and critic of the Roosevelt Administration, won reelection today by about 200,000 votes returns late tonight indicated.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 3 -- Eggs were hurled by hostile Nationalists today at General Agustin P. Justo, Argentine President from 1932 to 1938 and a candidate for re-election next year, as he left a luncheon where he had proclaimed his unlimited support of the United Nations cause before members and guests of the British Chamber of Commerce today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Speaking to an overflow audience at a luncheon meeting of the National Shoe Fair here today, Alvin J. Spring, chief of the WPB shoe unit, warned the industry that it must consider future production and merchandising programs in a role of "a service station, not a promotional bazaar," for the duration of the war.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 -- The reformed plater Riverland proved his upset triumph over Alsab last Saturday had been no fluke as he raced through Pimlico's mud to defeat the mighty Whirlaway in the seventeenth Riggs Handicap today before a stunned crowd of 10,000.

The sixteen-room residence with four acres of land formerly owned by Mrs. Dorothy Patterson in Wolver Hollow Road, Upper Brookville, L.I., has been purchased by Peter Grimm, president of the realty firm of Wm. A. White Sons, and former president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

The recapture of Kokoda by Australian troops is the best news that has come from New Guinea since the island became involved in the war. To be sure, Kokoda is only a hamlet in the foothills. But it is a key site. Toward the south it guards the only gap in the Owen Stanley mountains through which Port Moresby can be threatened.

Important savings in man-hours, costs, materials and time and substantial contributions to an advancing military technology have resulted from the application of the General Motors Corporation's "know how" to the war production effort, according to the quarterly report to stockholders by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The Royal Air Force's heavy four-engined Stirling bombers and Spitfire fighters fulfilled separate missions again today in a renewed offensive that struck at the enemy in Germany, France, Belgium and the Netherlands after a three-day respite.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Wednesday, Nov. 4 (AP) -- West Virginia voters, exhibiting the most pronounced Republican trend in twelve years, presented a 24,000 vote lead early today to Chapman Revercomb, who ran for the United States Senate against the veteran Democrat, Governor M.M. Neely.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 3 -- The British Eighth Army has won the first round of a great desert tank battle that developed after a British break-through of Axis lines yesterday morning, front dispatches reported tonight.

The general result of yesterday's elections was a decisive Republican victory, the magnitude and details of which will not be known for some hours. But it is evident that a nation-wide trend has been registered in favor of the opposition party.

Expansion of government bureaus and the leasing of additional space by the Army and Navy are bringing a material improvement in occupancy of buildings in the Wall Street area, according to Schlang Brothers Co., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The War Production Board's Inventory Policy Committee, together with its technical staff, will confer individually with representatives of manufacturers in New York City on Nov. 17 and 18. Conferences will be held at the same time with wholesalers and retailers on the details of the committee's proposed consumers' goods inventory limitation order.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- Earl Warren, Republican Attorney General, appeared late tonight to have been elected Governor, blocking the second term aspirations of Culbert L. Olson, Democrat, who had counted on organized labor to retain him in office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A majority of a War Labor Board mediation panel recommended today rejection of the request by the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation that a clause be inserted in its pending new contract with the C.I.O., providing that any member of the union participating in a strike be fined a dollar a day for each day or part of a day he remains out.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- With all buying interests anxious to obtain slaughter material, cattle prices generally were strong today. Choice steers rose to a new five-year peak at $17.45 a hundred pounds and the bulk of offerings sold at $14 to $17. Although strictly choice types were absent, heifers rose 10 to 15 cents.

The generals are right -- there is not yet enough hate in this war. It does not have to be personal, although it helps, and I for one find that easy when I think of Hitler, Goering, Goebbels, Mussolini, Ciano, Hirohito and their poisonous ilk, all badly in need of liquidation.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- After undergoing a severe slump, due to the exigencies of war, commercial advertising in the British press is now showing a slight upswing, not because many firms have products in sufficient quantity to meet the demand but because, with an eye to the home markets after the war, they wish to retain the public's good-will.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to abandon its line between Woodruff and Starlake, Wis., a distance of 16.8 miles.

Led by Frank T. Dixon 3d, the New York University cross-country team captured the metropolitan intercollegiate championship for the third straight year over the five-mile Van Cortlandt Park course yesterday, taking five of the first eight places.

An appeal to every woman of the country to appoint herself "a salvage sentry for the duration" was voiced yesterday by Mrs. Mortimer H. Hess, national chairman of salvage for the American Women's Voluntary Services and assistant director of salvage for New York City.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The British Government has just drawn up designs and let contracts for the construction of a standardized wartime locomotive which, instead of requiring the twenty-one tons of steelwork that hitherto went into a railroad engine in addition to the other materials, will need only four tons of steel.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- Major Gen. Edward Martin, 64-year-old former commanding officer of the Twenty-eighth Division, was elected Governor of Pennsylvania yesterday by a margin of about 200,000 votes.

Most of the familiar trappings of Election Day in New York City, such as Al Smith's brown derby, mechanical breakdowns of voting machines in a few scattered polling places and early bird candidates craning their necks toward cameras as they stepped into voting booths by the dawn's early light, were in evidence yesterday -- but there were some new touches, too.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The delay in announcing the sinking of an American aircraft carrier last week was explained today in an official statement issued jointly by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox and Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information.

" Army Surgeon," which arrives at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. James Ellison, Jane Wyatt and Kent Taylor head the cast of the RKO war drama, which was directed by A. Edward Sutherland. Walter Reed, James Burke and George Cleveland appear in featured roles.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Nov. 3 (AP) -- The 140 pupils of the Tabernacle township public school looked forward today to an unlimited holiday because their teachers do not have any gasoline to get to school.

With thirty seconds left to play, McKee Vocational High's football team resorted to a sleeper play that went for a touchdown and Les Hammond booted the extra point that spelled a 7-to-6 victory over Curtis at Thompson Stadium, Stapleton, S. I., yesterday.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Nov. 2 (Delayed) -- Elements of the British Eighth Army went forward early this morning to new positions. At the given hour another enormous concentration of fire was laid down on one whole section of the front.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 3 -- A recount of 500 soldiers' ballots was ordered late today by Justice Ralph W.E. Donges of the New Jersey Supreme Court after Mayor Robert E. Brunner challenged the right of two Republican members of the Camden County Board of Elections to count the votes in the absence of two Democratic members.

DAKAR, French West Africa (via Vichy), Nov. 3 (AP) -- Two ships chartered by the government sailed for France today with about 1,000 women and children ordered evacuated by Pierre Boisson, Governor General.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- The Red Army checked the great German drive in the Central Caucasus yesterday, the Soviet midnight communique indicated today, and made slight advances on several other fronts, including Stalingrad, where large-scale fighting flared up again.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, announced today that his office had authorized one extra section of a regular scheduled passenger train now in operation daily between New York and points in Southern Florida over each of two separate routes for five railroads.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, arrived at State Campaign Headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel at 8:30 o'clock last night, smilingly hopeful of the outcome, but hesitant to make any statement until the election returns neared completion.

The twelve-family house on a plot 60 by 100 feet at 64 Bay Thirteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Minnie Kahn to Abraham Beier, attorney, representing the Maab Realty Corporation. Sale was subject to mortgages aggregating $18,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A round robin urging President Roosevelt to appoint Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader, to the Supreme Court was in circulation among members of the Senate today with the prospect that it soon would be signed by a bipartisan majority.

Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York yesterday quoted a Domei Agency dispatch from a naval correspondent as asserting that Japanese naval forces had sunk two United States cruisers and a destroyer and heavily damaged a third cruiser in a surprise attack west of Savo Island in the Solomons on the night of Oct. 11.

The stock market gave yesterday a generous early show of enthusiasm over the Republican gains in the elections, but traders turned cautious after the opening rally and most price additions were turned into losses at the close. Business started at a pace matched only in one other opening hour this year, but the push soon subsided as profit-taking undermined the rally.
