The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- Once again a short lull in the fighting at Stalingrad has been broken by a renewed German onslaught. Since dawn Monday, when the cannonade of hundreds of guns heralded another assault on a big scale and swarms of Stukas dived in attacks on the Volga landing stages and pontoons, the battle has grown.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- An estimated 200 high-salaried film employes went payless today, the motion picture industry's first payday since promulgation of the Byrnes Wage Stabliziation Order on Thursday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 4 -- Trustworthy neutral sources said tonight that plans had been made to attach Marshal Erwin Rommel permanently to Reichsfuehrer Hitler's headquarters, possibly replacing Marshal Wilhelm Keitel, chief of the High Command.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The United States forces on Guadalcanal Island continued their advance against the Japanese westward of our position as recently as the morning of Tuesday (Solomons date), the Navy reported in a communique issued tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Justices of the Supreme Court were asked by the government today to sustain a lower court ruling canceling the citizenship of William Schneiderman, State secretary of the Communist party in California. Charles Fahy, Solicitor General, made the request in a brief filed with the court in answer to another entered by Wendell L. Willkie some time ago.

Spurred by a WPB directive to all branches of the knit underwear industry to submit recommendations for a simplified "victory" line for essential civilian needs by Nov. 19, members of the Underwear Institute held an all-day meeting yesterday at the Builders Club, at which equipment and yarns which could be used to best advantage for men's garments under such a program were discussed.

Interpretation of the latest rulings of the Office of Defense Transportation regarding the wartime operation of trucks and buses and an announcement of what replacement parts may now be obtained will be made tomorrow night at a bus and truck conservation meeting sponsored by the Mack Truck Company in cooperation with the ODT at the Mack Truck branch, 625 West Forty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Merchant-ship production dropped to eighty-one vessels last month, compared with ninety-three in September, the Maritime Commission said today.

Fifty-five dealers and reconditioners of used metal beds, bedsprings and folding cots signed representations yesterday that their legal maximum prices for these products were those set forth in a schedule drawn up by the Office of Price Administration after consultation with the industry.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Nov. 4 -- More than 71 per cent of Suffolk's total vote of the two major parties was cast for Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey in yesterday's general election, thereby bringing Republican pluralities for the head of the slate to an all-time high in the county.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Executives of the baby food packing industry met today with Merritt Green, chief of the canned foods section of the War Production Board, to discuss how the industry could pack the same amount of food and use less steel.

Because of "the totalitarian character of this war, the churches have been far more deeply affected by it than in the First World War," the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, declared yesterday afternoon at a meeting of Protestants interested in organizing a World Council of Churches.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The Republican sweep in Nassau County yesterday gave Thomas E. Dewey about 73 per cent of 152,424 votes cast and a plurality of 73,913 over John J. Bennett. The Republican candidate's vote was 110,456, against 36,543 for Bennett.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Senator McNary of Oregon, minority leader, was all smiles today over the election results.

The blanket use of graduate nurses for minor duties in war industries and the "extravagant" demand for nurses in the Army were scored yesterday as contributors to the nurse shortage throughout the country.

TRENTON, Nov. 4 -- The surprising victory of Albert W. Hawkes in yesterday's balloting, surprising for the size of his plurality, and the gains registered by the Republicans in seats in the Legislature and the House of Representatives was interpreted by some Republican leaders today as an indication of something more significant in New Jersey than dissatisfaction with the Administration's handling of the problems of the battle fronts and the home front.

The gains made by the Republicans in the Senate and the House bring us back to something like the normal conditions of government in Washington. We had moved a long way from those conditions. How far, one comparison will tell:

The Veteran Association of the Seventy-first Regiment, National Guard of the State of New York, founded in 1869 by the late Colonel Henry P. Martin, who commanded the regiment in the Battle of Bull Run on July 21, 1861, will hold its annual reunion and dinner on Nov. 13 at the Hotel Commodore.
Connecticut's open season on quail opens Monday in three counties, New Haven, Middlesex and New London, and the three-a-day bag allowance rules on this species until Nov. 21.

Dean Alfange, defeated candidate for Governor on the American Labor party ticket, in three foreign-language broadcasts made yesterday under the auspices of the Office of War Information, extolled the democratic process in wartime and said Tuesday's election proved that the American people could "fight a total war and vote at the same time."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 4 -- Five Williams College student leaders called upon Eastern colleges today to join in sending petitions to Congress urging the immediate and unqualified passage of the 18-19-year-old draft act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Acting to stabilize prices for fluid milk sold in retail stores in New York City, the Office of Price Administration issued today an order raising the sub-normal March ceiling prices of certain wholesalers and lowering the high March maximums of other wholesalers and retail stores.

The city's drive against allegedly indecent theatrical productions in Broadway playhouses was halted momentarily yesterday when Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney adjourned until tomorrow morning a hearing on "Wine, Women and Song," a burlesque type show at the Ambassador Theatre.
Carlos Martins, Brazilian Ambassador, and Mrs. Martins have come to the St_ Regis from Washington.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Hogs again advanced today as much as 20 cents a hundred pounds, bringing the top back to $14.75. ,,'here it was late last week. Today s report by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Assumption of control of the State government by the Republicans through the election of their entire State ticket and strengthened legislative majorities carries with it complete authority over eighteen State departments as well as a number of special divisions and bureaus set up within these departments, particularly the executive department.

Judge John A. Mullen of General Sessions yesterday held Anibal Almodovar, 21 years old, a Puerto Rican, of 7 East 113th Street, in $50,000 bail as a material witness in the murder of his wife, Louise.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Republican women were jubilant today at their 6 to 1 victory over the Democrats in electing law-makers to Congress.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Retailers in general and the shoe trade in particular were told today by Philip H. Coombs, executive assistant to the director of the retail trade and services division, OPA, that the forthcoming order curtailing services offered by stores would be "partially mandatory, partially permissive," and coupled with the forecast this warning:

Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and William M. Jeffers, administrator of the rubber program, will head the list of speakers at the two-day wartime meeting here of the Association of National Advertisers, Nov. 11 and 12. Sessions will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania but Mr. Nelson will speak at dinner on Nov. 11 at the Hotel Commodore.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Howie Odell, Yale's new young football master-minder, isn't quite sure whether the success that has come the Elis' way for the past two weeks is due to the Bulldogs' good luck or their opponents' bad luck.

Federal Judge Leibell rejected yesterday an agreement to settle for $4,000,000 certain claims of stockholders against principal officers and directors of the General Motors Corporation growing out of management of the company's bonus funds over a period of years.

Blended cloths will become prominent for the coming Spring in the quality end of the coat and suit business, according to the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers. The group pointed out yesterday that acceptance of these fabrics for better merchandise would be helpful in making available greater yardage to that branch of the industry than if only the all-wool materials were considered acceptable.

William Griffin, publisher of The New York Enquirer, testified yesterday that he had tried in August, 1939, to see Adolf Hitler at Berchtesgaden, in the hope of persuading him to cease his persecutions of "Jews, Catholics, Protestants and everybody else."

Flintkote Company directors declared yesterday a common dividend of 35 cents, payable on Dec. 21 to stock of record of Dec. 11. The previous payment was 15 cents on Sept. 15, making 1942 distributions 90 cents, against $1 in 1941.

Despite a weight handicap of about ten pounds and the undeniable resistance to punishment his opponent boasts, Ray Robinson, undefeated Negro welterweight, will enter the ring at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night a prohibitive favorite to defeat rugged Vic Dellicurti, Harlem middleweight, in a ten-round bout.

The overwhelming victory of Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, in Tuesday's election, carrying with it the election of all other Republican candidates for State office and increases in the Republican majorities in both houses of the Legislature, will give the Republicans complete control of the State government on Jan. 1 and will then end twenty years of Democratic control of its executive department.

In response to an appeal by the Board of Education for radios to be used in its war training program, school children in this city collected and presented to the board 3,600 radios and radio parts, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday. The equipment weighed 44,306 pounds.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- Allied troops, driving steadily across Eastern New Guinea, have "swept aside" Japanese resistance three miles west of the town of Oivi and now are within fifty-three miles of the enemy base of Buna on the north coast, it was announced today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- E.C. Eastwood's 5-year-old Challamore today whipped three other horses foaled in Maryland to win the seventh running of the $2,500-added Heiser Handicap at Pimlico. Challamore, with Farril Zufelt aboard, took the lead at the start and held it throughout to cover the six furlongs in 1:12 1-5 over a slow track.

Defeat by Utah voters of the chain store tax in the referendum on election day by a vote of more than two to one was hailed in chain store circles here yesterday as confirming "the definite trend away from this type of legislation."

The preservation of the spiritual achievements of humanity by artists and musicians is essential to the war effort in this country, Bruno Walter, the conductor, said yesterday at a luncheon attended by 600 persons which was given by the Metropolitan Opera Guild at the Waldorf-Astoria.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- For the second consecutive day Colgate placed emphasis on defensive play as Andy Kerr groomed his gridiron charges for their encounter with Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The posthumous award of the Distinguished Service Medal to Major Gen. Herbert A. Dargue, who was killed in an Army plane crash Dec. 12, 1941, near Bishop, Calif., was announced today by the War Department. General Dargue, former assistant to the Chief of the Air Corps, was commanding general of the First Air Force.

The failure of Senator Norris to be re-elected in Nebraska is a grave public loss. His position was unique. In 1936 he was the first candidate by petition to carry a State-wide election. He was also the first Independent to be elected a Senator. This year he was again nominated by petition.
CAIRO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A special Allied communique:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Every Republican candidate for Federal, State and local offices received substantial majorities in the Westchester election that gave Thomas E. Dewey a record gubernatorial plurality of 70,969, complete returns disclosed today.

In no district did the good sense and discrimination of the electorate show more strongly than in Manhattan's Seventeenth Senatorial District. There State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. was re-elected by a good majority in the face of a particularly unfair campaign against him.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Late tonight King George sent General Sir Harold Alexander, Commander in Chief of the British Middle East forces, the following congratulatory message:

While Mr. Dewey was rolling up his plurality on Tuesday, Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, candidate to succeed himself on the Democratic and American Labor tickets, was performing a political miracle. He was running ahead of the combined votes for Governor on those two tickets and threatening the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, Thomas W. Wallace of Schenectady.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Two hundred firemen and Coast Guardsmen were burned today in the explosion of tanks of carbon tetrachloride as they fought a three-alarm fire which destroyed a waterfront warehouse stored with chemicals and baled cotton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- As against an estimate of 50 per cent or 712,000 of East Coast domestic consumers who could convert oil heaters to coal without undue complications, only 57,000 have so far made the conversion, Harold Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, stated today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 4 -- An early reaction in German quarters to the United States elections is indifference although it was admitted in the Wilhelmstrasse that the results of the voting commanded "a certain interest."

An altar made for use in a service camp was presented yesterday by the Boy Scouts of Troop 613, Manhattan, to the Rev. Joseph G. Tennent, assistant chancellor of the Army-Navy diocese, at the Catholic Youth Organization headquarters, 35 East Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- American voters are obliged to wait for a fixed length of time before they can express themselves unmistakably on the records of the party in power and individual candidates for office.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Testimony to link Otto and Kate Wergin directly to the activities of Herbert Haupt, executed Nazi saboteur, was offered today in the government's prosecution of six Chicagoans on charges of treason, two of them being the Wergins.

Furniture dealers must not permit themselves to be scared into canceling factory orders by prospects of strict inventory control, Louis Bing Jr., president of the National Retail Furniture Association, declared here yesterday. Mr. Bing, who is head of the Bing Company, Cleveland, was here to preside at the association's Atlantic seaboard war problems conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania today.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The British people, who have a hard enough time following the simplest mechanics of American elections, were somewhat puzzled and more than a little disturbed today by returns indicating substantial Republican gains in Congress.
Following is editorial comment on Tuesday's election gathered by The Associated Press from many parts of the country:

AT AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Oct. 7 (Delayed) -- American forces in the South Pacific already are getting a foretaste of the difficulties the weather will bring when Summer arrives with its heavy rains and oppressive heat, swarms of mosquitoes and sudden devastating hurricanes.

Since the beginning of the war hundreds of thousands of men in uniform have poured through the streets of New York. Most of them would have difficulty in finding their way around if it were not for the Travelers Aid Society. For thirty-five years this efficient organization has been guiding the feet of visitors to the metropolis and helping them in many other ways.
A brief and generalized German High Command report on operations in Russia said yesterday that heavy fighting continued on both wings of the Caucasus front and at Stalingrad.

Sweeping along with the Dewey landslide, the Republicans increased their majorities in both houses of the State Legislature in Tuesdays elections, picking up an additional Senate seat and winning three more seats in the Assembly, complete returns revealed yesterday.

IT must be getting late. According to those who keep track of such things, ice hockey is just around the corner. The fast-flying stick-swingers are at it even now to the northward and westward. They are heading this way, with stop-over privileges.

The New Opera Company last night presented George Balanchine's "Ballet Imperial" in its first New York performance at the Broadway Theatre as the curtain-raiser to the Mussorgsky opera, "The Fair at Sorochinsk," and thereby indicated, among other things, that it recognizes the historic obligation of opera companies to sponsor the ballet.

WITH THE BRITISH AT SIDI ABD EL RAHMAN, Egypt, Nov. 3 (Delayed) (UP) -- From an observation post within sight of the shining white mosque of Sidi Abd el Rahman this correspondent watched the battle for this strategic town on the road back to Libya.

VICHY, France, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- The leaders of French West Africa and Algeria served notice simultaneously today that those colonies would be defended against any attack, not as a gesture of honor but with unswerving determination that they remain French.

The increase in child delinquency resulting from the war drew the suggestion from Justice Jacob Panken of the Children's Court last night that the city's parks be closed to children in the evenings and the schools thrown open.

College newspapers and magazines all over the country soon will be urging their student readers to buy war bonds and stamps by means of advertisements prepared by a City College class in advertising, which the Treasury Department is using as a laboratory for selling ideas to be used on college campuses.

Furriers were warned yesterday that they must file a schedule of the prices they charged last March for services with their local War Price and Rationing Boards by next Wednesday in a statement issued by H.W. Bissell, OPA New York district price office executive.

It was cheerful collection that was seen yesterday afternoon by a throng of women crowding the second floor showrooms of Stein Blaine, 15 West Fifty-seventh Street. The costumes were a carefully edited selection of the favorites of the ready-to-wear models designed by many of New York's most popular creators of the mode.

The body of a well-dressed woman about 35 years old was found early today in the grounds of the Dutch Reformed Church of Jamaica, Queens, after a policeman had followed a man who ran from the premises and escaped. The woman's throat had been slashed and a knife with a blood-stained blade was discovered near by.
Several leases of large apartments were among the contracts for residential units reported by brokers yesterday in Manhattan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- United Artists will release Walt Disney's next feature-length cartoon under a deal which is now in final stages of negotiations, it was learned today. The Disney-U.A. film will probably be "Victory Through Air Power" by Alexander P. de Seversky, although a United Artists source declined to specify the title of the picture.

Marshal Rommel's army is reported to be in full retreat along the Mediterranean shore. Where he will stop, or whether he can stop, obviously depends on the vigor of the pursuit. But the British success which drove him from his anchorage has already reached impressive proportions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- The cup-a-day coffee ration may be improved as soon as certain corrective steps are achieved under the rationing program which becomes effective Nov. 29, Latin-American coffee experts said tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a merger of the Cumberland County Power and Light Company and the Central Maine Power Company and a plan for refinancing the latter. Both companies, operating in Maine, are subsidiaries of the New England Public Service Company.

Bill Dudley, the Bluefield Bullet, who is being called the rookie of the year in the National Football League, as he paces Pittsburgh each week, added to his lead in the race for individual ground-gaining honors. By reeling off 135 yards against the Giants last Sunday, Dudley, whose 66-yard touchdown dash paved the way to victory in the closing minutes, forged to a 65-yard lead over Merlyn Condit of the Dodgers.

The second step toward the creation of a free school of design in New York City was taken yesterday with the presentation of a petition bearing 300 signatures of members of the American Council of Dress Manufacturers, Inc., to the New York Dress Institute.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America, which eleven years ago won the award of a new issue of $20,000,000 State of New Jersey 3 3/4 per cent highway bonds, in competition with several banking groups, resold yesterday, through competitive bidding, $14,100,000 of these bonds to a banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Rail shares provided the main feature in today's market, the home junior issues putting on 1/4 to 1/2 point further while a number of prior charges were 1/2 higher. In the foreign rails many prior charges fell 2 and the ordinaries 10s on reports issued by Buenos Ayres Great Southern and Buenos Ayres Western companies.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- In a statement admitted as evidence today by the court, Walter Froehling, one of the defendants in the treason trial, related that last June he met Herbert Haupt and that the latter produced a canvas money belt from beneath his clothing saying there was money in it, but without disclosing the amount.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 5 -- The Red Army held its ground in Stalingrad and the Central Caucasus yesterday and scored successes on the Black Sea front and northwest of Stalingrad, a Soviet communique said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Expenditures for new construction in the third quarter of this year reached an all-time high of $4,200,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. For the year as a whole construction activity is expected to top $13,300,000,000, as compared with $11,100,000,000 last year.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 4 (AP) -- A slight playground accident which resulted in the suicides of Robert E. Gibson, 9, and his aunt, Mary Helen Bickley, 10, was told today by Sheriff's deputies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- American wedding rings, German iron crosses and Japanese medals were among thousands of trinkets and other items given by Americans to their government to help the war effort, Treasury officials reported today in asking experts to determine what disposition can best be made of them.

After the cotton futures market had risen to gains up to 15 points at midday yesterday, hedge selling and profit-taking narrowed the increases and left active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange with final net gains of 5 to 7 points following a moderately active session.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Republican gains in Congress in yesterday's elections were regarded today by grain traders as forecasting a stronger farm bloc, and a belief that the Administration would have rougher sledding in passing additional legislation likely to have a depressing effect on agricultural products resulted in somewhat higher prices on the Board of Trade in the early trading today.

Germany is believed to have adequate food supplies for the coming Winter, although the occupied nations of Europe face acute shortages not only of food but of fuel, Jonkheer Henri Van Vredenburch said yesterday when he arrived at La Guardia Field aboard a trans-atlantic Clipper to become counselor of the Netherlands Embassy in Washington.

TRENTON, Nov. 4 -- New Jersey officials are watching with interest an experiment in human relations started at the Marlboro State Mospital for the Insane in Monmouth County where a group of twenty-five conscientious objectors were put to work today as hospital aides.

A requiem mass was celebrated for Arthur (Artie) McGovern, one of the country's outstanding physical instructors, yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena, 411 East Sixty-eighth Street. The Rev. Dominic Dolan, O.P., of St. Vincent Ferrer Church, a friend of Mr. McGovern, was the celebrant.

Gilbert Miller yesterday acknowledged he had acquired "Harriet," the drama based on the life of Harriet Beecher Stowe by Colin Clements and Florence Ryerson, which is being tested at Syracuse University, and Helen Hayes very likely will have the leading role.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Arguments are being advanced in some Congressional circles that incorporation into the draft measure of the amendment by Senator O'Daniel to require that youths of 18 and 19 years who may be drafted should receive a full year of training in the United States might establish a principle which would result in the loss of the war.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- Governor-elect Earl Warren tolled up an increasingly heavy lead over Governor Culbert L. Olson as belated returns from yesterday's election gave Republicans cause for satisfaction in several respects. The same returns dealt organized labor a blow in its attempt to legalize the secondary boycott in the State.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey, enjoying what he called his "first night off in two months," last night attended a performance of "Let's Face It" at the Imperial Theatre and announced that he would leave the city tomorrow to join his wife and children at their country home in Pawling.

All childless women between 20 and 30 years of age are being conscripted in England for work with the Army Territorial Service, Mrs. Neville Lawrence, wife of Captain Neville Lawrence of the Cold-stream Guards, told Barnard students yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Frank E. Gannett, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared today that his party's "great gains in the Senate and House will have a wholesome effect in checking the high-handed methods of the Administration in driving through its pet legislation."

Allocation of workers to civilian production, as contrasted with those to be shifted to war industries under the manpower-distribution program contemplated by the government, will be cut to a minimum, it was revealed yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, special assistant to President Roosevelt.
WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Nov. 3 (Delayed) -- British tanks of the particular unit this correspondent is accompanying have wrought considerable destruction among the foe.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, Canada, Nov. 4 -- Although the new Alaskan highway linking the United States with Alaska has been in use some time, the final link was not completed until the North and South crews met head-on in the spruce forests of the Yukon Territory yesterday.

There is something actually worse than keeping people in the dark about the war, and that is, as many of us feel, to tell the people something about the war, coupled with the warning that or coupled with the reminder that.
There is actually such a thing as a two-hour permanent, which is being accomplished every day in a sunny salon in the East Fifties.
Mayor La Guardia had an unexpected and somewhat embarrassing meeting at City Hall yesterday afternoon with Mrs. Ethel Epstein, whom he dismissed as his labor secretary last Monday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- With tears in his eyes, Senator Norris, his long Congressional career ended yesterday by Nebraska voters, sat in his office on Capitol Hill today and asked:
MOSOOW, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The text of the decree issued Monday by the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. on the formation of an extraordinary State commission on the Axis invaders follows:

The report of the Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday by David Sarnoff, president, shows a net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $5,158,058.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The Select Committee on National Expenditure, a Parliamentary body, said in a white paper issued today that the output per worker in tons of steel in United States shipyards was approximately half the output per man in British yards.

More than two dozen of the East's outstanding jumpers will participate in the Fifty-seventh National Horse Show to be held Saturday afternoon and night at the Riding and Polo Club, Ned King, manager of the event, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Thirty-five merchant ships formerly chartered to or owned by Allied powers have been allocated by Vichy to the Axis, it was said officially here today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Those impersonal judges -- the game statistics -- vote Tulsa as the nation's top football team, both in offense and defense.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Behind the present offensive of the Royal Air Force against railroads in occupied France stands a marked German shortage of railroad equipment and personnel. The Ministry of Economic Warfare announced today the Germans were embarking on a program to build 6,000 to 7,000 locomotives annually to meet the demand.
OTTAWA, Nov. 4 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced today the appointment of Canadian Ministers to Russia, China and Chile and of a High Commissioner to Australia.

Although almost every literary season contains a situation where two forthcoming books will be found to cover either exactly the same subject or the same general ground, there are two this Fall that, while bordering each other, are complementary rather than conflicting.

Having devoted all afternoon Tuesday to practice against Colgate's double-wing style of play, Columbia's football team turned back to sharpening its own attack yesterday in preparation for the Red Raiders' invasion of Baker Field Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Regret that Marian Anderson, Negro contralto, has not "accepted as extended" the invitation of the Daughters of the American Revolution to open the series of war benefit concerts the National Society is arranging to give in Constitution Hall was expressed today in a statement issued by its executive committee, stating its noncompliance with the conditions imposed by Miss Anderson.

Mounting Republican gains -- 43 in the House of Representatives and nine in the Senate on the basis of still incomplete returns -- imperiled the Roosevelt Administration's control of Congress, although the Democratic party remained nominally in the majority in both houses.

The week of racing to be conducted at Belmont Park by Army Emergency Relief, the Navy Relief Society and four other organizations will begin at 1 P.M. today with an eight-race program featured by the John Paul Jones Handicap, for which nine are entered.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- A plot to nationalize public utilities was charged to Rexford G. Tugwell, Governor of Puerto Rico; Secretary Ickes and other government officials by former Judge John J. Burns before the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today.

Herb Kopf looked a little grimly out of the window of the office of the graduate manager at Manhattan College yesterday, shook his head and said he hadn't the slightest idea of what made winning football. The grimness was not due to his job as graduate manager.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A communique:

Consolidated net income of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, after full accrual for taxes under the 1942 Federal tax law, totaled $19,308,862, Edward L. Shea, president, reported yesterday.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The paid fire department of Long Beach, which has been the center of a local controversy, came through its first severe test early this morning.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 4 -- About 7,000 American troops, the largest single contingent yet to be sent, has arrived safely at an Egyptian port, but the simultaneous arrival of 175 United States Army nurses had a greater impact on the country, which is accustomed to the sight of American military men.

The solid bonds of sympathy and determination between Cuba and the United Nations were attested yesterday by General Manuel Benitez of the Cuban Army, who is here at the invitation of J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

In an effort of "self-regulation" to prevent excessive drinking and drinking by youthful members of the armed forces, the State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association decided at a meeting yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker to ask the public to comply with six rules promulgated by the association.

In a contest for third place in the U.S. Federation amateur championship finals, Frank F. Ferryman of the Manhattan Chess Club lost to Sergeant Donald Hallman, United States Marine Corps, a member of the Marshall Chess Club, last night in the ninth round.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Wayne L. Morse, a public member of the War Labor Board, warned Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., today that if it defied the board there would be no alternative except to use "whatever forces of government are necessary to compel compliance."

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Representative Hamilton Fish, pre-Pearl Harbor Republican isolationist from the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, declared today that his re-election was an emphatic repudiation of New Deal war policies by President Roosevelt's home district.

Physical education teachers from New York, New Jersey and Delaware saw demonstrations yesterday afternoon of the physical fitness program, newly devised by the United States Office of Education and the Army and Navy, in the gymnasium and pool of Teachers College, Columbia University.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Coach George Munger revealed before today's practice that Bert Stiff, Pennsylvania's ace fullback, may not be able to play against the Navy Saturday.

Apricot jam with almonds, golden as Indian Summer; damson preserves, purple as royal velvet; quince jelly, pale and translucent and cool as an October morning. These are only a few of the delicious concoctions that now sit in shining rows on the shelves of an uptown store.

Fordham went through a heavy defensive scrimmage on Rose Hill yesterday in preparation for Saturday's encounter with Louisiana State at the Polo Grounds. The scrubs, attired in green jerseys, ran Tiger formations against the varsity for close to an hour, as Coach Earl Walsh instructed his regulars in the task of stopping the high-powered offense of the Southerners.

The Football Dodgers went through a hard workout yesterday in preparing for their National League contest with the pace-setting Bears at Ebbets Field on Sunday. Following the drill, Coach Mike Getto said that intensive practices also are carded for today and tomorrow.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Led into battle by Brig. Gen. A.C. Strickland, American fliers contributed mightily when the desert's fiercest air offensive helped boost the British to major land gains in Egypt yesterday.

The judiciary elections followed a normal course, at once encouraging and disillusioning. Their encouraging feature was that citizens seemed willing to follow the nonpartisan endorsements of the leading Bar Associations and the Citizens Union. It was a safe prediction that no candidate not considered at least "qualified" by these organizations stood much chance.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Seventeen-year-old Edward Haight was sane last Sept. 14 when he kidnapped, tortured and murdered two little Bedford Village girls, Dr. James F. Vavasour testified for the prosecution today as Haight's trial for first degree murder neared an end in Westchester County Court.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 4 -- So effective was the attack by American heavy bombers on Tobruk Harbor Monday night that Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur Tedder, Chief of the Royal Air Force in the Middle East, congratulated Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, Chief of the United States Army Air Forces in the Middle East.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The Axis forces in Egypt were in "full retreat" tonight, with the British Eighth Army in hot pursuit, in which it was aided by Allied air forces, according to a special joint communique reaching London late tonight from Cairo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Lowell Yerex, who operates the Taca and other Latin-American air systems, testified today at a Civil Aeronautics Administration hearing that there was enough business in the Caribbean area for several air lines.

Since Samuel Streppone, 45 years old, served nineteen months as an infantryman in the First World War, he has become the father of ten children, but he thought that was no reason why he should not join three of his sons already in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Further curbs on the use of iron and steel, particularly stainless steel, are imposed by the War Production Board in an effort to conserve the metals for strictly war uses. Some seventy-five products ranging from coffee pots and cutlery to farm machinery and hot-water heaters have been placed on the list of products for which stainless steel cannot be used.
The communication from J. Fearon Brown is so obviously uninformed on the facts and wrong in principle as scarcely to require a reply. However, may I point out the following?

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 79,159,000 barrels, a decrease of 386,000 from the 79,545,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago, these supplies were 82,303,000 barrels.

A woman who was associated with Edward John Kerling, one of the eight saboteurs landed here by Nazi submarines last June, pleaded guilty to charges of misprison of treason yesterday, and thus made herself available as a possible witness against others accused of helping the Nazis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The new C gasoline ration sticker will tell the public just why the motorist received it, whether he gets more than 470 miles of occupational driving a month for being a doctor, nurse, farm worker or essential war worker.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 5 (UP) -- General Ritter von Thoma, head of the German Africa Corps, who was captured in the present British offensive in Egypt, gained prominence while he was a junior commander under Col. Gen. Heinz Guderian, the German tank expert, in the French campaign of 1940.

With 53,248 new registrations yesterday for fuel oil rationing, more than twice the number that signed up on Monday, State Director Lee S. Buckingham of the Office of Price Administration said last night that "too many" house-holders were failing to answer some of the questions on their applications.
Virtually complete returns from New York State show that the final forecast of the Dewey vote by the American Institute of Public Opinion was in error by less than one-half of one per cent.

MIANWALA, Punjab Province, India, Nov. 3 (delayed) -- Deep in the heart of Punjab, where no auto can go and where life is as simple and natural as it is in 90 per cent of India, everything revolves around distrust and antipathy between the Moslems and Hindus.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

A truce has been asked by the Italians in one sector of the blazing Egyptian battlefront to permit them to bury their dead, according to dispatches from Cairo yesterday. The request was addressed to the British command, said a Reuter news agency dispatch received in London.

The Federal War Damage Corporation has informed the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, in reply to a number of questions submitted by them to ascertain if there are any "gaps" in the government agency's coverage of property risks, that losses occasioned by armed forces of the United States actually on patrol duty in the air, at sea, or on land are covered by the Federal insurance policies.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt saw one of the most spectacular sights of Britain this afternoon, when, from one of the hundreds of airdromes that dot the countryside, she watched a dozen Spitfires being put through their paces by youthful officers of an American Eagle squadron.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4 -- Still handicapped by mid-term examinations which kept half the squad from reporting for practice on University Field today, Princeton's varsity tested Dartmouth's tactics for the first time, as a rehearsal for Saturday's game in Palmer Stadium.
The British apparently have won a considerable initial victory in Egypt, but the hardest battles still must be fought.

CAIRO, Egypt, Thursday, Nov. 5 -- Day after day and several times a day light and medium bombers of the Allied air forces drop explosives on enemy defenses and vital centers behind the line in the Western Desert. They lay the first barrage, which prepares the way for artillery and the subsequent surge forward of tanks and infantry.

Seemingly unperturbed by the overwhelming defeat of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., whose nomination for Governor he sponsored, James A. Farley announced yesterday that he would continue as Democratic State Chairman until the expiration of the term for which he was elected -- in April, 1944.
MOSCOW, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A Soviet information bureau communique:

The Treasury Department has announced the limitations imposed on salaries over $25,000 under the regulations promulgated on Oct. 27. As to the Treasury's determination that a salary of $67,200 would be permissible after Jan. 1, 1943, there can be little dispute.

REMEMBERING the uneven quality of some of the books in the "Rivers of America" series, I was not anxious to read "The St. Lawrence"* until I discovered the author was Henry Beston. Then I dropped my guard, for Mr. Beston is one of the few living writers who can match his prose to the mood of nature. "The St. Lawrence" may have been written to order, but you would never know it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Regional organizations would be constituted as an integral part of a new League of Nations, to recognize special needs of nations joined by natural bonds of solidarity and common interests, under a report submitted as a Western Hemisphere pattern for the post-war world to the Governing Board of the Pan-American Union today by the Inter-American Juridical Committee.

HAVANA, Nov. 4 -- The Confederation of Cuban Workers, which controls the island's labor, wants to send skilled workers to the United States as a contribution to the Allied war effort, Juan Arevalo, secretary of the confederation's foreign relations committee, said today.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- Massachusetts voters rejected a birth control amendment which would have permited doctors to give contraceptive advice to married persons as a health measure. Final returns showed a "No" majority of 186,351.
Further restrictions on civilian wool goods will hinge on allocation regulations of the War Production Board at the close of the year, manufacturers said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, has arrived here for a series of conferences with Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board. Mr. Lyttelton and Mr. Nelson are co-members of the Combined Production and Resources Board.

The New York Life Insurance Company has sold to an investor, represented by Abraham K. Kaufman, lawyer, the Cluett Building at 19-23 West Eighteenth Street, running through to 22-28 West Nineteenth Street.

Parents should meet squarely their children's questions about the war, and no attempt should be made to dilute the truth in a mistaken notion of "protection," Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman, Professor of Sociology at the New York School of Social Work declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Witnesses representing unions in the automotive, steel, shipbuilding, metal mining and communications industries told a Senate Labor and Education subcommittee today that the manpower problem was in a critical state because some plants and cities had large pools of idle, skilled labor while many plants overloaded with war contracts had idle machines.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 4 (AP) -- District Attorney Herbert S. Phillips announced today that Federal grand jury indictment had been returned against the United States Sugar Corporation, its personnel manager and three of its camp superintendents charging them with holding Negro sugar cane workers in conditions of peonage.

The thirteenth season of Town Hall Endowment Fund concerts began bravely last night with a program by Marian Anderson. The distinguished American contralto was in rare voice, as if the refreshment and relative leisure of the Summer had brought out new subtleties of texture and color.

MONTVALE, N.J., Nov. 4 -- After six weeks in which their unerring aim with cobblestones had dented and broken dozens of rural free delivery mail boxes, the "mail box boys," as they had come to be known through the northern part of Bergen County and the southern section of Rockland County, across the New York State line, were trapped by the police early this morning.

CAIRO, Egypt., Nov. 4 (AP) -- General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Axis desert forces were officially declared in full and disordered retreat tonight across the sands of western Egypt, pursued relentlessly by British Imperial ground forces and under constant attack from above by American and other Allied airmen.

Mexico, now enjoying a "boom" period, is becoming industrialized and expects to supply the markets of Central America in the future, Daniel Del Rio, vice president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, who has recently returned from a tour of that country, declared yesterday.

Tuffy Leemans was in uniform yesterday for the first time since he was hospitalized by a brain concussion in the game with the Bears on Oct. 18. The veteran mainstay of the New York Football Giants, whose absence from the line-up has been sorely felt, was in his togs as his mates practiced at the Polo Grounds for next Sunday's meeting with the Eagles at Philadelphia, but he had only a light workout.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 4 -- Declaring that a "disgraceful amount of time" is being taken off from urgent war work for purely personal reasons, Dr. Victor G. Heiser said today that such absenteeism in war industry had gone too long unchallenged and that "it is about time that somebody got realistic" about the situation.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin, Republican national chairman and minority floor leader in the House, asserted today that the election results were "cause for profound national gratification."

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- The generally large pluralities received by Republican candidates in Rockland County yesterday are regarded by many political observers as an expression of confidence in the local Republican organization as well as evidence of dissatisfaction with the New Deal.

The report of the Continental Oil Company and its subsidaries for the nine months ended with September, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $9,249,606 after State and Federal income and excess profits taxes and all other charges including $303,943 representing pipeline earnings in excess of 7 per cent of I.C.C. valuations restricted as to distribution and use.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce rested today from the strain of her campaign after informing her defeated opponent, Representative LeRoy D. Downs, Democrat, that she hoped soon "to get together" with him to discuss county problems.

Recently there came to my attention a letter written in September by all the members of Local Board No. 1, Portage, Wis., to an official of the Selective Service System and relating to the effect of the Enlisted Reserve Corps in the colleges.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 4 -- An application for a writ of habeas corpus, argued by Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union, on behalf of eleven Negro witnesses imprisoned in the Hudson County jail since June, was dismissed without prejudice here today by Federal Judge Guy L. Fake on the ground that decisions by the United States Supreme Court required that the petitioners first exhaust their remedy in the State courts.

Thomas W. Wallace, the new Lieutenant Governor elected on the Republican ticket, began his public career in 1926 as Assistant District Attorney of Schenectady County, three years after he began the practice of law in his native city of Schenectady.

The Communist party in this State in the election on Tuesday failed to achieve its major objective of obtaining 50,000 votes for its candidate for Governor, the legal requirement before it can be considered a political party rather than a political group.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- Red Star writer today declared that the Germans face a second Winter of war on the Eastern Front without achievement of the strategic objectives of 1942. Signs of attrition are seen in the fact that the Ger man offensives no longer are general or constant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- No more safety razors are to be produced for civilian use, the War Production Board ruled today, and the manufacture of razor blades for civilian purposes must be reduced 20 per cent. Safety razors are to be made only for the fighting forces, for export and for lend-lease purposes.

Mrs. George Roberts entertained with a tea yesterday afternoon in the lounge of the New York Smith College Club at the Weylin for a group of women serving with her on the arrangements committee for the dinner of the Smith College Clubs of New York and the metropolitan district, to be held on Friday at the Cosmopolitan Club.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Capitol the new attraction will be "Cairo," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production starring Jeanette MacDonald and Robert Young. The supporting cast of the comedy with music includes Ethel Waters, Grant Mitchell, Lionel Atwill, Mona Barrie and Edward Ciannelli .

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 4 -- Of forty-one torpedo planes that the Navy sent against the Japanese fleet at Midway only six returned. The crews of the thirty-five other planes sacrificed their lives in keeping swarms of Zero fighters away from the United States dive-bombers that followed and sank four Japanese carriers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Thirteen Navy men, listed as missing after service in the Philippines with a motor torpedo boat squadron, have been advanced in rating for meritorious conduct, the Navy said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Harry J. Zimmerman of Bayside, Queens, was one of two Air Corps officers and three enlisted men of a crew of nine who were missing in an accident off the Maine coast in which an Army Air Force flying boat capsized on Monday.

Applications for enrollment in the third regular Waves officer candidate class which will enter training on Dec. 29 at Smith College, Northampton, Mass., are now being accepted, it was announced yesterday at the Waves procurement office, 33 Pine Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The War Labor Board has halted mediation procedure in a wage dispute involving J.S. Bache Co., investment bankers, of New York, and a division of the board will conduct a hearing privately on Saturday on the company's challenge of the board's jurisdiction to arbitrate the dispute.

At her annual recital in Carnegie Hall last night Ray Lev's pianism was, as always, technically secure, energetic and alive. Miss Lev's playing often tended to overstatement, resulting from an exuberant temperament not easily held under control.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 4 -- Three more ships appear to have been lost with all hands in the submarine war in the Baltic. There is now an acute lack of tonnage from Danzig and Gdynia, as well as from Hamburg and Rotterdam, and the war-risk insurance compensation for sailors on the Baltic and North Sea routes has again been increased.

An "Autumn Fiesta" was presented last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the British-American Ambulance Corps. The event, set in a colorful decor dominated by American and British flags, Autumn leaves and yellow and rust chrysanthemums, was sponsored by several members of the Real Estate Board of this city.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- Russia expects Germany and her supporters to make good the material damage in Russia, including the cost of the evacuation caused by the occupation. This was made known today when the Soviet Government announced it had appointed a commission to investigate the loss of life and damage to property resulting from the German occupation, to assess the amount of reparation due to Russia and to identify wherever possible the guilty.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Empress Hanover, full sister to Shirley Hanover, winner of the Hambletonian Stake in 1937, brought the top price of $3,500 today as the first wartime auction of the Standard-Bred Horse Sale Company opened.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Except for advances in average prices for certain agricultural commodities, principally livestock, there were few changes in the commodity markets in the last week of October. The Bureau of Labor Statistics index of prices for nearly 900 series in primary markets remained unchanged at 99.7 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales gained 14 per cent during the week ended Oct. 31 over the like week of 1941, compared with a gain of 18 per cent recorded for the previous week.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 5 (AP) -- General Ritter von Thoma, second in command to Nazi Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, was captured in the British desert drive when his armored car was set on fire by British guns in a mine field, an official observer who has just returned from the front disclosed tonight in giving first details of the incident.

The Beech-Nut Packing Company announced an extra dividend of $1 a share for payment Dec. 15 on the common stock and the regular quarterly of $1 payable Jan. 2. Dividend declarations this year total $5, compared with $6.25 declared in 1941.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Enactment of the amendment proposed which would require a full year's training in the United States for all drafted youths of 18 and 19 before they could be sent overseas was criticized by Secretary Stimson today as a threat to tie the hands of the Commander in Chief at the time when such action would do the most harm.

A warning that hundreds of colleges may be forced to close "almost at once," if the 18-19-year draft bill is passed without provision to permit students to complete their academic year was sounded yesterday in a joint statement by nine local educators.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- One of the Pacific Coast's post-season football classics, the East-West game, will return to its original site, San Francisco, on New Year's Day, and military approval of the event encouraged belief today that the Pasadena Rose Bowl contest might receive similar sanction.

Traced to his home by draft board records. James Mallon, 35 years old, a counterman, of 148-19 Eighty-seventh Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, was charged late yesterday with the early morning murder of Mrs. Carol Tuttle, a waitress in the tea room where he worked occasionally.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Advanced Allied patrols made contact with the Japanese yesterday near the New Guinea village of Oivi, fifty miles from the enemy-occupied northeast coast, and continued to drive ahead slowly, said General MacArthur's communique today.

Stockholders of the New York Merchandise Company are being notified that the company has deposited with the Bank of the Manhattan Company the sum of $385, 000 which will be used to purchase the stock at $11 a share. Stockholders are invited to submit tenders to the bank until 3 P.M. on Nov. 25 for the sale of stock to exhaust this sum.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 5 -- An appeal to the women of America to demonstrate their willingness to make any sacrifice required of them to bring about victory was made today by Mrs. Alfred J. Mathebat, national president of the American Legion Auxiliary.

PAWLING, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- A few hours after Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey had telegraphed a request to Town Supervisor Egbert Green that a homecoming scheduled for Mr. Dewey tomorrow night be a quiet affair, two fire companies were called to the Dewey home at Quaker Hill here to extinguish a blaze reported caused by defective fire bricks.

A German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York yesterday asserted that German submarines, harrying "transport fleets" from the Arctic to the Indian Ocean had sunk another twenty-six Allied vessels, totaling 168,000 tons, according to a special High Command communique.

Over-packaging is developing in many types of substitute wartime containers, particularly for government use, while at the same time there is "too much loose thinking" on just how the materials available can be used to achieve proper results, Joel Y. Lund, vice president of the Lambert Pharmacal Company, warned yesterday at the annual meeting of the Packaging Institute at the Hotel New Yorker.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase of $109,542,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, which were at a record high. Note circulation for the system as a whole was at the highest of the year to date, while ratio of reserve for the system and also for the New York bank were at a low for the year.

AT AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Oct. 5 (Delayed) -- Japanese-American hostilities in the South Seas and the Aleutian Islands in the last few months have delineated a pattern for warfare in the Pacific that seems likely to remain consistent for some time to come as the American counter-offensive gains headway and wins back territory from the enemy.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Nov. 4 (Delayed) -- No statistics or detailed information on what the Royal Air Force, the United States Army Air Forces and the Dominion air forces are doing, on how many planes are engaged or on what the targets are, are known up here in the forward area.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Allied ground forces, which on Sept. 29 began hurling back the Japanese from their approach to within thirty-two miles of Port Moresby, are continuing their advance beyond Kokoda toward the northeastern New Guinea coast, General Douglas MacArthur's command said today.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today revealed the seventh consecutive weekly increase in note circulation to the record total of 858,095,000, an increase of 6,920,000.

George M. Cohan, the Yankee Doodle Dandy of the American stage who gave his country its greatest song of the first World War, died yesterday at 5 A.M. in his home overlooking Central Park. His death climaxed more than a year's painful illness and was not unexpected.

The need for spiritual values in the struggle for "political and economic freedoms" was emphasized yesterday at a testimonial luncheon given by the Salvation Army Association of this city in honor of General and Mrs. George L. Carpenter, international leaders of the Salvation Army from London.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 5 -- A delicate barometer of the progress of military operations, semi-official feeling in Rome has dropped late tonight to the nadir of pessimism. Officially, however, some attempt is being made to keep up appearances pending the outcome of what are termed "important Axis High Command decisions."
WITH ATTACKING BRITISH FORCES, in Egypt, Nov. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- The enemy's Alamein line is crumbling tonight.

Deliveries of rayon filament yarn to domestic consumers in October totaled 40,600,000 pounds, compared with 38,400,000 pounds in September and 41,700,000 pounds in October of last year, according to the Rayon Organon published by Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. Rayon staple fiber deliveries aggregated 12,600,000 pounds in October, compared with 12,400,000 pounds the previous month and with 13,200,000 pounds in October, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The White House press conference tomorrow will disclose whether the President, if he decides to comment on Tuesday's elections at all, will follow the lead that was offered to him today by the Vice President. Mr. Wallace, after he had discussed the returns with Mr. Roosevelt, would only say to the reporters that they will find the President "in excellent spirits."
A special commission has been appointed by the Soviet Government to appraise the damage wrought by the Nazi invaders by the "ransacking and destruction'' of cultural and historical monuments.
For a moment yesterday afternoon it looked like a return to the panic days of August, 1941, when women ganged up on hosiery counters and stocked up on stockings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Board of Economic Warfare announced today that the stocks of goods in the possession of dealers which bear trade-marks, trade names, labels, brands or other marks indicating manufacture or processing in Germany, Italy, Japan or any other enemy country have been placed under strict export regulations.

Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, Democratic and American Labor party candidate for re-election, refused yesterday to concede the election of Thomas W. Wallace, his Republican opponent, even though unofficial returns showed that Mr. Wallace had been elected by a plurality of 24,999 with only four normally Republican up-State election districts missing.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Seventeen-year-old Edward Haight was found guilty by a Westchester County court jury tonight of the brutal first degree murders of Margaret Lynch, 7, and her sister, Helen, 8, last Sept. 14. Judge Frank H. Coyne will impose mandatory death sentences on both charges at 10 A.M. next Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Black Hawks, displaying crisp passing form in their first game of the season here, handed the Bruins their third straight National League setback tonight, 5 to 1. A crowd of 13,026 was on hand.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Axis Army in Egypt is "busted and virtually helpless" and is being subjected to the grimmest kind of slaughter in a narrow trap along the Mediterranean coast, a high British official said late today.

The New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads announced yesterday that they were not accepting, until further notice, any Pullman, chair car or coach reservations for trips to be made after Dec. 5. Spokesmen for both railroads said that this was not because of any order from the Office of Defense Transportation but in accordance with "routine" procedure of previous years in connection with the issuance of new time-tables on Dec. 6.

Sprays of orchids from Hawaii and miniature Chusan daisies grown from seeds brought from Shanghai before the Japanese invasion of that part of China, were included in the vast display of chrysanthemums and other Fall flowers shown in a preview last night to members and guests of the Horticultural Society of New York.

Edward S. Jackson Jr. of the Manhattan C.C. gained in the national amateur chess tournament by defeating Sergeant Donald Hallman of the Marine Corps in the tenth round at the Manhattan Club last night.

Patrolman Francis J. Bradley of 30-16 Forty-first Street, Astoria, Queens, was mortally wounded early this morning when he was shot by another patrolman who apparently had mistaken him for a gunman. Bradley was in civilian clothes at the time.

Supreme Court, Justice Carroll G. Walter granted judgment yesterday for $1,200,000, plus interest, against the Manufacturers Trust Company in a suit brought by the Broadway and Fifty-eighth Street Corporation against the bank and others. The suit involved transactions that occurred in 1929.

Sidney Warren, whose letter appeared Oct. 31, errs not in citing the need for and value of extramilitary education but rather in taking the Army to task for not exploiting psychological training, a form of preparation in which, he claims, we have pitifully been outdone by the British.

A quiet but intense internal struggle, the causes and aims of which are as yet only vaguely outlined, is shaking the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, Inc., the trade association of the American aviation manufacturing industry, and eventually may bring about its dissolution, it became known here yesterday.

Governor Lehman offered yesterday to Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey his fullest cooperation in Mr. Dewey's preparations for taking over the State government on Jan. 1, with particular reference to the preparation of the State budget for the next fiscal year.

Although New Deal supporters of President Roosevelt within the Democratic party are hailing the defeat of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, as marking the beginning of the end of James A. Farley's political power, Mr. Farley, it was learned yesterday, has no intention of retiring from politics, either now or after expiration of his term as Democratic State Chairman, which will end in April, 1944.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- After "prolonged discussion" the War Labor Board decided unanimously today that its wage control yardstick would be based on its "Little Steel" principle, whereby wage-earners are entitled to increases up to 15 per cent to cover the rise in living costs between Jan. 1, 1941, and May 1, 1942.

United action against active and potential fascists in this country was urged yesterday afternoon at a meeting in the Hotel Pierre, sponsored by Friends of Democracy, Inc., at which speakers outlined the aims and policy of the organization.

BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY FIELD HEADQUARTERS, in the Egyptian Desert, Nov. 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery, commander of the British Eighth Army, announced this morning that the Eighth Army, battling the Axis, had achieved complete and absolute victory and that the enemy now was in full retreat.

Continuing to exhibit the high spirit in practice that has characterized their drills all week, Columbia's football Lions wound up heavy preparations for Colgate at Baker Field yesterday. After polishing up on their individual assignments, the Lions worked on their main threat -- Paul Governali's passing.

In Great Britain the contraction of civilian production to make room for war production has followed three stages. There was first the curtailment of raw materials and the fixing of quotas which limited the output of civilian goods. Then, beginning in the Spring of 1941, a plan was adopted for concentrating all industries making civilian goods in "nucleus" plants and shutting down all but the nucleus factories.

It is vitally important that the people should know how seriously the O'Daniel amendment to the Selective Service Act would affect the war effort. This amendment requires that youths of 18 and 19 who may be drafted must receive a full year of training in the United States.

Because the exigencies of war have resulted in greater demands upon the postal service than ever before. Postmaster General Frank C. Walker, in a statement made public yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York City, urged that all gifts and cards be mailed twenty to twenty-five days before Christmas, depending on distance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- William M. Jeffers, rubber director, indicated approval tonight of the general adoption of a rule now prevailing in Los Angeles that taxicab operators must make no trips from places of entertainment and must refuse to carry passengers to places of entertainment.

Forty-two seamen were lost with two ships sent to the bottom by enemy submarines off the northern coast of South America last September, the Navy disclosed yesterday. Thirty-one of them were members of the crew of a medium-sized United States merchant vessel and eleven others were crewmen of a medium-sized British ship.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- The Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals won today its Supreme Court fight for the right to harbor animals in a $20,000 shelter on the nineteen-acre Hunterbrook Road site it purchased in Yorktown Heights a year ago.

Creation of a new V-7 special service classification which will enable college graduates with slight physical defects to become ensigns in the Naval Reserve was announced yesterday by the Office of Naval Procurement, 33 Pine Street.

The annual Silver Spoon tea dance and dinner of the Spence Alumnae Society will be given this afternoon and evening at the Stork Club for the benefit of the Spence Adoption Nursery. The event will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the nursery and the placing of the one thousandth child in a foster home.

LAHORE, India, Nov. 4 (Delayed) -- Punjab politics in this provincial capital as in the rural districts is dominated by the communal problem and by the part that Pakistan [separate Moslem and Hindu States] and the Moslem League are going to play in the final settlement of India's status that is shaping up.

Vic Dellicurti will seek to snap the winning streak enjoyed by Ray Robinson when the pair collide in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Robinson, speedy young Negro from mid-Harlem, will be seeking his thirty-eighth consecutive triumph as a professional in his clash with the veteran Dellicurti, who is a native of lower Harlem.

Declaring that many skilled mechanics employed on the city's unified transit system were taking jobs elsewhere because of "inadequate pay and intolerable working conditions" imposed by the Board of Transportation, the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., appealed to the public yesterday to bring pressure on Mayor La Guardia to back the union's demand for a 15 per cent wage rise for the 32,000 employes of the city lines.
VICHY, France, Nov. 5 -- The results of the elections in the United States were discussed in the French press today for the first time.
LONDON, Nov. 5 (Reuter) -- Only one line of retreat remains open to General Field Marshal Rommel's shattered forces -- the coastal road.
A young American conductor Howard Barlow, made his first appearance as guest leader with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with a large measure of success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Postwar modernization of the transportation facilities of the nation under a national transportation agency with emphasis on air travel, regional consolidation of the railroads and Federal financing of railroad improvements as public works were recommended by the National Resources Planning Board in a report sent to Congress today by President Roosevelt.

When Wendell L. Willkie flew back to this country recently from China, he brought with him a package of paintings, drawings and wood-cuts that will show the American people graphically something of the valiant fight the Chinese are making to insure victory for the United Nations.

The test newspaper advertising campaign to be conducted by the Conference of Alcoholic Beverage Industries in seven Southern States on behalf of the industry will begin next week. It is expected that 425 newspapers, both daily and weekly, in every town of 50,000 population or less, will be used in Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, Tennessee, Texas and Florida.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Chief Rabbi J.H. Hertz called on the Jews of all countries today to contribute their share at once toward the defeat on the Russian battlefields of "the murderer and destroyer of peoples and countries, the exterminator of the Jewish people."
Viscount Knollys, Governor of Bermuda, and Lady Knollys, who have been staying at Hampshire House, are leaving today to return to Government House, Bermuda.

In a report of the lectures in London by the keeper of the monuments of Westminster Abbey, Lawrence Tanner, we read that William Caxton "was the first English printer with movable type." May I point out that this claim for the voluminous translator is not always conceded?
The latest bulletin from Maine pertaining to the opening of the deer hunting season says that fewer hunters were out, but that the game was plentiful.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- The German attacks on Stalingrad, which since the beginning of the week had been increasing in frequency and scale, yesterday reached the dimensions of a general offensive. From all sectors of the city's defenses come reports of battles of great violence lasting into the night.
Mayor La Guardia expressed indignation yesterday over a report that city employes had failed to buy their share of war bonds and stamps.

EMPORIUM, Pa., Nov. 5 -- Criticizing "armchair strategists," one of whom he identified as Wendell L. Willkie, and their influence on public opinion in the conduct of the war effort, Lieut. Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, Deputy Chief of Staff of the Army, declared here today that such spokesmen were not acquainted with all the facts pertaining to the war and termed their statements "inaccurate, misleading and superficial."
WITH THE BRITISH, on the Egyptian Front, Nov. 4 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The British Eighth Army is moving down the reeling German Africa Corps in the grimmest fighting ever seen in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The War Labor Board recommended today that the Office of Defense Transportation should manage or arrange for the management of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad for the duration of the war because of "continued defiance" of the board's directive order and an arbitration award by George P. McNear, president.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Dr. Ethel C. Dunham of the Children's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor said today that twenty-nine State Health Departments, as a special wartime service, had indicated that they would finance maternity care for wives of enlisted men in 1943.

MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 6 -- Wave after wave of attacking Germans faltered and died in the rubble heaps of Stalingrad yesterday, and the Red Army also held firm and even gained ground in the battle of the Caucasus, the Russians announced early today.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 5 -- A conference of Japanese diplomats accredited to various European countries will be held in Berlin soon for political and economic consultation, it was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Reflecting the war time tempo of industrial activity, the net profit of thirty-eight corporations in the chemical field jumped $13,000,000 in 1941, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The selective service system is seeking to induce large numbers of men with dependents to shift from nonessential work to war-supporting occupations by offering them the prospect of longer deferment from the draft.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- The war council order which reduced automobile speed to thirty-five miles an hour was amended today to exempt motor vehicles operated by the armed forces and those operated for emergency measures, such as the preservation of life, health or public safety.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Consumers must wait at least until April for any increase in the quantity of coffee to be allowed under the rationing program, according to reports today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Over a forty-mile front that was littered with hundreds of wrecked enemy tanks, planes and gun posts, the British Eighth Army and its allies -- Fighting Frenchmen, Greeks and Poles -- drove relentlessly forward tonight on the heels of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's exhausted columns, which were withdrawing hastily toward Fuka, sixty-two miles westward of El Alamein.

Introducing boys' clothing in its stores for the first time, Crawford Clothes, Inc., manufacturer and retailers of men's clothing, announced yesterday that it would probably enter the boys' wear production field if its stores were successful in its retailing of such apparel, now being purchased in the open market.

While Japan's program in East Asia -- if completed -- calls for a number of far-reaching and radical changes, Japan has attempted to appeal to the people in the occupied areas and to appease her "Quislings" by retaining many of the practices and forms familiar to the Chinese.

Further large purchases of government securities in the open market for account of the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System were shown in the weekly figures as of Wednesday, released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Comment by the Axis propaganda machine on the results of Tuesday's elections in this country has been impressively restrained. There was a day when Dr. Goebbels would have leaped to the microphone at any news of a political reverse for President Roosevelt or his party.

Newsmen from the staffs of both the Associated Press and United Press are the authors of books coming out in the next few days. In the one to be published Monday, "Free Men Are Fighting" (Farrar Rinehart), some of the "living history" written since September, 1939, by AP correspondents all over the world has been fashioned to make "the story of World War II."
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Mike Getto has vetoed the suggestion that he build tank traps near the goal lines and mine the end zones in order to have a surefire way of stopping the Chicago Bears in Ebbets Field on Sunday. He is hopeful that his Dodgers will be able to do it without extra help.
Investment deals involving a loft property and apartment houses comprised realty activity on the West Side yesterday.
How many air raid wardens are there on your block? Figure it out for yourself. Do you have enough wardens to be sure your block is blacked out -- completely?

At the end of a day of questioning, eight jurors, among them two women, had been selected yesterday for the first degree murder trial of Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21 years old, who shot her husband, Alman, in the back last June 23 after they had quarreled.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- If there's one tactical problem to which Army has had the answer of late, stopping the Notre Dame attack would be it.
A penthouse apartment at 425 East Fifty-first Street has been leased by Mrs. Adelaide Brewster, through Culver, Hollyday Co., brokers, and Gordon J. Braislin, Inc., agents.
MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The midnight communique:
LONDON, Friday, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A single German raider blasted a village in Southern England with bombs late last night, killing four persons and injuring several others.
