A British official press broadcast recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES last night quoted a Cairo correspondent as declaring that terrific fire power, tremendous weight of armor and magnificent and overwhelming air support had been the main factors that led to General Montgomery's victory.

Council President Newbold Morris upset the equilibrium of the City Council yesterday when he attempted to censure members of the Democratic majority for interrupting the women members when they had the floor.

In one of the largest commercial leases negotiated recently in the downtown financial district, the Lawyers Trust Company, whose main office long has been at 135 Broadway, has taken the ground floor and basement space in the Trinity Building at 111 Broadway for a long term for its new head office.
The Germans continued to talk about Dakar and Casablanca yesterday, and they reported a large United Nations convoy at Gibraltar as Axis forces in Egypt continued in full retreat.

Anna Neagle and Herbert Wilcox, star and producer-director of the recently released RKO film biography of the late Amy Johnson Mollison, "Wings and the Woman," are returning to England immediately under the auspices of the Canadian Government to make a tropical film drama with the cooperation of the Royal Canadian Air Force, the Canadian Navy and the National Film Board of Canada.

Michael Todd, producer of "Star and Garter," a burlesque-revue now playing at the Music Box, yesterday resigned from the League of New York Theatres, representative organization of producers, owners and operators of Broadway theatres.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Soviet Ambassador Ivan M. Maisky, in a special article in the Soviet War News on the eve of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Russian revolution, said today that, although Russia had suffered great losses, her army was intact and her front firm.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Collections on account of the principal of bonds and defaulted interest coupons should not be treated as income until the full purchase price has been recovered, it was stated today in an opinion prepared by William W. Werntz, chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In the first Japanese comment on the United States elections, the Japan Times and Advertiser declared yesterday that "New Deal wings have been clipped," according to a Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press.

Thirteen kinds of Costa Rican and Colombian hummingbirds, ten of which have never before been seen in captivity, will be exhibited in a "jewel room," the first room of its kind ever built for hummingbird display, in the Bronx Zoo, beginning today, the New York Zoological Society announced yesterday.

John B. Kelly, director of physical fitness in the defense, health and welfare division of the Federal Security Agency, warned yesterday that Americans would have to toughen up physically if they expected to defeat Germany and Japan.

DETROIT, Nov 5 -- The Red Wings buried Steve Buzinski, rookie netminder of the Rangers, under a 12 to 5 defeat in a National Hockey League game tonight before 6,828 spectators. It was the largest total ever scored by a Detroit team. Carl Liscombe bagged three goals and four assists for seven points.

ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Governor Lehman tonight instructed chairmen of county election boards throughout the State to submit detailed statements of the vote for the officers of Lieutenant Governor, Controller and Representative at Large.

The volume of bank transactions in the week ended on Wednesday was only slightly below the preceding week despite the election day holiday, and was moderately above last year's turnover, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- A deal to borrow Ingrid Bergman from David O. Selznik for the lead in "Five Graves to Cairo" has reached final stages of negotiations, Paramount disclosed today. Miss Bergman recently finished an assignment as Maria in "For Whom the Bells Toll" at Paramount on loan-out from Selznik.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 5 -- Especially as it may now affect Tunisia, Vichy is closely following the progress of the British offensive in Egypt, according to private advices received, here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson explained today that the Army discouraged soldiers from answering letters from unknown correspondents because such correspondence afforded an easy method of espionage.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Many Rockland County commuters were late getting home to dinner this evening as the result of a twilight blackout test. From 7 o'clock until 7:30 all lights except those on airplane beacons and those necessary to the operation of trains were extinguished, and all motor vehicular traffic was halted by wardens and policemen in the earliest blackout drill held in the county.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 -- Declaring that the over-all record of Great Britain in this war was "one of the great achievements in military and spiritual history," Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, appealed in a speech here tonight to all Americans to evaluate fully the British war effort and reject as disloyal "a lot of complaining about the British" in this country.

A warning to employers that hundreds of thousands of their essential men in classifications 3-A or 3-B may be placed in 1-A soon, unless applications for deferment are filed with draft boards, was made yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City director of Selective Service.

When the Senate followed the House in extending compulsory service to youths of 18 and 19 it added an amendment sponsored by Mr. O'Daniel: "No person under 20 years of age inducted under this act shall be placed in actual combat duty beyond the territorial boundaries of continental United States until after he has had at least one year's military training following his induction."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Navy revealed in a communique today that more Japanese forces had been landed on the north coast of Guadalcanal east of the American positions on the island.

When the Germans broke through the French lines at Sedan in May, 1940, the tanks that passed the breach were under command of General von Thoma. Sweeping westward, von Thoma roared into Calais, to cut the British off in the pocket of Dunkerque. It was his great moment.

Under the chairmanship of Grover A. Whalen, a committee was formed yesterday to plan events for the observance here of "Thanks to Russia Month," covering the period between Thanksgiving Day and Christmas.

Prizes of war bonds and stamps were awarded yesterday morning lat the Victory Hobby Show in the Sachs Auditorium, 505 Eighth Avenue, held under the sponsorship of the American Hobby Federation, in cooperation with the Army, Navy, Coast Guard, marines, Civilian Defense Volunteer Office and the Treasury Department.

The German High Command said yesterday that its forces had captured a fortified position in Stalingrad and repelled Soviet counter-thrusts, while in the Central Caucasus they were waging "fierce offensive fighting" in the area of Alagir.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The story of how twenty American marines, sick, wounded and tired to their core after weeks of soul-wrenching battle on Guadalcanal, started for temporary peace and safety only to face and win a new struggle for life was related today by Bill Henry of The Los Angeles Times, home from the South Pacific.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The embodiment in the peace treaties of a press charter to insure "a reasonably unfettered exchange of news among the peoples of the world" was suggested by Ralph Deakin, foreign news editor of The Times, London, speaking at the Czechoslovak Institute today on "The Press in Wartime."
CAIRO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A joint R. A. F. and British Middle East Headquarter communique:

The arrest of a man and a woman accused of having sheltered and harbored Edward James Smythe while knowing that he was wanted by the Federal authorities on criminal charges was disclosed yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, local FBI chief.

Sixty years ago a young man from Massachusetts, just out of Law School, came to this town to try his fortune. In the law firm into which he was taken a number of his associates were to become famous. Of these Chief Justice Hughes is perhaps the last survivor.

The Indian Army, which has grown from a force of 177,000 to nearly 1,500,000 men since 1938, is the largest volunteer army in the world and, given the equipment, could hold its own with any force of similar number, particularly the Japanese if they attempt an invasion of India, Major Raj Kumar Shri Rajendrasinhji of the Second Bengal Lancers said yesterday in an interview arranged by the British Press Service, RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

The report of the Timken Roller Bearing Company given yesterday shows a net profit for the first nine months of $4,786,955 after Federal income and excess profits taxes and a deduction of $1,000,000 to cover war and other contingencies.

HONOLULU, Nov. 5 -- Although a number of Hawaii's Japanese will soon be relocated in mainland resettlement centers, there will be no mass evacuation, Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commanding general in the Hawaiian Department, said today in his second press conference held since he took command on Dec. 18, 1941.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Austria, whose capital once was a synonym for gayety, is flooded with German wounded, information received by Yugoslav circles here reported tonight. Virtually all the country's hotels, public buildings, sanatoriums and hospitals have been requisitioned by the German Army, these reports said.

Dogpatch, from the Milky Way Farm of Mrs. Ethel Mars, captured the John Paul Jones Handicap yesterday at Belmont as Victory Week, dedicated to the purpose of swelling racing's war contribution to $2,500,000, most of which already is in the treasury of the Turf Committee of America, began.

Part-time workers and those employed in seasonal trades will welcome the changes in the unemployment insurance plan, as announced in a recent issue of THE TIMES by Milton O. Loysen, executive director, Division of Placement and Unemployment, and by Murray Duberstein, editor in chief of Unemployment Insurance Service.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Axis retreat in Egypt caused a widespread rise in today's stock market. Eastern issues, as was natural, were among the leaders. The oils were the first to go ahead. Anglo-Iranians, Burma, Shell and Anglo-Egyptians all recorded rises.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- It looked tonight as if absentee ballots might determine whether Republicans or Democrats would control the next Congressional delegation from California. The outcome of several other contests, including Lieutenant Governor and Secretary of State, may also hinge on the absent voters.

The Celanese Corporation of America had record earnings of $15,651,238 before taxes in the nine months ended on Sept. 30, according to the interim report of Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president, issued for publication today. This represents an increase of $5,209,877 over the previous high of $10,441,361 earned in the first nine months of 1941.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent what, by comparison with her previous activities since her arrival here, was a "quiet day" today, filling a number of private engagements, at one of which she met the wives of the Cabinet Ministers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Encouraged by Tuesday's election results, Senate and House opponents of some recent labor legislation renewed their efforts today to suspend the Wages and Hours Law "for the duration," and demanded repeal of the National Labor Relations Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- During the week ended Nov. 4 member bank reserve balances decreased $35,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $230,000,000 in money in circulation and $11,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset in part by increases of $102,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $3,000,000 in Treasury currency, and decreases of $11,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks and $88,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The whole Egyptian battlefront is now moving slowly westward. The British Eighth Army is believed to have advanced some twenty-five miles in the last twenty-four hours. General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's forces are retreating behind a shield of anti-tank guns and armored units that is reported to be showing no signs of cracking.

With only today remaining for fuel oil consumers to register for their ration books at 331 public schools in the city, an accelerated registration yesterday brought the total of 160,000 of the estimated 300,000 users of furnace oil or kerosene for heaters.

William Griffin, fighting removal to face conspiracy charges in Washington, was cited by his own attorney yesterday as a man who received a special commission from President Roosevelt and was denounced as a "traitor" by William Power Maloney, special Federal prosecutor who obtained his indictment.

Earl Walsh, Fordham's head coach, has an idea. He's thinking of going to bed and staying there for a ten-day period during which the Rams will have met Louisiana State University (at the Polo Grounds tomorrow) and Boston College (in Boston the following Saturday).

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 5 (AP) -- If space in refrigerators and cash in pocketbooks permit, three Kansas City families will finish a week's test of government-suggested meat rationing menus on Saturday. Already they are saying:

A comprehensive exhibition of paintings by Corot, entitled "The Serene World of Corot," will open at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, on Tuesday afternoon, with a preview at 4 o'clock, for the benefit of the Salvation Army War Fund.

The song-and-dance man is dead. After a year's illness George M. Cohan died yesterday at the age of 64. The mourning will be general across the land. Even Americans who have never seen him have sung his songs with the kind of buoyancy he imparted to all his writing, and they have taken heart from his informal good humor.

AN ADVANCE BASE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Oct. 18 (Delayed) -- At a critical moment in the defense of Guadalcanal three days ago a marine pilot made an unprecedented dive with his patrol plane and released two torpedoes that certainly sank a Japanese transport.

Bidders paid $18,702 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for paintings by old masters, wood carvings, terra cottas and other art property. The name of the owner of the sixty-three lots sold was not disclosed, the collection being described by the galleries as that of "A Czechoslovakian Gentleman."

The abolition of interscholastic and intercollegiate sports and the substitution of intramural athletic activities was recommended yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Director of Selective Service for this city.

A variety of vegetables will greet you on your week-end shopping expedition. To judge by reports received from the Consumer's Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets, supplies are excellent and prices fairly moderate.

Consumers should have a "constructive and informed attitude" toward the new products offered them as part of the government's program to simplify consumer goods and conserve strategic materials, Dr. Faith Williams of the United States Department of Labor declared yesterday.

In the days of thy Pride, 'tis well, On the days of thy Need, to dwell. Today we preach the freedoms. We declare them every man's minimum right. We vow to bring them to all the peoples of the world, whatever the cost. But the sudden emphasis places us on tender gTound.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Five more infantry divisions, completing the organizational operations of the Army ground forces planned for this year, will be activated this month and December, Secretary Stimson said today. He declined to state the total number of divisions which would be in service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Monthly income payments to individuals in September reached the record total of $10,128,000,000 and represented on an annual basis the unprecedented amount of $116,200,000,000, the Department of Commerce announced today.

WINSTON SALEM, N. C., Nov. 5 -- The Army and Navy production award for excellence in the production of knit underwear for both branches of the service was presented to the P.H. Hanes Knitting Company this afternoon with most of the 3,500 employes attending.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 5 -- Military spokesmen in Berlin throughout the day were only grudgingly admitting the German retreat in Egypt. General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel still has many cards up his sleeve, it was said.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- First testimony as to the use intended for the $170,000 sent with the eight Nazi saboteurs captured last Spring was given today in Federal Court, where six relatives and friends of Herbert Haupt, one of the six executed spies, are on trial for treason.

Salesmen in the typewriter industry have been transformed into procurement officers, with official government standing, following failure of the War Production Board to acquire the 600,000 machines needed for the armed forces, it was revealed yesterday.

A few select issues registered yesterday minor gains on the New York Stock Exchange, but the major portion of the market drifted in a listless manner. Trading was reduced to the smallest volume of the week as transfers aggregated only 598,360 shares, against 771,830 on Wednesday.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Nov. 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- United States bombers and attack-bombers smashed at Japanese-occupied Lae at such low altitude today they could see the enemy running madly for cover in the New Guinea north coast port.

The United Gas Improvement Company reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income applicable to its capital stocks of $4,027,178, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 13 cents a common share. This compares with $4,541,436, or 15 cents a common share, in the third quarter of 1941.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace said today that because of the light vote it was a "miracle" that the Republicans did not capture the House in Tuesday's elections.

If the report of the National Resources Planning Board is followed, another era of railroad consolidations likely will follow the cessation of hostilities. After the World War, an effort was made to combine railroads, but it met no success.

Declaring that a growing shortage of manpower was threatening seriously the emergency shipbuilding program, Lynn H. Korndorff, president of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, warned yesterday that longer hours of labor would be necessary to attain war production objectives.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Confidence that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's forces would be crushed was voiced today in authoritative British quarters. It was asserted that General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander was not only rocking back the enemy on their heels, but at the same time was inflicting deliberate punishment of the kind the Nazis had meted out to helpless civilians in France, Belgium and the Netherlands.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Establishment of a new military and naval decoration, the Legion of Merit, was announced today by Secretary Stimson.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 5 -- The Brazilian Coordinator of Prices and Production, Joao Alberto Lins Barros, issued an order today stopping at once export of freshly killed meats and warning packers that he would set quotas regulating all meat exports next year.

The first attraction to reopen the doors of the Windsor, recently taken over by Samuel Schwartz and Harry Oshrin, will be "The Willow and I." It will make its bow there on Thursday night, Dec. 10, after polishing engagements in Wilmington (Nov. 20) and Philadelphia (Nov. 23).

Declaring that the price squeeze on retailers under the General Maximum Price Regulation had yet to be felt by many merchants because it has been "concealed" by increased sales volume, David R. Craig, president of the American Retail Federation, said yesterday that stores were piling up an increasing mark-down liability.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 5 -- It is estimated that at least 50,000 persons turned out this evening in the "March for Democracy," which moved along the central streets and filled the Plaza Constitution, where President Juan Antonio Rios, Cabinet members and other prominent officials watched from the government palace.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Confidence that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's forces would be crushed was voiced today in authoritative British quarters. It was asserted that General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander was not only rocking back the enemy on their heels, but at the same time was inflicting deliberate punishment of the kind the Nazis had meted out to helpless civilians in France, Belgium and the Netherlands.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Establishment of a new military and naval decoration, the Legion of Merit, was announced today by Secretary Stimson.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 5 -- The Brazilian Coordinator of Prices and Production, Joao Alberto Lins Barros, issued an order today stopping at once export of freshly killed meats and warning packers that he would set quotas regulating all meat exports next year.

The first attraction to reopen the doors of the Windsor, recently taken over by Samuel Schwartz and Harry Oshrin, will be "The Willow and I." It will make its bow there on Thursday night, Dec. 10, after polishing engagements in Wilmington (Nov. 20) and Philadelphia (Nov. 23).

Major league hockey, or the 1942-43 equivalent thereof, will open its local season tonight at Madison Square Garden, with the Rangers skating against the Canadiens of Montreal. Frank Boucher's skaters already have had two outings on foreign ice and have suffered decisive setbacks, but the Blueshirts' pilot is confident that his team will play better hockey before a home gallery.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- Industrial employment in the Northeast as measured by the index maintained by the New England Council, reached a new high during September, it was announced here today. While the incrase over the August figure was about 4 per cent -- compared with September of last year, it showed an increase of 28.4 per cent.

The fact that 68,000 football fans visited Franklin Field in Philadelphia last Saturday to see the Army-Penn game apparently proves that it was a mistake to transfer the Army-Navy classic, originally slated for Philadelphia, to the inaccessible confines of Annapolis.

The Bank of France admitted in papers filed in Supreme Court yesterday that it had turned over more than $200,000,000 in Belgian gold to the German Reichsbank, but said this was done under "compulsion'' of an order of the "Head of the French State" -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain.

New financing here this week was limited to a small issue of municipal bonds, the smallest weekly total in five weeks. Amounting to $1,037,000, it compared with $9,500,000 for a railroad flotation last week and with $31,095,000 for five State and municipal issues in this week a year ago.

CAIRO, Egypt, Saturday, Nov. 7 -- Pursuing British mobile forces, equipped with big American-made General Sherman tanks, have overtaken some of the remnants of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps in the Matruh region of Western Egypt "and are steadily chopping them to pieces," front dispatches said early today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Lieutenant Dorothy C. Stratton of the Women's Naval Reserves has been ordered to duty in the office of Vice Admiral R. R. Waesche, commandant of the Coast Guard. It is understood that if the bill creating a women's reserve in the Coast Guard Reserve becomes a law, Lieutenant Stratton will be appointed director of the women's reserve.

Games on three other New York fronts combine with the traditional Army-Notre Dame clash at the Yankee Stadium today to provide the city with its most active Saturday of the season. At the Polo Grounds Fordham plays host to Louisiana State University, Columbia will meet Colgate at Baker Field and at Lewisohn Stadium City College will encounter Moravian.

At its recent meeting in Philadelphia the Association of American Colleges, representing virtually every institution of higher learning in the country, rejected in emphatic fashion the suggestion that higher education plead for special considerations under the revised Selective Service Law.

The annual stag dinner of the National Horse Show Association was held last night in the Perroquet suite of the Waldorf-Astoria in honor of the judges for the two-session show that will be held today at the Riding and Polo Club, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street.

With a preview this afternoon, the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, will open the first installment of its 116th annual -- an exhibition filling most of the galleries and including work in the graphic media and architecture.

ATLANTA, Nov. 6 -- Perturbed by increasing race tension in the South, fifty or more representative Southern Negroes met recently at Durham, N.C., in an unannounced session at which was drawn the first draft of a statement on race relations in this area.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Madagascar, the former Vichy-controlled strategic island lying athwart the United Nations' sea routes to Ceylon, India and Russia via Iran, is now safely in British hands, the War Office announced tonight.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 7 -- The text of the order of the day issued by Premier Stalin today follows:

Dr. Leona Baumgartner, director of the Bureau of Child Hygiene of the New York Department of Health, will be married today to Nathaniel Elias of New York and Martha's Vineyard, chemical engineer now acting as consultant to the Bureau of Economic Warfare in Washington.

The Berlin radio, in a cautiously worded broadcast last night, indicated the possibility that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, Nazi commander on the Egyptian desert front, might have been captured in the sweeping advance of the British Eighth Army.

The first Regulation V loans for the aircraft industry to reach the capital market here are a $60,000,000 loan for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, to be managed by the Bankers Trust Company, and a $30,000,000 loan for the Vega Aircraft Corporation, to be managed by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

Price variations on the New York Cotton Exchange were confined yesterday to an 11-point range in a comparatively small market. Hedging operations and New Orleans selling near the close dropped active futures to final net losses of 5 to 7 points.

Bette Davis will become editor and commentator of the "Women at War" section of the forthcoming Warner Brothers newsreel, which is to be launched after the first of the year. According to the company, Miss Davis thus will be the first established feminine star to become a newsreel editor and commentator. . . .
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- After a particularly good week business in today's stock markets was less active. The tone continued firm on further good news from Egypt and Madagascar.

The American Chicle Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of $1 on the common stock. These payments will bring 1942 dividends to $5, against $6 paid in 1941.

Retail trade here this week did not show the heavy percentage gains noted in the preceding week. Department store volume was estimated as ranging from 7 to 10 per cent over the 1941 week, compared with a gain of 19 per cent the week before.

SOMEWHERE IN THE FREE MOUNTAINS OF YUGOSLAVIA -- I welcome the idea of presenting to the American public the struggle which our Chetniks and other patriots are waging for national independence and human freedom.

Today's events: Sergei Rachmaninoff, piano, Carnegie Mall, 2:30 P.M.; Elisabeth Schumann, soprano, Town Hall, 3; Jazz concert, Town Hall, 5:30; Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Witold Malcuzynski, piano, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; Student-faculty recital, Metropolitan Music School, 5.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- The crew of a Flying Fortress which sank a Japanese warship Oct. 31 disagreed today with the language of the official communique -- they sank a battleship, they said, not a heavy cruiser.

The fate of Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21-year-old mother of four small children, who is charged with the first-degree murder of her 23-year-old husband, Alman, will rest with a jury, which was completed yesterday in Bronx County Court, of eight men and four women.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

George and Elias Eliopoulos, brothers who were said to claim ownership of the bauxite (aluminum ore) and gold mines of Greece, were arraigned in Federal court yesterday under an indictment accusing them of conspiracy to supply narcotics to Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and other racketeers.

PAWLING, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey stepped off the 6:45 train at the New York Central Railroad here tonight into a milling, cheering crowd of his neighbors who made his home-coming a thing of first importance.

Because of his failure to carry out an order for the arrest of Joseph (Socks) Lanza, Fulton Fish Market racketeer, on election day, Acting Captain Harry Hanley was reduced to the rank of lieutenant yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine, who assigned him to duty in uniform at the Tenth Division in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Following is the text of the new wage stabilization policy issued today by the War Labor Board:
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- The grain markets continued today to show a decidedly firm undertone, with wheat, corn and oats advancing to new high prices on the current movement. Brokers reported a broader outside interest and commission house buying orders were a factor in helping along the advance.

Laymen in many city churches will conduct services and preach sermons tomorrow, participating in a national observance of the day as Laymen's Sunday, so designated by the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World. The day's services will be devoted to prayers for peace and for those fighting to protect the United Nations.

AT CAPTURED EL DABA, Egypt, Nov. 6 -- Thousands of British tanks and trucks poured through this city yesterday in a swift pursuit of fleeing Axis troops who are believed to be beyond Matruh, sixty-two miles from here.

Charles Weidman officially opened the season's activities of the Humphrey-Weidman company at its Studio Theatre, 108 West Sixteenth Street, last night. Doris Humphrey was not on the bill, which consisted of numbers which had been presented on the tour recently completed by Mr. Weidman and eight members of the group.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The War Production Board has decided to reduce materially the production of machine tools. The reason is given that a survey has revealed that factories all over the country are standing idle an average of fourteen hours a day.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 6 -- Displaying entirely too much power for its time-honored foe, Poly Prep's football team crushed St. Paul's School, 33 to 0, today, in the thirty-fifth meeting between the schools in a rivalry dating back to 1892.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission strengthened today its regulations for qualification of accountants certifying financial statements filed with the commission, adopting an amendment designed to give further protection to stockholders, creditors and the public.

The National War Fund Campaign of the American Red Cross, to be opened in March, may set a goal as high as $125,000,000, it was announced yesterday by Guy Emerson, vice chairman of the National War Fund Campaign. He addressed a meeting of 2,000 delegates attending the Regional Conference of Southern New York, North Atlantic Area, held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the auspices of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross.

Roland Gundry, one of the most generously gifted of the younger violinists now before the public, was heard in a recital last night in Town Hall. When, as a boy of 15, this talented performer made his local debut in 1937 in the same auditorium, he at once attracted attention by his superior attainments.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- There will be no telegraphic greetings this Christmas except to soldiers and sailors in expeditionary forces. Nor will any congratulatory, anniversary or holiday dispatches be permitted to go over the wires after Dec. 15 except to the men overseas.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 7 -- Premier Joseph Stalin assured the Russians yesterday that the Allies would open a second front against Germany in Europe and declared confidently that the Allies would win the war.

ARMY vs. Notre Dame -- That's being pitched right "in medias res." This might be a good time to sound off with something like "Army virumque cano," but apparently "age cannot wither nor custom stale" the infinite variety of the Notre Dame attack. With a salute to the Kaydets, the secretary will cast the customary vote for Notre Dame.

Thursday's edition of THE TIMES contained an excellent summary of the arguments advanced in Washington against Senator O'Daniel's amendment requiring men of 18 and 19 to receive a full year of training before being assigned to combat duty abroad. May I make two additional arguments?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Japanese forces made strong counter-attacks on Wednesday night (Solomons time) against the American troops who have pushed westward on Guadalcanal Island but were repulsed, the Navy reported today. In smashing the counter-attacks the Americans inflicted heavy losses on the enemy.

Town Hall, now opening its forty-ninth season, has added to its war program a special series of United Nations Days. Ambassadors and representatives of each of the thirty nations will present the issues of the war as their countries see them. These United Nations Days ought to be useful in helping to develop that international point of view which alone can assure a lasting peace.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- With General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's armies fleeing westward in North Africa, the Axis showed signs today of a wary watch for new Allied ventures that might imperil its position in the whole Mediterranean theatre.

The Studebaker Corporation will return to newspaper advertising this month, with a campaign on car conservation scheduled to appear in about 1,000 newspapers. Copy will tell automobile owners how the new driving regulations will affect their cars and urge them to give special attention to maintenance requirements.
In the sports pages of THE TIMES on Tuesday there was a short story from Calcutta headed "U.S. Starts Baseball in India."

Arthur Eilenberg's letter, appearing in THE TIMES last Saturday, in which he comments upon a recent article by Lincoln A. Werden regarding canine sagacity and understanding of his master, prompts me to write you.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- The British Eighth Army's victory in Africa has made a deep impression here, where news of any heavy blow struck successfully against the Germans is assured a warm welcome.

Marian Anderson has accepted the invitation of the Daughters of the American Revolution to sing for Army Emergency Relief at Constitution Hall in Washington. She is willing to sing even if the D. A. R. refuses to regard her appearance in the hall as a precedent for her future performances there.

Howard J. Casselbohn, 40 years old, of 31-50 Thirty-second Street, Astoria, Queens, an employe of the United States Appraisers Stores at 20 Varick Street, and Irving Spitz, 32, of 413 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, a customs broker's agent, waived examination yesterday in Felony Court and were released in $1,000 bail eacn to await grand jury action.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Mayor Frank Hague declared today that the action of the State Board of Tax Appeals in granting a reduction of $7,676,895 in the assessment of Jersey City property of the Central Railroad of New Jersey would be "fought to the bitter end and through all the courts."

Defeating G. Gustafson of the Hawthorne Chess Club of Brooklyn in vigorous style after 43 moves in the eleventh round, Sergeant Donald Hallman of the United States Marine Corps made his hold on third place more secure in the national amateur championship finals at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Amid some discussion in Congress over suspending or repealing the forty-hour-week laws, President Roosevelt declared today that examples in England and Germany proved that a working week of longer than forty-eight hours was not conducive to greater production.

Factory management problems in war industries will be analyzed Tuesday and Wednesday when production executives will meet at the New Yorker Hotel under the auspices of the production division of the American Management Association.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, and Emanuel Tsouderos, Greek Premier, sent cordial greetings to Russia today on the eve of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Soviet Union.

The second front naturally figured largely in the speech which Premier Stalin delivered yesterday, on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Russian revolution. Russia is facing three million Axis troops. He evidently estimates that the British in North Africa have had less than two hundred thousand to deal with.

TRENTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- New Jersey turkey growers are seeking a higher price ceiling on their birds, and some leaders in the industry say that if they do not get it they will hold their turkeys off the Thanksgiving market.

The fifty-seventh National Horse Show will be held this afternoon and evening at the Riding and Polo Club on West Sixty-sixth Street. With competition limited to one day and transferred to a small arena from spacious Madison Square Garden, the event nevertheless retains some of its old-time flavor.

The six four-family buildings at 29-11, 29-15, 29-19, 29-23, 29-25 and 29-29 200th Street, Bayside, L.I., have been sold to the Floral Park Apartment, Inc., through James C. McCormick, Inc., brokers. The total assessed valuation is $54,000 and the sale was for cash above a first mortgage of $40,320.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Ever on the alert against attempts by the Axis to ship reinforcements across the Mediterranean to North Africa, particularly at the moment when General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's columns are fleeing before the advancing British Eighth Army, British submarines operating in the Mediterranean area have destroyed six enemy vessels and damaged two large supply ships, the Admiralty announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Summarizing previous criticism of the alleged failure of the present manpower organizations properly to allocate men essential for industry and the armed forces, Henry J. Kaiser proposed today a plan for creation of a new over-all Federal Manpower Committee to handle the problem on a voluntary basis.

Supplementing his report to the American people on his recently completed tour of the global war fronts, Wendell L. Willkie last night told an audience invited to The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, that "the really disturbing thing about such emphasis on an Anglo-American world" is that it represents -- even though in a modified form -- what is essentially the old white man's burden philosophy."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- United States and British officials learned the taste and economic importance of dehydrated food at a luncheon given by the War Production Board today in an executive dining room of the Social Security Building. Lee Marshall, food consultant to Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, was host.
The Crown Cork and Seal Company and its wholly owned domestic subsidiaries showed a net profit of $1,351,043 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, according to the report issued yesterday.

Victor Dellicurti, East Harlem middleweight, who is 1-A in the draft, is going into the Army without having achieved his goal, an interruption to the amazing winning streak of the unbeaten Ray Robinson, superb Harlem boxer.

The increasing cruelty and harshness of the German military machine toward civilians is a clear-cut indication of its growing weakness, Dr. Emilio Mira, chief psychiatrist of the Republican army of Spain during the Spanish civil war, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Contending that net operating income of the railroads before making provision for taxes has increased as much as 2,700 per cent in the first eight months of this year, compared with the corresponding period last year, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a formal protest against proposed higher rail rates for crude oil and petroleum products shipped to the East.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Eight women and one man were burned to death and ten other persons, eight of them women, injured today in an explosion and fire at the Rochester Fireworks Company plant in the town of Perinton, Sheriff Albert Skinner said.

Dozens of specifications in an indictment accusing him and twenty-seven other persons of conspiring to injure military morale were denied yesterday by William Griffin, publisher of The New York Enquirer. The publisher testified at a hearing before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on government efforts to remove him to Washington, where the indictment is pending.

This year's chemical industry medal, awarded annually for "valuable application of chemical research to industry," was presented last night to Dr. Harrison E. Howe of Washington, technical journal editor and also chairman of the advisory committee to the chemical section of the War Production Board.

Plans of hotel men for a unified and effective compaign against future attempts by dry forces to impose prohibition on the country began assuming more definite proportions yesterday with the announcement that Robert K. Christenberry, vice president and manager of the Hotel Astor and chairman of the hotel men's group known as the "temperance committee," is setting up a national committee of forty-nine members.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- The complete text of Joseph Stalin's address to the Moscow Soviet today follows:
Dwellings, loft buildings and tenement houses were among the properties in the downtown area sold yesterday by banks.

Some time ago the city signed a contract with the Public Health Research Institute, a non-profit organization, to carry on fundamental research in medicine, biology, nutrition, and public health in general. David Heyman, president of the board of directors, now issues a report of importance because it deals with the initial activities of the first public health research institution of any municipality in the world.

The steel industry shattered all records for output by nearly 200,000 tons last month by producing 7,584,864 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, at 100.1 per cent of its rated capacity, which is the largest in its history, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

Although New York is football's focal point for the day, the rest of the country has any number of attractive offerings today. Yet not one among unbeaten titans or championship pretenders commands complete attention.

Consternation spread yesterday among the operators of bingo games in Queens following a raid on one of them by Police Captain Louis Goldberg, commanding the Newtown precinct, who has made a reputation as an uncompromising foe of gambling in all forms.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Roosevelt asserted today that all the United Nations are very much heartened by what appears to be a British victory of major importance in North Africa and are revamping their 1943 war production programs to key them more closely to strategic considerations.

Transportation to Germany of rare strategic metals sorely needed for making ersatz products was charged in Federal indictments, yesterday to Dr. Ferdinand A. Kertess, his Chemical Marketing Company, Inc., and others. United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa said the group had succeeded in getting $14,000 worth of palladium, iridium and rhodium into Nazi hands.

It now seems to be generally agreed that the Treasury will not move for Congressional consideration of its proposed new $6,000,000,000 tax program until some time next March, when there has been opportunity to observe the effects of the new $9,000,000,000 program recently enacted.

Army and Notre Dame play a game of football at the Yankee Stadium today and it's the old, old story of a glittering spectacle of marching soldiery, a full house studded with notables, and Notre Dame holding most of the aces as 1-to-3 favorite.

With no backward glances at the tradition of Capo di Monte, Meissen, Sevres and other national porcelains of the Continent, a new, all-American spirit shone forth from the collection of Castleton china presented at a press preview yesterday in B. Altman's china department.
I was amazed to read in THE TIMES on Wednesday that Joe Gordon has been voted the most valuable player in the American League for the 1942 season.

Eight, including the record-breaking Good Morning, have been named for the $10,000 Florence Nightingale Purse to be run today at Belmont as one of the richest events of racing's Victory Week for the men in service. Another $10,000 added test, in which it is hoped Alsab and other stars will compete, is scheduled for Armistice Day.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 6 -- The conflict between the extremists and relatively moderate members of Norwegian Premier Vidkun Quisling's party resulted in a sensational incident a few days ago when Party Minister Fuglesang and three other Quislingist leaders were beaten up in their homes by Hirdmen [Storm Troopers], it was reliably learned here tonight.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- Moscow has prepared for tomorrow's celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Soviet regime by lining the streets with decorations that include huge canvases of Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels, Nikolai Lenin and Joseph Stalin.

Vice President Wallace made one of the most cheering statements about this country that have been uttered in a long time. At least it should be cheering to the country, though Mr. Wallace himself was apparently not altogether happy about it.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A War Office communique:

The friendly exchange of telegrams in which Governor Lehman offered, and Governor-elect Dewey accepted, the help of the present State administration in preparing the 1943-44 budget was pleasant to read about. It proved what every informed person knows, that there is a wide area of administration into which partisan issues do not, or should not, enter.

With the possibility that steel virtually will be eliminated for civilian packaging purposes in 1943, progress in the development of paper and glass substitutes, together with proper packing of dehydrated foods and adequate bottle and other closures, was surveyed yesterday at the open forum of the annual meeting of the Packaging Institute at the Hotel New Yorker.
Mr. and Mrs. Roland L. Redmond, who formerly made their home at 760 Park Avenue, are now at 340 Park Avenue.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Errol Flynn was held today for Superior Court trial on three counts of statutory rape, after a preliminary hearing which ended with a photographer's testimony that the actor had told him he was being made the victim of an attempted shakedown.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 6 -- The first tropical storm of the late Summer season moved over the mountains of Central Cuba tonight, diminishing in intensity and sparing Havana and the Florida coast a possibly destructive blow.
CAIRO, Saturday, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- More than 40,000 Italian troops, trapped by the lightning Allied advance, are throwing aside their arms and surrendering, front dispatches reported today.

It will serve little purpose to correct the faulty Senate amendment to the new Draft bill. The urgent necessity is to reject the bill. Congress will then be able to set to work without delay to bring our separate war programs into some sort of working balance.

The stock market's high levels of the year, set in January, were duplicated yesterday under a broad buying movement which raised values fractions to 2 points. More definite confirmation of the sweeping British victory over the Axis forces in North Africa encouraged hesitant traders to re-enter the market in force.

It was inevitable that the extent of the Republican victories in the elections should put new courage into the forces in Congress that have been seeking revision of the labor laws. But already there are signs that many Congressmen in their zeal to correct faults in existing legislation will go to at least equally dangerous extremes.

A drive for $194,500 to finance the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, which is straining its resources to train thousands of young girls for the emergency tasks of war while maintaining its regular recreational programs for them, was launched yesterday by the Girl Scout War Emergency Fund at the home of the campaign's general chairman, Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, 5 East Eightieth Street.

HAVANA, Cuba, Nov. 6 -- The Belen College Observatory issued a bulletin tonight saying that a hurricane, which swept down from the Bahamas onto the North Central Coast of Cuba, is centered in the Moron area of Camaguey Province, and added that winds there have reached a velocity of eighty-five miles an hour.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Slashing relentlessly ahead, the British Eighth Army in Egypt was reported tonight to be pressing back Marshal Rommel's rearguards at a point about 110 miles west of El Alamein, where the British offensive was launched only two weeks ago today.

As a result of financial difficulties caused by a widespread loss in student enrollment, fifty colleges in the United States have closed their doors in the last few months, while scores of others are on the verge of bankruptcy, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- Twenty-one students passed the September licensing examination, the State Board of Dental Examiners said today. They will soon receive their licenses to practice dentistry. The list follows:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 6 -- The British armored forces used new American-made medium tanks called General Shermans against the enemy rear guard yesterday. From now on the battle is likely to be one of tactics and movement, like the previous desert campaigns and in this battle American tanks will play a major role.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A new listing of war materials and substitutes was issued today by the Conservation Division of the War Production Board and it revealed that magnesium, aluminum and copper are the three most critical metals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- The halting of production on Metro- Goldwyn-Mayer's "Gentle Annie," because of the illness of director W.S. Van Dyke, has caused the transfer of Robert Taylor from the film to the lead in "Bataan Patrol," a story similar in character to "The Lost Patrol" of the First World War.

A kind of short-change racket in which American soldiers and other service men were the victims was attributed yesterday to William F. Ellison, operator of the United States Package Service Company, 665 Fifth Avenue. He was accused of mail fraud and held in bail of $2,500 by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter.

Floral displays arranged by amateurs so that they might be readily adapted to home use were added yesterday to the Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York and the Chrysanthemum Society of America at the Museum of Natural History on Central Park West at Seventy-seventh Street. The exhibition was thronged.

This democratic country is shortly going to have "the most rigidly controlled economy it ever submitted to, because we can't win the war without it," Ernest Kanzler, director general for operations of the War Production Board, predicted yesterday at the annual convention of the American Trade Association Executives at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Agreements guaranteeing that officials of the War Production Board who are charged with the responsibility of channeling as much work as possible to small plants will receive full cooperation from the Army, the Navy, the Maritime Commission and other governmental procurement agencies were announced today by Lou E. Holland, deputy chairman of WPB for smaller war plants and chairman of the board of the Federally sponsored Smaller War Plants Corporation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A bumper crop of nuts this year prompted the New Jersey College of Agriculture at Rutgers University today to advise housewives to get more nuts into their families' diets.

The Berlin radio said yesterday that it had been announced officially in Tokyo that Japan would impose "reprisals against British prisoners of war in Japanese hands in case the British Government does not change its attitude" toward German captives, according to The Associated Press.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 6 -- Six young women from New York City were among the new arrivals today at Wangum Lodge in Rocky Hill, eight miles south of this city, where the National Youth Administration has established the first woman's labor placement center in the country.

Scoring two touchdowns in the fourth quarter, the Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School football team gained its first triumph of the season by turning back Power Memorial, 19 to 12, at Fordham Field yesterday.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 6 -- The placing of the New Zealand Army under American leadership was designed to cut the risk of divided command and to insure the best use of resources in the Pacific war zone, Lieut. Gen. Edward Puttick, Army commander, said today.
LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- British bombers were over Italy again last night, it was announced today.

Landlords insulating dwellings so as to get a larger fuel oil ration may place part of the cost upon tenants in the form of "a supplement to rent," if the Office of Price Administration approves, Joel Dean, director of the OPA fuel rationing division, said yesterday.

The case against the Broadway production "Wine, Women and Song," whose producers are charged with presenting an "obscene, indecent and immoral" performance, was sent to Special Sessions Court yesterday by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney, after a hearing in West Side Court.

Will an expert target archer develop into a good deer hunter? An academic question, said the young man who plans to go a-hunting with bow and arrow when the legal season opens in Westchester County Nov. 15.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Russians announced today that repeated assaults by large forces of German tanks, infantry and planes on a factory district in Stalingrad had been thrown back with heavy losses for the Germans and indicated that they were holding firm in the Nalchik and Tuapse areas of the Caucasus.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. B.L. Montgomery, commanding the victorious British Eighth Army in Egypt, revealed today an episode rare in military history -- a recapitulation by opposing commanders of a battle that was still raging between their respective forces.

Tavern keepers here are planning to protest the ruling of the Office of Price Administration that prices of unmixed drinks may not be advanced an even nickel, but only the exact amount of the new tax increases, it was learned yesterday.

WITH A BRITISH ARMORED DIVISION, Within the Gap in the German Lines, Egypt, Oct. 26 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- On this, the third day of battle, American-built General Sherman tanks already have been tested against the best German anti-tank guns and proved they are the best fighting tanks this war yet has produced, in the opinion of their British crews.

Manufacturers' associations in the coat and suit industry have been requested to continue through 1943 the present system of self-imposed taxation for raising funds for refugee relief, it was announced yesterday by John G. Frumkes, chairman of the board of trustees of the Refugee Relief Fund.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Nov. 6 -- The story of those bridge hands picked up yesterday afternoon at the meeting of the Millville Bridge Club in the home of Mrs. H. Garrett Miller has been checked and rechecked, and every one vows that it's true.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull in messages tonight to President Mikhail Kalinin and Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff congratulated Russia on her heroic military resistance and gave assurances that the steadily growing power of the United States was dedicated to "complete victory."

The Academy of Music has sold the two-family, ten-room house at 199A Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, to Mrs. Cecelia Berger through the M.J. Abrams Company. It is assessed for $10,000. The seller was represented by Mudge, Stern, Williams Tucker.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Even as the final surrender of Madagascar was announced here tonight, Japanese sources in Ankara, Turkey, disclosed that Reichsfuehrer Hitler, in desperation over his crumbling position in North Africa, had appealed to the Japanese to make a naval attack on Madagascar or South Africa as an Axis diversion.

Far in front during most of the race, LeRoy Schwarzkopf romped home an easy winner in the fourth heptagonal cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday and led Yale to its initial team victory in this annual intercollegiate fixture.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Governor Lehman today urged rejection by Congress of a proposed amendment to legislation on drafting 18 and 19-year-olds which would require a full year's training in this country before they could be sent overseas.

Elimination of rayon when used chiefly for decorative or non-utility purposes, and of both the lowest and highest priced numbers from individual lines, will be proposed by the knit underwear industry when its voluntary program of wartime style simplification is submitted this month to the WPB, it was learned here yesterday.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Nov. 6 -- The Treasury Department notified Cedar Rapids Friday that it will be the first city in the United States to receive "T," the Treasury flag for outstanding achievement in the war bond sales campaign.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Paced by Al Pontus, Villanova's football team defeated Iowa State, 32 to 7, before 11,000 at Shibe Park tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Setting out from London today on a strenuous trip during which she will visit various areas of Britain and see for herself all the things she has heard about the country's war effort, Mrs. Roosevelt witnessed a realistic air raid workout by the women of the much-bombed city of Bristol.

LYNN, Mass., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, Yankees' southpaw, entered the line-up of Uncle Sam's war workers today at the River Works plant of the General Electric Company. It was expected he would make his home in Lynn -- the home town of Bump Hadley, his former team-mate -- for the duration.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 6 -- Today, exactly a month after the official opening of the United States Naval Training School at Smith College, 900 white-capped Waves gathered in John M. Greene Hall to see 115 of their number receive their orders and commissions as officers of the Women's Reserve.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Negotiations for the transfer to Brazil of sufficient dehydrating equipment to make possible the production of dehydrated coffee to meet a part of the needs of the armed forces have been concluded by the Board of Economic Warfare, it was learned tonight.

Leading a group of speakers who urged city acquisition of the Staten Island Edison Company plant at a cost not exceeding $14,500,000, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick told the City Council finance committee yesterday that the purchase was a bargain that should be snapped up without delay.
Unique in these days of shifts in man and woman power is Miss Mac E. Daly, first woman to hold titular executive rank in the New York Cotton Exchange
CAIRO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A joint communique of the R.A.E. and the British Middle East Command:

AT A BRITISH PORT, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A great mass of Canadian fighting forces, including the first detachment of the Canadian Women's Army Corps, called Cwacs, and the largest Royal Canadian Air Force contingent yet to arrive, has reached this port after a safe crossing of the Atlantic.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- The movement started a month ago to enlist "the girls behind the men behind the guns" in the women ordnance workers (the Wows) is apparently growing in popularity among the women defense workers of the nation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Roosevelt said today he assumed that the new Congress, with forty-four more Republicans in the House and nine more in the Senate, would be as much in favor of winning this war as the Chief Executive himself.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- In its report of lend-lease purchases for the week ended on Oct. 31, the Agricultural Marketing Administration announced today its first buying of dehydrated pork. It purchased 109,688 pounds. Other unusual items in the list were purchases of 2,350,000 pounds of frozen lamb and 450,000 pounds of frozen mutton.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 6 (AP) -- With two fliers already rated as aces, thirteen more American pilots in the China air task force are on their way to the goal of bagging at last five Japanese planes, according to a listing today in the C.B.I. Round-Up, United States Army newspaper.
AT AN ADVANCED POSITION with the British Eighth Army, Nov. 5 (delayed) -- We are now on ground that until a few days ago was in enemy hands.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 6 -- For the first time the Nazi-inspired Stockholm newspaper Dagsposten today brings up an Allied victory as a possibility that must be reckoned with. One must not completely lose sight of the circumstance, writes the Dagsposten, that an Anglo-American victory is not at all an impossibility.

Taking advantage of what they believe will be a severe blow for German morale, our official broadcasters today contrasted the plight of the German forces in North Africa with the promise made by Marshal Erwin Rommel in Berlin on Oct. 4, when he said: "We stand 100 kilometers from Alexandria and Cairo; the gateway to Egypt is in our hands; you may depend upon it that we shall hold what we have."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Andrew J. Higgins said today that he was leaving tonight for New Orleans with new contracts which he indicated would involve a total of more than $212,000,000 of government expenditures. He said that he had arranged with the Army Air Forces to build 1,200 cargo planes.

The Original Don Cossack Chorus, under Serge Jaroff, its dynamic conductor, opened its thirteenth season of concerts in this country with an elaborate program given last night in Carnegie Hall. The talented ensemble of male singers delivered the varied unaccompanied offerings on the list with its accustomed accuracy of pitch, vivid color contrasts and remarkable control of dynamics.

A symposium of foreign writers will be held on the eve of Armistice Day under the auspices of the Writers War Board, the P.E.N. Club and the School of Education of New York University. The meeting will be held at 8:30 P.M. in the Main Auditorium, Education Building of N.Y.U., 35 East Fourth Street.
DETROIT, Nov. 6 -- An estimated 7,000 workers left their jobs, in a half dozen Detroit war plants tonight, suspending operations in the production of vitally needed weapons.

While I agree with Frederick Weidman's view that it would have been unfair to consider Mel Ott's managerial qualities in selecting the most valuable National League player of 1942, I cannot subscribe to his belief that the committee was justified in picking Mort Cooper for the honor.

MADRID, Spain, Nov. 6 -- An Allied naval force headed by the British battleship Rodney, the British aircraft carrier Argus and six cruisers steamed out of Gibraltar at dawn today and headed into the Mediterranean, dispatches from La Linea, Spain, said tonight.

VICHY, France, Nov. 6 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, appealed tonight in a broadcast to the French of both zones and of the colonies to join efforts in mutual aid "as another Winter approaches while our resources are running out and our sufferings increase."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A bitter battle is raging between Allied and Japanese ground troops at Oivi, in New Guinea, some fifty miles south of the Japanese coastal base of Buna, the High Command said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox asked today that the public do not indulge in "optimism" over the situation regarding German submarines in the Atlantic because of recent reports of relatively light losses of United Nations shipping.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 6 -- After the long-standing German ridicule of British General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander for his ability to make "glorious retreats," first from Dunkerque, then from Burma, it is now the turn of Berlin propagandists to try to "glorify" General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's retreat, which, according to various official spokesmen, is no retreat at all, but a "new masterpiece."

Christians and Jews have announced plans for celebrating Armistice Day with special services and prayers. Numerous announcements will be made at religious services today and tomorrow, where such programs are being held in local communities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Steel plate shipments last month totaled 1,101,382 net tons, the second largest volume on record, H.G. Batcheller, chief of the War Production Board's iron and steel branch announced today. About 80 per cent of the tonnage was for direct use by the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission, with the remainder being for export and essential civilian needs.

Satisfactory adjustment of the complaint of excessive noise lodged by fifty Maspeth residents against Merrill Brothers, Inc., of 56-02 Arnold Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, manufacturers of drop forgings for the Navy, was recorded by Magistrate D. Joseph de Andrea in the case following the report to him in the Flushing Court yesterday by a joint committee.

The unheard-of is about to happen. You are going to read a little treatise on what to do with left-over bread that has absolutely no mention of bread puddings or apple brown betty or poultry stuffings! The fact is, we sympathize whole-heartedly with the frugal housekeeper who receives these same trite suggestions every time she asks, "What shall I do with the stale loaf in my bread box?"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Treasury amended its $25,000 salary regulations today to except salaries payable under 1942 contracts, and the War Labor Board, which deals with wages and salaries under $5,000, announced what Chairman William H. Davis called "a pretty damn tough" policy of freezing these at Sept. 15 levels.
VICHY, France, Nov. 6 -- French resistance ceased in Madagascar yesterday, according to an agency message here tonight. Negotiations were opened with a view to concluding an armistice.

Thousands of workers from Manhattan's garment center packing Fortieth Street from Seventh to Eighth Avenue yesterday gave Wendell L. Willkie a tremendous ovation as he called for the opening of a second front and suggested that Washington's "armchair generals" copy the example of British Lieut. Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery and "spend their time on a battlefield instead of a platform."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Treasury amended its $25,000 salary regulations today to except salaries payable under 1942 contracts, and the War Labor Board, which deals with wages and salaries under $5,000, announced what Chairman William H. Davis called "a pretty damn tough" policy of freezing these at Sept. 15 levels.
VICHY, France, Nov. 6 -- French resistance ceased in Madagascar yesterday, according to an agency message here tonight. Negotiations were opened with a view to concluding an armistice.

Thousands of workers from Manhattan's garment center packing Fortieth Street from Seventh to Eighth Avenue yesterday gave Wendell L. Willkie a tremendous ovation as he called for the opening of a second front and suggested that Washington's "armchair generals" copy the example of British Lieut. Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery and "spend their time on a battlefield instead of a platform."

Army was still looking for its first victory over Notre Dame since 1931 and its first score since 1938 as the twenty-ninth meeting between them ended with the heavily favored Fighting Irish the winners by 13 -- 0 at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

THERE has never been a collection or "treasury" of the work of one of America's great philosophers and psychologists published before, so the Vanguard Press edition of "As William James Said" ($2.75) takes on an importance not commonly accorded to a book of fragmentary excerpts.

Marine experts, ship designers, builders and others associated with the construction of the country's record naval and merchant ship program, will attend the fiftieth annual technical session of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers this week.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 7 -- That a free Finland and a free Norway were indispensable for the survival of Sweden as a free State in an independent north of Europe was the main theme of a speech today by the Swedish Foreign Minister, Christian E. Guenther, before Parliament.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Some superb running back of punts by Ray Wolfe, coupled with aggressive alertness, gave Dartmouth a 19-7 victory over Princeton in their twenty-third football game today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 7 -- When President Ramon S. Castillo some time ago returned to Buenos Aires after a tour of the interior he was greeted at the station by crowds that shouted, "Viva el Presidente de la Paz" -- ("Long Live the President of Peace").

American elections seem often to puzzle the people of other nations. Last week's voting may have had this effect upon our friends as well as upon our enemies. We think our friends may take much comfort and our enemies none at all from what happened. Even those of us here who backed a defeated candidate or two may be glad that the party in opposition wasn't afraid to express itself.

THE National Academy of Design opens to the public today the first of a scheduled series of exhibitions. There was a preview yesterday afternoon. The present attraction consists of prints, drawings and architecture. Ample facilities in the new Academy building make it possible to cover the specified ground thoroughly and comfortably.
That forgotten stepchild of interior decorating, the common radiator, assumes a new and respected significance because of fuel shortages.

ALBANY, Nov. 7 -- A recheck of election figures for Bronx County revealed today that Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti had gained 8,000 votes there. The discovery was made during an un-official recheck in the Executive Chambers. Some districts were missing.

A MIDLANDS TOWN, Nov. 7 -- In field and factory today Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt saw Britain's women at war. She is conducting research on a neglected aspect of this nation's war effort with unequaled insight and thoroughness and with facilities that have been extended to no other visitor to these shores.

A tea dance will be given Saturday in the Neptune Room of the Pierre, for the benefit of Bundles for America, under the sponsorship of the Bundles for America Branch of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. Miss Virginia Chalmers Limbert is chairman of the executive committee for the event.

AGAINST an authentic background of white-washed, thatched cottages, fuchsia hedges, brown bogs, stony glens and purple mountains, Mrs. O'Faolain tells a long story based on the old folk tale, "The King of the Cats."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- About 130 officers and men who survived the torpedoing of the American aircraft carrier Wasp owe their lives to a trick of seamanship calmly executed by Captain Forrest P. Sherman from a bridge blistering with the heat of the ship's own burning gasoline and torn by the steel of its own exploding shells.

FOR a variety of reasons English-speaking peoples have long had a warm spot in their hearts for Austria in general and Vienna in particular. During the past decade their sympathies have been quickened by the series of tragedies that overtook the little country.

Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Manhattan, won two matches in the United States amateur chess championship yesterday and moved into second place. Jackson defeated Robert Langfelder of Brooklyn in the twelfth round and came back in the thirteenth to topple G. Gustafson of Brooklyn.

A YEAR ago today Saburo Kurusu, special envoy of the Government of Japan, left Asia for the United States to assume his part in the "peace conversations" that continued until more than an hour after Japanese forces attacked Pearl Harbor.

Several thousand persons who had known the four-story brownstone mansion at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street as the home of the late Jay Gould, millionaire of the Eighties, were permitted to enter it yesterday and see its interior almost as its owner left it.

Within the past month the non-operating group of railroad employes have presented demands for increases of wages which would add $450,000,000 to carrier payrolls. This sum equals the total annual interest charges, which were barely covered in the Nineteen Thirties.

IT is hard to say why "Turning Leaves" -- winner for 1942 of the Dodd, Mead-Red Book $10,000 prize -- isn't more interesting. It is the story of a big family, and big fiction families over as wide a spread as the Five Little Peppers to the Forsytes are intrinsically pretty fascinating.

President Roosevelt last Friday made a contribution to the growing discussion of the nation's manpower problem. At his press conference he said that a work week longer than 48 hours is not conducive to greater production. People who think so, he indicated, are overlooking the factors of fatigue and lowered efficiency of workers.

THE new Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, being organized under the conductorship of Reginald Stewart, will open its season of fourteen subscription concerts, Nov. 19, in Baltimore. Heading the roster of musicians of the orchestra is Samuel Thaviu, former concertmaster and assistant conductor of the Kansas City Philharmonic Orchestra, who has been chosen to serve in a similar dual capacity with the Baltimore organization.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 7 (AP) -- To Brig. Gen. Amaro Soares Bittencourt, recently Brazilian military attache in Washingon, was presented today the United States Legion of Merit. He is the first foreigner to receive the award.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 7--The British Eighth Army under Lieut. Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery hurled armored forces, motorized infantry and swarms of planes tonight at the remnants of German General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's once-proud Afrika Korps--possibly only 25,000 out of an original 140,000--now trying to brace for a stand at Halfaya [Hellfire] Pass on the Libyan frontier, 240 miles west of the Alamein battleground.

In today's issue of our Magazine Arthur Krock tells from authoritative sources the inside story of Secretary Hull's conversations last Fall with Ambassador Nomura and Special Envoy Kurusu. Kurusu left Japan a year ago today. When he left the Japanese were already assembling the expedition which was to attack Pearl Harbor.

An experiment in transforming a run-down, badly planned home of a farm family near Ithaca, N.Y., into a modern, livable home without spending much money, is being carried out by the New York State College of Home Economics at Cornell.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Stores got permission today from Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, to increase the price of potatoes, onions and turkeys.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 8 -- News of the United States expeditionary force landings in French Africa "broke" about 2 A.M., London time, just as the Sunday morning newspapers were closing up and long after the last home-service broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

Thanksgiving Eve, Nov. 25, is the date chosen by the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind for an elaborate benefit entertainment to be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The program will include a dinner, dance and entertainment by stars of the stage, screen and radio.

The Federal Government has started a plan for voluntary reallocation of the milk supply centred in the metropolitan markets of New York, Boston and Chicago to prevent any shortages in those areas, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--President Roosevelt's statement announcing the opening of a second front in French North and West Africa follows:

WISELY, Fritz Kreisler took time for established recovery, following his dangerous accident in April of 1941, before returning to his concerts. Months prior to his resumed public appearances he had been practicing and even playing informally in the company of friends -- the violin, and the piano too when he felt like it.

Described by government agents as an international swindler wanted here and in Australia in stock frauds aggregating $10,000,000, John Woolcott Forbes was held yesterday in $100,000 bail by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind, before whom he was arraigned on charges of having forged a United States Treasury Department check and violation of the securities and exchange act.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The North Carolina Pre-Flight football team showed far too much power and class for Georgetown and won, 23 to 7, before 12,000 spectators tonight.

With President Roosevelt's submission to Congress last week of the report of the National Resources Planning Board, railroad consolidations, a burning question in the Nineteen Twenties, again have been thrust into the foreground.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 7 -- With Bill Schmidt stealing the spotlight, unbeaten Williams defeated Wesleyan, 31 -- 6, before a large homecoming day crowd today. Schmidt personally accounted for four Eph touchdowns as the Purple took its seventh straight victory and its first Little Three triumph of the season.

The sun sets early. The moon is late. Only the stars light the evening sky, the bright belt of Orion, the low-swinging Dipper. Familiar stars, stars with which the countryman has lived since the Autumn nights of boyhood wonder long ago.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 8 (UP) -- First authoritative news from the Andaman Islands, in the Bay of Bengal, since their occupation by the Japanese early this year indicates that the Japanese are carrying on a "reign of terror," an official statement said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The civilian inhabitants of this country who are now coping with a shortage of meats, coffee, sugar and some kinds of canned goods, were told this week by the Secretary of Agriculture that 1943 would see canned fruits and vegetables added to the list, and that the supply of dairy products would be smaller than the demand.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Possibly the greatest invasion armada assembled in Europe since the start of the war undertook the invasion of French North Africa today in the first large-scale action in the European theatre in which the United States has participated.
