WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Under the constitutional system of fixed tenure in office, the voters of the United States once only in four years can register their judgment on the executive as well as the legislative conduct of the government. But biennially they can do that, indirectly so far as the Executive is concerned, by voting on the only Federal officials who present themselves at the polls.

One of the important, late Fall tasks in the garden and around the home grounds is to protect the evergreens against the time of snow and sleet. Both are destructive. Each season we are almost certain to have one or more heavy snowstorms with wet, heavy, clinging snow which accumulates on the evergreens; the weight breaks branches, snaps off the "leader" top branch and distorts the shape of the shrub or growing tree.

THE New York City Y.M.C.A. will observe its ninetieth anniversary this week. But no one who looks in at its thirteen branches in Manhattan and the Bronx, and particularly at two of them, can see where the association will be able to find much time for birthday doings.

CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 7 -- The great tidal wave that drowned 10,000 persons in the Midnapur district, south of Calcutta, swept over nearly 500 square miles of paddy fields. The flood, which rose in a few hours twenty days ago, is still draining away.

Gardeners in California are familiar with a host of lovely tulips all but unknown in the East. Showy Butterfly Tulips, jaunty Star Tulips, pensive little Globe Tulips are often barred from gardens in colder climates because of a fear that they might not survive the Winter.

HAITI has announced that the republic's patroness, Our Lady of Perpetual Help, will be honored on Dec. 8 with the issuing of nine postage and five air mail stamps. Through the first week of December each year the people of Haiti celebrate this feast in honor of the Virgin Mary.

Retail trade continued active here last week, but did not show the same percentage of increase over a year ago as in the preceding week. Estimates put the department store volume at 7 to 10 per cent over 1941. Election day trade was about equal to a year ago.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 7 -- Two laterals, from Bill Elliot to Walt Donahue, give Bowdoin a pair of third-period touchdowns and a 12-to-6 victory over Maine in a bitter struggle for the State championship today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- All passenger automobiles will be eligible for recapping services or replacement tires under the national mileage rationing program which goes into effect Nov. 22, the Office of Price Administration stated today.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 7 -- Australians have been hearing much lately about their "two armies," by which is meant the Australian Imperial Force and the Militia. It is safe to say that the great mass of Australians are affronted by this domestic political controversy, which is open to misconstruction in countries where the facts are not known or understood and where, as a result, Australia s war effort may be underestimated.
The need for the unity of all political parties in the prosecution of the war was emphasized by rabbis here in post-election sermons yes terday. Another sermon subject was Armistice Day.

Because "education as usual" is definitely out for the duration the curriculum of Brigham Young University (Utah) is undergoing drastic revision. Fortunately the sharp swing away from the liberal arts toward mathematics, the physical and applied sciences finds many faculty members versatile enough to fit into the new scheme of things.
Stocks yesterday extended their gains of the week and closed at the best levels since Pearl Harbor in the largest Saturday trading of the year.

THERE was a time in our town -- and in our country -- which Henry James called an era of "flagrant morality." It was also a time of ruthless exploitation -- a boodling time, a bawdy time and a gaudy time. Jay Gould belonged to it, Boss Tweed belonged to it.

THIS month's best album on all counts is the recording of Schubert's Trio No. 1, in B flat, Op. 99. (Victor DM- 923, four 12-inch records.) It is played by Artur Rubenstein, piano; Jascha Heifetz, violin, and the late Emanuel Feuermann, 'cello.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Nov. 8 -- American combat troops are in action near Buna, vital Japanese base on the north New Guinea coast, General Douglas MacArthur disclosed today.

SAVANNAH, Ga. -- If General James Edward Oglethorpe could return to this city he founded more than 200 years ago he would find very little to remind him of his first visit. Probably no Southern city the size of Savannah has been so completely revamped or militarized as this early Winter resort.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Official copies of the pamphlet outlining the now Controlled Material Plan of the War Production Board will be available for free and general distribution next week, WPB announced today. The plan, which will control the flow of steel, copper and aluminum into war production, goes into effect for some groups in the second quarter of next year and into full operation by next July 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- With Germany having exhausted her own labor force and with Japan having faced a shortage of workers for two years, the United States is only beginning to dip into its supply of potential reserves, the Office of War Information stated today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 7 (AP) Tennessee substitutes helped crush Cincinnati at football today, 34 -- 12.

THE tempo of activities in New York's night belt, which for the past fortnight has been moderately paced, will gain in momentum this week. Two new night clubs, a hotel room and two shows will be offered by the merchants of nocturnal entertainment within the next five days. Listed in chronological order, the assorted events for the week are as follows:

WHITINSVILLE, Mass., Nov. 7 -- Marking the conversion to war production of the Whitin Machine Works, which formerly produced half the preparatory machinery required by the textile industry, the United States Maritime Commission today presented the Maritime "M" Pennant, the Victory Fleet Flag and Labor Merit Badges to the concern and its employes.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in North Africa, Sunday, Nov. 8 -- Scores of thousands of American troops, led by amphibious landing parties and air-borne shock troops, landed today in numerous areas of French West and North Africa.
THE glum look on the face of a private shortly after mail call may not mean that his "sugar report" (letter from girl) has turned sour but that he has flunked his course.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A three-point coordinated program for local, State and Federal action was announced by the Automotive Safety Foundation tonight to strip the motor transport system of nonessentials and dedicate it to the winning of the war.

Ethelbert Smith said it was rather sad, wasn't it, what creatures of habit we are. Day after day and year after year a man will get up in the morning and brush his teeth and shave and climb under the shower and dress and sit down to breakfast.

A warning that juvenile delinquency could be expected to increase unless more funds were made available to provide better educational and recreational services during the war period was sounded yesterday by speakers at the annual conference of the United Parents Associations at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A $50,000 fund raised by painters in Greater New York, who contributed a day's pay on Sept. 25, was distributed yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt by District Council No. 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America, A.F. of L., to representatives of various relief organizations.

Money in circulation in the United States increased $230,000,000 last week, the largest gain in any week since the banking crisis in March, 1933. This time it was not the case of a frightened public withdrawing currency from the banks but a public with more and larger pay envelopes that prefers to retain large sums at home in anticipation of contemplated purchases of the dwindling supply of consumer goods.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 7 -- Mighty Michigan rolling up four touchdowns in the first half, extended its winning streak in intersectional football competition to 11 games today by crushing Harvard, 35 to 7, before 25,534 spectators.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 7 -- Taking a full measure of revenge for setbacks in recent years, Amherst's unbeaten eleven routed Trinity, 35 -- 6, today for its sixth straight conquest.

Ways in which clubwomen can line themselves up with the nation's war efforts and news items which may help to shape their club activities are being bulletined to all State federation war service chairmen, from the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

THE People's Symphony concerts had its genesis in a simple idea. There is a large audience for serious music and serious musicians if the prices are within its means. It might be argued that this is not a particularly new idea.

THIS is another tale of sleepy Torminster, where we meet again the two children, Henrietta and Hugh Anthony; Canon Fordyce and his wife, who were Hugh Anthony's grandparents and Henrietta's adopted grandparents; Felicity and Jocelyn, her bookseller husband; the Archdeacon and the Dean.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Detachments of marines and soldiers, trained to jungle fighting in three months of bitter and sweating experience on Guadalcanal, again are carrying the fight to the enemy. They opened in the past week the third chapter in the already notable land phase of the campaign of the Solomons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The War Department tonight released the English translation of a broadcast in French giving the text of a proclamation issued by General Eisenhower. The broadcast was as follows:

Labor union heads representing workers in the automotive, steel, ship-building, metal mining and communications industries have told a Senate Labor and Education subcommittee that the manpower shortage is serious partly because some plants and cities have large pools of idle, skilled labor.

Yesterday was the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution. In honor of the occasion Moscow was en fete. Streets radiating from the Red Square were lined with decorations that included huge canvases of Karl Marx, Nikolai Lenin, Frederich Engels, Joseph Stalin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Here is the story of the dramatic announcement, made at 9 o'clock tonight at the White House, that American forces had invaded French North and West Africa:

An English friend urges that we Americans talk too much about India. How would we feel, he asks, if Englishmen kept dinning in our ears their opinions on the Negro problem. Those of us who are sure we know the answer might resent it; but most of us recognize that the Negro problem is far from solution, and that it concerns not the United States alone but the whole world.
TRADE secrets are going by the boards, so it is entirely proper at this time to tell the truth about movie ice cream, and movie shaving cream, and movie cobwebs. They are Ersatz, all of them.

IN these days of scarcity and conservation, advice to throw something away may sound like heresy. However, when it comes to amateur movie editing there just isn't any alternative. Unless you did a perfect job, didn't make a single mistake in exposure, have all your scenes in exactly the right order and have what you want in just the way you want, you should do some editing.

MOST Westerners think of the Chinese as a strange unfathomable people, admirable and nice if you could get to know them, but as different from us in thought and feeling as a race from another planet. If Mine. Wei Tao-ming is an example of her people, strangeness is purely a matter of distance.

THE League of American Writers is preparing an anthology entitled "War Poems of the United Nations," to be published by the Dial Press early in 1943. It will contain battle poems from the Russian and Chinese war fronts as well as from the battlefields of the United States and Great Britain.

THE season of gallery exhibitions of antique art is ushered in tomorrow by an unusual exhibit at the Cooper Union. It concentrates on color in relation to crafts and design. From its collection of antique textiles, pottery, furniture and other objects of household decoration, selections have been made on a color basis: red, yellow or blue, and the origin of these colors from nonchemical sources is shown.

The trial board of the Port of New York Authority unanimously has recommended that twelve traffic officers employed by the Authority should be "cleared in all respects" of charges of irregularities in the collection of tolls on the Staten Island badges.

THE Council on Books in Wartime, as one of its activities, will from time to time select from the current lists a book which it believes can make an outstanding contribution to the war effort. It will do whatever is possible to direct the attention of the reading public toward the books which it selects for this purpose.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The proud and dashing Duquesne Dukes, stripped last month of their long victory string, barely held onto another record today -- that of remaining unbeaten at home in four years -- when hard-fighting St. Mary's of California forced a 7-7 tie before 14,000 fans.

" LIFE WITH FATHER" starts its fourth year tomorrow, and late last week the statisticians of the Oscar Serlin office observed that, while business had slipped in the third year as compared with the other two, the show was losing no money whatsoever.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A British Air Ministry communique:

Improvements in their wages and working conditions were won last week by 2,500 members of Belgian seamen's and officers' organizations when the unions, affiliates of the International Transport Workers Federation, signed a new collective agreement in London with the Belgian Government-in-Exile and the Belgian shipowners.

An exciting voyage through the Lachine Rapids of the St. Lawrence convinced the writer that he had fallen far short of appreciating the task of our country's pilot in steering the Ship of State through the yet more perilous passage of today's world turmoil.
NEWARK, Del., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Swarthmore threw a scare into unbeaten Delaware by taking a 7-0 first-quarter lead today, but the Blue Hens rallied to gain their twentieth straight victory, 19 to 7.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 8 -- For weeks American newspaper men have been the custodians of one of war's biggest secrets. It was not an easy secret to keep because through all that time they had to improvise excuses for the absence of a large number of the members of their London staffs to conceal the fact that they had gone with the expeditionary forces.
Exporters of American textiles expressed concern here last week about the problems of finding suitable post-war markets for this country's greatly expanded wartime production facilities.

OTTAWA, Nov. 7 -- Over 1,200,000 individual subscribers out of Canada's total population of 11,500,000 have contributed to the Third Victory Loan which closes tonight. The minimum amount of $750,000,000 has been exceeded by over $130,000,000, with another full day to go.

The annual card party in behalf of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service will be held on Thursday afternoon at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League. Mrs. Henry Gansevoort Sanford heads the benefit committee.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 7 -- A great expansion of the Army Air Forces Technical Training Command, which will make barracks out of virtually all of the 334 tourist hotels in Miami Beach and neighboring Surfside, was announced today by military authorities.

As this is written there is exactly one aluminum double-boiler left on the shelves of a venerable house-ware store in Manhattan. And in Washington the WPB announces that as for enamelware a total of 450 types of pots and pans have been reduced to 25.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 -- Industry and trade in the Far West area soared ahead again during the week ended Oct. 24 and established a new all-time high. Business activity advanced 0.3 per cent over the preceding week and stood 15.5 per cent above the corresponding week of 1941.

WITH the spurt in liquor sales over and the shopping for overseas accomplished in a tidal wave that overwhelmed receiving depots, trade became normal last week. Retailers discovered, however, that the public was willing and ready enough to obey the mandate for earlier Chrism buying.

DEVOTEES of radio crime, it is reported, are among the choosiest of listeners, ready at the drop of a Crossley rating to argue over the merits and subtleties of their favorite studies in homicide. Is the Thin Man a more eminent bloodhound than Bulldog Drummond?

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 7 -- Georgia's unbeaten, untied football team overwhelmed a bewildered Florida eleven, 75 -- 0, before 22,000 today. It was Georgia's fourteenth consecutive victory since midseason of 1941 and the eighth straight of 1942.

" A fighting man's fighting man," they say of Vice Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., new leader of our naval forces in the Southern Pacific. He flies his own plane; doesn't care a lot for gold braid; has for his motto, "Hit hard, fast, often" -- speed rather than weight. "
LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- There was no immediate word early today of the reaction of the French forces in the African colonies to the American invasion.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Lockport Lou Corriere put on one of the greatest scoring shows in University of Buffalo football history as the Bulls routed their traditional rival, Hobart, 66 -- 0, at Rotary Field today to close their home season with a distinct flourish.

IN this lavish novel of Louisiana, Frances Parkinson Keyes has veritably outdone herself. None of her dozen earlier romances, long and brilliantly descriptive though many of them were, reached much more than half the prodigious length of "Crescent Carnival."

Two forthcoming performances of "The Skin of Our Teeth," a new play by Thornton Wilder, at the Plymouth Theatre, have been taken over to further the work of charitable organizations. The performance of the play on the night of Nov. 23 will aid the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Powerful American forces, supported by British naval and air forces, landed simultaneously tonight at numerous points on the Mediterranean and Atlantic coasts of French North Africa, forestalling an anticipated invasion of Africa by Germany and Italy and launching effective second-front assistance to Russia, President Roosevelt announced tonight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Scoring 13 points in the second half to offset Rutgers's 13 in the same interval, Lafayette triumphed, 19 to 13, at the Rutgers Stadium today before a Homecoming Day crowd of 8,000. Passes from Hal Conners and Don Jones were intercepted, once to set up the final Lafayette tally in the fourth period and again to smother a Rutgers rally four minutes be fore the end of the game.

HERE is a ride on a cosmic roller-coaster that should leave most readers limp with excitement. Mr. O'Farrell tells us the story of Barney Page, a brilliant young actor, who in one short year has gone tragically to pot.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 7 (AP) -- North Carolina gained a 43-14 victory over Davidson College before 13,000 spectators today.
TO THE MOSSIES: Australian troops in New Guinea were singing a catchy new song last week:
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Van Lennep have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Newtown Square, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Eleven Pan-American republics will be represented at the annual meeting here of the Inter-American Commission of Women, which will open tomorrow and continue through Saturday at the Pan American Union.

In a bristling finish that was followed by a futile claim of foul, the Falaise Stable's Good Morning drove home first before 22,099 persons at Belmont Park yesterday as Victory Race Week, which will continue until Thursday, reached its high point.
Mount St. Michael High's eleven outgained Fordham Prep along the ground at Fordharn Field yesterday, but erratic ball-handling proved costly, a miscue giving Fordham Prep a 6-0 triumph.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Sunday, Nov. 8 -- American soldiers, marines and sailors from one of the greatest armadas ever put into a single military operation swarmed ashore today on the Vichy-controlled North Africa shore before dawn, striking to break Hitler's hold on the Mediterranean.

JAMES NORMAN HALL, as a writer, is not merely one-haft of the combination which produced such favorite reading as the "Bounty" trilogy. He is an essayist in his own sole habit as well. From time to time, and from place to place, he produces delightful individual pieces of reflection, of reminiscence, of protest, of whim.
Two changes have been made in the rules of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange against dislocations caused by air raid alarms or other emergencies.

Ernest Anderson, who introduced 5:30 Saturday afternoon jazz concerts to Town Hall last Spring, yesterday afternoon presented there the first of a bi-weekly series of similar concerts. Like the four concerts last season, it was directed by Eddie Condon, guitarist.

When it is known that Sergei Rachmaninoff will give a recital in Carnegie Hall, as he did yesterday afternoon, the hall is promptly sold far in advance of the performance. Usually, as on this occasion, a number have to be seated on the stage. When he wants to stop playing encores he has to close the piano, which he did, personally, yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 -- Labor unity, the establishment of a second front to blunt the Nazi attacks on Russia and problems arising out of the war effort will be the chief subjects before the delegates to the annual convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations which will be opened here Monday by President Philip Murray.

War against waste. Such is the injunction of the Bureau of Home Economics of the United States Department of Agriculture. Practicing frugality in the kitchen is good for your budget and, further, it conserves supplies vitally needed both here and abroad.
CAIRO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Royal Air Force and British Middle East Headquarters:

German air and naval reinforcements were thrown into the fight on the desert battlefront in Egypt yesterday, the Berlin radio reported, while General Field Marshal Erwin Rommell's battered army claimed the repulse of British attacks southeast of Matruh.

To my humble way of thinking, the leading article of THE TIMES Magazine of Oct. 18 is a lot of rot, and in saying this I do not mean to be as disrespectful to Mr. Priestley, its author, as I sound. What he says is just about what would be expected from one who is as highly intellectual as he.

SEATTLE, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- In the jungle of New Guinea, which swallowed him for more than six weeks and left him delirious and near death, Associated Press war correspondent Vern Haugland gave his socks to a companion who needed them worse than he did.

Jackie Cooper, Chicago middleweight, last night scored a technical knockout over Bob Wade, Newark boxer, in the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove S.C., Brooklyn. Referee Pete Hartley stopped the contest after 1 minute 51 seconds of the seventh round. Cooper weighed 151 1/2, Wade 157.

An unprecedented Congress of American-Soviet Friendship opened two-day sessions at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday with an appeal by Joseph E. Davies, its honorary chairman, for full unity and understanding between the peoples of the United States and Russia as indispensable to both victory in arms and the winning of the peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Members of Congress, returning from our peaceful war at the ballot boxes, will reassemble Monday to take final action on one of the toughest problems which the bitter fighting of the war of nations has yet put up to them.

Discrepancies between rising living costs and the amount of cash the "white collar" group of working girls finds in today's pay envelopes have become more acute during the past few months. Responses to a questionnaire circulated by the National Business and Professional Council of the Y.W.C.A. have indicated the need for accelerated action, which the unit is now formulating.

Some time ago Professor Nevins wrote for THE TIMES Magazine an article entitled "England Revisited." His views are optimistic, and the reasons for his optimism are, I think, well grounded and clearly explained; but his estimate of the food situation reads like that of some one who lived in hotels and large towns or who did not attempt to keep house for himself.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 -- An agreement between representatives of the War Labor Board and officials of the Mechanics Educational Society of America ended today the strike of 9,200 of the society's members which had closed fifteen war plants in Detroit and threatened to spread to other industrial areas.

DO children "outgrow" their problems? Suppose you took two groups of youngsters about equal in age, health and intelligence, and showing temper tantrums, "nervousness," difficulties in school, etc., in the same proportions.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady to lower today at the close of a week during which the market betrayed by its small irregular fluctuations the stabilizing effect of the ceilings on dressed meats. The report by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Stanford's amazing Indians, low one week and high the next, backed up their second upset of the season today by trouncing University of Washington's Huskies, 20 to 7, in Kezar Stadium.

Football, fur coats and frost are not the only signs of cold weather. If all other portents fail, there is still the "Rocking Chair Fleet of America," which annually proclaims to the world that yachting has gone ashore for the season.

IT is a thundering panorama that Mr. Ernest Hemingway unrolls before us in "Men at War." Here in a battlewagon of a book (nearly eleven hundred pages) he has gathered eighty-two short stories, excerpts from novels, memoirs or history, that show fighting men of all the ages engaged in practically every type of warfare.
MOSCOW, Nov. 8, Sunday (AP) -- A Soviet Bureau of Information communique:

Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. announced yesterday the appointment of Harold MacLean Lewis as consulting engineer to fill the vacancy caused by the recent promotion of Dean G. Edwards to the post of Chief Borough Engineer. Mr. Lewis will take over his new post next Saturday.

A wartime significance is attached this year to plans for a traditional early Winter benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund -- the premiere of the Ice Follies at Madison Square Garden. The opening performance will take place Dec. 1 and its net proceeds will be used to fee young artists to continue a series of concerts, under Musicians Emergency Fund auspices, for men stationed at East Coast naval bases.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- It was revealed today that Premier Joseph Stalin spoke last in the great St. Andrew's Hall of the Kremlin before about 2,000 persons from the rostrum whence in June Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff had reported to members of the Supreme Soviet on his London and Washington visits.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Great Lakes Naval Training Station football team routed Purdue today, 42 to 0, before a dad's day crowd of 12,000.

Aware that the 18 and 19 year old students may soon be called from the classroom, college and university presidents throughout the United States are seriously concerned with the immediate need of readjusting their campus programs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Congressional delay in enacting the 18-19-age draft bill will cause the induction into the armed forces in December of 200,000 married men who otherwise might not have been called until late in the Spring if at all, legislators said today.

There is a point below which civilian requirements cannot be cut without endangering the entire war effort, Gordon E. Cole, chairman of the board of the Association of National Advertisers, declared yesterday in discussing the two-day wartime conference of the association to be held Wednesday and Thursday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The educational department of the Women's Trade Union League will gain from the piano recital to be given by Rudolf Serkin on Dec. 1 at Carnegie Hall. A committee under the honorary chairmanship of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, with Miss Mary E. Dreier as executive chairman and Mrs. Otto H. Kahn, Mrs. Henry Ittleson and Mrs. Myron I. Borg, associate chairmen, is sponsoring the event.

Three seldom heard American works were performed by Howard Barlow, American conductor, last night at his third appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. The event was the first of the season's students' concerts.

The Greek forces taking part in the attack on Germany's Africa Corps in Egypt represent the largest number of fighting men of any country other than Great Britain, George Haniotis, newly appointed member of the Greek Embassy in Washington and now head of the Greek Office of Information, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Certificates of war necessity will be denied to forty-eight taxicab operators in Louisville because they advertised and provided taxi service from Louisville to Fort Knox, a distance of thirty-six miles, the Office of Defense Transportation said today.

THE use of a London label on commodities made in the American colonies was an act of deception resulting from the local snobbery. Anything that was produced abroad had a better chance of selling than the home-grown article.

Darkness, fog and sleet present no obstacle to television rays. The atmosphere is always clear as crystal. Then why isn't television used on airplanes to guide pilots in bad weather or at night to their landing places? The answer is that it is not enough to mount a transmitter near the center of an airfield and a receiver in a plane.

A reception and cocktail party will be given tomorrow afternoon at the English-Speaking Union, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, to mark the formal opening of a special clubroom for officers of the United Nations. High-ranking military leaders and several civic officials will be guests of honor for the occasion.

WINTER is settling down on the long Russian front and the German Wehrmacht is now face to face with its second Winter campaign. Protracted fighting both at Sevastopol and at Stalingrad and Marshal Timoshenko's bold forestalling attack on the Kharkov front caused month after month of good campaigning weather to slip by without the Germans' reaching a decision anywhere.

A further sharp decline in efficiency and production in the offices of non-defense concerns may be expected as a result of the continuing withdrawal of clerical workers by the draft and war industry, and the difficulty in recruiting suitable replacements, office managers said yesterday.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Autumn activities are varied in the Pocono Mountain region. Horseback riding is a popular sport through the Fall. There will be golf until the frost comes, and lawn bowling at Skytop and Buck Hill Falls.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Alabama's once-beaten Crimson Tide rolled up a wide lead over the South Carolina gamecocks in the first half today and then coasted for a 29-0 victory before 10,000 homecoming day fans.

SCREAMING headlines told of the battle of the marines on Guadacanal. The fourth-graders were full of it. They couldn't settle down or talk about anything else. A year ago the teacher of these children would have tried to divert their minds to recapture the mood of yesterday's lesson, which had centered about local problems.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Office of War Information, in reporting progress in an action by the Office of Price Administration against twenty-five steel companies under price ceiling regulations, made it clear today that procedure against most of the companies named was merely for buying over-priced steel.

Precisely how much American history is taught in the primary and secondary schools of the nation nobody knows, for no recent Federal statistics are available. A thorough investigation of the subject is badly needed. But there can be no question that Professor Erling Hunt's statement on the subject in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 25 is excessively roseate.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Hundreds of typical Londoners today joined members of their own and foreign governments in celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 8--Bombers from Britain struck a heavy blow at Northern Italy over Friday night, blasting the port of Genoa again in support of the Eighth Army's battling of the Nazis and Italians in the African desert.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 8 -- The chief of the Vichy generals in North Africa against whom Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will pit his strategy in the event of resistance is 53-year-old General Alphonse Juin, Commander in Chief there.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 6 (Delayed) -- "Now, you see, we're beginning to win this war," a British officer remarked to the writer today as we were weaving our way up from what had been our forward positions toward El Daba, amid a stream of briskly moving vehicles of battle -- guns, tanks and everything you can think of in connection with war, as well as trucks full of gay soldiery.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 7 -- Earl (Sparky Brown), whose Cazenovia home is only nineteen miles from the Syracuse campus, applied the ignition to a previously spluttering Penn State attack to send the Lions to an unexpected 18-13 victory over Syracuse today.

With boys in uniform crowding Southern resort towns where big hotels have been taken over by the military, attention is being focused on keeping the Winter vacation season down there on an even keel. There are many factors to be considered, factors that are being weighed by rail officials, hotel owners and heads of other enterprises, in an effort to give prospective travelers to Florida what they want.

So much that is deserving of the highest praise is published in THE NEW YORK TIMES that one finds it usually very difficult to select one item worthy of especially favorable comment. However, the illustrations entitled "Altars of Freedom" that appeared in a recent magazine are so splendid in their imagery and beauty that this reader feels he must be one of thousands who recognize their high power and influence for good.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Corn was the leader today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, moving up 1/4 to 5/8 cent a bushel and closing at the top as a result of buying induced by a further upturn of 1/3 to 1 cent a bushel in the cash market elative to December and on aggressive buying of the near future attributed to cash interests at 5 1/4 cents under May.

Close to a quarter of a million dollars was gained by Army Emergency Relief from the eight football games played in August and September between the two All- Army squads and teams of the National Football League, it was disclosed yesterday by the directors of War Football Fund, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- Complete mastery of the Franklin Field air lanes netted a stunning 7-to-0 victory for Navy's out-rushed but gallant football forces today and compelled highly rated Pennsylvania to absorb its first setback at the hands of a collegiate opponent.

CAIRO, main radio outlet for war news from the Egyptian front, is very busy these days flashing bulletins of the progress of the British Eighth Army on the El Alamein sector. The Marconi Telegraph channel (10.055 mcs.) is heard all the afternoon here sputtering code with lightning speed or talking in rapid "jumbled" syllables.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 7 -- The Economic Defense Commission was established yesterday as another force to be wielded against the Axis and against any fifth columnists that may still be trying to obstruct the country's economic life and block its war aims.

Friedman, secretary of the Authority, said last night. He indicated that this would take some time.

The Greek War Relief Association, 730 Fifth Avenue, on the occasion of its second anniversary, made public yesterday telegrams from King George II of Greece and Prime Minister E. Tsouderos, both of whom congratulated the organization on its relief activities.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Sparked by Marty Gonda and Jack Burntitus, Gorton High School of Yonkers scored a 24-0 W.I.A.A. victory over hapless New Rochelle High at Senior Field today. The loss was the sixth straight for last year's league champions, who bowed to Gorton for the first time in seventeen years.

Exclusive of the Senate's Hattie Caraway, women in the Seventy-eighth Congress will be one voice and one vote short of the delegation immediately preceding them. They are seven.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (Canadian Press -- The Queen's Park Rangers advanced in the English Football League's southern section today, defeating West Ham, 5 -- 2, while Arsenal lost to Tottenham, 1 -- 0, before 21,000, the day's largest crowd. Chelsea was downed, 2 -- 0, by Clapton Orient and Aldershot beat Brighton, 3 -- 0.

THE Vichy Government has not imposed the decrees which would have barred the showing of American motion pictures in unoccupied French territory and also prohibited transit through France of American photoplays destined for Switzerland, according to advices from the latter country.

There was a time when Dietrich Wortmann was much too busy earning honors as an amateur wrestler to give much thought to deer hunting. That was thirty-five years ago when he was seeking Olympic honors and bagging national and metropolitan wrestling crowns instead of nine-point bucks.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Virginia Tech's Gobblers won their fourth Southern Conference football game of the season today, making two quick touchdown thrusts, missing two others by a few feet and adding a late-game field goal to topple Richmond, 16 -- 7, before 7,000 spectators.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- After stubbing their toes on Temple's 10-yard line during the first few minutes of play, Boston College's undefeated Eagles settled down to a touchdown-a-period gait and overwhelmed the Owls, 28 to 0, before a 20,000 crowd at Fenway Park today.
IOWA CITY, Nov. 7 -- Iowa sent Wisconsin's proud Badgers reeling from the nation's undefeated football ranks today.

Declaring that "the age of the common man has dawned," Bishop Herbert Welch, who for sixteen years headed the Methodist Church in the Orient, celebrated his eightieth birthday yesterday at a luncheon in his honor at the parish house of Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. Three hundred church and civic leaders attended, with Bishop Francis J. McConnell presiding.

Taking their cue from grownups around them. children seem to be pretty much the same the world over. A report from the Congress of American-Soviet . Friendship, celebrating today as the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Soviet Union, tells of boys and girls helping to build shelters and barricades, learning fire-fighting. studying military subjects, as well as collecting scrap and keeping schools clean to release adult labor.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Three flyers received today the Navy Cross for their part in the battle of Midway in a torpedo squadron operating from the aircraft carrier Yorktown, and a fourth flyer received the Distinguished Flying Cross for heroic conduct in the batte ofl Bougainville.

Morris Bernson, 55 years old, of 1116 Kelly Street, the Bronx, was shot dead early last night by one of two Negro hold-up men who attempted to rob his haberdashery shop at 138 West 116th Street. His assailant escaped through crowded streets.

ALDOUS HUXLEY was brought close to blindness at the age of 16. After eighteen months, when he read by braille and walked with guidance, he was left with one eye that could distinguish light from darkness and the other barely able, at short distance, to read.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Elmer Engel, senior end, cantered 53 yards for a third-period touchdown which gave Coach Ray Eliot's rejuvenated Illinois football team a 14-to-7 victory over Northwestern today before a crowd of 35,000.

A conference of hundreds of Jewish religious and lay leaders called by Governor Lehman and Dr. Louis Finkelstein, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 3080 Broadway, will be held there today to discuss its program for strengthening the Jewish faith and the democratic tradition.

In its picturesque setting reproducing the Old World atmosphere of its namesake in Mayfair, London, the Piccadilly Arcade at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street will open its second edition on Tuesday morning to augment the British War Relief Society's fund for aiding the homeless in Britain.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Major Gen. Russell L. Maxwell, commander of American troops in Egypt, told newly arrived soldiers and nurses today that the smashing of the Axis armies in Africa was just the beginning of an operation that will "go to the heart of Germany."

Meetings held here last week by producers of men's, women's and children's knit underwear, at which voluntary steps were discussed to simplify essential civilian output during a war economy, attracted the interest not only of buyers for wholesale and retail distributors, but also of other branches of the textile industry.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Missouri, 1941 champion of the Big Six conference, spotted Nebraska a touchdown today, then ran over the Cornhuskers to take a 26-to-6 victory and move into commanding position in this year's race.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Navy's offer to provide a section of midshipmen to cheer Army's football team when the services meet in their traditional battle on Nov. 28 at Annapolis has been gratefully received by Army, it was announced today by Major Gen. Francis B. Wilby, superintendent of the military academy.

With Freshman Frank Dixon in his customary pace-setting role, New York University's undefeated cross-country team added a fourth consecutive dual-meet triumph to its recently acquired metropolitan intercollegiate championship by defeating Fordham, 15 -- 40, yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Georgia's Naval Pre-Flight School powerhouse, featuring some of the nation's outstanding football players, bowled over Auburn, 41 -- 14, today. Some 6,500 fans saw the game.

DALLAS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Blazin' Barney Welch praised the ball and passed it just three times -- all good for touchdowns -- to lead the Texas Aggies to a thrilling 27-20 victory today over Southern Methodist.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Winning two of the four places in the opening event of the first of the major retriever field trials of the season in the eastern section of the country was the reward of the Western owners for their fine sporting spirit in shipping their dogs here.

NEARLY twenty years ago Mrs. Orton wrote the first story about The Little Lost Pigs and the tale has remained a favorite with the 5 to 8 year olds ever since. Now Rosaline and Piggy Joe, who are quite as inquisitive and as enterprising as ever, are traveling once more and as they have no intention of getting lost in the woods a second time, they head for the big city.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 8 -- The Red Army held its ground on all fronts yesterday, the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Russian revolution, and killed more than 1,800 Germans in Stalingrad and the Central Caucasus and on the western front, the Soviet midnight communique indicated today.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. -- The Winter season is already under way at this resort on the northeast coast of Florida. Swimming, bicycling and golf by day; dimouts by night, are interspersed with side trips to St. Augustine and to Jacksonville, twenty-five miles distant.

General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, and Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the Fleet, will speak at the annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor on Tuesday. The general theme of the meeting will be "Transportation in Wartime."

LOS ANGELES -- Such tourist travel as California may have in this coming Winter will more closely resemble the seasons of half a century ago than those of the last hectic decade of pleasure seeking. Visitors will come for climate rather than excitement.
JOSEPH LEVIS, secretary of the Robert G. Ingersoll Memorial Association, 317 East Thirty-fourth Street, New York City, writes:
The arrest of seventeen enemy aliens here was announced yesterday at the office of P.E. Foxworth, agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- American Army troops on Guadalcanal Island have attacked Japanese forces and advanced in the area east of Henderson Airfield, encountering only light resistance, the Navy announced in a communique today.

The Bundles for Bluejackets, naval division of Bundles for America, Inc., 681 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that it had received official approval from Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart to provide Christmas trees, decorations, gifts and other comforts aboard ships and at bases, stations and training camps throughout the Third Naval District.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Smoldering resentment against reduced trade discounts broke into the open today when John W. Dargavel, executive secretary of the National Association of Retail Druggists, warned the drug trade pointedly that he would lodge a formal complaint with the OPA if conditions are not cleaned up.
In THE TIMES Magazine of Oct. 25 Charles Brockaway attempts to ridicule the pronunciation of the Spanish "z" and the "c" before "e" and "i" as taught in the schools of the United States.

THE Eastman School of Music's eighteenth season of American Composers' Concerts was inaugurated by the presentation of the annual Symposium of American Orchestral Music. From Oct. 27 to 30 the Eastman-Rochester Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Dr Howard Hanson, in three sessions read through the orchestral scores of twenty-five composers, spent a fourth in rehearsal and repetition and devoted the final session to a public concert of selected works.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Before a large Father's Day crowd, Lawrenceville's eleven continue undefeated and untied today, turning back Choate by 14 -- 7.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- War has taken a heavy toll of the once thriving shipping business in grain on the Great Lakes, market statistics showed today.

A one-day rose show, sponsored by Roses, Inc., in cooperation with the New York Florists' Club, will be held tomorrow in the Hotel Pennsylvania from 9 A.M. to 12 A.M. The display is open to the public and will include all types of roses in table settings, exhibition arrangements, bouquets, corsages and floral jewelry.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 -- The Louisiana Farm's Riverland, fashioner of two of the biggest upsets of the racing year in the last week, had the tables turned on him today as he was edged out in the Grayson Handicap before 15,000 persons at Pimlico.

STIMULATED no doubt by the great popularity of the detective story, there has come a marked increase in a type of novel fairly closely related to the detective story, but making claim to somewhat more serious consideration, the type in which atmosphere and psychology are of greater importance than the puzzle as to which one of several persons is the criminal.
The wartime edition of one of New York's oldest institutions, the national horse show, opened yesterday for a two-session event in the Riding and Polo Club.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- Southern California's speed-burning halfback, Mickey McCardle, personally led the Trojans to an upset 21-to-7 victory today over the University of California in a football game watched by 50,000 persons.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Minus Lou Thomas, their blond scoring punch, Tulane's Greenies went down, 7 -- 0, before Mississippi State today as a homecoming crowd of 28,000 looked on.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Indiana knocked Minnesota, the defending Big Ten champions, out of any chance for a share in the 1942 title by defeating the Gophers, 7 to 0 today, on a touchdown scored with only three and a half minutes to go.

WITHOUT any relaxation of the effort to win the war, much thought is being devoted nowadays to problems of post-war reconstruction. THE wage stabilization order limiting salaries to a gross of $54,425 or to an employe's 1941 salary gross, whichever figure is greater, hit the motion picture industry a blow this week which, for the time being, seems to have caused considerable confusion and a little hysteria.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 7 (AP) -Earl Gross rode A. Varanese's Easy Blend to victory today in the Hamilton Purse, feature of a nine-race card which drew a crowd of 15,000 to Rockingham Park.

TORONTO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs moved into a first- place tie with Detroit in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Red Wings, 5 -- 2, in a game marked by an outbreak of fisticuffs among the players and witnessed by a crowd oof 12,386.

A robust though somber shade of the National Horse Show tradition lived for an afternoon and evening at the Riding and Polo Club yesterday. NO week this season has offered more variety in the local exhibition field than last week's numerous shows afforded. Besides those commented upon elsewhere on this page, a number of the current attractions present work of more than passing interest.

PAINESVILLE, Ohio, Nov. 7 (AP) -- With United States soldiers mounting on six locomotives and guarding the right of way, the small but important Fairport, Painesville and Eastern Railroad resumed hauling war goods today in the face of a strike by eighty-four men.

JULIAN GREEN has written his first book in English. It is a book of vivid and diversely interesting personal remembrance, from imaginative childhood on into the novelist's maturity. TO hand this morning is a book which should be required reading for any one interested in the global aspects of radio -- not so much in the over-glamorized short-wave wireless but in broadcasting as it is indigenous to the several nations of the world, as it alone has proved the most important single factor in conveying the good and bad to the minds of men wherever they may be.

LEXINGTON, Va., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Turnbull Gillette passed the University of Virginia to a 34-to-7 victory over Washington and Lee today before 4,000 spectators. It was the most one-sided victory for the Cavaliers since the 52-year-old series was renewed in 1922.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Representative Joseph W. Herrick, former regional director of the National Labor Relations Board and now personnel director of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, announced yesterday that the employment of women workers in the company's Todd Erie Basin Dry Docks in Brooklyn had been "highly successful" and that the hiring of women would be extended to Todd Hoboken Dry Docks beginning tomorrow morning.

The City College eleven lost to Moravian by 32 -- 0 at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, completing a scoreless home season.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- America's production drive is more than half way to its goal, Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen, director of production for the War Department, said in a press conference today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Iowa Pre-Flight Seahawks ran into unexpected trouble today when an under-rated squad of Armoraiders from Fort Knox held them to a score of 13 to 7 before 3,000 football fans.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Warren Harding High of Bridgeport, contender for the Connecticut State championship, gained its sixth consecutive victory and handed the White Plains High School Tigers their first defeat in nineteen games with a 34-12 triumph today.

HOLLYWOOD at the moment is undergoing a crisis. Actors and others who earn more than $67,000 a year have had their salaries stopped if they already have been paid that amount, pending word from Washington, where a corps of lawyers is trying to interpret the new laws.

Edward Robinson, an ex-convict, suspected of attacking seventeen persons in the last week after following them from the subway station at Central Park West and Eighty-sixth Street, was arrested yesterday after his latest victim had described him in detail, down to an odd-colored green hat and an ill-fitting windbreaker that he wore.

Although she states positively that the characters in her book are not intended for portraits, it is clear that they are, at the least, quick approximations, and Katrine herself must be one of the three sisters, probably little Cora.

Retail trade was good last week, with election day sales in most stores drawing fairly good consumer response, according to the survey of the test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors and basements were busy.

The mighty Bears will roll into Ebbets Field today in their only local appearance of the year and before dusk they are expected to roll out again with the Dodgers as their twentieth straight victim. The stands should be full when the kick-off comes at 2:15 P.M.
Yesterday was a memorable day for Richard Thomas Johnston, a wounded and gassed veteran of the First World War, who has two sons in the nation's armed forces and a third son facing induction.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 8--Allied Army, Navy and air forces commanded by Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commander of all American forces in the European theatre, have struck a powerful blow to free the Mediterranean from Axis control and knock Italy out of the war.

Two hundred members of the American Women's Voluntary Services Motor Transport Service of Greater New York will take part in twenty tests to prove their qualifications as emergency drivers under wartime conditions today at the site of the New York World's Fair, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Margaret Furst, commander of the service.

Under the honorary patronage of leaders in governmental, diplomatic and civic affairs, an elaborate midnight revue entitled "Cheer China" will be presented Nov. 20 at the Radio City Music Hall as a benefit for United China Relief.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Wake Forest's Deacons, taking control of the play from the opening kick-off, smashed through Virginia Military Institute for a 28-to-0 victory in a Southern Conference game before 6,000 today.

ADVANCED TRAINING CENTER, FLEET MARINE FORCE, NEW RIVER, N.C., Nov. 7 -- These young marines, most of them not yet old enough to vote, are training in the expectation of combat within the next few months. It sharpens their attention as nothing else could.

BECAUSE he cannot well investigate a murder in which his own son is the chief suspect, Captain Woods of the Homicide Bureau sends for his old friend. Private Detective Desmond Shannon, and with Shannon on the case one knows what to expect, for he favors direct action and plenty of it.
It isn't amazing, after all, that the hullabaloodian "Truth or Consequences" broadcast, defying an accepted rule of radio, is enormously popular with a large away-from-the-studio audience.

If time permitted every Army Division should have a year's training in this country before being put into active service, but with our troops already fighting in several fields and casualties occurring from death, disability, illness and accident, the necessity for replacements without delay is absolute and pressing.

The reorganization of the New York City high school curriculum to include pre-induction courses such as radio, meteorology, nutrition and aeronautics was foreseen last week by Professor Nickolaus L. Engelhardt, director of the Division of Field Studies at Teachers College, Columbia University, as being the entering wedge for the replacement or reconstruction of "old-line courses."

William J. Brown, affectionately called Bill by his friends, yesterday authorized the announcement he is resigning from the State Athletic Commission, ending a connection of nine years as an administrator of the amended Walker law under which boxing is conducted in this State.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 7--The German battleships Gneisenau and Scharnhorst are said to have passed through the Kiel Canal on Nov. 4 and 5 on their way to the Baltic Sea.

Sharp Dohme, Inc., manufacturer of pharmaceutical products, reported yesterday for the quarter ended Sept. 30, a net profit of $534,285 after Federal income taxes and $200,000 provision for war contingencies. No provision was required for excess profits tax, the company stated.

NANCY HALE, who possibly shares with Virginia Creed, author of "Voyage of the Heart," the title of Prettiest-Novelist-Now-at-Work, had come early for the appointment and taken off her shoes and drawn up an extra office chair as a resting place for her feet.

Evening-up in advance of tomorrow's estimate of the crop yield by the Department of Agriculture backed the cotton futures market away yesterday from the highs to an irregular close, 2 points lower to 3 points higher than Friday's final prices, with the near months on the New York Cotton Exchange relatively weak.

ALTHOUGH the paid pipers of the forthcoming "I Married a Witch" insist that it reveals a "new" Veronica Lake, that lady on the screen has always seemed, at least to one bemused observer, more phenomenal than human.

RUTLAND, Vt., Nov. 7 -- The United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association launched its twenty-first annual convention today at Meldon School with the knowledge that it faced its most difficult problems since its formation in 1922 at Saranac Lake as a result of the war.

" Swing shift" lounges are the latest innovation in the city's Y.W.C.A. residences. Blacked-out rooms have been set aside in two dormitories, Margaret Louisa and Spelman Hall, so that girls now working late factory shifts may have a bite to eat and a place to read and amuse themselves when they come in from their post-curfew work.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A long list of Allied notables paid tribute today to the grimly fighting Russians on their twenty-fifth anniversary of the Communist revolution.

IN "Not Without Peril," which was published a few seasons ago, Miss Allis recounted the story of Jemima Sartwell, one of the earliest settlers in Vermont and a woman of exceptional fortitude and character. Harried cruelly by the Indians, Jemima endured hardships and perils far beyond the average, and Miss Allis's novel -- which she based on legends, family traditions, half-forgotten records -- was a saga of pioneer heroism remarkable for its integrity and veracity.

CAIRO, Nov. 7 -- After a brief stand at Fuka, sixty miles west of El Alamein, the Axis rear guard continued to retreat rapidly yesterday toward the Egyptian frontier. There appeared to be no prospect that the enemy would try to fight it out at any point in Egypt and such actions as that around Fuka seemed destined merely to keep the retreat from becoming a rout.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 7 -- Lehigh University defeated Muhlenberg today, 22 to 6. The Engineers displayed a powerful offensive to tally three touchdowns, kick 2 points from placement and profit by a safety.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Ohio State and Pittsburgh staged a touchdown marathon today as the high-powered Buckeyes crushed the outmanned Panthers, 59 to 19.

Murder investigations are quite outside Jimmy Jarnegan's regular line of work, but the problem offered him by J. Grant Harwood is so interesting that he cannot bring himself to refuse it. The story as told by Harwood is this: Some unknown enemy has threatened not only to kill Harwood, but first to strike at him through others in such a way as to make him wish that death would come quickly.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- In connection with current military operations in French North Africa, the President has broadcast by radio to the French people:

The 270 automobile graveyards in the city are doing such a good job in converting old cars into scrap metal and moving it on its way to war production that they are beginning to run short of "jalopies," George Sutherland, regional salvage manager of the War Production Board's conservation division, said yesterday.

The manufacture of an army overcoat or service jacket, from the time the cloth is placed on the cutting table to the time the garment is crated and marked for shipment, takes eighteen seconds at the plant of the Tops Overcoat Company, 275 Seventh Avenue, according to Harry Dresher, general manager of the company, and Harry Landen, inspector for the Quartermaster Corps, stationed in the plant. The factory employs 400.
WORD had just been passed that the ship was to return to Pearl Harbor for some vital repairs and the quartermasters and seamen working on the bridge had stopped work to celebrate.
The seventh campaign of North Africa turned suddenly into a swirling, slashing retreat last week as the famous German Afrika Korps, shattered and wounded, tried grimly to escape complete disaster.
Axis forces in the western desert, after twelve days and nights off ceaseless attacks by our land and air forces, now are in full retreat.

The American office of the International Transport Workers Federation last week received word of a strike of dockers and longshoremen in the port of Lisbon, Portugal, late last month, despite the absence of a free Portuguese trade union movement and the strict state supervision of all labor activities.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 7 (AP)--Demonstrating power reminiscent of other days, Duke's Blue Devils roared back from the depths of their worst season in a decade and scored almost at will today in crushing a highly regarded Maryland team, 42-0, before a crowd of 7,500.

On his wedding night George Chance promises his bride that he will give up his favorite sport of solving murder mysteries. Chance is a professional magician, but when he is not pulling rabbits out of hats or performing other feats of legerdemain, he likes to pit his wits against those of the criminal classes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Human nature, supplemented by the services of 1,500 trained investigators, will be sufficient to police the government's current program for the rationing of scarce products to citizens and for the establishment of price ceilings on rents and consumer items, according to opinions expressed by experts both in and out of the government.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 7 (AP) -- By land and by air, and by almost every other conceivable means of offensive striking power, Georgia Tech's rough-riding Engineers breezed on toward an undefeated football campaign today by overwhelming Kentucky's Wildcats, 47 to 7.

HOLLYWOOD has done it again! With "Cry Havoc" it presents its most potent contribution to America's war effort in the legitimate theatre and vindicates the belief that "Meet the People" was not merely a flash in California's dramatic pan but a true, if somewhat intermittent, spark of the old flame.

THE Great Big Bears -- or what's left of them -- will be in Flatbush this afternoon, and what the Dodgers can do about that remains to be seen. Nobody has beaten the Bears in more than a calendar year, though it wasn't for lack of trying.
Those who like to grow plants indoors, and who seek new things that are out of the ordinary and yet really worth while -- not mere curiosities -- will be glad to make the acquaintance of the moreas.

The nation went to the polls last Tuesday in its first wartime midterm election since 1918. As the votes were counted in the following days, a major shift in America's political tide seemed to have set in. The party of President Roosevelt barely retained nominal control over the House of Representatives; its topheavy majority was reduced in the Senate.

More than $100,000,000 is frozen in defunct and liquidating companies because the public does not know that it exists or how to go about getting it, according to Robert D. Fisher, whose new Manual of Valuable Securities will be on the market soon.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Nov. 8 (U.P.)--The announcement of sweeping Allied gains in New Guinea came as a surprise to observers here, although an Australian offensive through mountainous central New Guinea had been making steady progress toward the north coast for the past five weeks.

A large subscription has been reported for the annual card party in aid of the philanthropic work of the Convent of Marie Reparatrix to be held on Thursday afternoon at Sherry's under the auspices of the Ladies Adoration Society, of which Mrs. Frank A. Otis is president and Miss Frances Coleman, secretary.

TRADITIONS of American guerrilla fighters from pioneer times to the present day in China live on in the United States Marine Raider contingent under Lieut. Col. Evans Carlson, which in August carried out a successful attack on Little Makin Island in the Pacific, wiped out a Japanese garrison and destroyed valuable radio and seaplane installations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A new and vastly different Congress is coming to Washington with the beginning of the new year. Tuesday's election drew the blueprints for a national Legislature that promises much less dependence upon the White House for initiative and guidance and greater independence from its directives, but one which, despite campaign warnings, imposes no threat to slacken the war effort.

WHEN Denis Warden had dragged himself home after Lee's surrender he found the house still standing and the fields cultivated. With the help of his mother's foresight he expected to pick up the management of the plantation where his father, who did not return, had left off.

The House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee, by appropriate action, rejected the proposal to place a limitation on earned income of $25,000, after deducting taxes. The committees' consideration of the question, however, was from the viewpoint of whether they should so tax earned income as not to permit an employe to retain an amount in excess of $25,000.

HAVANA, Cuba, Nov. 7 -- The storm which struck Cuba's north coast last night passed through Santa Clara and Camaguey provinces in a southwesterly direction, leaving only minor damage in its wake, and was reported in the Caribbean early this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- En route to this city of brotherly love this morning Coach Steve Owen confidently predicted that his Giants would bob up with a good game one of these afternoons. "I don't know which Sunday it will be," he declared, "but, mark my words, we're overdue."

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The United States and Britain gave assurances today to Portugal and Spain that the United Nations have no ambitions concerning the African territories of these two neutral powers. This word was conveyed officially to the Portuguese and Spanish Governments in simultaneous calls by British and American envoys here and in Madrid.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Federal Court approval yesterday of the reorganization plan for the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway cleared the way for final steps.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Award of the Distinguished Service Medal to six high-ranking officers of the Army for exceptionally meritorious service in the Philippines was made public today by the War Department. Three officers are believed to be prisoners of the Japanese.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Enemy reports this afternoon that the French fleet had sailed from Toulon to fight the British in the Mediterranean caused a flurry of excitement in Britain, which always is most responsive to news of a sea engagement.

A proposal that there shall be three "public alliances popularly supported" in order to insure a just and continuous peace after the war was voiced yesterday morning by the Rev. Merrill C. Johnson at the 11 o'clock service at the Metropolitan-Duane Methodist Church, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

Eleven persons were injured about 2 A.M. yesterday when a Pennsylvania Greyhound bus struck an automobile at Thirty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue and crashed into the Central Fish Market at 527 Ninth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Critics of the United States policy toward Vichy France may now be told that it was all designed to pave the way for this country's invasion of North Africa to help win the war against the Axis and free the French people from German domination, Secretary Hull told an extraordinary press conference today.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The cease fire order given when Algiers capitulated applied to the general Algiers region, including the districts of Maison Carree, Hussein Dey, Maison Blanche and Retour de Chasse, Vichy reports said.

Albert Spalding's only violin recital in the city this season was given last night in Carnegie Hall before a large audience. That his endeavors met with the general approval of his hearers was obvious from the hearty demonstrations, punctuated with cries of "Bravo," which the performances evoked.

Prayers and praise for the men who sail the merchant vessels and fighting ships of the United Nations resounded through the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon at a special service conducted for them by Bishop William T. Manning at the request of all United Nations consuls in New York.

Noting with dissatisfaction that over a period of years the church of Jesus Christ slowly has diminished in power while the State has gained in strength, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, pastor of the Holy Trinity and St. James Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that without a "forceful, practical Christianity" there could be no hope for mankind.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- A firm undertone developed last week in the wheat market with an enlarged volume of business. The surprising showing in last Tuesday's election has revived hopes of wheat traders that when the permanent ceiling price on flour is announced it will give more liberal treatment to farmers so far as the reactionary effect on the cash market is concerned.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Although heavily outweighed, Fort Monmouth's hard - driving football team ripped off long end runs and tore through the line for seven touchdowns and a 46-0 victory over the Lancaster (Pa.) Presidents today at Frawley Field.

Instead of the usual sales approach, Keebler-Wayl Baking Company stresses nourishment value of cookies and biscuits in 400-line advertising now appearing in thirty-six Eastern metropolitan newspapers. Also emphasized are that no preparation or cooking is required and that there is no waste in cookies, crackers and other biscuits.

VICHY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The government of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain broke relations with the United States tonight as the shock forces of a mighty United States expedition entered the French North African city of Algiers and landed elsewhere on the shores of France's empire.

The special feature of yesterday afternoon's concert of the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, under Howard Barlow, in Carnegie Hall, was the superlative performance of the Brahms piano concerto in B flat major, with Artur Rubinstein as soloist.

Will the American business man emerge from the war terse and laconic? The government hopes so. WPB hopes so. Because 600,000 used typewriters are needed for the armed services, the War Production Board has asked the National Office Management Association to show business men how they can make three typewriters do the work of four.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The presence of large American air forces as well as British planes in the combined attack on Morocco and Algeria was indicated by the War Department's announcement today that Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle, leader of the raid on Tokyo, is in command of American air forces in the expedition.
Leon Kushner, 21-year-old New York pianist, made his local debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.
In a statement printed in THE TIMES of Nov. 5 the Gallup poll calls attention to the accuracy of its election predictions.

The mighty Chicago Bears rode roughshod over the Brooklyn Dodgers for a 35-0 victory before 31,643 entranced spectators at Ebbets Field yesterday and thus increased their string of triumphs to twenty in a row. There was nothing to it. The Monsters from the Midway scored twice in the first period and once in each of the others, never giving the battered Brooks a chance to take a deep breath.

Alexander Werth, war correspondent of The Sunday Times of London, relates in an article cited in the Nov. 4 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES about alleged atrocities committed by Finns in Yasnaya Polyana during the German occupation of the village.

The unqualified cooperation of the 6,000,000 members of the American Federation of Labor was pledged to the Navy's fighting forces yesterday by William Green, A.F. of L. president, in a "Labor for Victory" broadcast over the National Broadcasting System.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The new 35,000-ton French battleship Jean Bart and four French submarines have been hit by Allied dive-bombers and two Allied destroyers have been sunk in air and naval fighting raging off French Morocco, a Vichy report broadcast by the Berlin radio said tonight. Three waves of United States bombers dropped from 200 to 300 bombs in the Casablanca area, starting fires around the harbor and docks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- As Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Vichy's Chief of State, rejected President Roosevelt's explanation of the American invasion of French North Africa and announced he had rallied his empire to defend itself, the White House disclosed today that the President had appealed to the leaders of Spain and Portugal to remain neutral, promising that American operations in the Mediterranean or Eastern Atlantic area did not threaten their security or territory.

The news that United States forces had landed in French North domestic Africa gave American and short-wave radio stations the busiest twenty-four hours they have known since Pearl Harbor. Network and local stations were still breaking into commercial and sustaining programs yesterday at frequent intervals with news bulletins and comment.

ADVANCED TRAINING CENTER, FLEET MARINE FORCE, New River, N.C., Nov. 8 -- No matter what glamorous explanation a young man may give for volunteering to be a Paramarine, there comes a moment in his training when he is invited for the first time to put his trust in the parachute packed on his back, and take a flat dive out the side door of a plane.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Slingin' Sammy Baugh pitched three touchdown passes as the fast-stepping Washington Redskins rolled over the Chicago Cardinals, 28 to 0, today before 35,425 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said tonight that the Senate's amendment to the teen-age draft bill prohibiting the use of men under 20 in combat outside the United States until after a year's training would weaken the Army, prolong the war and increase the toll in American lives.

Starting today and continuing through Friday, the New York City school system is holding its annual open school week. Parents and citizens are invited to visit the classrooms, to see the innovations that have been introduced during the past year, to observe present-day education in action.

Declaring that the United States "has become totalitarian at home to defeat totalitarianism abroad," the Rev. Matthew J. Toohey, national chaplain of the Catholic War Veterans preaching yesterday at the eighth annual armistice memorial mass of the organization in St. Patrick's Cathedral, expressed the hope that "it will not take a bloodless revolution" to regain the rights yielded to the government in the interest of an all-out war effort.

Alumni and alumnae committees representing Yale University and Sarah Lawrence College, respectively, are arranging a benefit concert to be given by the Yale Glee Club and Sarah Lawrence College Chorus on the night of Dec. 5 at the Town Hall.
AT UNITED STATES HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Allied High Command reported today there were no material changes in the military situation in New Guinea yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 8 (UP) -- American forces now landing by the thousand in scattered areas of North Africa carry booklets warning them against talking with Moslem women, because the fate of the entire campaign may depend on their conduct in this respect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of seventy-eight American civilians, including eleven from New York, four from New Jersey, and one from Connecticut, interned by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands. Information at hand does not disclose their exact whereabouts.

Our new second front in North Africa will result in conquest of the Mediterranean, opening a side door to Germany and giving us the shortest possible supply route to Southern Russia, Vice President Henry A. Wallace said yesterday afternoon at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden bringing to a close the Congress of American Soviet Friendship.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Demand for hog products continues in excess of the available supply, packers report, and in some cases allocation of products has been necessary to give buyers part of their requirements. Some of the local chain stores ran out of supplies of vegetable shortening last week, forcing users to turn to lard, and offerings of the latter were relatively small.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 111.7 on Oct. 27. This compares with 112.3 a fortnight before, 112.8 a month before, 107.2 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

The news from Africa should not obscure the success of General MacArthur's drive to expel the Japanese from Papua. With the sole exception of two enemy beachheads at Buna and Gona, the eastern peninsula of New Guinea has now been reclaimed by Allied forces.

We believe that history will say that on Nov. 7 the blow was struck that marked the turning point in this war and the beginning of the great offensive against the Axis Powers. This is not too high a valuation to place on the operations which an American expeditionary army, supported by British naval and air forces, has launched in North Africa.

A firm undertone continued to mark the business in the Canadian dollar last week. While business was of fair proportions, the buying carried the dollar from 87.75 cents at the opening to 88.56 cents on Thursday. Later liquidation set the price back at the week's close to 87.93 cents, a gain of 1/16 cent over the preceding week.

The Equity Corporation reported yesterday that on Sept. 30 its net assets were equivalent to $46.11 a share on the $3 convertible preferred stock, entitled to $50 a share and accumulated dividends in liquidation. This compares with $40.69 for each preferred share on June 30, last, and $63.86 a preferred share on Sept. 30, 1941.

An anonymous gift of $1,000 was listed yesterday by Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger as the first contribution to the Girl Scout War Emergency Fund. Mrs. Sulzberger is general chairman of the campaign to raise the fund to $194,500.
Following are excerpts from Adolf Hitler's speech at Munich yesterday on the occasion of the National Socialist Party Commemoration Day as transcribed and translated by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A constant struggle against the cruelties of German and Bulgarian authorities is in progress in occupied Greece, the Greek Office of Information said here today.
