While guerrillas battle the enemy in the northern mountains, farther south in the heart of Macedonia peasants and workers are being driven from their homes by Bulgarian persecutions, the statement declared.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- American forces in the Solomon Islands damaged a Japanese cruiser and two destroyers in forays yesterday (Solomons Date), and two of the ships were hit so effectively that they may have gone down, the Navy reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Dr. J. Paul Leonard has been appointed chief of the group services branch of the Office of Price Administration in a reorganization of the OPA Department of Information by Robert W. Horton, deputy administrator in charge of the department, and Robert Ware Straus, it was disclosed today.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Fred A. McGlone of Roxbury, Mass., who ran his first distance race to win a bet and who would rather play golf than run, annexed the National A.A.U. marathon championship by finishing first in the historic Yonkers marathon today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The National Symphony Orchestra this afternoon opened its twelfth season, giving the first Washington performance of Shostakovich's new Seventh Symphony before a large audience sprinkled with uniforms, including some of the Red Army.

The concert of the New Friends of Music presented late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall was devoted to works by Bach and Haydn, and enlisted the services of the Musical Art Quartet; Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichord, and John Wummer, flute.

Russian War Relief has a Volunteer Service Department, which may interest New Yorkers who are anxious to contribute to the war effort but do not know how or where to offer their services. We are especially busy right now and require all the assistance we can get to help us wind up our extensive campaign program for this year.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The United States threw the full weight of its new and elite armed forces against nearly a dozen points of French North Africa today in a magnificently timed offensive.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- Recovering from nine wounds received during a Japanese raid in the Solomons, Lieut. Comdr. William M. Johnston, a Navy medical officer, warned here today that malaria, "the greatest disabling disease in that area," was likely to be increasingly "tough" on American troops in the Southwest Pacific during the coming months.

James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Board of War Communications, performed a valuable service with his letter published in THE TIMES of Nov. 1, explaining the rationale, of the new priority system which the board has set up for long-distance telephone communication.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The opening in Africa of a new American fighting front intensified today preparation for a showdown vote in the House on whether inductees of 18 and 19 may be used in combat without a full year of training at home.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 8 -- "Enfin!" (At last!) was the general feeling in France, according to reports received here today, when news came of American landings in North Africa.

MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Repeated German attacks in the critical Caucasus area southeast of Nalchik were thrown back by the Russians yesterday with serious losses for the enemy while Red Amy troops beat off German assaults in the Stalingrad and Tuapse sectors, the Soviet Command announced early today.

BOSTON COLLEGE, Georgia and Georgia Tech, apparently the Big Three of 1942, went rolling ahead in Saturday's scrimmaging, but there were operations in other sectors that threw great crowds into utter confusion.

As a result of the stability in commodity prices induced by price ceilings, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at 108.4 last week. However, certain price increases occurred which were not reflected in the index, which were in effect, evasions of price regulations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's letter to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, handed to the Vichy Chief of State as the North African operations began:

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Emerging from behind the curtain that has hidden his movements since his escape from Vichy several months ago, General Henri Honore Giraud, French hero of the first and second World Wars, made a dramatic appeal over the radio today for the French forces in North Africa to rally around him in support of "this unexpected opportunity" for the recovery of France offered by the American landings in French territories.
The first invasion of the North African coast by American forces dates back 138 years to the early days of the history of the United States.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Spain and Portugal were reassured by the British Government today they had nothing to fear from the Allied North African campaign so far as their territories or trade were concerned; indeed, the British remarked that their trade might prosper once the Nazi menace was removed.

DETROIT, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Pittsburgh, surprise club of the National Football League, gained its fifth victory in six starts by handing the Lions their eighth successive defeat, 35 to 7, before 16,679 spectators today at Briggs Stadium.
BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 8 -- A notable victory was scored today by the golden retriever dog Stillrovin Super Speed, owned by Lieutenant Paul Bakewell 3d, U.S.N.R. of St. Louis.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 -- Colonel Samuel Harden Church, president of Carnegie Institute, announced today his resignation as honorary chairman of the Committee of Christians and Jews established to organize a Jewish army of refugees in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- American doughboys in French Africa launched their invasion in the knowledge that "the hopes and prayers of America" sailed with them, in the words of General George C. Marshall, chief of staff.
The duck population in the Illinois River Valley has zoomed in the past week, according to the latest report by Frank C. Bellrose Jr., Illinois Natural History Survey game technician.

Every year the Postoffice Department has to issue an appeal for the early mailing of Christmas gifts, cards and letters. If anybody has come to regard this as a matter of routine he must know that this year it is a matter of extreme necessity. The coming Christmas absentees from the family board will be incomparably more numerous than ever before.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Official London, as well as the unofficial public, grasped eagerly today for every scrap of information available about the progress of the American expeditionary force in French North Africa in its part of the great battle for the control of the Mediterranean.

VICHY, Nov. 8 -- Another measure to foster thrift and thereby stabilize the capital created by State expenditures in excess of the budgetary receipts has been ordered in such a way as to combat monetary inflation.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 8 (AP) -- The University of Scranton Tomcats cashed in on two quick scoring drives for a 13 -- 6 victory over Fort Totten today, with all the scoring confined to the final quarter.

VICHY, Nov. 8 -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France dated Oct. 8 shows no important change in the credits accorded the securities market. Bills discounted increased 420,000,000 francs. Advances to the State did not vary to any notable degree, for ordinary advances decreased 450,000,000 francs, while advances for the costs of German occupation increased 163,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Issuing geographical and historical descriptions of Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia, the National Geographic Society today pointed out that French Morocco, larger by 19,000 square miles than France herself, composes the bulk of the Sultanate of Morocco, which includes also Spanish Morocco and the International Zone of Tangier, on the Strait of Gibraltar.

Despite the criticism, sometimes heard, that too many doctors and nurses are being called from their civilian practice to military posts, there is no waste of medical personnel in the armed services, Rear Admiral Ross T. McIntire, Surgeon General of the Navy, said yesterday in an address broadcast at Washington.

LIVERPOOL, England, Nov. 8 -- After passing another busy day, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a radio broadcast to the people of Great Britain tonight, called on all women who were helping to win the war, to go on working and sacrificing afterward to win the peace.

The annual "O. Henry Memorial Award Prize Stories" volume will be out on Friday (Doubleday, Doran) edited for the second year by Herschel Brickell The judges this year for the several awards that are made with the publication of the book were Joseph Henry Jackson, literary editor of The San Francisco Chronicle; Amy Loveman, associate editor of The Saturday Review of Literature, and Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings, novelist.
The text of Vice President Wallace's address before the Congress of American Soviet Friendship at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon follows:

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, -- American infantry is now in New Guinea. Some of the troops came by air -- the first American doughboys ever to be taken to field combat by this most modern method of military traunsportation. For many boys it was their first airplane ride, and they ate it up.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Corn assumed last week the leadership in the grain markets, prices advancing 4 1/4 cents a bushel on December from the early low, and the close yesterday on the Board of Trade here was at the top with the market in the highest ground since early in October.

It now is regarded as a certainty that Rowland Stebbins will be associated with the Playwrights Company in the production of "Thomas Jefferson," Sidney Kingsley's new play. This will be the first time an outsider has been associated formally with the Playwrights, and it will be the first production of a script by a non-member.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The invasion of French North African ports by United States forces, assisted by "lack of resistance" on the part of French colonial troops, is "advancing rapidly," the War Department announced tonight in a communique issued here.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 8 -- Renewed encouragement by Senator Bankhead to farmers to hold their cotton for 22 cents a pound, official figures showing a large amount of the staple going into the loan and the favorable Egyptian war events combined last week to give cotton futures here a thoroughly bullish tone.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Canisius College closed its 1942 football season today with a 47-to-7 victory over the Fort Hamilton soldier eleven before 6,891 spectators. The quarters in the game were reduced from regulation fifteen minutes to twelve.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 8 -- News of the American landings in French North Africa was communicated to the Italian people about 2 o'clock this afternoon. Reports from Rome Indicate that it caused a wave of "stupefied pessimism" which late tonight was being "eradicated" by a succession of radio speakers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 8 -- Conscious for the first time of the full significance of their westward drive, British Eighth Army forces continued today to pursue the fleeing Axis Africa Corps toward the Libyan border. Details of today's progress are not yet available, but yesterday the British advanced forces were well over half way from El Alamein to the frontier.

Large numbers of buyers were in the market last week, many of them replenishing goods bought for the holiday season as well as making initial commitments for Spring apparel, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
Algiers, Oran and Casablanca, three of the main bastions of the French North African empire, are busy metropolitan cities with good harbors and excellent rail connections.

A joint proposal for merger of the Central Congregational Church at 25 Hancock Street, near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, and the Clifton Avenue Community Church, at Lafayette Avenue, also in Brooklyn, was announced at the morning services of the two churches yesterday.
MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A Soviet Bureau of Information communique:
Washington, Nov. 8 -- The text of the Navy communique, No. 186:

BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Episcopal Bishop of Massachusetts, today announced the election of the Rev. William R. Brewster, at present rector of All Saints Church, Belmont, as headmaster of St. Mark's School, Southboro.
CAIRO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

Some of the strange and unfamiliar furnishings of wartime life are far from attractive, but many of them (products of priority in priority packages) some definitely under the heading of pleasant surprises. Exhibit A is a paperboard bandbox in white-and-lilac candy-stripes, with a trio of lilac-labeled bottles stowed snugly inside.

An immeasurable stiffening of French morale and determination to resist the Germans will result from the United States invasion of the North African colonies of France, in the opinion of Andre Philip, National Commissioner of the Interior and Labor of the Fighting French National Committee.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- The Liberty ship Will Rogers was launched here today with champagne, a victory for tradition over prohibition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A War Department communique:

CLEVELAND, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Warming up for their desperate effort to catch the Bears next week, the Packers tallied twice in the last two minutes today for a 30-to-12 triumph over the surprisingly stubborn Rams. Unstoppable Don Hutson snared three touchdown passes and place-kicked three extra markers to set a new National Football League season scoring record, 103 points.

Following victoriously in the footsteps of her owner's famed imported Pekingese Ch. Che Le of Matson's Catawba Mrs. James M. Austin's attractive American-bred white top poodle Ch. Karitena de Muriclar took top honors last night in the Progressive Dog Club's toys breeds' exhibition at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The first national convention of the fur industry will be held next Monday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, according to an announcement for publication today by Walter H. Pringle, chairman of the organization committee. He indicated the sessions would probably continue through Tuesday.

It was not until long after last week's financial markets closed that news of the American invasion of French North Africa was received. The week began with recovery, reflecting military reports from the Far East, which proved that at the very moment when Washington was gloomiest, a week before, our Pacific fleet was driving back the Japanese with heavy losses.

Completing his schedule of twelve games at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday with a victory over Albert C. Martin of Providence, R.I., in seventy-three moves and an equally well-contested draw with Irving Heitner of Philadelphia in sixty-eight, Edward S. Jackson Jr. was declared to be the first amateur chess champion of America by L. Walter Stephens, vice president of the United States Chess Federation.

MONTREAL, Nov. 8 -- The Montreal Canadiens tonight turned back the New York Rangers, 10 -- 4, in a fast-moving National Hockey League game. Despite the high score, the Rangers put up a stiff struggle against the Flying Frenchmen but could not pierce the heavy defenses in Montreal territory. A crowd of 10,364 attended.
Increasing use of profanity by men in public life and in the armed forces was condemned in two New York City pulpits yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering a rule to provide that the 10 per cent excess profits tax refund written into the 1942 Revenue Act be shown in net income of financial statements of companies required to file with the commission, it was learned yesterday.
Six films will have Broadway premieres during the week. The schedule follows:

VICHY, France, Nov. 8 -- "Owing to American participation in the attack on French North Africa," diplomatic relations were considered severed with the United States, it was announced this afternoon. This decision was taken at a Cabinet meeting.

Japanese and Chinese may be taught in the city's high schools if enough students show a desire to master these tongues, to play their part as members of a post-war army of reconstruction, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 8 -- Eager American combat teams swept ashore on the beaches near Algiers and Oran today, capturing three airfields against confused resistance and penetrating "swiftly into the interior" from several beachheads.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The French of North Africa were called to arms tonight by General Charles de Gaulle, broadcasting from here, in words stronger than any he has used since 1940. The firmness of his tone came as a surprise even to his closest followers, who thought he might be cautious since it was the first time he has asked his countrymen to come out in open revolt against the Vichy regime.

An exhibition of several hundred nurses' caps, including the frilled and pleated bonnet that started the custom in America, was opened yesterday in connection with the sixty-fourth annual United Hospital campaign for $1,383,729 for seventy-six voluntary, nonprofit hospitals of the city.

With productive capacity geared to the highest level in history, the United States will emerge from this war equipped to provide adequate minimum living standards for every one in this country "with ease," according to a report made public today by the Twentieth Century Fund.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Office of War Information today ordered further cuts for the duration of the war in what it termed nonessential information issued by government agencies.
Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin has returned from Les Alouettes, her Summer home in Southampton, L.I., and is at Mayfair House for the Winter.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Speaking at exercises celebrating the 106th year of Mount Holyoke College's founding, President Ada L. Comstock of Radcliffe College said today that the opportunities and scope and seriousness of women's new responsibilities had hardly been realized.

Let me preface these remarks by saying that I have yet to hear one actor complain about being forced to live on $25,000 a year or less, and this includes such players as Charles Boyer, Spencer Tracy, James Cagney and others.

VICHY, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- American troops swarmed ashore along broad reaches of French Algeria today under a canopy of Allied air and sea bombardment and, despite vigorous resistance, established footholds around all the key defense bases of the North African colony, official announcements said.

The changed significance of Armistice Day, the high cost to be paid for the next peace, the need for a more courageous outlook and various aspects of the holiday marking the end of the first World War were cited in sermons preached in New York City yesterday.

That despairing wail heard as Wisconsin was stopped a foot short of the tying touchdown against Iowa, and echoed as Pennsylvania and Minnesota failed by a yard to save themselves against Navy and Indiana, was the last feeble protest of the fancier of football form going down for the third time.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Marquette University, paced by its sensational sophomore, Johnny Strzykalski, who made a 93-yard touchdown run, crushed Manhattan College, 27 to 12, before a homecoming crowd of 14,000 football fans today.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8 (AP) -- New Jersey's 28,000 public school teachers gave the executive committee of their State Education Association authority today to decide whether any more conventions should be held for the duration of the war.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 -- Steel ingot output last week dropped fractionally to 100 per cent of rated capacity and indications are that the same amount of steel will be made this week. Furnace repairs were responsible for the slightly lower level.

Highly advertised wartime wages being paid workers in some war plants are making it more and more difficult to induce inexperienced and unskilled young New Yorkers in the 16-to-21-year-old group to accept jobs that do not guarantee a large weekly pay check, Richard C. Brockway, State director of the United States Employment Service, disclosed yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Detroit regained sole possession of the National Hockey League leadership tonight by playing Chicago to a 3-to-3 overtime tie before 12,471 spectators. Robert (Red) Hamill scored all three goals for the Black Hawks.
The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation announced yesterday the award of twenty fellowships in its thirteenth annual Latin-American competition.

Under more aggressive trade price-fixing, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced last week to their best levels since mid-September. At the end of trading on Saturday active futures contracts showed net gains of 25 to 35 points, or $1.25 to $1.75 a bale, for the period, despite profit-taking which had pared the higher gains in the early part of the week.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- For the past month the British press has been carrying reports of the big new "comb-out" of women that the government will undertake in order to replace men hitherto exempt who are about to be called into service.

RUTLAND, Vt., Nov. 8 -- The importance of recreational and junior skiing during wartime was stressed today as the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association concluded its twenty-first annual convention at the Meldon School.
The United Nations moved to the strategic offensive in the west yesterday as American troops in large numbers landed on the coasts of the French North African colonies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Office of War Information today issued some suggestions about Thanksgiving eating in the light of the fact that a voluntary share-the-meat program of 2 1/2 pounds a week will be in effect by that time.

Continuing his controversy with the New York Telephone Company over its alleged failure to cooperate in his crusade against professional gambling, Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday, in his weekly radio "Talk to the People," a list of forty-five telephone numbers in Manhattan said by the Police Department to be those of race track and other gambling "wire rooms" in near-by New Jersey communities.

The American people are experiencing a profound spiritual renaissance as a consequence of the impacts and sacrifices of war, a renaissance that will affect the future not only of this country but of the entire world, Governor Lehman declared last night in an address before a conference of 600 rabbis and laymen representing congregations from many parts of the country assembled at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 3080 Broadway.

Three guards at the Navy yard in Brooklyn, one of them a dismissed city policeman, who systematically looted a warehouse there of precision tools worth "at least $25,000," were rounded up by detectives of the safe and loft squad yesterday after they had stumbled on the trail of one of them accidentally.

Toscanini performed a new Russian symphony, the Second, by Dmitri Kabalevsky, at the concert given with the NBC Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Radio City. The symphony made an excellent impression, not only because the writing is fresh, enthusiastic and expert, but also for the very fact that no great hullabaloo was made about it in advance of its American premiere.

"ANOTHER student in the hurly-burly of delivering an infant had inadvertently allowed it to slip off his lap and slide to the floor. In some embarrassment he retrieved it, only to have the same thing happen again. The husband, who was standing by, expressed marked disapproval; but the student was equal to the occasion and, smiling brightly, he said, 'Sometimes we have to drop them as many as three times to start them breathing properly.'"

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 8 -- It is considered certain here that actual operations in French North Africa have not modified views entertained there for many months. They were summarized in the remark by a Frenchwoman uttered aloud in a railroad car: "The question is very simple: we become either Germans or Americans."

Janet Bush of Montclair, N.J., who was a mezzo-contralto at her debut and a contralto at her second appearance last January, last night gave her third Town Hall recital. She appeared as a mezzo-soprano.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Further increasing Axis supply difficulties in the Middle East, large formations of big British bombers gave Genoa, Italy's great naval base and arms center from which reinforcements and equipment are sent to Marshal Erwin Rommel, its heaviest battering of the war last night and early today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Nov. 9 -- Algiers, capital of French North Africa, capitulated to American forces shortly before 10 o'clock last night, according to an official communique from Vichy, received here shortly after midnight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 8 -- Addressing a gathering of National Socialist party veterans in Munich today on the anniversary of his abortive beer hall Putsch nineteen years ago, Reichsfuehrer Hitler declared that in due time Germany would strike a counterblow against the United States Army landings in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it had amended its service-price regulation to conform to the provisions of the tire-rationing regulations covering inspection of tires and removal of tires incident to inspection.

Miss Mary E. Dillon of Brooklyn, president and board chairman of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company, was named by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to succeed William R. Crowley of Brooklyn as a member of the Board of Education, to serve until 1946. Mr. Crowley resigned last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 31 were 239,266,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of Interior. This represented an increase of 1,280,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 1,293,000 barrels in domestic stocks and a decrease of 13,000 in foreign stocks.

OTTAWA, Ont., NOV. 8 -- In a statement issued to the press this evening Prime Minister Mackenzie King conveyed the impression that he would take no step to break off diplomatic relations with the Vichy Government and that any action that might be taken would depend on the decision of Pierre Laval and the pressure exercised by Berlin.

The critical shortage of physicians in war production areas is creating "a situation that contains within it all the makings of a national calamity," and constitutes "a very grave peril to the whole national war effort," the New York Physicians Forum warned yesterday in an open letter to Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -- Columbia has signed Zoltan Korda, brother of Alexander Korda, and director of his United Artists productions, "The Four Feathers," "Drums," "The Thief of Bagdad" and "The Jungle Book," to direct a newly scheduled Melvyn Douglas vehicle, "Sahara," which will deal with the present Libyan campaign by the United Nations against General Rommel.
VICHY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A Ministry of Information communique:

The average overweight woman is digging unnecessarily into the country's food supplies and constitutes a national health problem "of the first order," health authorities of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company assert in their current Statistical Bulletin.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 8 -- Addressing a gathering of National Socialist party veterans in Munich today on the anniversary of his abortive beer hall Putsch nineteen years ago, Reichsfuehrer Hitler declared that in due time Germany would strike a counterblow against the United States Army landings in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it had amended its service-price regulation to conform to the provisions of the tire-rationing regulations covering inspection of tires and removal of tires incident to inspection.

Miss Mary E. Dillon of Brooklyn, president and board chairman of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company, was named by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to succeed William R. Crowley of Brooklyn as a member of the Board of Education, to serve until 1946. Mr. Crowley resigned last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 31 were 239,266,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of Interior. This represented an increase of 1,280,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 1,293,000 barrels in domestic stocks and a decrease of 13,000 in foreign stocks.

OTTAWA, Ont., NOV. 8 -- In a statement issued to the press this evening Prime Minister Mackenzie King conveyed the impression that he would take no step to break off diplomatic relations with the Vichy Government and that any action that might be taken would depend on the decision of Pierre Laval and the pressure exercised by Berlin.

The critical shortage of physicians in war production areas is creating "a situation that contains within it all the makings of a national calamity," and constitutes "a very grave peril to the whole national war effort," the New York Physicians Forum warned yesterday in an open letter to Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 9 -- In all France today it may be said that there are only two topics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Efforts of the National Labor Relations Board to condemn the San Antonio Express for alleged failure to bargain collectively with the American Newspaper Guild were lost when the Supreme Court refused today to review a board appeal from a lower court ruling.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Early declines in the hog market, ranging from 10 to 15 cents a hundred pounds were extended to as much as 35 cents in late trading today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- It begins to look as if the whereabouts of the 3,500,000 pairs of nylon hosiery brought into the publicity spotlight by OPA the latter part of October would remain an unsolved trade mystery.

The opening next Monday of the nation-wide campaign for the collection of used silk and nylon stockings will give American women a chance to make one of their most important contributions to the War Production Board's salvage drive, but for most women, young and old, a new incentive was added to the campaign yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 9 -- Official Vichy French quarters continued throughout the day to reveal piecemeal developments in North Africa to the local population. Little, however, was said of American successes, which were minimized as and when they were announced. "Considerable French losses" in Casablanca and Port Lyautey, where the local garrisons were said to be still holding out "in face of overwhelming odds," were emphasized.
The extraconstitutional limitation of salaries to $25,000 seems to have been the result of a refusal by labor leaders to consent to wage restriction on any other terms.

The good fortune of Daniel (Lucky Dan) Mahoney seemingly continued yesterday in General Sessions. Because court records in Washington were destroyed in a fire nearly thirty years ago, Judge Jonah J. Goldstein had to sentence him to Sing Sing as a first offender,

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Describing the case as one of the most flagrant it had uncovered, the War Production Board today prohibited N. Pashelinsky Sons, Jersey City scrap metal dealers, permanently from purchasing, processing or selling any metal, in scrap or other form. The order applies to metals appearing in WPB's metals list of priorities regulation No. 11 and includes all strategic metals.

From the headquarters of General Eisenhower in North Africa comes the dramatic announcement that General Henri Giraud, hero of two World Wars, has arrived in Algeria and that he will organize there a French North African Army "to take up arms side by side with the forces of the United Nations for the defeat of Germany and Italy and the liberation of France and her empire."

By its vote yesterday refusing to endorse the Senate proposal that 18 and 19 year old draftees must be given one year's training before being sent to combat outside continental United States the House of Representatives gave expression to confidence in our Army and its leaders.
KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Albert W. Hawkes will quit his $100,000-a-year job as president of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., to become United States Senator from New Jersey at $10,000 annually.

Now it develops that a while ago the steward of a haughty hotel on the East Side presented to a knowing herbalist a sample of a French seasoning called les quatre epices. He asked the specialist to copy the compound as best he could.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A war Department communique (235) issued at 5:30 P. M.:

With trading on the Stock Exchange the heaviest this year, the stock market developed yesterday into a barometer of postwar prospects. Elated by the American successes in North Africa, buyers centered their activity on issues thought most likely to benefit by an early peace, while the so-called war shares were sold in fairly heavy volume.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- Beardsley Ruml, author of the pay-as-you-go income tax plan, said today that with 27,000,000 Americans paying the Federal income levy, the tax debt owed the government had become a national danger.

Substantial improvement in the unemployment situation in this city as a result of increased allocation of war contracts to New York manufacturers since July was reported yesterday at a conference of Army and Navy procurement officials, attended by Governor Lehman, Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti and Mayor La Guardia, in the office of Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, 11 West Forty-second Street.

LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- An Admiralty announcement said today: For five days and nights His Majesty's ships recently fought off repeated and determined attacks by a concentration of U-boats which chased a big convoy in the Northern Atlantic.
Motor vehicle commissioners of several States were concerned yesterday over the possibility that the Federal Government might take over control of such transportation from the States.

Members of the Dramatists Guild were paid the aggregate sum of $1,274,750 by Hollywood for the screen rights to twenty plays sold for the year ended Sept. 1. This was disclosed yesterday afternoon by Sidney R. Fleisher, negotiator, in his report at the annual meeting of the guild held at the Music Box.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 9 -- Americans in Vichy -- diplomats and newspaper correspondents -- will probably leave tomorrow for Chatelguyon, a watering resort some twenty miles to the south, where they will remain until negotiations are completed for exchange with French diplomats and journalists in the United States.

The resignation of Dr. Samuel Harden Church, president of Carnegie Institute, as honorary chairman of the Committee for a Jewish Army of Stateless and Palestinian Jews, will be submitted to the executive committee for action, Gabriel Wechsler, national secretary, said here yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 -- Judge Arthur F. Lederle signed an order in United States District Court today directing the Republic Steel Corporation to show cause why the Federal Government should not take over its plant at Monroe, Mich., under the War Powers Act.

Relics of early American wars, including fifty-two antique cannon and other guns and a six-ton steel ram, were added to the metal scrap pile at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday after they had been moved from conspicuous places they had occupied for many years.

H.M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, and Charles Einfeld, director of advertising and publicity of the company, arrived from the Coast yesterday to confer with home office officials and to interview technicians, editors, cameramen and other personnel for the forthcoming Warner newsreel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee introduced legislation today designed to give President Roosevelt the authority he requested to suspend for the duration all existing laws interfering with the free movement of persons, property or information in or out of the country.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 9 -- The presence of General Henri Honore Giraud in North Africa and the fact that he is taking command of the Fighting French forces there is being concealed from the French.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Office of Price Administration today cut 10 per cent from the civilian beef quota for the Oct. 1-Dec. 31 period to bring the supply for the armed forces and lend-lease up to requirements not now being met.

The Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries showed a net profit for the nine months ended with September of $9,244,080 after all charges, including $4,097,558 provision for Federal taxes on income, according to the report issued for publication today.

Eddie Katz, who will be 21 on Nov. 25, plays the violin with the luscious tone, assured technique and temperament to be expected from a talented instrumentalist of his age. In his New York debut at the Town Hall last night he proved that he belongs to the ever-expanding group of young Americans who have an abundance of mechanical aptitude for the instruments they espouse.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The Admiralty announced today that warships escorting a recent convoy across the North Atlantic sank two German submarines and probably damaged several others during a clash that lasted five days and nights when an enemy submarine pack made repeated attempts to attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President Roosevelt announced today that American military, food and industrial aid to the British Army in Egypt totaled $636,952,000 in the nineteen months ended Oct. 1, and included the shipment of more than 1,000 airplanes and "many hundreds of tanks, of which more than 500 were mediums."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, as announced by the Federal Reserve System today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 4:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- France and the United States formally severed diplomatic relations today, but neither country moved immediately to declare war as a result of the American Army campaign in French North Africa. Gaston Henry-Haye, the Ambassador of Vichy France, received his passport this afternoon.

LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Harold Keates Hales, 74 years old, British merchant, writer and donor of the transatlantic speed crossing trophy, is missing and believed drowned, it was said today. His overturned dinghy was found near Shepperton-on-Thames last Saturday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- In a statement read in Federal court today Mrs. Erna Haupt, mother of Herbert Hans Haupt, executed Nazi saboteur, admitted that she knew he had returned from Germany on a submarine. She and her husband and two other couples are on trial on charges of treason.

PANAMA, Nov. 9 -- Virtually every country in Latin America, with the exception of Argentina and Chile, is likely to follow the United States in severance of diplomatic relations with the Vichy government. Some may be deterred temporarily until the safety of their representatives in France is determined.

The New York Chapter of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization of America, has sold $1,018,500 in war bonds and stamps in the last year, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Abraham Tulin, chairman of the chapter's American affairs committee.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The stimulating war news gave brokers their busiest Monday in a long time. The markets opened with a burst of strength, the strongest sections being the Kaffirs, oils and industrials. Later a slight reaction took place on profit-taking.

Mrs. Arthur Stone Lord of Washington, formerly of New York, a former president of the Masters School Day Nursery, will preside at the annual luncheon in behalf of the nursery to be given today in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

TAMPA Fla., Nov. 9 -- George B. Howell, president of the Tampa Shipbuilding Company, testified in Circuit Court here today that a walkout of thousands of workers would have resulted if his company had not signed a closed-shop employment contract with labor unions last year.

The first program of the season by the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, was a fitting memorial to Emanuel Feuermann, the master 'cellist, whose untimely taking off constituted an irremediable tragedy to his art and to all those whose lives were touched by his.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 9 -- The Danish Government headed by Premier Buhl has had to yield to German pressure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Senator Tom Connally of Texas, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, told the Senate today that the Vichy Government had gone far beyond the terms of its armistice with Germany. In a message to the French people he said the United States coveted no French territory.
CAIRO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A communique of British General Headquarters and the Royal Air Force:

The prospects for an early reorganization of the $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric system brightened considerably yesterday when trustees in reorganization of the top-holding concerns in the system filed with the Federal Court here a compromise proposal designed to terminate involved litigation over the so-called "recap" plan, which to date has been a major obstacle to reorganization.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 9 -- Cloud, a black Labrador dog owned and handled by Mrs. Foye F. Staniford of Cedarhurst, today won the derby stake, first event in the two-day field-trial meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club, held on the estate of Charles Lawrance.

Urging the deferment of all college students until next June, representatives of the American Association of University Professors in the New York City colleges adopted a resolution yesterday calling for a "careful study of transitional arrangements for full utilization of colleges in the war effort."

A substantial volume of Spring orders was booked yesterday by twenty manufacturers of quality footwear, who displayed their lines at the Hotel Vanderbilt and in their sales offices here. Since the buying pressure on these manufacturers, who generally produce lines retailing at $8.95 and up, is not as great as on the makers of low and medium price models, they were somewhat more liberal in accepting Spring business than other manufacturers.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain called in Chief of Government Pierre Laval and other Vichy leaders in a series of hasty conferences today in an effort to determine quickly unoccupied France's position in the international picture as a result of the French North African campaign.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 9 -- The American and British successes in Africa will certainly affect the Indian situation and their progress is being watched with the keenest interest. It is generally agreed that the All-India Congress party's intransigeance at the time of Sir Stafford Cripps's mission was partly due to a feeling of defeatism on the part of some Indian leaders.

The six-story thirty-six family apartment house at 1452 Fifty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Trustees Series B K to Leomet, Inc. It is assessed for $110,000. The Lawyers Title Corporation of New York issued the title insurance.

The Yank, a giant sixty-petaled ruby red rose, was named yesterday for the boys in the service. The ceremony, held beneath an American flag made up of 1,600 roses, took place at the first National Rose Show in New York, which was held under the auspices of the Roses, Inc., in cooperation with the New York Florists Club in the main lobby of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- Allied forces in New Guinea have advanced seven miles and enveloped a Japanese position at Gorari, it was announced today. Gorari is six miles east of Oivi and forty-four miles from the coastal base of Buna.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The first official disclosure that American forces now landing in French North Africa would move east to attack and block the retreat of the Axis army of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel while it was being driven westward by the British Eighth Army came today in a message from President Roosevelt to Sidi Moncef Pasha, Bey of Tunis, in which permission for passage of American troops through Tunisia was asked.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 10 -- Russian Caucasian defenses aided by Soviet tanks continued to sap German strength yesterday in the Nalchik foothills and Stalingrad's garrison killed 300 more Nazi shock troops in that unconquered Volga River city.
Mrs. Anthony Bassler of the Westchester Country Club was reelected president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the annual meeting yesterday at the Junior League Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt has received many congratulatory messages on the American invasion of French North Africa, it was disclosed today -- a good share of them from French citizens in this country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Wendell L. Willkie argued today that the tenets of a political party do not necessarily bind a party member.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The legislation to lower the draft age to 18 years was rushed to conference today after the House, by a standing vote of 178 to 40, refused to instruct its conferees to insist that selectees under 20 years old receive at least one year's training before assignment to overseas combat duty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Complete allocations control over all construction equipment was invoked today by the War Production Board. In Limitation Order L-192 the war agency ordered production of certain types of equipment for civilian use stopped.

Urging the study of foreign languages, Mayor La Guardia suggests that Chinese and Japanese as well as the commoner tongues might be studied in the high schools. Chinese and Japanese are taught in a number of American universities, which provide elementary as well as advanced instruction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The constitutionality of the New York Decedent Estate Law requiring the proration of Federal estate taxes among all persons sharing in the estate was unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court today through an opinion said to be of national importance.

Anthony Cramer, who is accused of treason, was placed on trial yesterday in Federal court and today, as the first witness against him, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa will call Ernest Peter Burger, one of the eight men whom Adolf Hitler sent in submarines to sabotage United States war preparations.
NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 9 -- New Jersey experienced tonight a twenty-minute State - wide surprise blackout described by Leonard Dreyfuss, State Civilian Defense Director, as the "best we have ever had."

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- London had the Lord Mayor's "show" today. But it was held without the Lord Mayor in the elaborate parade and peacetime pageantry of flags, banners and symbolic floats that in other days marked the induction of a new executive of the City of London.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Nowhere in London today was there greater interest in the American invasion of French Africa than among officials and peoples of the exiled European regimes.

Two women widely known in racing, Mrs. Dodge Sloane and Mrs. Cary T. Grayson, shared in the victory yesterday at Belmont of Great Rush, the son of Cavalcade, who came on at the end of the Farragut Purse to win by a length and a half in 1:42 4-5, three-fifths of a second slower than the track record.

More aroused than dejected by the defeat at the hands of Louisiana State, Fordham's football players began preparations yesterday for Saturday's tussle with the high-flying Eagles of Boston College by going through an hour of practice on Fordham Field.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Smiling and affable, Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared tonight that he was "well satisfied" with the American Army's progress in North Africa. He described the work of the British and American navies as "marvelous."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Instructions to retailers and wholesalers on procedure for coffee rationing were issued today by the Office of Price Administration. The fact was emphasized that merchants will have greater responsibility than under any previous rationing program.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Continuing her tour of the industrial Midlands, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt saw today how Britain's women help in building the bombers which have been so successful against targets in Germany, France and Italy recently.
As the upland game season opens in New Jersey at 9 o'clock this morning, hunters may be glad to know that the State officials expect a full measure of good hunting.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Thirty-six persons were injured, only one of them seriously enough to require hospitalization, in a collision at 6:30 o'clock tonight between two buses, one of them empty, at Boulevard East and Woodcliff Avenue here.

AN EAST COAST PORT, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- A small British merchantman -- split amidships by Nazi torpedoes -- "broke in the middle and formed a 'V' for victory" before she plunged to the bottom of the Atlantic late in September, survivors said today.
Last Saturday's upsets apparently convinced the nation's sports writers that this year's capital of football is located in the State of Georgia.
At the end of the second day of our North African offensive American beachheads were well established last night on both the Atlantic and Mediterranean coasts.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

An increased tendency on the part of food wholesalers to "force" sales of private brands and slow-moving merchandise, as a condition for the purchase of items in short supply, was reported by retailers yesterday. In addition a growing number of food traders are violating the price ceiling regulations, and in view of the existing conditions some retailers asserted that the situation will continue "hopeless" until an overall system of food rationing is established.
In an official publication of the United States Office of Education, entitled High School Victory Corps, appears the following paragraph:

The number of service men who will be admitted free to performances at the Metropolitan Opera will be increased this season, and arrangements have been made to provide seats in parterre boxes for officers at special prices, it was announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 9 -- Although Germany's African army is still moving rapidly in the general direction of Tripoli, news of American landings in North Africa yesterday and today dwarfed news from the Western Desert.

All securities and commodity exchanges in the United States and all banks in this country will be closed tomorrow in observance of Armistice Day. Usually, all banks and exchanges in Canada are closed on Nov. 11 for "Remembrance Day."

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 9 -- After being admittedly caught off balance by yesterday's developments in North Africa, Italian press and radio commentators today boldly step forward with bitter accusations of "American imperialism" and scholarly dissertations on the futility of the Allied nations' attack, which "cannot, of course, bring any material change in the situation for the Russians."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Proclaiming Wednesday,. Nov. 11; as Armistice Day, President Roosevelt said today that "faith can be kept with those who died in the first World War only by resolutely prosecuting to final victory the great war in which we are now engaged and by crowning that vie. tory with a peace which will safeguard and extend the Four Freedoms.''

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The text of the White House announcement regarding messages sent by President Roosevelt to the Resident General of Tunisia and the Bey of Tunis, saying that American armed forces hoped to pass through French Tunisia, follows:

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The United States expeditionary forces in French Morocco were reported today to be making a tank-supported general attack on the eastern side of Casablanca after the French commander there had rejected an ultimatum to cease fighting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- A threatened exodus of "okies" and "arkies" from California cotton fields brought assurance to them today from Dave Davidson, Agricultural War Board Chairman, that migratory farm workers still would receive enough gasoline to travel from job to job and then to their homes after nation-wide rationing went into effect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The War Labor Board denied today the request of the Joint Council of Glovemakers of Fulton County, N.Y., for a wage increase to some 4,000 glove workers employed by forty-one manufacturers who are members of the National Association of Glove Manufacturers.

With the expansion of total civilian and military employment to the record total of 59,200,000, the labor shortage became acute in September as current and anticipated labor stringencies were disclosed in an increasing number of areas and in a growing number of key industries, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

Frankie Boucher leads his New York Rangers back onto the ice in Madison Square Garden tonight hopeful of getting the Blue Shirts definitely started in the right direction in the National Hockey League campaign. The attempt will be undertaken against the Chicago Black Hawks, in the first appearance of Paul Thompson's squad here this year.
A series of closed board meetings marked the first day's session yesterday of the annual board of directors' meeting of the National Council of Jewish Womer at Essex House.

Among the apartment rentals reported yesterday by brokers and agents operating throughout the city was one for nine rooms and four baths at 983 Park Avenue signed by Mrs. Lewis Frank Mahler through the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, agent.
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A communique of Allied headquarters in North Africa: General Henri Giraud has arrived in Algeria from France.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- A joint plan for the redemption or cancellation of bonds and debentures aggregating $15,550,000 and for the merger of the Houston Gas Securities Company into the United Gas Corporation was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four subsidiaries of the Electric Power and Light Corporation.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers Association attempted today to map a curtailed program for 1943, but admitted the outlook for nation-wide competition was gloomy.

At a special commencement of the Rabbinical School of the Jewish Theological Seminary last night Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, summoned the graduates to help sustain the faith of fighting American youth in God and devotion to religion as essential both to victory and the building of a better world after the war.
The South and the Middle West again come up with the week's two standout games of the national picture.

The State is expected to complete its case today in Bronx County Court against Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21-year-old mother of four children, charged with first degree murder in the shooting of her 23-year-old husband, Alman. Sylvester Ryan, chief assistant district attorney, based his entire case of premeditation on a "Father's Day" gift that Mrs. Harrington presented to Joseph L. Cammarata, husband of her husband's foster mother, Mrs. Florence Kelly Cammarata.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 9 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commanding Allied forces in the North African zone, said tonight in a special communique that General Henri Honore Giraud had arrived in Algeria from France "to organize the French Army again to take up the fight."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The American forces invading French North Africa, with Algiers already surrendered to them, have bypassed Oran on both sides and made good their landings at all other selected points, the War Department announced in a communique issued here at 5:45 P.M.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- "Victor Hugo," a biography of the nineteenth-century French novelist by Matthew Josephson, which was published in September, has been purchased by Twentieth Century-Fox, the studio announced today. Fox has been interested in producing a life of Hugo for some years and in 1941 the studio joined Doubleday, Doran in financing a year's research by Josephson, obtaining an option on the screen rights to the completed work in return.

Declaring that city hospitals could not continue to function without the aid of private institutions, Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday for public support of the United Hospital campaign for $1,383,729 for seventy-six institutions.

Frank (Big Boy) Davino, who spent seventeen months in the death house at Sing Sing Prison and said farewell to twenty-one fellow-inmates as they went to the electric chair, was cleared yesterday in Kings County Court of first-degree murder in the payroll hold-up slaying of Fireman Thomas J. Hitter in Brooklyn on Oct. 31, 1938.

As Columbia's football players gathered at Baker Field yesterday to start practice for the Navy game in Baltimore on Saturday, the chief items of interest were the passing marks made by Co-captain Paul Governali and the Lions as a team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- In his first appearance as a lawyer before the United States Supreme Court, Wendell L. Willkie argued today against a lower court decision upholding the cancellation of naturalization of a California Communist. He contended that such revocation had no basis in Federal law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Twenty-seven additional industrial plants have been selected to receive the Army-Navy production award for outstanding performance on war work, Under Secretary of War Patterson and Under Secretary of the Navy Forrestal announced today.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 9 -- Production quotas for the anthracite coal mining industry were restored to the five-day-week basis this afternoon when the Anthracite Production Committee, composed of State, mine and union officials, agreed upon an output of 1,201,360 tons from today to Nov. 14.

United States invasion of French North Africa and the end of diplomatic relations with Vichy brought repercussions in Wall Street yesterday. At the start of business all banks and many corporations having foreign dealings were notified by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York that the Treasury Department had declared all of France within Continental Europe "enemy territory" and subject to prevailing restrictions against trade and communication with the enemy.

New York City's automobile and motor-cycle owners must start a new phase of registration under gasoline rationing today. All are required to file a new application form, with record of tire inspection, to validate their right to use the ration books already issued to them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the indicated production of cotton this year is 13,329,000 running bales, based on Nov. 1 conditions, compared with 13,818,000 forecast a month ago, 10,744,000 produced last year, and an average production of 13,109,000 during the ten years 1931-40.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 9 -- Reductions totaling $2,838,574 in the gross operating budget of Nassau County for 1943 were recommended by J. Russel Sprague, county executive, in his proposed budget, filed with the clerk of the Board of Supervisors today.

Related selling is one of the solutions to the problem of manpower shortages and delivery difficulties faced by stores in wartime, A.O. Buckingham, vice president of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., asserted last night at the biweekly meeting of the Advertising and Selling Course, sponsored by the Advertising Club.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 9 -- Declaring that "the day of the specialist is over for the duration" due to the wartime shortage of doctors, Dr. M. Pinson Heal of Columbia, Mo., president of the Southern Medical Association, tonight urged medical societies of the country to continue meeting despite war conditions "in order to make every doctor a jack-of-all-medical-trades."

Addition of cereal to coffee to extend the supply was announced yesterday by the Bickford chain of restaurants. Placards on counters announced that cereal was being used with coffee because of the rationing program.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 10 -- There was considerable mystery here last night about what happened to General Alphonse Juin, Vichy commander in North Africa. It was believed he might have been captured and there was an increasing suspicion here, too, that Admiral Francois Darlan either had fallen into the hands of the occupying forces or had given himself up.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The text of Navy Communique 187:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- Yale's practice today for Saturday's game with Princeton in New York was devoted to signal rehearsal, after which pictures of last Saturday's losing battle against Cornell were shown to point out individual weaknesses and brilliancy.

Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey will leave for a two-week vacation in the South tonight or tomorrow, it became known yesterday. He will be accompanied by members of his family. Mr. Dewey feels that he needs the relaxation in order to be better prepared to assume control of the State government on Jan. 1.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 9 -- Its principal streets and Boardwalk bedecked with flags and patriotic bunting, this city opened today Technical Training Command Week, a seven-day civic and military celebration sponsored by this resort's Army post, Basic Training Center 7, Army Air Forces Technical Training Command, to inform the public of its functions.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 9 per cent over the comparative week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a rise of 19 per cent in sales over 1941.

While the office of the consul general of the Vichy government here yesterday was gloomy and almost deserted, the office of the Fighting French Delegation, a few doors away, presented a scene of elation and activity.

Maria Maximovitch, Russian soprano, last night gave a recital in the New York Times Hall in which the unifying thread that ran through the twenty-one songs on her program was that they were all concerned with heroines named Suleika.

In a letter to THE TIMES George H. Gladwell quotes from an article, "The Invention and Progress of Printing," author unknown, mentioning "a book has since been found with a date of its impression from Oxford in 1468," and from this meager information writes that William Caxton's claim as the first English printer is not always conceded.

After all that has been written and published on the subject, it is discouraging to find the President still defending an average working week that is far too short to do what must be done. The President persists in a separation between war-work and non-war-work that has ceased to have meaning.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 9 -- Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews was introduced to correspondents here today as the new Commander in Chief of United States Army forces in the Middle East. Major Gen. Russell L. Maxwell will continue as chief of supply services.
ADVANCED TRAINING CENTER, FLEET MARINE FORCE, NEW RIVER, N.C., Nov. 9 -- "The Japs have poor eyesight," said the rifle instructor to his class of young marines, "and that's a great advantage for you.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President Roosevelt conferred with military leaders today, lunched with Secretary Ickes, made public his message to the Bey of Tunis, issued a statement on France's break with this country and renominated Rear Admiral Ross T. McIntire to be surgeon general of the Navy.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham is the Naval Commander in Chief of the expeditionary force operating off French North Africa, the Admiralty announced today.

The passing wizardry of Paul Governali in Saturday's Columbia-Colgate game made such a deep impression on Andy Kerr, the Maroon coach who doubles in brass as mentor for the East-West classic, that Kerr promptly invited Pitchin' Paul to join his Eastern squad.
MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
A Vichy French communique broadcast from Vichy and recorded here by The Associated Press:
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Fighting French sources here indicated today that General Giraud would be welcomed in Fighting French ranks.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Squadrons of Flying Fortress and Liberator bombers pounded the Nazi-held port of St. Nazaire in daylight today in the first United States Army Air Forces attack on that target.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A nephew of General Douglas MacArthur is among the American foreign service officials now awaiting return to the United States from Vichy France and French North Africa. He is Douglas MacArthur 2d of Washington, third secretary of the embassy in Vichy.

A meeting of the first mortgage bondholders of the Buffalo Susquehanna Railroad Corporation has been called by the Chase National Bank, as trustee, for Nov. 18, to discuss action on a proposal to abandon and scrap the 44.6-mile segment of the main line between Sinnemahoning and Burrows, Pa., and the nine-mile branch between Wharton and Austin, Pa., portions of which were damaged severely by floods last July.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- An Office of Production Research and Development, intended to insure rapid appraisal and prompt effective use of new processes, materials, mechanisms and inventions in the production of war goods, was set up within the War Production Board today.

LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The North African landings were the first big-scale combat test for some of the United States Army's new equipment, such as landing barges and Garand rifles, as well as for its new methods of organization and operation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan today supported a Democratic resolution for creation of a joint bipartisan committee to advise President Roosevelt on conduct of the war, a move which he said the White House does not oppose.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Montgomery Ward Co. filed a brief in Federal court here today opposing the granting of an injunction sought by the Office of Price Administration for alleged violations of March ceiling prices.
State enator and frs. Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh are ex-i pected to come to Mayfair House today.

NOBODY wants to commit himself now. Not since Navy beat Penn and Iowa overturned Wisconsin, Scouts are throwing away their charts. Coaches are staring into space. Athletic directors are asking: "Whither are we drifting?"

Recognizing that accounting has become an indispensable element in war production and in control of the government's vast expenditures, the executive committee of the American Institute of Accountants yesterday announced adoption of a war activities program to remain in effect for the duration.

ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Oct. 27 (Delayed) -- Two formations of dive-bombers of a certain aircraft carrier, the X, carried a major part of the American attack to the Japanese in a battle between American and Japanese naval-air task forces that took place yesterday north of the Solomons.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 9 -- Francois Briere, French consul at Boston, today asked the State Department to grant himself and his family the hospitality of the country after resigning his position as a protest against his own government at Vichy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- United States war planes and motor torpedo boats in the Guadalcanal area conducted broad attacks on Japanese ships and installations, reporting, among other damage, the hitting of an enemy destroyer yesterday (Solomons date), the Navy Department reported here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today called Democratic legislative leaders to the White House for a conference tomorrow at which the manpower question is expected to be threshed out.

Moderate hedging filtered into the cotton futures market yesterday following the Department of Agriculture's estimate of a 13,329, 000-bale crop. The selling was fairly well absorbed by mills, however, and active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 2 points lower than Saturday's final quotations.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, with Robert E. Healy engaging in a mild dispute with the four other members, handed down today its findings and opinion in support of its order approving sale by the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation of all its interest in the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and the end of the former concern.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Powers of the Federal Government over wheat production were widely extended when the Supreme Court upheld today an amendment to the Agricultural Adjustment Act, placing all of the crop, even that consumed on the farm, in the quota system, and imposing a 49-cent a bushel penalty on wheat grown and sold above the allotment.

We are not at war with France. We shall not be. Vichy could no more commit us to such a war than could the French Directory in 1798. Some shots were fired then. Some shots are being fired now. The peace between the peoples remains unbroken, as it has been since the establishment of the two Republics.

The New Opera Company may have to curtail its season, it was learned yesterday. The reason is that the public campaign for $150,000 to finance the season has not been as successful as it was hoped. "La Vie Parisienne," its third bill, will open tonight at the Broadway Theatre.

Military developments in French Africa, implying a shorter war than previously expected, found reflection yesterday in a greater degree of conservatism in the wholesale markets here. Buyers continued to place orders for gift items and "in-between" Spring merchandise, but were reported cautious in planning commitments calling for deliveries later than March, 1943, it was reported in merchandising quarters.

PRINCETON, N.J., NOV. 9 -- Tad Wieman today had Princeton's football players drilling longer than they usually do on Mondays. Every one was out on University Field as preparations for Saturday's game with Yale at Baker Field got under way.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Motorists of the Eastern seaboard, gasoline-rationed since June, may have to take a further cut in motor fuel this Winter, the petroleum industry war council was advised today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Corn continued the leader in the grain markets today. Prices moved up around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading to a new high since early in October and at the extreme showed 5 1/4 cents above the inside figure of the preceding week.
Playing spectacular golf to beat par by six strokes, Al Brosch of Bethpage hewed out a round of 67, 69 -- 136 to regain the Long Island P.G.A. championship on the Bayside Links yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Even while the United States is at war with the countries from which they come, enemy aliens living here are fully entitled to bring lawsuits in our courts, an undivided Supreme Court ruled today in an opinion by Justice Black.

So much consumer advice floats around that the housewife may be tempted to give up in desperation. But before she does, it might pay her to visit the exhibit that opened yesterday at the Pershing Square Information Center of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

Arguments on the proposed establishment of a minimum wage of 40 cents an hour for 45,000 employes in the printing, publishing and allied graphic arts industries were heard yesterday in the Hotel Astor by Major Robert N. Campbell, arbiter for the wage and hour division of the United States Department of Labor.

Some notes on war books: Ruth Bryan Owen, former member of Congress and Minister to Denmark, has a book on Dodd, Mead's December list entitled "Look Forward, Warrior." The author analyzes the war and has some suggestions for what to do about future ones.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Secretary Morgenthau disclosed today that Vichy French officials in the Western Hemisphere now are dependent upon individual decisions of the Treasury Department for living expenses.

Brooklyn College swung into its final week of preparation for the last and most important test of the season against C.C.N.Y. on Saturday at the Brooklyn field. The Kingsmen devoted the afternoon to a light signal drill, and ran through a series of new plays.

More than half of the hotel supply houses are unable to take any further business, or can do so only on a limited basis, it was found yesterday at the opening of the twenty-seventh National Hotel Exposition in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Representative Cole of New York disclosed today an exchange of letters in which Attorney General Biddle cited recent anti-trust legislation as providing no means for suspending the government's anti-trust suit against The Associated Press and Mr. Cole in turn cited other new legislation which he said would permit suspension.
LAYTONVILLE, Calif., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Dolph Camilli, first baseman of the Dodgers and a National League baseball star for nine years, disclosed today he would not return to the Brooklyn club next year.

America will want to see a postwar settlement "that will settle problems instead of keeping them boiling" and considerations of justice dictate that Palestine be opened to large-scale Jewish immigration under Jewish auspices, Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the Jewish National Fund, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The per capita amount of money in circulation in the United States on Oct. 31 was $105.82, the Treasury disclosed today. This is twice as much as it was in 1920 and 45 per cent more than it was on Oct. 31, 1941.

A large exhibition of paintings by Corot, arranged as a benefit for the Salvation Army War Fund, will open with a preview this afternoon at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. Admission will be $5. Beginning tomorrow morning the exhibition will be open to the public until Dec. 12, with an entrance fee of 50 cents.
The Theatre Guild will open its twenty-fifth subscription season tonight at the St. James when it presents "Without Love," a new comedy by Philip Barry.
Mayor La Guardia paid tribute yesterday to the standing and tradition of the Marine Corps, which is celebrating its 167th anniversary today.

Plans were discussed at a meeting held yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Robert S. Davis, 280 Park Avenue, for a special performance of "Stars on Ice" and a $250,000 fur show to be given on the night of Dec. 23 at the Center Theatre, for the benefit of the Judson Health Center.

This department is now in a position to tell the whole inside story of the Second Front. Like so many other inside stories the information on which our narrative is based comes chiefly from the inside of the writer's inner consciousness.

MY collectivist friends frequently accuse me of having a monistic fixation on the subject of economic and political pluralism. That is a fancy way of saying that I believe more or less on Tuesday as I believe on Monday. Confronted with Alfred M. Bingham's "The Techniques of Democracy,"* I can only indulge once more in a perhaps maniacal insistence on a point of view.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Nov. 7 (Delayed) -- Forward elements of the British Eighth Army have been pursuing the enemy while other units have been doing what is commonly called "mopping up." With an advance at a great speed, such as this one attains, there are bound to be areas left behind that are pockets of enemy resistance.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving gave a large supper party last night at the River Club after the opening of the New Opera Company's second week of its subscription season with a performance of Offenbach's "La Vie Parisenne."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A Management-Labor Policy Committee, unanimously opposing enactment of a national war service act for the conscription of labor at this time, has submitted a broad-scale voluntary program designed to eliminate serious manpower problems which now threaten successful prosecution of the war, it was announced today.

Hitler in his putsch anniversary speech once more told the story of how he saved Germany. If, in 1933, he had not taken charge "Germany would have remained as she was, that is to say, a powerless state with an army of 100,000, to perish within itself."
During fifty-four years with one company she has met Ethel Barrymore, Richard Harding Davis and a crazy lawyer. All, of course, on a business basis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Hogs sold at about the lowest levels in two months today as prices dropped 10 cents a 100 pounds under yesterday's average. In the cattle pens trade was draggy with prices under heavy pressure from big packing interests. All sheep slaughter classes were strong to 25 cents higher. Department of Agriculture figures follow:

In strong contrast to stories brought here by other former residents of Axis internment camps was that told yesterday by Mrs. Gwendoline Priestwood, British woman who escaped last March from Hong Kong and arrived in this country a few days ago.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- A large number of Royal Air Force bombers battered several places in the coastal region of Northwestern Germany last night, including Hamburg, Germany's second largest city and Adolf Hitler's chief U-boat building center.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- What are regarded by the White House as "satisfactory" oral replies have been made by General Francisco Franco, Chief of the Spanish State, and General Antonio Oscar de Fragoso Carmona, President of Portugal, to the message delivered to them Saturday night from President Roosevelt disclaiming any designs on their territories and emphasizing the desirability of their neutrality in the face of the North African campaign.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- American naval forces under Rear Admiral Henry K. Hewitt have wiped out strong French destroyer forces in violent action off Casablanca, French Morocco, and Navy fliers have wrecked the battleship Jean Bart and badly damaged a cruiser, dispatches from field commanders said today.

These are days in which women are interested in economy in dress. How far can they make a dress go? This is a question which many ask themselves. It was with this in mind that Macy's yesterday gathered together a unique showing which offered costumes in pairs.

Fresh supplies of British lisle yarns made of Egyptian long-staple cotton may be made available soon by the WPB to American producers of women's stockings, chiefly as a result of the improved military situation in the Mediterranean sector, it was reported here yesterday in the market.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A communique:
