LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Russian official news agency Tass reported in a dispatch from Switzerland today that Premier Mussolini had officially applied to Berlin for military assistance "to defend the positions of the Axis countries in Northern Africa."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A slash of 15 per cent in the mileage covered by local buses in Manhattan was ordered today by the Office of Defense Transportation in a move designed to curb bus service in six major cities and to effect a saving of 100,000,000 bus miles a year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Senate Small Business Committee announced today that the Navy had decided to cancel an order under which two manufacturers enjoy a "virtual monopoly" in the production of ready-made uniforms for Naval officers.
The letter of Louis Kirshbaum, published in your issue of Nov. 6, merits reply in order to disseminate vital information concerning the operation of the Unemployment Insurance Law.

The Office of Price Administration does not believe that its job is to put exporters out of business and seeks to allow the trade compensation "for performing the job of exporting," Dr. Seymour E. Harris, director of export-import control of OPA, assured foreign traders yesterday.

A syndicate headed by the Union Securities Corporation won yesterday the award of a new issue of S1,000,000 of State of West Virginia road bonds, dated April 1, 1942, and due serially on April 1, 1943 to 1967. The bankers bid par for $80,000 of the bonds as 3 3/4 per cents and $920,000 as 1 1/2s.

New films will be presented in three Broadway theatres this morning. The Paramount will celebrate its sixteenth anniversary with the showing of "Road to Morocco," starring Bing Crosby, Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour. Among the supporting players in the Paramount comedy are Anthony Quinn, Dona Drake, Vladimir Sokoloff and Mikhail Rasumny.

The revival of the old "clip-joint racket," in which the signatures of business men are obtained on "tabs" which later are presented with demands for payment, was revealed yesterday with the arraignment of three men accused of mulcting $1,170 from a stock broker.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday temporarily stayed, pending decision, an order of the Federal Power Commission directing the Niagara Falls Power Company to write off $15, 537,943 from its accounts, an amount which the commission held was carried on the company's books in excess of legitimate original cost of its power project at Niagara Falls.

The jurors who will decide whether Anthony Cramer is guilty, as charged, of treason, heard yesterday the story of the eight Nazi saboteurs who were landed here by submarine last June, from the lips of Ernest Peter Burger, one of the two surviving members of the thwarted band.

War conditions have placed a considerable burden on the Long Island Railroad, which serves four aircraft factories in the Farmingdale area, instrument factories at Lake Success and Garden City and other plants needed in the war effort scattered along its right of way.

Three Special Sessions justices insisted yesterday on proceeding immediately with the trial of the three men producing the show "Wine, Women and Song" at the Ambassador Theatre, in West Forty-ninth Street, for an alleged obscene performance on Oct. 31.

General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the United States Army, and Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, discussed the workings of our system of command and our cooperation with Great Britain with unusual frankness in addresses last night at a dinner of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday by A.N. Williams, president, showed a net income of $6,519,815 after all expenses, taxes and other charges. The net was equal to $6.23 a share on the company's outstanding capital stock and compared with a net of $5,326,192, or $5.09 a share, in the first nine months of last year.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Military operations along the Russian front dwindled almost to skirmish level today, and foreign observers speculated that the Germans might be regrouping for a new major blow at the Red Army lines now holding firmly from the Baltic to the Black Sea.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Admiral Francois Darlan, chief of Vichy's armed forces, is now in Allied hands at Algiers "being entertained by one of our American generals with the respect and dignity due an officer of his rank," London headquarters of the Allied force announced tonight.

A new limitation policy, designed to curtail the present size of the magazine and believed to be the first forthcoming from the magazine field, will be announced in a few days by Life Magazine, Howard Black, vice president, revealed yesterday.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 11 (UP) -- The Russians, seizing the initiative on land and sea, have captured seven enemy points in Southern Stalingrad, blasted the Germans from another snowbound height northeast of Tuapse in the Western Caucasus and sunk a 10,000-ton transport in the Baltic, the Soviet High Command announced today.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 -- Mrs. John D. Hertz's Count Fleet won the thirty-sixth Walden Stakes at Pimlico today with enough space showing between him and the second horse to decide fifty races.

Milk distributors in this city and its suburban areas will have from Nov. 16 to Dec. 16 to show that they are making required savings in gasoline and rubber consumption in line with Office of Defense Transportation regulations in an order made public last night by the Metropolitan Milk Distributors Commission.
Declaring that the city's wrecking yards had only 4,200 old cars headed for the scrap-pile, Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday to owners of antiquated cars to sell them for scrap.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The uncertainties of war caused the Professional Golfers Association to end its two-day session today without making a decision on the fate of its own 1943 P.G.A. tournament other than to announce it would wait until after the first of the year to determine whether the event would be held.

The suggestion in your editorial "Cooperation at Albany," pointing to the excellent precedent set by Governor Lehman and Governor-elect Dewey, is timely. This mutual appreciation of their public responsibility was to be expected from these two statesmen whose records in public office have been exemplary.

Sergeant Bozo the Great. English bulldog mascot of the marine detachment at the navy yard in Brooklyn, couldn't be with his mates yesterday as they celebrated the 167th anniversary of the founding of the Marine Corps. Sergeant Bozo, sometimes called Barney, was in the A.S.P.C.A. hospital at Twenty-fourth Street and Avenue A, Manhattan, suffering from an injured foreleg and a case of eczema.

Every Jew will subscribe to the sentiment expressed by Mr. Sulzberger in Baltimore on Nov. 5, "What Jews want * * * is the right to call any place home." But viewed against the realities, is this more than a pious wish? What are the realities?

Though it was dinned into us long before Pearl Harbor that totalitarian war demands the mobilization of the country's intellectual and material resources we moved slowly. An Executive Order established the National Defense Research Committee, now a subsidiary of the Office of Scientific Development and Research, gave it full authority and money enough to solve the scientific problems of the Army and Navy.

A young woman violinist of high ability was revealed last night when Mary Backer of Syracuse, N.Y., made her debut at the Town Hall. She caught her audience's attention with her very first notes and held it steadily until she finished her recital by tossing off some difficult little show pieces with the greatest of ease.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- President Roosevelt and General John J. Pershing will lead the nation in observance of its first wartime Armistice Day tomorrow in traditional ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery.

Though the real test of the American offensive in North Africa still lies ahead, enough has already happened to show that this great manoeuvre was superbly organized. There is good reason to believe that it involved the largest expeditionary force ever to be transported in a single operation in naval history anywhere.

Chester S. Williams, director of the adult and civic branches of the United States Office of Education, declared last night at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street, that wider teaching of the truths which safeguard freedom had become an important wartime problem.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose by a slight margin last month, going from 548,365 shares at the end of September to 558,446 shares on the Oct. 30 settlement date. Neither figure included short positions in odd-lot dealers' accounts, which were 30,972 shares on Sept. 30 and 23,472 shares on Oct. 30.

To begin its twenty-fifth subscription season the Theatre Guild offers Katharine Hepburn in Philip Barry's "Without Love," which was acted at the St. James last evening. Since Katharine Hepburn in Philip Barry's "The Philadelphia Story" ran on month after month in 1939, the Guild may know a successful combination when it has once tried it, and the subscribers seemed last evening to be in agreement.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, in an address before the Industrial Hygiene Foundation at Mellon Institute, asserted today that America's situation in war production is critical and that industry cannot afford to discard the service of any man or woman who can be considered a potential worker even though physically handicapped.

The Y.M.C.A. of New York City has rendered 2,500,000 different services to men in uniform during the first ten months of this year, Richard W. Lawrence, president, declared last night at the ninetieth anniversary dinner of the association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, today called on organized labor to drop all peacetime rules and production restrictions for the duration of the war and, in view of the critical manpower shortage, to increase production "with the same force that we have now."

Helen Traubel will do Isolde at the Metropolitan Opera House early next month, and the audience at last night's Philadelphia Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall had something of a preview. With Eugene Ormandy conducting, she sang Isolde's narrative from the first act of the Wagner music-drama, and the "Tristan! Geliebter!" and the Liebestod from the last act.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 10 -- Although minor rear guard actions were reported in the areas of Sidi Barrani and Solum yesterday, enemy resistance in Egypt had lapsed into the gesture stage and was not important enough to goad the British Eighth Army into hasty mopping-up operations.

From several local sources yesterday satisfaction was expressed over the conduct of United States relations with the Vichy government, and the hope was expressed that the present occupation of North Africa would be recognized by the French as a step toward their liberation.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 10 -- A United States warship that recently sank two Japanese patrol vessels in the Ellice Island area rescued sixteen Japanese officers and men from the water. Pacific Fleet headquarters disclosed today.

Some interesting sidelights on the deer hunting season in New York State are contained in the information received from the Conservation Department at Albany. Of course, if any other sport than hunting were mentioned, some of the officials might be taken to task for not emphasizing that the biggest buck killed to date went to a Brooklyn hunter.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10 -Coach Dick Harlow's quest for a pair of extra Harvard wingbacks to make up for the loss of Gordon Lyle, who broke a leg against Michigan last Saturday, continued today. Bart Harvey, baseball captain, and Steve Gifford both were drilled hard as Don Richards substituted.

The only "draft-proof" jobs from now on will be those that require a minimum of three years' training, Lieut. Col. H.J. Schwabacher, liaison officer for the Service of Supplies and Wax Manpower Commission, warned yesterday at the opening session of the two-day production conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Colonel Fred W. Rankin, president of the American Medical Association, who is now associated with the United States Surgeon General's office, said tonight that "the vast majority, if not all" physically qualified doctors in the country under 45 would be in military service "before victory comes to our cause."

AT UNITED NATIONS' HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The battle for Oivi, fifty-five miles from the northeastern New Guinea coast, between Japanese and Allied ground forces now is approaching the decisive stage, the United Nations Command announced today.
Wendell L. Willkie saw for the first time yesterday afternoon the paintings, drawings, and woodcuts by Chinese artists which he brought from China to this country on his recent flight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Federal Crop Reporting Board said today that farmers made fair but uneven progress in October in harvesting this year's record production of crops, despite some unfavorable weather conditions and growing shortages of manpower, equipment and storage space.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 10 -- Concentration of industry by restricting the number of manufacturers permitted to produce civilian goods has proved a "drop-in-the-bucket" method of solving the manpower shortage, Walter D. Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company and chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, asserted in an address tonight before the State Federation of Women's Clubs.

AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, Nov. 10 -- Two Canadian naval men captured the crew of a sinking German submarine by leaping from the Canadian corvette Oakville to the deck of a sinking U-boat and shooting it out with the Nazis, the Navy revealed here today.

Members of the executive committee of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut initiated yesterday a program "to safeguard, protect and properly enforce" the rights of minority stockholders and "to better protect our investors and our corporate system."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The work of the Navy, which transported the American invasion force to French North Africa with the cooperation of the British fleet, was "the most superb piece of seamanship on record," Secretary Frank Knox said today.

Mayor La Guardia told a group of fifty-nine marine recruits at noon yesterday that they had "to be tough to be efficient" and that "no man should" be Mayor of this city unless he has been a member of the marines."

Greenwich House, the neighborhood Settlement at 27 Barrow Street founded in 1902 by Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, who is still its director, will complete its fortieth anniversary celebration on Nov. 23. The Settlement was incorporated in May, 1902, and formally opened on Thanksgiving Day of that year.

Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey, departing yesterday for a thirteen-day vacation at the Cloisters, Sea Island, Ga., announced before he left that he had appointed a four-man committee to study the problem of unemployment, idle factory and idle machine tool equipment in New York City, plus the problems faced by small businesses.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 11 -- Adolf Hitler has ordered German troops to occupy the remainder of France and the Mediterranean island of Corsica, 300 miles north of the coast of Africa, to counter the United States invasion of French possessions in Northern Africa, the Paris radio announced today.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 10 -- Negotiations for an alliance of Germany, France and Italy against the United Nations were reported under way "somewhere in Europe" tonight.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

HAVING quietly dropped anchor near by, Lieutenant (j.g.) Kidd (on the level, not a nickname) Brewer, U.S.N.R., from the North Carolina Pre-Flight school, began to talk about the football team from the station. He could speak with double authority on that topic. He's officially attached to the station and is a former captain and center of a Duke football team.

The International Paper Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 profit of $1,214,097 after provision of $1,047,568 for normal Federal income taxes and reserve of $1,672,855 for Federal excess profits taxes, but before post-war excess profits tax credits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The War Production Board's division of compliance announced today that it is conducting a survey of the operations of warehouses which stock brass and wire mill products. Particular attention will be paid to their degree of compliance with the order restricting the sale of copper and copper base alloys to customers whose purchase orders are rated A-1-k or better.
LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The text of an announcement read over the Paris radio by a German Army spokesman and heard by Reuter:
LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

One-week furloughs immediately after induction for New York City's Selective Service registrants already are in effect, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, draft director here, said yesterday, although in many parts of the country until Nov. 17 registrants will get two weeks.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- A scramble to buy cash corn has developed at terminal markets and some of the low grade grain here advanced 2 cents a bushel relative to the December, with buyers taking everything offered. There has been considerable improvement in the grading recently, and out of eighty-two carloads sold in the sample market, only one car of new grain graded sample.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The text of the 18-19 draft bill amendments, as agreed upon by the conference committee and passed-by the House, was as follows:

EAST ISLIP, L. I., Nov. 10 -The black Labrador bitch Champion Gorse of Arden today captured the open all-age stake, final field trial at the annual meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club. The 6-year-old daughter of Champion Raffles of Earlsmoor and Champion Decoy of Arden came through a field of thirty-one, which worked two days on land and in water on the estate of Charles L. Lawrance.

The recent recommendation of the War Production Board concerning use of gold and palladium, instead of platinum, in jewelry has resulted in many inquiries as to availability of palladium, its working properties and usefulness in jewelry, according to Charles Engelhard of Baker Co., Inc., Newark, N.J.

The teeming bird life and the lavish beauty of sea and land with which nature had endowed Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons is reproduced in a beautiful exhibit that will go on public view today at the American Museum of Natural History.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- An overwhelming voice vote of the House today ratified a conference agreement on the legislation to lower the minimum draft age to 18 years without "shackling" amendments.

Warning that railroads were operating near capacity, W. Lee Elgin, newly elected president of the Eastern Conference of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators, called yesterday on the nation's trucking facilities to move vital war materials, lest "production for victory be hopelessly bogged down."

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Reports from France tonight said another powerful fleet of United Nations warships and a great number of merchantmen were gathering at Gibraltar, while throughout European waters and in the Atlantic naval activities were reported on a vast scale.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Harry Silver, the Supreme Court jury foreman who caused a mistrial in a divorce suit here last May when he made and kept a "date with the women defendant accused of adultery, was himself the defendant in a divorce trial today.

LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- German troops were reported speeding through unoccupied France today toward a Mediterranean area at which Adolf Hitler said American and British troops proposed landings as a sequel to the American coup in North Africa.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The first public utterance by Prime Minister Winston Churchill since General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's victory in Egypt and the landing of Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's American Army in French Colonial Africa was made today at Mansion House.
The first ten rankings in foil, epee, saber and women's foil, with the national champions heading their respective divisions, were announced yesterday by the Amateur Fencers League of America.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The Armistice Day proclamation of Mayor Benjamin F. Barnes of Yonkers containing an order that flags throughout the city be flown at half-staff tomorrow drew a number of protests from residents here today, but the Mayor declined to rescind the order, declaring that he had received advice on how the flag should be flown from Harry T. Hollowell, chief-of-staff of the Armistice Day parade.

At the White House yesterday the President discussed the manpower question with Democratic legislative leaders. He is said to be considering a change in the administrative set-up to deal with the problem.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- American assault teams, grimy with battle and sleepless for three days, smashed into Oran today, occupying the great French naval base at 1 P. M., and freed the entire western end of the Mediterranean from the danger of Axis aggression.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 10 -- American diplomats and newspaper correspondents are sleeping in Vichy, France, tonight, according to the latest reports received here. The original purpose was to transfer them today to Chatelguyon, a Summer cure resort some twenty miles distant, but it seems to have been abandoned.

WITH THE TWELFTH U.S. AIR FORCE, Algeria, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- United States pilots, flying British Spitfires and supporting American ground forces cleaning up pockets of French resistance, have in the past forty-eight hours destroyed at least fifteen tanks and twenty-five troop trucks.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- A fast American mobile column sped eastward toward Tunisia today, and it was believed that the big Bizarre naval base might be brought into the area of operations momentarily. An otherwise unsubstantiated radio report from Buenos Aires, Argentina, said the Americans already had marched into Tunisia.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga granted yesterday a judgment dismissing a stockholder's accounting action against present and former officers and directors of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and absolving them of charges of breach of duty in connection with a buying program in which Socony-Vacuum participated with other oil companies and which was declared later by the Federal courts to be in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

The birth rate in New York City receded last week from the extraordinary high mark of the preceding week, while the general death rate rose above the "expected" level, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice directed the Delta Shipbuilding Corporation at New, Orleans today to "cease discriminating" against skilled Negro labor in its hiring practices.

Airplanes cannot and will not take the place of ships, and air transport, while absolutely necessary to modern war, must be regarded as a supplementary express service rather than as a substitute freight service, Robert A. Lovett, assistant Secretary of War for Air, said yesterday morning at the annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- After yesterday's turnover which was reported to be the heaviest in more than six or seven years the markets paused for breath today and turned easer. Early profit-taking sales which caused a mild reaction were readily absorbed.

ADVANCED TRAINING CENTER, FLEET MARINE FORCE, NEW RIVER, N.C., Nov. 10 -- The Japanese changed their tactics, according to individual combat instructors here today, when they found most marines could hit two out of three at 500 yards with a Garand rifle.

The constitutionality of Section 11 (B) 1, also called the "death sentence clause" of the PubUe Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, was taken under consideration here yesterday by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals. It was attacked as an unwarranted invasion of rights properly belonging to the States in argument by Charles E. Hughes Jr., counsel for the North American Company.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- An outright gift of 10,000,000 to Malta has been proposed by the government, Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Following is the interim report to the chairman of the War Manpower Commission submitted by the Management-Labor Policy Committee:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Battle of the Solomons is "shaping up rapidly in our favor," Lieut. Gen. Thomas Holcomb, Commandant of the Marine Corps, said here today in reporting on a tour of inspection of the Southwestern Pacific region, from which he has just returned.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's speech at the Lord Mayor's dinner at the Mansion House this evening:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 -With no sign of wasting much regret over the past Saturday, Yale's football forces began today to aim for their oldest rival and next Saturday's renewal, on a strange gridiron in New York, of their ancient series with Princeton.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- United States expeditionary armies wiped out effective resistance along 500 miles of Africa's Western Mediterranean coast today with the conquest of Oran, Algeria's second city, and a German report said that the Bey of Tunis had granted President Roosevelt's request for the passage of American troops to Libya.

The sale of 500 books of tickets, each containing ten 10-cent tickets. for a raffle with a $25 war bond as the prize and the profits to help pay for a motion-picture projector for educational use, was stopped yesterday in Kew Gardens. Queens, on the order of Mayor La Guardia.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- The surrender of the great port of Oran, Algeria, with its Mers-el-Kebir naval base, is expected to end organized resistance in most of French North Africa, Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commanding the American Expeditionary Forces, announced at a special press conference today.

Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday signed forty-five letters to C. T. Russell, vice president and general counsel for the New York Telephone Company, officially asking the company to cut racetrack bookmakers' lines running from New York to New Jersey.

DETROIT, Nov. 10 -- Wearing a heavy blindfold and with only the sense of touch to identify 200-odd parts which make up a .50-caliber Browning machine gun, Sergeant Maynard Radke of the Army demonstrated today for thirty newspaper men and Army, Navy and Coast Guard officers how he could dismantle and assemble the hard-hitting weapon in less than six minutes.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Women were urged to be on guard against subversive activities today in an address by Miss Katherine Clayberger of New York, editor of Woman's Home Companion, at the opening session of the annual meeting of the State Federation of Home Bureaus.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 10 -- The war-time drain on manpower opened a "strong man's game" to women today when nine members of what used to be called the weaker sex started work at the sawmill of the New England Timber Salvage Corporation at Turkey Pond, near here.

If Dolph Camilli, the Dodger first baseman, intends to retire from major league baseball, as he implied in a quoted interview on his California ranch on Monday, he will be permitted to quit with the Dodgers' blessings, but -- and there appear to be certain implications in that but, as well -- Branch Rickey sincerely hopes Dolph will reconsider the move before the 1943 campaign opens.

Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin have returned to 47 East Sixty-first Street after spending several months at Crow Land, their place in East Hampton. With them are their daughters, Mrs. George W. Pierpont, Mrs. Pierson Mapes and Mrs. Terance R. Harp.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 10 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French Chief of State, was still in Vichy tonight despite the fact that "in the absence of Admiral Darlan" he has assumed personal command of the French defense forces. The use of the word "personal" in the Vichy announcement had provoked a rumor that the Marshal had gone to North Africa.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- "The Snatching of Bookie Bob," a play by Earl Baldwin adapted from a story by Damon Runyon, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Charles Laughton, the studio announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- While larger British naval units are engaged in supporting Allied landings in North Africa, submarines, corvettes and small surface craft are constantly harassing enemy supply ships, battle units and U-boats whenever these are encountered.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Vichy broadcasts recorded here reported today that three United States tank columns had crashed into Casablanca, Morocco, and that the city was under heavy attack by superior American forces and was being bombarded violently. Gov ernor General Charles Nogues of Morocco has fled from Rabat to the interior, the radio added.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Declaring that a second front has to be tailor-made and custom-built and cannot be purchased ready made in a department store, President Roosevelt gave his press conference today a detailed account of the months of planning that preceded the French North African expedition and the limiting factors that made impossible a large-scale Allied offensive across the English Channel before the middle of 1943.

George M. Cohan left to his widow and four children the estate he earned in half a century of theatrical activity. The will and one codicil, disposing of an estate formally valued at "more than $20,000," were filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- French consular officials in New York and others of the twenty-nine cities where they have been established in this country are being kept under close surveillance and their activities are being watched, but it is a condition that officials believe will be clarified in a few days as the situation settles down.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 10 -- Brig. Gen. William E. Farthing, who was in command at the Hickam Field Army air base in Hawaii last Dec. 7 at the time of the Japanese attack, has been placed in charge of the Newark Airport and Port Newark Air Service Command, the supply and maintenance division of the Army Air Corps in this area, according to announcement today at the command's headquarters at the airport.

No editor of an anthology in this anthologized season or any other would think of letting his book go out into the world without attempting to answer in advance the readers who ask why certain things were included and other omitted. For instance, Morris Bishop, editor of "A Treasury of British Humor," due on Monday (Coward-McCann), spends quite a few pages telling about the reasons for his selections.
That area of French territory known as "unoccupied France" came into existence in June, 1940, after the overwhelming defeat of the French armies and the collapse of the Third Republic.
BELFAST, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Roosevelt arrived here today, and was welcomed by Prime Minister John M. Andrews.

It will be Alsab against seven others in the $10,000-added Victory Handicap today at Belmont Park, where the sixth program of Victory Race Week will be conducted, before a crowd which may reach 20,000. Alsab, the hero horse of many, is faced with formidable opposition for the prize to be had at the end of the mile and a quarter.

The performance of "La Vie Parisienne" this season by the New Opera Company is painstaking, intelligent, coordinated in ensemble, exciting only in moments, and far from Offenbach. The cast, with a single exception, is different from the one of last year.

HAVANA, Cuba, Nov. 10 -- Heinz August Luning, the first German spy to be executed in Cuba, was shot at 8 o'clock this morning by an army firing squad in the Principe Fortress jail. A last-minute appeal to President Fulgencia Batista by Dr. Armando Rabell, the defending attorney, failed to bring a reprieve.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Announcement was made today of the addition of Canada to the Combined Production and Resources Board, which has hitherto consisted only of representatives of the United States and Great Britain.

Trade buying in the near months shortly before the end of yesterday's session on the New York Cotton Exchange regained some of the ground that had been yielded earlier in the day through rather active commission-house selling. It failed, however, to offset hedging of spot interests in the distant positions. The market closed 1 to 9 points below Monday's final prices.

Profit-taking, combined with another drive on many of the so-called war issues, pushed the stock market yesterday into irregularly lower territory. Business lacked the aggressive power of the year's record turnover of 1,207,643 shares on Monday, but the volume on the Stock Exchange of 772,220 shares still constituted a fairly active day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Announcement was made today of the addition of Canada to the Combined Production and Resources Board, which has hitherto consisted only of representatives of the United States and Great Britain.

Trade buying in the near months shortly before the end of yesterday's session on the New York Cotton Exchange regained some of the ground that had been yielded earlier in the day through rather active commission-house selling. It failed, however, to offset hedging of spot interests in the distant positions. The market closed 1 to 9 points below Monday's final prices.

Profit-taking, combined with another drive on many of the so-called war issues, pushed the stock market yesterday into irregularly lower territory. Business lacked the aggressive power of the year's record turnover of 1,207,643 shares on Monday, but the volume on the Stock Exchange of 772,220 shares still constituted a fairly active day.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Nov. 9 (Delayed) -- At dawn this morning an officer told us that his unit had captured more prisoners than it was possible to deal with and enough equipment of all sorts to keep his force in the desert, fully stocked, for three years.

Today being both Wednesday and Armistice Day herewith the scheduled matinees: "Angel Street," "Arsenic and Old Lace," "Blithe Spirit," "By Jupiter," "Janie," "Life With Father," "Little Darling," "My Sister Eileen," "Rosalinda," "Show Time," "Stars on Ice," "Strip for Action," "The Damask Cheek," "The Eve of St. Mark," "Uncle Harry" and "Wine, Women and Song."

In more than four decades on Manhattan's waterfront, T. Walter Williams earned recognition as dean of New York's ship news reporters. He was more than that. He was a harborfront institution whose jovial manners and amiable habits endeared him to untold thousands of sailors and captains, longshoremen, passengers and tourists alike.

The Metropolitan Museum has announced that Mayor La Guardia has accepted the invitation of William Church Osborn, president of the museum, to speak at the opening of the exhibition of contemporary American paintings, prints and sculpture at the museum, on Monday afternoon, Dec. 7.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A three-year prison sentence imposed upon a young New Jersey pacifist was upheld today by the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Warning that widespread violations of War Production Board orders by distributors, jobbers and dealers in hard goods have been uncovered in this area, Linford C. White, chief of the distributors branch, War Production Board, Washington, issued a call yesterday for a distributors' meeting to be held at the Hotel Commodore at 10:30 A.M. on Friday.

The Brooklyn Federal grand jury handed up yesterday an indictment charging Johannes Kroeger, 44 years old, of Amityville, L.I., with violation of the United States censorship law and also conspiracy to violate the law. The defendant is a naturalized citizen of German origin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Blinded in one eye, wounded in the other and pretty badly battered otherwise, a marine, private Albert A. Schmid, has this solacing, helpful thought: His buddies say he killed more than 200 Japanese in one bloody night in the Solomons.

There was one vacant chair at Columbia's training table in the basement of the Faculty club yesterday -- the chair usually occupied by Mr. Lou Little, who is Orson Welles at his best when it comes to staging thrillers -- so we are unable to report just what the eminent impresario has up his sleeve for the spectators when the Columbia Lions perform against Navy in Baltimore on Saturday.

What had been presumed to be the New York Rangers' weak point proved their strongest in their National Hockey League clash with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. Steve Buzinski, expected to resemble a sieve, surprised the Hawks and a gathering of 8,559 by guarding the Blue Shirts nets ably enough to bring them a 5-to-3 triumph -- their second of the season.

In the first exercise of its authority to punish violators of its installment credit regulations, the Federal Reserve Board suspended yesterday for one week the operating license of eight Southern furniture stores. Heretofore, the board has policed its Regulation W, governing consumer credit, by issuing warnings to any violators. The regulations have been in effect about six months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Roosevelt at his press conference told some details of planning the North African expedition and said armed forces of the United States would reach 9,700,000 by the end of 1943; his visitors included Democratic leaders from Capitol Hill. Secretary Hull, Basil O'Connor, Harold Smith, budget director; Wayne Coy, his assistant, and Bernard Baruch.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Oct. 29 (Delayed) -- Caught in the Japanese lines at the height of the Japanese land attacks on Guadalcanal last Sunday morning, Marine Corps Private Thomas Cook and two companions fought off successive groups of Japanese totaling 150 or more for seven and one-half hours and regained the American positions.

TRENTON, Nov. 10 -- Governor Charles Edison was told today by the State Commission on Urban Colored Population that circumstances surrounding the jailing of eleven persons, including ten Negroes, in Hudson County "call to mind the concentration camps in Germany, where Gestapo methods are used."

The action of the House and Senate conferees yesterday in striking from the new draft bill the O'Daniel amendment to forbid the Army to use draftees under 20 in combat service until after they had received a year's military training has averted what would have been a disastrous error.

Israel Igo Hudes, 36 years old, an Austrian refugee with a police record there, was sentenced yesterday in the Municipal Term Magistrate's Court to a six-month workhouse term for cheating a girl employe of his now defunct Regent Novelty Company, Inc., formerly at 258 Fifth Avenue, of $15 in wages.

Meat and granulated sugar are not absolutely necessary in the preparation of attractive and tasty dishes, leading hotel chefs proved yesterday at the opening of the seventy-fourth Salon of Culinary Art, which is being conducted by the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique in Madison Square Garden, in conjunction with the National Hotel Exposition.

Occupation of Algiers and Oran completes the first phase of our African campaign. The two cities are the keys to all Algeria. With their fall, strategic control of the Mediterranean coast from Spanish Morocco to Bizerte passes from Vichy to the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- The National Power and Light Company, a registered holding company and a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company, received today from the Securities and Exchange Commission another year in which to comply with an order for dissolution handed down under the corporate simplification portion of the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 10 (UP) -- President Juan Antonio Rios said today in a message to President Roosevelt that Chile would play her part to help the United States in her fight to free French territory by increasing the production of vital war materials and by vigorous suppression of Nazi propaganda and espionage.
Andre Gomez, Havana, and Vinnie Rossano, Red Hook, fought to a draw in the feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Women of the United Nations must help make the peace for which we are fighting so valiantly if that peace is to insure freedom and justice, Senora Isabel de Palenira, Spanish-born reporter, author and formerly Spanish Republic Minister to Finland and Sweden, told the Women's National Press Club today.
Anheuser Busch, Inc., announced yesterday a dividend of $1 a share for payment on Dec. 10. This will bring payments for this year to $3.75 against $5 distributed in 1941.

Your obituary of T. Walter Williams, your ship news reporter and marine editor, gave a splendid picture of "the Skipper," as he was known to his legion of friends in public life and in journalism down through the years.

The Allied conquest of North Africa was continuing yesterday, with Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's shattered forces deep in Libya and still in full retreat and with American troops extending their holdings in Morocco and Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Faced with increasing difficulties in maintaining petroleum supplies on the East Coast, the government plans a further slash in the amount of gasoline to be allowed civilian motorists in this area.

Appointment of 2,500 "competent tire men" to serve as official OPA tire inspectors is being made by local War Price and Rationing Boards, it was announced yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, State OPA director, as word came from Washington that mileage rationing of passenger cars had been postponed from Nov. 22 to Dec. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The armed forces of the United States will total about 9,700,000 men by the end of 1943, President Roosevelt estimated at his press conference today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 10 -- To carry out continental obligations, "because one of us was attacked -- the United States -- and because we also were attacked," Brazil is fully mobilized and ready to fight on two fronts, the internal and the external, cooperating with all its means with "the noble North American nation," President Getulio Vargas said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Distinguished Service Medal awarded posthumously to Major Gen. Clarence L. Tinker, commanding the air forces in Hawaii, who was lost at sea during the battle of Midway June 7, was presented to his widow today by Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commanding the Army Air Forces.

General Henri Giraud, whose dramatic intervention in African affairs probably turned the scale in Algiers to the advantage of the Anglo-American invaders, escaped from France last Saturday dressed in the garb of an old woman. "She" was escorted by a young and attractive woman, who in the juncture is supposed to have been very active following upon General Giraud's flight from the German prison at Koenigstein.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 -- Whirlaway, in his last appearance of the Eastern racing season, showed his heels to three other routers today in the thirtieth Governor Bowie Handicap on the closing program at Pimlico.

The election of Dr. Miller McClintock as president of the Advertising Council, a new post, was announced yesterday by Chester J. LaRoche, chairman of the council. Up to now, Dr. McClintock has been executive director on a full-time basis.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Directors of the Eastman Kodak Company approved today payment of the company's thirty-first wagedividend to Western Hemispkere employes and declared quarterly dividends of $1.25 a share on the common stock and $1.50 on the preferred.

Rationing of tea probably will prove unnecessary, in view of the present stocks, if public purchases continue in a normal manner after the restrictions on coffee become effective Nov. 28, Benjamin Wood, managing director of the Tea Bureau said yesterday.

ADVANCED TRAINING CENTER, FLEET MARINE FORCE, New River, N.C., Nov. 11 -- All our fighting forces have morale, but the marines are convinced they have more of it than the others.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -On the basis of election returns now available, although not yet complete, it is possible to make an analysis of factors at work in the election Nov. 3.

SO many books about Nazi Germany have been written by so many scores of returned correspondents that one picks up each new one with dread and ennui. Goering's medals, Goebbels's promiscuity, the Fuehrer's vegetarianism, Ribbentrop's parvenu diplomacy, Ley's drunkenness -- all of these things constitute the debased reportorial coinage of a literary school which has just about written itself out.

Five minutes in the early morning devoted to the careful application of a good foundation and powder are worth half an hour of spasmodic retouching of make-up throughout the day. War marriages, with the provision that the couple have known each other "a reasonable length of time and are really in love," were advocated last night by Dr. Gulielma F. Alsop, physician at Barnard College, Columbia University. She spoke at the first in a series of lectures on war marriages being given for young women at the Central Branch of the Young Women's Christian Association, 610 Lexington Avenue.

Several large apartment rentals on the East Side were reported yesterday by the Madison Realty Company. Among the new leases was a garden duplex of five rooms and two baths in 215 East Sixty-second Street to Elizabeth de Vilmorin and in the same building another duplex of six rooms and three baths to Ida and Jean Wolfson.

November 10, anniversary of the 167th birthday of the United States Marine Corps, reminded Americans once more that this famous force, now at the very height of its glory, is the senior of the United States. The Continental Congress of 1775 in its resolution for the raising of two battalions of Marines showed a certain innocence.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 11 -Early this morning when news came of the entry of German troops into unoccupied France, coupled with the report that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain had left for "an unknown destination," the first impression given was that this report might be true, after all.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 12 U.P.) -- Soviet parachutists wrecked or damaged twenty-three German planes in a lightning raid on an Axis airdrome in the Western Caucasus yesterday, the High Command announced today amid reports that a new German drive on Stalingrad was imminent.

One of the seemingly small but none the less important services for American seamen in time of peace is the provision of sea-going libraries through the American Merchant Marine Library Association. In two decades the Association has sent to sea about half a million books and more than that number of magazines.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 12 -- The first clash between United States and German ground forces in this war is expected to come on the sandy wastes of Tunisia any hour now, if it has not already occurred.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 11 (AP) -Japanese soldiers are good fighters, "but they're the most treacherous on earth," in the opinion of a New Jersey marine who is home recovering from leg wounds suffered on Tulagi Island in the Solomons.

Led by heavy increases in apparel volume, sales of twenty-nine leading mail-order and chain-store companies showed an increase of 16.2 per cent in October, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The gain compares with a rise of 11.3 per cent in September.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Navy Department today announced that twenty-four more production centers, including two Navy yards and three naval ammunition depots, are to receive the joint Army-Navy "E" award for outstanding performance on war contracts. The list follows:

GLASGOW, Scotland, Nov. 11 -- Having waited patiently for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to make good her promise to visit Scotland, the hard-working people of Glasgow and West Scotland were disappointed today when her arrival coincided with the blackout and deprived them of the opportunity to demonstrate the affection and admiration that she has earned during recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -The Navy tonight announced dismissal of Lieut. Comdr. Maurice Aroff, who was court-martialed on charges of accepting gifts to facilitate the granting of a Navy commission. The Navy would not elaborate. He was accused specifically of accepting an automobile from Tony Martin, radio and film singer.

England's conscription of women may be a "socialistic" measure, but it is not worrying the English people very much, Mrs. Neville Lawrence, wife of Captain Lawrence of the Coldstream Guards, declared yesterday.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction will be "Once Upon A Honeymoon," starring Ginger Rogers and Cary Grant. Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended Tuesday totaled 769, which compared with 688 in the preceding week and 603 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Tuesday's registrations numbered 370, as against 251 for the same day last week.

LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Italians were reported to have landed troops today at Bastia, on the French island of Corsica. Long coveted by Premier Mussolini, Corsica would be an excellent stepping stone for the Allies in any move against the Southern European coast.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Although there was no official observance of Armistice Day today, there was a large attendance at a service of intercession held at St. Paul's as well as a short service at the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior in Westminster Abbey.

LONDON, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill told the opening session of the eighth Parliament today that the enemy's losses in Egypt had been "mortal." They include 34,000 Germans and 25,000 Italians killed, wounded or captured, besides many more wandering in the desert. British casualties, he said, had been 13,600, of which 58 per cent were from the United Kingdom.

The Clark-Robinson Corporation, dealers in first mortgages, have leased the ground floor space at 42 Broadway which was occupied for many years by the stock brokerage house of J.S. Bache Co. WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -The German occupation of all France was denounced by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his press conference today.

The Brooklyn Football Dodgers were out bright and early at Ebbets Field yesterday, trying to loosen up and, if possible, forget completely about the Chicago Bears. There was solace only in the fact that the Dodgers will not have to face them again this year.

The piano recital given by Ernest Hutcheson last night in Carnegie Hall attracted a large and responsive audience. Powerful offensives carried James Monroe and Seward Park to victory yesterday at Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island. They beat De Witt Clinton and Commerce in a schoolboy football double-header before 6,000 spectators. Monroe handed Clinton its worst beating in years, 40 to 6, while Seward overwhelmed Commerce, 25 to 12.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Roosevelt welcomed the fighting men of France today as Allies in a war in which the Axis nations face "inevitable, final defeat" as he laid a wreath on the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery in solemn wartime ceremonies commemorating the twenty-fourth anniversary of the first World War armistice.

Although wool stocks in the country are considered to be the largest in the history of the trade, it was forecast in mill, clothing and retail circles yesterday that blended fabrics will be prominent in men's wear for the Fall of 1943.

Four Armistice Day religious services were conducted yesterday, under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 11 -An army travels on its stomach and the United State Army Air Forces in China are no exception. The U.S.A.A.F. commissary here, however, is unique in that it is wholly in the exceptionally competent hands of the Chinese, thus enabling the Americans to concentrate their efforts and personnel exclusively on the business of fighting and leaving the problems of housing, feeding and general supply to the Chinese.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Thomas W. Delzell, a trustee of the Portland Electric Power Company, Portland, Ore., testifying today before the Securities and Exchange Commission, estimated at $25,800,000 and $6,700,000, respectively, the company's equity in its two main subsidiaries, the Portland General Electric Company and the Portland Traction Company.

WINNIPEG, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The wheat pit was deserted at times in a slow session on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today. December wheat closed unchanged at 90 1/2 cents a bushel. Grain markets in the United States were closed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Discovery of $2,650 in $50 bills under a rug in the home of Hans Max and Erma Haupt was described today at the trial of the Haupts and the four other Chicagoans on charges of treason.

Following conclusion yesterday of the series of conferences between officials of the Office of Price Administration and representatives of distillers, wholesalers, importers and other branches of the liquor industry, retailers here expressed fear that, while the agency apparently plans to require a "roll-back' of distillers' prices, the contemplated adjustment would not be sufficient to meet their needs.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 11 (AP) -Because a Flying Fortress proved more than a match for four German pilots who did not know what big game they were stalking, Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle, chief of the Twelfth Air Force, is continuing to direct the United States air attack against the Axis instead of lying dead.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Specific allegations of derelictions by government war agency executives in the steel, automotive, shipping, aluminum, radio and longshore industries were made here today by union chiefs at the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which adopted a resolution calling for full and equal participation of organized labor "in all the administrative agencies which make and execute our war policies and at every level."

Slashing out at the salvage section of the War Production Board for failure to move 100,000 tons of metal scrap out of the city, Mayor La Guardia expressed the hope yesterday that the entire section would be abolished.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 11 -- With many war production factories going at full speed and the induction of selectees continuing, New Jersey's observance of the twenty-fourth anniversary of the cessation of hostilties in the First World War was more subdued generally than in the peace-time years.

Columbia's defense and offense got a full-scale test at Baker Field yesterday as the Lions continued to push preparations for Saturday's encounter at Baltimore with a suddenly formidable Navy eleven. After about an hour and a half of stopping middie plays, the squad devoted an equal time to polishing every phase of its attack.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, the former Fulton Fish Market labor racketeer, who is scheduled to go on trial in General Sessions next Monday on a charge of extorting funds of a teamsters' local, was remanded to the Tombs without bail yesterday by Magistrate De Andrea in Felony Court for a hearing today in an alleged election law violation on Nov. 3.

Hailing the Jewish Theological Seminary of America on its fifty-fifth anniversary, President Roosevelt declared in a letter made public last eight that our enemies began their attack with an assault on religious institutions, and that the post-war world must be founded on renewed loyalty to the spiritual values inherent in the great religious traditions.

Immediate steps are being planned by Anthracite Industries, Inc., to undertake the largest research program ever carried out by the industry, Frank W. Earnest Jr., president of the organization, announced yesterday.

TRENTON, Nov. 11 -- In a move to conserve heat, light, power, gasoline and rubber, Governor Charles Edison issued an order today establishing a five-day, 37 1/2-hour week for most of the State's 15,750 employes. Heretofore the bulk of the State's workers have been on a five and one-half day week, but the total number of hours put in has varied, with some working less than thirty-seven and a half.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Army airplanes based in Alaska again struck at the Japanese in the western reaches of the Aleutian islands on Monday, destroying seven seaplanes and damaging two enemy cargo vessels, the Navy announced here today.

Brereton, United States Army Middle East Air Chief, who led the first combat operation undertaken by the American Tenth Air Force during the Burma campaign, received the Distinguished Flying Cross today for that action, in which he made two hits on a Japanese cruiser.

Arnaldo Estrella, the young Brazilian pianist who won the Columbia Concerts Award, will make his North American debut with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on Sunday afternoon, Feb. 7. He will play the Tchaikovsky piano concerto, with Bruno Walter conducting.

Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, and J.R. Parten, director of Transportation for the Office of Petroleum Coordinator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -Lieut. Gen. Leslie J. McNair, commander-in-chief of Army Ground Forces, declared tonight in an Armistice Day address broadcast to troops under his command that American soldiers must have one objective in life -- to hate, fight and kill.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 11 -- Twenty-four years, less six hours, after the signing of the armistice in World War I, the last vestiges of a "free" France disappeared from the map of Europe today when, preceded by two notes from Adolf Hitler -- one to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and the other to the nation -- German troops once again marched into territory that the Reichsfuehrer had promised to respect.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 11 -With a delay of one hour and a quarter, occasioned by German opposition to the departure of four members of the party, a special train left Vichy, France, at 4:15 o'clock this afternoon with American diplomats, newspaper correspondents and Red Cross workers.

LONDON, Nov. 11--Casablanca, the chief port of French Morocco, surrendered today to the American forces, marking the end of all effective resistance to the occupation of North Africa, designed eventually to liberate France.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Navy Department communique 188:

KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Setting a new record for speed in quadruple launchings of destroyers, the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company here celebrated Armistice Day today by sending four down the ways in twenty-eight minutes in ceremonies witnessed by 500 persons.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 11 -General Henri Honor Giraud, more than ever paladin of the French Army now that Adolf Hitler suggests that occupation of the whole of France is the consequence of his escape from captivity in Germany, crossed the Mediterranean one day last week in a British airplane, which took him to Algeria, where he is now organizing the Fighting French forces.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- More babies per 1,000 population were born in September than in any month since February, 1924, the Census Bureau announced today. The birthrate was set provisionally at 22.9.

While traffic in Times Square came to a halt and thousands of pedestrians and early theatregoers stood at attention yesterday, "Taps" was played by a Boy Scout on the marquee of the Hotel Astor at Broadway and Forty-fourth Street and echoed by another Scout across Broadway, in the annual observance of Armistice Day by the Boy Scouts of Greater New York.

The Management-Labor Policy Committee of the War Manpower Commission has performed an astonishing feat. It has submitted a report of several thousand words on the manpower problem and avoided all of the most important issues. It dwells on the urgency of the problem. It tells us that "several industrial centers are faced with a general shortage of labor."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- An official announcement as to the extent to which East Coast civilians must curtail further their use of petroleum products will be made before the end of this week by the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Supply, a spokesman for WPB said tonight.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, No. 12 (AP) -- A communique:

Chances that the exit gate will be shown the table d'hote dinner, at least for the duration, loom larger every day as restaurateurs find public opinion and that of their own associates adding to the strength behind the idea.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -The award of additional decorations to Army officers who distinguished themselves in the Philippines was announced today by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A realignment of War Production Board groups responsible for determining programs covering distribution of materials and for putting them into effect was announced today by Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- With French North Africa peacefully disposed in the hands of American troops, supported by British and American naval forces in the Atlantic and the Mediterranean, interest here hinged on an anticipated move eastward into Tunisia.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The news of the German move into unoccupied France effected the stock markets today where activity was on a reduced scale. Further profit taking also was a factor and prices sagged in most sections. The exception, however, was in the gilt-edge group where the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan and Old Consols gained 1-16.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Nov. 11 -- Just before sunrise, when there was a luminous band between the level stretch of the desert and the sky, fires here and there and everywhere for miles around could be seen flickering like candles over the dun landscape.
Reverberations from battle lines all over the world rumbled yesterday above prayers and the music of taps sent up from Allied countries in memory of the soldier dead of 1914-18.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

Governor Lehman had lunch with President Roosevelt in Washington yesterday, their first conference in some time. While no comment was forthcoming from either after the meeting, reports immediately were revived that the subject of discussion was the part that the Governor might be called upon to play in the war.

It is reported that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel established his headquarters in Tunis two or three days ago and has set himself to the task of making Tunisia the stronghold of the Axis in North Africa.

If three books can make a trend there is a trend of sorts this Fall in books of cartoons. While collections heretofore have usually been designed by their editors as variety packages, two cartoon books already published and another yet to come are built on a theme.

Some of Long Island's duck guides had a day off yesterday, others were busy with gunning parties on Great South Bay and Shinnecock Bay, and still others had almost decided to place themselves on the retired list. One veteran who has had four and five parties per week was out clamming since there were no gunners booked.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- The State's tax collections last month were $6,407,598 less than in October last year, with $2,350,600 of the decline attributed to the 25 per cent reduction of the personal income levy, which is effective on payments this year and next.

British experience in industry concentration programs has shown that the government should select nucleus firms, inasmuch as business men should not be forced to get together to "elect some of their members to commit at least temporary suicide," Arthur R. Burns, chief economic adviser of the Office of Civilian Supply, War Production Board, declared yesterday at the wartime meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Go home, and each one of you, work to win the war," was the parting message today of Mrs. Guy W. Cheney of Corning, outgoing president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, at the closing business session of the annual convention.

Concern over the future of approximately 200,000 Jews in what had hitherto been unoccupied France was expressed yesterday by officials of relief agencies that have been carrying on humanitarian work there, but this was counter-balanced somewhat by hope that the occupation of French North Africa by American forces would greatly ameliorate the lot of more than 300,000 Jews in that area.

A progressive increase in the number of women and minor males working in the "service" occupations in New York State, replacing men gone to armed service and heavy war industry, was reported yesterday by Miss Kate Papert, director of the women's division of the State Labor Department.

Net profit of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries amounted to $24,377,124 after depreciation, special amortization, taxes and all charges, according to the report covering the nine months ended on Sept. 30, issued by Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president, for publication today.

Sale of the Philadelphia National League Baseball Club, which has been in financial straits for several seasons and often reported on the block, is certain this Winter and possibly within a couple of months, according to The Associated Press yesterday.

Don Hutson, Green Bay's spectacular pass-catching end, who is headed toward his greatest season, set another National Football League record last Sunday, when he caught nine aerials for a gain of 96 yards against the Rams. That yardage increased his season's total to 915 yards and shattered the mark of 846, credited to him in 1939.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -"Iron Major," a biography of Frank Cavanaugh, hero of the first World War, written by his wife, Florence Cavanaugh, has been purchased by RKO as a vehicle for Pat O'Brien. The yarn will be filmed next year.

FLINT, Mich., Nov. 11 -- More than 500 serious young American soldiers who were just learning to walk alone or who were not even born when the First World War ended, marked the twenty-fourth anniversary of the signing of the armistice by putting in a full day of classroom and shop work today at the Buick Aircraft Engine School here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, and Admiral I.S. Isakoff, Chief of Staff of the Soviet Naval General Staff, have exchanged messages in connection with the twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the Navy announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- By their work in this war the women of Latin America must obtain recognition of their full rights, Senora Ana Rosa S. de Martinez Guerrero of Argentina, chairman of the Inter-American Commission of Women, declared today at the opening of the formal meeting of the commission in the Pan-American Union.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The text of Adolf Hitler's announcement to the French people, as carried by the Paris radio today on the entry of German troops into unoccupied France, follows:

Alsab and Victory Race Week smashed on to new triumphs yesterday at Belmont Park, where the bay colt decisively captured the $10,350 Victory Handicap, high point of the war charity meet which is bringing in hundreds of thousands of dollars for our service men.

Opposition to the proposal of railroads to cancel effectiveness of Rule 15 of the Consolidated Freight Classification for the duration, unless some provision is made whereby charges for less-than-carload shipments shall not exceed the charge for a carload shipment of the same kind of freight moving between the same points, was voiced here yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 11 (AP) -- American parachutists staged the longest air-borne invasion in history when they flew in transport planes 1,500 miles nonstop from England to participate in the assault on Oran.
Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday that it would take two years after Allied victories in Europe and Africa to drive the Japanese out of the Pacific.

The times in which we live call for a renewed faith in God "as essential to the well-being of man as bread and meat," the national sponsors' committee of the United Church Canvass, representing sixteen faiths, Christian and Jewish, declared yesterday.

Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, announced yesterday the establishment of a Radiological Research Laboratory as part of the cancer research program at Columbia University.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 11 (AP) -- While the British Eighth Army continued to hack away at fleeing Axis forces, both inside Egypt and across the border in Libya today, Allied bomber squadrons and submarines roamed the Mediterranean and struck repeated blows at enemy surface forces that might have hoped to assist General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel in his painful retreat westward.

Civilian Defense Volunteer Office branches throughout the city, many of which were closed for Armistice Day, will resume today the giving out of tire registration forms on which owners of passenger and commercial vehicles are to list the serial number of all tires in their possession.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 11 -Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement that he had not become leader of the London government "to preside over the liquidation of the British Empire" was taken by C. R. Rajagopalachari, former Premier of Madras, in an interview this morning, as confirmation of Indian suspicions that the British have no intention of giving up India.

ALLIED NORTH AFRICAN HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -The sudden end of hostilities in Morocco freed powerful American forces to swing their full weight eastward. Swift mobile units were striking today across the desert toward a prospective collision with airborne Axis troops rushed to Tunisia.

Warning against undue optimism over Allied successes in Egypt and Northwest Africa, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, called last night for an intensification of the country's war effort, as "there is no present reason to suppose that this is going to be a short war."

Governor-elect Dewey has made a promising start toward carrying out his campaign pledge to put the energies and resources of this State more effectively into the war effort. In the face of a national manpower crisis and a national need for full production, New York City, the greatest industrial city in the nation, has large unemployment, idle factories and idle machines, while many of its small businesses face the threat of extinction.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Delivering his fourth wartime speech from the throne at the opening of the new session of Parliament, King George VI, with Queen Elizabeth at his side, declared that his government was committed to a complete and speedy victory and the building of a better peacetime world at home and in the colonies throughout the world.

LONDON, Nov. 11--The moment Germany becomes "demoralized" by Allied pressure in Europe and Africa, she will be struck by invasion across the English Channel or the North Sea, Prime "Minister Winston Churchill promised the House of Commons today." An attack which will be made in due course across the Channel or the North Sea requires an immense degree of preparation," the Prime Minister declared.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Some measure of the hard, although brief, fighting that preceded the capitulation of French North Africa appeared tonight in an announcement by the War Department here that "sixteen Axis aircraft are now known to have been destroyed" in what were described as "intermittent attacks" in the Algiers area.

HARMON, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- A locomotive engineer and fireman were killed and three other trainmen were injured early today when a thirty-four-car fast freight crashed into the rear end of a seventeen-car baggage and express train that had stopped "for trains ahead" on the main-line tracks of the New York Central Railroad between Harmon and Ossining.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commander of the American Expeditionary Forces in North Africa, today broadcast an appeal to the French fleet to "join the United Nations in the fight for freedom" by sailing for Gibraltar.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (--Miss Vanbrugh had appeared in recent years with her daughter Prudence in Aldous'Huxley's play "This Way to Paradise," as well as in "Evensong" and "The lerry Wives of Windsor."
Payne Ratner, Governor of Kansas, and Mrs. Ratner have arrived from Topeka and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The War Labor Board, in line with its new policy not to grant wage increases "for the purpose of influencing or directing the flow of manpower," today disapproved an agreement made by the Staley Manufacturing Company of Painesville, Ohio, and the Chemical Workers Union (A.F.L.), calling for a 6-cents-an-hour general wage increase.
DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- A proposal by the Chrysler Corporation that the United Automobile Workers' Union (C.I.O.) freeze its contract with the company for the duration of the war was rejected today.

There is all the difference in the world between a job neglected and a job unfinished. This is one reason for congratulating the editors of The Survey Graphic on the happy choice of a title for their study of the race problem in the November number.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Senators who helped vote the one-year training requirement into the Senate's 18-19 draft bill abandoned hope today of restoring that restriction to the new Selective Service program. It was eliminated in conference yesterday, and the conferees' action ratified promptly by the House by an overwhelming vote.
In his address to the State Conference on Social Work, Father Lennon said:

Approximately $410,000,000 will be distributed to more than 8,000,000 Christmas Club members in the week of Nov. 30 through some 5,000 banking and savings institutions and other organizations, it was disclosed yesterday by Herbert F. Rawll, founder and president of the Christmas Club.

Judging by appearances late yesterday, the football players of Manhattan College are planning to serve as more than a welcoming committee for Jimmy Crowley's North Carolina Pre-Flight outfit at the Polo Grounds Saturday. Through preliminary work and a fairly stiff scrimmage, Herb Kopf had his charges working on the attack, and much of that attack was aerial.
at anchor in its home base of Toulon and to have left there.

Abraham Lincoln High finished its regular season unbeaten for the second straight year yesterday by scoring in every period to rout its Brooklyn rival, James Madison, 41 -- 0, before 3,500 spectators at Lincoln Field. It was the twelfth annual clash between the schools.

In a simple Armistice Day ceremony at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the yard, called on its thousands of workers to "salute those heroes of another war -- not with mere words but by producing a little bit more than yesterday."

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 11 "The housewife should be as particular about what she feeds her family as the farmer is concerning the feed for his livestock," Dr. Clive M. McCay, professor of nutrition, State College of Agriculture, Cornell, told some 300 delegates and guests attending the annual convention of the State Federation of Home Bureaus today.

AFTER Lieutenant (j.g.) Kidd (no kidding) Brewer, U.S.N.R., from the North Carolina Pre-Flight School, hauled anchor and steamed away yesterday, this observer pored over some printed material he left in his nautical wake. The word "nautical" is used advisedly, because Lieutenant Brewer, these Pre-Flight football players and all the instructors and aviation cadets at these Pre-Flight schools are -- and make no mistake about it -- in the Navy.

The Franklin Arms Hotel, a landmark at 66 Orange Street, in Brooklyn, opposite the Plymouth Church, has been purchased by A. G. Victor, formerly owners of the Graymore Hotel in Portland, Me. The hostelry contains 100 rooms.

A plan for consolidation of the Buckeye Pipe Line Company, the Indiana Pipe Line Company, the Northern Pipe Line Company and the New York Transit Company was announced yesterday by Kuhn, Loeb Co., investment bankers, who drew up the plan.

The events in Northern Africa and in France within the past few days mean that France has "reentered the war," and that all the internal French resistance to the Nazi rule acknowledge General Charles de Gaulle as its leader, Andre Philip, French National Commissioner of Interior and Labor declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Declaring that the peace plans of Woodrow Wilson and his hopes for America may yet be realized, Bishop James E. Freeman, from the tomb of the World War President in the Washington Cathedral, today called upon the nation to "bring about the triumphs of his noble ideals."
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- The uneasy lull at Stalingrad continues, perhaps, as Red Star suggests, for only a short respite before the German offensive is resumed. Reconnaissance raids, sporadic artillery and mortar exchanges and intensive sniping have characterized the last few days. Over the fighting lines there are air operations on a small scale.

The first dividend on New York Central Railroad common stock since 1931 was announced yesterday by F.W. Williamson, president of the road. The dividend, $1 a share, is payable on Jan. 15 to stockholders of record of Dec. 10.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have been driven from their main positions in the interior of Eastern New Guinea after suffering heavy losses, and Australian troops have blocked their road of retreat toward the northeastern coastal base of Buna, it was announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 -- Asserting the second front was now open and that America's part in the war had just begun, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, in an address to 1,200 industrialists, veterans of the first World War and labor leaders in McKeesport, declared tonight that management and labor must put aside bickering and complaints in order to help the country in the perilous days ahead.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Several months ago a visitor to the State Department found Secretary Hull gazing at a newspaper clipping.
