It was one of the many articles demanding immediate severance of relations with the Vichy government of France, and this particular article bore the opinion that no usefulness had ever come of these relations but that, on the contrary, post-war fascism in this country and current fascism elsewhere had been encouraged by their continuation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 11 (UP) -- The "cease-fire" order for French North Africa was given today by Admiral Francois Darlan, signing himself as commander in chief of the French forces in North Africa, and by Admiral Michelier, the commander at Casablanca.

Business was very good on Broadway yesterday afternoon. Sixteen of the twenty-five current offerings gave matinees. Three -"By Jupiter," "The Eve of St. Mark," and "Show Time" -- played to standee trade. Three others sold out: "Angel Street," "Blithe Spirit" and "My Sister Eileen."
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Alfred Moffatt, a department store executive of East Orange, told 300 North Jersey businessmen tonight to stop criticizing the government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A new and broader plan for Treasury borrowing "on an unprecedented scale," with the accent chiefly on borrowing from the public rather than from the commercial banks, was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Bank of England's weekly condition statement, issued today, shows an increase of 5,105,000 in notes in circulation to 863,200,000, another record.

Bank clearings in the five days ended on Nov. 11 amounted to $6,235,814,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total was 12.4 per cent below the previous week's five-day figure, but 9.2 per cent ahead of the $5,708,091,000 volume for the corresponding five-day week last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Sharply criticizing the War Manpower Commission as failing, after seven months, to establish a basic policy or program for meeting its increasing problems, a special Senate (Truman) investigating subcommittee today recommended a series of steps, including a lengthening of the basic workweek to at least forty-eight hours, which, it held, could be taken immediately by executive agencies through regulations and orders.

How Americans can help their Allies by voluntary food rationing was outlined yesterday afternoon by Dr. Henry C. Sherman, Mitchill Professor of Chemistry at Columbia University, at a forum on Meal Planning and Marketing Selection held at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Informants from the former unoccupied area of France said today that aged Marshal Petain was showing the strain of the crisis. Yesterday he was represented as deciding to remain in France and be close to the people, after declaring the 1940 armistice had been broken, with the right of free decision falling to all Frenchmen.

The cost of advertising space has gone up approximately 8 per cent since 1939, George S. McMillan, secretary of the Association of National Advertisers, reported yesterday at the annual convention of his group. Smallest rise was shown in outdoor and largest in network radio, he said.

The report of the Commercial Credit Company issued yesterday for the nine months ended with September shows a consolidated net profit of $5,609,929 after all charges and after adjusting Canadian and Federal income and excess profits taxes to terms of the existing statutes.

Thomas E. Dewey, through New York State's representative on the Republican National Committee, J. Russel Sprague, is maintaining a complete "hands-off" attitude in relation to the contest which is rapidly developing over a successor to Joseph W. Martin Jr. as Republican National Chairman.
Brooklyn College may be an offshoot of C.C.N.Y., but all paternal reverence will be forgotten when the Kingsmen meet the Beavers in their season's climax game in B.C.'s stadium tomorrow.

Columbia's first and second elevens scrimmaged against each other long after darkness at Baker Field yesterday as Coach Lou Little sent his squad through its last intensive drill before tomorrow's game with Navy. The Lions leave for Baltimore this morning and will engage in a light practice at the Municipal Stadium this afternoon.

One sentence in the letter Hitler sent to Petain as he took over the rest of France rises to a height of soaring hypocrisy seldom equaled even in the past record of this evil man. This was the sentence in which Hitler, speaking of the armistice of 1940, said: "The German Reich did not at the moment take advantage of the weakness of France in order to indulge in extortions * * * ."

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Berlin reported today that German anti-aircraft units had taken over all airfields and that other troops had been stationed at strategic points in Southern France. It was said that three panzer divisions were strung along the French Mediterranean coast and that medium and heavy tanks still were crossing the line that separated the formerly unoccupied part of France from the occupied area.

Pullman, Inc., reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $12,352,407, after all charges and taxes, equal to $3.74 each on 3,302,897 capital shares. For the corresponding period of 1941 the company had a net income of $7,853,401, or $2.38 a share.

Those rarely publicized members of the United States Navy who serve as gun crews on merchant vessels had their hour of glory yesterday afternoon on the windswept drill field of the Naval Armed Guard Station at the foot of Fifty-first Street in South Brooklyn.

The War Production Board, in the most drastic punitive order it has issued so far, yesterday forbade a Brooklyn rubber mat company to buy, sell or handle any kind of rubber until six months after the war.

It is distressing to read that fifty colleges in this country have closed their doors in recent months and that many others are on the verge of bankruptcy. These institutions are not large -- many are junior colleges or technical and professional schools. But for many years small colleges have been cradles of American democracy, and we cannot be complacent about their closing.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Although the majority of the Members of Parliament are satisfied with Prime Minister Winston Churchill's review of the Battle of Egypt there are still critics not only of Mr. Churchill but of the government as a whole.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- The Associated Electric Company received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to acquire $2,220,000 principal amount of its 4 1/2 per cent bonds, due Jan. 1, 1953, from Staten Island Edison Corporation, for $955,460 in cash, plus accrued interest.

ALGIERS, Nov. 8 (Delayed) -- Four American Commando soldiers led by a fast-talking British lieutenant colonel seized the vital airdrome at Blida, thirty miles southwest of Algiers, from several hundred well-armed French troops today.

An order granting judgment by default against Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer in a suit brought by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company as executor and trustee under the will of George R. Sheldon.

The pre-holiday irregularity in the stock market was carried over to yesterday's session, which resumed operations around the Tuesday pace. The idea still prevailed in many Wall Street sections that the quick-victory flush occasioned by the American thrust in North Africa might have been over-boisterous, and this thought invited a certain amount of selling.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- The government dealt its heaviest blow today in the treason trial of six Chicago men and women accused of sheltering and assisting Herbert Haupt, executed Nazi saboteur.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Two large waves of Japanese dive bombers hit our positions on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons on Wednesday (Solomons date), the Navy announced today.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- Two new airplanes expected to contribute materially to the United Nations war effort were introduced today by the Stinson Division of Vultee Aircraft, Inc., small highly maoeuvrable liaison craft and a navigation trainer for British naval pilots.

Furnishings of the Jay Gould house at Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street found new owners yesterday at an all-day auction sale on the premises. Some 1,500 bidders crowded into the old brownstone residence, paying approximately $15,200 for furniture, rugs, sculpture and a variety of other property.

Following closely on the previously announced withdrawals of Federal funds from commercial bank depositaries, effective yesterday, today and tomorrow, the Treasury notified banks late yesterday afternoon that it would make further withdrawals on Monday and Tuesday.

Public schools of New York State won high praise from Governor Lehman yesterday for their role in the war thus far, but the Governor called on their 48,000 teachers in a State-wide radio address to intensify the war program of the schools to meet the needs and hardships that beset the road to victory.

MONTREAL, Nov. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian banks will have to share in restriction of wartime civilian activity by closing more branches and curtailing or suspending certain services for the next few months, it was forecast today by Charles St. Pierre, president of the Canadian Bankers Association, at the annual meeting in session here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- President Roosevelt issued a proclamation designating Thanksgiving and New Year's as days of prayer and sent to the Senate the nomination of Major Gen. Mark Wayne Clark to be a lieutenant general. His callers included the Portuguese Minister, President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth, Ambassador Joseph C. Grew and Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The French fleet was reported to be lying with guns uncovered and steam up tonight off Toulon, the last remaining bit of unoccupied France, as the United Nations and the Axis vied feverishly behind the scenes and openly on the air waves for its control.
Chrysanthemums -- from the roly-poly, five-inch giant "spotlights" to the tightly curled, miniature pompoms -- continue to be the major items of interest on the floral scene.

The United States is losing 400,000,000 man days a year through absenteeism in industry, Charles P. Taft, assistant director of Defense Health and Welfare Services, declared last night at a dinner of the Kansas Society of New York at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Gambling raids were carried to within a block of City Hall at dusk last night when members of Police Commissioner Valentine's confidential squad entered five small offices at 277 Broadway, confiscated a large quantity of racing charts and betting sheets and disconnected ten telephones.

Lieutenant Robert Ludlow Fowler 3d, United States Naval Reserve, who was a grandson of the late Surrogate Robert L. Fowler of New York County, was killed in action in the South Pacific last month, according to word received by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Fowler Jr. of Katonah, N.Y., they announced yesterday. His age was 23.

Warning against a repetition of the "mental casualties" of the last war and the "ever mounting debt" for the care of the disabled, Dr. Marion E. Kenworthy of Columbia University called the Selective Service to account yesterday for emotionally unfit draftees.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Apprentice Johnny Tammaro, born and raised in the shadow of the Pimlico track, stole the show as Bowie opened its sixteen-day meeting today. The Baltimore lad rode five winners.
The 50-cent dividend voted yesterday on the common stock of American Export Lines, Inc. increases this year's payments to $2 a share from $1.50 distributed in 1941.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Following is the text of the report of the Special Committee Investigating the National Defense Program, filed with the Senate today:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, it was announced today, has awarded the Navy Cross to sixteen aviators for heroism in action against the Japanese during the Battle of Midway last June.

With the approach of Christmas and the need to make early shipments to England, headquarters of Bundles for Britain, 475 Fifth Avenue, appealed yesterday for "holiday contributions now" of clothing, knitted goods and cash for refugees and civilians in the British Isles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Declaring that there is a practical task for all young people in winning victory and securing the peace, President Roosevelt asserted today that "from the vast reserves of courageous and enthusiastic youth they must replenish the intellectual vigor of stricken lands, and with the clear eye and the firm hand of youth they must help create that better world toward which we strive."

Foot-tapping tunes from an accordeon lured women shoppers, idle service men and eager children to McCreery's downstairs fashion department last night, where the store staged an economy and budget fashion showing.

Marking the seventh consecutive week that the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System has given official support to the market for government securities by purchasing large amounts of government securities of all types, it was revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York that the committee bought $107,083,000 of these securities in the week ended on Wednesday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 12 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Commander in Chief of the Allied forces in North Africa, disclosed today the story of one of the war's most amazing undercover exploits. A Commandoescorted staff of American officers made a tour of French North Africa and gained essential military information three weeks before the American occupation began.

Unless the Army's stockpile of bed sheets is diverted to urgent needs of the Medical Corps, now critical as a result of the opening of the North African action, civilian purchases during January white sales may be limited by New York department stores in a voluntary program designed to prevent scare buying and to spread available stocks equitably.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to acquire from its subsidiaries the capital stock of eleven short-line railroads in Alabama, Utah, Pennsylvania, Missouri and Ohio at a total cost of $6,252,297.
TORONTO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Boston Bruins, 3 to 1, tonight and remained in a first-place tie in the National Hockey League race alongside the Montreal Canadiens.

Liquidation by commission houses and the South depressed prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, active futures contracts ending the session at the lows, 7 to 22 points under Tuesday's final quotations.

NATURALLY the eminent Mr. Charles (Chick) Wergeles would bubble over when speaking of Beau Jack, the lightweight boxer who is scheduled to have a go with Allie Stolz in the main bout at Madison Square Garden this evening. Mr. Wergeles is Beau Jack's manager. But it might be mentioned that Beau Jack isn't the only young fellow of belligerent disposition in whom Mr. Wergeles has a heartfelt interest.

A syndicate headed by Shields Co. and including H.B. Boland Co. and J.S. Rippel Co. won yesterday the award of $348,000 of city of Camden, N.J., refunding bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1942, and due serially on Nov. 1, 1950, to 1959. The bankers bid 100.79, naming the interest rate as 3.20 per cent.

ABOARD A U.S. TRANSPORT in the Mediterranean, Nov. 7 (Delayed) -- Autumn sunlight splashed over the waters of the harbor where scores of British and American ships of this convoy were assembling. American and British troops crowded the rails, singing and shouting.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- A bust of the late General Hugh S. Johnson, presented by Bernard M. Baruch on behalf of the War Industries Board and accepted by Colonel R. C. F. Goetz for the Military Academy, was unveiled this afternoon in the West Point library.

Lifting the threat of dismissal from 500 city school teachers, the Board of Education announced yesterday that as a result of economies made within recent months, all members of the teaching and supervising staff will retain their jobs during the present school year.

OTTAWA, Nov. 12 -- The Federal Department of Justice announced this afternoon that a warrant had been sworn out charging Edward J. Rohrbough, an American citizen, with a violation of the Defense of Canada Regulations.

More than 80 per cent of the people believe that manufacturers are doing a good job in the war effort but advertising should not be used to boast of industrial accomplishments, research experts told the concluding session of the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Navy announced today that 727 marine, Coast Guard and Navy casualties were reported to next of kin from Oct. 16 to 31.

Holders of Kingdom of Belgium external loan 6 per cent bonds, due Jan. 1, 1955, are being notified by J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., and the Guaranty Trust Company, as sinking fund administrators, that $443,000 of these bonds have been drawn for redemption on Jan. 1, 1943 out of moneys in the sinking fund.
Mr. and Mrs. R.C. Cecil St. George of Oldwick, N.J., have come to the Plaza.
In a letter to THE TIMES Paul Windels makes two points about the polls of the American Institute of Public Opinion which require an answer.

The War Production Board's salvage section, which Mayor La Guardia had said on Wednesday he hoped would be "cleaned out," may take out of the Mayor's hands the job of moving the city's household scrap metal to the steel mills, it was indicated last night.

To find if possible a cross-section of war manpower conditions that would be typical of the whole problem a survey of the Baltimore area was ordered recently by a group of public-spirited citizens and it has just been completed by Market Analysts, Inc. The revelations are discouraging, but they serve a most useful purpose in highlighting the manpower situation in the United States and in plainly indicating solutions.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Vast quantities of supplies, including 3,052 planes, were sent to Russia by the United States and Britain in the twelve-month period ended late in September or early in October, and despite enemy attacks on convoys bound for Russia over the northern route the great bulk of these supplies reached their destination, Richard K. Law, Under-Secretary of Foreign Affairs, told the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Over the protest of Senora Ana Rosa S. de Martinez Guerrero, chairman and Argentine delegate to the Inter-American Commission of Women, Senorita Minerva Bernardino, Dominican Republic delegate and vice chairman, summoned the women of Argentina and Chile today to urge their governments to break with the Axis and consolidate the hemispheric front.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 12 -- The American diplomatic and newspaper party from Vichy, which had become undesirable since the Petain government "registered that diplomatic relations were broken with the United States," arrived at Lourdes today in an unheated French train.

RICHMOND, Calif., Nov. 12 -- Four days fifteen hours twenty-five minutes after the first section of keel had been laid, the 10,500-ton cargo ship Robert E. Peary was launched today at Richmond Yard No. 2, one of Henry J. Kaiser's shipbuilding plants.

Distress conveyances of real estate in Manhattan last month declined in number and dollar volume from September, according to the monthly survey of the Real Estate Board of New York, which shows that there were 107 such conveyances involving a total of $7,945,521 in October.

Eight million tons of ships in 1942 and 16,000,000 tons in 1943, the goals set for the country by President Roosevelt, will be delivered on schedule, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission and head of the War Shipping Administration, stated yesterday in his presidential address before the fiftieth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Three men who pleaded guilty on Nov. 2 to an indictment charging them with acting as agents of the Japanese Government without registering with the Secretary of State as such were sentenced yesterday by Judge Marcus B. Campbell, in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to serve seven years each in prison.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Setting the Thanksgiving Day celebration for the traditional last Thursday in November, President Roosevelt proclaimed that day and New Year's Day as days of prayer.

Nine new tenants have signed leases in the Buchanan, 160 East Forty-eighth Street, Pease Elliman, managing agents, reported yesterday. They are R. Clyde Allen, Eugene H. Briggs, Keturah Blakely, Mrs. Camilla G. Clark, Felix E. Edmunds, James E. Glynn, Lawrence J. La Cava, Marie K. Neary and Mrs. Helen Newell.

MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 13 -- Fighting in sub-zero cold, the Germans and Russians traded narrow strips of Stalingrad's battle-ripped earth yesterday while the Red Army in the Caucasus successfully counter-attacked near Nalchik and held firm at Tuapse, a Soviet communique reported early today.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 12 (AP) -- British Blenheim bombers were reported officially today to have damaged two newly arrived Japanese supply ships and set fires among docks in a series of heavy attacks on the port of Akyab on the west coast of Burma.

While reports from almost 80,000 business firms have revealed 200,000,000 pounds of idle and excessive inventories of copper and copper-base alloy products, holders of 64,000,000 pounds thus far have refused to sell this material and the government will take immediate steps to requisition these stocks.
Manhattan's football team tuned its offensive weapons yesterday in a last stiff workout for the final home game against North Carolina Pre-Flight at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

To increase the incomes of dairy farmers and relieve a threatened shortage of fresh milk in the New York milkshed, the last "diversion payments" remaining in the Federal-State price-fixing machinery have been ordered eliminated, it was announced yesterday.

The report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept 30, made public yesterday by Earle Machold, president, shows a net income of $6,376,240, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges.

Eudora Welty, Mississippi short story writer and novelist whose first work was published only six years ago but who, particularly in the last two years, has achieved considerable popular and critical acclaim, is the winner of the first of this year's four O. Henry Memorial prizes for short stories.

Complaints of widespread violation in Brooklyn and Queens of the regulation forbidding gasoline stations to sell gasoline during more than twelve hours in one day or seventy-two hours in a week led yesterday to a characterization of those boroughs as "a particular hot spot" of the seventeen-State Eastern district.

The Philadelphia City Council adopted yesterday a refunding plan covering $162,296,000 of the city's bond debt, which will effect a saving to the city of about $45,000,000 debt service charges, it was announced here yesterday by Drexel Co., and Lehman Brothers, who, with associates, were designated as agents for the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- General John J. Pershing, 82 years old, General of the Armies of the United States and the leader of the American Expeditionary Forces in France in 1917-18, appealed tonight to the French as his "former comrades-in-arms" to form their battalions and join the ranks of the United Nations in the battle for freedom.

Are those famous secret agents and sirens of song and story really good for anything in real life? It is one of a dozen questions that leap out of Winston Churchill's fascinating story of the Battle of Egypt and the second front.

Our service men benefited by about $300,000 as the result of Victory Race Week, which ended yesterday at Belmont Park, with 10,559 present for the score of Bolingbroke in the General U.S. Grant Handicap. Congratulations were flying from all sides to Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the Turf Committee of America, and John J. Coakley, who managed the meeting.
The conversation on the morning train with the Connecticut duck hunter went something like this:

Many prominent persons, including Mrs. Payne Whitney, Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, Commander and Mrs. Vincent Astor, Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr., Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of Brooklyn and Commander and Mrs. Junius S. Morgan, are among the latest contributors to the United Hospital Campaign.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Unfounded rumors that the "tube-for-a-tube" regulation governing the purchase of tooth paste and shaving cream be extended to other products have resulted in the hoarding of many tons of tin in the form of empty tooth paste and shaving cream tubes, W.M. Rose, president of the Tin Salvage Institute, an agent of the Metals Reserve Company, a government concern, said today.

CALDWELL, N.J., Nov. 12 (AP) -- A two-year labor contract affecting hourly employes of the Caldwell and Clifton plants was signed today by the Curtiss Wright Corporation Propeller Division and Aircraft Lodge 703, International Association of Machinists, A.F.L.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's terms for immediate peace with Vichy, restoring to France all her 1939 Continental territory except Alsace and Lorraine, were carried to Vichy by Arch-Collaborationist Pierre Laval from his Munich meeting with the Reichsfuehrer, it was reported tonight in reliable Continental circles with close Vichy connections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Charging manpower waste in war industry. Harvey W. Brown, president of the International Association of Machinists, told a Senate labor subcommittee today that a worker in the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation's plant at Fort Worth had made this statement under oath:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Contending again that this country is losing the war in the Pacific and will not even begin winning it until basic changes are made in national policy, Representative Melvin J. Maas, Republican of Minnesota, voiced in a radio address tonight charges which he made in a speech in Richmond, Va., last night.

While high up on the white minarets that dot the skylines of the cities of Morocco and Algeria the muezzins praised the Lord, the Americans passed the ammunition on the shores of Africa in one of the most spectacular military coups in history.

The Third Avenue Transit Corporation continues to retire its obligations, Slaughter W. Huff, president, told the annual meeting yesterday. Another $400,000 has been placed in the hands of the trustee for retirement of its first extended 5 per cent bonds due in 1943, he said, making $800,000 retired since June 30 and cutting the amount outstanding to about $400,000.

Installment furniture sales in the third quarter were off 25.1 per cent from the corresponding period last year, according to a report issued yesterday by Arthur Fertig Co. The report, based on an analysis of operations by representative stores east of the Mississippi, showed a sharp drop in the rate of decline starting with September, the first month when 1942 figures were compared with a 1941 period in which Regulation W was in effect.

Marketing this week-end is slated to be a fairly tranquil affair, with no unpleasant surprises in store for budget-bound shoppers. Prices in butcher shops, at dairy counters and in fresh fruit and vegetable stalls are much what they were last Friday, and whatever changes have taken place have been slight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- For the third consecutive week there was no change in the general level of prices in primary markets as a further rise in farm product prices, particularly for grains and dairy products, was offset by declines for hogs and pork.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Leo Durocher, manager of the Dodgers, said today every one was overlooking one candidate for the job of leading the team next season -- Leo Durocher.

Jesse Donella, owner of a garage at 221 West Fifty-eighth Street, one-time associate in the taxicab business of Jules Martin, the gangster who was slain by George (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, in 1934, was held in $5,000 bail yesterday by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions as a material witness in an investigation of a "clip-joint" gang operating in the midtown section.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a plan for the merger of four subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, with the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company to be the surviving corporation.
GLASGOW, Nov. 12 -- Although Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's last engagement in Glasgow yesterday did not end until after midnight, she was out again early this morning.
MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

A letter writer to The Times of London records an ironic discovery, following the clearing away of debris after the Blitz bombings. Between "Guildhall and the garden of St. John Zachary and its adjacent neighborhood * * * it is now possible to trace the line of the Roman wall in a manner that has not been known for hundreds of years."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- General Antonio Oscar de Fragoso Carmona, President of Portugal, expressed "sincere appreciation" today, for the assurance of President Roosevelt when the North African campaign opened that Portugal had nothing to fear from the United Nations.

Anthony Cramer, in custody because of his associations with two of the Nazi saboteurs sent here by submarine, first lied to protect his friends and then admitted that he knew why one of them was here, according to evidence presented at Cramer's trial for treason yesterday.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 12 -- Federal manpower control was urged here today by members of the North Carolina Cotton Manufacturers Association Convention.

Your editorial "Two Hard Tongues" will no doubt be read by many students of the Chinese and Japanese languages with great interest. The great difficulty about the study of the Japanese language is not so much to speak Japanese but to be able to write and read it.

Tunisia and the Central Mediterranean area were rapidly becoming the key battleground of the war yesterday as United Nations and Axis forces concentrated ships, planes and troops in what may be a decisive struggle for the Mediterranean.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

MECKLENBURG, Silesia, Pomerania and East Prussia are sometimes called in Germany the Ostelbien, the land east of the Elbe. In the Reichswehr, built up in the Nineteen Twenties through treachery, intrigue and defiance of peace treaties by Hans von Seeckt, more than 60 per cent of the officers were Junkers from the Ostelbien, members of a hereditary military aristocracy.

Rev. Dr. Ralph C. Walker, vice president of the Northern Baptist Convention, which convened here yesterday at 2 Park Avenue, announced that the convention would seek to raise a world emergency fund of at least $600,000.

Because of the popularity of Offenbach's "La Vie Parisienne," the New Opera Company will continue the run of that offering at the Broadway Theatre, Mrs. Lytle Hull, president, announced yesterday. As a result of this decision, made at a meeting of the company's officials, the premieres of the other scheduled attractions have been postponed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A War Labor Board mediation panel ruled today in a Newark (N.J.) case that the WLB had jurisdiction over labor disputes of Federal and municipal employes, even though their salaries were fixed by law or civil service regulations.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The disposition of the sixty-two French warships known to have been lying in the harbor of Toulon under command of Admiral De la Borde hung in the balance today when the Germans announced that the fortified area of Toulon would not be occupied but that the men-of-war there would be "safeguarded."

Claims service offices have been set up by the War Damage Corporation in the United States and certain of the territories and possessions to service any claims that may arise under so-called "bombardment'' insurance policies issued by the corporation on and after July 1, 1942, according to regulations issued by the corporation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A national conference of the representatives of fifteen leading organizations of the country has been called to meet in Washington Nov. 20 to draw up a program for immediate government rationing of all commodities on which there are prospective shortages.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- While football dopesters were dividing their votes between Princeton and Yale on the outcome of the Big Three clash at Baker Field in New York on Saturday, Coach Tad Wieman spent two hours in a final all-out practice on University Field today shaping an entirely new offense with which the Tigers will attempt to surprise the Elis.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 12 -- Aiming at increased production of liquid-cooled aircraft engines, the Allison division of the General Motors Corporation will soon put into effect a work-day schedule of two ten-hour shifts to take the place of the three eight-hour shifts now in operation at the several plants of the company here.
The American Institute for Iranian Art and Archaeology has begun moving from 724 Fifth Avenue to its new home at 9 East Eighty-ninth Street, the former residence of Charles H. Keep.
VVASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Industrial diamonds have been placed under strict control by Amendment No. 2 to general preference Order M-109, announced today by the Director General for Operations.

The new Salary Stabilization Unit of the Bureau of International Revenue opened its New York offices at 253 Broadway yesterday and announced its readiness to receive applications for rulings on salary increases and decreases affecting all individuals who receive annual salaries of more than $5,000 and salary payments of less than $5,000 in the case of executive, administrative or professional employes who are not represented by labor organizations.

If truth is to be told it was heavy weather for American music and for the assembled audience last night in Carnegie Hall. This was because most of the music by native composers presented was conventional or bad and dull, or all three. It was no one else's fault.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Suppositions that the Department of Justice is conducting a widespread anti-trust investigation into the affairs of the railroads were dispelled today by Attorney General Biddle, who added that the department had no idea of instituting any proceedings against the carriers "which will impede or obstruct the war effort."

Your editorial "Two Hard Tongues" is accurate. There are no Americans who know all the 27,000 characters used in the Chinese and Japanese languages. There are probably fewer than 200 Americans of our race who know the 4,000 or 5,000 characters which form the equipment of, let us say, a Japanese army officer -- and at least half of those are missionaries too old for military service.

Vice President Marshall's famous remark that "What this country needs is a good five-cent cigar" must now be modified, whether his hope has been realized or not. The Office of Price Administration has ruled that the ceiling price of cigars may be raised by 20 per cent. So the old stand-by becomes a six-center.

When the novel "Reprisal" is released on Monday by Little, Brown the matter of the authorship credits will be handled this way: The book will be signed by Ethel Vance, for although the secret is out and Miss Vance, author of the best seller "Escape," has been revealed as Grace Zaring Stone, the pseudonym is now a more valuable literary property than the author's real name.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 12 -- Soviet troop concentrations are continuing, reports from Berlin said tonight, indicating a decision of the Russian Fiigh Command to launch offensive moves supposedly i related to the. British-Americanl operations in Africa.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A fund of $1,100,000 has been pledged to Nutrition Foundation, Inc., a national organization supported by the food and allied industries to support a five-year program of basic research in the science of nutrition, George A. Sloan, its president, announced today.

Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21-year-old mother of four small children, charged with first-degree murder in the shooting of her husband, Alman, 23, took the stand in her own defense yesterday in Bronx County Court after two of her husband's aunts, testifying in her behalf, told how their nephew beat Mrs. Harrington in their presence.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The noon communique:

The Supreme Court's unanimous decision upholding the Government's power to regulate wheat production even when the crop is consumed on the farm appears to have far-reaching implications. The case involved Roscoe C. Filburn, an Ohio farmer who, in the Fall of 1940, planted twenty-three acres of Winter wheat, twelve acres more than his allotment under the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

A fifteenth century Flemish illuminated manuscript was sold for $2,500 yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at an auction of rare books, drawings, prints and other property of the late B.T. and Philander L. Cable, Rock Island, Ill.; the estate of Charles M. Ayer, New York, and other estates and owners.

"Mr. Sycamore," described as "the saga of John Gwilt in eight verses," opens tonight at the Guild Theatre, the second of this season's -- and this week's presentations by the Theatre Guild. The play is by Ketti Frings and is based on a short story by Robert Ayre.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Nov. 13 -- American Flying Fortresses scored hits yesterday in the Northern Solomons on four Japanese transports loaded with troops and equipment, probably inflicting heavy losses, while in the jungles of Eastern New Guinea Australian troops neared the village of Wairopi, forty miles from the enemy-occupied northeastern coast, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The dramatic and complete success of American forces in occupying French North Africa is important to the war effort but does not diminish the program by which this country needs 7,500,000 trained soldiers by the end of next year, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said today.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- A Vichy broadcast today reported that German forces had entered Marseille, major French port forty miles west of Toulon. Dispatches from Portbou, near the Mediterranean junction of the French and Spanish borders, said German troops had taken over the French frontier posts.

One of the lesser publicized Giant stars in the snappy victory over the Philadelphia Eagles last week was Bob Trocolor of Alabama, Long Island University and way stations. But so impressed was Stout Steve Owen by the freshman back that the Giant coach is considering starting the 205-pounder against the Redskins at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Navy communique 189:
NEW DELHI, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A communique from British Headquarters in India:

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 12 -- Various indications today show what the German occupation of France is likely to mean. The current view among foreign observers is that France's fate is to be that of a second Denmark or even a second Belgium.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- A combined amphibious force of superbly equipped Americans and battle veterans of the British First Army struck tonight by land and sea at the immediate approaches to Tunisia. The attack was paced by a destructive Royal Air Force assault from the east on the air forces with which the Germans have infiltrated.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Uncle Sam's large-scale housekeepers again have their eyes on the average American kitchen. Having advised Mrs. Housewife on the allocation of sugar, coffee and fats, they are now scrutinizing the gas stove, which, too, can "join the colors" in the cause of conservation.

The Greenwich Savings Bank has sold the four five-story remodeled store and apartment buildings at 48-54 East Thirty-fourth Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, to an investor through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., and L.V. Hoffman Co.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- With a warning that the War Labor Board's alleged failure to readjust its machinery in advance of President Roosevelt's executive order on wage control threatened to destroy the effectiveness of the board because of the accumulation of cases, the Congress of Industrial Organizations adopted today a program urging the board to do these things:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 -- Having always believed that the air war in the Middle East was a war to secure control of the Mediterranean, Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur William Tedder has not had to alter his tactical ideas because of the American landings in North Africa.

ABOARD A U.S. TRANSPORT in the Mediterranean, Nov. 7 (Delayed) (AP) -- The explosive crash of a torpedo striking the ship just behind us ushered in the eventful final day of our convoy voyage carrying United States and British troops to a point from which landing operations could be carried out against Alegria.

AT TWELFTH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, somewhere in Algeria, Nov. 11 (delayed) (U.P.) -- When the history of the Algerian campaign is written Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle's fighter pilots will come in for a big slice of the glory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Treasury today set at rest the apprehension of French nationals living in the United States that their status under its freezing orders had been changed by Sunday's action in including hitherto-unoccupied European France within enemy territory.

"Casablanca," a Warner Brothers production about American war refugees in French Morocco, will have its world premiere at the Hollywood Theatre on Thanksgiving Day, Nov. 26. The picture, which was adapted by Howard Koch and Julius J. and Philip G. Epstein from an unproduced play by Murray Burnett and Joan Alison, was directed by Michael Curtiz and produced by Hal Wallis.

At least one housewife among the 102 persons accused yesterday by the Office of Price Administration of making improper use of supplemental gasoline rations, by driving to racetracks and football games in the metropolitan area, laid her plans to keep her husband in ignorance of her trouble.

The war has taken a definite turn in favor of the cause of the United Nations, but it would be dangerous to assume that victory is around the corner, Otto Tolischus and Hanson W. Baldwin told an audience in the New York Times Hall. 240 West Forty-fourth Street, last night in a symposium on the military situation in Europe and in the Pacific.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The deserts of North Africa are not the place in which the Allied powers should look for laurels on which to rest, Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Premier of South Africa, said here today, demanding that the exertions of every one must be redoubled.
Earl Walsh came out of his office into the pressroom at Fordham yesterday and there were tears in his eyes.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The voice of its long-time commander was added tonight to the radio chorus urging the French fleet to steam away from Toulon, where it is lying strangely orphaned -- the last bit of unoccupied France.
SOMEWHERE IN ALGERIA, Nov. 12 -- The American success in Algeria was cinched within a half hour of the zero hour in the early hours of Sunday morning.
The mother of one of our latest Army heroes in Africa rejoiced yesterday and acknowledged she was "very happy and I'm very proud of my son."

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Stock concern formation in October dropped to 610, making a total of 7,461 for the ten months, compared to 11,915 in the same period last year, according to Secretary of State Michael F. Walsh. The October total compares with 976 for October a year ago

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- To meet the increased demands for oil and gasoline required by the expeditionary forces in North Africa, Secretary Ickes asked today for a reduction of 139,000 barrels a day in the rationed supplies of petroleum and petroleum products to the seventeen East Coast States and for further voluntary curtailment of home oil and gasoline consumption.

Voluntary elimination of double-feature movies, without government compulsion, was advocated yesterday by Lowell Mellett, chief of the bureau of motion pictures in the Office of War Information, as a wartime measure that also would be beneficial to the nation's physical, mental and spiritual development.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The tone of today's stock markets was firm, and although trading was on a small scale there was little evidence of profit-taking.

Manufacturers revealed yesterday that their reports on overcoat sales through the Middle West and Northwest were quite favorable, showing gains of from 15 to 25 per cent over the previous week. Most retailers report that more serviceable types are in best demand.

Now, as German troops begin to be withdrawn from the Eastern Front for use in France -- Ankara reports that as many as forty-two divisions are involved -- a good moment has arrived to examine the familiar charge that the British and American Governments "misled" Russia about their intention to create a second front and thereby "let Russia down."

Forecasting that American soldiers soon would be in Tunis and Tripoli, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said last night that control of North Africa was part of an encirclement of Hitler of hemispheric proportions, which would give us and our allies many more jumping-off places "to carry the war to where it will be won -- on German soil."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- All priority assistance for three months was denied to the Colonial Supply Company of Louisville today for constructing a swimming pool for Senator Chandler of Kentucky without authorization by the War Production Board.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Dwight Deere Wiman, theatrical producer, announced yesterday that he had accepted the post of director of entertainment for the American Red Cross in the United Kingdom and that he would produce no more plays for the duration of the war.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Although trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade was restricted today, corn was again the market leader, with prices moving up around 5/8 cent a bushel at one time. Commission houses and professional traders were good buyers on a broad demand for cash grain.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 -- The British Eighth Army is now driving forward on a scale reminiscent of campaigns in Continental Europe. The retreating Germans, meanwhile, are jamming roads 150 miles inside Libya, well west of Tobruk.

An average gain of 23 per cent in inventory dollar values was shown in twenty representative retail lines during the twelve months ended June 30, according to the findings of a survey by the research and statistical division of Dun Bradstreet, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Shortages of gas, some of "alarming" proportions in many areas, prompted the War Production Board's power branch today to put strict curbs on deliveries of manufactured and natural gas in all parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Congress completed action on the 18 to 19-year-old draft bill late today when the Senate, just a month after President Roosevelt formally requested such legislation, approved with a voice vote the conference agreement which eliminated its own provision that selectees under 20 years old should receive at least a year's training before assignment to foreign combat duty.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase of $107,083,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, which were at a record high. Note circulation for the system as a whole was at the highest of the year to date, while ratio of reserve for the system and also for the New York bank were at a low for the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- At the White House these days noses are counted before the coffee is made so that none of it will be wasted. At present a demi-tasse is offered at luncheon and dinner and a full-sized cup at breakfast.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 -- For several days Allied bombers of the Middle East Command have hammered Axis airfields on the island of Sardinia, whence Axis airborne troops are being rushed to North Africa.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Theodore P. Wright, aeronautical expert and vice president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, has been elected an honorary fellow of the Royal Aeronautical Society, a rare honor that has been accorded to only fifteen of the society's total membership of 3,000, it was learned today.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- General Electric workers during the first ten months of 1942 were paid $115,000 for 12,250 ideas for saving materials or time in war production. This surpasses the best previous annual mark, $104,000 paid for all suggestions in 1929.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Captain William T. Cherry Jr. of Abilene, Texas, was found on a life raft. He was the pilot of the Rickenbacker plane.

The stock market failed yesterday to break out of its dull and irregular trend as volume dropped despite two special offerings of 50,000 shares each. With the first enthusiasm caused by the North African military successes evaporated, brokers see the market entering what it terms the dislocated period of the year.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A joint communique by the R.A.F. and British Middle East Command:
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- There was a much firmer tendency in today's stock market, where, however, business continued dull due to week-end considerations.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 14 -- Heavy bombers blasted two Japanese light cruisers and set fire to a transport in the same Buin-Faisi area of the North Solomons where only yesterday four troop-laden transports were bombed, the Allied High Command reported today.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- In an interview with representatives of the press of almost all the United Nations today Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Premier of South Africa, warned against hopes of an early victory.

Records for special offerings on the New York Stock Exchange were made yesterday when Smith, Barney Co. sold 100,000 shares of the Phelps Dodge Corporation and the Kennecott Copper Company. Each offering was for 50,000 shares -- a top so far -- and each broke the old record for purchasers, with 367 for Phelps Dodge and 305 for Kennecott.
Defenders of the table d'hote dinner spoke out yesterday against the movement that would ban it for the war's duration as a waster of food.

For the sixty-sixth time in the course of the oldest football rivalry in the country, the teams of Yale and Princeton will come together this afternoon, but with their game shifted to an alien gridiron by the fortunes of war.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- Robert Faulconer Jefferys, 46-year-old assistant financial vice president of the Insurance Company of North America, was accidentally shot and killed by his own gun in a hunting accident Tuesday on his estate, Faulcon Farm, near Ambler, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Production of metal plastering bases and accessories, now on a quota basis, will cease for any purpose except war procurement on Nov. 16, when a "stop production" order, L-59-b, becomes effective. The products affected are chiefly expanded metal lath, metal stucco mesh, sheet metal lath, wire lath and any one or more of these in combination with a metal paper, fabric or other backing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Montgomery Ward Co. rejected today an order of the War Labor Board directing the company to include the "membership maintenance" clause and other provisions in its contract with a C.I.O. union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- At least two medium-wave radio transmitters in North Africa, those at Rabat and Algiers, which easily reach Europe and the Near East, have been broadcasting American official programs prepared on the ground by representatives of the Office of War Information ever since the entry of American troops into those French colonial towns, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- William Wernecke, former German-American Bund officer on whose farm Herbert Haupt, executed Nazi saboteur, practiced to become a storm trooper, was indicted today for draft evasion.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- After a week spent in touring the Midlands, Northern Ireland and Scotland, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt returned to London early this morning by train from Edinburgh.

This week-end leaders in industry, education, government and labor will sit down together to discuss the complex problems of financing the New York City school system. A two-day conference on school finance has been called, sponsored by the local teachers group and the National Education Association, to see if some equitable method can be found to maintain existing educational facilities during the war period and beyond.

In all probability you will receive many letters condemning the action of the baseball writers in picking Joe Gordon as the most valuable player in the American League this year, so I am penning this note in defense of their choice.

On the subject of manpower, a subcommittee, headed by Senator Kilgore, of the Special Committee Investigating the National Defense Program, has turned in an excellent report. In its combination of common sense, careful study, good judgment, good writing and political courage it is, indeed, altogether the best report that we have had from Congress since the outbreak of war.

"One of Our Aircraft Is Missing" will enter its third week today at the Globe. . . . The Forty-eighth Street Theatre today will begin a two-week revival engagement of the Norwegian film, "Gjest Baardsen," and the Swedish picture, "Hennes Lilla Majestat."

Fowler Harper, first deputy chairman of the War Manpower Commission, will address the first national convention of the fur industry which begins on Monday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday by Walter H. Pringle, chairman of the organization committee.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, Nov. 12 (Delayed) -- A natural barrier between Egypt and Libya is the escarpment at Halfaya, which has figured again and again in the North African war. Seen from a distance, it resembles a papier-mache mountain of stage scenery.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Formation of a new utility holding company was proposed today in the Federal District Court here in connection with reorganization proceedings of the Central States Electric Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The United States, acting to assure more orderly movement of essential goods to Latin America, is shifting partial control of priorities and export licenses to new offices in the other republics headed by State Department experts.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Jack Sabol of Westchester Hills and C.W. Benedict of Mount Kisco won top honors in the Westchester P.G.A. post-season pro-amateur tourney on the Fenway links today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- Seventeen hours after Henry J. Kaiser's Richmond No. 2 yard had set a mark of four days fifteen and a half hours for a 10,500-ton Liberty freighter, from keel-laying to launching, the Pacific Bridge Company's No. 1 yard in Alameda broke that record today when it put a 4,000-ton ship into the water with a new record of three days eight and a half hours for vessels of its class.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- General Francisco Franco, Chief of the Spanish State, has accepted "with pleasure" the formal assurances of President Roosevelt in a message at the time of the opening of the North African campaign that Spain had nothing to fear from the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Roosevelt signed today the draft act amendment authorizing the calling of 18 and 19 year old youths for military service and declared that the measure was essential to "the successful prosecution of the war."

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Asserting that there were no freedoms "more important than the freedom of the spirit and the mind," Dr. William P. Tolley, who will be inaugurated seventh Chancellor of Syracuse University tomorrow, declared tonight that "if a sadistic and short-sighted Federal policy, "taxed wealth out of existence, adequate support for endowed colleges would disappear.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Occupied Poland celebrated the British victory in Egypt and the Allied landings in Africa by special editions of underground papers and by chalked messages on walls of Warsaw and other Polish cities showing the Axis armies were in flight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Roosevelt late today directed the Lend-Lease Administration to supply weapons of war, food and clothing to the armed forces and citizens of North African areas occupied by the United Nations in what appeared to be a new policy designed to raise "peoples' armies" all over Europe to throw out their Axis conquerors.

The sixty-second annual dinner of the City College Associate Alumni will be held tonight at the Hotel Roosevelt with Dr. Robert Valeur, director of information here for the Fighting French, delivering the principal address.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Burlesques of the American scene from the first to the second World War and a chorus of eight male "chorines" were features of the Princeton Triangle Club's fifty-fourth annual production, "Time and Again," which opened to a capacity audience in McCarter Theatre tonight.
MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 13 -- The German-Italian occupation is tightening on France, which soon may be cut from all communication with the outside world, it was evident tonight. Nazi control is being extended everywhere.

At some time while Harry Hansen was working on his forthcoming book "The Chicago" for Farrar Rinehart's Rivers, of America series, the publishers must have spoken to him slightingly of the Chicago. Mr. Hansen replied that the publishers were carrying forward "that, libelous bunk of the Erie Canal people," declared that "the Chicago has a pivotal place in history; without that river there would have been no Chicago," and so on.

Elmer Garel, 43 years old, of 97 Mountain View Avenue, West New Brighton, S.I., a machinist at the Mariners Harbor yard of the Bethlehem Ship Building Corporation, was taken into custody by the Staten Island police yesterday charged with being a fugitive from justice from Alabama because of violation of parole issued fifteen years ago at Kelby Prison, Montgomery.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Current needs have pointed out mistakes made in education over the last twenty-five years, said Miss Alice Lloyd, dean of women at the University of Michigan, in an address at the opening session of a conference on the college woman's role in the war effort which is being held at Northwestern University.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Boston College's bowl-bound express will try to crash one of the last red lights on its road to an undefeated season tomorrow at Fenway Park when it meets the Fordham eleven. With the return of Fullback Mickey Connolly, ace passer, the Eagles will have all the cogs in their vaunted aerial machine on hand.

Forcing a break that led to a touchdown with four minutes of the game remaining, Horace Mann School's football team turned back St. John's Prep, 19 -- 13, on the former's gridiron yesterday. Len Stolk scored all of Horace Mann's points.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The text of an order of the day that was issued tonight by General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, commander of the British Eighth Army:

LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The main French fleet, object of a vital tug-of-war between the Allied nations and the Axis, still rode at anchor in Toulon harbor today, wreathed in mystery and watched intently from the skies by German planes lest it make a break into the Mediterranean.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Enemy claims of heavy losses inflicted on the Allied North African invasion fleet were dismissed here today as "grossly exaggerated." Making up for the opportunity they missed when the transports carrying Americans to Algeria sailed unmolested to their destinations, German and Italian U-boats have been gathering outside the ports in increasing numbers in the last few days.

Tomorrow will mark the seventh anniversary of the creation of the Philippine Commonwealth. In accordance with the Independence Act of 1934 a democratic constitution had been written and had been accepted by the Filipino people and the new polity went into effect. It was another step, a temporary state of transition toward the independent Philippine Republic to be established on July 4, 1946.

Maria Kurenko, the Russian soprano, gave a recital last night in Town Hall for the benefit of the American Russian Committee for Medical Aid to the U.S.S.R. Miss Kurenko had arranged an elaborate program of selections in Italian, French and Russian for the occasion, and on the list were several novelties, including Castelnuovo-Tedesco's "Cadix"; a song from Krennikoff's opera, "Brothers," and Miaskovsky's "Kossack's Lullaby."

Representatives of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, Waves and Waacs told 250 secondary school principals and headmasters attending the opening yesterday morning of a two-day Conference on Wartime Problems in McMillin Academic Theatre, Columbia University, that "as far as humanly possible'' students would be allowed to start and continue in college to get a maximum of technical and liberal training before being called to active duty.
As far as the supply of game is concerned New Jersey officials, in reviewing the opening week of the upland season, are rather well satisfied with the quantity of pheasant and rabbits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- James F. Byrnes, economic stabilization director, outlined today to his policy board of government, management, labor and farm representatives "a positive program that will guarantee our people the basic living essentials that they must have at prices they can pay."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A wide variation in the price paid by different types of borrowers for commercial loans, so that some large borrowers were able to get long-term loans cheaper than others could get short-term ones, is reported by the Federal Reserve Board as the result of a recent survey of member banks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales gained 20 per cent during the week ended Nov. 7 over the corresponding week in 1941, compared with a gain of 15 per cent recorded for the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Part of the expansion of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps which Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, the director, is looking forward to after her three weeks' trip to Great Britain is the sending of Waacs to England for clerical and communications service. Mrs. Hobby said this today at a press conference, following her return to the office yesterday. She will leave soon for the training center at Fort Des Moines.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The War Department applied spurs today in an effort to end a labor dispute which has paralyzed since yesterday the production of what it said were "desperately needed war materials" in the two plants of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Henryk Strasburger, Polish Finance Minister, who arrived here Tuesday from London, has proposed that after the war Central and Eastern Europe be organized into a cooperating bloc of States extending from the Baltic to the Aegean and founded upon economic pacts between Poland and Czechoslovakia and between Greece and Yugoslavia.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 13 -- In a comprehensive statement recounting his dispute with Governor Charles Edison, Mayor Frank Hague expressed the fear today that this city faced bankruptcy as a result of cumulative financial difficulties.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court referee ruled as excessive today a city assessment on the property of Mrs. Mary Carroll of Albany, which was referred to by Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey in a campaign speech discussing evidence of a "poll tax" through assessment increases.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Illinois's first treason trial came to an abrupt halt today in the Federal District Court when the defense elected to rest without calling any witnesses to testify in behalf of the six Chicago men and women who for three weeks have been on trial for their lives.

Distributors of hard goods made of critical materials were charged with wholesale violation of War Production Board regulations yesterday by Linford C. White, chief of the distributors' branch of the WPB, in an address at the Hotel Commodore to 1,600 distributors of nineteen different types of supplies.

A loan exhibition, including paintings, sculpture, tapestries, rugs, china and silver of eighteenth century France and England, will be held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Dec. 19-30, for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The United States' defense program of 1941, lend-lease shipments and the buying power of retail consumers are shown in a survey made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which reported that combined net profits of fifteen rubber companies rose to $156,000,000 last year, an increase of $88,000,000.

A service flag for the 197 employes of the Sullivan Dry Dock and Repair Corporation, at Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, who are now in the armed forces was dedicated yesterday afternoon in the presence of several men who have been wounded in the war. Lieutenant Richard Kelly of the public relations bureau of the Third Naval District headquarters, presided.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 14 -- French Tunisian garrisons were reported fighting German tanks and parachutists in Tunis early today as dispatches said Allied troops had swept across that protectorate's western frontier amid appeals by Admiral Francois Darlan for all Frenchmen to lay down their arms and join the Allies.

The highest price in thirteen years, $3.01 a hundred pounds (forty-seven quarts), was announced yesterday by Charles J. Blanford, Federal-State milk market administrator here, as the uniform rate to be paid dairy farmers in the New York milkshed for their October production. Payment will be made within the next two weeks.

Five children, all under 15 years of age, yielded nothing in discrimination and cynicism to their adult competitors, the movie critics in an impromptu discussion of current motion pictures last night at the Nassau Straus Branch Library, 348 West Thirty-second Street.

Eight indictments accusing fourteen persons in the theft of $80,000 worth of jewelry and women's wear from the Long Island City terminal of the Railway Express Agency were handed up by the Queens County grand jury yesterday. Three of the defendants are women. Those indicted are:

The suggestion made on Thursday by Lowell Mellett, chief of the bureau of motion pictures of the Office of War Information, that double-feature movies be eliminated throughout the country as a wartime conservation measure was endorsed yesterday by the Independent Theatre Owners Association through its president, Harry Brandt.

Reporting that the closure problem is becoming more acute each day and that research on this problem should be intensified, the scientific advisory committee of the Toilet Goods Association yesterday summarized the closure situation as follows:

The Cloudbusters from the North Carolina Pre-Flight School, who have zoomed victoriously over every collegiate summit except the crag where the Boston Eagle perches, will swoop into the Polo Grounds today for a game with Manhattan College.

Anthony Albanese, 31 years old, who formerly lived with his wife and child at 129 Cherry Street, was in Class 3A of the Selective Service when he was indicted last July as a hold-up man. But subsequently, after he had succeeded in having his $50,000 bail reduced to $15,000 in General Sessions on his not guilty plea, he appeared before his draft board, had himself placed in 1A and was inducted into the Army.

Both the War Production Board and the National Machine Tool Builders Association have asked the American Standards Association to begin work at once on a standard color code for lubricants as a war emergency project, it was disclosed here yesterday.

The announcement that Bill Brown intends to resign his present post as a member of the State Athletic Commission when his term expires on Jan. 1 likely will start a big scramble among hopefuls desirous of being named as his successor.

With only one classification registering a gain, total advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities measured by Media Records declined 5.1 per cent in October from the like 1941 month. The loss for the ten-month period was 6.1 per cent.

A net profit of $514,646 was earned by the Indian Motorcycle Company in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, after $500,000 had been set aside for post-war adjustments and other contingencies, E. Paul du Pont, president, said on Thursday at the annual meeting in Springfield, Mass.

Former President Herbert Hoover will address the nation tomorrow evening at 10:30 o'clock over the Columbia Broadcasting System's network, speaking from WABC, marking the opening of a three weeks' "United Church Canvass" to procure financial support "for the religious enterprises of the country."

Yesterday the British announced "that R.A.F. fighters had shot down six big Italian troop-carrying planes flying north, probably from Tunisia, and filled with German troops." Since Italy has become the beast of burden for the Germans, this carriage of its masters is inevitable. The bearers of the rod are used to being flogged, but it seems cruel to mention Tunisia in connection with their punishment.

The Engineers Public Service Company announced yesterday that it would challenge in the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia an order issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission requiring that the utility system broken up in compliance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Predicting economic prosperity after the war is won, Dr. Alvin H. Hansen, special adviser to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and Professor of Political Economy at Harvard University, warned yesterday, however, that sudden relaxation of government control in the post-war period would result in inflation and unemployment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Nov. 7 amounted to 236,198,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 3,068,000 barrels in the week, comprising a decrease of 3,082,000 in domestic stocks but an increase of 14,000 in foreign stocks.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

To get some approximate idea of what is now passing between the American and British military authorities in Africa, on the one hand, and Admiral Francois Darlan and General Auguste Nogues, on the other hand, with the Vichy government in the background, this point must first be stressed -- the battle which, for the time being, will settle the fate of North Africa and of the French Fleet has not yet been won.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, expressed disagreement today on the question of labor unity.

Leonard Sillman has decided to open his production of "New Shoes," the John Lund-Lee Wainer revue, at the Ritz Theatre on Dec. 22 and not Dec. 15 as earlier announced. On the latter date, however, the revue will start a series of preview performances that are to last through Dec. 21.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- Following a mandate of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the North American Light and Power Company filed today plans for the liquidation of itself and of a subsidiary, the Illinois Traction Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A speed-up in the number of tire turnins by motorists under the Idle Tire Purchase Plan brought collections through Nov. 7 to 1,483,500, more than doubling the 637,750 received up to the end of October, the Office of Price Administration reported today.
DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -Friday the thirteenth hereafter will be a special day on the calendar for Mrs. William T. Cherry Jr., an aircraft plant worker at North American, Inc.

Kenkichi Yoshizawa, Japan's Ambassador to French Indo-China, has postponed an intended journey home and is scheduled to confer shortly with the French Governor General, Admiral Jean Decoux, "on the new developments in France, with special reference to future policy in Indo-China," the newspaper Asahi reported yesterday in a dispatch datelined Hanoi, according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Government moved today to withhold fuel oil from larger structures which can convert to other fuel in the thirty rationed States in an attempt to maintain supplies for private homes.

Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Staff to the President of the United States, told 1,200 of the country's leading shipbuilders last night that we were now building aircraft carriers and submarines twice as fast as we did in pre-war days, that we had reduced by fully two years the time required for building battleships, and soon would be turning out destroyers at the rate of two a month.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 13 -- Tapering off in their final workout on Farragut Field today, Navy was declared fit and ready for tomorrow's gridiron battle with Columbia's pass-minded Lions at Baltimore.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Bucknell ran up a three-touchdown lead in the first half tonight and coasted to a 21-to-6 victory over Case School of Applied Science, which avoided a shutout in the final minute.
The Police Pension Board, meeting last night at Police Headquarters, approved sixty-eight retirements out of 724 applications. Five of the retiring men will enter military service.

The age limit for girls employed by companies engaged in war production has been lowered from 18 to 16 years by a United States Labor Department ruling, it was announced here yesterday by L. Metcalfe Walling, administrator of the Public Contracts and Wage and Hour Divisions of the department.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13 -- The prestige of the United States is today higher than ever in Mexico. The brilliant victory of the American forces in French North Africa has impressed Mexicans of all walks of life and an attitude of respect for the "Gringos" -- as the North Americans are called here -- mingled with respect for our strength is apparent wherever one goes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Roosevelt scrambled a metaphor at his press conference today.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Admiral Francois Darlan announced tonight, in a statement broadcast from Algiers, according to the Vichy news agency, that he had assumed full responsibility for French interests in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Accusing Representative Maas of having "rendered aid and comfort to the enemy" in his speech which was broadcast last night, Representative Vincent called today for a Congressional investigation of the Minnesota Republican's charges.

After having finished a week of racing programs in the Victory Meet at Belmont Park, members of society returned to the track yesterday afternoon for the opening of the Fall meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association, the final outdoor sporting and society feature of the season.

Seventy paintings collected by the late Jay Gould and inherited by his daughter Helen, the late Mrs. Finley Johnson Shepard, were sold at auction for $49,965 last night in his former residence at Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. This was a part of the auction that will strip the old brownstone house of its decorations and furnishings.

Separation of the school district and the municipal government so that each would have its own tax base and deal independently with the State was suggested last night by Professor Paul R. Mort of Teachers College as a possible solution for the "perpetual financial crisis" New York City finds itself facing.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Meat for the table as well as good sport will be the aims of hundreds of metropolitan hunters when they invade the woods of Westchester County at sun-up Sunday to stalk deer from long bow and broad-headed arrows.

The city's unified transit lines carried 1,870,414,849 passengers in the fiscal year ended June 30, as compared with 1,837,743,130 in the previous fiscal year, the Board of Transportation reported yesterday. Traffic gains on the BMT and IND divisions more than offset a drop on the IRT division and the gain over the previous fiscal year amounted to 32,671,719 passengers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 -- Eddie O'Shea, signed by Hunt Stromberg last month from the cast of "The Eve of St. Mark" on Broadway, will be co-starred with Barbara Stanwyck in "G-String Murders," Stromberg's first United Artists picture, the producer announced today.

Of the many great achievements in American war production, none has been greater than the record of shipbuilding. Only a year ago our plans called for building 12,000,000 deadweight tons of merchant ships in 1942 and 1943. In the interval they have been stepped up first to 18,000,000, then to 24,000,000 tons, an advance of 100 per cent.

The United Hunts Racing Association began its two-day meeting at Belmont Park yesterday with a victory for Llanero in the Turf and Field Purse before a crowd of 6,946. The Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase, traditional feature, is expected to attract 15,000 today to the final racing program in New York this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- United States naval forces delivered a smashing attack on Japanese positions around Tassafaronga, twelve and one-half miles west of Henderson Field on Guadalcanal Island yesterday (Solomons time) silencing shore batteries and destroying thirty large landing boats.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Mexico, her people and her President, Manuel Avila Camacho, were praised by Secretary of State Cordell Hull for their contribution to the war effort and for their friendship today when he welcomed to his press conference a group of Mexican journalists who are touring this country.
BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

Three alleged bookmakers were arraigned in Brooklyn and Manhattan yesterday within forty-eight hours after they had been forced to move their bases of operations from New Jersey when a request from Police Commissioner Valentine had caused the disconnection of their direct telephone lines from Manhattan to New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Office of Price Administration extended today for two months the effective date of coffee rationing for restaurants, hotels, hospitals and similar establishments.

The increase in venereal disease in the skyrocketing industrial areas and around cantonments where prostitution is rampant has forced the United States Public Health Service to introduce a system of control which follows that adopted long ago with brilliant success in the Scandinavian countries.
