HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 13 -- Methods employed by Connecticut in meeting the farm labor shortage during the past Summer will be presented as a working model when representatives of the New England States, New York and New Jersey meet here Tuesday to discuss the national shortage to be faced in 1943.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 14 -- Joseph Stalin asserted today that the American and British campaign in Africa had turned the military and political position in Europe radically in favor of the Allies, opening the way for the early collapse of the German and Italian Axis. The Soviet leader praised American and British leaders as "first-rate organizers" of the African campaign and expressed confidence that it soon would relieve German pressure on the Eastern front.

Retail trade here this week probably exceeded last year's volume by a narrow margin. The sales increase for department stores was put at 3 to 5 per cent over 1941, against gains of 9 and 19 per cent, respectively, in the two preceding weeks.

The huge rubber dragon and six other giant balloons that were marched down Broadway last year in the Macy Thanksgiving parade were donated to the government's rubber scrap heap yesterday in ceremonies held on the steps of City Hall.

In an important step toward early reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric system, Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell referred yesterday to Frederick E. Crane as special master for study and report a proposed compromise of the "recap" litigation presented to the court earlier this week by the trustees in reorganization of both the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- British airplanes and American surface vessels destroyed eleven Axis planes in beating off yesterday an air attack on the occupied city of Bougie, on the north coast of Algeria, the War Department announced here today.

Not having produced a single new play since Tuesday evening, the Theatre Guild broke the spell by putting on "Mr. Sycamore" at the Guild Theatre last evening. Ketti Frings, author of "Hold Back the Dawn," has written a mildly imaginative tree fable that is based on a short story by Robert Ayre; and Lillian Gish and Stuart Erwin are acting it as generously as if it were the work of La Fontaine.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 13 -- Costa Rican Coast Guard guns prevented the landing of members of the crew of a German submarine at an unrevealed place and an unspecified time on the Atlantic coast, according to press reports here today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The noon communique:

The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that Triangle Publications, Inc., and New York Daily Tab, Inc., publishers of racing sheets, may take depositions from Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, and others in their suit to restrain License Commissioner Paul Moss from banning the racing sheets from newsstand sale.

Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder, called upon members of the American Medical Association last night "to investigate the honesty and integrity" of Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The A.M.A. Journal, whom the industrialist accused of making a personal attack upon him in an editorial.

WITH UNITED STATES TROOPS EAST OF ALGIERS, Nov. 9 (Delayed) -- Eager, confident American troops scrambled up three beaches in the neighborhood of Ain Taya and Surcouf early yesterday morning and swept on to capture all their immediate objectives, including a vital airfield, which is of primary importance to the Allied campaign in North Africa.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 13 -- The British Eighth Army occupied Tobruk at 9:30 o'clock this morning, while Allied pursuit groups continued to follow the enemy westward into Cyrenaica. Bardia was taken last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Navy communique 191:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Raymond Schroeder, Newark corporation counsel, in a telegram today informed William H. Davis, War Labor Board chairman, that Newark would contest the board's right to assume jurisdiction in the dispute between Local 277, State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C.I.O., and Joseph M. Byrne Jr., City Commissioner in charge of the Department of Public Works.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Inter-American Commission of Women unanimously approved today at its third annual meeting a resolution by Senorita Minerva Bernardino, vice chairman and Dominican Republic delegate, applauding the opening by the United States of a second front.

After recounting in detail the many beatings given her by her husband, even when she was pregnant, and telling of the time he tied her to a kitchen chair and branded her across the face with a red-hot roasting fork, Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21-year-old mother of four small children, described yesterday in Bronx County Court the "accidental" shooting of her 23-year-old husband, Alman, on June 23.

Today's events: Joseph Battista, piano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Kurt Applebaum, piano, Town Hall, 5:30; Gregory Ashman, piano, and Louis Persinger, violin, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Orchestra of the Juilliard School, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30; Paul Robeson, baritone, assisted by Clara Rockmore, thereminist, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; Florence Mercur, piano, Home for Incurables, 2:45; "Carmen," Mascagni Opera Guild, Community Center, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street, 8.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. yesterday was considering plans for a series of lightweight championship elimination bouts in cooperation with the State Athletic Commission and the National Boxing Association.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, assured the shipping industry yesterday that the United States was retaining "full title and control" in the allocation of American-built freighters to allies in the war. He reminded the industry that "we are fighting a United Nations war," and added that "if you are disturbed about allocations of ships to our allies I can assure you that title and control remain with the United States."

Financiers and capitalists will be found allied with scientists in the revolution of industry which is occurring as a result of the application of scientific research to finding wartime substitutes and synthetics, often revealing not only capable replacements but new and superior properties hitherto unknown.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Senate began today consideration of the long-blocked poll-tax repeal bill amid a crossfire of manoeuvres and debate by Southern members which threatened to develop into the first full-blown filibuster since 1938, when an anti-lynching bill was killed by thirty days of talking.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 13 -- Swift as was the occupation of the "free zone" of France by Axis forces, it was not swift enough to achieve Adolf Hitler's purpose, to prolong French resistance in Algeria and Morocco, especially in Morocco, until the German High Command had sent troops to Tunisia to check the Anglo-American advance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Navy gunboat Erie was damaged by a submarine attack yesterday and beached on the southern coast of Curacao, the Navy Department announced here today.

Dr. Gallup in his letter yesterday recalls that he predicted a Republican high of 178 seats in the House of Representatives as against an actual Republican score of 209 seats. It was a substantial error, says Dr. Gallup, and he has no desire to minimize it.

The War Production Board's plan for speeding the city's month-old household scrap metal to the steel mills will provide for putting about eighty more scrap dealers and their equipment on the job that so far has involved only nine dealers and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, it was learned last night.

Testimony apparently intended to show that Anthony Cramer knew what sort of person he was aiding when he associated with Werner Thiel, one of the eight Nazis landed here by German submarines last June, was introduced in Federal court yesterday, where Cramer is on trial for treason.
The Players celebrated Booth Day yesterday in tribute to the famous actor, Edwin Booth, founder of the club.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Red Army defenders of Stalingrad have beaten off new German drives, which in limited sectors developed into fighting of great intensity yesterday, the Russians announced today.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Rodin, owned by C.E. Nelson of Washington, came from behind to win the feature, race today. The 6-year-old son of Chance Shot scored by a neck over One Only, while a length farther back the favored Discouraged was third in the field of six going a mile and a sixteenth.

Prompted by Mr. Willkie's assertion that the Chinese are not quite sure about America's war aims, Arthur Krock wrote a rejoinder which appeared on Oct. 29 under the heading, "The Chinese Should Know What We Are Fighting For." But should they?

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 13 -- The Foreign Ministry issued an official communique today acknowledging receipt of three confidential memoranda delivered by the United States Ambassador, Norman Armour, on Nov. 3, 4 and 10, on espionage activities of Axis agents on Argentine territory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The vitamin content of raw and cooked meat's not the same, Senator Wheeler contends, and he wants housewives to know this when reading charts on nutritional values of various cuts. It is a "known fact," he said.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

"Loyalty Sunday" will be observed in churches in the New York area tomorrow with exhortations from the pulpits to be loyal to church and loyal to country in its war prosecution. Post-Armistice Day sermons will be preached with particular reference to the developments of the week in North Africa and France.

Allie Stolz's lightweight title pretensions disappeared last night in Madison Square Garden under the flailing fists of Sidney Walker, the former Georgia caddy who fights under the name of Beau Jack and in a manner that too closely resembles that of Henry Armstrong to be overlooked.

Activity in the market for new bonds this week was slightly better than in the preceding period, but was still only a small fraction of normal business. Three issues of tax-exempt bonds and notes, aggregating $2,098,000, were offered to the public, against one flotation totaling $1,037,000 the week before.

"Balcony Empire,"* by Reynolds and Eleanor Packard, former United Press man-and-wife Rome team, is a studious book about the course of history in Fascist Italy from the time of the Ethiopian campaign to the present. But the whole story is really quintessentialized in a single farcical episode, which Mr. and Mrs. Packard report in high glee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Liquidation of rye by houses with Eastern connections dominated the grain markets today. Prices dropped about 2 cents a bushel under yesterday's finish despite reports there had been the largest business in cash rye in some time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Congress was stirred today by a radio address delivered last night by Representative Maas of Minnesota, ranking Republican member of the Naval Affair Committee, and a Colonel in the Marine Corps Reserve, who returned recently from a four months' tour of duty in the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Hope that Captain E.V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker may be alive in the Pacific Ocean rose here today with receipt of word of the rescue yesterday of Captain William T. Cherry Jr., Army flier, in the South Pacific.

It was a shocking surprise to read in THE TIMES last Friday that Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service director here, favors the abolition of intercollegiate and interscholastic sports and the substitution of intramural athletic activities.

Stressing the gravity of the problem of recruiting millions of women for industrial jobs in 1943, Miss Amy Hewes of the Economics Department of Mount Holyoke College urged college women last night to begin playing a larger role in industrial relations.

The award for the most valuable player in the American League fires one's indignation to the boiling point. Ignoring the batting feats of Ted Williams of the Red Sox and disregarding precedence, the baseball writers voted the prize to Joe Gordon of the Yankees for his defensive ability.
The triangular race among Georgia, Boston College and Georgia Tech for the national football diadem may resolve itself into a dual affair by nightfall and set up the Sugar Bowl game.

AMHERST vs. Williams -- It's high time to brush up on ratings and insignia of the Army, Navy, Coast Guard and Marine Corps. Those uniformed men like to be recognized for what they are by what they wear. A chief petty officer in the Navy who is addressed by some careless civilian as "Sergeant" usually becomes rather indignant.

A female Leif Ericsson landed on these shores this week, looking for fields that less intrepid natives have seen disappearing over the horizon for some time. She is Mrs. Helga Sigurdsson, only woman wholesaler in Iceland, who is here in the hope of buying materials for shipment back to a land that is feeling the pinch of a lost trade with England.

Cotton futures held within a 7-point range yesterday and closed with net losses of 2 to 4 points. Trade and New Orleans buying offset fairly well liquidation and transferals in the December position in advance of first-notice day and hedging in the distant months by brokers with rubber company affiliations.

IT was a happy idea to present the famous Labrador doctor in a biography for the 'teen age, for that vital, courageous man is one to appeal inevitably to youth. Contemplating with awed wonder the achievements of the man who laughed at almost incredible hardships, we forget his title and honors and think of him affectionately as did the people he served as "t' doctor."

AS the war has speeded up and its impact has hit sharper and harder on home communities throughout the country there has been an increasing amount of thought and talk and worry and discussion about the effect of all this on young people, especially on young girls.

On June 18, 1942, Prime Minister Churchill, unheralded and grave of mien, arrived in Washington for talks with President Roosevelt. He had come, the communique said, to discuss "the war, the conduct of the war, and the winning of the war."

Judge Aron Steuer granted yesterday an order for Cravath, de Gersdorff, Swaine Wood, who on Oct. 29 entered a general appearance for the Chosen Corporation in a $5,900,000 stockholders' suit against Serge Rubinstein and others, to show cause why that notice should not be vacated.

The United Nations were on the march last week -- westward from the Valley of the Nile, eastward from Algeria -- closing a pincers upon Axis North Africa and preparing the way for a second front in Europe.

THE jacket of "Lark," a first novel by Helen Simmons, tells very little about her except that she was born in San Francisco and that her father owns the theatre at Needles, Calif. If she is very young, then it is possible that some day she will be a writer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- President Roosevelt endorsed today a proposal for increased centralization in the administration of oil matters and said that a decision on the plan would be announced in the near future.

MOST parents know that the active, creeping, climbing baby has a head-start toward walking as compared with the placid baby who just sits. Now it appears that the position in which a baby sleeps may affect his posture later on.

THIS afternoon in Town Hall the New Friends of Music will celebrate an anniversary. For its concert today is the one-hundredth chamber music event in its annals. Now in its seventh season, the organization founded by Ira A. Hirschmann has achieved such success that similar New Friends of Music groups have been founded in emulation of it in Pittsburgh, Milwaukee and Portland, Ore.

ORDINARILY no writer of "letters to the editor," the reason I am writing this one is because Richard Match, in his amusing and interesting article on juvenile radio on THE TIMES radio page on Nov. 1, gives only half the picture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The opening in North Africa of the first American offensive against Germany and Italy found American war production both good and disappointing, depending on what standard one adopted for it. It was good because, at the end of the first year of her intensified war effort, the United States was turning out more war material than any other country in the world, whether ally or enemy.

SOME experienced crowd enumerators estimate that eight or ten thousand people poured into or around St. Patrick's Cathedral a week ago yesterday morning to attend the funeral of George M. Cohan, America's beloved song-and-dance man.

A new and separate Department of Geography will exist at Dartmouth College next semester, in recognition of the global character of the war and of the responsibilities of the United States in the post-war world. Courses in physical and political geography and in cartography will be added to those which the college already offers in economic geography.

WHEN David Wolper, operator of the Hurricane, speaks about "Wings of Broadway," the new show which he is to unveil Friday night at his after-dark establishment, he is disposed to grow reasonably enthusiastic.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 8 Professors Nevins and McKee find "much reason for alarm and reform" in the present status of American history teaching in the United States; they find "good reason for State laws, and more of them."

Several committees have been formed to assist Mrs. George B. St. George, executive chairman, with plans for the Victory Debutante Cotillion and ball to be given Dec. 21 at the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Hoarding of cash by individuals, revealed as perhaps the greatest single threat to all attempts to check inflation of the currency, soared to a rate of about $16,000,000,000 a year in the third quarter of this year. It was disclosed today in an analysis of the volume and composition of saving prepared by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Taking for its slogan "Top That Ten Per Cent by New Year's," the Treasury Department is launching a six weeks' campaign from now to the end of the year to step up its Payroll Savings Plan. At present about 22,000,000 persons are buying war savings bonds by regular payroll deductions.

ELLEN DILLION'S Aunt Pearl Wimpler ran a rooming house in Knoxville. Ellen taught school there, and while the school term was on dutifully roomed with Aunt Pearl. Ellen was the only one of the lodgers who shared Aunt Pearl's very good cooking, served to an accompaniment of all the rooming-house troubles.

Troubles of the Fascist authorities of Northern Italy in controlling and caring for thousands made homeless as a result of the British bombing raids were emphasized in information from that region contained in European reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The population of Genoa, heavily attacked again Friday night by the R.A.F., was said to have dropped to 400,000 from a pre-war figure of 670,000.

THE "jump overcall" has had many interpretations. At one time it was used, and by few expert players it is still used, as a very weak shut-out bid. Within the last few years, however, in general use it has come to be a strength-showing bid made on a hand unsuitable to a take-out double.

OTTAWA, Nov. 14 -- The problem of how Canada is to avoid going into debt to the United States to keep her war machine running is beginning to weigh heavily among the preoccupations of those responsible for the country's welfare.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Port Chester High School won the second Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association title in its history with a 7-to-0 triumph over White Plains High at Ryan Stadium today before a crowd of 4,500.

AUSTRALIA'S Acting Trade Commissioner in New York, J. U. Garside, was informed from Melbourne last week that postage stamps with a portrait of Great Britain's Queen Elizabeth are in preparation. A 1 1/2-pence will be released early in December and a 1p shortly after Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Warships of the United States and Japanese fleets are fighting in a series of engagements that began Thursday night (Solomons time) in the Solomons area, the Navy announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Reorganization of the nation's manpower machinery under one directing head was reported today to be under consideration by President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) The entire aircraft production high command will be reorganized soon under Charles E. Wilson, vice chairman of the War Production Board according to a government official.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Captain E. V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, missing in the South Pacific since Oct. 21, when his Army bomber was forced down by lack of gasoline, has been found alive by a Navy Catalina flying boat, one of many that had been searching the area since the World War ace disappeared.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Andover's high-powered football forces marched to two second-quarter touchdowns on the frozen turf of Brothers Field today and toppled their traditional Exeter enemies to defeat for the second straight season.

Something figuratively like pyrotechnics was expected when Brooklyn College and C.C.N.Y. met yesterday on the former's field in their annual interborough gridiron tussle. It turned out to be a contest that kept 3,000 partisan rooters bobbing off their seats until the close, which found the rivals tied at 7 -- 7.

Tomorrow Gimbel Brothers great antique floor is the scene of another sale of unusual scope. Far from being limited to antiques, this collection comprises some of the most beautiful jewelry of our era -- high fashion spray-pins and earrings and clips as well as traditional rubies and sapphires and pearls. (Lillian Russell was the first woman to own a chrysanthemum pin made of diamonds and pearls.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Michigan State's Spartans exploded for three second-half touchdowns to rout a hapless Purdue team, 19 -- 6, before 7,500 fans today. It was the seventh defeat in eight starts for the Boiler-makers.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- Ohio State, attacking with devastating fury, trounced its old rival, Illinois, 44 to 20, today to take over undisputed first place in the Western Conference football race before 68,656 chilly fans.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- Green-clad American troops have begun closing in from the south on the Japanese coastal base at Buna, northeastern New Guinea, and Australian jungle troops fighting their way across from the southwest have captured the village of Wairopi, forty miles from Buna, General Douglas MacArthur's Command announced today.

A FULL-DRESS rehearsal on an elaborate scale of picture ideas available to photographers entering the American Red Cross $5,125 National Photo Awards camera contest will be staged tomorrow night between 8 and 11 o'clock in the grand ball room of the Hotel Pennsylvania, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-third Street.

DEMOCRACY, expressed in one theme or another, is the watchword of many new books for young people, yet we have not heretofore had an integrated picture of man's slow march through the centuries toward that goal.

THE British Prime Minster's life will furnish the substance for many biographies. Drama and action are its very breath. Because the long adventure is at its climax now, Winston Churchill's real story will not be told for many years.

Slingin' Sammy Baugh and his Redskins are favored to take another stride toward the Eastern championship of the National Football League today when they clash with the Giants before some 40,000 fans at the Polo Grounds at 2:30 P.M. Fifteen minutes earlier the Dodgers will meet the pass-minded Eagles in their last home game at Ebbets Field.

IT wasn't until her last semester at Langhorne-Evans, a woman's college tucked away in the Virginia Blue Ridge, that Janey Lou began to face seriously the problem of graduating. She hadn't, as she earnestly assured a troubled faculty member, come to college to play, but Janey Lou hadn't quite grown up.

THERE is more than one approach to glamour in the new mode of dressing for the hours of gayety after dark. Before the war, when there were women of leisure with comfortable cars or plenty of taxis to take them unruffled from place to place, trailing decollete gowns seemed to be the key to evening effectiveness.

Havoc wrought by the war in many countries of Europe has failed to bring about the disintegration of many organizations of women there. On the contrary, a tightening and strengthening of their common bond has been reported in letters reaching these shores, as well as a vast and varied list of accomplishments credited to them, especially in the field of relief work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Office of Price Administration inspectors throughout the Eastern gasoline rationing area moved in today on what a spokesman described as "widespread black market" racketeering in S card ration coupons.

Rare indeed is the garden that has no need for edging plants -- either to enhance its general picture or to be of definite service as a disguise for otherwise unattractive edges of borders, walks or woodland paths.

The pool of nine scrap dealers, whose dilatory handling of the city's household metal for war salvage has led to the possibility of direct action by the War Production Board, is now seeking to enlist other dealers and their equipment to speed the material to the mills, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Rutgers and the Fort Monmouth eleven played a scoreless tie today at the Rutgers Stadium before 2,500 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Army metallurgists and engineers, challenged by shortages in critical materials and machines, are finding new materials, conserving strategic, critical and essential metals, and are devising improved methods of production in the war of alloy steel.

The fact that your film critic doesn't like bohemianism in an artist, or doesn't like the type of bohemianism exploited by Hollywood, as revealed in a recent Sunday article, isn't germane to "The Moon and Sixpence" as a picture. When approaching the picture, we must begin with the existence of the book itself which set the delineation of the characters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt's National Resources Planning Board tonight urged postwar establishment of "a new bill of rights" designed to cure social ills "which our forefathers did not face."

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 14 -- Resistance to total German occupation is crystallizing in France even before the first week is out. One of the most popular officers, General Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, is under arrest and will appear before court-martial, it was revealed today.

Although some cities are lagging, Christmas trade for the country as a whole appears to be developing about three weeks earlier than last year, reports in retail circles here last week indicated. An unexpected restraining factor which cuts across prospects for the final month of holiday trade was the intimation late last week that the Treasury plans record borrowing of $6,000,000,000 to $8,000,000,000, mainly from current income and savings of the public.

Thirty million householders, accepting the war's challenge to their ingenuity and skill, can by their mere choice of menus release more freight cars for military purposes, make more meat available to men who are fighting and free quantities of commercial nitrates for munitions.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Full public ownership of land as well as control of the issue of credit was advocated today by the Archbishop of Canterbury, who resumed his fight for what he considers will be needed for the welfare of his countrymen after the war.
Mrs. Frederic W. Rhinelander is expected to arrive today from Newport and will be at Mayfair House.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Francis P. Sayre, former high commissioner to the Philippines, issued the following statement on the eve of the seventh anniversary of the Philippine Commonwealth Government:

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 14 -- As German troops and trailing Italians overrun their country "in order to defend it," what is the mood of the French? The answer is plain: It is the mood of self- questioning. Men, women, children even, asking where lies their duty, be they at home or abroad?
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 14 -- The Lawrenceville School football team finished its season undefeated and untied by halting Peddie, 14 -- 13, today.

IT is a young, tough army, rarin' to go, that Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower led to Africa. It is well trained and well equipped with all the tools and machinery of modern war. Most of the men who make it up have had two years of soldiering and were spoiling for a fight with the enemy, eager to kill Germans wherever they could find them.

WITH their menfolk in camp, thousands of American wives, mothers, sisters and sweethearts want to visit them, for a day, a weekend or even longer. But a visit to an Army camp isn't simply a matter of packing a bag and going -- not any more.

NOW that meatless Tuesday has become a fixture in New York restaurants, the question arises, "What do people like when deprived of steaks and chops and rare roast beef?" A survey conducted by this column seems to prove that there is no unanimity of tastes in food.

TWELVE stories search backward into old-fashioned school life, to recall for modern children typical scenes of long ago. From Boston in 1775 to Pennsylvania in 1863 a procession of little scholars, good and bad, follow the hard road to learning.

While the United Nations pressed their first big offensive in Africa there were further developments in the "defensive-offensive" campaign which they have employed in the Southwest Pacific. On Wednesday the Japanese naval and air forces launched another major effort to drive Americans from the southern Solomons.

THE gallant Cervantes has received appropriate treatment in the excellent biography that is now offered to children of high school age. Wisely chosen, subtly handled material reveals his life at close range, presented whole, with kindliness and clarity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Solomon Islands again have become an active battleground for sea, air and land forces of the United States and Japan. On the day that American armies landed in French North Africa, as a prelude to what observers agree will

Robert Casadesus's phenomenal pianism as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Howard Barlow, at its concert last night in Carnegie Hall, was as thrilling as anything the musical season is likely to bring forth. There was little to choose between his superlative performances of the Liszt concerto in A major and of Cesar Franck's "Variations Symphoniques."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Consumers who have stocked up on coffee will have to count all above one pound which they have on hand on Nov. 28 as part of their ration, the Office of Price Administration announced today. Deduction of stamps to cover excessive coffee supplies held by individuals will be made when they apply for War Ration. Book No. 2, about the first of next year.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 14 -- Regulations intended to implement and clarify questions about salaries of over $5,000 under the recent order of James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, are likely to be issued next week.

SOME of America's crack overseas correspondents make their reports to the book-reading public in these two volume. "This Is the Enemy" was written by Frederick Oechsner, Central European manager of The United Press for nine years, and his four collaborators.

THE title of this book need not mislead you. This is a volume about twenty-nine composers; obviously it does not cover all the modern composers, nor even all the important ones. And one might well wonder what constitutes the bounds of modernity.

Dullness marked trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Stocks drifted narrowly and closed mixed in the slowest trading since mid-October. Volume was but 260,620 shares, against 553,280 on the previous Saturday, and of 562 issues traded, 202 fell, 177 rose and 183 were unchanged.
The sixth annual dinner of the AfcCosker - Hershfield Cardiac Foundation will be held Dec. 12 at the Hotel Plaza.

Patriotic New Yorkers once pulled down an equestrian statue in Bowling Green and shipped it to be melted up, all but the horse's bridle and tail, for bullets. Now large numbers of their descendants are for scrapping the statuary in our parks for munitions.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 14 -- It was a week ago tonight. We had come straight from the Soviet Embassy. The Russians had been celebrating, with Allied diplomats, attaches and journalists, the twenty-fifth anniversary of the revolution of October, 1917. Now in the bar of Karpitch's restaurant we took a quick aperitif while the headwaiter arranged a table.

In recognition of their "notable post graduate attainments," five City College graduates received Townsend Harris Medals last night at the sixty-second annual dinner of the college's Associate Alumni at the Hotel Roosevelt. Dr. Robert Valeur, director of information here for the Fighting French delegation, delivered the principal address at the dinner, which was attended by 700 alumni, faculty, and guests.

"VIVE la France eternelle!" the radio kept saying. "Vive la France eternelle!" Over and over again the phrase was repeated. "The Voice of America" was broadcasting to Frenchmen everywhere President Roosevelt's appeal for cooperation with the American forces landing in North Africa. Another battle was in progress in the war of ideas that is a part of total war.

ORAN, Algeria, Nov. 12 (Delayed) -- A single American medium tank went on a rampage in the center of Oran for half an hour Tuesday morning, rammed and destroyed three 75-mm. guns and fifty motor vehicles and emerged from the city with its armor plate pockmarked but with the French guns hanging from its front.

Messages from Queen Wilhelmina and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and addresses by Admiral William H. Standley, Ambassador to Russia, and the Hon. David Bowes-Lyon, brother of Queen Elizabeth, will be highlights of The New York Herald Tribune Forum on Current Problems tomorrow and Tuesday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced last night by Mrs. Ogden Reid, vice president of the newspaper, who will preside at the meeting.

Harry Hanson commented on the new trend in the American short story in his book column the other day. "The drab, realistic story is on its way out, and it's about time." Mr. Hansen thinks the short story is a better weather gauge in literary fashions than the novel, and he should know.

WHEN Gordon Shadrow followed after Daniel Boone into Kentucky his purpose was to make a home at the end of the Wilderness Road for his wife and six children. But before he returned to North Carolina the mother died, leaving Juba in charge of the young Shadrows. Juba was a free Negro, a huge bulk of kindness, severity, good sense and executive ability.

Thousands of yachtsmen are doing more boating in these war days than they ever dreamed possible in normal times. Lieut. Comdr. Pete Mills, in charge of the Coast Guard Auxiliary for the Third Naval District, which extends, roughly, from New London to Manasquan and takes in, of course, the metropolitan New York area, has been musing with pride over the figures his records divulge.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 14 -- Michigan's great Western Conference team romped over Notre Dame in the third period today to drub the Fighting Irish, 32 to 20, in their first meeting since 1909, and a capacity throng of 57,500 howled their approval that the game was worth waiting for.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 14 -- The undefeated Coast Guard Training Station team from Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, had its hands full pinning a 14-to-13 defeat on a game Springfield College team today.

Kurt Appelbaum, young German pianist who made his debut here four and a half years ago, yesterday at Town Hall gave the first of a series of three Saturday afternoon recitals at 5:30, devoted to the piano sonatas of Beethoven.

As the Office of War Information quite logically asserts, one's own supply of gas for cooking is completely dependent on the national supply of oil and coal. And at the present moment, with the national fuel supply in slightly straitened circumstances, it is especially important to treat gas parsimoniously.

Disruption of school programs from "the kindergarten to the university" owing to the war should prove beneficial in bringing about future reforms in educational values, the Rev. Dr. George Johnson, Associate Professor of Education at the Catholic University of America, declared yesterday at a public forum conducted by the Alumni Association of that institution in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

THIS is the seventh in a series of musical biographies which has been received with enthusiasm by the 8 to 12 year olds. Mozart, Haydn, Bach, Schubert and Edward MacDowell were written by Opal Wheeler and Sybil Deucher together, "Stephen Foster and his Little Dog Tray," like the present volume, by Opal Wheeler alone.

Business was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Armistice Day sales accounted for the bulk of the activity.

THE sensitive artistic temperament, drawn into the Army, is ordinarily a headache to the Army and to the artist alike. The Army wastes its money and its energies on an apathetic or resentful subject; the artist wastes his gift and his youth by letting them go to seed.

ALL of Hugh Byas's writings on Japan for these twenty-five years, whether in THE NEW YORK TIMES or elsewhere, have been distinguished by the quality of sound common sense, a quality which, exercised on keen perception, has produced a kind of mellow wisdom on Japan as the years have gone by.

Confusion over the limitation upon salaries in excess of $25,000, after taxes, continues unabated. The only thing clearly understandable about the measure is that it is an attempt to reduce income from salaries by confiscating what may be deemed under the regulations as an excess payment. The method of determining the "excess" is not clear.

OCALA, Fla. -- Most of Florida's tourists will be wearing uniforms this Winter. With 40 per cent of the hotels already taken over by the Army and Navy, with defense industries ballooning cities to capacity, the State has traded in its traditional tourist season for a war boom.

THE clouds of war were gathering, but they had not yet risen enough to dim the joy of Bolek when he played his new violin at the harvest festival in his native village on the Wisla. Here is a picture of Poland in those last few days before the fury of the Nazis desolated it.

WITH each passing year Book Week seems to take on added significance. Constantly wider observance is being obtained for it, and this is fortunate. What children read has always been important, but never so much, probably, as now.
