PINEHURST, N.C. -- At the Pinehurst Country Club, one of the most looked-forward-to tournaments under the auspices of the Tin Whistles, the annual Charton L. Becker Trophy contest for best individual medal play, will be held for the seventh time next Saturday, with a large list of entries.

LEXINGTON, KY., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A second-string back and a reserve end combined their talents and luck in the last sixty seconds of today's West Virginia-Kentucky game to give the visiting Mountaineers a 7-0 triumph in the Wildcats' last home game of the season and possibly for the duration.

After the Office of Price Administration had complained in Federal Court yesterday that two wholesalers and a retailer were selling rancid coffee and were violating the general maximum price regulations, Judge William Bondy signed a temporary order restraining the three defendants from offering for sale coffee at prices in excess of those permitted by the regulations, which also prohibit the sale of rancid coffee.

The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, which has served the community as a welfare center for twenty-one years, will be the beneficiary of the performance of the Ice Follies on the night of Dec. 3 at Madison Square Garden. This is the largest

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 14 -- The cadets from the Lakehurst Naval Training Station sank the Lafayette team today, scoring twice in the last six minutes of play for a 14-0 triumph. Both touchdown drives went 40 yards following interception of Lafayette passes.

THE Theatre Guild, which has just commenced its twenty-fifth season in New York with the presentation of Philip Barry's new comedy "Without Love" with Katharine Hepburn and Elliott Nugent, and with "Mr. Sycamore" with Lillian Gish and Stuart Erwin, is not celebrating a silver anniversary this year.

THE liveliest and happiest memories of John Andrew Rice's boyhood beckon him -- and his present readers -- to his maternal grandmother's plantation near Lynchburg, S. C. As he knew it, South Carolina, he says.

John Peter Zuurmond, freight traffic manager of the Holland-America Line, will be the guest of honor tomorrow at a dinner given at the Netherlands Club by fellow executives and employes of the company on the occasion of his fiftieth anniversary in the line.

With its name slightly altered and its ranks swelled by three wartime groups, the nineteenth Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries will open on Thursday in Madison Square Garden, where it will continue daily and Sunday through Nov. 24.

JUST as a matter of record, this corner would like to take note of a couple of singular coincidents which have recently occurred hereabout. One week ago last Thursday, when the headlines were hot with the news of the British Eighth Army's triumphal break-through along the Egyptian front, Metro was opening a picture called "Cairo" at the Capitol.

Although we may be justly optimistic over the British victory in Egypt and the American landings in North Africa, we must not be lulled into a false sense of security but must redouble our efforts to vanquish the Axis, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.

Members of the medical profession who have followed the move for enactment of a National Service Act for physicians and surgeons estimated yesterday that the armed forces of the United States would take one-third of the country's medical men, compared with about one-fourth of the general practitioners absorbed by the British armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- If Italy is to be removed from the war by disintegration, the movement will develop only in consequence of military blows on her own territory, according to informed opinion here.

"A HISTORY of New York from the Beginning of the World to the End of the Dutch Dynasty, by Diedrich Knickerbocker" is the amusing, delightful farce with which Washington Irving vented his wit and humor, spiced with robust satire, that spared no one in 1809.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Bishop Loughlin High School of Brooklyn repeated as champion of the fourth annual Grout Memorial cross-country run today, placing two finishers in the first five of a field of forty-two runners.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Reports that the Commodity Credit Corporation would make an announcement over the week-end as to the resale of cash wheat expected to be redeemed by farmers from the government loan resulted today in a mild selling wave developing early on the Board of Trade.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 14 -- Allied troops have cleared Cyrenaica of enemy resistance as far as El Gazala, it was officially announced today, but bombing by Allied air forces has placed a good proportion of the retreating Axis forces around Derna, fifty-five miles beyond El Gazala and more than half way to Bengazi.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 14 -- Trailing by 19 to 14 in the last 18 seconds of the game, Wisconsin kept its Big Ten championship hopes alive with a dramatic thrust for a touchdown which defeated Northwestern by 20 to 19 today before 35,000 spectators.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Frankie Sinkwich led the undefeated and untied Georgia football team to a 40-to-0 victory over the University of Chattanooga today in a game that wasn't as one-sided as the score might indicate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Joe Gyorgydeak, a little-heralded back from Passaic, N.J., came through as a triple-threat star to spark a smooth-functioning Georgetown team to a 28-20 victory over North Carolina State today.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 14 -- An inspired Dickinson football team battled Lehigh to a standstill until the final minute of play today, when the Engineers, capitalizing on a pass interference penalty, followed by a forward pass, crashed through for a 7-0 victory.

Gunder Haegg and two other Swedish runners will not be able to make their proposed visit to this country for the indoor season because of inability to secure flying priorities, Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U., announced yesterday.

AFTER a too long absence Nurse Sarah Keate has returned to tell another of her adventures in nursing complicated with murder. Together with a younger nurse, Drue Cable, she comes to the country home of Conrad Brent to nurse the latter's son, who has been shot.

THIS nostalgic story preserves for children the author's intimate memories of old Provence, when the countryside along the Rhone bloomed with plenty, and the people were easily amused. Jules the baker turned out fragrant golden loaves each morning, and his wife Rosine drove along the cobbled streets of Avignon, delivering them to their customers.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 14 -- The report of the assumption of power in French North Africa by Admiral Francois Darlan "in the name of Marshal Petain" and with the apparent approval of the United States authorities has caused consternation in Fighting French circles here and among their many supporters in the Province of Quebec.

Mrs. Ernest G. Stillman will give a tea tomorrow at her home, 45 East Seventy-fifth Street, for members of the debutante committee aiding in the plans for the annual card party in behalf of the New York Child's Foster Home Service to be held on the after

Scale models of the two largest and fastest passenger liners under the American flag have been turned over to the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I, where they will be used in the education of cadets for the merchant marine.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Maryland's Old Liners, paced by Tommy Mont, 188-pound quarterback whose accurate passing accounted for much of the yardage, had too much punch and weight for Virginia today and thrashed the Cavaliers, 27 to 12.

After the first harvest the Pilgrims at Plymouth held a festival of thanksgiving. Their grain was reaped and in the storehouse corn and cornstalks were cut and yellow pumpkins gathered in from the fields. Bushels of ruddy apples were stored for the Winter and the wild turkey and pheasant hung ready for the feast.

All the casualties of this war are not listed under the heading, "Killed in Action." The records of our courts contain another casualty list, less final, but tragic enough. Still another is written nowhere except in the minds and hearts of troubled, anxious, frightened children.

WHATEVER the author whose pen name is D.E. Stevenson puts her fictional hand to has certain ineradicable, sure qualities. Humor, lightness of touch, the ability to plot an enthralling story in fascinating surroundings and to create characters that appeal, convincingly, both to head and heart have, previously, been the most outstanding of these.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull expressed today his own "deep gratitude and that of the United States Government" for the messages of support from other American countries in connection with the North African campaign.

An enlarged social welfare program to include more activities stemming from the war and expansion of the post-war studies being conducted by all groups in the National Council of Jewish Women was announced yesterday by the council president, Mrs. Maurice L. Goldman.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Three days of continuous attacks in the Stalingrad factory area have cost the Germans several thousand dead and have gained them only a few yards in a single street of that battered city, the Russians announced early today.
THERE were five of us composers who, in March, 1923, launched the League of Composers, in addition to a group of lay people headed by Mrs. Arthur M. Reis, present executive chairman.

IF it is a matter of wonder and regret that so many talented people write only intermittently for the radio, it is happily true that others work steadily and with skill at their craft. When last these columns looked Arch Oboler's way, early in March, Mr. Oboler was midway in his series of "Plays for Americans" over the National Broadcasting Company's network, and a fine time he was having, too.

MR. LIMBACH and his publishers have performed a real service to American boys and girls in making available at such a reasonable price a truly beautiful and useful book. Indeed adults as well as children will enjoy seeing fifty-five different trees, the main types found in the United States, delightfully illustrated in full-page and double-spread pictures in colors which are remarkably accurate.

PERFECTION, by a consoling truth, is a lonely and perilous condition; one slip, and the fall is fatal. Consider, for example, the frightfully precarious position of Adolphe Menjou. For two decades now, Mr. Menjou, already naturally gifted with needle-sharp mustache points and those distinguished circles under the eyes which are the sina qua non of any man of the world, has been the summum bonum of sartorial splendour.

STOWE, Vt. -- Mount Mansfield, the vast Eastern ski Mecca in the Green Mountains of Vermont, has begun padding his flanks for early Winter activity. On Oct. 20 he tried on his new '43 ski hood. On the twenty-seventh he donned an entire white nightgown.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- After dropping their first four National Hockey League starts, the war-riddled Boston Bruins, sparked by Buzz Boll, their veteran replacement, opened their home season by defeating the New York Rangers, 5 -- 3, tonight before 11,000 spectators at the Boston Garden. Boll registered two counters and set up another pair.

THE principal characters in this book are wholesome personalities who recognize the world, the flesh and the devil as adversaries in their private lives. Their struggles are, however, no glorification of the adversary.

THE author and her husband have brought from Holland for their duration visit in this country a gift to American children of a well-seasoned fairy tale. It is about three elderly brothers with quaint manners, long beards, and impractical habits.

Court decisions involving antitrust actions in some instances are coming into conflict with the war effort. While these actions may have been in the public interest when they were brought or when finally adjudicated, the subsequent change in conditions have resulted in some of the decisions working to the disadvantage of the government in its war effort.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Three fellows from Pennsylvania spelled disaster for Syracuse today as the Orange tangled with the Red Raiders of Colgate before a crowd of 22,000 in Archbold Stadium. This trio -- Mike Micka, John Batorski and Bob Orlando -- accounted for all the points in a 14-0 triumph for Colgate.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Missouri, held at bay for three periods, clawed back from the brink of defeat today to tie a surprisingly stubborn Oklahoma eleven, 6 to 6.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- United States expenditures for war purposes increased 4.8 per cent in October to a total of $5,722,000,000 or a rise of $264,000,000 over September, the War Production Board reported today.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 14 -- A touchdown and a safety provided the margin for Wesleyan's 8-to-0 victory over Trinity today. The safety came early in the first quarter, when Sadowski punted to the Trinity 7 and Black advanced the ball to the Trinity 12.
LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
My son, who is an officer on one of our destroyers, writes me as follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Along with guns and gasoline, candy is going to war wherever American soldiers and sailors go. Three basic Army rations now distributed contain candy or its principal elements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- An arrangement regarding control over prices of war goods along lines already in effect was announced today by the War and Navy Departments and the Office of Price Administration. The agreement was worked out by James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy; Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator.

IT will be news to most Americans that there was a time -- Thomas Raddall probably would fix it somewhere in the late Autumn of 1776 -- when our flag seemed likely to acquire a fourteenth stripe. That stripe would have represented Nova Scotia among the original States.

Earnings of the metal-working Industries were affected substantially by increasing tax rates in the first nine months of 1942, although production, sales and profits before taxes soared to unprecedented levels in virtually every instance.

WATER-COLORISTS of today and of yesteryear are represented by sharply contrasting work in the current exhibition at the Milch Gallery. Not often does even the confirmed gallery-goer find such masterly papers as the misty Wyant Adirondack landscape which, despite its small size, has such carrying power and literally steals the show.

THE division's Chief of Staff appeared to have something on his mind. He took a long drag on his cigarette, then let out a lungful of smoke. "You know," he said, "this division has picked up the soldiering game quicker than any lot of men I ever served with. Guardhouses are almost empty.

THIRTY-TWO years ago this month a handful of United States Navy officers huddled on the deck of the battleship Birmingham, lying at anchor in Hampton Roads, to witness the prelude to the Japanese air attack on Pearl Harbor.

WENATCHEE, Wash., Nov. 14 (AP) -- President Roosevelt told the Grangers, in a special message to their national convention, today that "in this war, the need for American food and other farm products is almost without limit."
WITH the highest respect for Mr. Jewell's critical opinion and artistic background, may I, however, express an opinion completely the reverse of his regarding John Flannagan?

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Six German-Americans who have been on trial for three weeks on charges of treason in aiding and sheltering Herbert Hans Haupt, the Nazi saboteur who was executed with others after an Army trial, were found guilty tonight by a jury in Federal court.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- One hundred and twenty-one dogs were benched today in the opening judging sessions of the twenty-first annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England at the Copley-Plaza. This was a remarkable showing under wartime conditions, the total being only six less than a year ago. Exhibitors came from as far west as Ohio and as far south as Maryland.

The position of honor in this anthology of detective stories dealing with sports is given to a horse-racing mystery, A. Conan Doyle's "Silver Blaze," in which Sherlock Holmes makes his famous observation about "the curious incident of the dog in the nighttime."

THOSE were indeed happy times which Mme. Undset recreates for us in this glowing record of her children's childhood; and if for the elders who are wise enough to read this with their children there is deep poignancy in the light of the present day, for the young there will be only the joyousness of good times generously shared from a rich store of memories.

VALENTI ANGELO has written another story of Italian family life so true, so touched with gentle humor and kindliness, that once again the reader feels that he has enlarged his circle of friends and added to his human experience.

Construction firms and war procurement agencies needing heavy-duty construction equipment to carry out war and essential civilian work may obtain such equipment through a new service established by the War Production Board at New York-Northern New Jersey regional headquarters in New York City, John F. McKernan, regional deputy director in charge of production service, announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD is today making films which are in the main as acceptable to the government as they are to the people whom the government represents. But there are exceptions. Pictures utilizing the war theme have become quite numerous.

Four officials of the United States Lines Company were promoted to new posts at a meeting of the board of directors last week, it was announced yesterday by Basil Harris, president. All are veterans in the shipping industry.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator and chairman of the Maritime Commission, announced last week in his annual address before the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers that the commission had designed a new Liberty ship with greater carrying capacity, longer, faster and higher-powered.

ANXIOUS and critical days in the nation's history one hundred and twenty years ago come into clear focus again through the adventures of Jeff Talbot, a young soldier during the War of 1812. Jeff was more occupied with his Latin lesson than with wartime happenings in Maryland on the evening that a chance encounter plunged him into the struggle.

In the third of a series of booklets on "Conditions in the Occupied Territories" the Inter-Allied Information Committee of London describes the Axis attacks on religion. Nazism began its career with attacks on the Jewish faith. The Jews were the weakest and least numerous of the German religious minorities, and hence could be most safely persecuted.

Wartime insurance problems of American industry will be analyzed at a conference sponsored by the insurance division of the American Management Association at the Hotel Drake, Chicago, Dec. 8 and 9, the association announced yesterday. Insurance buyers for companies in all types of industry are expected to take part in the sessions.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Army defeated the Virginia Tech eleven today, 19 to 7, in the cadets' final home appearance of the season before a slim crowd of 7,000 in Michie Stadium.

THIS is an unusually fine story of rural India, for it is based on real knowledge and sympathetic understanding of Indian village life. To Bim, a little village boy, the jungle is the most beautiful and mysterious place on earth.

New developments in the nation's transportation problem, especially that part dealing with civilian passenger travel, were announced last week. Fast trains were slowed down, local bus service was cut and motorists prepared for the coming mileage rationing.

DALLAS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Southern Methodist's Mustangs, shocked when the Arkansas Razorbacks tallied first in their Southwest Conference football game today, jumped to life and pushed over two quick touchdowns to win, 14 to 6.

President Roosevelt last Friday signed the measure lowering the draft age from 20 to 18 years. The new law made available for immediate military service young men born in 1924, the year Germany accepted the Dawes Plan for the repayment of the damage her troops had caused in the first World War, and in 1923, the year Adolf Hitler staged his "beer hall" Putsch in Munich.

At 8:30 A. M. yesterday the official thermometers of the city recorded the temperature at 26 degrees, the lowest mark so far this season. Indications last night were that there would be a further decline to 18 degrees today and possibly 15 in the suburbs.
The American Ethnological Society, holding its centenary meeting here yesterday, attacked the assumption of racial superiority by any group as false and contrary to scientific teaching.

DOROTHY L'HOMMEDIEU has written a simple, natural little story of a mischievous wire-haired fox terrier, who on every page is made still more real, and irresistibly engaging, by Marguerite Kirmse's beautiful drawings.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Soils that need liming -- and most soils that have not recently been used do -- are best treated now, rather than in the Spring. This is especially true if raw, ground limestone instead of hydrated lime is to be used. A soil test for acidity (pH reaction) will determine the amount to apply -- usually from 50 to 100 pounds per 1,000 square feet.

With one more obstacle to be cleared in order to finish undefeated for the second straight year, Erasmus Hall's football team recorded its twelfth victory in a row over a two-season period by handing its time-honored foe, Boys High, a 12-to-6 setback at Boys High Field yesterday.

Installment sellers generally were gratified last week to learn that the Federal Reserve Board had taken its first action to enforce Regulation W. Reputable dealers, who said they spoke for probably 95 per cent of the trade, had previously complained that lack of enforcement had resulted in unfair competition from a few stores which had never been too careful in living up to any regulation.

THE brilliant illustrator of "Daniel Boone" and "The Voyages of Cartier" has now turned his talent to childhood's first love. The result is a Mother Goose which fairly sparkles with life and color in the freshest of hues; even the black-and-white pictures glow with light.

OUT of this war to date have come many personalized accounts of battle experiences in various parts of the world. This one, "The Flying Guns," ranks with the best, just as the principal of its two authors -- Lieutenant Clarence E. Dickinson.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Prayers "for a victory and for a peace acceptable to God" were urged tonight by the Catholic Archbishops and Bishops of the United States in a "statement on victory and peace" which called for united support of the war effort and for a just and Christian peace.

While wholesale markets continued active, particularly on holiday merchandise, in many cases production fell further behind and failed to equal demand, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buying office.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 14 (AP) -- William and Mary's unbeaten football team turned on the power for two touchdowns and added two more on long pass plays to trounce Virginia Military Institute, 27 -- 6, before 17,500 spectators today.

A grinding attack along the ground, characteristic of the offense he formerly featured at Fordham, was Sleepy Jim Crowley's principal weapon against Manhattan College yesterday at the Polo Grounds, and the lieutenant commander's North Carolina Pre-Flight cadets employed it smartly and effectively while romping to a 17-0 football victory.

A LITTLE child is very serious about the puffing locomotives he sees when he goes for a walk on Saturday morning down by the train yards, or about the ferryboats and tugboats which he watches from a bridge.

THE first discovery of the continent that centuries later came to be named America is, properly speaking, an incident in the history of Iceland and Greenland. And in the heyday of their republic even the Icelanders considered the discovery of Vinland an incident of minor importance.

Appeals to the people of Italy to throw off their Nazi-Fascist masters and to re-enter the brotherhood of civilization were voiced by Assistant Secretary of State A.A. Berle Jr. and other speakers at a dinner held in Mr. Berle's honor last night at the Hotel Commodore by the Italian-American Labor Council and the Mazzini Society.

In a game that glittered in spots with the brilliance of the icy-clear weather in which it was played, Yale's resurgent football forces turned back their oldest rivals, Princeton, 13 to 6, before a gathering of 34,000 that packed Columbia's Baker Field yesterday.

Home economists should inform consumers regarding the effect of their spending on their own communities and the national economy ad aid them to adjust their consumption to the necessities of war, Mrs. Persia Campbell, director of consumer services of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Holley.

Although the disastrous retreat in Egypt of Marshal Rommel's once-threatening forces had already changed the aspect of the war, the announcement of the American landings on the shores of French Africa was electric in its effect. The gratification that it caused grew as events unfolded.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Spain has emerged from the swiftly moving events of this week in North Africa in a position of strict neutrality, backed by assurances from President Roosevelt in behalf of the United Nations. The same is true of Portugal.

The greatest nation-wide sales campaign for government securities since the Liberty Loan drives of a quarter century ago will be begun on Nov. 30. More than $6,000,000,000 is to be raised, with $8,000,000,000 the probable goal and $10,000,000,000 as a possibility.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Desert reports tonight said that German General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, accelerating the pace of his westward retreat, already had pushed the main remnants of his forces well past Derna, nearly 500 miles from the Alamein battleground, in a headlong race for El Agheila on the Gulf of Sidra, where he may make a stand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Congress, although still throbbing with jubilation and distress (according to party) over the war-year election results, is recovering from its shocks. It is settling down, particularly on the House side where the jolt was much more pronounced,

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 14 -- Pastor Friedrich Mueller of Dahlem -- long a collaborator of Pastor Martin Neimoeller -- died on the Eastern Front of heart disease toward the end of September, according to a report reaching Geneva church circles today.

"ORDER OF THE DAY" is the modest title which Thomas Mann has chosen for a volume of philippics in which he warned, first his fellow-Germans, then Europe, and finally our own country, that the peace and freedom of the world were being endangered by the rising power of Hitler's cohorts.

Several young women headed by Miss Jane Whitridge comprise a junior committee aiding in the sale of tickets for the performance of "The Skin of Our Teeth" on the night of Dec. 1 at the Plymouth Theatre for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Mobile forces of more than 6,000 civilian workers were moved into Canada and Alaska by plane, truck, boat and railroad to join with Army Engineers in cutting and bulldozing the Alaskan Highway through the wilderness of the Northwest.

According to information received by this department from Professor Grashnihenkov, corresponding member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, it is an inflexible principle in the Russian Army to carry every wounded man from the battlefield even though he may not reach a base hospital alive.

FOR the last two weeks a new musical organization has been presenting operas in two of New York's playhouses. In one, "Rosalinda," a version of Strauss's "Fledermaus," has been playing. In another, works by Mussorgsky, Verdi, Offenbach, Tchaikovsky and our own Walter Damrosch are being sung.

THE unique personality of Hans Christian Andersen again has inspired fresh interpretation for modern youth, a task that challenges the most skillful authorship. The present medium is fiction, wherein the imagined parts are woven carefully around known biographical facts.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- Wintry blasts at the head of the lakes are threatening to shave two or three weeks off this year's Great Lakes shipping season, but neither shippers nor vessel operators are alarmed.

A telephone rang in an apartment at 130 East End Avenue at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. Over the wire rang the voice of Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commanding general, Army Air Forces, speaking from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Navy announced today the names of fifteen officers who have received the Navy Cross, two enlisted men, recipients of the Silver Star Medal, and two enlisted men who have received the Navy and Marine Corps Medal.

Washington and Lee High of Clarendon, Va., inflicted the first defeat of the season on McKee Vocational, 20 -- 0, in Thompson Stadium, Stapleton, S.I., yesterday. The home side previously had won six straight. It was the eighth victory for W. and L.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Amherst refused to bow to the inevitable today although the Lord Jeffs, opposing the strong Williams eleven in a clash that had aroused frenzied interest through a considerable part of New England, seemed on the way to losing their standing as one of the few undefeated teams in the nation as this afternoon drew to a close.

AS you mount the main stair at the Metropolitan Museum you will see, straight before you, in the center of the wall of the Marquand Gallery, a new acquisition of considerable importance. It is a portrait by Velasquez, given to the museum by the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, of which Mr. Kress is president.

A police reporter discovers the body of a woman who has been murdered, reports it to the police and is immediately fired. Scott Cameron is astonished, as any reporter would be, for newspaper editors normally are pleased when one of their men has an inside track on a good murder mystery.

HERE is a story the 2 and 3 year olds will enjoy, for it is so simple that they can grasp all the incidents and recognize them as familiar experiences. Climbing up the stairs, Tommy Tippett finds his toys all along the way, from the red fire engine at the bottom, to the wiggly fish on the top step.

Under the leadership of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, whose buoyant spirit reminded them of "a bright boy of 25," England is doing her utmost to carry on the war on a democratic basis, eight South American journalists reported yesterday after their return here from a six-week journey to Great Britain.

The monthly flower show of the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue, will take place at 2:30 P.M. on Wednesday, with chrysanthemums and foliage plants being featured. Professor L. M. Massey of the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station is to speak on "Disease Control in the Flower Garden."

James L. Quesada, who argues for the spelling of Guadalcanal, is unfortunately mistaken on many points. It was not Mendana who discovered and named the island but his subordinate, the Maestro de Campo Ortega. Ortega was a native of Guadalcanal in Andalusia and named the island after his home town.

To raise funds for enlarging the headquarters and facilities of the New York Chapter of the Maple Leaf Fund, Inc., committees representing the chapter will conduct a Christmas sale of contributed articles, which will open with a preview on Dec. 1 at 682 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Speaking both for himself and on behalf of the entire American nation, President Roosevelt today sent a message of congratulation to Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Commander in Chief of the expeditionary forces in North Africa, for the "successful accomplishment" of his forces in seizing a large part of North Africa.

THE "last man" of this title refers, of course, to Mr. Longstreet's previous travel book, "Last Man Around the World." Except for this reference it does not fit the present book. After Mr. Longstreet got home he looked about him, as many other Americans were doing.

A SHORT, spare man of rigidly ascetic habits, and with fierce will to win over all obstacles, has emerged as one of the British Army's most brilliant generals in this war. He is Lieut. Gen. Bernard Law Montgomery, Field Commander of Britain's Eighth Army, known to his intimates as "Little Monty" and to his staff

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Penn's football team marched up and down Franklin Field today and got exactly nowhere against a Penn State eleven that definitely was "up" for the thirty-ninth battle in this series. Every time

Draft-board records indicate that certain physical defects are more prevalent in some regions than in others. The Northwest has a higher percentage of "heart trouble" and flat feet than other parts of the country. Bad teeth and stunted growth are fairly common in New England, goiter in the Great Lakes region, blindness in Texas.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The lowly pig win supplant the proud turkey on Thanksgiving Day at the place of honor on the mess tables of all United States forces stationed in the European theatre of operations, it was disclosed today.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Tobruk, Nov. 14 -- The enemy would have needed at least three brigades to hold Tobruk and even that number would not have been enough to hold it long, it is estimated.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- A rowboat and oars were worth more to members of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's recent secret mission to Algiers than 150,000 francs in cash, according to a story told today by United States officials here.

Mill buying featured trading in the cotton futures market yesterday as active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange worked from early losses of 3 points to final net gains of 5 to 6 points, the best prices in the two-hour session.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent most of today in privacy, seeing old acquaintances and friends. One of the first callers at her London home was Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister of South Africa, who was followed by other representatives of dominion governments.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 14 -- A powerful Georgia Tech eleven led by its freshman star, Clint Castleberry, took a one-touchdown lead in the first period and held it tenaciously today to defeat Alabama, 7 -- 0, before a capacity crowd of 32,000.

YOUNGER readers with their keen interest in wartime happenings will welcome this story of Winkie, a brave carrier pigeon. She was the special pet of young Tommy MacIntosh, who helped Mr. Raymond with the chores at a government cote in Dundee.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Reports from the Continent indicated today that, after the first gasp of amazement at the swift Allied occupation of North Africa, underground anti-Fascist groups were renewing their campaign against the Nazis.

HOLLYWOOD. OF the nearly twelve months devoted to the scripting of "Madame Curie" much of the more painful effort went into exploring the realms of pure science. With the fat scenario on his desk, satisfactorily stenciled "completed," Sidney Franklin, the producer, jokingly remarked that he felt capable of filling a chair at the California Institute of Technology.

THIN SKIN -- From the University of California's Medical School come the glad tidings that small doses of thyroid extract help to protect the skin of women workers who bruise easily. It turns out that something is wrong with the thyroid glands of women who are fair and thin-skinned.

Miss Ruth Ayres of OPA has informed representatives of local and national women's organizations with headquarters in New York that regional representatives of that agency are soon to be appointed for the specific purpose of providing these groups with educational material.

One thing about a fireplace: You don't have to own a ration book to keep it going. Heating engineers may moan about inefficiency and meticulous housewives may groan about wood ashes, but a good many folks are thankful now if they have a hearth and the firewood to feed it.

The longest New York season since the renaissance of racing in 1913 ended yesterday with a victory for Miss Ella Widener's Iron Shot in the Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase, two-and-a-half-mile feature on the second day of the United Hunts meeting at Belmont Park.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- With filibuster tactics against the poll tax repeal bill turning on the second day from sustained oratory to absenteeism which prevented a quorum, the Senate ordered the arrest of eight of its missing members, six of them from Southern poll-tax States.
LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A communique broadcast by the German-controlled Vichy radio, recapitulating the part played by Vichy French Naval Forces in fighting in the North African campaign:

Under the patronage of Crown Princess Martha of Norway the world premiere of "The Avengers," a screen dramatization of Norway's fight against Hitler and the "Quislings," on the night of Nov. 24 at the Rivoli Theatre will be a benefit for the American Friends of Norway, of which Mrs. J. Borden Harriman is national chairman.

CHRISTOPHER MORLEY. waited at the top of the four long flights of steep stairs that lead to his workroom in midtown New York. He called encouragement. He never yet, he said, had had a visitor who wasn't panting when he reached the top.

ORAN, Algeria, Nov. 12 (Delayed) -- The envelopment of Oran from three sides, supported by a bold thrust from the Mediterranean into the harbor mouth, is a fascinating story of elaborate and precise planning executed by determined soldiers.

AT ADVANCED SOUTH PACIF BASE, Oct. 29 (Delayed) -- The Americans a few days ago, through close coordination of dive-bombers and artillery, knocked out a Japanese 5-inch gun with which the latter had been shelling Henderson Airfield and scattered rear American areas for two weeks.

ORSON WELLES has returned to Hollywood after an eight months' absence to appease RKO, which underwent a change in regime while he was away in Brazil. The attitude of the new management was plainly indicated this week in an eighteen-page trade advertisement headed "Showmanship in place of genius: a new deal at RKO."
CARE OF HARDWOOD FURNITURE -- "Critical" is the word[ for wood these days. nd the] woods on Washington's mustn't-[ list are the very ones most popu-I larly, used in the making of furni- [ ture.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 14 -- Duke and North Carolina rated even at the kickoff, were still even with the score 13 -- 13 after a thrilling football game played before a crowd of 33,000 today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- Eighteen members of an international lottery ring which the Federal Government says collected at least $12,000,000 were sentenced to serve prison terms by Judge A.F. St. Sure today in Federal court. Eight of the prisoners were from New York City.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Striking by land, sea and air, British and American forces drove eastward today from Bone while field information showed the Axis was rushing reinforcements by sea and air into Tunisia.

ONE of the fascinating activities of the stamp collector is watching for familiar philatelic names in the days's news. The past week's war dispatches from North Africa abounded in names of cities and towns which were seldom heard from until American troops landed on the southern shore of the Mediterranean and the Atlantic coast of Africa but which have long figured in the conversations of collectors.

BENITO JUAREZ was far removed in temperament and personality from the dashing Bolivar of Mrs. Baker's "He Wouldn't Be King," which was awarded the 1941 Intra-American Award, yet so competent a biographer is she that we follow his indomitable footsteps with the same keen interest as we did the Venezuelan, and with warm sympathy as well as homage.

MISS FLEXNER has told with a lovely simplicity and a complete absence of melodrama a childlike little story of two children in a French village in wartime. Without harrowing their feelings and in terms which they can understand, it will give to boys and girls in this country some comprehension of what is happening to other less fortunate children today.

At this writing differences among the United Nations are momentarily eclipsed by the sense of success, and by the evidence of a unified strategy. By a master stroke of diplomacy and force we are now in a position to count France again among our friends. There is a well grounded hope that Italy may soon be added.

Changing over a heating system from oil to coal in order to save fuel is more than a heating engineer's problem. Almost as important is the job of preserving the cellar as a game room. The use of coal need not necessarily mean that the ping pong table

With increasing intensity, secondary schools throughout the United States are gearing their programs to meet the war needs, discarding the traditional classical subjects for courses that can be put to immediate practical use. Far-reaching changes, particularly in the technical fields, are now found in virtually every high school in the country.

This department has been reading Ernst Wagemann's Narrenspiegel der Statistik published in 1935, with the result that it is wondering how much reliance can be placed on the economic figures that come from all governments and that purport to indicate which side will win the war.

Though there is still plenty of furniture in the stores, shortages are being felt. By early next year some types of new furnishings will probably be unobtainable, and the number available will decrease further during the Spring and Summer.

BUCHANAN, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- A mother and her two small children were burned to death here early today when fire swept the two-story converted ice house in which they were living, while the scantily clad husband and father watched outside in the below-freezing temperature, unable to rescue them.

Considerable interest has centered on the sunflower recently, as uses that are almost unlimited have been found for it. New as this utilization may seem, our forefathers learned about the sunflower's versatility some time ago. The following excerpts are from "The Cottage Garden Almanac" for the year 1866:

IT is a pleasure indeed to welcome such a delightful combination of beauty, understanding of children and animals, and droll humor, as Mrs. Newberry's latest book, based we are told on fact, and with all the illustrations done from life.

THIS "tall tale" from the early days of the railroad is a cheerful bit of American folklore very welcome in a wartime year. The Sooner hound, so called because he'd sooner run than eat, could not bear to be parted from the Boomer who was his master, so when the Boomer, or traveling fireman, went to get a new job on another railroad, the Sooner went with him as a matter of course.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Labor Department opened the gates of war plants today to girls of 16 and 17 years.

The McCann collection, noted for its extensive and well-selected seventeenth and eighteenth century furnishings, will be sold at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on the afternoons of Tuesday through Saturday, with one session on Wednesday morning. The late Mrs. McCann was the former Helena Woolworth.
ALFRED BULLTOP STORMALONG, the legendary sailor who was four fathoms tall in his stocking feet, belongs in the company of Paul Bunyan and Pecos Bill, favorite heroes of the American tall story.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- General Francisco Franco, Chief of the Spanish State, in replying to President Roosevelt's message assuring him that Spain had nothing to fear from the United Nations when the North African campaign was undertaken, expressed his "intention of avoiding anything that might disturb our relations in any of their aspects."

"YOU'D be surprised," said an 8-year-old, "at what I get out of books." Since what reading does for the individual, like many of the pleasantest things in life, is among the imponderables, we can only try to gauge by intuition and sympathy how the child of today is affected by the enormous number of books provided for him.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Oct. 26 (Delayed) -- A Japanese Zero pilot, shot down with sixteen other Japanese fighter pilots during an air battle at Guadalcanal yesterday that proved to be another field day for American pursuit airmen, parachuted into the bay off Guadalcanal.

THE urgent desire of children and young people to read about the heroes of World War II had prepared a welcome for this book. It is dedicated "To these men of sublime courage who have brought glory to our flag."

America must not enter the demobilizing period after the war with the same lack of planning that characterized her mobilization for war, Dr. Joseph W. Barker, dean of the School of Engineering of Columbia University, declared yesterday morning in an address read for him by the Rev. Stephen F. Bayne Jr., chaplain of the university, at the closing session of a two-day Conference on Wartime Problems.

Joseph Battista, 24-year-old Philadelphia pianist, gave his second New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Mr. Battista was first heard here in the same surroundings two years ago. Since then, he was the first winner in June, 1941, of the Guiomar Novaes Award, which entitled him to a series of appearances made during that Summer in Brazil.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday by Edward Reynolds, president, and Philip Gossler, chairman, shows a net income of $7,568,988 after expenses, taxes and other charges.

News of the American invasion of North Africa has given heart to the people of occupied Denmark, of whom ninety-eight per cent favor the cause of the United Nations, John C. Moller, chairman of the Danish Council in London, said yesterday when he arrived here aboard a trans-Atlantic clipper.

THE tune that is sweeping the country is Frank Loesser's Praise the Lord and Pass the Ammunition. Such recordings as were made of it by bands before the cloture on recordings was imposed by the Musicians' Union ten weeks ago are selling as rapidly as they can be pressed and distributed.

One of the largest benefit theatre parties of the Winter will take place at the performance of Chekhov's "The Three Sisters" on the night of Dec. 22 at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, which has been taken over to advance the work of the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States.

THERE still lingers an inexplicable prejudice against the use of the first person in children's books, but its use is certainly justified in this interesting story, for it brings us close to the thought and experiences of a Basque youth who renounced his fervent love for his own land to become an American.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company in its report to the Federal Communications Commission for September showed gross revenues of $17,408,593 from operating activities only, compared with $12,056,929 in September last year. Net income, which included dividends received from subsidiaries, was $38,951,737, against $44.601,694.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Chairmen of five special Senate and House groups investigating the conduct of the war on the domestic front (all of them supporters of the New Deal) joined today in a drive for legislation to force a unified control of the non-military economy of the country by putting production, manpower and supply "under one civilian roof" and in command of a single director.

In the center of a circle of war-production activity, New York City is still striving to draw to itself some of the huge war orders that have poured into every other industrial area in the country. New York is the comparatively slow-moving hub of a wheel that is whirling at breakneck pace.

AS the new season for the theatre, radio, music and the other amusements gains headway, there will be an epidemic of an ancient and ubiquitous malady -- stage fright. Its blood brother is mike fright, and it has cousins, sisters and aunts in a hundred and one fields. Speechmakers, fliers, soldiers, sailors, football and baseball players, boxers -- all are subject to the virus which respects neither professional nor amateur, champion nor club.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Complete military victory over Japan is the only way of obtaining lasting peace in the Pacific, Joseph C. Grew, recently Ambassador in Japan, declared today in an address before the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Roosevelt expressed appreciation in a message today to President Juan Antonio Rios of Chile for his recent message approving the North African campaign.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 14 (AP) -- The highly regarded Tennessee Volunteers ran into unexpected opposition today from the victory-poverished Mississippi Rebels and emerged with only a 14-0 triumph in a Southeastern Conference duel. Some 10,000 spectators saw the Rebels threaten touchdowns twice in the second half.

ROBINSON CRUSOE would have to admit that his own inventive genius was purely elementary, should he meet his modern successors who are the heroes of this amazing yarn. Bob Mexican was a highly educated adventurer and man of many parts when his talents were employed by a present-day Balkan sovereign.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force fliers with the British Eighth Army pursuing the Africa Corps ranged far westward today and reported that the Germans in Tunisia had begun sabotaging installations at Bizerte, strategic Tunisian port.

THESE two authors, whose "Homesteaders' Horses," an excellent story with genuine humor and good characterization, appeared a year ago, have written another vigorous tale of the Western country, which combines camping out with a touch of mystery and the discovery of a hidden treasure.

Admiral Georges Robert, High Commissioner for the French West Indies and French Guiana, appealed yesterday to the people to obey Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, according to a Martinique broadcast recorded by The United Press.

Retail trade here made fair headway last week, but gains were smaller than in preceding weeks. Department store volume was estimated as showing an increase of 3 to 5 per cent over the corresponding period of last year. Gains in food sales continued heavy. Freakish weather held down the expansion of seasonal apparel purchasing.

Leaders in diplomatic, artistic and social circles are expected to attend an invitation preview of a benefit exhibition of Cezanne to be held Wednesday at the Rosenberg Galleries, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street. Louis Bromfield will speak at the preview.

Led by representatives of charities, local and national, outstanding among which is the American Red Cross, an earnest effort is impending to induce the administration at Washington to repeal or modify the executive order and the regulations derived therefrom which set a net salary limit of $25,000 annually on all working citizens except lawyers and certain others.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A retirement income plan for Bell Aircraft Corporation employes reaching the age of 60 will be voted on at a special stockholders' meeting Dec. 16, the company announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Elmer Davis, War Information Director, assured the country today that it was being kept fully informed of war developments and he challenged charges that the Navy was losing the Pacific war.

In Nassau and Suffolk Counties, leaders of women's organizations are lending their efforts to a drive which is gaining momentum there, to enlist and train more women for jobs awaiting them in Long Island's airplane factories. The goal of the campaign, launched by the United States Employment Service and the State Department of Education, is 10,000 workers.
TULSA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Tulsa proved its claim to national football prominence today by smashing Baylor, 24 -- 0, for its eighth consecutive victory.

ABOARD one of the dragon-prowed Viking ships which brought the first white settlers to America was Nils, orphaned nephew of Leif, the great explorer, and of Freydis, Leif's haughty grasping sister. It is through the boy's eyes that we see the founding of that colony under Thorfinn Karlsefni in Vinland, which is here placed on Martha's Vinyard.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he plans to seek both State and local legislation to eliminate abuses in the medical oxygen service business. The proposed State legislation would require all oxygen therapy technicians to be licensed by the State Department of Education.
More favorable war news last week found manufacturers, who are partially or wholly working on defense work giving more attention to the sales personnel problems likely to follow the end of the war.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 14 -- The Louisiana farm's Riverland, turf sensation after his upset defeats of Whirlaway and Alsab, finished next to last in the Thomas K. Lynch Memorial Handicap today as H.P. Metcalf's Star Copy romped off with the winner's purse of $4,200.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The American tanks rolling upon the sandy shores of North Africa not only made available to the United States the valuable French radio transmitters at Algiers and Rabat, but, by changing the strategic situation, they opened up what may be called a new era in our wartime propaganda. The tactics on both sides are linked with those of the general staffs.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 14 -- A hearty welcome for the American Expeditionary Force landed in Northwest Africa in the most bloodless occupation of the Arab-populated lands of that area has been voiced by the ruler of Trans-Jordan, Emir Abdullah Ibn Hussein, who expressed hope in an interview that this entry would produce a general understanding among the Arab peoples in the Mediterranean region.

THERE has been quite a lot of talk lately -- especially among women at work, and who isn't? -- about the "convertible coiffure." Every one has seen a picture of it. The informal version is smooth and well brushed on top with a halo of ringlets around the face and nape in a charming air of insouciance.

MICHEL KACHOUK, former manager of the Grand Opera Russe de Paris, will present a series of four Russian operas in concert form this season at Town Hall. The series opens on Dec. 26 with Glinka's "Russian and Ludmilla" and continues with Dargomizhsky's "Russalka" Jan. 30; Tchaikovsky's "Eugen Onegin" Feb. 27 and Mussorgsky's "Khovantchina," April 3.

ALLEN JENKINS, who has been away from Broadway too long now -- it is ten years -- is to return to town in "Something for the Boys," the Cole Porter-Herbert and Dorothy Fields affair which Mike Todd is producing.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Union College fought an uphill battle to tie Hamilton, 14 -- 14, in the fiftieth game between the football rivals today. The contest closed Art Lawrence's coaching career at Union, Mel Hein replacing him.

NOW that the Ballet Theatre has concluded the first chapter of its fourth New York season and has betaken itself Pacificward until Spring, the annual remarks upon its endowments and achievements are once more in order.

LORD GODIVA of the Army Air Force made his first and only appearance, riding a plane instead of a white horse about a year ago. He was an unnamed cadet at Maxwell Field, Ala., and he stripped and climbed into a grounded ship at the order of Ernest Smith, physical director of the Southeast Training Center.

The creation in Tokyo of a so-called Super-Ministry of Greater East Asia signifies one of two things. Either Japan believes that it has sufficiently consolidated and organized the conquered territories to begin exploiting them, or it has discovered that conquest is easier than development and is worried.

With practically the entire output of the dehydrated foods industry being taken by the military agencies, the shortage of tin containers and the consequent increased demand for the products by civilians will require considerable further expansion of the industry in the near future, it was reported yesterday.

The news that Eddie Rickenbacker was alive brought spontaneous smiles to the faces of millions of Americans yesterday. A "natural" as a story, it seemed to tie up in the minds of some with the general trend of good news ushered in with the surprise from North Africa a week ago.

H.A. REY'S spirited picture-story books have an unforced humor which is irresistible; while their grave attention to the matter in hand, their carefully worked out details, make the absurd so entirely logical and credible that the adventures of Cecily G. the amiable giraffe and her monkey friends have for children the absorbing interest of their own make-believe.

To enlist the services of young people in the recently launched nation-wide campaign to raise $2,000,000 for the United Yugoslav Relief Fund, a junior executive committee has just been formed under the chairmanship of Miss Clover Todd Dulles 2d.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Following is the text of the statement on Victory and Peace issued tonight in the name of all the Catholic Archbishops and Bishops of the United States by the members of the Administrative Board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Under the command of General MacArthur, in 1941 and 1942, some 20,000 Filipino soldiers were killed in action in the Philippines before American and Filipino resistance was overwhelmed.

WINNIPEG, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The Winnipeg Tribune in a newspaper story today said "a spectacular change in Western Canada's wheat production for 1943 is under serious consideration at Ottawa."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- The Chilean Government, which maintains diplomatic relations with the Axis nations, soon will ask Congress to discuss the Rio de Janeiro accords, which call for all Pan-American nations to sever diplomatic and economic relations with Germany, Italy and Japan, informed circles said today.

STATE COLLEGE, Miss., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Striking with lightning plays in the last three quarters, Mississippi State knocked over Duquesne's Dukes, 28 to 6, today before 10,000 home-coming fans in one of the wildest games ever played on Scott Field.

Willoughby House, a settlement in Brooklyn for young people and adults, will be aided by a card party on the afternoon of Nov. 24 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Rees S. Hines heads the benefit committee.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Armed with all the powers of a Moreland Act commissioner, former Justice William F. Bleakley of Westchester will investigate the workings of the Workmen's Compensation Law under appointment of Governor Lehman which he announced today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Correlating messages spirited out of concentration camps and forwarding them in a monthly newsletter to families of American civilians interned in the Philippines, as well as identifying prisoners and locating their relatives in this country, is a task which has been quietly undertaken in New York City by a group of wives, mothers, sisters and friends of internees.

IN a well-known passage in "The Mayor of Casterbridge" Thomas Hardy made vivid reference to a local landmark, one of the finest Roman amphitheatres remaining in Britain. "Melancholy, impressive, lonely," it was the scene of many a clandestine appointment.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Allied parachute troops were being flown tonight to relieve the French garrisons battling to prevent Axis forces from gaining a foothold in Tunisia before the arrival of Britain's First Army, which is racing eastward for Tunis, the capital, and Bizerte, strategic bases in the battle for the Mediterranean.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14 -- In a message to President Ramon S. Castillo the General Confederation of Labor, the oldest and strongest Argentine trade union organization, demanded today "a rupture of relations with Germany, Italy, Japan and all other countries that in one form or another contribute toward the continued existence of totalitarian forms of government."

OPENING of Christmas displays and the campaign to induce customers to shop earlier in the interest of service conservation led to a fair start on holiday buying in the week. This means that the season is some three weeks ahead of the normal period.

OUT in Phil Stong country -- which is known as Van Buren County, Iowa, on the map -- Sunday, the 7th of December, 1941, dawned as deceptively mild as it did in New York. "Chickens pecked at each other much more gently on this day, and hogs were nearly content.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14 -- Navy snatched victory away from Columbia in the final minute of play today with a weird scoring pass which had to be seen to be believed. While the 25,000 spectators in the Municipal Stadium watched with startled gaze, the middies came roaring from behind to beat the Lions, 13 to 9.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 -- Pitt's docile Panthers struck through the air for a quick first period touchdown and then fought off two desperate Nebraska bids in the second half today to gain a 6-0 victory over the Cornhuskers before only 7,000 fans.
There will be deer hunting in Westchester County today, but the bowman and not the gunner will be in the field this morning as the fifteen-day season opens.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Fleet-footed Johnny Bezemes led the Holy Cross Crusaders to a 13-0 victory over Temple University's Owls today, scoring in the first quarter on a 4-yard dash and racing 30 yards on an end sweep for the second touchdown in the fading moments of the game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Federal Government will take over more than $60,000,000 of Federal-aided low-rent public housing projects in Ohio on April 1, according to the National Housing Agency, unless action is taken to clarify the State's tax-exemption policy on projects owned by Metropolitan Housing Authorities.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Pushing over four touchdowns in the opening quarter, two by sophomore Jimmy Secrest, the East's leading scorer, the University of Rochester routed Hobart, 59 -- 0, in their golden anniversary game today.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- With bell ringers -- both amateurs and trained hands -- recruited hastily from far and near and going through lastminute rehearsals with "silent ropes," every one throughout the land was agog tonight at the prospect of hearing the church bells ringing tomorrow forenoon for the first time since the British evacuation of Dunkerque.

THE $25,000 income ceiling will not affect concert artists for the remainder of this year, but unless modified it will have a marked effect on their appearances in 1943. Just what those effects will be, however, is not certain.

A government investigation of persistent rumors along the entire Atlantic seaboard of inefficiency and deliberate bad stowage on the part of dock workers who load lend-lease cargoes on ships destined for war fronts and Allied ports is being considered in Washington, it was disclosed here yesterday.

The Westminster Kennel Club will hold its sixty-seventh dog show in Madison Square Garden Feb. 11 and 12, carrying on the annual exhibition as it did during the Spanish-American War and first World War. Appropriately, this event will be given for the benefit of Dogs for Defense, Inc., official recruiting agency for the United States Army.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Issues of States' rights came to the fore today as six Governors, three Democrats and three Republicans, took part in the annual meeting of the board of managers of the Council of State Governments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (Science Service) -- Warlike inventions are not lacking in the week's crop of 741 patents. One of them, No. 2,301,248, covers a breechbolt checking mechanism developed by Jonathan E. Browning of Ogden, Utah, member of the famous gun-making family. Rights in the patent are assigned to the Western Cartridge Company.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Minnesota's on-again, off-again football team wore out Iowa's iron men today to win, 27 to 7, and knocked the Hawkeyes out of the Big Ten title race.

Eighty per cent of the severely restricted shipping space of 30,000 tons monthly, which has been allotted to Puerto Rico is being used by the Agricultural Marketing Administration to bring in foodstuffs, most of which are of low quality and generally undesirable, it was charged yesterday by Jose A. Ferre, vice president of the Porto Rico Iron Works, one of the largest machine shops and foundries on the island.

SUCCESSFUL operation of an independent radio station in a metropolitan city involves a multitude of problems. Competition with the networks on major entertainment items is a financial impossibility, and generally the only feasible alternative is to operate a "record mill," employing a few personality kids to break the monotony of the spinning turn-tables with some snappy talk.

THIS is not the first time this haunting, tender tale has been published in the United States. It appeared here first in Story Parade and later in the first collection of stories from that magazine, but it is a fine thing to have it at last in a separate volume, especially one of such pleasing format.

ARMSTRONG SPERRY, whose "Call It Courage" won the Newbery Medal in 1940 and whose books for boys and girls, "All Sails Set," "Wagons Westward," "One Way With Manu" and many more, have been prime favorites for years, has now written two admirable little books for the younger children.

IT was hard enough for Alison Grant and her twin Gavin to live peacefully with the greedy relatives who had seized their brother's Scottish estate after Hugh had fled into exile following Prince Charles's defeat at Culloden.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Further defections from Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's Vichy regime came to light today, but the question as to which French faction will assume political control of the North African colonies still remained a mystery.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- So serious are some of the shortages in the confectionery industry that the board of directors of the National Confectioners Association win probably meet here within the next month to formulate policies for maintaining nutrition standards in this branch of the food industry.

BUFFALO, Nov. 14 -- After trailing twice, once by two touchdowns and then by one, Cornell's Big Red eleven rammed its way to its second consecutive victory by defeating its ancient rival, Dartmouth's Indians, 21 to 19, on the neutral ground of Buffalo's Civic Stadium today.

MOST children today are well informed about the Wright brothers, but two other brothers, much earlier pioneers in aviation, achieve modern acknowledgment in this attractive book. It offers a lively, informal account of Joseph and Etienne Montgolfier, who in 1783 invented the balloon.

SCHOOL children will make good use of this book which tells separately for the first time the whole consecutive history of the Liberty Bell. Although its tones have not rung out since the metal dome cracked in 1835, its home in Philadelphia's Independence Hall is a national shrine.

While the government in the last year and a half has stepped up sharply its attacks on violators of the anti-trust laws, the frequent acceptance of consent decrees has nullified the intent of these laws, leaving the triple-damage suit as the only effective weapon against trusts and combinations in restraint of trade, Henry Ward Beer, former special assistant to the United States Attorney General and authority on the anti-trust laws, declared here yesterday.

A recent check-up of Winter recreation centers shows that 70 per cent are within a few hours' ride of Army training sites, thus giving service men an opportunity for furlough sports. In the South nearly half the camps and military centers are within easy distance of popular resorts.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Little Beecher Montgomery jumped off the Texas Christian bench and led the Horned Frogs to a dramatic fourth-quarter 13-7 victory over Texas today to throw the Southwest Conference football race into a three-way tie.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- A crimson-clad halfback from the Providence lair of the Brown Bear turned on his home-towners in Harvard Stadium today and scored the only touchdown of the chilly contest before about 9,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- "Unless some means is found to discourage voluntary enlistments of workers doing essential jobs in war industries, the war production effort will suffer a severe set-back over the coming months."

JERUSALEM, Nov. 14 -- If they can be extricated from France under present occupation conditions and reach Palestine over circuitous wartime routes, 1,000 orphaned Jewish refugee children will be permitted to enter this country under the 1939 white paper issued by the British Government, providing for the admission of refugee immigrants.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- On the same field on which the Chicago Bears defeated the Army All-Stars, one of the greatest college football teams the East has seen ran riotously from the same T formation to annihilate Fordham by the score of 56 -- 6 today at Fenway Park.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- Plans have been perfected for a giant public rally to be held here on the night of Nov. 19, at which the chief speaker will be Price Administrator Leon Henderson. Following this, first the City of Boston and then the entire State of Massachusetts will embark on a campaign designed to make 100 per cent effective the General Maximum Price Regulation.

THERE is good news this morning for the mystery film devotees and particularly for the proprietors of the little art cinemas. In short, "The Thirty-nine Steps" is coming back into circulation. For of all Alfred Hitchcock's popular melodramatic exercises this seven-year-old British production appears to be the one that has best weathered the test of time.

The Metropolitan Opera's new production, a revival of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," will be given in the first week of the season, on Saturday, Nov. 28, it was announced yesterday. Also included in the week's schedule are "The Magic Flute," conducted by Bruno Walter, which was the largest new production last season, "Carmen," conducted by Sir Thomas Beecham, and two of the other biggest works in the repertoire, "Goetterdaemmerung" and "Aida."

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Nov. 13 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Direct hits were scored on two Japanese light cruisers and a near miss was observed near a Japanese destroyer early today when American Flying Fortresses based in New Guinea blasted enemy shipping in the much-bombed naval anchorage of Buin-Faisi in the Northern Solomons.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Sources in London said today that Marshal Petain's message -- if the Axis-controlled Vichy radio retains any reliability -- partly clarified the position of the Vichy regime, but left Admiral Darlan's status undetermined.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Georgia Pre-Flight eleven outplayed and beat Tulane, 7 -- 0, today before 18,000 fans, the lone counter coming in the second period immediately after Don Hightower's 75-yard kick runback for the victors had been officially discounted because he stepped out at midfield.

ANTIQUE needlepoint, always appreciated by the knowing, is in this wartime era attracting wide attention. For many are finding in embroidery a quiet refuge from nerve strain. As an avocation, needlepoint is not confined to the distaff side; here and there one finds members of the allegedly sterner sex who are not only creating original designs but actually learning the technique and making priceless coverings for chairs and sofas.
