As an avocation, needlepoint is not confined to the distaff side; here and there one finds members of the allegedly sterner sex who are not only creating original designs but actually learning the technique and making priceless coverings for chairs and sofas.

The four stories included in this volume are "Verdict of Twelve," by Raymond Postage; "Keep Murder Quiet," by Selwyn Jepson; "Warrant for X," by Philip MacDonald, and "The Case of the Late Pig," by Margery Allingham.

BY proposing to a group of prominent writers that they work up in themselves and in their writing an angry and indiscriminate hate of the German people (as opposed to merely attacking Nazi leaders) Rex Stout and Clifton Fadiman a few nights ago stirred up one of the stormiest literary sessions in a long while.

Closer cooperation of education, business, labor and other groups was recommended yesterday by speakers attending the School Finance Conference, sponsored by the joint committee of teachers organizations and the National Education Association, held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MR. RUSSELL goes after injustice with both fists flying in this sincerely conceived novel. The story he tells is not a new one. Most of us should know by now that life in the cotton counties of the deep South can be cruelly dull; today's headlines remind us once again that the Negro problem must some day engulf them.

A Polka Military Ball, its theme and decorations centered on the gallant role being played by the Poles in the war, will be given Jan. 22 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as the tenth annual benefit dance of the Kosciuszko Foundation.

CHUNGKING, China, Sunday, Nov. 15 -- Before the outbreak of the Chinese-Japanese hostilities in 1937 China had more than 1,000 daily newspapers, more than 1,000 weeklies and monthlies and a number of Chinese-owned newspapers and magazines published in English.

LONDON, Nov.14 -- In an address to the youth of twenty-six nations who met in London today for the opening of the International Youth Conference Ivan M. Maisky, Soviet Ambassador to London, voiced his country's satisfaction over the recent turn of events in North Africa and Egypt but at the same time warned that it would be folly to have any illusions about an easy comfortable victory.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- A great force of bombers from Britain, made up entirely of four-motored Lancasters and Stirlings, heavily attacked Genoa again last night and left that Northern Italian port, so vital to Axis reinforcements in Libya and Tunisia, a flaming and smoking mass of ruins.

The Rockefeller Foundation's International Health Division has established a louse laboratory to learn how it may cope more effectively with typhus. Five medical students from New York University spend one to two hours daily with trousers rolled to the knee, while 1,000 critters feed on their blood.

The creation of the forty-hour week was a device to spread employment and is a product of an excessive labor supply. The provision for higher pay for overtime was designed to discourage the employer from working men overtime and to compel him to hire additional available help. He was penalized for not dipping into the available pool of unemployed labor.

NYACK -- Rockland County and the contiguous areas in the Hudson Valley find themselves facing a particularly poignant situation. Rockland's beloved mountain. High Tor, is for sale. The craggy foot-hill, as important to Rockland as Arthur's Seat to Edinburgh or Mauna Loa to Hawaii, was thrown on the market recently to settle an estate.

ROBERT RUSSELL BENNETT has completed, at the request of Fritz Reiner of the Pittsburgh Symphony, a "symphonic picture," scored for modern orchestra with addition of banjos and inclusion of full wind choir and harp, of thematic material from George Gershwin's opera, "Porgy and Bess."

Religion is a dynamic, creative principle on which men and women should base their lives, but it cannot to be offered as a formula for the regulation of an unconverted world, the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, declared yesterday.

Thirty-four thousand long tons of scrap metal still remained in the month-old household salvage piles, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People," in which he renewed his attack upon the War Production Board's salvage division.
A German High Command communique broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The mighty Chicago Bears virtually assured themselves of the Western division championship of the National Football League today by smashing the Green Bay Packers at will for a 38-to-7 triumph before a sellout crowd of 42,787.

Gracita Faulkner, a New York Negro soprano, gave her first local recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Her program included classic airs, German lieder, a French group, spirituals and the aria "Ernani, Ernani, involami," from Verdi's "Ernani." Violet Saunders was her accompanist.

German and Italian naval and air forces operating in the Mediterranean have sunk or damaged eighty-nine Allied warships and transports since the start of the campaign in North Africa, it was announced yesterday in a German High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press.

Thousands of members of the parish of St. Catharine of Genoa, West 153d Street, Washington Heights, participated yesterday in a patriotic rally and memorial service, marked by the unveiling of a plaque affixed to the front of the church, bearing the names of nearly 200 members of the parish serving in the armed forces.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 -- Sidney Fox, who played in legitimate stage roles and in films in the early days of the talking pictures, was found dead in bed early today by her husband, Charles Beahan, an actors' agent, in their home in Beverly Hills.
Only four new films are scheduled to open locally this week. The program follows:

Charles W. Taussig, chairman of the American Section of the Anglo-American Caribbean Commission, and chairman of President Roosevelt's Caribbean Advisory Committee, took exception yesterday to published criticism of efforts made by various governmental agencies to supply foodstuffs to Puerto Rico.

ABOARD A BRITISH CRUISER, Somewhere in the Mediterranean, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A very tanned executive officer of this battle-scarred cruiser was embarrassed and apologetic today as correspondents came aboard.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Russian soldiers and workers received by every available channel today the glad news that they had fighting Allies, and that powerful British and American forces in Africa were striking effective blows at the Axis.

Events today: All-Out Concert, Garfield Swift, baritone, Joana and Louise Leschin, duo-pianists, Town Hall, 12:30 P.M.; New Opera Company, "La Vie Parisienne," Broadway Theatre, 8:30; Alfred Mirovitch, piano recital, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Arthur Dann, piano recital, Town Hall, 8:30; Emanuel Vardi, viola, assisted by Norman Secon, pianist, and Edward Vito, harpist, The New York Times Hall, 9.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Weather conditions were less favorable last week for harvesting corn and relatively slow progress was made in parts of the Central West. In the drier areas west of the Mississippi River, however, farmers were able to gather considerable corn, and it is expected that the bulk of the crop there will be out of the field with a week or more of good weather.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Asserting that the monthly increase of 100,000 in the number of Federal Civil Service employes between Pearl Harbor and Sept. 1 indicated that there would be more than 3,000,000 such employes by Jan. 1, Senator Byrd called today for dismissal of at least a third to stop what he called a manpower waste "criminal" in wartime.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, Nov. 16 -- American and Australian troops in New Guinea have joined forces and are moving in for an attack on the Japanese at Buna from the south and the west. The Australians are in the process of crossing the Kumusi River, thirty-two air miles from Buna, in strength, and the whole attack is developing with Allied troops pressing forward in a semi-circular manoeuvre against the Japanese beachhead.

Miller McClintock, executive director of the Advertising Council and widely known as an authority on traffic and engineering problems, has been appointed president of the Mutual Broadcasting System, the network announced here yesterday.
This department ranks Boston College ahead of Georgia and Georgia Tech this morning as the best college football team in all the land.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The European service of the British Broadcasting Corporation announced in its home and empire news bulletins tonight that "we have just received a report from a usually well-informed source that Weygand [General Maxim E. Weygand, former French pro-consul in Africa] had been arrested by order of the Germans."

A plea to men and women of Brooklyn to accept the responsibility of foster parenthood was made yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore, social workers and three foster parents at a meeting of 500 persons in the Brooklyn Boys High School.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- In connection with two meetings of members of the Wholesale and Retail Inventory Committee and representative merchants and merchant-manufacturers to discuss the War Production Board's forthcoming inventory limitation order, Dr. Eaton V.W. Read, committee chairman, outlined today the tentative formula for determining "normal" inventory.

Less aggressive trade buying and price-fixing rather than any pronounced selling pressure turned the cotton futures market lower last week following the steady upward movement of the two preceding weeks. On the New York Cotton Exchange the week ended with net losses of 6 to 30 points, equal to 30 cents to $1.50 a bale, with the greatest declines in the distant positions.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- The vanguard of Marshal Rommel's fleeing Africa Corps has passed through Bengazi. 300 miles inside Libya, and is racing heading toward El Agheila, 140 miles farther to the southwest, front dispatches reported tonight.

Results of a mail poll to determine the recipient of the distinguished war service award to be conferred on a native of Indiana by the Sons of Indiana showed Wendell L. Willkie to be the winner, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- In world-wide broadcasts, the Presidents of three of the United Nations this evening joined in hailing establishment of the Philippine Commonwealth, the seventh anniversary of which came today, as "providing in a very real sense a pattern for the future of other small nations and peoples of the world."

The first edition of the altar-size Roman Mass-book, the "Missale Romanum," to be printed outside Europe since the first edition was produced from movable type at Milan in 1474, has been completed by United States liturgical scholars and labor, Benziger Brothers, Inc., printers to the Holy See and to the Sacred Congregation of Rites, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Silk and nylon stockings are to become an official item in the nation's salvage program tomorrow. Beginning then, all women are requested to take their worn and discarded hosiery to collection centers which are established in retail stores having women's and misses' hosiery departments.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- As the deer season opened in Westchester County today, for the first time since 1928, and hundreds of archers scoured the hills, only two of the gazelle-like animals were reported killed, and those not by hunters.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A communique describing the naval operations off Algeria and Morocco:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- While reports circulated recently that the steel situation has eased slightly are based on factual data, they by no means indicate any relaxation in the restrictions already in force on non-essential steel requirements.

Acquisition by Twentieth Century-Fox of a large group of story properties and the services of stars, directors, cameramen and technicians under contract to David O. Selznick, independent producer and a partner in the ownership of the United Artists Distributing Corporation, was announced yesterday in a joint statement by Mr. Selznick and William Goetz, vice president in charge of production for Fox.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 15 -- How far can Vichy rely on its army? That question was raised here today by the abortive dissident move engendered by General Jean Lattre de Tassigny as revealed by Vichy itself with the announcement that he would be tried by a military court for rebellion.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Numberless bells in the churches of many faiths scattered throughout Britain and Northern Ireland rang out this Sabbath Day in a historic paean as millions of worshipers, Protestants and Roman Catholics alike, offered thanks for the Allied successes in Egypt.

Somehow, in spite of all forebodings and against all indications, Eddie Rickenbacker's rescue was expected. For more than a quarter of a century the veteran Ace has been flying under a lucky star. When a man like that falls into a spin even in the middle of the Pacific Ocean nobody gives up hope either for him or his companions.

Assailing the armistice between France and Germany as a "treaty with the devil," the Rev. Dr. John A.F. Maynard declared in his sermon yesterday at the French Church of the Holy Spirit, 109 East Sixtieth Street, that it was always a mistake to compromise with evil either in national life or personal behavior.

AUGUSTA, ]Vie., Nov. 15 -- Waiters S. Wyman was instrumental in getting such industries as the Iaine Seaboard Paper Company at Bucksport to come to Maine. He salvaged the three large cotton mills at Lewiston, the Bates, Hill and Androscoggin mills, as well as the Bath Iron Works.

Last week the Irving Fisher Index of wholesale commodity prices rose slightly from 108.4 to 108.5. Changes were mainly in the prices of agricultural commodities. The most notable individual advances were those in tobacco, potatoes and corn. The commodities which showed the largest declines were hogs, oranges and apples.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks skipped into second place behind the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League race tonight by upsetting the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 to 4, before a packed house of 16,089.

Wholesale demand for ready-to-wear improved last week as buyers placed large reorders for holiday merchandise and sought to cover early 1943 requirements as well, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHRISTMAS has as much business significance for a publisher as it does for a perfume manufacturer or a necktie-maker. Christmas sales cheer the melancholy bookseller, they add greatly to the momentum of good and popular books, they rid the bookshops' shelves of many strange hybrids hopefully labeled "gift books," and they produce an annual demand and consequent supply of books of humor.
Again it's a showdown in the Solomons.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- There is complete unity of command at the top in the several theatres in which American forces are operating, Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, has asserted, according to a copyrighted story appearing in The St. Louis Post-Dispatch today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth announced today the presentation of the Philippine patrol vessel Bataan to the United States Government. The boat was accepted by President Roosevelt and turned over at once to the Coast Guard for service.

Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal of Great Britain, will broadcast a message from London this afternoon to the opening session of The New York Herald Tribune's eleventh Forum on Current Problems at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The forum will continue through tomorrow.

The Norwegian people have not been conquered, but are standing up to the German "barbarians" at least 99 per cent, Wilhelm Morgenstierne, Norwegian Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday. He was one of thirty-eight passengers who arrived aboard a transatlantic clipper plane commanded by Captain Charles Titus.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 15 -- The large naval force, ranging from trawlers to liners, that carried the Allied expeditionary force to North Africa through thousands of miles of submarine infested waters arrived on time in spite of heavy U-boat and plane attacks, Allied headquarters announced tonight.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Corporations should be allowed to accumulate enough undistributed profits to enable them to resume peace-time production and employment after the war, Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said today in the bank's monthly bulletin.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The University of Detroit football team got a touchdown and a safety in the first twelve minutes today and then smothered Villanova's high-scoring attack to win, 9 to 0, before 11,755 spectators. The victory was Detroit's fifth of the season against one defeat.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Red Wings tightened their hold on the National Hockey League lead tonight by scoring two third-period goals to defeat the Canadiens, 3 to 1, before 12,491 spectators, largest crowd of the season here.

Squirrel and rabbit hunting have not proved exceptionally good in lower sections of the State during the past week. At the public hunting area at Carmel there has been a decided decrease in the number of hunters. The trees are still heavy with leaves shielding the grouse from the hunter and the result has been that only two or three birds are being taken each day from this sector.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Thirteen enemy submarines, drawn to the North African coast by the huge, concentration of United Nations naval and merchant shipping involved in the Allied offensive there, have been destroyed, it was announced tonight by Prime Minister Churchill's office at 10 Downing Street.
The Navy Department communique of Nov. 14 reads:
HUNTINGTON, Ind., Nov. 15 -- Modoc, the elephant which went on a rampage five days ago, was captured today, lured by ten loaves of bread.

Americans of German birth were asked last night to "devote all your wishing and working for the victory of America and the United Nations," by Thomas Mann, exiled German novelist, who now makes his home in California. His talk, delivered in German over station WHOM, was included in the program of the "German-American Loyalty Hour," a weekly feature under the title "We Fight Back," which is sponsored by the Office of War Information.

A new approach to the problem of war borrowing has been outlined by the Treasury. Instead of the frequent offerings of recent months, the Treasury plans much larger offerings at less frequent intervals, possibly two months apart. Instead of opening subscription books briefly and relying upon subscribers to come rushing in, the Treasury apparently plans to keep them open longer and to put on an intensive drive to sell subscribers other than commercial banks.

Captured enemy aircraft have yielded up whatever secrets of construction they may have to the careful probing of engineers in this country and in Great Britain. Bombers and fighters have been analyzed both as to power-plant and airframe. As regards the machines of the Luftwaffe, they have been found good, both as to construction and material.

The economic effects of a drastic curtailment or shut-down of the pulp and paper industry in the United States probably would be far-reaching, owing to the dependency of most communities where primary producers are located on these industrial operations, according to a report of a nation-wide survey made by the American Paper and Pulp Association.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Held even for three periods, Santa Clara's Broncos put together a slashing aerial game today to score two last-quarter touchdowns and a 20-7 victory over their keenest rivals, St. Mary's Gaels, before 36,000 fans.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Declaring his loyalty to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain but asserting that the aged Marshal was in the clutches of the Germans, Admiral Francois Darlan proclaimed himself protector of French interests in North Africa, and appointed General Henri Honore Giraud Commander in Chief of all French forces, land, sea and air, there, in a statement broadcast tonight by Radio Morocco, now under Allied control.

Victory-starved since opening day, the Philadelphia Eagles, following eight straight setbacks, suddenly found the range at the expense of the football Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field and handed Mike Getto's aggregation a 14 -- 7 defeat before 3,858 spectators.
The text of the new dimout regulations announced yesterday by Major Gen. T.A. Terry, Commanding General of the Second Service Command, superseding those announced last June 1, follows:

AT ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Algeria, Nov. 15 -- The eastward thrust of the British First Army toward Tunisia has "made a very good start," but "hard fighting" is expected in the final stages. Lieut. Gen. Kenneth Anderson, the army's commander, said tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Provision interests which expressed a great deal of confidence recently that production of lard would be so heavy as to force packers to hedge their excess product by sales of futures say that it is probable that the optimistic views will have to be modified.

A 12-year-old banker's son astride a coal-black charger and his 16-year-old pal riding a streamlined bicycle were being sought in deepest Jersey last night. They had vanished from their Staten Island homes after a hearty Saturday lunch.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 15 -- Further observation of Axis transport planes in the shuttle service between Sicily and Tunisia indicated that the enemy is almost certainly evacuating at least part of his troops from Tunisia.

Chairmen of five special Senate and House groups investigating the conduct of the war on the domestic front have joined in a drive for legislation to force a unified control of the non-military economy of the country. They want to put production, manpower and supply "under one civilian roof" and in command of a single director.

Former President Herbert Hoover opened a three-week United Church Canvass last night in a broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting Company's coast-to-coast network. The aim is to win greater financial support and greater personal participation in the work of churches and synagogues of sixteen creeds, Christian and Jewish.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The desolate bombed acres of the old City of London bore silent witness this afternoon to the savagery of the Luftwaffe when the men and women who fought the enemy's explosives and fire there during the Battle of Britain marched with their fellow civil defense workers from a score of the country's worst-blitzed towns in a review before the King and Queen.

She came up the river in the mist of the morning, in from the embattled seas, from "Somewhere in the Atlantic." For all her dull gray paint and her hidden name, she came proudly in, almost leisuring, no bone in her teeth, no wide-swirling wake. Tugs nuzzled her towering flanks and once or twice she huffed little signal grunts from her deep-throated whistle, but for the most part she came silently, as she goes.

Marjory Hess, a youthful soprano from Chicago, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall before a responsive audience of good size. With Stanford Schlussel at the piano, Miss Hess was heard in a program comprising groups of Lieder by Schubert and Strauss; lyrics by Berlioz, Faure and De Falla, and songs in English by Gibbs, Slonimsky and Erno Balogh.

Trailing by two goals when the first period ended, the Boston Bruins came back to fashion a 4-to-3 triumph over the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The visitors, undermanned because of injuries, waged a stirring, aggressive battle nevertheless, and their triumph was a deserved one.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Reports that American interests had purchased about 10,000,000 bushels of Canadian cash oats in the last ten days or so and that the grain was being offered in New England at prices that figured 1 to 2 cents a bushel less than grain of comparable quality could be offered from this point brought in scattered liquidation by holders of futures contracts last week on the Board of Trade.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Corn became last week the leader in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, prices moving up to a new high since early in October, and at the top showed around 5 cents a bushel above the inside figure of the preceding week.

In going "all out" for war, let us so live that we shall not be spiritually "all in" when the victory is won, warned the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman in his sermon yesterday in Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- Champion Nonquitt Nola's Candidate, a black dog owned by Mrs. R. Kenneth Cobb and Mrs. Florence L. Brister of New York, tonight was awarded the highest honors in the twenty-first annual specialty exhibition of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders' Club of New England at the Copley-Plaza.
CAIRO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Royal Air Force fighters shot down at least seven Axis ferry planes and damaged many more between Tunis and Sicily yesterday.

SOMEWHERE IN LIBYAN DESERT, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Lieutenant Lyman Middleditch of Union, N.J., who holds the American record for shooting down Messerschmitts to date, slowed down long enough today to have the Distinguished Service Cross pinned on his breast.
WITH A UNITED STATES TASK FORCE in French Morocco, Nov. 9 (Delayed) -- The French fight gamely in a battle already decided. They fight on a twenty-four-hour basis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Operations in soy beans on the Board of Trade here were at a minimum last week, with no business transacted in several days. What little business was done was largely in the way of liquidating old contracts, a practice which is expected to continue for the balance of the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Senator Byrd, in his statement today, charged that "the Federal Government is the chief offender in the waste and hoarding of manpower" and said that the open hearings by his committee would "tell the people the whole truth with respect to duplicated activities, the overmanning of practically every agency of government, and the useless employes that are carried on the payrolls of these agencies."

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 15 -- Under a heading "Has the Axis Lost the War?" Virginio Gayda in today's Voce d'Italia attempts to answer quite frankly a lot of questions that have been troubling the Italians for some time. The main news value of his discussion lies only in the fact he dared to print it under such a glaring headline.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Although the United States was then at the height of its preparations for the North African invasion, lend-lease goods and services furnished to our Allies in October topped the total for any previous month by more than a third and showed how wrong the Axis was in assuming that such aid would decline sharply once we had been brought into the war, President Roosevelt said today.

The city is faced with a shortage in the Police Department, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in appealing to more professional and business men to join the City Patrol Corps.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- A demonstration reaching riotous proportions resulted in the streets of Algiers today when ninety-six Italian officers, including two divisional generals, and 104 men of the Italian Armistice Commission were taken away as war prisoners.

Steve Owen apparently lost his rabbit's foot and four-leaf clover between halves of the Redskin-Giant game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Six times in those first two periods the capital Braves were inside the New York 20-yard line only to have misadventures of some sort or another balk them.

Last week's financial markets did not reflect the favorable war news from the British and American Armies in North Africa. The capture of Tobruk, the continued retreat of Rommel, the adherence of Giraud and, according to reports, of Darlan to the Allied side, appeared to evoke no response in the stock market, which merely drifted -- much as it did when Foch had begun his final counterstroke at Ludendorff in the middle of 1918.

In peacetime the college campus, and even the university, offers a quiet seclusion from the world. They are of the world, yet apart from it. They are a village within a village, or a city within a city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Official silence clothed the whereabouts tonight of Captain Edward V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, who was rescued by a naval flying boat after drifting for three weeks in the Pacific on a small rubber raft.

MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Fighting in a bitter cold wind that swept across the Volga, the Germans for the fourth successive day attacked a Stalingrad factory area yesterday and lost 400 men without the slightest gain, the Soviet midnight communique said today.

In these days when the Broadway stage is deservedly under attack for its vulgar and filthy plays, it is well that the death of George M. Cohan has reminded us that there have been producers and actors connected with the theatre whose ideals and principles were high, whose plays have been always above reproach and whose personal lives have compared favorably with the best in other walks.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 -- Increasing weight of hedging, particularly in the distant positions, was largely responsible last week for declines up to $1.50 a bale on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange in prices of cotton for future delivery.

New dimout regulations, intended to provide passive protection against hostile air attack, as well as to reduce the skyglow that has silhouetted ships along the coast for enemy submarines, were announced yesterday by Major Gen. T.A. Terry, commanding general of the Second Service Command, for the coastal dimout area of New York, New Jersey and Delaware.

Reports from England in recent months have indicated that war-working women there are learning to approach the matter of personal grooming with a more realistic attitude.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 15 -- According to reports received here through private channels, Reichsfuehrer Hitler has placed all his cast-off generals on something called the "Fuehrer reserve list," from which experts are called upon to do urgent or odd jobs whenever required.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 15 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Admiral Sir Andrew B. Cunningham made a hazardous landing in a Flying Fortress, and probably escaped with their lives only because of the skill of a pilot, it was disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co., mail-order and chain-store merchandisers, will report tomorrow for the third quarter of the year a net profit of $8,136,612, or $1.49 a share, compared with $8,613,885, or $1.58 a share, in the corresponding period last year.

The six-room dwelling at 16 De Kalb Avenue, White Plains, in Westchester County, has been purchased by Ralph Heinrich from the New York Life Insurance Com pany, which was represented by the Raymond R. Beatty Organization. Eisner-Moorehouse, Inc., was the broker.

The tragic plight of the people of Czechoslovakia, struggling for freedom and suffering bitterly from Nazi oppression, was described by speakers yesterday morning at a service in the Jan Hus Presbyterian Church, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street, commemorating the massacres of the students of Charles University, Prague, in November, 1939, after the German occupation.

Major F. Van Wyck Mason (the author uses the "F." when he signs the books published by Lippincott, drops it for his Reynal Hitchcock publications) has not only got the third volume of his Revolutionary novel series coming out soon ("Rivers of Glory," Lippincott, Nov. 25) but he is winding up the research into American historical fiction for a "war chest" of stories to be called "The Fighting American."

ORAN, Algeria, Nov. 15 -- French troops cooperating with the Americans raided a village near Oran today to take arms from the Arabs, who have been picking them up in the confusion around the recent battlefields. The Arabs have been extremely friendly to the Americans, but they are unable

Holders of bonds of the city of Philadelphia which are callable between 1944 and 1953 will have an opportunity beginning today to exchange them for new refunding bonds maturing between 1958 and 1975. All the new bonds will bear the same rates of interest as the old bonds to the original callable dates, and after that their interest rate will be 3 1/4 per cent.

Constant vigilance, exercised by individuals and groups, is necessary in this country to curb a growing tendency toward the centralization of economic and political authority, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Wyoming Democrat, declared last night in a speech before 400 members of the Alumni Association of Catholic University in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- A statement issued tonight at Prime Minister Winston Churchill's residence, 10 Downing Street, put Axis losses at 75,000 killed, wounded or captured in the three weeks of fighting in the Battle of Egypt and Libya.

Friends of Governor-Elect Thomas E. Dewey have expressed the opinion that he will move slowly in replacing Democratic office-holders in Albany with Republicans of his own choice. While they expect an eventual clean sweep, a number of Democrats now in office may hold over after Jan. 1, they say, because of the time element as well as other reasons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Lieut. Col. Roger Derby Black, 34, formerly an instructor at West Point, was killed last night when he was struck by an automobile in Arlington, Va., where he made his home. He was on the General Staff of the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York officiated today at a commemorative diplomatic mass at St. Aloysius Church in honor of the seventh anniversary of the Philippine Commonwealth.

The city faces a serious snow removal problem this Winter because of an almost total lack of trucks for hire, emergency laborers and drivers needed to clear the streets, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People."

ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- Governor Lehman today announced the appointment of Paul M. Herzog of New York City to succeed the Rev. John P. Boland, pastor of St. Thomas Aquinas Church, Buffalo, as chairman of the State Labor Relations Board.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that its safety-at-sea exhibit at the union headquarters at 346 West Seventeenth Street would be placed on display at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia after closing here. The exhibit has been extended in New York until the last of this month to afford the public an opportunity to inspect the various items of apparatus carried on ships to minimize losses among seamen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- United States railroads were called upon today to tackle their rapidly growing labor shortages through an increased use of women employes, centralization of personnel activities and modernization of training programs.

WITH BRIG. GEN. DOOLITTLE in North Africa, Nov. 14 (Delayed) -- With Brig. Gen. James H. (Jimmy) Doolittle and Brig. Gen. A.M. Gruenther of Omaha, brilliant Chief of Staff to Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commander of the Allied forces in North Africa, I flew today, at General Doolittle's request, in a Flying Fortress from Allied Headquarters over the greater part of West North Africa.

Defeating Samuel Reshevsky after 45 moves at the Marshall Chess Club last night, Isaac I. Kashdan of Brooklyn evened the score at 2 -- 2 in their match to break the tie reached in the last tournament for the United States championship.

Rayon production in the United States, including both continuous filament yarn and staple fiber, will probably approximate 625,000,000 pounds in 1942, setting a new production record, William C. Appleton, president, American Viscose Corporation, declared yesterday. This volume would compare with an output of 573,000,000 pounds in 1941, and 471,000,000 pounds in 1940.

Culminating six years of work and the expenditure of 50,000,000 yen (about $24,000,000 at pre-war exchange), the first railway passenger train ran through the new Kwas-Mon tunnel connecting Japan's main island, Honshu, with the adjacent island of Kyushu, yesterday, according to a Tokyo broadcast recorded by The United Press.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- To insure the safety of post-war Europe the United Nations must make sure that it will be impossible for any future Hitler to use the great industrial resources of Central Europe as a means of plunging the world into another holocaust of slaughter and brutality, Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, declared today.

The recital given by Cleora Wood, soprano, last night in Town Hall was the performance of a gifted and communicative singer, with a wide range of repertory, a voice of fine qualities under imperfect control, and diction prevailingly amateurish, so that she did not fully realize her own interpretive designs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The military, naval and air attaches of the French Embassy, facing internment with other members of Ambassador Gaston Henry-Haye's staff, sought the intercession today of their Commander in Chief, Admiral Francois Darlan, who is with the American forces in Africa.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Parker Hall pitched three touchdown passes and Gaylon Smith broke loose for a 50-yard scoring dash today as the Cleveland Rams virtually clinched third place in the National Football League's West- ern division with a 27-to-7 triumph over the hapless Detroit Lions, who have lost all nine of their starts this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Japanese precipitated the sea, land and air battles now being fought in the Solomon Islands region by a determined attempt to recapture from the Americans the positions in the Guadalcanal-Tulagi area and drive us from the Solomons, the Navy said today.

Linking anti-Semitic violence with propaganda directed against air raid wardens and other civilian defense workers, Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands said last night that he was investigating twenty-two specific cases of terrorism and vandalism committed in public buildings, including schools, synagogues and defense offices.

For a long time women have been stepping down from their "place of dignity and esteem in their own sphere to the level of industrial and commercial man," Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre declared yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Ladies of Charity of the Catholic Charities of New York at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

RESTRAINED and conservative New Englanders, calm and judicial as usual, agree that the Boston College football team is terrific. Nobody expected Fordham to win from the Eagles, to be sure, but the way the B.C. squad romped over the visitors from the Bronx was dazzling or dreadful, depending upon which team you were rooting for.

New advertising approaches in which newspapers are by far the dominant factor are called for by changes in the normal habits of homeseekers brought about by wartime restrictions tending to curtail automobile travel, according to Fred C. Simons, sales, manager of Gibson Corporation, builders of Nantucket Homes in Gibson at Valley Stream, Long Island.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15 -- Exploits of Lieut. Gen. Mark Clark and his aides during their pre-invasion mission to French Africa will be the subject of two films, according to announcements by Paramount and Twentieth Century-Fox.

The chamber music concert presented yesterday at Town Hall by the New Friends of Music was the one hundredth in the annals of the organization now in its seventh season. For this anniversary a program has been prepared containing the Schumann quartet in A minor, Op. 41, No. 1; Haydn's quartet, Op. 33, No. 2, and four little-known songs for four voices and piano by the latter composer.
FEDHALA, French Morocco, Nov. 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- America's first war dead in the Northwest African campaign were buried today after a simple military service.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced today the deaths of Brigadier Frank Vogel, a British army officer, and Captain F.T. Peters, a British naval officer, who were killed in a plane crash.

All economists and other public-spirited citizens must rejoice at your pointed and persistent editorials on harmful tendencies in our public affairs: your early warnings as to inflation; your complete, if so far vain, exposure of the silver folly, and your courageous opposition to all forms of sectional and group selfishness.

NORFOLK, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- A small American merchant vessel, which had been leaking since she left an East Coast port Wednesday, foundered and sank Friday off the Virginia coast, the Navy announced tonight. A naval craft rescued the entire crew of eight.

Rabbis throughout the United States joined yesterday in a declaration rebuking Jewish opponents of Zionism for dealing a "cruel blow" to the Jews of Palestine and unwittingly strengthening enemies of a Jewish homeland.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The stock markets here made a distinctly disappointing display last week. Had the exhilarating news of the American occupation of North Africa come a month ago it is certain there would have been no holding the markets and prices would have gone through the roof.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The battle for Bizerte has begun near the vital Tunisia naval base, London learned tonight. A spearhead of the Allied army that has been racing through the mountain passes from Algeria to Bizerte and Tunis has clashed with the Axis troops that Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini have been pouring into the base.

An experiment that should be of interest and value to every American community is being made this week in Nyack and Rockland County. Civic organizations, city officials, industrial plants and schools will all cooperate in an intensive safety drive. Each day of the week will be devoted to a specific phase of the campaign against accidental injury and death.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers whipped the Fort Knox soldier eleven, 28 -- 0, today in a USO benefit game before 23,491 fans at the Stadium.

There has been an overproduction of depression and gloom in the world, and one of the most helpful ministries that any man or woman can perform today is to disseminate cheerfulness, declared the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell in his sermon yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

I am connected with the management of a building in East Forty-ninth Street, and it is my duty to see that the A.R.P. organization for the building is functioning. Yesterday I received a letter from the liaison warden in our building in which was the following paragraph:

There was a time, perhaps about a year and a half ago, when people were a little dubious about dehydrated food. It was whispered, for example, that a whole shipment went to waste because the British found it utterly unpalatable. And on more than one occasion this column heard the buyer in a local department store emphatically expressing his doubt that the stuff "would ever be fit to eat."
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

Born at Oakland, e., l{ay 6, I 1874, a son of Hiram and EllenI :Frissell Vryman, Mr. Wyman received his early education at the l Coburn Classical InStitute in Waterville, Me., and then spent threei years, 1893-96, at Tufts College.

CAMP McCOY, Wis., Nov. 15 -- The Army has found a place for the halt and partly blind -- and discovered many of them can be built up to an active-duty fitness comparable to that of their more fortunate brothers.
Three current developments designed to aid small business are pointed out in the November business review of the National Association of Credit Men by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- Five firemen were killed and nearly two score were injured early today when a forty-foot granite and brick wall suddenly buckled and toppled into a burning four-story building in East Boston.

George W. Blossom Jr. has been nominated for a second term as president of the United States Golf Association and most of the officers who served with him during the past year have been slated for re-election. Announcement of the nominations was made yesterday by A.M. Reid, chairman of the nominating committee, who said they would be acted upon at the association's annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 9.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The furniture which the Federal Public Housing Authority is placing in the homes of war workers is a public education in interior design which should be reflected in functional, sturdy, attractive post-war homes, Miss Blanche L. Halbert, senior home economist in the home economics section and interior design consultant in the technical section of the FPHA, predicts.

Leopold Stokowski made his first appearance of the season as the conductor of the NBC Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Studio 8-H, Radio City. Because of the 5 o'clock broadcast celebrating the seventh anniversary of the winning of independence by the Philippines, the program was reduced to half an hour in length.
MOSCOW, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Speaking in support of the proposal for the setting up of a Jewish army to be composed of Palestinian and stateless Jews, under British command, Representative George Grant of Alabama, a member of the National Committee for a Jewish Army, declared in a radio address here tonight that the "right" of the Jews to form such an army was part of the four freedoms guaranteed by the Atlantic Charter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Formation of a staff of financial experts to help Congress in its hunt for economies was urged today by Representative Cochran, chairman of the Committee on Accounts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Formation of a staff of financial experts to help Congress in its hunt for economies was urged today by Representative Cochran, chairman of the Committee on Accounts.

ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Oct. 23 -- Japanese planes repeatedly machine-gunned survivors of the United States destroyer Meredith in the sea after sinking the ship with aerial torpedoes, according to members of the crew who arrived here yesterday after a three-day voyage from the scene of the sinking in a small motor boat.
A report on Axis oppression of education in occupied territories was issued yesterday in the United States and Great Britain by the Inter-Allied Information Committee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Establishment of what in effect amounts to a price ceiling on cash wheat by permitting farmers to redeem grain from the government loan and sell it in the open market at a price to be fixed by the Commodity Credit Corporation has brought trading in wheat futures to a virtual standstill.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Nov. 15 -- "Commandos" establishing a bridgehead at Timber Point early today were still in the field when manoeuvres of the Thirteenth Regiment, New York Guard, were ended shortly before dark. Although a third of their number were captured by the Blue forces, the defense of the immediate objective, a "power station," remained in doubt, since a major part of the Commando strength had not been incapacitated.

Calling on the American people to spread faith to strengthen themselves for the trying days ahead, the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, declared that "we should be a lamp to light the path for those who stumble, and we should be an anchor for souls tossed in the sea of unrest."

Mayor La Guardia's assertion in his broadcast on Sunday that the personnel of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department had been increased in the last year rather than cut was refuted yesterday by figures released without comment by Police Commissioner Valentine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Although some government agencies are guilty of hoarding and pirating labor, efforts to correct these abuses are meeting with success, according to Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

Wendell L. Willkie in a plea for early agreement between ourselves and all our Allies on the aims of this war, declared last night in a speech at The New York Herald Tribune's eleventh Forum on Current Problems at the Waldorf-Astoria that the need for basic agreement "among the Allied peoples themselves" obligated "every one of us" to speak out, to exchange ideas "freely and frankly" at home and across the oceans.

Mrs. William L. Bradley and Mrs. John T. Snyder gave a luncheon yesterday at La Salle du Bois for Miss Nancy Holton of Pelham, whose marriage to Ensign Gordon B. Moore Walker, U.S.N.R., will take place early next month. Others in the party were Mrs. Robert Knott, Mrs. Malcolm Gilchrist, Mrs. George Pickett, Mrs. Winfred B. Holton, Mrs. Lathrop Bishop, Mrs. Grant Simmons, Mrs. Edmund Nash, Miss Molly Gillett and Miss Janet Elliott.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army closed in swiftly on Bengazi tonight as the disordered remnants of beaten Axis forces raced toward El Agheila, where virtually impassable salt marshes to the south narrow to about thirty miles the passageway that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel in the past has studded liberally with mine fields.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Representatives of three European nations now under the control of the Axis pleaded for international solidarity in the post-war world before the American Academy of Political and Social Science here tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 -The authority of Gen. John L. De-Witt, Western defense commander, in the absence of a declaration of martial law to issue regulations affecting the daily lives of citizens was challenged today in an opinion by Federal Judge James A. Fee at Portland, Ore.

Active for thirteen years as director of the department of studio and public service of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Mrs. Alice Ames Winter announced yesterday her retirement. She will be succeeded by Mrs. Alice Evans Field, who has worked with her since 1930 and who has, for the last year, been associate director of the department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- It was revealed today that the United States fighting forces in North Africa are using a special United States currency so distinguished from ordinary notes that, like that now issued in Hawaii, it can be de tected by any experienced person handling it.

Even while he was approaching he homestretch at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday a certain and easy winner of the thirty-fourth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. varsity championship cross-country race. Frank Dixon, N.Y.U. freshman, was being compared with the great Leslie MacMitchell, his predecessor, who is now an ensign in the Navy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 -- A walkout of A.F.L. butchers in ten packing plants and slaughter houses left the San Francisco Bay area with a sharply curtailed meat supply today, but union leaders agreed tonight to a peace formula which, if acceptable to the membership, will send the butchers back to work tomorrow afternoon and continue their wage demands in arbitration.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -William Fox, bankrupt former motion picture producer, entered Moyamensing Prison today to begin serving a term of a year and a day soon after Judge Guy K. Bard in Federal District Court denied a plea that the commitment be extended because Fox was essential to the war effort.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A denial of United States permits to foreign airlines to operate as common carriers between Miami and points in the Caribbean would be inconsistent with the good neighbor policy and the principles of the Atlantic Charter, counsel for the British West Indies Airlines, its affiliate concern, Taca, and the Royal Dutch Airlines argued today before the Civil Aeronautics Board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Fresh from a six-week trip to England, during which he studied the operations of that country's wartime price and rationing procedure, Dr. Dexter M. Keezer, deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration and acting director of that agency's standards division, expressed high praise for the manner in which the English have handled their problem.

Nearly a quarter of a century and the length of a continent separate the battle of Tunis from the battle of the Argonne, but the first clash of American and German ground forces on the way to the great naval base at Bizerte will be only a continuation of the unfinished struggle of 1914-18.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The European news services of the British Broadcasting Corporation are telling the enslaved peoples the news of the Allied successes in North Africa in a series of broadcasts totaling eighty-seven daily, each lasting from ten to fifteen minutes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -President Roosevelt nominated Clyde B. Aitchinson and Claude R. Porter for reappointment to the I.C.C.; his visitors included Budget Director Harold Smith and Assistant Director Wayne Coy, Elmer Davis and Secretary Knox.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that employment on farms totaled 10,879,000 on Nov. 1, representing a seasonal decline in October, but practically unchanged from the same figure of November last year.

Mayor La Guardia gave the city's welcome at City Hall yesterday to Sub-Lieutenant Harold Lawrence and Stoker Petty Officer Arthur Powell, Canadian naval men who jumped from the deck of their vessel to that of a Nazi submarine, shot and killed two Germans, knocked two more overboard and captured the remainder of the crew.

Japanese Imperial Headquarters, in a communique summarized in a broadcast yesterday from Tokyo, claimed "more than half the enemy fleet was destroyed or crippled" in a naval battle in the Solomons that started on Nov. 12, according to a recording of the broadcast by The United Press at San Francisco.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 17 -- General Douglas MacArthur and his air and ground force commanders have gone into the New Guinea jungles to lead American and Australian troops who are pressing fast from two directions on the Japanese coastal base of Buna and driving the enemy into a narrowing trap, it was announced here today.
Eddie McGovern of Rose Poly apparently has clinched the individual football scoring championship for 1942, plowing through six opposing teams for 165 points before calling it quits for the season.

Apparently satisfied by the way his running game functioned in Saturday's game with Navy, Columbia's coach, Lou Little, turned his attention back to passing as his squad started its last week of practice at Baker Field yesterday. The Lions close their season Saturday against Dartmouth on the home field.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Dr. A. Sprague Coolidge, president of the Harvard Teachers Union (A.F.L.), today defended against criticism by Roane Waring, national American Legion commander, the appearance of Harry Bridges as an Armistice Day speaker here.

Lieutenant Willard D. Litt, Naval Reserve, of Locust Valley, L.I., a partner in W.R.K. Taylor Co., stock brokers, has been reported "killed in action in the service of his country," according to the firm. He was 42 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A comprehensive report on the manner in which some $50,000,000 worth of scarce chemicals have been allocated to industry by the WPB's chemicals division was issued today by the WPB division. The allocations reported do not include direct military needs.

Because the health of young Americans "is one of the front lines of our national defense," President Roosevelt has authorized the observance of his sixty-first birthday, Jan. 30, 1943, for the tenth annual fund-raising drive in the fight against infantile paralysis.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- British and American troops in Tunisia, under British Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson, were reported today to be fighting fiercely against an enemy screening force that stood between them and the battle line where French garrisons are carrying on delaying actions against Italian and German forces arriving by air and sea in the French protectorate.

Clarity and intelligence are the hallmarks of the piano playing of Arthur Dann, who gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night. These qualities were manifest from the outset -- even in "The Star-Spangled Banner," which prefaced the program.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 17 -- The defenders of Stalingrad have smashed German wedges and resealed their lines after a two-day battle in which more than 1,500 enemy troops were killed or wounded, the Soviet High Command announced today.
CAIRO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A joint communique by the Royal Air Force and British Middle East Command:

Announcing that he would confer in Washington today with Donald Nelson, head of the War Production Board, in an effort to straighten out the tangled scrap metal situation, Mayor La Guardia renewed his criticism yesterday of the WPB salvage division.

Reports are beginning to trickle through Rumanian and Hungarian censorships of an obscure frontier incident some two weeks ago between Rumanian and Hungarian troops at Banffyhunyad, on the "new" Transylvanian frontier, according to advices reaching here last night.

Every day is a day of mourning for the people of Czechoslovakia. Today is the anniversary of a famous Nazi exercise in murder. On Oct. 28, 1939, the national holiday, quietly observed by the Czechs, obedient to the requests of their Government, the Nazis provoked a disturbance, killed and wounded freely and herded thousands of Czechs to prison.

As the date set for the third Eastern gasoline rationing quota draws nearer one is faced repeatedly with the vexing attitude which can be summed up: "I might as well use the coupons I have left and get something out of my car. Those coupons will soon become worthless to me anyhow."

LONDON, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- The German-controlled Paris radio said today that a big naval battle was raging off the North African coast between an Allied squadron and a joint Italo-German squadron. Naval quarters here, however, believed that it was highly doubtful whether any German warships besides submarines were in the Mediterranean, which is sealed at Gibraltar and Suez by the British and at Gallipoli by the neutral Turks.

Matthew C. Brush, industrialist and former head of the American International Corporation, left an estate of $3,646,456 gross and $1,973,770 net when he died on Oct. 15, 1940, it was shown in the estate tax appraisal field here yesterday. Mr. Brush was a resident of Norwalk, Conn., and at his death was a Republican candidate for Presidential elector from Connecticut.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Motorized United States troops were disclosed officially tonight to have reinforced the British First Army in Tunisia. An Allied Headquarters communique disclosed the reinforcement, perhaps involving American armored troops.

ALBANY,, Nov. 16 -- Governor Lehman today proclaimed the week of Nov. 22 to 28 as "Women at War Week" in cooperation with the war savings drive of the Federal Treasury and asked the people of the State to join in this observance, with "each man, woman and child" supporting the savings program.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation is checking into the source of rumors current in Cleveland, Detroit, Chicago and other Midwestern cities that gasoline rationing would be postponed a second time, perhaps indefinitely, the Cleveland regional Office of War Information announced tonight.

Jacob A. Livingston, who is 72 years old and has been in public service for forty-five years, announced yesterday that he would retire as a Brooklyn member of the Board of Elections on Dec. 31. He gave poor health as the reason. He has held the post since 1911.

BELLPORT, L.I., Nov. 16 -- A duck-hunting trip today by two young Long Island Railroad firemen of Richmond Hill brought death from exposure to one and a narrow escape to the other, despite a three-mile row through the choppy waters of Bellport Bay by two middle-aged Bellport brothers who went to their rescue.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16 -Smarting from their third straight loss, the 13-6 defeat at the hands of Yale, the Princeton varsity players had a light workout on University Field today for the season's finale with Army at the Yankee Stadium Saturday.

The Provincetown Playhouse, where O'Neill hasn't been in years, lighted the torch again last evening, held it aloft for a brief period and then plunged it into the flood. The event was "Homecoming," a play by Edward Peyton Harris which managed somehow to combine various features of the allegorical and what used to be called the slaphappy-gran'pappy schools of the drama.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Office of Price Administration said today that automobile distributors, dealers and manufacturers could not pass on to buyers the monthly increment in price permitted for storage and maintenance before sale unless they maintained the vehicles in accordance with requirements specified by the OPA.

The American Gas Association, 420 Lexington Avenue, announced yesterday that a program had been prepared by which it would support the War Production Board's campaign to save critical fuels and transportation and help avert a possible gas shortage.

MELBOURNE, Fla., Nov. 16 (AP) -- A Navy patrol bomber, attached to the Atlantic Fleet squadron at the Banana River air station, fell into the ocean in heavy weather Wednesday with a loss of nine lives, the Navy revealed today.
Armchair naval strategists began a debate last night over whether the rout of the Japanese fleet in the Solomons surpassed the Battle of Jutland in 1916 as a major naval engagement.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer reserved decision yesterday on a motion by the producers of the show "Wine, Women and Song" to transfer to General Sessions, before a jury, their trial on charges of putting on an indecent performance.
An active real estate market in Great Neck, L. I., during the third quarter period is reported by Edgar Storms Jr., president of Edgar Storms Jr., broker.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Traders in wheat are marking time pending announcement regarding the release of loan wheat through government subsidy to producers, and pending an official statement as to the price at which the grain will be made available to mills in order to permit them to sell flour at the ceiling level.
A net profit of $1,621,126 was reported yesterday by the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation and its subsidiary for the first nine months of this year.

William F. Bleakley, former Supreme Court justice, who has been appointed Moreland Act commissioner by Governor Lehman to investigate alleged irregularities in the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Act, took the oath of office yesterday at White Plains, where he was sworn in by Justice Frederick P. Close of the Appellate Division.

Christmas seemed near yesterday afternoon. The word "gift" was repeated with the insistent patter of Winter hail on a roof. A large Christmas tree spread its gracious boughs. Packages nestled at its base. Children, dressed in sleepers of palest blue and wearing flannel coats of pink cross-barred with white, clutched toys in their arms and kept close to their fashion-show mother all done up in a snuggly bunny coat of pearly pink.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Nov. 16 -- Rear Admiral Daniel J. Callaghan, whose death in the Solomon Islands naval engagement was announced by the Navy Department today, died in the midst of battle -- victorious battle, in which Admiral Callaghan's cruiser sank an enemy cruiser and a destroyer in lightning salvos, then courageously engaged a Japanese battleship.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -While declining to make a long-range commitment, the Office of Price Administration said today that it did not intend to ration used automobiles at present.

Mrs. Wales Latham, founder of Bundles for Britain and of Bundles for America, has announced her resignation as president of Bundles for America, Inc., and its naval division, Bundles for Bluejackets. The directors of these organizations elected Mrs. Latham honorary president.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -Prices of hogs closed steady today after showing some easiness early. Arrivals here were only slightly above last week, and the total at twelve leading markets was nearly 6,000 under last Monday.

The new dimout regulations are a distinct advance over those that have been in force. With all the coastal cities of New York, New Jersey and Delaware now included in the Second Defense Area, the visibility of ships at night along the Atlantic seaboard should be perceptibly lowered.

DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP) -- George Romney, managing director of the Automotive Council for War Production, said today that, because of a realignment of war production schedules by the government and material shortages, demand for labor in the industry will be less than anticipated.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

A proclamation was published here yesterday over the signatures of 1,521 outstanding Americans, declaring the moral right of the stateless Jews of Europe and of the Jews of Palestine "to fight -- as they ask to fight -- under the ancient banner of David the King, as the Jewish Army."
HAVANA, Nov. 16 -- Some 1,500 persons crowded the Ministry of National Defense this morning as voluntary registration for foreign military service against the Axis opened.
When Anthony Cramer saw his old friend, Werner Thiel, emerge from the crowd about the information booth in Grand Central Terminal on that June evening, he felt he could scarcely trust his eyes.

Another voice was raised yesterday in praise of the Boston College powerhouse eleven. The voice was that of its coach, Denny Myers, who frankly told the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's restaurant that "this is a team coaches pray to get."

Though we do not know, and for reasons of safety cannot be told at this time, how many American ships were damaged in the Solomon Islands battle, in addition to those which were sunk, there can be no doubt that we have won a naval victory which will have far-reaching consequences on the course of the war in the Pacific.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Supervisor Ralph A. McClelland recommended to the Westchester Board of Supervisors today that part of the county's $87,000,000 bonded debt be refinanced and payments "leveled off" to offset expected wartime loss of county revenues during the next six years.

Today is General Montgomery's fifty-fifth birthday, as we learn from a number of sources, including James MacDonald's fine piece in last Sunday's Magazine. What will Rommel's conqueror treat himself to in the way of a birthday gift?

LONDON, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson reported to London today that his men were continuing their advance eastward "as rapidly as possible and said the initial objectives were airdromes now in enemy hands.

Emanuel Vardi, wearing his Navy uniform as Musician First Class, gave a program for the viola at the New York Times Hall last night. Mr. Vardi, who was a member of the NBC Sym phony Orchestra as well as a solo recitalist before enlisting, is now first viola of the Navy Symphony Orchestra in Washington, and he had to receive special permission to fill this date, which had been arranged months ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Army Nurse Corps revealed today that married women are eligible for enlistment and on acceptance will have the same status as single nurses, subject to assignments here or overseas, to residence in military quarters if they are available where stationed.

Under the wartime passenger train schedules of the New York Central System, effective on Dec. 6, the 20th Century Limited will take seventeen hours instead of sixteen ton its run, leaving Grand Central Terminal at 5:30 P.M., instead of 6 P.M., and arriving in Chicago at 9:30 A.M., instead of 9 A.M.

Wall Street is looking forward with considerable interest to the dividend meeting of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company scheduled for noon tomorrow. In each of the meetings this year speculation has run high as to whether the A.T. T.'s $9 annual rate would be reduced in view of the Bell System's steadily mounting tax problem.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- American casualties reported in the war to date, including those killed, wounded and missing in action, have reached a total of 48,956 officers and men, the Office of War Information said today. The figure does not include any losses in the African campaign or recent naval operations in the Solomons.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that the Board of Transportation would probably announce a million-dollar wage increase for the 32,000 employes of the unified city transit system within ten days, but denied that the transit fare would go up as a result.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- News received here today of special Fascist measures against defeatism and "alarming rumors," together with Italian press comments acknowledging that the Allied landings in Africa had added to Italy's already great difficulties, was taken as justifying the political or propaganda offensive that had followed the military offensive -- a propaganda offensive in which the State Department has now taken the lead.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 16 -- Forces of the British Eighth Army, advancing westward rapidly along the Cyrenaican coast, yesterday reached and occupied the Martuba landing ground, fifteen miles southeast of Derna, but the bulk of the fleeing German Africa Corps was already far beyond that point.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES IN NEW GUINEA, Nov. 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- An American ground task force advanced through the rain-soaked jungles of Northeastern New Guinea today to a point where bombs dropped by American airmen on the Japanese base at Buna could be heard exploding.

Edward L. Shea, president of the North American Company, announced yesterday that its directors had voted to redeem $3,000,000 more of the company's outstanding debentures and also had declared a common stock dividend in the form of capital stock of the Detroit Edison Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A diligent attempt has been made by this correspondent for the past few days to obtain a clear statement of the current and future policy of the United States in dealing with the various and rival French leaders -- a question made more acute by the escape to North Africa of former Premier Flandin and the verbal attack of General de Gaulle on our present French collaborationists in North Africa.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 16 -More than 8,000 shipyard workers knocked off work for a few minutes this afternoon to attend the launching of two cargo vessels at the Irish Bend yard of the Houston Shipbuilding Company, and incidentally to receive a merit award for themselves.
The text of the address delivered by Wendell L. Willkie at The New York Herald Tribune Forum on Current Problems as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES follows:

Walter Kollmar, 12 years old, and Allen Stockdale, 16, are back home in Staten Island none the worse for their two-day adventure that took them sixteen miles along the road to a ranch in the West before the police stepped in yesterday at Highland Park, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A "retailers economy for victory plan," under which frills and special customer services will be curtailed or eliminated to conserve manpower, transportation, gasoline, rubber, electricity and other war necessities, was announced jointly today by the Office of Price Administration and the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A Fighting French spokesman here evidenced considerable dissatisfaction today concerning the American cooperation with Admiral Francois Darlan and other former Vichy adherents in French North Africa, and asserted that such activities might weaken the cause of the United Nations when the time came for the invasion of continental France.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) -The War Department announced today that Lieut. Col. George F. Marshall of Jacksonville, Fla., and Second Lieutenant Paul Bateman were the first two Army commissioned officers reported killed in the French North African campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -Rear Admiral Daniel J. Callaghan who was killed in action when he led a cruiser force into a night battle for possession of the Solomon islands, was known to scores of Navy men as "Uncle Dan."

The appointment of Howard P. Ingels, who served in the last war as secretary of the War Industries Board under Bernard M. Baruch, as regional deputy director in charge of the smaller war plants division of the War Production Board was announced yesterday by John P. Maguire, regional director.

With the trade furnishing most of the activity on both sides of a rather dull market, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange experienced yesterday only minor prior fluctuations and closed 3 to 6 points higher than on Saturday.

The first of a new series of full-page ads in which leading industrial corporations will press the sale of war bonds from now until the end of the year will appear in newspapers today, with General Electric Company the first sponsor. A slogan devised by the Treasury Department, "Everybody Top That 10 Per Cent by New Year's," will be headlined together with "Only Forty-four More Days to Make Your Victory Quota for 1942."

Dressed in conservative clothing in place of the "zoot suits" they wore when arrested Joseph Annunziata, 19 years old, of 285 Manhattan Avenue, and Neil Simonelli, 16 years old, of 651 Metropolitan Avenue, both Brooklyn, went on trial yesterday for the first-degree murder of Erwin Goodman, 36-year-old mathematics teacher, at the William J. Gaynor Junior High School in Brooklyn.

EVEN among people who specialize in the history of the press the name of James Gordon Bennett of The New York Herald is associated with the facile reporting of frivolous things. Horace Greeley of the old New York Tribune is remembered as a cranky optimist who dabbled in politics; Henry J. Raymond of THE NEW YORK TIMES is recalled as a responsible believer in the sober truth.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 16 -- As a result of the recent election, the Republican party has become a "partnership party in the government of this nation rather than a minority party," Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota declared here tonight at a meeting of the Town Hall of Essex County at the Mosque Theatre.

THE football games will be fewer from now on, but the flow of gridiron gossip seems to be getting louder and swifter all the time. The following passes were caught around the fringe of the huddle yesterday:
Frank Rehn opened in his Fifth Avenue gallery yesterday the first one-man show that Henry Varnum Poor has held in nearly three years (his last previous appearance there was in February, 1940).
As the spotlight of European strategy focused on the Mediterranean last week, the Italian Fleet again became an important pawn on the chessboard of war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -Legislation to shift the administration of the Bituminous Coal Act from Secretary Ickes to a new three-man commission was introduced in both House and Senate today for the United Mine Workers of America.

Complaints in which the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System had sought the nullification of certain orders of the Federal Communications Commission were dismissed yesterday by a special Statutory Federal Court.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Warren Millais, research engineer from Hollywood, who leased a six-room penthouse at 400 East Fifty-ninth Street through Airs. Ida Catlin and Webb Knapp, Inc.
One by one they fell into receptacles in department stores yesterday. They made no noise as they dropped. The explosion is to come with their conversion -stockings into gunpowder bags.

I have no desire to engage in a debate with Dr. Gallup about the interpretation he places on his election polls. But when he says that such polls conducted and published during a campaign have no influence on the campaign, and that the existence of a bandwagon vote is a "delusion," I believe he is asserting something which those who have had practical experience in politics would be quick to deny.

OTTAWA, Nov. 16 -- Former Deputy Andre Philip, Commissioner for the Interior representing the Resistance Committee in France in the Fighting French organization, stated here this afternoon that under no circumstances would the French people, either inside or outside France, accept Admiral Francois Darlan or any other excollaborationist of the Vichy Government at the head or as part of the administration of French Africa.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week held even with those of the comparative week last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the pre-ceding week the bank had reported a rise of 9 per cent over the 1941 figures.

The report of the trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, filed in Federal Court yesterday, shows a consolidated net profit of $8,805,103, compared with $11,444,948 in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1941.

The large apartment house containing ninety-nine suites at 751 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, occupying the blockfront on the south side of East 157th Street from Walton to Gerard Avenue, has been sold by the Park Royal Holding Corporation to an investing client of Aekman Brothers, brokers.

The Association of Stock Exchange Firms yesterday elected fifteen governors and a new nominating committee, at its annual election, and the governors met thereafter to re-elect John L. Clark of Abbott, Proctor Paine, as president of the association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Selective Service headquarters revealed today that production of transportation equipment and production of textiles had been added to the list of activities classed as essential to the support of the war effort.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, one of five co-defendants charged with conspiring to extort $120 weekly from a teamsters' union local for the four years up to 1940, will come up for trial in General Sessions next Jan. 4 on that charge even if he has to get a new lawyer, Judge James Garrett Wallace announced yesterday after Lanza had requested a postponement on the ground that his attorney was ill in a hospital.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Two days of operations were covered in the Russian report today that about 2,000 Germans had been killed in the Red Army's capture and continued control of a village "of great tactical importance" in the Leningrad siege area.
