LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Genoa got it again last night. The attack was over within twenty-five minutes, but in that short time hundreds of bombs, weighing 1,000 pounds or more apiece, fell on the port that is so valuable to the Axis for supplying its forces in North Africa.

Sir Gerald Campbell, special assistant to Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador, pictured yesterday a "desperate situation" in Italy and a hard Winter ahead in Germany as a result of the campaign in North Africa. He spoke in Town Hall.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 16 -- Gradually preparing their public for the worst, Italian military commentators today continued their declarations that the presence in Tunisia of Italian-German troops should by no means be interpreted as an attempt by the Axis to hold positions there in the face of Anglo-American "aggression."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Navy Communique 194:

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- After he had issued today a communique in which he had said that by far the strongest Japanese attempt to recapture Guadalcanal had been "completely frustrated by the aggressive action of Admiral W.F. Halsey and his forces," Admiral Nimitz summoned newspaper men to his cabin to give them details of the smashing victory.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 16 -The closing of the French-Swiss frontier delays news of the American diplomatic and newspaper party transferred to Lourdes from Vichy when the French Government, before the total German occupation, "registered the rupture of diplomatic relations."

A system whereby storekeepers may have their display windows tested by light meters to make sure they comply with the new dimout regulations has been instituted jointly by the Police Department and various public utility corporations, it was revealed yesterday at a press conference at the Regional Civilian Defense Office, 122 East Forty-second Street.

"Street of Chance," the Paramount melodrama starring Burgess Meredith and Claire Trevor, which was scheduled to open at the Rialto on Saturday, instead will have its local premiere there tomorrow. . . . "Prisoner of Japan" and "Outlaws of Pine Ridge" compose the week's new double-feature program, beginning today, at the New York Theatre.
SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 16 (AP) -- America needs more metals now, speakers emphasized today at a metal mine conference sponsored by the Western division, American Mining Congress.

Intercollegiate football draws near the close of the season in the East and the Western Conference this week, but most of the sectional championships may not be decided until Nov. 28 and in some instances even later.
Westchester residents have been doing some speculating in the last two days on when, where and how the first deer is to be taken by an archer.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16 -Captain Spence Moseley of the Yale eleven played the second half of the game with Princeton in New York on Saturday with a broken finger, it was revealed today.

Senator Byrd, head of the Joint Congressional Economy Committee, charges that "the Federal Government is the chief offender in the waste and hoarding of manpower." This is a serious charge, but Senator Byrd asserts that his committee will soon begin hearings to bring out the facts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Announcement of the plan by which the Office of Civilian Supply hopes to curtail civilian consumption of petroleum products in the East coast area was postponed today for another day as experts of the agency continued to study proposals which have been placed before them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that he would communicate in a few days with Harry Bates, chairman of the American Federation of Labor's peace committee, in order to fix a date for the resumption of labor peace negotiations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Store-door jobbers who are members of the National Food Distributors Association have been cutting their truck mileage an average of 25 to 30 per cent in response to the plea of ODT to conserve tires, Emmet J. Martin, secretary of the association, reported today.

ANDORRA, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler gave a guarantee to another neutral State yesterday. The German Army occupied all of France, but stopped at the frontier of this little community, which lies high in the Pyrenees Mountains between France and Spain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The one-week Fall meeting of the National League of Women Voters board of directors opened today, Miss Marguerite M. Wells presiding, as members reported on the league in thirty-three States and the District of Columbia.

To obtain the labor supply required to keep war production going the War Manpower Commission "will deliberately raid the luxury industries first" and, in consequence, the fur industry faces a gradual suspension of its activities, Fowler V. Harper, deputy chairman of the commission, said here yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- In contrast to last Monday's activity today's market was quiet but steady. Gilt-edge issues felt the falling off in business and were 1-16 to 1/8 point lower.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- President Roosevelt told the special war conference of the United States Savings and Loan League today that "a nation of home owners, of people who own a real share in their own land, is unconquerable."

It is fitting to bow to the superior wisdom of our censorship authorities in the matter of releasing information as to the casualties suffered by our fleets. In fact, there is no real use in telling the public anything about them. Perhaps that is what the officials, too, have in mind when they give out the sort of information they do, when they do and as they do.

Plans are rapidly nearing completion for the Yorkville dinner dance to be held on Dec. 10 in the main ballroom of the Plaza to raise funds for the support of a Summer camp for children in Harriman State Park that has just concluded its twenty-sixth season.

The twenty-seventh annual exhibition of work by members of the New York Society of Painters opened yesterday at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, to continue until the end of the month. Of this organization Albert P. Lucas is president, Alphaeus P. Cole vice president.

The stock market experienced yesterday its most thorough shaking since the start of the month, although losses did not assume major proportions. The decline, which enveloped practically every section of the list, was accompanied by a falling off in volume.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, declared today that it would be unwise now to seek from Congress a reduction in assessments paid by insured banks to the corporation.

A NEW GUINEA BASE, Nov. 15 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- There was a birthday party over the Japanese base at Rabaul today, staged by a bunch of American fliers who used incendiary bombs for candles. The Japanese, who played host with anti-aircraft guns and lots of bright lights, didn't like it.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 16 -Reaching a new high in unprintable invective, the Regime Fascista, in two editorials, formally accuses the Vatican -- "which received in triumphal ceremony the Jewish envoy of [President] Roosevelt, 'Myriam Taylor'" -- of encouraging Royal Air Force bombers to fly over Italy sowing death in their wake.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Southern opponents of the House bill to outlaw poll tax payments as a requirement for voting in eight Southern States won the third day's round today in their efforts to prevent Senate consideration of the measure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) --- A message of tribute and encouragement to the Philippine people was given today by Wendell L. Willkie over shortwave broadcast facilities of the Office of War Information.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -Twentieth-Century-Fox today announced the purchase of Maxwell Anderson's current Broadway play, "The Eve of St. Mark," for $300,000. The deal, it was learned, included a commitment by Fox not to release the film version before January, 1944.

Until the urgency of the United States Medical Corps' requirements for several million bed-sheets has been relieved, which may require the total available output of manufacturers for the next several months, all civilian deliveries now pending for January white sales have been taken over by the Army Quartermaster General, it was learned here yesterday in the Worth Street textile market.

The Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation announced yesterday declaration of $1 a share for payment Dec. 18. This is in addition to the 50-cent dividend declared in September and payable on Dec. 18. Total disbursements this year will amount to $3, or $1 more than last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -Japanese military authorities were reported by an American official observer today to have imposed an iron rule on the Philippines and Malaya, shooting without trial any one who ventures into forbidden zones.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 16 -While in Vichy, Chief of State Marshal Henri Philippe Petain was signing a message outlawing Admiral Francois Darlan in which he said "I am not the sort of a man to give way to coercion in any form," General Maxime Weygand was undergoing his first day of captivity "somewhere East," it was disclosed here today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Under-Secretary of War Patterson and Under-Secretary of the Navy Forrestal tonight announced the selection of ten more industrial plants to receive the joint Army-Navy production "E" award for outstanding performance on war contracts.

The first player assigned a role in the forthcoming production of "Thomas Jefferson" is Madge Evans, it became known yesterday. She will portray the daughter of our third President in the play written by her husband. Sergeant Sidney Kingsley, winner of the Pulitzer Prize for "Men in White."

The National Conference of Christians and Jews gave citations to the chief chaplains of the Army and Navy last night at a dinner of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders held at the WaldorfAstoria. Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, presided.
LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Decorations for gallantry in action were conferred today upon some 120 men of the Eighth Air Force, United States Army.

AT ADVANCED R.A.F. HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 15 (Delayed) -- The long campaign for air control in the Mediterranean theatre appears nearing its close with British fighters and bombers and United States aircraft flying from a string of newly occupied airfields along the coast of North Africa.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 16 -Fresh from his triumph of yesterday in the Westchester P.G.A. title play-off, Mike Turnesa of Elsmford maintained his fast pace today to take the laurels in the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro best-ball tournament over the Salisbury course.

A call to American designers to turn from imitating the past and to evolve functional designs for the future, particularly in architecture and furniture, was sounded yesterday by T.H. Robsjohn-Gibbings, designer and architect. He spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group's Home Furnishings Division at the Murray Hill Hotel.

A nation-wide promotional campaign by food manufacturers to "sell" the importance of the industry in the war effort and the reconstruction period may soon be launched, it was learned yesterday. Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, who will make the keynote address at the group's thirty-fourth annual convention, which opens tomorrow at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, in an interview yesterday disclosed that he will urge such action.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -Reports that the radio station at Rabat, Morocco, is under the control of the Allies are false, it was stated here tonight.

TRENTON, Nov. 16 -- Assemblyman David Young 3d of Towaco, Morris County, was ordered by Supreme Court Justice Joseph L. Bodine today to answer certain questions concerning litigation he began and was warned that unless he did so "the jail doors will open."

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- Col. Gen. P. Artemieff of the Red Army writes in the Red Star, the army organ, that Russia is holding big ski forces in reserce for the coming Winter. At the front they will put into practice the lessons learned last Winter, on which intensive training has been based.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Nov. 16 -- The Japanese came down to Guadalcanal with the intention of ousting the American forces that are holding Henderson Field there, and to do that job they brought all the forces they could muster.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 16 (AP) -W.W. Haswell's 4-year-old In Dutch, with Johnny Brennan up, scored an easy stretch victory today in the Red Hook claiming purse, feature event of Rockingham Park's first day of a week of charity racing.
PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Nov. 16 -- From Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's headquarters:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 16 -Mayor Frank Hague accused Governor Charles Edison of having "unscrupulously sold out the people of the State of New Jersey," when in a statement issued today he denied charges by the Governor that the city's finances were not on a sound basis.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

The earliest possible induction of the city's first group of 18 and 19 year olds for military service cannot take place before Dec. 17, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, draft director here, said yesterday.

The memory of a gallant young French pursuit pilot comes to mind with the African report that General Nogues, Governor General of French Morocco, has switched from Vichy to the Americans. The aviator was that general's son. His bravery in 1918 saved the lives of several of us American or French fellow-members of Escadrille Spad 12.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 16 -Elected this month to fill vacancies, former Secretary of State Thomas A. Mathis of Ocean County, Assemblyman John G. Sholl of Gloucester County and C. Wesley Armstrong of Mercer County were sworn in today as members of the State Senate. All are Republicans. Mr. Armstrong replaces a Democrat.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Sydney Robey Leibrandt, one-time South African Olympic boxer who served in Germany's parachute corps before being put ashore from a submarine as a saboteur, went on trial today with five others on a treason charge.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- United States naval forces in the Solomons overwhelmingly defeated a formidable Japanese force, destroying twenty-three warships and transports, including one battleship and five cruisers, in a three-day series of actions that ended yesterday (Solomons date), the Navy Department reported today.

In response to a resolution of the Hunter College Student Council opposing racial and religious discrimination in employment requests filled by the college bureau of occupations, Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, announced yesterday that he would set up a citizens' committee to deal with employers and study the problem in all the city colleges.

Frederick S. Buck, director of pari-mutuel revenue for the New York State Tax Department, said yesterday through The Associated Press that including Saturday's take, the State had collected $10,411,896 during 1942 from pari-mutuel revenue, exceeding the $10,000,000 figure predicted by State Senator John J. Dunnigan, who introduced the bill in 1939.

Pastries of many nationalities -American and Austrian, French and English -- were set forth yesterday for the first time in the softly illuminated corner of a metropolitan store. The array, which would compel the attention of the most disciplined dieter, realizes a favorite plan of the buyer, who started in 1936 with four shelves and a counter devoted to groceries and who now has a department several times that size.

The latest book reported to have made its way out of Germany befor the war in the diplomatic pounch "of one of the great powers" is the forthcoming "Blood and Banquets: A Berlin Social Diary," by Bella Fromm. Mrs. Fromm was for many years the diplomatic correspondent of the Uullstein newspapers.

Frederick S. Buck, director of pari-mutuel revenue for the New York State Tax Department, said yesterday through The Associated Press that including Saturday's take, the State had collected $10,411,896 during 1942 from pari-mutuel revenue, exceeding the $10,000,000 figure predicted by State Senator John J. Dunnigan, who introduced the bill in 1939.

Pastries of many nationalities -American and Austrian, French and English -- were set forth yesterday for the first time in the softly illuminated corner of a metropolitan store. The array, which would compel the attention of the most disciplined dieter, realizes a favorite plan of the buyer, who started in 1936 with four shelves and a counter devoted to groceries and who now has a department several times that size.

A volunteer force of 700 workers began yesterday to process the first records required under the tire inspection order of the Office of Price Administration at offices at 1 East Forty-fourth Street. Huge piles of mail sacks represented the response of New York City automobile owners.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- While President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia was warning delegates to the International Student Rally today of their post-war responsibilities, Allied education ministers were discussing with the British Board of Education present and post-war educational problems in Europe.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Three Australian soldiers have arrived at an Allied base in New Guinea after a 2,800-mile, 267-day jungle and sailboat journey that began when the Japanese captured Rabaul, New Britain, last January, The Sydney Morning Herald reported today.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 -- Layaway, in the silks of Max Marmorstein, survived a three-way photo finish to win the featured Dumblane Purse as Bowie went into its first full week today.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Exiled Belgians in Britain celebrated in the traditional manner today the feast day of their King, now a prisoner of war at his palace at Laeken.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Net income of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad for 1942, after provision for all taxes and fixed charges, will be $34,065,000, Roy Barton White, president, estimated today at the ll6th annual meeting of stockholders.

The latest book reported to have made its way out of Germany befor the war in the diplomatic pounch "of one of the great powers" is the forthcoming "Blood and Banquets: A Berlin Social Diary," by Bella Fromm. Mrs. Fromm was for many years the diplomatic correspondent of the Uullstein newspapers.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The British Government and people and Fighting French headquarters, while ready enough to cheer the military achievements of the troops under Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Commander in Chief of the Allied forces in French North Africa, are somewhat disturbed by the political developments that have followed in their wake.

Columbia's football team continued practice for Dartmouth at Baker Field yesterday, with Coach Lou Little drilling his men in every phase of the game in preparation for the visit of the Indians, whom Little considers "as good a team as we have played all year."

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Norman J.O. Makin, Australian Navy and Munitions Minister, said today that the United States naval victory in the Solomon Islands was a momentous event and would give Australia much needed relief from the possibility of invasion.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- In the event of Italy's being brought to terms, a separate peace could be negotiated "with the good-will and even the mediation of the Vatican" in the opinion of the current issue of The New Catholic Herald, a weekly publication edited by Count Michael de la Bedoyere, former lecturer in philosophy at the University of Minnesota.

Secretary Knox wisely assumes only that we have won the second round in the hard-fought Battle of the Solomons. There will be a third round, but it may well be delayed. No doubt Japan has the ships and the will for another attack on Guadalcanal, but such heavy losses as she has suffered are not easily replaced or quickly repaired.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 17 -- Dartmouth placed emphasis on passing today as it began serious preparations for the game with Columbia in New York.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- Two Rumanian priests, Clicherie Moraru and Stefan Opreanu, named in an alleged plot to bring exiled King Carol into the United States and set him up in position to obtain $80,000,000 in Rumanian funds, pleaded innocent today in district Federal court.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- George Sanders's two months' old rebellion against Twentieth Century-Fox has ended, according to the studio, and he has been assigned to one of the leading roles in "School for Saboteurs," a photoplay by Ben Redman and Michel Jacoby, which Edward Ludwig will direct.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Because industrial medicine is short of doctors retired physicians were urged today by Dr. Victor G. Heiser, medical consultant to the National Association of Manufacturers, to "lend-lease" their services for wartime.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Nathan R. Sobel resigned today his $10,000-a-year position as counsel to Governor Lehman to prepare for his new duties as Kings County judge.

The North Side Savings Bank has sold the three-story store and apartment building at 3085 Third Avenue between 157th and 158th Streets, the Bronx, to Joseph Horowitz, through E.F. Wagner Company, broker. The Grenell Realty Company was co-broker.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 17 (AP) -- America's two-gun general, Major Gen. George S. Patton Jr., swept into General Headquarters today and reported with gusto to Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on the good fortunes of war.

Some misunderstanding has arisen with regard to officer personnel requirements for the Army because of the publication of the news of the abolition of the Specialists Corps. This action was the result of a change in administrative and organizational detail by the War Department, but not, as apparently has been supposed, any indication that there is no longer need for additions to the commissioned ranks of men with special training or abilities.

An application for dismissal of a suit brought by the government of France a year ago, on the ground that that government has no standing here since the United States severed diplomatic relations, was taken under consideration yesterday by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind.

AN AMERICAN PARACHUTIST BASE, Somewhere in North Africa, Nov. 17 -- From a paratroop transport plane, I saw United States parachutists leap to take an airfield somewhere near the long Algerian-Tunisian frontier.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's prepared speech tonight at The New York Herald Tribune Forum, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
AT UNITED NATION'S HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

Prompted by anticipated delivery delays and possible transportation difficulties in January, retailers have been placing a growing volume of orders for Spring ready-to-wear, a survey here yesterday indicated. Arriving buyers have also been placing additional reorders on Fall apparel, with reports indicating retail trade in this merchandise has been strong in most sections of the country.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 17 (AP) -- A vast lake-covered iron ore deposit in Ontario was presented today by Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland financier, as a key to uncurtailed wartime steel production.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Word was received today of the death of another admiral, Rear Admiral Norman Scott, who died leading a task force in the Solomons engagement, which also cost the life of Rear Admiral Daniel J. Callaghan, a cruiser force commander and for three years, ended in 1941, the naval aide to the President.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Leap-frogging ahead of the main body of British Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson's First Army, reinforced with United States and French detachments, British parachutists were reported tonight to be smoothing the way for their advancing comrades.

The American Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., through its executive vice president, Sam B. Eubanks, denied yesterday ownership of The Aliquippa (Pa.) News-Gazette, insisting that it had merely lent funds to the Aliquippa Publishing Company, which purchased the plant after the newspaper had been suspended for eleven and a half months during a Guild strike.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- The Germans have blasted out a new advance in Northern Stalingrad and stormed into the outskirts of a strategically important town south of Leningrad, but the Red Army cut down 4,000 of the enemy in these two battles, and has seized another important hill in the Central Caucasus, the Soviet High Command announced today.

A joint mass meeting was held at Manhattan Center last night by the New Zionist Organization of America and the Jewish State Party, advanced elements of the Zionist movement, to demand that the Jewish people be represented as a nation among the United Nations.

Mrs. Thomas L. Nightingale was hard at work crocheting last night in her home in Sacramento, Calif., when a telephone call from the National Needlecraft Bureau, 385 Fifth Avenue, informed her that she had just been judged Grand National Crochet Champion of 1942.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers was high bidder yesterday for a new issue of $4,258,000 city of Detroit sewage system revenue bonds, due Nov. 15, 1944 to 1956. The city officials, however, took the bid under advisement before making a decision.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Supplementing its recently announced dollars-and-cents nylon hosiery ceilings for manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers, the Office of Price Administration today extended the regulation to set prices on cut-and-sewn lace nylons as well as third-quality and fourth-quality grades of all types of nylon stockings.
The American victory in the Battle of the Solomons probably means that we have won the first phase of the Solomons campaign, and should soon be ready to push on toward the north.

An acute shortage of substitute teachers in New York City's schools was revealed yesterday when the Board of Examiners announced that it would accept applications for examinations for substitute teaching licenses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt returned home from Britain today. The end of the journey, which was marked by visits with the King and Queen and Prime Minister Churchill and to American troops in the British Isles, was announced this morning after the President motored to an airport to welcome her.

Anthony Cramer has been a farmer, flange turner and stationary engineer but never a student of law, yet there are three items of the Constitution of the United States that have interested him particularly, he admitted yesterday in Federal court. The items refer to granting Congress power to declare war, extending the right of habeas corpus and setting up rules for the conviction of traitors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The War Labor Board ruled today that its jurisdiction covers all nonwar industries in which wage adjustments are involved.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (Reuter) -- It was revealed in London today that Mrs. Roosevelt left London by train Sunday night for an airport, from which she flew the Atlantic for a second time. The American Ambassador, John G. Winant, said good-bye to her at the London railway station.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 17 -- A semi-monthly report on the dollar value of war contracts placed, the number of contracts and the number of plants participating will be issued hereafter by the Smaller War Plants Division of the War Production Board, Frank Smith, deputy director of the division, announced today.

Pointing out the effect of the war in reducing State revenues, Carroll E. Mealey, New York State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, yesterday urged Federal-State coordination of the tax system to avoid Federal encroachment without due regard to the interests of the States.

Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, told several thousand delegates at The New York Herald Tribune's eleventh Forum on Current Problems at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday that alarmists' fears for the permanent loss of this nation's freedom through wartime restrictions were groundless.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Little Rock Stable's Sunspark scored a half-length victory today in the Richmond Claiming Purse, feature event at Rockingham Park.

The three-story brownstone dwelling on a plot 20 by 100 feet at 282 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, has been sold by a client of Myers Sherwin to Helen B. Fredericks through the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, broker.

SOME weeks ago there was chronicled, in all its stirring heroism, the loss of our aircraft carrier Wasp in the battle in the Pacific. The Wasp, Captain Forrest Sherman commanding, was the flagship of a task force supporting our land forces on Guadalcanal and, when the Japs attacked, was hit by three torpedoes. The concussion was terrific.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- Governor Herbert B. Maw of Utah declared today that this nation was in greater danger of losing its democracy through the expansion of Federal bureaus than it was through a military defeat.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 -- Asserting the nation is moving toward an unprecedented peak of war production next year. B.W. Clark, vice president of sales of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, tonight warned the nineteenth semi-annual meeting of the Producers Council, national organization of manufacturers of building material and equipment, that there will be more and more problems of material procurement, manpower and transportation and that civilian restrictions will become more severe.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 831, as against 769 in the preceding week and 644 in the similar period of 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 408, which compared with 370 last Tuesday.

Samuel Klein, founder and owner of the S. Klein store in Union Square, directed in his will, filed yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court, that the business should be incorporated and continued under the merchandising methods established by him.

"The Skin of Our Teeth," Thornton Wilder's new comedy-fantasy, with Tallulah Bankhead, Fredric March, Florence Eldridge and Florence Reed heading a large cast, opens at 8:40 tonight at the Plymouth. Already seen in New Haven, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Washington, even before its Broadway premiere it has become the most talked-of play of the season.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- At the request of the Public Service Commission of New York the Securities and Exchange Commission reopened hearings today on the proposal by the Associated Electric Company to redeem $5,824,000 principal amount of its bonds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Motorists in sixteen East Coast States who are subject to gasoline rationing will have their allowance cut 25 per cent, beginning Sunday.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Warning there was no final victory yet in the greatest of Britain's military problems, the U-boat menace, A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, today joined the list of government spokesmen who have warned the British people not to become overoptimistic over the good news from North Africa.

A warning not to neglect common colds at this season was issued yesterday by city Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins on the basis of reports that the incidence and mortality from pneumonia had reached a new high for the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- An upward revision of Japanese Navy losses in the sea battle of Guadalcanal was predicted confidently today by naval authorities, who emphasized that the announced total of twenty-three ships sunk and seven damaged was based on incomplete reports from the South Pacific war zone.

Delegates to the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union in Chicago Dec. 11-13 will be asked to consider a total of twenty-four changes in the constitution, by-laws and general rules, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The following is the text of President Roosevelt's statement today on the political arrangements made by Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief in North America:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Finance Committee, said today that he was "wide open" to a proposal that one year's Federal taxes be postponed until after the war.

Organization of the National Federation of the Fur Industry was completed yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. A board of governors was elected, representative of all branches of the industry. Officers of the federation will also serve on the board. Its members comprise:

John Andosca, 52 years old, of 173 North Fifth Street, Brooklyn, collapsed from a heart attack as he was about to be placed on trial yesterday with his brother, Anthony, 56, of 103-27 Fifty-first Avenue, Corona, Queens, and two other men in General Sessions in the alleged $1,000,000 taxicab extortion conspiracy uncovered by Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey as District Attorney four years ago.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A new method of straightening armor plate, designed to speed up the final stages of its production and to eliminate the use of much cumbersome and costly straightening equipment, was reported today by the Ford Motor Company.

The belief that women's wartime advance in industry, aviation and other activities normally utilizing the country's manhood would be one of the permanent results of the war was voiced by Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, chairman of the New York Women's Division of the USO, and Mrs. Nancy Harkness Love, chief of the Wafs, in addresses yesterday at the New York Herald Tribune's eleventh Forum on Current Problems.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 17 -- The North African issue involving General Charles de Gaulle and Admiral Francois Darlan was being built up today by Nazi propagandists into an Anglo-American difference of opinion.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Nov. 17 -- While the naval superiority held by Japan over the United States after Dec. 7 has been whittled considerably in the series of engagements that began with the Battle of the Coral Sea and carried through last week's United States victory off Guadalcanal, observers here do not share the optimism that prompted speculations elsewhere yesterday that the United States now had the balance of power in the Pacific.

Reversing a trend under way here for two decades, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it had decided to restore street car operations on the Putnam Avenue line in Brooklyn, discontinuing the bus route it started a little over a year ago to replace the trolleys.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Efforts of Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia to obtain a larger share of war contracts for New York City, in view of the city's large amount of unemployment, have met with considerable success, according to figures from the War Manpower Commission, made public today.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Lord Louis Mountbatten, Chief of the Operational Command, has sent to Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Commander in Chief of Allied Forces in North African operations, a message congratulating General Eisenhower on "the greatest com bined operation of all times," it was disclosed at Allied headquarters here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- In his post-election analysis of Democratic losses in Congress on Nov. 3, Vice President Henry A. Wallace assigned as one of the causes the following:

GALESBURG, Ill., Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- Mrs. B.A. Freed, 40, of Moline, "pushed something" while helping her husband start his two-seater plane today and spent fifteen exciting minutes alone in the air without previous instructions in flying.

The Artists Cultural Society, 47 East Twelfth Street, whose members include a number of modern artists, announced yesterday that it had protested to Hobart Nichols, president of Artists for Victory against the membership of the jury of selection that is choosing paintings, sculpture and prints for the large exhibition to be opened by Artists for Victory next month at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- While the State Department had no official confirmation of the report from Madrid that Spain had ordered partial mobilization, there were rumors here tonight that the Spanish Government had mobilized troops in or along certain areas.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- William Thorp Sturges, assistant to the director of the Lederle Laboratories, Inc., at near-by Pearl River, was found dead in bed at his home, one mile south of New City, this morning. He had been in good health and worked until late last night at the laboratories.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- The War Department has awarded the Soldier's Medal posthumously to Private Vincent J. Puglia for heroism at Titusville Beach, Fla., Aug. 11. He was drowned attempting to rescue a soldier after the truck in which they were riding ran through a bridge rail.

There is smoke on the American prairies these days. The black plumes floating in the wide skies are like question marks expressing the surprise of wheat fields that have been cleared for great war plants, fringed with trailer towns and collapsible villages. Training camps create towns of 15,000, 30,000, 40,000 inhabitants where no towns existed before.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- A total of $21,000 in fines was levied today by Judge George A. Welsh in the Federal District Court against five companies and four locals of the A.F.L. United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union after they changed their pleas of innocent to nolo contendere on charges of conspiring to fix the price of Army caps.

The Tokyo radio claimed in a broadcast last night that the 35,000-ton North Carolina, America's new $70,000,000 superbattleship, and the 33,400-ton Idaho "fled after receiving terrific damage at the hands of the Japanese Navy" in the Solomon Islands last Saturday night. The broadcast was recorded in New York by The Associated Press.

Manhattan heads toward the last game of its football season -- with Holy Cross at Worcester -- still looking for the air attack Coach Herb Kopf thinks would give his Jaspers the offensive punch necessary to wind up the campaign on a pleasant note.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Declaring that too many Federal employes had been deferred from military service because of their jobs. President Roosevelt directed all departments and agencies today to cancel, as soon as possible, all outstanding deferments and refrain from asking new draft exemptions except for highly skilled or specialized technical or scientific employes.

A special meeting of wholesalers and retailers in the metropolitan area to discuss L-219, the proposed consumer goods inventory limitation order, will be held this morning in the Hotel Commodore, it was announced yesterday by Eaton V.W. Read, chairman of the WPB wholesale and retail inventory policy committee.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins clicked off their third straight victory after losing four National Hockey League starts, by outskating Montreal's short-handed Canadiens for a 4 -- 1 decision tonight before a crowd of 7,500 at the Boston Garden.

In line with its new administrative policy of concentrating on the over-all price picture rather than ironing out individual hardship cases, the Office of Price Administration yesterday enumerated the conditions necessary for a price adjustment for a seller or group of sellers.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- Russia charged today that Germany had created special military units, directed by the German Foreign Ministry, to plunder objects of historical and cultural value in Russia and occupied Europe.

Cooper Union announced yesterday that it had opened a course in industrial camouflage designed to thwart possible Axis air raids. Richard Belcher of the architectural faculty and Dikran Dingilian, instructor in industrial design, are in charge of the instruction.
LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Reuter reported from Advanced Allied Headquarters in North Africa today that German Field Marshal Erwin Rommel was now in Tunisia.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Hog receipts equaled yesterday's total of 25,000 head again today and despite the comparatively heavy runs prices ruled steady with yesterday's best.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 17 -- Losing no time in cashing in on their hold-up deal with Denmark, the Germans have obtained through the new Copenhagen Cabinet, headed by Premier Eric Scavenius, acceptance by Danish shipyards of a two-year building program for the Nazi merchant fleet, according to information received here today.

BERNE, Switzerland. Nov. 17 -- While the former so-called free zone of France is becoming more and more confined under German occupation. Vichy is at pains to insist on its "sovereignty." Tonight, for instance, Andre Demaison, a writer who has charge of radio propaganda, asserted that Vichy's broadcasting was "free" despite the fact that every listener to its stations has noted a significant change since last Wednesday.

The President's statement yesterday, characterizing as a "temporary expedient" the Army's arrangement with Admiral Darlan in North and West Africa ought to put an end to doubts about the course our Government is pursuing. As the President said, there is no question of the opposition of the United Nations to "Frenchmen who support Hitler and the Axis," but the primary objective is to defeat Hitler and his Axis armies.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia expressed gratitude to the United States today for "the magnificent forces it has used in this important theatre in cooperation with the forces under General Douglas MacArthur."

When the Metropolitan Opera box office opened yesterday morning for the sale of single seats for the first week's repertory beginning next Monday night, a long line of prospective customers had formed in front of the Broadway entrance to the theatre.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Eighteen Japanese planes were destroyed by Allied raiders in a night attack on Lae, Japanese New Guinea base, and Buin, Japanese fleet anchorage on Bougainville Island in the Northern Solomons, a communique said today, as American and Australian troops, led personally by General Douglas MacArthur, advanced on the New Guinea coastal base of Buna.

Branch Rickey the new designer of Brooklyn's baseball destinies, and the holdover manager, Leo Durocher, who for some time have been conferring at long range and close up over the Dodgers' 1943 managerial set-up, had what had been expected to be their final session at the club's Winter quarters yesterday.

The American Cyanamid Company and its subsidiaries, in a statement of operations issued for release today, report earnings of $14,638,023 before taxes and contingency provision for the first nine months of this year. On the same basis the earnings for the corresponding period last year amounted to $13,207,565.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 17 -- The gates are open now, just in case Frankie Sinkwich and those Georgia Bulldogs want to play football in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, making public the first of a new series of surveys of listed corporations, disclosed that the net profits of ten of the eleven leading food canning and preserving concerns after all charges amounted to $14,000,000 this year, compared with $11,000,000 in 1941.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York and Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board agreed today on the salvage of about 15,000 tons of idle rails in New York streets, an assistant to Mr. Nelson said.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- Yale's football players had two hours of scrimmaging today in which three varsity elevens faced the jayvees, who employed Harvard's formations, especially the T strategy.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 17 -Beyond confirming the landing of Axis troops in Tunisia, military circles in Berlin declined today to discuss impending Italian-German operations or the new situation in the Mediterranean.

The large art collection of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann went on sale yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., where additional auction sessions will be held each afternoon this week as well as this morning. Mrs. McCann was the former Helena W. Woolworth, daughter of the late Frank W. Woolworth, 5 and 10 cent store pioneer.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina Nov. 17 -- General Juan B. Tonazzi unexpectedly resigned today as War Minister and was replaced by General Pedro P. Ramirez, commander of the Cavalry Corps.

A General Sessions jury after deliberating for thirty minutes returned a verdit of guilty yesterday against John Walker Burns, 42 years old, a pseudo lawyer, in the looting of the estate of Mrs. Elizabeth Clark Tyler Miller, 60, of this city and Cleveland, in the last ten years. Judge Goldstein remanded Burns to the Tombs for sentence on Dec. 8.

On Nov. 11, 1939, Armistice Day, Captain Daniel Judson Callaghan, naval aide to Mr. Roosevelt, laid a wreath at the base of the tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery. In the night of Nov. 13, 1942, Admiral Daniel Judson Callaghan was killed in action on the bridge of his flagship.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Squadrons of the hard-hitting Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Army Air Forces here hammered the U-boat base at St. Nazaire, France, in daylight today for the second time in four days and the third time within a week.

Speaking for himself, said Ethelbert Smith, he could not but feel delighted at the type of Frenchmen who have been joining the Allied cause in North Africa or who have been escaping from the French homeland to take refuge with the Allies in North Africa.

There are about 6,000 refugee physicians in the country who escaped Hitler's persecution. Thanks to the work of the National Committee for Resettlement of Foreign Physicians, some of these have been placed in practice and in hospitals. Though the Army and Navy needs doctors, it cannot grant commissions to these men because officers must be citizens.

Just before she completed her testimony yesterday in Bronx County Court, Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21-year-old mother of four children, denied emphatically that she deliberately shot her 23-year-old husband, Alman, because he threatened to do bodily harm to her mother for lending her $3. Mrs. Harrington was on the stand for more than two days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A rapidly increasing number of women aviators are now earning their living as pilots and aiding the nation's war program, a survey of progress in the women's aviation field disclosed today.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Lieut. Comdr. Robert B. Kelly, member of the Navy's PT boat squadron that helped to evacuate General Douglas MacArthur from Corregidor, warned workers at the General Cable Corporation's plant here today that "unless present production is stepped up we'll go back into action with less equipment than we had the last time."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Navy program for scrapping relics, commemorative pieces and discarded equipment has netted more than 7,000,000 pounds of metal, including two old Spanish cannon which once fired directly at a Japanese delegation attending a peace conference at Portsmouth, N.H.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Judge Luther B. Way in Federal District Court late today signed an order authorizing receivers of Seaboard-All Florida railway to buy 6 per cent bonds at the rate of $160 for each $1,000 bond.

Hanging up their third straight triumph, the New York Rovers broke a first-place deadlock with the Philadelphia Falcons and gained undisputed possession of the lead by walloping the Quaker City skaters, 5 to 2, at Madison Square Garden last night.

After having received a summons because her pet dog was romping unleashed in Riverside Park, Mrs. Lillian Campbell, about 55 years old, of 660 Riverside Drive, jumped or fell to her death at 3:15 P.M. yesterday from a wall above the New York Central Railroad tracks opposite West 143d Street and the Drive.

MONTREAL, Nov. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Threat of inflation and shortage of manpower have introduced administrative difficulties of the first order and the energetic treatment of these problems in the manner now being pursued is essential to the successful prosecution of the war, A.A. Magee, president, today told shareholders of Barclay's Bank (Canada) at their annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Representative Bland, chairman of the Merchant Marine Committee, said today that as a result of the committee's investigation of conditions at the South Portland (Me.) Shipbuilding Corporation, the Maritime Commission already has received substantial reimbursement for overcharges made there.

The best answer to the criticism of the United States Office of Education and its Victory Corps plan for the high schools, from Dr. Joel H. Hildebrand of the University of California, published on your editorial page Nov. 10, was given by Congress on the very same day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder, endorsed today a centralized control of the nation's technological resources, first suggested in separate legislation and now proposed in a consolidation of the country's non-military economy "under a single roof."

New training principles being used by the United States Coast Guard to cut the time formerly needed to teach newly inducted personnel were described yesterday by Lieut. Comdr. Patrick Murphy, chief officer of the Guard's visual training section, at the meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, appealed to Americans today to spend Thanksgiving Day at work and to eat their turkeys only after they have earned them at desk or lathe.

The American Chemical Society made public yesterday the names of the eight candidates nominated for the society's presidency. Proposed by the society's local sections, the nominees will be voted for in a mail poll of the organization's 32,000 members and the four receiving the most votes will go before the society's council for election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- John R. Richards, chief of the Office of Price Administration's gasoline rationing branch, told a delegation of Oklahoma and Kansas Representatives today that country-wide gasoline rationing was the only practical solution to the rubber problem.

The Bowery, famed in song and story but for many years Manhattan's street of forgotten men, is to be rid of its unfortunates, whose lives are but an existence and whose better days are but dim memories.

President Roosevelt called upon "The clear eye and firm hand of youth to help create that better world toward which we strive" in a letter read at an International Student Day celebration held by the International Student Service at Hunter College yesterday to honor the 160 students and professors of Prague University who were massacred by the Nazis on Feb. 17, 1939.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Nov. 18 -- The Spanish Government late last night began what was officially described as a partial mobilization of its army, navy and air force in preparation for any emergency that might develop.

President Roosevelt declared last night that we have had a great deal of good news in the past two weeks, "and it would seem that the turning point of this war has at last been reached." But, he warned, we still have a gigantic task ahead, and this is no time for exultation or for anything but fighting and working to win.
The Long Island University basketball team opened its season last night by routing the alumni, 50 -- 27, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium. The victors led at the intermission, 20 -- 14.

By way of summarizing findings on Canada's duck population and the general increase of the birds this year, Tom Main, Dominion manager of Ducks Unlimited, has forwarded what may be considered as a final report.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Solomon Islands naval victory, won from a far superior Japanese battle force, created today in the most highly informed quarters here a new confidence that was only slightly qualified by the feeling that the Japanese would re-form their forces and try again.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Although the undertone was firm there was not much business today in the stock markets. Gilt-edged issues lost 1/16 to 1/8 point.
MOSCOW, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Federal Judge George H. Moore today heard arguments for and against a proposal that the Missouri Pacific Railroad pay $10,000,000 interest on three bond issues, then took it under advisement.

The war is bringing about a rediscovery of the American press and the vital services it renders to the public, the government and business, Frank Tripp, general manager of the Gannett Newspapers and chairman of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, declared yesterday at the annual convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the Hotel Roosevelt.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 17 -- Losing bettors at Bowie have at least one consolation -- they know the track itself is taking a financial beating.

Daily reports of any war plant costs which exceed normal, to prevent accumulated wastes of material and labor, were advocated here last night by C. Oliver Wellington of Scovell, Wellington Co., management consultants.

The world featherweight title bout between Champion Chalky Wright and Willie Pep at Madison Square Garden Friday night so intrigued the interest of John J. Phelan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, that he journeyed to Hartford, Conn., yesterday to give the challenger an official once-over.

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States showed a further decline in October, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the market. As of Oct. 31 the total outstanding was $118,581,000, a decrease of $4,913,000 on the month, and a drop of $66,225,000 from one year ago.

The annual fair and sale for the benefit of Greer School, Dutchess County. N.Y., formerly known as Hope Farm, is being given in the small ballrooms of the Hotel Pierre today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. until 6 P.M. Several luncheons will be given in the Cotillion today.
A fixed price for each brand of liquor will be set by the Office of Price Administration at the distilling, wholesale and retail levels, it was authoritatively reported yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17 -- With their hopes for a successful season punctured by successive losses to Harvard. Dartmouth and Yale, the Princeton Tigers are now sharpening their claws in preparation for a salvaging expedition.

BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Artificial limbs and teeth, eyeglasses and $40 cash a month are promised to Idaho's aged residents in the State's new pension act. The law also provides for $8 in medical care monthly for each citizen 65 or older and $100 for burial costs. It was approved by popular vote in the recent election.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The United States Forest Service was accused today by Wilson Compton, executive officer of the Lumber and Timber Products Committee, of trying to seize control of forestry practices under cover of the war emergency.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- American railroads have met successfully the huge freight traffic demands of the war and are now "over the hump"for 1942, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, announced today.

Erik of 15 East Fifty-third Street showed his new collection of hats yesterday at a fashion luncheon at the Ritz Carlton. Warm wrapped-up looking hats for windy days, walking hats with clean-cut tailored lines, dressy little hats for afternoon and dinner wear and a few forecasts for Spring were included in the showing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Roosevelt announced today that he had accepted the "political arrangements" made by Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower with former Vichy elements in Northern and Western Africa as temporary military expedients, justified solely by the stress of battle and designed to save lives and time.

World-wide health problems will require "global cooperation" if they are to be solved, Commander Thomas M. Rivers, M.C., U.S.N.R., declared yesterday in an address at the New York Herald Tribune Forum. Commander Rivers, who is on leave as director of the hospital of the Rockefeller Institute, declared that "better living" rather than drugs, pills and vitamins would rid humanity of disease.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -Rear Admiral Norman Scott was the second American admiral killed in the Solomons battle -Rear Admiral Daniel J. Callaghan's death was reported Monday -- and the fourth to perish in the war. He was in command of an unidentified naval unit during the battle in which American naval forces executed a daring manoeuvre that paved the way to victory, but also cost Admiral Callaghan's life.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- President Roosevelt's unequivocal statement that Allied accommodation with Admiral Francois Darlan was a temporary expedient dictated by military necessities was received by both the Fighting French and the British people tonight with considerable relief.

An exhibition of Ching dynasty art has been installed in the galleries of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., 451 Madison Avenue, material lent by C.T. Loo and Tonying Company. Included are paintings, scrolls, screens, tapestries, figures in wood, porcelain, ivory, coral and jade, handsomely arranged in the former Whitelaw Reid mansion.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Grain markets were on the downgrade today, paced by oats. A statement credited to Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard that 300,000,000 bushels of Canadian feed grain would be made available for shipment to this country as soon as possible and could be imported free of duty was responsible for the weakness.

The four loft buildings known as 48, 50, 52 and 54 East Thirty-fourth Street have been sold by the Greenwich Savings Bank to Kalman Isakoff through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

AT A UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Central India, Nov. 15 (delayed) -- The United States' biggest supply depot and airplane repair center in India is now functioning, with runways nearing completion and facilities to do everything except build new machines.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- For the first time in its 900-year history, Westminster Abbey will pass out of the hands of English ecclesiastical officials for a short time during the forenoon of Nov. 26, when the edifice will be used by United States forces for a non-sectarian Thanksgiving Day service in which Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish clergymen will participate.

The best college football team in the land, in the opinion of most of the 126 sports writers who voted yesterday in The Associated Press weekly poll, is unbeaten, untied Georgia, but thirty-seven of the voters still are not convinced that the Bulldogs are as good as the Eagles of Boston College.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Naturalizations of aliens outside the United States through an administrative order instead of a court process will be undertaken soon for the first time when citizenship is granted to more than 200 soldiers in the Panama Canal Zone and Caribbean Defense Command, Attorney General Biddle disclosed today.

Directors of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey declared yesterday a fourth-quarter common stock dividend of 25 cents a share, bringing total common dividends for the year to 95 cents a share. The 25-cent dividend is payable Dec. 21 to stockholders of record on Nov. 27.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A Soviet midnight communique:

Conservative estimates of the ship losses sustained by the United States and Japan to date in the Pacific, based on communiques issued by the various United Nations since the attack on Pearl Harbor, reveal that our losses in all categories amount to eighty-six vessels sunk, compared with 321 Japanese.

The German Foreign Office said yesterday that political issues arising from recent developments in Western Europe were of secondary importance, according to a Trans-ocean broadcast recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The only thing essential now, it was said, is to ward off "President Roosevelt's invasion of Europe."

Widening the previous session's losses by 1 to 2 points, the stock market was subjected yesterday to a barrage of liquidation that set prices to where they were a month ago. Only fleeting recognition was accorded early in the day to the United States naval victory in the Pacific, while the selling which brought such serious inroads to values in the final hour was labeled by brokers as mainly for tax record purposes.

Erwin Goodman, 36-year-old mathematics teacher of William J. Gaynor Junior High School in Brooklyn, was shot and killed in the school corridors on Oct. 2 by a youth whose hand he had clasped in thankfulness for acting as peacemaker a few minutes earlier in a dispute between the teacher and another youth, according to testimony offered yesterday in Kings County Court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Seventeen-year-old Edward Haight was twice sentenced to death in the electric chair by Westchester County Judge Frank H. Coyne today for the torture murders of two little Bedford Village girls last Sept. 14.

Although railroad bonds generally were quiet yesterday and inclined to be a little easier, a few of these issues were in demand at the highest levels for the year. The Seaboard-All Florida bonds gained a point to 14 on the belief that the receivers of the road will be permitted to purchase tenders of these obligations up to $160 for each $1,000 bond with accrued interest.

Concerning coffee cookery, there seem to be two schools of thought -- the people who believe in stretching supplies just as far as they will go and the people who don't. If you haven't made up your mind to which school you belong, you may be sure you will in the immediate future.

Lulu Costantino, 131, East Side, outpointed Billy Pinti, 128 1/4, Rome, N.Y., in the eight-round feature at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night before 3,000 fans. The winner was in command all the way, but although he did a workmanlike job he did not succeed in cutting down or even greatly weakening a sturdy foe.

On Oct. 27, 1917, in the midst of another war, 16-year-old Jascha Heifetz made his debut in this country. His first recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night was in the nature of a twenty-fifth anniversary celebration, though Mr. Heifetz's program made no mention of the significance of the date.

AT SEA WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET OFF GUADALCANAL, Nov. 6 (AP) (Delayed) -The strength of the United States grip on the Solomons area has been increased greatly by two successful landings by Marine and Army troop reinforcements in the past few days.

Charges that William Power Maloney, special Federal prosecutor, had been conducting for months a "campaign of persecution" and had tried to obtain false testimony against the Rev. Ignatius Cox before a Washington grand jury were made yesterday at a hearing before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 17 -- The British Eighth Army, its advance westward in Libya slowed just now far more by problems of supply and maintenance of communications than by the occasional shots from the German rear guard, has occupied Derna, on the coast, and is pressing toward Bengazi, about 150 miles to the southwest.

Necessity having mothered many an invention and conditions being what they are in Brooklyn, the football Dodgers may go in for wholesale changes Sunday at Washington, where the Redskins, who lead the National League's Eastern division, will tangle with the slumping Brooks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Promotional facilities of retailers have been pledged to aid the government program for forwarding the war effort, the Office of War Information announced today following a conference with merchants. Purpose of the program is to simplify government requests for cooperation in war campaigns made upon retailers.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- After three weeks on a rubber life raft in the Pacific Ocean, Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker rode the wing of the plane that rescued him as it taxied forty miles on the ocean surface back to its base, the War Department disclosed tonight.

Presenting a ten-point program for the voluntary recruitment of women for industry, the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs went on record yesterday through its president, Dr. Minnie L. Maffett of Dallas, Texas, against a general registration of women now.

A telegram, signed by twenty-one persons, was sent from New York yesterday to Senators Barkley, Norris and La Follette, condemning the Senate filibuster on the anti-poll tax bill and urging adoption of the measure.

Fordham's battered Rams began preparations for their game on Saturday with Missouri University's high-scoring eleven, favored to capture the Big Six Conference title for the second year running with a two-hour non-contact drill yesterday on Fordham Field.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 17 -- With the threat of a long-distance "Dunkerque" hanging heavy over what remains of the Axis army in Libya. Italian military commentators tonight professed to find some cause for "optimism" in the "bafflingly successful outcome of our strategic withdrawal, which has been so rapid that [General Sir Bernard L.] Montgomery has been obliged at many points to break off combat."
LONDON, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- British naval quarters said today that the United States victory in the Solomon Islands battle affected tremendously the balance of power and the whole Pacific strategy.
On Nov. 10 you published a letter in which Joseph H. Choate Jr. justified the restrictions on wages, but deplored the limitation of salaries to $25,000.

Argentina was likened to the United States of a year ago by Senora Ana Rosa S. de Martinez Guerrero yesterday at a luncheon in Sherry's, given by the National Council of Women for members of the Inter-American Commission of Women, of which Senora Guerrero is chairman.

The German-controlled Paris radio said last night that the new Spanish Ambassador to Germany, Jose Vidal, had arrived in Berlin yesterday. Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop had been scheduled to meet him, but instead sent his regrets, according to broadcasts recorded by The United Press.

"Guadalcanal Diary," the book by Richard Tregaskis, a King Features writer, for which Random House signed a contract a few days ago, will be a February Book-of-the-Month Club selection. It will form a dual selection with "Let the People Know," Norman Angell's book on the Viking list.

Following the development of satisfactory boxsprings using far less than the thirty pounds of wire now permitted and even the fifteen pounds which will be permitted after Dec. 1, the War Production Board is understood to be considering the advisability of cutting the permissible weight still further, possibly to six pounds for a full-size model, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Senators from eight Southern States which tax the right to vote for candidates for Federal office succeeded today for the fourth successive day in blocking efforts to bring up the recently passed House measure which would abrogate such taxation.

"Guadalcanal Diary," the book by Richard Tregaskis, a King Features writer, for which Random House signed a contract a few days ago, will be a February Book-of-the-Month Club selection. It will form a dual selection with "Let the People Know," Norman Angell's book on the Viking list.

Following the development of satisfactory boxsprings using far less than the thirty pounds of wire now permitted and even the fifteen pounds which will be permitted after Dec. 1, the War Production Board is understood to be considering the advisability of cutting the permissible weight still further, possibly to six pounds for a full-size model, it was learned yesterday.

Eric Partridge, the British author and editor who happened into lexicography ten years ago and who says he has been unable to get out of its meshes despite his good intentions, has a new book out. It's called "Usage and Abusage" and follows a long line of books on the world of words under such titles as "A Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English'' and "Words, Words, Words!"

A rush of selling orders in the December in advance of first-notice day entered the cotton futures market near the close yesterday, weakening the list on the New York Cotton Exchange to final net losses of 13 to 17 points, only slightly above the day's lows.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Legislation to permit an additional expenditure of $15,000,000 to overcome food shortages in Puerto Rico became an instrument today with which to start a movement in Congress to force the removal of Rexford G. Tugwell as Governor of that island possession.

WASHINGTON, Nov. l7 -- The Food Requirements Committee of the WPB at its regular weekly meeting tomorrow will discuss methods of reducing the consumption of dairy products by civilians, according to Herbert L. Forest, head of the foreign and lend-lease requirements division of the Office of Agricultural War Relations.
Beyond the shadow of a doubt the Christmas present men are fondest of giving and women are fondest of getting is -- perfume, and more perfume. It isn't original, but it is apparently infallible.

The weekly Federal Reserve figures to be released late this afternoon are expected to show that the New York City banks have improved their reserve positions materially during the week. One week ago, excess reserves of the New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System stood at $365,000,000.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Nov. 19 -- American and Australian troops have begun "closing in" on the Japanese base of Buna on the northeastern New Guinea coast, and eight enemy destroyers are prowling offshore, apparently trying to support the beleaguered Buna defenders, it was announced today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 18 -- Dissension between Major Gen. Hermann von Hanneken, commanding the German troops of occupation in Denmark, and Dr. Werner Best, Reichsfuehrer Hitler's envoy, is said in Copenhagen to be the reason why the general left the Danish capital for Berlin a few days ago, allegedly to complain at headquarters about the new German Legation's regime.
Irving Feist, one of Newark's duck-hunting enthusiasts and also an official of Ducks Unlimited, arrived back in town with an optimistic outlook regarding the present season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Rules under which employers can ask for price adjustments on wage or salary increases requiring approval of the National Labor Relations Board were established here today by the Office of Price Administration.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Nov. 9 (Delayed) -- Vice Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., making his first visit to what he calls the "first front' in the Pacific, this morning described the naval situation as "fine from our point of view" despite the loss of ships, which must be expected.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The stock markets marked time today pending the outcome of the battle in Tunisia. Most sections were quiet and mostly dull. Gilt edge issues steadied after early dullness, but the home rails were featureless.

Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday in an affidavit filed in Supreme Court that "tipster" sheets are "largely responsible" for the existence of illegal gambling and that they "have one and only one function, and that is to aid, abet and encourage illegal gambling and bookmaking."

The Bache Collection, 814 Fifth Avenue, has not reopened this Fall as in previous years but its art treasures may still be seen by groups who make application for admittance, Jules S. Bache, founder and director, announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 18 -- Eduardo Villasenora, director general of the Banco de Mexico and one of the leading economists of this country, said today that Mexico needs foreign capital equipment for its development. Mexico, he explained, does not need cash capital to be invested in existing industries.

Trade buying dominated the moderately active cotton market yesterday, and active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at net gains of 5 to 10 points, despite continued evening-up in the December position.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
The scrapping of our bronze memorials has been recently suggested by some of your readers. I must, as a sculptor, proffer a realistic approach to the value of the suggested plan.

Conferences between representatives of the United Mine Workers, headed by John L. Lewis, and spokesmen for soft coal operators of the Appalachian region on plans for the introduction of the six-day week, as requested by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, solid fuel administrator, broke down yesterday because of failure to agree on a mode of procedure.

Scoring the increase in juvenile delinquency among adolescent girls, former Magistrate Jeannette G. Brill of Brooklyn called yesterday for action on the part of schools and mothers to remedy "the sad situation."

It might possibly be a slight case of whistling in the dark, but Steve Owen, coach of the Giants, is of the opinion that his team has a fair chance to beat the Packers when they collide at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. Cecil Isbell, Don Hutson Co. were soundly and thoroughly whipped by the Bears last week and it is Owen's contention that this could work to the advantage of the Giants.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The Flying Fortress returned home from Lille, France, with one motor gone, a wingtip rolled up like a sardine can, half her controls useless and one tire shot flat, but she sat down on a British airdrome with scarcely a bump.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 18 -Lest they forget they have a rendezvous with Princeton's Tigers in the Yankee Stadium, New York, on Saturday afternoon. Coach Earl Blaik put the West Point cadets through a stiff scrimmage session on the Plains today.

SALEM, Ore., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Dr. J.C. Evans, superintendent of the Oregon State Hospital for the Insane, said tonight that thirty-two working inmates were dead of food poisoning and that 400 were ill.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A joint United States-British communique:

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Two Puerto Rican political leaders protested vigorously to Washington today against a House Agriculture Committee amendment yesterday making a proposed $15,000,000 appropriation to stimulate Puerto Rican food production conditional on the removal of Rexford G. Tugwell as Governor.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 (AP) -The pro bowl football classic will be played this year in Philadelphia for the first time, with the entire proceeds going to the "unsung heroes" of the Merchant Marine.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A communique:

Judge Vincent L. Leibell in Federal District Court approved yesterday a settlement under which thirty-two present and former directors of the General Motors Corporation will pay their company $4,500,000 as damages for careless administration of its bonus system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Office of Price Administration today amended its regulations covering the posting of ceiling prices for cost of living commodities by mail order houses so that all sales made by mail, whether by a mail order house or an ordinary retailer, are covered by the regulations.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- Thomas W. Wallace, Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, whose election up to now had been in doubt to some extent, won by 20,463 votes over Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, according to figures released today by Secretary of State Michael F. Walsh.

The news from Yugoslavia, "house divided against itself," partitioned and torn asunder by German, Italian, Bulgarian and Hungarian forces and rent by guerrilla warfare and civil strife, became of particular importance yesterday as the United Nations extended their control of the southern shore of the Mediterranean.

"Once Over Lightly," an "Americanized version" of Rossini's opera, "The Barber of Seville," will open tonight at the Alvin under the auspices of Saul Colin and Henri Leiser. The book is by Laszlo Halasz and the lyrics by Louis Garden and George Mead.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Office of War Information stated today that since Pearl Harbor the Army and Navy had bought, or were in the process of buying, private property equal to the combined areas of Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Delaware, the District of Columbia and fourfifths of New Jersey.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18 -- Realtors and home builders of the country met here today to study methods of cooperating in the war program while keeping their industry going in the face of rent control, construction restrictions and other emergency regulations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- That method of obstructing legislation called a filibuster, which a number of Senators have employed to prevent consideration of the anti poll-tax bill, is ancient if not honored in Congress. It is the only method by which a small minority can make any effective stand against the effort of a large majority to pass legislation which seems to the minority to violate its rights or that of its constituents.

The Maple Leafs will attempt to capitalize on the defense weaknesses of the Rangers tonight, when the teams collide in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. In fourth place in the loop, after a fine start, the Leafs hope to take advantage of the New Yorkers' sorry play of late and bolster their standing, as befits a team that holds the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Grain markets were under pressure at the start of trading today but oats quickly reversed their movement and advanced about 1 cent a bushel from the early low. Removal of hedges against shipping sales of 75,000 bushels and aggressive buying by a commission house which found offerings light resulted in the rally.

The United Hospital Campaign, entering the second half of its drive for $1,383,729 in behalf of seventy-six voluntary, non-profit hospitals that are members of the United Hospital Fund, has raised to date $942,864, which is $79,677 more than was contributed in the same period last year, according to figures released yesterday at the fourth report meeting of the women's division of the campaign committee at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Women members of the Citizens Service Corps and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office will have as their official uniforms slate blue skirts and jackets worn over white boys' shirts, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the CDVO in City Hall.
