Far from desiring the elimination of the fur business, it would appear that the War Production Board is against any such attitude, according to a survey made by Stephen Brooks, secretary of the New York Auction Company, the results of which were made public yesterday.

Turning from lighthearted, anecdotal story-telling before a Children's Book Week luncheon audience in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday, alter D. Edmonds, the novelist, attacked a non-literary subject he called "The German Bedtime Story."

About 50,000,000 individuals will owe the new and increased income taxes next year. Of this number about 33,000,000 will be meeting the income tax collector for the first time. To find out how well prepared the public is for this new problem the Gallup Survey made an inquiry recently.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The War Production Board's food requirements committee has decided to make a further study of the milk-supply situation before taking action on recommendations of Department of Agriculture officials that the government take control of distribution of dairy products to meet a threatened shortage.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 18 -- In a note addressed to the governments of fourteen provinces of Argentina, Interior Minister Miguel Culaciati today instructed them to take strict measures to prevent any activities that might be detrimental to the individual or collective security of the American republics.

"There is only one thing that counts for the moment. This is to obtain control of the whole north coast of Africa, Tunisia included * * *." Your editorial goes straight to the essential point of General Eisenhower's task. It has been wholly ignored in the outburst of speculation involving ulterior political problems.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- The Federal Government today accused Karl Oscar Hugg, 48-year-old German-born precision instrument maker, of maintaining direct short-wave radio communication with his daughter in Germany and of knowing of the sinking of the aircraft carrier Langley ten days before it was announced in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, is expected to become a principal Administration spokesman for the projected new tax bill, a measure which, under present plans, is to include a compulsory savings provision.

OTTAWA, Nov. 18 -- Canada's manpower problem, which has been becoming more and more acute during the past six months, reached a crisis today in the resignation of Elliott M. Little as Director of National Selective Service.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- Governor Lehman today announced the appointment of William Riordan, president of Stern Brothers, New York City, as a member of the State War Council to succeed Charles E. Wilson, former president of the General Electric Company, who went to Washington as assistant director of the War Production Board.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP) -The forty-third American Bowling Congress tournament, scheduled in Buffalo next Spring, was postponed today for one year in the first break of the classic which has run continuously since 1901.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -Secretary Ickes opposed today a Senate investigation of conditions in Puerto Rico, contending that it would serve principally as "a sounding board for a few people who hope to make political capital out of the effects of the war upon Puerto Rican economy."

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 18 -Henri Philippe Petain, Marshal of France, victor of Verdun, "Chief of the French State," virtually abdicated in Vichy today when he signed what may be his last "constitutional act," empowering Pierre Laval, "Chief of Government," to promulgate laws and decrees under his own signature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The fifth day of Senate filibuster against the bill to outlaw poll tax collections as a requirement to vote in Federal elections in eight Southern States left the opposition so confident of control of the situation tonight that they indicated they "might" permit the bill to go to the floor for consideration.

Many Americans besides myself who are greatly concerned that our country should become truly democratic in every aspect of its life welcomed, I am sure, the wholehearted support which THE TIMES gave the anti-poll tax bill and the clear statement of the reasons for its passage expressed in several editorials.

As Columbia continued to prepare for its final appearance of the season against Dartmouth here Saturday, it was disclosed yesterday that Passin' Paul Governali, mainstay of the Lion eleven, has smashed almost every offensive record in the Columbia football books.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -The Boston Terminal Company filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a reorganization plan under which it would pay $20 in cash on each $1,000 bond outstanding and replace the remainder, amounting to $15,155,000, with new securities.

Take the United States destroyer "Smith," for instance. Hit squarely by a two-thousand-pound torpedo from a Japanese diving plane in the battle of the Santa Cruz Islands. Flames enveloping bridge, reaching crosstrees. Ammunition rooms ablaze. Twenty-seven-pound powder cans.

Harry A. Strecker Jr., field consultant of the Temporary State Commission for Post-War Public Works Planning, told 150 business men yesterday that only if plans for post-war work were made now could New York State promise its returning soldiers and discharged war workers "honest work" which would support them until the "new and better order we pray for is functioning."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Pacific War Council, which meets weekly with President Roosevelt, held today what members described as "the most interesting meeting we have ever had," with a review of at least sixteen Allied war fronts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -A steel company official was accused today before the Truman Investigating Committee of exacting more than $73,000 profit on a $23,000 investment in the handling of war contracts.

The hurrying pace of events in North Africa provides the military explanation of the political decisions clarified in the President's statement on Monday. British and American armies are racing into Tunisia with a speed which emphasizes that time is the ally they value most in this bold drive to chase the enemy from the African Continent and regain control of the great waterway which is the historic entrance to Europe.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Remarkable and commanding qualities as an orchestral interpreter were unfolded by Artur Rodozinski, guest conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall with the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, and this notwithstanding details of tempo and interpretation with which it was easily possible to disagree.

Testifying in defense of their lives for nearly five hours yesterday, Neil Simonelli, 16 years old, and Joseph Annunziata, 19, told a blue-ribbon jury in Kings County Court that they participated in the killing of Erwin Goodman, 36-year-old mathematics teacher of William J. Gaynor Junior High School in Brooklyn, while trying to "scare him" with a pistol they did not know was loaded.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18 -- Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's Doublrab returned today to the sprint distance he likes so well to capture the W.P. Burch Memorial Handicap. Doublrab had attempted longer routes in recent months without success, but he was at home in this six-furlong dash, which he negotiated in 1:12.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- George W. Horton 3d, 11-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Walton Horton of 613 Belden Street here, was burned to death last night in an effort to rescue his dog, Rusty, during a fire in the two-story, two-family house.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -Treasury approval of a bill authorizing the government to sell silver from its stockpile for war purposes at a minimum average price of 50 cents an ounce was announced today by Senator Green of Rhode Island.

A few seasons ago Thornton Wilder increased the stature of the theatre with "Our Town," and now that November again lies heavy over Broadway he has done it once more. For in "The Skin of Our Teeth," which Michael Myerberg brought last evening to the Plymouth, he has written a comedy about man which is the best play the Forties have seen in many months, the best pure theatre.

Lehman Brothers, as head of the syndicate that was high bidder on Wednesday for $4,258,000 of city of Detroit sewage system revenue bonds, were notified yesterday by the city officials of their decision to reject all bids. The Lehman group's bid figured a 2.134 per cent interest cost to the city.

"THOROFARE," * says Christopher Morley of his new novel, was written slowly and should be read the same way. Check and double check, says the reader in reply. For "Thorofare" is 469 pages of ruminative essays that have been thinly disguised as a novel. It is a book whose pace is that of a very lazy cow ckewing its cud in a slow-motion moving picture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Ways and Means Committee rejected today a request by President Roosevelt for broad powers to suspend, in time of war, Federal statutes affecting the movement of war goods, information and persons into or out of the United States.

THE ice hockey season is in full swing again, but with a difference. It isn't "hockey as usual." The war has brought about a great shuffling on the big league rinks. For one thing, the league has shrunk under war pressure. The star-spangled Americans of other years have disappeared from the scene. That club was just limping along even in quiet times. The impact of war was the final crushing blow.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Nov. 19 -- Spain's "partial mobilization" continued apace yesterday. Hundreds of youths massed at railway stations throughout the country headed for their recruiting centers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- After filing a statement describing the sharp decline in medical care for the civilian population and especially for women and crippled children as a result of doctors entering the armed forces, Dr. Martha Elliott, associate director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, urged upon a Senate Labor and Education subcommittee today the need for an overall national plan for the distribution of physicians.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 18 -The Chinese Air Force is increasing its activities with newly arrived latest type American lend-lease planes. Last month tons of explosives and incendiaries were dumped on the enemy air base at Yuncheng in Southern Shansi.

What is the truth about this new small interdependent world that we are all so concerned about? It is a globe which has so shrunk in dimensions that henceforth all our wars are bound to be global and all our peace activities must also be global.

The suspicion and prejudice of national groups now assembled in America, all of them animated by two hatreds, one for the common enemy, the other for their own fellow-compatriots who differ from them in some point of policy or plans for the world after the war, was condemned yesterday by Hendrik Willem Van Loon, speaking at the annual membership tea of the Women's American ORT attended by 2,000 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -"Mr. Bullfinch Takes a Walk," a screen story by Philip Dunne and Charles E. McCarthy, was purchased today by Twentieth Century-Fox and assigned to Kenneth MacGowan for production.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today that more than 600 newspapers across the country had agreed to become official issuing agents for the sale of war bonds.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A gift of 19.07 acres of land in Englewood Cliffs to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission by the trustees of the William O. Allison estate was announced today.

A report from Montreal yesterday that Freddie Fitzsimmons has been offered the managerial post of the Royals brought from Fitz the reply that, for the present, he was not ready to consider such an offer.

A widespread police drive to clean up the Bowery and to convert the idle manpower of hundreds of "Bowery bums" into useful wartime labor opened yesterday and continued through the night. At 1:15 A.M., 229 vagrants, including two women, had been garnered into police stations for decontamination preparatory to their arraignment in Essex Market Court for study of their possibilities as war workers.

"I Married A Witch," co-starring Fredric March and Veronica Lake, will have its local premiere this morning at the Capitol. Rene Clair produced and directed the picture for United Artists release from an unfinished story by the late Thorne Smith, completed by Norman Matson.

Twenty-four girls studying retailing and home economics at New York University modeled yesterday a "patriotic wardrobe" of clothes borrowed from the college shop of Abraham Straus. Three hundred guests attended the showing.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Life is fast returning to normal in Algeria and Morocco under the "hands-off" policy of the American military commanders in those territories. The local administration will, wherever possible, be entrusted to the same persons who handled it before the campaign.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 18 (AP) -- On Location, 84-to-1 shot from the Humphries and Collins Stable, broke in front in the second race at Rockingham Park today and led all the way to pay $170.60 for $2. Covering the six furlongs in 1:16 3-5 on a muddy track, On Location returned $102.40 to place and $43.80 to show.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- How a 26-year-old New Yorker, Captain John D. Le Vien, a public relations officer, found himself leading street fighting in a small town in North Africa instead of preparing "handouts" about the scrap for distribution to reporters was recounted today in a letter received from him by friends in London.

The Office of Price Administration put the American housewife on her honor yesterday to buy no more than one pound of coffee -- if she can get it -- in preparation for the seven-day drought in retail sales for home use, due to begin Saturday midnight.

Returning to action yesterday after a four-day layoff, the City College squad went through a long drill at Lewisohn Stadium in preparation for the Thanksgiving Day replay of last week's 7-7 tie with Brooklyn College.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 18 (AP) -Federal Judge William F. Smith signed today a show-cause order on the request of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for an opinion whether the company might negotiate agreements with other companies for the use of its catalytic refining processes.

Pearl Buck warned yesterday that "in this war are already being sown the seeds of the next war" and called upon the people of America to sacrifice their prejudices and intolerances along with their sugar and gasoline. Asserting that a permanent peace must be based on the principle of equality for all peoples, she declared:

Bobbs-Merrill has announced the "forty-fifth anniversary edition" of a book -- Ralph Waldo Trine's "In Tune With the Infinite." Reissued at a time when religious books are in more demand than in many years, this statement of how the individual through meditation can "tap a greater spiritual power" will contain a new message by the author on coping with the anxiety of today's world.

Announcing the addition of 100,000 net tons to the Bethlehem Steel Company's annual steel producing capacity by the completion of two open-hearth furnaces on the Pacific Coast. Eugene G. Grace, president, said yesterday in a message to employes that present peak production was "not good enough."

Presentation of evidence in proceedings for the removal of William Griffin to face conspiracy charges in Washington was ended yesterday before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter. The commissioner allowed government and defense counsel a week to submit briefs, after which he will decide whether the publisher of The New York Enquirer should be required to face trial in Washington.

The concentration program for civilian industries was sharply attacked yesterday as a form of regimentation that can be the "kiss of death for the America we have known," by Walter D. Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company and chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, in an address at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York.

Our naval victory in the Solomons increases the difficulties of Japan's position in New Guinea. This position was already bad, with General MacArthur's forces closing in on Buna from two directions. But the Japanese chose to concentrate their available power in the drive against Guadalcanal, apparently hoping to deal later with the situation in Papua.

AGRA, India, Nov. 13 (Delayed) -- The British must do something constructive and do it soon, Pandit Rajnath Kunzru, one of India's well known "elder statesmen" told your correspondent today during a long talk.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 18 -- Although units of the British Eighth Army were only seventy miles away, the Germans appeared to be intent yesterday on hanging on to Bengazi until the last minute.

The stock market managed yesterday to present a firmer front, but only after considerable hesitation, during which cross-currents ran through the list. The temporary halt in selling for tax purposes was credited primarily with the development of a steadier tone, although year-end sales cropped out in some of the low-priced public utilities.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

Action by the city to contest the jurisdiction of the War Labor Board over the dispute between the Board of Transportation and the 32,000 employes of the unified transit lines over wages, hours and working conditions was forecast yesterday.

Maximum prices on various grades of anti-freeze mixtures, which a retailer may not exceed but which he may cut, were called to the attention of motorists yesterday by H.W. Bissell, district price executive of the Office of Price Administration.

The producers of "Wine, Women and Song" are entitled to a jury trial in General Sessions on charges of producing an indecent and immoral performance, Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer ruled yesterday, granting their motion to transfer their trial to General Sessions, before a jury, instead of the trial that had been scheduled in Special Sessions before three justices.

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 79,418,000 barrels, an increase of 180,000 over the 79,238,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago, these stocks were 83,683,000 barrels.

Japan made her broadest admission of naval losses of the war yesterday, apparently recognizing the futility of attempting to hide her disaster in the Solomons, but linked it with fantastic claims of damage inflicted in order to make the news as palatable as possible, according to The Associated Press.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY in the Jebel-El-Achdar, Libya, Nov. 16 (Delayed) -- British columns pushed on today through the green mountains of Cyrenaica in torrential rainstorms that made progress difficult. Except for Arabs, the whole region was deserted.

Five hundred thousand 'teen-age girls throughout the United States, many of whom belong to no youth service organization, will get an opportunity to join the Girl Scouts during the coming year, in accordance with expansion plans announced yesterday at Girl Scout national headquarters, 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 18 -- Extensive rehabilitation of some key lines of the Mexican national railways will be carried out jointly by Mexico and the United States to expedite Mexico's war efforts, following an exchange of notes today in Mexico City between Ezequiel Padilla, Mexican Foreign Minister, and George S. Messersmith, American Ambassador.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Camille Chautemps, former Premier of France under the republic, made the following statement today to THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Putting the wasting of manpower on the home production front on the "criminal" level of wasting critical materials, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, gave enthusiastic support today to legislation which would mobilize the nation's technological resources under a single independent agency.

Alexander Vilalta, Spanish pianist, gave his second New York recital last night in Town Hall. At his previous appearance in the same auditorium, last May, Mr. Vilalta was heard in a program devoted entirely to works by composers of his native land.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- German tank and infantry attacks on the factory district of Stalingrad, which the Nazis are trying to capture for Winter headquarters, were beaten off again yesterday and counter-attacking Russians seized several strong points, the Red Army announced early today.

Under the watchful eyes of Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, Chalky Wright yesterday completed hard training at Valley Stream, L.I., for the fifteen-round bout in which he will defend his world featherweight championship tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden against Willie Pep, Hartford challenger.

Most New York department stores probably will proceed with initial plans for January "white" sales, since advance preparations which include newspaper advertising schedules and printed circulars were completed before the Quartermaster General's office took over all supplies at mills this week for urgent military needs.

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries showed a consolidated net income of $27,514,668 equal to $3.17 a share on 8,674,338 capital shares, in its preliminary statement for the first nine months of 1942, issued for publication today.

The Prudential Insurance Company, which last week invited three banking groups to bid on a block of $5,990,000 of Nashville, Tenn., electric power revenue 2 1/4 per cent bonds, held in its investment portfolio, and later rejected all bids, sold the bonds yesterday to a combined syndicate comprising members of the three former groups.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 18 -- Foreign Minister Oswaldo Arhana reiterated today his statement of a week ago that in recognizing any de facto government in the French colonies Brazil would act in collaboration with the United States.

Lieut. Comdr. Louis Marcel LeHardy, who was on the staff of the late Rear Admiral Daniel J. Callaghan, was killed in action aboard the heavy cruiser San Francisco on Friday in the Solomon Islands area, according to word received here yesterday by his brother-inlaw, Ward Morehouse of the staff of The New York Sun.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -Leaders of the Congressional movement to forestall country-wide gasoline rationing expressed optimism today over the possibility of at least a ninety-day suspension of the program scheduled to go into effect Dec. 1.

For forty years now Greenwich House has been performing a neighborhood and a national service. Its neighborhood service has earned it an indispensable place in the constructive life and growth of this city. Its national service has been to help prove to the whole country that the melting pot still works its democratic miracle and that the city street can be made as fruitful a proving ground for future citizenship as the village green.

Plans to canvass virtually every person and every business establishment in Manhattan possessed of an account in a commercial bank in connection with the nation-wide drive next month to sell upward of $6,000,000,000 of new government securities were adopted yesterday at a meeting of the presidents of the forty-seven commercial banks and trust companies in the borough with the New York Victory Fund Committee at the Federal Reserve Bank.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Mrs. Roosevelt told her press conference today that she had learned "a tremendous amount" on her tour of wartime Britain, and that from it she had brought back "any number of ideas for the United States -- so many that we will have to take them up later, one at a time."

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 18 -- The Church of St. Stephen, in which Christopher Columbus was baptised, was severely damaged during the latest Royal Air Force bombing of Genoa, according to the Italian review Primato, out today.

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service here, took issue yesterday with Mayor La Guardia on draft deferments of policemen and firemen, quoting figures furnished by Police Commissioner Valentine to show that the draft had not impaired the municipal force.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Pierre Laval, who has thrown in his chips for a German victory, was made fascist dictator of Vichy France and designated successor to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain tonight. Observers predicted a new terror reign and a desperate Laval effort to swing France militarily into the Axis fold.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Faced with war demands beyond the apparent ability of farmers to supply, the War Production Board's Food Requirements Committee is expected soon to recommend civilian rationing of cheese and butter, fluid milk in larger cities and a curtailment of manufacture of ice cream.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Another of the American Football Statistical Bureau's prize modern records is headed for the discard -- threatened not by one team but by four.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Dovetailing neatly into the United Nations plan covering North African operations, United States Flying Fortresses and Liberators crossed the English Channel today to bomb U-boat bases at Lorient and La Pallice in France.
The Brothers Collyer -- Homer and Langley -- maintained their weird isolation in the faded old brownstone at 2078 Fifth Avenue yesterday, but at a price.

Dr. Eduardo Lopez, a one-man mission to this country from Colombia, where his brother, Alfonzo, is President, said yesterday that the United States could get 3,000 tons of raw rubber each month from his country if it set up air freight lines and paid an increased price.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A fully mechanized Allied column of at least 10,000 men, mostly Fighting French equipped with American machines, is driving northward toward the Axis rear in Western Libya from the Lake Chad region, deep in the Sahara, authoritative reports said tonight. Lake Chad is in Fighting French-controlled Equatorial Africa, one of the first colonial possessions to declare its allegiance to General Charles de Gaulle.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Roosevelt gave orders today for the registration between Dec. 11 and Dec. 31 of those youths, possibly 600,000, who have turned 18 since July 1, and provided for the continued day-by-day registration of those who reach draft age after the first of the year.

Two items in the same day's news show the baffling nature of the period through which we are living. Mayor La Guardia has arranged with Donald Nelson for the removal of 15,000 tons of unused steel rails from New York's streets. Steel is painfully scarce, critically necessary to the war effort and can't be left idle.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 18 -- Will Tripoli be taken?

There will be several things strange to Missouri eyes when they look across a scrimmage line at Fordham on Saturday. And all of it will not be because a good many of the Maroon youngsters have changed into other kinds of uniforms since the day the Tigers met the Rams in the Sugar Bowl.
MIAMI, Nov. 18 -- Miami's horse and dog track operators, already beset by wartime racing problems, got a scare over gasoline rationing today, but it proved short-lived.

They did all right until it came to the soy beans. And then it was the fearful calory, not the taste, that caused most of the women at a "Victory Luncheon" yesterday to hesitate. Only courtesy nibbles were accorded to the new companion to the famous Boston bean.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, told the House of Commons today that recent Allied successes had assuredly given solid reasons for a more confident outlook for the future, but he warned against overconfidence, saying that a stern, uphill fight still lay ahead, and he exhorted workers in war production plants to toil harder than ever to increase output.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Axis troops and Allied armies are deploying on the plains and mountains of Tunisia tonight for the coming clash, the outcome of which may decide the fate of Bizerte, the strategically vital naval base at the northernmost tip of Africa, and the control of the Mediterranean.

UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Algeria, Nov. 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- British-manned American-made planes figured in a strange submarine-airplane battle in the Mediterranean in which a U-boat was knocked out after she had damaged four attacking bombers, it was disclosed today.

Anthony Cramer was convicted at 7:54 o'clock last night of treason. The verdict which exposes the 42-year-old mechanic to the death penalty was returned just four days short of five months from that evening of June 22 when Cramer first kept a rendezvous with Werner Thiel, one of the eight Nazi saboteurs who were sent here in German submarines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The importance of the Navy's victory over the Japanese in the Solomon Islands in a three-day engagement that ended last Sunday gained new emphasis today in the tone of congratulatory messages that Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox dispatched to Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, and Vice Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., commander of United States Naval Forces in the South Pacific.

Two answers were found yesterday to the service man's problem of how to "get something for mother and a gift for a girl," send a few postcards, write some letters and have a "coke" and a sandwich, all in the space of one fleeting hour.
A Imperial Headquarters announcement broadcast from Tokyo and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company continued yesterday its quarterly dividend rate of $2.25 a share, thereby putting to rest for at least another three months anxiety on the part of its 635,000 stockholders as to maintenance of the annual $9 dividend, which has been in effect since 1922.

Mrs. Roosevelt returns from her visit to Britain with a message for American women. They can help shorten the war, she says, by exertions and sacrifices, ranging all the way from doing without bobby pins to working in factories. It was evident to her, as doubtless it is to every American visitor who goes where she went, that life has been drastically altered there as it has not been here.

Because strict enforcement of the Multiple Dwelling Law under present conditions would force an estimated 250,000 New Yorkers out of their homes, a bill will be submitted at the next session of the Legislature to permit the New York City Department of Housing and Buildings to defer compliance with the law until Jan. 1, 1944, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The Morocco radio broadcast tonight the text of a letter written by General Henri Honore Giraud to his children from the fortress of Koanigstein in Germany, where he was a prisoner of war until he escaped.

In this total war all men, women and children must work together for final, glorious victory. Working directly with the War Department, women take their place beside the soldier in the Anti-Aircraft Artillery Command and the Air-craft Warning Service.

A food "scandal far greater than the rubber situation" looms unless a food administrator is appointed to coordinate the wartime needs of the food industry, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, declared yesterday at the opening session of the group's thirty-fourth annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 18 -Addressing a gathering in Wuppertal, in the Rhineland, after he had inspected the ruins of Duisburg, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Minister of Propaganda, told his listeners that the Reich had every reason to be proud of their exemplary conduct under British bombings.

Strawberries in November? Yes, indeed -- amazingly plump ones with gleaming scarlet cheeks that proclaim their abundant good health. Take home a heart-shaped basket for Thanksgiving betweenmeal nibbling, for, you see, they are not really fruit at all, but soft, smooth marzipan.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Not only has President Roosevelt's statement on Admiral Francois Darlan satisfied the British people, but it also moved a Fighting French spokesmen to observe today that "the perplexed Frenchmen in metropolitan France will be encouraged rather than disheartened."
The Office of Naval Officer Procurement, 33 Pine Street, issued an appeal yesterday for qualified women to serve as Waves in the Naval Hospital Corps.

Slingin' Sammy Baugh's brilliant passing performance against the Giants last Sunday at the Polo Grounds, where he completed nineteen heaves in twenty-six attempts, enabled the Washington ace to boost his lead over Cecil Isbell of the Green Bay Packers in their duel for aerial honors in the National Football League.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 -Coach Howie Odell sent the Yale varsity squad through its last scrimmage of the campaign today. Dave Colwell's jayvees were on the attack, driving against the regulars with Harvard sweeps so that the latter could get their final chance of stopping Coach Dick Harlow's plays in practice.

Following a final conference which made it inevitable that the two parties involved would have to reach a decision soon or drop from sheer exhaustion, Branch Rickey new president of the Dodgers, announced yesterday that he had renamed Leo Durocher manager of the Flatbush Flock for 1943.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET, in the South Pacific, Nov. 8 (UP) (Delayed) -- A naval officer who has directed air operations in two major engagements said today that the United States holds aerial supremacy in the Pacific as far as navy and army planes can reach.

The departure of "Count Me In" from the Barrymore has been moved ahead a week to tomorrow evening. This will mark the fiftythird performance of the musical comedy, in which Charles Butterworth and Luella Gear are appearing.

A letter from Secretary of State Cordell Hull, asserting that the United States "does not recognize as a sovereign individual government any regime which Germany may permit to function in Metropolitan France," was filed in Federal court yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Rudolph Mobley and Camp Wilson of unbeaten Hardin-Simmons are well on their way to becoming the top two ball carriers of 1942 football.

The entire third floor in the Emmett Building at 95 Madison Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street, has been leased by Charles Bloom, Inc., dealer in fabrics and art novelties, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., the managing agent of the building, who reports it 100 per cent rented as a result of this contract.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Nine men were killed when two Navy patrol planes met over Pensacola Bay, the Naval Air Station officials said here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The War Department will form a special battalion of Austrians who have indicated a desire to fight with the American forces against Germany, Secretary Stimson stated today.

For the last few years Thanksgiving has been coming early, and the children at Lenox Hill House, one of the city's largest settlement houses, have been entertained with turkey dinners, and those families in greatest need have received baskets of food.
Pert pompons and their big brothers, the chrysanthemums, still hold the center of the stage in the city's flower shops this weekend, as they are expected to do until the end of the year.
" Nothing of importance can be won in peace which has not already been won in the war itself." This statement by Mr. Willkie, in a speech Nov. 16. should be taken to heart by every American.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- Admiral Lee, who commanded the battleship engagement reported in today's Navy communique, is a native of Natlee, Ky., but now makes his home on Owenton, Ky. Prior to his appointment to a command at sea last February he was assistant chief of staff to the commander in chief of the United States fleet.
The ninth National Conference on Labor Legislation has endorsed a forty-eight-hour working week -- provided that time-and-a-half pay is retained for all hours over forty.

The buying power of the Negro population of this country amounts to $7,000,000,000 to $10,000,000,000 annually, it was reported yesterday at a panel discussion on the Negro market sponsored by the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The War Production Board permitted the railroads today to order 250 steam and thirty-six Diesel locomotives for delivery in the first eight months of next year and 100 switching Diesels for delivery in the first six months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission said today that the Pacific Bridge Company of Alameda, Calif., which recently claimed a shipbuilding record by launching a small cargo ship eighty hours after keel-laying, was about five months behind schedule.
MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

The Young Women's Christian Association is doing much for men and women in all branches of the armed forces with its hospitality and recreation program, Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow said yesterday at the New York Y.W.C.A. campaign report luncheon at 600 Lexington Avenue.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Leon Henderson warned today that standardized and simplified civilian goods and more extensive rationing of many kinds of consumer products would be required next year. The Price Administrator told the New England War Conference that Victory models would be increasingly necessary.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- A rise of $14,000,000 in combined net profits of ten of the nation's leading manufacturers of agricultural machinery and tractors in 1941 after all charges was reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 19 (AP) -- A stock transaction which would have given to a group of New York financiers control of the American Cities Power and Light Corporation and Blue Ridge Corporation fell through today when Judge Robert N. Pollard in Federal District Court refused to order a show cause hearing on the proposed sale of a large block of American Cities stock now in the possession of Central States Electric Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman, chairman of the special Senate investigating committee, said today the Department of Justice had been asked to investigate construction of defense housing at Winfield, N.J.

Industry must learn how to control the movement of goods unless producers are ready to risk rigid regulation of transportation, Joseph B. Eastman, director, Office of Defense Transportation, indicated yesterday. Government authorities prefer to let industry work out its own solution of the cross-hauling problem which arises as a result of wartime needs, but is frankly skeptical of industry's willingness or ability to do so, he declared.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- A realignment of the screen cast of "Best Foot Forward," putting Lana Turner back into the leading role, was announced today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. Miss Turner had originally been assigned to the part of Gale Joy, the movie actress, which Rosemary Lane played on Broadway, but she had been replaced by Judy Garland, who in turn was supplanted by Lucille Ball.
Lou Little sat in his office at John Jay Hall yesterday and ruminated sadly over the vagaries of the season that ends for Columbia tomorrow against Dartmouth at Baker Field.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- The most interesting Yale football team of the last few years is resting on its arms, awaiting the arrival of its ancient friendly enemy, Harvard.

For more than a week the fighting in Africa and around the Solomons has held world-wide attention. Russia nearly vanished from American front pages -- rightly so if we go by reader interest at the moment. For the Nazis it was another story. Facing the Soviet armies they feared them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, who took over the Philippine defenses after General MacArthur was assigned to command in the Southwest Pacific, has been awarded the Distinctive Service Medal, oak leaf cluster, the War Department announced tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Most sections of today's stock market were quiet with the exception of the foreign group, where Japanese bonds and Brazilian issues were active. Profit-taking in Japanese bonds occured just before the close resulting in net declines up to 30s but Brazilians hardened.

While studying the map of North Africa on the front page of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 18 captioned "Allies Make for Tunisian Objectives," I noted a surprisingly exact representation of the Winged Victory of Samothrace, depicted by some of the map's outlines.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have massed 30,000 men west of the Salween River in Yunnan Province for a drive eastward against Kunming, strategic city of China's air supply route from India, and other enemy troops are poised in occupied Indo-China for a concurrent push from the south, a Chinese military spokesman disclosed today.

Generalissimo Francisco Franco of Spain has informed both the Axis and the United Nations that Spain immediately would accept aid from the other side if any of her sea and air bases were seized, advices reaching The Associated Press from informed European diplomatic sources reported last night.

MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 20 -- The Red Army, scoring a smashing victory in the Orjonikidze area of the Central Caucasus, has killed 5,000 German troops and routed the Nazi divisions spearheading the drive toward the vital Georgian highway, a special Soviet communique revealed last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- This country's aircraft production goal for next year will be more than double the present monthly rate of output, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told a press conference today. The assumption of the offensive by the United Nations in North Africa and in the Pacific made revision of the war production program essential.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Peace overtures, backed up by threats and calling for a conditional surrender by an evident majority of the Senate, broke into the sixth day of the filibuster against the poll-tax repeal bill today, but one member, Chandler of Kentucky, prevented the armistice which appeared to assure defeat of the bitterly contested measure.

Urgent selling by professional traders near the close in the cotton futures market yesterday after publication of recommendations by the agricultural commissioners of several States that farm restrictions be lifted for the duration of the war, sent the list to the session's low levels and final net losses of 2 to 13 points, with the distant contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange weakest.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Nov. 19 -- For the first time in the Southwestern Pacific the United Nations in recent weeks have had aerial superiority over the Japanese. This superiority has been evidenced in New Guinea by almost unchallenged Allied control of the air and in the Solomons by a dominance which has been qualitative, if not always quantitative.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Those who may find themselves unable to pay the first installment of their income tax when March 15 rolls around were urged today by John R. Sullivan, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, to make arrangements with their income-tax collector to meet it in installments out of their wage or salary.

The theatre and the better forms of music are growing like Darby and Joan. Not long ago the New Opera Company gave its benign blessing to the version of "Die Fledermaus" now known as "Rosalinda" and last evening Saul Colin brought to the Alvin an edition of "The Barber of Seville" called "Once Over Lightly."

The shoe trade yesterday questioned reports that there would be any rationing of their product during 1943 because of the effectiveness of the WPB style restriction order. It was pointed out that retail buyers and consumers have shown no resistance to the curtailment of colors or manufacturing restrictions and that the saving of sole leather thus created will stall any limitation of offerings to the consumer for at least another year.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 -- Less cumbersome wartime restrictions on rents and building, further decentralization of Federal bureaus to make room for expansion of war activity in the nation's capital and continuance of private home construction will be sought by the National Association of Real Estate Boards to keep the industry going during the war.

Wendell L. Willkie characterized last night the filibuster in the Senate against the poll tax bill as "a perversion of the legislative process." Speaking at a meeting of the Newspaper Guild of New York, he said:

MOULTRIE, Ga., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Two aviation cadets and a British pilot officer stationed at Spence Field here were killed today when their planes crashed in mid-air while on a routine training flight about eight miles east of Moultrie.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 19 -- A British promise to assist Egypt in getting a fair representation at the peace conference after the war was revealed today by Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha in a speech from the throne on the occasion of the reopening of the Egyptian Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- As Commander in Chief in time of war, President Roosevelt gave orders today to Montgomery Ward Co., Chicago mail order house, to comply with a War Labor Board union-security ruling which the company has rejected as economically unsound and illegal.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Nov. 19 -- It's a long way from the now extinct Press Building at the recent World's Fair to a tiny atoll in the South Pacific. But a man's dream laughs at time and space.

Because of lack of funds, it will be impossible to put into practice the special educational services needed in "problem areas" such as are found in parts of Harlem and other sections of the city, the Board of Superintendents declared yesterday in approving a report on means of improving educational facilities, headed by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof of the Board of Education.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, Nov. 20 -- Heavy bombers of General Douglas MacArthur's command sank a Japanese light cruiser and blew to pieces a destroyer which were caught last night trying to aid enemy ground troops now trapped by United States and Australian soldiers in the Buna-Gona area of New Guinea.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- President Roosevelt has lost about 75 per cent of his prestige with the French masses as a result of his approval of Admiral Francois Darlan as High Commissioner for French North Africa in the opinion of Leon Morandat, an influential trade unionist official and leading figure in the French underground movement who has just arrived in Britain.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- President Roosevelt in a message to the New England War Conference said today that "free exchange of ideas through regional discussion" throughout the country could aid in the conduct of the war and preparation for a better post-war world.

On the sound theory that the Giants can stop the Packers at the Polo Grounds on Sunday only if they can stop Don Hutson, Stout Steve Owen has arranged for a unique system of providing a permanent escort for the Alabama Antelope.

The quality of mercy is stronger than the rigors of the law. In Brooklyn three justices of the Court of Special Sessions imposed prison sentences on two operators of a Brooklyn dairy store with a suggestion that they serve their terms consecutively so that one of the two men, who are partners in the business, can continue its operation while the other serves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Office of Price Administration predicted today that consumers will save from 3 to 20 cents a garment shortly as a result of an action it took today. The OPA issued a new maximum price regulation No. 273 in which it requires that savings in material costs of knitted underwear due to the necessary wartime substitution of less expensive carded yarn for combed yarn be passed on to the consumer.

ORAN, Algeria, Nov. 18 (delayed) (AP) -- French troops of the Oran division in full battle gear entrained for the east today to join the Allied fight against the Axis in Tunisia amid scenes evoking memories of 1918.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, Nov. 17 (Delayed) -- We with a British armored unit that has been on the move with scarcely any respite, and then seldom more than fourteen hours at a time, since the last full moon, when General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery ordered our offensive to begin.
J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, received the Gold Medal of the Holland Society last night at the fifty-eighth annual dinner of the organization at the Hotel Plaza.

Fordham finished heavy preparation for tomorrow's game against Missouri at the Polo Grounds with a two-hour practice yesterday on Fordham Field. The afternoon work was followed by a blackboard lecture and signal drill in the gymnasium last night.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in North Africa, Nov. 19 -- American Army Flying Fortresses flew unusually low through rain and light flack when bombing in the first move to clear a way for the British First Army's march through Tunisia.
THE emissary from the office of Uncle Mike Jacobs, the boxing impresario, came bustling up to this desk with an air of importance fringed with excitement.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Strict control over the economic factors of international life after the war must be made the subject of much closer study than was the case after World War I, Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Premier of South Africa, wrote in a letter read today at a meeting of the general council of the League of Nations Union.

International disaster threatens unless the Administration takes immediate steps to coordinate the intricate operations of America's vast and sprawling food industry during the wartime emergency, Morris Sayre, executive vice president of the Corn Products Refining Company, asserted yesterday.

A check of retail butchers in the metropolitan area was started yesterday by the Office of Price Administration to make sure that prices for Thanksgiving turkey do not exceed the ceilings that went into effect last week.

Assuming that all women, like Pandora and Mrs. Bluebeard, are inquisitive, and that they are curious to know for example, what happens to the outworn and torn hosiery they are turning in, the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office of Greater New York has outlined the processes by which the stockings are put to war uses.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 19 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain tonight broadcast an appeal to French officers, especially in North Africa, to obey his orders and "resist Anglo-Saxon aggression."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A full-fledged House revolt against nation-wide gasoline rationing crystallized tonight as 100 Western and Midwestern Representatives met in caucus and unanimously adopted a resolution calling for ninety-day postponement of nation-wide curtailment, scheduled to begin Dec. 1.

ore than 600 policemen, including fifty Police Department officials, attended a funeral service yesterday for Acting Deputy Chief Inspector James F. 2V[cGrath in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in West Brighton, S. I. In[spector McGrath died early [onday in the Staten Island Hospital after a long illness.
The guerrilla forces of General Draja Mikhailovitch, which have been "fighting the good fight" against the Axis conquerors of Yugoslavia, probably number somewhere between 35,000 and 100,000 men.

The Bowery Savings Bank has sold to the Victor Holding Corporation the seven-family and store building at 4820 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, through Eugene J. Kelly, Inc., broker. The building is on a plot 26 by 100 feet, and is assessed for $30,000.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- Bendix Aviation Corporation, commenting on a Federal suit filed today in Newark, N.J., charging it with violating anti-trust and tariff laws, said the action involves agreements which are inoperative and moot because of the war and "is nothing short of tragic because the defense of the company will consume much time that is needed for the war effort."

A German who tried to sell the United States Government an apparently highly desirable anti-freeze compound, in a possible step toward disabling every airplane or other engine in which it might be used, was in Federal custody yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Members of the American Finance Conference, at the concluding session of their ninth annual meeting, were told today by one speaker that the postwar demand for automobiles might tax their resource and by another that taxes and other influences might hold buying power down and reduce purchases of all kinds of installment sale items correspondingly.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, including those here, gained substantially in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday, but this did not preclude further open-market purchases of government securities for account of the twelve central banks.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 12 (Delayed) -- The swift and cheap occupation of Algiers was due as much to the work of scores of British intelligence agents and hundreds of patriotic French men and women as to the skillful attacks on the east and west of the city by United States and British forces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The smashing victory achieved by our naval forces in the Solomon Islands sector last week grew even larger today with the receipt of a new report announcing the sinking of one battleship or heavy cruiser, three large cruisers and one destroyer, together with the damaging of one battleship, one cruiser and one destroyer by a task force that included American battleships.

Declaring that the city's "essential" services are being crippled by the loss of highly trained men to the armed forces, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of a local manpower commission whose function for the present will be to place before local draft boards requests for deferment of such employes.

Dock workers of the International Longshoremen's Association will receive an increase in hourly and overtime pay under a negotiated agreement just approved by the War Labor Board, it was announced here last night.

One clue to the present state of mind of the German people can be found in the communiques which the German High Command is now issuing about the fighting in North Africa. From the very start of the British campaign in Egypt the High Command has kept the truth from the German people.

Women's history-making, allover war activities were corralled for the first time yesterday as the ninteenth Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries got away to a brilliant start in Madison Square Garden.

The German High Command declared yesterday that the resurgent Red Army had gone from defensive warfare to violent new attacks in the Caucasus, along the Don, south of Leningrad and on the Rybachi Peninsula at the northernmost end of the Russian Finnish frontier.
UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- controversy over a $15,000,000 Puerto Rican food bill was renewed tonight in a wordy exchange. between Secretary Ickes and Bolivar Pagan, Puerto Rican Resident Commissioner in Congress.

Thirteen civilian auxiliary firemen who are standing watches at the firehouse of Engine Company 65 at 33 West Forty-third Street gave a demonstration of their prowess in dashing to a fire last night as the Fire Department showed how civilians can help fight fires.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The assignment of Major Gen. Henry J.F. Miller of Miami, Fla., commanding general of the Air Service Command, to head the Air Service Command in the European theatre was announced today by Secretary Stimson.

The prices that city housekeepers will pay for Thanksgiving turkeys and other holiday birds were announced yesterday by a spokesman for the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. In almost every instance they are appreciably higher than the figures quoted last season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Absolute truth in war news, even if the complete facts may be delayed to confuse the enemy, was pledged tonight by Elmer Davis, Director of War Information, in a radio speech over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The peoples fighting against Axis domination of the world never can fully repay the Russian people for their contribution to the struggle, Senator Albert D. Thomas of Utah declared last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of Russian war relief.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The turn of the tide for the United Nations from North Africa to the Solomons, plus Reichsfuehrer Hitler's strategic errors and party favoritisms, were reported here today to have led a strong group of dissident German generals into a subversive movement to sacrifice Herr Hitler and the Nazis and gain a peace favorable to their own class.

The reluctance of the House Ways and Means Committee to accept without modification the Administration bill to permit the President to suspend all customs, immigration, tariff or espionage laws which impede the movement of persons, property or information across our borders in wartime is understandable.

DHOLPUR, India, Nov. 16 (Delayed) -- Five thousand years of history have passed lightly over this little corner of the Eastern Rajputana. Today one still finds here the eternal India with its autocratic ruler, its worshipping people, its faith in the transmigration of souls, and horoscopes and the influence of gems on human lives.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Participation in an international conspiracy to choke competition and peg prices in the aircraft accessory and instrument industry was charged against the Bendix Aviation Corporation of South Bend, Ind., in a suit filed in the United States District Court here today by the anti-trust division of the Justice Department.

The War Labor Board has no jurisdiction over disputes between cities and other governmental agencies and their civil service employes on wages, hours and working conditions, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in an address at the annual conference of the New Jersey League of Municipalities at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Whitney Museum will open on Tuesday afternoon its annual exhibition of contemporary American art. It has been the custom of the museum in recent years to divide this annual event into two separate exhibitions, one of oils the other of sculpture, water-colors, drawings and prints.

Many dinner parties will be given before the "Cheer China" midnight revue at the Radio City Music Hall tonight for the benefit of United China Relief. One of the largest will be given by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson and Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Tibbett, who later will take their guests to the benefit.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A joint British general headquarters and R.A.F. communique:

Directors of the International Harvester Company authorized yesterday a year-end dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31. The current dividend, which is payable on Dec. 15, brings total disbursements for the calendar year to $2.50, compared with $3 received by stockholders in 1941.

As salvage from the catastrophe of war will come opportunities for social and economic gains, it was declared last night at the meeting of the New York Academy of Public Education by Shelby M. Harrison, general director of the Russell Sage Foundation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 14 totaled 826,601 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,889 cars or 0.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 57,289 cars or 6.5 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 81,306 cars or 10.9 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (z) Passenger revenues of Class I railroads in October were almost two and one-half times as large as in the same month last year. the Association of American Railroads disclosed today in preliminary reports from eighty-five carriers representing 81 per cent of the total Class I mileage.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

The three-story dwelling at 179 East Eightieth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, has been sold by the Goshen Savings Bank to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, in a deal negotiated by E.H. Ludlow Co. It is on a lot 16.8 by 100 feet and was acquired by the bank about a month ago.

President Franklin D. Roosevelt is one of the private collectors who has lent prints of historical American naval actions to an exhibition portraying "The United States Navy, 1776-1815," which will be opened to the public today at the Grolier Club, 47 East Sixtieth Street.

Twelve surplus business properties of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company in Manhattan, the Bronx, Westchester County and Queens offered at auction yesterday by Joseph P. Day brought a total of $12,000. Spirited bidding marked the sale held in the Vesey Street Exchange, one parcel drawing twenty-eight offers before it was sold.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told 200 Detroit automotive and advertising executives today that the press of America and industry must guard the fundamentals of our system of free enterprise against encroachments of government.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 19 -- Long-shot players continued to have plenty of opportunities for fattening their wallets today. The fourth race, for 2-year-olds, drew the highest-priced platers on an all-claiming card that was jammed with entries and it produced a straight pay-off of $163.40 for $2 when Sammy Hicks's Toss Up scored by two lengths.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 19 -- Winding up a two-day tour of inspection of the Bermuda Base Command of the United States Army, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the Eastern Defense Command and First United States Army, told correspondents this morning that he found "very happy" conditions in the colony and said operations in North Africa were "very auspicious" and "a very fine beginning of the end."

For one period the Maple Leafs were unable to do anything right in their National Hockey League game with the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. In the next two frames, though, they found out exactly how to play the New York forces, and they scored a 7-to-3 triumph before 8,172 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Chiefs of the "Big Four" operating railroad unions and of the Switchmen's Union of North America will confer in Chicago Dec. 7 to canvass the situation prior to making demands for a wage increase on behalf of 350,000 rail employes.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Brooklyn Baseball Club, it was learned today, may lose another veteran infielder for the 1943 season -- Third Baseman Floyd E. (Arky) Vaughan.

Brooklyn College scrimmaged for three hours yesterday, continuing work on the series of new plays designed by Coach Lou Oshins as a variation of the regular T formation attack. The Kingsmen are preparing for their post-season game with C.C.N.Y. at Brooklyn College Field next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The State Department announced today a crowded nine-day program for the State visit of President Carlos Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador, who will come to Washington Monday as the guest of President Roosevelt.

After hearing attorneys defend racing sheets as "trade journals of the sporting world" and assail them as responsible for gambling and for "many broken hearts and homes," Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel reserved decision yesterday on the motion by a group of publishers of racing sheets for an injunction to restrain License Commissioner Paul Moss from banning the sheets from newsstands under his jurisdiction.

The impression upon the ear of the performances of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, last night in Carnegie Hall was not only exhilarating, it was positively cleansing. The careful intonation, so rare in these parts, was primarily responsible for the clearness and vibrancy of the tone.

The Hecker Products Corporation has purchased the General Food Corporation's 29 per cent ownership in the Best Foods, Inc., for $5,500,000 cash, thus obtaining 100 per cent control of this company in the interest of more effective operation, it was announced yesterday by William J. Wardall, chairman of Hecker Products.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Literally thousands of small companies which now have no share in Federal contracts will be working on war orders within a very short time, Lou E. Holland, head of the smaller war plants division of the War Production Board and deputy chairman of the WPB, promised newspaper men here today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19 -- Coach Dick Harlow drove his Harvard varsity squad today through its last Cambridge drill before the trip to New Haven tomorrow morning for Saturday's game with Yale. Like all the other practices this week, the session was entirely without contact work.

As the "old marshals" fade out of the murky picture of France. Petain at last fully eclipsed by Laval. Weygand arrested and taken to Germany, we see how one blow from outside finished the tragic masquerade of Vichy and reduced to final impotence, even as symbols, the leaders who struggled in the strangling noose of the armistice to speak in the name of the French people.

Every Flying Fortress ought to have a name of its own. If that had been the case the one whose adventures over and on the way home from Lille we read about yesterday would seem a little more personal and definite. Over Lille, where she was making a business call. Staff Sergeant De John was hit in the left side when a cannon shell struck his turret and disabled one of his guns.

Assurance that Fort Greene Houses, the State-aided development for housing workers in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, will be completed was given yesterday when it was disclosed that the War Production Board had granted for the project priorities for small additional quantities of critical materials to finish 2,635 dwelling units.

The presentation of a gold trefoil, official Girl Scout emblem, to a member of the Girl Scout national staff for the first time and appointments of new officers and reappointments of others marked the second of a two-day semi-annual meeting of the board of directors yesterday at Girl Scout national headquarters, 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 19 -- American and British mechanized units have smashed their way to within thirty-five miles of the Axis Tunisian stronghold of Bizerte after scattered clashes with German patrols.

Among the important changes in the scale of values of the British people who carried on and survived the Battle of Britain is that life itself and the understanding of one another are the only things that "really matter," and this realization must play a major part in post-war planning, Miss Kathleen Courtney, chairman of the general purposes committee of the London International Assembly, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Department store sales gained 13 per cent in the week ended Nov. 14, as compared with the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This contrasted with a gain of 20 per cent recorded in the previous week.

Under a further contraction in volume, the stock market charted again yesterday an irregular course with prices mixed. Even some favorable dividends among the railroad issues failed to generate real bullish interest. Brokers, in pointing to the apathy in the face of continued victorious war developments, appeared generally resigned to the opinion that the recent recovery of stocks had fully discounted the current African and Pacific news.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- National registration of women for war work was indicated today as probable before the end of the year by the Labor Victory Committee of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations after a conference with President Roosevelt.

Four persons who pleaded guilty to conspiracy to smuggle platinum out of this country to Portugal in violation of the National Defense Act were sentenced yesterday by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Federal Court, Brooklyn. Seven others were sentenced last month by Judge Marcus B. Campbell after they had been found guilty by a jury.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- Battle-scarred and battered, the gallant American light cruiser Boise came home from the war today, wearing proudly under her shell-pocked bridge six newly painted Japanese flags as symbols of the enemy warships she sent to the bottom of the Pacific off Guadalcanal Island, in the Solomons, in a night battle on Oct. 11-12.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- American Flying Fortresses are leading the way to an expected quick victory over the Axis forces. There are so many of the big bombers now in North Africa that Axis air strength is being completely overwhelmed -- and there are more on the way.
Manhattan's football squad of thirty-four players will entrain this morning for Worcester, where the Jaspers will end their season against Holy Cross at Fitton Field tomorrow.

A tapestry in memory of "great teachers of Teachers College, Columbia University," was presented to the college in a ceremony yesterday afternoon by Miss Dana Gatchell, professor and head of the Food and Nutrition Department at Alabama Polytechnic Institute, who majored in home economics at the Columbia institution from 1915 to 1928.

SALEM, Ore., Nov. 19 -- Governor Charles A. Sprague tonight termed the death of forty-seven Oregon State Insane Asylum inmates from eating poisoned eggs "mass murder" and said that "the poison was evidently added in the preparation of the food."

A Soviet importation, "Mashenka," will have its local premiere at the Stanley Theatre this morning. The love story, which moves from a peacetime setting to the battlefields of Russia's northern front, features Valentina Karavayeva and Mikhail Kuznetzov.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A "don't travel drive" has been started by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 19 -- Spain's partial mobilization when completed will bring the fighting strength of the nation to an approximate peak of 1,000,000 men under arms, according to a dispatch from Madrid received here today.

Discussing this country's role in shaping the world's future in the post-war period, Mrs. Neyan Watts Stevens, world traveler and observer of international affairs, asserted yesterday at the Women's National Republican Club that "we must not revert to isolationism" and that we should establish a permanent "working relationship" with Russia.

Both sides rested yesterday in the first degree murder trial of Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21-year-old mother of four small children, and it is expected that the case will go to the jury on Monday. Lawyers will sum up today in Bronx County Court.

An opponent reading Mr. Willkie's speech before the Herald Tribune Forum must have rubbed his hands and soliloquized the famous words: "Oh, that mine adversary had written a book!" Mr. Willkie has done almost that, via radio.
LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Bank of England's condition statement, issued today, showed that note circulation was within 15,000,000 of the authorized fiduciary total issue of 880,000,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Doug Bentley jammed in three goals to lead the Black Hawks to a 6-to-2 victory over the Red Wings tonight before 10,035 fans.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Governors of the six New England States, after conferring with Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, announced today that "a completely perilous fuel oil shortage" was in prospect and immediately telegraphed all New England members of Congress that it was imperative that oil and gasoline be rationed on a national basis.

The first aggressive step in the wage dispute between the American Guild of Variety Artists and Leon Eddie's was taken yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Edison, when high-ranking members of all entertainer unions adopted a resolution publicly condemning the working conditions of the night club.

The 1943 dateline tags to be attached next year to 1942 automobile license plates in New York State as a war economy measure are row in production and the first batch will be ready in a week or two, it was disclosed yesterday by State Motor Vehicle Commissioner John Splain.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Princeton's varsity football forces polished all phases of their game and went through a brief passing scrimmage against the jayvees as intensive training for Saturday's game with Army at the Yankee Stadium in New York ended on University Field today.

Plans to promote "Music for Victory" were discussed yesterday at the Liberty District Forum of the National Federation of Music Clubs, Inc., at the Henry Hudson Hotel. There followed a luncheon and musicale in which young American artists took part.

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- Sultan Sidi Mohammed today pledged complete cooperation with the American Army in French Morocco. A similar pledge also was given by the French Resident General, Charles Auguste Norgues.

Yesterday afternoon was the occasion of celebrating in the recently opened Helene Lyolene School of Design and Dressmaking, 9 Rockefeller Plaza. Madame Lyolene. former well-known member of the Paris Couture, was receiving friends at a late afternoon party.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 -- W.G. Swigert, president of the Pacific Bridge Company, said today that Rear Admiral Vickery's criticism of his company's performance "came as a great surprise, as we are doing everything possible to further the war effort."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Following is tire text of the Navy's account of the part played by the light cruiser Boise in the Battle of the Solomons:

Representative and Mrs. Joseph Clark Baldwin of this city and Washington gave a dance last night in the roof garden of the Pierre to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Fanny T. Baldwin. The host and hostess entertained with a dinner at the hotel before the dance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Pierre Laval, newly endowed with the broadest powers as Chief of the Vichy Government, was again denounced by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today as a Hitlerite.

Irwin L. Moore, president of International Hydro Electric System, announced yesterday a net profit of $461,519 after Federal taxes for the third quarter of 1942, comparing with a net loss of $480,491 in the 1941 period. For twelve months ended Sept. 30 net profit was $248,154, comparing with a net profit of $9,259 in the preceding twelve months.

The New York County grand jury handed up a misdemeanor indictment late yesterday afternoon charging three executives of the show, "Wine, Women and Song," at the Ambassador Theater in West Forty-ninth Street, with giving an indecent performance on Oct. 30.

A blue-ribbon jury in Kings County Court brought in a verdict of guilty of murder in the second degree at 2:10 o'clock this morning against the two "zoot suit" slayers of Erwin Goodman, 36-year-old mathematics teacher, in William J. Gaynor High School in Brooklyn on Oct. 2.
Three Marine Corps flying officers, veterans of the Guadalcanal fighting, told their stories of combat yesterday at an interview in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Despite transportation problems, the Cubans hope to hold their annual series of international racing with the Star Class sloops this Winter. The Havana Yacht Club has set the week of Jan. 23-30 for the contests and the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association has approved the dates.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

HUGH BYAS and Harold Denny have rendered distinguished service to this newspaper for many years. This week sees them both conforming to the unwritten law that makes a foreign correspondent feel conspicuous and eccentric if he doesn't produce a book in jig time about the battle front or the nation that he covered. Both of their books are interesting and valuable additions to the literature of the war.
The Symington-Gould Corporation, manufacturer of railroad equipment, reported yesterday for the nine months ended with September, net profit of $741,892 after Federal income and excess profits taxes.

Coincident with discussions in Washington aimed at a limitation in the size of publications, Time, Inc., announced yesterday a curtailment in the number of pages for Time and Life and a reduction in the page size of Fortune Magazine.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- A more confident feeling prevailed in the grain trade today and the markets developed a firm undertone. While trading was not large, there was no material pressure, and late in the session short covering disclosed a lack of selling and prices advanced readily.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Federal Government has been, and still is, too much of a haven for young men qualified for military service but deferred when their services were not indispensable to the conduct of the war, the Senate was told today by Senator Tydings.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Many Westchester residents, those who commute to New York City and usually get home about 7:30 P.M., ate warned-over dinners this evening.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- A voice purporting to be that of John Amery, 30-year-old son of Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, was heard tonight broadcasting from Berlin as Nazi advance publicity had promised.

Although weekly carloadings have run steadily behind those of the corresponding periods of 1941 since July, indications are that the freight traffic for this year will be the largest in history. John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, recently estimated that the freight traffic this year will amount to 630,000,000,000 ton-miles, compared with 475,000,000,000 in 1941, a gain of 32.6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Borrowing in December of the unprecedented amount of $9,000,000,000 by means of an intensive sales campaign which will place with every class and type of investor Treasury issues specifically designed for them was announced today by Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, said today the Northern Breeding Grounds of Migratory Wildfowl reported more than four times as many birds this year as in the ebb years of 1934 and 1935.

Dr. Bernard F. Haley, acting director of the textile, leather and apparel division of the OPA, will speak on immediate problems of price control at the annual meeting of the Textile Fabrics Association on Dec. 11 at Hotel New Yorker.

A plea for an end to "this nonsense that irresponsible people can judge what strategic plans should be adopted or how the tactics should be executed" was voiced last night by W. Averell Harriman, United States Minister to Great Britain and President Roosevelt's representative on lend-lease to Great Britain and Russia, at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore marking the first anniversary of Freedom House.
