On Tuesday the open season on deer will extend to another section in New York State and hunting will be permitted in this area except on Sunday, Nov. 29, on through to the last day of the month, when the deer season closes in all parts of the State.

The city's post-war construction program, as recently approved by the City Planning Commission, will cost more than $1,000,000,000 instead of the $680,000,000 estimated by the planning board at its meeting on Oct. 30, the Citizens Budget Commission declared yesterday at a public hearing held by the Board of Estimate on the proposed capital outlay budget for 1943.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase of $36,879,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, which were at a record high. Note circulation for the system as a whole was at the highest of the year to date, while ratio of reserve for the system and also for the New York bank were at a low for the year.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The battle for Tunisia is still in its preparatory stages. There has been no major battle yet.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 19 -- A British pincer movement began to take shape around Bengazi yesterday, and the Germans tried desperately to keep the jaws pried apart long enough to get the remainder of their forces out of the region and into Tripolitania.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- If the War Labor Board and, on appeal, the President shall sustain the recommendations of a WLB panel in the matter of the Newark, N. J., garbage collectors' strike, the theory of unlimited Federal confiscation of local authority in wartime at the expense of the Constitution will have been established, and also the right of government employes to strike, even in wartime.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force roared out over the southeast coast of England in an uninterrupted procession for more than an hour last night to drop their bombs on Italy's Fiat works at Turin. It was the ninth raid on targets in Northern Italy, industries essential to the Axis in its efforts to oppose the Allied offensive in North Africa.

The volume of bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday almost equaled the high level for this year, in the period ended on Oct. 21, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Further advances in prices for agricultural commodities, largely grains, and the higher excise taxes on tobacco products and alcohol brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of nearly 900 price series up 0.4 per cent in the week ended Nov. 14 to 100.1 per cent of the 1926 average.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 19 -- A three-point major legislative program for the American Legion for 1943 was approved by the national executive committee this afternoon in adopting the report of a subcommittee which stressed winning the war, winning the peace and preserving American democracy.

Girl Scouts in their green uniforms are helping America's war effort all over the nation. They find a new usefulness and a new importance in this work. Here in this city 24,000 youngsters from 7 to 18 years of age are doing thousands of wartime chores cheerfully.

Whenever in the course of human events we find Americans and Frenchmen cooperating in a war of liberation the proceedings are not always 100 per cent legally correct. President Roosevelt says that expediency requires our doing business with Darlan in North Africa.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 19 -- It was officially announced this evening that Mexico and Soviet Russia had agreed to renew diplomatic relations, which were severed Jan. 23, 1930.

Preservation of private operation and management of railroads and other transportation agencies was advocated yesterday in a list of principles adopted by the National Industrial Traffic League at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Merger of the Central Maine Power and the Cumberland County Power and Light Companies into one of New England's largest utilities received full authorization today when shareholders of the latter concern voted approval of the consolidation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The first quarterly reduction in inventories of manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers since 1939 took place during the third quarter of 1942, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline, which was more than $300,000,000, indicated that business is now calling on its reserves as well as current resources to sustain the present high rates of production and consumption.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Navy Communique 195:

Juvenile delinquency is on the increase and will continue to become a serious problem unless immediate measures are taken to combat it, speakers warned yesterday at the second of three scheduled meetings called by the Public Education Association.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 20 -- Taking direct issue with President Roosevelt and including the United States in his hatred of Britain, Pierre Laval, on the morrow of receiving from Marshal Henri Philippe Petain almost dictatorial powers, broadcast from Vichy to the French nation tonight.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20 -- The National Association of Real Estate Boards went on record today as opposing the proposal for extension of rent control to business property, as favoring realty tax relief and relaxation of government regulations on residential rents and as suggesting a new effort by Federal agencies to foster wider home ownership.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Legislation to oust the three members of the National Labor Relations Board will be sought in Congress by the American Federation of Labor, said President William Green today, unless something is done to quash the board's complaint against three Henry J. Kaiser shipyards on the West Coast.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, Nov. 21 -- A new threat to Australia from Japanese- occupied Timor was revealed in an official statement at Canberra last night that the Japanese are massing equipment and reinforcing troops on the Dutch-Portuguese island 300 miles from the nearest point on the northwest coast of this country.

A property in midtown Manhattan passed to new control yesterday with the sale by the Chase National Bank of the six-story loft building at 318-20 West Forty-sixth Street to a buyer for occupancy. Assessed at $130,000, the parcel is 44 by 100.5 feet and was sold for cash through Williams Co., brokers.

The State did not demand yesterday the extreme penalty for Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21-year-old mother of four children, for the shooting of her husband, Alman, 23, but did ask a jury of eight men and four women in Bronx County Court to act courageously for justice and find her guilty.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Members of the Police Casualty Squad here, who had started out with a twenty-inch metal automobile ornament as their only clue in a hit-and-run fatality, announced today they had solved the case with the arrest of Mrs. Alice Nugent, 38 years old, of 36 Duncan Avenue, Jersey City, on a manslaughter charge.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- The big four-motored bombers of the Royal Air Force made their sixth raid of the month on Italy last night, British officials said early today. Indications were that the attack was in heavy strength.

Colonel Hans Lagerloef, donor of the annual challenge trophy for "the best stamp department in a United States newspaper," presented the 1942 award to Franklin R. Bruns Jr., stamp editor of The New York Sun, at a luncheon at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -The 198 fire insurance companies indicted at Atlanta today have headquarters in twenty-four States and the District of Columbia.

The subway circuit and its always vociferous alumni will have three choices today before joining the college alumni in attendance at local football offerings. All three games here promise brisk action and a casual spectator without any particular school affiliation hardly can make a mistake.

MADRID, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Reports from Africa tonight said that Allied forces in Tunisia were progressing smoothly and, barring unexpected developments, should win control of the ports of Sfax and Gabes on the Tunisian east coast within a few days.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- American land forces, in action for the first time south of Buna, smashed their way into the outskirts of the Japanese supply base today and were expected to enter the town at any moment.

In what was declared to be a new move to circumvent horserace gambling as a part of Mayor La Guardia's campaign, twenty-four men were rounded up yesterday by the polic on Special Sessions warrants on a general gambling conspiracy charge.

MIAMI, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Whirlaway will throw his heart and legs into two more seasons of racing before retiring to stud in 1944, and Trainer Ben Jones believes his charge may run his earnings up around the million-dollar mark.

The area covered by the Second Service Command went under new dimout rules last night, with Army orders issued by Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry to be enforced by the police of New York, New Jersey and Delaware.

Proof that the exigencies of war have not banished the feminine homespun instinct was found yesterday at the second day of the Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries in Madison Square Garden. In spite of the fact that the show has been geared to women's militant war role, it was the handicraft exhibits that attracted the crowds.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Lieut Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of Allied Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific, personally awarded medals today to the fliers responsible for the sinking of a Japanese cruiser and destroyer off Buna and told them the battle may prove to have been the turning point of the war in this area.
A High Command communique broadcast frorn Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

A merger effective Jan. 1 of Central Congregational Church, 25 Hancock Street, near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn and Clinton Avenue Congregational Church, at Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, to form the Cadman Memorial Church, was voted last night at meetings of the two churches.

If there is an investor in the United States, individual or corporate, of even moderate means who cannot find a type of security fitted to his needs in the "basketful" announced yesterday by the Treasury, he indeed will be hard to suit. That is the opinion in financial circles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- A 31-year-old lieutenant commander regained consciousness on the bridge of the cruiser San Francisco in the early hours of Nov. 13 to find that the admiral and captain had been killed by the same 14-inch shell hit that had wounded him.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 -- The entire statute of 1936 under which country clubs, social and eating clubs and college fraternities had claimed tax exemption was declared unconstitutional today by Supreme Court Justice Harry Heher.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Alaska-Canada Highway, which will be in war a 1,600-mile weapon against Japan and in the peace to come a route into remote Northern areas, reached the dedicatory stage today.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 21 -- Soviet troops, building up to a second Winter offensive against the Germans, seized an inhabited point in the snow-swept mountains northeast of Tuapse and knocked the enemy from another height south of Stalingrad yesterday, the High Command announced today.

Four Negroes were found guilty yesterday by a General Sessions jury of first-degree rape of Miss Ann Coleman, 23-year-old model, on Aug. 16, when she and her brother, Charles, 26, pursued two purse-snatchers to the roof of the tenement at 101 West 133d Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Congressional demands for postponement of country-wide gasoline rationing appeared tonight to be heading toward a White House showdown as the result of the statement by William M. Jeffers, rubber director, in a New York speech tonight, that the program would go into effect Dec. 1 as scheduled, regardless of opposition.

Luther Emerson Barnes, associate judge of the District Court of North Brookfield, Mass., and the oldest graduate of Amherst, has just turned 99. Good luck to him and as large allowance of years to come as he wants! Presumably he is the oldest judge in the country.

The Gaiety Theatre, which has been showing second-run features, will switch its policy on Thursday with the presentation of the local premiere of "Ravaged Earth." Made by Mark L. Moody, the picture is described as "showing the menace of Japanese invasion and its brutal, shocking results."

A point system will be used in the forthcoming meat-rationing program, Dr. Harold Rowe, chief of the food-rationing division of the OPA, disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Grocery Manufacturers of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Vice Admiral William F. Halsey, commander of Allied naval forces in the South Pacific, was nominated by President Roosevelt today for promotion to the rank of admiral in recognition of the great naval victory in the Solomon Islands area last week.
MOSOW Nov. 20 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Curly Lambeau, coach of the Packers, who will face the Giants in a National Football League game at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, said last night that he would start his regular backfield of Red Craig, quarterback; Cecil Isbell, left half; Andy Uram, right half, and Lou Brock, fullback.

Publishers, approaching their December hiatus (as far as issuing many new books) start now to shape up their January schedules. Lippincott reports a list of nine books and of these six are about the war, with one of the other three being about Napoleon.

Ninety air raid instructors from New York City and Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties attended yesterday the first session of a two-day training institute being conducted by the Office of War Training Programs of the State War Council in Albany.

The Army will take over control of motor truck carriers to assure the steady flow of needed war materials if steps by regulatory bodies threaten to interfere with shipment of such materials, Colonel W.J. Williamson, chief of the Transportation Corps, Traffic Control Division of the War Department, told more than 500 members of the National Industrial Traffic League at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Spain's attitude appears to be changing from pro-Axis non-belligerency to stricter neutrality, which is expected to be maintained unless Spanish territory is invaded by Axis forces, it was said authoritatively here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Governor Lehman of New York will soon be named to direct the feeding, clothing and rehabilitation of countries which are friendly to or occupied by the United Nations, according to reports here tonight.

The end of the month brings to a close the second annual Governor's New Jersey fishing tourney. Although the official awards will not be announced until next month, it appears that most of the eventual victors are on the list which the New Jersey Council has just made public.

Pre-Thanksgiving sermons will be preached tomorrow in the churches of the New York area. The proclamation of President Roosevelt, calling for public and private prayers for the United States "and the nations joined with it waging a battle on many fronts for the preservation of peace," will be quoted.
The wind snapped light snow along Fifth Avenue yesterday. But New Yorkers had only one season in mind. Christmas.
Municipal officials from a wide area of New Jersey yesterday upheld the view that the War Labor Board should not attempt to assume jurisdiction over disputes of municipalities with their employes.

A check for $100,000, representing payment for radio sponsorship rights to the Army-Navy football game, was presented to Army and Navy officials last night at a reception at the Waldorf-Astoria. Major Gen. Francis B. Wilby, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, and Rear Admiral John R. Beardall, superintendent of the United States Naval Academy, were guests of honor.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20 -- After finishing fourth in four straight races, C.E. Nelson's Johnnie J. today broke loose with a five-length victory in the six-furlong seventh contest as Bowie's new nine-races-a-day policy went into effect. Some 4,500 spectators saw the $14.20-for-$2-shot score in 1:12 4-5.

The allotment of men's clothing next year is receiving serious consideration among manufacturers, who believe that such a move will be necessary if the government decides to reduce the amount of wools to be woven into civilian cloths, it was reported yesterday.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Scarsdale High School's football team concluded an undefeated and untied season today with a 27-to-7 triumph over Bronxville High, traditional foe, for its fifth victory of the campaign. John (Jo) Mills and Charles Rensenhouse paced the attack with sweeping end runs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- German submarines still are operating "all over the Atlantic," despite the concentration of these Axis warships close to North Africa. Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Methods by which the spice trade may arrive at proper deductions in war risk insurance rates in computing their ceiling prices on imported raw spices and spice seeds were explained today by the Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Underground advices from the Continent said tonight that more than 100 persons had been executed or condemned by Axis occupation authorities, striving to put down a new wave of unrest inspired by the Allied campaign in North Africa.

In a field which included Miss Marilyn Sahner, national champion, Miss Charlotte Whitehouse turned in a sparkling performance to capture top honors in the 100-yard free style handicap event which featured the women's A.A.U. meet at the Henry Hudson Hotel pool last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- "Spars," the name for the proposed Women's Reserve of the Coast Guard Reserve, which was suggested by Lieutenant Dorothy C. Stratton of the Women's Naval Reserves, who would head the new unit, was accepted today by Vice Admiral R. R. Waesche, commandant of the Coast Guard.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- General Ritter von Thoma, 51-year-old commander of the German Africa Corps, whose capture by the British was disclosed in the Nov. 4 special communique that announced that Axis forces were in full retreat, has been brought secretly to England.

Japanese propagandists blared a confused tune yesterday on the Solomons naval battle as Tokyo newspapers stopped trying to make the outcome a "victory" for Japan, while an official spokesman still talked of a "disastrous" American setback, according to Tokyo broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Midwestern retailers aired their recommendations for putting the proposed inventory control on a more workable basis here today at a conference presided over by Eaton V.W. Read, chairman of the WPB wholesale and retail inventory committee.

Drivers of buses, trucks and other commercial vehicles were asked yesterday by the Office of Price Administration to make the "S" gasoline ration coupons, which were to have kept them rolling until Nov. 22, stretch out to Dec. 1.
Praise the OPA, and pass the Thanksgiving bird.

An exhibition of oils, watercolors and drawings by the Swiss artist, Franz Rederer, opens today at the Lilienfeld Galleries, under the patronage of the Consul General of Switzerland, Dr. Victor Nef. Rederer, who was born in Zurich, has been living in New York since 1940. A one-man show of his work was held at the Artists Gallery in February, 1941. The current exhibition at Lilienfeld's will continue through Dec. 12.

For the third consecutive week, tax-exempt securities were the only new bond issues offered here this week for public subscription. Two municipal flotations aggregating $4,380,000 were marketed, against $2,098,000 for three State and municipal issues in the preceding week and $16,444,000 for three assorted issues a year ago.

The British First Army, advancing on the coastal road in Tunisia, has reached the area around Tabarca, near the Tunisian-Algerian frontier, with strong forces, the German radio said yesterday, according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

Never was the need for safety more vital than at present, Miss Ann Barnard, national field director of the National Safety Council, declared yesterday. She spoke at the fourth and final luncheon meeting of members of the National Council of Women of the U.S.A., guests of the Women's International Exposition, in the A. W.V.S. canteen at Madison Square Garden.

A progressive improvement program, the first part of which contemplates more than sixty miles of further electrification with roadway, station and equipment improvements, costing nearly $17,000,000, is recommended to the Long Island Railroad Company by the J.G. White Engineering Corporation in a survey proposing higher commutation rates and lower taxation to put the railroad on a sound basis.

In preparing budgets for 1943, national advertisers are generally operating on a short-term basis, with some refusing to make plans beyond the first quarter and others beyond the first half. There is generally more optimism over the possibility of the war ending sooner than was prevalent a few weeks ago, but the availability of goods is the determining factor now rather than the length of the war.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Generalissimo, sent a message to "Cheer China" benefit, held last midnight at the Radio City Music Hall by the United China Relief, that the desire of Americans to make their contributions in aid of the Chinese people "in the midst of their own war effort is appreciated in China even more than ever before."

There is a system of legal costs so deeply ingrained in the operation of our civil courts that it is seldom questioned. Any person who wishes to institute an action must first deposit with the court a sum of money to defray expenses. Without cash, the legal mills will not turn.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- John Kiely, prosecutor of draft evaders who has been listed as a draft delinquent by his own Selective Service board, was relieved of his duties as Assistant Federal attorney at his own request today, pending a determination of his status.

When the bell rang at 10 A.M. yesterday at the High School of Music and Art, 1,100 students hurried to a special assembly. It was a notable occasion, for to them had been entrusted the task of selecting the best war song for the Ninth Division of the Army at Fort Bragg.

On learning of the anti-trust action in Atlanta, Lloyd T. Wheeler, manager-secretary of the Southeastern Underwriters Association, declared last night that "the indictments are a direct attack by the anti-trust division on State regulation of insurance which has been upheld over many years by the Supreme Court of the United States."

THE NEW YORK TIMES has published a series of articles by the distinguished military expert Mr. Hanson Baldwin on the fighting of the people of Yugoslavia. I am very grateful to Mr. Baldwin and to THE NEW YORK TIMES for the interest they are showing in the constant struggle of my people for their liberation and for the common cause of the United Nations.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 21 -- The heaviest fighting of the New Guinea campaign raged today in the Buna-Gona area, where the Japanese, pinned against the coast, lashed back at the advancing Allies with light artillery, mortars and machine guns.

ARMONK VILLAGE, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- One of the archers hunting deer in the sylvan precincts of Merrie Westchester shored a hit on an animal today, but the victim was not one of the species on which an open season, with the longbow, had been declared.
ATLANTA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Last Thanksgiving she went to Warm Springs an infantile paralysis victim; this Thanksgiving she returns to dance.

It was gratifying to read in THE TIMES on Sunday that, like the famed Lord Geoffrey Amherst, the 1942 football warriors of the fine New England college bearing his name conquered all the enemies who came within their sight.
BOSTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

MADISON, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Brothers College of Drew University, established as a men's school in 1928, will become coeducational next Summer in a move to offset the prospective decline in enrollment resulting from the teen-age draft law, it was announced today by Registrar F. Taylor Jones.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- One of the last letters written by Rear Admiral Norman Scott before he was killed in the naval battle in the Solomon Islands Nov. 13 was a message of praise of men wounded in Pacific fighting.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant Frank Joseph Smolinsky of 744 East Ninth Street, New York, shot down a German Focke-Wulf 190 off Flushing, the Netherlands, yesterday, the Air Ministry reported today. It was one of two German fighters destroyed in fighter sweeps carried out by British and American pilots.
Voltaire was born 248 years ago today. He is remembered wherever men love freedom, because he defended the weak, cried out against intolerance and preached that reason and humanity were one.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, will spend the first half of December ministering in military camps. His church has granted him a leave of absence for this "specialized ministry," which will be under the auspices of the combined Departments of Evangelism and the Commission on Religion and Health of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

The two articles by Hanson W. Baldwin on conditions within Yugoslavia, which we published in our issues of Thursday and yesterday, served to call attention to one of the most amazing achievements of this war. This is the achievement of General Mikhailovitch and his little band of Chetniks in raiding Axis garrisons, picking off isolated Axis forces, disrupting Axis communications and above all in keeping his force is being.

HONOLULU, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Charles H. McMurtry, 37-year-old Associated Press correspondent, is recovering in Honolulu from severe burns on the face and hands, painful reminders of the Oct. 26 battle of Santa Cruz in the Solomons area.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The main United States and British Armies engulfing Tunisia were only twenty-five or thirty miles outside Axis-held Bizerte and Tunis tonight and a death grapple for this strategic corner of the protectorate was expected to begin at any moment.

It is "self-evident" that no price differentials between advertised and non-advertised brands can be recognized under price control in cases where there is nothing except grade to differentiate products of different firms, A.C. Hoffman, director of the food price division, Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The midnight communique:
The Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company and its subsidiaries showed a net profit of $2,180,119, or 46 cents a share, in the quarter ended with September, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Navy communique 196:

Today is the day when the breakfast dishes may stand unwashed in the sink, when dust may lie in a thin film on the livingroom table, when lunch may be a helter-skelter meal, hastily conceived and hastily assembled. For today you don your hat and coat as early as you can, tuck a memorandum pad safely into your pocketbook and sally forth for a consultation with that busiest of men these times -- the butcher.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 20 -- As General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's retreating forces approached the vicinity of El Agheila yesterday, it appeared that the crisis that would foretell the future of the war in Africa neared.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Accidental deaths of American workers have exceeded deaths of American fighters by 7 to 1 since the war began, the National Safety Council reported today.

The last of the city's household scrap metal heaps should be on the way to the steel mills by March 1, barring unusually severe Winter weather, according to Charles J. King, spokesman for the nine-dealer pool with whom Mayor La Guardia arranged more than a month ago for speeding the scrap toward war industries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Roosevelt directed the Secretaries of War and the Navy today to halt temporarily the enlistment or commissioning of Federal employes in the armed forces until their essential status can be determined.

Japan, while admitting a little more, stands by its story of a great naval victory in the Solomons and the annihilation of the American Navy, which, incidentally, had already been annihilated off Midway. The reason is not only the inordinate vanity of the Japanese military caste and the divinity complex from which it draws inspiration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The promotion of Admiral William F. Halsey will put him on a par with Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Pacific Fleet commander, as far as rank is concerned, but there was no indication that Admiral Nimitz will not continue in supreme command of all Pacific operations, including those conducted by Admiral Halsey.

Taxi drivers and other civilians who risked their lives to assist the police will be honored today at a ceremony at City Hall marking the graduation of 109 probationary policemen and the induction of 216 rookies, including sixteen women.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Most sections of today's stock markets were quiet with business small before the week-end. Gilt-edge issues improved 1/16 to 1/8 partly on the announcement that an offer for the conversion of 16,500,000 of 2 3/4 per cent Australian Government stock maturing in January will shortly be made.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Roosevelt told a press conference today that there would be developments soon regarding the appointment of a food "administrator."

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Francis B. Sayre, former High Commissioner of the Philippine Islands, said tonight there could never be permanent peace in this world unless tariff barriers were knocked down and armament factories all over the world were kept under continuous inspection.

Warning that he would impose severe penalties in keeping with the nature of the crime, Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato set Dec. 7 yesterday as the date of sentence for Neil Simonelli, 16 years old, and Joseph Annunziata, 19, the two "zoot suit" slayers of Erwin Goodman, 36-year-old mathematics teacher, in William J. Gaynor High School in Brooklyn on Oct. 2.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- Twenty million men will be walking the streets looking for jobs after the war unless re-employment plans are started immediately as a vital adjunct of the peace to come, the closing session of the New England Council's war conference was told today by Paul G Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 20 -- While Pierre Laval tonight was telling France of his certainty that Germany would prove victorious, Vichy was discussing two things it had learned earlier in the day.

HEADQUARTERS, ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Army aerial reconnoissance substantiates recent reports of apparently renewed Japanese air activity at Attu Island, near the end of the Aleutian chain. The island was occupied once this Summer by the invaders and later abandoned.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 20 -- This city of 110,000 population acclaimed today a local boy who had made good thousands of mile away by dealing death and destruction to Japanese naval forces.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 20 -- Immediate passage of a National Service Act authorizing the drafting of manpower was recommended by the Employment Committee and approved by the Executive Committee of the American Legion here today.

The trustees of the Staten Island Edison Company, which Mayor La Guardia wants the city to buy for a price not exceeding $14,500,000, may soon consider sale of the property to another buyer, it was disclosed yesterday at a public hearing before the Finance Committee of the City Council.

The extraordinary heroism and courage that Chief Gunner's Mate Robert S. Nolan displayed when the aircraft carrier Yorktown was attacked by Japanese torpedo and dive-bomber planes in the Battle of Midway early in June was rewarded yesterday in an impressive ceremony on the parade grounds adjacent to the receiving ship Seattle, Fifty-second Street and North River.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 20 -- The British air evacuation scheme for the wounded carried out by the Royal Air Force has saved hundreds of lives during the Alamein battle and subsequent advance. A.R.A.F. pilot who crash-landed at Solum suffering from a shoulder wound was flown back within four hours and received a blood transfusion that assured his recovery.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- A decline of almost 80 per cent in investment contemplated in October building plans filed with the State Labor Department, in comparison with October, 1941, was attributed today to war priorities.

A suit by minority stockholders of the General Gas and Electric Corporation to recover $79,175,000 for the corporation from the group formerly in control was filed here yesterday in Supreme Court. The suit named as defendants fourteen individuals who formerly controlled General Gas through W.S. Barstow Co., Inc. The defendants include William S. Barstow, former president of General Gas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -Declaring that the Federal payroll had almost doubled in the last year, Senator Byrd, chairman of a joint economy committee, today said an effort would be made to prune the expenses of all government agencies, from the White House down.
It seems to me that if a filibuster is ever justified it is justified now in the opposition of Senators to the repeal of the poll tax in Southern States.

Despite unusually warm weather department stores here will show sales increases this week ranging from 25 to 35 per cent over last year. The 1941 week, however, contained the early Thanksgiving and hence comparison is with only a five-day period last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan for the dissolution and sale of the assets of Northwest Carolina Utilities, Inc., of North Carolina in a step to effectuate "death sentence" provisions of the Holding Company Act by its parent, East Coast Public Service Company.

As a Frenchman, I was painfully impressed by Pertinax's article of Nov. 11. As a friend of Guy de Wendel, whom I have known for forty-four years and who is in no position either to know in what manner his name has been exposed, or to reply, I think it is my duty to give simply his military record.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Repulsed in their first encounter on land with American troops in this war, German and Italian forces were reported tonight to be digging in along a line formed by an arc covering Bizerte and Tunis, the main ports in Tunisia, and landing men and equipment at Gabes, on the eastern coast.

ST. LOUIS. Nov. 20 -- At least ten years of intensive home construction will be necessary after the war to catch up with the demand now being developed, in the opinion of Chester C. Davis, president of the St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank.

Maxwell Anderson disclosed yesterday afternoon that he is planning to visit some of the Negro Army camps this Winter and then write a play about Negro soldiers in the armed forces, provided he can obtain the proper material. The Playwrights Company would sponsor it, but not until next Fall.

The twentieth annual joint Thanksgiving service, and the first in this war of the Patriotic Societies of New York, will be held in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and ll0th Street, tomorrow at 4 P.M. The sermon will be delivered by the Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

A program of more than usual interest was presented by Celius Dougherty and Vincenz Ruzicka, duo-pianists of this city, at their annual recital last night in Town Hall. Featured on the list was a new sonata by Paul Hindemith, which received its world premiere.

Increasing shortages of meats and other foodstuffs, as well as growing drains on the city's manpower, soon will convince New Yorkers that they are on the battle front of the World War, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at a meeting of 600 key workers of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, held in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall, to celebrate the organization's first anniversary.

Modern troops don't carry flags in battle. The color bearer and the color guard are for parades and ceremonials only. It was not always so. In the Civil War the flag was borne forward in the charge, not only to add to the fervor of the advancing soldiers but for the practical purpose of marking the line.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20 -- Harvard and Yale meet in Yale's famous Bowl on the outskirts of the city tomorrow. No semblance of a national football ranking or title depends on the outcome, except only the championship of the Big Three, yet wherever football is played or known throughout the world the result will be flashed and, despite difficulties of wartime travel, some 40,000 will be on hand for the kick-off at 2:30.

Mr. Whitehorn's reply to my letter on the limitation of salaries to $25,000 shows marvelous misunderstanding both of the measure and of my comments on it. He says: "Mr. Choate is encouraged to demand that no contribution be made by those who have perhaps profited most."

In writing about the Boston College team in THE TIMES on Monday, Allison Danzig quoted Cliff Montgomery as saying that "the T formation is the greatest thing in football" and that "any coach who doesn't use it is making a mistake."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- An 8.6 per cent drop in cash dividend payments during the first ten months of 1942 is noted by the Department of Commerce in the November issue of its Survey of Current Business.

A new psychological weapon tested in the Spanish civil war was described last night at the New York Academy of Medicine by Dr. Emilio Mira, formerly chief psychiatrist of the Loyalists, now Professor of Psychiatry at the University of Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Gasoline rationing is going into effect throughout the country as scheduled on Dec. 1 "for the good reason that we must conserve rubber" and despite "organized opposition," William M. Jeffers, National Rubber Director, declared yesterday.

Announcing that the Navy Department has ordered the surrender of one-half of the typewriters used by the clerical staff in its land offices, Arthur Harris, chairman of the office machinery procurement committee of the War Production Board, called upon business men yesterday to make a similar sacrifice in the campaign to obtain 600,000 machines for the armed forces.

Mayor La Guardia met the heads of the city's "nonessential" services at City Hall yesterday and advised them to encourage enlistments as well as draft inductions of their "replaceable" employes of military age. His new manpower commission, the Mayor said, would cooperate in getting draft exemption for "irreplaceable" workers.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 20 -- Dorothy Ledyard Knight filed suit for divorce here today against Richard Allen Knight, charging cruelty alleged to have taken place in Reno while both were here, although not living together. Nevada laws provide that such action may be filed if both are residents of this State at the time and the cruelty occurs here, the six-week residence requirement being unnecessary if both are residents here.

A syndicate headed by John Nuveen Co. won yesterday the award of a new issue of $4,258,000 city of Detroit sewerage system revenue bonds on which the city officials had rejected all bids earlier in the week. The early bid was on a 2.134 per cent basis and was made by Lehman Brothers and associates.

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Boston University -- Know ye all persons to whom these presents shall come: "That the eagle's fate and mine are one." In short, a brief vote for B.C. and a kindly suggestion that the coach spare the horses.

Wendell L. Willkie said yesterday that it was the "magnificent ability" of General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery at the battle of El Alamein that made possible the successful American invasion of Northwest Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- About 500 American industrial plants, made idle or threatened with idleness by the war production program and restrictions on raw materials, will be shipped to Latin-American nations as soon as arrangements are made with responsible interests in Latin America to operate them.

Magistrates Charles E. Ramsgate and Joseph DeAndrea sat jointly yesterday in the Municipal Term Court in the Criminal Courts Building to dispose of guilty pleas that had been entered five days before by twenty-seven of the "Bowery bums" who had been taken into custody to aid in the war effort.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt described her recent visit with the American armed forces in Great Britain over a National Broadcasting hook-up tonight and expressed "a deep sense of pride and satisfaction in out officers and men."

Displaying a vast amount of energy and enthusiasm, the members of the City College Dramatic Society last night staged a fast-moving, humorous musical revue entitled "College-I-Antics of 1942" at the college's Pauline Edwards Theatre, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Today is a national holiday, Peace Day, in the Republic of Colombia. It commemorates the fortieth anniversary of the establishment of domestic tranquillity. The Republic of New Granada, whose name was changed in 1861 to The United States of Colombia, was founded in 1831.

The stock market threw off its restraint yesterday, and as traders finally gave recognition to the long list of year-end dividend declarations prices advanced fractions to about a point. Pivotal issues accompanied by some of the rails and airlines paced the share list higher.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -Six Federal employes were discharged and one was disciplined between Aug. 22 and Oct. 1 on charges of activity in organizations advocating violent overthrow of the government, Attorney General Biddie told Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Early establishment by Congress of agencies for regional development of the natural resources of the country along the lines of the Tennessee Valley Authority was advocated in a report released today by the National Planning Association.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- Leo Abernathy was outsed early this morning as president of the Pittsburgh Central Labor Union, A.F.L. Assembly, for supporting Governor-elect Edward Martin, Republican, in the State election. He announced that he would seek redress in court.

If space permits, perhaps your readers will be interested in these incidents in the life of the late Joseph Hagan, who as Philadelphia Jack O'Brien was one of the finest characters in the history of the boxing ring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- An indictment charging conspiracy and monopoly by the South-Eastern Underwriters Association, twenty-seven of its officers and its 198 member capital stock fire insurance companies was handed down by a Federal grand jury at Atlanta today, it was announced here by the Department of Justice.

Directors of the Atchison, Topeka Sante Fe Railway authorized yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share for payment to common stockholders on March 1, 1943. This represents an increase of 50 cents over the disbursement in March this year.

With Boston College, Georgia and Georgia Tech heavily favored to stay in the winning column, interest centers on the meeting between Michigan and Ohio State at Columbus today as college football offers its final full program of the season in the East and the Middle West.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Office of War Information advised communities and organizations tonight to carry out plans for observance of the anniversary of Pearl Harbor although President Roosevelt said that, for himself, he would regard Dec. 7 "as a day of silence in remembrance of a day of great infamy."

IF one wants to get a reputation as a great military thinker the convenient formula is to utter a large, portentous remark that is both sweeping and simple. The French General Mangin is remembered for his: "He who holds Chad, holds Africa." Our own Billy Mitchell had his version: "He who holds Alaska can control the world."

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 20 -- The first man to return from the Solomon Islands since the United States naval victory of Nov. 12-14, Lieutenant De Witt Peterkin, 29, U. S. N. R., of New York City, related today the story of the battle as it came to the forces on Guadalcanal.
MILLTOWN, N.J., Nov. 20 (AP) -- This community of 3,500 citizens has volunteered to serve as a guinea pig for the nation's tin-can salvage efforts.

The editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 18 on Admiral Callaghan is a short but very beautiful tribute to a great and beloved soldier. There is one sentence in it of priceless value and will be of great comfort to thousands of parents who must lose their beloved sons in this grim war. I refer to these words: "Now he has won the great prize, of death in battle."

BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- A tremendous social change which will eliminate women's accepted role as a stay-at-home in the post-war world has been engendered because women are now making machine-guns and bombers and liking the work, the New England War Conference heard today.

When our cruiser commanders in the Battle of the Solomons chose to shoot it out with Japanese battleships of more than twice their weight was it because Rear Admirals Callaghan, Scott and Captain Young were impelled by a fanatic belief in the divine personality of our President?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- American forces on Guadalcanal killed half of a Japanese force of 1,500 men threatening their positions to the east of Henderson Field at about the same time that our naval forces were scoring last week's extraordinary victory over the Japanese fleet, the Navy Department announced today.
The cotton futures market weakened yesterday in the late trading under increased liquidation and transferals from the December position. The close showed net losses of 2 to 6 points.

War conversion of equipment formerly used to make lace curtains will be speeded by quartermaster contracts expected to be placed shortly for camouflage and sand-fly nets, approximately 5,000,000 yards of each, manufacturers reported here yesterday. As a result, it was said, lines of various lace products have been withdrawn from sale by some houses, leaving full dependency for future civilian supplies on other types.

The first Wing Scout troop to be organized in New York City and the tenth formed in the country held its first meeting last night at the home of Mrs. Helen Deason, Hudson View Gardens, 183d Street and Pinehurst Avenue. The newest specialized phase of Girl Scouting was started to make girls aware of the importance of air supremacy to the United States and to prepare them for community service in the field of aviation.

Thousands of sports enthusiasts must have rejoiced upon reading your pages on Tuesday and noting the remarks made by Adrian Berwick of the Office of War Information at the Football Writers Association luncheon the previous afternoon.
Restaurants, hotels, hospitals and other institutional users of coffee are to register for rationing on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday.
A new world featherweight champion was crowned in Madison Square Garden last night, at least, as far as the New York State Athletic Commission is concerned.

The people in the warring countries of Europe did not talk much in the first year of the conflict. Wherever he went in 1940 the first thing the visitor noted was the reticence of old acquaintances. While the war was brewing, they welcomed the chance to unburden themselves.

Wall Street's reaction yesterday to the Treasury's announcement of the terms of the record-breaking $9,000,000,000 of new government financing for December was that the "basketful" of new issues will fit every investment need. Predictions were made freely that before the campaign is finished the nation-wide sales total will exceed $10,000,000,000 and conceivably may reach $12,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Senate filibuster against the poll tax repeal bill was called off this evening, at the close of its seventh day, under an agreement which is accepted generally as spelling death for the measure for the present session of Congress, at least.

William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., announced yesterday the calling of a special meeting of stockholders for Dec. 16 for the purpose of slashing his salary approximately $122,000 a year. Under the proposal being forwarded to stockholders for their vote, Mr. Paley's salary would aggregate $65,000 annually and all his profit-sharing arrangements with the company would be terminated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Secretary Wickard said today increasing Russian demands and requirements of United Nations forces in Africa made him "more and more concerned" over the ability of this country to meet wartime food needs.

The thousands of stirrup pumps bought by owners of multiple dwellings and commercial buildings in compliance with the local defense law enacted six months ago will find them useless against the new type of delayed-action incendiary bomb, Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh declared yesterday at a hearing before the defense committee of the City Council.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN CHINA, Nov. 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- Fighter-escorted American medium bombers, striking down the Burma Road from Free China, unloaded three tons of explosives today on the Japanese army base at Lungling, starting several firse and inflicting heavy damage.

PAINTINGS, drawings and etchings by the late, George Gershwin, Nathan Milstein, Efrem Kuretz, Deems Taylor, Xavier Cugat, Morton Gould, Harold J. Rome, Tom Waring and others will be displayed at the first annual Exhibition of Art by Musicians, which opens Tuesday night at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center.

A Benefit for China: Beautiful examples of the art of the Ching Dynasty -- paintings, screens, tapestries, sculpture in various media -- have been assembled and charmingly installed by C.T. Loo, assisted by Beryman Ridges, in the galleries of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, 451 Madison Avenue.

Travel as travel may be out for the duration, but rail and bus lines expect to move big crowds over Thanksgiving. The movement will get under way on Tuesday, and visitors will be returning to destinations between Friday and Sunday. All rolling equipment will be in use, say the railroads, but in compliance with ODT rulings there will be no extra trains.

Notching two touchdowns in each of the first three quarters, Erasmus Hall High yesterday finished its football campaign unbeaten for the second straight year by crushing Samuel J. Tilden High, 39 to 6, at Tilden Field. It was the thirteenth straight success for the Buff and Blue, which won seven games this season.

OF all branches of the service, the Air Force must act with the least precedent, the least tradition. Nearly all tactics and formations of infantry have been tested over 10,000 years. Even tanks, operating at high speed, make use of tactics developed first by chariot and then by cavalry.

QUITE the highest level of achievement Jose de Creeft has attained in any one of his exhibitions is reached in the show of his recent sculpture at Georgette Passedoit's Gallery. Hitherto each successive show has presented outstanding pieces among more frankly decorative work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A strong ground attack and a few lucky aerial attempts brought Georgetown a 21-0 victory over George Washington today in the fifteenth renewal of their intra-city gridiron rivalry.

The New York Rovers defeated the Jamaica Hawks, 19 -- 2, in the feature of an Eastern Amateur Hockey League double-header in Madison Square Garden last night while 3,000 fans yawned. The Redshirts made more goals than any other team this season, exceeding the seventeen turned in by the Boston Olympics over the Manhattan Arrows.
DODGE CITY, Kan., Nov. 21 -- Politics in Kansas for the duration of the war will have the feminine touch if the policies of the Young Republicans and Young Democrats are successful.

TORONTO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, Stanley Cup champions, recaptured first place in the National Hockey League tonight by blanking the Canadiens of Montreal, 8 -- 0. It was the first shut-out of the season for the Canadiens.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 21 -- Racing to the front after going a furlong, Colonus, one of the outsiders in a big field, won the classic Melbourne Cup by seven lengths from Phocion and Heart's Desire, two other long shots, at Flemington today.

THIS new life of Parkman -- the only others date from 1900 and 1904 -- was well worth essaying, and will be of interest to all concerned with the history of American letters and scholarship and of the general American scene.
SOMEWHERE IN ALGERIA, Nov. 17 (Delayed) -- British engineers have done one of this campaign's outstanding jobs in unloading transports in this port.
ATLANTA, Nov. 21 -- Georgia Tech put in a strong bid for national honors today by rallying to whip Florida, 20 -- 7, for its ninth successive victory.

With our invasion of North Africa, all the islands of the Mediterranean have assumed a new importance. We now see the larger islands not merely as outposts of the Axis but as potential stepping-stones to Europe. The smaller islands fall into a new strategic pattern, with such dots on the map as Malta and Pantelleria about to reverse their previous roles in defense and attack.

ORANGE, Va., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Frederic II, 5-year-old bay gelding owned by Isidore Bieber of Brooklyn, with Emmet Roberts up, galloped to victory today in the Noel Laing Memorial Steeplechase Handicap, feature of the Montpelier Hunt races at the estate of Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott.

With club women throughout the country taking stock, as the anniversary of our entrance into the war nears, to learn what they have accomplished and to ascertain how their programs can be expanded, the wartime activities of the Woman's Club of Maplewood, N.J., are typical.

Young officers serving in the armed forces and midshipmen from the naval reserve training schools here will be special guests of committee members of the Debutante Charity Ball to be given Dec. 5 in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton as the annual dance in aid of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

IF you could have your way, what kind of meal would you choose to eat on Thanksgiving? What kind of dinner, perfect in every detail and utterly satisfying and memorable in its final effect, would you dream up for that day? These were questions the writer put to five people who are alike in but one respect: each has an intense interest in food.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Great Britain's First Army in North Africa has adopted the medieval Crusaders' emblem, the cross and shield with the sword of St. George of England, an official announcement said tonight.

Having successfully trained 3,000 foremen, supervisors, gang bosses and lead operators in the new job methods training program, the War Manpower Commission will immediately extend this plan on a nationwide basis with the ultimate objective of training 300,000 to 400,000 workers in supervisory jobs, Clifton Cox, assistant director of the New Jersey section, Training Within Industry Division of WMC, reported here yesterday.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 21 -- The University of North Carolina has established a College of War Training, on a par with the other schools of the university, to train students above 16 years of age for front-line and civilian duty.
I am more than a little surprised to see the Canadian airman's qualifications omitted in your "A Gallery of Fighting Fliers" in THE TIMES Magazine.

Next year gardeners are going to depend much on annuals for color in beds and borders. Seeds of worth-while varieties will be available. Those who must have bloom despite many extra duties connected with the war effort will find in annuals the quick and easy answer to their problem.

A thousand tons of iron and steel urns, plot enclosures and other graveyard accessories have been salvaged by seventy cemeteries in the metropolitan area for conversion into implements to deal death among the Axis, the regional office of the War Production Board's general salvage section disclosed yesterday.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Gettysburg College bullets exploded with a 45-to-20 victory over Dickinson College today, the triumph coming as a birthday present for Coach Hen Bream.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This seashore resort, host city to a huge Army Air Forces basic training center, looks forward to a record number of Thanksgiving visitors this coming week-end, largely as the result of the dispersal of war rumors.
MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique:

Many entertainment programs supported by volunteer workers have long been available to men in uniform, while valiant merchant seamen have had little more than terra firma to look forward to when they stepped ashore. This oversight is now being remedied.
HOLLYWOOD. WITH a pot of paint in one hand and a brush in the other, the late Sir Thomas Lipton once stood on the deck of a sinking ship in Near Eastern waters. He was not thinking of safety.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 -- Perplexed officials of the regional OPA administration were faced today with the possibility of having to make a choice between relaxing gasoline rationing here by Dec. 1 or risking curtailment of the vast war industries concentrated in this area.

FREQUENTLY overlooked in the selection of the right printing paper is the type of paper needed to get the most out of a particular negative. Of course, of any given type or brand of paper a number of different grades of contrast are available, permitting the choice of a grade ranging from soft to hard, or contrasty.

In mid-January, 1942, the Japanese first appeared among the islands on the eastern fringe of the Malay Barrier. By July the flag of the Rising Sun flew over the volcano-locked harbor of Tulagi and over an airfield hacked from the coconut groves of Guadalcanal, in the Solomons.

Evening college enrollment from coast to coast has been hard hit by war, according to a survey by the Association of University Evening Colleges. Average decrease in enrollment of the first semester of 1942-43 as compared to the same period in 1941-42 is 32.1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Senate has been engaged this week in one of the rather rare parliamentary storms in which a minority invokes seldom-used rules and devices to block action on a bill which the majority obviously wants to pass.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 21 (AP) -- A rugged Michigan State College eleven tumbled the Mountaineers of West Virginia, 7 -- 0, in a defensive football battle before 6,400 fans at Macklin Field today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- American and Australian ground forces today drove to within three miles of Buna, the main Japanese base on New Guinea's north shore, while enemy naval units approached the island, apparently to attempt an evacuation of the garrison.

Prosecution of prominent paving companies in Kings and Queens under two Federal indictments returned a year and a half ago by a grand jury in the Federal Court in Brooklyn came to an end yesterday when thirteen corporations pleaded guilty before Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo and were fined a total of $8,500.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Oliver Hunter of Notre Dame defeated a field of sixty-four in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's fifth annual cross-country run today and sliced 14.1 seconds off the meet record even though he strayed from the course at one point.

Almost a year after the entry of the United States into the war, women's organizations are still far from their goal of all-out participation in the war effort. This is the consensus of six prominent leaders of women's groups who were asked: "Are women's organizations making a maximum effort in volunteer war work?"

Prospects of a women's land army, similar to the auxiliary territorial services of other countries, are being revived as the supply of agricultural workers dwindles. A plan to bring girls and young women into such an organization is being studied by a special committee of the Department of Agriculture, headed by M.L. Wilson, director of extension work.
SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The Thanksgiving holidays in Southern Pines will be marked by a full program of sports, with quail shooting and fox and drag hunting as the feature events.

Ten women, lent by industry to the War Production Board, last week completed tours through the major areas of this country to step up the household salvage of waste fats, tin cans, silk and nylon stockings and other critical materials.
No one can say with finality what America's home makers should expect in the supply of textile home furnishings for the next twelve months.

THE musicians of London have been celebrating birthdays recently -- the anniversary of the foundation of the National Gallery lunch-hour concerts, which have just entered on their fourth year and the birthday of Ralph Vaughan Williams, who is now 70 years old and brimful of youthful energy.

" President Roosevelt's declaration that the turning point of the war seems to have come should inspire all Americans to yet greater effort on behalf of victory," Rabbi Louis I. Newman declared in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday.

New Zealand maritime labor unions have made sharp reductions in the time spent by ships in New Zealand ports between trips, according to an announcement made yesterday by the New York office of the International Transport Workers Federation.

A NEW broadcaster is on the New York air. Another may not be authorized by the Federal Communications Commission in the country until the war is over, so the occasion is worthy of more than passing interest.

The American Communications Association has requested Senator Burton K. Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, to hold public hearings on the bill HR 7370, which would set aside at the discretion of the Federal Communications Commission the sections of the Communications Act requiring operators of American radio stations to be American citizens and embracing other safeguards affecting marine radio.
WHIT BURNETT has attempted the impossible in "This Is My Best," and, naturally enough, he has not succeeded. How could he ?

THERE is no mention of the present war in Christopher Morley's latest book. But, despite the fact that it ends chronologically with a casual reference to the Agadir Incident, that African episode which was a prelude to the World War, it is quite evident that Mr. Morley had more in mind than a deliberately simple novel when he wrote "Thorofare."

THE five addresses to college students which President Conant of Harvard has published under the title. "Our Fighting Faith" (Harvard University Press), are distinguished by clarity and pith. There has been no clearer, more realistic statement of our war aims than this, from "What Are We Defending?"

Business was brisk last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors and basements were crowded and apparel and homefurnishings departments were busy. Toy sections were very active.

A symphony, new, modern in texture, unpretentious and very successful with the audience, and another symphony which, if there is one work supreme over all others in this form would receive our nomination for the distinguished post, made up the program given by Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 20 -- The English language daily World Journal printed in its anti-Tugwell campaign an editorial yesterday demanding impeachment of the Governor. El Mundo also continued its attacks. Reporters at the Governor's press conference expected an outburst when they asked, "Are you going to resign?"

Although most of the local hunting interest during the past week has been centering about the deer-stalking archers in Westchester, reports from New Jersey indicate that there has been a general improvement in the upland season there.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -- Labor and management represented equally in war manpower committees of five Western States agreed today on a voluntary stabilization program for essential industries.

IT was his essays rather than his verses that gained for A.C. Benson his great popularity. But there is one of his poems that in recent years has become far more widely known than any of his prose writings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- More "clarifications" -- some modifying, some tightening the President's $25,000 net earnings limitation rule -- are pending as this is written. But they will not strike at the New Deal-collectivist root of the plan, concerning which much more comes to light as it is further discussed and examined.

LONDON -- Ever since Adolf Hitler came to power in 1933 the Nazis have done all they could to increase the birth rate in Germany. If the Reich was to be a powerful State, able to defend itself against foreign encirclement and aggression, so ran their theory, and able also to wage a war for greater "Lebensraum," German women must bear many children.

As indoor gardeners begin searching for hardy material for the window garden they may become better acquainted with the beauty and adaptability of Pachysandra terminalis. Because for years this has been handled almost exclusively as a "ground cover for shady places," many persons have taken it for granted that it is only at home in the background, serving to show off its more showy companions.
Every mile saved on automobile usage means that more gasoline and rubber is available for our boys at the fronts.

IF you read and liked Mr. Chamberlain's "The Phantom Filly" about nine months ago you should like his new horse-and-dog book. It is more concerned with dogs this time -- English setters -- and so should have a wider appeal, since more people know and love dogs.

I HAVE followed with interest the Sunday TIMES radio page to see what the reaction was to Richard Match's article on juvenile radio. Last Sunday I read Sabra Holbrook's letter and I disagree completely with that writer. I am 17 1/2 years old and I followed the serials -- "Jack Armstrong," "Orphan Annie," "Buck Rogers" and "Bobby Benson" -- until I was 12 years old.

THE message of Lieut. Gen. Dwight Eisenhower which was spread by leaflets dropped from American planes over North Africa is not the first that a leader of an expeditionary force addressed to French colonials in their own language in the cause of liberty.

A large subscription has already been reported for the performance of Philip Barry's new comedy, "Without Love," with Katharine Hepburn and Elliott Nugent in the leading roles, on the night of Dec. 4 at the St. James Theatre for the benefit of the Berkshire Industrial Farm in Canaan, N.Y.

WITH airplanes produced annually by the thousands there is a clear need of pilots. But pilots need training in three-dimensional navigation and in meteorology. Hence the need of texts to supplement the instruction given in Army and Navy schools.

ALTHOUGH there were, I believe, differences of opinion about "Whistle Stop." Miss Wolff's first novel, most critics were agreed that it was an astonishing performance -- written with a vigor and maturity which belied the author's youth.

A reference work that is designed to replace the somewhat outdated companion volumes, "Authors Today and Yesterday" and "Living Authors" (H. W. Wilson), will be out early next month under the title "Twentieth Century Authors."

Announcements continue to come in from Florida of club openings and of Winter residents settling down in their own or rented homes for the cold months ahead. The Indian Creek Country Club on Indian Creek Isle at Miami Beach opened last week.
COPPER WIRING -- It is the unalterable ruling of the WPB that if a house is equipped with more than one electric circuit no priorities for rewiring will be granted.

ARMONK VILLAGE, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Westchester's first victim of the bow-and-arrow open season on deer, an aging English setter, was resting comfortably today in Dr. Irene Kraft's animal hospital, in this community, with a tidy bandage over a deep wound on a hind leg.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 20 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Miss Ida Horowitz of 1037 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, was elected "Sweetheart of Iceland Command" today in a contest conducted by the Army newspaper. She received 47 per cent of the total vote.

Projects for a future "American-Spanish theatrical entente" to produce native Spanish light operas were discussed yesterday by Evaristo Corredor in an interview at the Spanish Language Center, 292 Madison Avenue.
Evander Childs High's football team yesterday scored its seventh straight triumph and finished its season undefeated by outscoring Curtis, 13 -- 6, at Thompson Stadium, Stapleton, S.I.

It is one of the dogmas of Marxism that the capitalistic system was able to live and even to expand during the nineteenth century only because it was exploiting the backward countries of the world. Serious statistical evidence to support this thesis has never been offered.

WHEN the present reviewer was an undergraduate at Stanford University the Irwin boys. Will and Wallace were still a legend there, as no doubt they are today. Both the Irwins had been "graduated by request." though, as Will Irwin tells in this autobiography, the faculty afterward relented in his case and let him have his diploma.

The Bowery today is a street of pawnshops, cheap restaurants, small shops and flophouses where beds rent for 25 cents a night, all huddled under the gloom of the elevated structure. Once it was a peaceful rural road, "the road to the bouwerij (farm)" of Dutch times.

TO make comparisons among men who fight in the air is not easy. One can only distinguish their excellencies. But when one questions an English airman he -- having his own assured record which does not need boosting, which it would be bad form for him to boost -- is sure to answer, and enthusiastically: "Oh, the Canadians are absolute tops."

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 21 -- Merely a yard from victory when playing time ran out, Lafayette had to be content with a 7-all tie with Lehigh today as 16,000 spectators watched the old rivals wage one of the most thrilling encounters in their traditional gridiron series.

PAUL HORGAN has been a white hope in American letters ever since he stepped into the ring some ten years ago (in 1933 he won the Harper Prize with his novel "The Fault of Angels"). Since that date, not to prolong a metaphor, he has stolen more than one decision on points alone.

Five of the authors represented in this annual bargain volume are well known to readers of mysteries. The one newcomer is Dana Lyon, whose story differs from the others in that it is told from the viewpoint of a crook who is the principal witness against a man accused of murder.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- In many British minds there stirs the thought that as a counter-move in answer to the Allied success in North Africa the Nazis may attempt an invasion of Britain's island stronghold. It is the same thought that has persisted during all the weary months since the fall of France.

THE atmosphere of Della T. Lutes's new book is fragrant with the delicious odors of freshly baked bread, ginger cookies and apple pie, to say nothing of strawberry shortcake, hot biscuits and many other of those delectable "homemades" from which most of us are now debarred, not so much perhaps by the war as by the kitchenette.

Acting at the request of Dr. Bruno Weil, who charged that the recently published "Campaign of Treachery," by the French lawyer, Henry Torres, contained "unjust, untrue and derogatory" attacks upon him that were not substantiated, Dodd, Mead Co. has retracted "all such derogatory statements" and has withdrawn "Campaign of Treachery" from publication and sale.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- With most of the cottages now taken for the season at Pinehurst and all five hotels, the Carolina, Holly Inn, the Manor, Pine Crest and the Berkshire reporting many guests in residence for the Winter, Thanksgiving will be celebrated with more festivities than ever before.

THE ramifications of grand military strategy reached into Hollywood three weeks ago, embarrassed some people, puzzled others and put a stop to a projected film about Vichy and North Africa. John Wexley had written a screen story called "Trans-Sahara" which Columbia wished to buy.

A year ago the legend of the Wehrmacht's "invincibility" was finally dispelled on the Russian steppe. An almost incredulous world read that German forces at Rostov on the Don, gateway to the Caucasus and its oil, had been routed by the Red Army under Marshal Semyon Timoshenko.

Mrs. Cleveland L. Bacon will give a tea tomorrow afternoon at La Salle du Bois for members of the program committee for tha performance of Chekhov's play, "The Three Sisters," at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 22, which has been taken over by the New York City Women's Counci! for the Navy League of the United States.

It was predicted in these columns last Spring that if the Metropolitan could reduce its scale of prices through the cooperation of the musicians' union involved and other individuals or organizations accessory to production, the results would hardly fail to benefit both the association and its public.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- A British Spitfire has risen to almost 50,000 feet -- more than nine miles high -- over the Western Desert in North Africa to shoot down a German reconnaissance plane of special high altitude design, the Air Ministry disclosed today.

About A.D. 342 an old star exploded. Half a dozen astronomers discovered the explosion at about the same time around Nov. 10, 1942. So distant is the cataclysm that it has taken its light, traveling at the dizzy speed of 186,000 miles a second, 1,600 years to reach the earth.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 21 -- XGOY, "the voice of China," now ranks with some of the world's leading broadcasting stations if the amount of fan mail received here is any criterion. Letters running into the thousands come in from such widely scattered places as the United States, Australia, England, Portugal, South America, Alaska, Spain, Liberia and India and, before the outbreak of the Pacific war, from France, Germany, Italy, Scandinavia and elsewhere.
