WACO, Texas, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Southern Methodist tied Baylor, 6 to 6, today on a long, fourth-period touchdown pass from Frito Gonzales to Hardy Miller. The tie definitely put S.M.U. out of the running for the Southwest Conference football championship, but left Baylor still with a mathematical chance.

New Army and Navy contracts for several million dollars worth of clothing for men in the armed services awarded under a geographical allocation plan worked out by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C.I.O., combined with regular orders for civilian a el, will assure steady employment for the union's 50,000 members in the metropolitan area until next May, Sidney Hillman, president of the union, revealed yesterday.

THE publishers of this history of the Studebaker brothers, who made wagons long before the Civil War, and have made automobiles and airplanes since, have supplied a dust jacket for this book that would lead the unwary reader to think he was about to open one of those lush sagas of fictionized history.

THIS IS THE ENEMY," the new book on Germany many by Frederick Oechsner and the Berlin United Press staff, was originally a poker game. The staff, five correspondents interned at Bad Nauheim after Pearl Harbor, were busily hatching a book telling all they knew about Hitler Germany.

Featured by trade activity on both the buying and the selling sides, the cotton futures market fluctuated irregularly yesterday and closed near the lows, 1 point higher to 15 points lower than Friday's final quotations. Pronounced weakness in the October prevailed during the session as hedge selling was concentrated in that position.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Internal revenue tax collections in October amounted to $702,692,952, compared with $590,868,893 in October, last year, the Treasury Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Brazilian Government informed the United States today that the nationalization of the former German Condor airline, begun well over a year ago, had been concluded. The company, therefore, has been removed from the blacklist of the United Nations and hanceforth will be known as Servicos Aereos Cruzeiro do Sul, Limitada.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Sir William Beveridge, author of the long-awaited social security report to be issued soon, discussed in public today some of the problems that he considers of first importance for post-war Britain, including employment, private enterprise and he possible reconstruction of government.
Some Americans may be interested in what a foreigner, a Frenchman, thinks of America at war.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 21 -- Free China's annual commodity production has increased from two times to as much as one hundred times in some cases, it was announced by T.F. Tsiang, Director of the Political Affairs Department of the Executive Yuan acting as government spokesman at a press conference this week.

JAMES GORDON BENNETT, the elder, was one of the most colorful and important figures of American journalism. More than any other man he made newspapers what they are today. He found them sad, dull affairs with inadequate news coverage, living under the domination of political parties and mercantile cliques.

Although impatiently awaiting the appointment of a wartime food chief with full power to direct the industry's operations, food men were heartened last week by evidences that the need for such overall control is officially recognized and that positive action now seems imminent.

In response to a standing invitation to service men, a total of 4,121 soldiers, sailors and marines have been accommodated to date at three homes maintained by the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress. The first of the buildings, located at 46, 48 and 50 West Sixty-eighth Street, was opened in April, and adjoining structures were taken over as the number of applicants steadily increased.

" Her whole figure emanated a good-natured, dynamic viciousness," is the author's description of the villainous, not his pure, innocent heroine, Meg. The "emanator" is a phony evangelist with lots of make-up and a carnal admiration for Monty Rogers, a gambler "with a difference."

Disputing recent charges made against higher education, heads of America's leading women's colleges last week voiced a strong defense of the role that women have taken in this war and their preparation for greater service in the immediate years ahead.

Adults who buy books for children, as well as the children who read them, packed The New York Times Hall yesterday to listen to some of the best known writers of these books as part of Children's Book Week, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the leading publishers of books for children.

Do your children know the story of the Plymouth Colony's first American Thanksgiving? ("Our harvest being gotten in, our Governour sent foure men on fowling, so that we might after a special manner rejoyce together * * * ") This, and much more on Harvest Time traditions and ceremonies, along with ideas for community festivals and home entertaining, is conveyed in "The Thanksgiving Book," issued by the National Recreational Association at 25 cents.

TWENTIETH CENTURY-FOX, the movie makers, are on the verge of discovering Broadway. Not only are they backing three potential Broadway productions with hard cash -- "Flare Path," "Something for the Boys," "A Highland Fling" -- but they are giving serious consideration to the possibility of establishing a stock theatre -- near Broadway perhaps -- to serve as a training center for scripts, actors and directors.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Holy Cross repulsed Manhattan's attempted invasion of Worcester right handily today. The Crusaders, after being held fairly even in the opening period, turned on the power to score in each of the succeeding sessions and humbled the New York aggregation by 28 to 0.

THANKSGIVING TRIMMINGS: Make a centerpiece of a small, slightly flat pumpkin, top removed and pulp scooped out. Fill the shining bowl with polished red apples, pomegranates and oranges, and top with clusters of Tokay grapes and a sprinkling of almonds and pecans.

" INFORMATION PLEASE" is going on tour for the War Savings Staff of the Treasury Department. NBC popular quiz show, never seen outside New York except in movie versions, will visit cities along the Eastern seaboard in an ambitious attempt of its creator and owner, Dan Golenpaul, to raise several million dollars for the war effort.

AMERICAN journalists have been taught that it is not proper for reporters to have opinions in what they write. They are supposed to be objective and cool observers. But now it is no longer possible for even a physical scientist to take this attitude in regard to human events, and reporters acting as foreign correspondents see so much happening that directly affects them and their own people that they cannot feel aloof, except cynically.

Among the major suggestions made to WPB officials last week was that the forthcoming inventory limitation order gives the merchant the option of using either the retail inventory method or the wholesale cost basis for figuring inventories.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Office of Defense Transportation has opened up a new field of conservation in the motor trucking industry by paving the way for cooperative action by seven contract carriers in the Middle West who are transporting materials, supplies and manufactured products for the Container Corporation of America.

WHEN Andre Kostelanetz commissioned a series of portraits for orchestra from the composers Jerome Kern, Aaron Copland and Virgil Thomson, he was making a practical musician's approach to the practical problem of getting music written and played.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 13 reported that the C.I.O. at its Boston convention adopted a resolution urging the War Labor Board to "make a forthright and over-all determination accepting full jurisdiction over all employees and all industries," inasmuch as the executive order of Oct. 3 stated that it covered "all employees and all industries."

YOUNG Bill Carson loved the sprawling Texas cattle ranch he had inherited from his father. And he was doing well enough with it, thank you, to take a month off each year. While away on one of these vacations his ambitious friend Harry Morton discovered oil on Bills ranch.

THE Old Print Shop, 150 Lexington Avenue, is exhibiting a historic print showing the collecting of scrap metal in 1776. It depicts the "Sons of Freedom" pulling down the gilded lead statue of George III which stood in the center of Bowling Green at the foot of Broadway.

The annual card party in behalf of the Little Mothers Aid Association will be held on Dec. 7 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds this season will be shared with war relief activities. Mrs. Frank Oliver Hall is president of the organization which is one of the oldest institutions in the city furthering welfare work for children.
Members of the Women's City Club -- some 900 of them -- have chosen five civic issues which they consider of paramount importance. They are:

OMAHA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Tulsa's football team overcame an early deficit to continue undefeated, downing Creighton, 33 to 19, today before a crowd of 9,000. The Tulsans, who have a superb aerial attack, clinched the Missouri Valley Conference championship by their victory.

The War Department's censorship authorities, presumably understanding the pride of Chris Craft, are permitting for publication photographs of the new forty-two-foot Amphibian Command boat which Chris Craft is producing. This sturdy little ship has the general lines of a pleasure cruiser, and after the war is over and won it may be an actual pleasure cruiser.

THE fact has become too apparent for even the deepest ostrich-head to miss that our great motion-picture industry is approaching a crossroads, if not a jumping-off place. Already the wartime diversion of actors and other personnel has piled up increasing complications in the casting and making of films.

" NEVER before," writes Mr. Kazin, thinking of the number of books about America, "did a nation seem so hungry for news of itself." "On Native Grounds" is a news report, a majority report of the interpretation of American life through its novels and critical essays.

" JIM'S THE BOY," like "The Buttons Go Walking" by the same author and illustrator, qualifies for a place among the "funny books." Cap'n Jack, retired from the sea, had the reputation of being the laziest man in Weathersfield.

ONCE again the old Hermit of Aix galvanizes Fifty-seventh Street. And this time he is brought forward as a champion of Fighting France, for the benefit of which the admirable showing at Rosenberg's has been arranged (admission proceeds to be divided equally between the Fighting French Relief Committee and France Forever).

The second jazz concert in the series being presented currently by Ernest Anderson in Town Hall was given late yesterday afternoon, with Eddie Condon, guitarist, again conducting the group of fourteen musicians concerned. Bud Freeman, saxophone, who was the featured soloist from the ensemble, was accompanied by Sidney Catlett, drummer, with Dave Bowman at the piano.

ONE of the most important reprints of the year is "Realms of Being" by George Santayana (Charles Scribner's Sons, $4). This compact, cloth-bound volume is made up of "The Realm of Essence," "The Realm of Matter," "The Realm of Truth" and "The Realm of Spirit," which appeared separately during the past few years.

Somebody thinks that Jeff Quentin, newspaper columnist, knows too much about the murder of Linda Vale, but Jeff knows nothing that makes sense to him. Nevertheless, several attempts are made to remove Jeff before he can reveal what he is supposed to know to the police.

GEORGE O'NEAL is more than half way through a new script bearing the working title of "Mr. Collie" -- a name he doesn't like and will change. It is a satirical fantasy laid in Germany, has five characters (none of them a prominent Nazi) and requires but one set.
Apropos the suggestion of Stephen G. Rich that men adopt the bow tie to save fabric may I offer a suggestion on a larger scale? It is that men have their suits turned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- In a move to assure an adequate supply of work garments for the increasingly large number of women going into war industries, the War Production Board put strict controls today over the purchase and use of fabrics which are needed for this type of clothing.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 21 (AP) -- The fighting Generals of Washington and Lee, cannonading aerials all over Byrd Stadium, almost caught up with University of Maryland in the final seconds of a thrill-packed homecoming battle today, but the jittery Old Liners hung on to squeeze out a 32 to 28 decision.

Out of the past month, even out of the past two weeks, has come one of the most astounding reversals in all military history. Indeed, it is more than a military reversal. The victories of the United Nations in Egypt and in French North Africa, the terrific blow which our Navy has inflicted upon the Japanese in the Solomon Islands waters, have echoed in people's hearts and minds around the world.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Lakehurst naval air station ran its unbeaten string to five games today with a 27-7 triumph over Muhlenberg College.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21 -- What may be the last Big Three football race until the business overseas is finished, ended under gloomy skies in Yale's Bowl tonight with the Elis dancing on the torn turf behind a band that brayed "Good Night, Poor Harvard."

The War Shipping Administration has notified ship owners and operators that the government's merchant marine policy recognizes advertising expenditures as reasonable and justifiable overhead expenses to keep trade names and line services before the public.

Over the past few years, the production of floor coverings has been high and, thanks to the heavy buying policy of retailers and distributors in 1941, unusually large stocks of finished rugs and carpets were accumulated, of which sufficient remain to bridge the transition period from "all wool" to the "wool and rayon" combinations on which the industry is now working.

A herb tea will be given tomorrow at 2:30 in the laboratory building of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, following the last lecture in a course on herbs. Dr. H. K. Svenson, curator of the herbarium, is to speak on "Identification of Herbs," and Dr. R. H. Cheney, resident investigator, will talk on "Herb Teas."

WASHINGTON. Nov. 21 -- (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to show cause why its long-distance telephone rates and other charges should not be substantially reduced.

THIS is one of the comparatively few "must" books for every library shelf devoted to foreign affairs. There is no comparable survey in English of the decline and fall of the Third Republic, of the decline that went on gradually, sometimes imperceptibly, during the Thirties, reaching a climactic crescendo in the terrible days of the German invasion in 1940.

NEARLY ten centuries ago the fourth Fatimite Caliph, Al AI Mo'izz li-din Allah, ruled over the greater part of three African lands where American armed forces are now engaged -- Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia. He selected Cairo in Egypt as his capital in place of Mahdia, a Mediterranean port in Tunisia.

A survey of the main ski centers in the Northeastern snowbelt of the United States and Canada indicates that there will be no major curtailment of activities. The principal resorts will remain open and do their part in the "keep fit for all-out war effort" program, with the knowledge that recreation, no matter how brief its period, is a basic need.

Shipping men in New York warned last week that serious disruptions might occur in a smooth-running wartime industry if there is any attempt to change longshore hiring practices or if the threatened struggle for longshore labor control between the American Federation of Labor and the Congess of Industrial Organizations becomes an actuality.

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM is interested in conducting popular-priced concerts in this country which will be planned largely for service men and defense workers. He has already conducted one in Seattle and he has consulted with Seattle labor leaders about the sponsorship of further concerts there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The official assurances that have been given by the Spanish Government both to the American Embassy in Madrid and to the State Department through the Spanish Embassy here that Spain's policy in the war is one of neutrality are now accepted at their full face value.

FABULOUS, indeed, the career of Sarah Bernhardt! Born out of wedlock, daughter of a woman who neglected her child for her lovers, granddaughter of a Jewish dressmaker of Rotterdam, Sarah, still in her 'teens, began to earn her living as a salesgirl in a millinery shop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd's statement that the Federal Government is the chief offender in the waste and hoarding of manpower has raised but not answered an important question -- is the government overstaffed?

DHOLPUR, India, Nov. 17 (Delayed) -- The warring nations will have a chance to end the conflict in April, Swami Nirmalanand, a disciple of Swami Vivekananda, who was well known in the United States early in this century, said in an interview this morning.

The electric power and light industry, one of the nation's largest consumers of copper, has embarked on a widespread conservation program designed to cut down sharply its demand for the metal so essential to the war effort.

" WILL Germany crack, and, if so, when?" The question is raised again by recent military events. Germany cracked suddenly in 1918; the American soldier was a symbol of that disaster. And now the American soldier is once more uncomfortably close to the German soldier's line of vision.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Tokyo's radio announcement today to the Japanese of special efforts by their government to speed up aircraft production because of the new American plan to double our output in the coming year, was the latest of accumulating signs of rather frantic defensive efforts by the Axis powers in both the military and the propaganda fields.

LONDON, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- A Stockholm dispatch quoted Swedish newspapers today as saying tension in Berlin was mounting hourly about the battle of Tunisia, since the Germans were extremely curious about American fighting morale and efficiency.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 21 -- Ohio State's brilliant precision football machine overpowered the Buckeyes' bitterest rival, Michigan, 21 to 7, to win the Western Conference championship today before 71,896 fans.

FURTHER proof that the night club medium has considerably increased in stature since the clamorous days of the prohibition era (when four walls, a lusty singer and a broken-down piano generally constituted the average bistro) is offered with the announcement that it will cost at least $45,000 to open the doors of the Riobamba on the evening of Dec. 3.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Kansas State, victim of eight straight defeats, upset a favored Iowa State football team, 7 -- 6, today in a Big Six contest. The Wildcats scored on a 56-yard march the first time they got possession of the ball in the initial period.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The great oil industry of Texas is moving toward greater production for the war effort under two directives issued by the State Railroad Commission to sustain production and conserve waning reserves.

THE vast upheaval in American education is vividly realized today in any technical publishing office. We are in a war of science. Ordinarily, the day's mail would contain pieces from Boston Tech. Purdue, Cornell, and so on.

Paul S. Willis was re-elected president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at the close of the association's annual meeting Friday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday, after the board of directors met and approved the elections and a set of resolutions adopted by the food processors.

TO the vast army of commentators on Indian affairs at a supreme crisis in the destinies of Asia the personality of Mr. Gandhi has been an enigma. They have seen him casually, if at all, and judge of him from a distance.

In her first public address since returning from a month-long visit to the British Isles Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will discuss 'Women in a Democracy" at the sixteenth annual Friendship Dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt tonight. The program theme will be "Women in War and Peace."

With inventory control approaching and stocks of most home furnishings becoming extremely unbalanced, many merchants last week started to give serious consideration to the feasibility of swapping goods or even making outright sales among themselves.

The grand pincers drive of the United Nations was closing hard last week on the Axis forces in North Africa. In the weathered mountains of Tunisia, where ancient empires rose and fell, and on the sere wasteland of Libya, where armies have advanced and retreated for the past two years, one of the most dramatic chapters of World War II was being written.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Turning loose their power in every period, North Carolina defeated the University of Virginia today, 28 to 13, before a crowd of 6,000.

The General Motors Corporation, symbol of the peacetime mass production of automobiles, refrigerators and much other material equipment for normal modern life, till be largely a supplier of aviation needs for the United Nations until victory has been won.

Badeau, dean of the American College in Cairo, declared yesterday at a Foreign Policy Association luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that was devoted to consideration of the Allied situation in Africa and the Near East.

More merchandise will be available for consumer needs during the early part of 1943 than has been anticipated and many merchants expect gains in January over the extremely high sales figures of that month in 1942, it is disclosed in the first nationwide trade survey of retail prospects for the early part of the coming year.

The incomparable Don Hutson, who already has broken all National Football League pass-catching records with the season yet unfinished, will bring his talents to the Polo Grounds today when the Packers face the New York Giants. The kick-off is set for 2:30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Authority to rule upon requests for wage increases for about 8,000,000 workers in twenty-nine major industries was given by the War Labor Board today to directors of its ten regional offices.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 21 -- Georgia lost today to brilliant and under-rated Auburn, 27 -- 13, and the crash of America's No. 1 football team probably resounded all the way to Pasadena, Calif.

The bugle call of Krakow, the folksongs of Denmark and the hearty greeting of the Dutch Santa Claus, Sinterklaas sounded through the halls of the Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries at Madison Square Garden yesterday, giving true international flavor.

Charlotte Murray Russell's new detective is Noah Harper, a retired shoe manufacturer from Des Moines. He does not care particularly to be a detective -- or perhaps his reluctance is assumed -- but his wife, Louella, is consumed with curiosity about how other people live and die, and she eggs Noah on.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 21 -- An alert, efficient Wisconsin football team that smashed 61 yards to score in the first three minutes, checked Minnesota's power drives the rest of the way today to gain a 20-to-6 victory before 46,000 fans.

More student seamen are needed for the expanding training schools of the United States Maritime Service throughout the country, according to an appeal for volunteers sent out yesterday by Lieutenant (j.g.) Francis J. Mitko, U.S.M.S., regional enrolling director of the service at 45 Broadway.

FORT DES MOINES, Nov. 21 (AP) -- West Point's graduation day wedding tradition was copied by a Waac today when Third Officer Louise Bowery and First Lieutenant Philip Linden Smith of the Air Corps marched to the altar for a military ceremony immediately after she received her commission.

When the spotlights flash on the ice of the Madison Square Garden rink on the night of Dec. 1 the occasion will be one of singular importance to the Musicians Emergency Fund. For several years the directorate of the fund has taken over the opening performance of the Ice Follies of the current season to advance its various projects aiding musicians in need.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 21 -- Otto Graham's brilliant passing failed to match the effects of Notre Dame's pulverizing ground attack led by Sophomore Fullback Corwin Clatt today and the Irish snatched a 27-to-20 victory from Northwestern before a crowd of 30,000.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Great Lakes scored its fifth straight shut-out victory today, downing Illinois, 6 to 0, before a crowd of 10,856. It was the first time this year that the Illini failed to cross their opponents' goal line.

The public appears to have lost its taste for the silly love stories that Arnold Smith has been writing, and so, on the advice of his publisher, he decides to try his hand at writing a murder mystery. For this purpose, and because his flat in London has been bombed, he goes to the village of Nether Naughton and becomes a paying guest in the home of Mr. Hardstaffe, headmaster of the village school.

PORT LYAUTEY, Morocco, Nov. 17 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Major Pierpont M. Hamilton of 415 East Fifty-first Street, New York, told today how he and the late Colonel Demas (Nick) Craw of Charlottesville, Va., rode a jeep through French lines in a futile effort to prevent useless bloodshed.

CITY COLLEGE -- Study Added A recommendation that the social science curriculum at City College be revised to include one year of American Civilization, to be required for all liberal arts degrees, has been made by the college's curriculum committee, it has been announced by Professor Nelson P. Mead, chairman of the history department.

THERE are just a few small professional problems left in football. For instance, will the Redskins clinch the leadership of the Eastern segment by throwing the Dodgers for a loss in Washington today? Also what will be the score in the romp of the Great Big Bears over the Lions in Detroit this afternoon?

SALEM, Ore., Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- Dr. John C. Evans, superintendent of the State Mental Hospital, disclosed tonight that a patient had been found responsible for the introduction of sodium fluoride into a dinner of scrambled eggs which took the lives of forty-seven inmates and made more than 400 others ill on Wednesday night.

Widening its drive against violations of the price-posting and record-keeping provisions of the general maximum price regulation, the regional Office of Price Administration yesterday sent warning notices to 265 more retailers. The warnings were the same as the first batch of 440 sent out on Nov. 7, and more are to come as investigators continue their spot checks throughout the six-State area, according to Irvin C. Rutter, chief enforcement attorney for this region.

IF you want to spend $300 in four hours and have one of the best times in your life, the Lambs have a way. In the course of entertaining yourself you will incidentally be dining 200-odd soldiers, sailors, marines or merchant seamen of the United Nations.

Girls her own age may not care much for her story, but their parents should like it very much. Mrs. Aldis has an eye and ear too keen for the comfort of the observed, but she makes them a source of innocent merriment for older people.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 22 -- A French assault on German dugouts in the hastily erected Nazi defense are around Tunis and Bizerte, with the result still undetermined, and the capture by Allied advance units of an important crossroads in the Tunis area were reported early today from North Africa, where powerful Allied forces are moving rapidly to smash the beleaguered Axis Tunisian troops.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Stanford crowned its Pacific Coast Conference football season in brilliant fashion today with a stunning 26-to-7 victory over the University of California.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- More than 300,000 hotels, restaurants, clubs, boarding houses, hospitals and institutions were ordered by the Office of Price Administration today to keep records of virtually all foods they serve during December.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -- An American destroyer, a British corvette and a Liberty cargo ship slid down the ways yesterday in one of the busiest launching periods bay area yesterday shipyards have had in weeks.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 (AP) -- With the end of hearings near on the 1943-44 State budget, there were indications today that the present $380,000,000 State expenditure program would be reduced in Thomas E. Dewey's first year as Governor.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 22 -- German assaults intended to better the Nazi position in the Caucasus after the smashing Russian victory before Orjonikidze have been consistently hurled back by Russian units and at least two companies and a battalion of the enemy have been annihilated or dispersed, the Russians reported early today.

Retirement of Waiter C. Teagle as chairman and election of Ralph W. Gallagher, now a director and vice president, to succeed him, are scheduled to be ratified tomorrow at a meeting of the board of directors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- When United States troops waded ashore in North Africa on Nov. 7, opening the long-awaited "second front," they carried with them the finest equipment that money and American production ingenuity could provide.

The twenty-first annual Christmas sale of the New York State Commission for the Blind will open next Friday at 608 Fifth Avenue, corner of West Forty-ninth Street, and will continue daily, except Sundays, through Dec. 19. "The Blind See Through to Victory" is the 1942 wartime theme of the sale.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21 -- Leading virtually from start to finish and carrying his speed for the full mile and a sixteenth, Doublrab today won the $6,100 Prince George Autumn Handicap before a crowd variously estimated at from 5,000 to 8,000.

Next month the United States Government will ask its people for a $9,000,000,000 loan. This is by far the largest single financing operation any government has ever attempted anywhere. It eclipses even the great Fourth Liberty Loan of 1918 which totaled nearly $7,000,000,000.

THE identity of Ethel Vance is, of course, no secret now. For more than two years it was an almost embarrassingly well-kept secret. We were sure of only one thing, that the author of the grimly thrilling "Escape" was a writer already known to us under some other name.

THE latest Cornelia Otis Skinner book (with a bow to Emily Kimbrough, collaborator) is a fine, funny, effervescent tale of a trip abroad in the early Twenties. Cornelia and Emily, both 19 and quite on their own, sailed from Montreal for a Summer in England and France.

It was with a great deal of interest that I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine Cyrus Sulzberger's article on the second anniversary of the Italian invasion of Greece. The article was an exceptionally fine one. However, I wish to point out one slight historical mistake, Mr. Sulzberger's reference to the second defense of Thermopylae, in which the Australians and Greeks unsuccessfully attempted to stem the invading "Barbarians."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Senate held a clinic today over the moribund anti-poll tax bill, but lectures by its friends and foes only deepened the general conviction that the measure would die Monday.

Women prominent in society, artistic and business circles, and wives of military and naval leaders will participate in a unique show entitled "Women Can Take It," which will be presented on the night of Dec. 15 on the stage of the Rivoli Theatre under the auspices of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc.

These are reported to be the first to reach the United States in quantity, although they are listed as a minor variety, unpriced, in the Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Tennessee's rugged Volunteers brushed aside Kentucky to enhance their post-season Bowl chances today with a convincing 26-0 triumph before 20,000 fans.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Recovering from two successive defeats, White Plains High School's Tigers scored a 27-13 triumph over North Tarrytown High today.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- Boston College continued on its bowlward way today by crushing a hard-fighting Boston University eleven, 37 -- 0, at Fenway Park before a small crowd of 5,000.

EVERY once in a while -- even in these days -- the most sensible woman has an irrepressible impulse to become a femme fatale. The Red Cross worker yearns for a moment of glamour, the vacationing sophomore must become a siren just for an evening.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, whose appointment as Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation was announced officially at the White House yesterday, said in an interview last night at his home, 820 Park Avenue, that his new assignment would involve getting food, clothing, medicine and other assistance to the peoples of occupied countries as soon as their nations were freed of the Axis yoke.

The arrest of seven enemy aliens -- five Germans, one a woman, and two Italians -- was announced yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, agent in charge here of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The arrests were made in "spot raids" in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Westchester.

The saga of Powder Valley grows apace. If memory serves, this is the seventh volume that Peter Field has devoted to the exploits of his stock trio of thoroughbred old-timers, Pat Stevens, One-Eyed Ezra and Sharpshooter Sam, who used outlaw methods to enforce law and became the heroes of that lush and ordinarily peaceful Colorado valley.

The John Harms Chorus of seventy-five voices, with John Harms conducting, will give a performance of Verdi's "Requiem" next Saturday at 8:30 P.M. in Town Hall. Proceeds of the concert will be donated to Russian War Relief.

Chinese and French war orphans will be aided by a special performance of an "Ancient Chinese Porcelain Tea Dance" to be given by Chao Ming-Chu, young Chinese-Javanese dancer, on Wednesday night at the headquarters of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., 451 Madison Avenue, under the auspices of the Chinese Women's Relief Association, Inc.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES NEAR BUNA, New Guinea, Nov. 16 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A high commanding general of the United States forces had to dive frequently to avoid machine-gun bullets of Japanese planes which fired at him and other survivors of two trawlers sunk off the coast today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A reorganization of the engineering divisions of the Army engineers to make their boundaries coincide with those of the nine Army service commands in the United States was announced today by the War Department.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Senator Clark of Idaho outlined a new effort to bring the latest recorded music to the "juke boxes" and radio stations through a "showdown" with James C. Petrillo.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 21 -- Brig. Gen. Patrick W. Timberlake, chief of the Bomber Command of the United States Army's Ninth Air Force, narrowly escaped being shot down while on what had been planned as the longest raid by American heavy bombers in the war, the Air Force headquarters reported today.

IN another week the traditional holiday shopping season will be fully under way and retailers will have a better idea of what the final results are likely to be. Quite a little gift purchasing has already been done, particularly for the armed services, but volume is running below the estimates of a 20 per cent gain for the whole season.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 21 -- Army and Navy authorities here received word today that Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, rescued Nov. 12 after twenty-four days on a life raft following the emergency landing of his bomber plane in the Pacific southwest of Oahu, would be ready in another week to leave the hospital at a South Pacific base where he has been recuperating.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21 -- Yale will go ahead with its plans for football and other sports for another year unless the government makes a request for a change, Ogden D. Miller, director of athletics, said today. Yale will take immediate steps to carry out any policy presented by the government, he added, but no word has been received that would tend to interfere with present schedules.
Several dinner parties will precede the benefit performance of Thornton Wilder's new play, "The Skin of Our Teeth," at the Plymouth Theatre tomorrow night in aid of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery.

Fitts, director, military personnel division of the surgeon general's office, has written in a letter to the headquarters of the United Hospital Campaign, it was announced yesterday.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has attained forefront rank with a few European museums in the field of ancient engraved gems as a result of recent acquisition of more than 500 examples, which are to be placed on public exhibition tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Aggressive buying of rye futures by houses with Eastern connections and heavy short covering attributed to professional operators ran the rye market up 1 3/4 cents a bushel today as rumors were heard that the government contemplated having distillers use an increased amount of this grain in the production of alcohol.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- Temple upset Oklahoma, 14 to 7, before 3,000 fans at Temple Stadium today. The inexperienced Temple eleven scored both its touchdowns via aerials, one on its own pass and one on an interception.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) -- An immediate need for more combat planes and fast patrol bombers in the Pacific war theatre led the government to cancel its contract with the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation for flying cargo-boats, one of the largest commitments for that type of craft.

" ALWAYS Attempt the Impossible!" Such is the motto of General Henri Honore Giraud, the uncompromising patriot who today leads the French forces in the struggle against their traditional enemy on the North African battlefield.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Submarine warfare in the Mediterranean, which has been intensified by the opposing forces since the victorious battle of Egypt and the United States troop landings in North Africa, has resulted in still further successes for the British Navy in its ceaseless efforts to weaken the Axis's African forces by slicing their lifelines of supply.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The present campaign in North Africa promises to keep the Allied land, sea and air forces in that theatre of war extremely busy for months to come before they can complete their task of throwing out the Axis once and for all and gaining undisputed hold of the thousands of miles of coastline from the Atlantic to the Nile Delta.

The announcement after the Saturday, Nov. 14, episode that the "Gibbs and Finney" sketches were to take leave of the air waves was cause for considerable regret on my part. The two leading characters from whom the series derived its name, which were played by Parker Fennelly and Arthur Allan, had an ingratiating way of blending a certain hard-bitten humor with a pronounced touch of Yankee shrewdness.

THE Music School Settlement will do its share in the celebration of "Thanks to Russia" month by presenting a Carnival of Russian Music Dec. 3-6 at the school for the benefit of Russian War Relief. The participants, all of whom are donating their services, include the Budapest String Quartet; Maria Maximovitch, soprano; Ray Lev, Sylvia Smith and Milton Kaye, pianists; Benno Rabinoff, violin; Milton Katims, viola, and Ralph McLean, clarinet.

It has become a well-worn axiom of the second World War that the steel and copper and brass which in former times went into our washing machines, refrigerators and vacuum cleaners are now the raw materials for democracy's arsenal.

A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Nov. 6 (Delayed) -- We were all what the Army euphemistically calls "casuals," officers and men and newspaper correspondents who, for one reason or another, had no permanent billet at the moment.

Two subscription dances, designed for the entertainment of young officers in the armed forces and debutantes of this season and former years, will take place this coming week-end. The ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton will be the setting Friday night for the Autumn Dance, of which Miss Anne Delafield Finch is chairman and on Saturday the first of two Mayfair Assemblies Mill be given in the Viennese roof and penthouse suite of the St. Regis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Official announcement was made by the White House today that Governor Lehman of New York would resign about Dec. 3 to undertake the organization of participation by the United States in the activities of the United Nations in furnishing relief and other assistance to victims of the war in the areas reoccupied by the Allied forces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (Science Service) -- Abatement of fire danger from gasoline vapor in remote corners and glory holes of airplanes is the objective of an invention by F.J. Schirm of Hoboken, N.J., on which he has just received United States patent No. 2,302,061 from the Patent Office.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 21 -- Freshman Larry Joe's 90-yard return of the second-half kick-off for a touchdown featured Penn State's 14-to-6 victory over Pitt today before 12,000 spectators at Beaver Field in the two teams' football finale for the season.

The word filibuster, probably derived from the Dutch vry buiter (freebooter), was originally given to buccaneers, then to Yankees who started revolutions in Latin America. By extension it has come to mean a legislative tactic to defeat passage of a law opposed by a minority of legislators.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Germany entered the war with overwhelming air superiority. Adolf Hitler counted on it to terrorize his enemies into submission. But it failed miserably when it was hurled against Britain and ever since then the balance of power in the air has been shifting.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 -- Adverse weather conditions have disrupted plans of grain shippers, and large bulk freighters will not be switched from the ore to the grain trade until late next week, it was learned here today.

It is said that the future of the nation is in the hands of believers. When the Federal Government turned to the public schools in 1940 for the training of its industrial manpower for war production, it exhibited faith in the truest form. Detroit, known world wide as the motor car crucible, rightly became the arsenal of manufacture for the machines of war.

IT was a sound idea of Kathleen Hinni's to organize the Duncan Dance Congress, which took place last week-end under the auspices of the Dance Theatre of the Y.M.H.A., for, as she stated in her original call for the congress, little is known by either the public or the dancers themselves about the current trend of Duncan dancing.
KLUANE LAKE, Yukon Territory, Nov. 21 -- The wilderness route to Alaska is open today, seven months and seventeen days after building of the 1,600-mile road began.

SIR ALEXANDER KORDA, owner-producer member of United Artists, is closing out his film production activities in this country and hereafter will make his pictures in England. Sir Alex, who returned recently from London, said his production plans for the future are very indefinite at the moment, though he still is considering making a film of Tolstoy's "War and Peace."
The Red Army held the initiative yesterday in every Soviet sector mentioned in the German High Command's communique, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

THE late afternoon sun burned flame-red in the west like an omen from Mars. In the shower rooms steam and suds combined in a refreshing relief for men getting ready for chow after the routine day's work.

Frederick Graham, describing the qualities of the American in his text accompanying the photographs, "A Gallery of Fighting Fliers," in THE TIMES Magazine, used one particular sentence that I believe holds the key to our success, at the same time unlocking many mysteries concerning the Old World.

BAYPORT, L.I., Nov. 21 -- Mrs. Edmund W. Poor of Bay Shore, L.I., carried off the honors today as the annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Club opened in the covers and adjacent waters of the estates of Ralph Green and James I. Davis.

A special feature of the Metropolitan Opera Association's activities during the second week of the season, starting Monday night, Nov. 30, will be the revival of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" on Dec. 4, in which Helen Traubel will sing the role of Isolde for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House.

IF your taste runs to the sense of remote forests, and direct and echoing words (including proper names) to incarnate a wilderness, you will pause in delight to reread the third page of "We Took to the Woods": "There are very few people living here," the author introduces her home, "and no roads down into what we call the Outside.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- Military experts in the Soviet press this week are explaining the implications of the Allies' successes, and the public, seeing the Allied lines unfold along the coast of the African continent, is beginning to realize as never before the power of those forces for whose unleashing they longed so passionately during the black Summer days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that a medium-sized United States merchant vessel was torpedoed and sunk by an enemy submarine in the latter part of October in the Atlantic off the northern coast of South America.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The first old-fashioned pea-soup fog since the war started settled down on London on Nov. 11, it can now be said. So impenetrable was it that King George's car took an hour to creep from Buckingham Palace to the King's Cross Station, normally no more than a twenty-minute drive -- and it was only done at all with the aid of policemen walking beside the royal car flashing torches.

Children studying in special classes at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association community house, at 331 East Seventieth Street, are cooperating with committee members in plans for the benefit performance of "The Pirate" on Dec. 1, at the Martin Beck Theatre.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Stopped cold for three mauling periods, the North Carolina Naval Pre-Flight eleven, coached by Jim Crowley, exploded a pulverizing attack in the final quarter today to conquer a battling but outmanned William and Mary team, 14 -- 0, before 10,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- An average wage of 88.5 cents an hour in manufacturing industries in September -- a gain of 2.4 per cent over August and 16.9 per cent over September, 1941 -- was reported today by Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor.

IT is a wholesome experience to read a novel about the early settlers of Pennsylvania. What made these German immigrants good pioneers: their capacity for hard work, their stability, their love of home and their good cheer, are virtues planted deep in the republic, and it is a satisfaction to see credit given where it is due.

The thirty-sixth annual Christmas Seal campaign to raise funds for the control of tuberculosis will begin tomorrow throughout the city. Seals will be sent to 781,000 homes and booths for their sale will be set up in department stores, banks, postoffices, railroad terminals, moving-picture houses and theatres.

Contrasting the earning power of the automotive industry in 1942 with 1941 reveals that despite the tremendous strides made in converting the indusrty outright into armament production, the headway lost in the early stages of the change-over had not been made up at the three-quarter mark of the current year.
A message of a sincerely intended peace with justice has just been dispatched to Europe.
DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Duke, at its best, caught North Carolina State at its worst today, and when the ensuing slaughter had ended the Blue Devils had won, 47 to 0.

OUT over the coast today, almost a year after the Japs flew in over Pearl Harbor, many little planes are flying with the big blimps and bombers and Coast Guard ships. From many a coastal base, single-motored land planes are heading out over the water.

Five officers of the Police Department, including Captain James B. Harten, aide to Mayor La Guardia, were promoted one grade yesterday at exercises in City Hall Plaza to mark the induction of 219 "rookies" into the department and the graduation of 109 probationary patrolmen. Sixteen of the rookies were women.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 21 -- Congressional moves to suspend legal provisions for payment of overtime after forty hours of work have resulted in a renewal of the dispute which began last Spring when the House Naval Affairs Committee spent a week in listening to witnesses testify on the Smith bill banning such overtime pay.
