Civilian textile buyers will have to adopt a more realistic wartime viewpoint on 1943 supplies, one that recognizes "half a loaf is better than none," manufacturers pointed out here last week.

There was considerable activity in the wholesale markets last week, with quite a number of ready-to-wear and accessories buyers in town and more expected, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Members of Essex County Parent- Teacher Associations have embarked on an all-out campaign to interest housewives in training for war production jobs, under the leadership of Mrs. Fred H. Troup of Millburn, president.

ALL of the many patterns formed by that engaging human kaleidoscope, Tommy Ybarra, are pleasing and in gay colors. Basic pattern is his heritage -- Boston Back Bay and Venezuela -- described last year in his "Young Man of Caracas,'' which many a reader still hugs with delight.

Municipal bond dealers, faced with the smallest supply of new issues in nearly twenty-five years, and with little hope of increase for the duration of the war, are now seeking "merchandise for the shelves" by bidding sharply for blocks of bonds held in the investment portfolios of life insurance companies.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

The rousing impetus of a first-half drive along with the flourish of a 76-yard touchdown romp a half minute from the end gave Fordham a 20-12 upset victory over Missouri before 11,000 thrilled and unbelieving fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

" SAILOR JACK," which follows the same pattern as the author's "Soldier Sammy," tells of a small boy who lived near the water where the ships came in, wore a sailor suit and a sailor cap and wanted to be a real sailor like his father.

OTTAWA, Nov. 21 -- Canada's efforts to improvise an effective system of selective service and put the man and woman power of the country to a total use for total war blew up this week in a somewhat spectacular storm of accusation and counter-accusation that has left the country very puzzled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- In an open letter to President Roosevelt, made public by the White House today, the Prime Minister of Iraq, General Nuri es-Said, extended congratulations on the operations in North Africa and declared that they had caused the Arabs of North Africa and the Near East to be "full of rejoicing."

As the chill deepens through the lengthening nights, spare a thought for the sky watchers on towers and hilltops all through this seacoast land. When you are going to bed at midnight they are climbing to lonely eyries and a three-hour communion with the darkness and its stars.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Iowa Seahawks, a potent mixture of former collegiate and professional football stars, crushed Nebraska by 46 to 0 today, the worst defeat for the Cornhuskers since they started playing the grid-iron sport back in 1890.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Coast Guard reserves were sent into the Bethlehem Fairfield shipyards today because of a factional dispute within the International Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America (C.I.O.), Commander Carl H. Abel, captain of the port of Baltimore, said today.

NOEL COWARD certainly started something over here with "In Which We Serve" when he proved he could write, produce, direct, compose and act in a film and make a conspicuous success of it. Now he has all the boys unsettled.

W.L. Hemingway, president of the American Bankers Association and of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis, Mo., addressed yesterday a letter to all members of the association urging their support of the Treasury Department's new plans for distributing Government securities.

Marking the twenty-second anniversary of the founding of the Soldiers and Sailors Club, 283 Lexington Avenue, a Red, White and Blue tea dance and cocktail party will be given Dec. 17 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. The proceeds will aid in maintenance of the club, which is for the exclusive use of enlisted men in the armed forces.

A State-wide conference devoted to problems confronting Negro youth was held yesterday at the Abyssinia Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street. Three hundred delegates from Negro youth and educational organizations attended the opening of the two-day parley.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 20 -- A clean-up campaign has begun in Alsace to rid the Province of anti-Nazi Germans and Nazi defeatists, according to reports received here. Four prominent Nazis have been expelled. One hundred and thirty-one Alsatians, including the Burgomaster of Reichshoffen, have been transferred to the interior of Germany "to be re-educated" and a general investigation is under way on the activities of all Germans in the Province.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Setting up statutory "safeguards" and "controls," a subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee completed today and approved unanimously a substitute bill for the one in which the Administration asked sweeping powers for the President to suspend during the war laws affecting the free movement in and out of the country of persons, property and information.

AS the full story unfolds, Franklin D. Roosevelt's feat in outguessing the dictators becomes more and more spectacular. The North African venture, which caught the Axis totally unprepared, stamps the President as the equal, if not the master, of Hitler and his associates in the use of the psychological blitz.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- One of the most pleasing things about the recent performances of United States men and materiel in Europe and North Africa, so far as the United States Army Air Force headquarters here is concerned, has been the way in which its big four-engined bombers, the Liberator and the Flying Fortress, have met the test of combat.

" PROGRESS TO FREEDOM" tells with authority the highly dramatic story of how the democratization of education transformed the American wilderness of 300 years ago into our present state of civilization.

Gold-mining shares proved to be the high spot in yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange, but the list as a whole moved irregularly and closed dull and mixed. Volume was only 310,700 shares, which was better than the 260,620-share total of the previous Saturday, but was not regarded as good.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Washington is fighting on the price control front a very effective stabilizing and delaying action, but the pressure of the enemy -- the inflation gap, estimated at $15,000,000, 000 next year -- already is terrific and will increase.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Indiana University's backfield showed its power today and for the first time the Hoosiers won the Old Oaken Bucket three years in a row by defeating Purdue, 20 to 0, before a crowd of 20,000.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The U.C.L.A. Bruins snatched victory from an embattled crew of Washington Huskies in the last minute of play today, recovering a wildly bouncing bad pass from center and emerging with a 14-to- 10 decision that kept them in the race for the Pacific Coast football title.

Art collectors, dealers and a large number of private buyers filled the auction rooms of the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday to participate in the last of six sessions of the sale of valuable English, French and Italian works of art from the collection of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann of Oyster Bay, L.I., and this city.

Under the chairmanship of William J. Minsch of Minsch, Monell Co., Inc., a nominating committee of the National Association of Securities Dealers, District 13, has nominated a slate of successors for the governors and committee members whose terms will expire on Jan. 15.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 21 -- W.A. Clark, president of the New England Coal Dealers' Association, said this week that plans were being made to use boats now engaged in Great Lakes transportation to bring coal to New England to insure an adequate supply of solid fuel for industries which have been converted from oil, as well as for that group now hesitating because they fear that conversion will bring on a coal shortage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The War Production Board announced today that officials of the wool section of the textile, clothing and leather goods division yesterday placed before members of the woolen and worsted manufacturers' advisory committee for discussion a tentative plan to increase the worsted wool quota for manufacturers of civiilan clothing during the next six months.

Limited to one victory in ten previous meetings with Princeton, Army made up for past indignities by inflicting the most crushing defeat suffered by either team in the history of their rivalry yesterday as 18,000 looked on under leaden skies at the Yankee Stadium.

The shriek of the Saturday noon air raid siren rang through the narrow streets at Wall and Nassau yesterday to remind of war. At the same time 1,000 women stood jammed on the steps of the Sub-treasury Building to remind of women in war.

ALGIERS, Nov. 15 (Delayed) -- The Allies' main object in their campaign in North Africa is the expulsion of the Germans and Italians. The political and military administration in North Africa must be considered in this light. The administration now issuing orders in Algiers is regarded as the one best fitted to resist Axis attacks on North Africa and to aid United States and British troops in their campaign for the Continent's salvation.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- A force numbering several hundred of Britain's biggest bombers dealt terrific blows at the arsenal city of Turin late last night and early today in what officials here described as the heaviest raid thus far made by the Royal Air Force on an Italian city.

WITH ALLIED FORCES NEAR BUNA, New Guinea, Nov. 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- The officer at headquarters who writes the communiques used a half dozen words Wednesday to tell how Japanese bombers sank two Allied trawlers off the Buna coastal area, but he did not mention that two Allied generals were aboard the trawlers and had to swim to shore.

" ANYTHING that comes to the net is fish," is the popular quotation at the moment along the rock-bound coast of Maine. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has even started a survey of sea mussels, and to a rubber-booted population that's the height of something or other.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 21 -- With complete occupation by the Axis, the French ship of state may be compared to a galley. On the poop, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain still flies his flag, still styles himself "Chief of State," still has a household troop composed of a singular hybrid, half-gendarme, half-soldier group.
ONE can now drive by automobile from Washington, D.C., to Fairbanks, Alaska. The long-dreamed-of, long-discussed North American Highway is a reality.

Federal approval will be sought for an increase in local trucking rates, ranging from 10 to 25 per cent, it was announced yesterday by Morris Klemas, executive secretary of the Master Truckmen of America, Inc., who filed a petition with the Office of Price Administration for a determination of the status of local truckers as contract or common carriers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The independence of the French West Indies and French Guiana from the government of Pierre Laval is considered assured through an agreement reached in the light of the new European situation by Samuel Reber, representative of the American State Department, and Admiral Georges Robert, French High Commissioner, who has jurisdiction over French possessions in the Western Hemisphere from his headquarters in Fort-de-France, Martinique, it was learned here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The United States forces on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons have advanced in the face of enemy patrol activity and gained new ground west of their former positions, the Navy announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- William M. Jeffers, Rubber Administrator, assured a Congressional group today that he meant no reflection on them when he protested that opposition to nation-wide gasoline rationing was being financed "by people who should know better," but he gave no assurance that he would delay the program beyond Dec. 1 for further study.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 21 (UP) -- Alabama's Crimson Tide displayed power in every department to defeat Vanderbilt, 27 to 7, and win its last Southeastern Conference game today before a crowd of 18,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -The Army and Navy appealed today to aircraft, shipyard and other war plant workers to remain at their jobs rather than enlist. Secretary Stimson and Secretary Knox said in a joint statement:

A DISPLAY of Victorian furniture just opened in the Members' Room at the Newark Museum neatly coincides with a rising appreciation of the style by interior decorators and in purchases at antique shops. At the Coleman Galleries recently no less than five suites of rosewood sofas and chairs made by John Henry Belter, famous New York cabinetmaker, were sold at prices ranging from several hundred to over a thousand dollars a set.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- For outstanding gallantry in leading his battalion of a rifle brigade while it was cut off from other British forces for thirty hours in the recent battle of Egypt, during which the battalion wiped out fifty-five of ninety German tanks that attacked his position, Major Buller Turner of Thatcher, Berkshire, has received the Victoria Cross.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Best-in-show at the forty-eighth annual fixture of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia, held at Convention Hall, tonight went to Mrs. E.P. Alker's Welsh terrier, Ch. Flornell Rare-Bit of Twin Ponds, handled by John Goudie.

Retail trade here last week showed sharp percentage gains over the 1941 week, but in the main this was due to the fact that the latter period included the early Thanksgiving holiday. For the full week this year, against a five-day sales period in 1941, department stores had increases ranging from 25 to 35 per cent.

FRANK SWINNERTON'S new book, "Thankless Child," again shows him the master of mood and portraiture which made his "Nocturne" a memorable novel. Throughout this strange tale of the morbid relationship between a father and his daughter one is held not so much by the incidents he uses to develop his tale as by the dark atmosphere of the story and the brilliant portrayal of a unique group of characters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Within a single week the military and naval estimate of our war with Japan in the Pacific has changed from anxiety into the calm type of confidence that comes only with a victory such as naval forces -- supported by air power but themselves carrying the brunt of battle -- won over the last week-end in the waters around the wartorn Solomon Islands.

Members of the junior committee of the Spence Alumnae Society will be guests at a tea which Mrs. Kneeland L. Green will give Wednesday at her home, 129 East Sixty-ninth Street, to discuss plans for the Christmas tea dance the society will give Dec. 28 at the Stork Club.

NORTH AFRICA is a long way from Abilene, Kan., but everything that goes on at the African front is of intense interest to the people of this old town -- long famous in the cattle-driving days of the West, but more famous today as the home of Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. ( "Ike" ) Eisenhower.

Representatives of legislative and executive branches of fifteen State governments in the Northeastern area voiced general approval yesterday of proposals to permit modification or suspension of State laws in a unified war program without involving "any Federal dominance over the State."

FLUORESCENCE -- Gilbert T. Schmidling, an industrial chemist, has developed a new fluorescent material which, unlike most others of its kind, is not susceptible to moisture. A paint film is prefabricated in the form of a tape or a sheet and laminated under heat and pressure so that there is a transparent plastic film on each side.

ANNANDALE-ONTHE-HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- A School of Public Affairs, to offer study and practical field work for undergraduate students in research and administration, will be opened at Bard College, residential unit of Columbia University, starting next June.

The F.L. Jacobs Company, manufacturers of parts for automobiles, and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $571,922 for the year ended on July 31 after deducting $279,000 for Federal income taxes, $870,000 for excess profits taxes and $100,000 for wartime and post-war contingencies, according to a report issued yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Air Ministry said today that the day-and-night battle against Axis submarines in the area of Gibraltar was "the most intensive U-boat hunt of the war" by British aircraft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The council and committees of the Interamerican Bar Association ended a three-day conference today, with speakers paying tributes to the outgoing president, Dr. J. Honorio Silgueira of Buenos Aires, and expressing optimism over plans for the next association convention to be held in Rio de Janeiro Aug. 7-14, 1943.

BOSTON. THE staff of short-wave station WRUL is standing by these days, since the Office of War Information took over the station. Coming more than a week after the government moved, the official announcement indirectly gives a pretty good indication how important WRUL was felt to be in conjunction with the North African campaign.
IN the leading papers recently there were lengthy arguments for and against the operas of Handel. May I add to this the following regarding his oratorios:

STATE COLLEGE, Miss., Nov. 21 (AP) -- After being held, 7 -- 7, at the half, Mississippi State broke loose in a wild display of power and, led by the great Blondy Black, crushed the University of Mississippi Rebels, 34 to 13, today before 18,000.
MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- Russian forces in Central Caucasus continue to advance. The enemy is trying to form a defense line, fortifying heights, laying mine fields and digging anti-tank pits.

Basketball will make its Madison Square Garden debut of the new season tonight when three military teams and the Grumman A.A. quintet participate in the opening-round of a special invitation tournament.
MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- The Red Army is training junior officers in six months whereas before the war the process took two years. Their chief is satisfied little is lost in the intensification.

A check for $25,000 from the Jewish National Workers Alliance, made out to the United States Treasury Department to swell the funds in its campaign for the sale of war bonds and stamps, was handed to Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, as the designated representative of the Treasury Department, at the concert given late yesterday afternoon by the New York City Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Prices of oats futures declined 1 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel last week on the Board of Trade here on liquidation induced by an announcement that Canada had an exportable surplus of 300,000,000 bushels of feed grain, largely oats and barley, but recovered later and finished unchanged to 1/4 cent up for the week, with the last sales of December yesterday at 50 cents.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 -- It is expected that certain users of steel engaged in the manufacture of essential civilian needs or less urgent war requirements will find in December that the War Production Board has slightly increased the flow of metal to them.

The second in the series of supplements to "Advertising Goes to War," published last July by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, will be issued by the bureau today. The supplement reproduces more than fifty representative newspaper advertisements, covering national copy keyed to war, retail copy keyed to war, and straight product ads.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 22 -- The Italian people are reported tonight to be pouring southward by all means available, even as the Propaganda Ministry "suggests" evacuation.

Soviet forces assaulted German positions northwest and south of Stalingrad yesterday as a slight frost helped lift heavy mechanized equipment from the bogs left by recent rains, according to a German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Senate will act tomorrow to write an expected finish to the week-old Poll Tax Bill controversy and after that Congress is likely to go into an informal recess that may last out its life.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22 -- Anna Lee will be co-starred with Maureen O'Hara in RKO's "The Fallen Sparrow," which Richard Wallace will direct, the studio has announced. The film, based on a novel by Dorothy B. Hughes, is a romantic mystery involving espionage here and in Continental Europe.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- So many conflicting reports and factors prevail in the wheat market that trading has slumped to unusually small proportions. Prices fluctuated narrowly last week, with a considerable part of the business in futures on the Board of Trade consisting of spreading between the various deliveries.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices in October, based on 1930 as 100, was 160.0. This compared with 159.1 for September, with 154.6 for October, 1941, and with 98.1 for August, 1939.

Frank Dixon, N.Y.U. freshman who took the I.C. 4-A crown handily last week, gave another dazzling performance yesterday, easily winning the senior metropolitan A.A.U. cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 22 -- Prime Minister John Curtin's proposal to amend the Australian Defense Act to permit the dispatch of the militia to the Southwest Pacific area presents the Labor party with a tremendous opportunity to redeem the errors of the past, it was said here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Flying fists further enlivened a spirited struggle between the Redskins and the Dodgers today as Slingin' Sammy Baugh pitched the local eleven into the Eastern Division championship of the National Football League before a crowd of 34,450 at Griffith Stadium.

Charging that "some people get the idea that because we are in a war and because we are occupied in giving our efforts to the prosecution of the war it is possible to engage in unlawful practices," Mayor La Guardia served notice yesterday that he was not too busy to continue his war on "commercialized vice, gambling, filth or any unlawful activity."

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- The Viceroy's decision not to permit C.R. Rajagopalachari to see Mohandas K. Gandhi was "most unwise and short-sighted," Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru told newspaper men here this afternoon.
MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 22 -- The German city of Bremen has been so hard hit by Royal Air Force raids that women and children are being evacuated for long periods at a time "to rest their nerves," says a news agency dispatch from Berlin today.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Tomorrow will be the thirtieth birthday anniversary of Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell and the date on which she will receive from the trustees the remaining one-third in two trust funds created for her in the will of her father, James B. Duke, tobacco man, who died Oct. 10, 1925.

Assailing the theory of isolation and those persons who are not cooperating in the war because of selfishness anti fear of bodily injury, Dr. Horace J. Bridges, leader of the Chicago Ethical Society, declared in a sermon yesterday morning before the New York Society for Ethical Culture that only in readiness for sacrifice do human beings show their true character and justify the love showered on them by their fellow-men.

In an effort to forestall coffee bootleggers during the suspension of retail coffee sales and the period of rationing that will begin next Sunday, the Office of War Information appealed yesterday to the patriotism of American housewives to report at once to their local rationing boards or OPA office any attempt to sell them black market products.

If British, American and Free French forces are able to dominate the whole of Africa, and drive the last German and Italian soldiers from its shores, the strategic gain will have been enormous. Once more the Mediterranean will be open to British convoys and the British fleet.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- An advance British unit in Tunisia inflicted heavy damage on a German armored column and United States bombers made a large-scale attack on the Tunis airdrome yesterday, Allied headquarters in North Africa announced today.
A High, Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Training taught in the drill shed of their armory in New York City was put to test today as members of the Eighth Regiment, New York Guard, engaged in field exercises on the spacious wooded grounds of the Winged Foot Country Club, near the village of Mamaroneck.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Downing Street announced unexpectedly tonight another shuffle of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's Cabinet. The effects of the changes are more readily apparent than their causes.

ROBERT J. CASEY calls himself a "big harp." He is a reporter and war correspondent who may have traveled more miles covering this war than anybody else. His insatiable curiosity has landed him in many a mess and his broad Irish grin has so far got him out of all of them. He works for The Chicago Daily News and from Pearl Harbor until after the Battle of Midway his assignment was the Pacific Fleet.

Two famous landmarks of Trinity Parish are to be converted to new uses next year, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of that Episcopal Parish, and by the vicars of the chapels involved.

This week the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of wholesale prices crossed 100. The general price level was back to the 1926 level. The 1926 dollar, which nine years ago was the objective of our national monetary policy, has returned. That the event has attracted so little attention indicates how far we have traveled from the point of view of 1933.

BIRIMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 22 (AP) -- An American sailor, aboard a destroyer when American forces attacked Casablanca, in French North Africa, declared today that shells dropping on the city made it look like "boiling water."

The American people should be grateful to God on Thanksgiving Day for the opportunity to assume spiritual and democratic leadership in the world, declared the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton in his sermon yesterday at the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Although weather conditions were somewhat less favorable last week in parts of the Corn Belt, farmers made considerable progress in gathering the crop. Official reports indicate that more than 75 per cent of the crop in Iowa is out of the fields, while in Illinois harvesting ranges from 50 to 100 per cent.

News from the various battlefronts, last week, was quite uniformly favorable. Alike in North Africa, in the Pacific Islands, and even on the Russian frontier, the week's developments were heartening. The stock market, however, during most of the week was dull and slightly lower.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Nov. 22 -- An account of the condition of Captain Edward Rickenbacker, now recovering along with his six fellow-survivors in a hospital at a United States South Pacific island base from their ordeal of drifting on rafts for more than three weeks after their plane was downed on Oct. 21. has been received here from Sergeant Richard C. Seither, war correspondent for the Marine Corps.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will open its fifty-eighth season at 8:30 this evening with Donizetti's "La Fille du Regiment." Lily Pons will sing the title role in the work that was revived for her two seasons ago. Frank St. Leger will conduct.

Home owners and other users of fuel oil in the city, of whom 503,000 already have flied ration applications, will get their coupons by mail before next Sunday, Lee S. Buckingham. State director of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 22 -- The powerful Chicago Bears clinched the National Football League's Western division championship today by crushing the Detroit Lions, 42 to 0, while Green Bay was tied by the Giants.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- New York owes the Federal Government $4,473.50 in taxes on bottled water from the State-owned Saratoga springs under decision by Judge Frederick H. Bryant in the case, which was tried here last April.

Photographs taken by the Japanese in China and brought to this country show some very bad roads and some very tired-looking soldiers. The Japanese in China have a right to be tired. They have been walking up and down those bad roads for five years and four months.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The St. Mary's Navy Pre-Flight team retained its status as one of the country's undefeated football elevens today by scoring a 13-to-6 victory over the University of Santa Clara Broncos.

I wish Mrs. Roosevelt and others who continually urge women, including mothers, to go into industrial jobs would look at the picture in broader perspective. If all those workers at present employed in industrial plants would put in the twelve to fourteen hours, seven days a week, which a maidless mother of five young children is obliged to work there would be plenty of manpower.

The New York Rangers managed to snap their string of reverses last night by salvaging a tie from their National Hockey League game with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden. Losers of six of their eight previous clashes, the local skaters came through with a goal in the last minute of the third period to earn a 4-4 tie with the high-flying Red Wings.
LONDON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The classic American speakeasy sesame, "Joe sent me," is current again in London -- as the password for getting silk stockings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Cots were shoved into the fashionable dining rooms of San Francisco's big hotels yesterday and sleeping space was provided at the County Poor Farm as officials of the overcrowded city acted to give furloughed soldiers a roof over their heads.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Leaving a dummy made of pillows and bed clothing and his shoes and socks beside his cot, David L. Brosius, an iron worker from Newark, N.J., escaped from the Onondaga County Penitentiary early today. He was serving a ninety-day sentence for petit larceny, imposed in Broome County.
ALBANY, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The little red school house continues to lose its grip in New York.

A woman's complaint that she cannot identify the two ends of a monkey wrench is no excuse for her not entering war industry, Henry J. Kaiser, shipbuilder, declared last night through his labor relations expert, Harry Morton.
The recent trend toward frankness on the part of the Navy -- and of the government -- in the release of war news is an important contribution to victory on the Home Front.

Following a parade from the West Sixty-eighth Street station, 600 uniformed members of the Police Department yesterday honored their deceased comrades at annual memorial services held in Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

William Green and Philip Murray, respectively presidents of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, with the sub-chiefs of their organizations, will be the guests of the British War Relief Society at a dinner in the Hotel Astor, New York, on Nov. 24, inaugurating a large-scale campaign by American labor to help British civilian war relief sufferers.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 -- The Pittsburgh Steelers outkicked the Chicago Cardinals to the tune of 19 -- 3 today, making it the second time in a decade they have scored six league victories in a season.

One by one the publishers, coming out of their late Fall editorial huddles, announce, at least tentatively, what their line-up is for future months. Harper now has January fairly well scheduled, a list that includes these books: "Mrs. Parkington," by Louis Bromfield; a novel by Frederic Prokosch called "The Conspirators"; "Letters from England," by Margaret Culkin Banning, and "The Japanese Mind," by Gustav Eckstein.

"Yankee Point," a new play by Gladys Hurlbut, will open tonight at the Longacre. It is being produced by Edward Choate and Marie Louise Elkins arid it deals with a day's happenings among civilian defense workers in a small New England coastal town.

No man in the United States is more fully qualified than Governor Lehman for the tremendous task to which he has been called. It is a task which will expand with victory and extend far into the years of peace. Former President Hoover, relief administrator of the World War, estimates that it will ultimately involve half a billion people.
ARE YOU A PROUD PAPA? Are you the proud papa or mama of a small boy? What does...

LONDON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Emile Muselier, former commander in chief of the Fighting French Navy, predicted today that it he Allies would find it "virtually impossible to dislodge the Germans from Bizerte except by siege with an overwhelming force" if the Axis became well established there.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Navy Communique 198:

It is barely a month now until the eve of Dec. 25. For distant men of war buying has already been done and the packages have left the hand of the giver. But it can be assumed that most husbands have not really knuckled down yet to the problem of divining what their wives want this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 22 -- The Hotel Brigantine, converted last Summer into a "heaven" for followers of Father Divine, has been offered rent-free for the war's duration to the Coast Guard. The announcement was made by Louis M. Mallin, as legal representative of the present owners, eighty-six members of Father Divine's cult.

A united Canada, with language and sectarian differences forgot in the realization that every one in the Dominion is "just a Canadian, fighting with England and the United Nations for Canada," is one of the results of the Dieppe raid, Major J. Armand Sabourin declared here yesterday.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world, offers a partial list of free amusement and recreational activities available today.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 22 -- The biggest formation of United States bombers ever sent into the air from an Indian base teamed up with the Royal Air Force to cascade many tons of bombs upon Rangoon, Mandalay and Toungoo, major cities in Japanese-occupied Burma, during week-end raids that cut wide swaths of fiery destruction through enemy targets.

BAYPORT, L.I., Nov. 22 -- After one of the most exhaustive series of tests to which retrievers are subjected in competition, victory in the open all-age stake of the annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club, in the form of the Arnold Hanger Challenge Cup, was won today by the veteran Field Trial Champion Hi-Wood Mike.

I Two five-story buildings containi ing two stores and sixteen apartments on a plot 54 by 100 feet at 1267-71 Fulton Street, near NosI trand Avenue, Brooklyn, have been i purchased by H. Sanders for modernizing. The Bulkley Horton Company was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The nation's industrial output reached a new high level, with gains in armament production accounting for most of the increase, in October and early November, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A week ago the honors belonged to a team, Boston College. Today, with the book closed on the football season in the East except for a scattering of games, homage is paid to a player whose individual feats have become legendary and established him on a pedestal as one of New York's finest of all time.

All purchasers of woolen and worsted fabrics from A.D. Juilliard Co., Inc., were warned yesterday by the Office of Price Administration about paying for their purchases before the Federal court disposes of the suit for treble damages of at least $750,000 against the firm.

Governor - elect Thomas E. Dewey, when he returns this week from a two-week vacation to start the task of taking over the State government Jan. 1, is scheduled to receive news that the State fiscal surplus bequeathed to him will total at least $75,000,000 at the end of the current fiscal year.

MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 23 -- Germany's Stalingrad salient is in grave peril under a pulverizing Russian onslaught that has killed more than 15,000 Nazi troops, recaptured the Don River stronghold of Kalach and rolled up Soviet advances of forty to fifty miles, the Red Army reported today.

Until recently the appeal of yogurt -- a milk of custard-like consistency with a tart tang that is similar to buttermilk -- was fairly limited. People of European birth and Americans who had first tasted it in travel abroad were its chief supporters.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Two thousand of Britain's women today attended a meeting in honor of Lieutenant Liudmila Pavlichenko, the Soviet girl sniper, and gave her three gifts to take home to Russia with her.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Office of War Information offers this consolation to coffee drinkers who will be restricted to about a cup a day beginning with breakfast on Nov. 29 -- "take a look at Europe!"

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Apparent criticism of the accomplishments of the collaborationist Vichy government and commendation for such extreme pro-Fascists as Jacques Doriot, leader of the French Peoples party, and Jacques Benoist-Mechin, a dismissed Vichy Minister, came from Berlin and Rome quarters today.
UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

Joseph Schuster, 'cellist, was the assisting artist late yesterday afternoon at the New Friends of Music's fifth concert of the season at the Town Hall. He played Bach's Suite No. 2 in D minor for unaccompanied 'cello.

The vital part that women are playing in the war and the efficient manner in which they have adjusted themselves to fill important roles on the production front were stressed last night by women leaders at the sixteenth annual Friendship Dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- One perfectly executed play in which Forrest Hall broke loose for a 60-yard touchdown run in the second period gave Duquesne a 6-to-0 upset victory over Villanova before 20,000 at Shibe Park today.

LONDON, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt has sent a message to the Sultan of Morocco pledging a new era of peace and prosperity for North Africa after the defeat of the Axis, Radio Morocco said today.

According to the last census there are 184,000 manufacturing plants in the country. Of these 169,000 employ fewer than one hundred workers each and 72 per cent fewer than twenty. The great works in which steel is fabricated, tanks and airplanes are assembled, guns and ships are made, present so dramatic a spectacle of efficient quantity-production that we naturally hear more of them than of the little shops.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, declaring that on her recent trip to England she found no person, man or woman, who was idle, said today that the United States had mobilized only one-third its manpower and had fallen far short of the effort and sacrifices made by the British.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Molten steel flowed for the first time today from a unit of the $120,000,000 steel-mill expansion project begun by the government months before Pearl Harbor.

With the near months in cotton relatively stronger because of continued trade price-fixing orders and the distant contracts weaker under persistent hedge selling, especially in the October position, the futures market exhibited last week wide and irregular price movements and ended lower in the period.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 22 -- The British Eighth Army, now at least 100 miles south of Bengazi, was hammering the Axis rear guard back around the Gulf of Sidra tonight, preparatory to a frontal smash at the Agheila line and a 400-mile dash to Tripoli, which is already under American aerial bombardment.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 22 -- German Gestapo and Elite Guard police are being reinforced in the Balkans, Greece and Italy in order to protect the Reich's rear, according to reports reaching Istanbul today.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Hope that the North African front will soon be developed into a jumping-off place for a great offensive was expressed today by Clement R. Attlee, Deputy Prime Minister, speaking at Reading. He said that Allied action had not only made the Mediterranean safe but opened up bright prospects for the future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration is considering the issuance of an anti- hoarding regulation for householders to curb panic buying of foods and other commodities which it has found widespread, an official disclosed today.

The more government bureaus move out of jammed-up Washington, the better Miss Georgeanne LeBaron likes it. She is supervisional dispatcher of the Allied Van Lines, that moves household and office furniture all around the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Awards of the Silver Star, the Purple Heart or Oak Leaf clusters to several officers and men for their exploits in the Southwest Pacific area were announced today by the War Department.

CAIRO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Allied Air Force headquarters disclosed today an audacious manoeuvre pulled off to contribute to Marshal Rommel's rout. Compact fighter groups, complete with ground crews and equipment, were ferried to air fields well behind the enemy lines.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Dr. Moore, a member of Colgate's faculty for forty-four years, retired in 1934 with the rank of Professor Emeritus of German Language and Literature. He had also taught Latin and French.

ORAN, Algeria, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Major Gen. Lloyd R. Fredendall, commanding American forces here, decorated Leo S. Disher, United Press correspondent, with the Purple Heart today for "extraordinary heroism and a meritorious performance of duty" in the battle of Oran.

God can only be described in terms of experience and to believe in Him, to feel His reality and His presence is to recapture the basic dynamic of religion, the Rev. Allan Knight Chalmers declared in his sermon yesterday in the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

The twentieth annual joint Thanksgiving services for patriotic societies of New York was held yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. It was the first Thanksgiving service held in the entire length of the nave of the cathedral, which was formally opened last Nov. 30.

Belgian school children are acting as effective saboteurs, impeding the activities of German troops sent to occupy their homeland, Henri Fast of the Belgian Information Center said yesterday, according to The United Press.

The entry of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., into the newsreel field, already a subject of much controversy in the industry, is strongly protested by the influential Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors in a resolution calling on the War Production Board to restrain the film company.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The stock markets have continued in the comparatively inactive condition to which they receded last week after the initial flare-up which greeted the Allies' occupation of North Africa. Business fell to the lowest daily totals since the period of inaction which immediately preceded the launching of the brilliant Libyan offensive.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Nov. 23 -- American and Australian troops, battling against heavy resistance, are closing in steadily on all sides of the enemy's "dwindling positions" in the Buna-Gona area of Northeastern New Guinea, and Allied planes have sunk another Japanese destroyer and two smaller vessels, the Allied command announced today.
Only 1,203 policemen have qualified for promotion to the rank of sergeant, it became known yesterday, although 7,300 took the civil service examination seventeen months ago.

While wholesale trading continued brisk last week, retailers generally showed greater interest in getting deliveries of goods already ordered than in placing additional business, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
In Rockland County some of the results of the open season on deer are receiving the censure of Special Game Protector Louis Heydeman.

Four of the best known if not the ablest pickpockets in the East were in police custody yesterday after they had been arrested in Pennsylvania Station by a special detail of detectives sent there to halt an epidemic of thievery. The men have had lucrative pickings from relatives and friends of servicemen who throng the station daily bidding farewell to soldiers entraining for camp, the police said.

Dissatisfaction over the slowness with which the October accumulation of household scrap metal is being sent to the steel mills is interfering seriously with a new salvage drive begun in Brooklyn, the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Subtle changes have been affecting the British censorship since shortly after the United States entered the war and is causing increasing concern among American correspondents in London.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration emphasized today that merely changing the brand of a commodity does not change the commodity and consequently does not change its ceiling price. This statement was issued after the OPA received many reports that retailers, particularly grocers, were selling under new brand names and at higher prices commodities which they formerly sold under established names.

How Col. Gen. Franz Halder was ousted as chief of the German Army General Staff by Reichsfuehrer Hitler was revealed today in a letter smuggled out of Germany, printed in the Swedish magazine Trots Allt and reported here yesterday by the Office of War Information, The Associated Press said.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 108.5. Since ceiling prices have not been placed upon agricultural raw materials such as live stock and grain items, the market prices of this group continue to rise.

The city will go into the business of selling OCD stirrup pumps to building owners at the wholesale price of $1.91 plus shipping charges, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People" from City Hall.

With the completion of an addition to the biological laboratories of E.R. Squibb Sons in New Brunswick, large new quantities of human blood serum, which has proved a "miracle worker" in saving the lives of thousands suffering from shock on the battlefield, will become available, it was announced yesterday.

The whole world seems suddenly to have become conservation-conscious. Conservation is the keynote for almost every aspect of contemporary life -- even beauty care! The new cosmetics that appear on the market are being designed especially to conserve and protect the healthful tone of face, hair, hands . . . and feet.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22 -- "Admiral Darlan rendered a very important service to the Allied cause when he ordered the military forces in North Africa to cease resisting," said Jean Boorsch, Associate Professor of French at Yale, tonight, in the radio broadcast, "Yale Interprets the News," over the WTIC network.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The loss of a seventh United States destroyer as a result of damage inflicted in the battle of Guadalcanal in which our naval forces on Nov. 13-15 smashed the most powerful attempt yet made by the Japanese to pry loose the American hold in the Southeastern Solomons was reported today by the Navy.

Speaking in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the dedication of the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street west of Broadway, the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, the pastor, declared in his sermon yesterday that the principal thought prompted by the occasion should be that of responsibility for the fate of mankind.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- With Art Jackson performing hockey's "hat trick" by scoring three goals, the Boston Bruins gained a thrilling 7-6 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight before 11,500 fans at the Boston Garden.

ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- Thirty-eight candidates for optometry licenses were successful in the June examination, the State Education Department announced today. Residents of the metropolitan area entitled to licenses included:

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Yankee Sweet Perfection, Boston terrier owned by Harry J. Freeman of Manchester, N.H., and shown by Emily Shire, took best-in-show and American-bred laurels at the annual all-breed fixture of the Camden Kennel Club today.
LONDON, Nov. 22 (Reuter) -- The German-controlled Vichy radio said today:

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22 -- The cotton futures market here was uneven last week. The near months showed resistance and narrowed moderately the premiums of distant positions. Demand in the near December, approaching first-notice day, came from evening-up activities and switching, while the distant contracts were called upon to absorb hedging.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Chinese airmen flying bombing planes loosed devastating raids today against Shasi, Yangtze River port in Hupeh Province, and Shayang, on the Han River, thirty-five miles to the northeast, the official Central News Agency reported tonight in a dispatch from a secret airdrome.

The Office of Price Administration has begun a study of the fluid milk shortage in Maryland, it was announced here yesterday by Regional Administrator Sylvan L. Joseph. Declaring that a new administrative procedure permits the OPA regional administrator to make price adjustments to relieve local shortages which would impair the war program, Mr. Joseph said the Maryland milk case was the first in this six-State region where such adjustments were being considered.

John Keefe purchased from the Provident Institution for Savings the one-family dw611ing on a plot 50 by 118 feet at 140 Wegman Parkway, Jersey City, N. J. The George J. Wolf Realty Company was the broker in the sale of the house, which formerly was the home of the late Isaac Klinghoffer, who was active in the development of Wegman Parkway.
FAIRVIEW, N.J., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Twenty-four of the ninety air raid wardens in this community's fourth defense district were on strike today in protest over the dismissal of their district warden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Educational Policies Commission recommended today that 17-year-old students of ability who have reached senior standing in high school be permitted to enter college or university immediately and earn a high school diploma and credit for a year in the higher institution at the same time.
VALDOSTA, Ga., Nov. 22 -- Three persons were killed and more than a score were injured today when a trestle over Withlacoochee River collapsed as the crack Royal Palm passenger train rolled over it.

To the "four freedoms" that have been set forth by President Roosevelt for the preservation of the world the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of the Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, yesterday morning added a "fifth freedom" that, he said, was embodied in the spirit of religion and acted as a "steering wheel" for the other four.

At his recital last night in Carnegie Hall Josef Lhevinne was heard in a program devoted entirely to compositions by Chopin. The longer the eminent pianist played, the more highly vitalized his performances became, the more amazing his technical skill and the more gripping his interpretations.
The National Civil Service Reform League made public yesterday a resolution challenging jurisdiction assumed by the War Labor Board over State and municipal governments and their employes.

THE TIMES has repeatedly urged, editorially, that the forty-hour work-week be abolished for the forty-eight-hour week before starting time-and-one-half wage scales. You cite our urgent need for vastly increased production in support of this immediate change, and that such change need only be invoked for the duration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Radio broadcasting companies and stations, telephone and telegraph companies and this city's trolley and bus systems are "defense industries" and cannot legally discriminate against employment of persons because of, their race, creed, color or national origin, the War Manpower Commission said today.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- A four-motored Liberator bomber of the United States Army Air Force, on patrol over the Bay of Biscay yesterday, was tackled by five Nazi fighters. It destroyed two of them, possibly shot down a third and damaged the others, the U.S.A. A.F. headquarters here announced today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A communique:
LONDON, Nov. 22 (Reuter) -- The Morocco radio reported that Admiral Francois Darlan today signed a decree establishing an economic and general secretariat in French Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- William R. Boyd Jr., chairman of the Petroleum Industry War Council, said tonight that first reports on country-wide tests of tubeless tires indicated that the revolutionary idea would work.
There was some, but not much, grumbling and a ray of hope as motorists throughout the East began yesterday to get three instead of four gallons of gasoline for an A ration coupon.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Evidence collected by the Air Ministry on last Sunday's attack on Genoa bears out pilots' impressions of widespread damage. A motion picture made during the raid will be shown to the public soon but, in addition, there are reconnaissance, "stills" and the testimony of an eyewitness who stood on a hill.

Five weeks ago a subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, having held hearings on the subject, reported favorably a bill by Senator Green of Rhode Island to permit the Government to sell non-monetary silver to private industry for consumptive use upon recommendation of the War Production Board at not less than 50 cents an ounce.

The resignations of three leading executives of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, which will be accepted today at a meeting of the directors here, reflect the company's rules on obligatory retirements, it was said yesterday. Moreover, at least one of the retirements results from the recent government order limiting corporate salaries.
Properties on the West Side formed the bulk of real estate in Manhattan reported sold over the week-end.

Despite the feeling of helplessness that overwhelms the individual in times of crisis such as these, each one of us can make a contribution by "being what we ought to be and can be," declared the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers in his sermon yesterday in Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, Japanese Ambassador to the United States when war started in the Pacific, was quoted in a Trans-ocean dispatch from Tokyo yesterday as warning his people "against underrating the enemy," according to a German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press.

Grace Castagnetta's pianism at her recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall had, as usual, much to commend it. The youthful artist had devised an exacting program and all of it was accurately, cleanly and intelligently played. In addition to the other varied offerings on her list Miss Castagnetta provided her large audience with a group of remarkable improvisations, which met with pronounced success.
Seven new films will have their local premieres this week. The schedule follows:

It is a century and a half this year since Rouget de Lisle wrote a marching song to be sung by the French Army of the Rhine. It was a good song, and even with no radio to carry it to a nation's ears it reached as far as Marseille. When the men of Marseille marched north to defend their revolution they sang this song all the way, and did not tire of it:

The editorial on "The Mite of Empire" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 14 shoots an arrow of irony keenly barbed with classic wit at the self-inflated, substanceless Duce who has led his misguided Fascisti through a succession of cruel and flamboyant episodes toward a mirage of imperial grandeur that is already dust, ashes and bitterness for the great Italian people.

HOLLIDAYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Sergeant John J. Feeney, 25, of Glen Ridge, N.J., son of Patrick M. Feeney, advertising manager of The Newark Evening News, and Alma Wentz, 26, of Hollidaysburg, were struck and killed by an automobile in this Western Pennsylvania town early today.

Reaching heights of furious efficiency that they had not even approximated all year, the Giants played a sensational 21-21 tie with the Ponderous Packers from Green Bay before a thrill-sated crowd of 30,246 at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Properties on the West Side formed the bulk of real estate in Manhattan reported sold over the week-end.

Despite the feeling of helplessness that overwhelms the individual in times of crisis such as these, each one of us can make a contribution by "being what we ought to be and can be," declared the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers in his sermon yesterday in Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Donald M. Nelson visited the White House today. An authorized WPB spokesman was asked if Mr. Nelson went to offer a resignation.

" Fortunate" companies with large excess profits tax credits, as defined in the 1942 Internal Revenue Act, will pay the 40 per cent rate on the bulk of their income while "unfortunate" companies with small tax credit have the larger part of their earnings taxed at the 90 per cent rate.

William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, told 1,000 representatives of management and labor last night that the vast powers vested in the board were justified only in time of war and that entirely new machinery for the adjustment of labor disputes would have to be set up after the war, with the element of compulsion eliminated.

Mexico is ready to shed her blood in the cause of democracy, Jose Perez Moreno of the Mexican newspaper Universal declared yesterday at a luncheon for twelve newspaper men from Mexico and Bolivia who will make a tour of war plants in the United States and Canada.

Hedwig Engemann, friend of the executed Edward John Kerling, testified yesterday as the first witness for the prosecution at the trial of Helmut Leiner for treason. She said that Kerling, one of the eight Nazi saboteurs seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last June, had told her in Leiner's presence that he came here by submarine.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24 -- With a greatly increased Republican representation in the new Congress which will convene in early January, legislation to control labor unions is certain to arise.

One of the "gratifying features" of the war in the Pacific is the "intensity of unity between Dutch and Indonesians," Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday. The Indonesian population was "loyal to the last," Dr. Loudon told a Town Hall audience at a "Netherlands Day" program.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 26 per cent last week over the comparative week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The week had six selling days against five last year due to the early Thanksgiving in 1941.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- French West Africa, with its important port of Dakar dominating Allied sea lanes from the jutting bulge where Africa is closest to Brazil, came over to the Allies today under the leadership of Admiral Francois Darlan.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A proposal by the Educational Policies Commission that selected 17-year-olds be allowed to combine their last year of high school and first year of college "smacks of 'Alice in Wonderland,'" Dr. Edwin R. Van Kleeck, assistant State education commissioner, declared today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -The shortage of leading men resulted today in a casting switch at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer which moved Gil Stratton, who is imported from the Broadway cast of "Best Foot Forward," out of the screen version of the musical and into one of the male leads in "Girl Crazy" with Mickey Rooney, Van Johnson and Judy Garland.

The gala premiere performance last night of the Metropolitan Opera's new season, its traditional luster somewhat dimmed by the war, drew to the famous lyric theatre a capacity throng in which were noted many leaders in society and men and women of distinction in diplomatic, military, civic and artistic circles.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 -Jerry McCarthy and Bob Brundage, backfield substitutes, were used in Pennsylvania's first string line-Up today as the Red and Blue scrimmaged against the second team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that its experiment in ration banking, which it carried out in the Albany-Schenectady-Troy area of New York, had proved so successful that the plan will be expanded on a national basis in January.

The two-family dwelling on a plot 29 by 100 feet at 4525 Monticello Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Louis A. Biaggi to Catherine Alpegiani through Albert Pfeifer, broker. Sale was for cash above a $3,448 mortgage held by the Home Owners Loan Corporation.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 23 -- In an effort to demonstrate what will happen if rubber tires continue to be consumed at the present rate, about half the operators of Peoria's 40,000 automobiles will leave their cars at home tomorrow.

CAIRO, Nov. 23 -- As advance units of the British Eighth Army brought their guns to bear on the German screen of tanks and anti-tank guns around the village of Agedabia, this half-hearted rear guard began to crumble. It appeared yesterday that the Nazis would soon pull back to El Agheila and that then General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel would have to show his hand.

Mayor La Guardia arrived ten minutes early, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins was there, President Roosevelt sent a message -but the center of attraction at Greenwich House yesterday, as it has been for forty years, was Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, founder and only director of the settlement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Congress, already involved in a controversy over nation-wide gasoline rationing, heard today that the petroleum industry wants a general increase in crude-oil prices -- which determine the cost of gasoline for the consumer.

The shadow of our participation in another world conflict dominated a first night at the Metropolitan Opera House once again last night, as it had a quarter of a century ago. As on Nov. 12, 1917, the last opening that took place while we were engaged in a great war, the accent of the evening was patriotic.

" The Avengers," a British-made drama about Norwegian resistance to the Nazi conquerors, which is being distributed here by Paramount, will have its American premiere at 8:30 tonight at the Rivoli Theatre. Produced by Paul Soskin and released in Britain under the title, "The Day Will Dawn," the film's cast is headed by Ralph Richardson and Deborah Kerr.
Today when the smallest bit of string, the fat from your cooking, or last year's dress has real value, it is a crime to waste.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 23 -- A State-wide surprise daytime alert today taught Civilian Defense Director Leonard Dreyfuss the acute need for women air raid wardens in residential districts. Today's alert, which lasted from 2:10 P.M. to 2:35 P.M., caught dwelling areas throughout New Jersey without men wardens.

ATLANTA, Nov. 23 -- The Rev. Dr. M. Ashby Jones received today at the Atlanta Rotary Club recognition for a lifetime of work for the promotion of understanding and good-will among persons of various races and religious faiths. A citation from the national conference of Christians and Jews was given to him.

Two more of the thirty-three men named last week in a Special Sessions conspiracy "information" involving an alleged ring that supplied horse-racing information to gamblers surrendered yesterday, bringing the arrests to twenty-seven. One of them, William (Hockey) Hocklerin of 4366 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, was released in $5,000 bail when arraigned before Chief Justice William R. Bayes in Special Sessions; the second, Louis Simon of 95 Christopher Street, gave $1,000 bail.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- In an apparent preliminary to the record war financing program for December, four Federal financial offices tonight "let down the bars" to facilitate holding of government securities both by banks and by non-banking investors.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 23 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister of South Africa, has left the Middle East after inspecting a number of South African units in a hurried 1,000-mile tour of former battle areas over the week-end.

LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Sir Stafford Cripps, who left the War Cabinet yesterday to become Minister of Aircraft Production, took on still another new job today, that of second in command of the Anti-Submarine Strategy Board, which is undertaking "special new measures" to protect shipping.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Running a gantlet of Nazi fighters over France this afternoon, American Flying Fortress and Liberator bombers made a strong attack on the U-boat base at St. Nazaire and absorbed as heavy punishment as they have had to take in a raid over Europe -- four of them were reported missing.
Under the heading "Austrians in Our Army," THE NEW YORK TIMES, in its Sunday issue, publishes a letter signed Czernin. The writer of that letter was Pan Edmund Czernin, A.D.C. to Otto von Habsburg.

The National Association of Manufacturers attributed yesterday the critical shortage of rubber to government inaction when the nation's sources of crude rubber first were threatened and to the Administration's confused approach to the synthetic rubber program.

The attempt to broaden the franchise in eight Southern States by means of Federal legislation has failed. This is what yesterday's Senate action on the poll tax debate means. Primarily this attempt failed because a minority of Senators was willing, and is still willing, to paralyze the nation's legislative process on this issue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Some of the ablest and most experienced students of the warmaking organization of the government, after observing the new production and economic set-ups in action, remain convinced that the creation of a War Cabinet is necessary to give full force and coordination to the combat program.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin has cabled to President Roosevelt Australia's "gratitude and appreciation" for American successes in the Solomon Islands campaign and the President, in reply, has expressed pleasure over the progress of Allied forces in New Guinea, it was learned today.

If further proof were needed of the wisdom of the policy which our Government is pursuing in North Africa, Dakar provides it. The commander of this strongly fortified French base announced yesterday that "in view of the situation in France," and no doubt in view of the situation in North Africa as well, he has decided to put Dakar under the orders of Admiral Darlan.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Witnesses at the court martial of Second Lieutenant William N. Wilson differed today on the courses of an Army bomber and an airliner which were in collision a month ago. Twelve persons were killed.

In an effort to conserve vital freight space, the War Production Board has adopted a new policy on the sale of mechanical refrigerators by manufacturers to distributors, it was learned here yesterday. Upon appeal by manufacturers, they may be allowed to ship at one time a carload of refrigerators to a distributor, whereas previously these shipments have been going out in driblets, such as two or three boxes at a time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Lumber consumption during the first nine months of this year was about 12 per cent over that in the 1941 period and was roughly 15 per cent in excess of production and imports in the same period, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The report of American Airlines, Inc., and its consolidated subsidiaries, issued for publication today, shows a net profit for the nine months ended Sept. 30 of $2,407,480 after all charges, including $1,847,100 provision for normal Federal income taxes.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:
CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 23 -- An overwhelming majority of the Ministers at the Cabinet meeting today endorsed Prime Minister John Curtin's proposal to use the militia in the Southwest Pacific zone.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Weakness in cotton and easiness in securities dominated the action of the grain markets today and prices on the Board of Trade declined, with rye in the lead. The latter, which had shown independent strength on Saturday dropped 1 1/4 cents a bushel under the previous close after being up 1/2 cent at the opening.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 23 -- A sizable group of Cleveland's professional and business men, lawyers, architects, auditors and office executives, has volunteered to make itself useful in the war effort after business hours, and B.C. Seiple, United States Employment Service manager here, already is visualizing a small army of half-shift, white-collar war workers.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 -- Dr. William P. Merrill, pastor emeritus of the Brick Presbyterian Church of New York City, today struck the theme of a "conference for victory and a free world" with the assertion that personal and national interests of the United Nations must be put into the background if there is to be a lasting peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Control of civilian manpower requirements would be taken out of the hands of the War Manpower Commission, headed by Paul V. McNutt, and lodged in the hands of the military authorities under a replacement schedule plan prepared by Selective Service, it was reported today.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 23 -- C.E. Nelson's Uncle Billies, a colt that finished second to the remarkable Count Fleet in the Pimlico Futurity -- though he was beaten thirty lengths -- found no such opposition today and drove to a length triumph in the featured Laytonsville Purse.

The first of a series of schoolboy basketball programs in Madison Square Garden is slated for Dec. 12, it was announced yesterday. Four Saturday dates are listed for the school quintets, with five games being listed for each of the days.

Muted glitter, reflecting the dimmed-out lights of New York, keynoted the gowns worn by fashionables last night at the Metropolitan Opera's first wartime opening since 1917. A simpler elegance set in a subdued key forecast the acceptance of less brilliant formal fashions for the Winter season.

A Thanksgiving recess limited to twenty-four hours will prevail at many colleges this week, thereby releasing railroad coaches and Pullman cars for military and essential civilian transport, Dr. Guy E. Snavely, executive director of the Association of American Colleges, announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt said today she had been disturbed to find that private income from investments was not covered by the $25,000 net income limitation on salaries, "but I was assured we would tax that too."

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Jacob Kisselbach, 58-year-old New York Central Railroad engineer, piloted his thirty-four-car fast freight past at least five signals between Scarborough and Harmon before it crashed into the rear of a halted baggage and express train on the main line just south of Harmon early on the morning of Nov. 11, trainmen testified at a hearing today.

Boston College, recognized as the best team in the East during recent weeks, yesterday was named as the country's outstanding college football machine in The Associated Press poll of 118 gridiron experts.

In a prelude to the college basketball season at Madison Square Garden, the Grumman A.A. of Farmingdale, L.I., was host to three Army quintets in a special invitation tournament at the arena last night. The Grumman Wildcats routed Camp Lee, 44 -- 27, after the ordnance outfit from the Aberdeen Proving Grounds in Maryland had eked out a 45-44 victory over Fort Monmouth.

IT'S a hard job to pin a football coach down on a game that is coming up. In the weekly huddle yesterday a couple of blockers tried to "scissor" Coach Lou Little of Columbia -- one coming at him from each side -- on the question of the Army-Navy game, and Lou squirmed through the block.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, Nov. 24 -- Besieged within the confines of the narrow beachhead at Buna, the Japanese today were stubbornly fighting off increasingly strong Australian-American attacks and seemed determined to make a desperate attempt to retain their southernmost foothold in New Guinea or sell their lives dearly in losing it.

The publishers John Day have just released under the title "My Appeal to the British" the "authentic record of what Gandhi actually wants, or wanted, during the crucial period of three months before his arrest in August." The volume includes without commentary the complete series of Gandhi's articles, interviews and statements on India's pleas for freedom between April 26 and July 26.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The investigation by the Federal Communications Commission into rates charged by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for long-distance rates will cover charges for all interstate and leased wires, James Lawrence Fly, commission chairman, said today.

Directors of Chicago Southern Air Lines, Inc., authorized yesterday a 25-cent dividend on the common stock for payment on Jan. 2. The previous payment was 50 cents in June this year. No payments were made in 1941. The regular quarterly dividend of 17 1/2 cents on the $10 par value, 7 per cent cumu lative convertible preference stock also was voted, payable on Jan. 1.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,500,000 of Sanitary District of Chicago 2 per cent refunding bonds, series F, dated Jan. 1, 1943, and due Jan. 1, 1963.

Granting of an A-2 preference rating by the WPB to cotton and rayon fabrics intended for women's work clothing will open the door to increased production to meet the needs of millions of women war workers, it was stated yesterday by Erwin Feldman, managing director of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 24 -- Australian troops have stormed into Gona, on the northeastern coast of New Guinea, and now are mopping up the remnants of its Japanese defense force, while an American column, smashing ahead despite heavy resistance, pushed to within a mile of Buna, fifteen miles down the coast from Gona, Allied Headquarters announced today.

An apartment of eight rooms and four baths at 115 Central Park West has been leased to Gustave Greene, vice president of Henry Pollak, Inc., importer, through the Apartment Renting Company, Inc., broker.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today to confer tomorrow on a proposal to permit the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation to resume dividend payments.

Dr. Conrad Berens, ophthalmologist, was chosen president-elect of the Medical Society of the County of New York, largest component unit of the American Medical Association, at its 137th annual meeting held at the New York Academy of Medicine building last night.

Further light was shed yesterday upon the Westchester incident in which it was alleged that an archer who had gone a-hunting had hit a dog and not a deer. An investigation over the week-end by Albert Vanderkogel, president of the Metropolitan Archery Association, and Harold Kimball, president of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, apparently served to refute the report.

The Whitney Museum, 10 West Eighth Street, opened its annual exhibition with a preview yesterday afternoon, which was attended by exhibiting artists and their friends. The show opens to the public today and will be current through Jan. 6.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today was granted a Supreme Court review of a decision holding that a stock dividend of common shares upon common shares, when there was no other class of stock outstanding, did not constitute taxable income.

Stockholders of the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank at the annual meetings in January will be asked to indemnify their officers and directors against the expense of litigation involving banking matters in cases where they have won such litigation, it was announced yesterday in a statement issued in behalf of both institutions.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- British and American troops were massing tonight in Eastern Tunisia for a crushing onslaught against the Axis positions at Bizerte and Tunis. That is the interpretation placed here on the Allied communique announcing that the "concentration of Allied forces" in the eastern area continues according to plan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Extension to all of vast French West Africa, including Dakar, of the new status enjoyed by Algeria and Morocco since the Allied occupation was greeted by Army and Navy authorities here tonight as a military-diplomatic victory that amounted to an increase of American and other Allied power, offensive and defensive, on both land and sea, in both African and American waters.

German and Rumanian forces are fighting "heavy defensive battles" south of Stalingrad and in the great loop of the Don River west of the city, the German High Command announced yesterday in a Berlin broadcast recorded by The Associated Press.

A delicate problem of war censorship is raised by the mutual complaints of British correspondents in America and American correspondents in Britain. British correspondents here say that the American censorship will not let them send to their countries full accounts of criticisms here of British war policy.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Captain E.J. (Mike) Moran of the 10,000-ton cruiser Boise which sank six Japanese warships in twenty-seven minutes off Guadalcanal six weeks ago, described his ship's feat today succinctly:

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Radio broadcasters do not intend to finance any private WPA for James C. Petrillo and the American Federation of Musicians, Neville Miller of Washington, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, told radio men today at the opening of the annual two-day conference of the Eleventh District of the association.

Women at War Week was opened officially in Brooklyn yesterday at a noontime rally on the steps of Borough Hall. A Chinese woman aviator and a Russian exchange student helped Borough President John Cashmore and "Red" Barber, radio announcer, in giving the message of the Kings County War Savings Staff urging the purchase of war bonds and stamps.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Army Communique 247:

MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Nov. 23 -- Word that soldiers on furlough from Selfridge Field, Army air base near here, were working for private contractors enlarging the base's facilities, set officers today to examining the regulations to determine whether the practice was legitimate from a military standpoint.
