LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The youthful Commando captain whose job it was to get Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, deputy commander of the Allied Forces in North Africa, and his fellow conspirators safely in and out of Algeria shortly before the Allied assault on North Africa, told today how he did it.

Three hundred women garbed in white opened officially yesterday the thirty-sixth annual drive for the sale of Christmas seals of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association. This year's campaign, which will continue until Dec. 25, seeks $390,000 in the city.

AT THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Nov. 23 -- An already wide rift in France between the "collaborationist" government and the preponderatingly "anti-collaborationist" nation is likely to grow wider, rapidly according to reports that even closed frontiers cannot stop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Coffee will be rationed at the White House, as elsewhere, and the demitasse may be dispensed with after luncheon and even after dinner, but every one will have coffee as usual for breakfast, Mrs. Roosevelt said today.

James W. Bell Co., custom tailors, located at 522 Fifth Avenue for more than twenty years, have signed a lease for the entire second floor of 647 Fifth Avenue, adjoining Cartier's at Fifty-second Street, it was announced yesterday by Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.
AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, Nov. 23 -- In the heat and dust of an advanced Army base are eighteen American young women who believe that, of all the nurses in the United States Army, they are the happiest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Army and Navy lost approximately 360 men killed in the occupation of French North Africa, the War Department reported today on the basis of preliminary estimates collected by Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief in North Africa.

Tonight John Golden revives, at the Royale Theatre, "Counsellor-at-Law," the Elmer Rice melodrama that was a hit in 1931. In it Paul Muni returns to the role he created. Also from the original cast are Jennie Moscowitz, Sam Bonnell, Elmer Brown, Jane Hamilton and William Brown.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- By a vote of 41 to 37 the Senate today rejected a motion to impose closure on debate on the anti-poll tax bill, thus ending for this Congress further consideration of a measure against which Southern Senators had filibustered for more than a week.

The New York State Association of Real Estate Boards has created a War Emergency Committee to deal with real estate problems occasioned by the war and to enable real estate interests to cooperate more effectively in the war effort, George L. Long, president of the association, announced yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Women workers at one of General Electric's plants producing aircraft instruments have started a voluntary back-to-school movement to brush up on subjects which can help them do their jobs faster and better.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 23 (AP) -- A young Negro soldier, who declared that days of "ribbing" by a fellow private had enraged him, shot and killed his alleged tormentor, another Negro soldier and a white civilian here tonight, County Attorney Albert Knudsen said.
Although a good many teams have laid away their uniforms in mothballs for no one knows how long, college football will still be very much in the picture this week, particularly in the East and South.

The exportation of American methods of education to Europe may become one of the most important contributions of this country to the rest of the world in the post-war era, Dr. George D. Stoddard, New York State Commissioner of Education, asserted last night at the annual dinner meeting of the House of Delegates of the New York State Teachers Association in the Hotel Commodore.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 23 -- Women fliers from all parts of the country have gathered at the municipal airport to begin training for ferry duty with the Air Transport Command.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Governor Lehman in a few days will hand his resignation as the State's Chief Executive to Michael Walsh, Secretary of State, and on Dec. 3 he will assume the duties of Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, he said today upon his return from New York City, where on Saturday he confirmed the Washington announcement of his appointment by President Roosevelt.

THE NEW YORK TIMES recently reported that the German Nazis, temporarily in control of France, have arrested and handed over to the Spanish Franco authorities two Spanish Republican refugees, Largo Caballero and Quiroga.
BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The National Hockey League's board of governors voted in special session today to reduce their club player limits from fifteen to fourteen men as a wartime measure.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate today rejected, 41 to 37 (two-thirds required), a motion to adopt a closure rule to limit debate on the anti-poll tax bill.

Admiral King was 64 yesterday. By a wise and fortunate exemption he is not subject to forced retirement at that age. The old superstitions of numbers clung to 49, 63, 81. The second of these was the grand climacteric, a culminating and dangerous period. Admiral Farragut was 63 when he won the battle of Mobile Bay.

Liquidation developed in the late trading in the cotton futures yesterday, sending active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to net losses of 47 to 52 points, or $2.35 to $2.60 a bale. This was the most abrupt price movement since Aug. 28, when gains up to 82 points were registered.

American Dairy Association has begun an advertising campaign, now appearing in a selected group of magazines, in which copy will stress that its messages on behalf of butter and cheese are presented "by more than 5,000,000 farmers." Cooperating in this year's drive, backed, by an appropriation expected to top the $400,000 mark, are two additional States, Missouri and Arkansas, swelling the total of ADA States to thirteen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Roosevelt signed the bill authorizing the Women's Coast Guard Auxiliary, received President Arroyo of Ecuador, made public his message to the Sultan of Morocco and stated that the White House song and prayer service Thanksgiving Day would be broadcast:

To the somber work uniforms of 800 women who voluntarily serve seventy-six hospitals affiliated with the United Hospital Fund were pinned service emblems yesterday in recognition of their help as "ammunition passers" in the last year.

Prominent Norwegians residing here will attend the premiere of "The Avengers," the motion picture dramatization of Norway's fight against Hitler and the Quislings, which will be held tonight at the Rivoli Theatre for the benefit of the American Friends of Norway.

When 9-year-old Ellen larie IV[cGurk of 595 Columbus Avenue was admitted to the Hospital for Special Surgery at 321 East Fortysecond Street Sept. 4, paralyzed after an attack of infantile paralysis, it was a toss-up whether she would live.

The best coaching job of the season has been done by Red Blaik of Army, Tad Wieman of Princeton declared to the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's restaurant yesterday. Furthermore, the Tigers' mentor expressed the opinion that this season's West Point squad is the best team he has seen in his eleven years at Nassau.

Air superiority, which cut the enemy's supply lines and battered his rear bases while knocking his combat planes out of the sky, must be given a major portion of the credit for routing Marshal Erwin Rommel's Axis army in North Africa, Air Commodore Henry N. Thornton, British Air Attache in Washington, asserted here yesterday in an interview at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

A general retreat, with prices pushed back to the lowest level in more than a month, developed yesterday in the stock market. The list gave no evidence of any rallying force during the session, and the impairments to values averaged between 1 and 2 points, with a few issues widening the decline.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Senate passed today a bill by Senator Murray giving the Director of the Budget authority to veto any projected government questionnaires planned to be sent to corporations and individuals in pursuance of the war effort as a means of reducing "the tremendous burden of paper work" allegedly being imposed by unnecessary and duplicating demands of Federal agencies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The American forces on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons are slowly advancing westward "in the face of stubborn enemy resistance," the Navy announced today. This movement appeared to observers here to mark the start of a determined drive to oust the enemy from his only stronghold on Guadalcanal.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 23 (AP) -- One unit of the African Falange is ready to leave for the front, Fernand de Brinon said today at Paris. He added that Pierre Laval's step in forming the African Falange was in accord with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's wishes.
The activities of the American Women's Voluntary Services were demonstrated last night at Madison Square Garden as a feature of the Women's International Exhibition of Arts and Industries.

May I suggest a bit of caution against the hysteria which has been aroused in Westchester over the wounding of a dog with an arrow in deer hunting. The incident is, of course, to be regretted, and in sympathy for the dog it is probably regretted by no one so much as by the archer whose arrow caused the mishap.

Commenting on the statement issued last week by Joseph M. Kershaw, head of the ration banking section of the Office of Price Administration, which has been conducting a test of ratio coupon banking in the Albany-Schenectady-Troy area in recent weeks, that the test had been successful and will be made nation-wide soon after Jan. 1, the American Bankers Association issued a statement yesterday agreeing that the system is feasible on a nation-wide scale.

For twenty-one years New York has been helping its blind men and women find ways to support themselves. Teachers are sent throughout the State to instruct home workers on a year-round basis, and eighteen associations maintain shops where other sightless workers produce beautiful handicraft.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A United States bomber and fighter mission smashed the dock and warehouse area at Haiphong in Japanese-occupied Indo-China yesterday and on the way down the coast sank a big Japanese ship of 12,000 or 15,000 tons which probably was a troop transport but may have been an aircraft carrier.

The high standard of previous "Concerts at Nine" was maintained last night in the vocal chamber-music recital given by Lilian Knowles, contralto, as the sixth event of the series that is being presented by Ray Halmans at The New York Times Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The poll tax closure vote, the fourteenth the Senate has taken since adoption of the rule in 1917, found thirty-one Democrats and ten Republicans in the opposition. Voting for the motion were twenty-one Democrats, fourteen Republicans, a Progressive and an Independent.

It seems that once upon a time there were three Anglo-Saxons named Eisenhower, Nimitz and Rickenbacker whose names often appeared in the papers singly or together. The story about the three Anglo-Saxons differs from the usual story about two Irishmen named Pat and Mike, or two Frenchmen named Alphonse and Gaston, in this respect, that we are not interested in what they said to each other but in what was said about them.

Condemning "avarice masquerading as patriotism," Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins put an end yesterday to the corporate existence of the Park Avenue Canteen by revoking the charter of the American War Heroes Foundation, Inc.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 23 -- Chile is ready to break off relations with the Axis "if the interests of this country and of the American continent make it advisable," President Juan Antonio Rios said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Silver-haired Clark Griffith, 73-year-old major-domo of sports in the capital whose lobbying efforts gave baseball a stay of execution from July to Labor Day, 1918, is going to the annual major league meeting in Chicago next month in the full expectation that the national game will escape wartime extinction.

Several luncheon parties were given yesterday in the Sert Room of Waldorf-Astoria after the first in the series of Monday morning musicales for this season held in the main ballroom of the hotel under the auspices of Mrs. Lytle Hull, acting president of the Musicians Emergency Fund, in behalf of that organization.
AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Youth may be the watchword in J this global war, but women past 40, I and even grandmothers, can andI do become good soldiers on the in- I dustrial front.

The Irving Subway Grating Company, at 50-09 Twenty-seventh Street, Long Island City, Queens, was cited as the originator of the steel portable runways in use by Allied air forces in all parts of the world, at a ceremony held in the plant yesterday afternoon at which the Army-Navy E for efficiency in production was awarded to the company and its employes.

Three hundred young men who for six months have studied radio under the supervision of the civilian training section of the Army Signal Corps became yesterday the first graduates of that course in the Second Service Command at exercises in the Seventh Regiment Armory.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 23 -Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, returned to New Delhi today from a triumphant tour of the Punjab, which has strengthened his position both among the Moslems and in the country as a whole.

OMAHA, Nov. 23 -- James A. Farley, former Democratic national chairman, offered today his explanation of the party's reverses in the recent election. In an interview published in The Omaha World-Herald he said:

AN ADVANCE R.A.F. AIRPORT, North Africa, Nov. 19 (Delayed) -- The long arm of the Royal Air Force reached over the dust and the brown hills of Western Tunisia today to halt an Axis dive-bomber onslaught on the advance forces of Britain's First Army.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities as announced by the Federal Reserve Board today shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 18: Increases of $386,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $135,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $771,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $242,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $591,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A reporter at Mrs. Roosevelt's press Continued From Page One conference today noted that it was rather warm in the White House and asked if there were any fuel-conservation regulations governing the Executive Mansion. Mrs. Roosevelt explained that the White House, like other government buildings, was heated from a central plant.

Six platinum minks made their debut in the fashion world yesterday afternoon. Their beady eyes peered through the bars of their cages at the invited crowd that filed past them in the showrooms of Fromm Brothers at 275 Seventh Avenue. Present were fashion experts, leading merchants, designers, scientists and those who were just interested.

The resignation of Walter C. Teagle as chairman of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey was accepted yesterday by the directors of the company. Ralph W. Gallagher, who had been a vice president and director in charge of finance, was advanced to succeed Mr. Teagle as chairman.

The Investment Bankers Association of America, in a special report issued yesterday by its public service securities committee, urged that "needless hampering of utility operations by governmental agencies be suspended for the duration."

LONDON. Nov. 23 (AP) -- An announcement that all French West Africa, including the strategic naval base of Dakar, had come under the orders of Admiral Francois Darlan was made by the Admiral tonight over the Algiers radio, and it was rebroadcast from Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's capital.

In anticipation of a day when packages and letters may be sent to Americans interned in the Philippines, the Relief for Americans in the Philippines Committee, 101 Fifth Avenue, is striving to complete a list of names and addresses of all Americans in the islands, with additional data on their relatives in the United States.

Attacking organized gambling, which he said was controlled by the underworld and in previous administrations had corrupted the police and "even this bench," Magistrate J. Roland Sala promised yesterday in Flatbush Court that he would penalize bookmakers' runners so severely they would have to drop out of business, and "once the runner is out," he explained, "the bookmaker starves to death."
With only two days of practice remaining before it meets Brooklyn College on Thursday, the City College football squad engaged in a strenuous session at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Lieut. Comdr. Dorothy C. Stratton, college administratrix, whose ancestral roots are generations deep in the United States, became director today of the Spars, the women's reserve of the Coast Guard. Previously she both named the reserve and literally made it ship-shape in time for launching of the unit by President Roosevelt's signature on the authorization bill.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 24 -Russian troops in their great new Winter offensive have smashed across the Don River to a point approximately 100 miles west of Stalingrad in a great double flanking movement that has cost the Germans 50,000 casualties and threatens to exterminate thousands of other Nazi soldiers stalled near the Volga River to the east, it was announced today.

Property in the United States owned by nationals of Italy, Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania may be insured against so-called bombardment risks, according to a new ruling by the War Damage Corporation, which sets those countries apart from Germany and Japan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A showdown between the War Production Board and the armed services over the former's exercise of powers to direct the scheduling, production and expedition of aircraft is expected this week, according to reports which were general here today.

Mandatory salary increments totaling $116,747 will be added to the wage schedules of 257 staff members in City, Hunter and Brooklyn College to whom these increments had been denied since 1936, it was revealed yesterday by Henry E. Schultz, chairman of a special Board of Higher Education committee arranging the payments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A corn loan rate averaging about 6 cents a bushel more than last year was announced today by the Commodity Credit Corporation for the record 1942 crop of 3,185,300,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Carlos Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador was welcomed to Washington today by President Roosevelt and declared in a message his belief in a permanent union of the Americas, "indestructible and enduring'' and qualified to deal with the problems of peace which will follow victory for the United Nations in the war.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The fastest, highest-flying fighter planes known to the Allied public, the American twin-motored Lockheed P-38, Lightnings, have been in action from British bases since the beginning of September, it was disclosed today.

Fines of $5,000 were imposed yesterday by Judge Edward A. Conger on a Westchester automobile sales agency, in one of a group of Federal court cases involving violations of various Office of Price Administration regulations. The concern, Fairchester Motors, Inc., of Rye, and Alvin Mayer, its general manager, had pleaded guilty to a criminal information involving "black market" sales of used and retreaded tires.

The recent order of the War Production Board releasing materials for the construction of almost 400 locomotives and 20,000 freight cars in the first eight months of next year should result in an increased business in railroad equipment trust issues. In recent months this class of business has been unusually small.

Captain Edward Rickenbacker is just as mortal as any other man. Yet he has heard four times in his life what he himself described after his rescue the other day as the "beautiful soft music" of death. Once he was all but killed in an automobile race. Once he almost bled to death after a tonsil operation.

Cliff Montgomery, captain and quarterback of Columbia's 1934 Rose Bowl champions, and Grantland Rice, sports columnist, will be the featured speakers at Columbia's third annual football tribute dinner tonight at the Men's Faculty Club.

The initial group of fifty houses in what may be the last large home development in the Long Island war plant areas until after the war is nearing completion and the houses are expected to be ready for occupancy Jan. 1, states Thomas G. Grace, State Director of the FHA.

Governor Lehman, newly appointed United States Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, declared yesterday in a statement in the 1942 Yearbook of the United Palestine Appeal that the plight of the Jewish people will be so desperate after the war ends that "the survival of large numbers will hinge on the opportunity to find healing and home in Palestine."

If there had been any doubt of the wisdom and the sure effect upon the numbers of its audiences that would follow upon the Metropolitan's reduction in the price of its seats this season, that doubt would have been dispelled last night at the opening.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Business on the Stock Exchange today was quiet but firm. Earlier improvements in prices were not fully maintained.

Major de Seversky has pointed out a profound difference between surface and aerial warfare. In surface warfare, either military or naval, the interior position has a tremendous advantage. Forces for attack or defense can move faster and more easily over interior lines.
CAIRO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A Royal Air Force and Britisk Middle East Command communiqug :

The disruption of a ring that supplied tons of obscene printed matter to children in their teens was reported yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, assistant to J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Jimmy Bivins of Cleveland arrived in New York yesterday. Close on his heels came Lou Nova from California. And forthwith, interest in the heavyweight boxing ranks, at a standstill since cancellation of the proposed Joe Louis-Billy Conn championship battle, took an upward trend.

In an accelerated program for decentralization of the Army Air Forces Materiel Command, Colonel Orval R. Cook has been placed in command of the new Eastern Procurement Division, it was announced yesterday at Army Public Relations Headquarters, 90 Church Street.

The Moscow Pravda quotes a diary found on the body of a German noncommissioned officer. He wrote, "The road to Stalingrad may be called the road of the dead." Pravda says that in two months the Germans lost 800 tanks, 1,000 planes and 100,000 men in the assault on the Volga city.

In an accelerated program for decentralization of the Army Air Forces Materiel Command, Colonel Orval R. Cook has been placed in command of the new Eastern Procurement Division, it was announced yesterday at Army Public Relations Headquarters, 90 Church Street.

An application of the legal fiction of "business visitor," believed to be without precedent, was made yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn in a 4-to-1 decision that upheld a $20,262 award to a 67-year-old man who lost his right leg and right arm when struck by a locomotive while seeking employment in the freight yards of the Long-Island Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -Reports that the Textile Clothing and Leather Goods Division of the War Production Board will be moved either to New York or Philadelphia in the near future gained circulation here yesterday. Government officials admitted that the question is now under study with conditions in New York as well as Philadel-I phia being surveyed.
The Russian offensive against the Stalingrad salient, which was continued yesterday, is of more importance strategically than tactically.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:...

Although his season was completed ten days ago, Eddie McGovern of Rose Poly gained a tighter grasp on the national football scoring honors last Saturday when Bob Steuber of Missouri, Frank Sinkwich of Georgia and Gene Fekete of Ohio State were held in check by rivals.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 23 -- Testifying today in Supreme Court, Governor Charles Edison in effect substantiated the contention of its foes that the New Jersey 1942 liquor sales bill was not legally enacted.

OTTAWA, Nov. 23 -- In the post-war world there must be some limitation of national sovereignty, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared here today at a joint meeting of the Rotary and Canadian Clubs of Ottawa.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- Allied air forces were revealed today to be carrying forward the strongest bombing offensive of the war against the Japanese in Burma and Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Selection of five additional industrial plants to receive the joint Army-Navy E production award for noteworthy war work was reported today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

HEADQUARTERS ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND, NOV. 23 (AP) -- The indecision of the Japanese command and the insufficient equipment for the Aleutian Island campaign has been clearly demonstrated in recent activities in the northern island sector, and the Japanese, who made so brave a showing in June, are now apparently unable to decide whether to hold even what they have.

Fifteen hundred truck and taxicab operators besieged the box offices at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, yesterday in quest of supplementary S gasoline rationing coupons to tide them over the period between Nov. 22 and Dec. 1, representing a delay in distributing the new T books.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Rear Admiral William C. Watts, U.S.N., retired, warning against "optimism" over the war news from North Africa, asserted today that "the task ahead in the European theatre of war is still a tremendous one."

LONDON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Authoritative British sources said today that the British Government has received word from Russia that the Red Army offensive already was a major drive that promised a grim Winter for the Nazis.

Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21-year-old mother of four small children, not only gained her freedom yesterday in Bronx County Court but also apparently won back her children. After deliberating almost six hours a jury of eight men and four women acquitted her of a first degree murder charge in the shooting of her 23-year-old husband, Alman.
MOSCOW, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Tossy Spivakovsky, Russian violinist, gave his first New York recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Since Mr. Spivakovsky is the concertmaster of the Cleveland Orchestra it could be taken for granted beforehand that his musicianship was of a high order.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull confirmed today that an agreement had been reached concerning French possessions in the Caribbean area that appeared to render unnecessary any occupation by American forces.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- On many sectors of the Russian front the German Army still seems short of Winter clothing even though Adolf Hitler assured Germany that her soldiers would not freeze in this second Russian Winter.

A change in Junior League membership, with a swing away from young women of leisure to the ranks of employed women, was reported yesterday by Mrs. DeForest Van Slyck at a meeting of representatives of the eight Junior Leagues of New Jersey at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Acting Athletic Director Asa S. Bushnell of Princeton University, announcing the 1943 football schedule today, said that the university would play a full schedule of intercollegiate sports during 1943 despite the war.

The Brooklyn College football squad moved indoors yesterday for a two-and-a-half-hour workout in preparation for tomorrow's postseason Red Cross charity game with C.C.N.Y. at the Brooklyn College field. The Kingsmen devoted the major part of the long drill to a complete review of all offensive plays.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

While Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21-year-old mother of four children who was acquitted Monday by a Bronx jury in the shooting of her husband, Alman, 23, tried yesterday to pick up the strings of her tangled life a new complication confronted her.
MOSCOW, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -Dr. Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the World Jewish Congress, said tonight that he had learned through sources confirmed by the State Department that about half the estimated 4,000,000 Jews in Nazi-occupied Europe had been slain in an "extermination campaign."

Calling for a new understanding and cooperation under the forthcoming regulation for pricing women's, children's and infants' Spring apparel. H.W. Bissell, price executive of the New York district office of the OPA, yesterday charged that the garment industry has given a "miserable performance" so far as compliance with OPA price regulations was concerned.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -Country-wide gasoline rationing as a rubber conservation measure must be put into effect on Dec. 1 as scheduled, William M. Jeffers, Federal rubber director, declared today.

The view that sports had an important place in the realm of education was expressed last night by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College before 300 at Columbia University's third annual football tribute dinner in the Men's Faculty Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The need of petroleum products in the North African campaign threatens for the Eastern seaboard new cuts in oil supplies, particularly fuel oil.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -Gloria Jean Schoonover, 16-year-old Universal contract actress who is known professionally as Gloria Jean, was named today for the leading feminine role in the third episode of "Flesh and Fantasy," with Allan Curtis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Very responsible and highly placed observers of the American section of the Allied war-making machine have reached certain conclusions to improve its efficiency and coordination and made them available to this correspondent today.

The election of W.W. Wachtel as a director was announced yesterday by the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd. Mr. Wachtel is president of the Calvert Distillers Corporation and formerly was vice president of the Loose Wiles Biscuit Company.

" The Pirate," an extravaganza by S.N. Behrman, opens tonight at the Martin Beck under the auspices of the Playwrights Company and the Theatre Guild, with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in the leading roles. This will be the twenty-fifth play in which Mr. and Mrs. Lunt have appeared together.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Spreading operations between December and May wheat at 3 3/4 to 3 7/8 cents premium for the latter featured trading in wheat on the Board of Trade today, the spread showing little change from the previous day. The close on futures was unchanged to 1/4 cent a bushel higher.

SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- Since some one must have been in a hurry, the plane roared on for three days and nights. Now and then she dropped from the cool empyrean to a refueling depot and for three or four hours the eighteen warriors who were riding in her could stretch their cramped legs and clear their deafened ears and stare disapprovingly at a place that was not their own.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Overcoats, heavy underwear and shoes are urgently needed for hundreds of merchant seamen who come to the "Sloppe Chest" at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York at all hours of the day and night after surviving the perils of submarines and Winter storms.

A new issue of $750,000 Pittsburgh, Pa., School District bonds, which had been held in the district's pension fund, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising Lehman Brothers, Estabrook Co., Hemphill, Noyes Co., Charles Clark Co., and Phillips, Schmertz Co., of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The House Merchant Marine Committee recommended today to the Maritime Commission that it cancel contracts for eighty-four Liberty ships entered into with the South Portland (Maine) Shipbuilding Company on the ground that it had "bungled" the job.
Several leases in the Fifth Avenue and Riverside Drive sections were among the apartment rentals announced yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24 -- W.H. Lipscomb's Overlin, unsuccessful in stakes company early in the season, easily defeated five other 2year-old fillies in the St. Margaret's Purse before close to 3,000 fans today.

Arturo Toscanini will be 76 next March, but there seems to be no diminution of his flaming intensity. Appearing as guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra in its third Carnegie Hall concert of the season last night, he was a torrent of energy, and the exceptional ensemble played with a magnificence that made the evening one of the peaks of any orchestral season.

The first annual exhibition of "Art by Musicians" was opened with a preview and promenade concert last evening at the Museum of Science and Industry in the R. C.A. Building, Rockefeller Center. It was organized as a benefit for the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24 (AP) -- George P. Kinniry of Hartford, Conn., a first-string guard, today was elected captain of Princeton University's 1943 football team.

While satisfied with the War Production Board's program to increase the amount of worsted system fabrics available for the civilian trade during the next six months, wool goods manufacturers declared yesterday that they would be unable to form any definite opinions about future business until the latter part of January or February.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, Nov. 25 -- The capture of Buna and its environs from the Japanese within a matter of days seemed inevitable this morning as Australian and American troops narrowed their encirclement of the enemy positions on the northern coast of New Guinea.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Bruins and the Black Hawks each lengthened their National Hockey League string of undefeated games to five by staging a spirited 5-5 tie tonight before a crowd of 9,000 at the Boston Garden.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 24 -- If there is to be a battle at El Agheila it is likely to begin soon, for the German rear guard is moving southwestward from Agedabia toward there, putting up only enough of a fight to keep from being overrun.
Hang your herbs on the kitchen wall where you may see them and constantly be reminded of their thousand and one uses in poultry, meats, vegetables and soups.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -The anti-trust suit brought by the Justice Department against the Aluminum Company of America has been pigeon-holed by the Supreme Court because four justices have disqualified themselves from acting on the controversy and hence the required quorum of six justices is not available.

The final in the special invitation basketball tournament will be contested at Madison Square Garden tonight, with the Grumman A.A. Wildcats clashing with the Ordnance outfit from the Aberdeen (Md.) Proving Grounds for principal honors.

Senator Albert B. Chandler, chairman of a subcommittee of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, who is inspecting all military headquarters in the western hemisphere, visited Governors Island yesterday and discussed the military situation in the New York area with Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command and First Army, and Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry, in command of the Second Service Command.
The Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries closed at Madison Square Garden last night with a Thanksgiving celebration.

The investment banking community, which has had little to cheer it up in the way of new corporate financing for many months, is looking forward with interest to the competitive bidding sale of Central Main Power Company bonds scheduled for next Monday.

Eleven rules for shoppers who order by mail or telephone because of gasoline restrictions or increasing wartime duties were formulated yesterday in a pamphlet issued by the National Consumer-Retailer Council, 8 West Fortieth Street.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 24 -There was no evidence today that any one here shares the opinion most football followers hold concerning an engagement the cadets have on the banks of the Severn River in Maryland Saturday. Starting with Earl Blaik, head coach and working down through the complete squad, there is no inclination at all to consider Army any favorite over Navy.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- More than 1,500 British Internees held in a French Moroccan camp at Laghouat, in the Sahara -- formerly a French Foreign Legion post -- went mad" with joy, "simply gave one cheer, then beat it for Algiers," when the news reached them over the Algiers radio, that "the Yanks have landed at Algiers."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Leaders of the anti-monarchist "Austrian action" movement said today that no democratic Austrian could assist, even if asked, in the formation of an Austrian battalion in the United States Army through the instrumentality of "the purely monarchist" group called "the Military Committee for the Liberation of Austria" which Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, has recognized as a recruiting medium for the battalion.

Warning against "over-enthusiastic predictions" that the transport airplane of the post-war period would doom the railroad and the steamship, W.A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, declared last night that "air transportation will augment surface transportation, not supplant it."

The first wave of an imminent invasion of in-tragic-Norway films established a tenuous beach-head on the screen of the Rivoli last night, and is holding it boldly with melodrama, if not a great deal else. "The Avengers" is the title of this loose-jointed British-made job.
In the introduction of S. Kip Farrington's latest book, "Pacific Game Fishing," Joseph D. Peeler says it was the west coast of South America that "came to the rescue of Pacific fishing."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Richard Krebs, whose sensational book on his experiences as an agent of police was a best seller, had been at liberty in $5,000 pending the Immigration Board's decision.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Algiers dispatches to Madrid today said that, with Dakar and French West Africa having joined the Allied-controlled French Empire under Admiral Francois Darlan, the admiral's first order to High Commissioner Pierre Boisson at Dakar was to permit no ships to leave the harbor, including the considerable French naval concentration there.

The stock market received yesterday some quiet support in the afternoon, but its recuperative powers were not sufficient to eliminate the losses sustained in the early trading. Isssues with peace-time rating managed a moderate show of strength, but the list as a whole closed mixed to lower.

Kenneth La Barre, vice president of the Childs Company, says in a letter to bondholders that the company has acquired sufficient bonds to meet the court decision of Justice C.G. Walter of the New York Supreme Court on Oct. 23, directing the company to pay $423,000 in cash or outstanding debentures into the sinking fund of its 5 per cent debentures of 1928.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- New manifestations against "government by bureaucracy" became plain in Congress today, leaving the future of the Third War Powers Bill in doubt and suggesting that moves were afoot for application of brakes to administrative authorities when the new session begins in January.

One of the most baffling spectacles of this war is that of Western and Midwestern members of Congress trying to prevent the national rationing of gasoline. There can be just criticism of the mistakes, military and economic, which produced the rubber shortage. There can be no denial that the shortage exists.

The soaring birth rate reached a new high for the year in New York City last week, when 3,178 boys and girls were born, it was reported yesterday by City Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins. The birth rate for the week was 21.9 per 1,000 population.

A saboteur sent here from Germany by submarine, the widow of another such saboteur, several hotel employes, three salesmen and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were arrayed yesterday as witnesses by United States Attorney Matnias F. Correa at the trial of Helmut Leiner for treason.

Forty-seven years ago the Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street, first gave thanks for an opportunity to be of service to less favored citizens, to help those in need of health care, education, recreation and rehabilitation.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A Russian communique:

So well-pleased was Steve Owen by the fine showing his Giants made against the Packers last Sunday, the portly coach gave his charges the day off yesterday and preparations for Sunday's Polo Grounds clash with Jimmy Conzelman's Cardinals will not get under way until this morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President Roosevelt declared at his press conference today that he was delighted over the Russian offensive at Stalingrad.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army hounded the remnants of the fleeing Axis desert army beyond Agedabia today and poised another punch to throw at El Agheila's defenses, where the Germans were believed to be gathering all their available strength to try to hold the pursuit away from Tripoli.

Presto-chango coiffures, which turn an efficient volunteer war-worker into a lady of elegance, were introduced yesterday at a millinery and beauty presentation given in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Festive hats by Mary Goodfellow of 23 1/2 East Sixty-first Street were keyed to the varied formal coiffures adapted from a single, basic cut by Leo of the Primrose House.

President Arroyo, honored guest of President Roosevelt, is no less the honored guest of the United States, of the American people. By word and act he has shown himself and his nation as firm friends of the unity of the Americas in resistance to the Axis. His term of office began Sept. 1, 1940.

Substitutions and equipment redesigned to avoid the use of critical materials will be featured at the fifteenth National Exposition of Power and Mechanical Engineering, to be held in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 30 to Dec. 4, the International Exposition Company, which manages the show, announced yesterday.

Murals depicting "Holland's Contribution to the Four Freedoms" by the Dutch artist, Joep Nicolas, were displayed for the first time last evening in the lobby showroom of Holland House, 10 Rockefeller Plaza. The artist attended a reception given later by the Holland House Corporation of the Netherlands in the New Amsterdam Room of the building.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Navy believes it has closed the routes by which the Japanese may reinforce their garrisons on Guadalcanal Island, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said today. This result was credited to the naval victory recently won by American sea forces against "seemingly hopeless odds" in the waters around the Solomon Islands.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The controversy that has arisen in and out of Parliament over the recognition of Admiral Francois Darlan's leadership in North Africa and the resultant political complications with the Fighting French are expected to evoke a statement from either Prime Minister Churchill or Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden at the next session of the House of Commons.

If there is any doubt remaining in the public mind about the morale of our military service at the present time, the following excerpt from a letter to his aunt from a boy training to be a pilot should certainly dispel all doubt:

Problems of schools and teachers in wartime were outlined yesterday at the final session of the annual convention of the New York State Teachers Association at the Hotel Commodore. Various resolution were adopted, aimed at maintaining present standards in the schools of the State.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 777, which compared with 831 in the preceding week and 415 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 249 as against 408 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -The government moved today to assure retention of a sufficient army of war workers on the home front by forbidding enlistment of essential aircraft and shipbuilding workers and expanding the list of necessary jobs to one out of every nine types in industry and agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Following out his plans for more effective cooperation between labor and the War Production Board, Donald M. Nelson, chairman, appointed two labor experts today to important posts.

The new Controlled Materials Plan, with its rigid scheduling of materials and war goods production, will eliminate excessive buying by industry, hoarding of vital materials and unbalanced manufacture of war materiel, it was indicated yesterday at what was one of the largest business conferences ever held in New York.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Nov. 24 -- The turning of Dakar to the United Nations' cause had prominent attention today in Argentine newspapers.

My observations covering many wears in two New York high schools have made me believe that the generally reported increase in juvenile misdemeanors and crimes is largely due to the serious breakdown of discipline in the public schools.

CHICAGO, Nov.-24 -- Three German-Americans who aided and sheltered Herbert Hans Haupt, executed Nazi saboteur and spy, were sentenced to death for treason today by Federal Judge William J. Campbell "as a timely and solemn warning to all who would attempt the smallest act of sabotage."

Are those Spars we read about the same Coast Guard Reserve women that were provisionally baptized the Warcogs? There is almost need for a little pocket dictionary to identify the growing number of new auxiliary services.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -The War Labor Board announced today increases for nearly 4,000 employes of nine major baking companies in New York City, ranging from 5 to 6 1/2 cents an hour and from $2.50 to $3 for those paid on a weekly basis.

BETHEL, Conn., Nov. 24 -Richard Krebs calmly ate breakfast at his Chestnut Ridge home this morning and asked if he might take time to shave, after immigration officers served him with a deportation warrant, authorized by Attorney General Biddle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Navy communique 200:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Jan Valtin, author of "Out of the Night," was arrested today in Bethel, Conn., on a warrant issued by the Immigration and Naturalization Service and held for deportation to Germany. The arrest was announced here soon afterward by Attorney General Biddle.

Dr. Bernard Sachs, past president of the New York Academy of Medicine, and one of the world's leaders in neurology, was honored yesterday at a special ceremony at the Mount Sinai Hospital in tribute to his "sixty years of participation in the progress of medicine."

If Clark Griffith, owner of the Senators, hopes to increase his quota of night games to something like forty-five next season he will have to overcome not only the generally expected opposition of the National League but that of Branch Rickey in particular.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- United States Army bombers based in India heavily attacked the Japanese-held city of Mandalay in Burma on Sunday, adding to the destruction wrought in the big American raid last Friday, it was announced tonight.

Two more medium-sized merchant ships of the United Nations, one of American registry and the other British, have been sunk by enemy submarines in our waters, the Navy Department announced yesterday. They brought the tabulation of The Associated Press of ships sunk in the western Atlantic since Pearl Harbor to 536.

The new amendment to the War Production Board's Conservation Order M-237, setting monthly quotas on wholesale deliveries of canned foods, was accepted with general satisfaction in the trade yesterday. The order, which affects canned fruits, fruit and vegetable juices and vegetables, gives both wholesalers and retailers a more official basis for the informal systems of trade rationing already established and foreshadows the early announcement of a civilian rationing regulation, it was said.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- While the Red Army's two-barbed thrust was plunging deeper into the enemy's flanks, Stalingrad's defenders grasped the initiative and, exactly three months after the city was first assaulted, began to clear the Germans systematically from fortresses and cellars. Continuing their gradual advance last night, the Russians took blockhouses by storm and broke resistance in both the northern factory and southern regions of the impregnable city.

The bloodless victory at Dakar means far more than the acquisition of a strategic port by the United Nations. A month ago this would have seemed of prime importance in itself. As the nearest point of the Eastern to the Western Hemisphere, Dakar has been referred to as a "dagger" pointed at the Americas, and the thought that it might fall into Axis hands has never been far from the mind of Washington.

Increases in the number of congregational units and church members participating in the church pensions system for twenty-one major Protestant denominations, the Y.M.C.A. and the Y.W.C.A., were reported yesterday at the opening session of the twentyeighth annual church pensions conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Directors of the Clinchfield Coal Corporation voted yesterday to clear up the remaining arrears on the preferred stock with the declaration of $28 a share payable on Dec. 14.

Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance of New York State, in a report on fire insurance made public yesterday, takes issue indirectly with the indictment handed down by a Federal grand jury at Atlanta last Friday charging violation of the anti-trust laws by the South-Eastern Underwriters Asociation and its 198 member capital stock fire insurance companies.

Saturday will be home-coming day for Lieut. Comdr. James Harold Crowley when he leads his North Carolina Naval Pre-Flight School Cloudbusters against Fordham at the Yankee Stadium, but the Ram is not being fattened for the return of the prodigal coach.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Bitter, close-quarter fighting is raging throughout the Buna section of the Northeastern New Guinea coast as the entrapped Japanese troops are subjected to repeated low-level bombing and strafing attacks, the Allied High Command announced today.

Clarence Adler, pianist, and the National Orchestral Association Alumni Orchestra, conducted by Leon Barzin, played two more of the Mozart piano concertos last night at Town Hall in the second of the series of six concerts they are devoting to the Mozart works for piano and orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Mrs. Michael E. Fleming of St. Paul received from President Roosevelt today the Congressional Medal of Honor awarded posthumously to her son, Captain Richard E. Fleming, 24, a Marine Corps flier who crashed in the sea during the battle of Midway after scoring a near miss on a Japanese battleship with a bomb dropped from only 500 feet.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Officials of the Florida East Coast Railroad announced today that they had received permission from the Office of Defense Transportation to increase the number of trains between Florida and Northern points from six to eight daily, early next month, in order to accommodate the increased Winter traffic.

Ralph H. Tapscott, who has been identified with the Edison system since 1917, was elected yesterday chief executive officer of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, thereby succeeding to the responsibilities held by the late Floyd L. Carlisle.

The destroyer Isherwood, named for the late Rear Admiral Benjamin Franklin Isherwood, was launched yesterday during a heavy rainstorm at the Staten Island yard of the Bethlehem Steel and Shipbuilding Company of Mariners Harbor in the presence of fifty invited guests and officers of the Navy.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 -- It was announced officially tonight that all resident male nationals here of the countries allied with Mexico would, with some exceptions, be compelled to enlist in the Mexican armed forces "in the event of international war."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan of reorganization for the Lone Star Gas Corporation to comply with "death sentence" provisions of the Holding Company Act.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The German Government has been operating for some time a large-scale racket in the sale of exit permits to persons in occupied countries who want to escape from the shadow of the Axis and who can pay for the privilege in foreign currency.

WINDSOR, Ont., Nov. 24 -- The three plants of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, all situated here, were closed by a strike of United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) today and about 14,000 men were made idle. It was the first strike to hit the company, engaged almost exclusively in war work, since the war began.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 24 -- The Senussi Arabs, a Moslem sect that includes a fair share of the inhabitants of Cyrenaica, have been assured by their leader, the Grand Senussi, that they would soon go back to their native land.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Two New York City companies and one Long Island concern were penalized by the War Production Board today for alleged violations of the war agency's regulations.

Using paint brushes as weapons, 2,000 American artists have attacked the enemy in one of the country's largest war poster competitions. The 200 entries judged best by the jury of awards will go on public exhibition today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. Nine $300 war bonds were given as prizes.

The National Association of Manufacturers reported today American industry's ability to produce war goods at far greater rates than had been expected was in itself one of the major factors in current basic raw-material shortages.

The Electric Auto-Lite Company announced yesterday in its report for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, a net profit of $3,633,932 after provision of $4,853,900 for Federal and foreign income and excess profits taxes. Taxes have been computed on the basis of the Revenue Act of 1942 and allow for the full year's excess profits credit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The State Department revealed today that the German authorities were developing an organized business of selling exit permits from occupied countries and warned against any one's participation in the illegal practice, under penalty of the law.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The optimistic war atmosphere had a good effect on the stock markets today. Many issues improved.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 24 -- Back-to-the-horse-and-buggy days became more than just a Presidential remark in Peoria today. That is exactly what residents of this city and its suburbs resorted to in order to get to work.

MONTREAL, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Montreal Canadiens staged a thrilling rally in the third period of a National Hockey League game with the Detroit Red Wings tonight to gain a 4-4 draw. The Wings maintained their firstplace deadlock with the Chicago Black Hawks.

A proposal that New York City be rated under meat rationing the same as military and war production areas because of its vast transient population made up predominantly of beef-eaters, has been laid before the Food Requirements Committee of the War Production Board by the Society of Restaurateurs.

A new fingerprinting station manned by the Downtown Business Girls unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services was opened yesterday in the subway arcade of the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway. They hope to have the fingerprints of the 9,000 persons employed in the building by Jan. 1.

A round of cocktail parties and dinners was given last night by members of the board of trustees of the Madison Square Boys Club, committee members and their friends, before the pre-Thanksgiving buffet supper and entertainment presented by members of the club at its headquarters, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation, announced yesterday that directors of the utility had approved the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application calling for a reduction in the stated value of outstanding $6 preferred stock from $100 to S10 a share.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- John Donaldson, senior 225-pound left tackle, has been appointed acting captain of the Pennsylvania team for the final game with Cornell on Thanksgiving Day.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood announced today in Commons that the current issue of 2 1/2 per cent national war bonds dated 1949-51, which had already raised 673,000,000, will be discontinued at the end of November and immediately replaced by a new issue, also 2 1/2 per cent, at par and repayable at par on March 1, 1951-53.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President Roosevelt said today that he was planning to give a radio address before long to explain the program of the United States for rehabilitating distressed and impoverished countries after the war, both in the Americas and in other continents.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 -Pre-Holiday buying made the San Francisco Bay area's food shortage more critical today as Thanksgiving shoppers found virtually no butter, too few turkeys, little meat, a shortage of eggs and no coffee for sale in their markets.

The German High Command acknowledged yesterday that Russian forces attacking southwest of Stalingrad had penetrated German defense lines on the Don, and military quarters said the Soviet offensive is continuing, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.
The turkey and the man in uniform will be the most important elements in the celebration tomorrow of the city's first wartime Thanksgiving in twenty-five years.
Incessant trade demand lifted prices yesterday to net gains of 22 to 33 points, or $1.10 to $1.65 a bale, representing a recovery of more than half the preceding day's losses.
In his letter published Nov. 21 Charles S. Joelson, a member of the bar, disapproves of court costs and states that "without cash the legal mills will not turn."

The story about the potential composer who could not read or write music, but who hummed his own tunes until they caught on, has come true in the case of Joseph Trapani, 27-year-old Brooklyn metal painter, who is confined to Kings County Hospital as an infantile paralysis patient, the National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- In its first major move to implement the recently announced "retailers' economy for victory plan," the Office of Price Administration issued today a supplementary order definitely authorizing the curtailing of many peacetime retail services without reductions in ceiling prices.

The ninth annual "Night of Stars," huge variety show for the benefit of the United Jewish Appeal, attracted a capacity crowd of 20,000 to Madison Square Garden last night and raised $100,000 to aid Jewish refugees from Europe and help them resettle in Palestine.

The conscientiousness and intelligence of the New Opera Company's performance of Tchaikovsky's "Queen of Spades" were last night manifest. Prevailingly there is good singing, acting that for the most part is careful, uneasy stiff with the inevitable amateurishness that the best-drilled artist will have until he has enjoyed the benefits of years of stage routine.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Africa's wealth in foodstuffs is being surveyed by the British Ministry of Food, possibly with a view to easing the supply position of his country, though this was not promised. William Mabane, parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry, said that a study of available sources in Algeria, Morocco and French West Africa had been undertaken.

Stockholders of the Punta Alegre Sugar Corporation will vote on Dec. 18 on a proposal to change each share of no-par capital stock into five shares of $1 par value, thereby increasing the authorized stock to 500,000 shares from 100,000.

A gift of $10,000 from the George F. Baker Charity Trust to the Girl Scout War Emergency Fund was reported yesterday by Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, general chairman of the fund, in a revised list of contributions presented before a progress meeting of campaign volunteers at the headquarters of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, 670 Lexington avenue.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 25 -- The three-month-old Nazi grip on Stalingrad was weakening today after a swiftly advancing Red Army had killed 15,000 more Germans yesterday and captured 12,000, including three divisional generals, in a great Winter offensive rolling so fast that some Nazi units were cut down from behind in panicky retreat.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 -- Information received here of methods by which the Germans in Poland are carrying out the slaughter of Jews includes accounts of trainloads of adults and children taken to great crematoriums at Oswiencim, near Cracow.

The National Arts Club, where the thirty-seventh annual exhibition of new books of the year is on view, will hold its fourth "authors' night" tonight at 8:15 o'clock. The speakers will be Curt Riess, whose "The Self-Betrayed" has just been published; Margaret Tayler Yates, mystery novel writer, and Gaynor Maddox, author of "Eat Well for Less Money."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 24 -- Brazilian newspapers proclaimed today that "Brazil is free of a grave menace" in reporting happily that Dakar and French West Africa had been brought over to the United Nations' side in the war through the action of Admiral Francois Darlan.

American organized labor laid aside all differences last night to demonstrate its solidarity in support of British relief and the war aims of the United Nations, when 3,000 representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations assembled at a dinner of the British War Relief Society at the Hotel Astor and pledged once more labor's determination to help win the war and achieve a democratic peace.

A loan exhibition of paintings, studies and drawings by the great seventeenth-century Flemish artist Peter Paul Rubens is being held at the Schaeffer Brandt Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, as a benefit for the United Hospital Fund of New York.

It is two thousand miles from the German outposts on the Spanish border to the North Cape of Norway. It is another two thousand miles from the North Cape to the Caucasian oil fields. It is two thousand more miles from the Caucasus back to the Spanish border. Within those lines lies the triangle of German power as the fourth Winter of the war begins.

The liquor, hotel and restaurant industries in the city banded together yesterday to stamp out in their fields illegal operators who are taking advantage of men in the armed forces and thereby giving prohibitionists ammunition with which to press for restrictive legislation.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, at Bengazi, Libya, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- Hours before we reached Bengazi early this morning we could see a pall of dense black smoke hovering over the town and the flat country adjoining it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -The resignation of Frank E. Gannett, Rochester, N.Y., publisher, as assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, was accepted "with sincere regret" tonight by Joseph W. Martin Jr., retiring chairman.

IT was Hal, of the four famous brothers of the House of Stevens, the noted catering firm, who did it. He put King William -- William J. Klem to the income tax collector but King William to all baseball folk -- on wheels.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Republican State Committee spent $163,662 to elect the party's State ticket, headed by Thomas E. Dewey for Governor, a statement filed with the Secretary of State showed today.

The honor of Westchester County's hunting archers has been cleared. An investigation made by the South New York Fish and Game Association shows that the dog injured in Armonk Village last Friday was not hit by an adult Robin Hood who mistook him for a deer.

HANOVER, Pa., Nov. 24 (AP) -The Hanover Shoe Farms, breeder of three Hambletonian winners and owner of two other victors in the trotting classic, today announced it would discontinue racing standardbred horses.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- The Japanese air force, harassed in Burma and occupied China by American and British fliers operating from India and Free China, has transferred 300 planes to Saigon, Indo-China, about 900 miles from Allied bases in China's Kwangsi and Yunnan Provinces.

Mayor La Guardia and William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, charged yesterday that an attempt had been made to "shake down" a stirrup-pump distributor on the claim that a proposed local law could be killed by the City Council as the result of "influence."

The New York City Ski Patrol held its first meeting of the year last night at the Hotel New Yorker with some fifty persons, including several service men, in attendance. Ken Littlefield, who succeeded Dick Rocker as patrol captain, said "that despite the obstacles arising from the war the standards of the patrol, one of the toughest in the country, will not be relaxed."

Protestants, Roman Catholics and Jews in the New York area will attend services tomorrow forenoon in obedience to the Thanksgiving Day proclamation of President Roosevelt that the day be observed "with a deepened appeal for Divine guidance in the crisis through which the nation is passing."

Unless advertisers in this country increase their efforts in South America now, it is possible that many of their trade marks will disappear from that market in the new competition that will follow the war, O.E. Zimmerman, manager of the Argentine Trade Promotion Bureau, warned yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Export Advertising Association in the Hotel Belmont-Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President Carlos Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador stressed the theme of democracy in an address to the members of the House of Representatives today.

Churches in every land, "hammered into oneness by hostile blows, are the most promising nuclei of any future world fellowship, and can exercise a ministry of reconciliation," the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday afternoon at the annual Thanksgiving service in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

What was most significant in Monday's speech by William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, was its admission that the decisions of the board involved "an element of forced acceptance * * * a substantial element of compulsion."
The battle for Tunisia -- and for Tripolitania and Libya -- was rapidly turning into vicious, scrambling fighting yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Sharp fighting took place today in several sectors of Tunisia, where the Allied forces are advancing on Axis-held Tunis, the capital, and Bizerte, the vital naval base. There has been no major clash yet, however, although air activity is increasing as the opposing forces manoeuvre for positions.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 24 -- In opening the convention to consider amendments to the Commonwealth Constitution embodied in a bill that Attorney General H.V. Evatt introduced in the House of Representatives in October, Prime Minister John Curtain announced today that the Australian Government had examined objections to them and framed readjustments designed to overcome the objections.

The L.I.U. basketball team routed the Bolling Field five from Washington, 62 to 26, on the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy court last night. Fifteen players were used by the winners, with ten of them getting into the scoring column.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -Temporary food shortages were developing in some sections of the country as consumers, enjoying a record volume of purchasing power, rushed to grocery stores to buy supplies for Thanksgiving Day dinners.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Old persons, children, infants and cripples among the Jewish population of Poland are being shot, killed by various other methods or forced to undergo hardships that inevitably cause death as a means of carrying out an order by Heinrich Himmler, Nazi Gestapo chief, that half the remaining Polish Jews must be exterminated by the end of this year, according to a report issued today by the Polish Government in London.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- With reports current in the capital of a growing crisis within the Administration on the issue of civilian versus military control of the country's economy, President Roosevelt today brushed aside questions as to whether the War Production Board or the armed forces have the final authority on war production problems.

Some people in Toronto, where Wendell Willkie has been scheduled to speak tonight at an Aid-to-Russia rally, seem not to have learned that one good way to call attention to a man's views is to try to keep him from expressing them. Members of a First World War veterans' association say they won't go to the meeting.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 24 -- Brig. Gen. Clayton Bissell, who has just returned from an inspection tour of American forces on the Burma and Chinese fronts, said at a press conference here today that the Japanese were so occupied in other places, especially in the Solomon Islands, that they could not take on any new commitments now, such as an attack on India.

One of the main objectives of the forthcoming intensive war-financing drives will be to place as large a part of the Government debt as possible outside the commercial banks. But however successful this effort is, the commercial banks will have to bear a very heavy load.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Merchant Marine Committee, in a report made to the House today, urged the Maritime Commission to "tighten up" its standard contract form to curb profits. The report was drafted by a sub-committee named to investigate the circumstances surrounding the cancellation of the commission's contract with the Higgins corporation of New Orleans for construction of 200 Liberty ships.

The Newspaper United Scrap Metal Drive throughout the nation has netted 6,000,000 tons of scrap iron and steel and other strategic-metals, it was announced yesterday by Richard W. Slocum, chairman of the campaign.

In a drive to develop a worthy holder of the world lightweight title that Sammy Angott relinquished on Nov. 13, the State Athletic commission, acting in harmony with the National Boxing Association, yesterday designated eleven 135-pounders of recognized ability to engage in an elimination series.
Sales of several tenements and dwellings and a small loft building and leasing of a number of residential and business buildings in various parts of Manhattan were reported by brokers yesterday.

Rent control will be put into effect in the New York area shortly, but because of "favorable" conditions existing here it may be possible that a "modified form" can be used, Maurice L. Stone, regional director of the rent division of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Nov. 24 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, assured a news conference today that, so far he knew, there was no naval action going on in the Solomons area, such as had been announced by the Japanese radio last night. He said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- At her first press conference today Lieut. Comdr. Dorothy C. Stratton, director of the two-day-old Spars, women's reserve of the Coast Guard, revealed that some of the Waves, women's naval reserve, now taking the indoctrination course at Smith College, would be allowed to volunteer in the Spars, becoming procurement officers.

Details of modern American methods for making sponge iron will be sent to China shortly to assist wide-scale manufacture of munitions, arms and machinery in that country, it was announced here yesterday by David Leacock, technical director of "Indusco," the American committee in aid of Chinese industrial cooperatives.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25 -- Ariel Patrol, a coal black colt that had finished second four times and third twice in eight attempts, finally broke the jinx today when be defeated half a dozen maiden juveniles of his sex in the Bethlehem-Fairfield purse.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Four German soldiers, captured by Australian forces in Africa, escaped near here early today from a prison train carrying them to an internment camp in the United States, but all were recaptured within seven hours.

Two Harlem Negroes who had pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in a "mugging" hold-up, in which they fatally stabbed their victim, a white man, were sentenced yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions to twenty-five years to life imprisonment.

The question has been frequently asked, Why has not this war produced the crop of rollicking soldier marching songs as the past wars ? My reply is, for the same reason modern wars do not inspire the artist to reproduce on canvas the stirring scenes of the battlefield.
A longer work week will not be advisable for women, Miss Frieda Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday.

The sweep and splendor of Wagner's Goetterdaemmerung, lustily projected, made last night the second offering of the current Metropolitan opera season. The opera attracted an immense audience, an audience soon and inevitably under its spell.

The voluntary retail service controls outlined by the OPA in its supplementary order No. 29 were viewed in retail circles here yesterday as paving the way for the issuance by the Office of Defense Transportation of a mandatory order further restricting store deliveries.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 -- The seventy-fifth Liberty ship launched at the Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipyard here, named for the late Daniel Willard, long president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, was launched today. The keel was laid Oct. 26.

Official figures released yesterday by the National Football League reveal that the race for individual ground-gaining honors between Bill Dudley of the Steelers and Merlyn Condit of the Dodgers is closer than it has been in recent weeks.
Two more ships have been added to the toll exacted by enemy submarines, according to Navy announcements yesterday that indicated that forty-eight men were missing.

Extension of Tuesday's gains left the cotton futures market yesterday at virtually the same levels as those prior to the sharp decline on Monday. Price-fixing by mills in the December position led yesterday's rise to net gains of 2 to 25 points for active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Choice of a successor to Representative Martin as chairman of the Republican National Committee was reported unofficially today to be narrowing down to three candidates, although there was no disposition to dismiss the chances of a "dark horse" aspirant.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Nearly a third of Poland's Jewish population -- 1,000,000 persons -- has perished in three years of German occupation, Dr. Ignacy Szwarcbart, Jewish member of the Polish National Council in London, told this correspondent today, amplifying Polish Government information on the new Nazi onslaught on the Jews.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Lakehurst Naval Air Station's first football team in history -- twenty-eight huskies who have never practiced together as a unit -- winds up a successful campaign at Pittsburgh tomorrow with hopes of upsetting favored Duquesne University.

Some of the lonely soldiers and sailors who will spend Thanksgiving in New York, far from their homes, will enjoy pumpkin pie at the Travelers Aid Society Lounge, in Pennsylvania Station, today through the efforts of Mrs. Olin Bevin, co-director of the society, who twenty-five years ago was baking pumpkin pies in far-away Neufchateau, France, for the soldiers of yesteryear.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- Louis (Lepke) Buchalter lost another round in his fight for life today when the court of appeals refused to permit a reargument of his appeal rom a conviction of murder. The decision also affected Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone, who were convicted of slaying Joseph Rosen, a Brooklyn storekeeper.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Many vital war-production plants in this area will be in full operation throughout the holiday tomorrow as the result of an appeal to them by Naval officials. A majority of the large plants had announced they would work full shifts tomorrow, but factories with subcontracts had indicated they planned to close.

The filibuster has no justification in parliamentary law. Like the sit-down strike, it is a corruption of the right of occupancy. It is an abuse and perversion of the legislators' right of expression without unreasonable limitation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- President Roosevelt was assured today by Sidi Mohammed, Sultan of Morocco, of the friendship of Morocco for the United States. Morocco has no disagreement with the United States, the Sultan declared in a message to the President.

The twentieth festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music will be held next August at the University of California in Los Angeles, it was announced yesterday. Werner Janssen will be the director.

The Russians have succeeded in "temporarily penetrating" Nazi positions on the Rzhev front, northwest of Moscow, and have reached a point west of the rail center of Toropets, German broadcasts, as recorded by The Associated Press, disclosed yesterday.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The grand Allied assault on Tunis and Bizerte is about to be launched by the force of British Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson, the Morocco radio announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A public official once saved from possible death on the battlefield by Stephen T. Early, White House press secretary, resigned his post today to re-enter the Army as a major in the Transportation Corps.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- John P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor, charged today that the complaint by the National Labor Relations Board against Henry J. Kaiser, in which he is alleged to have discriminated among unions in favor of the A.F. of L., was "but the beginning of a nation-wide move to sabotage one of our most vital industries at the very height of the war."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Ben Alexander, WPB lumber coordinator, declared today that while the lumber negotiations were continuing, and he still retained hope, Allen Nicholson, former timber controller, now deputy controller, for Canada, had "absolutely refused" to lift the restrictions.

Hitler and Hirohito were charged with another crime yesterday. Because of the war the Brewers Board of Trade, Inc., 270 Madison Avenue, announced that its members, leading brewers in this area, would not brew bock beer next Spring.
