An invitation to advertising interests in this country to join in celebrating Pan-American Advertising Day on Dec. 4 has been extended by the Brazilian Advertising Association, the Advertising Managers Association of the Argentine and other similar organizations in Central and South America.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, Nov. 26 -- In laying siege to prepared Japanese strong points in the Buna area of New Guinea Australian and American troops were engaged last night in a battle of bitter intensity. Although small in scale, the fighting had developed into an engagement as sharp as any yet fought between Allied and Japanese troops.

TORONTO, Nov. 25 -- Appealing for a grand coalition of peoples to fight a common war for liberation, Wendell L. Willkie declared here tonight that the people must discuss and define their common purpose before the war is over or run the risk of having worked and sacrificed and suffered to win a war for no purpose.

The large current governmental deficit should be financed on a sound basis to ward off inflation, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, declared yesterday at the closing session of the annual Church Pensions Conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A Negro woman, who said she had been chauffeur for a number of Hollywood notables, was held in $200 bail yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court for hearing in Special Sessions on an assault charge brought by the white teacher of her 12-year-old son, Alvin.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Norwegian Telegraph Agency said today that reports from Norway continued to tell of mutiny among the occupying German troops. German officers and men in chains were said to have been seen on ships that put into Norwegian ports on the way south.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 25 -- With the fear of renewed American air raids growing, law and order in Hong Kong, especially in Kowloon, are rapidly breaking down, according to a traveler who left the British colony some weeks ago. Armed robberies occur daily, with murders in broad daylight, despite rigid though inadequate policing by gendarmes of the Japanese military and of the puppet government.

Specialty salesmen of various manufacturers and wholesalers, especially those selling home furnishings, clothing, textiles, footwear, etc., will be lent to accounts which find their selling staffs short during the holiday selling period following reports that stores need 400,000 sales people.

One $1,000 6 per cent purchase money mortgage bond of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was sold on the New Cork Curb Exchange yesterday at $1,800, a gain of $210 since Monday and an increase in price of $275 for the current week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -President Roosevelt's engagements included conferences with Donald Nelson and Charles E. Wilson of the War Production Board; William Green of the A.F.L. and Philip Murray of the C.I.O.; Admiral Leahy, Admiral King, General Marshall and General Arnold; Governor Lehman and the Haitian Minister.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- The National Industrial Chemical Conference was told today by Ralph H. Ball, chief of the organic plastics and resins sections, WPB, that lack of materials both for the plastics themselves and for new plants stood as a barrier to widespread use as substitutes for scarce items.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commanding United States forces in China, said in a communique today that American bomber and fighter planes had bombed and machine-gunned widely separated Japanese installations during the past five days.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 25 -- The development of an inter-American inland waterway using the Orinoco, Casiquiare, Negro and Amazon Rivers is being studied by Brazilian and Venezuelan Government commissions, it was revealed today by Foreign Minister Parra Perez.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The stock markets were firm at the opening today and the better tone was maintained.

At his press conference on Tuesday the President's comments called attention to the central weakness of the present war organization in Washington. WPB and Army and Navy officials, he said, are supposed to agree, and when they do not, he will lock them in a room and tell them they will get no food until they come out with an agreement.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Red Army striking across the snow-covered Don steppes west of Stalingrad has seized strategic points at the junction of the Don and Chir Rivers in a move threatening rapidly to complete the envelopment of the 300,000-man German assault army at Stalingrad.
AT HEADQUARTERS OF U.S. AIR FORCES in China, Nov. 24 (Delayed) (AP) --A communiqtd:

Artur Rubinstein gave a piano recital last night in Town Hall as the second event of the season in the Town Hall Endowment Series. The artist's magic touch and formidable technique made all of his offerings of interest as examples of highly perfected pianism.

Stocks of gasoline throughout the country at the close of last week amounted to 78,583,000 barrels, a decline of 835,000 from the 79,418,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 85,409,000 barrels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Proponents of a process to make alumina, the base of aluminum, out of domestic clay told a joint Congressional subcommittee today of unsuccessful efforts to get the necessary approval from the National Academy of Sciences for the erection of a pilot plant.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- The American Football Coaches Association today pledged itself to carry on intercollegiate football next year with whatever material and means are available under wartime conditions.

Many Americans will sit down to a Thanksgiving dinner today at which turkey will be the principal fare. It has been so for a long time. But in the early days of our nation the wild turkey graced the festive board because some one in the family was a good shot.

The clerk in downtown traffic court yesterday afternoon called out the name of Harry Schendler of 1663 48th Street, Brooklyn, summoned for illegally parking a car Nov. 5 in front of 114 Eldridge Etreet.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Mike Holovak, one of the several good reasons why Boston College is rated the nation's No. 1 football team, finally is getting statistical confirmation of the great job he's doing.

Rayonier, Inc., reported yesterday for the six months ended on Oct. 31, the first half of its current fiscal year, net profit of $1,078,298 after all charges. The profit is equal after preferred dividend requirements to 47 cents a common share.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Any bowl committees that had ideas of getting one of the Navy's Pre-Flight elevens for their New Year's Day football games can just forget all about it.

Your editorial of Nov. 20 on the overtime aspects of the resolution of the National Conference on Labor Legislation follows so much editorial discussion of overtime that I trust you will give space to the facts as we who administer the Fair Labor Standards Act see them.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 25 -- Vichy propaganda asserts that French skilled workers are continuing to "volunteer" in large numbers for service in German armament plants and that in exchange more prisoners of war are being released.

The Grumman A.A. basketball team, to the surprise of no one, won the final of the special invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden last night. But the manner in which the prohibitive favorites triumphed over the Ordnance team from the Aberdeen (Md.) Proving Ground was, indeed, a surprise.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Nov. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- On the punctured deck of a United States warship, Admiral William F. Halsey presented decorations to forty officers and men and told his command, "We will show them that every one of you is a better man than that little yellow monkey."

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 -- It is hoped here that, as the result of discussions that began today between Norman Robertson, Under-Secretary of State for External Affairs, and H.K. Travers, chief of the visa division of the State Department at Washington, there will be some slackening instead of tightening of the border-crossing regulations between Canada and the United States.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25 -- Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O. United Steel Workers of America, notified officials of the United States Steel Corporation today that the union was laying the dispute over the existing wage differential between Northern and Southern subsidiaries before the National War Labor Board.

TEANECK, N.J., Nov. 25 -- The Teaneck Board of Education is confronted with a war problem that has become a collective headache -- that of rationing leaves for teachers who want to get married to men in the services or spend a few weeks with husbands who have been called for military duty.

The Council on Books in Wartime announced yesterday that it would sponsor on Dec. 6 a large symposium on the book trade's "wartime part." The meeting, to be attended by publishers, librarians, booksellers and their associates, will be held at 8:15 P.M. at the CBS Radio Theatre No. 4 at Fifty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue. W.W. Norton will be chairman of the meeting.

Shipments of iron ore on the Great Lakes this week lifted the total for the 1942 season above the 90,000,000 gross ton goal set by the government early last Spring. Deliveries to date are 17 per cent ahead of last year's ore movement, the previous record.

Protests against a recent order of the Office of Defense Transportation curtailing milk routes to conserve gasoline, rubber and manpower were made by representatives of eighteen settlement houses and welfare organizations in a resolution adopted yesterday by the United Neighborhood Houses at a meeting in the Recreation Rooms and Settlement, 68 First Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- An indictment charging the New York Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, twelve subsidiaries and seventeen officers and directors with violation of the anti-trust laws in the production, processing, sale and distribution of food and food products, was handed down by a Federal grand jury at Dallas, Texas, the Department of Justice announced here today.
Blended worsteds have received wider attention in both men's and women's wear, according to the weekly trade report of the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange, Inc.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The demands of British workers for partnership in industry, security of employment and a good standard of living care never again be ignored, Sir George Schuster, M.P., one of this country's best known financiers, said today in advocating some measure of government control over the nation's commerce after the war.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 25 -- Colgate opposes Brown tomorrow morning in the twenty-fourth meeting of a series that dates back to 1908. Brown spent the afternoon polishing its offense and defense in Marvel Gymnasium, but topped that off with a thirty-minute drill on Aldrich Field.

The theatre celebrated Thanksgiving a little early this year, quietly advancing the clock a few hours in order to bring the Lunts back to town. Anything that serves to return the Lunts to Broadway is an occasion for rejoicing, for they are the theatre's greatest pair of actors, and they have been magnificent in plays from Shakespeare to Sherwood, with snatches of vaudeville thrown in to relieve the danger of too much intensity.

In Africa the American Expeditionary Forces have entered French territory, and the whole relationship of France to the world and the war has changed as quickly as if a wind had swept across a cardboard stage set and ended all the make-believe. Quite apart from its importance as a military coup, this move had the effect of a breakthrough to reality.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A special communique:

Now and then in the course of his daily duties it may have occurred to our Brooks Atkinson that all the world's a stage and all the men and women are players with exits and entrances. Today the airplane has made this more than ever startlingly true.

LYNN, Mass., Nov. 25 (AP) -- A message of thanksgiving for "the weapons and the equipment with which to conduct our North African campaign" was received from Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today by the employes of the General Electric Company's Lynn plant.

The four-family house on a plot 25 by 100 feet at 134 Vermont Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Tillie Seidman to Rudolph Casal for cash, subject to a mortgage of $7,710. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

High ranking naval officers and outstanding figures in the shipping world joined yesterday afternoon 317 cadets from the New York State Maritime Academy in observing the institution's "Founders Day" in the Maritime Exchange which was decorated for the occasion with more than fifty American shipping company house flags.
Dividend declarations on three preferred issues of the Northern Indiana Public Service Company, announced yesterday, will clear up arrearages on those shares.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Thousands of American soldiers will celebrate Thanksgiving in the British Isles tomorrow. With them they will carry along countless Englishmen, Scots, Welshmen and Irishmen who have written their own significance into the holiday.
Mr. and Mrs. Clark Williams have left the Drake for their plantation, The Cedars and The Pines, in Camden, S.C. Mrs. Williams expects to return here in a fortnight.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Meeting for the forty-ninth time since 1893, the Pennsylvania and Cornell elevens will play tomorrow on Franklin Field before a crowd of 60,000 or more.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The statutes fix a Supreme Court quorum -- the number of justices required to act in a case -- as six members. Therefore, when as many as four disqualify themselves to hear a pleading, as they did this week on the government's appeal in the anti-trust litigation against the Aluminum Company of America, no quorum exists and the case must go on the inactive list.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, the only major ensemble in the United States that had been nonunion in recent years, has come to an agreement with the American Federation of Musicians and its president, James C. Petrillo, it became known last night. The Boston Symphony's acceptance of a union contract came after months of negotiations that had been preceded by years of attack and counter-attack.

The volume of engineering construction contracts for the year thus far has reached $8,932,207,000, an increase of 60 per cent over the work listed in the nation during the same forty-eight-week period last year, according to statistics compiled by Engineering News-Record.
The names of several business executives were on the lists of new apartment rentals made public yesterday.

Shipments of munitions by the General Motors Corporation in October rang up a new high record of $248,400,000, continuing an uninterrupted advance, month by month, since the original national defense program got under way late in 1940.
TORONTO, Nov. 25 -- Following is the text of an address by Wendell L. Willkie at a rally of the Canadian Aid to Russia Fund here tonight:

Despite wartime regulations on shipping space and governmental controls on United States exports, Venezuela continues to receive large quantities of "non-essential" materials and one vessel which sailed for that country during the last five days carried 72 per cent of relatively unimportant merchandise, A. Davila-Delgado, Venezuelan Shipping Coordinator at Washington, declared yesterday.

A cut in newsprint production in the United States and Canada within a few weeks was foreshadowed yesterday in a statement by Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

TRENTON, Nov. 25 -- The elimination by next Summer of a "dangerous bottleneck" on Route 21, known as McCarter Highway in Newark, was forecast today oy State Highway Commissioner Spencer Miller Jr. in announcing that an agreement had been reached to acquire the Wilkinson-Gaddis property, around which detouring over narrow, rough streets has been necessary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. started a Victory Loan drive today by selling the first of the new securities to President Roosevelt. It was the first disclosure that new bonds to go bon public sale on Nov. 30 will be called '"Victory Loan" securities.

Members of the American Women's Voluntary Services, working under the New York War Savings Staff, started an accelerated program yesterday designed to increase participation in the payroll savings plan. They will attempt to stimulate pledges by showing films and arranging for speakers in 1,500 business concerns in Manhattan, according to an announcement released by the war savings office, 1270 Sixth Avenue.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, made an unannounced call on President Roosevelt today in connection with reports in Congressional circles of a possible reshuffling of cabinet posts centering on the manpower program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Brig. Gen. Asa N. Duncan, Chief of Air Staff for the European Theatre of Operations, has been missing for eight days, the War Department disclosed here today.

FORT DIX, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Streets in near-by Wrightstown were clogged with thousands of Fort Dix soldiers tonight awaiting bus transportation to take them home or to the metropolitan area for the Thanksgiving holiday.

An increase of 30 per cent in output of new doctors and several other measures taken by the Government make the prospect of medical care in the nation during the war a happier one than has been pictured generally, it was said here yesterday by Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, medical adviser to the War Manpower Commission, and Trustee of the United Hospital Fund.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Racing dates for the five tracks in the Chicago area and for Fairmount Park, near Collinsville, all of which expect to operate in 1943, were announced by the Illinois Racing Board today. The 157-day season will open May 1, closing Oct. 30.

Collectors of American Art will hold this year's final open-house reception before the annual distribution of works of art to members at the gallery, 106 East Fifty-seventh Street, from 5 to 7 on Sunday afternoon. Reginald Marsh will be guest of honor.
The day before Thanksgiving was a big day for butchers but at least three of them were victimized by hold-up men last night as they counted up the day's receipts.
NAHUNTA, Ga., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Uncle Sam asked questions and Carl Broome, editor of the Brantley Enterprise, a weekly, answered and in detail.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Office of Price Administration voted today to eliminate "unnecessary handling and wasteful extra finishing" of cotton and rayon piece goods. The move was necessary, it was held, because of the increasingly disturbing aspects of the "tight" civilian textile markets.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 (AP) -- President Alva Bradley of the Indians expressed doubt today that fans want wartime baseball and declared that he "would rather not open" the ball park next Spring if he thought the "wolves" would ride his players for not being in the military service.

Police of nine States and Canada are seeking 14-year-old John M. Kennedy, the son of Representative Martin J. Kennedy, Democrat, from the Eighteenth Congressional District, who left his home at 1349 Lexington Avenue at 3 P.M. Monday, leaving a note saying that he intended to join the Canadian armed forces.

A General Sessions jury of six men and six women last evening convicted Dr. Samuel Buckler, 60 years old, head of the Jewish Court of Arbitration, former city official, former Sing Sing Jewish chaplain and disbarred lawyer, in his seven-day trial for frauds on visitors to his former office at 377 Broadway.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- Lieutenant Governor-elect Thomas W. Wallace made a special call on Lieutenant Governor Poletti today and the two chatted for half an hour, the present presiding officer of the Senate explaining to his successor the procedure in the upper house.
Christmas food packages for men in the armed services should contain only such delicacies as will arrive in good shape after careful packing, the United Service Organizations warned yesterday.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan started yesterday an investigation into charges made by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, in a report to Mayor La Guardia that an $8,000 shakedown had been attempted in connection with a bill pending in the City Council that would affect the stirrup pump market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A six-month postponement of country-wide gasoline rationing was urged today by a committee representing a bipartisan group of House members, largely from oilproducing States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Details of a new agreement reached with Brazil under which export control will be decentralized were learned here today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- A wave of short covering and a broader commission house demand sent rye futures up today on the Board of Trade, the market advancing around 1 1/2 cents a bushel over yesterday's finish to a new high in about a month.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Thursday, Nov. 26 -- Allied bombers have turned back a new Japanese attempt to land reinforcements in the beleaguered Buna area, on the Northeastern New Guinea coast, sinking two destroyers and probably a third, all of them apparently heavy laden with enemy troops.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- First Lieutenant John F. Segrest Jr. of Milstead, Ala., and Sergeant George E. Williams of Liverpool, N.Y., have received both the United States Army Air Medal and the Order of the Purple Heart for conspicuous heroism in action over enemy-occupied Europe.

Predicting that the United Nations will "carry the fight to the enemy," Vice President Henry A. Wallace, in a message to Junior Hadassah at its nineteenth annual convention, declared last night that "more and more the German people are realizing that the tide is turning."

NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Boston College's unbeaten football squad suffered a shock today with the report that Fred Naumetz, center and co-captain, might be unable to play in Saturday's game with Holy Cross.

WINDSOR, Ont., Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- There was no sign tonight of settlement of the strike that has closed down the huge plant of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, despite an appeal from Ontario Labor Minister Peter Heenan in Toronto for a return to work pending settlement negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- WPB officials blame much of the delay in warplane and other arms production on faulty scheduling, by which they mean, principally, the failure to arrange a balanced flow of parts for assembly into finished planes, guns and ships.

Brooklyn College concluded preparations for today's post-season contest with C.C.N.Y. with a review of all offensive plays yesterday, stressing passing plays. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 o'clock at the Brooklyn College field and the entire proceeds of the game will go to the American Red Cross.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden assured the House of Commons today that he was in entire agreement with Prime Minister Winston Churchill in the matter of "postponing" a broadcast by General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, which, it has been charged, the British Government suppressed.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 (AP) -- New and expanded Adirondacks mines will yield between 9,000,000 and 10,000,000 tons of iron ore annually under a program undertaken by the government and private industry to increase production there. There is as much as 500,000,000 to 1,000,000,000 tons of high and low grade ore in the Adirondacks to feed the country's smelters, some geologists estimate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, carried direct to President Roosevelt today his conflict with the Army and Navy on the question of final authority to direct war production scheduling.

Dioramas of bygone Christmas days, brought to life from authentic old prints, will be opened to public inspection today in the Thirty-fourth Street windows of James McCreery Co. The scenes, dating back to the days when New York was known as New Amsterdam, will be made up of authentic furniture and trimmings, including material gathered from museums, libraries and individuals.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 25 -- Taking a stranglehold on the European lumber industry, the Germans now have established a central office in Berlin, which, through granting or withholding clearing service for payments, will check every lumber deal henceforth concluded between the Continent and Sweden and Finland, the two big Nordic exporters of lumber.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The humble minesweeper Bengal, assigned to escort a Netherland tanker across the Indian Ocean, won a naval battle Nov. 11 when, with the tanker's aid a powerfully armed Japanese raider was destroyed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Gary Botsford, 3 1/2-month-old child who was kidnapped yesterday from a buggy in downtown Waukegan, was found safe late today by the Zion (Ill.) police. They arrested a woman who identified herself as Mrs. Anne Tyrell Lussier, 29 years old, wife of a soldier in a Southern camp.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. The newcomer at the Hollywood will be "Casablanca," a Warner Brothers drama of intrigue in French Morocco, featuring Humphrey Bogart, Ingrid Bergman, Claude Rains, Sydney Greenstreet, Paul Henreid, Conrad Veidt and Peter Lorre. . . .

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- The Brewster Aeronautical Corporation filed a suit in Federal District Court today to recover $3,200,000 said to have been paid to the Miranda brothers as "commissions" on the sale of airplanes and parts to foreign nations, naming as defendants James Work, former president, chairman of the board and the principal stockholder of the old Brewster Corporation; Philip M. Stephenson, a former vice president, and J. Griffith Boardman, a former director.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Dairy producers were forbidden today by the War Production Board to distribute whipping or heavy cream to the public.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 25 -- The Germans in Tunisia still appeared to be largely supported by air communications today and British twin-engined fighters of the Middle East Command continued to take their daily toll of these aerial freighters and buses.

Warning motorists to take special care this year in selecting anti-freeze mixtures, the National Better Business Bureau asserted yesterday that some of the newer products on the market may cause damage to the engine cooling systems.
AT ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- President Carlos Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador assured the Senate today that in Ecuador there was and would be "a forthright effort to cooperate with the United States in the struggle for victory for democracy."

Before leaving yesterday for Chicago, Frank Boucher of the New York Rangers announced that he had signed a new goalie for his National Hockey League sextet. Jimmy Franks, formerly the property of the Detroit Red Wings, was the net-minder acquired by the Blueshirts, and he will see action in the contest with the Black Hawks tonight.

It has been said time and time again that it takes ten years to get a new medical discovery into a textbook and ten more to get it out after it has been superseded. When quinine was first introduced into Europe in the treatment of malarial fever physicians were hostile; and when Koch lectured on the bacterial causation of tuberculosis the great Virchow stamped out of the room in indignation at such heresy.
Boxing will have an outstanding civilian heavyweight on the night of Jan. 8 in Madison Square Garden if Promoter Mike Jacobs's plans materialize.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Hal Conners of Buffalo, who played 150-pound football last year, led Rutgers in scoring, passing and running, a statistical review of the Scarlet's 1942 season disclosed today.

" The Great Big Doorstep," a new comedy by Frances Goodrich and Albert Hackett, derived from the novel of E.P. O'Donnell, opens tonight at the Morosco under the auspices of Herman Shumlin. It is all about a Louisiana Cajun family which snags a huge doorstep from the Mississippi flood and then tries to live up to its grandeur.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 25 (AP) -- A Navy operations officer made a daring descent to a rough sea fifty miles offshore yesterday to rescue four fliers who parachuted after their planes met in collision.

The New York-New Jersey region, which sent 790,500 tons of iron and steel scrap to mills during July, August and September, led the rest of the country in percentage-of-quota shipments for the third quarter of the year, it was reported yesterday by John P. Maguire, regional director of the War Production Board.

A post-war era of housing and building activity that will give that industry a role comparable to that played by the automobile industry after the first World War was predicted yesterday by George A. Sloan, New York City Commissioner of Commerce.

Mayor La Guardia's sponsorship of a pension for Philip A. Hines, who resigned as first deputy city clerk under charges of accepting "tips" for performing marriage ceremonies, was branded as "utterly indefensible" yesterday by the executive committee of the Citizens Union.

London seems to be "completely taken over by American soldiers who have, for their own purposes of identification, renamed Grosvenor Square 'Eisenhower Platz,'" Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, president of Bundles for Britain, said yesterday on her return by Clipper from an inspection tour of English hospitals and relief agencies.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 -- The order came through from the Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy that no one is to be permitted to purchase tickets to the Army-Navy football game except residents of Annapolis, and the Navy is adhering so strictly to the letter of the command that fewer than 15,000 are expected to get inside Thompson Stadium here on Saturday.
CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 25 -- After a series of conferences between non-Labor delegates today's proceedings of the Constitutional Convention assumed a marked party tinge.

Melvin Ott, who did such a crack job in his managerial debut the past season in bringing the Giants home in third place, breezed in to town from New Orleans yesterday to take inventory of his playing resources for 1943.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The War Production Board's program of style simplification spread into the men's and boys' furnishings field today through an order requiring shirt manufacturers to reduce by two to three inches the length of men's and boys' shirts.

Ask almost any woman what sort of present she wants for Christmas and she will say "something pretty and completely impractical." Christmas-time cosmetics are the answer to that characteristically feminine wish -- and add the extra dividend of a practical purpose concealed beneath the tinsel and trimming.
Thanksgiving, 1942, finds American soldiers, sailors or Marines stationed at more than fifty foreign outposts.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Pupils of the Gorton High School in North Yonkers and the Yonkers High School, whose football teams meet tomorrow, joined forces tonight, girls as well as boys, in an unscheduled rally that resulted in considerable vandalism, according to the police.

BELLA FROMM, "Frau Bella," as she was called, ran a daily diplomatic column in the staid Berlin Vossische Zeitung during the earlier years of Nazism. She was Jewish, but she had connections who, for a time, managed to protect her. The Vossische -- or "Aunty Voss," as sophisticated Berliners called the paper -- was an Ullstein property, and it, too, was marked for destruction or "Aryanization."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Cynthia McKee, 20-year-old daughter of Mark T. McKee, aviation executive, surrendered her 2-year-old half-brother in Superior Court today and said she fled with the child because she feared her father.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A demand that the War Production Board "get tough" with the Canadian Government and insist on the lifting of its embargo against the movement of American-owned timber into this country to meet vital war needs was made today by Senator Wallgren at a hearing of the Senate (Truman) committee investigating the national defense program.

Evidence of resistance to the weakening trend appeared yesterday in the stock market, but pre-holiday influences prevented anything more than a moderately firmer closing. Some brokers felt that the action of the list indicated a let-up in the reactionary or corrective phase through which stocks are regarded as having been passing recently, but others clung to the opinion that a new base must be formed.

On several occasions recently we have pointed out how thoroughly the German High Command has deceived the German people about the war in the Eastern Mediterranean. To this day there has been nothing in the German communiques to indicate that Rommel's army met with a great defeat in Egypt.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Rosemary Lane will return to the screen after an absence of nearly two years to play the feminine lead in Republic's "Chatterbox" with Judy Canova and Joe E. Brown, the studio announced today.

Bert Briggs, described by the police as "payoff man" for Frank Erickson, gambler, was cleared of a disorderly prison charge in West Side Court yesterday by Magistrate Raphael Koenig, who put over until Friday the hearing on the bookmaking charge against him.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- While important but small-scale battles were being fought in the mountain passes of Tunisia today, the real prelude to the battle for the vital naval base of Bizerte was being fought in the air. The mystery of what has happened to the German air force was being solved objectively by what was happening over Tunisia and on land before Stalingrad.

WITH THE UNITED STATES AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Nov. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- American bombers, accompanied by the largest fighter escorts yet seen in the China theatre, subjected two of Japan's main air bases in South China to punishing attacks today without drawing opposition from a single enemy plane.

After presenting letters and statements of Helmut Leiner to illustrate the German gardener's "state of mind and motive" for his alleged aid to two of the eight submarine-borne Nazi saboteurs, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa yesterday closed his case against the man.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 -- The General Motors Corporation delivered $248,405,560 worth of war materials to the government in October, surpassing any previous month in its war production program or in the company's history, C.E. Wilson, president, announced today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The local gentry backing racing's comeback at the Fair Grounds hope there's a good omen in the fact so many horses were entered for the opening-day Thanksgiving handicap tomorrow that the race was split into two divisions.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Nov. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Refusing to rest on their laurels during the past ten days, during which a Japanese naval task force was wiped out and a huge landing party eliminated, United States land forces today began a temporarily delayed advance toward Kokumbona village and the mouth of the Poha River, on the western front.

The nation's fraternities have been hit hard by the war, Dr. G. Herbert Smith, president of Willamette University, reported yesterday to the annual meeting of the College Fraternity Secretaries Association of the National Inter-fraternity Conference at the Hotel Commodore.

Screeno and bingo, motion picture theatre games of chance that became a definite part of the community scheme in New York City during the depression about nine years ago, passed from the contemporary scene last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The War Labor Board delegated today to the Secretary of War the power to rule upon all wage and salary adjustments of more than 1,000,000 civilian employes in the United States and Alaska employed by the War Department, the Army Exchange Services and government-owned, privately-operated facilities of the War Department.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Attorneys for the Alton Railroad Company filed today a petition for reorganization under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act in Federal District Court here.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 -- A new system of occupational deferment in war industry, known as manning tables, was set up here today to provide a timetable for replacing this area's 650,000 war workers as selective service boards mustered them into the Army.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Lieutenant William N. Wilson, accused of manslaughter in the death of twelve persons after a collision between his Army bomber and a commercial airliner, was acquitted today by a court-martial.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- British women, scorning a proffered compromise, demanded a showdown from their government today. On the issue of whether women risking their necks equally with men in total war and paying equal income taxes should accept less than men who might conceivably be sitting in shelters, they were defeated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Governor Lehman of New York arranged conferences at the White House and the State Department today to take up his duties here next week as Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation. He plans to resign as Governor on or about Dec. 3.

Turkey, though at present following a neutral course, is "all set to come over to the Allies," in the opinion of Bayard Tuckerman Jr., sectional leader of the American Field Service, who returned yesterday from Egypt.

The traditional American Thanksgiving is a family affair in a rural setting. It calls for the gathering together of at least three generations, with a suitable number of appurtenant uncles, aunts and cousins, preferably on a farm which has no mortgage, is being profitably cultivated and raises most of the bill of fare.

The imposition by executive order of a $25,000 net ceiling on earned income, after Congress, through its appropriate committees, had refused to write into the tax bill such a limitation upon all incomes appears less and less justifiable the more it is examined. Congress has every right to disapprove of this action and to take steps to rescind it.

New York's hospitality will go out today to thousands of the country's blue and khaki-clad fighters. Not since 1917 have so many been invited to be guests for Thanksgiving dinner. While religious services and other traditional celebrations also will mark the day, the forces in uniform, not forgetting the Waacs and Waves, will be the center of attention.

Antique furniture, decorations, and other lots were sold at auction yesterday afternoon at the Park Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $15,138.50. The three-session auction, which will be continued tomorrow afternoon, includes property of the late Mrs. Henrietta J. Simonds, the late Mrs. Robert W. de Forest, and of Mrs. Carl J. Schmidlapp, and others.

With most of the ration coupons for the city's 500,000 fuel oil and kerosene users either in the mail or already delivered, Ralph C. Baker, district rationing officer of the Office of Price Administration, cautioned householders yesterday to use their supply as sparingly as possible "since the fuel oil shortage is becoming increasingly critical."

Mrs. John J. Moore of 51-10 Thirtieth Avenue, Woodside, Queens, was the winner of a prize offered by the La Guardia Field restaurant for the most practical suggestion to eliminate the 150 pounds of sugar previously used in the icing of a birthday cake designed for the airport's third anniversary, on Dec. 2, Edward C. Sherry, manager of the airport restaurants, announced yesterday.

ROSELAND, N.J., Nov. 25 -Lester W. Stickel, chairman, and seven others of the eleven members of the Roseland Defense Council resigned today in protest against the action of Police Recorder Charles Conaway in exonerating Herbert S. Waters, chairman of the Newark Defense Council, on charges of violating State blackout regulations when he drove through Roseland during the air raid test on Oct. 2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The wages of several million women workers may be increased as a result of a general order issued today by the War Labor Board, allowing employers to make wage or salary adjustments to equalize the wages of women with those of men for comparable quality and quantity of work without prior board approval.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 -- Edward Gay Rohrbough, 31-year-old American-born newspaper correspondent, pleaded guilty and was placed on suspended sentence for two years today in Barrie Court for having violated the censorship regulations.

Mayor La Guardia again criticized yesterday those South American countries that are trying to continue friendly relations with both the Axis and the United Nations. He told a group of Mexican and Bolivian newspaper men who visited him at City Hall that such countries "can't flirt with Hitler and still be in the family with the republics of the Western Hemisphere."

The imposition by executive order of a $25,000 net ceiling on earned income, after Congress, through its appropriate committees, had refused to write into the tax bill such a limitation upon all incomes appears less and less justifiable the more it is examined. Congress has every right to disapprove of this action and to take steps to rescind it.

Sherry, manager of the airport restaurants, announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia again criticized yesterday those South American countries that are trying to continue friendly relations with both the Axis and the United Nations. He told a group of Mexican and Bolivian newspaper men who visited him at City Hall that such countries "can't flirt with Hitler and still be in the family with the republics of the Western Hemisphere."

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26 -- It looked like old times today when a throng estimated at 12,000, which bet $672,507 on the nine races, saw Mrs. Barclay K. Douglas's Chop Chop win the Endurance Handicap and a purse of $6,475.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- A reliable forecast of the "Beveridge report," a historic 100,000-word document compiled by Sir William Beveridge, noted economist, and his committee, which will affect the entire lives of the 45,000,000 British people, indicates that it is the most important social document produced in Britain in very many years.

There was a passage in a recent message from Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to the American people which should be marked. It was directed at certain groups in this country and evoked by fears that have been expressed here, though in whisperings rather than outright statements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Senator Nye said today that he and Senator Johnson of California would recommend to the Senate that United States real estate and utility holdings in Panama be transferred to that country by treaty instead of resolution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The controversy over detailed direction of armament manufacture between the War Production Board and the armed services will probably be settled by agreement on a practical modus operandi. Failure to settle the argument would merely add to the dislocations and impediments of the war program, and, since this is too serious to endure, both parties to the dispute will be willing to make concessions.

BENGAZI, Libya, Nov. 22 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Emaciated British and South African officers and men who had been prisoners of the Axis until the enemy abandoned Bengazi charged today that they had suffered brutal treatment at the hands of the Italians, and asserted that some captives had been shot merely for making the V-for-victory sign.

A racket used by some grocers to sell inferior grades of coffee at an advanced price was exposed yesterday by George C. Thierbach, president of the National Coffee Association, who warned housewives against buying coffee in unmarked paper bags.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- White Plains turned back Watertown High School, 20 to 6, today at Parker Stadium before 7,000 fans for its sixth victory in eight games.

Arthur Hocking, who works for a Syracuse firm manufacturing refrigeration equipment for war use, wrote a letter to his fellow-employes after his only son was killed in action. The letter has appeared as an advertisement in this newspaper, and it could profitably be read by all war workers and by all Americans.

Bizet's "Carmen" was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House as the third offering of the season. The ever-popular work was conducted by Sir Thomas Beecham, whose leadership throughout the evening was of such a superior nature that he easily reaped first honors in the performance.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 26 (AP) -- American Skydragons went to the support of Chinese ground forces battling to keep Japanese troops on Northern Hunan Province from crossing the Sintsiang River in what might be the prelude to a fourth battle for Changsha, Chinese dispatches reported today.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 26 -- Missouri's big gold-clad football team won its second straight Big Six Conference football championship today by riding roughshod over Ray Evans and his Kansas teammates, 42 to 13.

Heavy Soviet tank and infantry attacks are continuing in the big bend of the Don River, while in the central sector west of Moscow the Russians have started a new attack on a broad front, the German High Command said yesterday, according to broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY, at Casablanca, French Morocco, Nov. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- French pilots in Morocco are being armed with fast new American fighter planes, it was revealed today by a high American officer, who said that he expected them to be "a great help to our side in the coming campaign."

Although more than 10,000 Christmas packages have been sent to service men overseas by the American Women's Voluntary Services of Greater New York, thousands of packages can still be used, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Zachary Goldston, chairman of the organization's victory pastime division, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Despite the transition toward war economy, consumers will be able to buy most goods they want this Christmas, and the dollar volume of Christmas trade, spread over the entire fourth quarter of the year, will be the highest on record, the Department of Commerce estimated today.
Prayers for the nation's victory and for a just and righteous peace were offered throughout the city yesterday at Thanksgiving services in cathedrals and churches of all faiths and in synagogues.

Dr. Joseph Nisonoff of 110 Riverside Drive was held in $150,000 bail for a hearing tomorrow, when he appeared yesterday before Magistrate Raphael Murphy in Bronx Magistrate's Court, charged with homicide in connection with the death of a woman government employe after an illegal operation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Confronted with the problem of supplying labor sufficient to plant, tend, harvest and process the enormous food crops which the country will need next year, the War Manpower Commission will hold a special meeting here Saturday to discuss the farm labor situation, it was learned tonight.

Several dinner parties will be given tonight in advance of the performance of "The Pirate," a comedy with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, which has been taken over by members of the Women's Auxiliary of Union Settlement to raise funds for that organization.
LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Bucknell won its fifth consecutive game today, swamping Franklin and Marshall, 27 to 0, to climax one of its best football seasons in years.

Count Franco Mazzotti, noted Italian flier, who was second pilot in an attempted flight from Rome to Buenos Aires, Argentina, in 1934, has not returned from a flight "against the enemy in the Mediterranean," according to a broadcast by the German Trans-ocean news agency yesterday recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Permission to increase their prices to the extent that their costs have risen as a result of the purchase of newly-mined domestic silver was granted to sellers of rolled gold or gold-filled stock in the form of sheet, wire and tubing, by the Office of Price Administration today.
Edward H. Wilson, lawyer, died yesterday in the Peck Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of six months at the age of 68. He lived at 21 Van Buren Street, Brooklyn.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- Field Marshal Jan Christian Smuts, Premier of South Africa, expressed utmost confidence today in an Allied victory in North Africa, but warned that "hard fighting is ahead; we still must win."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- President Roosevelt, the heads of the armed forces and about 250 governmental leaders and old friends celebrated Thanksgiving today with an unprecedented thirty-minute White House service of song and prayer which was broadcast.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Virginia Tech put an impressive climax to its best football season in a decade by conquering Virginia Military Institute today, 20 to 6, before a crowd of 22,500, the largest ever to see a football game in this State.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings came from behind with two third-period goals tonight to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 1, before 13,912 spectators, largest crowd ever to see a National Hockey League game here. Connie Brown fired the winning goal with less than five minutes to play.
LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- And now, at long last, Mr. Bazaj is back in India.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- With conversion of household and other heating boilers developed by fuel shortages into a major industry, the Office of Price Administration announced today it had revised its regulations to permit increases in prices of conversion parts sold to the consumer, which will raise the cost per household by approximately 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Treasury Department officials disclosed today that one-cent pieces would be minted of steel coated with zinc so as to free copper for war industries as soon as Congress passed legislation permittting the use of substitute materials for small coins.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits for the week ended yesterday decreased $1,444,000 to $26,006,000, chartered banks deposits decreased $4,967,000 to $265,703,000 and notes in circulation increased $126,000 to $665,377,000, the Bank of Canada reported today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The Chicago Black Hawks were defeated for the first time in their last five games tonight as the last-place New York Rangers, greatly fortified by a goalie playing his first National Hockey League contest, made two first-period scores stick for a 2 -- 1 victory before a crowd of 11,354 at the Stadium.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 26 -- Louisiana State scored two late touchdowns to win its traditional football argument with Tulane today, 18 -- 6, in a game capped by numerous fist fights among some of the 35,000 spectators.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Senator Carter Glass, one of the first to assert that we should "lick hell out of Hitler," today said the response to the Victory Loan drive will determine whether America is behind the fighting men who have gone overseas.

Japanese newspapers devoted their entire front pages yesterday to a report to the empire by Saburo Kurusu, special envoy to Washington, and banner lines said that Kurusu put the full responsibility for the war in the Pacific on the United States, The Associated Press reported from Tokyo broadcasts recorded in this country.
MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A special communique:

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Industrial stocks held the spotlight today on the Stock Exchange. The holiday in the United States evidently reduced the buying demand for some of the inter-listed issues and turnover was down to 161,000 shares compared with 292,000 in the previous session.

The eight-family four-story apartment house at 552 Dean Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Dime Savings Bank to a client for investment, through the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company. The building is on a plot, 40 by 100 feet, and is assessed for $21,500. The house is fully rented.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Increased employment occasioned by war work was seen today as largely responsible for a 20 per cent jump in industrial accidents in New York in the first six months of 1942, compared with the same period last year.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Pennsylvania reverted today to its invincible form of October and brought a season of inexplicable frustration to an end with its most crushing defeat of Cornell since 1928.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Aside from members of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps who are on duty at the two Waac training centers, Fort Des Moines, Iowa, and Daytona Beach, Fla., most Waacs are doing aircraft warning service, the War Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- In an apparent effort to restore harmony among Senate Democrats, Senator Barkley, majority leader, called a meeting today of the steering committee for tomorrow to map the legislative Program for the rest of this session.

Twelve Americans, including one from Hamden, Conn., and another from Scarswood, N.Y., are among "several thousand" Royal Air Force fliers held at Stalag Luft 3, a prison camp somewhere in Germany that is visited regularly by neutral representatives of the War Prisoners Aid of the Y.M.C.A., with headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland.

Revision of the State income tax system along the lines he proposed during the recent campaign will be among the first matters Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey will discuss with legislative and party leaders at a series of conferences beginning next week, friends of Mr. Dewey said yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Friday, Nov. 27 -- Japan's defenders of their Buna beach head in Northeast New Guinea have received reinforcements despite the naval losses they suffered in such an undertaking and presently are holding against the attacking Americans and Australians, the High Command said today.

A young mother and her baby, tightly clasped in her arms, were found asleep on the stairs in the hallway at 82 West Ninetieth Street at 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning by Patrolman Jacob Rothman of the West 100th Street station.

THE chatter of football followers on the Army-Navy game and service rivalry brings up an added point this year. It has to do with service rivalry on a wider scale. The young fellows in uniform are stirred up about it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Representative Charles A. Wolverton of New Jersey strongly opposes the proposed changes in the proxy rules of the Security and Exchange Commission and has introduced a bill to suspend the commission's authority to issue new rules and regulations for the duration of the war and six months after.

Earl Welsh sent his Fordham football charges through a single workout yesterday morning, after which the squad was excused until this afternoon, when the finishing touches will be put on the preparations for tomorrow's final game with the North Carolina Pre-Flight eleven in the Yankee Stadium.

Make thrifty use of the turkey that is left over, and you help to compensate for the stiffish price you paid for the holiday bird. A spicy-sweet sauce, for example, when served piping hot, is an excellent companion to the cold sliced meat.

Manpower is one of the most widely discussed issues before the nation today -- and certainly it is the most important. Unless we can adequately transport, feed and equip our fighting men we cannot win this war. And in the effort to do this there are obvious and most critical shortcomings.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Quick-thinking St. Louis University backs, working behind a hard-charging line, ran up a 26-to-0 victory over Washington of Missouri in their annual Thanksgiving football game today. A crowd of 13,192 fans saw the game.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Shadows draped Memorial Stadium today as the University of Texas eleven started a surge that went sixty-six yards for a touchdown to give the Longhorns a 12-6 victory over Texas A. and M. and their first Southwest Conference championship in a dozen years.

Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, told "America's Town Meeting of the Air" last night that the nation's schools and colleges while training young men to meet manpower needs and to win this war of survival still could "continue the long-term task of general education."
CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 26 -- The Constitutional Convention today debated an amendment by Premier R. Cosgrove of Tasmania to the motion of A.W. Fadden, leader of the Opposition.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- This morning, for the first time in the history of Westminster Abbey, going back more than 1,200 years, men of a foreign army took possession of that sacred ground. It was a congregation of Americans numbered in the thousands, filling the ancient church for service of a thanksgiving.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Duquesne powered over two touchdowns today to haul down the Lakehurst Naval Air Station Blimps, 13 to 0, before a crowd of 8,000. The game finished the Dukes' season and gave them a record of six victories, one tie and three defeats.

The Freed-Eisemann Radio Company has leased from the Trinity Operating Company 25,000 square feet of space in 200 Hudson Street. The broker was Joseph M. Koehler. This lease will enable the company to quadruple its production and hasten its deliveries to the armed forces, according to Arthur Freed, vice president.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 26 -- Shipments of Canadian lumber to the United States this year will approach 1,300,000,000 board feet, or more than double the corresponding exports to that country in any year from 1932 to 1940 inclusive, Alan Williamson, timber controller, said today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 26 -- A Berlin military spokesman has found a new explanation for the present Mediterranean situation, according to the Stockholm Nazi newspaper Tagsposten.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Nov. 24 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The American thrust against Buna along the northeast New Guinea coast, where the Allies had hoped for a quick and easy victory, has turned into a serious campaign against a stubborn and skilled Japanese defense.

The American Bankers Association announced yesterday that it had issued a communication to its entire membership of 14,000 banks throughout the country urging them to do their utmost in the Treasury's campaign to sell $9,000,000,000 of government securities.

For scores of thousands of workers in shipyards and war plants in this city and vicinity Thanksgiving Day was just another Thursday, devoted to the task of producing the ships and sinews of war needed by the armed forces of this nation and its allies.

Former Governor John M. Slaton of Georgia and Mrs. Slaton were guests of honor at a Thanksgiving dinner given last night by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Bonham of Hampshire House at the hotel. Others in the party were Mr. and Mrs. Burton Holmes, Mrs. Thomas T. Gaunt, Mr. and Mrs. Wallis Mann, Mrs. Charles Cushman, Mrs. Charlotte Stancliff, Harvey Clinkscales, John S. Van Gilder and Wallis Mann Jr.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 26 -- The Freeport High Red Devils defeated Baldwin, 6 -- 0, at the Municipal Stadium today to finish the season undefeated in eight games and gain Nassau County's mythical scholastic football crown.

John M. Kennedy, 14-year-old son of Representative Martin J. Kennedy, who left his home at 1349 Lexington Avenue at 3 P.M. Monday after leaving a note saying that he was going to enlist in "the Canadian armed forces," walked into his home at 12:30 yesterday none the worse for his trip to Canada.
Your editorials on the forty-hour week and particularly the letter of Mrs. Helen S.K. Willcox in your issue of Nov. 23, in my opinion, neglect some important matters:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 26 -- Anti-Jewish persecutions in German-occupied Norway reached a peak today when more than 1,000 persons, including women and children and elderly and sick persons, were packed aboard a 9,000-ton German freighter and sent from Oslo, bound for an undisclosed German port, whence, it is reported, they will be sent to Poland and German-occupied areas in Russia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Navy Department announced tonight its casualty list No. 17, covering the period Nov. 1 to 15, inclusive. The following men whose next of kin were listed as living in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were included:

Delivering a second-quarter touchdown blow from which the losers never recovered, and adding another six-pointer in the third quarter, a determined St. John's Prep football team upset its old foe, Brooklyn Prep, 12 to 0, before 6,000 spectators, in the twenty-fifth clash between the schools at Brooklyn College Field yesterday morning.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Flashing speed and power in the second half, William and Mary clinched the Southern Conference and Virginia Big Six college championships today by beating the University of Richmond, 10 -- 0, before a crowd of 8,000.

An appeal for men and women over 16 years old to serve as radio-telephone operators at fixed and mobile stations throughout the city was issued yesterday by Vincent T. Kenney, director of the War Emergency Radio Service, which is the city's latest Civilian Defense organization.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Nov. 26 -- The University of Notre Dame has kept faith with America because it has kept faith with God, the Right Rev. Mgr. Fulton Sheen said today in a sermon on the occasion of the observance of the 100th anniversary of the arrival of the founder of Notre Dame, the Rev. Edward F. Sorin of the Congregation of the Holy Cross.

An excerpt from a release of the Michigan Conservation Department has been forwarded, due to the interest displayed here in the hunting of deer by archers. Should the Westchester bowmen become downhearted, it will probably be because the fields look greener in Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Married men represented 54 per cent of the white males in the group 20 to 34 years of age in 1940, the Census Bureau said today. This is the age group from which most members of the armed forces are drawn at present.

The five-story building containing twenty-three room units at 14 Morton Street has been sold by Ida C. Lilienthal after an ownership of thirty-five years to the Warney Realty Corporation, R. Rongs, president. The building is on a plot 25 by 95 feet and is assessed for $24,000.

To coordinate the wartime research activities of engineering college laboratories and personnel, seventy-three engineering colleges have formed the Engineering College Research Association, it was announced yesterday.

As Chairman of the War Production Board, Mr. Nelson has carried direct to the President his conflict with the Army and Navy on the question of final authority to direct war production scheduling. In a struggle on the question whether civil or military forces shall control the country's economy there ought to be no question concerning the President's decision.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The forthcoming report of Sir William Beveridge embodying proposals that will be published next Wednesday appeared tonight to have virtually no chance of being adopted as a whole as soon as it is presented to Parliament.
READING, Pa., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Muhlenberg overcame its Albright "jinx" today to beat the Lions for the first time in years, 20 to 0, before a crowd of 5,000.

" Mashenka," the Soviet picture at the Stanley Theatre, will enter its second week today. . . . The Majestic Theatre in Brooklyn, which today starts a week's engagement of "Prisoner of Japan," will donate the entire proceeds of tonight's performances to the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross. . . .

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Southern Pacific Railroad in a letter to the Interstate Commerce Commission today held that the 4 1/2 per cent rate of interest it intends fixing on an issue of $23,215,000 of Texas New Orleans Railroad first and refunding Series A bonds to be sold to the parent company is "fair and reasonable."
LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Fourteen British Commandos made a daring raid on the Norwegian coast, wrecked the power station and blew up the dam at Giomfjord last month, advices from Stockholm said today.

The Bank of Montreal reported yesterday that profits for the year ended on Oct. 31, after taxes, amounted to $3,283,018, compared with $3,437,025 in the previous year. Total resources, as of Oct. 31, were $1,175,319,231, a new high record, and an increase of $128,767,752 in the year.

The Gaglio family down on East Twenty-ninth Street had its usual fare yesterday, but come Sunday there'll be a fourteen-pound turkey on the dinner table. Thanks to Brother Eddie, aged 13, an indeterminate number of Gaglio boys, girls and in-laws will celebrate a delayed Thanksgiving.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- From the far Southwest Pacific to the shores of Tripoli, or thereabouts, American Marines face a change in their musical habits. They have to learn a new fourth line to the first verse of their famous hymn.

Sailors are keeping up the romantic tradition for which they are famous, to judge by the latest figures on the increased sale of gardenias compiled by the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES. Somewhere in New Guinea, Nov. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- Fanatical Japanese resistance and "beautifully placed defense positions" are confronting American troops in their drive to uproot the Japanese from the rain-soaked jungle defenses guarding the approaches to Buns, but the Americans are determined they will drive out the Japanese in the end.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 26 -- For the eleventh year in a row the red-shirted football players of Colgate have ruined Thanksgiving Day for Brown.
LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 26 -- The great majority of workers in war industries are willing to work at least 48 hours a week at their jobs, but most of them want overtime pay for anything over 40 hours.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- So whole-heartedly was Thanksgiving celebrated in Great Britain by Americans and their hosts that all caught the holiday spirit, despite wartime restrictions.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 26 -- Only "orthodox" news must be given to the French people, which means in present circumstances news approved by the occupying authority. The latest ban is on Swiss broadcasts, which had remained the most objective in Europe.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Daily Mail in a Madrid dispatch today said Marshal Petain had made a last-minute attempt to save the honor of the French Army on the eve of the German occupation of Vichy France but had been foiled by Chief of Government Pierre Laval and Berlin authorities, who got wind of his plans.

MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 27 -- The net that is being relentlessly drawn around the Axis army at Stalingrad was tightened again yesterday, and as it contracts an increasing number of enemy troops are in danger of being swept up in it.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- This cradle of American freedom celebrated Thanksgiving today with the sounding of the code signal for victory on the Liberty Bell.

Ten young speakers, representatives of as many United Nations, spoke on the war work and war aims of the youth of their countries at the "Voice of United Nations Youth" rally last night, which closed the first day's session of the nineteenth annual convention of Junior Hadassah, Young Women's Zionist Organization of America, at the Hotel Plaza.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Great Lakes Naval Training Station football team rolled up its biggest score of the season to wallop Northwestern today, 48 to 0, for its sixth straight shutout victory.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -- This story is being written under the influence of about half a pound of turkey, not to mention a large slice of pumpkin pie two inches thick. On this basis even India is looking good on Thanksgiving Day to thousands of American soldiers who, throughout the country in many camps, are trying to forget that they are 12,000 miles away from home.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 26 -- Former French Premier Paul Reynaud and Georges Mandel, former Colonial Minister, held in custody pending action on their "war guilt," have been seized by the Germans, according to a Vichy report tonight, and "there is reason to believe" that they have been transported to Germany where, like General Maxine Weygand, they are being held as hostages.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Racing opened at the Fair Grounds today with 8,000 fans out to see an eight-race card which included a split Thanksgiving Handicap.

" THE nation is at war. There isn't time for ceremony and parade. This isn't a war of flags and marching. It is a war of finding the target in the cross-hairs of the bombsight and setting the release, and it isn't a war of speeches and frothy hatred. It is a technical job, a surgeon's job. There is only time for hatred among civilians.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -- Charles Laughton's next film at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will be "The Man From Down Under," a screen story by Mark Kelly and Bogart Rogers, which the studio purchased as a vehicle for Wallace Beery in May.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 26 -- A monument to Dr. James Emman Kwegyir Aggrey, West African Negro educator, who died in New York City in 1927, was dedicated today at Livingstone College, Salisbury, N.C., from which Dr. Aggrey was graduated forty years ago and where he taught for twenty years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The new Congress will be required to decide whether President Roosevelt's $25,000 maximum net salary order ought to be ratified or set aside by legislation, Senator George, chairman of the Finance Committee, predicted today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 26 -- Former Foreign Minister Juan Bautista Rossetti disclosed today that he had signed with United States Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles at Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, last January a pact whereby the United States undertook to give military aid to Chile if the latter should be attacked by a non-American power.

Commerce and DeWitt Clinton closed their football seasons yesterday by battling to a 6-all tie at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. The contest, finale of a scholastic double-header which attracted a crowd of 15,000, was the thirty-ninth between the old foes. Clinton holds a 24-12 lead in the series, with three games tied.

MADRID, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Executing for the first time Generalissimo Francisco Franco's partial mobilization order, the captains-general of all Spanish military regions today ordered members of the 1938, '39, '40 and '41 classes to report for duty by Sunday

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 26 -- Anxiety over the effects that North African events and those on the Russian front may have on the attitude of Turkey and Spain becomes increasingly apparent in Germany where the press multiplies its warnings to both countries against Anglo-American "intrigues."

LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today showed an increase in note circulation of 4,798,000 to 870,033,000, a new record. This was the tenth consecutive weekly increase, bringing the outstanding notes within 10,000,000 of the authorized fiduciary total of 880,000,000.

First honors on two counts went to Arthur Hall, 42-year-old member of the Staten Island Harriers, in the thirty-second annual handicap walk to Coney Island staged by the Walkers Club of America yesterday over a partially new course.
The United Hospital Campaign announced yesterday that thus far it had raised $1,042,941. Its goal is $1,383,729. A gift of $10,000 from Mrs. Edward S. Harkness was announced yesterday.

The shades of the Pilgrims must have mingled yesterday with the mighty ghosts of Westminster Abbey. When the first settlers landed on the rocks of Plymouth to found another England, the Abbey was already gray and venerable, older than anything in the New World.

Dairy farmers in the New York milk shed will receive a fraction more than 7 cents a quart for all their milk delivered in November, Charles J. Blanford, administrator of the New York metropolitan milk marketing area estimated yesterday.

Bank clearings for the twenty-three leading cities of the United States for the week ended on Wednesday were $7,205,364,000, a gain of 12.9 per cent above the $6,380,647,000 in the similar week last year that contained only five business days in many States.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Tulsa unwrapped a spectacular passing combination -- N.A. Keithley to Saxon Judd -- to rout Arkansas, 40 -- 7, today and climax a perfect year before a season's record crowd of 18,000.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 26 -- Services at noon today marked Thanksgiving Day for the American colony, the members of which listened to an address by the American Ambassador, Jefferson Caffery.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.Y., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Lloyd Blethen of Foxcroft Academy, Dover, Me., won the national interscholastic cross-country championship today by outdistancing the largest field in the seventeen-year history of the event.

LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The stock market displayed a firm undertone today although trading was quiet. Home rails were well supported and tobacco shares were active, British American Tobacco selling at 98s, off 9d.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 26 -- East Orange High and Barringer High came to grips today on the gridiron in their forty-sixth annual battle and the result was the same as in the two previous years -- a tie, 7 to 7. A capacity crowd of 13,000 saw the game.

From E.P. O'Donnell's novel, the writing Hacketts -- Albert and Frances Goodrich -- have fashioned an engaging comedy called "The Great Big Doorstep," which Herman Shumlin put on to much laughter last evening at the Morosco.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Navy today reported that its casualties, as reported to next of kin during the first fifteen days of November, were 747, including 304 dead, 252 wounded and 191 missing. It was at the end of this period that the Navy smashed the Japanese fleet in the Solomons, killing Japanese sailors and soldiers estimated to number more than 25,000.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Although most of the news from Africa today concerned air activity, in which the Allies were obviously more than holding their own, there was one important land engagement reported in an Allied High Command communique broadcast by the Morocco radio.

The destruction by the Nazis of great seats of Jewish learning in Europe transfers, to American Jews the responsibility "for the strengthening of our spiritual values and resources and for nurturing Israel's steadfast devotion to books,"

Norman Corwin, radio writer and director, has leased a furnished suite in 36 Central Park South through R. Fabricant, broker. Douglas L. Elliman Co. rented an apartment of eight rooms and four baths in 290 Park Avenue to Eurico Penteado, United States representative of the National Coffee Department of Brazil.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 26 -- Following indications by government officials of additional restrictions in the production of nonessential consumer goods in 1943, wholesale orders for furniture expanded still further in October, rising 7 per cent over the September level and 15 per cent above the corresponding 1941 figure, according to a report by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 26 (AP) -- A broomstick always has been one of the emblems of the housewife, but few, if any, women ever received cash for sawing one in two.

CAIRO, Egypt. Nov. 26 -- "German efficiency" was questioned in no uncertain terms today by Air Vice Marshal Sir Arthur Coningham, commander of the air arm in the western desert, who called this a myth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- President Roosevelt served notice tonight that, Congressional upheavals and sectional objections notwithstanding, the government must and would begin the nationwide rationing of gasoline to conserve rubber on Dec. 1, as scheduled.

A deficit of three touchdowns was the predicament the Brooklyn College football team was in at the end of the first half of its game with City College at the former's field yesterday. A deficit of one point confronted the City College eleven when the battle was over and nothing further could be done.

Political "manoeuvres" by followers of Archduke Otto, pretender to the throne of the Austro-Hungarian empire, whose cooperation has been accepted by the War Department, were protested by official Yugoslav quarters, a Polish labor leader and Count Carlo Sforza, free Italian leader, according to a release yesterday from the Overseas News Agency.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- General Charles de Gaulle, leader of Fighting France, will very shortly make "a strong personal appeal" to President Roosevelt to change the status of Admiral Francois Darlan as French High Commissioner in North Africa, it was said in certain circles in London today.

Twenty-five of the twenty-eight shows on Broadway gave holiday matinees yesterday, and while business was regarded as generally favorable, no records were broken. Standees were observed at five, with "The Skin of Our Teeth" topping them all with thirty-two.

,-N'EV'ARK. N. J., Nov. 26 2P)-A clarge was made and denied today that there was racial discrimination against Negroes in the War Department's Office of Dependency which recently moved here from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- President Roosevelt s stand on nationwide gasoline rationing in effect repeated pleas of members of Congress from oil-producing and other Western States outside the existing rationed area of the East that extension of rationing be delayed from 90 days to six months pending a trial of voluntary tire-saving schemes.
MOSCOW, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Conductors are not only vying with each other in their haste to play the latest music of Dimitri Shostakovich, but they are even competing with one another as to who recognized his talent earlier. Artur Rodzinski, current guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, is one of those who directed Shostakovich's music before it became fashionable, and he is doing it brown during this New York visit.

A new agreement under which the Mexican Government will resume service on its external debt "on a modified and reduced" basis has been reached here by Eduardo Suarez, Mexican Finance Minister, and the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, it was announced yesterday by Thomas W. Lamont of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., who is chairman of the bankers' committee.

In the early mail, day before yesterday, came a letter soliciting one's interest in behalf of a good public cause. It began by saying that recent events in Africa have shown once more that military victories must be preceded by political victories, and the march of the armies must be prepared by an advance guard of ideas, etc., etc.

The Russian counter-attack that began five days ago at Stalingrad has now developed into a great battle that flames into fierce action at points a thousand miles apart.
