There is heavy fighting far to the south, on the Kalmuck steppes. West of Stalingrad itself three main Russian columns are on the move.

MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Russian armies sweeping across the Don River elbow west of Stalin-grad and attacking frontally inside that ruined city occupied a dozen places, including more railway points, yesterday and knocked out an additional 16,000 Germans, the Red Army announced today.
By the rules for bestowal of the Medal of Honor, the President is authorized to present it in the name of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Farm conservation benefit payments in 1943 may be reduced $100,000,000 below the $500,000,000 authorized by Federal crop-control legislation and $50,000,000 below the amount Congress appropriated for the current crop year.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) -- From a record volume of sales a net profit of $7,123,579 was realized by Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and wholly-owned subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, it was announced today.

Former President Herbert Hoover endorses meat rationing in a signed article in today's issue of Collier's in which he declares that the United States will not be able to produce enough food to prevent famine after the war. Mr. Hoover suggests that with Allied financial aid the production of fats should be stimulated in South America where there is plenty of feed and labor.
As your editorial aptly states concerning "La Marseillaise," "the century and a half that has passed has not changed the tune. It still sets men's hearts aflame. The words mean what they used to."

LONDON Nov. 26 (AP) -- British airmen on offensive patrols over the Netherlands and France shot up enemy shipping and freight trains and brought down four enemy planes, the Air Ministry announced tonight.

Even Mrs. Roosevelt hedged on the President's suggestion that old coffee grounds be dried and re-brewed. He "thinks" he is a coffee expert, she said. True, a hot, brown brew can be made as the President suggests. Such a concoction can also be made from chicory, dandelion root, sweet potatoes or rye.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- A new model of the electron microscope, much less expensive than the present model, which makes it available for the first time to hundreds of hospitals, small laboratories and many university and industrial research institutions, has been developed by the R.C.A. laboratories, Dr. Vladimir K. Zworykin, associate director of the laboratories, stated tonight.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 26 -- An old-fashioned snow, roast turkey and the rare army privilege of sleeping late, made Thanksgiving a gala holiday for 7,600 Waacs at Fort Des Moines Army Post.

Not a single man in the uniform of the armed forces of this country or any of the United Nations was denied a feast here yesterday, unless he chose to forego the bounty of New York. Nor were the poor, the sick or even the criminal neglected.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- A wartime development in concentrates, a condensed form of human blood plasms, has been found to be highly effective in relieving the shock of battle wounds, says the Journal of the American Medical Association.

Formal protest against the establishment of extensive recording studios in this city by the overseas branch of the Office of War Information will be lodged today in Washington by a committee representing the Association of Recording Studios, Inc., of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Commodity markets were comparatively steady in the week ended on Nov. 21. There were some increases in quotations for cattle, sheep, live poultry, and certain fruits and vegetables, and reductions for cotton, peanuts, potatoes and most grains.

A letter from Archbishop Francis J. Spellman to be read Sunday by all pastors in the New York Catholic archdiocese will ask for a collection on Dec. 6 to support the Catholic University of America, which "provides intellectual and moral leadership of a caliber that is vitally needed in our national life."

While it has been believed that New York City lacks adequate day care for pre-school children whose mothers are working in war industry, actually one-third of the child day care units are operating under capacity, City Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday.

Nearly a thousand bingo fans, who staged a vociferous demonstration when the police closed down their bingo game late Wednesday night in the quarters of the William A. Leonard Post of the American Legion, 140-26 Franklin Avenue, Flushing, Queens, sat down yesterday to organize a campaign for the modification of local regulations and the State law to permit their play to continue.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 (AP) -- New York educators view as "bargain basement education" a proposal by the Educational Policies Commission to telescope the senior year of high school and the freshman year of college, Dr. Edwin H. Van Kleeck, assistant State education commissioner, asserted tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Major Thomas Hitchcock reported today that in the opinion of both American and British fliers the United States P-51 fighter, known to the British as the Mustang, will be the best fighter plane for 1943.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

In announcing yesterday that the 1943 Thomas Jefferson Southern Award Contest is now open, Dutton reveals that the 1942 contest drew a blank and that no award was made. The 1942 contest, which closed March 15, offered a $2,500 prize for the best book manuscript by a Southern author.

Copy touching directly or indirectly upon the war has lifted readership of advertising to new highs, if a recent analysis of The Syracuse Herald-Journal, made by the Advertising Research Foundation as No. 53 in its Continuing Study of Newspaper Reading, is an indication of a national trend.

The belief that the War Production Board might make a further cut in the use of cocoa to 50 per cent of last year's rate of consumption was expressed among cocoa manufacturers this week as reports indicated that housewives were finding it more difficult to obtain cocoa in stores.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A joint British General Headquarters and R.A.F. communique:

The 1942 city-wide appeal for funds of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities will be launched at a service at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, at 3:30 P.M. on Sunday.

The Allied advance into Tunisia, the British pursuit of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel and the Russian offensive against the Stalingrad salient were still driving hard yesterday, but their rate of advance, though relatively rapid, has been and probably still is impeded by mine fields.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- As a first step toward building a War Cabinet President Roosevelt is moving toward the creation of what may be the American parallel for the British Ministry of Labor and National Supply, headed by Ernest Bevin, it was reported today as light was shed on some aspects of his program.

Jimmy Bivins, the Cleveland battler who has established himself as a formidable heavyweight, will make his New York debut tonight when he tackles Lee Savold, St. Paul gladiator, in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- New regulations announced by Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt, Western Defense Commander, will end the sale of intoxicants to service men of the Far West at midnight every night and, for the first time since soon after Pearl Harbor, will provide uniform treatment in taverns to Army and Navy personnel.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Friday, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The noon communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 26 -- There was virtually no change on the Agheila front in Libya yesterday, but sporadic firing continued as General Field Marshal Erwin Romreel dug in his rear-guard screens a few miles northeast of the coastal bottleneck.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Four wild elk, captured in a round-up here yesterday, were shipped out on a truck to the Central Park Zoo in New York City.
An urgent call for 100 experienced women drivers to serve in the Motor Corps of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross was made yesterday by General Robert C. Davis, executive director.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Forty-five policemen were on hand today at the football field of Gorton High School and in the streets and street cars after the game was over to prevent a recurrence of the vandalism that broke out in the pre-game celebration last night.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- United States Army heavy bombers raided Japanese-held Thailand today for the first time, blasting an oil refinery at Bangkok in what was officially called a Thanksgiving Day celebration following new widespread Royal Air Force raids on enemy bases in Burma.

Miss Elsie M. Bond, chairman of the State War Council's Committee on Child Care, Development and Protection, would like to start two societies, one for "a moratorium on surveys," the other for "the promotion of action."

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 28 -- Five German divisions now more or less surrounded on the east bank of the Don are trying to break through southward across the Kalmuck Steppe, over which a fierce northeast wind is sweeping snow and sand into deadly storms, it was reported here early today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 -Stripped for action like a man-of-war, with most of the usual glitter and trappings thrown overboard, the Army-Navy football game will be played here tomorrow before a highly selective but not the usual select gathering numbering hardly more than a tenth its customary size.

The New York Public Library, at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue, will open with appropriate ceremony Tuesday an exhibit of some of the books now denied to readers who are under Nazi domination. The exhibition, to be on view in Room 112, will start with a brief presentation of official Nazi theories of censorship and continue with titles covering many fields of literature and the sciences.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Three extra trains a day from the North and Midwest into Florida have been authorized, the Office of Defense Transportation reported today. All passenger train schedules were "frozen" Sept. 26. Two of the three trains operate out of New York, with the other one out of Chicago.
The suspicion that another Sam Langford loomed on the pugilistic horizon was proved last night in Madison Square Garden to be a gross exaggeration.

Those critics who regard racing as one of the greatest evils tempting the average citizen to gamble away his hard-earned dollars and accordingly applaud all efforts to damage the sport might well pause and reflect upon its great value as a tax producer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Secretary Stimson said today that his letter to the Archduke Otto, pretender to the Austro-Hungarian throne, accepting the Archduke's offer to help recruit an Austrian battalion for the American Army, was sent with the approval of the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The war is progressing favorably for the United Nations on all fronts from the Caucasus and North Africa to New Guinea, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said today in an authoritative summary of reports of action from all fronts as they pass across his desk.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Pilots at all United States ports are to be put at once in the uniform of Coast Guard Reserve officers and under administration of the Coast Guard.

Although various appeals have been made to the Office of Price Administration by food distributors seeking relief under the regulations covering fruits packed in glass, no action has yet been taken and trading is being curtailed, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- To prevent any interruption in manufacturers' sales and deliveries of women's, girls' and children's Fall and Winter outerwear garments, the Office of Price Administration announced today that the termination date of the regulation establishing ceilings for this type of apparel (Maximum Price Regulation 153 as amended) is being extended for manufacturers from Dec. 1 to Dec. 12.

Four names were added yester-[ day to the list of lightweights un-I der consideration by the State Ath- i letic Commission in connection I with its projected eliminations to develop a successor to the retired Sammy Angott.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- The State has collected about $2,683,000 from personal income-tax delinquents in its two-year-old campaign to recover arrears.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 27 (AP) -Bad feeling between Negro soldiers and Negro military police flared into a furious three-hour gun battle here early today, leaving two men dead and twelve persons wounded.

The merger and consolidation of the Southern Union Gas Company, a holding company, with three of its operating subsidiaries has been approved by more than the requisite two-thirds vote of each class of stockholders. Ross Byron, vice president of Southern Union, announced yesterday.

"Remember Pearl Harbor Day" will be observed on Sunday, Dec. 6, in the churches and on Saturday, Dec. 5, in the synagogues of New York City. Worshippers will be asked to dedicate themselves to a renewed "home front" participation in the war as the best possible commemoration of the attack on Pearl Harbor, the request coming from the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office and the War Production Board.

Mrs. Bessie Lewis, wife of a corporal now with a unit of the Army Service of Supply in Africa, is to be the guest of Alfred Lunt and his wife. Lynn Fontanne, when they appear in this evening's performance of "The Pirate" at the Martin Beck Theatre.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 20 I read the statement of Secretary Stimson on the formation of an Austrian battalion to fight against Hitler. Parallel to this there was a statement made by the Military Committee for the Liberation of Austria with Archduke Otto Habsburg at its head.
The Rev. Andrew V. Harbin Jr. has taken up his duties as pastor of the Union Methodist Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street, known as the "Actors Church." He succeeds the Rev. C. Everett Wagner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- President Roosevelt's request for power to permit the free passage in and out of the country of persons, property and goods was virtually shelved today when the Ways and Means Committee failed to act on it.

Nine religious and charitable institutions share $148,800 and five institutions will eventually share the residuary estate of /V[rs. Leonora E. Winslow, wife of Clarion B. Winslow, a retired vice president of F. W. Woolworth Company, who died April 18 leaving a gross estate of $684,674 and a net estate of $644,927.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- A wave of relief swept over London today at the dramatic news of the scuttling of the French fleet at Toulon, thereby ending the tension felt hitherto lest the fleet should fall into Hitler's power.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 27 -- The period of comparative security that bad weather had given the Axis air forces and ground units in Tripolitania appeared today to be over. The United States and Royal Air Forces of the Middle East have resumed attacks on enemy landing grounds just in the rear of German Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's El Agheila line and Allied heavy bombers again pounded Tripoli harbor yesterday, despite some continuing weather obstacles.

Two small issues of municipal bonds, aggregating $3,250,000, constituted this week's new financing. It was the fourth consecutive week in which only tax-exempt issues were marketed and reflected the continued dearth of business available to the investment banking community in the field of corporate financing.

By the grace of his draft board, Miklos Schwalb, pianist, appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night. He was to be inducted Nov. 12, but when he told his board that this recital had been scheduled months before, he was granted a four-week deferment. Now he will be able to take the press clippings of his second New York recital with him into the Army.

Discipline in schools throughout the city, particularly in the underprivileged areas, is in a "serious" condition, with many teachers terrorized and frequently beaten by their students, it was charged yesterday by various teachers. The situation has been growing steadily worse in recent months, they declared.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- All barriers to final action on the reorgan- ! ization plan of the l,Varren Broth-i ers Company of Cambridge, AIass., general contractors, were removed today with the issuance of a mandate by the Federal court dismissing all appeals before it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Department store sales were up 30 per cent in the week ended ]Nov. 21 as compared with the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This compared with a gain of 13 per cent in the week ended lqTov. 14.

George Foley, 19-year-old torpedoed seaman, and First Lieutenant Pearl E. Smith of the Army Second Service Command, Governors Island, received Victory packages yesterday when Mrs. Hugh Grant Straus, chairman of the New York State Commission for the Blind, opened that organization's twenty-first annual Christmas sale of merchandise made by the blind, at 608 Fifth Avenue.

The German radio, reporting Russian offensive blows from Leningrad to Stalingrad, admitted yesterday that the Red Army had driven tanks deep into Nazi lines west and northwest of Moscow and was battering at a curving, 200-mile line from Rzhev to Velikiye Luki, barely 100 miles from the Latvian border.

Unless the draft law is revised to permit the deferment of all engineering students until graduation, number of engineering colleges in the metropolitan area will be forced to close within a few months, Dr. Albert B. Newman, regional adviser of the United States Office of Education's war training program in New York City and Long Island, warned yesterday.

A removable four-page center spread in four colors will climax the current magazine and newspaper advertising campaign of RCA Manufacturing Company promoting Victor records for Christmas gifts. It will appear in the Dec. 7 issue of Life, with other magazines of about that date to carry full pages in color.

The ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton was the setting last night for the Autumn Dance, a fete arranged by a group of debutantes of this season and recent years in compliment to many young officers in the armed forces who are stationed here or are in town on furlough.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Several changes in the Royal Air Force command were announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Congressional circles were speculating today on the part which might be played by James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, in the coming rearrangement of Cabinet posts.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -Adoption of a rule requiring all registered brokers and dealers and members of national securities exchanges who are engaged in business with the public to file annual reports of their financial condition was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

FROM A BASE IN THE GUADALCANAL SECTOR, Nov. 15 (Delayed) -The fifth battle of the Solomons, which in many ways proved a Japanese disaster unprecedented in the history of the world's great navies, began with a contest over reinforcements of men and supplies for our embattled land forces on Guadalcanal.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 27 -- According to accounts heard here, guns of the French warships at Toulon had a part in their self-destruction early today. At ships where explosions were not accurately timed or not sufficient French gunners poured fire to hasten things.

An extra dividend of $2 a share was authorized yesterday by directors of the Westmoreland Coal Company for payment on Dec. 15. This will increase disbursements for 1942 to $6 from $3.75 received by stockholders last year.

During the last war Liberty Bonds purchased in this town could be left at the bank where they were purchased in safe custody, but not one of the banks here will take care of War Bonds for their purchasers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The War Department officially defined its censorship policy today as based on the premise that all news must be withheld from the public that contains material which the enemy would like to know.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- During the week ended Nov. 25 member bank reserve balances increased $124,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $232,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $10,000,000 in Treasury cash and $26,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and increases of $38,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by an increase of $183,000,000 in money in circulation.

DOROTHY THOMPSON'S "Listen, Hans"* began as a series of short-wave broadcasts aimed at the German people, or at those among them who have the combined courage and intelligence to tune in on foreign programs. But specifically she had in mind a single German individual, an old friend whose mind is thoroughly familiar to her. If this one person could be reached, then probably many Germans could be reached.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Thousands of dogs have been enrolled in military patrol work and many are already guarding military installations in this country and at overseas bases.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Donald Woodward's Piccadilly moved up from last to first in the final furlong today to win the featured Oxon Hill Purse at the Bowie race track in a photo finish.

The Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System purchased $147,938,000 of United States Government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday in the weekly Federal Reserve figures, one day late this week on account of the Thanksgiving holiday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The German move on Toulon and the scuttling of French warships and defenses there occurred with such suddenness, and official information was so meager today, that Secretary of State Cordell Hull said it was impossible to estimate the situation and, therefore, it would be premature to comment on it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The War Department announced today the names of 145 additional United States soldiers who had been killed in action or had died of wounds.

As the commentators said on Thanksgiving Day, we have things to be thankful for and things to hope for. Readers of serious books and of serious book reviews will think gratefully of the year 1942 for two words that are obviously on their way out, leaving us much happier.
Following is the text of the letter in which Adolf Hitler announced to Marshal Petain his decision to occupy Toulon, as broadcast by the German radio:

Supplies of more than 100 different chemicals can be obtained for war production through the regional office of the War Production Board, which has set up an informal exchange to bring together war producers and holders of idle stocks, H.M. Brundage, regional deputy director in charge of priorities and materials, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Adolf Hitler's gray clad soldiers are in possession of Toulon tonight but the great French port and naval base on the Mediterranean is a useless mass of ruins and the cream of the fleet that flew the Tricolor lies forever beyond Nazi reach.

Many thousands of young men now in the armed services will be transferred from the barracks to the classrooms of the nation's colleges to begin intensive courses, according to a plan that has been worked out by the Army and Navy in cooperation with leading educators, and now awaits only the President's approval before going into effect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Miss Mary M. Cannon, the first official working women's ambassador from the United States to Latin America, will fly to Brazil tomorrow on her second trip as inter-American representative of the Department of Labor's Women's Bureau.

"This is Thanksgiving Day," writes Stanley J. Patrick from Richmondville, N.Y., "and we have much for which to be thankful. Last Saturday my 12-year-old son shot a ten-point buck deer in his grandfather's woods in this township, county of Schoharie.

The first price-ceiling violations reported in Brooklyn resulted yesterday in $50 fines for each of two merchants before Official Referee O. Grant Esterbrook in Small Claims Court, Brooklyn. Regulations of the Office of Price Administration provide for recovery by the purchaser of treble the overcharge or $50, whichever is the greater.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 28 -- Although the latest communique made public here from Allied headquarters in North Africa described only preparatory actions, the Allied-controlled Algiers radio reported last night that the period of patrol activity had ended and Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson's British First Army and American forces with it had left "defense positions for the big offensive" to smash the Axis hold in Tunisia.

Sermons will be preached tomorrow in observance of the first Sunday in Advent, marking the beginning of the new church year. The discourses will include Advent lessons to be drawn from the war developments of the week. A number of the larger mid-Manhattan churches will have advent oratorios.

PORT LYAUTEY, French Morocco, Nov. 11 (Delayed) -- The battle of "Depth Charge Junction" turned the tide in the bitter three-day battle for Port Lyautey and gave the American invasion forces possession of this city and its invaluable airdrome.

Mrs. A. Lindsay O'Connor, newly elected president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, announced yesterday the appointment of twelve war service chairmen to head this work during her administration. Direction of the entire program will rest with Mrs. O'Connor, assisted by Mrs. Ward B. Gorman of Watertown, who will correlate the State activities with the program established by the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

WORCESTER, i[ass., Nov. 27-lVrs. Slater, whose husband's mills were located in Webster, AIass., controlled an estate once estimated at $25,000,000 and was know-n as an inventor, traveler and benefactor. After long litigation over the property she was confined as insane at the request of members of her family and failed in an equally long legal battle to regain her freedom.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 27 -News that the report of Henry F. Grady on ways to improve India's war industries had been shelved by Washington was received here with "bitter disappointment" among Indians, says the Madras Hindu.

A total of $10,197,757 of new municipal financing is scheduled for award next week through competitive bidding, representing the requirements of fifteen communities, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with $6,251,777 this week and with the weekly average for the year to date of $21,632,369.
The Regional Plan Association recently announced a comprehensive motor traffic plan for either New York alone or the entire metropolitan region.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- American and Australian troops have hurled back local Japanese counter-attacks with heavy losses in the Buna area on the Northeastern New Guinea coast and are continuing to advance against the enemy's organized positions, the Allied Command announced today.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, as head of the dominant Kuomintang, or Nationalist party, redefined the party's attitude toward the Chinese Communists in a speech to the Central Executive Committee, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Net corporate profits after allowance for taxes declined only 5 per cent in the first nine months this year from the relatively high levels of the same period in 1941, the Department of Commerce announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Assurances were given today by William M. Jeffers, Rubber Administrator, that the automobiles, trucks and tractors of farmers, ranchers, factory workers and others essential to war production would be kept rolling under the nationwide rationing of gasoline which starts on Tuesday to conserve rubber.

The city administration was left with more than 30,000 tons of household scrap metal on its hands yesterday by the refusal of steel mills to continue to buy the material that a pool of nine large dealers had agreed to remove from municipal salvage depots.

Influenced by trade buying in the December and March and hedging in the distant months, cotton futures moved unevenly yesterday and closed near the session's peak prices at levels 4 points lower to 10 points higher than Wednesday's final quotations.
Governor-elect Thomas E. Dewey and Mrs. Dewey will be guests of Governor Lehman at luncheon in the executive mansion at Albany today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, set retail prices of women's silk hose at 35 cents to $1.65 today in an order effective Thursday. The bottom price for first quality hose, coarsest circular knit, is 69 cents. The order Protects consumers from rising prices resulting from scarcity.

A plan that seeks to end the inefficient and archaic custodial service, long a disgrace to the New York City school system, has been prepared by the Board of Education's law committee. It would, eventually, place the 3,000 janitors, cleaners, elevator men and other building workers under civil service and return the school building supervision to the proper educational authorities.

Promising that there would be enough coffee on retail shelves in the next five weeks to redeem all ration stamps covering that period, the Office of Price Administration and the coffee industry warned housewives yesterday against stampeding to the grocers with their first coupons, which become valid tonight at midnight.

Representative John Sparkman of Alabama, member of the House Military Affairs Committee, in an address here yesterday stressed the necessity for a national program to insure a continuing flow of educated and trained personnel to supply adequately the increasing war and civilian needs of the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Officials here refused to admit today that the report of Henry F. Grady on improving economic conditions in India and stimulating her production contribution to the war effort has been shelved.
Fordham's football season comes to its close this afternoon with a game made possible only by the war. The Rams face the North Carolina Pre-Flight cadets at 2 o'clock at the Yankee Stadium.

The territory we occupy in North Africa was never self-sufficient. It has been drained drier than usual by Nazi requisitions in the past two years and is now cut off from exchanges with France. As the first field of operation for Governor Lehman's new agency, it emphasizes the immediacy of the tasks of relief and rehabilitation we have undertaken as a weapon of war and a preparation for peace.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Admiral Francois Darlan, leader of the French forces in Africa, in a statement read over the Algeria radio tonight about the German occupation of Toulon, asserted that he had asked the fleet to leave the harbor for a safe destination on Nov. 11.

One way to meet the shortage of butter -- a way that is regrettably popular, to judge by recent reports -- is to canvass every grocery in the neighborhood, buy all the prepared vegetable shortenings that you can lay hand to, and store them side by side on a cup-board shelf.

The announcement that the British First Army in North Africa had adopted as its insignia an old Crusaders' emblem as evidence of unity in a great cause points once more to a grave defect in the morale policies of the United Nations.

Public Works Commissioner Irving V.A. Huie disclosed yesterday that he would recruit, at the request of the Army and with Mayor La Guardia's approval, an ordnance company of mechanics, machinists and repair men to be known as "Knickerbocker's Own."

Baseball's first move toward clarification of the government's salary-freezing regulations with regard to ball players for 1943 was made yesterday when the Giants, through their vice president and treasurer, Leo J. Bondy, filed application for a ruling with the Salary Stabilization Unit of the Treasury Department.

WITH THE BRITISH FIRST ARMY, Sixty Miles West of Tunis, Nov. 23 (Delayed) -- The high tide of war is flowing over these rough, brown hills with American, French and British troops fighting shoulder to shoulder for the first time since 1918 in preparation for a major offensive against the Germans holding Tunis and Bizerte.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The stock markets closed the week quietly. The textiles and tobaccos eased. Marks Spencer was fractionally lower on profit-taking and the breweries improved. The home rails met further buying with Great Western up 5s and London, Midland Scottish 2 1/2s higher.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Nov. 23 (Delayed) -- German bombers are pounding the Allied communications behind the front in an attempt to slow the American-British advance and to permit Germans and Italians to take up defense positions.

While retail trade here was active this week, sales comparisons with a year ago were affected by the five-day week against a six-day period in 1941. Department store volume was estimated at from 6 to 8 per cent under last year.

Imagine, if you can, Minnesota, Ohio State, Michigan and even the so-called Ivy colleges, like Harvard, Yale, Penn and the others, suddenly announcing a football schedule listing games with Wake Forest, Temple, Clemson. Boston University, Holy Cross, West Virginia, Georgetown of this year's vintage and Fordham with its war-depleted squad.

The audience had reason to rejoice in the performance of Mozart's "Magic Flute," sung in English, under Bruno Walter's direction, last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. The opera, which is such a delicious farrago of fairy tale, popular comedy, symbolic ceremony and nonsense, was done in the true play spirit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Justice Department reported today the arrest of the daughter of William Dudley Pelley, the Silver Shirt leader, and four other persons on charges of conspiring to harbor Howard Victor Broenstrup during the four months that he was a fugitive from a charge of seditious conspiracy.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- After being sworn into the United States Naval Reserve as a lieutenant commander, Richard Cresson (Dick) Harlow, head football coach at Harvard for the past nine seasons, today said he "didn't know" how his departure would affect the Crimson's future gridiron plans.

In December, 1903, a Danish postal clerk, the late Einar Holboll, conceived the idea of selling stamps which could be applied to letters and packages and thus make it possible for the public to bring Christmas joy to tuberculous children. The seed that he planted is now a flourishing tree under which millions have found shelter.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The sinking of the American destroyer Duncan during a battle in the Solomon Islands Oct. 11-12 was revealed today. It was disclosed that 150 of the survivors were landed at the Philadelphia Navy Yard on Nov. 19 when the light cruiser Boise arrived here for repairs.

The battles for bowl invitations mark football's last big day of the campaign. Rose Bowl and Sugar Bowl nominees-to-be face their final tests today. Unbeaten Boston College, the nation's top-ranking team, faces an old obstacle in Holy Cross at The Hub before heading for New Orleans, while unbeaten Georgia Tech meets a traditional foe in Georgia.

Flotations of new bonds here this week, like those in the three preceding weeks, were few and for small amounts of tax-exempt securities. Two issues of municipal bonds aggregating $3,250,000 were offered to the public, compared with a like number totaling $4,380,000 last week and $48,408,201 for seven diversified flotations in this week a year ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The nutritive values and edibility of dehydrated foods was pictured today by Charles Glen King as a major problem which worries "nearly every one who works with foods, either in the Army or in civilian life."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 27 -- Appearing as special counsel for Eugene E. Aggar, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, and for the new anti-Hague Hudson County Board of Taxation, John Warren challenged today the right of the city to apply for a writ of certiorari before Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the State Supreme Court on the ground Justice Brogan formerly represented the city as corporation counsel.

Reflecting increased operating revenues due to heavy wartime traffic and lowered operating costs, earnings of the United Airlines Transport Corporation for the third quarter of 1942 were substantially larger than those of the corresponding three months last year, according to the statement of W.A. Patterson, president, issued for release today.

An irregularly higher trend of prices appeared yesterday in the stock market, although some gains in the so-called peace issues exceeded a point. Scuttling of the French fleet at Toulon was regarded as a significant war development, but from a market viewpoint it was ignored.

Magistrate Savarese in Queens Felony Court yesterday told Police Captain Louis Goldberg, commander of the Newtown Precinct, that his methods in making gambling arrests were "fast approaching something that may be found in Germany."

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The grain markets were on the upgrade in the early trading today, with rye in the lead. Rye advanced around 1 cent a bushel to a new high on the current movement before profit-taking checked the rise and brought about a reaction.

Estimating that probably half of the Jewish population of Europe would perish under Nazi domination before the end of the war, Dr. Nahum Goldmann declared last night that the only practical way of solving the problem of those who might escape extermination was "to establish a firm foundation for a new Jewish future in Palestine."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The first Army-Navy "E" awarded to any quartermaster depot in the country was presented today to the Philadelphia depot.

The NBC String Symphony, under Frank Black, gave the second concert of its Carnegie Hall series last night, with Egon Petri, pianist, as soloist. Transcription, again figured on the program. Two of these were arrangements for strings by Mr. Black and were concerned with Beethoven's piano sonata in E flat major, Op. 7, and Debussy's string quartet.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's noon communique:

Joe Trapani is happy. He heard a song on a radio yesterday -- just a plain little song from a scratchy little radio -- while he lay in a bed in Kings County Hospital, a victim of infantile paralysis. The song was Joe's own, "It Isn't My Eyes That Cry, It's My Heart," played over the air for the first time.

Reforms in the manufacture and making of rayon stockings, intended to eliminate possible misleading of American women preoccupied with wartime tasks, probably will accompany or follow the WPB's pending plan to simplify hosiery styles from the standpoint of wartime utility, distributors here declared yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- The First Circuit Court of Appeals reversed here today a ruling by the Federal District Court of Puerto Rico allowing the government to seize, under the War Powers Act, the plants and equipment of the Puerto Rico Railway, Light and Power Company.

"Winter Soldiers," a new play by Dan James, will open tonight under the management of Erwin Piscator at the Studio Theatre of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. The play started last Sunday for Studio Theatre subscribers. The leading roles are played by Ross Matthew, Herbert Berghof, Ronald Alexander, Vaughn George, Dolly Haas, Guy Sorel, Boris Marshalov and Sara Strengell.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Axis armies are reeling back on all fronts, British Air Secretary Sir Archibald Sinclair said today.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 28 (AP) Russian troops were declared officially today to have seized four more villages and surrounded a fifth m the continuing Stalingrad offensive, which has caused a reported toll of more than 116,000 Nazi dead and captured, but the Red Army's pace apparently has been slowed through stiffening German resistance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Senate approved today a $5,000 investigation of economic and social conditions in Puerto Rico. There was no opposition to the resolution, but there was heated debate before rejection of a Republican proposal that the administration of Governor Rexford Guy Tugwell be also investigated.

Closer cooperation between the amateur and professional theatres, resulting in widespread production of professional plays by amateur groups, was urged yesterday by Paul Green, president of the National Theatre Conference, which opened a two-day conference at the Hotel Piccadilly.

Declaring that war and the coming reconstruction emphasize as never before the importance of education for democratic citizenship, the Commission on Wartime Policy of the National Council for the Social Studies urged yesterday that every high school pupil study the historical development of American democracy.

Six midshipmen, chosen from among 1,100 classmates, the largest New York Naval Reserve midshipmen's graduating class to date, received swords yesterday as tokens of outstanding ability and devotion to duty in an impressive ceremony at the New York Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Declaring that recent war developments had increased the demand for pork products, Secretary of Agriculture Wickard revised upward today previously established 1943 hog production goals and at the same time announced a program designed to support hog price at an average of $13.25 a hundred pounds, Chicago basis, until Sept. 30, 1944.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -Senator Caraway of Arkansas, only woman member of the Senate, told the women of occupied Europe in a Thanksgiving message that she knew what their anxieties have been "during the years of awful war" because she has two sons in the armed forces.

A large furnished apartment in 1100 Park Avenue has been leased by Prince and Princess Francis Windisch-Graetz through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter. Hamilton, Inc. The Prince is a great-grandson of Emperor Francis Joseph of Austria-Hungary.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 -- Development of a tough and translucent film of medicated cellulose which can effectively shut out infection from war wounds and burns, yet is easily carried in a soldier's first-aid kit, was reported today.

Mrs. Bigelow Clarke of the St. Regis gave a dinner last night in the Maisonette there for Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Gray, Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Iselin, Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Whitehouse and Joseph Earle Stevens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- William M. Jeffers, Rubber Administrator, saw a tubeless tire mounted on an automobile rim today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 27 -The scuttling of the French Fleet is only part of today's story. The French Army is being demobilized. Pierre Laval's powers have been extended so that he is now virtual dictator, if only in name, and the Gestapo is active everywhere, lists of suspects being circulated.

The French have decided the fate of the French fleet. When the German forces entered the last bit of unoccupied French territory they found the harbor of Toulon, the day before crowded with great battleships, cruisers and destroyers, a smoking graveyard. There was a note of somber triumph in the Vichy broadcast that the orders of Admiral de la Borde had been executed so effectively that not one vessel is left afloat.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Sir Archibald Sinclair, Secretary for Air, evoked a prolonged outburst of enthusiastic applause while lauding General Charles de Gaulle and the Fighting French forces today in a speech at a luncheon of the Foreign Press Association.

ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- A plan to speed up college and high school education in the State without lowering standards has been approved by the Board of Regents, according to an announcement today by Dr. J. Hillis Miller, associate commissioner in charge of higher and professional education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 21 totaled 836,427 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,826 cars, or 1.2 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 37,041 cars, or 4.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 102,939 cars, or 14 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

"Distinct gains" and "great relief" from hay fever in one to three days from relatively large doses of vitamin C, the anti-scurvy vitamin present in citrus fruits and green vegetables, is reported in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
Would you go to a friend and say, "Please take us in" if a bomb demolished your home? Or if you came to a strange city to work and found no adequate living quarters, where would you turn?

May I say, unofficially, that the airplane spotters on top of the Empire State Building appreciate your kind thoughts as expressed in your editorial. That post is manned by Legionnaires only, some of us having been up there for almost two years, long before Pearl Harbor.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 27 -As the manpower shortage moves swiftly to the emergency stage, it becomes increasingly apparent that the new Congress, when it convenes in January, will give the question early attention.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 27 -As the manpower shortage moves swiftly to the emergency stage, it becomes increasingly apparent that the new Congress, when it convenes in January, will give the question early attention.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins approved yesterday as fair and reasonable a settlement offer of $675,000 made in an accounting suit brought by minority stockholders of the Consolidated Oil Corporation. The offer was made by sixteen defendants in the suit, including Harry F. Sinclair, Albert H. Wiggin, the estate of Harry Payne Whitney and the Amerex Holding Corporation.
The Germans have failed in what must have been one of their main purposes ever since the Anglo-American expeditionary corps landed in North Africa: to capture the French fleet gathered in Toulon.

In a hearing in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday, marked by the enmity of one family for another since the shooting of Alman Harrington, Mrs. Anna Harrington was reunited with her four small children, who have been the pawns in a custody proceeding.

Publishers of racing sheets, branded by Mayor La Guardia as "tipster sheets," won from Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel yesterday a continuance of the injunction restraining License Commissioner Paul Moss from barring the sale of the sheets on newsstands under his jurisdiction.

The mystery of the missing 700-pound bull elk was solved yesterday when Central Park Zoo officials revealed that the animal, one of four shipped last Wednesday from the Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park to the zoo, suffered a fractured skull en route and had to be destroyed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, American-educated wife of the Generalissimo and the leader of Chinese women in the war effort, has arrived in the United States for medical care and after completing the course of treatment will be a guest of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, it was announced at the White House late today.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and Dean Carl W. Ackerman of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism, were made honorary associates of the Union of Journalists of Ecuador at a tea yesterday afternoon in the journalism building held in honor of seven Mexican newspaper men and one Bolivian.

The action of National Hockey League officials in cutting the club player limit from fifteen men to fourteen as a wartime measure and in suspending the present required minimum of twelve players on each squad likely will restore to the game much of the individual glamour lacking in recent years.
CAIRO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A joint British Middle East Army headquarters and R.A.F. communique:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -- The Gregory Ratoff Production Unit at Columbia announced today that Mae West has been signed to star in "Tropicana," a story by Edward Eliscue and Henry Myers, which Ratoff will produce and direct after he completes "Russia" at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Larger quotas of passenger car tires and tubes will be available in December, the OPA stated today, to meet the needs of the new mileage rationing plan which goes into effect Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today a request from trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation that hearings be accelerated on a proposal for the New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey Utilities Company to acquire $1,000,000 of 6 per cent consolidated refunding gold bonds, due 1981, of the Mohawk Valley Company.

The long, unhappy history of Mexico's defaulted foreign debt has reached a final chapter. Under agreement between the Finance Minister of Mexico and the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, which was formed more than twenty years ago to seek a settlement, Mexico has agreed to resume service "on a modified and reduced scale" on her external debt.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, Nov. 28 -- With the Japanese throwing in increasing air support for their ground forces, the battle for the Buna-Gona area of New Guinea has settled down to a stand-off struggle in which neither side for the last few days has made any important gains.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 27 (6 P.M.) (U.P.) -- Allied forces have reached the town of Tabourba, fifteen miles due west of Tunis, front dispatches reported tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- A solemn protest against German outrages in Poland and the attempts by the Nazis to exterminate the Jewish people there was unanimously voted tonight by the Polish National Council, the acting Parliament in exile, at a special meeting convened to hear reports that have reached the Polish Government from leaders of the underground movement in the occupied country.

The commitment took place after a sheriff's jury hearing here. The New York Banking and Trust Company was named a committee for her property, and the children as a committee for her person.
A special High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told the country's war workers today that they should take a full holiday on Christmas Day and then buckle down to the job again with increased determination.

The Axis received another setback yesterday. French men-of-war were scuttled by their crews in Toulon harbor to prevent them from falling into the hands of Adolf Hitler, and the United Nations recruited more allies.

SIGNS point to a wider use than usual of antiques as holiday gifts. Already, say dealers, many customers are making selections of small articles and ordering them sent, marked "Not to be opened until Christmas." Porcelains and silver, some auction galleries report, are attracting livelier bidding than usual because of their gift possibilities.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The wide-awake Oklahoma Aggies intercepted 10 of 41 University of Detroit passes today and swept to a 33-to-6 victory, their first over the Titans in four games since 1934.

The old-fashioned country editor still lives, and the nation is safe. His name is Carl Broome and he edits The Brantley Enterprise, a Georgia weekly. His draft board showed some curiosity as to how he filled in his time, and he told them. He wrote down his duties as they came into his mind. Sorted out a little, the list shows what goes on.

Frank Widdis, formerly assistant director of the Dessoff Choirs, is now a private first class and has been attached to the chaplain's division in Fort Belvoir, Va. One of his present duties is to organize some of the men into a male chorus to sing excerpts from "The Messiah" at Christmas time.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- German counter-attacks of a widespread, frequent character are reported from the southwest and northwest sectors of the Stalingrad front. Some dispatches indicate a movement of German reinforcements to the southwest sector.

A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Although he lived without water and had only one half an orange to eat for twenty-two days, Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker was in excellent shape when rescued from a rubber lifeboat in the mid-Pacific, according to Navy Pilot Lieutenant Joseph Isner.

WHEN the Metropolitan Opera House threw open its doors for the first time in 1883 American-born singers in the company were as rare as skyscrapers. But today an American-born opera singer is neither a freak nor an exception. He need not trail behind the European opera stars like a second-class citizen behind the Herrenvolk in Naziland.

BERNARD SHAW "can now boast that he has had as many lives as a cat." That is how St. John Ervine opens his Spectator review of the biography just published by Hesketh Pearson, which he pronounces the most readable of the lot.
ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 28 (AP) -- After triumphing over Georgia Tech today, Georgia accepted an invitation to play in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., Jan. 1 next.

ROLAND HAYES'S father wasn't much of a farmer, nor yet much of a churchgoer; and both these deficiencies troubled the stern, wise, large-hearted but unsentimental woman -- born in slavery -- who was indeed to become the guardian "Angel Mother" of the singer's maturing life.

SEATTLE, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- The latest issue received here of The Kodiak Bear, Fort Greeley (Alaska) newspaper, disclosed that a lake, having an hour-glass figure had been named Rose Teed by Army engineers preparing maps of Kodiak Island.

Advocating a reduction of four years from the twelve now needed to complete the courses of study in grammar and high schools, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, associate professor of Philosophy at Catholic University, told 800 educators yesterday that "there isn't any one who couldn't get a nigh school education, as it is presently taught, in two years."

Observation of children's games shows that boys give up playing house before girls do, take more interest than do their sisters in wheeled toys. But suppose we gave dolls and doll houses to the boys; gave the girls trains and marbles and tops -- what then?

Rapid headway in self-service types of operation is probable in retail distribution during the months ahead to supply at least a partial answer to problems raised by the growing labor shortage and the necessity of spreading the services of available sales people as far as possible.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 28 -- General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps is either preparing to make a stand at El Agheila or attempting to convince the British that such a stand is intended, it was said today.

SOME months ago these eyes were astonished to read in an American newspaper a letter from London which said that the big success of the West End was "Let's Face It!" Obviously this slip of the pen for a show then in the early stages of its New York run and the prospects of its coming to London had not been publicly discussed.

ONE of those four-engine bombers which occasionally fly overhead with motors singing in the deep tones of a basso profundo choir costs a quarter of a million dollars to build and carries a crew of nine men. That crew is really a team with human coordination as delicate and as sturdy and as dependable as the bomber's complex mechanism.
As a sidelight to the discussion of the double feature problem in last Sunday's issue the following might be of interest.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 28 (AP) -- A badly out-rushed, but crafty Michigan State team battled Oregon State's favored Rose Bowl champions to a 7-7 deadlock before a slim crowd of 5,400 today in the season finale for both teams.

Three thousand members of twenty-six reform synagogues in the metropolitan area who are now serving with the armed forces will be honored at a Maccabean rally next Sunday afternoon at the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, under the auspices of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues.

A meeting at which Lady Doverdale will give a talk on the Fighting French in England and Mme. Denise Davey will speak for the Fighting French Relief Committee in the United States will take place at 5 o'clock Thursday afternoon on the St. Regis Roof.

Evidences of a closer cooperation among all elements of the theatre -- professional and amateur -- were reported by representatives of university and civic theatrical groups attending the National Theatre Conference's second session yesterday morning at the Hotel Piccadilly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- An intimation was given by the Board of Appeals on visa cases in its first report today to President Roosevelt that plans were under way for expediting wherever possible the procedure for granting visas.

Requests for fill-ins of scarce holiday merchandise continued to pour in on wholesale markets, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Particularly requested were military gifts, sweaters, handbags, luggage and similar items on which, it was said, output has been unable to catch up, with demand.

HOW does a civilian, accustomed to peacetime pursuits, become transformed into a soldier whose business it is to kill? Private Kahn tells the story from the time of his induction to the day of his embarkation for some unspecified war front.

I WAS sitting on the fifty-yard line at the Polo Grounds reporting the radio story of the final professional football game of the National League season. The Dodgers and the Giants were battling up and down the gridiron.

SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Washington State College's Rose Bowl hopes suffered a setback today as an outplayed University of Washington eleven held the Pacific Coast Conference leader to a scoreless tie.

Prospects that production of upholstered furniture with wooden springs would start soon were pushed farther into the future last week when the Office of Price Administration, after meeting with manufacturers in Washington, failed to take any steps toward setting prices.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- This resort community in the Sandhills and its neighbor, Southern Pines, are starting their Winter season little affected by war. Some formal sports events have been dropped and others reduced in size, but the activities which draw Northerners here year after year will go on almost as usual.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Plans for squeezing the Axis out of Africa between General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army, now pursuing General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel across Libya, and Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson's British First Army, pressing the Axis hard in Tunisia, are developing.
