WHEN the furlough bride plans her trousseau she has to figure on wearing the major part of it on her back and carrying the rest in a suitcase. Maybe she is going to a camp in the South or West -- or, perhaps, her man will have a few days' leave.

Elmer Davis some time ago in a single sentence summed up the role which propaganda should play in America's war effort. He said; "Democracies have a good story to tell, and they ought to tell it." One way to tell the good story of American democracy in tile twentieth century is to make it the story of a completely typical American baby named Bill Smith, born of a representative American family in the year 1940.

A clear division of the sources of revenue among the Federal, State and local governments was advocated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as a necessary step to avoid wholesale bankruptcy of cities in the post-war period.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Fuel oil rations for heating throughout the thirty-State rationed area will continue unchanged in the five weeks embracing the second heating period, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

Producing hydrangea plants that will remain dwarfed and that will bloom beautifully in pots and hold their blossoms for two months or more is a horticultural feat not unlike the accomplishment of dwarfing trees, but any one who wishes can do it.

Although the railroads have successfully met the unprecedented traffic demands placed on them by the war, the outlook for next year is a bit dubious unless they are able to obtain more equipment and materials for maintenance of track facilities. For four years the volume of rail traffic has been steadily increasing.

POPULATION PROBLEMS -- With the death rate practically constant, last year's jump in the birth rate has brought United States population up to an estimated 133,039,000. Internal migration is increasing, with 1941 migration from farms to cities doubling that of 1940.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 28 -- The first steel cargo vessel to be launched in Rhode Island slid down the ways here today at a shipyard for which ground was broken only eight months ago.

AT AN ADVANCED TWELFTH AIR FORCE BASE, in North Africa. Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- American medium bombers led by a veteran of last April's raid on Tokyo, blasted Sfax, an important port and railway center on the east coast of Tunisia, in a lightning low-level attack today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be initiated into the Radcliffe Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa Dec. 11 preceding the annual dinner at the college.

The importance of the settlement house as a center for enlisting men, women, and children in underprivileged areas for all phases of war activity was stressed yesterday by Samuel S. Fishzohn, director of the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, the largest and one of the nation's oldest community centers.

A clash of "opinions," with open charges of cowardice and desertion, is reported from Rome to have broken out between General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel and General Ettore Bastico following the disastrous turn of events in the Libyan offensive and the latter's recall from Tripoli, according to European reports reaching THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BROADWAY'S most significant contribution to the nation's war effort is under way. At this writing the first contingents in a procession of no fewer than seventy shows have begun a 750,000 mile trek throughout the country that will last for twenty-two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Office of War Information stated today that of about 15,000,000 women gainfully employed in the country 4,000,000 were in war jobs and predicted that "by December, 1943, we will have 18,000,000 women, about 29 per cent of the female population, in paid employment, and 6,000,000 of them, or 30 per cent of our expected total war labor force of 20,000,000, in war industries."

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- An unexampled attempt to stop the spread of venereal disease begins tomorrow in Chicago. Vice President Wallace will dedicate the country's first intensive treatment center for gonorrhea and syphilis, and Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, president of the Chicago Board of Health, predicted it would blaze a new trail in the war against social diseases.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A suggestion that the value of "A" and "B" coupons be increased in the first phase of nation-wide gasoline rationing to eliminate possible disruption of necessary transportation was made to William M. Jeffers, rubber administrator, today by Representative Voorhis of California.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Approval of names submitted by the country's school children for twenty-four Liberty ships is announced by the Maritime Commission.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 28 -- Eight hundred and sixty thousand voters, including 328,000 women, will go to the polls tomorrow in one of the important elections in the history of Uruguay.

EXCEPT for one game, it will be all in fun on the professional field in what little is left of the football season. Eight of the ten teams are just going ahead to finish out the schedule. The Great Big Bears and the Redskins will be getting in some practice scrimmaging for their national championship encounter in Washington on Dec. 13.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Under urgings from the White House and the War, Navy and Justice Departments, ranking members of the Ways and Means Committee, after a conference with House and Senate leaders, agreed today to try again to draft an acceptable substitute for the sweeping third war powers program sought by the Administration.

The second part of the property of Mrs. William Fox will be sold at public auction by the Kende Galleries at the Gould Mansion, 579 Fifth Avenue, on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. Mrs. Fox has stipulated that all proceeds from this sale, which consists entirely of paintings by old and modern masters, be paid to her in war bonds.

WARREN GROVE, N.J. -- In anticipation of one of the greatest deer hunting seasons in the history of the State, hundreds of sportsmen are reported scouting the vast Ocean-Burlington-Atlantic County deer wilderness for the purpose of picking their hunting grounds for the approaching Winter season.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- There was something missing Thanksgiving Day in the Irish Channel section of New Orleans -- the Turkey Bowl -- and the reason has just come to light.

For the first time in many years, early December will not see the departure of the usual special Winter trains to Florida. With 40 per cent of the sleeping cars and 15 per cent of the coaches continuously engaged in moving troops and with the armed forces having priority on the remainder, tourist travel as usual is out for the duration.

While he is investigating a murder in a shabby lodging house, Lieutenant Marshall of the Los Angeles police stumbles upon another mystery even more puzzling than the first one. It is a locked room murder which does not quite come off.

LEADING entertainers have received a letter from the War Department suggesting that perhaps more care might be exercised in the use of soldiers and "soldier humor" on the air. Lieut. Col. Edward M. Kirby, in charge of the department's division of radio public relations, has reminded the stars that the war has entered the serious phase and that what once was funny "is not so funny now."

IF you are like most cooks, you want to prepare plain food now that Thanksgiving is over. You want to forget candied sweet potatoes, oyster stuffing, thick giblet gravies, hot mince pies. All these, to be sure, were right in every respect last Thursday, but now your mood is for simpler stuff.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Plans to take more than 250 experienced agricultural workers from Bridgeton, N.J., to Florida for Winter farm work, were told today by J.H. Wood, regional director of the Farm Security Administration.

In the dullest Saturday session in several weeks, the cotton futures market moved yesterday within a narrow trading range and closed with net losses of 2 to 14 points. Demand slackened and light hedging and liquidation of the distant contracts were responsible for the losses.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 29 -- The Russians announced today that a surprise offensive on the Northwest Rzhev front had killed 10,000 German troops, routed five divisions, "liberated more than 300 populated places" and broken wide gaps in German fortifications less than ninety miles from the old Latvian border.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The scuttling of the French Fleet at Toulon yesterday when German forces entered that port was carried out in accordance with general instructions dating back to the time of the Franco-German armistice in June, 1940, according to a communique broadcast from Vichy tonight.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 -- Although the absence of customary frills and the sight of many empty seats made today's wartime Army-Navy football game a somber affair in comparison with the spectacles of former years, the gridiron hostilities possessed all the spirit and zest so typical of sports contests between the service rivals.

Fordham's varsity eleven added its quota to yesterday's dizzy upsets and did it with a crisp, workmanlike job. The Rams turned back the North Carolina Pre-Flight cadets at the Yankee Stadium, 6 to 0, on the wings of a long forward pass from Steve Filipowicz early in the game that Al Litwa, freshman halfback, gathered in to carry to the visitors' 2-yard line.

Baseball men of the major and minor leagues are converging today upon Chicago, where, for the balance of this week, they will sit in what looms as the most momentous Winter session the national game has ever known.

The International Foto, Motion Picture and Television Corporation of America is not nearly so impressive as its name. It is not international, and it has nothing to do with motion pictures or television, but Handsome Kuzak and Bingo Riggs, who are the partners in this organization and also its entire working staff, hope to expand some day when business picks up.

Captain Folkert H. Dobbenga, master of the combination cargo-passenger vessel Sloterdyk of the Holland-America Line, was decorated last week with the Cross of Merit of the Netherlands, for exceptional devotion to duty while under fire.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman, newly appointed Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, urged Americans of all creeds tonight to give increasing support to religion, both in its spiritual sense and in its humanitarian wartime activities.

THIS story, based on the deeds of a real patriot and king, takes us back with a vivid sense of life to the forgotten days of an Ethiopia tyrant-ridden and persecuted as it was when it stirred our sympathies only a few years ago.

THIS is a book which the wise grown-up will borrow from the younger members of the family, reading it aloud, perhaps, to share its flavor, enjoying it not only for the innate interest of the subject but for the skill and imagination which have shaped fact with plausible fancy into one of the most delightful biographies of the year.

CHRISTMAS LIGHTS -- Since the stores report that only about 25 per cent of the usual supply of Christmas lighting paraphernalia will be available this December, an early-bird shopping policy is more than ever desirable.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 28 -- On Friday, Nov. 27, the French at long last were provided with a precise definition of the word "collaboration." It came from Adolf Hitler. On Oct. 24, 1940, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain had accepted "collaboration" in principle, prompted to it by Pierre Laval, who had induced him to go to Montoire and there meet the Reichsfuehrer.

Women will be trained in electronics and metals at Columbia University in courses to begin Dec. 8 and 14. Prospective students will be interviewed Tuesday and Wednesday evenings for the ten-week electrical course, which, it was said, would open an entirely new field for women, and on Dec. 8, 10 and 11 for the metals class.

In the late Summer the Rockefeller Foundation invited Sir Hector Hetherington, vice chancellor of the University of Glasgow and a member of the Permanent Committee of the Vice Chancellors of Great Britain, to visit the United States to confer with educational and governmental administrators on the difficult problems of student manpower confronting this country.

ALBANY, Nov. 28 -- In the quiet of the Governor's private office on the second floor of the old Executive Mansion, Herbert H. Lehman, retiring Governor, explained this afternoon to Thomas E. Dewey, who takes office on the first day of January, some of the details of the State government on which Mr. Dewey wanted first-hand information.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Representative Celler of New York contended today that "a bill of goods" had been sold to Secretary Stimson in connection with his authorizing of the formation of a "Free Austrian Legion" within the United States Army.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 28 -- An official (German) broadcast by the Paris radio tonight asserted that, contrary to "fantastic reports" issued by the Vichy Havas news agency yesterday, the main operation of occupation of Toulon was carried out by German forces "almost without incident."
LONDON, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Radio Berlin admitted tonight that the Russians were pressing heavy attacks northwest of Moscow and in the Stalingrad area between the Volga and the Don.
WASHINGTON, Nov, 28 -- Jack Hagerty, head football coach at Georgetown University for the last ten years, was sworn into the Navy today as a lieutenant in the service's physical fitness program.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 28 -- Eastern racing on major tracks came to an end for 1942 with a victory today for Pictor before 8,000 spectators. The son of Challenger II was bred, foaled and is owned in this State, which always has been so cordial to the thoroughbred sport.

ORAN, Algeria, Nov. 24 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- As the main Allied forces move eastward toward Bizerte, troops behind the lines, armed with American money, are carrying out mopping-up operations of their own, buying vast quantities of everything from dime score goods to automobiles.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 -- The most ancient mariner in Crab-town racked his memory in vain for a parallel to the stunning reversal inflicted upon Army by Navy today as the service rivals met at football on the grounds of the Naval Academy for the first time since 1893.

THE other day, while I was watching a British-made motion-picture biography of Jim and Amy Mollison, the fliers, called "Wings and the Woman,'' there suddenly appeared on the screen the image of Robert (Bobby) Newton in the slightly ridiculous regalia of the ultra-dressy race-going Britisher -- gray cutaway and tall, pearl-gray topper.

To listen to Sylvia Zaremba, 11-year-old pianist from Springfield, Mass., during her recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, was a refreshing experience. For the modest, unspoiled little performer played like a normal, if decidedly gifted child, and not like a prematurely adult virtuoso.

ATLANTA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A mistrial was declared today in Fulton Superior Court in the trial of former Governor E.D. Rivers, when a jury reported itself unable to reach a verdict on charges that he embezzled $66,119.60 while serving as chief executive.

It used to be geometry for the sake of geometry; now it's geometry applied to ballistics and aerial navigation. It used to be domestic science, now it's canteen feeding in emergencies. And the boy who was once a reluctant sufferer in a gym class is now an enthusiast in the rough-and-tumble of Ranger training.

While half a dozen top-flight retrievers in the metropolitan district are eligible to compete the coming week-end for the national retriever championship, only two are expected to take the journey to Madison, Wis., which will be the scene of the second annual meeting.

Delegates to the National Inter-fraternity Conference, representing a membership of 1,500,000 in fifty-nine national fraternities, took measures yesterday at the close of their annual session in the Hotel Commodore to protect their extensive financial investments and to preserve organizations of collegiate standing during the war.

THE Netherlands Information Bureau in New York was informed last week that W.L.Z. van de Vegte, the Nazi Director-General of the Netherlands Post and Telegraph Department, issued 7 1/2-cents red and 12 1/2c blue stamps on Nov. 1, the design picturing a soldier of the Netherlands Legion.

OTTAWA, Nov. 28 -- In half a dozen incidents and speeches the issue has been raised this week in Canada of how and where liberty must be controlled to give efficiency and how and where control may become an impediment.
FURTHER evidence of Russia's interest in American music: Roy Harris recently received a letter forwarded to him from the Soviet Embassy in Washington.

PIQUED by an idle curiosity (and the grim urge to make a minor point), this corner was just now wondering how high has been the average in past years of the good and commendable pictures which have come along in Thanksgiving weeks.

Establishment of an international office of education with power to experiment with education and to train teachers to understand and to treat international fears and differences was urged yesterday by James Marshall, president of the city's Board of Education.

GLOWING, opulent, vivid almost to the point of smelling and tasting good, here is a picture of the most attractive side of life on a rich plantation in tidewater Virginia a few years before the Revolution. The author has a charming gift for making the sounds and fragrances of Spring or Autumn apparent, and she is offering a picture of one of the sweetest lands on earth.

BECAUSE they are forever with us, it is inevitable that the soap operas now and then raise their dolorous heads and ask for discussion, although, as in the notorious case of the weather, nothing much ever seems to be done about them.

Anxious to adjust its curriculum to the needs of women in changing times, the Woman's College of the University of North Carolina is making a survey of 6,000 of its alumnae to find out "how they're doing." Mailed to about 3,000 graduates and 3,000 nongraduates among the former students of the last ten years, a questionnaire asking for personal education, occupational and social information will be the basis for the study.

Logic, fairness and appreciation of the growing importance of women in war industry support the equal pay order issued by the War Labor Board last week. With the number of women war workers constantly increasing and likely to reach one-third or more of the total employes in many plants, inequality in pay is bound to cause trouble -- as, indeed, it has already done.

Mrs. Bessie Lewis, wife of a corporal now stationed "somewhere in Africa," arrived at the Martin Beck Theatre rather early last night, walked excitedly backstage, held an animated two-minute conversation with Alfred Lunt and his wife, Lynn Fontanne, who had invited her to see them in last night's performance of "The Pirate," and then exclaimed, "My, but will I have much to write to Charles this time!"

Rubens Benefit Show: In a week less thronged with space-consuming events, the Rubens loan exhibition at Schaeffer Brandt's would certainly be reviewed in detail (a much more comprehensive account appeared in our daily art column Wednesday).

Commercial paper, long known as a "blue ribbon" loan of banks' portfolios, is proving once more that the ebb and flow of its supply are far more changeable than those of regular commercial loans. At the moment, the supply of prime commercial paper is diminishing, aggregating little more than $270,000,000 for the entire country.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 -- The bubble of Boston College invincibility burst today. The unbeaten Eagles, rated the nation's No. 1 team, not only were upset by Holy Cross before the unbelieving gaze of 41,000 spectators in Fenway Park, but they were routed by the most lopsided score in the history of this ancient clash.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Two coastal tankers built for the Maritime Commission were launched today at the yard of the Marine Maintenance Corporation at Constable Hook here before a group of 2,500 workmen and visitors, including Governor Charles Edison.

JEROME K. JEROME, in his day, was the most popular English author that America ever had, and the average reader who has grown up since his "Three Men in a Boat. to say nothing of the dog," sailed into instant popularity, think of him as one of our early humorists instead of the son of a non-conformist preacher of Staffordshire, England.

THIS novel might be subtitled "Why Men Leave Kansas." It is a saga in reverse, heart-rending and all too familiar in these troubled years: the story of the average farmer, hopelessly outdistanced by the march of the machine.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The Admiralty announced today that British submarines, operating in highly dangerous waters, have smashed an Axis effort to reinforce their slender garrisons holding Bizerte, Tunis and Tripoli, Tripolitania.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The government described today as "purely hypothetical" the request of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey for an opinion from Federal Judge William F. Smith whether it might negotiate agreements with other companies for the use of its catalytic refining processes.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The British people will soon see specially designed locomotives built in the United States running over British railroad systems.

Preparatory to the graduation of 1,100 midshipmen on Wednesday, the entire Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School, 2,500 strong, passed in review yesterday morning on South Field, Columbia University, after awards of swords and watches to four members of the graduating class.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade today was unusually heavy for the end of a week because of fairly general buying based on a combination of overnight developments which induced professional operators and commission houses to act with much less caution than has been shown recently.

A JUMP rebid is not defined as forcing unless it is made in a "new suit," that is, a suit which has not previously been bid. In the following situation, South's three-heart rebid shows strength, but may be passed:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The country is shoveling bituminous coal into its furnaces faster it than it can build stockpiles, Harold L. Ickes, Solid Fuels Coordinator, reported today, though reserves on hand in October were the largest of all time.
Youths who will go down to the seas as officers of the expanding merchant marine are being trained by the hundreds at the new United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I.

DISTINCTIVELY different from the ordinary run of Westerns, this is a story of a Wild West show. In the skillful hands of Bennett Foster the performers in it are shown as flesh-and-blood human beings, and the tale of their actions and reactions becomes perfectly credible and mounts in cumulative and absorbing interest.

AGNES HUNT, frail and crippled, persisted in a nurse's training under conditions which were themselves very difficult in England half a century ago. She was the prime founder and moving spirit of the Bas-church Orthopedic Hospital (now renamed with "Agnes Hunt" as part of its official title), with its 300 beds, after-care organization and orthopedic clinics in eight counties, and of the scarcely less important and even more daringly novel Derwen Cripples Training College.

Three methods by which the eating of meats can be reduced, in line with the voluntary rationing whereby no person is to eat more than 2 1/2 pounds a week, are outlined, and recipes for substitute dishes given, in a government pamphlet of which the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office will distribute 2,000,000 copies throughout the city, beginning this week.

The Heisman Memorial Trophy, awarded annually to the college football player who, in the opinion of sports writers and radio broadcasters, is foremost, in the nation, goes this year to Frank Sinkwich, the University of Georgia's great halfback.

TO present an adequate picture of the blithe, careless quality of Ogden Nash's rib-tickling poems one would have to be another Ogden Nash -- and he is sui generis. He takes his fellow man, and woman, apart in his new collection of vivacious verse -- the first in four years -- with engaging cheerfulness and an insight into their foibles that is almost uncanny.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Like the Vichy radio, believed here to have been completely under German control all along, the German domestic broadcasts in the last twenty-four hours have told in graphic detail of the suicide of the French Navy at Toulon; and the Frankfort station, speaking in German, said the Nazis had been able to board and save "only a few" of the coveted French warships.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Two touchdowns by Joe Bavosa in the second half and fine play by Frank Di Buono and Frankie Hogg featured as Isaac Young High beat the Alpert Leonard eleven by 15 -- 0 today.

THE service man knows what he likes and why he likes it. And when it comes to women's fashions, he knows what he doesn't like and makes no bones about the reasons. He may come from Grand Island, Neb., but he knows that "bangs are old-fashioned." Kokomo, Ind., may be his home town but out there "those strapless jobs are out of style now."

The benefit concert of the Bagby Music Lovers' Foundation, to be given the afternoon of Dec. 14 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, has received such a large advance subscription that only a few floor boxes and parquet seats remain for disposal, it has been announced by George L. Bagby, president of the foundation.

A RECORD of family pleasures and problems shared in affection and loyalty, this story of a year in a mining community of Northern Michigan brings to children of 8 to 12 a picture of the life which the foreign-born of many nationalities are making for themselves in America.

In Topics of The Times recently, the writer hit the nail on the head in his witty criticism of our Arabists. In their efforts to reproduce the sounds of certain Arabic letters, they have succeeded only in creating confusion in the minds of those who are not familiar with the Arabic language, and have not helped those who know Arabic.

Strong in comedy and with a star-studded cast of 120 talented figure skaters who have played before more than a half-million spectators since September, the Ice Follies of 1943 will open a ten-day stand in Madison Square Garden Tuesday night.

Special quantity discounts on war contracts were advocated yesterday by the Eddy-Rucker-Nickels Company, management and sales counsel, Cambridge, Mass., as a solution to the problem of renegotiation of contracts when unforeseeable increases in volume and not high prices have boomed earnings far above their pre-war normal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Colorado gold miners asked government officials today for a quick decision on their appeal from the War Production Board shutdown order, asserting that economic chaos faced the Cripple Creek mining district if its workings were closed.

FIRST of all, France! The German night has swallowed up the country. For a time we were still able to know a little about those we love; we could still send them words of affection, even if we could not share the wretched bread on their tables. From afar we could catch their breathing.

This Winter civilians skiing for fun will be joined by men and women in uniform skiing to develop physical stamina for strenuous jobs. Stories of trained skiers who have accomplished outstanding rescue work in this war have given impetus to the sport, and pictures of white-clad troops traveling over rough terrain have pricked the imagination.
LONDON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

WITH AN AMERICAN TANK UNIT, Advancing on Tunis, Nov. 25 (Delayed) -- As dive-bombers attacked Allied columns at Medjez-el-Bab, less than thirty-five miles from Tunis, this column of United States tanks roared into action to break through the last center of German opposition this side of Tunis.

MICHAEL MYERBERG, if pressed, would probably say that Mr. and Mrs. Antrobus's survival of the Ice Age was a song and dance compared to his own. He would be thinking, of course, of the misadventures that preceded his production of "The Skin of Our Teeth," Thornton Wilder's superfantasia now making them scream with delight and squirm with anguish over on Forty-fifth Street.

For years I tried raising peach-leaved bellflowers (Campanula persicifolia), but rarely got them to bloom. Lingering from year to year, making good growth during the Summer, they failed to Winter in good condition. To cover or not to cover, that was the question. Covered, the leaves were subject to decay, while uncovered, the milky leaves and delicate roots were subject to frost action.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Navy Department communique 204:

In today's Magazine Antoine de Saint-Exupery addresses a letter "To Frenchmen Everywhere." He reminds them that the Vichy episode is over. Disputes and divisions about the proper attitude that should have been maintained by the French people to the Vichy regime have now no reason for existence.

When Jim Silver, variously known as "Arizona Jim," "Silvertip." or "Silver," received an invitation from his old enemy Steve Wycombe to do a job of "the sort of hell fire that you prefer to breathe," he accepted it "as a prospector in a land of trouble, with a chance of a rich strike of danger straight ahead."

With last week's 21-21 tie with the Packers indicating that they finally have arrived as a full-fledged football team, the Giants will clash with the Cardinals at the Polo Grounds today at 2:30 P.M. There will be a revenge motif to this fray for the Giants since the Cards upset them, 10 to 7, a year ago.
IN its Nov. 8th issue, THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review gave an exceptionally large amount of space to a review of Prince Starhemberg's "Between Hitler and Mussolini."

Fourteen major national organizations of women throughout the country have in preparation a plan for merging their energies in a united appeal for complete utilization of womanpower is the war effort -- a goal which they feel is not yet even in sight.

CONTEMPORARY American art is being brought forward in a big way just now. A few of the regular large annuals about town, current or spent, have already been recorded here, among them the meritorious show of prints, drawings and architecture at the National Academy (closes at 5 P.M. today).

Beethoven: Symphony No. 8, in F. New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra conducted by Bruno Walter. (Columbia M-525, three twelve-inch records.) Mr. Walter's way with Beethoven is honest and heartfelt, and he and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony play the joyous symphony with an unpretentiousness that helps to project its flavor.

FRIEDRICH SCHORR will probably appear only once this season at the Metropolitan. It will be a "farewell" performance. The singer has been trying to retire for the last three years, and has agreed to come back this season only to say good-bye.

Leading engineers and industrialists, including hundreds of those who are now forging America's weapons for victory, will participate in the sixty-third annual convention of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, one of the Big Four among the national "Founder Societies" in engineering, which opens here tomorrow at the Hotel Astor.

THE present wave of "uniformed" weddings has produced a new group of young Americans -- the "suitcase brides." Their clothes, cosmetics and all their worldly goods come out of a single suitcase -- and must be ready to go back at a moment's notice. The cosmetics they demand, as do innumerable other active women, must keep them pretty as the proverbial picture and add a bit of charm to strange surroundings.

NEW KENSINGTON, Pa., Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- John Haser, business agent of Local No. 2, Aluminum Workers of America (C.I.O.), said today that the union would take a strike vote at the Aluminum Company of America plant here Friday unless women workers received the same wages as men.

LAKE CHARLES, La., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Clutching a tiny crucifix, Mrs. Annie Beatrice (Toni Jo) Henry, 26, of Shreveport, La., was executed in the electric chair here at 12:12 P.M. today for the murder of J.P. Calloway, a man who had befriended her.

AMONG forty-eight American Commonwealths none is more distinctive in the initial pattern than the last State to be carved from the Louisiana Purchase and the most populous ever admitted to the Union. The uniqueness and complexity of Oklahoma's short history grow directly out of the all-pervading fact of its Indian origin.

Mrs. John Henry Hammond will give a tea tomorrow at her home, 9 East Ninety-first Street, for members of the women's committee assisting with plans for the performance of the Ice Follies on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, which will be a benefit for the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Reemployment "immediately" of seven members of Jehovah's Witnesses who were discharged last December by the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company of Clarksburg, W. Va., for refusing to participate in a flag-raising ceremony, was ordered today by the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The first wounded American soldiers to return from North Africa have arrived at Walter Reed Hospital here, the War Department announced today.

A feature of the Treasury's Bond Wagon program over the Mutual network last night was the singing of Kent Cooper's "America Needs You," by Earl Wrightson, baritone, who a few years ago was a page and guide employed by the National Broadcasting Company.

Retail trade was brisk last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, with all gift departments busy, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Toy departments were crowded, while main floors and basements were active.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Frederick M. Tobin, president of the Rochester Packing Company, announced today merger of the company with the Albany Packing Company and the Tobin Packing Company, Fort Dodge, Iowa.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 28 -- The Mexican Government appealed yesterday to the railroad workers to cooperate in eliminating waste and corruption and in rendering more efficient the operation of the national railways.
DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Emery Nix returned to the firing line today to pass Texas Christian to a 14-6 decision over Southern Methodist in a Southwest Conference game.

REFERENCE to the "Bombshell" group in connection with the recent exhibition by several of that organization's members (The Hetero Painters, at the Pinacotheca) has brought communications from Fred Buchholz and others to the effect that the "Bombshell" group is very much alive, not "erstwhile," and looking forward to an exhibition in January.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN CHINA, Nov. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- American airmen, making their first night dive-bombing assault on the Japanese in China, set the Yangtze dock area aflame at Hankow and scored hits on a gunboat and big river steamer early today.

Last Friday morning, in the dark hours just beyond midnight, a large part of the French fleet in Toulon Harbor was destroyed by explosion and flame -- sacrificed by its French crews to prevent the Germans from laying hands on it.
RENO, Nev., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Tom M. Girdler, the Cleveland steel manufacturer, was divorced by Mrs. Lillian S. Girdler at a private hearing today.

At the Northwestern University conference on "College Women and the War" I led an informal discussion on the needs of the Waves and Waacs as they applied to college-trained women, asking for questions from the audience, which consisted of representatives of approximately one hundred institutions where women are being educated.
ROCKFORD, Ill., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Illinois closed its most successful football season since 1934 today with an easy 20-0 victory over Camp Grant before 5,000 fans.

The fighting has been hard in New Guinea, the great strategic island that screens Australia's northern shore. Last week it was getting harder. American and Australian troops, pressing the Japanese back against the northeast coast of the island's long dragon-tail, had battled through one of the world's worst jungles against a foe who had proved his worth as a jungle fighter.

"RIVERS OF GLORY" is the third volume of a projected series of four historical novels in which F. Van Wyck Mason sets himself to describe the effect of the American Revolution upon the lives of the maritime people of the Thirteen Colonies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- In the perspective of the time that has elapsed since our last naval victory over Japan in the Solomon Islands, it is apparent that the power of our enemy in the Pacific has been clipped but not yet crippled in telling fashion.

The Putnam Avenue trolley line in Brooklyn, discontinued on Sept. 21, 1941, is scheduled to resume operations today. Thereby is reversed a trend in the history of the city's transport. Over the past twenty years the trolley lines that once laced the town's streets have been slowly, one by one, passing out of existence.

The natives of the Solomon Islands are listed among the most primitive of the earth's peoples, and the strangest in their tribal ways. Their ruling passion, according to the authoritative American Museum of Natural History, is to amass vast wealth in the form of pigs, taro root, coconuts, breadfruit and shell money, all for the purpose of throwing a party so lavish that the neighbors will be astonished and ever thereafter humbled.

THE Pacific is now in the limelight of the news. We think of naval battles, bombings and Japs when we read of the Solomon Islands, Rabaul, New Guinea and Java. But this is only a passing phase, fortunately!

An immense audience took keen delight in the Metropolitan performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor" yesterday afternoon. The principal reasons for this approval, one believes, lay primarily in three things: in Miss Pons's singing of the Mad Scene, which was far more brilliant and sure than at any previous moment, in Jan Peerce's smooth and mellifluous delivery of Edgardo's music; and, by no means least, the prevailing charm and style of Donizetti's music.

Salesmen of manufacturers and wholesalers, released by their companies because of lack of merchandise to sell, are being sought by retailers who are faced with a serious loss of help, personnel directors disclosed last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Emphatic assertion that "there is no employment of unnecessary personnel" in their plants was made in letters from the Bell Aircraft Corporation and the Curtiss-Wright Corporation's Airplane Division, both of Buffalo, N.Y., made public here by Senator Mead.

A FEW days after the Department of Commerce had estimated last week that Christmas trade might run 6 per cent in dollar volume over the 1941 peak, there was the Federal Reserve report that department store sales for the week ended Nov. 21 had jumped 30 per cent over the corresponding week of last year.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the board of trustees of the United Seamen's Service and War Shipping Administrator, last week appointed Homer L. Ferguson, president and chairman of the board of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, as chairman of the shipbuilders' division in the United Seamen's Service campaign for $6,000,000.

THE Violin Teachers Guild of New York, organized exactly a year ago, has already enrolled sixty-five members and organized two string orchestras -- a Junior Violin Ensemble, with ages from 8 to 14, and a Senior String Orchestra, which is being conducted by Leon Barzin and being organized as a preparatory unit for the National Orchestral Association.
ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 28 -- Georgia heard sweet music today -- a brass band blaring "California, Here I Come!" and followed it to a New Year's Day engagement in Pasadena's Rose Bowl.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission will meet this year's goal of 8,000,000 tons of new ship-carrying capacity, Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, its vice chairman, predicted today.

Bus travel is another commodity that is feeling the double strain of war -- increased demand and decreased supply. Assigned to the wartime role of filling the gap left by withdrawal of passenger automobiles, and also called upon to supplement the railroads in the all-important task of carrying war workers and men of the armed services, bus lines everywhere are operating on an extra-duty schedule.

IT is obvious that of two opponents within effective range of each other, possessing weapons with which they can instantly destroy each other, the one who aims and fires first will survive. Should one of the two adopt some method of concealment or disguise to increase his chance of survival, or become, as Dr. Hugh Cott says, "clothed in the armor of light," he would employ the science of camouflage.

MISS THOMPSON'S new book is most valuable for its refutation of the notion that a Utopia cannot be realistic. False realism has probably caused more misfortune than any other attitude. I call false realism the belief that the world is entirely governed by economic, political, geographic and ethnographic necessity, and that human feelings and instincts, hatred, love, egoism and altruism are unimportant.

Many boxes and seats have been sold for the benefit piano recital to be given by Rudolf Serkin on Tuesday at Carnegie Hall. The event will aid the educational department of the Women's Trade Union League, which maintains for industrial men and women workers classes designed to create a better understanding of the peoples and war aims of the United Nations, through courses in sociology, economics and current reading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The French Navy's dying defiance of Hitler in sinking its ships at Toulon rather than surrender them to the Nazis lent incomparably dramatic emphasis to what the successful attacks by the Russians near Stalingrad and the developing battle for Tunisia had already shown -- that Hitler's Reich now stands in an essentially defensive position whatever local offensive thrusts it may yet prove capable of making.

Mayor La Guardia was criticized yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., for permitting John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, to maintain an "unjust and reactionary labor policy" in the operation of the city's unified transit lines.

I AM known in my chosen profession, not entirely with reverence, as The Beard, I regard this sobriquet as an accolade. I regard the beard itself in a somewhat crasser light, as an economic asset. Also it enhances my beauty.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 28 -- Paced by Billy Hillenbrand's running and bullet passes, Indiana romped to a 51-0 victory over Fort Knox today before 5,000 fans.

WHEN Franklin Walker wrote the one and only biography of Frank Norris in 1932 the Californian novelist had been dead for over thirty years. It has taken another ten to bring out a critical account and, although Mr. Marchand's "Frank Norris -- A Study" is not always an inspiring book, it is, on historical grounds alone, a sufficiently welcome one.

WHEREAS most great rivers have small beginnings, the St. Lawrence is great from the start. Other great northern rivers may flow through scenes of savage grandeur but are inhospitably empty of the warmth and dignity of long settled, place loving humanity.

THIS is a story of Honolulu and Pearl Harbor and of the few days immediately preceding Dec. 7. 1941. It is fiction, of course, but it presents a stirring picture of those days when Japan was merely a potential enemy and when few believed that it would ever dare to attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A recommendation that the War Labor Board establish maximum wage rates for more than 50,000 skilled tool and die workers in plants in the Detroit six-county metropolitan area was made today by William E. Simkin, special WLB representative, who said the move would prevent "pirating" of labor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Acting under its new policy of curtailing the use of materials for construction projects, the War Production Board has ordered immediate stoppage of all work incidental to the construction and equipment of the $45,000,000 expansion of the Continental Ordnance plant at Hammond, Ind.

Miss Emma Converse Davis, chairman of the debutante committee of the benefit performance of "The Pirate" at the Martin Beck Theatre which will aid the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will give a dinner tomorrow night before the event at the home of her mother, Mrs. Walter E. Davis, 825 Fifth Avenue, for her aides.

WITH the shooting day growing ever shorter, compressing outdoor photographic activity to only a few daylight hours, the photographer will find in back-lighted effects the means for stretching his daylight opportunities to the limit.

HERE is a thumping story, though it has none of the horrid earmarks of the Alger-type climb. Zora Neale Hurston has a considerable reputation as anthropologist and writer. When her autobiography begins she was one of eight children in a Negro family with small prospects of making a name for herself.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Two officers and two enlisted men, who braved death to rescue wounded crewmen from the blazing wreckage of a bomb-loaded plane that had crashed at a New Guinea airport, have received Soldiers' Medals, General Douglas MacArthur announced today.

As a result of the induction of many of its male orchestral players into the armed forces, about 25 per cent of the personnel of the Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra will consist of women musicians this season.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Liverpool, unbeaten until a week ago, when Southport scored a 3-2 upset, gained revenge today in a Northern League football game, downing Southport by 6 -- 2 before a crowd of 25,000 at Liverpool.

COMMENTING on German radio organization in Holland, London reports that Dutch broadcasters have been ordered to submit musical programs to Nazi authorities two weeks in advance because the Dutch have been slipping in too many recordings of American and British war songs.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 -- The Tigers announced today the dismissal of Del Baker as manager and the appointment of Steve O'Neill, former Indians' pilot, as his successor to head an entirely new board of strategy.

Verdi's "Aida," at its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan last night, was conducted by Cesare Sodero, who made his initial appearance with the company. Under his knowing leadership the presentation would have prospered notably, had he been fortunate enough to have the sort of cooperation on stage he received from the musicians in the orchestra pit.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY IN MOROCCO, Nov. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- The American Army brought along its own radio station and is believed to have been the first to use a powerful long-wave transmitter during landing operations in an attempt to calm the local population and enlist aid.

The end of the war will not bring an end to the Jewish problem but will only open up to fuller view its gravity, complexity and scope, Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the World Zionist Organization and of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declared yesterday in a message to the convention of Junior Hadassah.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (Science Service ) -- Paratroopers sometimes become casualties before they get a chance to go into action, through spraining their ankles or otherwise injuring their feet -- and the bigger and huskier the soldier the harder the jolt with which he ends his drop.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP) -- George McAfee threw 'em and Marty O'Hagan caught 'em today as the Jacksonville Naval Air Station Fliers turned back the Duke Blue Devils, 13 to 0, before a crowd of 7,500.

Discussing the limitation on salaries imposed under executive order by James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, made the observation that the Treasury Department has been permitted in the past to fix what it considered a reasonable salary for an employe which would be deductible by a corporation as a business expense in computing its taxable income.

HAM CYLINDERS are made by trimming the crusts from enriched bread, spreading each slice with deviled ham and bundling up, jelly-roll fashion. Brushing the outside with melted butter or margarine and toasting until golden brown are the final gestures.

TUCKED away amid soap operas some rather startling music comes out of the Columbia Broadcasting System at odd times in the morning and afternoon. It is the new music of Raymond Scott, a band composed of top-flight instrumentalists, preponderantly Negro.

Joseph Barth, a 20-year-old sophomore at George Washington University, entered the offices of his brother-in-law, Dr. Jerome Meadow, a dental surgeon, at 203 East Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday morning, and shot and seriously wounded him.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Three bullets, fired today by Miss Florence Ferrara, 29, who said later she believed that she was slaying an impostor, killed Dr. Marion L. Klinefelter, a noted bone surgeon.

The systematic theft of durable goods valued at $250,000 from the Long Island City warehouse of Bloomingdale's Department Store was disclosed yesterday by the police following the arrest of two $45-a-week clerks, the alleged ringleaders of a gang of warehouse employes, truckmen and small storekeepers who had profited from the venture since 1938.

"Stars Shine for Young America'' is the appropriate title chosen for a gala four-hour program of entertainment to be presented at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 15 on behalf of the Police Athletic League's Juvenile Aid Bureau, to advance its work among New York City's underprivileged children.

Autumn ends, not by the calendar, but by the season itself. The leaves are gone, save those few parched hangers-on that will cling the Winter through to twigs of oak and beech and ironwood. The weeds have ripened and their pods are empty. A few jays remain, and the earliest juncoes are dropping in; but even they speak softly now.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 28 -- A new weapon to fight the burns of war will soon be added to the surgeon's tools.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY, at Fedhala, French Morocco, Nov. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- The German members of the Axis armistice commission captured by the United States Army in Morocco are on their way to the United States as prisoners of war it was disclosed today.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Kansas State roared over Nebraska, 19 to 0, today to drop the Cornhuskers into third place in the final Big Six football standings and to take over the leadership of the second division.

Appointment of six automotive specialists, who will aid dealers and repair stations in procuring parts, tools and equipment and otherwise help get the maximum use out of passenger cars and trucks, was announced yesterday by John F. McKernan, regional deputy director of the War Production Board.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Charles Michelson, 73, publicity chief of the Democratic National Committee for thirteen years, has fired his last verbal barrage at the Republican Party, he says.
The contest for a violin concerto by a Latin-American composer sponsored by the music division of the Pan American Union has been won by Camargo Guarnieri of Brazil, it was announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A special communique:

ORDINARILY a war romance author who doubles as narrator and central figure of his story weakens it by eliminating a main factor of suspense: the reader is denied a single apprehensive tremor over the fate of a protagonist who manifestly survived every peril.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 28 -- Through the Nazi-controlled Norwegian press the Germans have launched a new phase in their war of nerves against Sweden, which is again called a "bastion of international Jewry and plutocracy."

DIOGENES searching for an honest man had nothing on the poor American correspondent seeking something or some place typically Indian. Even Gandhi, when he wanted to settle down, could not do any better than to choose the geographical center of India, just outside Wardha.

Commander William H. Lee, U.S.N.R., who recently left his post as assistant general manager of the United States Lines and is now on active duty, has been promoted on the reserve list to the rank of captain, according to word received by the company last week.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Nov. 29 (Sunday) (U.P.) -- A mixed force of American and Australian ground troops has smashed back a Japanese counter-attack south of Buna while enemy naval forces, apparently intending to relieve Japan's critical situation on New Guinea's north shore, manoeuvred off the coast, General Douglas MacArthur reported today.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 28 (AP) -Little Tulsa, only major undefeated and untied football team in the nation, accepted a bid to the Sugar Bowl today with a big grin. Squad members yelled approval as Coach Henry Frnka asked if they wanted to go.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 28 -- Michigan unfurled its vaunted gridiron might, mixed it with cunning and marched over an ever-battling Iowa football eleven for a 28-to-14 Western Conference triumph before 20,643 spectators today.

Restaurants, hotels and institutions have been directed by the Office of Price Administration to keep detailed records of the amounts of food used and the number of persons served during the month of December, it was announced last night by the Office of War Information.

LOWELL MELLETT, Chief of the Motion-Picture Bureau of the Office of War Information, came to Hollywood last week following his public plea for elimination of the double feature, met with producers and discussed the matter with them, but found, as far as can be determined, that the protestations of the film industry against the evil are empty talk.

THE man in Washington who might have more reason than almost any one else for satisfaction over the outcome of our Vichy policy is William D. Leahy, our Ambassador to France during what was known in some quarters as the appeasement period Admiral Leahy contributed to the success of that policy more perhaps than any other man by his cool, disillusioned conduct of an office for which he had little experience and less inclination.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Carrying with them the spirit and letter of our Good-Neighbor policy, as well as the word and spirit of Christianity, 100 priests of Maryknoll are now on their way to the remotest jungles, mountains and plains of Central and South America, it was disclosed here today.

The recent revelation of a program of systematic extermination of the Jews in Poland brought forth last night the condemnation of Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, in an address at the opening session of the annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine at Carnegie Hall.

When you talk about a 'WOW" you may be referring to a member of the Women's Ordnance Workers, but hereafter you will also be correct in using the abbreviation when speaking of affiliates of the newly organized Washington (D.C.) Outdoor Writers group.

Five hundred young persons, including one hundred student officers, attended the first of this season's Mayfair Assemblies, a series of dances for debutantes and post-debutantes and for young men in the armed forces, which was held last night in the Penthouse Suite and the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

THE subtitle of this animated and informing book is The Story of an Insect Garden. To those who have thought of a garden only as a sanctuary for the plant world -- to be cultivated for the glory of its bloom and the sweetness of its fragrance -- a horticultural undertaking dedicated to the interests of the insects may seem bizarre and perhaps even shocking.
The opening of an exhibit sponsored by the United States Secret Service to teach the public how to detect counterfeit money produced immediate action yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Statements concerning the inventory situation in scrap dealers' yards are being investigated by the government, it was said today by Lessing J. Rosenwald, director, Conservation Division, and H.G. Batcheller, director, Steel Division, WPB.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 -- Notre Dame beat Southern California, arch football rival, in a rough and bruising game today that ended in a free-for-all between some of the players and a large group of spectators.

Since June 1, 1941, at least 7,000 nurses' aides have been trained under the auspices of the American Red Cross in 159 hospitals of New York State but many more are needed, it was revealed yesterday by Miss Margaret C. Arnstein, State nursing officer, in report to Major John J. Bourke, deputy chief of emergency medical services for the Health Preparedness Commission of the State War Council.

THE author of this book of adventure is a mining engineer, and its principal subject is his wilderness journey to the "lost world of Venezuela," the plateau of Auyan-Tepui. But although the long unmapped fortress of Nature -- 300 square miles in area, 8,000 feet high -- forms the core of the whole narrative, it is hardly necessary to point out that Mr. Dennison met with a variety of excitements in all his jungle treks.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Commander John E. Whelchel, Navy football coach who was pessimistic all week about his team's chances of beating Army, did not say anything to his players today after their victory.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 -- The shortage of automobile mechanics is caused by misguided draft boards and misguided Federal employment officials, according to V.E. Doonan, head of the Ford Motor Company parts and service department.

By way of Switzerland comes word that Norway released three stamps in June to mark the centenary of the death of Rikard Nordraak (1842-1866), one of Norway's most brilliant musicians and the composer of his country's national anthem, "Ja, Vi Elsker," which he scribbled on an envelope while at Berlin in 1862.

Approximately 100,000,000 yards of textile fabrics, chiefly cottons plus some spun rayons, will be siphoned by A-2 ratings from civilian apparel trades to assure a sufficient stockpile of serviceable war-work garments for the estimated 7,000,000 women needed in 1943 to keep the wheels of industry turning at high speed, it was estimated by textile men here last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Indications that official Washington has a growing appreciation of the fact that this country faces severe shortages in many types of foodstuffs about the turn of the year and through most of 1943 were apparent this week.
SOME notes on a talk with Somerset Maugham, very random, since the novelist was putting out more questions than he could be asked and the topics were about one a minute:

MUCH has been heard about the wartime need for keeping the country's radio sets operating, and what might happen if big shortages occurred in vacuum tubes, condensers, volume-control units and the like. Despite the fact that shortages in such things have been widely reported by radio dealers and distributors, they are, in the main, almost non-existent.

HAVING received their seasoning under fire in beach landings and subsequent actions in Morocco and Algiers and having advanced to the borders of Tunisia, the American troops in North Africa are preparing for further action.

Public and private welfare agencies have an important role to play not only in wartime but in helping to prevent a recurrence of the vast army of unemployed of the depression era, Commissioner of Welfare William Hodson declared yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- The University of Georgia Bulldogs tonight had football's greatest plum in their pockets -- an invitation to represent the East in the traditional New Year's Day Rose Bowl game against a Pacific Coast opponent who won't be decided until Dec. 12.

LENA HORNE is a light brown, soft-spoken, young Negress who came to Hollywood straight from Brooklyn, the Cotton Club. Noble Sissle's band and Care Society, Downtown. Naturally, no one out here ever heard of her.

BENGAZI, Libya, Nov. 26 (delayed) -- Probably never before has one been made so aware of propaganda while privileged at the same time to examine as it were behind the show window and thus see for one's self the collapse of those very values that propaganda sought to exalt.

Directors of the St. Louis Public Service Company authorized yesterday dividends of 75 cents each on the class A and class B stocks, payable on Dec. 15. These are the first dividends by the new company since termination of reorganization proceedings on Nov. 16, 1939, when the concern was returned to private management.

Peace shares extended yesterday their gains in a New York Exchange market which drifted irregularly and closed mixed. Volume was 283,190 shares, and of the 646 issues traded 218 fell, 208 rose and 220 held even.

THE general public is more familiar with the symphonic and operatic works of most composers than with their chamber music. While it may be that chamber music is regarded as a more recondite branch of art, the truth is that the average listener -- if there be such a happy soul -- does not have much opportunity to hear chamber music.
BOSTON, Sunday, Nov. 29 -- More than 300 persons had perished early this morning in flames, smoke and panic in the Cocoanut Grove Night Club in the midtown theatre district.

ONE of the most thoughtful and suggestive books we have had on the problems arising out of this war is Raoul de Roussy de Sales's "The Making of Tomorrow." It was reviewed in these columns last April.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 28 (UP) -- The Georgia Pre-Flight eleven completely outplayed Alabama's Crimson Tide for three periods today and then hung on grimly against a late rally to defeat the Southeastern Conference team, 35 to 19, before a slim crowd of 7,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The movement for assuring equal pay for women when their work is of comparable quality and quantity with that performed by men received a distinct impetus this week in a general order by the War Labor Board.

CHARLES COURTNEY first made use of his lock-picking gift at the age of 7: a little matter of jam in the pantry. But when he was in the marines he opened a safe for the glory of the service, and won high praise from the commander.

"Just the sort of man who would take such action," was the way an American Navy officer yesterday summed up Admiral Jean de la Borde of the French Navy, who scuttled the French Fleet in the harbor of Toulon rather than have the vessels fall into German hands.

DURING the night of April 9. 1940, the Germans struck a blow at the Norwegian city of Narvik in the Arctic. The place had become famous as the terminus of the ore railway from the iron range of Sweden across the frontier and as the most important ice-free ore port of Scandinavia.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Nineteen more Czechs have been executed, it was announced in Prague today, according to reports from the German frontier received here. Their deaths bring to ninety-one the number said to have been killed in the last ten days.
The victories of the United Nations in North Africa and the heroic action of the French in scuttling their fleet at Toulon were hailed yesterday in sermons in synagogues.

The sweeping victories which the United Nations have been scoring on various war fronts have stimulated business interest in post-war planning, with the result that scores of companies, which previously felt it was untimely to talk about such programs, are now rapidly undertaking them, reports last week from executives indicated.

TO many operagoers Emannuel List is known only as the well-established Austrian basso who came to this country from Berlin in 1933 and has been singing important Wagnerian and Strauss roles at the Metropolitan Opera ever since.

Two hundred photographs of bridges in New York City and vicinity and close-ups of the Panama Canal locks and United States warships, as well as the approaches to a number of Midwestern munitions plants, were seized in one of forty raids Friday night in Manhattan, P.E. Foxworth, in charge of the local offices of the Federal Bureau of investigation, announced yesterday.
