The true or hardy geraniums are excellent subjects for the perennial and even the rock garden. The indoor plants, tender plants that will not withstand Winter outdoors, are, really, pelargoniums. The hardy types are herbaceous perennials, and offer colorful effects throughout the entire Summer.

WITH THE BRITISH TROOPS IN NORTH AFRICA, Nov. 28 -- The roads to this war wind crazily across rugged mountains and desolate plateaus, each road bearing infantry and guns of all descriptions and all warlike stores of modern combat toward the Tunisian front and the final Allied onslaught on the Axis in Africa.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- A crack Red Air Force regiment, under Lieut. Col. Konstantin Katarzhin, has been operating American-built medium bombers of the North American aircraft type during the last seven months, it was revealed yesterday.

One problem which often must be met on the home front is how to provide for adequate living in limited space. Congestion, especially in defense areas, coupled with lack of new building operations, makes it necessary for many young couples -- and other young men and women -- to carry on their living activities, including eating and sleeping, in one room.
Prince and Princess Alexandre de Caraman-Chimay have come to the Pierre from Hot Springs, Va.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Despite inroads made by the Selective Service Act and an expected deficit for the fiscal year, Princeton University showed an operating profit of $55,800 for the year ended last June 30, it was announced today by George A. Brakeley, vice president and treasurer.

MR. ARTURO TORRESRIOSECO has made an important and distinguished contribution to our intrahemispheral understanding. The very marrow of a nation's racial inheritance, its creative powers, and its spiritual and intellectual life are preserved in its literature, so his book, "The Epic of Latin-American Literature,'' that gives so clear and complete a history of its growth, significance, and the influences which molded it, becomes an instrument of international rapprochement.

IN the evolution of society, historians have observed that events and situations sometimes recur in such a manner as to warrant a certain belief in their periodicity. The quickened pace of modern civilization has brought about a telescoping of the incidents upon which the theory is based.

Don Whitfield and his shipmates in the New Jersey Outboard Association will gather on Saturday evening at the Swiss Town House in Union City for what these regatta devotees choose to call their "Fourth Annual Indoor Regatta." The association's high-point trophies will be awarded for the 1942 scoring performances in the alcohol-fuel race meets held on New Jersey and Long Island waterways.

At 5:30 every afternoon Fourth Avenue and Ninety-third Street in Brooklyn has a startling visitation. Cabs screech to a stop before a small red brick building on the corner across from the branch public library. Soldiers pile out of the cars, while the neighborhood children swing around on their roller skates and nudge one another when they see a strange uniform.

Thirteen bequests to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund received during the last twelve months are acknowledged as the time approaches for the annual Christmas appeal, which will be opened in THE NEW YORK TIMES next Sunday.

Many seats have been purchased for the performance of "The Skin of Our Teeth," the comedy by Thornton Wilder, on Tuesday night at the Plymouth Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

THE education of Flip, that giddy colt -- or foal, as his creator insists he still is -- continues a-pace. Flip, it will be recalled from the first lively picture book, had mastered the art of stream-jumping, but he is now wrestling with a fear of cows.

Selecting war jobs in line with their special talents, members of the Advertising Women's Club of New York are offering their services as promotion organizers and slogan writers for authorized war drives. Their first undertaking is in cooperation with the home and rural safety program sponsored by the State War Council to curtail "nonwar" accidents.

PITTSTON, Pa., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The earth split open, houses cracked, pavements buckled and scores of families left their homes last night and early today when a settling of the surface earth over a mine spread ruin through a residential section covering a half square mile.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Nov. 15 (Delayed) -- Another round in the continuing air, sea and land battles for the lower Solomons has been won by the United States. Japan has suffered a crushing defeat.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 28 -- The first official reaction in France to the latest developments in connection with relations with Germany was to increase censorship and police measures. Popular reactions are yet to come.

French and English art treasures of the eighteenth century, donated by leading museums throughout the country as well as by many private collectors, form the basis of an exhibition to be held Dec. 19-30 at the Parke Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, as a benefit for the American Women's Voluntary Services.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Wartime controls over the cost of living have given farmers and urban labor the most favorable economic position in American history, with the farm population having made much greater economic gains than industrial workers, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, asserted today in his second quarterly report to Congress on activities of the Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Sir Stafford Cripps entered the War Cabinet after the fall of Singapore when Britain was in such a slough of despond that even Winston Churchill's leadership was being widely questioned. That he leaves it now at the first breath of victory when the Prime Minister is at the peak of his political strength has led political observers here to seek some inner significance in the rather striking coincidence.

FAMOUS beauties and great actresses have never been more eagerly pursued by photographers and reporters than are the ordinary women of today who are joined to the war effort. Candid pictures of them appear everywhere, as seen at their lathes, filling cartridges, handling cranes, saluting in new uniforms, sewing parachutes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- John P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Department, American Federation of Labor, charged today that the National Labor Relations Board was seeking "to stimulate the C.I.O." in five war production plants.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 28 -- The recent elections have had an important effect upon the political fortunes of the five men whom political observers cite most frequently as leading candidates for the Republican nomination for the Presidency in 1944.

Louis George Finch, 23 years old, of Lowell, Mass., has received the Merchant Marine Distinguished Medal, the third given since Congress authorized the award for outstanding acts of heroism, the Maritime Commission announced last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Miss Gordon first appeared on the stage as Nibs in "Peter Pan," with Maude Adams. Her motion pictures include the role of Mary Todd in "Abe Lincoln In Illinois" and Mrs. Ehrlich in "Dr. Ehrlich's Magic Bullet." She also is a contributor to magazines.
UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 28 (AP) -- President Roosevelt was urged today by the Farmers Union to create a powerful marketing authority in the New York milk shed.

If the classics are to survive as part of the educational curriculum, teachers must learn to democratize them, emphasizing the shortcomings of antiquity while interpreting the present and the future in terms of the common man, it was urged yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker at the meeting of the Classical Association of the Atlantic States by Dr. Ernest Riess of Hunter College.
MOSCOW, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 28 -- The University of Tennessee's powerful Vols clinched a spot in the Sugar Bowl game classic today by defeating a fighting but outmanned Vanderbilt football team, 19 -- 7, before a crowd of 18,000. The Vols will meet undefeated Tulsa at New Orleans Jan. 1.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Miami put a smashing end to a successful season today with a 21-to-13 victory over West Virginia in a brilliant football exhibition before 9,717 fans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Battle of Washington was fought at a furious clip on many local fronts this week. The stakes were high: civilian versus military control of the national economy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Dr. Harry N. Holmes, president of the American Chemical Society, urges the Army to make greater use of vitamin C in the treatment of shock from wounds.

The report of the Canadian Industrial Alcohol Company, Ltd., for the fiscal year ended with August disclosed yesterday a net profit of $554,860 after income and excess profits taxes of $556,879 and contingent reserve of $100,000.

The Dug Out at 235 East Fifty-second Street, a clubhouse established shortly after the First World War to aid men who had been disabled in the service, will hold a reception next Sunday to institute a new patriotic project designed to extend its services to the armed forces of all the Allied armies.

ARE your children afraid of you? If they are anything like the 12-year-olds represented in a recent study, there's a 33 1/3 per cent chance that they are. About a third of these children said they were afraid of their parents.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 28 -- What is unanimously called here the "Toulon epic" was described today as a severe setback to German plans in the Mediterranean.

I was requested some time ago by Mr. Whit Burnett to select some piece of writing, of mine for his anthology called "This Is My Best." I suggested an essay called "The Old Stone House," writing him that it "seemed to me one of my short pieces that came out best."

An increased volume of Christmas shopping featured retail trade here last week. Comparison with a year ago, however, was unfavorable as the week contained five days against six last year when Thanksgiving was a week earlier. Department store sales were estimated as running about 8 per cent under 1941.

Mayor La Guardia agreed yesterday to turn over to the government the city's household scrap metal piles for $1 and the promise of whatever profit may develop from Federal contracts with scrap dealers and steel mills that have agreed to move the accumulations into production at a faster pace than it has in the last six weeks.

THOSE who may possibly be of the opinion that dance criticism in America is a new and experimental business are hereby directed to the latest issue of Dance Index, Lincoln Kirstein's little monthly magazine, which has just put forth a triple number consisting of the dance criticisms of Carl Van Vechten.

Manufacturing executives, plant managers, production engineers and government procurement agents will constitute the principal groups in attendance at the fifteenth National Exposition of Power and Mechanical Engineering which opens tomorrow at Madison Square Garden and continues to Dec. 4.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Salary increases for all employes of the Elizabeth Police Department, including the $500-a-year members of the Board of Police Commissioners, but excluding rank-and-file patrolmen, are included in the 1943 budget sent this week to the finance committee of City Council.

About 135,000,000 inner tubes are in the hands of automotive vehicle owners, and 50,000,000 more are in the stockrooms of manufacturers and dealers ready for sale. Since each tube contains about 2.5 pounds of rubber, and consists of 68 per cent virgin rubber and therefore of the highest quality, it follows that about 277,500 tons are thus locked up.

A FORTNIGHT ago the Theatre Guild took a deep breath and in the space of four days launched the first two plays of this, its twenty-fifth season. As is customary up on Fifty-second Street, the curtains were not so late as under many a younger management, although the audiences were, and as is customary the intermissions were fierce with dissension.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Fowler McCormick, president of the International Harvester Company, announced today development of a successful mechanical cotton picker and said tests had proven it capable of doing the work of from fifty to eighty hand pickers.

TORONTO, Nov. 28 -- Toronto defeated the New York Rangers, 8 -- 6, in a wild National Hockey League game at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight and advanced into second place ahead of the idle Chicago Black Hawks.

AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Auburn's Plainsmen celebrated Homecoming Day with a 41-13 victory over Clemson today, scoring in every period in a game that was never in doubt. About 10,000 saw the fireworks.

The rush to buy liquor, whenever the Federal proof gallon tax is increased -- as lately and probably again next March -- indicates a general belief that the amount of that tax is the main element in the retail price of whisky.

The three-day annual meeting of the New Jersey State Horticultural Society will be held on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at the Walt Whitman Hotel in Camden. Among the topics to be discussed at the convention will be plans for handling farm labor problems in 1943. Special sessions are scheduled for the study of production in the coming year.

CONTRARY to the Cooper tradition, not all Indians are born brave and strong and handy with the bow, yet when the life of one's tribe depends on such qualities it is hard to be a dunderhead. So Sungi, a Cherokee boy who knew the Tennessee forests when the only white men were infrequent traders, had much to bear from his own awkwardness.

THE word story (as witness this collection) has come to include sketches and even mere fragments and might be defined as a body of words, generally from one to 10,000, purportedly fictional, or imaginative, designed to evoke an emotional response on the part of a reader.

An international agency, animated by the principles of liberty and democracy, has become an imperative necessity to keep the peace following the war, Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, said yesterday afternoon at the Opera Victory Rally that was one of the intermission features of the first Metropolitan Opera broadcast of the season.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Villanova, beaten by Detroit and Duquesne, broke out in full fury today and climaxed an indifferent football season by trouncing Temple, its arch city rival, by 20 to 7 before 20,000 in Temple Stadium.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Rice triumphed today, 20 to 0, over a strong Baylor football team that was trying to win second place in the Southwest Conference after its hopes for a championship were blasted Thursday by Texas' victory over Texas A. and M.

National leaders in America, Britain, Russia and China agreed that after the war India should be transformed into a free federation, and that the population of India shall be entitled to determine the character of its future.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A communique broadcast from Vichy tonight said that British troops, including South Africans, had landed this morning on Reunion Island, 400 miles east of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean, and that the Vichy Governor was organizing resistance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- American bombers struck damaging blows at two important Japanese bases in the Northwestern Solomon Islands this week, the Navy Department reported today. Meanwhile, American troops on Guadalcanal Island killed more Japanese west of Henderson Field and the Navy raised to eight its list of the number of Japanese warships sunk in the Battle of Cape Esperance on Oct. 11-12.

FOR fifty years Fred Gaisberg has been an important figure in the recording business. Known to several generations of musicians whom he brought to the phonograph, he is one of those behind the scenes workers of whom the general public hears little.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information midnight communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Friends of Harold L. Ickes reported tonight that he was pondering at his Maryland farm over the weekend whether to accept the combined post of Secretary of Labor and War Manpower boss.

FOR its first operatic performance, to be presented Friday, Dec. 11, and Saturday, Dec. 12, the High School of Music and Art has chosen Aaron Copland's "Second Hurricane," with libretto by Edwin Denby, which will be conducted by Alexander Richter.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- Tomorrow will be the hundredth day since the Battle of Stalingrad began. When night fell on Sunday, Aug. 23, fourteen weeks ago, a finger of smoke pointed skyward over the ruined city. It rose from the center of Stalingrad which had been blitzed all day by the Luftwaffe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- To utilize the millions of high school boys and girls throughout the country for farm work, the United States Office of Education is sponsoring a nation-wide program calling upon students to take farm jobs on week-ends, during vacation periods and in the Summer time.

THE percentage of dopes in any age seems to remain constant. And if this record is at all reliable the Eighteen Forties were no exception. In reading a book of this sort one's normal impulse is to shake his head and say.

When the first wintry blasts clear the city's parks and playgrounds of all save those hardy souls who have a dog which must be walked, or a pram which must be pushed, the Parks Department opens a program of indoor activities.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28 -- A powerful Ohio State football team with abundance of speed and deception outclassed the vaunted Iowa Seahawks, 41 to 12, today before 27,259 fans.
IN a concise novel Owen Elford, nom de plume of an Austrian playwright, tells about the European underground movement and its courageous struggle behind the backs of Hitler's Gestapo men.

All the boxes have been sold for the benefit concert to be given jointly by the Yale Glee Club and the Sarah Lawrence College Chorus next Saturday night in the Town Hall. The concert will be the only New York appearance of the two groups, and probably the last for the Yale unit for the duration because of the accelerated schedule at the university.

A city library somewhere in the Middle West is the scene of the first murder in this book, and a young assistant librarian, Linda Ware, nearly becomes the second victim when she discovers the body. By the time the police arrive the body has disappeared, and Linda is believed to be suffering from fright after falling over a chair and bumping her head.

While much of the recent public discussion of post-war problems in this country has been concerned with larger aspects of international organization and even with the disposition of the British Empire, the trend in Britain seems to be toward greater concern with domestic economic questions.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill will make a world-wide broadcast at 9 P.M. [4 P.M. Eastern War Time] tomorrow on the eve of his sixty-eighth birthday.

Warnings against the loss of the peace through abrogation of civil liberties were voiced yesterday by speakers at a luncheon of the National Lawyers Guild in the Hotel Roosevelt. Declaring that favorable war news is stirring into action dormant forces of reaction which subscribe to "a people's war but not a people's peace," the speakers called for careful guarding of democratic freedoms in the closing period of the war.
Coffee rationing goes into effect today, with purchases limited to one pound every five weeks for persons over 15 years old.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- A new effort to reopen the way to settlement of India's internal political difficulties was under way tonight with an announcement that an all-party conference had been called for Dec. 12 by Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru, Hindu liberal leader.

Although the extent of women's clubs' participation in the war effort remains undetermined, its scope may soon be outlined through surveys either completed or under way. The total is expected to put at rest any doubts of their whole-hearted contribution to local and national projects.

Under a program sponsored by the United States Office of Education, 225 colleges and universities throughout the country are now participating in a vast retraining project, preparing men and women who are in nonessential civilian jobs for vital war industries.

THE deadlock between the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Musicians Union has ended. The Boston orchestra, whose founder, Major Henry L. Higginson, would rather have had the orchestra pass out of existence than see it happen, has joined the union.
The destruction of units of the French Toulon Fleet, which the German radio continued to denounce yesterday as "an act of treachery" will have no effect upon the balance of world naval power.

President Carlos Arroyo del Rio of Ecuador and his official party, who will arrive in New York this morning, will be met at Grand Central Terminal by Mayor La Guardia, members of the Board of Estimate and S.E. Duran-Ballen, Ecuadorean Consul General, it was announced yesterday at City Hall.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 28 -- Editorial comment reported from Berlin today was not lacking in recrimination. It was more out-spoken even than Reichsfuehrer Hitler's impeachment of certain French military and naval cliques on the ground of sabotaging the Vichy government's alleged efforts to come to terms with Germany.

CLIFFORD C. FISCHER, theatrical producer and showman extraordinary, is seriously contemplating the opening of a new night spot on Broadway. Mr. Fischer discloses that he has all but obtained the grand ballroom of the Hotel Edison for his latest project and if the proper structural changes can be made there the club will be opened to the public by the end of next month.

HERE is a "composite portrait," which, unlike most symposiums, has unity and drive. Though concerned primarily with "Jewish living in America" and only incidentally with Jewish-Gentile relations, this analysis and evalution deserves to be read widely by non-Jews as well as by Jews.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The War Labor Board announced today creation of a Nonferrous Metals Commission to stabilize pay and labor relations for 85,00 workers in that industry to obtain maximum production and speed up decisions in disputes.

DESCRIBED as "The First American Modern," a hitherto unheralded and almost unknown painter, T. Chambers, is currently being presented at the Macbeth Gallery. For six years Albert Duveen and Norman Hirschl have been combing up-State New York for the score of pictures assembled.
BR-R-R. . . . One-third less oil for heating than last year. Don't use the gas as a substitute. Sixty-five degrees temperature in the house. It sounds ominous.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Chairmen of five Congressional Investigating Committees gave strong endorsement here tonight to the proposed merger of all manpower agencies and operations within the Department of Labor. In a joint statement, the five committee chairmen, Senators Truman, Kilgore, Murray and Pepper, and Representative Tolan, indicated that the President would have their support in his reported intention of appointing Harold L. Ickes to handle the manpower problem as Secretary of Labor.
James N. Weiss, in 170 E 77f St. M. Morgenthau-Seixas Co, broker. Paul M. Turner, Iichael D. Baldinger, Walt Mandry, Clara Tucker, in 108 E 38th St. N.A. Berwin Co, brokers.

Immature hints of peace on Monday accounted last week for a severe price recession in the cotton futures market, but a moderate volume of trade price-fixing orders following the decline won back most of the lost ground. For the week active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were mixed, 10 points higher to 36 points lower, than a week before, with the near months appreciably stronger than the distant positions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 29 -- A German officer was shot and killed by his own people yesterday at the Norwegian frontier station of Halden on the Swedish border as he and seventeen comrades jumped from a troop train carrying them back to Germany, according to an Oslo telegram to the Goeteborg Posten, widely reproduced today by Stockholm afternoon newspapers.

Your news item about the closing of all screeno and bingo games in the city by order of the Police Commissioner contains one startling and devastating statement: "On and after next Monday bingo, screeno and similar games will be allowed to operate only in churches, if conducted by the church itself, in the church hall or auditorium."

Possibly because the week's earlier decline had been overdone, possibly because of the week-end defiance of Hitler and the destruction by its own officers of the French fleet on which the Nazi dictator was evidently about to lay his hand, last week's markets ended with recovery.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- United States food-production goals for 1943, "the most crucial and important task our farmers have ever been asked to perform," were announced today by Secretary Wickard.

Joseph Szigeti was the solo artist yesterday afternoon at the sixth concert of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall. He played two of the Bach works for unaccompanied violin, the Sonata No. 2 in A minor and the Partita No. 3 in E major.

Uniformed service men and their guests, invited through the USO and the headquarters of various Army posts and Navy bases, will attend a special free performance of Ice Follies of 1943 in Madison Square Garden tonight. The public will not be admitted.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 29 -- German forces in Italy at the end of the fourth week of November total more than 300,000, including Elite Guards and special police troops, but excluding upward of 90,000 Gestapo and civil agents and administrators, this correspondent was told by foreign military men in Istanbul.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (ONA) -- The Brazzaville [Fighting French] radio on Friday characterized the War Department's acceptance of Archduke Otto von Habsburg's collaboration in the creation of an Austrian battalion as "exactly like" Lieut. Gen. Dwight P. Eisenhower's deal with Admiral Jean Francois Darlan, it was disclosed today in monitoring reports of the Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service.

Playing in daring fashion with the white pieces, which were triumphant for the fifth time, Samuel Reshevsky yesterday regained the lead in his match with Isaac I. Kashdan, arranged to break their tie in the last national chess championship tournament.

A special service at Temple Emanu-El yesterday afternoon commemorated the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, which together with the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities, initiated its second wartime appeal since its foundation in 1917.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings poured five shots past Goalie Paul Bibeault in the first period and went on to beat the Montreal Canadiens, 7 to 3, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 10,294 spectators. The victory maintained Detroit's grip on the league lead.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- A smashing blow was delivered at Turin last night by a large number of British aircraft, some carrying 8,000-pound bombs to Italy for the first time.

Frederick Brown, the operator, has added to his holdings of Brooklyn real estate by purchasing the six-story elevator apartment building at 770 Ocean Avenue, near the corner of Cortelyou Road, for cash over a purchase money first mortgage of $159,500 due in 1950 at 4 per cent.
MOSCOW, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- Neutral Sweden enters the fourth Winter of the war with plenty to eat -- at high prices -- and clothing enough to stave off any real hardship.

Earnings of consumer goods industries in the first nine months of 1942 have fared remarkably well in the light of rising tax requirements and other costs. The combined net profit of fifty companies in this field amounted to $114,727, 203 for the nine months, against $143,541,242 last year, a decline of $28,800,000, or 20 per cent.
MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

Urging Federal legislation to enable the President and the Secretaries of War and Navy to use the Federal law enforcement agencies to deal with the problems of drinking near military establishments or war industries, the executive committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America made public yesterday a resolution adopted by the council.

One of the noteworthy beauty discoveries of the year is a new creme-shampoo that is not a soap but a lathering lotion. Designed originally as a sort of conditioner to precede a permanent wave, the rich, rose-petal cream speedily whips the hair into a state of silky cleanliness.

Bingo and similar games of chance will be barred in churches as well as in motion picture houses and the rooms of fraternal organizations, if Police Commissioner Valentine follows a broad ruling laid down yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in his weekly radio "Talk to the People."
Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's broadcast from London yesterday as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- A special Soviet High Command communique:

On Saturday evening, while the presses were rolling out a headline reading "Red Army Breaks German Lines," the Studio Theatre at the New School for Social Research was telling one phase of that welcome story. The occasion was the opening of an exciting and moving play called "Winter Soldiers," the work of Dan James, who with it won this year's Sidney Howard Memorial Award from the Playwrights Company.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 29 -- History teachers from twenty-five junior colleges of California, after a two-day conference at Stanford University, recommended today that this State's junior colleges "require a course in the history of the United States for graduation."
Only four new films are sched uled to reach Broadway theatres this week. They are:

The major part of the bus mileage reduction in Manhattan that the Office of Defense Transportation had ordered to begin tomorrow will be delayed a few days because of difficulties in working out new schedules, eliminating parts of routes and dropping some service altogether, it was indicated last night.

KINGSTON, Pa., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Scranton University scored a 34-to-7 victory over the soldier eleven of Camp Kilmer, N.J., today before a slim crowd of 1,200. The teams were even, 7 -- 7, at the intermission.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Among the New Yorkers listed as killed in the Boston fire disaster were David Hillman, 17-year-old student in a New England college, whose parents live at 135 Central Park West. They left immediately for Boston on being notified of their son's death.

ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- Governor Lehman made his final public appearance in Albany this afternoon when he stood for two hours with Mrs. Lehman in the north reception room of the Executive Mansion in a farewell to officials and the public.

A survey of Jewish religious textbooks, conducted to eliminate from them passages that might be regarded as unfriendly to other faiths, has been completed, it was announced yesterday by Rabbi Israel Goldstein, president of the Synagogue Council of America.

The Rev. Jesse W. Stitt, in his sermon yesterday at the Greenwich Presbyterian Church, 139 West Thirteenth Street, declared that if the world of the future is to be true to the tremendous sacrifices made for it now, there must be recognition that moral integrity must motivate men's actions and not expediency.

Yesterday's radio speech by Prime Minister Churchill will rank among his historic utterances. It presented a strange paradox. Though Mr. Churchill was rightly warning against overconfidence, it was the most confident speech he has made since he became Prime Minister.

The New York Rovers registered their fifth straight triumph and their seventh in a row on home ice yesterday afternoon when they downed the Coast Guard Cutters from Curtis Bay, Baltimore, 7 -- 0, in the feature game of an Eastern Hockey League double-header at Madison Square Garden.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 29 -- Reports from semi-official Italian sources reaching here tonight said that Adolf Hitler had convoked an "extraordinary meeting" of his High Command at Berchtesgaden to discuss the future of operations on the African front.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 29 (AP) -- As an aftermath of Navy's astonishing gridiron victory over Army came reports today that wartime assignments may cause major shifts in the Naval Academy's sports set-up, not the slightest of which may bring in Captain Mike Moran, skipper of the famous cruiser Boise, as director of athletics.

A 6 per cent increase in laundry prices, which the industry had planned to put into effect today, was ordered suspended last night by Sylvan L. Joseph, regional director of the Office of Price Administration. The industry had intended to raise its prices throughout the metropolitan area to pass on to housewives a wage increase recently awarded by an arbitration board.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Probable destruction by bombing of a small enemy cargo vessel off Attu Island in the Aleutians was announced today by the Navy.

I have read with great interest Hanson W. Baldwin's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 19 on the conditions in Yugoslavia. The situation in that country has become of particular importance since the Balkans are considered as a possible objective of an early invasion of Europe.
Only through democracy can human dignity be preserved, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon in The Riverside Church.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Prime Minister Churchill, in a world broadcast on the eve of his sixty-eighth birthday, warned the Italian people tonight that the day of reckoning with them was drawing nigh, and implicit in his speech was an appeal to them to settle with their leaders who had misled them and to avoid now the holocaust that was awaiting them.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Housewives in Britain received a lesson in the high strategy of war last week. They saw how their sacrifices on the kitchen front helped to make possible the Allied attacks in North Africa and Egypt.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 29 -- Military spokesmen in Berlin today seemed markedly reticent about the situation on the Eastern Front.

SILVER CREEK, N.Y., Nov. 29 (AP) -- More than a score of persons were injured, four requiring hospitalization, when the westbound Commodore Vanderbilt, fast New York Central passenger train, was in collision with a freight engine just east of Silver Creek early today. None was reported seriously hurt.

Charles J. Kramer, 49 years old, of 111 Tremont Avenue, Orange, N.J., was struck and killed by two hit-and-run drivers at 10:25 o'clock last night as he was crossing Fifth Avenue at Twenty-third Street.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- American Air Force Headquarters in North Africa announced today that the Allied air forces had destroyed 230 Axis planes in air combat and on the ground during the first twenty days of the North African campaign.

The Old House has been discovered by the New York regional office of the National Housing Agency, which has a use to suggest for it. "In many of the war industry areas in the three States embraced in this region, where housing shortages have become acute," says its statement, "there are a number of old Victorian mansions containing twenty rooms and more that can be readily converted into multiple dwellings suitable for light housekeeping."

The Victory Fund Committee of the New York Federal Reserve District, with approximately 10,000 volunteer workers, of whom 5,000 will be concentrated in Manhattan and the Bronx, will swing into action today to open the nation-wide Victory Loan Drive to sell upward of $9,000,000,000 of government securities within a month.

WITH AMERICAN AIR FORCES IN CHINA, Nov. 29 -- American fliers, in their most successful operation of the war in China, shot down twenty-three, possibly twenty-eight, Japanese planes over Canton Friday and spread devastation among shipping and harbor facilities at the great Pearl River base.

Richard Strauss's "Salome," which has been absent from the repertoire for the last three seasons, will be revived by the Metropolitan Opera Association the evening of Dec. 9, it was revealed yesterday with the announcement of the operas to be performed during the third week of the season.

In Honan, a battlefield province of China, some six million persons are officially reported to be on the verge of starvation. In Norway, according to a refugee who escaped to England, "it is pretty tough -- more and more people go about all day hungering, never feeling 'filled.'"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Women should be made eligible for Federal jury duty in twenty States where they are still disqualified, according to recommendations for the improvement of the Federal grand and petit jury system filed here today by a committee of Federal judges.
From coast to coast members of the American Women's Voluntary Services are taking part in the solution of one of the war's greatest home-front problems -- child care.

Plans for the continued upbuilding of Palestine as a national home for the Jewish people, with emphasis on the settlement in Palestine of hundreds of thousands of uprooted Jews immediately after the war, were approved yesterday at the final session of a convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine in the Hotel Commodore.

It was with great pleasure and satisfaction that I read your editorial "Coffee Is Coffee," the sentiments of which I completely endorse. When you refer to the "devious by-paths of substitution" you touch the heart of the danger which lies in attempts to change the beverage which has become the favorite among the people of the United States.

The American Merchant Marine Library Association is revising its publication, "The Seamen's Handbook for Shore Leave," and coincidentally issues an appeal for public support in distributing this manual to members of all branches of the armed services.
President Roosevelt's recent warning to the American people to keep their psychological balance and not be unduly elated or depressed by day-to-day operations was well timed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Dr. Albert McCowen, national medical director of the American Red Cross, left here tonight by train for Boston to lend any assistance necessary in the treatment of victims of the night club fire.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Prices, slightly below average levels of last March, have been announced by the Office of Price Administration for canned Pacific and Atlantic mackerel.

MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 30 -- Russian armies have killed nearly 15,000 Germans in the new Soviet offensive west of Moscow and have crashed through a new German defense line on the east bank of the Don before Stalingrad in triumphant pursuit of the Nazis across the snows of Russia, it was announced early today.

Time was when the friends of the American system loved to expatiate upon the riches that would come to us if the shirt of every Chinese was lengthened by an inch. Now we hear without a murmur that under Government regulation our own shirts are to be shortened by two or three inches.

Directing the flow into war production of hundreds of items and materials, ranging from aluminum watch cases from Switzerland to copper recovered from the bottom of the East River, is the job now being done in this region by the materials redistribution section of the WPB, Alfred G. Birkenmeier, regional chief, reported yesterday.

Despite the enactment of new Federal laws to control prices and wages, much remains to be done if general economic stabilization is to be achieved, the Guaranty Trust Company asserts in the Nov. 30 issue of The Guaranty Survey, its monthly review of business and financial conditions.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Federal Judge William H. Hastie, civilian aide to Secretary of War Henry Stimson, said today that a personal investigation disclosed no racial discrimination in the Office of Dependency Benefits.

Today the United States Treasury launches its Victory Fund Drive, the biggest single money-raising operation in history. The goal is $9,000,000,000, plus, and, for the first time in this war, a wide public appeal is being made. The objective is not merely to raise the money but to obtain the widest possible participation in the financing of the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 29 -- From Lourdes, in the Pyrenees, comes word that developments in France have not modified the position of the American diplomatic and newspaper groups sent there from Vichy when Pierre Laval "registered the severance of relations with the United States."

LONDON, Nov. 29 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Prince Bernhard told the people of the occupied Netherlands in a broadcast this morning of the impression made upon him by President Roosevelt's "deep insight into world happenings" and "his enormous energy."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 29 -- Foreign Minister Joaquin Fernandez will attend a session of the Senate Wednesday and explain Chile's international position in the light of recent developments, it was announced last evening.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Fort Monmouth's football warriors brought a successful season to a close today with a victory over the strong Fort Totten eleven, 6 to 0, on Frawley Field. The triumph enabled Fort Monmouth to retain the championship of the U.S. Army Second Service Command.
Householders throughout the nation began working both ends of their war ration books toward the middle yesterday as coffee joined sugar on the stamp redemption list.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Although the output of lard at leading slaughtering points increased last week, there is no evidence of any material accumulation of supplies, owing to an urgent demand from the domestic trade and further liberal sales for lend-lease purposes.
One youngster hopes to come dressed up as a toothpaste tube. Another as a broken victrola record and a little girl as a hula-hula dancer, in a "grass" skirt actually made of silk and nylon stockings.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- One of the most moving books about this war, telling for the first time as a consecutive narrative how Great Britain fought the Blitz, will be published tomorrow under the title "Front Line 1940-1941." Anonymous in authorship, it is the official story of the civil defense of Britain issued by the Ministry of Home Security.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Our aircraft in the Solomons have returned to the Munda Bay area in the New Georgia Islands northwest of Guadalcanal in a night attack on Japanese shipping there, the Navy announced today. No details of the result of the attack were given.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Today, fourteen days after the opening of the deer season in Westchester County for the first time since 1928, a deer was shot and killed by an arrow from a long bow, the only weapon hunters were permitted to use in hunting buck deer.
There are plenty of ducks in the vicinity of Great South Bay, but the scarcity this year pertains to the hunters.

The collapse of man's self-confidence and self-reliance is one of the most striking aspects of the world today, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

In a sermon yesterday morning at the French Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit, 109 East Sixtieth Street, the Rev. Dr. John A.F. Maynard, the pastor, paid tribute to the French sailors who died at Toulon to prevent their ships from falling into the hands of the Germans, and voiced his hope that General Charles de Gaulle and his Fighting French would receive total recognition as "the expression of the soul of France."

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Vice President Wallace and a small group of men gathered here today to dedicate the Chicago venereal disease hospital, the country's first intensive treatment center where persons of all ages can receive the best medical care free of charge for syphilis and gonorrhea.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The Allied occupation of Djedeida, about ten miles west of Tunis, the capital of Tunisia, was officially announced today as the British First Army brought its guns within range of that important objective and awaited orders for a general attack, expected at any moment.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A Reuter dispatch from Madrid tonight said that Spanish naval mechanics had boarded the French submarine Iris, only warship known to have escaped from Toulon, in Barcelona harbor and had removed essential parts of the machinery to immobilize the vessel.

Fire safeguards here bar any inflammable material in places of public assembly, and the test of their vulnerability is to expose them directly to a blow torch, Fire Chief and Commissioner Patrick Walsh said yesterday in discussing the disastrous Boston fire.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Sulfapyridine saved the lives of 17,000 persons in Britain in 1940 and 1941, Ernest Brown, Health Minister said today. Ten thousand were suffering from cerebro-spinal meningitis or spotted fever and 7,500 had pneumonia.

Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler is leaving the city's service for the duration, to serve as a lieutenant colonel in the Army, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. The Mayor said that he has yet to choose a replacement, but that whoever he picked would be some one already employed by the city.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Complaints have flooded trade associations with headquarters here that ODT gasoline allotments for trade purposes reflected arbitrary cuts from the 25 per cent reduction in operating mileage requested by that agency and that store operations of all classes and types would suffer when nation-wide gasoline rationing goes into effect Dec. 1.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The stock markets closed the week quietly but with a firm undertone. This unexciting description applies indeed to the markets' conditions throughout the week and has aroused disappointed and critical comment.
The battle is over. The 1942 football season may have been a headache, but it never was a bore.

Ida Krehm, Canadian pianist resident in Chicago, was heard in a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. For her program she had chosen the Bach harpsichord toccata in C minor, two Scarlatti sonatas, the Schumann "Fantasy," Liapunoff's "Lesghinka," a "Fairy Tale" of Medtner and Prokofieff's sonata in A minor.

Instructions for making over civilian suits discarded by men entering the armed forces into clothes that can be worn by other members of the family have been issued in leaflet form by the textiles and clothing division, Bureau of Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture.

The first Sunday in Advent, which is the first day of the Roman Catholic ecclesiastical year, was marked yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral by the opening of the Forty Hours Adoration, a solemn devotion to the Blessed Sacrament, in which the faithful, "relieving each other in relays of forty hours, offer a continuous round of prayers and supplications to God."

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- Fire broke out in the Cocoanut Grove night club here around 10:15 o'clock last night. Not one of the survivors can fix the exact time. One moment they were dancing, or enjoying their drinks at their tables or at the great cylindrical bar.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and re corded here by The Associated Press:

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- This stunned and grieving city saw the list of known dead in the nation's worst fire disaster in almost four decades mount to 440 tonight while the critical condition of many of the 173 burned and injured persons in hospitals led to fears that the eventual death toll would pass the 500 mark.

The Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, declared yesterday in his sermon that whatever long and hard road might be ahead of the people of this country, recent events seemed to indicate that the turn had come and that victory was ahead.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- It is inevitable that several hundred colleges will not open next Fall, Maury Maverick, Director of the Governmental Division of the War Production Board, predicted here today as he spoke before members of the National Council of Chief School Officers.

Members of the Republican National Committee who at first favored the election of Werner W. Schroeder of Illinois as chairman to succeed Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. have started a movement to get Mr. Schroeder to withdraw and thus avert a fight at the committee meeting in St. Louis next week, it was learned yesterday.
WITH THE U.S. FLEET IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC (Delayed) -- "Prepare for enemy bombing."
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 29 -- The Allied air forces resumed their hammering of forward Axis landing grounds -- the tactic that helped to break the Nazis at El Alamein.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 -- The Football Dodgers found the opposition superior mudders today and dropped a 13-0 decision to the surprising Steelers at Forbes Field. It was the seventh triumph of the season for the local squad, its best showing ever in the National League.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- A moderate revival in the domestic demand for flour and lack of hedging pressure resulted in a higher range of wheat prices last week, the market advancing into new ground since early in October and to around the level used by the Office of Price Administration in determining the ceiling price on flour.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 29 -- Arrests and internments are multiplying fast in France, where the most important official today is Robert Bousquet, Secretary General for Police, who takes his orders direct from Pierre Laval. He holds the lists of "suspects," and no one can cross the frontier without his written order.

Reporting on operations of Abraham Straus, Inc., for the six months ended on July 31, Walter Rothschild, president, told stockholders that the net profit was increased to $288,896 after provision for interest, depreciation and taxes, from $145,689 for the corresponding period last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Don Hutson, pass catcher de luxe in the National Football League, snared a 31-yard toss from Cecil Isbell in the first quarter today to give Green Bay a 7-to-0 victory over the Eagles before 14,000 at Shibe Park.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- The market for corn was more active late last week than it had been recently on the Board of Trade here.

Pluck is something the whole world admires, and Marjorie Lawrence offered an outstanding example of it at her superb recital last night in Town Hall. Since June, 1941, the Metropolitan dramatic soprano has been paralyzed as the result of a vaccination.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Frank Dixon, 20-year-old New York University freshman, won the National A.A.U. cross-country championship today over a slow 10,000-meter course (about six and one-quarter miles) at Weequahic Park.

Consider the immediate military consequences of the offensive in Africa: Toulon and the complete occupation of France; the relief of Stalingrad and the sweeping advances of the Red Army on Germany's weakened Russian front; police measures revealing that the long-smoldering unrest in Italy is becoming a danger to Hitler; mobilization in Spain and General Franco's open warning against seizure of the Balearic Islands; final demands for general mobilization in Hungary.

"Lifeline," a drama about the men of England's merchant marine, by Norman Armstrong, opens tonight at 8:45 at the Belasco, a presentation of Gilbert Miller. Heading the cast, of men only, are Dudley Digges, Colin Keith-Johnston, Rhys Williams and Whitford Kane.

Centralization of control of the nation's manpower in one agency with complete authority over recruiting for the armed services, for war industry and civilian industries was urged in a report made public yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Pierre Laval appeared today to be falling out of the favor of the Germans, following upon the Nazi occupation of Vichy France and the subsequent scuttling of the French fleet.

Wholesale trading continued brisk last week, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. A report that furs might be classified as nonessential resulted in exceptionally heavy demand in that market.

A cocktail party and exhibition of modern paintings will be features of the all-day open house to be held on Saturday at the new Irvington House Thrift Shop, 874 Third Avenue. Articles of all descriptions, antiques, bundles of clothing and household furnishings will serve as admission to the opening.

Endorsing the united effort of seventeen child-caring agencies to find several thousand more family homes for neglected children, religious leaders of the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths urged yesterday that more families in New York take homeless children.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Although the recent reduction of the discount rate of the Federal Reserve Bank in New York to only one-half of 1 per cent is generally regarded as of merely academic interest to London, it has been suggested that the Bank of England ought to follow suit and at least halve its present rate of 2 per cent.

Prior to the admission last week by its chairman, William H. Davis, the War Labor Board's compulsory arbitration had been disguised by the fiction that obedience to the board's orders was voluntary. "Industry" and "labor" were merely abiding, it was contended, by "their" no-strike-no-lockout agreement.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 -- Steel ingot output throughout the country last week again remained unchanged at 99.5 per cent of rated capacity. These figures, however, represent a tremendous tonnage of steel in view of the increased capacity added to mills in the last year.

The service of Thanksgiving and Rededication at Temple Emanu-El yesterday marked three anniversaries of major consequence in New York's social service. The New York Federation of Jewish Charities completed its twenty-fifth year.

Perhaps Americans have had too many bouquets on the present healthy state of civilian morale. For it certainly seems barely possible that a good many so-called 100 per cent Americans do not always see this war as realistically as does our Administration at Washington.

We are approaching our second war Winter with gasoline and fuel, sugar and coffee rationed, and Tuesdays "meatless." Undoubtedly there will be rationing of other foods. But to talk of any serious shortage would do injustice to the situation. In fact, there are some respects in which our position is better than it was during the second Winter of the First World War.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Sid Luckman catapulted two scoring passes, Charley O'Rourke pitched another and strapping Gary Famiglietti smashed his way to a pair of touchdowns as the Chicago Bears piled up their greatest victory margin of the season today -- a 47-to-0 lacing of the Cleveland Rams.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Here is New Jersey's schedule for registering for the draft those boys whose eighteenth birthday anniversaries fall between July 1 and Dec. 31 of this year:

The Giants flashed to two touchdowns within the first seven minutes of a rather damp engagement with the Chicago Cardinals before a gathering of 20,354 yesterday at the Polo Grounds and then managed to hold the fort in firm hands for a 21 -- 7 victory.
BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- Vivid descriptions of the scenes attending the Cocoanut Grove fire were given today by survivors and spectators.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 -- The Washington Redskins, Eastern division champions, completed their best National Football League record in eleven years under Owner George Preston Marshall by defeating the Detroit Lions, 15 to 3, before 6,044 spectators today for their tenth victory against one defeat.

Announcement that the Harvard University Business School is to embark on a program to re-train business executives for war work comes as interesting and welcome news. This country, in growing need of all available manpower, cannot overlook the successful business leaders who are no longer needed in civilian jobs.

Mayor La Guardia vehemently denied yesterday that there was any real basis "for all this talk about the so-called Harlem problem" and asserted that the residents of Harlem, generally speaking, were as fine, respectable, patriotic and law-abiding people as one could find in any similar community in the country.

This war is a judgment upon nations, cities and inhabitants who have abandoned God, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at Catholic University, declared yesterday in the first of a series of five Advent sermons. He addressed 1,100 people attending solemn mass in the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street, east of Broadway.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- The diplomatic correspondent of the Italian news agency Stefani said tonight in a broadcast from Rome that Prime Minister Churchill's "threats of new trials will not make an impression on the Italian nation."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 29 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has revived plans for the filming of Oscar Wilde's short story, "The Canterville Ghost," first announced by the studio in 1939, and has engaged Edwin Blum to prepare a scenario.

New York City's Victory scrap metal heaps became Federal property yesterday afternoon when Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick put his signature on the agreement reached Saturday by Mayor La Guardia and officials of the War Production Board and the Metals Reserve Company, Inc., a subsidiary of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at 108.5 for the third consecutive week. This is an increase of 9.6 per cent over last year. Although there was an advance of 0.3 per cent in the foodstuffs group, the decline in raw materials and farm products was sufficient to keep the index at the same level as last week.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 29 -- The triumph of the liberal pro-United Nations forces, under the banner of the Colorado party, over the reactionary Blanco or National party was assured soon after the closing of the polls tonight in a national election to choose a President and Vice President for the next four years.

NARVIK is well above the Arctic Circle in the "high north" of Norway. It is a young, new city built up in recent years. Through its ice-free port the iron ore from the Swedish mines across the mountains was shipped to the outside world, most of it to Germany. The population of 10,000 worked on the railroad and transshipped the ore to ships flying both the Union Jack and the hooked cross.

Eight more men were accused yesterday of involvement in the systematic thefts from Bloomingdale's warehouse of goods valued at $250,000 and, with the two ringleaders arrested Friday, were arraigned in courts in the Bronx, Queens and Manhattan.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 -- With tenders of cotton extremely light in the December spot position and considerable price-fixing incident to large dry goods sales, the near month last week was in the vanguard of a good recovery in futures following the sharp break at the opening of the week, when "peace" talk came out of Rome.

A budget of $100,000 for education, vocational training and land settlement projects for youth in Palestine was accepted yesterday by Junior Hadassah at the final session of its four-day convention at the Hotel Plaza.

Trailing until the game was well into the second period, the New York Rangers rallied to register a 3-to-2 triumph over the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- With 2,000,000 Civilian Defense Block Leaders enlisted in the project, the Office of Civilian Defense will begin what it terms "the greatest house-to-house campaign in history" tomorrow, when the block leaders will call on householders of the country to explain the government's voluntary share-the-meat plan.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick May Eliot, president of the American Unitarian Association, in a sermon at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street, on "The Army of the Faithful," declared there was immense value in the reassuring thought that the fabric of the world was held together by the fidelity of millions of nameless individuals in every country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The battling Bentley boys, Doug and Max, each scored a goal in the final period tonight to give the Black Hawks a victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 2, and send the Chicago club into second place in the National Hockey League before an approving crowd of 13,366.

With gasoline rationing becoming nation-wide, some of the advertising trends which first started in the East as a result of cuts in salesmen's mileage, will spread throughout the country. Two obvious changes have been the increased use of direct mail by manufacturers to reach their accounts and a sharp reduction in display material.

Speakers at a meeting in Carnegie Hall last night under the auspices of the Committee of Jewish Writers and Artists praised the victorious advance of the Russian armies and urged Russian and American Jews to cooperate in the solution of the Jewish post-war problems.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Nov. 30 -- Allied airmen are believed to have sunk two more Japanese destroyers trying to reinforce the beleaguered New Guinea garrison around Buna, while to the west Allied naval forces intercepted a German auxiliary vessel of 8,000 tons and captured seventy-eight Nazis after they scuttled the ship, Allied headquarters announced today.

On June 30 the Insurance Company of North America was assessed $154 for its share of a total loss of $1,400 on the cargo of an airplane en route to an overseas destination, no other particulars of which can be disclosed, it is revealed in "Biography of a Business," which has just been published to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the company's founding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 25, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: Increases of $151,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $102,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, and $526,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $390,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

The lightweight battle of fifteen rounds between Beau Jack of Georgia and Tippy Larkin of New Jersey, scheduled for Madison Square Garden on Dee. 11, received strong support yesterday when Matchmaker Nat Rogers of the Twentieth Century S.C. announced a bout between Roman Alvarez and Terry Young, East Siders, as the eight-round semi-final.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- President Roosevelt in a message to Congress requested legislation facilitating the use of government equipment in the war effort; he met with House and Senate leaders; his visitors included Wayne Coy and Harold Smith, Isador Lubin, Sir Oliver Lyttleton, Frank Walker and General H.H. Arnold.
College football attendance hit the down grade this Fall, showing its first big decline in recent years as every section of the country failed to match the high figures of 1941.
TORONTO, Nov. 30 -- Reviewing Canada's war production, Munitions Minister C.D. Howe, in a speech to the Canadian Club of Toronto today, revealed some hitherto unknown accomplishments and figures.
Alexander H. Pekelis of Larchmont, N.Y., has been elected editor-in-chief of the Columbia Law Review, highest scholastic honor in the Columbia School of Law, Dean Young B. Smith announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Nov. 30 -- Operations on the central front have now entered a phase of manoeuvre battles in which good generalship and the element of surprise spell success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today to call Byron Price, Director of the Office of Censorship, before it next week for what Senator Van Nuys of Indiana, chairman, described as "an investigation of the whole censorship set-up."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Major League baseball and school basketball were menaced by the transportation shortage today when Director Joseph B. Eastman of the Office of Defense Transportation asked the National and American Leagues to curtail travel by their teams in 1943 and announced that the use of school buses for sports events would not be authorized this Winter.

New, permanent price orders to replace the Temporary Maximum Price Regulation No. 22, covering dairy products and a list of other items, which is due to expire on Thursday, may be expected momentarily, it was learned yesterday. The new orders, it was explained at the regional headquarters of the Office of Price Administration here, will probably correct the inequities discovered during the two-month operation of the temporary regulation and include clarification of adjustments already made.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Other action by war agencies today included:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Mrs. Roosevelt is doing "rather less" Christmas shopping this year, much of it being war bonds and stamps, she said today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 30 (AP) -The Office of Price Administration filed in Federal Court today a complaint charging the Hygrade Food Products Corporation and the Dold Packing Corporation, Buffalo meat packers, with violating the maximum price regulations governing the sales of beef, veal and pork.

Christmas Eve has always meant much to Germans. Every family feasted and looked forward to a cheerful new year. Accordingly, Hitler's government is doing its best to make the most of the traditional spirit. There are to be special rations for the civilian population and one kilo of peas or beans, one of flour and sugar and a large sausage for every soldier on leave, while Czechs, Poles, Greeks, Frenchmen and Yugoslavians starve.

The Office of Price Administration announced here yesterday that credit extension has been granted under gasoline and fuel oil rationing to operators of commercial motor vehicles and householders pending distribution of the necessary rationing coupons.

Facilities for training 15,000 men in the armed forces for specialized duty are available in New York's four municipal colleges, City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens, if the Government wishes to use their services, it was revealed yesterday by Pearl Bernstein, Administrator of the Board of Higher Education.

AN EAST COAST PORT, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- After a submarine attack in the Atlantic early in October had sliced a medium-sized United States merchant vessel in two amidships, thirty-three men kept the aft end afloat in twenty-foot waves throughout the night and were rescued by a British corvette the next day.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech had a cheering effect on the stock markets but business was subdued awaiting further news from North Africa. Gilt-edge issues improved in connection with the opening of the new war bond subscription lists tomorrow.
MOSCOW, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, at Agedabia, Nov. 28 (Delayed) -- Within the last few days there has been a possibility, perhaps even a probability, of the enemy's having had a breathing space sufficient to build up his reserves behind his El Agheila positions.

Christmas gifts and Christmas cards from many nations, including items brought by refugees from war-torn countries, will be offered for sale at the annual Christmas carnival of the International Center of the Young Women's Christian Association, which will open on Thursday night at the headquarters, 341 East Seventeenth Street, and will continue Friday and throughout Saturday.

Helen Hayes, who has been on vacation from the theatre since her appearance last season in "Candle in the Wind," will appear early in the new year under Gilbert Miller's auspices in the play about Harriet Beecher Stowe by Florence Ryerson and Colin Clements that was tried out recently at Syracuse University.

William P. Witherow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, told The Associated Press yesterday that a quick post-war relaxation of government controls over business would be necessary for survival of the system of free enterprise in the United States.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 1 -- The Red Army killed 7,500 more Germans and knocked out seventy-five tanks on the blizzard-swept central front west of Moscow and gained six miles near Stalingrad yesterday in twin offensives that still were rolling onward despite desperate Nazi counter-attacks, the Russians announced early today.

In a survey conducted by General Printing Ink Corporation, 44 per cent of 116 companies queried reported that they have curtailed their printing this year, while 51.7 per cent indicated they had not and 4.3 per cent gave no answer. Of those curtailing 64.6 per cent has reduced printing from 10 to 50 per cent and 35.4 per cent from 50 to 100 per cent.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 30 -- The victory gained in yesterday's Presidential election by the liberal democratic Colorado party over the reactionary Blanco or National party assumed the proportions of a veritable triumph today when almost complete returns for the whole country reached Montevideo.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- The Rev. Harold C. Dewindt, pastor of the Webb Horton Memorial Presbyterian Church here, has resigned to accept a call to the West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, New York.

Moved by a short-sighted patriotism not unrelated to nervous strain, and avowing an unwillingness to suffer less in the present dislocation than the men's colleges, women's colleges seem determined to wreck their best educational practices without stopping to balance gains and losses or inquire what demands the nation really makes of them.

In a move unprecedented in the competitive book publishing industry, it was announced yesterday that a large group of publishers, librarians, editors and booksellers had agreed to a joint plan by which books adjudged important contributions to the war will be cooperatively promoted and publicized.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 30 -- German troops on the central Russian front are facing their hardest test, it was declared tonight in Berlin, where Nazi spokesmen show greater optimism concerning the Stalingrad battlefield.

A few miles to the northeast of the city of Tunis are the ruins of Carthage. The cathedral of St. Louis stands on the site of the citadel of Hannibal's native town. General Anderson's British First Army and our own American tanks and flying forces may at the moment of writing be very near the site of Scipio's camp when the Romans appeared before the city after crushing Hannibal's army at Zama.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters in Manhattan were Richard S. Newlin, associated with the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, who leased a large suite at 7 Gracie Square through Wm. A. White Sons, agents, and Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Intuition, that mysterious faculty that lies at the basis of the creative powers of man, with which hitherto only poets and artists largely concerned themselves, was a major topic of discussion yesterday at the opening sessions of the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, at the Hotel Astor.

The owner of six small confectioneries in the city will tell you a legend about the malt candies that are newly on sale in his shops. He will describe them, just as he used to hear them described in Vienna, as a "hausmitel" -- an old-fashioned home remedy used to ease a sore throat.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Former Attorney General George A. Malcolm, who was recently removed from office by order of President Roosevelt, blamed Governor Rexford Guy Tugwell for the plight of the people of Puerto Rico at a farewell dinner in his honor last night.

A gala concert at special prices was given last night in Carnegie Hall by Arturo Toscanini and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the benefit of the Red Cross. The public, responded in large numbers and with immense enthusiasm to this offering.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Four French submarines were reported tonight to have escaped German capture at Toulon. Two of them were in Allied hands at Algiers. Another was believed to be on the way there. The fourth, the 597-ton Iris, was obliged to put in at Barcelona Saturday, and today her crew of twenty-one officers and men was interned by the Spaniards.

The Appelate Division in Brooklyn reversed yesterday the conviction of Isaac Brown, Manhattan insurance broker, for the attempted first-degree murder of Mathilda Le Boyer, 17 years old, in a parking lot in Mount Vernon, N.Y., on Dec. 19, 1940.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The five-story apartment house at 34-36-38 Caryl Avenue, Yonkers, Westchester County, was sold by Lena Lico to Elisabeth Meyer for a consideration said to be in excess of $100,000. The Advance Realty Corporation and Charles Schelling were co-brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Nov. 30 -- The new champion submarine skipper on the Pacific, a mild man, so polite that he even called the newspaper men "Sirs," related today an amazing saga of eight Japanese ships sent to the bottom and four others at least badly damaged, all within sight of big Japanese ports.

Tin can sombreros trimmed with bottletops and hula skirts made of old silk and nylon stockings were the height of fashion at a salvage parade held by 400 children of the Hunter College Elementary School yesterday as the opening festivity of "Fun Week."

A market survey covering the post-war period, which will be carried out on a larger scale than ever before, will be made by the United States Chamber of Commerce with the help of 1,700 local chambers throughout the country, William J. Moll, in charge of field organization for the National body, announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Sheraton.

An announcement yesterday by the New York Red Cross Chapter that it had sent blood plasma to help save the lives of victims of the night-club fire in Boston impressed upon New York City's thousands of volunteer blood donors that their contribution to this great humanitarian enterprise could save civilian lives as well as the lives of wounded men in battle.
ALBANY, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Three times more women than men have been added to New York factory payrolls since industries boomed into full war production, the State Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Board of Economic Warfare announced today that it has adjusted certain phases of the procedure used in applying for export licenses for iron and steel to Latin-American republics. The action was taken, it was explained, to assure the issuance of export licenses for iron and steel products considered most vital to the neighboring republics and to facilitate the procurement of the materials.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Navy reports indicated tonight that Japan's amphibious forces in the South Seas, having repeatedly failed to break America's hold on the Southeastern Solomons, may be attempting to develop a powerful base in the center of the archipelago.

Spurred on by wartime demand, schools of nursing throughout the country have already recruited enough students to meet 68 per cent of the quota set for them for 1942-43, according to a report just made by the Department of Studies of the National League of Nursing Education.

Chaim Gross, the well-known American sculptor, is having his first one-man show in several years at the galleries of the Associated American Artists, 711 Fifth Avenue. There will be a preview today and the show opens to the public tomorrow, to remain through Dec. 19.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Senator Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas, and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, praised the "indomitable" Yugoslav guerrilla armies of General Draja Mikhailovitch today for their fight against the Axis forces, asserting that their resistance had forced Italy and Germany to keep "some twenty-three divisions away from the Russian and African fronts to protect themselves in what was once Yugoslavia."

The open season on deer in Westchester has ended, as in other parts of the State, and it is likely that on many Winter evenings wherever sportsmen gather there will be many references to the role the archers had during the past fifteen days.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Aggressive buying of corn futures by cash and commission houses as well as covering by shorts lifted prices on the Board of Trade today around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading to a new high since early in October.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Charles (Buck) Jones, cowboy motion picture star, died at a hospital late today of burns suffered in the Cocoanut Grove fire. Mr. Jones was the guest of honor at a party when the fire broke out. Attending physicians said they "had abandoned all hope for Jones's recovery immediately after examining his burns."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- That Italian resistance might collapse within six months, especially if facilitated by definite announcement of the terms available to Italy, was the view expressed today in highly authorized quarters.
